name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the Mid-term review of the Investment Plan (2016/2732(RSP)).

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members of the European Parliament for joining us in this debate. Hopefully there are a few more MEPs around because the topic is so important, boosting investments and by doing so strengthening job creation in Europe. I will not go to the root causes as to why we are lacking investments. Everybody knows many of the reasons, but I would just like to raise some points on what we have already done in order to promote investments and strengthen job creation in Europe. As everybody remembers, in the investment plan for Europe we had three different parts which are mutually reinforcing. The most important part of the plan is the removal of barriers to investments. There we have national barriers but also European-wide barriers. The Commission has paid more attention than before to investment barriers at national levels. For instance, in annual growth surveys and when analysing Member States’ economies, we have identified national barriers for investments and some of those findings ended up in the country-specific recommendations.  So we are encouraging Member States to carry out structural reforms which will boost an investment environment at national and local level. At the same time, we are putting more focus and emphasis on deepening and widening the internal market. The internal market and the whole third pillar of the investment plan, in my mind, is the most influential part in terms of job creation. We have some major projects like the Digital Single Market, the Energy Union, and the Capital Market Union but one should add to this list also the circular economy package which the Commission proposed last year and also decarbonisation of transport. They will all reshape the internal market in Europe. Just to give you some ideas of what we have already done in terms of creating a better investment environment, we are lowering capital charges for insurance companies investing in long-term infrastructure. We are also making it more possible to find venture capital in Europe for small and medium-sized enterprises by launching a new venture capital fund of funds later this year.  We are giving guidance on what constitutes state aid. We are making it easier for service providers to expand to the other Member States and creating a digital single market. So lots of things are happening on this front and I hope Parliament will support these projects. The faster we can deliver on the internal market side, the faster we can get a better business environment and a better investment environment.  A second pillar of the investment plan consists of two major initiatives. The first one is an investment advisory hub which is providing technical assistance and advice to private investors, but also to public entities. This is functioning quite well. We already have more than 100 requests, mostly from private companies. They are asking for advice and technical assistance to improve the quality of the projects. For instance, some of the investors are asking for technical assistance on how to benefit from various EU funds.  So this is a very elementary and important part of the investment plan because it makes it easier for Member States to use the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) but also the other funds and also to create investment platforms collecting together smaller investments, and by doing so it is easier to get financing for smaller projects. The newest creation under the second pillar is the European Investment Project Portal. The idea came from the UK. I visited London and the financiers, for instance investment banks, said that they are able and willing to invest more in European infrastructure but it is sometimes very difficult to find good projects from different countries. Their idea was to create a transparent open portal to which both public and private project promoters could send their projects, and the promoters could get better visibility for their projects.  So it is some sort of dating service for project promoters and financiers, and it is up and running now. We disclosed it at the beginning of June and I am quite excited to see how well it functions. We have designed the portal together with the private sector in order to make it as pragmatic and practical as possible. So over time there should be thousands of investment projects, and hopefully it functions as we have planned.  Finally, the first pillar of the EFSI plan is also up and running. So far we have used EFSI to the tune of EUR 12.8 billion for the infrastructure and innovation window but also for SME financing. This EUR 12.8 billion is expected to trigger mostly private investment, or public-private partnership investments worth EUR 100 billion. Of this, 80%, in other words, EUR 80 billion out of EUR 100 billion, comes from the private sector, so EFSI seems to function as planned. It provides risk financing mostly to private investors and by doing so it crowds in private money, which is currently peacefully resting in bank accounts.  So there seems to be a lack of risk financing in Europe. There is plenty of liquidity everywhere, this is not a problem at the moment, but because we have changed banking regulations this is one of the reasons the banks cannot take as much risk as they did a few years ago. That is why EFSI is providing something which is lacking, at least to a large extent, in the market. We have around 65 projects, I mean infrastructure or industrial investment projects, which have got financing from EFSI. In addition to this, and I would say more importantly, we have 185 agreements between the European Investment Fund (EIF) and intermediary banks, between the fund and private banks, on SME financing. These 185 agreements between the EIF, which has support from EFSI, and banks, will provide financing to approximately 150 000 European SMEs. In Italy alone we have 28 banks which have made an agreement with the EIF, and 44 000 Italian SMEs will get financing because of these agreements. This is sometimes the fastest way to stimulate the economy. There seems to be a lack of SME financing, especially equity financing, everywhere in Europe, even in the most developed markets. That is why I think in the future we have to pay special attention to this SME window, especially in equity financing, because this is something which the market does not offer that much at the moment.  Of course, we are developing the Capital Market Union in order to improve the capital market environment in Europe, but it will always take some time and meanwhile we have to address the market gap by providing EFSI financing. The UK has been very active on this issue. The UK is a country which is familiar with financial instruments and that is why British banks have been actively contacting the EIF and providing more financing to British businesses. The Commission will present a new proposal to prolong EFSI later this year. We have to analyse EFSI, its achievements and possible weaknesses, and once we have done the analysis we will make a new proposal, which will continue EFSI beyond the expiry date which we have at the moment.  The main issue in this is to focus on addressing market failure. The main issue is not to make it larger. The main thing is to focus EFSI financing on the areas where market does not function properly. Also one thing on which we have to be very careful is to provide financing for new innovations which will strengthen the sustainable development of our economies in social terms, in environmental terms, and for instance provide financing to the investments which will promote the circular economy. We are also going to propose some kind of external investment plan. EFSI has functioned very well in Europe, but we could use the same model also for external financing, especially when trying to achieve development goals. So the Commission is looking at the opportunities, how we could use existing development resources in a more efficient way by establishing a new fund which could function in a similar way as the EFSI functions but in third countries. The aim is to address the root causes of migration. Having said this I do not want to oversell the idea; we cannot address the root causes for migration overnight, or very fast, but anyway we could use our development resources more efficiently and by establishing a new external investment fund we could encourage private investment in third countries and by doing so strengthen economic structures and address the root causes of migration. This idea is at the initial stage but we will come with a proposal hopefully later this year. Honourable Members, I will stop here and I am very interested to hear your views, how you have seen the investment plan as a whole and maybe the final word here is that we need to cooperate very closely, because MEPs are representing the European people. You are representing our regions, and the more you are raising awareness amongst investors about the opportunities that EFSI can offer, the better. Even though we are working very hard every single day advertising EFSI opportunities, we are never as efficient as you are if you are meeting local investors, local entrepreneurs and bankers explaining how EFSI can help the situation in the regions.

name: Othmar Karas
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We have structural problems, we have high deficits, too little investment, too little innovation, too little growth and employment. The European Fund for Strategic Investments, the so-called Juncker Fund, is one of our responses. And today we can say: the start has been successful! 249 projects in 26 Member States with an investment volume of EUR 100 billion were initiated. In 185 agreements, mainly in cooperation with the national promotional banks, 140 000 European SMEs were provided with financing. I therefore also welcome the fact that the SME window is to be enlarged. But we are far from the finish line.  We need large-scale projects, more sustainability, more investment in the digital future, we need higher risk profiles. Yes, we need an extension, we need enlargement to include states outside the European Union that we are involved in, we need a strategic link between the parallel activities of the EIT and EFSI, we need an addition to an EFSI in the neighbouring countries and an Africa EFSI, and we need an increase in our projects and an acceleration. I can therefore only welcome the interim report. But we are not there. Initiating investment is not a sprint, it needs a marathon, and we should therefore continue along the path consistently.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President, economic growth, social cohesion, transition to a sustainable economy, energy transition, the environment, deficit reduction and debt reduction through growth. Not blind rigour, not asphyxiation, but oxygen to small and medium-sized enterprises, responses to young unemployed people, greater competitiveness of our companies in the world. For this reason, we Socialists and Democrats asked Mr Juncker to provide for a European investment plan and voted for this Commission on the basis, above all, of this commitment. There have been important results, why deny it? But more can and must be done! There are three critical issues that need to be addressed. Firstly, additionality. This funding must be additional, not substitute. It cannot be business as usual, normal work that the EIB does, otherwise we would not have needed an investment plan and a special fund. Secondly, we must accept higher risks. I say to the EIB that triple A must not be a dogma, otherwise we would not have needed an investment plan if the higher-risk projects cannot be financial. Thirdly, relations with Parliament. You acknowledged this just now, Vice-President Katainen. We are the elected representatives of the citizens, and this plan comes from our own intuition and our request.  We need a constant relationship with the Commission and the European Investment Bank. We need more listening. Together we need to work on points of suffering, on the points of greatest need for change. We need to work together on more information than local realities, which need to know and must be able to apply for these opportunities. In conclusion, it is necessary to make this plan, through an extension, but it must not be an extension for its own sake, it must be an extension aimed at making this plan a serious, convincing and concrete response to the economic and social crisis that europe is deeply experiencing.

name: President. –
text: There are already Members of Parliament who have asked to put blue card questions, but I want to inform you that I will open it up after the Group speeches, so if you still want to put a blue card question after that, please ask again.

name: Sander Loones
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. I fully understand that the European Commission wants to communicate positively about its projects, which makes sense to me. But one can still ask whether this hurrah communication today is not just a little too early. Firstly, I notice that the Commission is already informing us today that the plan will be extended. I took a look at the state of play. In particular, I see a whole series of projects that have just been drawn up or have not even been drawn up yet. I see figures on investments and jobs, which are mainly estimates, and I see that almost no independent analyses have been made. So it may be a little too early to draw all those seemingly definitive conclusions.  We have also agreed that the European Investment Bank will evaluate the plan and that it should be done within 18 months. I haven't seen that analysis, unless I've missed something. At least we have to wait for that. Only when that analysis is positive, when it shows that the objectives of the plan are being achieved, can the European Commission possibly propose an extension. But I would suggest that we should then discuss this in this Parliament, and also in the Council, how best to set it up or not.  Secondly, the theme of the day: should we extend the investment plan to third countries, to developing countries? Yes, we need to strengthen that economy and the European Union can play a role in that. But I also want to call for not being naïve. We are all aware that not all countries concerned will be equally stable and loyal partners. We will therefore have to use extra control to avoid corruption and bad investment. I am not necessarily against, but I would like to call for a move. Finally, let us not lose sight of the essence. EFSI can have a very positive impact on our economy, on the investment climate. But if we really want to bring about change, then the Member States will have to reform. I was therefore very pleased, Commissioner, that it was precisely your first and very well-worked point in your speech, which is that we need to work towards these structural reforms.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to underline firstly that ALDE gave its support to the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and we remain supportive with maybe some question marks. I would especially give credit to the Commission for having had the courage to launch something that we have not seen from the Commission before. Commissioner, let me follow a little the structure of your introduction. You spoke, among other things, of widening and deepening of the internal market. I agree, but there is more to it. I think that if we speak of the investment environment, of the climate, of the conditions, then we should also look at the existing legislation, without lowering standards – this is not the point that I would like to raise – but still cutting significantly the administrative burden for businesses, especially for SMEs. This is where I would expect a serious initiative from the Commission with a serious and thorough review of the existing legislation in this respect. In terms of the financial means that have already been invested, we were aiming for EUR 60 billion – so let us say EUR 20 billion a year – and we were around EUR 12 billion for the first year. I do not think that this is a major problem. Every programme has a slow start, but it means that in the second year we have to have more than EUR 20 billion and, in the third year, most likely around EUR 30 billion if we are to meet it.  More of a concern is what kind of projects are we really financing? That is where, so far, I see the weakness of EFSI. If we look at the projects – and I have not seen any information about the last ten or so, maybe we are seeing a positive curve – but 90% of these projects are very similar to those that we would be financing from cohesion funding – let us say, low—risk EIB funding, CEF, Horizon whatever – so I am not sure that we are really meeting the objective of the added value , the additional financing and the risky projects.  I think this is something that we should focus on – or maybe I am ill informed and maybe the EIB could do better, as well as the Commissioner, in really portraying the difference between the projects that we finance from other instruments and the high-risk projects. All this is against the background that we have taken resources from Horizon 2020, as well as CEF, so we also need to balance the positive value against the background that we have reduced that sum somewhere else.  So regarding the expectations – without at the moment discussing prolongation or not – we need to review the quality of the projects and we should also maybe have a look, in terms of the review, at whether the EIB in the future should not rather be financing the lower—risk projects with a lower share, but with a higher share on the high-risk projects. I think that then we can really deliver. One final remark: you have spoken about the innovative, the creative and also the high—risk circular economy. It is absolutely clear that this has to be a key priority, which in fact could create a whole new industry. Am I wrong in saying that so far one single project has been financed? That is completely insufficient. So let us have a look at the weaknesses. We are happy to work with you on that.

name: Miguel Viegas
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, the latest data on the implementation of the European Strategic Investment Fund confirm the criticism we made at its launch. We said then that the ratios were unrealistic, we said that this plan did not correspond to the needs of relaunching the economy, we finally said that this plan was not neutral because it has no geographical distribution criteria, favours the richest countries and represents an authentic feast for large companies through public-private partnerships.  Current figures show that most of the investment in reality is concentrated in the richest and most developed regions of central Europe, confirming a private management framework for energy transport infrastructure, which should be public and put at the service of development and not at the service of the accumulation of profits for large multinational companies.  Portugal is currently at zero in the implementation of this plan and this is despite austerity policies having drastically reduced investment, to the point that they do not even cover capital depreciation, compromising future growth.  Instead of welcoming fictitious results, particularly in relation to SMEs, it is time to think about a genuine public investment plan made at the level of each Member State, thereby ensuring social and territorial cohesion.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is right that the Juncker plan should be the big deal of this Parliament, because the European economy is deeply ill with a chronic lack of investment, both public and private. But what about the cure? The means of this plan are, at the same time, so modest - we are talking about much less than 1% of European GDP - and so scattered, both geographically and thematically, that this dusting seems to me to be more homeopathy than the horse remedy that our economy needs.  In practical terms, if you want this plan to have any chance of success and to have a macroeconomic impact, it must be substantially strengthened by the Member States that have the capacity, but above all concentrated. Concentrated both in countries that suffer from a lack of investment and a lack of investment capacity - it is still incredible that we are financing countries like Germany, which has all the capacity of the world to invest - but also focused thematically on the great European value-added project, I mean the energy transition.  Energy is the heart of the economy, and the energy transition, energy independence, is a strategic, economic and ecological imperative for the Union. This is a good thing because the countries on the periphery are the ones that need the most investment, but also those with the greatest potential for renewable energy.  But the great contradiction of your policy, Vice-President Katainen, is the fact that while you are modestly pressing the accelerator with this investment plan, you are putting all the brakes on, both by the application of budgetary and accounting rules that handicap public investment, by an obsession with structural reforms that push more Europeans into poverty and exclusion every day, thus reducing aggregate demand and, even more so, by refusing to hold to account those States which deliberately have massive deficits - and I am obviously thinking of Germany - of their domestic demand. If you really want to get the European economy out of the hole, Mr Vice-President, we will have to get out of this schizophrenia.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I do not think we can call the Juncker investment plan a rip-roaring success. Just have a look around at the empty seats this morning. And the idea that tens of billions of private capital are going to arrive for joint projects with you guys frankly I think is pie in the sky. Though happily Mr Cameron, of course, has committed GBP 6 billion of our money to this project and if ever you are short of money just ask Mr Cameron because he always pays up. But it is I think these grand projects that in many ways, I think, are sowing the seeds of the end of this political project. I came in here in 1999 and sat at the back and there were only three of us in the whole building who thought our Member State should leave the European Union. But it is grand projects that have turned the tide of public opinion, in particular the introduction of the euro. You know I warned you, we all warned you, that it would not work for the Mediterranean countries. It could comfortably work for the optimal currency zone in the north. But no, through massive ambition and hubris you ploughed on and you allowed countries like Greece to join a currency that they were never fit for. And what is happening to Greece now? Well they are facing the next bailout, in probably July of this year, and because you want to hold your project together you are forcing them, bit by bit, to become a third-world country. And all I can say, frankly, is shame on you. The other big grand project was to allow into this Union first eight, and then ten, former communist countries, some of them with human rights records that are frankly shocking and abysmal, and others in which corruption is so rife that these countries have not made the transition to being full Western democracies. When I was first elected here the word immigration did not even appear on my election address. We did not use that word once when the first three of us got elected here. But now, as we have allowed much poorer countries to have the free movement of peoples, we see considerable anger in Britain and in many countries across the north of Europe. And yes, it has led to the rise of parties that some may consider to be deeply unpleasant, but that is what happens when you take control out of people’s lives. And the other feature I have noticed here is the growth of what I can only describe as authoritarianism. You know, we actually saw the Prime Minister of Greece removed effectively by a coup d’état and we saw Mr Berlusconi removed by a coup d’état and in both cases represented by appointees who were former directors of Goldman Sachs. So I think you have sowed the seeds of your own destruction. We have, in two weeks’ time, what is to be the biggest event in the history of this project. It is the British referendum and it is not just about whether Britain leaves the European Union, because if we make that choice I am confident many other countries will make that choice too. I did originally believe that we should leave because we were a square peg in a round hole. When I saw what happened here in 2005, when the French and Dutch rejected the constitution and yet sneakily it was brought in through the back door as the Lisbon Treaty, I realised then that this is not just bad for Britain; it is bad for the whole of Europe.  And I hope that on 23 June it is not just Independence Day for the United Kingdom. I hope it brings an end to this entire project and in a few years’ time we could be sovereign, democratic nation states that work and trade together. I hope this is the last time I will be speaking in this Parliament from a Member State. I hope that we are going to leave this Union on 23 June. And so I am going out now; I may be some time.

name: Steeve Briois
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a year ago you almost unanimously adopted the Juncker Plan, billed as the most important bailout in history, which is supposed to boost public investment and economic growth in Europe. Admit that a year later, your rescue plan turned into a smoke plan; in a word, it is total failure. This was not the case because the European Fund for Strategic Investments, with a budget of 21 billion euros, failed to drain enough private capital, since the profitability of public investment was by definition lower. This failure was the failure, as the investments financed under this European fund focused on large-scale projects in the city centres, neglecting many local projects, resulting in an increase in regional disparities. Failing, finally, because the figures speak for themselves: economic growth stalled, youth unemployment historically high and poverty taking hold all over Europe. In reality, the Juncker plan aims to create dependence on European funds while imposing a budgetary diet on the Member States, with the sole aim of uniting our peoples around your doomed project, which destroys national identities. But the peoples of Europe are not fooled, they are waking up at the moment, I want to prove the results of the FP in Austria or the polls in the United Kingdom, where the Brexit camp is de-announced as the winner. Whether you like it or not, a Europe of nations and freedoms is on the move.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, only a fantasist can be described as the one who believes that Juncker's Investment Plan has so far achieved what he promised when he first advertised it in 2014 in order to be elected President of the Commission. It cannot be considered a success when the investment trend in the Union remains below the historical low and has continued at the same pace since 2013 without change in the implementation of this Plan. I do not see it as a success when this money is mainly directed to developed countries of the Union and not to states that continue to be in economic crisis, such as Greece and Cyprus. It is not a success, when in the 140,000 small and medium-sized enterprises and mid-caps expected to benefit from the Plan there is only one Greek and none Cypriot.  Businesses in Greece do not close only because they do not have access to finance. They are closing because they cannot meet the debts arising from the austerity policies imposed, and only these plans are not enough. Change policies! If there is one thing you have achieved, it is that you have succeeded in destroying my country completely, taking advantage of the undying left-wing government and the former co-governments of the Centre. That's why I can congratulate you.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for allowing me to intervene in the debate. I think it is better to be more interactive in this way.  I have just a few comments on the interventions we have heard so far. It is very important for the EIB to remain a triple-A bank, because triple-A status has a direct connection to the financing power the EIB has. But I fully agree with Members who have said that the EIB should take more risk, and for this reason we have established the EFSI. It enables the EIB to finance projects which are seen as more risky and is worth EUR 63 billion. This is what the EIB is doing at the moment. The EIB has done an excellent job. Apart from adding finance to risky projects, it has upgraded its presence in many of our Member States, including Greece, in order to help the Greek authorities, and the private sector especially, to benefit from EFSI and benefit from other financial instruments of the EIB. The EIB has done its share very, very well.  One issue I want to raise in the debate – and I want to raise awareness amongst MEPs on this issue – is that it is also possible to combine structural funds with EFSI. We already have a very good example of this kind of financing in northern France where the Nord-Pas-de-Calais region has organised an investment platform which aims to gather together a large number of SMEs and start—ups, especially in the digital field. They will use private capital, regional money and EFSI funds in order to provide risk financing for those companies. You can find this example on the website. This is a model which could be copied in the other countries, especially the cohesion countries. There we need the help of MEPs, because you know EFSI funds and you know the regions. EFSI is a demand—driven fund. I am happy that we have one genuine circular economic project which has got financing from EFSI, but I am dissatisfied that there is only one. So, again, we have to raise awareness amongst circular economy players and investors that EFSI can really provide something which the market cannot provide, or does not provide, at the moment. EFSI is a perfect instrument for the circular economy, for new innovation and new technology investments, which for some reason cannot get full financing from the market. There again, the role of MEPs is crucial. The EIB does not create projects, it only finances them, and that is why we have to raise awareness amongst investors, and also amongst the regions and cities to use EFSI for new innovations. I want to raise one issue. We are following very closely what is going on in our Member States in terms of EFSI activities and related things. I have very good information on the activities of MEPs. So far only a handful of MEPs have organised EFSI events in their regions or Member States. A very good example of these kinds of activities was last week, when I had a chance to visit Mr Pittella’s and Mr Gualtieri’s event, where southern Italian regional leaders came together. We were talking about opportunities to use EFSI for southern Italian purposes. Also, Ms Spyraki has organised events in Greece, Ms Paunova in Bulgaria, and Mr Guoga in Lithuania. This is exactly what we need at the moment. We need to raise awareness of what EFSI can do and what EFSI has done in other countries in order to make it possible to use EFSI in a more efficient way. If you want to see the projects which have already been signed, you can find all the projects on the internet. It is very good to look at them and pass the message on to the other regions about what the others have already done. EFSI will not solve all the problems in Europe. In the best case, it can provide financing or it can help to get investments worth EUR 315 billion euros. This is only one third of what is needed. That is why the other parts of the investment plans are even more important than EFSI. It is easier to talk about money when we are talking about EUR 315 billion, or what EFSI has already financed, but the rest of the plan is even more important. That is why I expect co—legislators to be as fast when implementing, or when approving, single market—related proposals as we were when we approved EFSI legislation. It took only six months to push EFSI through the Parliament and the Council. Why should we wait longer when dealing with, for instance, a waste legislation proposal or digital single market-related proposals? So the internal market-side of the plan is even more important than EFSI, even though EFSI is very much needed.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the European Fund for Strategic Investments has proved in this first year of operation that it strongly encourages investment in the European Union. It is strengthening confidence, growth and jobs. It has already mobilised EUR 100 billion, which is not short-seeded in 26 Member States.  Moreover, more than €75 billion for the SME window has already been mobilised, exceeding all expectations and best expectations. Portugal, for example, has already used this plan for SMEs, which supports more than 590 SMEs and mobilises more than €588 million.  In view of these data, it is easy to predict and argue that this fund should continue beyond the three years originally envisaged. It is also important, at the outset, that the EIB complies with the Regulation with regard to additionality, with regard to the selection of projects, which should take into account territorial cohesion, job creation.  I insist that no minimum amounts for project eligibility are defined in the Regulation. No one is obliged to apply for this fund, but member states and local authorities need to be encouraged to do so, to set up regional, national and transnational investment platforms to promote the geographical dispersion of investments as much as possible.  In addition, it is necessary to disseminate the advisory support platform, the IAP adviser, so that the investment is known and mobilised throughout the European Union.

name: President. –
text: I will now give the floor to Mr Bullmann, whose birthday it is today, so congratulations.

name: Udo Bullmann (S&D).
text: Thank you Mrs. President, thank you very much. Madam President, Vice-President Katainen, I would like to thank Mr Katainen for his excellent work on this EFSI could be a gift – indeed – and that is why the European Parliament has given it a great deal of hope. However, an interim report is also a good opportunity to correct mistakes. And I think we have reason to do that. Error number one – and I would ask you to take a closer look there, also as EFSI's governing body: we have the impression that the European Investment Bank is using the funds that Parliament has made available, among other things, to scale back its own activities. That is not the point of EFSI. We are in need in the European Union, more investment is needed. So, please take a look at what the European Investment Bank is doing in its normal programme. We believe that cooperation with the regions, with the actors there, is being neglected. Where are the platforms that we have set up as possibilities? There is not one mentioned in your interim report. Finally, a third important point: you are not using the instruments provided for in the legislation. We have given you a benchmark to set priorities. They finance a motorway in Baden-Württemberg, the richest part of the Federal Republic. The observer wonders whether we in Europe have no other problems. Is that really extra? Tell us where in the scoreboard ranking this project has been given priority over others. If these questions are answered, we are also talking about a necessary extension. But first we have to make a clean table.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The villages of Prince Potemkin were, as we all know, real successes. Different from what the saying goes. But the EFSI's successes have so far been on paper. Even if the Christian Democrats, some of them the Social Democrats, are overwhelmed with enthusiasm in the face of the paper successes, so far it is mere hopes that are on this paper.  What worries me, frankly, Commissioner, is that you said that the lack of investment in Europe is due to banks no longer being able to take risks to the extent that they used to do so because we re-regulated them. Mr Katainen, if that is the reason that we do not have any investments, then it is not right to extend the EFSI as an instrument of state risk-taking, then we must approach this regulation, then we need to revise it. Then it is not right to say that EFSI has raised billions in private investment, but then we have to find that our regulation has outed that our regulation has prevented banks from taking risks.  And that, Mr President, we in this House will have to work that out and correct the mistakes we may have made in the context of regulation. It is important that we do not turn public policy on its head here. It is not the case that banks are supposed to finance the safe sides of the investments and the state takes the risk. No, it must be the other way round, Mr Katainen. Banks are the risk-taker, and banks are the ones that need to check risk. The banks are the ones who have to do the assessment. If that does not work, Mr Katainen, then something fundamentally is wrong in the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), blue card question. – I am not one of those who will argue that the European Strategic Investment Plan will solve all the problems. But this European Commission, this Commissioner, this European Parliament voted and supported the European Strategic Investment Plan which is nothing on paper. They have already given 100 billion and there is a prospect of up to 315 billion being mobilised in the European Union. We're not saying it's perfect, but it's very easy to zero in and flatten without submitting any alternative proposals. We expect enrichment proposals, alternative proposals that will help this Plan to be effective and not to have a complete refusal, probably because it will be convenient for some, if the Plan fails, to criticise the European Union further, for doing nothing. Help us support it for the European Union to succeed and succeed together.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, thank you very much for the question. But we have been naming the alternatives for a long time. The alternatives are to make countries competitive again, and for that we must dissolve the euro as a single currency and allow those countries that need devaluation to devalue. Then we will indeed be able to stimulate economic activity in Europe again. Please do not pretend that the alternatives have not been identified. You don't listen, or you don't want to hear them, or you don't want to hear them. There is talk in this House of all sorts of things, but there is no talk that the euro is an unsuitable currency for Europe.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE).
text: Madam President, the Juncker Fund is undoubtedly the european Commission's flagship initiative. It aims to fill the investment gap that Europe has suffered over the past decade. The first projects funded are numerous and encouraging, but it is still too early to draw up a reliable assessment and, in this regard, Vice-President Katainen, you will have to dispel three doubts.  The first doubt concerns the requirement of the fund's additionality, in other words its added value. We will have to show that, without the intervention of the Juncker Fund, the projects in question would not have been financed. The second doubt concerns the temptation to be used by some public investors to de-de-force capital expenditure and the corresponding debt, in order to lighten the presentation of public accounts in an optical way. The third doubt concerns the risk of replacing the European Investment Bank, which has the competitive advantage of the fund guarantee, with market operators.  As exciting as this fund is, let us be in mind that the brakes on investment are still very much present. First in the commercial sector, investment is conditioned by competitiveness. That is to say if countries that are slow to reform cannot wait for a miracle. Beyond the Member States, the Union has its own brakes, especially when the monetary environment is the subject of questions. Investors are haunted by uncertainty. There is an urgent need to decide the British referendum, to draw the consequences and to reform the governance of the euro area to make it more effective and more democratic.  Finally, the commitment of operators depends on the predictability and stability of market rules. In many areas, the single market is fragmented by national regulations, by local competition authorities. There is also an urgent need to complete the single market, to accelerate the convergence of tax, social regulations, in short, to make the euro area and the European Union an optimal economic zone.  Clearly pleased with the first results of the Juncker Fund, the Commission is considering making it sustainable. Financial engineering allows volumes to be increased tenfold. The fact remains that the guarantee must be mobilized in cash that is ringing and stumbling. But before we decide, since we are at the end of the first of three years, let us make sure to dispel the doubts I have just expressed and to remove without delay the brakes that hinder investment, growth and employment.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL).
text: – A Uachtaráin, bliain tar éis plean infheistíochta an EFSI táimid anseo chun éisteacht leis an athbhreithniú faoi. Is é seo an plean mór, gan dabht, a bhí chun an tAontas Eorpach a tharrtháil. Is baolach go bhfuil sé soiléir, faoi mar a dúras cheana féin, nach bhfuil an plean seo ag obair.  Bhí an EFSI chun infheistíocht réadúil a chruthú go háirithe sna tíortha sin a bhí i gcruachás de dheasca polasaithe déine. Bhí an EFSI chun infheistíocht a dhéanamh ar thaighde nuálaíoch, tionscail inbhuanaithe agus glas, fiontair shóisialta, SMEs, comharchumainn; is iad seo an chnámh droma d’aon fhíorgheilleagar. Ach níl fiú an t-eolas búnusach acu seo ar conas éileamh a dhéanamh ar an EFSI. Tá iasachtaí an BEI ag titim go mór ar an breisíochtaí a bhí geallta. Cruthaíodh formhór den infheistíocht i SMEs i lár agus in oirthear na hEorpa. Bhí infheistíocht de EUR 2 bhilliún as an EUR 3.5 billiún caite anseo. Ach cé mhéad post a cruthaíodh? Cad iad na tíortha a bhain tairbhe as? Cad iad na tíortha go bhfuil an gá is mó acu le hinfheistíocht? Do luadh, ó na hoibríochtaí EFSI atá ceadaithe go dtí seo go bhfuil timpeall 85% den infheistíocht iomlán le teacht ó infheisteoirí príobháideacha agus poiblí eile lasmuigh den ghrúpa BEI. Ach abair liom: cad é an céatadán d’infheistíocht phríobháideach atá i gceist? Cad atá i gceist le hinfheistíocht eile poiblí? An infheistíochtaí áitiúla agus infheistíochtaí údarás réigiúnach iad; an infheistíocht ár mBallstát, ár gcánacha atá i gceist? Faoi mar atá feicthe againn in Éirinn, tá EUR 200 milliún infheistithe cheana féin in Uisce Éireann, agus is iad na gnáthdhaoine a bheidh ag díol go daor as seo; an cáiníocóir atá ag díol as uisce cheana féin. Ní mór na botúin a deineadh lenár n-airgead, a íocadh trí cháin, a cheartú, agus deirtear linn nach gá athruithe a dhéanamh ar an MFF chun saol an EFSI a leathnú níos faide ná 2018. Ach tá deontais airgeadais agus maoiniú ón AE laghdaithe go mór agus caithfimid aghaidh a thabhairt ar seo. (Aontaíonn an cainteoir freagra a thabhairt ar cheist ó "chárta gorm" (Riail 162(8) de na Rialacha Nós Imeachta)).

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question. –This plan is not working. How can it be said that because there has been very little time and, for example, in Italy, as Commissioner Katainen said, forty-four thousand SMEs have already received funding? It's working. What do you think of the idea of using this funding, for example, to solve europe's biggest problem today: the integration of immigrants, for example by repairing inconsolable European suburbs or preventing the emergence of new inconsolable suburbs? We think a little too much about the fact that this is just motorways or railways, and we also need to invest in increasing people's skills.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: freagra ar ‘chárta gorm’. – Is léir nach bhfuil sé ag obair i bhformhór na dtíortha imeallacha ach go háirithe. B’fhéidir go bhfuil an plean seo ag obair sna tíortha móra a bhfuil na pócaí doimhne acu agus go bhfuil infheistíocht phríobháideach ar siúl. Ach is baolach i mo thírse ach go háirithe, níl an t-eolas ag na daoine ar conas éileamh a dhéanamh air seo. Níl an struchtúr ann chun éileamh a dhéanamh air seo agus is léir go bhfuil an t-airgead ar fad ag dul isteach in infheistíocht phríobháideach seachas in infheistíocht phoiblí. Agus mar sin, ní dóigh liomsa go bhfuil sé ag obair ar chor ar bith. Caithfear aghaidh réadúil a thabhairt air seo chun an geilleagar a chur i gceart.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Vice-President Katainen, last week there was a pretty self-congratulatory press statement by the Commission on how successful the Juncker plan is, but I think we really first need to have a good couple of questions answered before we can be so satisfied with it. First of all, EFSI should be additional; it should fund projects where no money would otherwise go. Can you explain the widening of motorways in Germany and Netherlands? Where is the additionality there? Secondly, this one should also be for the countries mostly affected by the crisis. How can you explain that Greece only has one project on infrastructure and one SME project? That is really one of the regions most affected by the crisis, yet it is not benefiting from EFSI at all. That is also a genuine problem. Thirdly, this should be a transition of the economy. Bank Watch concluded that, without EFSI, the EIB is subsidising 25% of the projects related to climate. With EFSI it is 27%. It seems like business as usual. These things need to be answered properly before we make self-congratulatory statements on what a big success this plan is.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what I witnessed this morning is absolute self-celebration on the part of the Commission. He said that 44 000 small and medium-sized enterprises were financed in Italy. I went to see on the Commission's website and there are eight projects, many of which are environmentally and socially unsustainable. I can tell you that there is the enlargement of a motorway, the A4, and explain to me how environmentally sustainable it is to focus again on the automotive sector, the Milazzo refinery, then oil, then the Arvedi steel works, steel, and the gas network. Gas does not seem to me to be a renewable source, so I cannot explain why the Greens are also clapping. Meanwhile, the Commission's concept of SMEs, if we look at the definition of what SME EFSI can finance, also concerns companies with up to 3 000 employees. I want to see in Italy how many companies there are of this type. So a total self-celebration for a project that is a failure. Now you also want to make a similar one for developing countries. Well, but I want to see transparency about this type of system, because there we always sin: we go to finance projects and then we see that subcontracting always subseas the usual known ones. Transparency is the first watchword.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner Katainen, you said today that the internal market part is certainly the most important part of the investment boost. I fully agree with you on this. The Member States of the European Union must implement their structural reforms. This is the only way to create sustainable growth and employment in Europe. Investor confidence must be restored. Now I wonder where the added value of the EFSI actually lies – and this has already been mentioned several times today. I would like to give an example of this. Just last week, the first Austrian project was implemented, namely an EFSI project, a wind farm project in Hof-Seibersdorf, twelve wind turbines with a capacity of three megawatts each, EUR 70 million in project volume, 40 million of which was taken over by EFSI as a guarantee, 20% by the house bank. I do not see that this project would have a particular risk profile that would justify the additionality of the EFSI. This wind farm operator has been working with the EIB for three years, and the bank has been financing from the outset. So: I don't see the added value. Perhaps this added value should be made clearer. Several other projects have already been mentioned in other countries where there is no additionality. A second momentum for not fulfilling the core business, namely to take over the high-risk projects, is the leverage 1:23. 249 EFSI projects were funded, four billion euros were needed to kick-start 100 billion. This shows that you are not going into high-risk projects here. Perhaps it would be better to increase the eib's capital in order to actually invest more money in the economy and in development. The investment gap must be closed, and the EUR 16 billion from the European budget must be channelled more into Horizon 2020 in order to promote innovation in addition to investment. Then investing in Europe can go uphill again.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Madam President, after so many financial instruments, NSRF, European Investment Bank, billion-dollar packages, Juncker-type packages, you are still lying. In Greece, where every government with SYRIZA in the dirtiest role considers it an obligation to cut back wages and pensions, where you pay out of your own pocket, if you have the medical materials if you want to operate in a hospital, it is a challenge to talk about fair development for all. Who pays for the packages? Workers, of course, with their memoranda, with their taxes, with the ever-increasing VAT on the national contribution to the European Union, subsidies and tax exemptions to investors, their bank financing, since the recapitalisations of the banks are paid by the people.  Who benefits? Of course, not small but only large enterprises in priority areas not of the people but of capital, such as energy, transport, tourism, ensuring that investors are guaranteed profitability with few temporary jobs, lousyly paid, as another wage reduction is being made. The truth is one: Recovering capital gains means deeper poverty for folks. It's time to reverse it! It's time to turn it around!

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, there is a great need for investment in Europe. That is why the PPE Group has supported this plan and will continue to support it. It was a good start. The figures show that things are going well, but I think you need to come before Parliament with a different kind of analysis: a qualitative analysis. Let's see if this fund filled a gap, so it replaced what couldn't be done through other tools. Let us see if this desire that you have expressed here, for the EIB to keep its triple-A, is – well, a right wish – but this means that it will not finance high-risk projects, which is the first purpose of this fund. I believe that a comparative analysis needs to be made with the financial instruments that are provided for in absolutely all European funds. Has this fund replaced the financial instruments? Have the financial instruments been used? If not, let us move the money from the financial instruments to the fund and, in this way, we can also recover the money for Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility. I believe that this analysis is absolutely necessary. The information must be made. You need offices everywhere so that people and institutions can find out what the EFSI can do. We parliamentarians can do this, but I believe that you and the EIB must do this first. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I want to thank you, Mr. Advocate, for accepting my question. Listening carefully, I have come to one conclusion, but I would like to hear your confirmation. Does it seem to you that EFSI, which is of course an excellent instrument and which I strongly support, nevertheless tends to finance projects in the so-called old Member States of the European Union, and primarily in new countries, i.e. in eastern European countries, we have almost no serious funding and there is almost no greater knowledge of financing opportunities through EFSI? And do you think the Commission should do something in this direction to help these countries, which of course are less developed than the old member states?

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: answer to a question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. Yes, it's true. The figures show that in the eastern countries, there are not many projects. I am not, however, very sure whether it is because of the EIB or the Commission or because of perhaps a lack of interest and a lack of information in these countries. That is why I was saying, at the end of my intervention, that information offices are needed, especially in these areas. Aggressive action is needed, say, towards these areas so that projects can be presented there. I am absolutely convinced that these projects exist.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Vice-President Katainen, today we assess the successes and failures, compliances and deviations from what we approved here a year ago. And, like everything in this life, nothing is black or white. It is undeniable that EUR 100 billion has been injected into the economy and that many projects have been allowed to obtain this funding through public and private mobilization, but we cannot fall into complacency, nor in the mistake of letting ourselves be dazzled by quantity, because quality and additionality are more important than quantity. And in this respect the objectives are not being fully met. The impact on employment and the social impact of projects are not being taking into account, let's not mention geographical or thematic coverage. And that is why I hope that the Commission and the EI will be working harder to improve these parameters than to reach the magic figure of EUR 315 billion. Surely the greatest success of this plan has to do with SMEs. But nothing new, nothing different from what was already being done with initiatives as successful as COSME or InnovFin. And finally, I'd like to talk about the advisory center and the platforms. These two tools need to be given a boost, so that both local and regional entities and smaller projects have access to them, because that's where we can really make a difference. Because, honestly, so far, of everything that has been done, what could not have been done with a simple expansion of the EI's capital?

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The Commission's statement on the implementation of the so-called Juncker Plan, which states that EUR 13 billion has already been spent from the EFSI – which should generate eur 100 billion in investment – has been supported by 64 infrastructure projects and 185 financing agreements have been concluded for small and medium-sized enterprises, sounds encouraging. Unfortunately, there is clearly a lack of balance in the territorial distribution of the supported projects. The vast majority of them come from Western Europe, including projects that seem to be market-funded, such as motorway projects in Bavaria and the Netherlands.  Central and Eastern Europe is unfortunately a white spot in this respect, despite its investment lagging behind and huge infrastructure, energy and innovation needs. In my country, Poland, only one project in the dairy industry has been supported, amounting to EUR 46 million. However, none of the many projects in the energy sector has unfortunately received support. I would therefore like to express my hope that, over the next two years of the Juncker Plan, the issue of balance in the territorial distribution of investments supported by the EFSI will be at the heart of the Commission's focus.

name: Искра Михайлова (ALDE).
text: – I would like to remind colleagues from the outset that EFSI is a new tool – new as a design, new as goals and new as opportunities for both Member States and individual regions. EFSI is a tool that has a triple structure. It includes both the dedicated advice hub and funding opportunities, the potential of the European Investment Bank's experience and the European Commission's potential in co-managing the fund.  Last but not least, EFSI started its work with specific guidelines for good coordination with existing European funds, including cohesion funds. Here lies one of the potentials for efsi development in the future. Good coordination between the various financial instruments of the European Union allows for better investment. We cannot seek the opposition of individual instruments, we can use the simplification, flexibility and potential of the various instruments to achieve the objectives we aspire to – i.e. growth and employment.  Last but not least, I would like to point out that EFSI has not yet unleashed its potential for sufficient awareness of member states. The advice hub works, but it is necessary to work with advice and technical assistance at national and regional level, as well as to exchange good practices. I wish good luck in prolonging the work of the fund.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, when President Juncker came to this Plenary to announce his investment plan, he told us that Christmas had come earlier. Clearly it was an exaggeration of optimism, but also, with the age we are, already only believe in Santa Claus who wants and just spend a year of the investment plan to realize that he fell far short of what was announced.  We really need investment in the European Union, but not this kind of investment. It has to be put to the taboo about public investment, it must be in strategic sectors that create added value, such as the energy sector. I don't understand the added value of motorways in Germany or the Netherlands. There has to be regional distribution, it cannot be concentrated in the same countries as always and what more investment they have. Southern Europe or Eastern Europe cannot be deleted from the map. It needs to be directed to the true European industrial fabric and not just to multinationals.  To say that small and medium-sized enterprises are 3000-employee enterprises, Mr. Katainen, really? Finally, the miracle of multiplication did not happen, Mr. Katainen, and the European Commission is still in a state of denial, full of reality and self-dazzled. So nothing new.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, 'tell me what you presume and I will tell you what you lack', we say in Spanish. Our precautions a year ago have become concerns now. EIE is not, for the time being, the investment plan that Europe expects and needs. It is simply a new financial instrument for the European Investment Bank to expand its activity. The Juncker Plan has gone from being the big star of the mandate to irrelevant financial normality. Looks like we're competing with Draghi. We add money, little and without much selective judgment, but we do not start the engine of growth.  Where did the extraity go? What is the actual level of risk of projects with a European budget as collateral? How was the hard-won scoreboard used? What is the real involvement of States and what role do the parties play in regional or thematic investment problems?  We remain installed in supply policies when we have a serious problem of insufficient demand, starting with Germany's outrageous resignation from acting as an engine of European growth. We're in time to rectify. We need a genuine European investment plan, including public investment. With clear sectoral objectives and consistent geographical application: energy transition and climate change, investment in the digital economy, education, research and social equipment. Let us draw the logical conclusion of the experience of this first year of validity of the FEIE. Private investment will only result in sustainable growth if we adopt demand stimulus policies with a European dimension. The only real extraity we should get.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF).
text: – When the banking crisis erupted in 2008, the Member States of the European Union were no longer able to react adequately because of the euro. Economic growth collapsed, unemployment soared and public debt doubled. And nothing has helped since then: nowadays even interest rates are negative, so it is now beneficial to retire first and then go to work, because with a negative interest rate, nothing pays off at all.  Nevertheless, President Juncker saw a bright spot, a hundreds of billions of EU investment funds that set things right and at the same time make it clear that the Member States are no longer in charge. Does it help? No, unemployment is still sky-high and growth is still among the lowest in the world.  That is why I am asking the fundamental question: why would Brussels prefer a single, poor EU to free, sovereign and prosperous European countries?

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Katainen, I believe that today we can make a reasonably good assessment of the evolution of the plan so far. In its first year, the mobilized investment is estimated at 100 billion euros, which is undoubtedly a good sign, but we still have to keep making progress. The Juncker Plan has allowed access to EUR 242 million of SME funding in my country in Spain, mobilizing EUR 4.4 billion and could benefit up to 17,000 of these small and medium-sized enterprises. The European Commission has proposed the extension of the EIEF. This will allow projects under study that are strategically very important for my region, for Navarra, such as the electrical interconnections between Spain and France, to benefit from this plan. That's why we definitely support him. But let's be aware. The Vice-President said that EIE is not the solution to all the economic problems that the European Union has. We need to continue structural reforms. On the other hand, I would like to stress that, in order to fully exploit the potential of the FEIE guarantee and avoid distortions in the markets, it is imperative that the EI actively and fairly cooperate with national promotional banks and private investors. Only in this way will the FEIE instrument serve as a tool of true 'crowding in' and thus we will be able to avoid the phenomena of mere substitution of sources of financing in projects in favour of the European Investment Bank. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. "Thank you very much for the opportunity, Madam President, for you, Too, Congressman, for the chance to respond. You mentioned that there are certain distortions, although you see fit overall for this plan. I would like to ask you, in the light of this, why do you know that there have not been any applications from certain Member States, such as Hungary? What could possibly be done to encourage these countries, who are not applying, to do something about geographical balancing?

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Szanyi, I do not know in depth the situation in Hungary, but I certainly - and as the Vice-President has said before - it is also the responsibility of Members of this House to help promote and publicize this plan. I did it in my town. I did so in Pamplona, with the cooperation of the European Commission, and I encourage you and your Hungarian colleagues to do so in your country too because, I certainly stress, it is also our responsibility to contribute to spreading the benefits of this Plan.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, we must succeed in the investment plan, so let us give ourselves the means to achieve it. You said earlier that the EFSI is there to finance what the market cannot finance. That is where the problem lies. Doubts are mounting about the additionality of the device. The EIB's choices do not seem to be more risky than before and our objectives on employment, cohesion and energy transition are being neglected. We need to fix the system as soon as possible so that it can help projects other than those with a high level of profitability that could probably have been financed by the market. One of the corrections, in my opinion, is to abandon the quest for the highest multiplier effect, which mechanically implies that the most profitable projects are retained and that the riskiest but often the most structuring projects are excluded at the same time. It is not a question of throwing the baby out with the bathwater, but of adapting the system so that it can respond to projects with low and less profitable multiplier effects, but - as I said - more structuring, responding in particular to the priorities of energy transition, cohesion and employment.

name: Stanisław Ożóg (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Mr President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Over the course of almost a year, the European EFSI fund has initiated investments of around €100 billion for nearly 250 infrastructure projects in twenty-four Member States. According to the information provided on the European Commission's website, we can see huge differences in the disposal of these funds from the fund for individual countries. Most projects – as mentioned – are carried out in the western part of Europe. Mr President, I have a question: what do these differences come from? Is the problem only in the quality of the projects presented by each country? In the case of my country, Polish – where the European Commission has practically become a party to the internal conflict – are partly politically decided?

name: Nedzhmi Ali (ALDE).
text: –  Madam President, 18 months after the introduction of the investment plan, it is time to make the first mid-term overall assessment of the results in order to be sure that it supports the priorities declared by the Commission and adds value to the European economy. The last figures revealed that we have already substantial investment from EFSI that should trigger total investment of EUR 100 billion. These resources are spread throughout the vast majority of the EU Member States and are concentrated in the areas of energy, research and development, transport, the digital single market and other sectors vital for the European economy.  In the case of Bulgaria, several banks have already signed agreements and are active in the area of supporting small and medium enterprises. Equally important are the other two strands of the investment plan: the transparency of investment opportunities and strengthening the advisory services, as well as improving the investment environment. Bearing in mind that the first results will support the implementation of the plan, in the case of extending the activities of the plan, we call for more effective project distribution to include all the underdeveloped regions of the Union.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, Mr Katainen, instead of complacency and satisfaction, a decisive shift is now needed. The Juncker Fund needs to take a turn for more investment across Europe but especially where there is more recession, more poverty, more unemployment, more disinvestment. It cannot be that in the 64 projects there is only one project, and indeed a small one, my country Greece, which has suffered enormously in recent years from a great recession and great disinvestment, and at the same time finance expensive motorways in rich Germany, the rich Netherlands and the richest parts of these two countries and criticise you by MEPs from these countries, both Dutch and Germans, for this injustice.  These investments must therefore be directed towards the poorest regions, southern Europe, Eastern Europe, renewable energy sources, small and medium-sized enterprises, to create employment. Next time you will come with less self-satisfaction and with more changes in the direction requested by the majority of the European Parliament.

name: Claude Turmes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I have just one minute and I have to be sharp on energy efficiency and the circular economy. Mr Katainen, you are right. EFSI is demand driven, but why is there only one circular economy project? Why is the energy efficiency pipeline empty? Why?  First, it is because you have completely investment-hostile accounting rules for the local authorities. It is because they are on-book and they cannot invest through third parties. This is so counterproductive. You have known this for one year and you have not done anything.  The second issue is that you have promised us EUR 350 million of technical assistance, and we have EUR 60 million because your services gave us the wrong information when we negotiated. I have proposed since September last year an energy efficiency hub for south-east Europe to allow technical assistance from the Structural Funds to come into the scheme. No answer from the Commission. So do not accuse me of not having done my work. I have done my work but it is the Commission who will have to act to make EFSI more efficient.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: – The EFSI is a kind of hocuspocus project, where, following the example of Jesus Christ, you have the European Union promulgate a kind of multiplication of loaves in favour of what you call more risky projects. In the meantime, Belgium has three infrastructure projects, I take this as an example, which are financed by the EFSI. EUR 380 million will be deselugged and this should actually generate a total of EUR 1.8 billion in investment and create 3200 jobs. Bravo! Applause! How you can live up to this in an SME country like Belgium and justify it with three projects is beyond me. And it is also a mystery to you, because the figures are not explained anywhere. Hocuspocus statistics, I call it. By the way, when I see that most of the money goes to a project for offshore wind turbines, I hold my heart, and with me the entire Flemish population. In Flanders, we have enough experience with green-flow madness and the mountain of debt it causes.  In short, I'm not impressed with your good news show. This EFSI fund is not a new deal for Europe at all. In the euro context, it is rather a long-term debt mountain for the European population.

name: Herbert Reul (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Of course, one cannot ask an instrument to solve all the problems that lie. We have too few investments in Europe, and I cannot solve that with one instrument. But EFSI could and can make a contribution if it is applied correctly. In this respect, after one year, I think it is quite fair to simply assess soberly: where are weaknesses, where are strengths, and where are there perhaps other homework that needs to be done? For me, this is a problem, that there are not so many particularly strong investments in economically weaker and smaller countries, that certain countries that we actually want to have are not included, or that the impression arises that very often investments are also being made in products or projects that are already running or that have already been started. It's not always just brand new projects. That is why we need to look at how to sharpen this instrument, how to make it work better. In any case, however, this instrument is much better than lamenting and the message that we only have to throw in more money. It is not about more money, it is about the intelligent use of money. And there is an idea whose final success cannot yet be assessed. That is why I think it is too early to say today: 'We will definitely prolong'. But there needs to be further work on this. And it is part of it to honestly admit that investment weakness also has something to do with the points that the Commissioner himself has mentioned. Of course, banking regulation also seems to have a weakness in the fact that banks are no longer as willing to finance. You have to think about whether you have to correct it. Or why is industry in Europe investing very heavily outside Europe at the moment? This has something to do with our regulations, and that is something that needs to be considered in the same way. So please: do one thing, but don't let the other.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would point out to Mr Katainen that he is the Vice-President for growth and jobs. So let me recall the three objectives the investment plan and EFSI should meet and, in fact, the crucial questions the European Parliament will address to you to ensure a regular oversight.  The questions are very simple. How far is EFSI going in raising recovery and job creation? The second question is: How far is EFSI going in promoting the transition to a new growth model, greener and making the best of the digital revolution? The third is: How far is EFSI going in reducing the regional divergences?  My conclusion, and my Group’s conclusion, is that the Commission needs to change something fundamental, first on the promotional strategy, because you need to build up investment platforms and to spread advisory hubs everywhere. Secondly, we need to change the financial strategy. Sooner or later you need to confront the need to raise the ceilings of the MFF and, most of all, you need to create real room to invest in the national fiscal policies.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR).
text: – Madam President, when I was flying back from Strasbourg to London a few months ago, I looked down at the sea and I saw line after line of huge wind turbines, generating clean, green energy, and I thought: is this the Juncker plan? Is this EFSI? But then I thought, maybe that was the project that was funded already by the European Investment Bank. It is great to see new investment in infrastructure. We need it, but we cannot be complacent because public confidence in European spending is at a very low level and we need to make sure that all the money is well spent. So when we are reviewing the performance of the fund for strategic investments, we should also evaluate how this programme relates to other EU funding, including the EIB. We should make sure there is no overlapping of overheads and also double check whether science and research projects have suffered from having their budgets top-sliced.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, in order to prevent the EFSI from being a mere capital increase by the EIB, the European Parliament, aware of the abundance of liquidity in the market, had defined the terms for the use of the European taxpayer's money, namely the European value added and the additionality of the projects selected.  What is the record a year later? In the transport sector, for example, the additionality and European added value of the selected projects, mainly motorways, do not seem optimal. For projects more in line with European political priorities, additionality will often require coupling with financial instruments and subsidies. In this regard, we can only regret the budgetary drain on the interconnection mechanism for Europe by 2020, which goes against the very effectiveness of the plan.  The qualitative improvement of the projects requires an equally proactive approach by the Union. The good national and regional articulation in the selection of projects requires improving the results with national promotion banks. Having said that, all these details will be in vain if we do not act in parallel on the creation of an attractive environment for investors, I mean the necessary evolution of the regulatory framework concerning the financing of the real economy, and in particular infrastructure. Europe must defend this priority within the international institutions responsible for the development of these prudential standards to which institutional investors are subject.

name: Monika Vana (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to add one more thing to the many criticisms made by my fellow Members about the implementation of the EFSI: this is the striking lack of social investment. Only four percent of all EFSI investments go to the social sector, for example in health and education. This is the lowest share of all sectors. I believe that, especially in times of crisis, social innovation, green jobs or even social entrepreneurship should be particularly encouraged. It should also be ensured that EFSI's investments are in line with the Europe 2020 targets such as poverty reduction, lowering the number of early school leavers, climate protection and research and development promotion. Mr Vice-President, we Greens are fully committed to the objective of increased investment, private and public investment, in order to get us out of the crisis and to create employment. However, the Greens' criticisms of the design and implementation of the EFSI, which have been made from the outset, are justified if we look at the figures for this interim report. Not only have expectations been fuelled by far too high expectations and the announced leverage is far too low, but the geographical distribution and sectoral distribution of funds is also unbalanced. Mr Vice-President, make sure that the EFSI has added value for Europe's citizens! We are not able to see that at the moment.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE).
text: – I was rapporteur in the Committee on Regional Development for the EFSI. We have welcomed the EFSI under three conditions.  The first is additionality, as well as the contribution to territorial cohesion in the EU. We have very little information on your first communication. It is not only about investing in itself, but also about reducing the imbalance in Europe.
