After the crisis, after EFSI, in three years' time, it should not be the case that the richer regions have been strengthened and the distance with other poorer regions increased. When do you come up with a real report? That's very important.  The second point is the synergy between the funds. In this respect, you will come forward with a proposal to amend the general regulation for structural and investment funds. That is what we have asked for.  And thirdly, the role of regions in the investment platforms. That's a good pick. This has given you close to people, companies and governments to take advantage of opportunities. Small and medium-sized enterprises and family businesses can be addressed directly. And everywhere we have the same need for long-term guarantees to promote innovations. You don't do that for one or two years, the way the banks want it now. That in itself is a positive approach. But when are you going to come up with your real report? [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to ask Mr Lambert how he actually sees the EFSI in terms of employment. Does the EFSI actually bring employment, or does it only secure employment, or does the EFSI also lose employment somewhere? Is this an important component that should also be taken into account in the order of projects?

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. –The objective of EFSI - and I am also looking at the Vice-President of the Commission - is growth and jobs. The beauty of this project is that, by guaranteeing, there is now also room for new employment, whether or not it is the result of developments in the digital world. We need to set up the training for our people. We should not look at the statistics from day to day, but look at how we can achieve sustainable development, energy transition and so on in the slightly longer term. There's a need for that. Think of industry 4.0. That's where employment comes in.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: – The S&D group was undoubtedly one of the biggest supporters of investment policy and of EFSI. But you will notice in the many interventions that there is some criticism of the success story that is now being presented. The figures are there, but for our group, investing to invest is not enough. It's about what we invest in. It's about the transition in energy, circular economy, low-carbon economy. Those must be the priorities. It is crazy to say that money is being taken away, for example from the financing facility for European connections to invest in motorways.  We want to see change in EFSI for the future. We want more investment in sustainable economy and we also want much more investment in small projects. So not business as usual, not rebranding projects that were already there, but really betting on the new challenges in Europe.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: – According to the European Commission, EFSI is a success. Also in my country, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. Investments in the order size of around 40 million euros will then receive a return of perhaps 330 million euros through leverage. That sounds really good, but now let's go to practice. Last week, my party had organised a large meeting with entrepreneurs and I asked them in particular whether they were participating in this type of investment project. And they all basically said, no, we don't, because it's a whole effort that we have to make to make an application and you don't know what the outcome is. It's too much bureaucracy and too complicated.  I would like to give this to the Commissioner in an evaluation: improve accessibility so that small and medium-sized enterprises get involved and want to participate, because I have experienced that this is not going well yet.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I think that after one year of operation we have achieved reasonably good results. Of course, EFSI does not produce miracles but I hope nobody expected that. The figures on balance are good and encouraging. One concern I have is that the geographical distribution of projects is not well balanced. This issue has already been raised earlier. We would like to have a clear explanation on that and perhaps suggestions as to what can be done in order to make this distribution more balanced. Another important concern which I also have is on one of the initial goals of the EFSI plan. This goal was to improve the investment climate in Europe in general. Basically, EFSI was supposed to work as a confidence-building measure. To what extent do you think we have achieved this goal, Commissioner? To what extent have we managed to improve the investment environment and the regulatory framework in the EU Member States in order to encourage autonomous private investment to take place? When I look at the statistics, we see that investment is still very sluggish. Of course, one question is to what extent this additionality condition has been fulfilled and to what extent we have avoided the crowding out effect of private investment. But the other thing is the regulatory framework, to what extent we have managed to make the environment more conducive to business, and to what extent we have managed to convince private business to start investment because the prospects for growth in Europe have improved. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President, my fellow colleague, I agree with what you have said about the geographical distribution. I want to ask you specifically: do you think that the criteria used by the European Fund for Strategic Investments - 'first come first served' - help to improve cohesion or affect the cohesion we are talking about in the Treaty of the European Union?

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for this question. I think we have to indeed had a closer look into the system of project selection. I think the project selection should be based on the criterion of additional value added, in terms of European value added. In this sense, I am, for instance, against excessive concentration of projects in selected countries. No, the project should be selected on the basis of economic viability. We should not forget, after all, that it is the EIB which is behind this selection, and of course the projects have to fulfil economic criteria.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in the face of the great beneficiaries of the EEF, countries which are neither the most unemploymenty nor the most crisis-affected countries, for countries in excessive deficit proceedings such as mine, which were largely the result of misguided policies of cuts and austerity and with an express ban on being able to borrow, the only attractive novelty — a real European added value — of the EEF was the implementation , finally, from golden rule to European investments. We were initially told that it would apply to the first tranche of contributions from the Member States, which, as you know very well, Mr Katainen, were null and void. We are now told that it will be possible to apply, in accordance with Vice-President Moscovici's communication, to the platforms of intermediary investment banks, but neither is functioning as they should. And the European Investment Bank, when the president of my region, Aragon, approaches to demand concrete support on specific projects, offers him business as usual, without solution to the problem of indebtedness. Not to mention distressing examples such as the Beaver project, which the EID still advertised when Mr Rajoy's government was already proposing to paralyze him with costly consequences for Spanish taxpayers. Now he proposes to extend it further, when we have not yet resolved the greatest contradiction, which comes from his own services. An instrument of indebtedness is offered to countries and regions which are prohibited from borrowing from guidelines and sanctions of the Commission itself. Mr Katainen, how are we going to solve this contradiction that is lethal to the EIE?

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Madam President, EFSI has been particularly successful in the United Kingdom, with 1.9 billion financing in infrastructure and innovation projects and 462.3 million in SME financing already achieved. Examples of EFSI-backed projects include the roll-out of smart meters across a large number of households in the UK, the construction of a new teaching hospital in Birmingham and the operation of an offshore farm in Scotland. However my constituency of Northern Ireland has not been able to make such good progress, even though we have a Barroso task force – now a Juncker task force – set up so that Northern Ireland should do well. Can you actually explain to me why Northern Ireland has not done so well?  I will understand if you cannot accept my question today and I will accept your answer in writing down the road, if that is the case. But why have we not done more? Is the problem in Brussels? Is it in London? Is it in Belfast? Please tell me, because my people want to know because we want to make up and we are very supportive of this, so I hope you will respond to me.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her My question goes in the direction of what is the difference between a bank loan and EFSI; What are the main differences? And I would very much like to ask my friend Katainen if he sees a further development here, because he has already said in his opening speech that a direct equity instrument is actually going away. What can we do to make venture capital available easily, especially for spin-offs, for start-ups, for scale-ups? Have we in Europe ever thought about implementing accelerators, as there are already many in Silicon Valley, to help our companies, which already exist, to conquer the world markets? I believe that this would be a very important procedure. I believe that private-public partnership is important in that, of course, small and medium-sized enterprises must first develop products or services that are bought by consumers accordingly. But making known, producing, usually requires capital and investment. If you tax that away beforehand, then of course there is nothing left for investment. That is why it is important that we also use incentive instruments in terms of tax policy. Private individuals or those who have a lot of money at their disposal today and are willing to take risks, of course, must also be given a risk premium. So what is Mr Moscovici's incentive strategy? How can we involve Mr Moscovici in incentivising those who create jobs, invest and ensure Europe's prosperity?

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for expressing your support for the Juncker plan. We European socialists wanted this plan and the European Parliament wanted it as well. We are pleased that you are considering its extension because, indeed, investment in Europe is not going well. Paradoxically, low interest rates do not encourage investment. There are countries that are struggling to mobilize investment projects, where it takes 10 years to start building a bridge, and there are those that do not have the necessary funding. So, yes, the Juncker plan was necessary. It needs to be extended.  But, this plan, we wanted it on other terms than the ones you agreed to hear. We wanted an additional plan, we wanted a job-creating plan, we wanted a plan for the ecological transition and we wanted a plan for the cohesion of the European Union. None of these criteria are availab at the rendezvous. In addition, I would add that in order to finance it, you must relaunch securitization or accept Chinese funds unconditionally. So, yes, we want to continue with you this investment plan, but not in any condition. It is time for you to listen to the European Parliament.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Madam President, there is a Swedish expression which says that you should not shout hello until you are over the river. I do not know how you look upon that in other parts of Europe, but I would like to advise that as an approach from the Commission during the review, because the fact that the money in EFSI is spent and used is not a success as such. It would have been a surprise if not, because public—subsidised and public—guaranteed money is always preferred to other types. The remaining problem is that Europe still has an investment gap of between EUR 300 to 400 to 500 billion annually, and we see it very clearly when we look at the flows of foreign direct investments. Since 2007, they have been more or less halved, while in other competing regions they have been doubled. This is the core problem, and in the review the Commission needs to look at whether this money is replacing other investments. Is it creating attraction to more investments, and at what does it mean that we have undermined research science and the Connecting Europe Facility? This must not be an alibi for reforms to make Europe the most entrepreneurial economy in the world by attracting investments, instead of promoting them. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – The geographic repartition is a very problematic issue. We need to know – and this is my question – what has been done, or will be done, to correct that – to allow less—developed financial Member States’ markets to access finance through the European Fund for Strategic Investments, and not only the most stable, technical—capacity countries. What should be done?

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I think the answer is both simple and complex, as always. The main reason for investments in any of our countries is that you can get a return on the investment. Otherwise, it is not an investment. Therefore, we need to strive for stable public finances but also remind ourselves that, if we in the European Union on average have a 10% to 15% higher tax load than in any other competing region, of course this is influencing the climate for investment. So let us change the climate for investment in all parts of the European Union and go ahead with that.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Has EFSI actually been launched? Mr Katainen, please answer the question of how many additional, new and sustainable jobs have been created so far by EFSI. After all, investment for the sake of investment does not bring the European economy or the European citizens any further. And the citizens should keep an eye on them. If you are honest – and this has already been mentioned in the discussion – the desired leverage has not been achieved. EFSI has made a lot of investments that were already planned and that would have taken place. So what is the added value of EFSI at the moment? What we need is a genuine investment offensive that takes effect where stimulus to the economy is really most needed, and not just that profits are made. We need an investment programme that is popular with people, which reduces unemployment and poverty. Only then does an extension really make sense.

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. It is no coincidence that the Commissioner would like us to talk about the investment plan all the time, and our House is talking about an investment fund, in fact, confined to the fund only. This is no coincidence, and it is worth thinking about why we are not talking about the remaining elements of the plan. After all, the evaluation of the fund, in accordance with the rules, is foreseen for 2018. That's the first thing.  Secondly, as rapporteur for the budgetary revision, I would like to express my satisfaction that the Commission is proposing a revision of the budget. The proposal to extend the EFSI for the coming years is de facto a proposal to revise the multiannual perspectives. I am therefore pleased that the Commission wants a revision of the budget.  And the third very important element: there is a difficulty in implementing the merger of the EFSI with the Structural Funds – the Commissioner has said this, we have an example from France – but in fact it is very difficult. Furthermore, I would like to draw the Commissioner's attention to the fact that the requirements for the Funds are different from those of the EFSI projects: there is no compatibility between the two elements. If this, and this is to be European, then the conditions must be similar. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (
text: PPE), blue card question. – Dear Mr Olbrycht, I intend to propose to the Vice-President of the Commission, and I would like your point of view, the creation of a expertise transfer task force in countries with low leverage from the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). I'd like your opinion on that.

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – With this design of the Fund, it is not possible to make a simple geographical translation. It is therefore, in my view, a good idea to create a kind of entity that reflects on how to mobilise investors so that the effect is geographical, since geographical assumptions cannot be ed. I would absolutely support this idea.

name: Jens Geier (S&D).
text: Madam President, Vice-President Katainen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Yes, EFSI can present a generally positive balance sheet when you look at investment. This morning, however, we want to optimise EFSI in the first place. The European Parliament, as the budgetary authority, is expected to put EUR 8 billion on budget figures guaranteeing investment. We have taken the money from research policy, from the Horizon 2020 programme, and have been harshly criticised for this by the community of researchers. We have taken the money out of the Connecting Europe Facility, thereby restricting the most important financial instrument of European transport policy. And in the 2017 budget, we are expected to mobilise an additional EUR 3.3 billion for these budget lines. Mr Katainen, I have the honour of preparing the 2017 draft budget for this House. I will be watching very closely what your authority is doing to improve the additionality and sustainability of the projects. Please do something to ensure that the Committee on Budgets of this House does not agree that we are actually only paying what the European Investment Bank would have paid anyway. Then we would have left the money better in research policy.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). Madam President, Mr Vice-President, all of us in the European Parliament have sometimes called for growth and new jobs in our countries. For all this to happen, investment is needed. The European Commission responded quickly and created the Investment Plan with a huge contribution from the European Parliament to make it better, and we must not forget the unlimited important contribution of his dear colleague José Manuel Fernandes, who was the rapporteur for this Project.  I'm not one of those people who thinks this plan would solve all the problems. I am not even one of those who believe that this project will be a complete success, but to date I have not heard another alternative proposal. I have not heard any suggestions for optimising this Plan. And I am telling you, that I belong to a country such as Cyprus, which has been tested and so far has not taken a cent from this Investment Plan, to formally ask Vice-President Katainen for countries such as Malta and Cyprus, which have not been able to participate to date, to receive the contribution and assistance of the Investment Fund. , to provide information on the Investment Fund, because until now all of us believed or believe that it is only for major projects, for infrastructure projects, for large deployments. It's for small and medium-sized enterprises. If possible, make a one-stop shop in each country where small and medium-sized enterprises are informed, in order to achieve the objective and dissemination of this Fund to 140,000 small and medium-sized enterprises. Frankly, I do not want to think that some people would prefer the European Strategic Investment Plan to fail to criticise, because I believe that the Plan has not failed but can succeed much more with suggestions, with a positive approach, with constructive dialogue. And the European Parliament will do that.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if we look at the data, I believe that we can say that, on the one hand, the EFSI formula can work and, in many cases, it is working. For example, there is no doubt that the 'small and medium-sized enterprises' window is producing additionality, leverage, very high, and is producing positive results. But it is also true, especially if we look at the 'infrastructure and innovation' window, that we can and must do better and do more. I as the main critical elements individual the following. Firstly, I believe that the involvement of national development banks must be strengthened. Secondly, we need to see more platforms created in the various countries and also transnational. Finally, we must help more to combine the Structural Funds with EFSI funding. We have examples, the Nord-Pas-de-Calais case, of mezzanine tranches, junior tranches with European funds, but they are still isolated cases. This combination, together with the national platforms, I believe is the key to really enabling EFSI to address market failures across Europe.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I just wonder how often it happens that we vote for something here in plenary last June and we actually bear very concrete results a year later. Citizens, as well as businesses, expect swift decisions and this is one. At the same time, the plan is not a panacea for all our economic hurdles but it paves and facilitates the way ahead for the European economy, with more competition-based investment in projects with added value and a much easier access to finance for business. Thanks to our suggestions, the SME window was enlarged and, in this way, has reached 185 agreements with commercial banks that will contribute towards more than 140 000 SMEs across Europe. This contribution will go towards the innovative ideas of younger professionals, of those digital entrepreneurs in businesses that want to contribute to a more prosperous Europe because it is precisely these businesses that say their number one problem in bringing their ideas to life is lack of financing and this is what the plan addresses.  I would like to encourage the Commission to act much more quickly and to bring the advisory services to national and regional level. This will have a twofold effect: they will be more involved and develop better expertise. Second, this will allow more coherent technical advice when it comes to combining EFSI and ESI funds because the Member States already have a solid capacity on that.

name: Massimo Paolucci (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, finally, with the Juncker plan, we are concentrating on investment. We are finally talking about development, which is our real big problem. We see the glass half full, the first results, but it would be wrong to be too enthusiastic, it would be wrong not to see the problems. Firstly, the environment and sustainable development and the transition to a circular economy must be a clear strategic priority. We're not on that. Secondly, we need to finance new, additional projects, as they say. If we only finance projects that are already mature and market-supported, we do not go very far, we do not make progress. Thirdly, integration with the structural funds is technically difficult if we do not put the regions, especially the regions of the South, in a position to free themselves from dull budgetary constraints.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Dear Commissioner Katainen, first of all congratulations on the first year of operation of the Fund. I think he's taken a positive surprise in a lot of ways. He also pointed to some shortcomings. They have been mentioned here today, and I also think personally, that one of the key drawbacks is the lack of investment in the countries that are most needed. It's not your fault. To a large extent, I think that there is also the fault of the Member States, which have under-prepared for this and do not have the infrastructure built for this type of investment. Similar fates have been given to cohesion funds in the previous perspective and also to the current one when it comes to more complex projects. I therefore recommend that you do the most about this promotion with us in Member States where there are no such projects and projects are urgently needed, and that countries deal with their development backlog in this way, otherwise Europe will be less cohesive than it is today.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President, I will be rapporteur for the REGI Committee on the mid-term review of the EFSI. As other Members have said, we believe that cooperation between EFSI and ESIF, the Structural Funds, is still insufficient. In particular, where there are market failures, we need greater cooperation with the Structural Funds and, in particular, with the grants part of the Structural Funds. It is also because, as has become very clear, the poorest regions are those where the presence of EFSI is still small and the knock-on effect has not been there. Secondly, we need more ambition: EUR 100 billion roughly one year of investment in Europe is a drop in the ocean. You are well aware that investment has fallen greatly as a whole as a crisis. There are about 500 billion missing from the appeal, so I think we need to move forward if we are to have a really important effect.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, Mr Katainen, the Juncker Investment Plan for Greece has failed because the troika, in which the Commission is a member, has imposed a stifling economic environment on Greek society and entrepreneurship. It has reduced wages and pensions, resulting in a reduction in purchasing power in the Greek market, which discourages investment. The troika has increased indirect taxes and the tax rate on small and medium-sized enterprises, which leads to padlocks. Instead of the troika returning to Greece the profits of the ECB and the central banks, SMP and ANFA, of 10 billion euros by 2020, in order to finance a new Marshall Plan for development, the ESM keeps that money. Finally, the referral of Greek debt regulation to the Greek calends is a burden on the economic climate and discourages investment. So the Juncker Investment Plan can only support the Greek economy if Greece gets rid of the memorandum and the troika. You have to understand that.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL). – Mr Katainen, instead of the Investment Plan promoting public investment for growth for the benefit of society, it is based on private investment and aims to reduce their risk. This is also confirmed by the data for the first quarter of 2016, according to which the money goes mainly to developed states and regions. Where multinationals make greater profits and not in states such as Cyprus and Greece, which are most in need because of the memoranda of austerity policies that have torn their economy apart, they have led to high rates of unemployment, youth migration and the poverty of the people. Equally dangerous is that the Commission's report clearly states that, instead of giving new money, further involvement of the Fund for Strategic Investments with Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe programme as well as the Structural Funds will be promoted. In other words, it is planned to further cut off funds from existing programmes and funds. Unless the objectives of the Investment Plan are changed and new funds are not given to new investments, there will never be a way out of the crisis and recession.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Vice-President Katainen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Katainen, for his excellent work on this It is striking that in this discussion on the package that you mentioned, Mr Vice-President, the focus is clearly on the EFSI and the focus on the further development of the internal market, which you have emphasised so much, is much shorter. There are two reasons for this. Firstly, the difficulties that exist with the EFSI, which have now been presented in so many ways by colleagues, almost force us to make it clear to you that the EFSI as it has been practised up to now does not fulfil the hopes that you have raised with it. Secondly, with regard to the further development of the internal market, the digital single market and capital, you do not set out anything that gives us hope. Change your policy, otherwise you will not inspire anyone in Europe!

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I am going to get down to business. Two comments: there is no default geographical and sectoral lease in the plan, because to date there is a high concentration of investment in a few countries, including those least affected by the crisis, and when you invest in renewable energy, you do so by favouring large companies, and not self-handling and self-sufficiency. Secondly, there is a lack of clarity and transparency as to how credit lines and funds granted to banks and large financial groups operate. I would remind you that there are several private equity funds. Commissioner, you say that EUR 12.8 billion is expected to be EUR 100 billion. Is this expected? Be transparent and precise. How much money has come? To whom? Where? Under what conditions? Are you funding the real economy or creating a new financial bubble? What happened to the leverage effect? One for fifteen: but 12.8 billion for 15 is not 100 billion.

name: Andrey Novakov (PPE).
text: – Madam President, facts and figures do not need explanation: they are self-explanatory. Facts and figures are showing that Juncker’s plan is performing better than a lot of people here believed it would. If I had to use aviation terms I would have to say that the Juncker plan and EFSI have had a very short and bumpy runway but still flies and while it has a very strong tailwind from pessimism and political hate at the moment it is working perfectly. And exactly now, when we have reached our cruising altitude, along with planning to go further and watch further, we have to see what the results are and analyse them. Here, I have three main improvements that I believe have to be made: investment platforms at a regional level to help meet potential investors and public entities; create more public and private partnerships, and more and strong technical assistance on the ground to help potential beneficiaries; and last but not least, more synergies between EFSI and ESIF.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the investment plan, which must certainly be extended, has education and the cultural and creative industries as one of its priorities, I would like to remind you. But these two areas have hardly noticed, as shown by the analysis you have presented on the sectors. With the exception of some countries such as my own, Italy, which has launched an ambitious "Digital school" plan in which EFSI is actually additional to public resources and the Deposit and Loan Fund, there are few projects around. As we have already said to your colleague Mr Navracsics and the European Investment Bank in the Committee on Culture, Youth, Education, the Media and Consumer Policy, the Commission and the EIB must play a proactive European direction role in this extraordinary plan, as a great opportunity for employability, innovation and transition, not just waiting for projects that do not arrive. National and European platforms should be promoted, including to facilitate access to schools, universities, as well as creative and audiovisual SMEs, with more targeted advice to these actors. I am thinking of some of the proposals that we have also made, I am thinking of the e-card of European students, the platform for e-teaching, the online recognition of skills, platforms for the promotion of cultural industries.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I have the following remark: you have doubled the time for almost all speakers. I was the first man in the room at 9.00 and I spent two hours at the debate and you don't give me catch-the-eye. I find it unethical and it's not the first time you've done this. I think it is not collegial either, but, above all, it is not beneficial for debate.

name: President. –
text: Thank you for the point. As you know, I came into the Chamber during the debate. I tried to be flexible and explained to colleagues that there were over 20 people wanting catch-the-eye, so please make your contributions in writing, and I am conscious of giving new voices to the debate for the lots of colleagues who have been in the Chamber. I hope you will accept that I am trying to be fair and flexible and that I do have to stop the debate at 12.00.  Yes, colleagues ran over their speaking time and I tried to control that. So, with apologies to those who have not spoken, I hope you will respect my attempts to be fair. I know, Mr Jakovčić, that the ALDE Group have not spoken in catch—the—eye, but you did get a blue card and you were the only colleague looking. I hope you understand. Thank you for your understanding. I do accept and take your points on board. Commissioner, I would like if I may to invite you to respond to the debate and, if I may say, from the point of view of communication, perhaps Parliament and the Commission have work to do in the Member States.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I will make a few comments. I will try to group my answers to your questions together. First, around 30% of EFSI projects are in the energy field and mostly in the renewable energy efficiency field. Some of our colleagues said that there were no projects in energy efficiency. That is a complete mistake. EFSI provides risk financing for new technologies and innovative projects and that is very good because this is what we all wanted.  For everybody who is concerned about projects already financed – or if there are some areas which have not been covered, like the circular economy for instance – I strongly encourage everybody to be active with the people who are operating in, for instance, the circular economy field to raise awareness of what EFSI can provide for them. I do this every single day. I go around Europe explaining the opportunities EFSI has to offer, for instance, new innovations and circular economy projects, but unfortunately the level of awareness varies between the Member States. Now, I will come to the point concerning why some Member States have not benefited very much from EFSI already. It is mostly – if you look at it very concretely – because public authorities have not been active in promoting EFSI opportunities. As we all know, EFSI does not finance pure public projects, but very often regional authorities, national authorities and Ministers play a role when raising awareness about what EFSI can do among the private sector – private investors – and there are huge differences between Member States.  Some Ministers have even indicated very clearly when I met them that if there were not more trains coming to their country, then they were not interested in EFSI at all. I asked them, if they were not interested, to please convey the message to investors in the private sector that they could contact the EIB directly.  Private investors in many countries are hearing for the first time, even though we have repeated it over and over again, that they do not need any public sector approval if they want to apply for resources from EFSI. We just have to repeat this over and over again. That is why I have repeated here a couple of times that we need your help. In some Member States some MEPs have been very active at regional level, conveying the message that companies can apply directly for resources from the EIB. Another point is that we have Commission Representations in all the Member States, which are ready to serve both public authorities and regional authorities, but also the private sector, to explain what EFSI can do. In most Member States too we have EIB offices, which are there for technical assistance and advice.  In many Member States we have seen excellent events organised by the private sector itself or by political parties, for instance, or by public authorities, to which they have invited private investors, entrepreneurs, industrialists and regional leaders, and to which the EIB has sent its representatives and the Commission has sent its representatives to explain what EFSI has done in other countries. We have to do this more in all the Member States.  So there are some attitude problems. Some Member States are very passive but we try to contact the private sector directly in those Member States where the public authorities have not been the most active. When looking at the projects, there were a few concerns about whether EFSI has financed motorways without good reason. Actually the few motorway investments which have benefited from EFSI have been technically the most difficult, there has been uncertainty about the traffic and it has been very difficult to attract private financing for those projects. Before you condemn those projects, I really encourage you to look at them and discuss them, for instance, with the EFSI management because they can explain in more detail why they have selected those projects.  We are helping – although it is not our primary duty – Member States to create platforms for green shipping, for instance. This means that we try to collect together port investment and other green shipping types of investment in order to spread EFSI to the areas where there have not been any projects so far.  I visited Greece for the second time a month ago. I met representatives from the five biggest banks in Greece and tried to explain what they could do for SMEs for instance. In Greece too it was the first time that Greek banks had heard that they could apply directly for resources from EFSI for SMEs.  I understand all the difficulties that the Greek banks have, but another idea which I raised there was to build an investment platform, for instance in the tourism sector, which means, basically that the platform could collect together a large amount of small—sized investment – for instance hotel renovation projects or things like that – and the private sector could put some equity in the platform while EFSI could provide , for instance, long—term, very low interest rate loans to the entrepreneurs.  I am a hundred percent sure that these would function in Greece. I spoke about it with the Greek authorities and the Greek Government and we have very close cooperation with the Greek Government on this issue. So I do want to see this happening in Greece. The same thing would also function in Cyprus.  There were lots of other issues. Mr Nicholson, you raised Northern Ireland and why Northern Ireland has not benefited from the EFSI yet. I do not know what the Northern Ireland authorities have done or have not done, but we have our Representation there at the authorities’ disposal. I visited there personally and I tried to convey the message to the private sector in Northern Ireland that they could apply resources directly from EFSI and it would be good to establish a platform for smaller projects. So everything is possible, in Northern Ireland too.  All Member States have the same opportunities and in those Member States which have been the least active, the Commission, and even my Cabinet directly, try to help the authorities understand how they could utilise the opportunities we have at our disposal. I will stop here. We have mostly been talking about EFSI and this is only one part of the Investment Plan. I want to underline the importance of the single market project. I will repeat once more that hopefully Parliament and the Council can adopt and approve the proposals from Mr Ansip on the digital single market and from Commissioner Vella on the circular economy, etc. This is even more important than what EFSI can do because, when we take down barriers to investment, it has a big impact on growth and on sustainable growth.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. – Today we assess the successes and failures of what we approved a year ago. EUR 100 billion has been injected into the economy and many projects have been allowed to secure funding through public and private mobilization. But we cannot be dazzled by quantity: quality and additionality are decisive for this plan. And in this respect the objectives are not being fully met. The social and employment impact, geographical or thematic coverage is not being taking into account. And that is why I hope that the Commission and the EI will be working harder to improve these parameters than to reach the magic figure of EUR 315 billion. Surely the greatest success so far has to do with SMEs. But nothing new about what was already being done with initiatives as successful as COSME or InnovFin. Boosting the advisory centre and platforms will give both local and regional entities and smaller projects access to the plan. That's where we can really see the difference between what has been done so far and the investment plan that Europe so desperately needs.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – We discussed at the plenary session of the European Parliament the progress of the Juncker investment package, which aims to stimulate the European economy. The investment package so far has proved to be shadowy in terms of its benefits for Greece. To date, 64 projects have been approved in Europe, with a total funding of 9.3 billion, and most of them are in major economies, such as France, Italy, Germany, Britain and Spain, while only one is in Greece. The European Commission proposed on 1 June to extend the investment package for another three years, but did not propose structural changes to ensure that the necessary funds were channelled to the economies most affected by the economic crisis and austerity policies. If the parameters of the programme are not changed to benefit the weakest economies and if the available funds are not increased, then we are talking about a drop in the ocean and the stimulus of the European economy is doomed to be left on paper alone.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. In today's debate in this House, the Commission presented a first assessment of the Juncker plan, one year after its inception; While it can be said that important results have been achieved – over 100 billion investments have been made, with 65 projects financed and more than 150 thousand SMEs involved – I am convinced that more needs to be done. I believe that the EFSI should give priority to greater additionality and finance innovative projects at higher risk, which would otherwise not find ordinary funding opportunities, so as to unleash its leverage effect to the maximum and provide added value for the European industrial and social fabric. Secondly, I believe that the success of the Juncker plan must be based on better integration with the existing Structural Funds, with the aim of involving local authorities and the poorest and most needy areas more closely. The Juncker plan is already providing a concrete stimulus to economic growth, offering new vital oxygen to our companies and SMEs. It is the most effective response to the economic and social crisis of recent years and the lack of investment in Europe. We must work to make it even more ambitious and effective.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. – The economic crisis has led to a sharp drop in investment and severely shaken the confidence of European citizens in the ability of the Union institutions to solve Europe's economic problems. When we adopted the Juncker Plan last year, we sent a signal to citizens and businesses that we would work to break the vicious cycle of low consumption, low investment and, as a result, low growth. A year later, we can say that the results are encouraging. The European Fund for Strategic Investments already operates in 26 Member States and is expected to attract €100 billion worth of investments, although most projects are still in the initial phase. It is important to ensure that all approved projects fulfil the additionality criterion in order to avoid shifting private investment. In Bulgaria, EFSI support already facilitates access for small and medium-sized enterprises to finance through the so-called EFSI. window for SMEs. However, projects in the Infrastructure and Innovation Investment Window remain mainly concentrated in larger Member States or those with developed financial markets, indicating a need for a more efficient distribution in order not to undermine cohesion policy objectives. At a time of challenges to EU unity, it is important not to create dividing lines between Member States.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE)
text: In writing. I would like to congratulate Mr Katainen, Vice-President of the Commission, for his action and for his great personal availability to welcome project leaders and regional leaders. Eighteen months later, the Juncker plan is an institutional and administrative success: the mechanism was put in place and reached its cruising pace on time. But the question marks we originally had remain, first of all on the quality of the projects: are we sure that these are innovative investments that will make the EU more competitive? Then on the added value of the device: the list of selected projects gives the impression that they would have emerged with already existing funding. Is the Special Fund more than an additional EIB window? Finally, on the macro-economic outcome: the aim was to bring investment in the Union back to 2008 levels. You didn't tell us anything about that. However, despite the collapse in interest rates, despite the mass of savings and available liquidity, despite the Special Fund, investment has not restarted and, since 2007, foreign direct investment has fallen by 15%. This is why the mid-term balance sheet should be an opportunity to readjust the device or objective.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – When trade unions and left-wing parties asked for an investment plan for Europe, we did so because mass unemployment and the deind industrialization of the European periphery required another productive model, capable of ending dependence and the spiral of precarization of employment by dumping between countries. Nothing, absolutely none of this analysis is present in the Juncker Plan. At best, the EI and European budgets are being duplicated, with no new resources and no democratic oversight. At worst, private speculation is being socialized, from Beaver to Abengoa. And all this at the service of the same neoliberal project: the privatization of transport and energy infrastructures and the subordination of public policy to the market, including in this game regional funds and national budgets. We continue to believe that the EU should finance projects capable of improving its social and territorial cohesion, reinforcing the priorities of public administrations in their economic planning and workers in business management. We're still waiting.

text: in writing. – Today we assess the successes and failures of what we approved a year ago. EUR 100 billion has been injected into the economy and many projects have been allowed to secure funding through public and private mobilization. That's where we can really see the difference between what has been done so far and the investment plan that Europe so desperately needs.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In the context of the revision of the Investment Plan for Europe, I call on the Commission to help achieve one of its key objectives, namely to improve the quality of the education process by creating new funding opportunities for the education and training sector. Unfortunately, so far no education-related project has been submitted under the Investment Plan. In order to encourage potential beneficiaries to apply for funding, we therefore need additional information campaigns and practical support for educational centres in the development of relevant projects. I would also stress that priority should be given to projects that focus m.in. on bridging educational and training inequalities and implementing a dual education system based on international cooperation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. - The new investment plan, through the implementation of EFSI, well supersedes the lack of investment on the European market. However, there are often questions in discussions about how many of the 65 projects funded so far are really new and whether they are projects that would not have been realised without EFSI, as well as funds formed to finance entrepreneurs. Criticism goes in the direction that this is only a continuation of the EIB's classic activities. Nevertheless, the fact is that funds are being invested, projects are being realised and that the European Commission will encourage additional funding from 2017 to continue.  By using EFSI well, we could achieve synergies with EU funds. For example, from the funds we can finance a very limited number of projects and real needs related to energy efficiency, digitisation, new technologies, reconstruction and construction of railways, ports and the like. For all this, we could form investment platforms and raise investment potential through public-private partnership projects or just public and private projects.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing – The Investment Plan for Europe, funded by the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), is designed to finance high-risk investments and finance areas where the market is not functioning. These are complementary investments that would not have been possible without EFSI. EFSI is financed from the budget at the expense of Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility (approx. €5 billion). This money is what we are missing for projects with high added value. Among the EFSI projects supported are projects that do not require any risks to be borne (e.g. thermal insulation of 40 000 apartments and houses in France). In Slovakia, let us make such investments without EFSI. On 22.2.2016, in its report on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies , the Annual Growth Survey 2016, Parliament invited the Commission to verify that EFSI funding is provided only to high-risk projects that comply with the principle of additionality; in this context, Parliament will evaluate projects as well as their leverage to ensure that the EFSI Guarantee Fund is used in an appropriate manner within the EU budget. To date, the Commission has not presented such an assessment. I assume that the Commission has not found enough projects to implement the Juncker Investment Plan. The next time we use this fund, we must use it for the purpose for which it was intended.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Investment Plan should have brought a big change in the European economy. Despite the efforts, it seems that the initial declaration do not match in reality. The multiplication effect expected is not there and only few countries are taking benefit of this opportunity. The Commission is wrongly blaming the Member States for their lack of involvement instead of correcting the errors of the plan. I therefore call on the Commission to review the Investment Plan in order to: – allocate the financial resources based on the development needs of beneficiaries and regions by integrating the cohesion criteria – develop special instruments for start-ups with a special focus on youth and the poorest regions in Europe – create distribution quotas for countries in order to enable an equitable access across Europe – increase the transparency in the financial allocation and pro-actively engage in generating consortium in the countries having less experience in such type of financial aid The Investment Plan has to work, we have to raise the EUR 315 billion expected to be invested through this mechanism, but we also have to make sure no inequalities are made and that everyone can benefit out of it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. - On 24 June 2015, Parliament approved a regulation establishing the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) within the European Investment Bank in response to the financial crisis. So far, 64 projects have been approved for which EUR 3.9 billion has been allocated. The total amount of investments is expected to exceed EUR 100 billion.  Most projects (75 per cent) relate to energy, research and development, transport and digital technology and most of them are approved for the 5 Member States that are also europe's 5 largest economies (France, Italy, Germany, UK and Spain) – as many as 43 of the 64 projects. The 12 member states have not yet withdrawn funding from this fund for strategic projects. On 1 June, the Commission announced a plan to extend the initiative after an initially conceived three-year period and strengthen support for SMEs, given the success of this part of the programme so far.  Given the obvious disproportionateity in the withdrawal of the EFSI Fund between member states, but also the fact that the vast majority of funds go to the more developed and largest EU economies, I ask the Commission to extend the EFSI fund award criteria – rather than allocating only according to project preparedness, to take into account both the economic development of member states and the impact of their economies through the financial crisis.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. My support for the Juncker Commission depended in particular on the promised Investment Plan. We were promised additional investments of EUR 315 billion. This is necessary to get Europe's real economy back on track. The EFSI must become the instrument it was planned to be: to cushion the impact of the crisis with investments in health, social infrastructure, energy and environmental projects, the digital sector and new innovations. However, the impression is created that the actors are scaleing back their own use of financial resources. In Germany, for example, a motorway in Baden-Württemberg, the richest state, is being expanded. It seems to me that projects are being implemented that would have been carried out anyway. It must be clear to everyone that this is not enough to deal with the crisis. Additional investment must be created, the EIB must not reduce its resources, and the players – the EIB, the EFSI and the European Commission – must enable effective and courageous investments. For me, moving away from Europe's austerity is a priority. Greater flexibility for crisis-hit Member States in their budgets within EU fiscal rules must be ensured. The Golden Rule for Public Investment must be implemented at European level. It is up to the actors to make full use of their room for manoeuvre and to actively apply the existing investment clause in order to turn the recovery, which is only paralysingly progressing, into a real recovery.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – I am among those who are very disappointed with the outcomes of EFSI’s first year. The Commission’s euphoria about the results cannot be reconciled with the reality. But I am unsurprised things have turned out this way. The financial fundamentals of EFSI, based on relatively insignificant ‘own’ funds, levered extensively through guarantees to surpass EUR 300 billion with private capital, militate against a choice of projects considered by markets as having low payoffs or being too risky. The institutional fundamentals of EFSI, tied into the European Investment Bank framework, constrain the Fund to follow the EIB operational model. The claim is that some low-risk, long-term infrastructure projects launched by EFSI would have featured as an EIB project otherwise. Similarly projects have been concentrated in infrastructure areas which can only be considered as ‘safe’. For them, non-EFSI finance could easily have been found. There is, too, a concentration of projects in the bigger economies of the Single Market, with southern and other peripheral small economies practically not featuring at all. Indeed, one could claim that EFSI is providing an example of how, under EU initiatives, a transfer of resources from the periphery to the centre is occurring, further emphasising structural divergences.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – As it stands so far, we can appreciate that the launch of the investment plan proposed by the European Commission was a good idea. Funds mobilised from capital markets to finance approved investment projects are significant and confirm the reality of the multiplier of public resources envisaged by the initiators of the investment plan. However, we have one regret: there are Member States, including Romania, which do not yet have any projects financed under this plan. I believe that an additional effort by the European Commission is needed to identify projects that can be financed in each Member State.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – The efforts of the EC and EIB to reduce the EU investment gap show potential, especially in increased investments for a greater number of SMEs. It has to remain clear that the EFSI financial support is additional; more private investment is yet to be attracted in order to generate more for the real economy. The success of boosting investments for an effective response to the economic and social crisis really depends on Investment Plan’s implementation achievements. Projects and agreements to benefit from EFSI have been approved in almost all member state. Some countries are still struggling and Romania is one of them. I believe that CEE is a region where investments are needed the most and the EC should do more to help these countries in attracting private investment. The role of the EIB is crucial here - more projects need to be supported to pass the AAA rating. Without that we cannot talk about economic growth, social cohesion or transition to a sustainable economy. I welcome the extension of the lifetime of the EFSI beyond 2018, but it needs to show more results and deliver better on the ground.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. – Mr President, the ESIF Investment Fund, which was set up a year ago, has got off to a surprising start. During the first year of operation, the Fund has mobilised investments of more than EUR 100 billion, so it is at the target rate. Increased investment in Europe is essential to promote growth, competitiveness and employment. European financial instruments are needed, but it is even more important to create an environment in Europe that encourages companies to invest. Regulation must be streamlined and, on the other hand, it must be ensured that companies have sufficient certainty about the future legislative framework well into the future. This applies in particular to energy and environmental policy, which has seen far too short-term bouncing around. It does not encourage investment. A more business-friendly attitude in Europe is also needed in its approach to new business models, such as: Mobile services enabled by the Internet have brought. The Commission's guidance on the sharing economy last week was therefore very welcome. New funding opportunities are still needed for companies whose products and services are still in the research and product development phase. Europe has a lot of expertise, and we should be better able to exploit that potential. Many European success stories are still waiting for their inventor. Future growth is in SMEs. They must now be encouraged to grow and international. The EU's internal market of 500 million inhabitants is accessible to every company. SMEs in particular would also benefit from the TTIP agreement with the United States. It would significantly increase export opportunities and economic growth.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Investment Plan aims to remove obstacles to investment in Europe, both at national and European level. Its task is to create a friendly environment for small and medium-sized enterprises. This project has created appropriate financial instruments that have to some extent increased the potential of the Single Market. Moreover, despite visible unemployment, high deficits, structural problems, I am convinced that the effects of previous inefficient policies have been mitigated. The positive impact of the Investment Plan on the functioning of some institutions that have decided to use it is already visible.  However, we must be aware that the cooperation of the Member States in promoting this project needs to be strengthened. We as representatives must take action to raise awareness of the benefits of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). I am of the opinion that the increase in funding for innovative projects, which will consequently increase competition on the European and global markets, as well as joint action, cooperation between Member States will increase the reach and effect of the Juncker Plan, which will consequently boost economic growth, slowed down by the global financial crisis.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. – I think that already a year after the adoption of this investment plan here in the European Parliament, we need not be afraid to say that it is successful. This is exactly what Europe needs to overcome the fear of reinvesting after the crisis and re-start its economy. The available statistics clearly show that the absorption from this fund, as currently legally set up, is not only beneficial for individual actors in the Member States, but above all shows great EU added value. I consider it essential for Europe, above all, to invest in science and research as well as in the digital single market, areas where we are still lagging behind the rest of the world. As a former entrepreneur, I am particularly pleased that small and medium-sized enterprises have also achieved efsi absorption, because they are the driving force behind our European economy.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I am relieved to receive today's Commission statement summarising the achievements of the Investment Plan so far eighteen months after President Juncker launched this plan and one year after the launch of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI).  However, I am still far from satisfied when it comes to harnessing the high potential of the cultural and creative sectors in job creation, long-term growth and competitiveness under the Investment Plan for Europe. Referring to my role as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education on the proposal for a REGULATION of the EP and of the Council on the EFSI, I would like to stress once again that this fund should also be targeted at projects in the cultural and creative sectors. These sectors act as catalysts and promoters of innovation, and their beneficial effects are not limited to themselves, but are also felt in many other sectors of the economy.  In this way, I would point out that their contribution to the achievement of EU policy objectives is undeniable and I hope that this will be used in the EC's ambitious plans to mobilise at least EUR 315 billion for additional investment in the real economy by mid-2018. I also see particular potential for the use of cultural and creative sectors in the framework of the recently launched European Investment Project Portal and the European Investment Advisory Hub.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Strategic Investment Plan is one of the central tools for changing the European Union's priorities, strengthening investment, fostering growth and jobs and supporting competitive differentiation priorities such as the Digital Union, the Energy Union, Industry 4.0 and the new smart grids. After one year of implementation, the results of the Plan are frankly negative, not only for the resources mobilized, but above all for the allocation made. The Fund was mainly implemented as a reinforcement of projects that could have continued to be financed by instruments already in the EU and was channelled not mainly to countries with higher investment needs, but to those where investment rates were already higher than the European average. It has failed, therefore, either as a lever for innovation and as a promoter of cohesion. The strategy for implementing the Strategic Investment Fund must be radically changed. It has to incorporate more innovation and more capacity to take risks. It has to finance projects with potential but which could not be financed by traditional instruments and finance projects located in territories with difficulties in raising funding for reasons external to the merits of the projects.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Marielle de Sarnez, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council providing further macro-financial assistance to Tunisia (COM(2016)0067 – C8—0032/2016 – 2016/0039(COD)) (A8—0187/2016).

name: Marielle de Sarnez
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, (inaudible) I would like to thank all my colleagues in the parliamentary groups who have invested a great deal in the decision we will take later, I hope, because they are aware that this is an important moment for Tunisia and that we must be by its side.  Everyone in the Chamber knows the important challenges facing Tunisia: the economic challenge, with soaring unemployment, extremely strong regional disparities between the Tunis region and southern Tunisia, and because there have also, of course, we all remember this, terrorist attacks that put an end to tourism. You should know that tourism in Tunisia is 500,000 jobs and that there is no tourism in Tunisia today. Security challenge, I just talked about it with the attacks. We all have in mind the attack on the Bardo Museum, we all have in mind the sousse attack, we also saw what happened on the border between Libya and Tunisia. Tunisia has nearly 500 kilometres of borders with Libya, a country terribly destabilized with all the trafficking, the jihadist attack - I was talking about a second ago - all drug trafficking, human trafficking. I also want to talk not only about the security challenge but about the migration challenge. Our Tunisian friends have received more than 1,800,000 refugees from Libya, representing almost 20% of their population.  These are the challenges and difficulties facing Tunisians, and despite these challenges, Tunisia is at the fore of democracy. Its democratic transition is absolutely remarkable. Let us remember that the Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to Tunisian civil society to encourage it to continue on this path, and for all these reasons, these difficulties and, at the same time, the fact that Tunisia is staying the course, even in difficult times, we Europeans must be by its side. That is why we are presenting this morning this 500 million macro-financial aid plan - the second - to help Tunisia, which needs this capital.  This plan is part of Europe's comprehensive strategic policy vis-à-vis Tunisia. Trade negotiations have been opened, and even beyond trade. That is, the idea of a political and economic partnership with the ALECA was opened up. We have taken emergency measures with the olive oil quotas - 35,000 tonnes of zero-tax money for Tunisia - and today we are discussing this macro-financial aid. It is an aid of 500 million, the second, over 15 years, conditional on a number of reforms, which I really hope will be relevant, will not only be accounting and will really serve the development of Tunisia. If this report is adopted earlier, which I think, the Council, in my opinion, will support it and I really ask the Commission to make these capital disbursements as soon as possible, before the summer, because Tunisia needs it. People sometimes think that this macro-financial assistance is a gift or a grant. It is only a loan, we lend money to Tunisia, which it will have to repay. I want to say a word about the Tunisian debt, which is obviously increasing. I want to open up a line of reflection - and I would be happy if the Commission listened to it: both France and Germany decided to convert part of the debt they had to Tunisia - 60 million for France, 60 million for Germany - in exchange for investments in the development of that country. I think this is very relevant and intelligent, and I really invite the Commission for the future, beyond the plan we are going to adopt this morning, to think and think about it in this way. I think it would be more useful and wiser for Tunisia. What France and Germany have done, the European institutions should, in my opinion, also propose to Tunisia. Colleagues, we all see that we must stand with Tunisia and Tunisians. We owe it to them, but we also owe it to our European Union, to our Europe. We need a stable, prosperous and peaceful Tunisia alongside Europe.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, let me first thank the rapporteur, Mrs de Sarnez, and the Committee on International Trade (INTA), for the valuable work on this report.  As we all know, Tunisia faces enormous political economic challenges, and that is the reason why the Commission made its proposal for a macro—financial assistance operation in that country. Tunisia is confronted with the consequences of the terrorist attacks of 2015. The result is that its vital tourism sector, in particular, has been seriously affected and foreign investments have sharply declined. These developments have led to falling growth rates and foreign currency reserves. This shows that the situation is very acute, and Tunisia needs international financial systems in order to stabilise and further political transition started during the Arab Spring of 2011.  International bilateral donors, led by the IMF, have clearly expressed their willingness to support Tunisia, now and in the near future. The Commission can and should contribute to these renewed financial support efforts and we propose to do so by providing a new macro-financial assistance (MFA) of EUR 500 million which builds on the previous MFA operation of EUR 300 million. It is foreseen that this new assistance, which is the largest MFA ever given to a country of the Southern neighbourhood, will be disbursed in three tranches over the next two years. This exceptional assistance effort must also be seen against the background of the courageous efforts and significant progress that Tunisia has been making in recent years to establish a fully—fledged democratic system, despite the difficult regional and security environment. Of course, the new MFA operation will be subject to the fulfilment of a number of economic policy conditions. Indeed, Tunisia must satisfactorily implement the new IMF programme and fulfil economic and financial policy conditions to be agreed between the EU and Tunisia in a memorandum of understanding. Potential policy measures could cover areas such as public finance management, fiscal reforms, strengthening the social safety net, labour market reforms and measures to support the recovery of the tourism sector, as well as in trade and investment. I would like to stress that timing is of the essence here. Tunisia requires the micro-financial assistance to cover its large external financing needs for 2016 and 2017, so a swift adoption of the current proposal by co-legislators, under the ordinary legislative procedure is very important. Therefore, I am pleased that the INTA Committee has approved the Commission proposal without amendment. I am also pleased that the Council in the letter from Coreper, has expressed its commitment to adopting a Commission proposal without amendments, subject to the same outcome at today’s plenary vote. Thank you for your attention and I look forward to having a fruitful debate.

name: Salvatore Cicu
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I, on behalf of the GROUP of the European People's Party, strongly support this type of measure. I believe that there is urgency, I think there is urgency for the reasons that have already been explained. I try to make the most of these reasons. Firstly, the European Union's neighbourhood policy, an important policy, an effective instrument, especially when it is intended for a project of democracy, for a project of freedom. The effects of this project are certainly necessary for Europe itself. This project is precisely about the maintenance of certain borders, about keeping in relation also to the centrality of a tragedy, a major problem such as migration, on which, in some ways, we continue to postpone decisions, and so we still need to focus on policies that are effective. On the other hand, there is the great problem of structural reforms that Tunisia needs. Reforms which, let us remember, would need not EUR 500 million but EUR 5 billion. Of course, 500 million is a fundamental input of certainty that realizes the condition of a progression in the right direction. Therefore, the PPE strongly supports it, the PPE has not tabled any amendments that are obstructing or instrumental. However, it is clear that the rules and regulations cannot be exceeded, and so we say that we are going to overcome this in the name of urgency and in the name of a European interest, but certainly also of a country such as Tunisia.

name: Emmanuel Maurel
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Madam President, since the Tunisians have embarked on a democratic transition, of which everyone here has reminded us how exemplary it is, the European Parliament has always wanted to show solidarity with Tunisia and, of course, with Tunisians. We did so when we launched a free trade agreement process, which was collectively stressed, which had to be obviously asymmetrical and progressive, so-called partnership with Tunisia; we have also been, even if this has caused much debate between us, when we had to extend the quota of zero-rights olive oil for the Tunisian economy; we are now when we address this issue of macro-financial assistance.  So, of course, we do it, the group, and for the text as it stands. What for? Because there is an emergency and it has to go fast. That is the only reason why we are for the text as it stands. But, at the same time, there are a number of things that need to be remembered in this debate. First, when we say that Tunisia must be able to make structural reforms. I call on the Commission to be very flexible, to be more intelligent if possible about this, because it is not a question of completely stifling the Tunisian economy. That's the first point. Second point: we talk about AMF, but who says AMF, says ready, says loan, says debt, but Tunisian debt, today it is a problem. This is a problem that is essentially inherited from the Ben Ali period and the money that is lent to Tunisians should not be used for only one thing, namely to repay the interest on the debt it had incurred under the former regime. That is a second problem. Third problem, very important for us: precisely, the assets of Ben Ali, there are still many that are hidden in Europe and there are obviously things to do from the point of view of Europe - because there are also in the European countries - to solve this problem. While we are obviously in favour of this emergency aid, this should not prevent us from thinking about the longer term. We must be in solidarity in a sustainable way and not rely mainly on emergency aid. That is why the group is in favour of this text.

name: Sander Loones
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Welcome to the group in the stands. More than ever, the European Union must focus on its own backyard, on our neighbours, on our region. We must take responsibility there and I see that Tunisia is fully building this new democracy. I see the seeds of progress.  At the same time, no one will deny that this is a trial and error process. There are the major socio-economic challenges, the sky-high unemployment among young people, for example, but also the difficult recovery from the terrorist attacks. Tunisia - as the rapporteur has also said - has a very important role to play for the European Union as a strategic, reliable partner in the region. So we must support the country in this difficult transition process towards a fully stable democracy. A good trade policy is crucial in this respect.  The fact that we are now providing a new tranche of this macro-financial support is an important step towards greater stability. I can count on my support, but we are not giving blank cheques. We call for this to be done: deep reforms for growth and jobs and financial stability.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, yes, we must obviously help the Tunisian people, we must support the spirit of responsibility of Tunisian society, trade union organisations, political forces so that the democratic transition continues and improves the lives of Tunisians. But this aid cannot be done on the old conditions of the International Monetary Fund, which increase debt and reduce popular sovereignty.  We should be with Tunisia - and more broadly with the peoples of the South - bolder, more inventive, by creating a common public bank or, at least, a common fund so that existing debts are frozen and turned into a sustainable development project, creating jobs, promoting human and ecological development. At the same time, it is time to repatriate the assets confiscated by the Ben Ali family and return them to the Tunisian people.

name: Yannick Jadot
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we know the extremely complicated situation that Tunisia and the Tunisian people are going through today. We know the collapse of tourism-related resources, particularly as a result of the attacks, we know Tunisia's export difficulties - and we have done well to facilitate the conditions for the export of olive oil to Europe - we know all the fragility, the vulnerability of the democratic process begun five years ago.
