We know that Tunisia today, in a territory that is no bigger than England, hosts as many refugees as the whole of the European Union, and we know the extraordinary importance of this democratic light in our neighbourhood. So, of course, at the request of the Tunisian government, we must promote macro-financial aid to Tunisia and, at the same time, we must - and the European Parliament voted to do so in 2012 - reverse Tunisia's odious debt, particularly under the Ben Ali years.  It is absolutely necessary to lighten the burden of debt. When we talk about structural reforms, ladies and gentlemen, be careful, look at the state of Tunisia today, consider that because this macro-financial aid is conditional on a Monetary Fund programme, we cannot support reforms that address the basic needs of Tunisians. Today we have to be extremely flexible on this aid, we have to make a lot more donations to Tunisia. I find that today, basically, when we see the billions that are given to the Turkish government, which is not at all a democratic light, not giving much more to Tunisia to enable it to strengthen its democratic process on the basis of a development concerned with its resources and capacities would be a serious fault. Let's support Tunisia.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are all aware of the very serious situation in Tunisia today. It has been mentioned earlier: galloping unemployment, especially youth unemployment, terrorism that has brought to its knees a sector such as the fundamental tourism sector, 1 800 000 Libyans who are now welcomed by the solidarity of the Tunisian people, and trafficking in the south, which still represents a large part of the black economy. This first aid, unfortunately this eur 500 million loan, is not enough. We support it, but we believe that human rights and solidarity should be exported to Tunisia, not austerity. That is why we must also give real aid. Soft loans are not enough, that is not enough if we do not also convert a large part of the debt that there is, including towards Europe, into investment. Democracy cannot exist where there is someone rich enough to buy it and someone so poor to sell themselves. We must say this to the Tunisian people and if we do not support them we will really risk the whole Maghreb deflagration.

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, political fragility, Islamist threat, terrorist acts, neighbouring Libya torn apart by a terrible civil war, an unprecedented economic crisis with the collapse of tourism, in short, the situation in Tunisia remains worrying to say the least. That it is far from the time when the Tunisian model of democratic transition was unreservedly welcomed. But the purpose of my intervention is not to throw oil on the fire or to stir the knife in the wound.  On the other hand, unlike you, I do not welcome the dismantling of Tunisian tariffs on industrial products. Unlike you, I do not welcome this deep free trade area that you want to set up and which I do not believe is beneficial to Europeans or Tunisians. Unlike you, I am not preaching that, I quote, "the Union's macro-financial assistance should strengthen Tunisia's adherence to the values it shares with the Union". For my part, I denounce your perpetual desire to interfere, which creates more problems than it solves.  Please, let us not further weaken the precarious balance that Tunisia has achieved and are finally working on healthy cooperation rather than guardianship.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Madam President, the European Union is in a prolonged period of crisis with millions of its citizens below the poverty line, countries in recession for years and unemployment galloping. Have you ever wondered how all these unemployed people and citizens of the countries of the South, such as Greece, will react when they learn that the Union is spending billions on aid to third countries at a time when it is being subjected to onerous memoranda, unbearable taxation and the mortgages of national wealth and property? Are you aware that with a fraction of the money you give Tunisia, homeless people who have arrived to sleep even outside the European Parliament building in Brussels would have at least one roof over their heads? Moreover, it is recent the duty-free import of olive oil from Tunisia which has not allowed European farmers to increase their profits once. In Greece, which was one of the few countries that this year had high quality olive oil production and its producers had the opportunity to see their income increased, with your undermining move you dropped the price so much that they will not be able to amove their production costs either.  History teaches us that whenever Western countries intervened in the rest of the world, the result was nothing more than manipulation and exploitation. You're doing it this time, too, wearing a so-called philanthropic mask. It would therefore be better to try to solve some of Europe's many problems and to let third countries develop as they can. They'll do better than you in Europe.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I firmly believe that it is important to support the granting of this additional aid of five hundred million euros to Tunisia. Tunisia is a privileged and strategic partner of the Union, meets the democratic requirements to be a beneficiary of this aid and is carrying out a series of economic reforms that are endorsed by the International Monetary Fund. It is imperative that the European Union continues to show its support for what is probably the only country that, after the so-called 'Arab Spring', can be consolidated as a democratic country despite attempts by radical Islamists to want to destabilize it. In a very difficult context, with the consequences of the terrorist attacks suffered, the reception of more than one million Libyan displaced persons, not counting the nearly three thousand more who cross the border every day, in that context, I repeat, is vitally important to show our full commitment to this friendly country that needs more than ever to consolidate its democracy.

name: David Martin (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in 1995 Tunisia was the first Mediterranean country to sign an Association Agreement with the European Union and it now needs our help more than ever. Mr Maurel has set out very clearly the Socialist Group position on Tunisia.  We see three stages in this. Firstly we think it is vital that the EU does more to assist Tunisia in getting the Ben Ali money back to Tunisia. Some of that money is currently stuffed in EU banks, and that is an unacceptable situation. Secondly, we do want a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement with Tunisia, but it has to be asymmetrical: we have to open up our markets more than we demand them opening up their markets because of the precarious economic situation in that country. And thirdly, of course we do welcome this macro-financial assistance to Tunisia, but we want to emphasise that this is not a blank cheque and that we expect continued progress on multi-party democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we believe that it is right to help Tunisia out of the serious economic crisis it is suffering, following also the attacks on a key sector such as tourism. It is precisely for this reason that we are voting against the Commission's proposal, just as we have already voted against the measures concerning Tunisian oil quotas. The urgent need for support for the Tunisian people cannot be translated into an instrument such as the macro-financial assistance that accompanies the Programmes of the International Monetary Fund and the related agenda of structural reforms that are imposed on Tunisia. Over the past twenty-three years, Tunisia's economic and social policy has been dictated by the Washington consensus and the recipes of the International Monetary Fund, recipes that have only increased inequalities. We therefore believe that we must no longer proceed in this direction, that we must renegotiate the debt, that Ben Ali's assets should be returned to the country and that development and employment projects should be supported. This should be used for aid, not for a loan to finance other loans.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the terrorist attacks that have stricken Tunisia and the economic difficulties that the country is facing are a reminder that Tunisia needs, more than ever, the solidarity of the European Union. The country continues its relentless transition to a stable and sustainable democracy. The Nobel Prize awarded last October to the Quartet of National Dialogue is proof of this.  This new macro-financial aid is a loan, as has been said, and will, I hope, contribute to an economic recovery for the benefit of all Tunisians and will, in particular, enable them to meet the challenge of youth unemployment, which affects one in three graduates.  The Union must continue to support Tunisia's rapid return to economic growth and political stability that benefits the region as a whole.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the changes that have taken place since 2011 in our southern neighbourhood, Tunisia seems to be the only example of success in terms of democratic consolidation. This has led to the country acquiring privileged partner status and becoming a key stabilising player in the region put to the test by the Libyan question.  Tunisia has been hit several times by terrorist attacks, which have brought tunisia's economy to its knees, and unemployment remains very high. Economic and financial resources must be made available to implement reforms and support for civil society. Of course, Tunisia will have to play its part. The EUR 500 million made available is therefore a good thing. However, Commissioner Katainen, this Parliament is telling you that more needs to be done on the facsimile of what we are doing for Ukraine, in the knowledge that the political stupidity of the nationalists would certainly not understand that Tunisia can also play an important role for the European Union.

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The rapporteur has set out the challenges facing Tunisia. I am glad that we in this House have a very broad consensus on support for the country. We are also doing this in our interests. The country has the conditions and the will for comprehensive cooperation. We want to further strengthen young democracy at all levels, including, for example, in the holding of local elections. Above all, it is important that the support now provided improves the framework for foreign investment. It is crucial for the success of democracy that jobs are created. There are well-trained workers. Our economy should seize the opportunity to take advantage of the country's central position in the Mediterranean. The government has also taken concrete steps to improve the security situation, so that I would like to thank our citizens to return as tourists and thus make a significant contribution to the creation of jobs.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the terrorist attacks and the persistent risk of new ones are significantly affecting the key economy, as all my colleagues have already said. The country lost more than one third of its income from tourism last year, but the most important thing is that, in spite of Tunisia being greatly affected by the instability in its surroundings, we are all in agreement today that this is the only successful democratic transition in the region and it is in our best interests to help Tunisia and the Tunisian people. Europe has already provided substantial financial and technical assistance to this country. This should be reinforced by the conclusion soon of the deep and comprehensive free trade agreement and I strongly support the idea of stronger asymmetrical trade relations with Tunisia. This would be of benefit to the whole country.  Finally, I will just stress once more that there is an urgent need for Europe to disburse as soon as possible the money to the Tunisian people. I add my voice to those asking the EU banks to identify the penalised assets in order for the assets to be given back to the Tunisian people.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, tunisia has managed in a few years' time to significantly strengthen its process of consolidating democracy and is now a real hope in the Arab Mediterranean context. From an economic point of view, however, it has an economy on its knees. The country has repeatedly been the target of terrorist attacks and attacks, which have mainly affected the tourism sector, which is the real hub of tunisia's economy. Europe must be able to adequately accompany this delicate phase of the country. The proposal to grant additional macro-financial assistance to Tunisia to support the country's economic stabilisation and substantial reform programme is to be welcomed. In this way, Europe will be able to show solidarity and determination by means of concrete acts, encouraging the country from which the Arab spring began and which is certainly a model for promoting peace and democracy in the Middle East, North America and the rest of the world.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, we need Tunisia as a partner, we need Tunisia as a democratic state in the southern Mediterranean, as an example of success in transition. Tunisia is once again at a crossroads today and that is why our effort to help Tunisia with 500 million euros is a good way, a path we have to take because there is no other way, no alternative to this path, or chaos again or accident again in that country. That is why I am sure that what we want to decide today is a good example of how to help those countries that really want to adopt democracy and want to become part of the free world.  I support this report in its entirety and, of course, I will vote for it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we are in favour of the principle of international cooperation and for the help of countries experiencing economic difficulties for the most diverse reasons. However, this cooperation must be genuine and based on respect for the sovereignty of states and their right to be able to dispose of their resources and choose their development model.  Helping Tunisia to improve its public finances, reform its financial system, improve its trade and investment regulatory framework, or correct its budgetary position, clearly leaves out this genuine cooperation that we advocate.  It is more similar to the imposition of reforms aimed at imposing a model based on the complete liberalisation of the economy. These are reforms that the European Union imposes on its Member States, the results of which are in sight.  We therefore repudiate this aid because it is not exempt from conditionality. It imposes on the Tunisian people a model which, as here in Europe, will generate more inequalities and more poverty in the medium term.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, just very briefly, I want to underline the importance of the urgency of this decision, and in this context I hope that we can get support from Parliament because we do not have any time to waste. Thank you very much for your opinion. I think we have the same view on this issue and we have to look carefully at how to support Tunisia because it is a matter of economic growth, it is a matter of social justice and it is also a matter of stability in our region.

name: Marielle de Sarnez
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, I am very, very struck by the convergence of the analysis and the state of mind of all the colleagues who have spoken. We all agree that there must be real solidarity with Tunisia, we all agree to tell the Commission that there is an urgent need, that there will be an urgent need to give the funds, because Tunisia is waiting for them. We all agree that yes, we need reforms, but be careful, we must find a path that corresponds to the point where Tunisia is today. And lo and behold, I would like to say that this morning - and I am happy - this is yet another signal sent to our Tunisian friends. We say to them this morning: "In the difficult path that is yours, you are not alone: Europe is at your side."

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments) Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing – Despite various disinformation, it must be acknowledged that Tunisia has made a smooth and democratic transition to democracy. The country is ruled by a broad government coalition that has broad public support, has its own constitution and is trying to protect civil liberties. At the same time, however, Tunisia is in major trouble. The security and political situation in the region and terrorist attacks have a significant negative impact on several economic sectors. It is our duty to help Tunisia succeed in combating attempts to destabilise the country. In this context, it is therefore important that we provide Tunisia with macro-financial assistance, which will mainly constitute assistance for the reforms that Tunisia is undertaking in order to improve its budgetary situation, balance of payments and thus create a more favourable environment for investment.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: President Plevneliev! Welcome to the European Parliament! It is a great honour for us to be with us today. You have maintained a close relationship with the European institutions for many years, as President of your country, an important Member State of the European Union, which has also been particularly challenged in the last two years with regard to the migration issues that affect us. We would therefore like to thank you for the visit you are visiting us today, President Plevneliev. It is an honour for us to speak to us in the European Parliament. Please very much, Mr President.

name: Rosen Plevneliev
text: President of the Republic of Bulgaria. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, Excellencies, ladies and gentlemen, dear friends, it is a privilege to address you today as President of Bulgaria. It is an honour to speak here at the heart of European democracy. I am a proud pro-European President of a pro-European nation.  (Applause) We Bulgarians are proud to be an anchor of stability, an engine for positive development in South-East Europe. It is our common duty to defend the European values of peace, freedom, democracy, human rights, the rule of law and solidarity. It is our common cause to continue making and shaping history with our project for Europe that is united and at peace.  But peace and freedom are tested, are confronted today. We witness the worst security situation since the end of the Second World War. We see fundamental differences between world and regional powers. National borders and international principles are questioned. We witness a much more complicated international system where world and regional institutions and powers are unable to prevent and solve the record number of conflicts.  In many regions war and terror prevail. States and institutions disintegrate. Today in Europe we understand that what happens in the Middle East or Africa affects our lives directly. Today borders are making a comeback. The same generation that brought down the Berlin Wall is building new walls in the very heart of Europe today.  Yes, the world is out of balance today and it will take time to find a new one. We see unstable regions, unsafe borders and worried citizens. Terrorism is on the rise. At any moment, in any place in the world, there could be a terrorist attack. No one is immune and no one is safe. Today, power in the world is shifting and changing.  At the Munich Security Conference, the Russian Prime Minister spoke about the time of the First Cold War, and the New Cold War time we are facing today. I hope we are not heading into a new Cold War. We are not in a time of a new Cold War, but we are rather in a time of Cold Peace. Two years ago, at the Munich Security Conference, I pointed out that Europe has entered a new period. The Ukrainian crisis was the game changer. We have entered a new phase of development, which I call Cold Peace Time. Peace, because nobody wants to have a war, but Cold Peace because we see confrontation and methods from the Cold War time – propaganda wars, cyber-attacks, proxy and hybrid warfare. And some countries got ‘cold’, destabilised and weakened through frozen conflicts. The Russian President often talks about a new balance in the world with spheres of interest of Great Powers that need to be respected. Are we heading towards a new Yalta Conference? If the West allows this, it will be a historic shame.  (Applause) We need to show character, we need to stand up and defend our vision – our vision for our united Europe. We are living in difficult times, because world and regional leaders demonstrate a different approach and different goals in politics. The cause of wise politics is to modernise, to educate, to give way to diplomacy and not to fight. But if you do not have a cause, you need a war, you need a convenient enemy. It is easy to destabilise. States can be broken easily by powerful neighbours. But broken societies can only be repaired by people, not by Great Powers. You can quickly destroy order but it takes a lot of time to rebuild it. Unfortunately this is exactly what I see today in some parts of Europe. The goal of wise politics should not be to create frozen conflicts and occupy your neighbour’s territory. In the 21st century it is not wise to move borders, but to think beyond borders. The goal of wise politics is to make your nation educated and prosperous, to empower citizens, to create societies that are free and tolerant.  We do not want to go back to the time when the Great Powers allocated their spheres of influence. We cannot once again allow ‘political interests’ to divide and occupy the territory of sovereign states. What happened in Ukraine is a bitter reminder that the achievements of progressive mankind cannot be taken for granted. We never wanted to have a war again in Europe, but unfortunately today, there is a war in Europe, and that is in Ukraine.  For me, for us, Crimea is Ukraine and Ukraine is Europe.  (Applause) I consider lifting visas for Ukrainian citizens as a significant and urgent step to support Ukraine and let its people feel welcome and supported by the Europeans.  The lack of proper knowledge about the past, the lessons not learned from history, continue to cast a shadow on our future. We should not give a chance to populists to exploit ignorance and forgetfulness and change the past to their liking. I welcome the creation of a European House of History. Remembrance of the tragic past should be encouraged and passed onto younger generations. And what we need to pass to the younger people is the most important lesson: that peace is not given and it is up to every one of us to protect it. And that peace is not just the absence of war. Peace is human rights, peace is the rule of law. Every young European should be able to see where and how battles such as Verdun or Doyran happened and understand why we should never go to war again. The Bulgarian revolutionary Gotse Delchev dreamed of a future world where nations would never again go to the battlefield, and only compete in the field of culture, science and knowledge. In the 21st century Europe’s disagreements should be solved in parliaments, not on battlefields! The European integration project is making exactly that dream a reality. Of course Europe cannot be an island of stability in the ocean of world instability today. The EU is facing a record number of crises. Additional crises are on our radar screens, for example the possible Brexit, the rise of nationalists and populists, migration and others. We must not allow Europe to fall into a moral crisis – a crisis of lack of solidarity, a crisis of values. Whether it is migration or the sanctions on Russia, we need to stand and stick together. We are a family. A family in a crisis stands together! And every member of the family has to contribute, has to solve and not deepen the problems. Bulgaria is proud to be always part of the European solution and acts in a more solid and responsible way.  The EU has unique significance and strong political legitimacy, because of the peaceful discussions and settlement of differences, because of the shared fundamental rights and rules, and because of the unprecedented level of cooperation achieved between 28 Member States. The EU is a unique project for peace, where every nation is important. No state is peripheral or subordinate. The problems of migration, terrorism, climate change, economic crises and others go beyond our borders. These problems are transnational and require joint efforts. Cooperation is no longer a matter of choice, but of necessity. We see chaos around our borders, failed states, and frozen conflicts. Brutal criminal interests and human traffickers make business by playing with people’s lives. Because of that, operations of NATO and Frontex on the outside borders are just and timely. Helping people whose lives are in danger is a universal value. But it is also essential to make the difference between those who run for their lives and migrants that are just looking for a better economic perspective.  Today the refugee crisis is crucial for Europe. It has the capacity to change it politically, economically and socially. It inflames old plagues like populism, nationalism and division. It embodies the crucial need for a better, common and long-term decision-making. In the face of an unprecedented migration flow, every Member State has to demonstrate solidarity and responsibility. Bulgaria has proved to be a loyal partner in good and in hard times. We are situated on the easiest and most direct way from the crisis zones to Western Europe. Bulgaria is protecting the external borders of the EU in a professional and efficient manner. We follow the rules of Dublin and Schengen. We show solidarity with all refugees and give humanitarian status to those that meet the criteria. Bulgaria fulfils all its responsibilities and duties as a Member State and it needs to be taken on an equal footing with Schengen members by joining the Schengen area as soon as possible for the sake of the EU common security policy.  (Applause) Bulgaria supports the establishment of the solidarity scheme, which will allow the fair relocation and resettlement of refugees among all Member States.  As Chair-in-Office of the South-East European Cooperation Process, Bulgaria initiated a Joint Statement on Migration and has put security and migration as a priority in the region.  The Balkans today are frontline and first on the line to protect Europe. I wish to see the Balkans become a frontline of stability and prosperity, a frontline of tolerance and peaceful coexistence of different religions and ethnic minorities. As the Bulgarian President I say: ‘We want borders to fall and not to be moved’. We have a balanced and a principled foreign policy, we want to be friends with everyone, because everyone can and must contribute to peace and stability. The close cooperation on migration and countering radicalisation, violent extremism and terrorism is just another example that the EU and the Balkans belong together. The EU integration process is also a historical chance for the Western Balkan countries to leave behind the heavy burden of conflicts. Nationalistic doctrines that led to atrocities belong to the past. Therefore, strengthening good neighbourly relationships and just being a good neighbour and a friend is a fundamental for the enlargement policy and a clear indicator whether the aspiring countries have sincerely embraced core EU values.  Bulgaria plays an important role in strengthening the EU’s expertise in the region. We strongly support the regional cooperation and work for reconciliation, connectivity and integration. The Summit of the South-East European Cooperation Process held in Sofia last week marked the very successful Bulgarian Presidency and the 20th anniversary of this format, which has proved to be the authentic voice of the region.  Dear friends, we need to team up and develop common strategies, rather than building fortresses to defend short-sighted national interests. We have to engage leaders from political, economic and civil society sectors, and not just to talk and discuss, but to implement, to contribute, to solve the problems. As new economic, demographic and political powers emerge, this underlines the necessity to intensify the links with partners that share our values. Transatlantic relations are strategically important in the face of growing challenges to our liberal-democratic model.  A bright future for Europe requires devising a new economic model, one that can respond to the upcoming challenges and make use of the wide range of opportunities. The new economic model of Europe has to be dynamic and open. We need to embrace new approaches and mechanisms. We should not fear phenomena like the collaborative and sharing economy, the e-commerce. Instead, we must welcome and use all innovations in the most pragmatic and productive way.  (Applause) Europe must become a leader of the new industrial revolution, of disruptive innovation, of digital technologies. Europe of the future has to be a Europe of entrepreneurs, a Europe of technology, of innovation and yes, we all want to have a Europe that is dynamic, that is flexible, that is adaptable, one that unites and leads.  What do we need to do? We need prevention, to be proactive, detect early and solve the crises. We need to calibrate and have a focus, choose one crises, get it solved and be proud. You did it in a European way, in our own way. We need to take bold political decisions. Our Union badly needs exactly that today, when it is hard and difficult. We need to empower diplomacy – negotiate, negotiate and do not fight, because the use of weapons is a proof that you have no arguments. We need to give way to principles, not interests. To reconfirm, and not to renegotiate the principles of rule of law, human rights and freedoms, territorial integrity, sovereignty and inviolability of the borders of each and every state in Europe and the world.  Yes, we face years of growing risks and uncertainty, as we are moving into a more unstable world order. And yes, it will take time until a new balance is reached in a new multipolar world. In this transitional period we have to build and rebuild a more resilient regional and world order through our joint efforts. We should promote institutional reforms, diplomacy and principles. We should support leaders that understand that differences should be resolved peacefully and not through proxy or propaganda wars. And we need to be firm, because if we are not, we will encourage irresponsible leaders to destabilise further.  Dear friends, the European Union is a daily plebiscite on our desire to live together. History shows that without constant efforts everything we have gained can be lost. The debates on migration, Brexit, populists or Euro-sceptics, only reaffirm that conclusion. Today, more than ever, we need to bring back confidence in the vitality, in the lack of alternative of our European project. We need to dispel the doubts of Europeans and reassure them we know where we are heading. Today’s Europe raises more questions than answers. Our citizens demand security in an increasingly more insecure world and ask themselves how we can live in harmony with our neighbours. The balance between rights and responsibilities in European society is an irrevocable part of the answer. We need to show to the outside world, but also to our citizens, that we believe in, and are ready to enhance, our potential. Issues like terrorism, migration, frozen conflicts cannot be handled without treating the root causes – geopolitical frustrations and heavy conflicts. This makes it necessary to strengthen our crisis management structures and enhance the role of strategic planning in European foreign and security policy.  But we need to be realists. Many of our problems have European roots – social exclusion, marginalisation, bad education, ineffective dialogue between religions. This mix of problems creates conditions for radicalisation. Terrorism starts where education fails.  (Applause) Many of the terrorists and foreign terrorist fighters are Europeans. We do not forget our moral obligation to be a land of freedom, human rights for the oppressed and for the endangered. But we also represent rules and values that outline rights, but also responsibilities. Integration and education is a commitment for both host societies and migrants.  Today, it is obvious, more than ever, that without a clear policy and solutions conducted through dialogue, citizens’ fears will be exploited by populists. Without a realistic approach, it would be difficult to parry the speculations that someone wants to build Europe behind the back of the Europeans. Populists and nationalists are forcing us to make a choice – between the values we inherited from the founding fathers and the imperatives of security for our citizens. We choose both! We choose values and security. We see no contradiction between keeping our borders safe and sticking to human rights and freedoms. And we see the difference between nationalists and patriots. A great European president, President de Gaulle, once said: ‘patriots are those who love their country, nationalists are those who hate the different’. Today, more than ever, we need modern patriotism, not aggressive nationalism in Europe. (Applause) Uniformity of principles and all-inclusiveness in the process of integration into the EU is key for the future of our European project. It is clear that national societies are different and have different historically motivated reactions to events. In the diversity of our history and culture lies the richness of Europe. This, however, should not be a cause for changing the nature of the European Project by initiating a ‘two-speed’ or ‘multi-speed Europe’. The equality of European engagement has a direct relevance for our own European identity. Even the suspicion that we can accept Europe to be built on ‘different speeds’ sends a message of doubt for the European Project. It insinuates inequality. It would be a mistake to underestimate the potential for development of some parts of Europe, for example the Balkans. It would be a historic mistake not to support them or leave them to the outside influences from former empires. European nations should not be played against one another, regardless of interest. There can be only one answer: solidarity with those countries that have a longer road ahead of them. Especially in a period of challenges this solidarity should go beyond the instruments of cohesion policy and be a part of every European policy. No matter what the outcome of the UK referendum is, the discussion about Europe’s many speeds will continue. We need to avoid the destructive nature of the discussion about ‘Europe à la carte’. We cannot pick and choose solidarity and turn the EU into a sum of transactional relationships.  (Applause) Because each country has different issues to deal with, ‘zero sum’ games have had terrible – I repeat, terrible – outcomes in the past. We all need just to listen better to our partners. Bulgaria is an example of a middle-sized Member State that turned from a peripheral into a front-line country: Ukraine, Russia, migration. Our borders are Europe’s borders, our neighbours are Europe’s neighbours. We have difficult choices to make, but we never think of sacrificing European solidarity. Because we, Bulgarians, have learned that you cannot change geography, and true European integration can turn the risks of geography into opportunity.  Certainly, European democracies are not perfect. Often, and not without reasons, they are criticised. We are not perfect, but we are better than many others. We cannot convince the Eurosceptics, but we should mobilise the pro—Europeans. I want to make it clear: all predictions for the failure and even disintegration of the European Union are wrong, are false! We have seen many crises in our history. The cure is clear: more solidarity, humanity and empathy. More rule of law. More synergies. More education. More integration. The first democratically elected Bulgarian President, Zhelyu Zhelev, used to say: ‘You can cure democracy only with more democracy’. I am confident that we will tackle the challenges without diminishing our core values. We have done it more than once before. It would be a mistake if some read our tolerance as weakness. On the contrary, it is a clear sign of strength and determination to defend our way of life. The history of the European Union has taught us that in times of hardship only integration works. The only weapon we have to achieve peace, security and human development is integration. Not a single country can cope with the challenges alone. Erecting borders – no matter whether they are territorial, economic or legal – is a tempting, yet temporary and not sustainable solution.  The challenges ahead of us are very serious and we cannot afford to wait, delay or shift the problems to the next government or generation. We need to act, we need to take decisions. Being indifferent is not an option today. We need to address the problems and have a plan how to solve them.  There are many crises. One of them is that today Russia does not support the principles of international order. The Kremlin is opposing us and is trying to destabilise the EU, by bringing mistrust to the very core of our project. It is trying to destroy and bring down the foundations of the European Union, which are unity, solidarity and the rule of law. (Applause) Moscow has initiated a vast propaganda operation in Europe that spreads messages of mistrust, not values. The goal is to undermine the trust of people in the EU. And that is the biggest danger: to erode the trust of Europeans in integration and our common destiny. To open the door for the ghosts from the past – nationalism, populism, Great Powers and spheres of influence, interests that prevail and oppose principles and values.  And it seems like they are succeeding. It looks like we are not making any progress now. We are stuck, we have stopped the only engine we have – integration. We are pulling the brake on enlargement, on Schengen and others. What we need to do is to open the door. Bring fresh air and a new horizon! Turn on our engine of integration! Start new projects of integration! What we need to do is to reaffirm and strengthen the foundations of our order and values, but also adapt and open up to the fast changing world. We need to integrate, not isolate. We need to look ahead, not behind. Europe has a meaningful global role to play and it needs to mobilise, to start new projects of integration.  And we need to make the difference between technique and content. The future of Europe does not depend so much on technique – eurofunds and directives, crisis management and others. The future of Europe depends on the content, on the very core of who we are. And this is the rule of law. The future of Europe depends on not forgetting the big ideas and getting just stuck in technique. Not to lose the big picture. The big question is what our vision for Europe is? How do we add value to the work of the previous generation and to the vision of the founding fathers? I wonder what was in the minds of the founding fathers of the European Union 70 years ago, right after the devastation of the Second World War, when everybody hated everyone in Europe? They knew that peace is only possible when nations get such a level of cooperation that makes future war impossible. And they started to integrate – steel markets, coal markets and others. Their idea was not to weaken the national states, but to make them stronger in a union. Bulgaria was always weak, when it was alone. Bulgaria is strong today as a proud member of the EU and NATO. The very big question is where do we want to be by 2030 or 2050? Of course we will be solving the migration, the banking, the debt and other crises. But is that all? Do we want just to deal with crisis management by jumping from one crisis to another? This is just technique, not a dream or vision. I want us to all continue dreaming and make history as our founding fathers did. I want us to all start new engines of integration – the enlargement process, a more efficient and coordinated common European foreign, defence and security policy, the European Energy Union, the Single Digital Market, the EU Capital Markets Union and others. And let us continue, write and make history and the history of a strong European Union with strong and prosperous Member States. If we forget or do not have a cause any more, someone else will focus on us as a convenient opponent. If we stop making history, somebody else will. As some want to question and destabilise our foundations, let us give a new extra dose of trust in the European Union! Let us give it now and let us give it together! (Sustained applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mr President, for your very encouraging speech. Thank you very much, ladies and gentlemen, for your lively applause. I think you can say, Mr President, that you have made a very courageous speech. You could see from the reactions in the House that, I would say, the vast majority of Members share your views. But there are certainly colleagues in this House who take a very different view. I allow myself to say that I belong to the first group. Thank you for this courageous speech. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Before we proceed to the vote, I have a statement to make. You will recall that on 11 May 2016, the President imposed a sanction on Mr Synadinos for making unacceptable remarks about the Turkish people during the meeting of 9 March. On Monday 6 June, in the Bureau, we discussed Mr Synadinos' objection, dealt with this objection and unanimously confirmed the President's decision. The penalty consists in the cancellation of the entitlement to daily allowance for a period of ten days. The decision was taken yesterday by Mr Synadinos. The procedure is now closed.

name: Godelieve Quisthoudt-Rowohl
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The reform and extension of the Information Technology Agreement (ITA) is important for two reasons. Firstly, the ITA was the first WTO agreement to massively reduce tariffs, and the innovations in the agreement are very good news for the WTO's multilateral trading system. We know that in some areas there was more of a slumber than a lot of activity. Secondly, the innovations will significantly reduce costs for consumers and businesses and significantly facilitate market access for the European IT industry. The IT industry has developed rapidly over the last 20 years, and that is why it was urgently necessary to modernise an agreement based on 1996. It includes an additional list of IT products whose tariffs are being eliminated – navigation systems, medical devices, satellites, touch screens, and so on. It also includes transition periods of zero to seven years, so that European industry can adapt slowly where necessary. Finally, I would like to say here: the EU exports EUR 189 billion worth of IT products. This sum is covered by the ITA expansion. We can assume that there will be a boost for us in more exports and then more jobs. Thank you for your agreement!

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I would like to make a final appeal to the signatories of the next resolution to reconsider their vote. At a time when the Venezuelan opposition is involved in a process of dialogue with the Government promoted by UNASUR and in which the Permanent Council of the Organization of American States, with the support of the right of several countries, approved a statement in which it supports ... the parties ...  (the President withdraws his word to the speaker)

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of this committee, because I consider it essential to continue the work of the TAXE investigative committees in the light of panama's new leaks, which, as was already the case in the case of Luxleaks, concern the Commission doubly: because of their complicity with tax avoidance and evasion and for the direct political responsibility of the current Commissioners for their past responsibilities in the Government. In addition, Panama acquires great relevance in the key of the Spanish State, as it is a favorite destination for the evasion of large local fortunes, including Commissioner Cañete's wife, who thus adds another knot to the network created by his conflicts of interest, his participation in tax amnesty and his possible participation in a web of corruption , the Acuamed case.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which, in order to combat tax evasion practices, proposes to find a common solution so that companies pay their taxes where they actually make a profit.  To the extent that bilateral agreements are insufficient to curb tax evasion in Europe, I believe that it is essential to find a common solution while preserving our national sovereignty.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcomed the vote in Parliament to establish a Committee of Inquiry into the Panama Papers revelations. The committee will comprise 65 Members of the European Parliament and will have 12 months to report. The Panama Papers revelations released by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists caused shockwaves around the world, including resignations from office by political figures implicated in the scandal.  The Panama Papers – 11.5 million leaked files from the Panama-based law firm Mossack Fonseca – have caused outrage around the world as the public have become aware of the extent of tax-dodging, money laundering and general criminality by the world’s wealthiest corporations and individuals, using offshore tax havens. This Committee of Inquiry will investigate possible contraventions and maladministration in the application of the law on money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. A number of Irish companies, business people, property developers and other individuals have been implicated in this scandal. It is vital that this Committee has sufficient powers of inquiry to investigate the Panama Papers scandal effectively in order to identify the loopholes that need to be closed.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I welcome this vote. Since 8 April, I have been campaigning for the establishment of a parliamentary commission of inquiry to shed light on these unbearable cases. The Panama Papers scandal has once again shown that some banks, past masters in the socialization of their losses, are not playing the game. These banks, having been the subject of extensive bailouts since 2008, are accountable to citizens, especially the millions of citizens who cannot make ends meet, and who pay their taxes. Europe must act more firmly against fraudsters, tax evasion and money laundering. It is time to put an end to tax havens and these practices of another age.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the above motion for a resolution setting up a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged breaches and maladministration in the implementation of EU legislation on money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion and setting out its tasks and duration.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I wholeheartedly agree with Parliament's resolution to set up a committee of inquiry to examine money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. Corporate tax avoidance must be combated, because the EU should not support the fact that small and medium-sized enterprises have to pay their taxes, while multinationals can avoid them. Stricter restrictions on the deductibility of interest and better taxation and taxation of foreign income are needed. I also welcome the fact that the European Parliament has called for greater transparency in trusts and foundations.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of transparency and democracy, I wish to confirm I abstained on this resolution. I condemn money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. However, it is not for the European Union to interfere in how the UK Treasury investigates illegal activity. However, I do not believe that UK taxpayers’ money should be used to set up an EU committee of inquiry.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, carried out by my colleague Enrique Calvet Chambon, which I hope will push the Member States of the Union to adopt an ambitious approach. European citizens are fed up with unethical tax practices. The adoption of this report allows the European Parliament to send a strong signal to the Council and the Commission. There is an urgent need to address existing legal and technical gaps in tax evasion. A fair and equitable taxation of business must become the cornerstone of the single market; it is not demagoguery, nor is it a gratuitous attack on businesses or business activities. The aim is to combat fraud on the basis of a competitive and productive approach, and to protect small and medium-sized enterprises from the damage caused by these practices.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal to set up a Panama Papers investigation committee. The mandate of this committee was already endorsed on 2 June by a conference of EP Presidents composed of the presidents of the EP and its political groups.  The committee of inquiry, which will have 65 MEPs, will have to assess the proper implementation of EU rules on money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. It will have 12 months to final report.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this measure, which calls for the creation of a commission of inquiry into the Panama Papers scandal for a period of 12 months. The fight against tax evasion is an increasingly crucial issue for Europe at a time of fiscal austerity.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. We voted in favour of opening a commission of inquiry that will shed light on the so-called Panama Papers scandal. This commission of inquiry will broaden its scope of investigation by also looking at the mechanisms that enable money laundering, one of the main reasons why a group of individuals organize tax evasion of this magnitude. The mechanisms that organize money laundering must also be those used to finance international terrorism.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. One of Parliament's most important powers is monitoring and monitoring. I think it is of the utmost importance for the establishment of this committee to investigate, interless, the Commission's alleged commitment to implement and by the Member States to effectively implement and implement Directive 2005/60/EC on the prevention of the use of the financial system for money laundering and for the financing of terrorism.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposal for a decision establishing a committee of inquiry into the Panama Papers scandal. The request was made by 377 Members, including myself, to investigate complaints of infringement and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. These are serious accusations and crimes which have already had several political consequences. The 65-member Committee of Inquiry will have 12 months from this vote to present its report and shed light on the case and the allegations made.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of an investigative committee to investigate allegations of infringement and mismanagement in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. I think it is essential that there is a specific working committee which deals with this issue in depth and that it is given the importance that this problem deserves in the European Parliament.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 Conduct on illegal and corrupt occasions and sometimes perhaps legal but dubiously ethical conduct that has uncovered the so-called 'Panama papers' advises the European Parliament to investigate this scandal. In the list of 'users' of these services there are citizens of virtually all states of the Union and some well relevant ones, so an intervention at European Union level is better than that carried out State to state. At a time when the EU is legislating to avoid tax avoidance, knowing in detail the tricks and coordination failures that allow tax evasion is not an option. It's an obligation.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the creation of this commission of inquiry to examine allegations of breaches of EU law and maladministration in its application of money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. This includes shedding light on this so-called "Panama Papers" case, in which, I would like to point out, the media-political authorities have behaved outrageously and issued cookie-cutter judgments, notably by insinuating the involvement of patriotic parties. I therefore look forward to the medies, the only representatives at European level of the voice of the peoples, to be able to carry out this investigation and determine the implications of each in this matter.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote the establishment of the Committee of Inquiry on the "Panama Papers"

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it has led Parliament to set up a committee of inquiry to investigate allegations of irregularities and maladministration in the application of Union law in the application of Union law. The committee of inquiry will be composed of 65 Members and the committee of inquiry should take into account any changes in its area of competence in the course of its mandate.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 National governments have a great responsibility both in terms of increasing tax revenues and preventing terrorist financing. At the same time, it is of the utmost importance that this activity is carried out in a transparent manner and in strict compliance with the legislation in force. I therefore voted in favour of the establishment of a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged infringements and maladministration in relation to the implementation of EU legislation on money laundering, tax evasion and tax fraud, defining its powers, number and duration of its mandate.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I welcomed the vote in Parliament to establish a Committee of Inquiry into the Panama Papers revelations. The committee will comprise 65 Members of the European Parliament and will have 12 months to report. The Panama Papers revelations released by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists caused shockwaves around the world, including resignations from office by political figures implicated in the scandal. The Panama Papers – 11.5 million leaked files from the Panama-based law firm Mossack Fonseca – have caused outrage around the world as the public have become aware of the extent of tax-dodging, money laundering and general criminality by the world’s wealthiest corporations and individuals, using offshore tax havens. This Committee of Inquiry will investigate possible contraventions and maladministration in the application of the law on money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. A number of Irish companies, business people, property developers and other individuals have been implicated in this scandal. It is vital that this Committee has sufficient powers of inquiry to investigate the Panama Papers scandal effectively in order to identify the loopholes that need to be closed.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the increased incidence of money laundering, tax evasion and fraud, it becomes necessary to set up a commission of inquiry to investigate these alleged irregularities. The role of this Committee of Inquiry is fundamental in ensuring the enforcement of Union law. As a result, the Commission of Inquiry will investigate the Commission's alleged omissions in ensuring compliance with directives such as: Directive 2014/91/EU, Directive 2011/61/EU, Directive 2009/138/EC and Directive 2006/43/EC. It will also develop recommendations on measures to encourage third countries to apply minimum standards of good governance in aggressive tax and tax planning issues and assess the latest developments in relation to the Commission's External Strategy for Effective Taxation. I considered it appropriate to set up a commission of inquiry to investigate allegations of infringement of EU law and maladministration in its application in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion in view of the negative financial and legal impact, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this initiative.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. As a result of the scandal known as Panama Leaks, which revealed the existence of thousands of opaque bank accounts for tax avoidance in Panama, the Socialist and Democratic Group called for the establishment of a commission of inquiry, given that very significant European citizens have participated in this network, and the Union's financial interests may also have been severely damaged. The Group's priority objectives have entered the Commission's mandate, i.e. to investigate whether Member States: - have implemented the Anti-Money Laundering Directive well to prevent money laundering through the establishment of offshore companies. - If they cooperated in relation to the automatic exchange of information. - If the laws in the audit sector have been well implemented. I think it is imperative to get to the bottom of this issue, which is why I voted in favour of the establishment of this committee of inquiry.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of setting up a commission of inquiry to examine allegations of breaches of EU law in the area of money laundering and tax evasion. The creation of this commission of inquiry echoes the revelations of the international consortium of investigative journalists on the Panama Papers. We can no longer tolerate this kind of happening. Businesses and individuals must report their income and be properly taxed. I welcome the tax transparency package drawn up by the Commission and call on Member States to take action to combat tax evasion. The mandate of the Commission of Inquiry seems appropriate to me in order to analyse the practices of money laundering and tax evasion.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the decision to set up a committee of inquiry to examine complaints of infringement and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. All too often, existing EU anti-money laundering rules are not properly applied. Every year, billions of euros disappear into tax havens that deprive European citizens of valuable resources that could be invested in education, health, public services and the fight against poverty. That is why we need full transparency and sanctions for those in Europe who help European individuals and companies to evade taxation. It is essential that this Committee of Inquiry can also make any recommendations regarding the implementation by Member States of the Commission's recommendations on measures to encourage third countries to apply minimum standards of good governance in tax matters.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal to set up a Committee of Inquiry into the Panama Papers. This Committee will investigate breaches and maladministration of EU directives and regulations related to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. In the light of the revelations made by the Panama Papers and the massive public outcry against the offshore world, Parliament’s political groups have decided to set up a committee. I will represent Sinn Féin and my European political group, GUE/NGL, on this Committee.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the establishment of a committee of inquiry to examine complaints of infringement and maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the adoption of this resolution as I believe there is a case for Parliament to investigate what the European Union and its Member States do in order to fight money laundering and limit ways for systematic tax avoidance. The Panama Papers revelations show there has been, apparently, such a practice in place and EU citizens should see whether it means that the relevant EU legislation was by-passed or not properly implemented.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and expect the final report of the committee of inquiry to Parliament within 12 months.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with this proposal to set up a committee of inquiry to examine complaints of infringement and maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. I am of the opinion that a committee of inquiry can be useful in examining complaints that the Commission has failed to enforce and enforce the directives that have been decided upon. I am convinced that such a body can help to have better control and organisation, and I have therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is important that within the remit of this committee we have a fair, strong and balanced report.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree to the establishment of a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged misdemeanors or mismanagement in the application of EU law relating to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. Corporate tax avoidance deprives the public budgets of EU Member States of several billion euros a year. It also undermines the fair burden-sharing between taxpayers and fair competition between undertakings. Companies also take advantage of the complexity of tax rules and the lack of cooperation between Member States to relocate profits and reduce their taxes to a minimum. I support this Decision to set up a parliamentary Committee of Inquiry to investigate the non-application of a set of Directives within the financial system, money laundering, automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, etc., including investigating the potential breach by Member States and their associated territories and dependent on the duty of sincere cooperation enshrined in Article 4. , paragraph 3 of the Treaty on European Union.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of setting up a committee of inquiry to investigate possible administrative infringements in the application of Community tax law. This committee will be responsible for analysing complaints that the Authorities of the Member States have failed to comply with administrative sanctions against institutions responsible for serious breaches of national provisions. The work of the Committee of Inquiry will be useful in combating maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of this committee, because I consider it essential to continue the work of the TAXE investigative committees in the light of panama's new leaks, which, as was already the case in the case of Luxleaks, concern the Commission doubly: because of their complicity with tax avoidance and evasion and for the direct political responsibility of the current Commissioners for their past responsibilities in the Government. In addition, Panama acquires great relevance in the key of the Spanish State as a preferred destination for the evasion of large local fortunes, including Commissioner Cañete's wife, who thus adds another knot to the network created by his conflicts of interest, his participation in tax amnesty and his possible participation in a corruption , the Acuamed case

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution decides to set up a committee of inquiry to examine complaints of infringement and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. I voted in favour of this resolution because, by voting, I intend to support any type of activity that can help to promote better and more harmonised application of tax rules, including through greater transparency of public administration and to eliminate possible abuses in the application of tax rules that give competitive disadvantages to some States compared to others.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Due to the nature of the document and its objectives, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of full disclosure of politicians’ assets and accounts in order to preserve their political integrity and avoid any shadow of doubt, be it factual or perceived, in relation to corruption. In line with Malta’s longstanding position against tax havens and tax evasion I also fully support all efforts aimed at the preservation of the rule of law in relation to payment of taxes. In view of these elements and in full respect of our citizens’ right to information and to clean politics, I supported the setting up of such a committee and look forward to the outcomes and actions on such findings.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the creation of a commission of inquiry into allegations of infringement and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering and tax evasion. This commission, of which I will be a member, should shed light on the Panama Papers scandal. I will pay particular attention to the issue of money laundering financing terrorism.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal because it is absolutely imperative to combat money laundering and tax evasion, which too many multinational companies use with impunity. It is essential that the Member States of the European Union take joint action to investigate cases of violations of EU law and its poor application of money laundering, tax evasion and evasion. That is why I support the establishment of this commission of inquiry, which will be made up of 65 members of the JURI, LIBE and ECON committees. I am therefore awaiting the recommendations of the members of this committee, which are expected to be presented in the summer of 2017.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the proposal for a decision on the establishment and the reported powers of the Committee of Inquiry to investigate violations and forms of maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax evasion and tax avoidance. Given that these illegal activities are increasingly a scourge for each Member State, it is necessary to set up the Committee, as natural and mainly legal persons exploit legal loopholes in tax systems in order not to pay their fair share of taxes, which results in a further burden on other taxpayers. The committee must therefore be set up and used to the fullest in order to achieve greater transparency but also to combat tax evasion and avoidance and to achieve a fairer distribution of tax burdens for European taxpayers.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ It has been almost three months since the unprecedented leak of documents known as the Panama Papers detailed how some people were succeeding in concealing their wealth to avoid paying tax. Parliament has today agreed the mandate of the Committee of Inquiry into this scandal. I welcome the opportunity for us to raise the importance of the exchange of tax information between Member States, and to better understand the measures needed to tackle tax avoidance. We have a duty to fight tax fraud and illegal activity and my constituents in Wales quite rightly demand this.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to set up a committee of inquiry because I consider it important to investigate the alleged non-implementation of Directive 2005/60/EC by the Commission and the alleged non-effective implementation and non-implementation of that Directive by the Member States, as well as the alleged non-application by Member States of administrative sanctions and other administrative measures to institutions which have been held liable for serious infringements of national provisions.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The establishment of a committee of inquiry to investigate the scandals revealed by the Panama Papers was in our favour. However, we must point out that the recent past, with the succession of tax scandals, leads us to conclude that we are in the presence of a structural problem and not just conjuncture. This committee, regardless of the fact-made facts about the protagonists of these practices, be they consultancy firms, multinationals or national governments, should raise a broad reflection on the deeper causes that have created the conditions for these practices are common and have been generalised to the majority of large multinationals with the connivance of several EU Member States. And these root causes are naturally associated with the deregulation of the financial system and the lifting of all restrictions on the movement of capital. It is to be hoped that these matters will not be the subject of the work of this committee. We regret that the committee's mandate does not reflect this need.  Having made possible the constitution of this committee, we denounce what seem to us to be its limits and, in a way, some perversity that may be associated with it: to give the idea that something is done so that something changes, and it is actually all the same. So it was with the committee on the Luxleaks scandal.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against because this inquiry is essential.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 This report in question regulates the scope, composition and term of office of the Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged breaches of EU law and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. The Committee of Inquiry has the task of clarifying and investigating the alleged failure of the EC to enforce Directive 2005/60/EC and the Member States in its enforcement and effective implementation. At the end of its work, it will propose any recommendations it will evaluate as necessary in this area, including recommendations on how Member States implement those EC recommendations.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report because we need to clarify this matter.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the proposal for a decision on the establishment and the reported powers of the Committee of Inquiry to investigate violations and forms of maladministration in the implementation of EU legislation in relation to money laundering, tax evasion and tax avoidance. Given that these illegal activities are increasingly a scourge for each Member State, it is necessary to set up the Committee, as natural and mainly legal persons exploit legal loopholes in tax systems in order not to pay their fair share of taxes, which results in a further burden on other taxpayers. The committee must therefore be set up and used to the fullest in order to achieve greater transparency but also to combat tax evasion and avoidance and to achieve a fairer distribution of tax burdens for European taxpayers.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the establishment of a parliamentary committee of inquiry to comprehensively investigate alleged infringements and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax fraud.  Cooperation between member states' tax authorities is more important than ever in order to reduce tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning. The global economic and financial crisis of recent years has highlighted the importance and enforcement of joint burden-sharing.  It is estimated that member states will be lost billions of euros in revenue as a reason for corporate tax avoidance. Businesses are taking advantage of the complexity of tax rules and the lack of cooperation from Member States to redeploy their profits and minimise their tax obligations. It is therefore essential to promote transparency and cooperation in the fight against aggressive tax planning and abusive tax practices. The importance of this has only been highlighted by the Panama Papers scandal, which makes the establishment of a commission of inquiry inevitable.  We need to investigate any allegations that the Commission has not enforced and the Member States have not actually implemented and actually implemented Directive 2005/60/EC, taking into account the obligation to implement Directive 2015/849 in a timely and effective manner.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a decision with the firm conviction that the result should be to avoid infringement of EU law with regard to money laundering. This committee should be used to affect the errors or malpractice committed by both the Commission and the Member States in implementing the directives and to address those problems.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution establishing and regulating the operation of a committee of inquiry responsible for examining complaints of infringement and maladministration and in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, avoidance and tax evasion, of which I was one of the proposers of the institution formulated at the Conference of Presidents.  I fully agreed with the need to give the committee a broad mandate to include the possibility of examining complaints of the Commission's failure to enforce and enforce all anti-money laundering directives, timely implementation of the anti-money laundering directives, to examine the potential breach of the duty of loyal cooperation enshrined in the Treaties, provided it is relevant, to make any recommendations that it considers necessary also with regard to the implementation by the Member States of the Commission's recommendations. 2012, concerning measures to encourage third countries to apply minimum rules of good governance in tax matters and aggressive tax planning. In addition, the committee will be able to assess the most recent developments in the Commission's external strategy for effective taxation and the link between the legal framework of the EU and the Member States. The Commission will have twelve months to achieve these important objectives.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I am fighting for tax justice and transparency. That is why I voted in favour of setting up a 'Committee of Inquiry into alleged breaches of EU law and maladministration in its application in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, its powers, numerical strength and mandate time'.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. In order to combat tax evasion effectively, we need to create more transparency in letterbox companies. There is no reasonable reason why the owner of a company should remain anonymous. We now need to overcome national egoisms on the subject of taxes and to solve the global problem together. The Committee of Inquiry will make an important contribution to this. The Committee will be responsible for examining alleged breaches of Union law and maladministration in its application in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. In particular, it will examine the inaction of the Member States that led to the abuses disclosed in the Panama Papers. It is important that the law firm Mossack Fonseca and the Government of Panama answer parliament.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of an investigative committee to investigate allegations of infringement and mismanagement in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. I think it is essential that there is a specific working committee which deals with this issue in depth and that it is given the importance that this problem deserves in the European Parliament.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to establish this new commission of inquiry, which will shed light on the Panama Papers scandal and tax evasion practices. The mandate of this commission will enable it to have broad investigative powers, to hear from key players in the dossier, and to publish a report with concrete recommendations and proposals to combat tax evasion and money laundering more effectively.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. One of the main matters of the Committee will be to assess the latest developments in the Commission’s external strategy for effective taxation and assess the links between the legal framework of the European Union and Member States and the tax systems of third countries as well as efforts made to promote, at international level, the transparency of beneficial ownership information.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. As a result of the scandal known as Panama Leaks, which revealed the existence of thousands of opaque bank accounts for tax avoidance in Panama, the Socialist and Democratic Group called for the establishment of a commission of inquiry, given that very significant European citizens have participated in this network, and the Union's financial interests may also have been severely damaged.
