The Group's priority objectives have entered the Commission's mandate, i.e. to investigate whether Member States: - have implemented the Anti-Money Laundering Directive well to prevent money laundering through the establishment of offshore companies. - If they cooperated in relation to the automatic exchange of information. - If the laws in the audit sector have been well implemented. I think it is imperative to get to the bottom of this issue, which is why I voted in favour of the establishment of this committee of inquiry.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of setting up a Parliament's committee of inquiry to investigate alleged violations and maladministration in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. The issue is one of the most important issues that has seen the light of day and as a group we will insist that the issue be dealt with in its full depth.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of setting up Committee of Inquiry into the ‘Panama Papers’ revelations concerning detailed information on offshore companies and their ultimate beneficiaries in a vote on Wednesday. The Committee of Inquiry will investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of European Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, its powers, numerical strength and term of office. This Committee will have 65 members and twelve months to present its report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this committee as it benefits transparency within the EU.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Decision submitted in accordance with Article 198 TB. Rules of procedure for establishing a commission of inquiry to investigate alleged violations and irregularities in the application of Union legislation in the field of money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, its powers, numerical composition and term of office (2016/2726(RSO)), since I believe that all market operators, including large multinational companies, must be in the same position as citizens and pay taxes in accordance with their business activities. Any tax avoidance is unacceptable. We need to support the OECD plan and the European Commission's proposal to set rules against tax avoidance practices. Greater cooperation and coordination between Member States and competent national tax services in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance is needed. I support the European Commission's proposal, which relies on the principle that tax should be paid where profits are made and create new value.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tax havens and the tax avoidance opportunities of large companies need to be tackled more effectively than they are today. Member States should also cooperate in harmonising the rates of taxes. This is necessary in order to avoid the abuse of loopholes resulting from differences in the legislation of the Member States and to reduce the possibility of abuse and fraud. The European Commission's proposal points the way, but the European Parliament's proposal, in part because of amendments by green members of the European Parliament, is even more than the Commission's proposal, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to establish a parliamentary commission of inquiry into the Panama Papers. After this scandal, which follows that of the Luxleaks, the European Union must be at the forefront in the fight against tax evasion. It is anomalous that some large multinationals can evade tax.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this resolution. It concerns the establishment of the committee of inquiry called for by Parliament on the Panama Papers revelations about offshore companies. The Committee of Inquiry is to have 65 members and will be responsible for examining alleged breaches of Union law and maladministration in its application in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of setting up an inquiry committee to deal with alleged irregularities in the so-called 'Panama Papers' scandal. I believe that we must be strict and unyaltered in the fight against tax evasion and money laundering schemes. The Panama scandal shows that this fight must be global. I believe that there is a need for greater transparency with regard to the ofstor zones and the companies registered therein. This would help to combat money laundering and tax avoidance. The European Parliament expresses its clear willingness to take action to eradicate such practices.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the proposal. The new Committee of Inquiry will build on the work of the special tax committees set up 18 months ago and will address issues such as money laundering and the impact on third countries. We want full transparency and sanctions for those who help individuals and companies evade tax. Fighting tax fraud, tax avoidance, and eradicating tax havens must become a top priority of the EU. Otherwise, the overwhelming majority of people who pay their taxes will not understand and will turn their back on the European project.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. We have approved the creation of a committee of inquiry to clarify offshore companies and their beneficiaries, following the panama papers scandal. The committee's task will be to investigate alleged breaches and cases of non-compliance with EU rules on money laundering, avoidance and tax evasion. It will also examine complaints of member states' failure to comply with administrative sanctions against institutions found guilty of serious breaches of national provisions and examine complaints that Member States have failed to comply with the TFEI's regulatory provisions in such matters.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to set up a European commission of inquiry into the Panama Papers scandal, in which at least one European Commissioner appears to be involved. Every effort must be made to shed light on this tax evasion scandal. I would like to be part of this commission of inquiry.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the mandate of the Commission of Inquiry on the Panama Papers in light of the revelations of possible violations of European tax, anti-money laundering and corporate governance regulations. In fact, I have applied to this committee to represent the positions of the French delegation of the EPP Group.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to set up a commission of inquiry to examine allegations of breaches of EU law and maladministration in its application of money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. Of course, the question must be asked whether the European Parliament is well placed to investigate this matter, but the problem of evasion and tax evasion is too important not to address it. There is also a need for political solutions to address this problem.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of this committee, because I consider it essential to continue the work of the TAXE investigative committees in the light of panama's new leaks, which, as was already the case in the case of Luxleaks, concern the Commission doubly: because of their complicity with tax avoidance and evasion and for the direct political responsibility of the current Commissioners for their past responsibilities in the Government. In addition, Panama acquires great relevance in the key of the Spanish State as a preferred destination for the evasion of large local fortunes, including Commissioner Cañete's wife, who thus adds another knot to the network created by his conflicts of interest, his participation in tax amnesty and his possible participation in a corruption , the Acuamed case.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ An investigative committee will be established to investigate alleged violations or reports related to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. If any failures by the competent authorities of the Member States are established, administrative penalties or other administrative measures will apply.  Close and open cooperation between Member States on tax data and documents is required, in particular where there are grounds to assume that there are irregularities. Member States should exchange information on specific cases where requested by another Member State. Particular attention will be paid to tax evasion, tax avoidance in other Member States, money laundering and intermediaries and lawyers who make all this possible.  Member States should take measures to encourage third countries to plan optimally and aggressively tax. This will also enhance cooperation at international level.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the light of recent scandals, first of all the so-s. LuxLeaks and the Panama Papers agree fully that it is clear that the time has come to set up a committee of inquiry within the European Parliament, whose members would analyse in detail both the specificities of the scandals mentioned above and any other possible violations and maladminisorial irregularities and maladminiding of the application of Union law on money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. I believe that this committee of inquiry will also become an excellent complement to the already existing TAXE2 Committee, thus allowing for a more effective examination of the often similar issues. It is hoped that in the next 12 months the Committee will produce a report that will allow for the full implementation of measures on a much wider scale of this type of illegal transactions and infringements.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the establishment, definition of competences, numerical composition and term of office of a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged violations and maladministration in the implementation of EU legislation in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, because it is complete and documented.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the proposal to set up a commission of inquiry into the so-called "Panama Papers". We must rigorously investigate possible infringements committed, and ensure that we have the best Community legislation in place to combat laundering, evasion and tax avoidance.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. It took the biggest tax scandal in history for the European Parliament to deploy all the means at its disposal to develop a political response. On the tax justice front, history is moving slowly. Swissleaks had given nothing for politics; Luxleaks gave birth to the special commission TAXE, then its extension TAXE 2, of which I am a member, but which was still not equipped with resources. Without these special means of investigation, national administrations and multinationals have given us only what they want to give us.  This start is beneficial. The creation of a commission of inquiry for which I have been advocating since 2014 finally gives the signal of a proportionate response from European parliamentarians. We will be able to obtain and review all the necessary documents, and have sufficient authority to summon all the players in the file. Of course, the tax exile of individuals, as mediated as it is, will represent only part of our work, which will focus on tracking down profits hidden by multinationals, sometimes with the help of the States of the European Union or at least with the help of complacent legislation.  I fully supported the establishment of the Commission of Inquiry.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to investigate media information related to the Panama Papers scandal, the EP decided to set up a committee of inquiry to assess the proper implementation of EU anti-money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion rules. I support this decision.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution proposes the establishment of a commission of inquiry to examine allegations of breaches of EU law and maladministration in its application of money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. Simply put, it is a question of setting up a committee of MEPs to investigate the Panama Papers case. It should be noted that this is a "commission of inquiry" with broader powers than the "special committees" that had been granted to the European Parliament for the Luxleaks case. I am voting for the establishment of this commission.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to establish a 12-month commission of inquiry into the Panama Papers scandal.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. We need to ensure that those who abuse to the detriment of others are held to account. Our citizens expect strong measures to clamp down on tax evasion and aggressive, abusive tax avoidance, particularly by those with a political responsibility to safeguard the common good.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 337 MEPs have submitted an application for the establishment of a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged infringements and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax fraud. On this basis, the Conference of Presidents proposed to Parliament the establishment of a 65-person panel, with the committee of inquiry to submit a final report within 12 months of the adoption of the decision. I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Scandals involving tax evasion and tax avoidance mechanisms by multinationals have been on the rise since the Luxleaks affair in November 2014.  In order to protect the President of the European Commission, Mr Juncker, MEPs from his Socialist majority and the EPP had refused to set up a commission of inquiry, settling for a temporary, less solemn committee.  This time, the Panama Papers are being discussed and Parliament is moving towards a 65-member commission of inquiry, elected for 12 months, to investigate allegations of breaches of EU law and maladministration in its application of money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion.  The European Union is still lagging behind fraudsters and the repeated committees have so far failed to blame any officials.  It is feared that the same will be true of this new commission, even if it needs to be supported in principle.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the foregoing and in order to ensure the confidence of citizens in the European institutions, so in the light of the principles of transparency, rigour and justice, the establishment of a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged misdemeanors or mismanagement in the application of Union law relating to money laundering and tax avoidance and evasion deserves my vote in favour.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. I am voting for the creation of a commission of inquiry into the serious acts of which both companies and the administration itself are suspected. Nevertheless, I will remain attentive to the smooth running of this committee.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of the new Commission of Inquiry to examine allegations of breaches of EU law and maladministration in its application of money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. After the revelations of the Panama Papers affair, it was essential that the European Parliament react by looking for the flaws that led to such a scandal.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to justify my vote in favour of setting up a Commission of Inquiry into the so-called Panama Papers scandal and the possible responsibilities of the Commission and the Member States for the implementation of Community directives. As I have said on other occasions here, tax evasion and avoidance and money laundering are practices which, on the one hand, take economic resources away from state budgets, whose ability to invest in promoting employment and combating poverty are being reduced, and which, on the other, undermine citizens' confidence in democratic institutions. We need horizontal European coordination based on the exchange of information between Member States, the creation of a European blacklist of tax havens, the control of the financial institutions that create these offshore companies, sanctions against non-cooperative jurisdictions and a harmonised and common European tax identification code. Setting up a committee of inquiry into the Panama Papers scandal, together with the adoption of the new EU anti-evasion directive, is therefore the best way to give a concrete response to the democratic needs of citizens.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal that will set up a Committee of Inquiry of 65 members that will investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of European Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. The request for this committee to be set up was presented by 337 Members of the European Parliament.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it provides for the establishment of a committee of inquiry to examine allegations of omission or non-application of several directives on European Union law by the European Commission and the Member States, leading to its breach and poor administration. I believe that taxation is a crucial area of activity for the development of each Member State of the European Union. It is therefore necessary to apply the rules drawn up for the tax field. In this respect, the report voted on today set out the spectrum of activity of this committee, as well as lasting and compositional issues. This committee will consider the application of the tax rules laid down by the European directives, in particular those on the obligation of fair cooperation. I welcome the investigative approach in which this committee of inquiry will be engaged, and I hope that, if there are indeed some institutional slippages at European Commission level, they will be resolved with the help of this committee.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I welcomed the vote in Parliament to establish a Committee of Inquiry into the Panama Papers revelations. The Committee will comprise 65 Members of the European Parliament and will have 12 months to report. The Panama Papers revelations released by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists caused shockwaves around the world, including resignations from office by political figures implicated in the scandal.  The Panama Papers – 11.5 million leaked files from the Panama-based law firm Mossack Fonseca – have caused outrage around the world as the public have become aware of the extent of tax-dodging, money laundering and general criminality by the world’s wealthiest corporations and individuals, using offshore tax havens. This Committee of Inquiry will investigate possible contraventions and maladministration in the application of the law on money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. A number of Irish companies, business people, property developers and other individuals have been implicated in this scandal. It is vital that this Committee has sufficient powers of inquiry to investigate the Panama Papers scandal effectively in order to identify the loopholes that need to be closed.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. If I had had the opportunity to take part in this vote, I would have voted in favour of setting up the committee in the interests of full transparency and responsibility towards the taxpayer.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Commission's task is to ensure the orderly functioning of the tax system and better coordination of member states' tax systems and to prevent deviations from administrative obligations.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is known that criminal conduct involving the use of money of criminal origin involves an alteration of economic market mechanisms. I believe that the request made by 337 Members for the setting up of a committee of inquiry to examine complaints of infringement and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion is incisive in the European Union's action in this regard. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament established the Panama Papers Investigation Committee at the initiative of the European People's Party, which I also co-signed, which called for transparency in registering ownership of companies, wanting to put an end to the registration of companies where it is sufficient to have a mailbox to register and the beneficial owner remains secret and unknown. Ownership of companies, whether in Europe or any other part of the world, cannot be secret because a real entrepreneur should not be ashamed of the work he does.  We need to put an end to shell companies that produce nothing and have zero workers and only serve the powerful for criminal money laundering activities and tax evasion. The Committee of Inquiry should investigate member states' failings which led to what was revealed in the Panama Papers. It also aims to shine a light on structural problems that make it difficult to effectively combat money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. Very often it is member states that paralyse international action aimed at preventing money laundering and tax evasion. I believe that representatives of the Law Office of Mossack Fonseca and the Panamaic Government should be summoned for a hearing at the European Parliament.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. I am voting for the creation of a commission of inquiry into the serious acts of which both companies and the administration itself are suspected. Nevertheless, I will remain attentive to the smooth running of this committee.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the establishment of an investigative committee to investigate allegations of violations and irregularities in the application of Union legislation in the areas of money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. The Committee of Inquiry will be tasked, inter alia, with investigating alleged failures by the Commission in implementing and member states in the effective application and implementation of Directive 2005/60/EC, taking into account the obligation to implement Directive (EU) 2015/849 in a timely and efficient manner; an investigation into alleged cases where member state authorities failed to apply administrative sanctions and other administrative measures to institutions responsible for serious breaches of national provisions adopted under Directive 2005/60/EC, as required by Directive 2013/36/EU; investigating the Commission's alleged failings in implementing and implementing Directive 2014/91/EU; Etc.  In view of recent affairs known as Panama Papers, Luxembourg Leaks, etc., more than ever, proper application of Union legislation on money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion is needed more than ever.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the decision to establish a commission of inquiry to investigate alleged breaches and irregularities in the application of European legislation. Whenever possible, they should prioritise resolving contentious issues within existing parliamentary committees. However, in this case it is a multi-layered issue that tosses different areas of tax evasion, money laundering and legal instruments that should prevent financial malfeasance, so there are strong reasons for this to be discussed by a special commission of inquiry. I expect the Commission, in line with its mandate, to investigate the numerous alleged failings of the European Commission in the implementation, i.e. of the Member States in the application and implementation of European legislation, and in the most not part of Directive 2005/60/EC on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering or terrorist financing. In addition, I consider it essential that the commission fulfils the second duty of its mandate and, taking into account the information obtained through the investigation, proposes clear recommendations for more effective taxation that would minimise abuse opportunities and ensure the full application of the new Directive 2015/849, as well as the transparency of beneficial ownership information.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament has decided to set up a committee of inquiry into the Panama Papers, the revelations about offshore companies and their beneficiaries. The committee's task will be to investigate alleged infringements and cases of non-compliance by the Commission or the Member States with Community rules on money laundering, avoidance and tax evasion. The committee will consist of 65 members and will have twelve months to present the final report. The terms of reference of the Committee of Inquiry were agreed on Thursday 2 June by the Conference of Presidents of the European Parliament. I voted in favour of this proposal for a decision.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the establishment of a commission of inquiry following the so-called Panama Papers revelations. Operating on the same model as the Commission of Inquiry on Vehicle Emissions (EMIS), of which I am a member, this committee will have to investigate possible infringements or the mismanagement of the application of European laws on money laundering and tax evasion. Comprised of 65 MEPs, the committee will have 12 months to present its final report.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP motion for a resolution on the establishment of a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged misdemeanors or maladministration in the application of EU law relating to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion because this proposal was submitted by 337 Members. The committee set up shall investigate the alleged non-application by Member States of administrative sanctions and other administrative measures to institutions which have been held liable for infringements and the alleged non-implementation of Directive 2011/16/EU by the Commission and the alleged non-effective application of that Directive by Member States and the potential infringement by Member States and their associated territories and dependent on the duty of sincere cooperation enshrined in Article 4, Treaty on European Union. The committee set up shall make the recommendations it deems necessary on this matter, as well as assess the latest progress in the Commission's external strategy for effective taxation, the links between the Union and Member States' legal framework and the tax regimes of third countries.  The Committee of Inquiry, consisting of 65 elements, shall submit a report within 12 months.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the establishment of this Committee of Inquiry of this House, which follows the Panama Papers revelations. Similar in form to the EMIS Commission of Inquiry of which I am a member, it will be tasked with investigating allegations of infringement and maladministration in the application of European laws on money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. My 65 colleagues who will be members of this committee will have 12 months to present their report and I encourage them to shed light on everyone's responsibilities in this matter, as the practices of money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion are unacceptable and must be combated and stopped.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I support the Committee of Inquiry on the Panama Papers in its mission, namely to shed light on alleged offences and failures in the application of European laws relating to money laundering, tax evasion, but also tax avoidance. These revelations point to unacceptable behaviour, in terms of fairness, ethics and also in economic terms. Furthermore, I call for a European tax inspection, capable of investigating, monitoring cases and condemning the practices that need to be investigated. More broadly, I am in favour of the adoption of European rules which govern tax optimisation, which, while legal, still raises a moral question when it benefits large companies and the wealthy, able to implement such engineering, to the detriment of SMEs and citizens. Member States, which have jurisdiction over this issue, must take responsibility for establishing fairer and fairer taxation.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal we are considering setting up a Committee of Inquiry to investigate allegations of breaches of Union law and maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion is a major step towards ensuring the effectiveness of EU financial management. It needs unconditional support. All the more important and welcome, that Parliament also takes on a greater role and responsibility on this issue in the exercise of its mandate extended in the recent constitutional reform.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a decision based on a Resolution of the European Parliament on the establishment of a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged misdemeanors or maladministration in the application of UNION law relating to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, its tasks, numerical composition and duration of the mandate.  It is a question of investigating the lack of implementation by Member States of directives relating, inter alia, to the legal review of annual and consolidated accounts, financial statements and also to money laundering or terrorist financing.  The final objective of the 65-member committee will be to produce a report after 12 months, in which recommendations are made to Member States contributing to better governance in tax matters.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the creation of a commission of inquiry into the Panama Papers, which follows the revelations published a few weeks ago. The committee of inquiry will be made up of 65 MEPs and will aim to publish a detailed report within a year. The objective will be to analyze what has been revealed by the Panama Papers, as well as tax evasion practices. Hearings can be held and recommendations will ultimately be made to effectively combat tax evasion and evasion.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision on the establishment of a committee of inquiry to investigate cases of maladministration in the application of EU law. Parliament has long been engaged in a real fight against cases of evasion and avoidance, ranging from money laundering, to tax avoidance and evasion and to the competences of the Union. The establishment of this committee of inquiry is clearly the line taken by the parliamentary assembly on this matter and to which I support it.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of an investigative committee to investigate allegations of infringement and mismanagement in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. I think it is essential that there is a specific working committee which deals with this issue in depth and that it is given the importance that this problem deserves in the European Parliament.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the establishment of a committee of inquiry to investigate possible breaches of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. I consider the provisions of the Committee initiated by the Social Democrats not only to be the European Parliament's response to the publication of information in the so-called Panama Papers case, but also as another concrete contribution to the public debate on the unsustainability of the current situation of tax evasion in the EU Member States. In the context of the Panama Papers case, it is clear that, in order to set tax transparency and fair taxation of multinational supranational companies, it is necessary, inter alia, to evaluate the links between the legal framework of the Union and the Member States and the tax systems of third countries, which will be one of the main objectives of the Committee of Inquiry.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of this committee, because I consider it essential to continue the work of the TAXE investigative committees in the light of panama's new leaks, which, as was already the case in the case of Luxleaks, concern the Commission doubly: because of their complicity with tax avoidance and evasion and for the direct political responsibility of the current Commissioners for their past responsibilities in the Government. In addition, Panama acquires great relevance in the key of Galiza or even the Spanish State, as it is a favorite destination for the evasion of large local fortunes, among which could be the wife of Commissioner Cañete, which thus adds another knot to the network created by its conflicts of interest, its participation in tax amnesty and its possible participation in some corruption framework.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on the establishment, scope, composition and term of office of the Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged breaches of EU law and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. The committee of inquiry shall have 65 members and submit a final report within 12 months of the adoption of the resolution. In its work, the Committee should focus on the alleged failures of the investigate, inter alia, the enforcement of Directive 2005/60/EC and the Member States in its effective enforcement, investigate the alleged failure of Member States' authorities to apply administrative sanctions and other administrative measures to the institutions and investigate the Alleged Failure of the Commission to enforce Directive 2011/16/EU on the submission of information to other Member States on its own initiative in cases where there are grounds for presuming tax evasion. In its report, the Committee of Inquiry will also propose recommendations that EU legislation should not be infringed in the future.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As important as proper investigation of money laundering cases, it is also the setting of rules that will prevent or at least significantly make this action more difficult in the future.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this report as I consider it necessary to establish an investigative committee to investigate allegations of breaches and irregularities in the application of Union legislation in the field of tax avoidance and evasion and money laundering. I believe that the creation of the committee is useful because it would help investigate alleged cases where member state authorities have failed to apply administrative sanctions and other administrative measures to institutions responsible for serious breaches of national provisions.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the establishment, responsibilities, numerical composition and mandate of the Committee of Inquiry to examine alleged breaches of Union law and maladministration in its application in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. I am a member of this committee of inquiry. Let us wait and see whether the 'Panama Papers' will lead to more regulatory fury in the EU.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament has decided to set up a committee of inquiry to investigate allegations of breaches of Union law and irregularities in the application of this legislation in the areas of money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. The Committee of Inquiry is responsible for investigating alleged failings by the Commission in the implementation of both Member States in the effective application and implementation of Directive 2005/60/EC. He is also in charge of investigating alleged cases where member state authorities have failed to apply administrative sanctions to responsible institutions for serious breaches of national provisions adopted under the same directive. The Committee of Inquiry is also in charge of investigating potential cases where Member States and its associated and dependent territories have breached the obligation to cooperate loyally under the Treaty on European Union to the extent relevant to the scope of this investigation. Furthermore, the Committee of Inquiry is also in charge of making the recommendations it deems necessary for this matter, as well as for measures to encourage third countries to apply minimum standards of good governance in tax matters. I support this motion for a resolution because I believe that the establishment of a committee of inquiry will sanction potential law-breakers, but also force Member States to fully respect and apply EUROPEAN Union legislation.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision establishing a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged infringements and irregularities in the application of Union law relating to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, its powers, numerical composition and mandate. I support the creation of a committee of inquiry to deal with whether the Commission and the Member States do not comply with directives and other regulations. One of the allegations that needs to be investigated is that member states' authorities have not applied administrative sanctions and other administrative measures in cases of institutions found to be responsible for serious infringements of national rules. One of the allegations relating to the Commission, which will be investigated by the Research Committee, is that the Commission has not implemented a directive on the communication of tax information to other Member States on its own initiative.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a decision on the establishment and the reported responsibilities of the Committee of Inquiry is intended to investigate violations and forms of maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to money laundering, tax evasion and tax avoidance. Given that these illegal activities are increasingly a scourge for each Member State, it is necessary to set up the Committee, as natural and mainly legal persons exploit legal loopholes in tax systems in order not to pay their fair share of taxes, which results in a further burden on other taxpayers. The committee must therefore be set up and used to the fullest in order to achieve greater transparency but also to combat tax evasion and avoidance and to achieve a fairer distribution of tax burdens for European taxpayers.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to set up a committee of inquiry, as it would investigate alleged infringements and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax fraud. This committee plays a niche role and its setting-up is essential, as there are strong suspicions in a number of directives that they have not been properly enforced by the Commission or that they have not been implemented or enforced by the Member States. I welcome the establishment of the Board, as it will be the first to examine as its main activity and to assess specifically whether an infringement may have been the result of failure to take measures to prevent the operation of financial instruments that allow beneficial owners to hide from financial institutions and other intermediaries, lawyers, trustees and corporate service providers. At the same time, we will have the chance to review the functioning of other instruments and intermediaries that allow money laundering, tax fraud and tax avoidance in different countries.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I am strongly in favour of the creation of a Commission of Inquiry into the Panama Papers, and I believe that national selfishness must stop paralysing international efforts to combat tax fraud, and that information about who actually owns the company must cease to be a secret.  At the same time, I believe that the discussion on this subject should also include an aspect of the analysis of the reasons for the popularity of so-called tax havens in recent decades. The rampant bureaucracy, the ever-new rules and regulations that are constantly being created, the successive financial burdens, including taxes, sometimes up to 70% of their income, mean that many companies are choosing to move their business to other countries, not only to so-called tax havens, but simply to other countries with a lower level of bureaucracy and fiscalism. This is often compounded by irrational and inefficient spending of public money and extensive spread, which makes entrepreneurs dissuasive to donate a significant part of their earnings to the state. On the one hand, they believe that they pay too much tribute, on the other hand, that their money is being wasted by some countries.  Of course, there is no doubt that criminals need to be prosecuted, but I am of the view that it is necessary to analyse the causes of these unacceptable phenomena in order to develop effective mechanisms for their elimination. I therefore believe that a committee of inquiry has been set up to deal with these issues as well.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the creation of the Committee of Inquiry as I see the need for better transparency in the area of tax and the necessity to have a body designated solely for investigation of alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of European Union law in relation to money laundering, tax evasion and tax avoidance. The Committee will investigate failures by the Commission and Member States to enforce and implement various EU directives on tax. I am looking forward to receiving a final report within 12 months of the adoption of this decision.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I have, of course, voted in favour of the decision to set up a commission of inquiry to examine allegations of breaches of EU law and maladministration in its application of money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion, as well as its responsibilities, its numerical composition and its mandate. I would like to acknowledge the excellent work of my colleague Hugues Bayet in this area.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of setting up a Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of European Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. Such an inquiry is important not only to clarify any wrongdoings, but also to safeguard the credibility of EU law. The Panama Papers have been a shock and we need to work to avoid it happening again.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The establishment of an committee of inquiry to investigate alleged infringements and irregularities in the application of Union law relating to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, its powers, the numerical composition and mandate have been supported. The Committee of Inquiry will be tasked with investigating a number of allegations relating to the implementation of the various directives, both by the European Commission and the Member States.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of an investigative committee to investigate allegations of infringement and mismanagement in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. I think it is essential that there is a specific working committee which deals with this issue in depth and that it is given the importance that this problem deserves in the European Parliament.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 337 Members have submitted an application to set up a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged infringements and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax fraud. I voted in favour, of course.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of an investigative committee to investigate allegations of infringement and mismanagement in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. I think it is essential that there is a specific working committee which deals with this issue in depth and that it is given the importance that this problem deserves in the European Parliament.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the setting up of a Committee of Inquiry to investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application of Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, its powers, numerical strength and term of office. The main task of the Committee of Inquiry is to investigate alleged contraventions and maladministration in the application, of European Union law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I supported the establishment of the Panama Papers Commission of Inquiry, which will have a mandate to investigate the non-application by banks and authorities of European laws against money laundering, circumvention and evasion. Finally, the spotlight will be on the role played by banks in creating a parallel world in which to launder dirty money and hide large sums of money stolen from the community, with the support of thousands of EU-based consultancy firms and law firms, in the intolerable complacency of European governments and supervisors. It is precisely in the obscure banking system protected by the Europe of fake transparency and the 'secret banking end', that the origin of the problem and the solution must be sought. This would be enough: the introduction of exemplary sanctions, up to the withdrawal of the banking licence, for banks that are complicit in abuses; maximum transparency, traceability and publicity of financial flows and tax information; effective, loophole-free anti-money laundering legislation, including trusts and introducing a publicly accessible mandatory register of final beneficiaries. These are, of course, simple measures whose implementation depends solely on the political will to change. The problem is that the status quo is too convenient for this Europe, which is enslaved to the interests of big business and banks.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution proposes to set up a commission of inquiry, which would be responsible, among other things, for examining allegations of breaches of EU law and maladministration in its application in the case of money laundering, tax evasion and tax evasion. On several occasions, the Commission has failed to ensure the application of directives on money laundering or administrative cooperation in the tax field; For their part, Member States have failed in their duty to implement these same directives, to name but a few examples. It is on these issues that the future commission of inquiry will have to look into. It will also be responsible for making any recommendations it deems necessary on the subject, and will have to address key issues such as information-sharing agreements or transparency in information on actual beneficiaries, i.e. those who benefit from transactions. Shortly after the Panama Papers scandal, such a proposal made sense; combating this kind of reprehensible practice is paramount, so I naturally voted in favour of this resolution and have no doubt that the members of my group will be very active there.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The establishment of a committee of inquiry to investigate the scandals revealed by the Panama Papers is an important political signal aimed at combating a practice that is at all levels reprehensible. However, the recent past, with the succession of tax scandals, leads us to conclude that we are in the presence of a structural problem and not just conjuncture. This committee, regardless of the fact-made facts about the protagonists of these practices, be they consulting firms, multinationals or national governments, should raise a broad reflection on the deeper causes that have created the conditions for these practices that are common and are generalised to the majority of large multinationals with the connivance of most of the so-called rich countries, many of them part of the EU. And these root causes are naturally associated with the deregulation of the financial system and the lifting of all restrictions on the movement of capital. We therefore regret that the mandate of this committee does not reflect this need. But with our work, we trust that it will impose itself, so that citizens understand that fraud and tax evasion will only be answered with a new economic model in which the sovereignty of states is above the agenda of large multinational companies.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Money laundering, tax evasion, non-compliance with European Union administrative rules have negative economic consequences not only for the world economy, but also for the economies of individual Member States and their regions. I am of the opinion that such criminal activities lead, as a result, to a slowdown in economic growth as a result of the increase in financial crime and thus a reduction in the cost of crime. I am convinced that the establishment of a committee of inquiry to examine the functioning of institutions operating in a tax haven such as Panama will help to significantly reduce the number of criminal activities. The Commission, which will have twelve months to prepare its final report, will certainly allow for a more in-depth look at the Panama Papers and for action to be taken to prevent financial crime.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this decision for obvious reasons. It is clear that we cannot accept malicious activities such as money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. The EU has laws in place to counter these. However, they will only be effective if they are abided by. More specifically, when it comes to enforcement and implementation, these are, respectively, the responsibilities of the Commission and the Member States. When there is any suspicion that they are not following up on their obligations, it is my duty as an MEP to support the call for an investigation.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution approving the establishment of a committee of inquiry by the European Parliament to investigate alleged misdemeanors or maladministration in the application of UNION law relating to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion. I would like to highlight the fact that the European Parliament is the democratic body par excellence of the European institutions and it has a duty to investigate what has happened and to determine why the current tax avoidance and avoidance measures have not been effective. I would stress that, in compliance with this mandate, Parliament should also propose in its final report measures to prevent the repetition of cases such as that of the Panama Papers. In addition to strengthening internal regulation of this matter, it is also essential to encourage third countries to apply minimum standards of good governance in tax matters and aggressive tax planning.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the proposal for a decision establishing a committee of inquiry to investigate alleged infringements and irregularities in the application of Union law relating to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion, its powers, numerical composition and mandate. In addition to detecting alleged infringements and irregularities, the creation of an investigative committee will indirectly contribute to the more effective harmonisation of directives in national rules relating to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is a step forward for relations between the European Union and the State of Palau. I voted in favour of reducing the bureaucratic burden on the free movement of persons in the event of travel for professional reasons, tourism or family reunification. This vote is a further sign of strengthening economic political relations between these states and the Union.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the visa waiver of citizens of the Republic of Palau for trips of up to 90 days to the European Union and for European citizens on trips of the same duration to the Republic of Palau. Although this agreement has been negotiated opaquely and without taking into account the positions of the European Parliament, I am in favour of visa-free processes which allow the right to freedom of movement to be exercised with fewer restrictions.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Palau when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. We have succeeded in reaching a comprehensive agreement with all political groups on this text which will strengthen social and cultural ties between the European Union and the Republic of Palau. This agreement will open up opportunities for EU citizens, who will now be able to travel to this country without a visa.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation of the agreement between the EU and the Republic of Palau on the short-stay visa waiver, as this agreement will create opportunities and advantages for European citizens, as any visa requirement to be able to travel to these countries will be abolished.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report plans to liberalise visas between the European Union and the Republic of Palau. In this case, the aim here is to lift the visa requirement for people travelling to the territory of one or more Member States of the Union for up to 90 days over a total period of 180 days. As usual, the Union continues its policy of removing borders, which it has repeatedly denounced as unnecessary and harmful obstacles to the free movement of people, goods and goods. This is a pernicious drift which must be opposed in the interests of the peoples, whether they are European or not. Moreover, given the scale of the migration crisis, there is an urgent need to freeze all forms of visa liberalisation. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency, I wish to confirm I voted against this report. I do not believe that the European Union should be negotiating waiving visa agreements on behalf of the UK.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text as advocated by the committee on the merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for an EU-Palau agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short stays. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau shall be governed by the Partnership Agreement between the Members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part, the so-called Cotonou Agreement. The proposed Agreement establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and Palau travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service and/or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose other than persons who are on paid employment.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. While the Republic of Palau and the Kingdom of Tonga, small Pacific archipelagos with less than 150,000 inhabitants, are not a real problem, the third country to benefit today from the largesse of the Eurocrats, Colombia, with 48 million inhabitants and gangrene by drug trafficking. The technocrats in Brussels are giving a real boost to their irresponsible massive immigration policy, which has disastrous consequences on the already precarious balance of our European nations, both economically and socially, as well as identity and security. Voted in the European Parliament by the socialist and EPP groups, including LR MEPs, this visa exemption opens up new routes of illegal immigration and will exacerbate the migration chaos. While the European Commission foresees the arrival of an additional 3 million migrants by 2017, the National Front reminds us that the only policy to avoid social, economic and cultural chaos is to restore our national borders, put an end to all forms of laxity in the face of illegal immigration, drastically reduce legal immigration and reaffirm our identity.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved this agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas of up to 90 days over any 180-day period for the Republic of Palau, a democratically stable state and part of the ACP countries.  This will not only strengthen economic and cultural exchanges, but also promote political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Gabriel report approving the agreement between the EU and Palau on the visa waiver for short-stay stays. The text establishes an exemption for Union citizens and palau citizens travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons regardless of the reason for the stay provided that this is not linked to the performance of a paid activity. This is an important agreement which favours the intensification of relations with the Pacific state and the development of a more regular political dialogue.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, the purpose of which is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other contracting party , where the stay does not exceed 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Visa Waiver Agreement for short-term stays is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report for consistency with the letter and spirit of the Cotonou Agreement. This island republic is a country fully committed to democracy and human rights. Visa waiver will improve Europe-Pacific relations and, in particular, can encourage the archipelago's economy based mostly on the services sector and with a tourism industry in full expansion. It is consistent with the EU-Asia-Pacific partnership agreement.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the exemption of short-stay visas. The text provides for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Republic of Palau travelling to the EU for 90 days or less. This policy of massive visa liberalisation seems to me to be completely irresponsible in the context of the eu's migration crisis. This is not an attitude of distrust towards the citizens of this Republic of Micronesia, but visas allow any state to control who goes to its territory and under what conditions; the fact that France, as a country of the Union, cannot have a hold on part of its migration flows means that we cannot allow this situation to be aggravated by an inconsequential enlargement of this visa liberalisation policy.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text on the EU-Palau agreement for short-term visas is well structured and has no problems. I therefore intended to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation by which Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of this bilateral agreement in development of the amendments introduced by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014, which transferred the Republic of Palau to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that regulation, the Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations with a view to concluded the bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, which was signed on 7 December.  The signed Agreement establishes a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Palau nationals travelling to the territory of the other party where the stay does not exceed 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the short stay of visa waiver in the case of a short stay. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau shall be governed by the Partnership Agreement between the Members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part, the so-called Cotonou Agreement. The agreement signed establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and Palau travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service and/or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose other than persons who are on paid employment. This agreement on the short stay of visa waiver is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The visa waiver agreement for short-stays is both a success of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, which is of great political importance, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  With regard to mobility, the available data show that the reliability of visa applicants is high and there are few applications rejected. The country poses no threat to irregular migration, security or public order. I also consider it important that the visa waiver is not a negligible means of eddation between the people of the European Union and the citizens of the country concerned. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the partnership in a full, cheaper and simpler way.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the proposed report. The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the result of deepening relations between the EU and the Palau, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement. The agreement is also an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and deepening political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement will be able to have positive effects by simplifying travel conditions for entrepreneurs, enabling investment and promoting tourism. Palaua's economy is mainly based on the service sector, which contributes 86% of GDP, and the tourism sector is rapidly developing due to the increased number of air links to the island. The Palau Archipelago has one of the highest living standards in Pacific countries. Investment and trade between the EU and Palau are still fluctuating and weak in absolute and relative terms, but they have a great development potential that will be further strengthened by such an agreement.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. These three agreements provide for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Palau nationals travelling to the EU for up to 90 days of 180-day stay. I have nothing against the citizens of these countries, but given the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, we are opposed to any visa liberalisation. So I voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Palau when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Republic of Palau is today a democratic country with a strong rule of law and respectful of human rights, in recent years very active, in particular, in promoting and defending the principle of equality between men and women. From this point of view, I believe that the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and that territory on mutual exemption from short-stay visas is an important instrument capable, by promoting trade, investment and the development of tourism, of further strengthening cooperation between the two political entities and of encouraging the promotion of these principles at international level.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and nationals of the Republic of Palau who travel to one of the EU Member States for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. At a time when the Member States of the Union are facing an unprecedented migration crisis, it would be absolutely inappropriate to conclude such an agreement which will speed up the migration influx into Europe. We know full well that our "old continent" is extremely attractive, especially in terms of social protection, encouraging a significant number of tourists to come and enjoy these social benefits; it would therefore be wise to fight social tourism instead of liberalising their visas. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement on the exemption from the requirement to hold a short-stay visa is a strengthening of the partnership between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, constituting progress towards deepening economic and cultural relations and enhancing political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This agreement will have a positive impact on tourism as well as facilitating investment. It should be noted that the economy of the Republic of Palau focuses on the services sector, having an effervescent tourism sector, and this agreement will foster the support of the economic sectors. With regard to concerns about illegal migration, confidence in visa applicants in Palau is high, with a low level of visa refusal, as a result, this republic poses no threat from the perspective of mobility and public security. I have expressed myself in favour of this agreement, because I believe that it is a partnership that benefits both parties, helping to extend the rights of free movement for the benefit of both Union citizens and nationals of the Republic of Palau.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation today because the short-stay visa waiver agreement is to be seen as the culmination of good relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, on the one hand, and the European Community and its Member States, on the other, the so-called Cotonou Agreement. The short-stay visa waiver is, in my view, of great political significance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement and is a concrete instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations and facilitating political dialogue on a number of issues still on the table, such as human rights and fundamental freedoms. This agreement will have positive effects by simplifying travel conditions for entrepreneurs and facilitating tourism. I would like to point out that Palau's economy is mainly based on the services sector, which accounts for 86% of GDP, with an expanding tourism sector, thanks in part to the increase in the number of flights serving the island.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on short-stay visa waivers with Palau, although it will not apply to Ireland since Ireland does not participate in the Schengen acquis. For other EU countries, this vote means that citizens from Palau and the EU will have a maximum period of 90 days for visa-free travel when visiting the territory of the other party.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of the Agreement that allows visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and of Palau. I believe short-stay visa waiver can intensify the relationship between the EU and Palau as well as effectively promote cultural communications and business collaborations.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Short-term visa waiver has important political significance and marks an important stage in the EU's relations with other countries. It is also an instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The State of Tonga has met the requirements to access it.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The visa waiver agreement was initialled in Brussels on 7 December 2015 and its full implementation will begin after approval by the European Parliament. The document establishes visa-free travel for Union citizens and palau citizens travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a short stay. The agreement excludes stays, even if short, aimed at carrying out a paid activity. The political and economic stability of the Republic of Palau as well as the absence of situations of repatriation or irregular immigration by the citizens of Palau are the basis for the conclusion of the agreement which may have positive effects for both parties. The simplification of visa procedures will facilitate investment in the island which, together with the increase in the number of flights to that destination, will be able to promote the development of tourism, which is an important part of the territory's economy. For these reasons, I therefore decided to vote in favour of the agreement.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the short-stay visa waiver agreement and believe that it contributes decisively to the strengthening and deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the recommendation on the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the short-stay visa waiver is a step towards improving relations between the two sides, also with a view to improving the conditions of movement and living of citizens. As I believe it is moving in the right direction, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The strengthening of the number of flights serving the island of Palau has allowed the development of a strong tourist economy that is still growing. I am convinced that the exemption for the Republic of Palau of short-stay visas can really simplify the conditions of many entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and stimulate tourism. This exemption would also further strengthen relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, representing a strengthening of economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues. Furthermore, the country poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. I strongly believe in this initiative because it demonstrates Europe's willingness to enter into agreements with third countries in order to facilitate travel for those who would have had unpleasant difficulties before. I therefore voted in favour for the above reasons.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ After the adoption of the Regulation on 20 May 2014, the Council adopted, on 9 October 2014, a decision authorising the Commission to open negotiations with a view to the conclusion of the bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau. Negotiations commenced on 17 December 2014 and ended on 27 May 2015 (Palau) and10 June 2015 (Union). The agreement was signed on 7 December 2015 in Brussels. Since that date, the agreement has applied provisionally, pending approval by the European Parliament. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Palau when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union carries out a visa policy, in particular with regard to the exemption of short-stay visas. This exemption is defined at European level as it is valid for all Member States except the United Kingdom and Ireland. Moreover, the various requirements for the conclusion of the agreement include reciprocity. In other words, European citizens also no longer need a visa. Another criterion that must be underlined is respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, which is also the case here.  It is up to the European Parliament to give its consent to the agreement for its establishment. That's right.  For all this and because this Agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations with the Republic of Palau, I vote in favour of its celebration.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposed agreement on short-term visa waiver is an important tool for strengthening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau. Such an agreement would strengthen economic and cultural relations, help to develop a political dialogue in the field of human rights and fundamental freedoms. I also voted in favour of the project in view of the benefits it would bring for tourism, investment and entrepreneurship. In addition, the agreement would be an opportunity for the Republic of Palau to invest more in its resources, such as fisheries, tourism and to increase the diversification of the economy in order to reduce its dependence on external assistance.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Palau when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The report advocates a visa waiver covering all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.  I see the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau which is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement – and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.   Palau is a democratic republic completely committed to human rights, which are guaranteed under the Constitution, and like the European Union, it embraces the values and principles of democracy and good governance and upholds human rights and the rule of law. I also register that the country has made great progress in recent years, particularly as regards women’s rights and human trafficking; hence I support more positive cooperation based on mutual respect for our values and principles.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the visa waiver of citizens of the Republic of Palau for trips of up to 90 days to the European Union and for European citizens on trips of the same duration to the Republic of Palau.
