Although this agreement has been negotiated opaquely and without taking into account the positions of the European Parliament, I am in favour of visa-free processes which allow the right to freedom of movement to be exercised with fewer restrictions.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau are governed by the Cotonou Agreement. The signed agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for the benefit of Union citizens and Palau nationals travelling within the territory of the other Party. It will have positive effects, simplifying travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitating investment and dynamicising tourism. I voted for the closeness between the Peoples of Europe and those of the Pacific Region.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part. By amending Regulation (EC) No 539/2001, the Republic of Palau has been transferred to third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The agreement was signed in 2015 and has since been provisionally applied, pending approval by the European Parliament.  The Agreement provides visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and residents of the Palau Republic for travel to the territory of the other Party for 90 days within 180 days. The visa waiver agreement would simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and have a positive impact on tourism. Palau has great potential for development and the EU is therefore negotiating a comprehensive economic partnership agreement with Palau. The AGREEMENT between the EU and Palau would strengthen the relationship between the Member States and Palau. Visa-free travel is also important for the transport of peoples in Europe and the Pacific.  Today, the European Parliament has given its consent to the conclusion of the agreement, which I voted in favour of.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Last December, the EU signed identical agreements on the short-stay visa waiver with the Republic of Palau, the Kingdom of Tonga and the Republic of Colombia. As provided for in the agreements, EU citizens will be able to spend 90 days without a visa in these countries in any 180-day period, as will nationals of those countries in the EU. In order to benefit from visa-free travel, EU citizens and signatory countries must have a valid passport: ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special. However, the abolition of short-stay visas does not apply to persons travelling for gainful employment. The Agreements are already applied provisionally after unanimous support from the Schengen Governments of the Council, but the consent of the European Parliament is required for their full conclusion. The United Kingdom and Ireland will not participate in the agreement as their visa regimes remain subject to national legislation. I personally see these agreements as a way of promoting people-to-people contacts in the countries in question. They should provide trade opportunities in view of the increase in tourist numbers and help promote economic relations between the EU and these countries. I therefore did not object to these agreements and voted in favour of them.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this agreement, which represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement will open up opportunities and advantages for EU citizens too and could have positive effects by simplifying travel for businesspeople, facilitating investment and boosting tourism.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the exemption of short-stay visas. This visa-free regime for EU citizens and Palau nationals for a stay of up to 90 days over a 180-day period should strengthen our economic and cultural relations by positively impacting both contracting parties.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Palau nationals travelling to the EU for up to 90 days of 180-day stay. In view of the current migration crisis, any visa liberalisation would be an irresponsible measure. However, risks are considered "manageable" through increased cooperation on return and the implementation of border controls. Having disagreed with this approach, I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the EU-Palau agreement on the short-stay visa waiver. According to the agreement signed in December last year, a new visa-free regime applies to European citizens and reciprocally for palau citizens when they travel to Europe for 90 days. It is important to note that this visa regime does not apply to citizens taking trips for work or other paid activity. I believe that the benefits of this agreement will have a beneficial effect on the tourism sector and promote bilateral business relations.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is completely wrong to think that the short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau and is a complementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the mistaken view that there is a high degree of confidence in visa applicants , which results from the low percentage of discharges. As with the other countries of the 'Koton Agreement', it is inconceivable that the practice of signing visa waiver agreements should be applied and provisionally implemented before they are approved by the European Parliament.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The Economy of Palau is mainly based on the services sector, which accounts for 86% of GDP, with a tourism sector expanding, also due to the strengthening number of flights to the island. The European Union is currently negotiating a comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with 14 countries in the Pacific region, including Palau. Fishing, conquiliculture and tourism represent the main development sectors. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, with high political importance in the framework of the Cotonou Agreement, and is also an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue on various issues , including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it: we have nothing against the citizens of these countries, but given the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, we are opposed to any visa liberalisation.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau are in line with the Partnership Agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States. The Agreement provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of Palau who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. Visa waiver is an important element for bringing the peoples closer to Europe and the Pacific. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens to fully benefit from the ACP-EU partnership. As on other similar occasions we voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the EU and the Republic of Palau, as it is a key instrument for strengthening economic, political and cultural relations between the two parties. Palau is a democratic republic that fully respects human rights, enshrined in its constitution. The visa waiver agreement will allow citizens to benefit fully from the ACP-EU partnership and to travel more cheaply and practically.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 This particular agreement is about continuing to deepen the above-standard relations between the EU and the Republic of Palau. The visa waiver agreement will have positive effects for both parties, as it simplifies travel conditions for entrepreneurs while facilitating investment and dynamising tourism. The agreement in question has the potential to strengthen the area of investment and trade, which have strong development potential in the future.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report as it does not present any critical elements.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is completely wrong to think that the short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau and is a complementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the mistaken view that there is a high degree of confidence in visa applicants , which results from the low percentage of discharges. As with the other countries of the 'Koton Agreement', it is inconceivable that the practice of signing visa waiver agreements should be applied and provisionally implemented before they are approved by the European Parliament. For these reasons I am voting against the EU-Palau Agreement on short-stay visa waiver.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This Agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau which is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement – and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement could have positive effects by simplifying travel for business people, facilitating investment and boosting tourism. The EU is currently negotiating comprehensive economic partnership agreements with 14 Pacific countries, including Palau. Fishing, shellfish farming and tourism represent key development sectors. Furthermore, Palau has announced its intention of obtaining 20% its energy from renewable resources by 2020 and the government has launched economic diversification measures in order to reduce dependence on external aid. Considering that this agreement will open up opportunities and advantages also for EU citizens, I supported its adoption.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we give our consent to the agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Republic of Palau when travelling to the each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days. We welcome the agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas as politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement. This is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and enhancing political dialogue. We however call on the Commission to observe any developments in relation to the criteria on clandestine immigration, public policy and security.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation, pursuant to compliance with the agreements signed between the European Union and the Republic of Palau. This agreement, based on the exemption of visas for short-term stays, this is an achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, and gives political content to the Cotonou Agreement, as well as being a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as serving to intensify political dialogue.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the adoption of this agreement as it aims to strengthen the ties between the EU and the Republic of Palau and deepen the cooperation between us. Palau shares many of the values of the European Union; such as democracy, human rights, the rule of law and good governance; and I hope that this agreement can serve to be a step towards a more enhanced political dialogue between the EU and the Republic of Palau. The agreement would also make business travel easier and serve to facilitate investment and boost tourism between the EU and Palau.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As coordinator of my ECR Group for the EU-ACP delegation, I voted in favour of the EU-Palau visa waiver agreement for short-stay stays. I have discussed this with colleagues in the small Pacific island state on several occasions at past ACP meetings and I support the approach adopted in the agreement.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the visa-free regime between the European Union and the Republic of Palau. It will apply to all categories of persons and all travel purposes, except for for-profit stays. The visa waiver is valid for a maximum of 90 days in a period of 180 days.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to initiate negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, the purpose of which is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other contracting party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Visa Waiver Agreement for short-term stays is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement between the EU and Palau will open up opportunities and advantages for both the citizens of Palau and the EU, as any existing visa requirements for EU citizens to travel to Palau will be eliminated.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Palau when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the agreement on a visa waiver for short-stay citizens of Palau. However, we are critical of the procedure chosen and leaving Parliament out, and it is simply being asked for approval.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my Group ALDE, supported the agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas between the European Union and the Republic of Palau. This is politically significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement – and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa-waiver agreement will simplify travel for business people on both sides, facilitating investment and boosting tourism. Palau’s economy is based primarily on the service sector, which accounts for 86% of GDP, with a booming tourism sector, thanks also to the increase in the number of flights serving the island. Palau has one of the highest standards of living of the Pacific. Relations with the EU have strengthened since the admission in 2000 of Palau as an ACP country. While investment and trade with Palau are currently unstable and low in terms of value and in relative terms, they have strong potential for development which could benefit European investors and businesses.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement as it expands the relationship between the EU and the Republic of Palau. It will also greatly benefit EU citizens traveling to the country as they can avail of visa-free travel.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. If we take the particular case of the Republic of Palau, I see no difficulty in lifting the requirement for a short-stay visa, i.e. three months over a period of 180 days, for nationals of this small island of Oceania of nearly 20,000 inhabitants, 40% of whom are Christians. The risk of migration is zero. However, beyond this small Republic, I wonder about the strategic choice of granting short-stay visa exemptions to countries with high migration and security risks such as Ukraine, Georgia and Turkey. Visa policy is not just an instrument. It is also a political and geostrategic choice. However, it must not only take into account what it will bring to the third country concerned, but also the impact it will have on the Member States.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Agreement on relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau is governed by the Partnership Agreement between the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States and the Member States of the European Union, an agreement called the Cotonou Agreement. It provides for short-stay visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Republic of Palau travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. I voted in favour of this report with direct and positive effects for investors, the development of tourism and economic progress.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Recommendation on the Draft Decision of the Council on the Conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the abolition of short-stay visas, as this gives consent for the conclusion of this Agreement, which I think will also be useful, as it will most help simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and stimulate the development of the tourism sector. Palau's economy is primarily based on the services sector, which accounts for 86% of GDP, so this Agreement is more than desirable.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. These three agreements provide for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and nationals of Palau, Tonga and Colombia who travel to the EU for up to 90 days over any 180-day period. We have nothing against the citizens of these countries, but given the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, we are opposed to any visa liberalisation. I objected to these three texts.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since all the necessary conditions have been met, I voted in favour of visa-free travel for short stays in favour of Palau. Visa-free travel for short stays of up to 90 days applies mainly to tourists, diplomats, etc. At the same time, this agreement represents the culmination of the deepening of relations between the EU and the Republic of Palau, which is very important politically within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement. And it is another way to intensify economic and cultural relations and strengthen political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the conclusion of an agreement with the Republic of Palau to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report concerns an agreement between the EU and the Republic of Palau on the visa waiver for the citizens of Palau in the European Union. Visa waiver is a national task and better lifted in the Council or the Schengen Group than at pan-European level. That is why I am voting against this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this agreement to enable visa-free travel between other EU Member States and Palau, Tonga and Columbia. The agreements would not affect the UK, which has its own national visa agreements with these countries.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution provides for a reciprocal visa waiver for short-term stays, up to a maximum of 90 days within a 180-day period, between the EU-Schengen states and the Republic of Palau. Since this visa waiver is only valid if the traveller is not required to carry out a paid activity in the destination country during the stay and an official identification document must be available, there is no risk of irregular labour migration. On the contrary, this agreement simplifies travel, establishes personal contacts and strengthens the tourist economy. I agree to the agreement for these reasons.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The Republic of Palau is a constructive partner of the EU in the context of the Cotonou Agreement. In this regard, the agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau. It is also a clear signal that the EU is seeking to facilitate political dialogue with Palau in terms of protecting the environment in relation to climate change, defending human rights, and gender equality. Last but not least, I supported EU-Palau agreement on the short-stay visa waiver because the country does not present any threat to the EU in terms of irregular migration and security issues.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The aim of the nascent agreement between the EU and the Republic of Palau is governed by the Cotonou Agreement, the aim of which is to facilitate the issue of short-stay visas. It takes into account both the situation of Member States which do not implement the Treaty of Shengen and the visa waiver for EU and Palau citizens travelling to other territories for a period of ninety days over a period of one hundred and eighty days. This exemption applies to all categories of persons, irrespective of the reason for their stay, with the exception of persons staying there for paid employment. It will simplify travel and investment arrangements, stimulate tourism and strengthen economic and cultural relations, as well as political dialogue on sensitive issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms. For these reasons, I support the implementation of this recommendation.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I am opposed to any visa liberalisation.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the exemption of short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Palau nationals travelling to the EU for up to 90 days of 180 days. I have nothing against the citizens of this country, but given the scale of the migration crisis in Europe and the security problem that follows, I am opposed to any further visa liberalisation.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The text proposes to establish a visa-free travel regime between nationals of both parties, for a maximum of 90 days over any 180-day period. Given the current context of the migration crisis, I am opposed to any visa liberalisation, which is why I am voting against this text.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the visa waiver of citizens of the Republic of Palau for trips of up to 90 days to the European Union and for European citizens on trips of the same duration to the Republic of Palau. Although this agreement has been negotiated opaquely and without taking into account the positions of the European Parliament, I am in favour of visa-free processes which allow the right to freedom of movement to be exercised with fewer restrictions.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Palau Republic. I also consider that it is of significant political significance under the Cotonou Agreement and reinforces political dialogue on various issues, as well as economic and cultural relations.  The Republic of Palau has proven to be a democratic republic committed entirely to human rights, which are enshrined in its constitution. With this agreement, we will achieve positive affections in our economy, as travel conditions for entrepreneurs will be simplified, so that investments will be facilitated and tourism will be energized.  In addition, the available data show that this country poses no threat ely in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order.  For the reasons set out above and because with visa waiver citizens will also be able to benefit directly from the agreement, with fewer economic and practical burdens, I give my positive vote for approval.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution provides for a reciprocal visa waiver for short-term stays, up to a maximum of 90 days within a 180-day period, between the EU-Schengen states and the Republic of Palau. Since this visa waiver is only valid if the traveller is not required to carry out a paid activity in the destination country during the stay and an official identification document must be available, there is no risk of irregular labour migration. On the contrary, this agreement simplifies travel, establishes personal contacts and strengthens the tourist economy. I voted in favour of the agreement for these reasons.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of visa-free travel between the EU and the Republic of Palau for short periods of 90 days for travel purposes except for carrying out a paid activity.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 With this proposal, the citizens of Palau will be able to travel to the EU without visas and in return we will be able to travel to Palau without visas. This is visa-free travel for tourist or business purposes for a maximum period of 90 days. Palau is a republic in the Pacific Ocean, which has about 20 thousand inhabitants. The rate of visa refusals is low and Palau does not even pose a threat when it comes to irregular migration. That's why I was on visa waiver.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau are governed by a Partnership Agreement between members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific States Group, on the one hand, and the European Union by the Cotonou Agreement, on the other. The signed Agreement allows citizens of the European Union and the citizens of Palau to stay without a visa on the territory of another Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any period of 180 days, which applies to all categories of persons whose purpose of the trip does not include the performance of paid activity. The report underlines that this Agreement will have a positive impact, as it will simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment, stimulate the development of the tourism sector and improve the Union's trade exchange with Palau.  The EU is currently negotiating a comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with 14 Pacific countries, including Palau. Fishing, shellfish farming and tourism are the sectors that record the highest level of development. Among other things, Palau has announced its intention to draw 20% of its energy from renewable sources before 2020, and the Government has launched a diversification of the economy to reduce its dependence on external aid. Palau poses no threat in terms of irregular migration, security and public order ither. As visa waiver is an important factor in bringing European citizens and pacific citizens closer together, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU-Palau Agreement on the abolition of short-stay visas provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and Palau citizens travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of travellers (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) travelling for any purpose, except for the purpose of gainful employment. Relations between the EU and Palau have strengthened since their second intake in 2000 within the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States. Palau is a highly developed democratic republic with absolutely more presuring (86%) services sector in the economy. In the context of the agreement, it is worth noting that trust in Palau visa applicants is high and the level of rejection of visa applications is low. There were no illegal immigrants or asylum seekers from Palau in the EU in the same year 2014. Consequently, given the dynamics and future prospects of eu-Pacific relations, it was logical to vote positively.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the short-stay visa waiver because it is not complete and documented.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the EU-Palau agreement on short-stay visa waivers is in my favour. This agreement is based on the intention to deepen relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, thus intensifying cultural and economic relations. Simplifying travel conditions also facilitates and encourages investment by promoting general improvement. These are some of the main reasons why I am in favour.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Relations between the EU and the Republic of Palau are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (Coton Agreement). The short-stay visa waiver agreement can facilitate entrepreneurs' journeys, attracting investment and boosting tourism. Palau's economy relies on the services sector, which generates 86% of GDP. By adopting this agreement, we can contribute to the convergence of relations between the EU and the Pacific region, thus strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as dialogue on various issues. I voted in favour of such an agreement.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The Visa Waiver Agreement for Short Stays is a step forward in relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau and is of significant political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. My support, therefore, for the recommendation of this Parliament, which is a new rapprochement of the European and Pacific peoples.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Partnership Agreement between the EU and the African, Caribbean and Pacific States also includes the Republic of Palau. Through this agreement and under Regulation No 509/2014, the Republic of Palau is among the countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement for crossing the external borders of the Member States of the Union. Since the entry into force of the Rules of Procedure, the Commission has been in negotiations with the Republic of Palau for a bilateral agreement which remains for approval by Parliament. This agreement shall include the right of Union or Palau citizens to travel to the territory of the Parties without a visa requirement for a maximum of 90 days. I am voting in favour of the adoption of the agreement so that there can be closer relations between the Union and that country at political and cultural level, with a view to promoting the basic principles and values of the Union and strengthening the protection of human rights.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The agreement between the European Union and the island state of Palau is dealt with here. There are currently no credible arguments in favour of this agreement. This is where the European Union is trying to attract competences. Therefore, I cannot support this agreement.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the visa waiver agreement with the Republic of Palau. This agreement will facilitate travel for both tourism and business purposes, and is therefore likely to promote tourism and facilitate investment and economic development.  Palau, like the European Union, defends the principles and values of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law. This country does not pose a risk of illegal immigration, either security or public order.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. When cooperation with certain third countries permits, a reciprocal short-stay visa exemption (usually mainly for tourism) is negotiated. The Council, representing the states, decides. The criteria observed are as much the political situation, respect for human rights, as well as the type of migration. In practical terms, the absence of "irregular migration risk". This is the Republic of Palau, next to the Philippines, with some 21,000 souls and as many coconut trees to offer. I see no reason to oppose this tourism, but taken in a broader context, it is also a matter of softening the country with which the Union is currently negotiating a regional free trade agreement. Considering, however, that the development of tourism and cultural exchanges is a key advantage for the development of this country, I vote for it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens as well as nationals of the Republic of Palau, for a maximum of 90 days out of 180. Being opposed to any visa liberalisation, in view of the migration crisis we are experiencing, I objected to this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU-Palau Agreement under the Cotonou Agreement provides for visa-free travel for CITIZENS of the European Union and citizens of Palau who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. This is an important agreement for strengthening relations between the two parties, in particular in economic and cultural areas, enabling dialogue and learning on issues of civil liberties and human rights. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's recommendation on the draft Council decision.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Palau when travelling in the other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I supported this resolution as it is an opportunity to deepen economic relations and develop tourism.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I am in favour of the Council's draft decision on the conclusion between the European Union and the Republic of Palau of an agreement on the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement signed in 2015 provides for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the Republic of Palau for a period of 90 days over any 180-day period on European soil and vice versa. This treatment will apply to anyone other than those engaged in paid work, in which case it will be up to the Member State to legislate.   I am in this agreement because it will send a strong political message within the framework of the Cotonou agreements by strengthening relations between the EU and Palau. On a cultural and political level, this agreement is important because Palau defends the same values and principles of good governance as the Union and has made great progress in relation to human rights. The agreement could also have a beneficial economic impact by simplifying investment and boosting various economic sectors.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – Relations between the European Union and its Member States and Palau are governed by the so-called The Cotonou Agreement. Nationals of the Republic of Palau shall be exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. Citizens of the Union and citizens of Palau may travel without a visa to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. The lifting of the visa requirement applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) travelling for any reason other than the pursuit of a paid activity. The agreement on short-stay visa waiver significantly strengthens economic and cultural relations and is the basis for political dialogue on respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, especially in the field of gender equality. The Constitution of the Palau Republic enshrines respect for human rights, the role of democracy and the rule of law, and Palau is also a signatory to international treaties for the protection of human rights. This agreement will also help entrepreneurs by facilitating investment and adjusting their travel conditions and improving tourism in the country. In view of the above, I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement, which represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, which is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement – and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The agreement can have positive effects by simplifying travel for business people, facilitating investment and boosting tourism. Politically, Palau has made great progress in recent years, particularly as regards women’s rights and human trafficking. It has adopted legislation specifically relating to human trafficking and has become a member of the International Labour Organization. Regarding gender equality, more women are now to be found in administrative posts and elected office. Similarly, Palau has signed all the international conventions on human rights and is receiving EU support to ratify and implement them. The current political dialogue between the EU and Palau is focused on human rights and gender equality, and both parties are discussing how to collaborate more closely on these issues. In this context, the agreement represents a significant step towards more regular and enhanced political dialogue.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council submitted a draft decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the exemption from short-stay visas. In order to adopt the decision, it must obtain parliament's consent. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Relations between the EU and the Republic of Palau are governing the Partnership Agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific States, on the one hand, and the European Union and its Member States, on the other, called the 'Cotonou Agreement'. As part of the amendment to Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, the Republic of Palau has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States.  The Council adopted a decision in 2014 authorising the Commission to open negotiations for the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the EU and the Republic of Palau. The Agreement provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of Palau who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days.  In view of the foregoing, I am in favour of concluding the Agreement.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. In view of the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, I oppose any visa liberalisation, and therefore vote against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement to enable visa-free travel between other EU Member States and Palau. The agreement would not affect the UK, which has its own national visa agreement with this country.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and nationals of the Republic of Palau for stays of up to 90 days over any 180-day period. As long as there is reciprocity and the length of stays is limited, there are no difficulties with visa exemption for non-EU nationals.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mariya Gabriel's report. The European Parliament must give its approval to the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, which has already been negotiated between the Republic of Palau and the European Commission. The aim of the proposal is to reach an agreement with the Republic of Palau to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas. This agreement takes into account the situation of the Member States which do not yet apply the Schengen acquis in its entirety. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and nationals of the Republic of Palau who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over the entire 180-day period. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official, or special) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Palau is an archipelago composed of more than 500 islands, part of the Micronesia region in the western Pacific Ocean. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau are governed by a partnership agreement also known as the Cotonou Agreement. I voted for this recommendation that will provide visa-free travel for the citizens of the two parts when travelling to the other for a maximum period of 90 days.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Palau when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against the agreement because I consider the privilege of Pala's residents to be completely unnecessary and the wrong signal in view of the current global migration situation.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Agreement provides for the possibility for citizens of the European Union and Palau to travel on a short-stay visa-free basis to the territory of the other Party. The agreement will help facilitate investment and promote tourism.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver for those wishing to travel between the EU and Palau is further confirmation of the policy of rapprochement between European citizens and Pacific citizens, as stated by my colleague in her report. I also note that the measure will allow an increase in travel that will bring benefits both in terms of investment and in terms of tourism. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this agreement with the Republic of Palau on short-stay visa facilitation, which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Republic of Palau for all purposes other than carrying out a paid activity when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party. This is to be available for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period and takes into account the situation of Member States outside of the Schengen acquis.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the draft decision to conclude an agreement between the EU and the Republic of Palau with a desire to deepen relations between the EU and the Republic of Palau. It strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, such as those relating to human rights and fundamental freedoms. It is to be expected that this agreement will have a positive impact, as it will simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and stimulate the development of the tourism sector, which is very important because the Economy of Palau is primarily based on the services sector, which accounts for 86% of GDP, and fisheries, shellfish farming and tourism are the sectors that have the highest level of development.  Given that in recent years Palau has made great progress, in particular with regard to the strong political participation of women, but also in the area of preventing human trafficking, that it is a signatory to all international human rights conventions, for which ratification and enforcement is supported by the EU, as Palau poses no threat in terms of irregular migration or the security of public order , I believe that visa waiver is a good solution that will greatly reduce the cost of travel and bring european citizens and citizens of that Pacific country closer.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. In view of the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, I oppose any visa liberalisation, and therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I welcome the conclusion of the Short Stay Visa Waiver Agreement aimed at deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau and has great political weight under the Cotonou Agreement. It further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I agree with rapporteur Mariya Gabriel that the Visa Waiver Agreement will have a positive impact, as it will simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and stimulate the development of the tourism sector. Palau's economy is primarily based on the services sector, which accounts for 86% of GDP, in addition to the full-scale tourism sector thanks to the increased number of flights serving the island. The standard of living of the Palauan archipelago is one of the highest in the Pacific. Since 2000, when Palau was accepted into the AKP category, relations with the Union have intensified. When it comes to investment and trade with Palau, from a value point of view and in relative terms they are still small and fluctuate, although they represent a great potential for development. The EU is currently negotiating a comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with 14 Pacific countries, including Palau.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau are being governed by the Partnership Agreement between the States of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific. The Agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Palau who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. Visa waiver is an important element for bringing the peoples closer to Europe and the Pacific. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens to fully benefit from the ACP-EU partnership. We voted in favour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau are governed by a Partnership Agreement between members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Countries Group, on the one hand, and the European Union and its Member States, on the other. The visa waiver agreement is of great importance as it strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  I supported MEP Gabriel's recommendation to simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and boost the development of the tourism sector. The abolition of short-stay visas is an essential step in bringing European citizens and citizens of the Pacific region closer.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Visa waiver for short stays between the European Union and the Republic of Palau is the logical procedure with regard to the Cotonou Agreement. In this context, as part of the Sustainable Development Strategy, the Union is committed to deepening cooperation and integration of African, Caribbean and Pacific states into the world economy. Visa waiver can have a positive impact on the development of tourism and services and therefore on the overall economic development of this island state. Moreover, Palau is a democratic state that emphasizes human rights and thus represents a relevant and credible partner.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau are governed by the Partnership Agreement known as the 'Cotonou Agreement'. The Agreement provides for visa-free travel for union citizens and citizens of the Republic of Palau who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of those aimed at carrying out a paid activity. I voted in favour of this agreement because it represents the conclusion of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which approves the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the exemption of short-stay visas.  This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Palau nationals travelling to the territory of the other party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The Republic of Palau is a democratic republic that fully respects the human rights enshrined in its constitution. In line with the fundamental values of the European Union, Palau upholds the principles of freedom, democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms.  The progress made on women's rights and trafficking in human beings, as well as the participation of the International Labour Organisation, confirms Palau's democratic commitment and establishes the common basis for the conclusion of this Agreement. Moreover, the agreement represents the culmination of closer relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, and will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitating investment and streamlining tourism. As regards the dangers of mobility and the risks posed by the opening of borders, it should be noted that the available data attest to the confidence placed in applicants for national visas in the Palau Republic, whose visa applications enjoy a low rate of refusal. Because I consider it important to encourage the rapprochement of the Peoples of Europe and the Pacific, and thus to value the countries that respect fundamental rights, I supported this resolution.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Agreement providing for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Palau who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, with high political importance, and is also an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement could have positive effects, simplifying travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitating investment and streamlining tourism. Palau is a democratic republic that fully respects the human rights enshrined in the Constitution and defends the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law. Visa waiver is an important element for bringing the peoples closer to Europe and the Pacific.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has just voted this afternoon in favour of the introduction of a new, more flexible visa regime between the European Union and the Republic of Palau.  This visa-free agreement for short-term stays is a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and this country of Oceania.  In line with the Cotonou Agreement (ACP-EU) that binds the Union with the Pacific States, this agreement is an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations with the Republic of Palau and intensifying political dialogue. On the economic front, investment and trade with Palau have a strong development potential that this agreement is able to encourage. The country is expected to receive EUR 1.6 million under the 11th EDF (2014-2020), which focuses on renewable energy and civil society. In terms of tourism, the visa-free agreement will allow the 21,000 Paluans to discover the riches of Europe.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, with high political importance in the framework of the Cotonou Agreement, and is also an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue on various issues , including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation by which Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of this bilateral agreement in development of the amendments introduced by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014, which transferred the Republic of Palau to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that regulation, the Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations with a view to concluded the bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, an agreement which was signed on 7 December.  The agreement signed establishes a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of the Republic of Palau travelling to the territory of the other party where the stay does not exceed 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report which gives the approval of the European Parliament to the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the short-stay visa exemption signed on 7 December 2015. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Palau nationals in the territory of the other contracting party. The stay is for up to 90 days over the entire 180-day period.  I voted in favour of this visa exemption in particular because Palau is a democratic republic entirely committed to human rights, which are enshrined in the Constitution.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 European integration ensured the free movement of people in Europe. It is gratifying to see that the Commission is also trying to ensure the free movement of Europeans in the world. The agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the short stay of visa waiver is a successful and welcome example of such activities, which will foster bilateral relations.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau are being governed by the Cotonou Agreement in 2014, and negotiations for the conclusion of a bilateral agreement began in 2014. This Agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and vice versa for citizens of Palau who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in each 180-day period.  The Agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the two sides, with high political importance in the framework of the Cotonou Agreement and strengthening economic and cultural relations. Palau is a democratic republic that respects the human rights enshrined in the Constitution. However, political dialogue on issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms is expected to be intensified. Since the economy of Palau is essentially based on the services sector and with a tourism sector in full expansion, it will also be possible to invest and train tourism. I agree with the position she has made on the importance of visa-free travel as an element of bringing the peoples of Europe and the Pacific closer, benefiting fully from the ACP-EU partnership, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Palau nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement in question provides for visa-free travel for nationals of both countries travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party. I am in favour of this type of measure which, as pointed out in the report presented in plenary, will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs and citizens in general, thus stimulating economic investment and the tourism sector.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to initiate negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, the purpose of which is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other contracting party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Visa Waiver Agreement for short-term stays is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. The agreement gives EU citizens a visa-free right in Palau. This is beneficial for EU citizens as they are now free to travel to and from the country without restriction. However, it is important that the rules laid down for the duration of your stay are always adhered to.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the short-stay travel agreement with Palau. As early as 2014, the EU had decided that Palau, like many other Pacific states, should have a right to a short visa. At the same time, this agreement also allows EU citizens to travel to Palau without short-stay visas. However, these visas do not apply to gainful employment and are only valid for a period of 90 days in a period of 180 days.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the visa waiver of citizens of the Republic of Palau for trips of up to 90 days to the European Union and for European citizens on trips of the same duration to the Republic of Palau. Although this agreement has been negotiated opaquely and without taking into account the positions of the European Parliament, we are in favour of visa-free processes which allow the right to freedom of movement to be exercised with fewer restrictions.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement between the EU and Palau will open up opportunities and advantages for both the citizens of Palau and the EU, as any existing visa requirements for EU citizens to travel to Palau will be eliminated.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I am eager to foster freedom of movement for citizens of responsible third-country nations who will visit, study and work in EU, and was happy to support this visa liberalisation.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the EU-Palau Agreement on short-stay visa waiver will allow EU citizens and Palau citizens to travel without a visa to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within a 180-day period. The abolition of the visa requirement will make it easier for all categories of persons travelling for any reason to travel. The positive effects of the visa waiver will certainly be reflected in facilitated travel for entrepreneurs, tourism and other activities. Palau reaches one of the highest living standards in the Pacific. The country has made great progress in recent years, particularly with regard to women's rights. Palau women are increasingly appointed to management positions in administration and receive representative seats in elections. Palau has signed all international human rights agreements and has the EU's support in ratifying and implementing them. Despite all the fact that this country poses no threat either in the area of illegal immigration or security or public order, I support the rapporteur that the EC and the authorities of the Palau Republic should ensure full reciprocity in the abolition of visas, which must allow equal treatment of all citizens.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution provides for a reciprocal visa waiver for short-term stays, up to a maximum of 90 days within a 180-day period, between the EU-Schengen states and the Republic of Palau. Since this visa waiver is only valid if the traveller is not required to carry out a paid activity in the destination country during the stay and an official identification document must be available, there is no risk of irregular labour migration. On the contrary, this agreement simplifies travel, establishes personal contacts and strengthens the tourist economy. I agree to the agreement for these reasons.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Opening up opportunities for citizens of other countries to get to know the European Union and establish cultural, economic and academic relations here is an important part of our foreign policy.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The agreement mentioned allows citizens of the European Union and the citizens of Palau to stay without a visa on the territory of another Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, official and special passport) whose purpose of travel does not include the performance of paid activity.  I support the report on the Agreement between the European Union and Palau on the abolition of short-stay visas, as such an Agreement is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the EU and the Republic of Palau and will further strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs supported this agreement to enable visa-free travel between other EU Member States and Palau, Tonga and Columbia. The agreements would not affect the UK, which has its own national visa agreements with these countries.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the short-stay visa waiver.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Partnership Agreement between members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Countries Group, on the one hand, and the European Union and its Member States, on the other hand, regulates relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau. In December 2015, a bilateral agreement was signed between the European Union and the Republic of Palau. This Agreement allows citizens of the European Union and the citizens of Palau to stay visa-free on the territory of another Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any 180-day period and applies to all categories of persons whose purpose of the trip does not include the performance of paid activity. Based on the available mobility data, there is a great deal of confidence in the applicants from Palau, as the rate of rejected applications is very low. The Republic of Palau poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. I support this Agreement because I believe it strengthens cultural and economic relations, brings to the forefront other important political issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver will also simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and encourage the development of tourism. Visa waiver is an essential precondition for bringing European citizens and citizens of the Pacific region closer.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the short-stay visa waiver on behalf of the European Union. I support the conclusion of an agreement allowing citizens from the Member States and citizens of the Republic of Palau to travel visa-free for all categories of persons travelling for any purpose other than the performance of paid work. The conclusion of the visa waiver agreement for EU citizens and the Republic of Palau is also the result of good relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is completely wrong to think that the short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau and is a complementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the mistaken view that there is a high degree of confidence in visa applicants , which results from the low percentage of discharges. As with the other countries of the 'Koton Agreement', it is inconceivable that the practice of signing visa waiver agreements should be applied and provisionally implemented before they are approved by the European Parliament.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union supports the development of African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries, especially following the ratification of the Cotonou Agreement, which enhances economic and cultural relations with these countries, with a focus on specific issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms. The EU is currently negotiating comprehensive economic partnership agreements with 14 Pacific countries aimed at strengthening cooperation, especially in the areas of tourism, fisheries and marine resources. These countries include Palau, an island country with a democratic regime and values, respecting human rights, good governance and the rule of law. In recent years, this state has made important progress, in particular in combating trafficking in human beings and in the field of women's and children's rights, but also in the field of renewable energies. In these circumstances, the signing of this Agreement to exempt the holding of short-stay visas (90 days) for nationals of the two Parties is a normal development, especially in the context of the fact that there have been no negative events in the bilateral relationship. This agreement will make it easier for citizens of both parties to travel, for business or tourism, strengthening good relations. I therefore support the adoption of this recommendation.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I acceded to the rapporteur's request. The signed agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Palau nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for up to 90 days of 180-day stay. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official, or special) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Palau Agreement, which allows visa-free travel for the citizens of the EU and for the citizens of Palau when travelling to each other’s countries for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. Decided upon in the context of the Cotonou Agreement, this Agreement constitutes an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This Agreement also reflects the considerable progress made by Palau in recent years. Finally, I believe it will have a positive effect on Palau’s economy by simplifying travel for business people, facilitating investment and boosting the already blooming tourism sector.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I believe that this Agreement will have a positive impact as it will simplify travel for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and stimulate the development of the tourism sector, and I have supported the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the abolition of short-stay visas. That Agreement will allow Citizens of the European Union and palau citizens to stay visa-free on the territory of another Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, official and special passport) whose purpose of travel does not include the performance of paid activity.  In my view, this Visa Waiver Agreement does not only enable citizens to benefit fully from the partnership between the African, Caribbean and Pacific Countries Group and the European Union, but also to actively participate in it and travel more easily and at less cost.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the short-stay visa waiver on behalf of the European Union, as the agreement allows citizens of the European Union and Palau to travel visa-free to the territory of the other Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The agreement is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, which has great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement and will further strengthen economic and cultural relations. It will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, enable investment and boost tourism. In recent years, the latter has become one of the main branches of the island state, whose economy is primarily based on the service sector. Palau is a democratic republic and, like the EU, stands up for the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law. The visa waiver is an important step on the road to bringing the EU and pacific nations closer together.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to initiate negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, the purpose of which is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other contracting party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Visa Waiver Agreement for short-term stays is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Palau nationals travelling to the EU for up to 90 days over any 180-day period. Given the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, we are opposed to any visa liberalisation. I'm voting against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union, through its actions, should support countries that follow the path of democracy, freedom and respect for human rights. Visa liberalisation not only enables tourism to develop and investment to grow, but also provides an opportunity to promote the values on which the European Union is founded. As a global policy actor, the EU should ensure that economic and cultural relations with different regions of the world are strengthened. I hope that this agreement will allow for increased cooperation with the Pacific countries, which is why I voted in favour of the abolition of short-stay visas for the people of palau.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau are governed by the Partnership Agreement (Cotonou Agreement) between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part. The visa waiver agreement for short-stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, which is of great political importance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to initiate negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, the purpose of which is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other contracting party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Visa Waiver Agreement for short-term stays is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. Good results are that nationals of Palau will be able to travel to the Schengen area without visas and EU nationals to Palau.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the short-stay visa waiver. The Agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Palau when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I believe that this Agreement represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau, which is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement.
