Moreover, the Agreement is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. By this agreement, the European Parliament consents to the agreement already negotiated between the European Commission and the Republic of Palau to provide the country with short-term visa waivers. Since the European Parliament's Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs has issued a positive recommendation at the conclusion of this agreement, I think it is appropriate to vote in its favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau are being governed by the Partnership Agreement between the States of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific. The Agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Palau who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. Visa waiver is an important element for bringing the peoples closer to Europe and the Pacific. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens to fully benefit from the ACP-EU partnership. Supported.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The Agreement provides for visa waiver for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Palau (island state in the Pacific Ocean) if they travel to the territory of the other Party for a maximum of 90 days in a period of 180 days. This is argued with a positive impact on tourism and a "high" trade potential. Apart from the fact that current trade and investment are very limited, it is hardly possible to demonstrate why such an exemption should be voted for. That is why I voted negatively.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Palau on the short-stay visa waiver. The lifting of the visa requirement is an important means of bringing European and Pacific nations closer together, simplifying travel conditions for entrepreneurs, enabling investment and promoting tourism.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is a step forward for relations between the European Union and the state of Tonga. I voted in favour of reducing the bureaucratic burden on the free movement of persons in the event of travel for professional reasons, tourism or family reunification. This vote is a further sign of strengthening economic political relations between these states and the Union.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the visa waiver of citizens of the Kingdom of Tonga, during trips of up to 90 days to the European Union and for European citizens on trips of the same duration to the Kingdom of Tonga. Although this agreement has been negotiated opaquely and without taking into account the positions of the European Parliament, we are in favour of visa-free processes which allow the right to freedom of movement to be exercised with fewer restrictions.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Tonga when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. We have succeeded in reaching a comprehensive and balanced agreement with all political groups on this text which will strengthen social and cultural ties between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga.  This agreement will open up opportunities for EU citizens, who will now be able to travel to the country without a visa.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation of the agreement between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga on the short-stay visa waiver, as this agreement will create opportunities and advantages for European citizens, as any visa requirement to be able to travel to that country is abolished.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. As with the two previous reports, this text aims to liberalise visas between the European Union and a third country (in this case the Tonga Islands) considered safe due to increased cooperation on return and the proper implementation of border controls.  Gradually, the EU is making national and EU borders obsolete. For that reason, I objected to this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I voted against this report. I do not believe that the European Union should be negotiating waiving visa agreements on behalf of the UK.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text as recommended by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for an agreement between the EU and Tonga on the short stay of visa waiver.  Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Palau shall be governed by the Partnership Agreement between the Members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part, the so-called Cotonou Agreement. The proposed Agreement establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and Tonga travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service and/or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose other than persons who are on paid employment.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. While the Republic of Palau and the Kingdom of Tonga, small Pacific archipelagos with less than 150,000 inhabitants, are not a real problem, the same is true of the third country to benefit today from the largesse of the Eurocrats: Colombia, a country with 48 million inhabitants and plagued by drug trafficking. The technocrats in Brussels are giving a real boost to their irresponsible massive immigration policy, which has disastrous consequences on the already precarious balance of our European nations, both economically and socially, as well as identity and security. Voted in the European Parliament by the socialist and EPP groups, including LR MEPs, this visa exemption opens up new routes of illegal immigration and will exacerbate the migration chaos. While the European Commission foresees the arrival of an additional 3 million migrants by 2017, the National Front reminds us that the only policy to avoid social, economic and cultural chaos is to restore our national borders, put an end to all forms of laxity in the face of illegal immigration, drastically reduce legal immigration and reaffirm our identity.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved this agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas of up to 90 days over any 180-day period for the Kingdom of Tonga, a democratically stable state and part of the ACP countries.  This will not only strengthen economic and cultural exchanges, but also promote political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Gabriel report approving the agreement between the EU and Tonga on the visa waiver for short-stay stays. The text establishes a visa waiver for EU citizens and tonga citizens travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons regardless of the reason for the stay provided that this is not linked to the performance of a paid activity. The agreement will make it possible to intensify the partnership with the Kingdom of Tonga, promoting future cooperation on issues such as the abolition of the death penalty, the fight against violence against women and gender equality.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, the purpose of which is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other contracting party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Short-Term Visa Waiver Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. The visa waiver for the Kingdom of Tonga is, as in the case of Palau, consistent with the Cotonou Agreement. The EU is now working on agreements with a group of 16 Pacific states, including this monarchy to which these agreements will help consolidate their development policies. It is very interesting to insist on agreements with a State which stands out, inter alia, for its vocation for sustainable development and, in particular, for renewable energy.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to oppose this agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the exemption of short-stay visas. Indeed, this agreement comes at a time when the European Union has proved incapable of giving a coherent response to the migration crisis and yet dares to continue to open the doors of European territory to all winds. Visas are not brakes, but are part of a protective edifice, allowing a sovereign state to control the movement of people entering its territory. They therefore relate to a measure of security and common sense which the EU only wants to abolish by ideology of the great market without borders.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the granting of tourist visas between the EU and Tonga is well structured and coherent, which is why I supported it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation by which Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of this bilateral agreement in development of the amendments introduced by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014, which transferred the Kingdom of Tonga to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that regulation, the Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations with a view to concluded the bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, which was signed on 20 November.  The signed Agreement establishes a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Tonga nationals travelling to the territory of the other party for a stay of up to 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the visa waiver in the case of short stays. Relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga shall be governed by the Partnership Agreement between the Members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States (ACP) and the European Community and its Member States, of the other part, the so-called Cotonou Agreement. The agreement signed establishes visa-free travel for nationals of the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service and/or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose other than persons who are on paid employment. This agreement on the short stay of visa-free travel is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays is both a success of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, which is of great political importance, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  With regard to mobility, the available data show that the reliability of visa applicants is high and there are few applications rejected. The country poses no threat to irregular migration, security or public order. I also consider it important that the visa waiver is not a negligible means of eddation between the people of the European Union and the citizens of the country concerned. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the partnership in a full, cheaper and simpler way.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I also supported the proposed eu-Tonga report on the short-stay visa waiver. Confidence in visa applicants in Tonga is high, as the proportion of applications is low, and the citizens of that country have not lodged a single asylum application. In fact, migration flows have increasingly been directed towards New Zealand, Australia and the United States, and much less to the European Union. It should be noted that, even in terms of irregular migration, the state does not pose a threat, nor does it pose a threat to security and public order. The lifting of the visa requirement will, in my view, also make an important contribution to the convergence of European and Pacific nations. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens to benefit from the ACP-EU partnership and to travel at a lower cost in economic and practical terms.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Tonga nationals travelling to the EU for up to 90 days over any 180-day period. I have nothing against the citizens of this country, but given the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, I am opposed to any visa liberalisation. So I voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. –I voted in favour of this agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Tonga when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support the new agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on short-stay visa waivers, as a privileged mechanism to support cooperation, trade and the development of tourism in both territories; it is also an instrument capable of strengthening ties and promoting greater mutual understanding between the peoples of Europe and the peoples of the Pacific area.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and nationals of the Kingdom of Tonga who travel to one of the EU Member States for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.  At a time when the Member States of the Union are facing an unprecedented migration crisis, it would be absolutely inappropriate to conclude such an agreement which will speed up the migration influx into Europe. We know for a fact that our "Old Continent" is extremely attractive, especially in terms of social protection, which encourages a significant number of tourists to come and enjoy these social benefits; it would therefore be wise to fight social tourism instead of liberalising their visas. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement on the exemption from the requirement of a short-stay visa is a strengthening of the partnership between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, constituting progress towards deepening economic and cultural relations and enhancing political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This agreement will have a positive impact on the main economic sectors, facilitating investment and fostering the mobility of entrepreneurs. The Agreement provides for a visa-free travel scheme for the benefit of Union citizens and Tonga nationals travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party, including all categories of persons. With regard to concerns about illegal migration, confidence in Tonga visa applicants is high, with a low level of visa refusal. As a result, this kingdom poses no threat from the perspective of mobility and public security. I have expressed myself in favour of this agreement, because I believe that it is a partnership that benefits both parties, helping to extend the rights of free movement for the benefit of both the citizens of the Union and the nationals of the Kingdom of Tonga.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation today as I consider the short-stay visa waiver to be another useful measure to intensify the EU's political dialogue with Tonga. Tonga's economy is essentially based on the agriculture and fisheries sectors, which account for 20% of GDP, and the services sector, which accounts for 60% of GDP, with a tourism sector gradually developing. Although the EU is currently of little importance to Tonga in terms of trade, trade has considerable development potential. Let us not forget that the Kingdom of Tonga has considerable wind power generation capacity and places considerable attention on renewable energy and energy efficiency. The visa waiver agreement will, I am sure, have a positive impact on investment and the development of the tourism sector. This important measure provides concrete support for the country in question and rewards the many efforts undertaken. To this end, I would like to point out that Tonga has made considerable progress, in all of them the decision to ratify the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on short stay visa waivers with Tonga, although it will not apply to Ireland since Ireland does not participate in the Schengen acquis. For other EU countries, this vote means that citizens from Tonga and the EU will have a maximum period of 90 days for visa-free travel when visiting the territory of the other party.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to give my consent to the conclusion of the Agreement that allows visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and of Tonga. I believe short-stay visa waiver will deepen our relations with Tonga and will positively contribute to our cultural and business exchanges.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Short-term visa waiver has important political significance and marks an important stage in the EU's relations with other countries. It is also an instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The State of Tonga has met the requirements to access it.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga have strengthened considerably over the last decade. Tonga's economy is mainly based on agriculture and fisheries as well as services, which accounts for 60% of GDP with tourism-related activities gradually developing. Although the flow of investment between the EU and Tonga has remained fairly limited in recent years, there is strong development potential. Recently, the country has made great progress, particularly with regard to the protection of human rights, by promoting awareness-raising activities on issues such as the death penalty, freedom of religion and belief. The political and economic stability achieved in recent years in the country provides the right guarantees to give the citizens of the Kingdom of Tonga the visa waiver for short stays in Europe, an opening that will help to strengthen relations between the two parties, giving impetus to trade and tourist flows. The absence of asylum applications and the low rate of refusal of visas have led to the view that the country poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the short-stay visa waiver agreement and believe that it contributes decisively to the strengthening and deepening of relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the recommendation on the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the short-stay visa waiver is a step towards improving relations between the two sides, also with the aim of improving the conditions of movement and living of citizens. As I believe it is moving in the right direction, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although trade with the Kingdom of Tonga is numerically small for the European Union, it has considerable development potential, particularly in the tourism sector. I support this proposal for a short-stay visa waiver, which underlines the good relationship between the parties. I am convinced that the exemption agreement will bring benefits by facilitating tourism. Furthermore, it can be seen that the country poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ After the adoption of the Regulation on 20 May 2014, the Council adopted, on 9 October 2014, a decision authorising the Commission to open negotiations with a view to the conclusion of the bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga. Negotiations commenced on 19 November 2014 and ended on 29May 2015 (Tonga) and 10 June 2015 (Union). The agreement was signed on 20 November 2015 in Brussels. Since that date, the agreement has applied provisionally, pending approval by the European Parliament. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Tonga when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union carries out a visa policy, in particular with regard to the exemption of short-stay visas. This exemption is defined at European level as it is valid for all Member States except the United Kingdom and Ireland. Moreover, the various requirements for the conclusion of the agreement include reciprocity. In other words, European citizens also no longer need a visa. Another criterion that must be underlined is respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, which is also the case here.  It is up to the European Parliament to give its consent to the agreement for its establishment. That's right. For all this and because this Agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations with the Kingdom of Tonga, I am voting in favour of its celebration.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of Tonga who wish to travel to each other for short periods in European territory or in the Kingdom of Tonga. This agreement aims to promote relations between the EU and the State of Tonga, to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote full respect for fundamental rights and freedoms. In addition, this agreement would promote the tourism sector for the Kingdom of Tonga and bring benefits to its economy based on the agricultural and fisheries sector.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Tonga when travelling for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. While EU trade relations with Tonga are relatively insignificant, the report says that they have strong potential for development, particularly in the context of EU negotiating on Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreements with 14 Pacific countries, including the Tonga. Moreover, Tonga has a large wind energy production capacity and 90% of the 11th set of EDF appropriations for 2014-2020, amounting to EUR 11 million, which are earmarked for renewable energy and energy efficiency. I see scope in intensifying our partnership, focusing however on fundamental aspects such as abolition of the death penalty, combating violence against women and gender equality; which would be indispensable preconditions towards further cooperation. In this context, the visa exemption could send out a positive message of support for the country and the efforts it is making.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the visa waiver of citizens of the Kingdom of Tonga, during trips of up to 90 days to the European Union and for European citizens on trips of the same duration to the Kingdom of Tonga. Although this agreement has been negotiated opaquely and without taking into account the positions of the European Parliament, we are in favour of visa-free processes which allow the right to freedom of movement to be exercised with fewer restrictions.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement on the exemption from the requirement to hold a short-stay visa constitutes progress towards stabilising relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, a kingdom which has a major political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Although the Union occupies a less important place in terms of trade in that country, they have great potential for development. As regards mobility, the available data show that confidence in Tonga visa applicants is high. The short-stay visa waiver agreement allows citizens not only to benefit fully from the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it, travelling at low costs economically and practically.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 By a amendment to Regulation (EC) No 539/2001, the Kingdom of Tonga has been transferred to third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The agreement was signed in 2015 and has since been provisionally approved by the European Parliament. The main export products of the Kingdom of Tonga are non-processed agricultural products such as palm oil and sugar, and imports are mainly made up of vessels, and the trade surplus always occurs on the side of the Pacific State. The EU is a relatively small trading partner, but there is a serious opportunity to develop relations. The EU is currently negotiating a Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with 14 countries in the Pacific region, including Tonga. The Kingdom of Tonga has significant wind generation capacities and, in the 11th century, the 19th century was a time when the world was in a state of flue. 90% of the European Development Fund budget for 2014-2020, or EUR 11 million, is earmarked for renewable energy and energy efficiency. The EU's relations with the Pacific ACS countries, in particular Tonga, are intensify. The agreement would intensify our partnership, stressing the abolition of the death penalty, the fight against violence against women and equality between women and men. The country has already made significant strides in this area. The visa waiver would also indicate the UNION's support for the country and its efforts. Today, the European Parliament has given its consent to the conclusion of the agreement, which I voted in favour of.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Last December, the EU signed identical agreements on the short-stay visa waiver with the Republic of Palau, the Kingdom of Tonga and the Republic of Colombia. As provided for in the agreements, EU citizens will be able to spend 90 days without a visa in these countries in any 180-day period, as will nationals of those countries in the EU. In order to benefit from visa-free travel, EU citizens and signatory countries must have a valid passport: ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special. However, the abolition of short-stay visas does not apply to persons travelling for gainful employment. The Agreements are already applied provisionally after unanimous support from the Schengen Governments of the Council, but the consent of the European Parliament is required for their full conclusion. The United Kingdom and Ireland will not participate in the agreement as their visa regimes remain subject to national legislation. I personally see these agreements as a way of promoting people-to-people contacts in the countries in question. They should provide trade opportunities in view of the increase in tourist numbers and help promote economic relations between the EU and these countries. I therefore did not object to these agreements and voted in favour of them.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this agreement which represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga. It is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement will enable citizens not only to derive full benefit from the EU-ACP partnership but also to participate in it by travelling at a reduced, economical and practical cost.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the exemption of short-stay visas which provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Tonga nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period.  Through this agreement, we will strengthen not only political dialogue between the two sides, but also economic relations.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Tonga nationals travelling to the EU for up to 90 days over any 180-day period.  In view of the current migration crisis, any visa liberalisation would be an irresponsible measure. However, risks are considered "manageable" through increased cooperation on return and the implementation of border controls.  Having disagreed with this approach, I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the EU-Tonga agreement on the short-stay visa waiver. According to the agreement signed in December last year, a new visa-free regime applies to European citizens and reciprocally for palau citizens when they travel to Europe for 90 days. It is important to note that this visa regime does not apply to citizens taking trips for work or other paid activity. I believe that the benefits of this agreement will have a beneficial effect on the tourism sector and promote bilateral business relations.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Tonga as a country does not theoretically represent any threat to the EU, either in terms of illegal immigration or in terms of security and public order. The short-stay visa requirement could be lifted, but there are no measurable data and no real-world tests have been carried out in areas relating to public policy and security, but also in the Union's external relations with that country.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The economy of Tonga is mainly based on the agriculture sector (pumpkin production and tuna fishing), which accounts for 20 % of GDP, as well as on the services sector, which accounts for 60 % of GDP, with a progressive developing tourism sector. As regards investments and trade relations with Tonga, they remain variable and weak, both in value and in relative terms. In addition, Tonga has significant wind electricity generation capacities and 90 % of the 11th EDF envelope for 2014-2020, worth EUR 11 million, is earmarked for renewable energy and energy efficiency. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, with high political importance in the framework of the Cotonou Agreement, and is also an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue on various issues , including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I vote against it: we have nothing against the citizens of these countries, but given the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, we are opposed to any visa liberalisation.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga are in line with the Partnership Agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Tonga travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. Visa waiver is an important element for bringing the peoples closer to Europe and the Pacific. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens to fully benefit from the ACP-EU partnership. As on other similar occasions, we voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga, as it is a key instrument for strengthening economic, political and cultural relations between the two parties. It will encourage people-to-people contacts between these countries, offering new business opportunities through increased tourism and facilitating the promotion of trade relations between the EU and Tonga.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 This particular agreement is about continuing to deepen the above-standard relations between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga. The visa waiver agreement will have positive effects for both parties, as it simplifies travel conditions for entrepreneurs while facilitating investment and dynamising tourism. The agreement in question has the potential to strengthen the area of investment and trade, which have strong development potential in the future.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report as it does not present any critical elements.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the EU-Tonga Agreement on short-stay visa waiver, as Tonga as a country does not theoretically represent any threat to the EU, either in terms of illegal immigration or in terms of security and public order, and the short-stay visa requirement could be lifted, but there are no measurable data and no real-world trials have been carried out in areas relating to public policy and security , but also in the Union's external relations with that country.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga which is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement – and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This agreement will open up opportunities and advantages also for EU citizens, as any existing requirement for EU citizens to travel to these countries will be eliminated. I voted in favour of the agreement.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we give our consent to the agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Republic of Tonga when travelling to the each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days. We welcome the agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas as politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement. This is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and enhancing political dialogue. We however call on the Commission to observe any developments in relation to the criteria on clandestine immigration, public policy and security.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation on the basis of compliance with the agreements signed between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga. This agreement is based on visa exemption for short-term stays, this is an achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, and gives political content to the Cotonou Agreement, as well as being a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the adoption of this agreement between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga as this agreement serves to deepen the economic and political relations between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga. I also believe that this agreement could send out a strong message of support for the progress that has been made in fundamental freedoms in the Kingdom of Tonga since the country’s first democratic elections in 2010 and allow the EU to influence future progress in the country.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As coordinator of my ECR Group for the EU-ACP delegation, I voted in favour of the EU-Tonga visa waiver agreement. I have discussed this with colleagues in the small Pacific island state on several occasions at past ACP meetings and I support the approach adopted in the agreement.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the visa-free regime between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga. It will apply to all categories of persons and all travel purposes, except for for-profit stays. The visa waiver is valid for a maximum of 90 days in a period of 180 days.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, the purpose of which is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other contracting party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Short-Term Visa Waiver Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement between the EU and Tonga will open up opportunities and advantages for both the citizens of Tonga and the EU, as any existing visa requirements for EU citizens to travel to Tonga will be eliminated.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. This agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas constitutes simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga which is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement – and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the agreement on a visa waiver for short-stay citizens of Tonga. However, we are critical of the procedure chosen and leaving Parliament out, and it is simply being asked for approval.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this agreement between the EU and Kingdom of Tonga. Firstly, the agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Tonga when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. This will allow for greater access and integration between the two blocks in terms of tourism and investment. Tonga’s economy is based essentially on agriculture and fisheries, accounting for 20% of GDP, and services, representing 60% of GDP. The main products exported from this country are unprocessed agricultural products such as palm oil and sugar, and the main products imported are boats and ships, with a trade surplus for the Pacific. While EU trade relations with Tonga are relatively insignificant, they have strong potential for development especially in the areas already mentioned. On a political note, this agreement will allow the EU to intensify its partnership, focusing on aspects such as abolition of the death penalty, combating violence against women and gender equality.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this agreement as it enables both EU citizens and citizens of the Kingdom of Tonga to experience the culture of both parties more easily.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution provides for a reciprocal visa waiver for short-term stays, up to a maximum of 90 days within a 180-day period, between the EU-Schengen states and the Kingdom of Tonga. Since this visa waiver is only valid if the traveller is not required to carry out a paid activity in the destination country during the stay and an official identification document must be available, there is no risk of irregular labour migration. On the contrary, this agreement simplifies travel, establishes personal contacts and strengthens the tourist economy. I agree to the agreement for these reasons. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. If we take the particular case of the Kingdom of Tonga, I see no difficulty in lifting the requirement for a short-stay visa, i.e. three months over a period of 180 days, for nationals of this small Pacific island of nearly 100,000 inhabitants whose population is much more attracted to Australia and New Zealand than to Europe. The risk of migration is zero. However, beyond the case of this constitutional monarchy, I question the strategic choice of granting short-stay visa exemptions to countries with high migration and security risks such as Ukraine, Georgia and Turkey. Visa policy is not just an instrument. It is also a political and geostrategic choice. However, it must not only take into account what it will bring to the third country concerned but also the impact it will have on the Member States.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States and the Member States of the European Union, an agreement called the 'Cotonou Agreement'. It provides for short-stay visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Kingdom of Tonga travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a stay of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. I voted in favour of this report, with direct and positive effects in the energy industry, especially renewable ones, for the development of tourism and for economic progress.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Recommendation on the Draft Council Decision on the Conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the waiver of short-stay visas, as this gives consent for the conclusion of that Agreement and could allow for a better trade exchange which has great potential for the development of that country. The agricultural sector accounts for 20% of the KINGDOM of Tonga's GDP, with the service sector accounting for 60% of GDP. While their investments and trade are still small, exports are one of the areas where the country could make a big breakthrough. With the help of this Agreement, this situation is easily possible.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. These three agreements provide for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and nationals of Palau, Tonga and Colombia who travel to the EU for up to 90 days over any 180-day period. We have nothing against the citizens of these countries, but given the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, we are opposed to any visa liberalisation. I objected to these three texts.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Kingdom of Tonga has fulfilled all necessary conditions and conditions for visa-free travel for short stays. The waiver of the obligation to have a visa to stay in the EU within 90 days mainly concerns tourists, diplomats or exchange students and is a considerable administrative facilitation for the benefit of Tonga citizens. This visa waiver agreement is also another evidence of the deepening EU-Tonga relationship and is another way to intensify economic and cultural relations and strengthen political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I was therefore happy to support the granting of visa-free travel.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the conclusion of an agreement with the Kingdom of Tonga to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report concerns an agreement between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga on the visa waiver for short stays of the citizens of Tonga in the European Union. Visa waiver is a national task and better lifted in the Council or the Schengen Group than at pan-European level. That is why I am voting against this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this agreement to enable visa-free travel between other EU Member States and Palau, Tonga and Colombia. The agreements would not affect the UK, which has its own national visa agreements with these countries.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution provides for a reciprocal visa waiver for short-term stays, up to a maximum of 90 days within a 180-day period, between the EU-Schengen states and the Kingdom of Tonga. Since this visa waiver is only valid if the traveller is not required to carry out a paid activity in the destination country during the stay and an official identification document must be available, there is no risk of irregular labour migration. On the contrary, this agreement simplifies travel, establishes personal contacts and strengthens the tourist economy. I agree to the agreement for these reasons.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The Kingdom of Tonga is an important partner for the EU in the African Caribbean Pacific region. In this context, the agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas represents a further step towards a deepening of relations between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga. Visa liberalisation could send out a positive message of support for the country and the efforts it is making in terms of protecting its vulnerable environment and defending human rights and gender equality. Last but not least, we should support the EU-Tonga agreement on the short-stay visa waiver because the country does not pose a threat to the union in terms of irregular migration and security.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. As in the case of the agreement between the EU and the Republic of Palau, we are voting to strengthen economic and cultural relations with the Kingdom of Tonga. Its economy is based on fishing, agriculture, but also on the export sector of un processed agricultural products, and it also has considerable electricity production capacity from wind. It is therefore stated that the forecast of visasensation can bring positive improvements both on investment and also on the development of the tourism sector; It will also bring the peoples of Europe and the Pacific closer together and enable citizens to benefit fully from the ACP-EU partnership by guaranteeing them the opportunity to travel more economically and practically.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I am opposed to any visa liberalisation.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the short-stay visa exemption.  The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for nationals of the Kingdom of Tonga who travel to the EU for up to 90 days of 180 days.  I have nothing against the citizens of this country, but given the scale of the migration crisis in Europe and the security problem that follows, I am opposed to any further visa liberalisation.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The text proposes to establish a visa-free travel regime between nationals of both parties, for a maximum of 90 days over any 180-day period.  Given the current context of the migration crisis, I am opposed to any visa liberalisation, which is why I am voting AGAINST this text.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the visa waiver of citizens of the Kingdom of Tonga, during trips of up to 90 days to the European Union and for European citizens on trips of the same duration to the Kingdom of Tonga. Although this agreement has been negotiated opaquely and without taking into account the positions of the European Parliament, we are in favour of visa-free processes which allow the right to freedom of movement to be exercised with fewer restrictions.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution provides for a reciprocal visa waiver for short-term stays, up to a maximum of 90 days within a 180-day period, between the EU-Schengen states and the Kingdom of Tonga. Since this visa waiver is only valid if the traveller is not required to carry out a paid activity in the destination country during the stay and an official identification document must be available, there is no risk of irregular labour migration. On the contrary, this agreement simplifies travel, establishes personal contacts and strengthens the tourist economy. I voted in favour of the agreement for these reasons.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of visa free travel between the EU and Tonga for short periods of 90 days for travel purposes except for carrying out a paid activity.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 With this proposal, the citizens of Tonga Island will be able to travel to the EU without visas and in return we will be able to travel to Tonga without visas. This is visa-free travel for tourist or business purposes for a maximum period of 90 days. Tonga is a kingdom in the Pacific Ocean with a population of about 100,000. The rate of visa refusals is low and Tonga does not even pose a threat to irregular migration. That's why I was on visa waiver.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This Agreement on the abolition of short-stay visas is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga and further strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The EU is currently negotiating the conclusion of a comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with 14 Pacific countries, including the Kingdom of Tonga. It has large capacity to generate electricity from the wind, and 90% of the amount of the 11th financial envelope of the European Development Fund for the period 2014-2020, i.e. €11 million, is earmarked for renewables and energy efficiency. This report notes that the Visa Waiver Agreement will have a positive impact on investment and development of the tourism sector. This Agreement allows us to strengthen the partnership, and the visa waiver can be seen as a positive sign of support for that state and the efforts it is undertaking. Because of all of the above, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga on the abolition of short-stay visas provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and tonga nationals travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of travellers (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) travelling for any purpose, except for the purpose of gainful employment. The Uk economy in Tonga is 60% based in the service sector and around 20% in agriculture, especially in pumpkin farming and tuna fishing. It is worth noting that, from a geographical point of view, the Kingdom of Tonga has significant capacity for wind power generation. Since the democratic elections organised in 2010, relations between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga have been gradually flourishing. The Kingdom of Tonga poses no threat to the European Union, either in the area of illegal migration, security and public order. Primary migration flows are directed to Australia, New Zealand, as well as to the US. In 2014, the EU registered the arrest of five Tonga citizens who were staying illegally, issued five refusals of entry at the Union border and, finally, ten return decisions. In view of the above and the prospects for the development of future relations with both the Kingdom of Tonga and the rest of the region, it was logical to vote positively.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the short-stay visa waiver because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text.  These three texts provide for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and nationals of Palau, Tonga and Colombia who travel to EU Member States for up to 90 days.  Due to the current migration crisis in Europe, we are opposed to any liberalisation of the visa regime. Furthermore, we are dubious about strengthening cooperation on return and the proper implementation of border controls, which are necessary to limit the risks posed by this liberalisation.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the EU-Tonga agreement on short-stay visa waivers is in my favour. This agreement is based on the intention to deepen relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, thus intensifying cultural and economic relations. Simplifying travel conditions also facilitates and encourages investment by promoting a general improvement.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Eu-Tonga relations are governed by the Partnership Agreement between african, caribbean and pacific states (Coton Agreement). The visa waiver agreement shall allow stays in the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days during any 180-day period. Visa waiver would apply to all categories of persons (holders of travel, diplomatic, service passports) except those travelling for gainful employment. Tonga's economy relies mainly on agriculture and tourism is gradually developing there. This agreement could also be supported. I voted to close it.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. My support also for the proposal to sign the visa waiver agreement for short-term stays between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga is signed. This agreement is also the result of the good relations enabled by the ACP-EU partnership, so the citizens of the Kingdom of Tonga will be able to benefit from the progress of that partnership and now, moreover, to travel with less economic and practical costs.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Partnership Agreement between the EU and the African, Caribbean and Pacific States includes the Kingdom of Tonga. Through this agreement and on the basis of Regulation No 136/66/EEC, the Commission has adopted a proposal for a directive on the protection of the 509/2014, the Kingdom of Tonga is among the countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement for crossing the external borders of the Member States of the Union. Since the entry into force of the Regulation, the Commission has been in negotiations with the Republic of Tonga for a bilateral agreement which remains for approval by Parliament. This agreement shall include the right of Union or Tonga citizens to travel to the territory of the Parties without a visa requirement for a maximum of 90 days. I am voting in favour of the adoption of the agreement, so that there can be closer relations between the Union and that country at political and cultural level with a view to promoting the basic principles and values of the Union and strengthening the protection of human rights.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is about the visa waiver for short stays between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga. The European Union has little trade relations with the Kingdom of Tonga. The report itself reveals that the tourism sector is undeveloped. I therefore see no need for action here.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the agreement on visa-free travel with the Kingdom of Tonga. The agreement signed establishes visa-free travel for EU and Tonga nationals travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons entering the country for any purpose, with the exception of persons who are on paid employment.  According to 2014 data, no citizen of that country submitted asylum applications to the EU. It has also historically been that the largest migration flows from Tonga have been to New Zealand, Australia and the United States and very little to the EU. It is likely that this country does not pose any risk of illegal immigration, security or public order.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. When cooperation with certain third countries allows, a reciprocal short-stay visa exemption (usually mainly for tourism) is negotiated. The Council, representing the states, decides. The criteria observed are as much the political situation, respect for human rights, as well as the type of migration. In practical terms, the absence of "irregular migration risk". This is the Kingdom of Tonga, which has 100,000 souls and as many coconut trees. I see no reason to oppose this tourism, but taken in a broader context, it is also a matter of softening the country, with which the European Union is currently negotiating a regional free trade agreement. Considering, however, that the development of tourism and cultural exchanges are a key advantage for the development of this country, I vote for it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens as well as nationals of the Kingdom of Tonga, for a maximum of 90 days out of 180.  Being opposed to any visa liberalisation, in view of the migration crisis we are experiencing, I objected to this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU-Tonga Agreement under the Cotonou Agreement provides for visa-free travel for CITIZENS of the European Union and citizens of Tonga travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. This is an important agreement for strengthening relations between the two parties, in particular in economic and cultural areas, enabling dialogue and learning on issues of civil liberties and human rights. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's recommendation on the draft Council decision.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome Parliament's approval of the visa-free agreement with the Kingdom of Tonga. As a partner of the Union in the framework of the Cotonou Agreement, the Kingdom of Tonga is engaged in a political dialogue with the Union in which such crucial topics as the abolition of the death penalty and the fight against violence against women are discussed.  I am pleased that this visa-free agreement will further strengthen the partnership between the Union and the Kingdom of Tonga. More generally, it also represents a further step forward in our relations with the Pacific countries and sends a strong signal of cooperation and support for the efforts undertaken by these countries, particularly in the area of human rights.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Tonga when travelling in the other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I supported this resolution as it is an opportunity to deepen economic relations and develop tourism.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – In order to deepen relations and build political dialogue between the European Union and its Member States and Tonga, an Agreement on short-stay visa waiver has been drawn up. The Union has drawn up a proposal for a regional plan for civil society organisations in the Pacific in order to ensure a more structured and effective dialogue with these organisations. The European Union is working with organisations and civil society to strengthen the protection of human rights by organising activities to raise awareness of the death penalty, religious freedom or freedom of belief. The lifting of the visa requirement will be a positive expression of support for this country and the extensive efforts it is making. This agreement allows citizens not only to fully benefit from the partnership, but also to participate in it more simply by travelling at less cost, and I am therefore voting in favour of this proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this agreement, which is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This agreement may allow us to intensify our partnership, focusing on aspects such as abolition of the death penalty, combating violence against women and gender equality. The country has achieved considerable progress, as evidenced for example by the decision to ratify the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against women. The visa exemption could send out a positive message of support for the country and the efforts it is making. The visa waiver agreement will enable citizens not only to derive full benefit from the ACP-EU partnership but also to participate in it by travelling at a reduced, economical and practical cost. This agreement will open up opportunities and advantages also for EU citizens, as any existing requirement for EU citizens to travel to these countries will be eliminated.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council submitted a draft decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the exemption from short-stay visas. In order to adopt the decision, it must obtain parliament's consent. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Relations between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga are governing the Partnership Agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific States, on the one hand, and the European Union and its Member States, on the other, called the 'Cotonou Agreement'. As part of the amendment to Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, the Kingdom of Tonga has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States.  The Council adopted a decision in 2014 authorising the Commission to open negotiations for the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga. The Agreement provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of Tonga who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days.  In view of the foregoing, I am in favour of concluding the Agreement.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. In view of the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, I oppose any visa liberalisation, and therefore vote against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement to enable visa-free travel between other EU Member States and Tonga. The agreement would not affect the UK, which has its own national visa agreement with this country.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and nationals of the Kingdom of Tonga for stays of up to 90 days over any 180-day period.  As long as there is reciprocity and the length of stays is limited, there are no difficulties with visa exemption for non-EU nationals.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mariya Gabriel's report. The European Parliament must give its approval to the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, which has already been negotiated between the Kingdom of Tonga and the European Commission. The proposal for the agreement to facilitate the issuance of visas is aimed at reaching an agreement with the Kingdom of Tonga on facilitating the issuance of short-stay visas. The agreement takes into account the situation of Member States that do not apply the Schengen acquis in its entirety. The agreement also provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and nationals of the Kingdom of Tonga who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official, or special) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Tonga is a Polynesian kingdom consisting of more than 170 islands, many of them uninhabited. Relations between the European Union and Tonga are governed by a partnership agreement also known as the Cotonou Agreement. I have voted for this recommendation that will provide visa-free travel for the citizens of the two parts when traveling to the other for a maximum period of 90 days.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. –I voted in favour of this agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Tonga when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report. The report reveals that the tourism sector is underdeveloped and that the European Union has little role to play in trade relations and that the economy is more state-organised. It is argued that this could have a positive impact on investment and tourism. In my opinion, this argument is not reason enough to vote in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Agreement provides for the possibility for EU and Tongan citizens to travel on a short-stay visa-free basis to the territory of the other Party.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Cotonou Agreement, which enshrines relations between the Kingdom of Tonga and the EU, is a partnership agreement that has poverty eradication and sustainable development as one of its main aims. I believe that the visa waiver for short stays can strengthen the dialogue between the parties in these matters, thereby supporting a strengthening of cultural and economic ties. I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the draft decision to conclude an agreement between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga on visa waiver, as it is important for further deepening relations between Member States and the Kingdom of Tonga. It strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue, and it is expected that this agreement will have a positive impact on investment and development of the tourism sector.  Tonga's economy is based on the agriculture sector (pumpkin cultivation and tuna fishing), which accounts for 20% of GDP and on a service sector that accounts for 60% of GDP, with the tourism sector gradually developing. The main products it exports are unprocessed agricultural products, such as palm oil and sugar, and the main imported products are smaller and larger vessels, with Tonga achieving a constant trade surplus. Therefore, trade has great potential for development.  This Agreement allows for the strengthening of partnerships, while focusing on issues important to Union citizens such as the abolition of the death penalty or the fight against violence against women. Tonga has made significant progress and visa waiver can be seen as a positive sign of support for the country and the extensive efforts it is making.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. In view of the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, I oppose any visa liberalisation, and therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the concluded Short Stay Visa Waiver Agreement, which aims to deepen relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga and has great political weight under the Cotonou Agreement. It further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Tonga's economy is primarily based on the agriculture sector (pumpkin cultivation and tuna fishing) which accounts for 20% of GDP, and on a service sector that accounts for 60% of GDP, with the tourism sector gradually developing. When it comes to investments and trade with Tonga, from a value point of view and in relative terms they are still small and fluctuate. The main products exported by the country are unprocessed agricultural products, such as palm oil and sugar, and the main products imported by it are smaller and larger vessels, with the Pacific State achieving a constant trade surplus.  While the Role of the Union is relatively irrelevant when it comes to trade with that Country, this exchange has great potential for development. The EU is currently negotiating the conclusion of a comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with 14 Pacific countries, including the Kingdom of Tonga.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga are in line with the Partnership Agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific States. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Tonga travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. Visa waiver is an important element for bringing the peoples closer to Europe and the Pacific. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens to fully benefit from the ACP-EU partnership. We voted in favour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The AGREEMENT between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga to abolish short-stay visas allows European Union citizens and tonga citizens to stay visa-free on the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any 180-day period. We should point out that this country poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of disturbing security and public order. I supported MEP Gabriel's recommendation on the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on visa waiver, as I see it as a positive sign of support for the country. The agreement will also have a positive impact on investment and the development of the tourism sector.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Kingdom of Tonga is a state in Oceania whose economy is mainly based on services in addition to tuna fishing and gound cultivation – due to the beauty of this island kingdom, tourism development has enormous potential. The Government of Tonga is gradually taking steps to remove obstacles to democratic reforms of the young constitutional monarchy – so far they are measures for greater private-sector participation in the economy or efforts to eliminate all forms of discrimination against women. As a Social Democrat, I believe that visa waiver can be a positive signal to this country in the sense that the efforts it is making are right and have our support. This agreement will therefore be a further step towards strengthening economic and cultural relations and deepening political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Kingdom of Tonga is a young country that intends to develop more and more the tourism sector, which is progressively replacing the agricultural and fisheries sector, once the state's first resources. In this sense, the agreement will make it possible to strengthen relations between the two parties, to give new impetus to trade and to instil dynamism in tourism. I therefore voted in favour of this agreement because it represents the conclusion of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, assuming an important political and economic significance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which approves the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the exemption of short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Tonga nationals travelling to the territory of the other party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of deepening relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, with high political importance, and is an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue that includes human rights and fundamental freedoms. The Kingdom of Tonga has been a constitutional monarchy since the organization of the first democratic elections in 2010. Political dialogue between the EU and each of the ACP Pacific countries, including Tonga, has been gradually intensifying. The European Union is negotiating a comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with 14 countries in the Pacific region, including the Kingdom of Tonga and there is strong development potential. The visa waiver agreement could have a positive effect on investment and development of the tourism sector. Visa-free travel can be a positive sign of support for that country and the many efforts it has made and is an important element for bringing the peoples closer together and the Pacific.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. MEPs, in adopting the Gabriel report, agreed to the introduction of a new, more flexible visa regime between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga.
