This visa-free agreement for short-term stays is a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Pacific State. In line with the Cotonou Agreement (ACP-EU) that binds the Union with the Pacific States, this agreement is an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations with the Kingdom of Tonga and intensifying political dialogue in particular on the issue of human rights and fundamental freedoms.  Politically, this agreement can enable us to intensify our partnership, emphasizing aspects such as the abolition of the death penalty, the fight against violence against women and gender equality. Visa exemption can therefore be a positive sign of support for this country and the many efforts it is making. Tourism benefits are also expected; the visa waiver agreement will allow European citizens to travel at a reduced economic and practical cost.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of deepening relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, with high political importance in the framework of the Cotonou Agreement, and is also an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue on various issues , including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation by which Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of this bilateral agreement in development of the amendments introduced by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014, which transferred the Kingdom of Tonga to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that regulation, the Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations with a view to concluded the bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, an agreement which was signed on 20 November.  The agreement signed establishes a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of the Kingdom of Tonga travelling to the territory of the other party for a stay of up to 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report which gives the Approval of the European Parliament to the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the short-stay visa exemption signed on 20 November 2015. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Tonga nationals in the territory of the other contracting party. The stay is for a maximum of 90 days over any 180-day period. I voted in favour of this visa exemption in particular because this agreement will intensify the partnership between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, emphasizing aspects such as the abolition of the death penalty, the fight against violence against women and equality between men and women.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 European integration ensured the free movement of people in Europe. It is gratifying to see that the Commission is also trying to ensure the free movement of Europeans in the world. The agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Tonga on the short stay of visa waiver is a successful and welcome example of such activities, which will foster bilateral relations.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. Relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga are in line with the Cotonou Agreement. Negotiations for the conclusion of a bilateral agreement providing for visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of Tonga travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period began in November 2014.  The Kingdom of Tonga has been a constitutional monarchy since 2010 so political dialogue with the EU has been gradually intensifying. The Agreement will intensify dialogue on aspects such as the abolition of the death penalty, the fight against violence against women, or equality between men and women.  Tonga's economy is based on a progressively developing tourism sector in the agriculture and services sector, so this agreement could have a positive effect on the investment and development of the latter. Not representing this country, either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order, visa-free travel is an important element for bringing the peoples closer to Europe and the Pacific, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Tonga nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Similar to the agreement with the Republic of Palau, the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on visa-free travel for nationals of contracting parties who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for short periods, represents an important opportunity for economic recovery and the deepening of good relations between the countries concerned in the political and cultural field. That is why I voted in favour of Mr Gabriel's recommendation.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, the purpose of which is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other contracting party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Short-Term Visa Waiver Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. (u2012 The agreement gives EU citizens visa-free travel in Tonga. This is beneficial for EU citizens as they are now free to travel to and from the country without restriction. However, it is important that the rules laid down for the duration of your stay are always adhered to.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the agreement with Tonga on the short-stay visa waiver. It is now possible for EU citizens and citizens of Tonga to spend a short stay – with a duration of 90 days in a period of 180 days – in the other country without a visa. However, this scheme does not apply to employment.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the visa waiver of citizens of the Kingdom of Tonga, during trips of up to 90 days to the European Union and for European citizens on trips of the same duration to the Kingdom of Tonga. Although this agreement has been negotiated opaquely and without taking into account the positions of the European Parliament, we are in favour of visa-free processes which allow the right to freedom of movement to be exercised with fewer restrictions.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement between the EU and Tonga will open up opportunities and advantages for both the citizens of Tonga and the EU, as any existing visa requirements for EU citizens to travel to Tonga will be eliminated.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I am eager to foster freedom of movement for citizens of responsible third country nations who will visit, study and work in the EU, and was happy to support this visa liberalisation.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ RELATIONS between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga are governed by an agreement called the Cotonou Agreement. This short-stay visa waiver agreement represents a successful completion of the deepening of relations between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga. The agreement acts as a means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and creates the conditions for intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The EU has a very low trade relationship coefficient and the agreement is also expected to contribute to the development of trade potential. The EU-led political dialogue is aimed at strengthening human rights. This agreement will also create the conditions for intensifying our partnership by highlighting aspects such as the abolition of the death penalty, the fight against violence against women, or equality between men and women. I support the rapporteur, who emphasises the not inconsiderable impact of visa cancellations on the convergence of European and Pacific friendship and which calls on the EP to observe the possible development of illegal immigration and public order and security, including the issues of respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution provides for a reciprocal visa waiver for short-term stays, up to a maximum of 90 days within a 180-day period, between the EU-Schengen states and the Kingdom of Tonga. Since this visa waiver is only valid if the traveller is not required to carry out a paid activity in the destination country during the stay and an official identification document must be available, there is no risk of irregular labour migration. On the contrary, this agreement simplifies travel, establishes personal contacts and strengthens the tourist economy. I agree to the agreement for these reasons.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Opening up opportunities for citizens of other countries to get to know the European Union and establish cultural, economic and academic relations here is an important part of our foreign policy.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EU-Tonga Agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas allows Eu citizens and Tonga citizens to stay visa-free on the territory of another Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, official and special passport) whose purpose of travel does not include the performance of paid activity.  I support the report on the Agreement between the European Union and Tonga on the abolition of short-stay visas, as such an agreement is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga and will further strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various issues.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support this agreement to enable visa-free travel between other EU Member States and Palau, Tonga and Colombia. The agreements would not affect the UK, which has its own national visa agreements with these countries.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the agreement between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga on the short-stay visa waiver. This Agreement provides for visa waiver for citizens of the EU Member States and citizens of the Kingdom of Tonga if they travel to the territory of the other Party for a maximum of 90 days in a period of 180 days.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Partnership Agreement between members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Countries Group, on the one hand, and the European Union and its Member States, on the other hand, regulates relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga. In November 2015, a bilateral agreement was signed between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga.  This Agreement allows Eu citizens and Citizens of Tonga to stay visa-free on the territory of another Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any 180-day period and applies to all categories of persons whose purpose of the trip does not include the performance of paid activity. In terms of mobility, the available data show that the level of trust in tonga applicants is high and poses no threat in terms of irregular migration, as migration flows from Tonga have always been mostly directed towards Australia, New Zealand and the United States. I support this Agreement because I believe that the visa waiver can be seen as a positive sign of support for this country and any effort it is undertaking, in particular in the area of human rights protection.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the short-stay visa waiver on behalf of the European Union. I support the conclusion of an agreement allowing citizens from the Member States and citizens of the Kingdom of Tonga to travel visa-free for 90 days for all categories of persons travelling for any purpose other than paying for work. The conclusion of the agreement is the result of good relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, but also the announcement of even better cooperation, particularly as regards the dialogue on human rights and fundamental freedoms in Tonga.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Tonga as a country does not theoretically represent any threat to the EU, either in terms of illegal immigration or in terms of security and public order. The short-stay visa requirement could be lifted, but there are no measurable data and no real-world tests have been carried out in areas relating to public policy and security, but also in the Union's external relations with that country.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's relations with the ACP countries have developed greatly in recent times, especially in the context of the Cotonou Agreement. In these circumstances, the EU's relations with Tonga have also developed positively, strengthening the political dialogue between the two sides. In recent years, Tonga has made important progress towards democratisation and respect for human rights, especially after the first free elections in 2010. The role of civil society organisations has also increased, which has helped to intensify debate on the abolition of the death penalty, religious freedom, combating violence against women and gender equality. The abolition of short-stay visas for nationals of the two parties would be a positive message in the light of good bilateral relations of late. This important step would help to strengthen social, cultural and business relations between the two parties, including the development of the tourism sector. I believe that this measure is welcome and I express my support for this recommendation.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I acceded to the rapporteur's request. The signed agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Tonga nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for up to 90 days of 180-day stay. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official, or special) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Tonga Agreement, which will allow visa-free travel for the citizens of the EU and for the citizens of Tonga when travelling to each other’s territories, for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This is a highly significant step for the political relations between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga, which have developed in the context of the Cotonou Agreement. I am certain that this visa exemption will also send out a positive message of support for the recent efforts made by the Kingdom, and further intensify the cooperation on sensitive issues such as the death penalty, freedom of religion and belief, and gender equality.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the abolition of short-stay visas, as I believe it further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I believe that the visa waiver can be seen as a positive sign of support for the country and the extensive efforts it is making as it poses no threat to the European Union, neither in terms of irregular migration nor in terms of security and public order.  The signed Agreement allows Citizens of the European Union and the citizens of Tonga to stay without a visa on the territory of another Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons, holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, official and special passport, the purpose of which does not include the performance of paid activity.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the short-stay visa waiver on behalf of the European Union, as the agreement allows citizens of the European Union and the citizens of the Kingdom of Tonga to travel visa-free to the territory of the other Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The agreement on the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, which has great political importance in the context of the Cotonou Agreement, and will further contribute to strengthening economic and cultural relations and deepening political dialogue on various issues. Since the first democratic elections in 2010, the political dialogue between the EU and the Kingdom of Tonga has been intensifying. The country has made considerable progress in this time. The country's economy is mainly based on the agricultural and service sectors, and tourism is gradually evolving. The lifting of the visa requirement is an important step on the road to bringing the EU and the Pacific nations closer together, as it would support the country and its many efforts.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, the purpose of which is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other contracting party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Short-Term Visa Waiver Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and tonga nationals travelling to the EU for up to 90 days of 180-day stay. Given the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, we are opposed to any liberalisation of visa regimes. I'm voting against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union, through its actions, should support countries that follow the path of democracy, freedom and respect for human rights. Visa liberalisation not only enables tourism to develop and investment to grow, but also provides an opportunity to promote the values on which the European Union is founded. As a global policy actor, the EU should ensure that economic and cultural relations with different regions of the world are strengthened. I hope that this agreement will allow for increased cooperation with the Pacific countries, which is why I voted in favour of the abolition of short-stay visas for the people of the Kingdom of Tonga.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga are governed by the Partnership Agreement (Cotonou Agreement) between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part. The visa waiver agreement for short-stays is both a success of deepening relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, and another instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to open negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, the purpose of which is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other contracting party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Short-Term Visa Waiver Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Voted in favour. Good results are that nationals of Tonga will be able to travel to the Schengen area without visas and also EU nationals to Tonga without visa.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Tonga when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I believe that this agreement represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga, which is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement. Moreover, the agreement is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. By this agreement, the European Parliament consents to the agreement already negotiated between the European Commission and the Kingdom of Tonga to provide the country with short-term visa waivers. Since the European Parliament's Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs has issued a positive recommendation at the conclusion of this agreement, I think it is appropriate to vote in its favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Tonga are in line with the Partnership Agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific States. The Agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Tonga who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. Visa waiver is an important element for bringing the peoples closer to Europe and the Pacific. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens to fully benefit from the ACP-EU partnership. Supported.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The Agreement provides for visa waiver for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Tonga (Kingdom of the South Pacific) if they travel to the territory of the other Party for a maximum of 90 days in a period of 180 days. The report itself reveals that the tourism sector is undeveloped, that the European Union plays little role in trade relations and that the economy is more state-organised. The argument is that there are "possible" positive effects on investment and tourism. This is not reason enough for me to support the report.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga on the short-stay visa waiver, since the Kingdom of Tonga does not pose a threat in terms of irregular migration, nor does it pose a threat to security and public order. The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Kingdom of Tonga and will allow citizens to travel at a lower cost in economic and practical terms.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is a step forward for relations between the European Union and Colombia. I voted in favour of reducing the bureaucratic burden on the free movement of persons in the event of travel for professional reasons, tourism or family reunification. This vote is a further sign of strengthening economic political relations between these states and the Union.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this visa facilitation report, so that Colombians can make short-term trips, without the need to meet that requirement, to any of the countries of the Union, with the exception of the United Kingdom and Ireland, as well as that of the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands. The agreement signed by the EU and Colombia, allows citizens of the Latin American country to travel to the European territory for a maximum period of 90 days every 180 days and covers all persons who hold any type of passport – from the ordinary to the official. They can enter the Union without being required to have a visa when travelling for any reason except to work, for which a specific permit is required. We Socialists are proud of an achievement in which we have made every effort. This is a major step forward in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia and one more way to strengthen economic and cultural relations between the two sides and to intensify political dialogue, including issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the visa waiver of citizens of the Republic of Colombia during trips of up to 90 days to the European Union, and for European citizens on trips of the same duration to Colombia. Although this agreement has been negotiated opaquely and without taking into account the positions of the European Parliament, I am in favour of visa-free processes which allow the right to freedom of movement to be exercised with fewer restrictions.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this agreement, which provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and British nationals travelling to one of the Eu's Member States for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. This agreement follows the Commission's report highlighting a significant improvement in the economic and social situation in Colombia. I consider that the reasons given do not justify granting Colombians visa liberalisation, especially at a time when the Member States of the Union are facing an unprecedented migration crisis.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a technical report which was concerned with the Croatia joining the EU-Colombia / Peru Free Trade Agreement. As I oppose the free trade agreement, and am also concerned about serious human rights violations in Colombia, I abstained on this report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. We have succeeded in reaching a comprehensive and balanced agreement with all political groups on this text which will strengthen social and cultural ties between the European Union and Colombia. This agreement will open up opportunities for EU citizens, who will now be able to travel to this country without a visa.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation of the agreement between the EU and Colombia on the short-stay visa waiver, as this agreement will create opportunities and advantages for European citizens, as any visa requirement to be able to travel to that country is abolished. The agreement also includes a joint declaration on cooperation on irregular migration in which the EU and Colombia reaffirm their commitments regarding the readmission of illegal immigrants.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report plans to liberalise visas between Colombia and the European Union. Not only should liberalisation be opposed because of the current migration invasion in European countries and the harmful logic of which it is taking place, but it is also necessary to question the relevance of lifting the visa requirement for Colombian nationals travelling to the territory of one or more Member States for up to 90 days over a total period of 180 days. Although the situation in Colombia has improved in recent years, it is still far too delicate and these two scourges of drug trafficking and organised crime persist. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I voted against this report. I do not believe that the European Union should be negotiating waiving visa agreements on behalf of the UK.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for an AGREEMENT between the EU and Colombia on the short stay of visa waiver. The agreement signed establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and Colombia travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service and/or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose other than persons who are on paid employment.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. As our old continent is going through an unprecedented migration crisis, the "European" Union is multiplying the so-called visa liberalisation agreements. "In light of the overall positive assessment" carried out by a European Commission which considers that Colombia is experiencing a "relatively stable regime", the Brussels bureaucrats have therefore decided to exempt Colombians from visas for "short-term stays" in Europe. And these great Democrats in the Commission did not even wait for the European Parliament to docilely validate their decision: indeed, this visa liberalisation agreement came into force the day after it was signed on 2 December... "pending the approval of the European Parliament." The chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee said he was aware that "organized criminal groups [...] could take advantage of the removal of the visa requirement, for example by increasingly resorting to drug and money smugglers."  Nevertheless, there is no way for this first-class Euroglobalist to question this ill-fated agreement: the drug traffickers who thrive in this country of nearly 50 million people will appreciate it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved this agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas for up to 90 days over any 180-day period for the Republic of Colombia.  This will not only strengthen economic and cultural exchanges, but also promote political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Gabriel report approving the eu-Colombia visa waiver agreement for short-stay stays. The text establishes a visa waiver for EU citizens and citizens of Colombia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons regardless of the reason for the stay provided that this is not linked to the performance of a paid activity. The agreement will also make possible future cooperation on politically relevant issues such as human rights, impunity and the protection of the rights of children and women, particularly in armed conflicts.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to initiate negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, the purpose of which is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other contracting party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Short-Term Visa Waiver Agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. After the subscription of the EU-Colombia Agreement and the dramatic progress made in relations between the Union and this South American State, it would be a countersent to oppose this agreement to facilitate travel, relationship and contacts between Colombia and the EU. Personally, even before the importance it has in the economic sphere, I would like to stress that all these kinds of decisions are a backing point to the Colombian peace process. The country's potential will be multiplied by stability and social justice in line with achieving peace. This factor has further reduced the risk of illegal immigration.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Once again, I objected to an agreement between the European Union and a third country to exempt visas for short stays.  This is Colombia, which was already the subject of a Commission report in October 2014. In this one, the Commission justifies the liberalisation of visas for the short stays of Colombians on European territory... because of the security that would have improved in Colombia! While I am pleased that this country is now experiencing some stability from this point of view, it has nothing to do with the eu's control over the flow of people within its borders. On the other hand, I do not believe that the strengthening of cooperation on return and the implementation of proper border controls will be sufficient.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text on the agreement between the EU and Colombia on short-term visas contains unclear passages, which convinced me to prefer a vote to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this visa facilitation report so that Colombians can make short-term trips, without the need to meet that requirement, to any of the countries of the Union, with the exception of the United Kingdom and Ireland, as well as that of the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands. The agreement signed by the EU and the Republic of Colombia, allows citizens of the Latin American country to travel to the European territory for a maximum period of 90 days every 180 days and covers all persons who hold any type of passport – from the ordinary to the official. They can enter the Union without being required to have a visa when travelling for any reason except to work, for which a specific permit is required. We Socialists are proud of an achievement in which we have made every effort. This is a major step forward in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia and one more way to strengthen economic and cultural relations between the two sides and to intensify political dialogue, including issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia on visa waiver in the case of short stays. The agreement signed establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and Colombia travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service and/or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose other than persons who are on paid employment. This agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short-stay stays is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This agreement will also help to strengthen regional cohesion, as Colombia is one of the few Latin American countries whose citizens are still subject to visa requirements and will be a rather important factor for european nations and Colombians.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays is both a success of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, which is of great political importance, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  With regard to mobility, the available data show that the reliability of visa applicants is high and there are few applications rejected. The country poses no threat to irregular migration, security or public order. I also consider it important that the visa waiver is not a negligible means of eddation between the people of the European Union and the citizens of the country concerned. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the partnership in a full, cheaper and simpler way.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and British nationals travelling to the EU for up to 90 days of 180-day stay. I have nothing against the citizens of this country, but given the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, I am opposed to any visa liberalisation. So I voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained on this report, which is a proposal to waive visa requirements for all EU and Colombian citizens for a 90 day period. However, I have concerns in relation to the free trade agreement and the current Colombian government’s standards in relation to human rights. I am also not satisfied that the Colombia government is doing enough to tackle and dismantle the paramilitaries and to prosecute those that finance and support them. Without criminal records or prosecutions, people who have committed or helped facilitate human rights violations, political assassinations, and other illegal acts such as land grabbing could freely enter the EU. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The drafting of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia on short-stay visa waivers is an important mechanism capable of deepening economic relations and cooperation between the two territories in question, while supporting the development of European soft power in the world. This mechanism will also make it possible to strengthen cultural relations between the two areas and to intensify political dialogue on a large number of issues, in particular respect for and protection of human rights, as well as on the fight against organised crime and drug trafficking. Only by working closely and on time, through an inclusive process, with a context such as colombia, which is at the root of many of the flows of illegal products to the European Union, can we hope to combat the complex transnational problems mentioned above more effectively.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and nationals of the Republic of Colombia who travel to one of the EU Member States for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. This agreement follows the Commission's report highlighting a significant improvement in the economic and social situation in Colombia. We consider that the reasons given do not justify granting Colombians visa liberalisation, especially at a time when the Member States of the Union are facing an unprecedented migration crisis. We know for a fact that the "Old Continent" is extremely attractive, especially in terms of social protection, encouraging a significant number of tourists to come and enjoy these social benefits; it would therefore be wise to fight social tourism instead of liberalising their visas. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement on the exemption from the requirement of a short-stay visa is a strengthening of the partnership between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, constituting progress towards deepening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The Agreement provides for a visa-free travel scheme for the benefit of Union citizens and nationals of the Republic of Colombia travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party, including all categories of persons. With regard to concerns about illegal migration, confidence in visa applicants in Colombia has increased as it does not pose risks related to irregular migration, with a low level of visa refusal (4.3%). As a result, this republic poses no threat from the perspective of mobility and public security. The agreement also provides for increased cooperation on irregular migration, in which the EU and Colombia reiterate their commitment to the readmission of their own irregular migrants. I have expressed myself in favour of this agreement, because I believe that it is a partnership that benefits both parties, helping to extend the rights of free movement for the benefit of both Union citizens and nationals of the Republic of Colombia.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this visa facilitation report so that Colombians can make short-term trips, without the need to meet that requirement, to any of the countries of the Union, with the exception of the United Kingdom and Ireland, as well as that of the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands. The agreement signed by the EU and the Republic of Colombia, allows citizens of the Latin American country to travel to the European territory for a maximum period of 90 days every 180 days and covers all persons who hold any type of passport – from the ordinary to the official. They can enter the Union without being required to have a visa when travelling for any reason except to work, for which a specific permit is required. We Socialists are proud of an achievement in which we have made every effort. This is a major step forward in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia and one more way to strengthen economic and cultural relations between the two sides and to intensify political dialogue, including issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia providing for visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of Colombia who travel to each other's territory for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of stays aimed at carrying out a paid activity. This agreement will be useful in strengthening economic and cultural relations between the EU and Colombia and in intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. It will also make it possible to strengthen the regional coherence of EU policies, since Colombia belongs to a minority of Latin American countries whose citizens still need a visa and remains a not insignificant factor in bringing the peoples of Europe and Colombia closer together.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on short stay visa waivers with Columbia, although it will not apply to Ireland since Ireland does not participate in the Schengen acquis. For other EU countries, this vote means that citizens from Colombia and the EU will have a maximum period of 90 days for visa-free travel when visiting the territory of the other party.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of the Agreement that allows visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and Colombia. The short-stay visa waiver will have a positive impact on our relations with Colombia. Clearer and easier travel arrangements are bound to have a positive effect on our cultural and economic ties.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Short-stay visa waiver is an important step in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries. Colombia has characteristics (i.e. meet certain conditions) which allow this measure to be introduced smoothly.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the short-stay visa waiver agreement and believe that it contributes decisively to the strengthening and deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the recommendation on the agreement between the European Union and Colombia on the short-stay visa waiver is a step towards improving relations between the two sides, also with a view to improving the conditions of movement and living of citizens. As I believe it is moving in the right direction, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Colombia is a trading partner with excellent potential as it has a dynamic and growing economy, thanks also to its availability of natural and agricultural resources that attract a lot of investment. Although there are still risks from the point of view of irregular immigration, it can be seen that the situation has improved considerably and I believe that Europe can benefit greatly from this agreement. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Given the generally favourable assessment of the situation regarding Colombia, the Council adopted on 19 May 2015 a decision authorising the Commission to open negotiations with a view to the conclusion of the bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia. The negotiations were held on 20 May 2015 and the agreement was initialled by the chief negotiators on 9 June 2015. An official ceremony was held on the occasion of the EU-CELAC Summit on 10 June 2015. The agreement was signed on 2 December 2015 in Brussels. Since that date, the agreement has applied provisionally, pending approval by the European Parliament. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Colombia when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union carries out a visa policy, in particular with regard to the exemption of short-stay visas. This exemption is defined at European level as it is valid for all Member States except the United Kingdom and Ireland. Moreover, among the various requirements for the conclusion of the agreement is to include reciprocity. In other words, European citizens also no longer need a visa. Another criterion that must be taken up is respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, which is also the case here. However, the need for close monitoring in this area should be stressed.  It is up to the European Parliament to give its consent to the agreement for its establishment. That's right. But here too there are specificities that, as the Committee on Foreign Affairs pointed out, stem from the FARC. It is therefore essential to ensure that these organised crime groups do not benefit at any point in the agreement, given the obvious repercussions this would have on European security - but also colombian.  For all this, I vote in favour of the conclusion of the Agreement with the Republic of Colombia.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The conclusion of an agreement with the Republic of Colombia on short-stay visa waiver would be an important achievement for the European Union's relations with Colombia and an opportunity to strengthen economic and cultural relations. Furthermore, this agreement would allow the opening of a political dialogue also in the field of protection of citizens' fundamental rights and freedoms. I voted in favour of approving this agreement, which would also bring mutual economic benefits due to the intensification of trade and economic relations between the European area and the Republic of Colombia.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Trade Agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru will now take account of the accession of Croatia to the European Union. It also contains provisions on the origin of goods, technical barriers to trade, sanitary and phytosanitary measures, competition, intellectual property and public procurement. I agree with the consent to the conclusion of the additional protocol on the participation of Croatia in the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the visa waiver of citizens of the Republic of Colombia during trips of up to 90 days to the European Union, and for European citizens on trips of the same duration to Colombia. Although this agreement has been negotiated opaquely and without taking into account the positions of the European Parliament, I am in favour of visa-free processes that allow the right to freedom of movement to be exercised with less restrictions

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement on the exemption from the requirement to hold a short-stay visa constitutes a success in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic relations. In terms of mobility, Colombia has taken great steps to stop irregular migration. I voted for a strategic partnership in the field of security and the fight against organised crime, as well as for a strengthening of cooperation between the European Union and Colombia.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 By araking Regulation (EC) No 539/2001, the Republic of Colombia has been transferred to third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The agreement was signed in 2015 and has since been provisionally approved by the European Parliament. Citizens of the European Union and Colombia may travel visa-free for any journey to the territory of the other Party for a maximum of 90 days within any 180-day period.  A short-term visa waiver would strengthen economic and cultural relations between the European Union and Colombia. Colombia is the EU's fourth most important economic partner in the region and the EU is Colombia's second most important trading partner. Colombia's natural and agricultural conditions attract investors, so a visa waiver would make it easier for investors to travel, making it easier to build the Colombian economy and trade. More and more Colombians are visiting the EU for holidays, so visa-free travel could increase this number further. Furthermore, Colombia can be an important partner in stopping organised crime and drug trafficking, a declaration of cooperation has been made.  Today, the European Parliament has given its consent to the conclusion of the agreement, which I voted in favour of.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Last December, the EU signed identical agreements on the short-stay visa waiver with the Republic of Palau, the Kingdom of Tonga and the Republic of Colombia. As provided for in the agreements, EU citizens will be able to spend 90 days without a visa in these countries in any 180-day period, as will nationals of those countries in the EU. In order to benefit from visa-free travel, EU citizens and signatory countries must have a valid passport: ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special. However, the abolition of short-stay visas does not apply to persons travelling for gainful employment. The Agreements are already applied provisionally after unanimous support from the Schengen Governments of the Council, but the consent of the European Parliament is required for their full conclusion. The United Kingdom and Ireland will not participate in the agreement as their visa regimes remain subject to national legislation. I personally see these agreements as a way of promoting people-to-people contacts in the countries in question. They should provide trade opportunities in view of the increase in tourist numbers and help promote economic relations between the EU and these countries. I therefore did not object to these agreements and voted in favour of them.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and Colombia on the exemption of short-stay visas. The agreement will allow a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Nationals of Colombia who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. However, it was necessary for the agreement to provide certain security guarantees. It also contains not only a declaration on the implementation of biometric passports, but also a commitment by both sides for cooperation in the fight against irregular migration.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Nationals of Colombia travelling to the EU for up to 90 days of 180-day stay. In view of the current migration crisis, any visa liberalisation would be an irresponsible measure. However, risks are considered "manageable" through increased cooperation on return and the implementation of border controls. In a report, the Commission found that Colombia's security, economic and social situation had improved significantly in recent years. In her view, this justifies the need for Colombians to be able to access the territory of the EU states without a visa. Having disagreed with this approach, I voted against it.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this agreement which marks a significant milestone in the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations. The agreement will also make it possible to cooperate further in the field of human rights and to pursue a balanced, regular, in-depth political dialogue on more specific issues such as impunity, human rights defenders and security for women and children in armed conflicts, issues which remain priorities for the EU.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the EU-Colombia agreement on the short-stay visa waiver. According to the agreement signed in December last year, a new visa-free regime applies to European citizens and reciprocally for palau citizens when they travel to Europe for 90 days. It is important to note that this visa regime does not apply to citizens taking trips for work or other paid activity. I believe that the benefits of this agreement will have a beneficial effect on the tourism sector and promote bilateral business relations.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Colombia, a typical South American country, faces numerous challenges due to long internal conflicts, drug cartels and the dangers of illegal immigration. Above all, there is a lack of democracy and respect for basic human rights. In this light, any short-stay visa waiver agreement is a wrong political and moral decision.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Colombia is the EU's fourth economic partner in the region, with trade volume amounting to €11.884 billion. The EU is Colombia's second trading partner. Foreign trade accounts for about 20% of GDP. Visa-free travel will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, strengthen economic ties between businesses and facilitate investment. In this sense, this Agreement will strengthen relations between the two parties and give a new impetus to trade. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia and is also an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it: we have nothing against the citizens of these countries, but given the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, we are opposed to any visa liberalisation.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, the Republic of Colombia has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States. Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 amended applies to all Member States except Ireland and the United Kingdom. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens from Member States of the European Union and for nationals of Colombia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. As on other similar occasions, we voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the EU and the Republic of Colombia, as it is a key instrument for strengthening economic, political and cultural relations between the two parties. Colombia has become a key partner for the EU in the field of security and the fight against organised crime, especially for drug trafficking.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 This particular agreement is about continuing to deepen the above-standard relations between the EU and the Republic of Colombia. The visa waiver agreement will have positive effects for both parties, as it simplifies travel conditions for entrepreneurs while facilitating investment and dynamising tourism. The agreement in question has the potential to strengthen the area of investment and trade, which have strong development potential in the future.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstain as Colombia is a country with strong emigration and not yet stable.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Colombia, a typical South American country, faces numerous challenges due to long internal conflicts, drug cartels and the dangers of illegal immigration. Above all, there is a lack of democracy and respect for basic human rights. In this light, any short-stay visa waiver agreement is a wrong political and moral decision. For these reasons I am voting against the EU-Colombia Agreement on short-stay visa waiver.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas marks a significant milestone in the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The agreement will also strengthen regional coherence, given that Colombia is one of the minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa and is of considerable importance in bringing the peoples of Europe and Colombia closer together. The agreement also contains a joint declaration on cooperation with regard to irregular immigration in which the EU and Colombia reaffirm their undertakings regard to the readmission of irregular migrants. This agreement will open up opportunities and advantages also for EU citizens, as any existing requirement for EU citizens to travel to these countries will be eliminated.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Colombia when travelling to each other’s territory, for a maximum period of 90 days. This Agreement is significant for stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues. We call on the Commission and the authorities of Colombia to ensure enhancing the cooperation agreement concerning irregular migration. Colombia should also become a key partner in the field of security and the fight against organised crime, including drug trafficking, which represent an important aspect of cooperation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation on the basis of compliance with the agreements signed between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia with the desire for this agreement to represent a new achievement in relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, as well as a supplementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue. In this way, the agreement will allow the Republic of Colombia, its nationals to no longer need visas to enter the European Union, this factor also encourages rapprochement between Europeans and Colombians.

I voted in favour of this visa facilitation report so that Colombians can make short-term trips, without the need to meet that requirement, to any of the countries of the Union, with the exception of the United Kingdom and Ireland, as well as that of the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands. name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to adopt this agreement between the EU and the Republic of Colombia on short-stay visa waiver as I believe that this agreement will serve as a good stepping stone to further political, economic and cultural cooperation between the EU and Colombia. The Colombian economy has experienced rapid growth during the last years and the EU is its second largest trading partner while itself being the EU’s fourth largest trading partner in the region. Allowing visa free travel will serve to achieve closer business links and facilitate investments and tourism in both the EU and in Colombia. Lastly I believe that an intensified political dialogue with Colombia could allow us to deepen our cooperation on several other issues such as security issues and organised crime.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the EU and Colombia, and also of similar recommendations concerning Council decisions concerning agreements with the Kingdom of Tonga and Palau on short-stay visa waivers. The agreements underlying these decisions provide for visa-free travel for citizens of both parties for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days and cover all categories regardless of the reason for their stay, with the exception of those aimed at carrying out paid employment. I strongly supported the conclusion of these agreements, because they certainly represent an important opportunity to deepen relations between the European Union and these countries, as well as an additional instrument for improving economic and cultural relations through an open and frank political dialogue on major issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the EU-Colombia visa waiver agreement for short stays, as I consider the mutual abolition of the short-stay visa requirement to be justifiable and beneficial in terms of mutual tourism or economic development.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the visa-free regime between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia. It will apply to all categories of persons and all travel purposes, except for for-profit stays. The visa waiver is valid for a maximum of 90 days in a period of 180 days.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. Last December, the European Union and the Republic of Colombia signed an agreement on the mutual exemption of short-stay visas for nationals of both parties. However, Colombia is still in conflict with FARC guerrillas. Although peace negotiations are currently underway, this conflict has not yet been resolved.  It therefore appears risky to abolish short-stay visas with this country, especially since, apart from the guerrillas, this exemption could also facilitate the work of drug smugglers. So I voted against that proposal.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to initiate negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, the purpose of which is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other contracting party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Visa Waiver Agreement for short-term stays is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement between the EU and Colombia will open up opportunities and advantages for both the citizens of Colombia and the EU, as any existing visa requirements for EU citizens to travel to Colombia will be eliminated.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The new visa regime provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens when travelling to the territory of Colombia and for citizens of Colombia when travelling to the EU, for a period of stay of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this visa facilitation report so that Colombians can make short-term trips, without the need to meet that requirement, to any of the countries of the Union, with the exception of the United Kingdom and Ireland, as well as that of the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands. name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the agreement on a visa waiver for short-stay Colombian citizens. However, we are critical of the procedure chosen and leaving Parliament out, and it is simply being asked for approval.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas marks a deepening of relations between the EU and Colombia and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Colombia is the EU’s fourth most important economic partner in the region, with a trade volume of EUR 11 884 billion. The EU is Colombia’s second trade partner. External trade represents around 20% of GDP. The visa waiver will simplify conditions for travel by businesspeople, strengthen economic links among businesses and facilitate investments. Colombia is experiencing strong growth (+ 20% growth between 2009 and 2013 and + 4% in 2014) owing to the scale of its natural and agricultural resources and the development of mining and hydrocarbon sectors. In this context, this agreement will make it possible to step up relations between the two parties and to impart fresh impetus to trade. In addition, the number of Colombian tourists in the EU has increased in the past years (increase of 5% annually). Visa liberalisation is likely to further increase tourist flows between the two, as well as investment in tourism.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this agreement as it supports the good relations between the EU and Colombia while also benefitting EU citizens.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution provides for a reciprocal visa waiver for short-term stays, up to a maximum of 90 days within a 180-day period, between the EU-Schengen states and the Republic of Colombia. Since this visa waiver is only valid if the traveller is not required to carry out a paid activity in the destination country during the stay and an official identification document must be available, there is no risk of irregular labour migration. On the contrary, this agreement simplifies travel, establishes personal contacts and strengthens the tourist economy. In the case of Colombia, it should also be borne in mind that this dynamically growing country, which favours free trade, is not only the EU's fourth largest trading partner in the region. Colombia is also a key partner in the fight against organised crime and illicit drug trafficking. The agreement demonstrates the will ingness to cooperate further in this area as well. I agree to the agreement for these reasons. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the visa requirement for Colombian nationals because I believe that the risk of migration and security is low from that country. Indeed, if criminal networks and cartels still exist, it will be difficult for them to return to the territory of the Member States by air without being identified. On the other hand, I am much more concerned about the decision to grant short-stay visa exemptions to countries in our immediate vicinity whose migration and security risk is high, such as Ukraine, Georgia and Turkey. Visa policy is not just an instrument. It is also a political and geostrategic choice. However, it must not only take into account what it will bring to the third country concerned, but also the impact it will have on the Member States.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As shadow rapporteur for the report on the EU-Colombia agreement on the short-stay visa waiver agreement, I support the report as I believe that the abolition of visa requirements for short-term visits will stimulate cross-border dialogue between Member States and Colombia. The safeguard clauses contained in the agreement for suspending or terminating it in the event of a security risk or risk of migration, as well as the cooperation agreement concluded between Colombia and Europol, ensure that the agreement will only benefit the EU, Colombia and their citizens.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia on exemption from the requirement to hold a short-stay visa for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Republic of Colombia travelling within the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for a period of 180 days in order to further encourage trade , investment, tourism and economic progress.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for the Recommendation on the Draft Decision of the Council on the Conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia on the waiver of short-stay visas, as this gives consent for the conclusion of that Agreement. The country is one of the few Latin American countries whose nationals still need an EU visa.   This Agreement will give the possibility to the process of approximation of european and Colombian peoples, which is extremely important for many reasons, and one of them is the fact that Colombia is the FOURTH ECONOMIC PARTNER of the EU from the region and the volume of trade with it amounts to as much as EUR 11.884 billion.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. These three agreements provide for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and nationals of Palau, Tonga and Colombia who travel to the EU for up to 90 days over any 180-day period. We have nothing against the citizens of these countries, but given the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, we are opposed to any visa liberalisation. I objected to these three texts.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this visa facilitation report so that Colombians can make short-term trips, without the need to meet that requirement, to any of the countries of the Union, with the exception of the United Kingdom and Ireland, as well as that of the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands. The agreement signed by the EU and the Republic of Colombia, allows citizens of the Latin American country to travel to the European territory for a maximum period of 90 days every 180 days and covers all persons who hold any type of passport – from the ordinary to the official. They can enter the Union without being required to have a visa when travelling for any reason except to work, for which a specific permit is required. We Socialists are proud of an achievement in which we have made every effort. This is a major step forward in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia and one more way to strengthen economic and cultural relations between the two sides and to intensify political dialogue, including issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the granting of visa-free travel for short stays in favour of Colombia, given that all the necessary conditions were met. Granting visa-free travel will facilitate short stays of up to 90 days for students, diplomats or tourists. It is also a step in the long-term deepening of relations with the Union, as well as another way to intensify economic and cultural relations and strengthen political dialogue with Colombia, including on human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the conclusion of an agreement with the Republic of Colombia to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report concerns an agreement between the EU and the Republic of Colombia on the visa waiver for the citizens of Colombia in the European Union. Visa waiver is a national task and better lifted in the Council or the Schengen Group than at pan-European level. That is why I am voting against this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this agreement to enable visa-free travel between other EU Member States and Palau, Tonga and Colombia. The agreements would not affect the UK, which has its own national visa agreements with these countries.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution provides for a reciprocal visa waiver for short-term stays, up to a maximum of 90 days within a 180-day period, between the EU-Schengen states and the Republic of Colombia.
