Since this visa waiver is only valid if the traveller is not required to carry out a paid activity in the destination country during the stay and an official identification document must be available, there is no risk of irregular labour migration. On the contrary, this agreement simplifies travel, establishes personal contacts and strengthens the tourist economy. In the case of Colombia, it should also be borne in mind that this dynamically growing country, which favours free trade, is not only the EU's fourth largest trading partner in the region. Colombia is also a key partner in the fight against organised crime and illicit drug trafficking. The agreement demonstrates the will ingness to cooperate further in this area as well. I agree to the agreement for these reasons.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The Council adopted a decision authorising the Commission to initiate the visa waiver agreement for EU citizens and citizens of Colombia who travel to other territories for a maximum period of ninety days over a period of one hundred and eighty days. The EU is Colombia's second largest trading partner, so for this reason, this agreement complements the relationship established between the two states, and is also a suitable instrument for strengthening economic, cultural and political relations, and will tend to strengthen economic ties between different companies and facilitate their investment. I also believe that Colombia can become a key partner in the field of security and the fight against organised crime, with particular reference to drug trafficking.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Nodding palm trees, caressing seaside, azure ocean, this is obviously the image that most people will like when they hear the name of the country: Colombia. If you don't, it's drug trafficking, emerald smuggling, counterfeiting. According to 2015 statistics, 2 of the world's 10 most dangerous cities are in Colombia, based on homicides per 100,000 inhabitants, and the country as a whole ranks 23rd, but before that it is largely war-fighting countries. Is it good for us if weary mobsters can come to the EU visa-free? That said, if you're only visiting here for tax optimization or corruption, you're in the right place.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution because Colombia is an important political and economic partner for the EU in Latin America. The agreement on the waiver of short stay visas is an important step in deepening EU’s relations with Colombia which are built on political dialogue, trade and development cooperation and cover a wide range of bilateral, regional and multilateral issues. Moreover, the visa waiver will simplify conditions for travel by businesspeople, strengthen economic links among businesses and facilitate investments. Visa liberalisation is likely to further increase tourist flows between the EU and Colombia. However, there are concerns that with visa liberalisation the level of irregular migration, human and drug trafficking will increase. Therefore, we should further enhance and strengthen cooperation between the EU and Colombia in the fight against irregular migration and organised crime.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I am opposed to any visa liberalisation.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia on the exemption of short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for British nationals travelling to the EU for up to 90 days of 180 days. I have nothing against the citizens of this country, but given the scale of the migration crisis in Europe and the security problem that follows, I am opposed to any further visa liberalisation. The Commission concluded that Colombia's security, economic and social situation has improved "significantly" in recent years, justifying that Colombians should be granted visa-free access to member states' territory. The risks associated with visa liberalisation were considered "manageable", despite the problem of organised crime and drug trafficking. We all know these kinds of promises...

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. Colombia was the subject of a Commission report in October 2014 to assess the situation. The balance sheet was in favour of the state, noting the improvement in the security, economic and social situation in recent years. The text submitted to the vote builds on this observation to create an agreement with the country. This agreement provides for the establishment of a visa-free travel regime between nationals of both parties, for a maximum of 90 days over any 180-day period. However, despite promises of increased cooperation and border control, visa liberalisation is a risk not to be taken, given the current migration crisis. My vote is against it.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this visa facilitation report so that Colombians can make short-term trips, without the need to meet that requirement, to any of the countries of the Union, with the exception of the United Kingdom and Ireland, as well as that of the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands. The agreement signed by the EU and the Republic of Colombia, allows citizens of the Latin American country to travel to the European territory for a maximum period of 90 days every 180 days and covers all persons who hold any type of passport – from the ordinary to the official. They can enter the Union without being required to have a visa when travelling for any reason except to work, for which a specific permit is required. We Socialists are proud of an achievement in which we have made every effort. This is a major step forward in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia and one more way to strengthen economic and cultural relations between the two sides and to intensify political dialogue, including issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of visa free travel between the EU and Colombia for short periods of 90 days for travel purposes except for carrying out a paid activity.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the visa waiver of citizens of the Republic of Colombia during trips of up to 90 days to the European Union and for European citizens on trips of the same duration to the Republic of Colombia. Although this agreement has been negotiated opaquely and without taking into account the positions of the European Parliament, I am in favour of visa-free processes which allow the right to freedom of movement to be exercised with fewer restrictions.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This agreement is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia. I believe that this agreement will strengthen regional coherence, as the Republic of Colombia is part of a minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa, and is still a not inconspicable vector for the rapprochement between Europeans and Colombians. We must first take into account that the EU is the second trading partner of the Republic of Colombia and secondly, the potential with which the Republic of Colombia has thanks to the abundance of natural and agricultural resources and the development of the hydrocarbons and mining sectors, which are attracting more and more investors. The Republic of Colombia can also become a key partner in the field of security and the fight against organized crime. Many challenges shared by the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, justifying the importance and need to strengthen cooperation through a visa-free agreement for short-term stays.  For the reasons set out above, I vote favorably for the adoption of this recommendation.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution provides for a reciprocal visa waiver for short-term stays, up to a maximum of 90 days within a 180-day period, between the EU-Schengen states and the Republic of Colombia. Since this visa waiver is only valid if the traveller is not required to carry out a paid activity in the destination country during the stay and an official identification document must be available, there is no risk of irregular labour migration. On the contrary, this agreement simplifies travel, establishes personal contacts and strengthens the tourist economy. In the case of Colombia, it should also be borne in mind that this dynamically growing country, which favours free trade, is not only the EU's fourth largest trading partner in the region. Colombia is also a key partner in the fight against organised crime and illicit drug trafficking. The agreement demonstrates the will ingness to cooperate further in this area as well. I voted in favour of the agreement for these reasons.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 While at Palau or Tonga I voted in favour of visa-free travel, in the case of Colombia against. Visa-free travel with Colombia poses a risk, given that so far the relatively high proportion of visa applications rejected has been 4-8%. There is also an increased risk of drug smuggling.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. In view of Colombia's generally positive assessment, the Council adopted a decision on 19 May 2015 authoring the Commission to start negotiations on the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia. The agreement was signed on 2 December 2015 in Brussels and has since been provisionally applied pending approval by the European Parliament. The signed agreement allows citizens of the European Union and Colombia to stay without a visa in the territory of another Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons whose purpose of the trip does not include the performance of a paid activity. This Agreement is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia and further strengthens economic and cultural relations and political dialogue on various issues. This Agreement will also allow for strengthening regional coherence, as Colombia is one of the few Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa and is a non-negtiable factor in the process of bringing the European and Colombian peoples closer.  With Colombia being the EU's fourth economic partner from the region with trade volumes of as much as €11.9 billion, the visa waiver will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, strengthen economic ties between businesses and facilitate investment. For these reasons, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The AGREEMENT between the EU and Colombia on the abolition of short-stay visas provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and Colombian citizens travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of travellers (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) travelling for any purpose, except for the purpose of gainful employment. The agreement concluded can be seen as a rather positive incentive for the further development of economic, cultural, political dialogue and, in principle, a factor that will help to combat organised crime more effectively. It is worth noting that the EU is Colombia's second largest trading partner, while the number of mutual tourists is growing rapidly every year. One of the main reasons for approving this agreement was that the situation in recent years in the area of colombian entry refusals, arrests and return statistics and the relevant risks improved significantly. The agreement also includes a joint declaration on cooperation on illegal migration. In view of the above and the future prospects for the development of EU-Colombia relations , particularly in the field of security and the fight against organised crime, it was quite logical to vote positively.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia on the short-stay visa waiver because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. These three texts provide for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and nationals of Palau, Tonga and Colombia who travel to EU Member States for up to 90 days. Due to the current migration crisis in Europe, we are opposed to any liberalisation of the visa regime. Furthermore, we are dubious about strengthening cooperation on return and the proper implementation of border controls, which are necessary to limit the risks posed by this liberalisation.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the EU-Colombia agreement on short-stay visa waivers is in my favour. This agreement is based on the intention to deepen relations between the European Union and Colombia, thus intensifying cultural and economic relations. Simplifying travel conditions also facilitates and encourages investment by promoting a general improvement. Colombia is also an important trading partner, and this treaty certainly also promotes closer dialogue on issues such as human rights. Finally, it can become a key partner in the field of security and the fight against organised crime, in particular drug trafficking.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The deepening of relations between the EU and the Republic of Colombia is always good news. That is why my support for the recommendation to sign the agreement between the EU and this country on visa waiver for short-term stays, which will result in increased economic and cultural exchanges and, without a doubt, an intensification of political dialogue. The agreement also includes a joint declaration on cooperation in the field of irregular immigration in which the Union and the Republic of Colombia recall their commitment to the readmission of their irregular migrants. We also want the Republic of Colombia to become a key partner in the field of security and the fight against organized crime, especially drug trafficking, which can represent an important aspect of cooperation.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Partnership Agreement between the EU and the African, Caribbean and Pacific States includes the Republic of Colombia. Through this agreement and on the basis of Regulation No 136/66/EEC, the Commission has adopted a proposal for a directive on the protection of the 509/2014, the Republic of Colombia is one of the countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement for crossing the external borders of the Member States of the Union. Since the entry into force of the Regulation, the Commission has been in negotiations with the Republic of Colombia on a bilateral agreement which remains for parliament's approval. This agreement shall include the right of Union or Colombian citizens to travel to the territory of the Contracting Parties without a visa requirement for a maximum of 90 days. I am voting in favour of the adoption of the agreement, so that there can be closer relations between the Union and that country at political and cultural level, with a view to promoting the basic principles and values of the Union and strengthening the protection of human rights.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is about the visa waiver for short stays between the EU and Colombia. Colombia is an important economic partner, but the government is unstable. I therefore see no reason to change the visa regime.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the agreement on visa-free travel with the Republic of Colombia in the case of short stays. I am pleased that the agreement contains a declaration of cooperation on irregular migration, in which the Union and Colombia recall their commitment to the readmission of irregular migrants.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. When cooperation with certain third countries allows, a reciprocal short-stay visa exemption (usually mainly for tourism) is negotiated. The Council, representing the states, decides. The criteria observed are as much the political situation, respect for human rights, as well as the type of migration. In practical terms, the absence of "irregular migration risk". This is Colombia, with which the EU has signed specific free trade and readmission agreements (return of migrants). Considering that Colombia is one of the only countries in Latin America whose citizens do not have a short-stay visa exemption to travel to the EU, I vote in support.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens, but also for nationals of the Republic of Colombia, for a maximum of 90 days out of 180. I am opposed to any liberalisation of visa regimes, in view of the migration crisis we are experiencing, and I have opposed this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU-Colombia Agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Colombia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days.  Colombia is a very important partner in Latin America, and it is therefore an important agreement for strengthening relations between the two parties, particularly in economic and cultural areas, enabling dialogue and learning on issues of civil liberties and human rights.  Peace negotiations between the Colombian Government and the FARC are closely monitored by the European Parliament, and it is important to obtain assurances that organized crime groups will not benefit from the agreement, causing security problems in Europe, but also in Colombia.  I voted in favour of the European Parliament's recommendation on the draft Council decision.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Colombia when travelling in the other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I supported this resolution as it is an opportunity to deepen economic relations and develop tourism.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the approval given by the European Parliament to the conclusion of the visa-free agreement with Colombia. This agreement is a further step towards strengthening relations between the Union and this Latin American country. There are many and varied areas in which the EU and Colombia can cooperate fruitfully. Political dialogue on human rights, security and the fight against organised crime and irregular migration are among the actions and policies for which both sides have a strong interest in working together.  The strengthening of ties with Colombia, enshrined here by the visa-free agreement, will also provide a new impetus in the areas of trade, tourism and investment. More generally, I am pleased that with this visa-free agreement, Colombia is joining the other Latin American states whose nationals are already exempt from the visa requirement, as this contributes to the coherence of the Union's action vis-à-vis this continent.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Colombia is one of a small number of Latin American countries whose nationals still need visas, which is still a not inconsiderable vector of the european population's convergence with Colombians. This agreement will further strengthen economic relations between the Member States of the Union and Colombia, as the Union is its second trading partner. The agreement also contains a joint declaration on cooperation on illegal immigration, in which the Union and Colombia reiterate their commitment to the readmission of their own illegal migrants. Colombia can also become a key partner in the field of security and the fight against organised crime, in particular drug smuggling, which can be an important part of cooperation. These are all challenges that the Member States and Colombia also face, justifying the importance and need to strengthen cooperation with the short-stay visa waiver agreement. I therefore consider the abolition of visas to be beneficial for both parties, and I am therefore voting in favour of the proposal in question.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this agreement, which marks a significant milestone in the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia. The visa facilitation agreement will make it possible to cooperate further in the field of human rights and to pursue a balanced, regular, in-depth political dialogue on more specific issues such as impunity, human rights defenders and security for women and children in armed conflicts, issues which remain priorities for the Union. The agreement also contains a joint declaration on cooperation with regard to irregular immigration in which the EU and Colombia reaffirm their undertakings regard to the readmission of irregular migrants. Colombia may also become a key partner in the field of security and the fight against organised crime, including drug trafficking, which can represent an important aspect of cooperation. These are all challenges faced by the European Union and the Republic of Colombia alike, showing how important and necessary it is to enhance cooperation by means of a short-stay visa waiver agreement. This agreement will open up opportunities and advantages also for EU citizens, as any existing requirement for EU citizens to travel to these countries will be eliminated.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council submitted a draft decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia on the exemption from short-stay visas. In order to adopt the decision, it must obtain parliament's consent. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Relations between the EU and the Republic of Colombia are governing the Partnership Agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific States, on the one hand, and the European Union and its Member States, on the other, called the 'Cotonou Agreement'. As part of the amendment to Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, the Republic of Colombia has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States.  The Council adopted a decision in 2014 authorising the Commission to open negotiations for the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the EU and the Republic of Colombia. The Agreement provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of Colombia and Tonga who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period.  In view of the foregoing, I am in favour of concluding the Agreement.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. In view of the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, I oppose any liberalisation of visa regimes, and therefore vote against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement to enable visa-free travel between other EU Member States and Colombia. The agreement would not affect the UK, which has its own national visa agreement with this country.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Nationals of Colombia for stays of up to 90 days over any 180-day period. As long as there is reciprocity and the length of stays is limited, the visa exemption for third-country nationals does not raise any difficulties. I also support the presence in this report of a readmission commitment at the request of one of the parties, in the event of an increase in irregular migration.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mariya Gabriel's report. The European Parliament must give its approval to the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, which has already been negotiated between the Republic of Colombia and the European Commission. The aim of the proposal is to reach an agreement with the Republic of Colombia to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas. This agreement takes into account the situation of the Member States which do not yet apply the Schengen acquis in its entirety. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and nationals of the Republic of Colombia who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official, or special) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I vote in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and Colombia on the exemption from short-stay visas. This agreement is an excellent opportunity to further boost tourism, facilitate investment and dynamise trade. Colombia is now the EU's fourth largest economic partner in the region. In addition, the agreement offers new allies to join forces on issues of such importance as the fight against terrorism. We also see the emergence of political dialogue as a positive, most often aimed at joint action against corruption, criminal networks and trafficking in human beings.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Following a favourable assessment of the situation in the Republic of Colombia the European Council adopted on the 19th of May 2015 a decision that authorises the Commission to open a negotiation with a view to the conclusion of the bilateral agreement between the EU and the Republic of Colombia. I have voted for this recommendation that will provide visa-free travel for the citizens of the two parts when travelling to the other for a maximum period of 90 days.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I have also spoken out against this report. The agreement provides for visa waiver for citizens of the European Union and citizens of Colombia if they travel to the territory of the other Party for a maximum of 90 days in a period of 180 days. Because of the instability of government, I cannot speak in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Agreement provides for the possibility for EU and Colombian citizens to travel on a short-stay visa-free basis to the territory of the other Party. The Agreement will, inter alia, allow for further cooperation on human rights and will help address issues such as human rights defenders and the security of women and children in armed conflicts. Colombia can become an important partner in the EU's action against drug trafficking and, for example, the signing of a strategic cooperation agreement with Europol is essential to prevent organised crime.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement between the EU and Colombia will allow the development of political dialogue between the parties; dialogue regulated by the Rome Declaration of 1996 and the Memorandum of Understanding signed in 2009. Considering the percentage of Schengen visa applicants, the rate of visa refusal was 4.3 % in 2014, it can be accepted that there has been a decrease in refusals as an expression of greater confidence on the part of Member States. I can vote in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Free movement within the European community’s is one of the most important freedoms of the European Union. This is why I vote in favour of the waiver of short-stay visas, as for the citizens of the European Union and Colombian people. I believe that the agreement will bring nations closer together and this is crucial part to the development of people’s relations. Businesses will also benefit greatly from this agreement and more specifically the tourism, a key part of every counties economy.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree to the conclusion of the agreement with the Republic of Colombia on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. This provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Republic of Colombia when travelling to the corresponding territory on a short-term basis for all purposes other than carrying out a paid activity.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This Short Stay Visa Waiver Agreement further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia. Colombia is the EU's fourth economic partner from the region and the EU is Colombia's second largest trading partner. The visa waiver will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, strengthen economic ties between businesses and facilitate investment.  Thanks to its rich natural and agricultural resources and the development of the oil and ore sectors, Colombia has seen strong growth. The number of Colombian tourists in the EU has increased in recent years (annual growth of 5%), and a number of European companies have already invested a lot of money in hospitality and tourism infrastructure, and visa liberalisation can further increase tourist traffic between the two sides.  The agreement contains a joint declaration on cooperation on illegal immigration, and Colombia can also become a key partner in the field of security and the fight against organised crime, in particular against drug trafficking. It is also not negligible that this agreement will allow for strengthening regional coherence, as Colombia is one of the few Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa, so I support this agreement and I believe that such a decision will help in the process of bringing the European and Colombian peoples closer.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. In view of the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, I oppose any visa liberalisation, and therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ This Agreement on the abolition of short-stay visas is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia and further strengthens economic and cultural relations and intensifies political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This Agreement will also allow for strengthening regional coherence, as Colombia is one of the few Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa and is a non-negtigible factor in the process of bringing the European and Colombian peoples closer. Colombia is the EU's fourth economic partner from the region, with trade volumes of as much as €11.884 billion. The EU is Colombia's second largest trading partner. Foreign trade represents about 20% of GDP. The visa waiver will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, strengthen economic ties between businesses and facilitate investment. The Republic of Colombia has one of the most dynamic and open economies in the region. Thanks to rich natural and agricultural resources and the development of the oil and ore sectors, which are attracting more and more investors, Colombia has seen strong growth (20% between 2009 and 2013 and 4% in 2014). To that end, this Agreement will allow for strengthening relations between the two sides and will give trade a new zest.  For this reason, I support the EU-Colombia Agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, the Republic of Colombia has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States. Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 amended applies to all Member States except Ireland and the United Kingdom. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Colombia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. We voted in favour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The agreement on the abolition of short-stay visas helps strengthen relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue. Colombia's foreign trade represents about 20 percent of the world's GDP, and the visa waiver will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs and facilitate investment. The agreement also contains a joint declaration on cooperation on illegal immigration and it is important to highlight the signing of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement with Europol, which represents an important progress in strengthening cooperation in the field of fighting organised crime, in particular against drug trafficking.  In line with all of the above, I supported Mep Gabriel's recommendation on an Agreement that will strengthen relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. – Colombia is now one of the few South American countries whose citizens need visas to travel to the EU. In my opinion, this should also change, given that Colombia is the fourth economic partner for the Union in the region. As regards the political situation and the state of state institutions, The Republic of Colombia is one of the oldest formal democracies on the continent and its political system is relatively stable. I therefore see no reason to prolong the visa waiver.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The signed agreement establishes visa-free travel for Union citizens and citizens of the Republic of Colombia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. Colombia is the EU's fourth largest trading partner in the region, accounting for €11,884 billion in trade. The EU is Colombia's second largest trading partner. External trade accounts for about 20% of GDP. The visa waiver will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, strengthen economic ties between businesses and facilitate investment. I voted in favour of this agreement because it represents an opportunity to enhance economic relations and tourism, another key sector for the development of this country that could attract many European citizens both as tourists and as investors.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which approves the agreement between the European Union and Colombia on the exemption of short-stay visas.  This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Colombian nationals travelling to the territory of the other party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.  Colombia is now concerned with the issuance of biometric passports for its nationals and a readmission agreement is provided in the event of an increase in regular migration.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Short Stay Visa Waiver Agreement, which is the culmination of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia and is also an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  This Agreement will strengthen regional coherence, as Colombia belongs to a minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need visas, and remains an important element for bringing the Peoples of Europe and Colombia closer.  Colombia is the EU's fourth economic partner in the region and is one of the most dynamic and open economies in the region. This Agreement will strengthen relations between the two parties and give a new impetus to trade.  The Republic of Colombia is one of the oldest formal democracies on the continent and has a relatively stable regime. The Agreement also contains a joint declaration on cooperation on irregular immigration in which the Union and Colombia recall their commitment to the readmission of undocumented migrants.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has just voted this afternoon in favour of a new, more flexible visa regime between the European Union and Colombia. The privileged relations between the EU and this South American country, coupled with the fact that Colombia is no longer a country with a sulphurous reputation, justify the conclusion of such a short-stay visa waiver agreement, which allows Colombian citizens to travel freely in Europe for 3 months, and vice versa. This agreement applies to all categories of people regardless of their reason for travel (e.g., tourism, cultural visits, scientific activities, family visits, business, etc.), except for paid activity. This is an additional opportunity for the European Union to get closer to Colombia by promoting contacts between populations and by enabling the development of tourism activity. This sector is doing very well, as evidenced by the 17.5% growth between August 2014 and 2015 in the number of Colombian travellers visiting the European Union, or about 310,000 per year in 2014. Everything suggests that this agreement will have a positive impact on European tourism in the coming years.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The Short Stay Visa Waiver Agreement is the culmination of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia and is also an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  The Agreement will also strengthen regional coherence, as Colombia belongs to a minority of Latin American countries whose nationals still need visas, and remains an important element for bringing the Peoples of Europe and Colombia closer.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report which gives the European Parliament the approval of the agreement between the EU and Colombia on the short-stay visa exemption signed on 2 December 2016.  This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Colombian nationals on the territory of the other contracting party. The stay is for a maximum of 90 days over any 180-day period.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 European integration ensured the free movement of people in Europe. It is gratifying to see that the Commission is also trying to ensure the free movement of Europeans in the world. The agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia on visa waiver in the case of short-stay stays is a successful and welcome example of such activities, which will foster bilateral relations.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After a globally positive assessment of the situation in Colombia in May 2015, the Commission began negotiations for the conclusion of a bilateral agreement with the European Union. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and Colombia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days.  The EU is Colombia's second trading partner, so visa-free travel conditions for entrepreneurs, strengthening economic ties and facilitating investment and boosting trade.  In the tourism sector, the number of Colombian tourists in the EU has increased in recent years, and has encouraged several European companies to make considerable investments in hotel and tourist infrastructure, so visa liberalisation could be likely to further increase tourist flows and investments between the two parties. As one of the oldest formal democracies on the continent and with a relatively stable regime, Colombia shares with the EU multiple challenges justifying the importance and need to strengthen cooperation, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia on the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Colombian nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia on visa-free travel for nationals of the countries concerned for short stays in the territory of the Contracting Party represents an important stage in the history of relations between Europe and Colombia and a means of intensifying political, economic and cultural dialogue between the two parties. For all these reasons and in line with the position of my group, the PPE, I voted in favour of the recommendation presented by Mr Gabriel.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to initiate negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, the purpose of which is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other contracting party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Visa Waiver Agreement for short-term stays is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. The agreement gives EU citizens visa-free travel in Colombia. This is beneficial for EU citizens as they are now free to travel to and from the country without restriction. However, it is important that the rules laid down for the duration of your stay are always adhered to.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the EU-Colombia visa waiver agreement because it improves and facilitates business relations and binds the recently economically successful country more closely to Europe.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the visa waiver of citizens of the Republic of Colombia during trips of up to 90 days to the European Union, and for European citizens on trips of the same duration to Colombia. Although this agreement has been negotiated opaquely and without taking into account the positions of the European Parliament, I am in favour of visa-free processes which allow the right to freedom of movement to be exercised with fewer restrictions.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement between the EU and Colombia will open up opportunities and advantages for both the citizens of Colombia and the EU, as any existing visa requirements for EU citizens to travel to Colombia will be eliminated.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I am eager to foster freedom of movement for citizens of responsible third country nations who will visit, study and work in the EU, and was happy to support this visa liberalisation.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ this short-stay visa waiver agreement not only represents a successful completion of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, but also creates the conditions for further intensifying political dialogue. The Republic of Colombia has one of the most dynamic and open economies in the region. The agreement will make it possible to strengthen relations between the two parties and give a new impetus to trade. Vast natural and agricultural resources, oil sectors, mines attract more and more investors. The agreement on visa liberalisation will allow for even greater cooperation in the field of human rights and will make it possible to continue a balanced regular and intensified political dialogue on specific issues such as impunity, the safety of women and children in armed conflicts. Colombia can become a key security partner against organised crime, in particular drug smuggling. I support the rapporteur, who calls on the European Commission to implement and monitor the agreement in order to observe the possible development of possible illegal immigration, including issues relating to respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution provides for a reciprocal visa waiver for short-term stays, up to a maximum of 90 days within a 180-day period, between the EU-Schengen states and the Republic of Colombia. Since this visa waiver is only valid if the traveller is not required to carry out a paid activity in the destination country during the stay and an official identification document must be available, there is no risk of irregular labour migration. On the contrary, this agreement simplifies travel, establishes personal contacts and strengthens the tourist economy. In the case of Colombia, it should also be borne in mind that this dynamically growing country, which favours free trade, is not only the EU's fourth largest trading partner in the region. Colombia is also a key partner in the fight against organised crime and illicit drug trafficking. The agreement demonstrates the will ingness to cooperate further in this area as well. I agree to the agreement for these reasons.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Opening up opportunities for citizens of other countries to get to know the European Union and establish cultural, economic and academic relations here is an important part of our foreign policy. However, all existing rules on restricting the entry of persons who may be potentially at risk, in particular as regards crime and terrorism, must be respected.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EU-Colombia Agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas allows citizens of the European Union and Colombian citizens to stay visa-free on the territory of another Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any 180-day period. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, official and special passport) whose purpose of travel does not include the performance of paid activity.  I support the report on the Agreement between the European Union and Colombia on the abolition of short-stay visas, as such an agreement is the result of efforts to deepen relations between the EU and the Republic of Colombia and will further strengthen economic and cultural relations, intensify political dialogue on issues such as those on human rights and fundamental freedoms.  Furthermore, this Agreement will allow for further strengthening of regional coherence, as Colombia is one of the few Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa. Therefore, the Agreement is significant for the process of approximation between the European and Colombian peoples.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support this agreement to enable visa-free travel between other EU Member States and Palau, Tonga and Colombia. The agreements would not affect the UK, which has its own national visa agreements with these countries.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia on the short-stay visa waiver. This Agreement provides for visa waiver for citizens of eu Member States and Citizens of Colombia if they travel to the territory of the other Party for a maximum of 90 days in a period of 180 days.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. In December 2015, a bilateral agreement was signed between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia. This Agreement allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of Colombia to stay visa-free on the territory of another Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any 180-day period and applies to all categories of persons whose purpose of the trip does not include the performance of paid activity. Colombia is the European Union's fourth economic partner from the region, and the visa waiver will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, strengthen economic ties between businesses and facilitate investment. In terms of tourist traffic, the number of Colombian tourists in the European Union has increased significantly. In terms of mobility, data on entry bans, arrests and returns show that Colombia was at risk in terms of irregular migration.  However, it should be acknowledged that the situation has improved significantly in recent years. I support this Agreement because I believe that this can make Colombia a key partner in the field of security and the fight against organised crime, in particular against drug trafficking.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia on the short-stay visa waiver. I support the conclusion of an agreement allowing citizens from the Member States and citizens of the Republic of Colombia to travel visa-free for 90 days for all categories of persons travelling for any purpose other than paying for work. The agreement is an excellent opportunity to deepen relations between the two contracting partners, including strengthening political dialogue on issues related to human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's agreement by the European Parliament to conclude an AGREEMENT between the EU and Colombia on the abolition of the visa requirement for short stays. This consent from the European Parliament comes after member states that are the only ones able to assess the security aspect have agreed to introduce a visa-free regime with Colombia and after an agreement on visa waiver has been concluded between the EU and Colombia to ensure equal treatment of all EU citizens without distinction. The European Parliament is therefore now giving its consent to the conclusion of this treaty after the possibility of introducing a visa-free regime has already been assessed by the Member States. It can be added that all third-country nationals are subject to a 90-day stay limit every 180 days. The same applies to the agreement with Tonga and Palau, which the EP also agreed to conclude today.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Colombia, a typical South American country, faces numerous challenges due to long internal conflicts, drug cartels and the dangers of illegal immigration. Above all, there is a lack of democracy and respect for basic human rights. In this light, any short-stay visa waiver agreement is a wrong political and moral decision.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has very good relations with the countries of Latin America and promotes their consolidation through all existing instruments. Colombia is one of the few countries in the region whose nationals still need short-stay visas. This was due to the fact that, internally, the country was crushed by a long and costly conflict with farC guerrillas. In recent years, however, significant progress has been made in this regard, in particular following the adoption of the Victims and Land Restitution Act in 2011 and the start of peace negotiations in 2012, which could soon be concluded with a final agreement. At the same time, Colombia has a competitive democratic regime and respects human rights and fundamental freedoms, making important progress in ensuring the security of women and children against armed conflicts and in combating organised crime. The abolition of short-stay visas would provide an additional impetus for the reforms still needed and would help strengthen relations between the EU and Colombia, in particular in the area of combating drug and human trafficking, illegal migration, security security and cooperation in the cultural, social and business fields. I support the adoption of this recommendation.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I acceded to the rapporteur's request. The signed agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and British nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for up to 90 days of 180-day stay. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official, or special) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Colombia agreement, which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the EU and for the citizens of Colombia when travelling to each other’s country for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This is a much-awaited step, as Colombia is one of the few countries in Latin American whose nationals still need a visa to travel to Europe. This agreement will be an opportunity to bring the peoples of Europe and Colombia closer together, and will also be beneficial in terms of economic cooperation and trade, as Colombia has become one of the most dynamic and open economies in the region. Finally, I hope that this will contribute to concluding the final peace agreement between the government and FARC in Havana.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia on the waiver of short-stay visas. The agreement to abolish short-stay visas is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia.  I believe that this Agreement will allow for strengthening regional coherence, as Colombia is one of the few Latin American countries whose nationals still need a visa. The visa waiver will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, strengthen economic ties between businesses and facilitate investment. I also believe that the Agreement will make important progress in strengthening cooperation between the Union and Colombia in the fight against organised crime, as evidenced by the willingness to continue cooperation in this area.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia on the short-stay visa waiver on behalf of the European Union, as it represents a deepening of cultural, economic and, above all, political relations between the EU and Colombia. Visa liberalisation would also allow for further cooperation in the area of human rights. Trade between the two is very important and the agreement would allow for even closer cooperation and new impetus in the area of trade. The EU is closely monitoring respect for human rights in a country marked by a long-running conflict with the FARC guerrilla. Progress has been made in this area and could even lead to a final peace agreement in the short term. Colombia can also become a key partner in the area of security and the fight against organised crime, in particular drug trafficking, which can be an important aspect of cooperation.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to initiate negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, the purpose of which is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other contracting party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Visa Waiver Agreement for short-term stays is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Nationals of Colombia travelling to the EU for up to 90 days over any 180-day period. Given the scale of the migration crisis in Europe, we are opposed to any visa liberalisation. I'm voting against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Republic of Colombia is one of the few Latin American countries whose residents still need a visa to travel to the European Union. I believe that the abolition of short-stay visas will make it possible to strengthen cooperation links. I believe that political dialogue should be continued in order to further strengthen the principles of democracy and fundamental freedoms in the Republic of Colombia. Despite the existing risks (m.in, it is necessary to seek an agreement, which is why I voted in favour of the abolition of short-stay visas for the people of the Republic of Colombia.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays is both a success in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The agreement would also strengthen regional coherence, as Colombia is one of the few Latin American countries whose citizens need visas and would thus make a major contribution to the convergence of Europeans and Colombians. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Council authorized the Commission to initiate negotiations with a view to concluded a bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, the purpose of which is to establish a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of those countries travelling to the territory of the other contracting party where the stay is not more than 90 days for each 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity. This Visa Waiver Agreement for short-term stays is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Voted in favour. Good results are that nationals of Colombia will be able to travel to the Schengen area without visas and also EU nationals to Colombia without visa.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. By this agreement, the European Parliament consents to the agreement already negotiated between the European Commission and the Republic of Colombia to provide the country with short-term visa waivers. Since the European Parliament's Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs has issued a positive recommendation at the conclusion of this agreement, I think it is appropriate to vote in its favour.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. We have voted on three short-stay visa waiver agreements for nationals of the Republic of Colombia, the Republic of Palau and the Kingdom of Tonga. The GUE/NGL is in principle in favour of freedom of movement, visa liberalisation, including short-stay. However, I would like to point out that it is a pity that these visa exemptions are increasingly being used as a gift following the signing of the free trade agreement, or as a blackmail tool. In the case of Colombia, for example, these visa exemptions came at the right time in an attempt to overshadow the disastrous consequences of the recent entry into force of the free trade agreement with the European Union. They also raise questions when the fight against organised crime is pitted against visa liberalisation by refusing to accept many countries geographically close to the EU. Two weights, two measures in this area as in many others. Given the current difficulties for Colombian nationals in obtaining these visas, I can only support this facilitation.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, the Republic of Colombia has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States. Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 amended applies to all Member States except Ireland and the United Kingdom. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Colombia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity.  The Republic of Colombia has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States. Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 amended applies to all Member States except Ireland and the United Kingdom. Support.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The agreement provides for visa waiver for citizens of the European Union and the citizens of Colombia if they travel to the territory of the other Party for a maximum of 90 days in a period of 180 days. Although Colombia is definitely an important economic partner, it does not have a stable government on the one hand and internal conflicts on the other. There are also still serious concerns about human rights. That is why I cannot understand the need to abolish visa regimes across the national level.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Colombia on the short-stay visa waiver. The Agreement allows citizens of the European Union and Colombia to travel visa-free to the territory of the other Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The agreement is also an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and deepening political dialogue on various issues and cooperation in the area of irregular migration.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The first ITA agreement was concluded in Singapore in 1997, with the number of acceding states originally equal to 29 and, today, equal to 82. The main purpose of the agreement is the reduction and subsequent elimination of duties on a number of computer products, such as telephones, computers, and machinery. The catalogue of goods has been expanded over time. The benefits of ITA, such as lower costs, improved interactions and development, will be even more visible in 2019, the deadline for the complete elimination of duties. However, there are critical issues in the text which led me to abstain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 The expansion of the ITA agreement facilitates the technological exchange of semiconductors, machinery, lenses, GPS, medical devices etc. between a total of 54 countries under the WTO. However, due to asymmetry among participating countries, it functions in practice as a mechanism to strengthen the technological and financial dependence of developing countries, benefiting large European, US and East Asian multinationals. That's why I voted against it.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement is an extension of the 1996 information technology agreement. It aims to eliminate tariffs on almost all information technology products by 2019.  On 16 December in Nairobi, the WTO Ministerial Conference was held in Nairobi, during which the members of the organisation developed a timetable for the abolition of tariffs on 201 information technology products valued at 1,300 billion euros per year. Next-generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, machine tools used to make circuit boards, telecommunications satellites and touch screens are affected.  I objected to this agreement, which includes a passage on the removal of non-tariff barriers. This free trade agreement, like the previous ones, will help exacerbate the unfair international competition that weighs on our businesses.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report had a particularly regressive and unconstructive agenda. Its aim was to increase developing countries’ dependence on IT multinationals by expanding the Information Technology Products Agreement (ITA) ITA is a trade agreement which primarily profitable large companies who can now buy and sell these products without any tariffs. ITA signatories often argue that the agreement is very good for developing countries because it will increase their trade and therefore their GDP. In reality, not many developing countries are signatories to the agreement. With every expansion of the agreement it will be harder for them not to join the agreement as the agreement increases their dependency. Moreover, when tariffs are eliminated, developing countries will also lose a significant amount income out of duties that they would normally receive from their exports. Therefore, this is an agreement that will not help developing countries develop; it will only help multinationals trading in technology (related) products. It was for these reasons that I voted against this report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. We supported this recommendation. The expansion of information technology products is expected to boost the EU's manufacturing sector, making it easier to access new markets. It should continue to promote employment, provide lower prices for consumers and stimulate economic growth, and foster innovation.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement in the form of a declaration on the extension of trade in information technology products (ITA), because this extension will strengthen the EU construction industry, allowing easier access to new markets.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The first Convention on Trade in Information Technology Products, or ITA for short, entered into force in 1997. It was only concluded between 29 WTO Member States at the time, but now has 82 members. According to the ITA, each participant must eliminate the duties on all it products covered, which has led to increased trade in the sector. Although the technology has evolved and changed since the ITA came into force, the ITA's coverage remained the same. For this reason, the ITA needs to be expanded, because it has great potential for job creation and growth. That is why I supported the proposal to approve Parliament's agreement on the convention and I share the view that more Member States should subscribe to this convention.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement is an extension of the 1996 WTO-brokered agreement on information technology. In principle, this new agreement should reduce tariffs on nearly 200 products such as next-generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical products (magnetic resonance imaging equipment, machine tools used to manufacture circuit boards, telecommunications satellites, touch screens, etc.).  Together with my colleagues on the National Front, we oppose these agreements, which have the effect of weakening our nations in the face of competition from countries in which there are shameful working conditions. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I abstained. I do not believe that the European Union should be negotiating trade agreements on behalf of the UK.

name: Margrete Auken (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. The agreement to expand trade in information technology under the WTO is in itself a clear step forward. The multilateral system of the WTO is important, and I would prefer it to work and to make a statement here. That is why I voted in favour of the agreement. A large part of the industrial goods covered by the ITA agreement are now being moved from the Doha negotiations. The most important argument against the ITA agreement can therefore be that we weaken the Doha negotiations. But the Doha Round is if not dead, at least in a deep coma. It is a major problem that the industrialised countries are hiding behind Doha, rather than quickly accommodating developing countries with increased liberalisation of agricultural products. The European Union, in particular, has a protectionist agricultural policy, which must be stopped as soon as possible. Instead of waiting for progress in the Doha negotiations, the EU should remove its agricultural protectionist actions - by itself. It will be fair and benefit developing countries, but also be a win for European consumers.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒  The Information Technology Agreement (ITA) today counts 82 WTO Member States as participants. Each participant must eliminate and require customs duties at zero for all information technology products (IT) covered. The duty free treatment of IT products has been crucial in the development and expansion of trade in the IT sector. In July of 2015, an agreement was reached to expand the product coverage of the agreement between 27 members. By 2019 almost all of the imports of the relevant IT products will be duty free. The expansion of the ITA is important for trade, and this is the first major tariff cutting deal since the inception of the WTO. I voted for this resolution because of the huge potential to create jobs and increase the GDP of the EU. It is important for the EU to not just give its consent to the agreement, but to ensure that more members join the agreement to create a beneficial situation for all.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The first Agreement on trade in information technology products (ITS) was concluded in 1996. It requires each participant to undertake to abolish customs duties and to apply a zero rate of duty to all information technology products covered by this Agreement, in accordance with the most-favoured-nation principle. May 2012 Six countries (THE EU, USA, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Costa Rica) have entered into negotiations with a view to extending the list of products covered by this Agreement. Products covered by this Agreement include a new generation of semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical devices that include magnetic resonance imaging formaters, machine equipment for the production of printed circuits, telecommunications satellites and touchscreens. This agreement will reduce prices for consumers as well as prices for producers who depend on imported ingredients. The extension of ITS is a historic agreement, the first since the WTO was established to agree on tariff cuts, with great potential for job creation and GDP growth, and I therefore support the conclusion of the agreement.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement is an extension of the 1996 Information Technology Agreement, following the WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi in December 2012, at which THE members of the Organization considered a historic agreement to eliminate tariffs on 201 information technology products. The agreement also includes a commitment to work to remove non-tariff barriers in this sector, and to leave the list of affected products open so that it can be expanded in line with future technological developments.  This type of extension of an existing agreement allows many products to enter the free trade circuit, which is catastrophic for the French economy; I therefore voted against this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The first Information Technology Agreement (ITA) was adopted in 1996 and focused on eliminating tariffs on all information technology products (e.g. computers and telephones). In 2015, an agreement on an additional list of 201 products was reached and is subject to approval by the European Parliament. I have endorsed this point, which will enable, in particular, an increase in EU exports as a result of the reduction of tariff barriers.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Quisthoudt-Rowohl report approving the agreement on the extension of trade in information technology products. The aim of the text is to eliminate customs duties for all information technology products such as computers, telephones, but also for inputs, components and machinery for the production of it goods. The first ITA agreement, signed in 1996, had to be expanded to include 201 new products whose commercial value was estimated at more than $1.3 billion per year, about 10% of today's total global trade. The expansion of the ITA is an important milestone and will have enormous potential for job creation and for stimulating GDP growth in Europe.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against this report in considering that the ITA agreement, far from contributing to the coverage of the technological gap of developing countries, presents risks of impacting inversely in these countries, harming not only the collection of resources via customs, but also increasing south/north technological dependence and exposing the scarce business fabric to lethal competition by highly technified countries. In addition, the environmental impacts arising from this industry are not covered throughout the document.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. The Agreement on Information Technology and Trade in Derived Products (ITA) is an adaptation in line with the staggering of the planned tariff disarmament, which will benefit consumers in prices and supply and introduce more competition in some sectors. It is a stimulus for European innovators and our ability to compete in that market. The tariff disarmament measures adopted forecast european export growth in this sector.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement in the form of a declaration on the expansion of trade in information technology products (ITA). This agreement aims to expand the 1996 agreement on information technology and will eliminate almost all tariffs on information technology by 2019. In addition to the great danger of this measure, which will bring to the wild competition our information technology industry (in the face of giants such as China, Taiwan, South Korea), I would like to stress that once again this wild free trade programme was prepared by the large multinationals meeting in Nairobi on December 16th. By the WTO Director's own admission, this agreement is historic. This will put all our SMEs in the field of GPS navigation systems, imaging equipment and telecommunications satellites at risk. Once again, the large groups, with the complicity of our ruling elites, agree to eliminate all measures to protect the interests of the peoples.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report being voted on is unbalanced and i do not agree with it. I believe that this text opens up a problem for our companies, which would find themselves even more faced with the often unfair competition from third countries. The EU should protect the production and interests of its producers and not those of the rest of the world. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Agreement on Trade in Information Technology Products (ITA) entered into force in 1997 and today covers around 200 information technology products, including not only products such as computers or telephones, but also inputs, components and machinery for the production of information technology goods.  Since its entry into force, however, technological progress has profoundly changed the information technology sector. Therefore, 54 States party to the Agreement have completed a review of the Agreement to include new products such as the new generation of semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical products, printed circuit manufacturing tools, telecommunications satellites or touch screens. 65% of tariffs on these products will be eliminated by 1 July 2016 and, in 2019, almost all of the products in question will be duty-free.
