I supported this revision of the Agreement as it will be positive for the EU economy, which currently exports EUR 189 million in products covered by the itA expansion, for consumers, who will see prices reduced, and for producers, who depend on imported components.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the conclusion of the Agreement as part of the Agreement on the Extension of trade in Information Technology Products (ITS) on behalf of the European Union. ITS requires each participant to undertake to abolish customs duties and to apply a zero rate of duty to all information technology (IT) products covered by this Agreement, in accordance with the most-favoured-nation principle. ITS includes approximately 200 tariff lines, including computers, phones, as well as raw materials, components and equipment for the production of IT goods. The duty-free regime applied by ITS participants played a key role, which has led to a dramatic increase and expansion of trade in the IT sector over almost 20 years. Trade in this sector has quadrupled. However, the technological progress that has taken place during this period has not changed the IT sector beyond recognition and its scope has remained the same. Products covered by this Agreement include a new generation of semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical devices that include magnetic resonance imaging formaters, machine equipment for the production of printed circuits, telecommunications satellites and touchscreens.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has today approved the extension of an important, though little-known, agreement on information technology (ITA) signed within the framework of the WTO. The agreement, signed in Singapore in 1996 and entered into force the following year, has expanded over time to more and more participants, from the initial 29 signatories to 82 today, representing more than 90% of world trade in it goods. After more than twenty years, in the light of the rapid and multiple developments in this area, the agreement needed to be reviewed extensively, and it is in this direction that the European Parliament has expressed itself today. The extension of the agreement agreed by the Strasbourg Assembly provides for the liberalisation of 201 new articles, including GPS, touch-screens, telecommunications satellites and medical equipment. In addition to strengthening the multilateral it trading system, the extension of the agreement should facilitate the export of these products from the EU, to the benefit of our manufacturing sector, and result in higher supply and lower prices for consumers.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement is an extension of the 1996 information technology agreement. Under the agreement, by 2019, tariffs on almost all of these products will be 0,00 for the 82 participating countries. The WTO Director-General said: "This agreement is the first major tariff reduction agreement reached at the WTO since 1996." It also includes a commitment to work to remove non-tariff barriers, and to leave the list of affected products open for review to determine whether further expansion will be necessary to take account of future technological developments. This new free trade agreement further increases the pressure of global competition in this sector with the future consequence of large numbers of job losses in EU countries. It exacerbates our countries' dependence on those with low labour costs in this very strategic area. For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report had a particularly regressive and unconstructive agenda. Its aim was to increase developing countries dependence on IT multinationals by expanding the Information Technology Products Agreement (ITA) ITA is a trade agreement which primarily profitable large companies who can now buy and sell these products without any tariffs. ITA signatories often argue that the agreement is very good for developing countries because it will increase their trade and therefore their GDP. In reality, not many developing countries are signatories to the agreement. With every expansion of the agreement it will be harder for them not to join the agreement as the agreement increases their dependency. Moreover, when tariffs are eliminated, developing countries will also lose a significant amount income out of duties that they would normally receive from their exports. Therefore, this is an agreement that will not help developing countries develop; it will only help multinationals trading in technology (related) products. It was for these reasons that I voted against this report.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Improving the ability to source and sell ICT products at cheaper prices is certainly a good thing, but for the agreement to be of real benefit to the EU and its Member States, care must be taken to ensure that the removal of customs barriers is truly carried out fairly by all contracting parties. Care must also be taken to introduce the implementation of the agreement gradually, and by promoting the accession to the ITA of as many third countries as possible in order to maximise the Union's trade advantage as a world leader in the sector with an export of more than EUR 189 billion per year to non-European countries.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This text aims to eliminate tariffs on almost all information technology products by 2019. On 16 December in Nairobi, the WTO Ministerial Conference was held in Nairobi, during which the members of the organisation developed a timetable for the abolition of tariffs on 201 information technology products valued at 1,300 billion euros per year. This agreement includes next-generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, machine tools used to manufacture circuit boards, telecommunications satellites and touch screens. I have, of course, opposed this agreement, which includes a passage on the removal of non-tariff barriers. On the contrary, we should protect ourselves against this savage globalization that has been responsible for the deindustrialization of Western countries since the early 1980s.  This free trade agreement, like the previous ones, will help exacerbate the unfair international competition that weighs on our businesses. This is why any removal of tariff and non-tariff barriers must be reciprocal and conditional on compliance with anti-dumping laws.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement on the Extension of Trade in Information Technology Products aims to eliminate customs duties on all information technology products that are concerned. The duty-free regime under this agreement plays an important role in strengthening and expanding trade in the information technology sector. Approximately 200 tariff lines including computers, telephones, as well as inputs, components and machines for the manufacture of computer products are concerned. Following the negotiations, 65% of the tariff lines will be completely eliminated by 1 July 2016, with almost all customs duties applicable to imports of the products covered by the agreement to be abolished by 2019. The expansion of the trade in information technology products is a step forward in the process of reducing customs duties, having a major positive impact in boosting employment, as well as in stimulating the growth of gross domestic product, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this agreement.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation today because I consider it of great importance and topicality for the EU to conclude an agreement on the extension of trade in information technology products (ITAs). This agreement will, in my view, result in lower prices for both consumers and producers. The first information technology agreement was concluded at the ministerial meeting in Singapore in December 1996 and entered into force in 1997. Today, ITA has 82 participants. Over the nearly 20 years of application of the agreement, technological advances have radically changed the IT sector, while the products covered by the ITA have remained unchanged. Products covered by this Agreement include next-generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical products, machine tools for the manufacture of printed circuit boards, telecommunications satellites and tactile screens. It is expected that by 2019 almost all imports of the products in question will be duty-free. The enlargement of the ITA is crucial as it is the first real agreement to reduce tariffs since the establishment of the World Trade Organisation.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on the Information Technology Agreement, which is a trade agreement focusing only on technology products. The expansion would see more technology products benefit from the elimination of tariff barriers. I voted against, because this agreement is mostly profitable for large companies. The expansion will also make it more difficult for developing countries not to join, pushing dependency on products from these multinationals. These countries will lost out on a lot of income from duties they normally get from these exports. For this unequal benefit, I voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation to encourage commitment from more Member States into expanding the coverage of duty free trade on information technology (IT) products. Taking into account the leading role of our technologies, our trade policies should always keep up with any IT developments. Eliminating unnecessary tariffs can effectively create more jobs and stimulate economic growth. I am confident that consumers will benefit from lower prices and suppliers will benefit from fewer trading barriers.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement generally seems to be accepted worldwide without any particular protests. The WTO itself regards it as one of the best agreements ever negotiated at international level. However, the ITUC (the World Trade Union Confederation) had been critical of this in 2013, so I preferred to abstain.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as we believe that the enlargement of ITA has enormous potential to create jobs and increase Gross Domestic Product.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this agreement is the progressive abolition of customs duties for a certain quantity of information technology-related products. It is a question of updating the old agreement, concluded twenty years ago and now full of obsolete products and still lacking in everything that has been invented since then. Trade in these products is now estimated at over $1.3 billion, accounting for 10% of today's global trade. In addition, this agreement will lead to lower prices for consumers and an increase in choice. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the agreement.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The ITA requires that each participant eliminates and binds customs duties at zero on a Most Favoured Nation basis for all information technology (IT) products covered. The ITA covers about 200 tariff lines, including computers, telephones, but also inputs, components and machinery for the production of IT goods. The duty free treatment given by the ITA participants has played an important role in the enormous development and expansion of trade that the IT sector has experienced over the close to 20 years of application of the ITA. Trade in the sector has quadrupled. However, during this time span technological progress has changed the IT sector beyond recognition, while the coverage of the ITA remained the same.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The information technology agreement is heading in the right direction towards the progressive reduction of customs barriers and the promotion of trade in information technology products. The data exemption granted to ITA participants has already demonstrated the benefits in terms of expanding trade in the IT sector. In addition, the agreement will favour more competitive prices for consumers and producers who depend on imported components. It should be borne in the view, however, that progressive technological development entails a constant change in the IT sector, which should update the products contained in the ITA Agreement, which are currently unchanged.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is worth taking note that only 29 WTO Member States initially concluded the agreement and today these count to 82 participants. The duty free treatment given by the ITA participants has played an important role in the enormous development and expansion of trade that the IT sector has experienced over the close to 20 years of application of the ITA Annual trade in 201 products valued at over USD 1.3 trillion per year, and accounts for approximately 10% of total global trade today. Taking into consideration that the EU exports EUR 189 billion in products covered by the ITA expansion, a figure that is expected to increase significantly following tariff cuts; the agreement will lead to lower prices for consumers, but also for producers who depend on imported components. I agree with the scope of the report which will lead to the majority of the non-sensitive tariffs to be eliminated at the entry into force of the agreement.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 The expansion of the ITA agreement facilitates the technological exchange of semiconductors, machinery, lenses, GPS, medical devices etc. between a total of 54 countries under the WTO. However, due to asymmetry among participating countries, it functions in practice as a mechanism to strengthen the technological and financial dependence of developing countries, benefiting large European, US and East Asian multinationals. That's why I voted against it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution, which I voted in favour of, authorises the Council to conclude the international agreement on the extension of trade in information technology products. The aim of this agreement is to eliminate tariffs on 201 information technology products worth more than $1.3 billion per year. The economic benefits of the agreement will fall on consumers and producers in Europe and third countries and will result in a greater boost for the European manufacturing sector, which will enjoy easier access to new markets, the creation of new jobs, lower costs for consumers and a boost for innovation.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The first Information Technology Agreement was concluded at the Singapore Ministerial Conference in December 1996 and entered into force in 1997. In 2015, an agreement was reached on an additional list of IT products. The value of annual trade in these products is estimated at over USD 1.3 trillion per year and accounts for about 10% of total world trade at the moment. Products covered by this agreement include GPS navigation systems, a range of medical products, telecommunications satellites and touch screens. I voted for the extension of the Information Technology Agreement because it has the potential to create jobs and stimulate economic growth.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament agrees to conclude an agreement on the extension of trade in information technology products on behalf of the European Union. The extension of the First Information Technology Agreement (ITA) is a milestone. This is the first large-scale tariff reduction agreement with substantial job creation and GDP growth potential since the establishment of the World Trade Organisation (WTO). The first information technology agreement was reached in 1996 and now has 82 participants. The Agreement provides that all participants shall lift duties on information technology products. Trade in the sector has developed considerably through the duty-freeness of products. This development has changed the information technology sector. In 2012, the EU, USA, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Costa Rica initiated negotiations to change the subject. In 2015, an agreement was reached on an additional list of 201 IT products. Sales of these products are estimated at more than $1.3 trillion.  Products on the list include next-generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical products containing magnetic resonance imaging devices, machine tools for the manufacture of printed circuit boards, telecommunications satellites and touch screens. Following the reductions in customs duties, prices will fall and competition in the markets will be more intense. The effectiveness of the above can be increased by joining the agreement as many States as possible.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the conclusion of an agreement in the form of a declaration on the expansion of trade in information technology products (ITA). The agreement provides for the elimination of tariffs on more than 200 information technology products. It will lower prices for consumers, but also for producers who depend on imported components.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In May 2012, five countries (usa, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Costa Rica) together with the EU started negotiations to expand the ita product range. They were later joined by 21 other WTO members. On December 16, 2015, at the WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi, 53 WTO members reached an agreement on a second information technology agreement that includes a timetable for the elimination of duties on 201 IT products worth more than $1.17 trillion per year. Under the agreement, about 65% of tariff items will be completely eliminated by July 1, 2016. The extension of the ITA is the first major tariff cutting agreement since the WTO was established. It also has great potential to create jobs and boost GDP growth. I am a strong supporter of this multilateral agreement, which is why I voted yes.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this initiative since the expanded ITA should boost the EU manufacturing sector and will benefit consumers, producers and the economies of both the EU and partner countries. This landmark deal was one of the significant outcomes from the Nairobi Ministerial meeting. It aims to eliminate tariffs on 201 information technology products valued at over USD 1.3 trillion per year.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Declaration on Trade in Information Technology Products (ITA) is one of the great achievements of the tenth WTO Ministerial Conference last December, in a context still difficult for the advancement of the Doha Development Agenda. In Nairobi, 82 WTO partners agreed to amend the ITA agreement, including some 200 additional high-tech products. These are components for computers and phones, television screens, as well as GPS navigation systems and medical equipment such as scanners and MRI machines. The agreement, which covers 97% of trade in this sector, will see the phasing out of duties for each product, with an estimated global economic value of more than $1.3 billion. The most important result, however, will come from the direct impact on consumers: more of these products will lead to more affordable prices and a wider variety for end-users. The hope is that the European Union, together with its partners, will be able to keep up with one of the fastest growing sectors in world trade over the last decade, with policies that foster innovation and the development of the digital economy and protect citizens and consumers. That is why I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. This report follows the historic agreement reached on 16 December 2015 at the World Trade Organization in Nairobi, which provides for the elimination of tariffs on more than 200 information technology products, such as GPS navigation systems, medical products, telecommunications satellites and touch screens.  I support the approval of this agreement, whereby all imports of communication technology products will benefit from a total elimination of tariffs by 2019. This will lead to a real boost to growth by promoting world trade and EU exports will benefit greatly.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The first Information Technology Agreement ('ITA'), concluded in December 1996 at the Singapore Ministerial Conference, entered into force in 1997. While the agreement was initially concluded by only 29 WTO member states, it now has 82 participants. For all information technology products covered by the Agreement, the ITA requires all participants to lift and fix duties at zero on the basis of the principle of the most favoured nation.  In May 2012, six countries (EU, USA, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Costa Rica) began negotiations to extend the product scope of the agreement. They were joined by 21 other members. On July 24, 2015, an agreement was reached on an additional list of 201 IT products.  Under this Agreement, participants are expected to submit timetables with a phase commitment for each product, for a transitional period of up to 7 years (3 years for normal phases, 5 years for sensitive products and 7 years in exceptional cases). As a result of the negotiations, by 1 July 2016, some 65% of the tariff groups will be completely eliminated. By 2019, almost all imports of the relevant products will be duty-free.   The extension of the ITA is considered to be a milestone. This is the first high-profile tariff reduction agreement with huge job creation and GDP growth potential since the wto was established. I therefore voted in favour of Parliament giving its consent to the agreement.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The first Information Technology Agreement ('ITA'), concluded in December 1996 at the Singapore Ministerial Conference, entered into force in 1997. While the agreement was initially concluded by only 29 WTO member states, it now has 82 participants. For all information technology products covered by the Agreement, the ITA requires all participants to lift and fix duties at zero on the basis of the principle of the most favoured nation. The ITA includes approximately 200 tariff groups, including computers, telephones, input units, components and machines for the production of information technology tools. In May 2012, six countries (EU, USA, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Costa Rica) began negotiations to extend the product scope of the agreement. They were joined by 21 other members. On July 24, 2015, an agreement was reached on an additional list of 201 IT products. Under this Agreement, participants are expected to submit timetables with a phase commitment for each product, for a transitional period of up to 7 years (3 years for normal phases, 5 years for sensitive products and 7 years in exceptional cases). As a result of the negotiations, by 1 July 2016, some 65% of the tariff groups will be completely eliminated. By 2019, almost all imports of the relevant products will be duty-free. The Agreement on the extension of the ITA in the form of a declaration (and the timetables for the intermittent commitment of the participants) was adopted by the ministers of the participating countries on 16 December 2015 at the WTO ... (Written declaration abbreviated in accordance with Article 183 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. On 16 December, at the WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi, members of the organization representing major exporters of information technology products agreed on the timetable for the implementation of a historic agreement. It aims to eliminate tariffs on 201 information technology products, which are valued at $1.3 trillion a year.  The products covered by this agreement are next-generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical products such as magnetic resonance imaging equipment, machine tools used to manufacture circuit boards, telecommunications satellites and touch screens.  The agreement also includes a commitment to work to remove non-tariff barriers by allowing many products to be integrated into the free trade circuit in a sparsely transparent manner. Also, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – I supported this dossier because I am generally a supporter of stimulating innovation and economic growth. This is a remarkable deal, the removal of basic tariffs at the level of the WORLD. If the terms and conditions of the deal are met, we must soon witness a significant economic boost. Of course, we must not forget to be careful, especially when it comes to major international transactions, and therefore each Member State must continue to closely monitor this deal.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The abolition and consolidation to zero of customs duties for up to seven years in respect of technology and information products, through the ITA agreement, will lead to lower prices, increased competitiveness, but above all to job creation and growth in gross domestic product.  We therefore vote in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement in the form of a declaration on the extension of trade in information technology products (ITA), in order to make progress and technological progress in all areas.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The first Information Technology Agreement ('ITA'), concluded in December 1996 at the Singapore Ministerial Conference, entered into force in 1997. While the agreement was initially concluded by only 29 WTO member states, it now has 82 participants. For all information technology products covered by the Agreement, the ITA requires all participants to lift and fix duties at zero on the basis of the principle of the most favoured nation. The ITA includes approximately 200 tariff groups, including computers, telephones, input units, components and machines for the production of information technology tools.  In May 2012, six countries (EU, USA, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Costa Rica) began negotiations to extend the product scope of the agreement. They were joined by 21 other members. On July 24, 2015, an agreement was reached on an additional list of 201 IT products.  Under this Agreement, participants are expected to submit timetables with a phase commitment for each product, for a transitional period of up to 7 years (3 years for normal phases, 5 years for sensitive products and 7 years in exceptional cases). The Agreement in the form of a Declaration on the extension of the ITA (and the agendas containing the intermittent commitment of the participants) was adopted by ministers from the participating countries on 16 December 2015 at the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi.  The extension of the ITA is considered to be a milestone. I therefore voted in favour of Parliament giving its consent to the agreement.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU exports €189 billion in products covered by the EXPANSION of ATI, a figure that is expected to increase after customs duties are eliminated. The agreement will result in lower prices for consumers, but also for producers who depend on imported components. However, in some sectors there may also be increased competition. The ATI requires each participant to eliminate customs duties and consolidate them at zero rate on the basis of the most-favoured-nation principle for all information technology (IT) products covered.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: This type of expansion of an existing agreement allows many products to enter the free trade circuit without any advertising!

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement in the form of a declaration on the expansion of trade in Information Technology products (ATI) requires each participant to eliminate customs duties and consolidate them at zero rate on the basis of the most favoured nation principle for all information technology (IT) products covered. ATI covers about 200 tariff items, including computers, telephones, but also the insums, components and machines for the production of IT items. The exemption from customs duties granted by ATI participants played an important role in the development and expansion of trade over almost 20 years of ATI implementation. In 2012, six countries proposed to extend the list of products covered by the agreement (EU, USA, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Costa Rica). The products covered by this agreement include new generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical products, including magnetic resonance imaging machines, machine tools for the manufacture of integrated circuits, telecommunications satellites and touch screens.  Rather, this agreement does not call into question the hegemony of large multinationals, which want to strengthen market control, either by increasing turnover or by ensuring the absolute mastery of knowledge and research through 'intellectual property rights'.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation on expanding trade in information technology products (ITA) as I believe that the expansion of the ITA is crucial for the growth of the volume of trade within the IT sector. This is, in fact, the first major tariff reduction agreement since the WTO was established, which could bring immense benefits in terms of job creation and GDP growth.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as this agreement is by no way addressing the environment concerns of the proliferation of devices and the need to recycle.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The ITA Agreement requires each participant to eliminate customs duties and bind them to zero on the basis of the most-valued clause for all IT products covered by the Agreement. In 2012, 6 countries, including the EU, launched talks and negotiations aimed at increasing the number of products covered by the ITA Agreement. In 2015, agreement was reached on an additional list of 201 IT products. The new text of the agreement and its reform will bring lower prices for consumers, but also for producers who depend on imported parts.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report as it could pose a danger to our production system.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The abolition and consolidation to zero of customs duties for up to seven years in respect of technology and information products, through the ITA agreement, will lead to lower prices, increased competitiveness, but above all to job creation and growth in gross domestic product. I therefore vote in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement in the form of a declaration on the extension of trade in information technology products (ITA), in order to make progress and technological progress in all areas.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This landmark deal was one of the significant outcomes from the Nairobi Ministerial. It aims to eliminate tariffs on 201 information technology products valued at over USD 1.3 trillion per year. Negotiations on the expanded Information Technology Agreement of 1996 (ITA) were conducted by 53 WTO members, including both developed and developing countries, which account for approximately 90 per cent of world trade in these products. However, all WTO members will benefit from the agreement, as they will all enjoy duty-free market access to the markets of the members eliminating tariffs on these products. The expanded ITA should boost the EU manufacturing sector, allowing easier access to new markets; like its 1996-predecessor it should continue to promote jobs, offer lower prices to consumers and boost economic growth and foster innovation. It will benefit consumers, producers and the economies of both the EU and partner countries.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The First Information Technology Agreement (ITA), concluded in December 1996 at the Singapore Ministerial Conference, entered into force in 1997. For all information technology products covered by the Agreement, the ITA requires all participants to lift and fix duties at zero on the basis of the principle of the most favoured nation. The ITA includes approximately 200 tariff groups, including computers, telephones, input units, components and machines for the production of information technology tools.  In May 2012, six countries began negotiations to extend the scope of the agreement. They were joined by 21 other members. On July 24, 2015, an agreement was reached on an additional list of 201 IT products.  Under this Agreement, participants are to submit timetables for each product with a phase commitment for a transitional period of up to 7 years. As a result of the negotiations, by 1 July 2016, some 65% of the tariff groups will be completely eliminated. By 2019, almost all imports of the relevant products will be duty-free.   The agreement in the form of a declaration on the extension of the ITA was adopted by ministers of the participating countries on 16 December 2015 at the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi.  The extension of the ITA is considered to be a milestone. This is the first high-profile tariff reduction agreement with huge job creation and GDP growth potential since the wto was established. I therefore voted in favour of Parliament giving its consent to the agreement.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this recommendation with the conviction that a free market system with countries outside the EU to import and export ITA (Information Technology Products) products would be very beneficial for both the EU and other countries. Today, the Union exports EUR 189 million in products contemplated by the itA expansion, a figure that is expected to increase considerably as a result of tariff cuts. The most immediate consequences of the agreement is that prices will be reduced for consumers, but also for producers who rely on imported components.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the "Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement in the form of a declaration on the extension of trade in information technology products (ITA) on behalf of the European Union". The technical text completes the necessary "update" of long existing trade flows in the field of the ITA and extends its competence to more than 200 new elements and components.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The value of trade in information technology goods represents about 10% of total world trade annually. The abolition of tariffs on these products can further promote trade in this area.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The expanded Information Technology Agreement should provide a boost to the EU manufacturing sector and will benefit consumers, producers and the economies of both the EU and partner countries.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the expansion of trade in information technology products (ITA) because in this way all the countries belonging to the World Trade Organisation will be able to benefit from this agreement, which represents a valuable and decisive step forward for the technological development and growth of Europe's trade volumes and which fully reflects the economic realities of today. Allowing, albeit gradually, the liberalisation of trade in high-tech goods is a necessary precondition for progress.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against this report in considering that the ITA agreement, far from contributing to the coverage of the technological gap of developing countries, presents risks of impacting inversely in these countries, harming not only the collection of resources via customs, but also increasing south/north technological dependence and exposing the scarce business fabric to lethal competition by highly technified countries. In addition, the environmental impacts arising from this industry are not covered throughout the document.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this as it is a success story for EU trade policy with measurable positive effects and it shows that plurilateral agreements can be achieved through the WTO.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The agreement will remain up to date and in line with the latest developments in the sector. Modern information technology and the so-called Industry 4.0 will be important driving forces of future economic growth and demand a comprehensive trade framework.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 ITA is mainly for the benefit of large companies in developing countries engaged in high-tech production. It was sold as a tool to help developing countries. Instead, it acts as a tool to increase the dependence of poor countries, increasing the technological and economic gap between industrialised countries, on the one hand, and poor countries, on the other. At the time of signing this agreement, developing countries lose much-needed revenue from the duties paid on the introduction of information technology. At the same time, this agreement in no way helps to address the environmental problems of device proliferation and the need for recycling. For these reasons we voted against extending the agreement.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the above agreement as it will lead to lower prices for consumers, but also for producers who depend on imported components. The ITA requires that each participant eliminates and binds customs duties at zero on a Most Favoured Nation basis for all information technology (IT) products covered. The ITA covers about 200 tariff lines, including computers, telephones, but also inputs, components and machinery for the production of IT goods. Some sectors will however also experience increased competition. It is therefore good to see that the EU negotiated longer staging for some products that were considered to be sensitive, while the majority of the non-sensitive tariffs will be eliminated at the entry into force of the agreement. As well as this the ITA agreement has huge potential to create jobs and boost GDP growth.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement as it will benefit trade within the EU by minimising tariffs within a vastly expanding industry.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The new Information Technology Agreement (ITA) updates the rules adopted in 1996 within the framework of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) on international trade in information technology goods. The new agreement logically provides for an update of listed information technology goods – including smartphones and tablet computers that did not exist 20 years ago. More than 50 countries – including the US, China and all EU countries – have agreed on a gradual, complete reduction of import duties for a total of 201 product categories. This lowers prices for consumers and promotes trade.  It is also foreseen that the product categories will be subject to regular review in the future. The repetition of a "sighting gap" of 20 years is thus excluded. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the new information technology agreement. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The ITA requires all participants to lift and fix duties at zero for all information technology products covered by the Agreement on the basis of the principle of the most favoured nation. name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Information Technology Agreement (ITA) currently comprises 82 Member States and provides for the abolition and zeroing of customs duties, based on the most favoured nation clause for all targeted information technology products. I voted in favour of this report for the exemption of customs duties for participants and for the considerable development and expansion of trade in the IT sector. I support the extension of this agreement, which encourages job creation and the stimulation of the economy.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for the Recommendation on the Draft Decision of the Council on the Conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement in the form of the Information Technology Products Trade Expansion Statement (ITA), as this gives consent for the conclusion of that Agreement. How necessary, significant and useful information technology products are today - this is not to be talked about. Trade in the sector is expanding at an immense rate and has been experiencing violent developments for the past 20 years.  The first Information Technology Agreement (ITA) was signed in 1996 and more and more signatory countries have since joined. The expansion of the ITA is crucial, as it is the first major agreement to reduce tariffs since the establishment of the WTO with the strong potential to create jobs and encourage GDP growth, but it is very important that more countries join the agreement in order for the Union to fully benefit from its benefits.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The agreement includes a commitment to work to remove non-tariff barriers in the information technology sector, and to leave the list of affected products open for review to determine whether further expansion will be necessary to take account of future technological developments. I can only stand against this text.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the elimination of tariffs on 201 information technology products, as part of a WTO agreement between the European Union and 24 countries. This agreement, the largest in the WTO's history on tariff reduction, will enable European companies to be better protected from unfair competition and to earn between EUR 5 and EUR 8 billion in exports.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report concerns an increase in trade in information technology goods. This Convention covers components and machinery for the manufacture of IT goods as well as medical devices. This will have positive effects and lead to price reductions in the field of medical products. At the same time, innovation and competitiveness of Austria as a business location are being promoted. For these reasons, I agree with this request.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal. The expanded ITA will boost the EU manufacturing sector, allowing easier access to new markets and, as its predecessor it will continue to promote jobs, offer lower prices to consumers and boost economic growth and foster innovation. It will benefit consumers, producers and the economies of both the EU and partner countries.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. This recommendation on the extension of trade in information technology products aims to provide for the elimination of tariff lines by 10 July 2016. This is the result of what was discussed at the WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi. The subject of this Agreement are GPS navigation systems, 200 tariff lines, medical instruments such as magnetic resonance imaging, telecommunications satellites and touch screens. Most tariffs not considered to be sensitive will be eliminated when the aforementioned agreement enters into force. The first tariff cuts are planned for July 1, 2016, through a rapid authorisation procedure.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. I therefore voted in favour of Parliament giving its consent to the agreement.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The directive is concerned with extending trade in information technology products. I believe that the expansion of trade in information technology products is mainly in the interests of large companies. Information technology has been promoted as an aid tool for developing countries, but instead increases the dependence of poor countries, increases the technological and economic gap between industrialised countries and developing countries. Developing countries lose revenue from the duties paid on the introduction of information technology through this tool.  I therefore voted against the directive.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ For one reason or another, we are living in time of enormous technological progress. Nowadays IT industry is booming and therefore it is not surprising that the free market is demanding more IT goods such as computers, telephones, machinery and etc. In this regard, it is important to note that the duty free information technology agreement (ITA) has played an important role in the enormous development and expansion of trade that the IT sector has experienced over the last 20 years, since the application of the agreement in 1997. However, because of continuing technological progress and emergence of new IT products there is a real need of expansion of ITA. In May 2012, six countries launched negotiations to expand the product coverage of the agreement (EU, US, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Costa Rica). On 24 July 2015, an agreement was reached on an additional list of 201 IT products. Annual trade in these 201 products is valued at over USD 1.3 trillion per year, and accounts for approximately 10% of total global trade today. The EU exports EUR 189 billion in products covered by the ITA expansion therefore we should support it.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it endorses an agreement that destroys tariffs on 201 information technology products.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the expansion of trade in information technology products.  On 16 December, at the WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi, countries representing major exporters of information technology products agreed on the timetable for the implementation of a landmark agreement to eliminate tariffs on 201 information technology products, estimated at $1.3 trillion a year. The products covered by this agreement are next-generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical products such as magnetic resonance imaging equipment, machine tools used to manufacture circuit boards, telecommunications satellites and touch screens, etc.  The agreement also includes a commitment to work to remove non-tariff barriers in the information technology sector, and to leave the list of affected products open for review to determine whether further enlargement will be necessary to take account of future technological developments. This type of expansion of an existing agreement allows many products to enter the free trade circuit.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Expanding trade in information technology products is the European Union's response to global technological progress. Thanks to these rules, manufacturers of this type of products from Europe will have easier access to a market that is constantly growing. Moreover, the development of trade in modern technologies is also a step towards developing the innovation of the European economy and improving the situation of manufacturers of such solutions.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The text in question focuses on the agreement being prepared, which aims to expand the 1996 agreement on information and communication technologies.  Under the aegis of the World Trade Organization (WTO), the 82 participants (United States, Russia, Japan, Korea, China, European Union...) began negotiations in 2012 with the aim of lowering tariffs on almost all information products to 0 in 2019.  Under the terms of the agreement are 201 products (next-generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical products with imaging equipment, etc.). This historic agreement will eventually remove non-tariff barriers to information technology, allowing major global producers such as Asian countries to invade our markets without resistance or opposition. I opposed this report by voting AGAINST.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 The expansion of the ITA agreement facilitates the technological exchange of semiconductors, machinery, lenses, GPS, medical devices etc. between a total of 54 countries under the WTO. However, due to asymmetry among participating countries, it functions in practice as a mechanism to strengthen the technological and financial dependence of developing countries, benefiting large European, US and East Asian multinationals. That's why I voted against it.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The new Information Technology Agreement (ITA) updates the rules adopted in 1996 within the framework of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) on international trade in information technology goods. The new agreement logically provides for an update of listed information technology goods – including smartphones and tablet computers that did not exist 20 years ago. More than 50 countries – including the US, China and all EU countries – have agreed on a gradual, complete reduction of import duties for a total of 201 product categories. This lowers prices for consumers and promotes trade. It is also foreseen that the product categories will be subject to regular review in the future. The repetition of a "sighting gap" of 20 years is thus excluded. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the new information technology agreement.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 Proposal means the abolition of many tariffs on technological products such as GPS navigation, mobile phones, satellites, magnetic resonance imaging devices, etc. The agreement already includes 82 states (including, for example, the United States, the United States, the Taiwan and the US. This is how I imagine a trade agreement, not a TTIP.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The first agreement on the expansion of trade in information technology products (ITA) was concluded at a conference for ministers in Singapore in December 1996 and entered into force in 1997.  The aim of extending the ITA agreement is to abolish import duties for 201 IT technology products not included in the original ITA agreement. Trade duties worth $1,300 billion are projected to be lifted, which should boost the world economy by $190 billion. Products covered by this agreement include new generations of semiconductors, GPS navigation systems and medical devices. Tariffs on these products will be phased out, with 65% of products immediately being done and all products within seven years.  As estimated by the European Commission, by extending the ITA agreement, the European Union will lose approximately EUR 1.5 billion from customs duties for information technology products. However, this loss will also be deployed over 7 years. I supported this recommendation because I believe that the expansion of ita agreements will result in lower prices for consumers, but also for manufacturers, and will thus stimulate both job creation and GDP growth.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Under the Information Technology Agreement, each participant (currently 82) for all information technology products covered by it (computers, telephones, as well as raw materials, components and equipment for the production of IT goods) abolishes customs duties and undertakes to set them at zero under most-favoured-nation treatment. Last year, an additional list of 201 IT products was included. The sales value of these products amounts to around USD 1.3 trillion, equivalent to around 10% of global trade. In the case of the European Union, the EU is exporting EUR 189 billion of products on this additional list, so this figure is expected to increase significantly after the reduction in customs duties. In view of the above and the other benefits that the expansion of trade in information technology products could bring to the Union, it was quite logical to vote positively.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this report that seeks the eventual phasing out of tariffs on IT products.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the EP agreed by resolution to extend the AGREEMENT on trade in INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY products, which extends the current list to 201 tradable IT products. The Agreement contains commitments by the parties to progressively reduce customs duties. The current volume of trade in exports of these goods from the EU amounts to EUR 189 billion. Once the duty has been removed, this volume will increase substantially, which will help economic development and increase the transparency of competition.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The revision of the Agreement on the Expansion of Trade in Information Technology Products (ATI-2), concluded in the WTO on 16 December 2015, provides for the phasing out of tariffs on 201 information technology products. These include computers, phones, touch screens, GPS navigation equipment, MRI-type medical devices or ultrasonic diagnostic devices, as well as inputs, and other components and machines... Trade in these products is valued at $1.3 trillion per year, or about 10% of world merchandise trade. This agreement has not only significant potential to stimulate growth, but also to increase global trade in high-tech products. It also represents a significant market expansion opportunity for many European industrialists, particularly French ones. A rapid ratification of this agreement will undoubtedly send a positive signal that will help to enhance the WTO's responsiveness in adapting global trade regulation to the rapid evolution of information technology products. I therefore vote in favour of this recommendation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement in the form of a declaration on the extension of trade in information technology products, because it is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. The agreement is an extension of the 1996 information technology agreement. The negotiations aim to reduce tariffs to 0 and involve 82 participants including the European Union, the United States, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, China, Southeast Asia, Russia, etc.  At the WTO Ministerial Conference, members of the Organization representing major exporters of information technology products agreed on the timetable for the implementation of a landmark agreement to eliminate tariffs on 201 information technology products, estimated to be worth $1.3 trillion a year.  We oppose this type of expansion of an existing agreement to bring many products into the free trade circuit without any advertising.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement on the extension of trade in information technology products (ITA). The agreement provides for exemption from duties for all information technology products. Products covered by this Agreement include new generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, machine tools for the manufacture of printed circuit boards, telecommunications satellites and tactile screens. This duty-free exemption, granted to ITA participants, played a decisive role in the expansion in the trade sector.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The Information Technology Agreement (ITA) came to improve the regulation of continued-increasing product exchanges. But not only have we seen an increase in trade in recent years, but new products have been introduced, which must also be considered in the agreement to avoid harm, especially for consumers. As a result of this new agreement, prices will be reduced for consumers, but also for producers who depend on imported components. However, some sectors will also have greater competition, so it is positive that a longer staggering period has been established for certain products considered sensitive, where as most non-sensitive tariffs will be eliminated on the date of entry into force of the Agreement. My support, therefore, for the recommendation for this agreement and my desire for a greater number of countries to join it.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The Quisthoudt-Rowohl report proposed to endorse the conclusion of a multilateral agreement on trade in information technology products (ITAs), a sector in which the EU and France play a major role in the world. The aim is to phase out tariffs on 201 information technology products (computers, telephones, GPS, MRI devices, etc.), representing about 10% of global merchandise trade. The agreement, which covers 82 countries, should be welcomed as an important step in reviving the multilateral system, which by definition has more safeguards than bilateral (TTIP, CETA) or multilateral (TiSA) mega-trade agreements. I have mainly supported this multilateral agreement because it has access to France's offensive interests in trade in high value-added goods, while offering provisional protection to its sensitive technological products, such as electric meters, optical lenses or fibre optics. It is now a question of making these new markets grow, to the primary benefit of French and European workers and consumers.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Agreement on Information Technology currently lists 82 Contracting States.  This agreement requires participants to consolidate customs duties on all information technology products to zero. This contributes to greater development and expansion of trade for all participants. An agreement was signed between the EU, the US, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Costa Rica in 2012 to expand ITA's product coverage. Some 200 IT products have been added to the agreement, including GPS navigation systems as well as medical equipment. I believe that this agreement can significantly increase the Union's revenue in this area while leading to a reduction in the prices of these products for consumers. Our aim is to extend the agreement even further and to attract even more states.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This agreement is an update of the coverage for various medical devices. This should reduce prices for the consumer. In addition, this agreement can strengthen the competitiveness of Austria as a business location. I can therefore only agree to this agreement.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the conclusion of this agreement. Tariff reductions are projected to lead to lower prices for consumers, as well as prices for producers who depend on the imported components. However, competition will increase in some sectors. In order for the EU to be fully benefiting from the agreement, it is important to ensure that more members join it.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The first Information Technology Agreement (ITA) was adopted at the Singapore Ministerial Conference in December 1996 and came into force in 1997. The agreement provides that each of the 21 participants eliminate tariffs on all information technology products covered. These include more than 200 products: computers, telephones, but also inputs, components and machines used to manufacture information technology products.   There is now talk of increasing the number of products involved to include next-generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, touch screens, and even medical products, such as magnetic resonance diagnostic devices.  The resolution before us approves this draft. With this agreement, Europe's information technology industries will be subject to increased competition and employees will be subject to social dumping. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The agreement in question is an extension of the 1996 Information Technology Agreement. By 2019, tariffs on almost all of the products cited will be zero. In addition, the agreement includes a commitment to work to remove non-tariff barriers in the information technology sector. Finally, this type of expansion allows many products to enter the free trade circuit without any advertising. As a result, I voted against this recommendation.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this recommendation due to its goal of furthering development of trade and economic growth in the IT sector.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the Council's decision to conclude the revised WTO Agreement on Information Technology (ITA) on behalf of the EU. This revised agreement is the first tariff reduction agreement sealed at the WTO in 18 years!  Aimed at phasing out import tariffs on 201 information technology products, this new agreement now includes products such as next-generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical devices including magnetic resonance imaging equipment and ultrasonic diagnostic devices, telecommunications satellites and touch screens...  Such an agreement should facilitate market access and offer more attractive prices for consumers. This agreement is essential when we know that global trade in these high-tech products amounts, according to the WTO, to more than $1.3 trillion annually.  I take this council's decision to recall the wto's unavoidable role as a global forum for trade rules and trade governance. Such a rules-based multilateral trading system is a plus for the strength and stability of the global economy.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The AGREEMENT on trade in INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY products requires each participant to eliminate customs duties and tie them to zero on the basis of the most-valued clause for all IT products covered by the Agreement. These are mainly computers and telephones, but also input equipment, components and devices for the production of information technology products. New products covered by this agreement include a new generation of semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical products including magnetic resonance imaging equipment, printed circuit board tools, telecommunications satellites and touch screens. The Agreement requires the submission of timetables containing commitments to progressively reduce customs duties for all products over a maximum period of seven years – three years for ordinary products, five years for sensitive products and seven years in exceptional cases. The agreement will bring lower prices to consumers, but also to producers who depend on imported parts, and has huge potential in terms of creating jobs and boosting GDP growth. I am therefore voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which aims to eliminate tariffs on 201 information technology products valued at over USD 1.3 trillion per year. Negotiations on the expanded Information Technology Agreement of 1996 (ITA) were conducted by 53 WTO members, including both developed and developing countries, which account for approximately 90 per cent of world trade in these products. However, all WTO members will benefit from the agreement, as they will all enjoy duty-free market access to the markets of the members eliminating tariffs on these products. The expanded ITA should boost the EU manufacturing sector, allowing easier access to new markets; like its 1996-predecessor it should continue to promote jobs, offer lower prices to consumers and boost economic growth and foster innovation. It will benefit consumers, producers and the economies of both the EU and partner countries. It is possible that there will be another update of ITA in 2018. I hope that when negotiations reopen then, progress would be made in reducing non-tariff barriers.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In May 2012, the EU, the USA, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Costa Rica began negotiations to extend the product scope of the Information Technology Agreement concluded in Singapore in December 1996. They were joined by a further 21 participants in the original agreement. On July 24, 2015, an agreement was reached on an additional list of 201 IT products, including next-generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical products containing magnetic resonance imaging devices, machine tools for the manufacture of printed circuit boards, telecommunications satellites and touch screens. Annual trade in these products is estimated at more than US$1.3 trillion, which is about 10% of total global trade today. The Council submitted a draft decision on the conclusion of the Agreement in the form of a declaration on behalf of the European Union. In order to adopt the decision, it must obtain parliament's consent. In its report, the Committee on International Trade points out that this is the first high-profile tariff reduction agreement with huge job creation and GDP growth potential since the wto was established, and therefore recommends that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The first Information Technology Agreement (ATI) was signed at the Singapore Ministerial Conference in December 1996 and entered into force in 1997. Although initially only 29 WTO Member States signed the agreement, the ATI currently has 82 participants. The EU exports €189 billion in products covered by the EXPANSION of ATI, a figure that is expected to increase after customs duties are eliminated.  I am voting in favour of this agreement because lower prices will result for consumers, but also for producers who depend on imported components. However, in some sectors there may also be increased competition.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This type of expansion of an existing agreement allows many products to enter the free trade circuit in a sneaky way and without democratic debate, I strongly oppose it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which is a success story for EU trade policy with measurable positive effects and it shows that plurilateral agreements can be achieved through the WTO.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This report relates to the expansion of trade in information technology products and will reduce tariffs on these products under the WTO.  The EU's exports of the products affected by this expansion amount to EUR 189 billion. In a context where the European Union is still too affected by unemployment and where trade in information technology products is on the rise, such a measure will create jobs. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Twenty years after its signing, given the incredible technological advancement that has involved the sector, the Agreement on Trade in Information Technology Products (ITA) was in danger of becoming obsolete. We therefore welcome the dismantling of tariff lines for a further 201 products, many of which did not yet exist in 1996. Europe, with 196.7 billion exports between 2011 and 2013 and a positive trade balance, is, in fact, a net exporter and global leader in the production of technological goods. The ITA will also benefit consumers and intermediate producers with significantly lower product prices and, of course, support exports. The agreement will therefore benefit European companies and workers with more growth, better access to foreign markets and support for employment. The agreement, reached within the framework of the World Trade Organisation Ministerial Conference in Nairobi, strengthens the multilateral system, the only instrument capable of responding effectively to major global problems. We also share the commitment of the parties to meet and update the agreement by January 2018. The promise of updating is, in fact, an excellent signal towards the goal of transforming ita into a "living" agreement, that is, able to adapt to evolutions and discoveries in the IT field and, above all, provide for the dismantling of non-tariff barriers.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The first Information Technology Agreement (ITA) was signed 20 years ago. The participants in the agreement lifted tariffs on products such as computers and phones. Duty exemption has contributed greatly to the rapid development of the sector. Information technology has developed very rapidly over the last few years, but it has not changed its product range. It is necessary to extend the product scope so that the latest acquis can be included in the agreement. The latest agreement also includes products such as GPS navigation systems, touchscreens and telecommunications satellites. I voted in favour of this proposal because it is a big step, because it is a tariff reduction agreement to create jobs.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ During the Ministerial Conference in Singapore in December 1996 the first Information Technology Agreement (ITA) entered into force in 1997. I have voted for this recommendation that aims to expand the ITA highlighting its huge potential to create jobs and boost GDP growth.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of an agreement on the extension of the trade in information technology products (ATI) is to eliminate taxes on some IT products. According to the Commission's assessment, the agreement targets EU exports worth €74 billion to €150 billion. A simulation of the overall balance shows that total exports of goods could increase by about 0.7% to 1.4% compared to the base value. This means, at the moment, an increase of EUR 12 to EUR 24 billion in the value of exports of additional goods to third countries. EU exporters will also save between €0.8 billion and €2.1 billion in tax payments for exports to third countries.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report had a particularly regressive and unconstructive agenda. Its aim was to increase developing countries dependence on IT multinationals by expanding the Information Technology Products Agreement (ITA). ITA is a trade agreement which primarily profitable large companies who can now buy and sell these products without any tariffs. ITA signatories often argue that the agreement is very good for developing countries because it will increase their trade and therefore their GDP. In reality, not many developing countries are signatories to the agreement. With every expansion of the agreement it will be harder for them not to join the agreement as the agreement increases their dependency. Moreover, when tariffs will be eliminated, developing countries will also lose a significant amount income out of duties that they would normally receive from their exports. Therefore, this is an agreement that will not help developing countries develop, it will only help multinationals trading in technology (related) products. It was for these reasons that I voted against this report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because this report is an update of the coverage. In particular, it should be noted that this report also promises benefits for the consumer. The prices of IT products will fall for the consumer. Prices for medical products are also being lowered.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The it sector has grown significantly over the last 20 years. The agreement increases the number of IT products not subject to most-favoured-nation duties. It will benefit both consumers and producers, and this agreement has the potential to create jobs and promote GDP growth. However, it is important that as many members as possible join this agreement.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The first Information Technology Agreement (ITA) dates back to 1996, and there have been a number of changes since then. In fact, while affecting around 200 tariff lines, including computers or it goods manufacturing machinery, it is easy to argue that the ITA product agreement has played a key role in the expansion of the economy. However, technological advances are not part of the agreement, remaining excluded from ita products. I believe that enlargement is necessary and I am therefore voting in favour of it.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – As the declaration of Nairobi Ministerial Declaration is prepared to be implemented and establish the first cuts in tariffs, the Expansion of trade in Information Technology Products (ITA) will result in allowing the industry to reduce the cost of importing the hardware necessary to develop the IT sector. It will also help create higher quality jobs for young IT experts and will impact on other industries, making them more efficient as a whole. As a firm supporter of the IT sector in Europe and in my home country Bulgaria, I vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this recommendation, which gives consent to the conclusion of an agreement on the elimination of tariffs for about 200 information technology products that have not been included in the first Information Technology Agreement (ITA) so far. The agreement abolishes duties on next-generation semiconductor, GPS navigation devices, medical equipment such as magnetic resonance imaging devices, printed circuit board tools, telecommunication satellites and touchscreens. Further strengthening the economy and growth especially in the computer science and computing sectors, as well as the communications and medicine sectors, the availability of the latest information technology is necessary. Estimating the benefits of expanding trade in INFORMATION technology products, it was found that the benefits of eliminating tariffs on products on the expanded list for the EU economy would be around EUR 45 million and consumer benefit would grow by EUR 520 million. As the exports and imports covered turned out to be significantly higher than estimated, the economic impacts may also be expected to be greater in reality, and this will also have an impact on job creation.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This type of expansion of an existing agreement allows many products to enter the free trade circuit in a sneaky way and without democratic debate, I strongly oppose it. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I give consent to the conclusion of the agreement in the form of the Information Technology Product Expansion Statement. The first Information Technology Agreement (ITA) was concluded at the Singapore Ministerial Conference in December 1996 and entered into force in 1997. The agreement was originally concluded by only 29 Member States of the World Trade Organisation, and today has 82 signatories. The INFORMATION Technology Agreement commits each signatory to abolish customs duties and impose zero duty on all information technology products covered by the agreement, in accordance with the principle of the most advantaged nation. The agreement covers about two hundred tariff items, including computers, phones, but also raw materials, components and machines for the production of IT products. The duty-free regime introduced by ITA signatories played an important role in the forceful development and expansion of trade in the information technology sector during the almost 20 years of application of the agreement.  Trade in the sector has increased fourfold. However, with technological progress during this period, the information technology sector has been completely transformed, while the scope of this agreement has remained the same. It is for this reason that I think it is necessary to align the scope of this agreement with technological advances in the IT sector.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The INFORMATION Technology Agreement entered into force in 1997. Today it counts 82 co-signers and covers 97% of IT store products. The agreement obliges members to abolish customs duties and impose a zero duty rate for all information technology products prescribed by the agreement. The abolition of customs duties creates the conditions for the expansion and development of trade in these products, as confirmed by its fourfold increase. As the agreement does not cover next-generation products, their inclusion could mean a huge increase in jobs and boost GDP growth. If customs duties were abolished, the value of INFORMATION technology products exported from the EU, currently amounting to EUR 189 billion, would increase significantly. As a result, it would be suitable for consumers, but also for producers dependent on imported parts. I therefore supported MP Quisthoudt-Rowohl's recommendation.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ITA (Information Technology Agreement) requires each participant to abolish customs duties on all information technology products on the basis of the most-favoured-nation principle. The exemption from duties granted to ITA participants played a decisive role in the huge expansion of trade in the IT sector. Over this period, technological advances have radically changed the IT sector, while the products covered by the ITA have remained unchanged. For this reason, several ITA countries have started negotiations to extend the scope of the products covered by the agreement. The European Union has exported EUR 189 billion in products that are part of the expansion of the ITA, a figure that is expected to increase significantly after tariff reductions. The agreement will result in lower prices for consumers, but also for producers who depend on imported components. For all this, I have given my approval to the agreement.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to expand trade in information technology products as part of the expansion of the Information Technology Agreement (ITA) signed in December 2015 by 53 members of the World Trade Organization (WTO). The agreement aims to reduce tariffs in this sector, which accounts for 10% of total world trade.  This decision by the European Parliament is therefore part of a dynamic of strengthening world trade through the reduction of customs barriers and constraints. Above all, it will have concrete effects for consumers, which will gradually see a decrease in the price of technological goods.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the expansion of the Information Technology Agreement, taking into account that the first ATI was signed at the Singapore Ministerial Conference in December 1996 and entered into force in 1997. Although initially only 29 WTO Member States signed the agreement, the ATI currently has 82 participants.
