The ATI requires each participant to eliminate customs duties and consolidate them at zero rate on the basis of the most-favoured-nation principle for all information technology (IT) products covered. The exemption of customs duties granted by ATI participants played an important role in the huge development and expansion of trade that the sector has recorded over the nearly 20 years of ATI implementation. The expansion of THE is a historic milestone, being the first major agreement to reduce customs duties since the creation of the WTO and presenting a huge potential for job creation and promotion of GDP growth.  It is important for the European Parliament to approve it and it is important to stress the importance of more members assinating it, so that the EU can benefit fully from it.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament wants the Eu to take the new information technology for good, the proof again this lunchtime with the adoption of a report giving its consent to the extension of the ATI agreement.  It is a law that came into force in 1997 on the abolition of tariffs on a range of information technology products such as computers and telephones. The agreement also covers the components and machinery used to manufacture these products. Under the ITA, participants commit to the phasing out of tariffs over a period of up to 7 years. As a result of these negotiations, approximately 65% of the tariffs will be completely eliminated by July 2016. By 2019, almost all imports of the affected products will benefit from duty-free access.   The EU's exports of products covered by this enlargement amount eur 189 billion, an amount that is expected to increase as a result of the reductions in deductibles.  This agreement therefore has enormous potential in terms of job creation. Annual trade in these 201 products is estimated at more than USD 1,140 billion per year, or about 10% of total world trade.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 THE ATI requires each participant to eliminate customs duties and consolidate them at zero rate on the basis of the most-favoured-nation principle for all information technology (IT) products covered. On July 24, 2015, an agreement was reached for an additional list of 201 IT products. Annual trade in these 201 products is valued at more than US$1.3 billion per year and represents about 10% of all world trade today. As a result of these negotiations, around 65 % of tariff items will be completely eliminated by 1 July 2016. In 2019, virtually all imports of relevant products will be exempt from customs duties. The EU exports €189 billion in products covered by the EXPANSION of ATI, a figure that is expected to increase after customs duties are eliminated. The agreement will result in lower prices for consumers, but also for producers who depend on imported components.  The expansion of THE is the first major agreement to reduce customs duties since the creation of the WTO and has a huge potential for job creation and promotion of GDP growth.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The ITA agreement on trade in information technology products entered into force in 1997 and today covers around 200 information technology products, including not only products such as computers or telephones, but also inputs, components and machinery for the production of information technology goods.  Since its entry into force, however, technological progress has profoundly changed the information technology sector. Therefore, 54 States party to the agreement have completed a review of the agreement to include new products such as the new generation of semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical products, tools for the manufacture of printed circuits, telecommunications satellites or touch screens. 65% of tariffs on these products will be eliminated by 1 July 2016 and in 2019, almost all of the products in question will be duty-free. I supported this review of the agreement as it will be positive for the EU economy, which currently exports EUR 189 million in products covered by the expansion of the ITA, for consumers, who will see prices reduced, and for producers who depend on imported components.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I have decided to support the Council's draft decision to conclude the revised WTO Information Technology Agreement (ITA) on behalf of the EU. This is an important text as it is the first WTO-sealed tariff reduction agreement since 1995. This revised agreement extends the list of covered products to 201 new products. In addition to the inclusion of these new products, the agreement also provides for a phased commitment to reduce tariffs on these products. The European Union has also managed to negotiate a staggered tariff reduction over a longer period of time for certain products considered sensitive.  The agreement, reached by ministers from 53 WTO member countries on 16 December 2015, is expected to boost EU exports of these products. It should be noted that today, these exports already amount to 189 billion euros.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trade in information technology products is probably one of the fastest developing areas of international trade. Although the first Agreement on trade in information technology products was concluded back in 1996, its success is illustrated by the fact that the number of its participants has increased from 29 signatories, WTO countries, to the current 82. ITS requires each participant to undertake to abolish customs duties and to apply a zero rate of duty to all information technology products covered by this Agreement, in accordance with the most-favoured-nation principle. ITS includes approximately 200 tariff lines, including computers, phones, as well as raw materials, components and equipment for the production of IT goods. The duty-free regime applied by ITS participants played a key role, which has led to a dramatic increase in trade in the IT sector over almost 20 years. The EU exports products falling within the extended scope of ITS for EUR 189 billion. This amount is expected to increase significantly as a result of the reduction in tariffs. This agreement will reduce prices for consumers as well as prices for producers who depend on imported ingredients.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The first Information Technology Agreement (ATI) was signed at the Singapore Ministerial Conference and entered into force in 1997. Although initially only 29 WTO Member States signed the agreement, the ATI currently has 82 participants. The ATI requires each participant to eliminate customs duties, on the basis of the most-favoured nation principle, for all information technology (IT) products covered. The exemption of customs duties granted by ATI participants played an important role in the development and expansion of trade that the sector has recorded, with trade in the sector quadrupled.  The EU exports €189 billion in products covered by the EXPANSION of ATI, a figure that will increase after the total elimination of customs duties. This agreement will result in lower prices for consumers, but also for producers who depend on imported components. However, in some sectors there may also be increased competition. The expansion of THE is a historic milestone, with enormous potential for job creation and promotion of the union's GDP growth.  Because I agree with the rapporteur's position, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which gives the European Parliament the approval of the agreement to expand the Information Technology Agreement (ITA). The agreement was reached in the WTO on 16 December at the WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi by 53 WTO members (the ITA now has 82 participating countries). The agreement will eliminate tariffs on 201 information technology products, which are valued at more than 1 trillion euros per year. Annual trade in these products accounts for about 10% of total world trade. Under the agreement, approximately 65% of tariff lines will be completely eliminated as of July 1, 2016. By 2019, almost all imports of the affected products will benefit from duty-free access. Products covered by the agreement include next-generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, telecommunications satellites and touch screens. Finally, the EU has negotiated a staggered reduction over a longer period of time for certain products considered sensitive.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on expanding trade in information technology products. The agreement that the European Union signed in December 2015 within the framework of the World Trade Organisation provides for the elimination of customs duties on a wide range of information technology products, worth more than one thousand billion per year in terms of the volume of trade. By 2019 all these duties will be eliminated, facilitating the free trade of these products, among which we find GPS navigation systems, medical products such as magnetic resonance machines, machine tools for the production of printed circuit boards and touch screens. These are technologies that improve the lives and everyday lives of European citizens, from the service sector to health, through entertainment. In view of the benefits that this type of technology brings to the lives of all of us European citizens, I can only support the expansion of their trade.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against this report in considering that the ITA agreement, far from contributing to the coverage of the technological gap of developing countries, presents risks of impacting inversely in these countries, harming not only the collection of resources via customs, but also increasing south/north technological dependence and exposing the scarce business fabric to lethal competition by highly technified countries. In addition, the environmental impacts arising from this industry are not covered throughout the document.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the Quisthoudt report, which supports the revision and extension of the Information Technology Agreement, so that the new generation of modern IT products can benefit from customs facilities. Thus, 201 products will benefit from the gradual abolition of customs tariffs.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. The agreement gives us the first major tariff reduction agreement since the WTO was set up. That is why the agreement has great potential for creating jobs and boosting GDP growth. In addition, the agreement may also lead to lower prices for consumers, but also for producers who depend on imported components. However, some sectors will also experience increased competition, which is why it is important that the agreement takes into account a longer settlement for certain products considered to be sensitive.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the "Information Technology Agreement" as IT is a key product of the future that should be dealt with as easily as possible. This includes the abolition of tariffs.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 The expansion of the ITA agreement facilitates the technological exchange of semiconductors, machinery, lenses, GPS, medical devices etc. between a total of 54 countries under the WTO. However, due to asymmetry among participating countries, it functions in practice as a mechanism to strengthen the technological and financial dependence of developing countries, benefiting large European, US and East Asian multinationals. That's why I voted against it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 16 December 2015, at the WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi, 53 members reached an agreement under the Second Information Technology Treaty (ITA), which includes a programme to phase out tariffs on 201 IT products. In 2015, the European Union exported eur 189 billion worth of products, which are part of the expansion of the ITA, a figure that is expected to increase significantly after tariff reductions. The agreement will result in lower prices for consumers, but also for producers who depend on imported components. I therefore consider it essential that I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This represents a success for EU trade policy with measurable and positive effects, showing that plurilateral agreements can be achieved through the World Trade Organisation as a platform.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the fact that new products covered by this Agreement, such as new generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical products including magnetic resonance imaging equipment, printed circuit board tools, telecommunications satellites and touch screens, are gradually eliminated and import duties lifted by 2019. This will help the development of technology and lower prices for consumers. I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I abstained for this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the first Agreement on Trade in Information Technology Products (ITA) was concluded in December 1996 at the Ministerial Conference in Singapore and entered into force in 1997. The agreement was originally signed by 29 WTO Member States and now has 82 signatories. The ITA Agreement requires each Participant to eliminate duties and bind them to zero under the most-benefit clause for all IT products covered by the Agreement. The ITA agreement covers around 200 customs items, including computers and phones. In May 2012, six countries (eu, US, Japan, Republic of Korea, Taiwan and Costa Rica) launched negotiations to expand the number of products covered by the ITA. They were joined by 21 other WTO Member States. In July 2015, an agreement was reached on an additional list of 201 IT products. The annual volume of trade in these 201 products is estimated at more than USD 1.3 trillion per year, representing approximately 10 % of current total world trade. The enlargement of the ITA, which is the first major tariff reduction since the establishment of the WTO, is an important event that has huge potential to create jobs and boost GDP growth. I therefore supported the motion for a resolution to give its consent to the agreement.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The new Information Technology Agreement (ITA) updates the rules adopted in 1996 within the framework of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) on international trade in information technology goods. The new agreement logically provides for an update of listed information technology goods – including smartphones and tablet computers that did not exist 20 years ago. More than 50 countries – including the US, China and all EU countries – have agreed on a gradual, complete reduction of import duties for a total of 201 product categories. This lowers prices for consumers and promotes trade. It is also foreseen that the product categories will be subject to regular review in the future. The repetition of a "sighting gap" of 20 years is thus excluded. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the new information technology agreement.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Information technology is becoming an increasingly important business item. Europe has the potential to become a leader in this area in the future. We must do everything we can to make this a reality. One of the instruments is the removal of trade barriers.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The first Information Technology Agreement (ITA), originally concluded by only 29 Member States of the World Trade Organisation and today has 82 signatories, was concluded at the Singapore Ministerial Conference in December 1996 and entered into force in 1997. With the INFORMATION Technology Agreement, each signatory agrees to abolish customs duties and impose a zero duty on all information technology products covered by the agreement, in accordance with the principle of the most advantaged nation. The agreement covers about 200 tariff items, including computers, phones, but also raw materials, components and machines for the production of IT products.  I support this report on the expansion of trade in information technology products, as I believe that the expansion of ITA plays a major role in the development of economies. It is the first major tariff reduction deal since the creation of the World Trade Organisation with strong potential to create jobs and stifies GDP growth. It is important that more countries join the Agreement so that the EU can fully benefit from the Agreement.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. The Agreement on Trade in Information Technology Products (ITA) now has 82 participating countries, half of which are members of the WTO. It covers 97% of trade in this area. The aim of the ITA extension that has now been decided is to eliminate customs duties on IT goods that were not covered by the original ITA. The ITA expansion covers areas covered by the common commercial policy. That makes sense, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The first Information Technology Agreement (ITA) was concluded in Singapore in 1996 and to date has 82 signatory states. The agreement obliges each signatory to abolish customs duties and impose a zero duty for all information technology products covered by the agreement. The agreement covers about two hundred tariff items, including computers, phones and raw materials.  Technological advances over the last 20 years have transformed the IT sector completely, while the scope of the Agreement has remained the same. On 24 July 2015, an agreement was reached to expand the list for 201 IT products. The value of trade in these 201 products is estimated to be more than $1.3 trillion per year. The ministers of the signatory countries concluded an agreement at the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi on 16 December 2015 in the form of the ITA Enlargement Statement, which contains deadlines for implementing the obligation to gradually end tariffs.  The value of products included in this agreement exported from the EU is EUR 189 billion, and this amount is expected to increase significantly after tariffs are lifted. I support this recommendation because I believe that the Agreement will result in lower prices for consumers, but also for producers that are dependent on imported parts.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement in the form of a declaration on the enlargement of the Agreement on Trade in Information Technology Products (ATI). The existing agreement, covering 200 tariff headings, eliminates customs duties on INFORMATION technology products. However, as there has been remarkable progress in the field of information technology in recent years, the existing agreement must, of course, be modernised, and trade in the sector has quadrupled. It is therefore essential to upgrade the existing agreement in order to increase the volume of products covered by the agreement to come to that.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement in the form of a declaration on the expansion of trade in information technology products (ITA) on behalf of the European Union. This is a multilateral agreement within the WTO that will lead to lower prices for consumers, but also for producers whose production depends on imported components. In view of technological developments in the sector, the members decided to update the bož coverage of the agreement and proceeded to update it. Items such as semiconductor, GPS navigation, smart cards, optical lenses, ultrasounds and microscopes have now been added to the list. Most of the IT goods concerned will be traded duty-free from July 2016, with further duties eliminated in 2019 and 2021, with the remaining duties by 2023 at the latest.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The abolition and consolidation to zero of customs duties for up to seven years in respect of technology and information products, through the ITA agreement, will lead to lower prices, increased competitiveness, but above all to job creation and growth in gross domestic product. We therefore vote in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement in the form of a declaration on the extension of trade in information technology products (ITA), in order to make progress and technological progress in all areas.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The first Information Technology Agreement ('ITA'), concluded in December 1996 at the Singapore Ministerial Conference, entered into force in 1997. While the agreement was initially concluded by only 29 WTO member states, it now has 82 participants. For all information technology products covered by the Agreement, the ITA requires all participants to lift and fix duties at zero on the basis of the principle of the most favoured nation. The ITA includes approximately 200 tariff groups, including computers, telephones, input units, components and machines for the production of information technology tools. In May 2012, six countries (EU, USA, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Costa Rica) began negotiations to extend the product scope of the agreement. They were joined by 21 other members. On July 24, 2015, an agreement was reached on an additional list of 201 IT products. The Agreement in the form of a Declaration on the extension of the ITA (and the agendas containing the intermittent commitment of the participants) was adopted by ministers from the participating countries on 16 December 2015 at the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi. The extension of the ITA is considered to be a milestone. This is the first high-profile tariff reduction agreement with huge job creation and GDP growth potential since the wto was established. I therefore voted in favour of Parliament giving its consent to the agreement.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on an agreement to expand trade in information technology products, as it has a high potential for job creation and GDP growth. Since the first INFORMATION Technology Agreement was concluded in December 1996, it was timely to expand the product scope covered. On the basis of the principle of the most favoured nation for all information technology products covered by the Agreement, the participants shall abolish and fix duties at zero. It is to be welcomed that the products covered by the current extension of the INFORMATION Technology Agreement cover EU exports amounting to EUR 189 billion and that figure is expected to increase significantly following the tariff reductions. The agreement will result in lower prices for consumers, but also for manufacturers dependent on imported parts. However, as the Recommendation notes, certain sectors will face greater competition. It is therefore to be welcomed that, during the negotiations, the EU managed to extend a period of phase-out for some sensitive products.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The Agreement on the Development of Trade in Information Technology Products (ITA), signed in 1996, was undoubtedly a milestone in the liberalisation of trade in IT products. However, after 20 years, it required adaptation to the huge technological changes that have taken place in recent times.  By a amending and extending the scope of this agreement, next-generation IT products will also be able to benefit from customs facilitation. This is an important step for the World Trade Organisation and it is good that it was the European Union that was the driving force behind these changes. This will ensure that European companies are properly protected from unfair competition under the global system. By acceding to the Agreement, 54 signatory countries commit to phasing out tariffs on as many as 201 information technology products such as video game consoles, GPS navigation systems, magnetic resonance imaging devices, telecommunications satellites, touchscreens and video cameras. Extending and extending the scope of the ITA agreement is of great economic importance. According to data from the World Trade Organisation, its products account for around 7% of world trade, or EUR 1.1 trillion. The European Parliament's green light confirms the EU's commitment to liberalising trade in these products.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the dossier of this landmark deal which was one of the significant outcomes from the Nairobi Ministerial. It aims to eliminate tariffs on information technology products valued at over $1.3 trillion per year. Negotiations on the expanded Information Technology Agreement of 1996 (ITA) were conducted by 53 WTO members, including both developed and developing countries, which account for approximately 90 per cent of world trade in these products. However, we shall remember that all WTO members will benefit from the agreement, as they will all enjoy duty-free market access to the markets of the members eliminating tariffs on these products. The expanded ITA should boost the EU manufacturing sector, allowing easier access to new markets; like its 1996-predecessor it should continue to promote jobs, offer lower prices to consumers and boost economic growth and foster innovation. It will benefit consumers, producers and the economies of both the EU and partner countries. I look forward to another update of ITA in 2018. I hope that when negotiations reopen then and progress would be made in reducing non-tariff barriers.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The ITA enlargement agreement is historic, as it is the first major tariff reduction agreement since the WTO's inception and has enormous potential in terms of job creation and boosting GDP growth. That is why I am pleased that the European Parliament has given its approval to the conclusion of the agreement. I would like to stress, however, that it is important to ensure that more members join the agreement so that the Union takes full advantage of it.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In the last two decades, the IT sector has experienced tremendous changes and trade in the sector has quadrupled. This is why I voted in favour of expanding and adjusting the agreement in Information Technology Products (ITA) to new products reflecting today’s reality. This agreement requires that each participant eliminates and binds customs duties at zero on a Most Favoured Nation basis for all information technology (IT) products covered. By eliminating approximately 65% of tariff lines by mid-2016 and making almost all imports of the relevant products duty free by 2019, this will be the first major tariff cutting deal since the creation of the WTO. The potential of this agreement to create jobs and boost GDP growth is therefore great.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the It Technology Product Expansion Report, as the expansion of ita includes issues covered by the common trade policy and products under negotiation are essential in much of the European Union's exports, so significant impacts on the value chain can be expected. The entry into force will abolish most low duties, representing 25% of the value of customs duties.  After three years, more than 60% of customs duties will be phased out and 30% will be abolished after seven years. In accordance with the ITA, each participant must abolish and bind tariffs to a zero tariff rate, based on the principle of the most advantaged state, for all information technology products covered. Bescarin's conduct has played an important role in the development and expansion of trade in the IT technology sector over 20 years of ita application.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement in the form of a declaration on the enlargement of the Agreement on Trade in Information Technology Products (ATI). It provides that each Party shall abolish customs duties and bind them to zero in respect of all IT products covered on the basis of the most-favoured-nation principle. The agreement includes around 200 tariff lines relating to computers and telephones, raw materials, components and machinery for the production of INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY products. The duty-free treatment has made a significant contribution to the development and expansion of trade, which has quadrupled in the 20 years since the agreement was applied. Following the signing of the agreement, the parties had to present timetables with a gradual reduction of duties on all products during the seven-year phasing-out period, which means that imports of all products concerned will be exempt from customs duties by 2019. The EU exports EUR 189 billion of products included in ita, which is expected to increase further. The agreement can only be fully exploited if a large number of Member States accede to it.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against this report in considering that the ITA agreement, far from contributing to the coverage of the technological gap of developing countries, presents risks of impacting inversely in these countries, harming not only the collection of resources via customs, but also increasing south/north technological dependence and exposing the scarce business fabric to lethal competition by highly technified countries. In addition, the environmental impacts arising from this industry are not covered throughout the document.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because the trade rules for the exchange of technologically advanced products are very important for innovation cycles. The duty-free market access given to ITA participants has played a very important role in the huge development and expansion of trade that has taken place in the IT sector in almost 20 years of ITA implementation, which I welcome.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The first Information Technology Trade Agreement (ITA) entered into force in 1997. It required the parties to eliminate and bind customs duties at zero rate for products such as computers, telephones, IT equipment, etc. Its implementation has resulted in a revival of trade in such products, lower prices for consumers and producers. The current amendment to the agreement extends the list of products included in the 1997 agreement. I assume that extending the ITA to new products will further develop trade, increase industrial jobs and increase GDP. An important role for the EU is to support the development of modern technologies, which is why I voted in favour of the ITA.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The first Information Technology Agreement ('ITA'), concluded in December 1996 at the Singapore Ministerial Conference, entered into force in 1997. While the agreement was initially concluded by only 29 WTO member states, it now has 82 participants. The extension of the ITA is considered to be a milestone. This is the first high-profile tariff reduction agreement with huge job creation and GDP growth potential since the wto was established. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against this report in considering that the ITA agreement, far from contributing to the coverage of the technological gap of developing countries, presents risks of impacting inversely in these countries, harming not only the collection of resources via customs, but also increasing south/north technological dependence and exposing the scarce business fabric to lethal competition by highly technified countries. In addition, the environmental impacts arising from this industry are not covered throughout the document.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement in the form of the Declaration on the Expansion of Trade in Information Technology Products (ITA). The agreement requires that each participant eliminates and binds customs duties at zero on a Most Favoured Nation basis for all information technology (IT) products covered. I voted in favour because I believe that the expansion of the ITA is a landmark deal with a huge potential to create jobs and boost GDP growth.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 We are talking about an agreement negotiated by the Commission which provides for a timetable for the elimination of customs duties on 201 information technology products, representing annual trade in these products 10% of total global trade. Since the European Parliament's committee on international trade voted in favour of this agreement by a large majority, I consider it necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In May 2012, six countries proposed to extend the list of products covered by the Agreement (EU, USA, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Costa Rica). The products covered by this agreement include new generation semiconductors, GPS navigation systems, medical products, including magnetic resonance imaging machines, machine tools for the manufacture of integrated circuits, telecommunications satellites and touch screens.  The ATI requires each participant to eliminate customs duties and consolidate them at zero rate on the basis of the most-favoured-nation principle for all information technology (IT) products covered. ATI covers about 200 tariff items, including computers, telephones, but also the insums, components and machines for the production of IT items.  This agreement is part of the broader picture of free trade agreements, and essentially aims to further increase the hegemony of large multinationals, which want to strengthen market control by either increasing the volume of business with a view to sales or by ensuring the absolute mastery of knowledge and research through "intellectual property rights". We're against it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The extension of the ITA Convention is about updating the coverage. This is necessary because, although the IT sector has developed considerably since 1997, the ITA's coverage is not. On the positive side, both the prices of IT products for the consumer are falling and important medical devices, such as imaging magnetic resonance devices, are becoming cheaper to purchase and produce. It is also positive to note that longer phased tariff reduction systems have been negotiated for sensitive IT goods.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the expansion of the trade in information technology products (ATI). The First Information Technology Agreement (ITA) was concluded at the Singapore Ministerial Conference in December 1996 and entered into force in 1997. Although, in the initial phase, only 29 WTO Member States have signed this agreement, the number of States participating in the ITA is currently 82. The value of EU exports of products falling within the scope of the ATI, following the extension of this agreement, amounts to EUR 189 billion, with this figure expected to increase significantly as a result of tariff reductions. The implementation of the agreement will lead to lower prices for consumers, but also for producers, whose activity depends on imported components. However, some sectors will face increased competition. The rapporteur therefore welcomes the strategy adopted by the EU, which has negotiated longer periods of time for the phasing out of duties on products considered to be sensitive, while most tariff lines for products that are not considered to be sensitive will be abolished upon the entry into force of this Agreement.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. The Agreement on the Expansion of Trade in Information Technology Products was already needed, as the last update was almost 20 years ago. This expansion will allow prices to drop in information technology products, which will benefit producers and consumers and will in the end encourage trade and growth.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I support the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on International Trade to sign the Information Technology Agreement (ITA) concluded by the 29 WTO Member States at the Ministerial Conference in Singapore in 1996 and to the future conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement in the form of a declaration on the development of trade in information technology products (ITA).  This is a very important document that aims to bind and eliminate customs duties on an additional 201 IT products. The elimination and binding of customs duties at zero rate should apply to the widest possible number of IT products. It is very good that products such as GPS navigation systems, medical devices, telecommunications satellites and other high-tech products are indicated in this list. However, we should not forget about sensitive products. A transitional period of seven years for the complete elimination of the duty for such products is reasonable. Nevertheless, it is important that the conclusion of an agreement will contribute to the economic development of the European Union. According to the calculations provided by the experts, if all parties ratify the agreement, exports of goods from the Union could increase by around 0,7 % to 1,4 % of its base value, representing eur 12-24 billion.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement in the form of a declaration on the enlargement of the Agreement on Trade in Information Technology Products (ATI), because the agreement to expand the ATI agreement has great potential to create jobs and increase GDP growth.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with Council Decision 2005/387/JHA on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA) assessed the risks of the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidinil)-1-pentanone (alpha-pyrrolidinovalerophenone; α-PVP). I voted in favour of the proposal, which is concerned with the Commission's call on the Member States to subject this substance to control measures.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. New psychoactive substances have been found to be available without medical or veterinary benefits and, according to WHO, produce violent behavior, psychotic behaviour and cardiological toxicity. I voted in favour of the implementation of the measures contained in the 1971 UN Convention on Psychotropic Substances, which require these substances to be subjected to a series of checks and, if considered dangerous or addictive, States regulate their use within a period of time not more than twelve months.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to subject the alpha-PVP psychostimulant to control measures throughout the European Union, given that 16 Member States monitor it in accordance with their legislation and 5 Member States use other legislative measures to control it. To date, there have been 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings directly linked to the use of the substance in eight Member States. Furthermore, it is accepted that alpha-PVP has no therapeutic value. The evidence gathered on the risks associated with the use of this substance are sufficient grounds to subject the alpha-PVP to control measures throughout the European Union in order to protect the population from the danger of this powerful psychostimulant and to avoid any obstacles to cross-border police and judicial cooperation.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I shadowed this report and I was pleased with the direction of the report. The report was concerned with subjecting a new psychoactive substance to control measures. The report further invited Member States to subject the substance in question to control measures provided by their own legislation by virtue of their obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. Most Member States have already done so. As a member of the Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs Committee, I have followed legislation on these substances very carefully. Their availability is a cause of great concern and the effect some of these substances have on users is horrific. In relation to this particular substance, more than a 130 deaths have been associated with A-PVP and non-lethal side effects include cardiotoxicity, violent behaviour and displays of psychotic behaviour. Sinn Féin have been at the forefront of calling on Member States to legislate as efficiently as possible to prevent these substances from gaining a foothold in the illicit market.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this report: our overriding objective is to reduce the use of this type of substance.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council decision on the inclusion of the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(pyrroline-1-yl)penan-1-one (a-pyrrolidinovalerophenon, α-PVP) in control measures, because it is important to protect against risks that can be created by its availability and use.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Α-PVP is a powerful psychoactive substance. It has already been discovered in 28 Member States, as well as in Turkey and Norway, and is mainly imported into the EU drug market from China, mainly in powder or tablet form. Two illegal production sites for this substance have already been seized in one Member State, which shows that it can also be produced in the Union. A total of 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings have been recorded so far in eight Member States, with α-PVP recorded. There is no comprehensive information or studies on the health risks (chronic and acute toxicity) posed by α-PVP, but observations in animals suggest similar effects to other stimulants. The Council then proposes that Member States be obliged to subject α-PVP to the control measures and criminal sanctions provided for in their law in accordance with their obligations under the 1971 UN Convention on Psychotropic Substances. I voted in favour of the Council's proposal because I am at high risk to my health. The substance can be highly harmful. For me, prevention in the interests of the citizens is a more than justifiable reason for being in favour of the need to introduce Control Measures throughout the Union.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Powerful and dangerous psychostimulating, alpha-PVP is believed to be responsible for 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings recorded in eight Member States. In both human and veterinary medicine, this substance has no recognized therapeutic value. Several Member States already control the alpha-PVP. Extending these controls to the whole of the Union will strengthen the protection of people from the risks associated with its availability and consumption. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I abstained. This report is the result of a consultation on the alpha-PVP drug. I am in favour of drug control measures however this report has no relevance to the UK.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to encourage Member States to apply control measures and criminal sanctions to α-PVP material, as provided for in their legislation, which fulfils their obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council Decision proposed by the EP makes cooperation between Member States more effective in combating α-PVP, this dangerous psychotropic substance. The α-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant. The substance detected in the 28 Member States, as well as in Turkey and Norway, comes primarily from China and is marketed throughout Europe. The α PVP was detected in a total of 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings in eight Member States. The proposal for a Council Decision aims to call on Member States to subject the α-PVP to control measures and criminal sanctions in accordance with the provisions of their legislation based on their obligations under the United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances of 1971. Combating the use of psychotropic substances is in the common interest of all of us, so I supported the adoption of this report, of course.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the powerful psychostimulant alpha-PVP to be subjected to control measures. A total of 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings were recorded in eight Member States where the presence of alpha-PVP was reported, all the more problematic as the substance in question has no established or recognised therapeutic value (whether in human or veterinary medicine).  Thus, it appears necessary to subject this substance to control measures throughout the Union in order to avoid the emergence of obstacles related to cross-border police and judicial cooperation and to protect people from the risks associated with its availability and consumption.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved this report which proposes to subject a new psychoactive substance to better controls.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Boni report on control measures for α-PVP. It is a new psychoactive substance, 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidinil)-1-pentanone (alpha-pyrrolidinovalerophenone; α-PVP), which must be subject to control measures and criminal sanctions under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. At present, only 16 Member States are applying measures of this kind, so action is needed at Union level to standardise control measures. The draft Council decision provides for a strengthening of judicial cooperation and the removal of obstacles to cross-border cooperation.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 α-PVP is a psychomotor stimulant first recorded in the EU in 2011. It is a derivative of synthetic cathinine, and is commonly referred to as a new psychotropic substance that has, among others, effects similar to methamphetamine and cocaine. WHO research suggests that α-PVP is readily available on the internet and in some retail vendors; it has also been discovered on the illegal market in the form of ecstasy pills. More than 130 deaths have been associated with α-PVP, as well as non-lethal side effects such as cardiovascular toxicity, violent behavior and psychotic behavior samples. The Boni report proposes that this substance be subject to EU control measures, in accordance with Decision 2005/387/JHA (for the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances) of 10 May 2005. If approved, Member States will have to legislate within 12 months. Its application would allow the authorities of the Member States to take such measures as they deem necessary to prevent the sale of such substances (including the internet). I voted for it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 In view of the deaths caused by this new psychotropic from China— namely one hundred and fifteen deaths and one hundred and ninety-ninety and acute poisonings in eight Member States, where α-PVP has been detected — and the limited data available on its medium- and long-term effects, clearly meet the conditions set out in the Council Decision , of 10 May 2005 on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychotropic substances and, in particular, Article 8(3) thereo. This report should therefore be supported.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Alpha-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant. A total of 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings were recorded in eight Member States where alpha-PVP was reported. Alpha-PVP has no established or recognized therapeutic value (whether in human or veterinary medicine). Unfortunately, we have little scientific data on alpha-PVP, but the limited information we have on the risks of the substance is sufficient grounds to subject alpha-PVP to control measures throughout the Union. Given that 16 Member States control alpha-PVP in accordance with their legislation and that 5 Member States use other legislative measures to control it, it is interesting to subject the substance to control measures throughout the EU. So I decided to vote for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Boni report is acceptable and without any critical issues and I therefore intended to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this draft resolution by which Parliament approves the draft Council Decision to submit α-pyrrolidinovalerophenone (α-PVP) to control measures and criminal sanctions in the Member States under its obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. Currently, sixteen Member States control α-PVP under their national legislation, in compliance with the obligations imposed by the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances, and five Member States apply other legislative measures to control it. Subjecting this substance to control measures throughout the Union will help to avoid obstacles to cross-border judicial and police cooperation, and help protect society against the risks that may arise from the availability and consumption of that substance. Not for nothing in the eight Member States where the α-PVP was detected, there were 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the draft Council decision on the application of control measures to the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(pyrolidine-1-yl) pentane-1-one (α-pyrolidinvalerofenone, α-PVP). Council Decision 2005/387/JHA on the exchange, risk assessment and control of information on new psychoactive substances provides for a three-step procedure whereby control measures may be introduced for new psychoactive substances throughout the Union. Α-PVP was assessed by the Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction and presented the following conclusions of the key risk assessment: α-PVP is a potent psychostimulant. The substance, which has been detected in all 28 Member States, as well as turkey and Norway, is mainly imported into the EU drug market from China and then distributed throughout Europe.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this report and the prohibition of a-PVP. Young people are the target group of consumers and as such suffer the most harm from the consumption of synthetic drugs. Deaths have been registered across Europe, and recently a teenager died in the middle of consumption in Croatia. Some of the compounds that are on the market are extremely strong and can cause consequences such as increased pressure, paranoia, psychosis, nausea, seizures and in some cases – death. The most severe consequences occur because the active substance is incorrectly distributed per product during mixing and drying. As a result, some packages are many times stronger and more harmful than usual. The common market and the abolition of borders have brought multiple benefits to Europe, but in this case this freedom has negative side effects. Member States cannot tackle the problem of 'legal drugs' on their own, as they cannot keep up with the speed at which new compounds appear.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report discusses control measures for alpha-PVP, a substance considered a powerful and dangerous synthetic drug responsible for many deaths in some Member States. This agreement aims to facilitate police and judicial cooperation and to protect EU citizens by establishing measures to control this psychoactive substance. For all these reasons, I voted for this agreement.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I shadowed this report and I was pleased with the direction of the report. The report was concerned with subjecting a new psychoactive substance to control measures. The report further invited Member States to subject the substance in question to control measures provided by their own legislation by virtue of their obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. Most Member States have already done so. As a member of the Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs Committee, I have followed legislation on these substances very carefully. Their availability is a cause of great concern and the effect some of these substances have on users is horrific. In relation to this particular substance, more than a 130 deaths have been associated with A-PVP and non-lethal side effects include cardiotoxicity, violent behaviour and displays of psychotic behaviour. Sinn Féin have been at the forefront of calling on Member States to legislate as efficiently as possible to prevent these substances from gaining a foothold in the illicit market.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to subject the alpha-PVP to control measures throughout the European Union. As a reminder, alpha-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant, structurally related to other psychotropic substances such as cathinone or pyrovalron, which are already subject to control measures under the 1971 United Nations Convention. There are now 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings in eight Member States directly related to the use of the substance. Moreover, it is commonly accepted that alpha-PVP has no therapeutic value. The evidence gathered on the risks associated with the use of this substance are sufficient grounds for subjecting alpha-PVP to control measures throughout the European Union. This will, on the one hand, protect the population from the danger of this psychostimulant and, on the other hand, avoid any obstacles to cross-border police and judicial cooperation. So I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The substance α-PVP is a psychoactive substance detected in all 28 Member States, imported into the European market from China. 115 deaths and 191 poisonings caused by this substance have been reported in the Member States. Although there are no exhaustive studies on the risk posed by this substance, following animal observations, it has been found that the harmful effects are similar to humans. However, a risk assessment report has been carried out highlighting the toxicity of this substance, which seriously affects human health. As a result, I consider it necessary to subject the psychoactive substance α-PVP to control measures, and I therefore express myself in favour of this report. Nothing can be more important than ensuring high standards for human health, with any initiative in this regard enjoying my support.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report which assesses European influence in the formation of international accounting standards and their subsequent reception in European law, which emphasises the importance of financial stability in setting accounting standards.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe it is necessary to subject the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidinil)-1-pentanone (alpha-pyrrolidinovalerophenone; α-PVP) to control measures. The assessment of the risks caused by the consumption, manufacture and trafficking of the new psychoactive substance α-PVP is of particular importance. Furthermore, I agree with the preparation of further investigations to establish the involvement of criminal organisations in the trade in this substance and the existence of any consequences of the control measures to be applied. The substance α-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant, the presence of which is detected in all 28 Member States, as well as in Turkey and Norway. Imported into the drug market mainly from China, this substance is subsequently distributed throughout Europe. In eight Member States reporting the presence of α-PVP, 115 deaths and 191 cases of acute intoxication were recorded. At present, no definite information is available and no studies have been published which fully assess the health risks associated with the substance α-PVP, i.e. chronic and acute toxicity. Observations on animals, however, indicate that this substance would have effects similar to those of other stimulants.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The report was concerned with subjecting a new psychoactive substance to control measures. The report further invited Member States to subject the substance in question to control measures provided by their own legislation by virtue of their obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. Most Member States have already done so. I have followed legislation on these substances very carefully. Their availability is a cause of great concern and the effect some of these substances have on users is horrific. In relation to this particular substance, more than a 130 deaths have been associated with A-PVP and non-lethal side effects include cardiotoxicity, violent behaviour and displays of psychotic behaviour. Sinn Féin have been at the forefront of calling on Member States to legislate as efficiently as possible to prevent these substances from gaining a foothold in the illicit market.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because I agree that the new psychoactive substance, α-PVP, needs to undergo strict control measures across all Member States. The Council rightly underlined the risk associated with its use and called for control to ensure safety of its clinical application.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA) assessed the risks of this new psychoactive substance and, on the basis of the final report, the Commission calls for the substance to be subject to control measures across the Union. I certainly voted in favour.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Studies carried out by the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA) and Europol have shown that the substance α-PVP (alpha-pyrrolidinovalerophenone) is a powerful psychostimulant. This substance has been identified by the police in the drug markets of the twenty-eight Eu ropean Union Member States, mainly from China. As a result of taking this substance in the form of powder or tablets, 115 deaths and 191 cases of acute intoxication have already occurred in eight EU states. At present, only sixteen European countries, complying with their obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances, control this substance and which, according to their national legislation, provide for sanctions. In order to avoid obstacles to cross-border cooperation between police and judicial authorities and to protect citizens from the risks posed by their availability and consumption, the α-PVP must be subject to control measures throughout the European Union. The legislative resolution voted in plenary, on which I voted in favour, mandates the Council to make control compulsory for states that will have one year to comply with the text of the European decision to take measures to penalise the use of the substance.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and call on the Member States to take the necessary measures, in accordance with their national legislation, to make the new psychoactive substance α-PVP subject to the control measures and criminal penalties provided for in their legislation, in accordance with their obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the submission of alpha-PVP to control measures because of the dangerousness of this new psychoactive substance and thus to avoid numerous poisonings and even deaths.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Alpha-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant structurally related to cathinone, pyrovalerone and methylenedioxypyrovalérone (MDPV). These substances are subject to control measures under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. A total of 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings were recorded in eight Member States where alpha-PVP was reported. Alpha-PVP has no established or recognized therapeutic value (human or veterinary medicine). Information and evidence on health risks are sufficient grounds to subject the alpha-PVP to EU-pending control measures. This would protect people from the risks associated with its availability and consumption. Also, I voted for this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the draft Council decision on the subjecting of the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidine-1-yl) pentan-1-one (α-pyrrolidinelerofenone, α-PVP) to control measures. This substance was detected in 8 Member States, causing the deaths of 115 people and 191 with severe consequences of poisoning.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the draft Council decision on the inclusion of the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(pyrroline-1-yl)penan-1-one (a-pyrrolidinovalerophenon, α-PVP) in control measures is clearly an attempt to protect the health of citizens. As I believe that any action to control and monitor substances administered to citizens is a positive and legitimate measure that goes in the interests of Europeans, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Psychoactive substances, in general, need to be controlled to reduce their impact on citizens' health and their costs to the health system. I voted in favour of this proposal because I am in favour of increasing constant controls on these substances in order to reduce the possibility of European citizens being victims of intoxication due to substances whose danger is not always known.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Alpha-PVP is a potent psychostimulant. The substance, which has been detected in all 28 Member States as well as in Turkey and Norway, is mainly imported into the EU drug market from China and then distributed across Europe. There have been a total of 115 deaths and 191 acute intoxications registered in eight Member States reported where α-PVP was detected. There is no available information or published studies assessing in a comprehensive way the health risks associated with α-PVP, namely chronic and acute toxicity, but observations in animals suggest similar effects with those observed with other stimulants.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Council Decision 2005/387/JAI on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the dangers inherent in new drugs require rapid and concerted intervention by States at European level. When a new substance is found, the Member State should report this to Europol and the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction, which will also try to assess its risk to public health as well as associated crime. Once the procedure is complete, they may request control or prohibition measures from Member States.  Although Parliament's involvement is unnecessary - given the exclusively technical content of this decision - Parliament must be consulted and given its opinion. This substance had already been banned and, given its enormous toxicity and associated deaths, it is suggested that its ban be maintained and Parliament approves it.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the report by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, I voted in favour of the Council's draft to adopt control measures against the new psychoactive substance in question.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I understand that α-PVP, like other psychostimulants, can cause a condition called ‘excited delirium’ that involves hyper stimulation, paranoia, and hallucinations. It has been reported that α-PVP has been a significant contributory cause of death in suicides and overdoses caused by combinations of drugs. I therefore support a health friendly approach and agree to depart from the text approved by Parliament asking the Council to consult Parliament again if it intends to substantially amend the text approved by Parliament.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. New psychoactive substances have been found to be available without medical or veterinary benefits and, according to WHO, produce violent behavior, psychotic behaviour and cardiological toxicity. I voted in favour of the implementation of the measures contained in the 1971 UN Convention on Psychotropic Substances, which require these substances to be subjected to a number of checks and, if considered dangerous or addictive, States regulate their use within a period of time not more than twelve months.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On 3 August 2015 The Council requested an assessment of the risks caused by the use and manufacture of a new psychoactive α-PVP. According to its risk assessment, α-PVP is a highly potent substance with psychostimulating properties, with a total of 115 deaths and 191 acute poisoning cases reported in eight Member States where α-PVP was detected. I believe that if α-PVP system were to become widely available and used, the consequences for people's health and public health could be significant. On the basis of the findings of the risk assessment report, the Commission concluded that there are reasons for the inclusion of α-PVP substances in control measures across the Union. I fully agree with the Commission's proposals, and I therefore support this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal for a Council Decision to call upon the Member States to subject the recreational drug known as α-PVP to control measures and criminal proceedings. Currently, sixteen Member States control α-PVP under national legislation complying with the UN Convention on Psychotropic Substances and five Member States use other legislative measures to control it. Subjecting this substance to control measures across the European Union would help avoid the emergence of obstacles in cross-border law enforcement and judicial cooperation.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Each new psychoactive substance should be subject to control, risk assessment and the results of controls disseminated as information between Member States.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: to subject the alpha-PVP to control measures throughout the EU.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report proposes the approval to subject substances to control measures provided for by legislation under their obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. Psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidin-1-il)-pentan-1-one (α-pyrrolidinovalerofenone, α-PVP) is a psychomotor stimulant first recorded in the EU in 2011. It is a derivative of synthetic cathinone commonly referred to as a new psychoactive substance. α-PVP is a potent blocker in the transporter of norepinephrine and dopamine and clinical research suggests that the effects of α-PVP will be similar to those of MDPV, methamphetamine and cocaine. Once the submission to EU control measures in accordance with Decision 2005/387/JAI (on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances) of 10 May 2005 has to legislate on the issue within 12 months of the decision. This implementing decision allows the authorities of the Member States to take the measures deemed necessary to prevent the sale of such substances. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 A-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant used in the manufacture of various products, often in excessive and harmful quantities. The long-term consumption and extensive trafficking of this substance would have repercussions in terms of the health of European citizens. I therefore support this report, the purpose of which is to subject the substance to control measures in all Member States. The EU has a duty to protect its citizens, especially by preventing the use and abuse of suspicious substances.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained because the prohibition path does not work.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of more control measures for this new psychoactive substance used in the creation of new types of very dangerous and harmful synthetic drugs.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of report A8-0175/2016, as every new psychoactive substance must be subject to control, risk assessment and the results of controls disseminated as information between Member States.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The objective of this proposal for a Council Decision is to call upon the Member States to subject α-PVP to control measures and criminal penalties as provided under their legislation by virtue of their obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. Currently, sixteen Member States control α-PVP under national legislation complying with the obligations of the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances and five Member States use other legislative measures to control it. Subjecting this substance to control measures across the Union would help avoid the emergence of obstacles in cross-border law enforcement and judicial cooperation, and would help protect from the risks that its availability and use can pose. I supported the report as it will lead to the reduction of the use of these kind of substances.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the firm determination that it is necessary to urge the Member States, to subject the α-PVP to control measures and to comply with their obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the ep's non-legislative resolution on the Council decision subjecting the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidinil)-1-pentanone (alpha-pyrrolidinovalerophenone; α-PVP) to control measures, because I believe it is important to take action at Union level to prohibit the spread of these dangerous psychotropic substances. Animal tests denote the toxicity of these substances. A total of 115 deaths and 191 cases of intoxication were also recorded in the 8 countries where the substance was detected. I therefore agree with the European Commission's proposal to subject this substance to common control measures at EU level, because this decision will avoid problems related to possible cross-border controls and investigations, which are necessary given that these substances are mainly imported from China. Given that as many as 16 Member States already have control regulations which comply with the 1971 Convention on Psychotropic Substances, I believe that European intervention has the advantage of standardising these sanction regimes.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. Α-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant. It has already been discovered in all 28 Member States, as well as in Turkey and Norway, and is mainly imported from China into the EU drug market and then spread throughout Europe. A total of 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings have been recorded so far in eight Member States, with α-PVP recorded. I have therefore voted in favour of increased control measures in all EU countries and in favour of the relevant report.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The decision on control measures for the new psychoactive substance α-PVP is necessary to ensure the continuity of control measures for the new substance in the EU Member States.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I approve of the efforts to reduce the use of these sorts of psychoactive substances, hence why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 α-PVP is a psychomotor stimulant first recorded in the EU in 2011. It is a derivative of synthetic cathinine and is commonly referred to as a new psychotropic substance that has, among others, effects similar to methamphetamine and cocaine. WHO research suggests that α-PVP is readily available on the internet and in some retail vendors; it has also been discovered on the illegal market in the form of ecstasy pills. More than 130 deaths have been associated with α-PVP, as well as non-lethal side effects such as cardiovascular toxicity, violent behavior and psychotic behavior samples. The Boni report proposes that this substance be subject to EU control measures, in accordance with Decision 2005/387/JHA (for the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances) of 10 May 2005. If approved, Member States will have to legislate within 12 months. Its application would allow the authorities of the Member States to take such measures as they deem necessary to prevent the sale of such substances (including the internet). I voted for it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in line with Socialist MEPs on this, with our objective being the reduction of the use of these harmful substance.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is a simple endorsement of the Council's plan calling on Member States to take action because of their obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. The World Health Organisation states of the substance α-PVP, which is mentioned in the resolution, that 130 deaths are due to it and that this substance offers no medical benefit. In view of this, we voted in favour of the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidin-1-yl) pentan-1-one (α-pyrrolidinovalerophenone, α-PVP) should be subject to control measures. Despite the limited scientific evidence available on α-PVP, the evidence and information on the health risks that the substance poses, as documented in its detection in fatalities and acute intoxications, provides sufficient ground for subjecting α-PVP to control measures across the Union. I believe that it is in the interest of the citizens of the European Union to subject this substance to control measures.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposal endorsed by the Council on control measures for the new psychoactive substance α-PVP, aims to urge Member States to subject this substance, as a powerful psychostimulant, to accurate control measures and criminal sanctions, in accordance with the obligations laid down in the UNITED Nations Convention. To date, in eight Member States, deaths and acute intoxication have been reported, although it is not possible to provide certain information to give a concrete assessment of the risks that the substance α-PVP is capable of producing, namely, chronic and acute toxicity. Observations on animals, however, suggest that the substance would have effects similar to those of other stimulants. On the basis of these results, we believe that there are the right reasons for subjecting the substance to appropriate control measures across the EU, in order to protect the health of citizens.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement as it raises safety levels amongst EU member states and brings about harmonised control measures.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. Alpha-PVP is a new substance, considered a powerful psychostimulant, that has no established or recognized therapeutic value. Today, 21 Member States have introduced control measures against the drug, which is believed to have caused several deaths. Since this substance is already controlled in most Member States, EU-wide control measures could strengthen cross-border police and judicial cooperation and protect people from the risks associated with its availability and consumption.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report, which calls on the Member States to subject new psychoactive substances 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrolidin-1-il) pentan-1-on (α-pyrolidinovalerofen, α-PVP) to control measures and criminal proceedings. Subjecting this substance to control at European Union level would help to avoid the emergence of possible cross-border barriers to law and judicial cooperation.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I vote for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the subject of the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(pyrolidine-1-il) pentan-1-on (a-pyrolidineovalorofenon, α-PVP) control measures, because, based on the risk assessment, acute toxicity of α-PVP can cause severe consequences for human health. α-PVP strong psychostimulating substance is imported into the EU drug market from China, with 115 deaths and 191 cases of acute poisoning reported so far. Therefore, I support this report endorsing the draft Council.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing.
