Given that 16 Member States control alpha-PVP in accordance with their legislation and 5 Member States use other legislative measures to control it, subjecting the substance to EU-wide control measures would prevent the emergence of obstacles to cross-border police and judicial cooperation and protect people from the risks associated with its availability and consumption. Being, of course, in favour of this, I voted for the text.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to subject the new psychoactive substance alpha-PVP to control measures because of its high toxicity.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – α-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant and is mainly imported from China into the EU pharmaceutical market. To date, 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings have been recorded in eight Member States where this substance has been detected. There is currently no comprehensive information or studies on health risks available. By voting in favour of this report, the Commission's proposal to prevent dissemination, control and criminal sanctions is adopted.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal as it calls upon the Member States to subject α-PVP to control measures and criminal penalties which are in line with the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances, which all Member States have ratified.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it is a matter of subjecting alpha-PVP, a psychostimulant that has caused severe poisoning, to control measures.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the submission of alpha-PVP to control measures. Alpha-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant. To date, 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings have been recorded in the eight Member States where alpha-PVP has been reported. Alpha-PVP has no established or recognized therapeutic value, whether in human or veterinary medicine. Given that 16 Member States control alpha-PVP in accordance with their legislation and that 5 Member States use other legislative measures to control it, subjecting the substance to EU-wide control measures would prevent barriers to cross-border police and judicial cooperation, and protect people from the risks associated with its consumption.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union strives to raise the standards of safety and standard of living of its citizens from year to year. One of the important elements of this process is the proper control of substances such as psychotropic substances, which can be dangerous for life and health. Thanks to the compromise that has been achieved, the adopted legislation will reduce the potential risks of such measures and strengthen cooperation at European level on psychotropic substance control measures.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I have spoken for this text. It proposes to create a control of alpha-PVP, a powerful psychostimulant, at the level of the European Union. This psychotropic substance has been under control since the 1971 United Nations Convention. In addition, 16 EU countries have currently included this control in their legislation and 5 others have established legislation. Indeed, alpha-PVP has adverse health effects (acute poisonings that can lead to death) and has no recognized therapeutic value, either in the medical or veterinary sectors. Introducing its control throughout the EU promotes cross-border police and judicial cooperation and protects European citizens from its consumption.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. New psychoactive substances have been found to be available without medical or veterinary benefits and, according to WHO, produce violent behavior, psychotic behaviour and cardiological toxicity. I voted in favour of the implementation of the measures contained in the 1971 UN Convention on Psychotropic Substances, which require these substances to be subjected to a number of checks and, if considered dangerous or addictive, States regulate their use within a period of time not more than twelve months.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 By delay, I have allowed this proposal to pass, which will allow the introduction of control measures with regard to the subjugation of the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidine-1-yl)pentane-1-on (α-pyrrolidinovalerofenone, α-PVP) control measure. I take the view that the authorisation process for potentially toxic substances should not be subject to a vote by Parliament, that it should be a matter for experts in the authorities to have studies and scientific knowledge on the benefits and harmfulness of such substances.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The role for assessing the risk of the psychoactive substance α-PVP has been taken over by the scientific committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction. The Chair of the Scientific Committee submitted a risk assessment report to the Commission and the Council on 27 November 2015. The results of the risk assessment showed that α-PVP is a powerful psychostimulative substance detected in all Member States of the European Union and neighbouring countries such as Turkey and Norway. So far, 191 cases of poisoning and 115 deaths have been reported in eight Member States. Currently, there are no studies or available information to comprehensively assess the health risks associated with α-PVP. Animal studies have highlighted effects equivalent to those of other psychostimulative substances.  In my view, it is extremely important to determine what adverse consequences for human health can α-PVP. I supported the Report on the Proposal for a Council Decision on the Subject of a New Psychoactive Substance 1-Phenyl-2-(Pyrolidine-1-il) pentan-1-on (α-pyrolidinovalorophene, α-PVP) by control measures.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 alpha-Pirolidinopentiophenon or simply α-PVP is a synthetic excitation from the catinton class developed in the 1960s, which is still often sold as a 'designer drug'. This can lead to a condition called "agitated delirium", which includes hyperstimulation, paranoia and also hallucinations. While in some countries the substance is controlled or even partially legal, it is completely banned in EU Member States such as Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania, Slovenia, Sweden, the United Kingdom and the Czech Republic. The aim of today's vote was to apply control measures aimed at the α-PVP in the territory of the Union. Although much stricter rules already exist in those Member States in this respect, it was logical to support the draft Council decision in order to lay down uniform rules throughout the Union.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the substance α-PVP is a powerful psychostimulation element that is subject to scrutiny under the 1971 UN Convention. Its presence in the form of powder and tablets was detected in 28 Member States of the Union, while China was identified as the country of origin. The Commission has reasonablely concluded that, in view of the acute toxicity of this substance and the potential serious harm to human health, there are grounds for subjecting it to control measures across the EU. The EP has approved this procedure. Member States shall, in accordance with their national rules, take measures to control this substance, even with criminal consequences.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council decision on the inclusion of the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(pyrroline-1-yl)penan-1-one (a-pyrolidinovalerophenon, α-PVP) in control measures because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text.  Subjecting alpha-PVP, a powerful psychostimulant and cause of 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings, to control measures throughout the Union would prevent the emergence of obstacles to cross-border police and judicial cooperation and protect people from the risks associated with its availability and consumption. It should be noted that 16 Member States already control alpha-PVP in accordance with their national law and that 5 Member States are using other measures to control it.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the proposal for a Council decision subjecting the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidinil)-1-pentanone (alpha-pyrrolidinovalerophenone; α-PVP) to control measures. The substance is a powerful psychostimulant, detected in all 28 Member States, and is imported into the EU drug market mainly from China and subsequently distributed throughout Europe. Despite this, there is no information on the actual health risks associated with the substance α-PVP, i.e. chronic and acute toxicity, although in many states where the presence of this substance has been reported, many cases of deaths and as many cases of intoxication have been recorded. It is therefore necessary to activate control measures in the Union that assess the real toxicity of this substance and the damage it could cause to health, and thus protect citizens from the risks posed by the use of the substance α-PVP.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome Parliament's resolution on the Council's proposal to subject the new psychoactive substance alpha-PVP, a powerful psychostimulant, to control measures throughout the Union. As assessed by the scientific committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction, the acute toxicity of alpha-PVP is such that its use can pose high health risks. Given that the substance has been detected in all EU countries as well as in Turkey and Norway, and has caused 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings in eight Member States, I believe it is imperative to subject it to control measures throughout the Union. Currently, 21 states already control alpha-PVP. I welcome the fact that the submission of this substance to eu-wide control measures will contribute to the coherence of European action in the fight against such substances and can facilitate cross-border police and judicial cooperation in this regard.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report dealing with new psychotropic substances, namely 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidin-1-yl)pentane-1-on (α-pyrrolidinovalerofenone, α-PVP). The aim of this proposal for a Council Decision is to invite Member States to subject α-PVP to control measures and criminal sanctions provided for by their legislation in accordance with their obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. The proposal builds on Council Decision 2005/387/JVV on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, which provides for a three-stage procedure which may lead to the subjection of a new psychoactive substance to control measures throughout the Union. As I believe that the proposed measures are of great importance in order to avoid endangering people and their health with these substances, I voted in favour.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Α-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant imported from China into the EU drug market. This has already claimed 115 deaths and 191 poisonings. The aim of this proposal is to increase the control measures for α-PVP. I therefore agree with this proposal.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the Council's decision to apply specific control measures to the psychoactive substance α-PVP. According to the Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA), the α-PVP is a potent psychostimulant. It has been detected in all 28 Member States, as well as in Turkey and Norway, and is mainly imported into the EU drug market from China and then distributed throughout Europe.  A total of 115 deaths and 191 cases of acute poisoning were reported in eight Member States where α-PVP were detected.  As this substance can cause serious harm to human health, I support the decision to impose control measures and criminal sanctions on the use of this psychoactive substance.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. New psychoactive substances (NSPs) are multiplying at considerable speed on the European market, making it increasingly difficult to control them. Alpha-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant made in China. This substance appeared as a synthetic drug from the 2010s under the name Flakka. Cheap and extremely toxic, it has been detected in all 28 Member States as well as in Turkey and Norway. A total of 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings were recorded in connection with this substance. The report calls on Member States to take the necessary steps to subject the substance to the control measures and criminal sanctions provided for by their legislation, in accordance with their obligations under the 1971 UN Convention on Psychotropic Substances. In view of the risks to public health, I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite limited scientific data on alpha-PVP, evidence and information on the health risks of the substance are sufficient grounds for subjecting alpha-PVP to EU-based control measures. This homogenisation at European level would avoid the emergence of obstacles to cross-border police and judicial cooperation and protect people from the risks associated with its availability and consumption. That is why I voted for it.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because of the public health risks this stimulant poses to EU citizens and in order to combat organised crime within our Union resulting from trade of such substances.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: In writing — α-PVP substance is an active psychostimulant and the presence of this substance has been confirmed in all Member States of the Union as well as in Turkey and Norway. It is primarily imported into the European drug market from China and subsequently distributed throughout Europe. There are currently no relevant studies to comprehensively assess the risks associated with α-PVP, in particular chronic and acute toxicity, but animal observations have found similar effects to those of other stimulants and I therefore believe that this substance should be subjected to close control. Member States should take the necessary control measures and penal penalties for persons who do business with it. Subjecting this substance to control measures across the Union would help prevent obstacles to cross-border law enforcement and judicial cooperation and help protect against the risks that their availability and use may pose. In view of the above, I support the proposal in question.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because my overarching objective is the reduction of the use of these kind of substances. Currently, sixteen Member States control α-PVP under national legislation complying with the obligations of the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances and five Member States use other legislative measures to control it. Subjecting this substance to control measures across the Union would help avoid the emergence of obstacles in cross-border law enforcement and judicial cooperation, and would help protect from the risks that its availability and use can pose. Taking into account the above, the new proposed approach will include expanding the proposed Directive based on Article 83 TFEU with the provisions on information exchange, introduction of two categories of risk that the substance can pose (‘risk’ allowing to take further action at EU level and ‘no risk’ stopping further actions at EU level). In the event that the substance will be assessed harmful (‘risk’), the substance will be subject to the permanent control measure in the form of an EU-wide obligation to declare the substance illegal on the national level.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council submitted a draft decision on the subject of new psychoactive substances 1-phenyl-2-(pyrolidine-1-il)pentan-1 (α-pyrolidine-valerofenon, α-PVP). Parliament must be consulted in order to adopt the decision. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that Parliament approve the Council's draft. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In September 2015, following a request from the Commission and seventeen Member States, an assessment of the risks caused by the consumption, manufacture and trafficking of the new psychoactive substance α-PVP was requested, as well as the involvement of organised crime and the possible consequences of control measures that would be applied to that substance. As α-PVP is a potent psychostimulant, it has been found in all 28 Member States as well as in Turkey and Norway, and in eight Member States where α-PVP has been found to have recorded a total of 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings. On the basis of the findings of the risk assessment report, the Commission considers that there are grounds for subjecting this substance to control measures across the Union and that the acute toxicity of α-PVP may cause serious harm to people's health.  I am therefore in favour of the α-PVP subjection to control measures and criminal penalties in accordance with their laws.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Given that 16 Member States control alpha-PVP in accordance with their legislation and 5 Member States use other legislative measures to control it, subjecting the substance to EU-wide control measures would prevent barriers to cross-border police and judicial cooperation and protect people from the risks associated with its availability and consumption. So I'm voting for the text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to subject α-PVP to control measures. The UK is not bound by the Decision and has decided to not take part in the adoption of this Decision.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which provides for the alpha PVP to be subject to control measures. This substance is a powerful psychostimulant, of no therapeutic value, and is already controlled in 21 Member States. The report aims to extend control measures to the whole of the European Union.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction produced a report on the new psychoactive substance α-PVP, in which it concluded that α-PVP is a strong psychostimulant. The substance has been detected in the 28 Member States, as well as in Turkey and Norway, and its presence is known primarily in the form of powder and tablets, according to the samples seized and collected. According to the information available, α-PVP comes to the Union from China in several kilogram packs and is then placed on the market within the Union. If α-PVP becomes more widely available and consumed, this can have a significant impact on individual health and public health. I therefore support the report that the new psychoactive substance should be subject to control measures in the European Union.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will subject the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidin-1-yl) pentan-1-one (α-pyrrolidinovalerophenone, α-PVP) to control measures.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I shadowed this report and I was pleased with the direction of the report. The report was concerned with subjecting a new psychoactive substance to control measures. The report further invited Member States to subject the substance in question to control measures provided by their own legislation by virtue of their obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. Most Member States have already done so. As a member of the Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs Committee, I have followed legislation on these substances very carefully. Their availability is a cause of great concern and the effect some of these substances have on users is horrific. In relation to this particular substance, more than a 130 deaths have been associated with A-PVP and non-lethal side effects include cardiotoxicity, violent behaviour and displays of psychotic behaviour. Sinn Féin have been at the forefront of calling on Member States to legislate as efficiently as possible to prevent these substances from gaining a foothold in the illicit market.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I am clearly in favour of this report, as α-PVP is an effective psychostimulant that is increasingly becoming a problem for our society. It is therefore inevitable that greater monitoring of this substance, its use and its introduction must also take place.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The psychoactive α-PVP may have a toxic effect on human health and therefore a control measure must be established to ensure its safe use.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the draft Council decision subjecting the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidinil)-1-pentanone to control measures, I believe I support the draft resolution. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ α -PVP is a new psychoactive substance that poses a major danger to human health and I unreservedly supported this report on the subjecting of the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(pyrolidine-1-il) pentan-1-on (α-pyrolidinelorophenone, α-PVP) by appropriate control measures.  The fact is that under the influence of globalization, new drug markets are opening up, and that puts us all in front of a big challenge. It is our duty to use all available tools to fight for people's lives. As stated in the explanatory statement of the Council decision, a total of 115 deaths and 191 cases of acute poisoning were recorded in eight Member States where the presence of α-PVP was detected. It is necessary to adopt and enforce the law that will bring this psychoactive substance under control. We must be aware of the fact that in 2012 alone 212 psychoactive substances were discovered in Europe and we are witnessing that this trend does not stop growing.  We must not only stop to enforce the law, but we must also help public health, design and support national anti-drug action plans and provide financial assistance to European funds to institutions that care for the treatment of addicts. We need to be aware of the damage that new psychoactive substances have already done and come up with programmes to reduce this harm.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Given that sixteen Member States control alpha-PVP in accordance with their legislation and five Member States use other legislative measures to control it, subjecting the substance to EU-wide control measures would prevent barriers to cross-border police and judicial cooperation and protect people from the risks associated with its availability and consumption. So I'm voting for the text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal to subject α-PVP to control measures and criminal justice sanctions under the United Nations Convention on Psychoactive Drugs, 1971. Given that not all Member States have implemented provisions of the United Nations Convention on Psychoactive Drugs in their legislation, control measures should be provided across the European Union in order to facilitate judicial cooperation and the application of law.  Furthermore, subjecting α-PVP to control measures will reduce the risk of the presence and use of α-PVP. I support all reasonable measures aimed at reducing the availability of psychoactive drugs in the European Union.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report proposes the approval to subject substances to control measures provided for by legislation under their obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. Psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidin-1-il)-pentan-1-one (α-pyrrolidinovalerofenone, α-PVP) is a psychomotor stimulant first recorded in the EU in 2011. It is a derivative of synthetic cathinone commonly referred to as a new psychoactive substance. α-PVP is a potent blocker in the transporter of norepinephrine and dopamine and clinical research suggests that the effects of α-PVP will be similar to those of MDPV, methamphetamine and cocaine. Once the submission to EU control measures has been adopted in accordance with Decision 2005/387 /JAI (on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances) of 10 May 2005, Member States will have to legislate on the issue within 12 months of the decision. This implementing decision allows the authorities of the Member States to take the measures they deem necessary to prevent the sale of such substances. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. A total of 115 deaths and 191 acute intoxications were recorded in eight Member States where this psychoactive substance α-PVP was detected. The European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction defines this psychoactive substance as a new psychotropic drug not controlled by united nations convention drugs, which may pose a public health threat. I supported Representative Boni's report to subject the new psychoactive substance to control measures in all Member States. If the α-PVP becomes widely available and enters use, the consequences for human health and public health could be great.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Until now, the decision adopted by the Council on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new drugs and synthetic drugs has proved to be a useful tool for Member States. During the debate in the LIBE Committee, the European Commission and the Council stressed that the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2- (1-pyrrolidinil) -1-pentanone (alpha-pyrrolidinovalerophenone α-PVP) has already caused a large number of deaths and intoxications. The report supports the position of the two institutions, agreeing on the danger of this new substance and the need for more controls. I am therefore in favour of its approval by Parliament and I reiterate my absolute opposition to all forms of drugs, without distinction between so-called 'light' and so-called 'heavy'.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The alpha-PVP substance is a strong psychostimulant and today has no established or recognized therapeutic value. Since it is controlled in 21 Member States of the European Union, I voted in favour of extending the control of this substance to all the Member States of the Union.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The above decision concerns the continued application of control measures on the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidin-1-il)-pentan-1-one.  In this respect, the European Commission and the European Council have found, in discussion, that the administration of drugs with that substance is the cause of a high number of deaths and poisonings. It is therefore essential to strengthen control of the entry into circulation of new chemicals.  In line with the position of the Commission and the Council and in line with the position of the rapporteur-designate, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the Council proposal to subject the new psychoactive substance a-PVP to control measures, taking into account Council Decision 2005/387/JAI of 10 May 2005 on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, in particular Article 8(3).

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I approve the Council's decision to subject this new psychoactive substance to strict control measures.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, by which Parliament approves the proposal for a Council decision to subject α-pyrrolidinovalerophenone (α-PVP) to control measures and criminal sanctions in the Member States, pursuant to its obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. Currently, sixteen Member States control the α-PVP under their national legislation, in compliance with the obligations imposed by the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances, and five Member States implement other legislative measures to control it. Subjecting this substance to control measures throughout the Union will help to avoid obstacles to cross-border judicial and police cooperation, and help protect society from the risks posed by the availability and consumption of this substance, not in vain in the eight Member States where α-PVP was detected, 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings were recorded.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Alpha-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant. The substance has been detected in all 28 Member States as well as in Turkey and Norway, and is mainly imported into the European drug market from China before being distributed throughout Europe. A total of 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings were recorded in eight Member States where alpha-PVP was reported. According to the risk assessment report, the acute toxicity of alpha-PVP is such that its consumption can seriously harm people's health. In view of these elements, I have decided to approve the Council's draft which envisages subjecting the new psychoactive substance alpha-PVP to control measures throughout the Union.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Control of new chemicals, in particular those that may have an impact on human health, is an important task for the EU. The centralisation of such decisions shall facilitate the work of the relevant authorities of the Member States. I fully support the draft Council decision on the application of control measures to the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrolidine-1-yl) pentane-1-one (α-pyrolidinevalerofenone, α-PVP).

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal for a Council Decision is to call on Member States to subject the psychoactive substance α-PVP to control measures and criminal sanctions as a result of the obligations resulting from the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. The psychoactive substance α-PVP is an extremely potent psychostimulant and has been verified to be used in all 28 Member States, as well as in Turkey and Norway. The sad and alarming figures of 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings recorded in eight Member States and linked to the use of this psychoactive substance require immediate, firm and concerted action by the European Union. For this reason, it is essential to create a uniform framework for the control of this substance in order to avoid the emergence of barriers to the application of the Law in cross-border terms and with regard to judicial cooperation, while also protecting against the risks that the use and availability of this substance may entail. For the reasons set out above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes to subject the new psychoactive substance alpha-PVP to control measures throughout the Union. Alpha-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant structurally related to substances that are controlled under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. This product has proven to be dangerous to health on many occasions.  Despite the limited scientific evidence, evidence and information on the health risks of the substance are sufficient grounds for subjecting alpha-PVP to EU-pending control measures. Protecting the health of EU citizens is paramount. Finally, with 21 Member States having already adopted legislation on alpha-PVP, legal harmonisation is urgent and necessary.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats and the parliamentary majority, I voted in favour of Mrs Boni's report on measures to be taken on a new psychoactive substance (α-PVP). The substance α-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant imported into the EU drug market mainly from China. In eight Member States reporting the presence of α-PVP, 115 deaths and 191 cases of acute intoxication were recorded. No information is available and no studies have been published that fully assess the health risks associated with the substance α-PVP, but observations in animals suggest that the substance would have similar effects to those of other stimulants. Both the Commission and the Council have taken a strong position on this matter, in fact, on the basis of the results of the partial risk assessment report, they consider that there are reasons for subjecting the substance to control measures throughout the Union. According to the risk assessment report, the acute toxicity of the substance α-PVP is such that its consumption can seriously harm people's health. In-depth studies of this substance must therefore be carried out as soon as possible in order to safeguard the health of citizens.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 α-PVP is a psychomotor stimulant first recorded in the EU in 2011. It is a derivative of synthetic cathinine and is commonly referred to as a new psychotropic substance that has, among others, effects similar to methamphetamine and cocaine. WHO research suggests that α-PVP is readily available on the internet and in some retail vendors; it has also been discovered on the illegal market in the form of ecstasy pills. More than 130 deaths have been associated with α-PVP, as well as non-lethal side effects such as cardiovascular toxicity, violent behavior and psychotic behavior samples. The Boni report proposes that this substance be subject to EU control measures, in accordance with Decision 2005/387/JHA (for the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances) of 10 May 2005. If approved, Member States will have to legislate within 12 months. Its application would allow the authorities of the Member States to take such measures as they deem necessary to prevent the sale of such substances (including the internet). I voted for it.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'draft Council decision on control measures for the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidine-1-yl)pentan-1-on (α-pyrrolidinovalerophenone, α-PVP)', as it is right and important to protect our citizens from such proven dangerous substances. Research shows that this substance can not only be toxic, but has also led to deaths. That is why we are now introducing stricter control measures in all Member States to prevent further incidents of this kind.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. New psychoactive substances have been found to be available without medical or veterinary benefits and, according to WHO, produce violent behavior, psychotic behaviour and cardiological toxicity. I voted in favour of the implementation of the measures contained in the 1971 UN Convention on Psychotropic Substances, which require these substances to be subjected to a number of checks and, if considered dangerous or addictive, States regulate their use within a period of time not more than twelve months.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament today approved the proposal calling on Member States to subject the substance α-PVP to control measures and criminal sanctions under their legislation. It was necessary to assess the risks caused by the consumption, manufacture and marketing of this new psychoactive substance, the use of which resulted in a total of 115 deaths and 191 cases of acute intoxication in eight Member States. In view, therefore, of the possible repercussions for the health of citizens, I have spoken out in favour of accurate control measures for the substance α-PVP throughout the European Union.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Socialist MEPs in the LIBE committee have done excellent work on this file, achieving our overarching objective of reducing the use of these kinds of substances.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ New drugs are a blight on our European society, as citizens seek kicks that are more and more dangerous. We have a responsibility to protect against the evils of these drugs, and I give my full support to adding this to illegal dangerous classified drugs in our Member States.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We need to respond flexibly and in a timely manner to the discovery of new, potentially hazardous substances and subject their production, storage and distribution to a thorough inspection.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the Council's proposal for a decision to subject the new psychoactive substance α-PVP to control measures, as I believe there is a high risk of new substances and there is a need for control. By deciding to subject the new psychoactive substance α-PVP to control measures, the European Parliament aims to ensure the continuity of control measures over new substances in all Member States. Discussions at the European Commission and the European Council highlighted that the new substances have caused a high number of deaths.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. Α-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant, mainly from China and has already been discovered in all 28 Member States, Turkey and Norway. The EU Commission believes that there are legitimate reasons for the introduction of Union-wide control measures for this substance. Therefore, all Member States should now be obliged to subject the illegal drug to national control measures and criminal sanctions. Each Member State must consistently combat the trade in illegal drugs. That is the national task. Why do we need a Brussels target? That is why I am abstaining from this vote.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The European Parliament wishes to ensure the continuity of control measures over new substances in all Member States through a decision on subjecting the new psychoactive substance α-PVP through control measures. During the debates in the European Commission and the European Council, it was pointed out that the new substances caused a large number of deaths. I support the council's proposal to subject the new psychoactive substance α-PVP to control measures, as I believe there is a high risk of new substances and there is a need for control.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Each new psychoactive substance should be subject to control, risk assessment and the results of controls disseminated as information between Member States.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which approves the Council's draft decision on the subject of new psychoactive substances to control measures at pentan-1 (α-pyrolidine-valerofenon, α-PVP). A new psychoactive substance is called new drugs in pure form or in a preparation, or new psychotropic drugs, which can be harmful to health. I consider it important to take a Council decision on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control on new psychoactive substances, as I believe that, given the particular dangers inherent in the development of psychoactive substances, member states need to act swiftly. This is also important, referring to the Council Regulation, since new psychoactive substances are not regulated by criminal law in all Member States, and problems may arise in cooperation between the judicial authorities of the Member States and law enforcement services, since the offences or offences in question are not equally punishable under the legislation of the requesting and requested States.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in the Council's proposed decision subjecting the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidin-1-yl) pentan-1-one (alpha-pyrrolidinovalerophenone, alpha-PVP) to control measures and followed our specialist LIBE.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of subjecting the new psychoactive substance, α-PVP, a potent psychostimulant, to control measures across the Union, as there have been 115 deaths and 191 acute intoxications registered in eight Member States reported where α-PVP was detected. Despite the limited scientific evidence available on α-PVP, the acute toxicity of α-PVP is such that it can cause severe harms to the health of individual. In addition, observations in animals suggest similar effects with those observed with other stimulants. I therefore strongly agree that α-PVP should be subject to control measures across the Union.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the subjecting of the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(pyrolidine-1-il) pentan-1-on (α-pyrolidinovalorophene, α-PVP) by control measures.  Despite the limited scientific evidence available on α-PVP, the evidence and information on the health risks posed by that substance, as documented by its detection in deaths and cases of acute poisoning, provides sufficient basis for the subjecting of α-PVP substances through control measures across the Union. The available data suggest that quantities of several kilograms of α-PVP from China are imported into the Union drug market and then distributed throughout the Union. The capacity to produce α-PVP also exists within the Union, as the substance has been confiscated at two sites of illegal production within one Member State.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 Draft Council Decision establishing control measures for the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidine-1-yl)pentan-1-one (α-pyrrolidineovalerofenone, α-PVP) was supported. α-PVP is a potent psychostimulant and there are 115 known deaths and 191 acute poisonings in the eight Member States where α-PVP was detected. No information or published studies are available to assess in a comprehensive manner the health risks associated with α-PVP, namely chronic and acute toxicity, but similar effects have been observed in animals to other stimulants. For this reason, it is necessary to introduce control measures and criminal sanctions in the Member States for the α-PVP, as provided for by their legislation in accordance with their obligations under the United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 α-PVP is a psychomotor stimulant first recorded in the EU in 2011. It is a derivative of synthetic cathinine and is commonly referred to as a new psychotropic substance that has, among others, effects similar to methamphetamine and cocaine. WHO research suggests that α-PVP is readily available on the internet and in some retail vendors; it has also been discovered on the illegal market in the form of ecstasy pills. More than 130 deaths have been associated with α-PVP, as well as non-lethal side effects such as cardiovascular toxicity, violent behavior and psychotic behavior samples. The Boni report proposes that this substance be subject to EU control measures, in accordance with Decision 2005/387/JHA (for the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances) of 10 May 2005. If approved, Member States will have to legislate within 12 months. Its application would allow the authorities of the Member States to take such measures as they deem necessary to prevent the sale of such substances (including the internet). I voted for it.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Alpha-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant structurally related to cathinone, pyrovalerone and methylenedioxypyrovalérone (MDPV), which are controlled under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. A total of 115 deaths and 191 acute poisonings were recorded in eight Member States where alpha-PVP was reported. Alpha-PVP has no established or recognized therapeutic value (whether in human or veterinary medicine). Despite the limited scientific data on alpha-PVP, evidence and information on the health risks of the substance are sufficient grounds to subject alpha-PVP to EU-pending control measures. Given that 16 Member States control alpha-PVP in accordance with their legislation and that 5 Member States use other legislative measures to control it, subjecting the substance to EU-wide control measures would prevent barriers to cross-border police and judicial cooperation and protect people from the risks associated with its availability and consumption. So I'm voting FOR.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The new psychoactive substance α-PVP is a powerful substance with psychostimulating properties. Despite very few information and studies carried out, it can be concluded that this substance is a great threat to human health and life. A total of 115 deaths and 191 cases of acute intoxication were reported in eight Member States where α-PVP was detected. Cooperation between the Countries of the European Union can help fight the new drug and facilitate judicial cooperation. The essential objective is to protect against the risks that may arise as a result of the availability and use of this substance, which is why I voted in favour of subjecting α-PVP to control measures.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the document in connection with the draft Council Decision on the subject of a new psychoactive substance control measures at pentan-1 (α-pyrrolidine-valerofenon, α-PVP) on 1-phenyl-2-(pyrolidine-1-il)pentan-1(α-PVP).

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 α-PVP is a psychomotor stimulant first recorded in the EU in 2011. It is a derivative of synthetic cathinine and is commonly referred to as a new psychotropic substance that has, among others, effects similar to methamphetamine and cocaine. WHO research suggests that α-PVP is readily available on the internet and in some retail vendors; it has also been discovered on the illegal market in the form of ecstasy pills. More than 130 deaths have been associated with α-PVP, as well as non-lethal side effects such as cardiovascular toxicity, violent behavior and psychotic behavior samples. The Boni report proposes that this substance be subject to EU control measures, in accordance with Decision 2005/387/JHA (for the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances) of 10 May 2005. If approved, Member States will have to legislate within 12 months. Its application would allow the authorities of the Member States to take such measures as they deem necessary to prevent the sale of such substances (including the internet). I voted for it.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the draft Council decision on subjecting the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidin-1-yl) pentan-1-one (α-pyrrolidinovalerophenone, α-PVP) to control measures. Council Decision 2005/387/JHA on the information exchange, risk-assessment and control of new psychoactive substances provides for a three-step procedure that may lead to the submission of a new psychoactive substance to control measures across the Union. Based on the findings of the risk assessment report the Commission, I believe that there are grounds for subjecting this substance to control measures across the Union.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of this decision, as both the Commission and the Council have expressed the dangers of these substances and the need to control them.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. α-PVP is a potent blocker in the transporter of norepinephrine and dopamine and clinical research suggests that the effects of α-PVP will be similar to that of MDPV, methamphetamine and cocaine. The report proposes the adoption to subject substances to control measures provided for by legislation under their obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. Once the submission to EU control measures has been adopted in accordance with Decision 2005/387/JAI (in the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances) of 10 May 2005, Member States will have to legislate on the issue within 12 months of the decision. This implementing decision allows the authorities of the Member States to take the measures deemed necessary to prevent the sale of such substances. Supported.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Α-PVP is a powerful psychostimulant that has already been discovered in some Member States. It is mainly imported from China into the EU drug market and then spread throughout Europe. The draft calls on the Council to inform and consult Parliament if it deviates from the text approved by Parliament on the Council decision on control measures for the new psychoactive substance α-PVP. There is a clear agreement to this.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. - Draft Council Decision establishing control measures for the new psychoactive substance 1-phenyl-2-(1-pyrrolidine-1-yl)pentan-1-one (α-pyrrolidineovalerofenone, α-PVP) was supported. Close monitoring is necessary as the α-PVP is a new powerful psychostimulant that poses a higher health risk.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament is called upon to approve the accession by Member States to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage caused by the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Substances (HNS) by sea with regard to aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. Accession to the Convention is desirable because it offers more specific rules and much more specialised and effective legal instruments. I have therefore voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to give Parliament's consent to the Council for its adoption of the 2010 Protocol on harmful and dangerous substances relating to the maritime transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances, with the exception of aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. Since regional bodies cannot do so, it is up to the Member States to join. I voted in favour of this report, since it proposes to ensure the assumption of responsibilities and the payment of adequate, timely and effective compensation for loss or damage caused to persons, property or the environment as a result of the maritime transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances through the SNP Specialised International Compensation Fund.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the ratification of the 2010 Protocol on the International Convention on Harmful and Potentially Dangerous Substances, with the exception of aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters.  The agreement establishes the responsibility of the owner of the vessel carrying harmful substances in the event of damage resulting from an accident at sea. It provides for limited exceptions to this liability, which is accompanied by the obligation to purchase insurance. Finally, it establishes a specific fund to cover the full extent of the damages and damages suffered by an individual who could not have been fully compensated by the ship owner or his insurer.  I believe that a comprehensive approach is better suited than regional solutions given the global nature of the maritime sector and its cross-border implications. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a single vote on an interim report calling for dialogue between this EU institutions to coordinate a compensation scheme for victims of hazardous and noxious substance spilling at sea. It seeks to protect coastal communities and fishing communities beyond the liability limits of the ship owner which is an important development. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to send a strong signal to the Council. We want the protocol to be ratified quickly. However, the Council should reconsider its position in order to avoid creating legal uncertainty within the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the 1996 HNS Convention, established under the aegis of the International Maritime Organization, the 2010 Protocol amending it, and finally the 2010 HNS Convention, which consolidates the two aforementioned texts. The latter establishes objective liability for the owner of a vessel carrying harmful or potentially dangerous substances in the event of damage resulting from an incident at sea during that transport, provides for limited exceptions to that liability, which is accompanied by the obligation to take out insurance or other financial guarantee to cover his liability in the event of damage under the agreement. , establishes a specific compensation fund to compensate anyone who has suffered damages related to the sea transport of harmful substances when the owner of the vessel in question or his insurer does not have to meet the amount of repairs. The report believes that, in order to ensure a uniform application of the rules on liability and repair of such accidents, an international regime is better suited than regional solutions given the global nature of the maritime freight transport activity. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I abstained. The EU does not have the legal power to sign up to this Convention even though it would like to. Instead the EU is forcing Member States to sign up individually. This is another example of the European Union enforcing its will even when it does not have the legal power to do so.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to ensure a uniform application of the rules on liability and reparation in the event of accidents caused by vessels carrying harmful and potentially dangerous substances at sea throughout the Union. It will also ensure the availability of sufficient funds for compensation for victims of such accidents.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this proposal by which the EP made its recommendations for the ratification and accession to the Protocol of 2010 of the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage related to the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by Sea. I support the preliminary report proposed by the EP in order to work with the Council and the Commission to achieve a positive result. It would be inappropriate for the EP to give its assent until uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of Union law and the fundamental principle of conferring EU competences are ensured.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement, which amends the 1996 HNS report, establishes objective liability for the owner of a vessel carrying harmful or potentially dangerous substances in the event of damage resulting from an incident at sea during such transport. It matches this responsibility with the obligation to take out insurance or other security in the event of a disaster, and establishes a specific compensation fund for damages related to the transport of harmful substances by sea.  The report believes that, in order to ensure uniform enforcement of the rules on liability for such accidents, an international regime is best suited given the global nature of the maritime sector and its cross-border implications. In fact, given the global nature of the maritime freight business, a comprehensive approach is preferable. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The 1996 International Convention on Responsibility and Compensation for Damages Related to the Sea Transport of Harmful or Potentially Dangerous Substances aims to ensure adequate, prompt and effective compensation for those who are victims of damage caused by spills of harmful and potentially dangerous substances while transporting them by sea. This Convention was amended by a 2010 protocol, which incorporates protection against environmental damage. In order to become contracting parties to the protocol, Member States must ratify it. This report, which I have approved, allows them to do so.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2010 HNS Convention aims to ensure the accountability and payment of adequate, rapid and effective compensation for losses or damage to persons, goods and the environment resulting from the transport by sea of dangerous and harmful substances through a specialised International HNS Compensation Fund. It is, of course, an important legal instrument whose ratification is, however, only permitted by the Member States. I voted in favour of the Svoboda report because I agree with the need to ensure certainty in the application of legislation which, with the Council's decision, could be compromised. The purpose of the interim report adopted is therefore to put pressure on the Council to approve the proposal put forward to call for uniform ratification of the HNS Convention, without leaving the vagueness of the timing of the first wording.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this text on the urgent consideration of the urgent ratification of a protocol whose effective implementation by The Member States will entail greater certainty against the human and environmental risks caused by such substances.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. The European Union is pending ratification of the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages in connection with the maritime transport of harmful and potentially hazardous substances of 1996, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG). In full accordance with the European approach to the problem and the recommendations that Parliament makes through this report to the Council to ensure economic sufficiency to compensate victims of disasters caused by ship accidents carrying this type of substance and its homogeneous application at international level.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Under the aegis of the International Maritime Organization (IMO), the 1996 HNS Convention was amended by the 2010 Protocol (the "Protocol"), which were consolidated by a new text, the 2010 HNS Convention (the "Convention"), which is not open to signature or ratification. The convention will take effect when the protocol enters into force in the Member States.  The agreement establishes, for example, the objective liability of the owner of a vessel carrying harmful or potentially dangerous substances in the event of damage resulting from an incident at sea during that transport, provides for limited exceptions and establishes a specific compensation fund.  Given the global nature and peculiarities of maritime areas, an international regime is better suited than regional solutions. So I voted for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Svoboda report appears to be well structured, coherent and without any critical issues, and I therefore intended to vote in favour of it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages in Connection with the Maritime Transport of Harmful and Potentially Hazardous Substances is a key legal instrument in terms of transport and the environment. The ratification of the 2010 Protocol, which represents practically the ratification of the above-2010 Convention, is relevant to the EU because it provides enhanced protection for those affected by maritime transport of dangerous substances.  In its December 2015 decision, the Council releases Member States to decide when each will carry out ratification. This possibility could lead to legal uncertainty because of differences in the applicable rule. In addition, some of the provisions overlap with the Environmental Liability Directive 2004/35/EC, which could lead to confusion as to the legal basis for complaints.  With this interim report, which I voted in favour of, Parliament intends to pressure the Council to correct its decision by calling for a uniform ratification of the Convention and thus clarifying its implementation.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it made parliament's recommendations for a Council decision on the ratification and accession to the Protocol of 2010 of the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage to the Sea by the Member States in the interest of the European Union. This time, Parliament decided, instead of accepting the Council's decision, to draw up a preliminary report so that the Council and the Commission could finally achieve a positive result. In Parliament's view, it would be inappropriate to give its assent to this agreement until uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of Union law and the fundamental principle of conferring EU competences are ensured.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea (IMO) is the last of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) Conventions on liability and compensation for the transport of hazardous and harmful substances, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied natural gas (LPG), which has not yet been ratified. On the basis of experience gained in relation to similar international systems governing liability for other maritime transport activities, the IMO adopted this international agreement, amended by the HNS Protocol of 2010, to complement the system of conventions on maritime liability with a specific agreement. Neither the HNS Convention of 1996 nor the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention entered into force. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention will ensure uniform application across the EU of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and noxious substances by sea. It will also ensure that sufficient resources are available to compensate victims of such accidents. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the current fragmented system with regulation at international level.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this Ratification Report, which lets you know that the protocol is to be ratified as soon as possible, but also calls on the Council to reconsider its position. In this way, a certain division is created between Member States that are ready to ratify the protocol immediately and those Member States that are not. The Council should adopt a single decision for all Member States, as this creates some legal uncertainty, preventing the protocol from being ratified swiftly and effectively.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The report believes that, in order to ensure consistent enforcement of the rules on liability and repair of such accidents, an international regime is better suited than regional solutions given the global nature of the maritime sector and its cross-border implications. Given the global nature of the maritime freight transport activity, the peculiarity of maritime areas, a comprehensive approach is preferable. Moreover, it has the merit of taking this issue away from the Union's legislative arsenal. So I voted for it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This was a single vote on an interim report calling for dialogue between this EU institutions to coordinate a compensation scheme for victims of hazardous and noxious substance spilling at sea. It seeks to protect coastal communities and fishing communities beyond the liability limits of the ship owner which is an important development. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2010 HNS Convention establishes the objective liability of the owner of the ship carrying dangerous and harmful substances for damage resulting from an event related to the carriage of such substances on board by sea. There are limited exceptions to the objective liability of the owner, which is linked to the owner's obligation to take out insurance or other financial guarantee in order to cover his liability for damages in accordance with the provisions of the Convention. The establishment of a special compensation fund to compensate anyone who has suffered damage resulting from the transport by sea of dangerous and harmful substances is also positive, inso far as that person has not been able to obtain full and adequate compensation for damages from the owner of the ship and its insurer, up to a maximum of 250 million units of account (about 310 million euros) , on the basis of a system of contributions paid to the HNS Fund by recipients of dangerous and harmful substances in each Contracting State. It should be noted, however, that it is in the interests of the Union as a whole to have a uniform system of liability applicable to environmental damage, which is why the Council and the Commission must comply with the european Parliament's recommendations.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report supports the ratification of the 2010 Protocol on the International Convention on Harmful and Potentially Dangerous Substances, with the exception of aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. The agreement establishes the responsibility of the owner of the vessel carrying harmful substances in the event of damage resulting from an accident at sea. It provides for limited exceptions to this liability, which is accompanied by the obligation to purchase insurance. Finally, it establishes a specific fund to cover the full extent of the damages and damages suffered by an individual who could not have been fully compensated by the ship owner or his insurer. I believe that a comprehensive approach is better suited than regional solutions given the global nature of the maritime sector and its cross-border implications. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because, first of all, it is necessary to protect the environment, but at the same time we must come to the aid of victims who suffer such a maritime accident, this being achieved only through a coherent policy framework in the area of liability and compensation for environmental damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances at sea. In accordance with the 1996 Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage in connection with the Carriage of Dangerous and Noxious Substances by Sea, it is the latest of the International Maritime Organisation conventions dealing with compensation and liability for damage caused by the transport by sea of dangerous and harmful substances. As regards the 2010 Convention, it establishes the strict liability of the owner of the ship carrying dangerous or harmful substances for any damage arising from an incident related to the transport of substances at sea and on board that vessel. Both conventions overlap with the scope of Directive 2004/35/EC on environmental liability of operators engaged in professional activities, including maritime transport.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which focuses on the aspects of judicial cooperation in civil matters of the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances by sea. The report highlights, in particular, the clear overlap of the Convention with Directive 2004/35/EC on the liability of professional operators. The application of European legislation to the accidents covered by the Convention would in fact amount to the EU repudiation of the International Maritime Organisation's approach, which could have considerable negative repercussions. Since, by its very nature, maritime transport is a global activity with a cross-border impact, the report calls for the elimination of existing contradictions, favouring an international regime, rather than regional solutions, which is more appropriate for ensuring uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation in relation to accidents caused by ships transporting dangerous and harmful substances by sea throughout the EU.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a single vote on an interim report calling for dialogue between this EU institutions to coordinate a compensation scheme for victims of hazardous and noxious substance spilling at sea. It seeks to protect coastal communities and fishing communities beyond the liability limits of the ship owner which is an important development. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this first position on the ratification by Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of the 2010 Protocol on the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages Related to the Sea Transport of Harmful and Potentially Dangerous Substances, as well as the accession of Member States audit protocol, with the exception of aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. We will continue to insist that an international regime is better suited than regional solutions because of the global nature of the maritime sector.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report and I give my consent to the ratification of the Protocol of 2010 to the International convention on liability and compensation for damage in connection with the carriage of hazardous and noxious substances by sea. I welcome the fact that it states clearly who is to be responsible for any damage done to the environment while the hazardous and noxious substances (NHS) are being transported. I believe that the Convention helps ensure the security of the sea and it provides better protection for any victims of such accidents. I am particularly satisfied with the proposal of consistent application of the rules across the EU considering the global scale of the issue at stake.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Svoboda's report concerns a Council decision on the ratification and accession by Member States to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage caused by the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Substances (HNS) by sea. In the absence of a REIO (Regional Economic Integration Organisation) clause in the text of the Convention or in the Protocol, Member States should conclude such an international agreement on behalf of the Union, subject to authorisation by the Council and approval by the European Parliament on a proposal from the Commission. The rapporteur considers that it is not appropriate for Parliament to give its approval before seeing the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of EU law guaranteed, as well as the fundamental principle of the allocation of EU competences. Accession to the International Convention on Harmful Substances is desirable because it offers more specific rules and legal instruments that are much more specialised and effective than those offered by the Community regulatory framework, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as we believe that the conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the RNS Convention will ensure uniform application of the provisions on liability and compensation in relation to accidents caused by the sea transport of ESOs to the EU. Adequate funds are also ensured to compensate victims of these accidents.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The interim report on the draft Council Decision on the ratification and accession of Member States, in the interests of the European Union, to the 2010 Protocol to the 1996 International Convention on Civil Liability and Compensation for Damage in relation to the Carriage of Dangerous and Harmful Substances by Sea, focuses on a complex but important issue. The effort to improve judicial mechanisms with a view to faster and more correct administration of justice can only be aimed at better protecting European citizens. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The release of toxic substances into the sea can cause both harm to people's health and significant economic losses to those working in fisheries and maritime tourism. I therefore believe that public institutions must commit themselves to limiting these phenomena, to punishing them, and to ensure that those who are harmed receive the right compensation. I voted in favour of this proposal because I agree with the aim of creating a fund that guarantees the injured citizen fair compensation also for damage that exceeds the limits of liability of the owner of the ship or his insurance.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In view of the significant share HNS cargo represents in maritime freight transport, the global nature of the shipping business, as well as the cross-boundary impact accidents involving HNS cargo are likely to have, I believe it is in the interest of the Union as a whole to have a homogenous liability regime applicable to environmental damage arising from the carriage of HNS at sea , which can only be achieved if Parliament’s recommendations are duly considered by the Council and the Commission.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2010 HNS Convention establishes the objective responsibility of the ship owner in the case of the transport of hydrocarbons and hazardous and harmful substances (HNS) for damage arising from incidents related to the carriage of those substances on board the ship. It is envisaged that the owner will take out insurance to cover his liability for damage caused under the Convention and a specific compensation fund to compensate all persons who are victims of damage resulting from the carriage of the NHS, if those persons have not been fully and adequately compensated by the owner of the ship or the insurer. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the NHS Convention will ensure uniform application of liability and compensation rules in the event of accidents caused by ships carrying NHS on EU territory. An international scheme is more appropriate than regional solutions to ensure uniform application of liability and compensation rules in the event of an accident. It is therefore in the Union's interest to have a homogeneous liability regime applicable to environmental damage caused by the transport of HNS by sea.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage caused by the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Substances by Sea should be ratified, as the risks of maritime transport have a major cross-border impact. In the current Community legal framework, there is a lack of uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation in relation to accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and harmful substances throughout Europe. I voted in favour of this report for ratification and accession to this Convention, in view of the international maritime transport regime, which needs harmonisation so that we can ensure uniform and effective measures to attest liability and to provide for possible compensation for damage to the victims of accidents.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with putting strict liability of the ship-owner to be in possession of mandatory insurance to cover damages to third parties. This puts in place a right of direct recourse of persons suffering damages against the insurer, limitation of liability and, in the case of oil and hazardous and noxious substances, a special compensation fund that pays for damages when these exceed the liability limits of the ship-owner. The ‘polluter pays’ principle and the principles of prevention and precaution to the effect that preventive action should be taken in case of possible environmental damage needs to be taken into account and falls squarely within the Union policy and general principles regarding the environment. I agree with the removal of the permanent co-existence of two maritime liability regimes – a Union-based one and an international one – which would result in the fragmentation of Union legislation. The clear channelling of liability could save on lengthy and costly legal proceedings to the detriment of victims and the shipping industry.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to give Parliament's consent to the Council for its adoption of the 2010 Protocol on harmful and dangerous substances relating to the maritime transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances, with the exception of aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. Since regional bodies cannot do so, it is up to the Member States to join. I voted in favour of this report, since it proposes to ensure the assumption of responsibilities and the payment of adequate, timely and effective compensation for loss or damage caused to persons, property or the environment as a result of the maritime transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances through the SNP Specialised International Compensation Fund.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 the 2010 SNS Convention applies to claims for damage resulting from the carriage of SNS by sea, with the exception of claims under a contract for the carriage of goods or passengers, and establishes the strict liability of the shipowner for any damage caused in connection with the carriage of the ESM.
