The Convention also introduces a new system of liability and compensation, which not only covers damage caused by pollution by ships, but also takes into account the risk of fire and explosion, including loss of life or personal injury and loss or damage to property. Importantly, the Convention establishes a special compensation fund for the payment of compensation to any person who has suffered damage in connection with the transport of the SNS by sea, provided that such person could not receive full and sufficient compensation for the damage from the shipowner and his insurer. The Convention also contains provisions on the jurisdiction of the courts of the States Parties with regard to claims by persons who have suffered damage (as indicated in the Convention) against the owner or his insurer or against the SNS fund. Unfortunately, there were issues in the document that raised my doubts, which is why I abstained.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In line with the rest of my Group I am in favour of adopting measures for victims of damage in connection with the carriage of hazardous substances more swiftly but I also agree that the Council should make sure that it is not creating legal uncertainty and divisions between legal regimes in Member States. The ratification of the 2010 Protocol provides for improved protection of the victims of damage in connection with the carriage of hazardous and noxious substances (HNS) by sea, but there are divisions in terms of the period in which that should be done. In order to put pressure on the Council to amend its decision in a way that would ask for the uniform ratification of this Convention and bring clarity as regards its applicability, Parliament drafted this Interim Report.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea (IMO) is the last of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) Conventions on liability and compensation for the transport of hazardous and harmful substances, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied natural gas (LPG), which has not yet been ratified. On the basis of experience gained in relation to similar international systems governing liability for other maritime transport activities, the IMO adopted this international agreement, amended by the HNS Protocol of 2010, to complement the system of conventions on maritime liability with a specific agreement. Neither the HNS Convention of 1996 nor the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention entered into force. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention will ensure uniform application across the EU of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and noxious substances by sea. It will also ensure that sufficient resources are available to compensate victims of such accidents. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the currently fragmented system with legislation at international level.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea (IMO) is the last of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) Conventions on Liability and Compensation for The Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances, including Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) and Liquefied Propane Butane Gas (LPG), which has not yet been ratified. On the basis of experience gained in relation to similar international systems governing liability for other maritime transport activities, the IMO adopted this international agreement, amended by the HNS Protocol of 2010, to complement the system of conventions on maritime liability with a specific agreement. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Under the aegis of the International Maritime Organization (IMO), the 1996 HNS (Hazardous and Noxious Substances) Convention was amended by the 2010 Protocol. In the event of damage resulting from an incident in the transport of harmful or potentially dangerous substances, the agreement establishes the objective liability of the ship's owner, with limited exceptions with the obligation to purchase insurance. The agreement also establishes a compensation fund for those who have not been able to obtain a satisfactory remedy for the damage. I supported this text that the uniform application of international rules on the liability and repair of such accidents is better suited than regional solutions.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this dossier. It rightly addresses some major problems when it comes to spills of dangerous and harmful substances carried by sea. I believe there is still a lot of work to be done, especially when it comes to clarifying the status and opportunities for countries that have significantly fewer resources and therefore more hesitation when it comes to signing and ratifying new agreements and protocols. We must, as a further step, focus on improving assistance to these Member States so that countries can balance standards for security and safety measures without risking sanctions or reregulation. However, I support this report as I believe it is a good initiative. International cooperation is important in this area, as the consequences of such a spill can be very lasting and affect multiple Member States at the same time and as clarity of rules and procedures is needed.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Positive, because first preventive measures should be taken to transport harmful goods to the seas and then there should be severe fines to those responsible for environmental disasters in the event of an accident.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea (IMO) is the last of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) Conventions on liability and compensation for the transport of hazardous and harmful substances, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied natural gas (LPG), which has not yet been ratified. On the basis of experience gained in relation to similar international systems governing liability for other maritime transport activities, the IMO adopted this international agreement, amended by the HNS Protocol of 2010, to complement the system of conventions on maritime liability with a specific agreement. Neither the HNS Convention of 1996 nor the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention entered into force. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention will ensure uniform application across the EU of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and noxious substances by sea. It will also ensure that sufficient resources are available to compensate victims of such accidents. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the currently fragmented system with legislation at international level.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. This report stresses that in order to ensure the uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation in relation to accidents caused by vessels carrying SNP in EU seas, the application of an international convention rather than regional solutions is more appropriate. In this regard, it is in the EU's interest as a whole to have a homogeneous liability regime applicable to environmental damage arising from the transport of SNP at sea, which can only be achieved if Parliament's recommendations are duly considered by the Council and the Commission.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The HNS Convention of 1996 and the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention have not yet entered into force, establishing the latter the objective responsibility of the owner of the ship, in case of transport of HNS, for damages arising from incidents related to this transport. More importantly, it establishes a specific compensation fund to compensate all persons who are victims of damage resulting from the carriage of HNS by sea if those persons have not been fully and adequately compensated by the ship owner and the insurer. The total amount of compensation available amounts to around EUR 310 million.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text. Given the global nature of the maritime freight transport activity, the peculiarity of maritime areas, a comprehensive approach is preferable. Moreover, it has the merit of taking this issue away from the Union's legislative arsenal.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on liability and compensation for damage resulting from the transport of hazardous and harmful substances by sea is the last of the Conventions of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) governing liability and compensation for damage resulting from the transport of these substances, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), which has not yet been ratified. The Convention establishes: - the objective liability of the ship owner for damage arising from incidents; - the obligation of the ship owner to take out insurance or other financial guarantees to cover his liability for damage under the Convention; - the establishment of a specific compensation fund to compensate all persons who are victims of damage resulting from maritime transport if those persons have not been fully and adequately compensated by the shipowner and the insurer. There is some discrepancy between the EU Directive for the same matter and the Convention. It is considered that it is in the EU's interest to have a homogeneous regime of liability for environmental damage caused by the transport of these substances by sea, which can only be achieved if Parliament's recommendations are duly taken into account by the Council and the Commission. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary in the interests of the Union to provide for a uniform system of liability for environmental damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances into the sea.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as it is positive for public health.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention will ensure uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying hazardous and noxious substances at sea across the EU. At the same time, sufficient funds will be available to compensate victims of such accidents. In order to ensure uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying hazardous and noxious substances at sea throughout the EU, given the nature of shipping as a global sector with a cross-border impact, the international regime is preferable to regional solutions. In future, the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission must work together to establish a framework for a coherent EU policy on liability and compensation for environmental damage caused by the transport of hazardous and noxious substances at sea.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour in order to arrive at a more homogeneous solution for a sector with a natural cross-border impact.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The parties to the international convention are States which sign the Protocol in their own name and not on behalf of the Union. It is not for the European Parliament to authorise them to do so, which is why I abstained. My doubts do not concern the risk assessment of the dangerous substances transported, because I have a clear and firm view on this point.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the ratification and accession to the 2010 Protocol to the Convention on Dangerous and Harmful Substances with the exception of aspects of judicial cooperation in civil matters, because first preventive measures should be taken to transport harmful goods into the seas and then there should be severe fines for those responsible for environmental disasters in the event of an accident.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage in connection with the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by Sea - HNS Convention - represents a relevant international legal instrument in terms of transport and environment. The ratification of the 2010 Protocol, which represents practically the ratification of the HNS Convention in its new form of 2010 is considered to be very important for the EU, as it provides for improved protection of the victims of damage in connection with the carriage of HNS by sea, but there are divisions in terms of the period in which that should be done and the terms that the Council established for it. In order for the Convention to enter into force, some Member States would like a swift ratification, while others are not yet ready to ratify. I support a swift ratification of this Protocol, but Council should reconsider its position, and should see that it is not beneficial to create legal uncertainty and divisions between legal regimes in Member States in an issue that has so many cross-border implications.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea (IMO) is the last of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) Conventions on liability and compensation for the transport of hazardous and harmful substances, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied natural gas (LPG), which has not yet been ratified. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this interim report, with the intentionality of Member States joining the 2010 Protocol on the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages in relation to the Maritime Transport of Harmful Substances. To date, the competence to be part of this Protocol or not is State, until the rules are a change, I share with the rapporteur the need to urge States to be part of the 2010 Protocol.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the Council decision on the ratification and accession by Member States, in the interests of the European Union, to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage caused by the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Substances by Sea, with the exception of aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters, because I believe it is important to send a signal to the Council regarding the importance of the timely implementation of the Protocol by all member states. I believe, in fact, that the Council's proposal to give the Member States the freedom to decide when to ratify this Convention goes in the wrong direction, as it risks creating legal disparities and legal uncertainties, differentiating the conditions of operators from those countries that have ratified the Convention from operators subject to European legislation alone. The 2010 Convention, in fact, overlaps with the existing regulations on civil liability for environmental damage, with the aim of strengthening the 'polluter pays' and precautionary and preventive principles and introducing compulsory insurance. It is important for Parliament to put pressure on the Council for simultaneous ratification by all states.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As an MEP from the coastal region of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, I am particularly concerned about the safety and protection of our seas. I therefore voted with conviction in favour of ratifying the 2010 Protocol on the Convention on Harmful and Dangerous Substances and acceding to it, with the exception of aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. It is important that the European Union adopts an international convention on liability and compensation for damage caused by the transport of harmful and dangerous substances by sea by the Member States. Sufficient financial assistance will also be provided to be able to make compensation payments to potential victims.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this text on the urgent consideration of the urgent ratification of a protocol whose effective implementation by The Member States will entail greater certainty against the human and environmental risks caused by such substances.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this file, which sets out some guidance to the Council on its accession to a new Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for damage in connection with the carriage of hazardous and noxious substances by sea.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Parliament has been invited by the Council to approve its draft decision on the ratification and accession of the Member States to the HNS1 Convention. The aforementioned Convention regulates the objective liability of the owner of the vessel carrying dangerous and harmful substances, and also regulates their liability for damage resulting from the incorrect transport on board the same substances. It is also planned to set up a compensation fund for those who have suffered injury. It is considered that the conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention will ensure uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation for damage caused by accidents caused by ships carrying harmful and dangerous substances. In view of the danger that maritime transport can generate by conducting harmful and highly risky substances, I support this proposal.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage in connection with the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by Sea 1996 is the last one of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) Conventions dealing with liability and compensation for damages arising from the carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by sea, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) that has not yet been ratified. The rapporteur stresses that the present interim report should not be seen as an impediment to the establishment of a uniform liability regime, but as an effort to ensure that this is done in the most effective and fair fashion, without impairing the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of common rules of EU law and without creating excessive disparity for the victims of pollution (e.g. coastal communities , fishermen, etc.) and the shipping industry.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea (IMO) is the last of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) Conventions on liability and compensation for the transport of hazardous and harmful substances, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied natural gas (LPG), which has not yet been ratified. On the basis of experience gained on similar international systems governing liability for damages in relation to other maritime transport activities, the IMO has adopted and amended this international agreement by means of the 2010 HNS Protocol to complement the system of maritime liability conventions with a specific agreement. Neither the HNS Convention of 1996 nor the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention entered into force. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention will ensure uniform application across the EU of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and noxious substances by sea. It will also ensure that sufficient resources are available to compensate victims of such accidents. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the currently fragmented system with legislation at international level.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This interim resolution ensures that a clear obligation is imposed on Member States to take all necessary steps to achieve a concrete result, namely to ratify or accede to the 2010 HNS Convention within a reasonable timeframe, which should be no longer than two years. It will also ensure that the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of common Union rules will not be adversely affected by the international commitments undertaken by the ratification of or accession to the 2010 HNS Convention. Further, I also support the provision which advocates the removal of the permanent co-existence of two maritime liability regimes – a Union-based one and an international one in favour of a single coherent regime.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I had no objections to it.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention will ensure uniform application across the EU of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and noxious substances by sea. It will also ensure that sufficient resources are available to compensate victims of such accidents. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the currently fragmented system with legislation at international level.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as it wants to set up a coherent EU policy framework for the uniform application of liability rules and compensation for damage caused by ships carrying dangerous and harmful substances within the EU.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for an interim report on the Council's draft decision on the ratification and accession of the Member States, in the interest of the European Union, the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages relating to the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Goods by Sea, with the exception of aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters, as the Council and the Commission must comply with the principle of granting eu competences under Article 5(1) of the UEU and the court's established case law according to which 'the choice of legal basis for Community measures must be based on objective factors subject to judicial review, which include, in particular, the objective and content of the measure'.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Given the global nature of the maritime freight activity, the uniqueness of maritime areas, a comprehensive approach is preferable. Moreover, it has the merit of taking this issue away from the Union's legislative arsenal. I voted for this text.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of these two interim reports on the ratification and accession of the Union to a protocol on the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for damages related to the sea transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – This report deals with the ratification of the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage in the Carriage of Harmful and Dangerous Substances at Sea (HNS). The rapporteur uses the interim report to draw the attention of the Council and the Commission to the remaining overlaps between the UHRL and the HNS Convention and considers that Parliament should not give its consent until the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of Union law and the fundamental principle of the limited individual authorisation of the EU are guaranteed. For these reasons, I agree with this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal as it sets out some guidance to the Council on its accession to a new Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for damage in connection with the carriage of hazardous and noxious substances by sea.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 When voting on the report on the ratification of the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage related to the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Substances, I voted in favour of the proposal. The aim of the report is to give the Council its consent by the European Parliament for the adoption of the 2010 Protocol to the Convention. The Convention itself aims to ensure immediate and effective compensation for the damage caused by the release of dangerous and harmful substances when transported by sea. The Protocol brings about change, particularly in the area of a stricter pollution liability regime. In the event of ratification of the Convention as amended by the Member States, the resulting legislation may partly overlap with the adaptation provided for in Directive 2004/35/EC aimed at preventing and remedying environmental damage. The report therefore recommends that the Council focus on this issue as part of the admissions process. Furthermore, the report recommends to the Council, among other things, that the integrity and effectiveness of common EU rules should not be adversely affected by international obligations under the Convention, and warns against the possibility of the permanent existence of two regimes, union and international, legal liability for marine pollution. I agree with the draft report in this text.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea (IMO) is the last of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) Conventions on liability and compensation for the transport of hazardous and harmful substances, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied natural gas (LPG), which has not yet been ratified. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the currently fragmented system with legislation at international level.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this international convention because it takes away from the Union any room for manoeuvre in the area of maritime freight transport, which requires a comprehensive approach.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to ratify the 2010 Protocol on the International Convention on Harmful and Potentially Dangerous Substances, and to adhere to the audit protocol. The agreement establishes objective liability for the owner of a vessel carrying harmful or potentially dangerous substances in the event of damage resulting from an incident at sea during that transport. It provides for limited exceptions to this liability, which is accompanied by the obligation to take out insurance or other financial guarantee to cover its liability in the event of injury. It establishes a specific compensation fund to compensate anyone who has suffered damages related to the sea transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances when they have not been able to obtain a full and adequate repair of the damage from the ship owner and his insurer. The report rightly believes that, in order to ensure a uniform application of the rules on liability and reparation for such accidents, an international regime is better suited than regional solutions given the global nature of the maritime sector and its cross-border implications.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This 1996 international convention was established under the aegis of the International Maritime Organization (IMO) and amended in 2010. The aim of this new text is to create an international regime to respond effectively to accidents and determine liability and compensation for the damage caused. For example, it establishes objective liability for the owner of a vessel carrying harmful or dangerous substances, provides for an obligation to take out insurance or financial guarantee to cover liability, and creates a specific compensation fund for victims. I welcome the coherence of this report, which differs from European legislation. An international regime is indeed more coherent and adapted to the overall character of the maritime sector. I voted FOR this text.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to give Parliament's consent to the Council for its adoption of the 2010 Protocol on harmful and dangerous substances relating to the maritime transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances, with the exception of aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. Since regional bodies cannot do so, it is up to the Member States to join. I voted in favour of this report, since it proposes to ensure the assumption of responsibilities and the payment of adequate, timely and effective compensation for loss or damage caused to persons, property or the environment as a result of the maritime transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances through the SNP Specialised International Compensation Fund.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Czech Republic does not have a sea, so the protocol does not apply to it. I agree with the principle that the polluter should repair and compensate for the damage suffered. However, the Treaty will be ratified by individual Member States, not by the Union, which is why I abstained.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This interim report proposes to find a positive solution in cooperation with the Council and the Commission, which is in the Union's interest, as it is important that it has a harmonised liability regime measurable for environmental damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances by sea. The rapporteur considers that it would not be appropriate for Parliament to give its consent before ensuring the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of Union law and the fundamental principle of confering EU competences. This interim report is not an obstacle to establishing a uniform accountability regime, but is an effort to ensure it in the most effective and emanate manner.  Maritime transport is a global sector with cross-border impact, so for the purpose of ensuring uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation of damages caused by ships transporting dangerous and harmful substances by sea across the EU, an international regime is more appropriate than regional solutions. This will ensure that sufficient funds are available to compensate victims of such accidents. Therefore, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The International Convention on Dangerous and Nosalysing Substances was concluded in 1996. The ratification of the 2010 Protocol, which is under way, would allow a full mirroring of the principles of the 1982 UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, which is aimed at realising liability and damages for the release of such substances into world waters. It is rather regrettable that this ratification is only taking place now. It is true that, since the prestige oil tanker accident on the Galicia coast in Europe in 2002, there has not really been such a scale of ecological and economic damage, but, given the importance of the issue in principle, it certainly should have been achieved much earlier. In other words, I voted unequivocally in favour of ratifying the protocol. I very much hope that this protocol will enter into force as soon as possible in the selected four-year period after its ratification at EP level.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Ratification of this Protocol will allow uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying hazardous and noxious substances at sea across the EU. This international regime will help to enforce rights and obligations transparently and more effectively for all actors concerned.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council Decision on the ratification and accession of The Member States, in the interests of the European Union, to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Civil Liability and Compensation for Damage in relation to the Maritime Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Substances, with the exception of aspects of judicial cooperation in civil matters, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text.  The agreement establishes objective liability for the owner of a vessel carrying harmful or potentially dangerous substances in the event of damage resulting from an incident at sea during that transport. It provides for limited exceptions to this liability and establishes a specific compensation fund. Given the international nature of the maritime freight activity and the uniqueness of maritime areas, a comprehensive approach is preferable to ensure consistent enforcement of the rules on liability and repair of such accidents.  The rapporteur wants to start a dialogue with the Council and the Commission with a view to building a coherent European policy in this area.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The interim report on the draft Council decision on the ratification and accession by Member States, in the interests of the European Union, to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for damage caused by the transport by sea of dangerous and harmful substances, with the exception of aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters, is favourable to me. That Convention lays down the objective liability of the owner of the vessel carrying dangerous and harmful substances for damage resulting from an event related to the transport by sea of dangerous and harmful substances on board that vessel. The existence of international standards, rather than regional solutions, on liability for non-contractual damage resulting from the transport by sea of dangerous and harmful substances is of fundamental importance, especially given the high number of dangerous and harmful substances in maritime freight transport worldwide. It is in the Union's interest to have a uniform system of liability for environmental damage resulting from the transport of dangerous and harmful substances into the sea, a regime which is effective and fair and which does not affect the effectiveness and uniformity of the common rules of Union law and which does not create excessive disparities for the victims of pollution.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 17 December 2015, Parliament received a letter seeking its consent to the draft Council Decision on ratification by the Member States and their accession on behalf of the Union to the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention. The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage related to the Transport of Dangerous and Noxious Substances by Sea, 1996, is the last International Maritime Organisation (IMO) Convention dealing with liability and compensation for damage resulting from the transport of hazardous and harmful substances by sea, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), which has not yet been ratified. The IMO has gained experience with similar international regimes governing liability for damage resulting from other maritime transport activities, such as the transport of oil by tankers, and has adopted this International Agreement, as amended by the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention, to complement the system of maritime liability conventions with a specialised instrument. Neither the 1996 HNS Convention nor the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention have yet entered into force. Since I consider the protocol to be significant, I have advocated its ratification.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. My vote in favour of the interim report on the draft Council Decision on the ratification of the 2010 Protocol on The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages in connection with the maritime transport of harmful and potentially hazardous substances and the accession thereof by Member States in the interests of the European Union , with the exception of aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters. It certainly responds to the Union's interest as a whole to have a homogeneous liability regime applicable to environmental damage caused by the transport of SNP by sea, which can only be achieved if the Council and the Commission take adequate account of Parliament's recommendations.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 2010 Protocol on the International Convention on Civil Liability and Compensation in relation to the Carriage of Dangerous and Harmful Substances by Sea requires ratification by Member States separately on behalf of the EU. The original international convention on this subject was signed in 1996 and regulates issues of objective liability and compensation for damage caused by harmful substances such as liquefied natural gas and LPG. This objective responsibility concerns the shipowner carrying the dangerous substance. There is also mention of the establishment of a special compensation fund for payment to any person who has suffered damage from the sea transport of ESOs. Given that shipping is an international business with cross-border implications, an international regime and not only a European one, which is uniformly applicable, should be ensured so that the response to such accidents is more effective but also fairer. I would like to vote in favour of this resolution in order to move in this direction.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This report deals with the ratification of the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention. This concerns liability and compensation for damage caused by the transport of harmful and dangerous substances at sea. The rapporteur makes recommendations on the overlap between the UHRL and the HNS Convention. I can therefore only vote in favour of this report.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the report as it seeks to ensure that there is a strict responsibility for the owner of a ship carrying dangerous and harmful substances for damage caused by an incident involving the carriage of hazardous and noxious substances by sea on that ship.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The purpose of the 1996 International Convention on Harmful and Potentially Dangerous Substances (HNS) is to ensure accountability and compensation for damage caused by sea transport of such substances. Under this agreement, the owner of the vessel carrying the substances is liable. The agreement also creates a compensation fund, comprising approximately 310 million euros. The report proposes to authorize ratification of this convention within two years. It also proposes adherence to its protocol, but makes an exception for aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. The report also calls for preventive measures to be taken to prevent or reduce such damage (prevention measures, primary repair and complementary repair). I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Given the global nature of the maritime freight activity and the uniqueness of maritime areas, a comprehensive approach is preferable. Moreover, it has the merit of taking this issue away from the Union's legislative arsenal. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the progress report on the draft Council decision on the ratification and adoption of the Member States, in the interest of the Union, to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for damage resulting from the carriage of harmful dangerous substances by sea with regard to aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters. As stated by the rapporteur, the aim of the 2010 HNS Convention is to ensure accountability and to provide adequate, rapid and effective compensation for losses or damage caused to persons, property and the environment resulting from the transport of harmful and dangerous substances by sea, ensuring uniform application of liability and compensation rules in the event of accidents within the EU. It will also ensure the availability of sufficient funds to compensate victims of such accidents.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report in order to provide a uniform and comprehensive legislative protocol for compensation to those adversely affected by these substances. This report is essential to ensuring proper responses by those liable for damage done by hazardous and noxious substances while in EU Member States.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Maritime cargoes of goods, because of their intercontinental nature, can result in accidents with a global impact involving harmful and potentially dangerous substances. It is in the interest of the European Union to have a homogeneous system of responsibility for environmental damage caused by the transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances at sea. With this report, we have the opportunity to achieve a uniform accountability system as effectively and equitably as possible, without altering the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of the common rules of EU law, and without creating excessive disparities for victims of pollution (e.g. coastal populations, fishermen, etc.) and the maritime industry. The opening of a dialogue with the Council and the Commission to build a coherent European policy in the area of liability and compensation for environmental damage resulting from the transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances at sea is a step in the right direction.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage in the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances at Sea, 1996, provides for liability and compensation for damage caused by the transport of hazardous and noxious substances at sea, including liquefied natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas, which has not yet been ratified. The 2010 Convention establishes the strict liability of the owner of a ship carrying hazardous and noxious substances for any damage resulting from an incident relating to the transport of hazardous and noxious substances at sea and on board the ship in question. A special compensation fund has been set up to pay compensation to persons who have suffered damage in connection with the transport of hazardous and noxious substances at sea and who have failed to obtain full or adequate compensation from the shipowner or his insurer. The existing Union legal framework lacks a requirement for compulsory insurance, and the Convention specifically provides for this obligation for shipowners, together with the right of applicants to bring a direct action against the insurer. Taking into account the nature of shipping as a sector with a cross-border impact, the international regime is preferable to regional solutions. The proposal has my support.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because, as today, there is nothing under the Environmental Liability Directive to provide for compensation of victims in excess of the limits of the ship owner’s liability. Furthermore, the existing legal framework in the EU lacks a mandatory insurance requirement, whereas the Convention specifically establishes this obligation for ship owners coupled with a right of claimants for direct action against the insurer. I believe it is in the interest of the Union as a whole to have a homogenous liability regime applicable to environmental damage arising from the carriage of HNS at sea, which can only be achieved if Parliament’s recommendations are duly considered by the Council and the Commission. I believe that report should not be seen as an impediment to the establishment of a uniform liability regime, but as an effort to ensure that this is done in the most effective and fair fashion, without impairing the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of common rules of EU law and without creating excessive disparity for the victims of pollution (e.g. coastal communities , fishermen, etc.) and the shipping industry.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council submitted a draft decision on the strengthening and accession of the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Substances by Sea, with the exception of aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters, in the interest of the European Union. In order to adopt the decision, it must obtain parliament's consent.  In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs makes a series of recommendations and recommends that Parliament take a position that this interim report would be an additional opportunity for the Council and the Commission to address these recommendations. It therefore recommends that Parliament ask the Council and the Commission to conduct further negotiations, taking into account the recommendations. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Given the global nature of the maritime freight activity, the uniqueness of maritime areas, a comprehensive approach is preferable to a regional approach. I vote for this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to give consent to the form the negotiations should take on this protocol.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which looks at a protocol on the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for damages related to the sea transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances. This is a report which analyses the legal basis that the European Union could use if it decided to adhere to this protocol.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The HNS Convention also known as The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage in Connection with the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by Sea was set-up in 1996. I have voted for this interim report that aims to ensure that the establishment of a uniform liability regime, with the exception of aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters, is done in the most effective and fair fashion.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – It seeks to protect coastal communities and fishing communities beyond the liability limits of the ship owner, which is an important development. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Accession to the Protocol ensures that ships carrying dangerous and harmful substances in EU waters take responsibility for their cargo, and allows funds to be used to compensate victims in the event of accidents.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage caused by the Transport by Sea of Dangerous and Harmful Substances of 1996 is the last of the Conventions of the International Maritime Organisation concerning liability and compensation for damage caused by the transport by sea of dangerous and harmful substances that have not yet been ratified, nor has the 2010 Protocol been ratified. Both agreements would provide support for the overall framework in this area, which the rapporteur would like to see because, given the cross-border nature of maritime transport, he believes it would be more useful for there to be international legislation rather than regional solutions. I welcome my colleague's interim report and vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages relating to the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Goods by Sea of 1996 (HNS Convention), amended in 2010, is the last of a series of International Maritime Organisation (IMO) conventions relating to the liability and compensation of damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances by sea that has not yet been ratified by all Member States and has not yet entered into force. The aim of the proposed Council decision is to authorize Member States to ratify or access, on behalf of the Union, the Protocol to the HNS Convention of 2010, which aims to ensure uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation for damages related to accidents caused by the maritime transport of dangerous and harmful substances on THE TERRITORY of the EU and to provide sufficient funds to compensate for losses to injured parties (natural, legal and public persons) and to remediate damages as a result of such accidents. The application of this Convention and Protocol is also significant for Croatian citizens, in light of the further strengthening of maritime traffic in the Adriatic, because it provides all affected stakeholders with adequate, prompt and effective compensation for loss or damage to property or the environment, caused by accidents related to the transport of dangerous and harmful substances by sea.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Given the global nature of the maritime freight activity, the uniqueness of maritime areas, a comprehensive approach is preferable to a regional approach. I vote for this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The 2010 Convention on Dangerous and Harmful Substances aims to ensure accountability and adequate, prompt and effective compensation for damages or damages caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances by sea through a specialised international compensation fund.  I am committed to ratifying and acceding to the 2010 Protocol with the International Convention on Dangerous and Harmful Substances, which provides for the application of the principle that the polluter pays, as well as the application of the principles of prevention and caution, in order to take preventive measures in case of possible environmental damages, and therefore to enter the field of Union policy and its fundamental principles on the environment. The swift ratification of the Protocol is welcome, but an even better development would be if the Council reconsidered its position and took into account that it is not good for the EU, even for its citizens, to create legal uncertainty and differences between the different legal regimes of the Member States.  Therefore, I call on the Council to take a better decision which does not imply differences in the legal regulations of the different Member States, especially since the loss or damage to which persons, property or the environment are damaged, caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances by sea, and often have an inter-border element.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on liability and compensation for damage resulting from the carriage of dangerous and harmful substances by sea is the last of the IMO conventions governing liability and compensation for damage resulting from the carriage of dangerous and harmful substances by sea, including LNG and GPL, which has not yet been ratified. In view of the experience gained from similar international regimes in the field of liability for damage caused by other maritime transport activities, such as the transport of oil on oil tankers, the IMO adopted this international agreement as amended by the 2010 HNS Protocol.  The Convention highlights: - the responsibility of the owner of the ship in case of transport of HNS, for damages arising from incidents related to its transport; - the obligation of the ship owner to take out insurance or other financial guarantees to cover his liability for damage; - the establishment of a specific compensation fund to compensate all persons who are victims of damage resulting from the carriage of SES by sea.  The aim is to ratify the Convention and to eliminate legal conflict with Community law in order to alleviate the damage to persons and communities affected by spills of these substances at sea.  We voted in favour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒In the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages related to the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Goods by Sea in 2010, a decision was taken on the strict liability of the owner of the ship transporting harmful substances for any damage caused under those circumstances. The exception to this liability arises due to the owner's obligation to own insurance that will cover the costs. A compensation fund intended for damages by shipowners and insurers was also established. There is currently no possibility of payment to the victims if it exceeds the owner's responsibility. In addition, the EU legal framework lacks a requirement for mandatory insurance, although this is mandatory under the Convention. As the transport of dangerous and harmful goods constitutes a large part of marine transport, the international regime would be more appropriate than regional ones to ensure liability and compensation rules.  I supported Svoboda MP Svoboda's report on the creation of a coherent policy to deal with the liability and compensation of environmental damages resulting from the transport of dangerous and harmful substances by sea.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The main objective of the SNS Convention is to enable international cooperation to protect the marine environment from harmful and dangerous substances. The implementation of its provisions is in the interest of both the maritime economy (and tourism) and those living in the coastal strip, as their losses and uneasy benefits caused by pollution will be compensated. It is assessed that the Convention will not lead to an additional burden on Member States' budgets, while the responsibilities of the national maritime administration will change. The Convention will also affect shipowners who will have to conclude appropriate insurance contracts, as well as the recipients of harmful and dangerous cargoes, as they will be obliged to pay contributions to the SNS fund. The ESM Convention has the opportunity to ensure uniform application of the provisions on liability and compensation in relation to accidents caused by ships carrying ESM and, by setting up a fund, should ensure that sufficient resources are available to compensate victims of such accidents. However, there is a risk that two different systems will be imposed on the shipping sector at the same time, eu and international, which may result in unequal treatment of victims of pollution. I hereby abstain.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this interim report on a draft Council decision on the ratification and accession of the European Union to a protocol on the International Convention on Responsibility and Compensation for Damages Related to the Sea Transport of Harmful and Potentially Dangerous Substances.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Resolution to ensure compliance with the principle of conferral of powers on the EU pursuant to Article 5(1) OF the ETand the settled case-law of the Court of Justice which states that 'the choice of the legal basis for a Community act must be based on objective elements which are subject to judicial review, including , in particular the purpose and content of the act'. And, 'since the proposal for a Council decision is intended to allow Member States to ratify or accede, on behalf of the Union, to the 2010 HNS Protocol and subsequently to be bound by the 2010 HNS Convention, and taking into account that the latter covers not only cases of environmental damage (applying the principles of preventive action and polluter pays) , but also in cases of non-environmental damage caused by the transport of certain substances by sea, the appropriate legal basis for the tender consists of Articles 100(2, 192)(1) and 218(6)(a) tfeu's tfeu'.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages arising from the Maritime Transport of Toxic and Hazardous Substances is a key legal instrument in terms of transport and the environment. The ratification of the 2010 Protocol, which represents practically the ratification of the above Convention in its new terms of 2010, is relevant to the EU because it provides enhanced protection for those affected by the maritime transport of hazardous substances.  In its December 2015 decision, the Council releases Member States to decide when each will carry out ratification. This possibility could lead to legal uncertainty because of differences in the applicable rule. In addition, some of the provisions overlap with the Environmental Responsibility Directive 2004/35/EC, which could lead to confusion as to the legal basis for claims.  With this interim report, which I voted in favour of, Parliament intends to pressure the Council to correct its decision, calling for a uniform ratification of the Convention and thus clarifying its implementation.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages Related to the Sea Transport of Harmful and Potentially Dangerous Substances (1996 HNS Convention) aims to ensure adequate, prompt and effective compensation for those who are victims of damage from spills of harmful and potentially dangerous substances while transporting them by sea. This 1996 HNS Convention was amended by the 2010 Protocol and provides for improved protection for victims of damage related to the sea transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the request for a more in-depth debate on this issue with the Commission and the Council is a good thing.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although in 2010 The HNS Convention addresses an important task of ensuring accountability and adequate, rapid and effective compensation for damage or damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances by sea through the specialised International HNS Compensation Fund in accordance with the polluter pays principle, but it may conflict with the provisions of the Directive on environmental liability which , caused by an event the liability or compensation of which is governed by the international conventions listed in Annex IV, as well as their future amendments in force in that Member State'. This report is therefore essential in EU law to define the limits of liability of shipowners and operators. The document itself is really well drawn up and that is why I support it.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are in the presence of a report on the same subject already dealt with in report A-0191/2016 (adoption of the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention), with a view to the adoption of uniform international rules on liability and compensation in the event of accidents caused by ships carrying HNS on EU territory, although in this case specifically on aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters. In this case too, an interim report was chosen to call for further discussion on this matter with the Commission and the Council, in particular with regard to the overlaps between the recast Brussels I Regulation and the 2010 HNS Convention, provided that the procedural rules applicable to claims for compensation and legal proceedings under the Convention before the courts of the States—Parties and ensure that the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of the COMMON EU rules are concerned will not be adversely affected by any international commitments made by the Union or its Member States, as can be read in the document. As a result of the foregoing, I was therefore in favour of its approval.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Svoboda's report. This text concerns the accession of the European Union to the 2010 Protocol to the Convention on Dangerous and Harmful Substances and compensation for damage caused by the transport of these substances by sea. Accession to this Convention will make it possible to harmonise international intervention in order to ensure uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation for damage caused by ships carrying these substances.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this text on the urgent consideration of the urgent ratification of a protocol whose effective implementation by The Member States will entail greater certainty against the human and environmental risks caused by such substances.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. Denmark is covered by the opt-out in this area. Nevertheless, I support the EU's ratification of the Convention, as it has already been ratified in Danish law.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'decision to ratify the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage caused by the transport of harmful and dangerous substances at sea by the Member States on behalf of the Union and their accession to this Protocol, with the exception of aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters', as it takes account of the 'polluter pays' principle in the event of accidents.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to give Parliament's consent to the Council for its adoption of the 2010 Protocol on harmful and dangerous substances relating to the maritime transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances, with the exception of aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. Since regional bodies cannot do so, it is up to the Member States to join. I voted in favour of this report, since it proposes to ensure the assumption of responsibilities and the payment of adequate, timely and effective compensation for loss or damage caused to persons, property or the environment as a result of the maritime transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances through the SNP Specialised International Compensation Fund.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2010, the Protocol to the Convention on Dangerous and Harmful Substances (HNS) introduced liability and compensation for damage resulting from the transport by sea of dangerous and harmful substances, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG). The main objective of the HSN Convention is to enable international cooperation to protect the marine environment from harmful and dangerous substances. In addition, the HNS Convention establishes the objective liability of the owner of the vessel carrying dangerous and harmful substances for damage resulting from an event related to the transport by sea of dangerous and harmful substances on board that vessel. As this convention is very important for the environment of the European Union, I have decided to vote in favour of this interim recommendation, which aims to initiate a dialogue on this subject with the Council and the Commission.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I want to see the swift ratification of this Protocol, but the Council of the EU needs to reconsider its position and it should see that it is not beneficial to create legal uncertainty and divisions between legal regimes in Member States in an issue that has so many cross-border implications.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I think it is important that a special compensation fund has been set up under this Convention to pay compensation to persons who have suffered damage in connection with the transport of hazardous and noxious substances at sea and who have failed to obtain full or adequate compensation from the shipowner or his insurer. I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Liability and compensation for damages resulting from specific types of shipping activities are regulated at international level by a series of International Maritime Organisation conventions based on the same guiding principles. These principles include: strict liability of the shipowner, compulsory insurance to cover damages caused to third parties, a claim to exercise his rights directly with the insurer in the case of persons who have suffered damage, limitation of liability and, in the case of oil and hazardous and noxious substances, a special compensation fund which pays for damages in so far as they go beyond the liability of the shipowner. The 2010 Convention establishes the strict liability of the owner of a ship carrying hazardous and noxious substances for any damage resulting from an incident relating to the transport of hazardous and noxious substances at sea and on board the ship in question. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the Convention on Liability and Compensation will ensure uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying hazardous and noxious substances at sea throughout the EU.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Only qualified persons and designated institutions must have access to hazardous substances and their movements must be subject to control by national states as well as bodies at Pan-European level.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The International Convention on Dangerous and Harmful Substances establishes the strict liability of the shipowner transporting dangerous and harmful substances for any form of damage caused by an incident related to the maritime transport of dangerous and harmful substances loaded aboard that ship. There are limited exemptions from the strict liability of the owner which is accompanied by the obligation of the owner to be insured or obtain another financial guarantee due to the insurance against possible liability for damages. Furthermore, a special compensation fund has been established, the role of which is to compensate all persons who suffer damages related to the transport of dangerous and harmful goods by sea in the event that those persons could not receive full and adequate compensation from the shipper and its insurer.  I support this report, as I believe it is necessary to ensure a uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships transporting hazardous and harmful substances by sea across the EU, and that for the maritime sector, as a global sector with cross-border impact, the international regime is more appropriate than the regional one.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this resolution.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages related to the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Goods by Sea (1996 HNS Convention), as well as the 2010 HNS Protocol, are the latest in a series of International Maritime Organisation conventions relating to the liability and compensation of damages caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances by sea that have not yet entered into force.  The scope of the 1996 and 2010 HNS Conventions overlaps with Directive 2004/35/EC as regards the liability of economic operators for professional activities, including maritime transport, which does not provide compensation to victims. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention will ensure a uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships transporting dangerous and harmful substances by sea across the EU. In addition, this will ensure that sufficient funds are available to compensate victims of such accidents. I support this report, as I consider that a more appropriate international regime than regional solutions is more appropriate for ensuring uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships transporting dangerous and harmful substances by sea across the EU.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the interim report on the draft Council decision on ratification and accession to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage related to the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by Sea by the Member States, on behalf of the Union, with the exception of aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters. The 2010 Convention aimed to pay appropriate, rapid and effective compensation for damage caused to persons, property and the environment by the transport of hazardous and noxious substances by sea.  I would like to open the adoption of an opinion in the form of a letter stressing that Member States accede to the Protocol and recognise the rules of the Convention as binding, as the competition covers not only cases of environmental damage, but also cases of non-environmental damage.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Preventive measures should first be taken to transport harmful goods into the seas and then there should be severe fines for those responsible for environmental disasters in the event of an accident.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea (IMO) is the last of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) Conventions on liability and compensation for the transport of hazardous and harmful substances, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied natural gas (LPG), which has not yet been ratified. On the basis of experience gained in relation to similar international systems governing liability for other maritime transport activities, the IMO adopted this international agreement, amended by the HNS Protocol of 2010, to complement the system of conventions on maritime liability with a specific agreement. Neither the HNS Convention of 1996 nor the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention entered into force. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention will ensure uniform application across the EU of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and noxious substances by sea. It will also ensure that sufficient resources are available to compensate victims of such accidents. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the currently fragmented system with legislation at international level. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the interim report, which makes recommendations to the Council and the Commission on the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea, in order to develop a coherent EU policy. I agree with the report that it is in the interest of the Union as a whole to have a homogeneous system of liability for environmental damage resulting from the transport of hazardous and harmful substances by sea. It intends to contribute to this by means of the report's recommendations, so that the international system is transposed in the most efficient and fair manner possible, without prejudice to the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of the common rules of EU law, and without causing excessive inequality for pollution victims and the shipping sector.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage in connection with the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by Sea – HNS Convention – represents a relevant international legal instrument in terms of transport and environment. The ratification of the 2010 Protocol, which represents practically the ratification of the HNS Convention in its new form of 2010 is considered to be very important for the EU, as it provides for improved protection of the victims of damage in connection with the carriage of HNS by sea, but there are divisions in terms of the period in which that should be done and the terms that the Council established for it. I therefore welcome a swift ratification by all Member States. The Council should reconsider its position, and should see that it is not beneficial to create legal uncertainty and divisions between legal regimes in Member States in an issue that has so many cross-border implications.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The conclusion of the 2010 protocol to the SNPD Convention will ensure a uniform application of the rules on liability and reparation in the event of accidents caused by vessels carrying harmful and potentially dangerous substances at sea throughout the European Union. It will also ensure the availability of sufficient funds for compensation for victims of such accidents.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the ratification and accession of EU members to the 2010 Protocol to the Hazardous and Noxious Substances (HNS) Convention. This convention ensures uniform application of rules on liability and compensation in connection with accidents caused by ships carrying HNS at sea across the EU, and ensures availability of sufficient funds for compensation of victims of such accidents. Considering the nature of shipping as a global business with a cross-boundary impact, I do believe that an international regime rather than regional solutions is better suited to tackle this type of challenge. This protocol would also be an opportunity to frame a coherent policy at EU level.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Ratification and Accession Report of the 2010 Protocol with the International Convention on Dangerous and Harmful Substances, with the exception of aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters, as I hold it extremely important to promote measures at international level to address regional or global environmental problems.  I believe that the environmental policy of the European Union contributes to preserving, protecting and improving the quality of the environment, protecting human health, using natural resources cautiously and rationally. The interest of the Union as a whole is to have a single liability regime measurable for environmental damage arising from the transport of dangerous and harmful substances and to ensure the availability of sufficient means to compensate victims of such accidents.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Interim report on the draft Council decision on ratification and accession to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage related to the Carriage of Dangerous and Noxious Substances by Sea by the Member States, on behalf of the Union, with the exception of aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters, I supported it. The 2010 Convention establishes the objective liability of the shipowner transporting dangerous and noxious substances for damage resulting from an incident related to the transport of dangerous and noxious substances by sea on board that ship. It is important to set up a specialised compensation fund of around EUR 310 million to compensate persons who have suffered damage in connection with the transport of dangerous substances. International regulation in this area is more appropriate than regional. It is in the interest of the European Union to have a single liability regime for environmental damage.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this text on the urgent consideration of the urgent ratification of a protocol whose effective implementation by The Member States will entail greater certainty against the human and environmental risks caused by such substances.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The report believes that, in order to ensure consistent enforcement of the rules on liability and repair of such accidents, an international regime is better suited than regional solutions given the global nature of the maritime sector and its cross-border implications. This legal framework should apply to the whole of the Union, which will therefore have a homogeneous legal regime for this specific responsibility. Nevertheless, the rapporteur wants to start a dialogue with the Council and the Commission with a view to building a coherent European policy in this area. Given the global nature of the maritime freight transport activity, the peculiarity of maritime areas, a comprehensive approach is preferable. Moreover, it has the merit of taking this issue away from the Union's legislative arsenal. So I'm voting FOR.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given that the transport of hazardous and noxious substances represents a significant part of maritime freight transport and the expected cross-border impact of accidents affecting the global nature of the shipping business and shipments of hazardous and noxious substances, the rapporteur considers that it is in the interest of the Union as a whole to have a homogeneous liability system for environmental damage resulting from the transport of hazardous and noxious substances at sea , which can only be achieved if the Council and the Commission take due account of Parliament's recommendations. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this text on the urgent consideration of the urgent ratification of a protocol whose effective implementation by The Member States will entail greater certainty against the human and environmental risks caused by such substances.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
