text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Interim Report on the draft Council decision on the ratification and accession by Member States, in the interest of the European Union, to the Protocol of 2010 to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage in Connection with the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by Sea, with the exception of the aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters. The 2010 HNS Convention establishes strict liability of the owner of the ship carrying HNS for any damage resulting from an incident in connection with the carriage of HNS by sea and on board that ship. I believe that the conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention will ensure uniform application of rules on liability and compensation in connection with accidents caused by ships carrying HNS at sea across the EU. It will also guarantee availability of sufficient funds for compensation of victims of such accidents.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage resulting from the carriage of hazardous and harmful substances by sea is the last of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) conventions governing liability and compensation for damage resulting from the carriage of hazardous and harmful substances by sea, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) which has not yet been ratified.  It is considered to be in the interest of the whole Union to have a homogeneous liability regime applicable to environmental damage caused by the transport of HNS by sea, which can only be achieved if Parliament's recommendations are duly taken into account by the Council and the Commission. However, greater attention should be paid in this context to the overlaps between the recast Brussels I Regulation and the 2010 HNS Convention and to ensure that the possibility of divergence between the DRA and the 2010 HNS Convention is minimised.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In general, it is a question of ratifying the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage caused by the transport of harmful and dangerous substances at sea. The interim report makes it clear that it is not appropriate for Parliament to give its consent before ensuring the unity, integrity and effectiveness of Union law and the fundamental principle of the EU's limited individual authorisation. The report also shows that the Council and the Commission need to make recommendations on the remaining overlap between the UHRL and the HNS Convention in order to achieve a positive outcome.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the interim report on the draft Council decision on ratification and accession to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage related to the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by Sea by the Member States, on behalf of the Union, with the exception of aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters. The interim report calls for Member States to ratify the 2010 HNS Convention or to enter into an agreement within a reasonable period of time, which should not exceed two years from the entry into force of the Council Decision. The 2010 HNS Convention aims to ensure accountability and payment of adequate, rapid and effective compensation through the specialised HNS Fund for damage to persons, property and the environment as a result of the transport of hazardous and noxious substances by sea.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament is called upon to approve the accession by Member States to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage caused by the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Substances (HNS) by sea, with the exception of aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. Accession to the Convention is desirable because it offers more specific rules and much more specialised and effective legal instruments. The assessment of these reports has therefore been positive.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to give Parliament's consent to the Council to adopt the 2010 Protocol on the Convention on Harmful and Dangerous Substances Relating to the Maritime Transport of Harmful and Potentially Hazardous Substances, in this case as regards matters relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. Since regional bodies cannot do so, it is up to the Member States to join. I voted in favour of this report, since it proposes to ensure the assumption of responsibilities and the payment of adequate, timely and effective compensation for loss or damage caused to persons, property or the environment as a result of the maritime transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances through the SNP Specialised International Compensation Fund.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for the ratification of the 2010 Protocol on the International Convention on Harmful and Potentially Dangerous Substances on aspects of judicial cooperation in civil matters.  The agreement establishes the responsibility of the owner of the vessel carrying harmful substances in the event of damage resulting from an accident at sea. It provides for limited exceptions to this liability, which is accompanied by the obligation to purchase insurance. Finally, it establishes a specific fund to cover the full extent of the damages and damages suffered by an individual who could not have been fully compensated by the ship owner or his insurer.  I believe that a comprehensive approach is better suited than regional solutions given the global nature of the maritime sector and its cross-border implications. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a single vote on an interim report calling for dialogue between this EU institutions to coordinate a compensation scheme for victims of hazardous and noxious substance spilling at sea. It seeks to protect coastal communities and fishing communities beyond the liability limits of the ship owner which is an important development. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to send a strong signal to the Council. We want the protocol to be ratified quickly. However, the Council should reconsider its position in order to avoid creating further legal uncertainty within the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The report believes that, in order to ensure consistent enforcement of the rules on liability and repair of accidents related to the transport of harmful or potentially dangerous substances, an international regime is better adapted than regional solutions, given the global nature of the maritime freight transport activity. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I abstained on this report. I am in favour of international action to ensure that where possible pollution caused by hazardous and noxious substances by sea is prevented. I support the idea that the polluter should pay and that a regime is in place for clearing up that pollution. However these are matters that should solely be the province of sovereign governments of Member States and not subject to an undemocratic instruction from the European Council.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea is the last of the International Maritime Organisation Conventions on Liability and Compensation for The Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances at Sea, including Liquefied Natural Gas and Liquefied Propane Butane Gas, which has not yet been ratified. The Convention shall state the objective liability of the owner of the vessel for any damage resulting from an accident involving dangerous and harmful substances carried on board the vessel in question. It lays down a limited number of exceptions to the owner's objective liability, which is combined with the obligation of the owner to have insurance or other financial collateral to cover his liability for damage covered by the Convention. More importantly, a special compensation fund will be set up to compensate all persons who are harmed by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances at sea if they have not received full and adequate compensation from the owner of the vessel and its insurer. The rapporteur intends to initiate a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to develop a coherent EU policy on liability and compensation for environmental damage resulting from the transport of hazardous and harmful substances by sea. I supported the proposal because it gives a reasonable and justified mandate to join an international convention.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement, which amends the 1996 HNS report, establishes objective liability for the owner of a vessel carrying harmful or potentially dangerous substances in the event of damage resulting from an incident at sea during such transport. It matches this responsibility with the obligation to take out insurance or other security in the event of a disaster, and establishes a specific compensation fund for damages related to the transport of harmful substances by sea.  The report believes that, in order to ensure uniform enforcement of the rules on liability for such accidents, an international regime is best suited, given the global nature of the maritime sector and its cross-border implications. In fact, given the global nature of the maritime freight business, a comprehensive approach is preferable. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The 1996 International Convention on Responsibility and Compensation for Damages Related to the Sea Transport of Harmful or Potentially Dangerous Substances aims to ensure adequate, prompt and effective compensation for those who are victims of damage caused by spills of harmful and potentially dangerous substances while transporting them by sea. This Convention was amended by a 2010 protocol, which incorporates protection against environmental damage. In order to become contracting parties to the protocol, Member States must ratify it. This report, which I have approved, allows them to do so.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2010 HNS Convention aims to ensure the accountability and payment of adequate, rapid and effective compensation for losses or damage to persons, goods and the environment resulting from the transport by sea of dangerous and harmful substances through a specialised International HNS Compensation Fund. It is, of course, an important legal instrument whose ratification is, however, only permitted by the Member States. I voted in favour of the Svoboda report because I agree with the need to ensure certainty in the application of legislation which, with the Council's decision, could be compromised. The purpose of the interim report adopted is therefore to put pressure on the Council to approve the proposal put forward to call for uniform ratification of the HNS Convention, without leaving the vagueness of the timing of the first wording.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this text, considering the urgent ratification of a Protocol, the effective implementation of which by the Member States, will entail greater security against the human and environmental risks caused by such substances.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote concerns ratification, including aspects of judicial cooperation in civil matters.  Under the aegis of the International Maritime Organization (IMO), the 1996 HNS Convention was amended by the 2010 Protocol (the "Protocol"), which were consolidated by a new text, the 2010 HNS Convention (the "Convention"), which is not open to signature or ratification. The convention will take effect when the protocol enters into force in the Member States.  The Convention establishes, for example, the objective liability of the owner of a vessel carrying harmful or potentially dangerous substances in the event of damage resulting from an incident at sea during that transport, provides for limited exceptions and establishes a specific compensation fund.  Given the global nature and peculiarities of maritime areas, an international regime is better suited than regional solutions. So I voted for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is well structured, interesting and without any critical issues and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages in Connection with the Maritime Transport of Harmful and Potentially Hazardous Substances is a key legal instrument in terms of transport and the environment. The ratification of the 2010 Protocol, which represents practically the ratification of the above-2010 Convention, is relevant to the EU because it provides enhanced protection for those affected by maritime transport of dangerous substances.  In its December 2015 decision, the Council releases Member States to decide when each will carry out ratification. This possibility could lead to legal uncertainty because of differences in the applicable rule. In addition, some of the provisions overlap with the Environmental Liability Directive 2004/35/EC, which could lead to confusion as to the legal basis for complaints.  With this interim report, which I voted in favour of, Parliament intends to pressure the Council to correct its decision by calling for a uniform ratification of the Convention and thus clarifying its implementation.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it made its recommendations for a Council decision on the ratification and accession to the 2010 Protocol in the interest of the Member States of the European Union in the interest of the European Union as regards judicial cooperation in civil matters. 1996 The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage related to the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by Sea, including Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) and Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG), and the Protocol to the 2010 HNS Convention have not yet been ratified. This preliminary report by Parliament should not be seen as an obstacle to the creation of a uniform regime of responsibility, but an effort to ensure that this is done in the most effective and fairest way, without compromising the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of common rules of EU law and creating excessively unequal conditions for victims of pollution (e.g. coastal communities, fishermen, etc.) and the shipping industry. Parliament wants to enter into a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to define a coherent EU policy in the area of responsibility and compensation for environmental damage caused by the transport of hazardous and noxious substances by sea.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea is the last of the International Maritime Organisation Conventions on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea, which has not yet been ratified. The IMO adopted – and amended by the HNS Protocol of 2010 – this international agreement to complement the system of conventions on maritime liability with a specific agreement. Neither the HNS Convention of 1996 nor the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention entered into force. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol will ensure uniform application across the EU of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and harmful substances by sea. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the currently fragmented system with legislation at international level.  I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The report believes that, in order to ensure consistent enforcement of the rules on liability and repair of such accidents, an international regime is better suited than regional solutions, given the global nature of the maritime sector and its cross-border implications. Given the global nature of the maritime freight transport activity, the peculiarity of maritime areas, a comprehensive approach is preferable. Moreover, it has the merit of taking this issue away from the Union's legislative arsenal. So I voted for it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This was a single vote on an interim report calling for dialogue between this EU institutions to coordinate a compensation scheme for victims of hazardous and noxious substance spilling at sea. It seeks to protect coastal communities and fishing communities beyond the liability limits of the ship owner which is an important development. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Having taken note of the discussion on this subject, the positive contribution of the Commissions and the relevant working groups, and in view of the significant proportion of shipments of dangerous and harmful substances in maritime freight transport, the global nature of the shipbuilding sector and the possible cross-border impact of accidents involving shipments of dangerous or harmful substances, we consider that it is in the interests of the Union as a whole to have a uniform liability regime applicable to environmental damage resulting from the the transport of dangerous and harmful substances into the sea, which can only be achieved if – as has already been said and hoped for – the Council and the Commission take due account of the Recommendations of the European Parliament.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I have supported these guidelines in order to continue negotiations on the ratification by Member States, in the interests of the European Union, of the 2010 Protocol on the International Convention on Responsibility and Compensation for Damages Related to the Sea Transport of Harmful and Potentially Dangerous Substances, as well as the accession of Member States audit protocol, with regard to aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. The exception to the general application of the brussels I regulation is justified in order to avoid legal difficulties.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report supports the ratification of the 2010 Protocol on the International Convention on Harmful and Potentially Dangerous Substances on aspects of judicial cooperation in civil matters. The agreement establishes the responsibility of the owner of the vessel carrying harmful substances in the event of damage resulting from an accident at sea. It provides for limited exceptions to this liability, which is accompanied by the obligation to purchase insurance. Finally, it establishes a specific fund to cover the full extent of the damages and damages suffered by an individual who could not have been fully compensated by the ship owner or his insurer. I believe that a comprehensive approach is better suited than regional solutions given the global nature of the maritime sector and its cross-border implications. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the 2010 HNS Convention, uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation related to accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and harmful substances at sea within the EU is assured. Sufficient funds to compensate victims shall be ensured, thereby ensuring that an international regime, rather than regional solutions, is more appropriate to ensure uniform application of the rules on compensation and liability of naval accidents. This interim report should not be considered an impediment to the establishment of a uniform liability regime, but on the contrary, an effort to ensure that this process is carried out with the utmost effectiveness and fairness, without affecting the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of the EU's common rules of law, but also without creating excessive disparities for pollution victims and the shipping industry. We have given a vote in favour of this report, because it is necessary to protect the environment, but at the same time we must come to the aid of victims who suffer such a maritime accident, this being achieved only through a coherent political and judicial framework in the area of liability and compensation for environmental damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances at sea.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because it offers sound ideas and constructive criticisms with a view to the ratification by the Member States of the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage caused by the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Substances by Sea. The dossier notes that the above convention and Directive 2004/35/EC operate in the same context with regard to the liability of professional operators, with obvious differences. In particular, EU legislation is not binding on third countries, including those that are important flag states, which could prove problematic when handling complaints about spills of dangerous and harmful substances with international aspects. Furthermore, in the event that the neighbouring countries of the EU Member States were parties to the Convention and an accident occurred in both an EU Member State and a neighbouring country, the applicants and owners of the vessels would be subject to different (and contradictory) regimes. With the position taken today, the EP intends to enter into a dialogue with the Council and the Commission with a view to outlining a coherent EU policy in this area.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a single vote on an interim report calling for dialogue between this EU institutions to coordinate a compensation scheme for victims of hazardous and noxious substance spilling at sea. It seeks to protect coastal communities and fishing communities beyond the liability limits of the ship owner which is an important development. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report and I believe that the Protocol of 2010 to the International convention on liability and compensation for damage in connection with the carriage of hazardous and noxious substances (HNS) by sea with regard to aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters should also be ratified and entered into force across the EU. I especially welcome the polluter pays principle here and greater protection for the victims of any HNS leakages. I am particularly satisfied with the proposal of consistent application of the rules across the EU considering the more globalised sea transportation.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Svoboda's second report concerns a Council decision on the ratification and accession by Member States to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage caused by the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Substances (HNS) by sea. In the absence of a REIO (Regional Economic Integration Organisation) clause in the text of the Convention or in the Protocol, Member States should conclude such an international agreement on behalf of the Union, subject to authorisation by the Council and approval by the European Parliament on a proposal from the Commission. The rapporteur considers that it is not appropriate for Parliament to give its approval before seeing the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of EU law guaranteed, as well as the fundamental principle of the allocation of EU competences. Accession to the International Convention on Harmful Substances is desirable because it offers more specific rules and legal instruments that are much more specialised and effective than those offered by the Community regulatory framework, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Justice wants that, as the Italian Civil Code states, any damage obliges the one who caused it to compensate those who have suffered it. And so far we all agree. However, there are cases where the amount of damage goes far beyond the availability of those who caused it. I voted in favour of this proposal because it provides a concrete response to these cases, and it goes in the direction of a just solution.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In view of the significant share HNS cargo represents in maritime freight transport, the global nature of the shipping business, as well as the cross-boundary impact accidents involving HNS cargo are likely to have, I believe it is in the interest of the Union as a whole to have a homogenous liability regime applicable to environmental damage arising from the carriage of HNS at sea , which can only be achieved if Parliament’s recommendations are duly considered by the Council and the Commission.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2010 HNS Convention establishes the objective responsibility of the ship owner in the case of the transport of hydrocarbons and hazardous and harmful substances (HNS) for damage arising from incidents related to the carriage of those substances on board the ship. It is envisaged that the owner will take out insurance to cover his liability for damage caused under the Convention and a specific indemnity fund aimed at compensating all persons who are victims of damage resulting from the carriage of the NHS, if those persons have not been fully and adequately compensated by the owner of the ship or the insurer. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the NHS Convention will ensure uniform application of liability and compensation rules in the event of an accident caused by ships carrying NHS on EU territory. An international scheme is more appropriate than regional solutions to ensure uniform application of liability and compensation rules in the event of an accident. It is therefore in the Union's interest to have a homogeneous liability regime applicable to environmental damage caused by the transport of HNS by sea.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the significant share of shipments of dangerous and harmful substances in maritime freight transport, the global nature of the shipbuilding sector and the possible cross-border impact of accidents involving shipments of dangerous or harmful substances, I consider it appropriate to proceed with ratification and accession to this Protocol. I voted in favour of this report, as it promotes a system of uniform liability applicable to environmental damage resulting from the transport of dangerous substances at sea and provides for a system of compensation for damage caused by the maritime transport of dangerous and toxic substances.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to give Parliament's consent to the Council to adopt the 2010 Protocol on the Convention on Harmful and Dangerous Substances Relating to the Maritime Transport of Harmful and Potentially Hazardous Substances, in this case as regards matters relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. Since regional bodies cannot do so, it is up to the Member States to join.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Environmental Liability Directive has no provision for compensating victims beyond the limits of the ship's owner's liability. Furthermore, the existing legal framework in the EU does not include any requirement for compulsory insurance, while the Convention specifically sets out this obligation for shipowners, coupled with the right of complainants to bring direct action against the insurer. An international regime, rather than regional solutions, is more appropriate to ensure uniform enforcement of liability rules and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and harmful substances at sea across the EU, given that it is global commercial activity. I voted for a homogeneous liability regime applicable to environmental damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances at sea, given the global dimension of this phenomenon.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The main objective of the SNS Convention is to enable international cooperation to protect the marine environment from harmful and dangerous substances. The implementation of its provisions is in the interest of both the maritime economy (and tourism) and those living in the coastal strip, as their losses and uneasy benefits caused by pollution will be compensated. It is assessed that the Convention will not lead to an additional burden on Member States' budgets, while the responsibilities of the national maritime administration will change. The Convention will also affect shipowners who will have to conclude appropriate insurance contracts, as well as the recipients of harmful and dangerous cargoes, as they will be required to pay contributions to the SNS fund. The ESM Convention has the opportunity to ensure uniform application of the provisions on liability and compensation in relation to accidents caused by ships carrying ESM and, by setting up a fund, should ensure that sufficient resources are available to compensate victims of such accidents. However, there is a risk that two different systems will be imposed on the shipping sector at the same time, eu and international, which may result in unequal treatment of victims of pollution. Due to doubts about this Convention, I abstained from voting

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote deals with the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage in connection with the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by Sea (HNS Convention). The ratification of the 2010 Protocol provides for improved protection of the victims of damage in connection with the carriage of HNS by sea, but there are divisions in terms of the period in which that should be done. In order to put pressure on the Council to amend its decision in a way that would ask for the uniform ratification of this Convention and bring clarity as regards its applicability, Parliament drafted this Interim Report which I supported.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea is the last of the International Maritime Organisation Conventions on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea, which has not yet been ratified. The IMO adopted – and amended by the HNS Protocol of 2010 – this international agreement to complement the system of conventions on maritime liability with a specific agreement. Neither the HNS Convention of 1996 nor the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention entered into force. The highly specific nature of the system of jurisdiction of the HNS Convention, stemming from efforts to prevent the practice of forum shopping, and the legal and practical difficulties arising from the application of a different jurisdictional system to the Union and other parties to the HNS Convention justify an exception to the general application of the revised Brussels I Regulation. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol will ensure uniform application across the EU of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and harmful substances by sea. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the currently fragmented system with legislation at international level.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Substances by Sea is the last of the International Maritime Organisation Conventions on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea, which has not yet been ratified. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol will ensure uniform application across the EU of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and harmful substances by sea. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the current fragmented system with legislation at international level.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Under the aegis of the International Maritime Organization (IMO), the 1996 HNS (Hazardous and Noxious Substances) Convention was amended by the 2010 Protocol. In the event of damage resulting from an incident in the transport of harmful or potentially dangerous substances, the agreement establishes the objective liability of the ship's owner, with limited exceptions with the obligation to purchase insurance. The agreement also establishes a compensation fund for those who have not been able to obtain a satisfactory damage remedy. I supported this text that the uniform application of international rules on the liability and repair of such accidents is better suited than regional solutions.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this dossier. It rightly addresses some major problems when it comes to spills of dangerous and harmful substances carried by sea. I believe there is still a lot of work to be done, especially when it comes to clarifying the status and opportunities for countries that have significantly fewer resources and therefore more hesitation when it comes to signing and ratifying new agreements and protocols. We must, as a further step, focus on improving assistance to these Member States so that countries can balance standards for security and safety measures without risking sanctions or reregulation. However, I support this report as I believe it is a good initiative. International cooperation is important in this area, as the consequences of such a spill can be very lasting and affect multiple Member States at the same time and as clarity of rules and procedures is needed.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Positive, since there should be common laws and regulations between states on such a serious issue concerning the transport of harmful materials by sea. There should also be no other rules that would lighten the position of the person responsible for a disaster.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea is the last of the International Maritime Organisation Conventions on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea, which has not yet been ratified. The IMO adopted – and amended by the HNS Protocol of 2010 – this international agreement to complement the system of conventions on maritime liability with a specific agreement. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission shall ensure that the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of the COMMON EU rules shall not be adversely affected by the international commitments made for ratification or membership of the 2010 HNS Convention, and to take all appropriate measures to ensure that the exclusivity clause, according to which no complaint can be made against the owner of the ship which does not comply with that Convention , is fully respected by the Member States which have ratified or acceded to the Convention. I also agree with the elimination of the permanent coexistence of two maritime liability schemes.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for it. Given the global nature of the maritime freight transport activity, the peculiarity of maritime areas, a comprehensive approach is preferable. Moreover, it has the merit of taking this issue away from the Union's legislative arsenal.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on liability and compensation for damage resulting from the transport of hazardous and harmful substances by sea is the last of the Conventions of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) governing liability and compensation for damage resulting from the transport of these substances, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), which has not yet been ratified. The Convention establishes: - the objective liability of the ship owner for damage arising from incidents; - the obligation of the ship owner to take out insurance or other financial guarantees to cover his liability for damage under the Convention; - the establishment of a specific compensation fund to compensate all persons who are victims of damage resulting from maritime transport if those persons have not been fully and adequately compensated by the shipowner and the insurer. There is some discrepancy between the EU Directive for the same matter and the Convention. It is considered that it is in the EU's interest to have a homogeneous regime of liability for environmental damage caused by the transport of these substances by sea, which can only be achieved if Parliament's recommendations are duly taken into account by the Council and the Commission. We also voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary in the interests of the Union to provide for a uniform system of liability for environmental damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances into the sea.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because it is positive for public health.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of improving homogeneity on judicial cooperation in terms of liability and compensation for environmental damage resulting from the maritime transport of dangerous or harmful substances.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The parties to the international convention are States which sign the Protocol in their own name and not on behalf of the Union. It is not for the European Parliament to authorise them to do so, which is why I abstained. My doubts do not concern the risk assessment of the dangerous substances transported, because I have a clear and firm view on this point

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the ratification and accession to the 2010 Protocol to the Convention on Dangerous and Harmful Substances with the exception of aspects of judicial cooperation in civil matters, as there should be common laws and regulations between States on such a serious issue concerning the transport of harmful materials by sea. There should also be no other rules that would lighten the position of the person responsible for a disaster.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage in connection with the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by Sea – HNS Convention – represents a relevant international legal instrument in terms of transport and environment. The ratification of the 2010 Protocol, which represents practically the ratification of the HNS Convention in its new form of 2010 is considered to be very important for the EU, as it provides for improved protection of the victims of damage in connection with the carriage of HNS by sea, but there are divisions in terms of the period in which that should be done and the terms that the Council established for it. In order for the Convention to enter into force, some Member States would like a swift ratification, while others are not yet ready to ratify. I support a swift ratification of this Protocol, but Council should reconsider its position, and should see that it is not beneficial to create legal uncertainty and divisions between legal regimes in Member States in an issue that has so many cross-border implications.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea is the last of the International Maritime Organisation Conventions on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea, which has not yet been ratified. The IMO adopted – and amended by the HNS Protocol of 2010 – this international agreement to complement the system of conventions on maritime liability with a specific agreement. Neither the HNS Convention of 1996 nor the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention entered into force. The highly specific nature of the system of jurisdiction of the HNS Convention, stemming from efforts to prevent the practice of forum shopping, and the legal and practical difficulties arising from the application of a different jurisdictional system to the Union and other parties to the HNS Convention justify an exception to the general application of the revised Brussels I Regulation. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol will ensure uniform application across the EU of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and harmful substances by sea. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the current fragmented system with legislation at international level.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea is the last of the International Maritime Organisation Conventions on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea, which has not yet been ratified. The IMO adopted – and amended by the HNS Protocol of 2010 – this international agreement to complement the system of conventions on maritime liability with a specific agreement. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol will ensure uniform application across the EU of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and harmful substances by sea. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the current fragmented system with legislation at international level.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this interim report, with the intentionality of Member States joining the 2010 Protocol on the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages in relation to the maritime transport of harmful substances. To date, the competence to be part of this Protocol or not is State, until the rules are a change, I share with the rapporteur the need to urge States to be part of the 2010 Protocol.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the Council decision on the ratification and accession by Member States, in the interests of the European Union, to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage caused by the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Substances by Sea with regard to aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters, because I believe it is important to send a signal to the Council regarding the importance of the timely implementation of the Protocol by all Member States (MS). I believe, in fact, that the Council's proposal to give ms the freedom to decide when to ratify this Convention goes in the wrong direction, as it risks creating legal disparities and legal uncertainties, creating different systems of jurisdiction in the event of accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous substances. The 2010 Convention overlaps with the Brussels 1a Regulation with regard to jurisdiction and the recognition of decisions, appropriately introducing a stricter regime than EU legislation in order to limit the phenomenon of 'forum shopping'. It is therefore important for Parliament to put pressure on the Council to ensure that all Ms ratify international legislation at the same time.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As an MEP from the coastal region of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, the protection of our seas is a real concern for me. I therefore voted in favour of ratifying the 2010 Protocol on the Convention on Harmful and Dangerous Substances and acceding to it with regard to the aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. It is important that the European Union adopts an international convention on liability and compensation for damage caused by the transport of dangerous substances by sea by the Member States. Sufficient financial assistance will also be provided to be able to make compensation payments to potential victims.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this text, considering the urgent ratification of a Protocol, the effective implementation of which by the Member States, will entail greater security against the human and environmental risks caused by such substances.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this file, which sets out some guidance to the Council on its accession to a new Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for damage in connection with the carriage of hazardous and noxious substances by sea.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The 2010 HNS Convention establishes the objective responsibility of the owner of the ship carrying harmful substances, while at the same time regulating their liability for damage resulting from inso good transport. The same Convention lays down rules on the jurisdiction of the courts, the recognition and enforcement of decisions, overlapping with the application of the rules contained in the Brussels I Regulation. We will also enter into a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to outline a coherent EU policy on liability and compensation for environmental damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances by sea.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the ratification and accession to the 2010 Protocol to the Hazardous and Noxious Substances Convention with regard to aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters. In view of the significant share HNS cargo represents in maritime freight transport, the global nature of the shipping business, as well as the cross-boundary impact accidents involving HNS cargo are likely to have, it is in the interest of the Union as a whole to have a homogenous liability regime applicable to environmental damage arising from the carriage of HNS at sea.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea is the last of the International Maritime Organisation Conventions on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea, which has not yet been ratified. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the current fragmented system with legislation at international level.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support this interim resolution as I believe it will ensure that the risk is diminished of creating and consolidating a competitive disadvantage for the states that are ready to accede to the 2010 HNS Convention, compared to those who might wish to delay this process and continue to be bound by the Environmental Liability Directive only. Thus, the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of common Union rules will not be adversely affected by the international commitments undertaken by the ratification of or accession to the 2010 HNS Convention in accordance with the settled case law of the Court of Justice.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I had no objections to its final edition.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea is the last of the International Maritime Organisation Conventions on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea, which has not yet been ratified. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the current fragmented system with regulation at international level.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ Voted with for an interim report on the Council's draft decision on the ratification and accession of the Member States, in the interest of the European Union, the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages relating to the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Goods by Sea in relation to aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters, as I consider it necessary to make greater efforts to ensure the integrity and effectiveness of common rules under EU law in the most effective and efficacy manner and without excessive differences for pollution victims (i.e. coastal communities, fishermen, etc.) and the maritime transport sector. EU liability and environmental damage compensation caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful goods by sea should be harmonised.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Given the global nature of the maritime freight activity, the uniqueness of maritime areas, a comprehensive approach is preferable. Moreover, it has the merit of taking this issue away from the Union's legislative arsenal. I voted for this text.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of these two interim reports on the ratification and accession of the Union to a protocol on the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for damages related to the sea transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – This report deals with the ratification of the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage in the Carriage of Harmful and Dangerous Substances at Sea (HNS). The rapporteur uses the interim report to draw the attention of the Council and the Commission to the remaining overlaps between the UHRL and the HNS Convention and considers that Parliament should not give its consent until the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of Union law and the fundamental principle of the limited individual authorisation of the EU are guaranteed. I agree with this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal as it sets out some guidance to the Council on its accession to a new Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for damage in connection with the carriage of hazardous and noxious substances by sea.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 When voting on a report taking into account aspects of judicial cooperation in civil matters in the context of the ratification of the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances, I voted in favour of the proposal. The aim of the report is to give the Council its consent by the European Parliament for the adoption of the 2010 Protocol to the Convention. The report takes into account related aspects of judicial cooperation in civil matters. The main objective of the Protocol is, in particular, to strengthen the regime of responsibility for the pollution of the seas by dangerous substances in connection with their transport. In the event of ratification of the Convention as amended by the Protocol, the resulting legislation in Chapter IV of the Protocol on civil matters may be partially overlapd with certain rules under the Brussels I Regulation. The aim of the report is therefore, inter alia, to draw the Council's attention to the possibility of such an irregularity in the event of member states acceding to the Convention as amended by the 2010 Protocol. It is essential that the Convention guarantees uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation for damage caused by accidents caused by vessels carrying dangerous substances. At the same time, the report calls for the ratification of the Convention by the Member States within two years at the latest.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea is the last of the International Maritime Organisation Conventions on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea, which has not yet been ratified. The IMO adopted – and amended by the HNS Protocol of 2010 – this international agreement to complement the system of conventions on maritime liability with a specific agreement. Neither the HNS Convention of 1996 nor the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention entered into force. The highly specific nature of the system of jurisdiction of the HNS Convention, stemming from efforts to prevent the practice of forum shopping, and the legal and practical difficulties arising from the application of a different jurisdictional system to the Union and other parties to the HNS Convention justify an exception to the general application of the revised Brussels I Regulation. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol will ensure uniform application across the EU of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and harmful substances by sea. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the current fragmented system with legislation at international level.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The report discusses a very important topic, as maritime freight transport is a huge proportion of substances, including those considered dangerous and harmful. Accidents may have a cross-border effect due to the nature of transport and can therefore only be carried out under a uniform liability system. The report is on the right track to ensure uniform application across the EU of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships. In addition, further dialogue with the Council and the Commission should be pursued in order to develop a coherent UNION policy on both liability and compensation for environmental damage resulting from the transport of hazardous and harmful substances at sea.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this international convention because it takes away from the Union any room for manoeuvre in the area of maritime freight transport, which requires a comprehensive approach.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to ratify the 2010 Protocol on the International Convention on Harmful and Potentially Dangerous Substances, and to join the audit protocol, with regard to aspects of judicial cooperation in civil matters. The agreement establishes objective liability for the owner of a vessel carrying harmful or potentially dangerous substances in the event of damage resulting from an incident at sea during that transport. It provides for limited exceptions to this liability, which is accompanied by the obligation to take out insurance or other financial guarantee to cover its liability in the event of injury. It establishes a specific compensation fund to compensate anyone who has suffered damages related to the sea transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances when they have not been able to obtain a full and adequate repair of the damage from the ship owner and his insurer. The report rightly believes that, in order to ensure a uniform application of the rules on liability and reparation for such accidents, an international regime is better suited than regional solutions given the global nature of the maritime sector and its cross-border implications.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to give Parliament's consent to the Council to adopt the 2010 Protocol on the Convention on Harmful and Dangerous Substances Relating to the Maritime Transport of Harmful and Potentially Hazardous Substances, in this case as regards matters relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. Since regional bodies cannot do so, it is up to the Member States to join. I voted in favour of this report, since it proposes to ensure the assumption of responsibilities and the payment of adequate, timely and effective compensation for loss or damage caused to persons, property or the environment as a result of the maritime transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances through the SNP Specialised International Compensation Fund.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Czech Republic does not have a sea, so the protocol does not apply to it. I agree with the principle that the polluter should repair and compensate for the damage suffered. However, the Treaty will be ratified by individual Member States, not by the Union, which is why I abstained.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages relating to the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Goods by Sea is the latest of a series of International Maritime Organisation (IMO) conventions relating to the liability and compensation of damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances by sea, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) which has not yet been ratified. The IMO adopted this international agreement to complement the system of liability conventions at sea with a specialised instrument.  The HNS Convention of 2010 establishes strict liability of the shipowner transporting dangerous and harmful substances for any form of damage caused by an incident related to the maritime transport of dangerous and harmful substances loaded on board that ship. The HNS Convention aims to ensure accountability and adequate, prompt and effective loss compensation. Neither the 1996 HNS Convention nor the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention entered into force. This report considers that it is in the interest of the Union as a whole to have a harmonised liability regime measurable for environmental damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful goods by sea, which can only be achieved if parliament's recommendations are adequately considered by the Council and the Commission.  I believe that a more appropriate international regime than regional solutions is more appropriate to solve this issue. Therefore, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Unlike another vote today on the ratification of the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Dangerous and Nosalysed Substances, this vote referred specifically to aspects of judicial cooperation in civil matters. Active transnational cooperation on such issues is of principle importance, as the environment is often polluted in the territories of several countries, which requires effective cooperation. In view of the above and the importance of the issue under consideration, I have unequivocally voted positively.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council Decision on the ratification and accession of The Member States, in the interests of the European Union, to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Civil Liability and Compensation for Damage in relation to the Maritime Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Substances, with the exception of aspects of judicial cooperation in civil matters, because it is complete and documented.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the ratification and accession to the 2010 Protocol to the Convention on Dangerous and Harmful Substances with regard to aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. That convention establishes the objective liability of the owner of a ship carrying substances which are harmful or dangerous, where damage is caused by this transport, and a special compensation fund is established to compensate anyone who has suffered damage from the transport of such harmful substances. It is in the interests of the European Union to have a system of uniform liability for environmental damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances at sea.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. My support for the proposal for ratification of the 2010 Protocol on the Convention on Harmful and Hazardous Substances and Accession to the Convention on Harmful and Hazardous Substances with regard to Matters Related to Judicial Cooperation in Civil Matters.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 2010 Protocol on the International Convention on Civil Liability and Compensation in relation to the Carriage of Dangerous and Harmful Substances by Sea requires ratification by Member States separately on behalf of the EU. The original international convention on this subject was signed in 1996 and regulates issues of objective liability and compensation for damage caused by harmful substances such as liquefied natural gas and LPG. This objective responsibility concerns the shipowner carrying the dangerous substance. There is also mention of the establishment of a special compensation fund for payment to any person who has suffered damage from the sea transport of ESOs. Given that shipping is an international business with cross-border implications, an international regime and not only a European one, which is uniformly applicable, should be ensured so that the response to such accidents is more effective but also fairer. I would like to vote in favour of this resolution in order to move in this direction.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is about the ratification of the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage caused by the Transport of Harmful and Dangerous Substances at Sea. The rapporteur points out the remaining overlaps between the UHRL and the HNS Convention in order to achieve a positive outcome. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the report as it seeks to ensure that there is a strict responsibility for the owner of a ship carrying dangerous and harmful substances for damage caused by an incident involving the carriage of hazardous and noxious substances by sea on that ship.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The purpose of the report is to authorize the ratification of the 2010 Protocol on the International Convention on Harmful and Potentially Dangerous Substances. This is the part of the issue of judicial cooperation in civil matters. The conclusion of the 2010 protocol to the HNS Convention will ensure a uniform application of the rules on liability and reparation in the event of accidents caused by vessels carrying such substances at sea throughout the Union. It will also ensure the availability of sufficient funds for compensation for victims of such accidents. The report calls for dialogue with the Council and the Commission to build a coherent European policy in the area of liability and compensation for environmental damage resulting from the transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances at sea. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Given the global nature of the maritime freight activity and the uniqueness of maritime areas, a comprehensive approach is preferable. Moreover, it has the merit of taking this issue away from the Union's legislative arsenal. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the progress report on the draft Council decision on the ratification and adoption of the Member States, in the interest of the Union, to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for damage resulting from the carriage of harmful dangerous substances by sea with regard to aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters. As stated by the rapporteur, the aim of the 2010 HNS Convention is to ensure accountability and to provide adequate, rapid and effective compensation for losses or damage caused to persons, property and the environment resulting from the transport of harmful and dangerous substances by sea, ensuring uniform application of liability and compensation rules in the event of accidents within the EU. It will also ensure the availability of sufficient funds to compensate victims of such accidents.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as there is a need for uniform legislature on both compensation and legal procedures in cases related to damage caused by the misuse or mishandling of potentially dangerous substances. This report establishes a uniform regime for judicial procedure and compensation for cases relating to parties liable for damage from pollution.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – The 2010 HNS Convention lays down rules on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments. Its scope therefore overlaps with those set out in the recast Brussels I Regulation. , as well as the anticipated legal and practical difficulties in applying a separate regime of competence within the Union compared to that applied to other parties to the HNS Convention , a derogation from the general application of the recast Brussels I Regulation is justified. Given the significant share that cargoes of hazardous and noxious substances represent in maritime freight transport, the global nature of the shipping sector, as well as the cross-border impact likely to be caused by accidents with cargoes of hazardous and noxious substances, I believe that it is in the Union's interest to establish the most effective way without undermining the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of common RULES of EU law and without undue differences for victims of pollution and the shipping sector. In view of the above, this proposal has my support.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council submitted a draft decision on the strengthening and accession of the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Substances by Sea by the Member States in the interests of the European Union, with regard to aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. In order to adopt the decision, it must obtain parliament's consent.  In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs makes a series of recommendations and recommends that Parliament take a position that this interim report would be an additional opportunity for the Council and the Commission to address these recommendations. It therefore recommends that Parliament ask the Council and the Commission to conduct further negotiations, taking into account the recommendations. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The International Convention on liability and compensation for damage resulting from the carriage by sea of harmful and potentially dangerous substances (HNS Convention 2010) aims to ensure accountability and to provide appropriate, rapid and effective compensation for losses or damage caused to persons, property and the environment resulting from the carriage of harmful and dangerous substances by sea , by the specific international compensation fund HNS. I endorse the rapporteur's position on the relevance of an exception to the general rule of application of the recast Brussels I Regulation, taking into account the very specific nature of the regime of jurisdiction of the HNS Convention, as well as due to the foreseeable legal and practical difficulties linked to the application in the Union of a separate jurisdiction regime, by virtue of an exception to the general application of the HNS Convention. I believe that this progress report aims to ensure that a uniform liability regime is implemented in the most efficient and fair manner possible, without prejudice to the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of common rules of Union law and without creating an excessive disparity in the treatment of victims of pollution and the maritime transport sector.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Given the global nature of the maritime freight activity, the uniqueness of maritime areas, a comprehensive approach is preferable to the regional one. I vote for this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to give consent to the form the negotiations should take on this protocol.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which looks at adherence to a protocol, with regard to the provisions relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters, relating to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages Related to the Sea Transport of Harmful and Potentially Dangerous Substances. This is a report which analyses the legal basis that the European Union could use if it decided to adhere to this protocol.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The HNS Convention also known as The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage in Connection with the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by Sea was set-up in 1996. I have voted for this interim report that aims to ensure that the establishment of a uniform liability regime, with regard to aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters, is done in the most effective and fair fashion.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This was a single vote on an interim report calling for dialogue between this EU institutions to coordinate a compensation scheme for victims of hazardous and noxious substance spilling at sea. It seeks to protect coastal communities and fishing communities beyond the liability limits of the ship owner which is an important development. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report deals with compensation for damage caused by the transport of harmful and dangerous substances at sea. The report also highlights the need for the Council and the Commission to make recommendations on the remaining overlap between UHRL and the HNS Convention. As this will have a positive result, I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Convention governs the taking of liability for ships carrying dangerous and harmful substances and compensation for injured parties in the event of accidents.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Due to the numerous cargoes of dangerous and harmful substances in maritime freight transport, the global nature of the shipbuilding sector and the possible cross-border impact of cargo accidents, I believe it is essential for the EU to have a uniform system of liability. I support my colleague's interim report, which is aimed at establishing a dialogue with the Commission and the Council, and I am therefore voting in favour of it.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages relating to the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Goods (HNS Convention) by Sea in 1996 and amended in 2010 is the last of a series of International Maritime Organisation (IMO) conventions relating to the liability and compensation of damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances by sea.  The liability and compensation of damages arising from ship transport activities are governed internationally by a series of IMO conventions that rely on the strict liability of ship-owned ships, mandatory insurance to cover damages incurred by third parties, the right of injured parties to claim damages directly from insurers, limitation of liability and, in the case of oil and hazardous and harmful substances, the use of a special compensation fund from which damages are paid if those damages exceed the ship's liability limits. The objective of the proposed Council Decision is linked to the Danish exemption from the application of the aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters, which are enshrined in the proposal for a Protocol.  For this reason, I supported this Decision.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Given the global nature of the maritime freight activity, the uniqueness of maritime areas, a comprehensive approach is preferable to the regional one. I vote for this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I call on the Council and the Commission to consider the following recommendations: A) to ensure that the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of the Common Rules of the Union will not be adversely affected by the international commitments made by ratifying the Convention or joining the Convention, in accordance with the court's established case law; B) to take more account in this regard of the overlapping of the recast Brussels I Regulation and the Convention in the part relating to the procedural rules applicable to the requirements and actions under that Convention before the courts of the States Parties; C) to ensure that the possibility of conflict between the Environmental Liability Directive and the Convention is minimised by taking appropriate measures, to ensure that Member States ratifying or joining the Convention will fully comply with the exclusant clause referred to in Article 7(4) and 5 prohibiting the lodging of any claim for damages from ship-owned persons other than that of the Convention in question. I agree with the rapporteur, Mr Pavel Svoboda, who concludes that this interim report will provide the Council and the Commission with an additional opportunity to consider the recommendations made.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this interim report on a draft Council decision on the ratification and accession of the European Union to a protocol on the International Convention on Responsibility and Compensation for Damages Related to the Sea Transport of Harmful and Potentially Dangerous Substances.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, bearing in mind that it is important to ensure that the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of the COMMON EU rules will not be adversely affected by the international commitments made for ratification or membership of the 2010 HNS Convention.  It aims to minimise the possibility of divergence between the DRA and the 2010 HNS Convention and also to ensure the elimination of the permanent coexistence of two maritime liability schemes (one at Union and one at international level), which would lead in particular to the fragmentation of Union legislation. Moreover, it would clearly undermine the determination of responsibilities and could lead to lengthy and costly legal proceedings to the detriment of victims and the maritime transport sector.  In this context, member states should be guaranteed the obligation to take all necessary measures to achieve a concrete result, that is, ratify or accede to the 2010 HNS Convention within a reasonable period, which shall not exceed two years from the date of entry into force of the Council decision.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages in Connection with the Maritime Transport of Harmful and Potentially Hazardous Substances is a key legal instrument in terms of transport and the environment. The ratification of the 2010 Protocol, which practically represents the ratification of the above-2010 Convention, is relevant to the EU because it provides enhanced protection for those affected by maritime transport of dangerous substances.  In its December 2015 decision, the Council releases Member States to decide when each will carry out ratification. This possibility could lead to legal uncertainty because of differences in the applicable rule. In addition, some of the provisions overlap with the Environmental Responsibility Directive 2004/35/EC, which could lead to confusion as to the legal basis for claims.  With this interim report, which I voted in favour of, Parliament intends to press the Council to correct its decision by calling for a uniform ratification of the Convention and thus clarifying its implementation.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages Related to the Sea Transport of Harmful and Potentially Dangerous Substances (1996 HNS Convention) aims to ensure adequate, prompt and effective compensation for those who are victims of damage from spills of harmful and potentially dangerous substances while transporting them by sea. This 1996 HNS Convention was amended by the 2010 Protocol and provides for improved protection for victims of damage related to the sea transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the request for a more in-depth debate on this issue with the Commission and the Council is a good thing.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
