text: Writing. \u2012 While the 2010 HNS Convention addresses an important task of ensuring accountability and adequate, rapid and effective compensation for damage or damage caused by the transport of hazardous and noxious substances by sea through a specialised International HNS Compensation Fund in accordance with the polluter pays principle, it may conflict with the provisions of the Directive on environmental liability that this Directive "does not apply to environmental damage or to the imminent threat of such damage to the environment". , caused by an event the liability or compensation of which is governed by the international conventions listed in Annex IV, as well as their future amendments in force in that Member State'. This report is therefore essential in EU law to define the limits of liability of shipowners and operators and their participation in civil matters. The document itself is really well drawn up and that is why I support it.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has received a letter with a view to approving the draft Council decision on the ratification and adoption of Member States on behalf of the Union to the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention (International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage resulting from the carriage by sea of harmful and potentially dangerous substances), with the exception of aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters. However, the European Parliament has chosen to carry out an interim report with a view to requesting further discussion on this matter with the Commission and the Council. In fact, this interim report, which received my vote in favour, is based on the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs (which determines the legal basis on which the future report should be based), and aims to ensure the possible coexistence of two maritime liability schemes and to ensure the uniformity, integrity and effectiveness of the EU's common rules on this matter (with a broader scope) , if the HNS Convention were ratified by the Member States. In fact, there is a risk of the HNS Convention being overjustifiable in relation to European provisions on environmental liability, in particular as regards its scope, environmental damage and preventive measures to minimise them.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the ratification and accession to the 2010 Protocol to the Convention on Dangerous and Noxious Substances and liability for damage caused by the transport of these substances by sea. I am in favour of the adoption of a uniform liability regime applicable to environmental damage caused by the transport of these substances. Harmonisation of legislation in this area can only have positive effects.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this text, considering the urgent ratification of a Protocol, the effective implementation of which by the Member States, will entail greater security against the human and environmental risks caused by such substances.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. Denmark is covered by the opt-out in this area. Nevertheless, I support the EU's ratification of the Convention, as it has already been ratified in Danish law.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to give Parliament's consent to the Council to adopt the 2010 Protocol on the Convention on Harmful and Dangerous Substances Relating to the Maritime Transport of Harmful and Potentially Hazardous Substances, in this case as regards matters relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters. Since regional bodies cannot do so, it is up to the Member States to join. I voted in favour of this report, since it proposes to ensure the assumption of responsibilities and the payment of adequate, timely and effective compensation for loss or damage caused to persons, property or the environment as a result of the maritime transport of harmful and potentially dangerous substances through the SNP Specialised International Compensation Fund.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1996 HNS (Dangerous Harmful Substances) Convention is the latest of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) conventions dealing with liability for damage caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances by sea that has not yet been ratified. The 2010 protocol also sought to ensure adequate, rapid and effective compensation to ensure that accident victims can benefit from clear procedural rules so as to speed up their claims before the courts. Parliament has made recommendations to the Council and the Commission on the uniform application of liability and compensation rules in relation to accidents caused by ships carrying harmful and dangerous material. It also calls for the obligation for all Member States to ratify the 2010 HNS Convention as soon as possible. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I want to see the swift ratification of this protocol, but the Council of the EU needs to reconsider its position and should see that it is not beneficial to create a legal uncertainty and divisions between legal regimes in Member States on an issue that has so many cross-border implications.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I think it is important that a special compensation fund has been set up under this Convention to pay compensation to persons who have suffered damage in connection with the transport of hazardous and noxious substances at sea and who have failed to obtain full or adequate compensation from the shipowner or his insurer. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Close cooperation between member states' judicial authorities is important in controlling the production, movement and storage of hazardous substances.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The International Convention on Dangerous and Harmful Substances establishes the strict liability of the shipowner transporting dangerous and harmful substances for any form of damage caused by an incident related to the maritime transport of dangerous and harmful substances loaded aboard that ship.  There are limited exemptions from the strict liability of the owner which is accompanied by the obligation of the owner to be insured or obtain another financial guarantee due to the insurance against possible liability for damages. Furthermore, a special compensation fund has been established, the role of which is to compensate all persons who suffer damages related to the transport of dangerous and harmful goods by sea in the event that those persons could not receive full and adequate compensation from the shipper and its insurer.  I support this report because I think it is important that uniform, holistic and effective common rules are created without creating excessive differences for pollution victims (i.e. coastal communities, fishermen, etc.) and the maritime transport sector.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this resolution.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damages related to the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Goods by Sea (1996 HNS Convention), as well as the 2010 HNS Protocol, are the latest in a series of International Maritime Organisation conventions relating to the liability and compensation of damages caused by the transport of dangerous and harmful substances by sea that have not yet entered into force.  In Chapter IV. 2010 HNS Convention the rules on the jurisdiction of courts and the recognition and enforcement of judgments, which overlap with the rules of the Brussels Regulation I. The HNS Convention contains a restrictive jurisdictional regime, contrary to several grounds of jurisdiction available in the Brussels I Regulation. the EU. This will ensure that sufficient funds are available to compensate victims of such accidents. I support this report, as I believe that for the uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships transporting dangerous and harmful substances by sea across the EU, the international regime is more appropriate than regional solutions.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the interim report on the draft Council decision on ratification and accession to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage related to the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by Sea by Member States in the interest of the European Union with regard to aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters. I support the call on the Council and the Commission to ensure that international matters arising from the ratification of or accession to the HNS Convention of 2010 do not adversely affect the unity, integrity and effectiveness of the common Union rules, in accordance with the court's settled case-law.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 There should be common laws and regulations between states on such a serious issue concerning the transport of harmful materials by sea. There should also be no other rules that would lighten the position of the person responsible for a disaster.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea is the last of the International Maritime Organisation Conventions on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea, which has not yet been ratified. The IMO adopted – and amended by the HNS Protocol of 2010 – this international agreement to complement the system of conventions on maritime liability with a specific agreement. Neither the HNS Convention of 1996 nor the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention entered into force. The highly specific nature of the system of jurisdiction of the HNS Convention, stemming from efforts to prevent the practice of forum shopping, and the legal and practical difficulties arising from the application of a different jurisdictional system to the Union and other parties to the HNS Convention justify an exception to the general application of the revised Brussels I Regulation. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol will ensure uniform application across the EU of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and harmful substances by sea. This interim report is a step towards the EP initiating a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to replace the current fragmented system with legislation at international level. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the interim report, which makes recommendations to the Council and the Commission on aspects relating to judicial cooperation in civil matters in the context of the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for the Transport of Hazardous and Harmful Substances by Sea. I agree with the report that the conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention will ensure uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation for accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and harmful substances by sea, and will also ensure that sufficient resources are available to compensate victims of such accidents. Therefore, instead of regional solutions, an international system is better suited to ensure uniform application of the relevant rules throughout the EU, if only because shipping is a global business with a cross-border impact. I believe that the recommendations made by the interim report concerning the Brussels I Regulation will help to ensure that a single system of responsibility is developed in the most efficient and appropriate way possible.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The conclusion of the 2010 protocol to the SNPD Convention will ensure a uniform application of the rules on liability and reparation in the event of accidents caused by vessels carrying harmful and potentially dangerous substances at sea throughout the European Union. It will also ensure the availability of sufficient funds for compensation for victims of such accidents. We therefore believe that, in order to ensure uniform enforcement of the rules on liability and reparation in the event of accidents caused by vessels carrying harmful and potentially dangerous substances at sea throughout the Union, an international regime is better suited than regional solutions given the global nature of the maritime sector and its cross-border implications.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the ratification and accession of EU members to the 2010 Protocol to the Hazardous and Noxious Substances (HNS) Convention. This convention ensures uniform application of rules on liability and compensation in connection with accidents caused by ships carrying HNS at sea across the EU, and ensures availability of sufficient funds for compensation of victims of such accidents. Considering the nature of shipping as a global business with a cross-boundary impact, I do believe that an international regime rather than regional solutions is better suited to tackle this type of challenge. This protocol would also be an opportunity to frame a coherent policy at EU level.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Ratification and Accession Report of the 2010 Protocol with the International Convention on Dangerous and Harmful Substances in relation to aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters. The International Convention on The Liability and Compensation of Damages related to the Transport of Dangerous and Harmful Goods by Sea (HNS) of 2010 establishes strict liability of the owner of the ship transporting dangerous and harmful goods, in case of any damage caused by an incident related to the transport of dangerous and harmful substances by sea and boat.  I believe that the PROTOCOL of the HNS Convention will ensure the uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation in relation to accidents caused by ships carrying dangerous and harmful substances. I would also point out that sufficient funds will be provided to compensate victims of such accidents.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Interim report on the draft Council decision on ratification and accession to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage related to the Carriage of Dangerous and Noxious Substances by Sea by Member States in the interest of the European Union on aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters. The 2010 Convention establishes the objective liability of the shipowner transporting dangerous and noxious substances for damage resulting from an incident related to the transport of dangerous and noxious substances by sea on board that ship. It is important to set up a specialised compensation fund of around EUR 310 million to compensate persons who have suffered damage in connection with the transport of dangerous substances. International regulation in this area is more appropriate than regional. The conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention will ensure uniform application of the rules on liability and compensation for damage caused by ships carrying dangerous and noxious substances by sea in the European Union. It is in the interest of the European Union to have a single liability regime for environmental damage.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this text, considering the urgent ratification of a Protocol, the effective implementation of which by the Member States, will entail greater security against the human and environmental risks caused by such substances.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The report believes that, in order to ensure consistent enforcement of the rules on liability and repair of such accidents, an international regime is better suited than regional solutions given the global nature of the maritime sector and its cross-border implications. This legal framework should apply to the whole of the Union, which will therefore have a homogeneous legal regime for this specific responsibility. Nevertheless, the rapporteur wants to start a dialogue with the Council and the Commission with a view to building a coherent European policy in this area. Given the global nature of the maritime freight activity and the uniqueness of maritime areas, a comprehensive approach is preferable. Moreover, it has the merit of taking this issue away from the Union's legislative arsenal. I'm voting FOR.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The rapporteur for the report intends to initiate a dialogue with the Council and the Commission in order to develop a coherent EU policy on liability and compensation for environmental damage resulting from the transport of hazardous and harmful substances at sea. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this text, considering the urgent ratification of a Protocol, the effective implementation of which by the Member States, will entail greater security against the human and environmental risks caused by such substances.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Interim Report on the draft Council decision on the ratification and accession by Member States, in the interest of the European Union, to the Protocol of 2010 to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage in Connection with the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by Sea, with regard to the aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters. The 2010 HNS Convention establishes strict liability of the owner of the ship carrying HNS for any damage resulting from an incident in connection with the carriage of HNS by sea and on board that ship. I believe that the conclusion of the 2010 Protocol to the HNS Convention will ensure uniform application of rules on liability and compensation in connection with accidents caused by ships carrying HNS at sea across the EU. It will also guarantee availability of sufficient funds for compensation of victims of such accidents.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1996 International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage resulting from the carriage of hazardous and harmful substances by sea is the last of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) conventions governing liability and compensation for damage resulting from the carriage of hazardous and harmful substances by sea, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) which has not yet been ratified.  It is considered to be in the interest of the whole Union to have a homogeneous liability regime applicable to environmental damage caused by the transport of HNS by sea, which can only be achieved if Parliament's recommendations are duly taken into account by the Council and the Commission. However, greater attention should be paid in this context to the overlaps between the recast Brussels I Regulation and the 2010 HNS Convention and to ensure that the possibility of divergence between the DRA and the 2010 HNS Convention is minimised.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In general, it is a question of ratifying the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage caused by the transport of harmful and dangerous substances at sea. The interim report makes it clear that it is not appropriate for Parliament to give its consent before ensuring the unity, integrity and effectiveness of Union law and the fundamental principle of the EU's limited individual authorisation. The report also shows that the Council and the Commission need to make recommendations on the remaining overlap between the UHRL and the HNS Convention in order to achieve a positive outcome.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the interim report on the draft Council decision on ratification and accession to the 2010 Protocol to the International Convention on Liability and Compensation for Damage related to the Carriage of Hazardous and Noxious Substances by Sea by Member States in the interest of the European Union in relation to aspects related to judicial cooperation in civil matters. I support the purpose of the Convention, which establishes, inter alia, the objective liability of the shipowner for any damage caused by the transport of hazardous and noxious substances by sea under the Convention, and the obligation on the owner to take out insurance or obtain other financial security to cover his liability for damages under the Convention.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr I wanted to say that the aim of the vote was to support the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Philippines in order to take account of Croatia's accession to the Union as early as 2013. I would like to add that almost three years have passed since Croatia's accession to the European Union, but there are still many agreements, many international texts, which have not yet been amended in the light of the Territorial Changes of the Community. And, of course, hopefully everything will be properly modernised in the near future, so that it is possible to involve Croatia fully in the implementation of the issues raised in these agreements, because as than Croatia is our Member State, our member in the European family, and, of course, I voted in favour.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would just like to say that I wanted to speak on the following point, which also concerns the Philippines, and that is where the trade strategy is concerned, but I dare say that if this point is also called the Philippines and cooperation with the European Union, albeit with regard to croatia's accession, then perhaps this point will also bear my speech. I supported both of the two recommendations on the grounds that the Philippines and Southeast Asia in general are a very strategic region for the European Union. A region that is developing and that needs our help. Precisely so as not to bring about various violent extremist formations of a primarily Islamic nature, which undermine the public administration there. I think that we should give public authorities in the Philippines support, although after the election of a new president we might have to wait a while to see how it manifests itself.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the adoption of this framework agreement between the EU and the Philippines, because the EU's cooperation and cooperation agreements with third countries are the antechamber of a free trade agreement, which we oppose because of its negative effects on the working class of the countries concerned. Moreover, such trade agreements pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. The amendments tabled by our GUE/NGL group on the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region, the crackdown on left-wing activists and politicians, extrajudicial killings and our concerns about how this economic agreement will harm the local population were all rejected, so I have no doubt voting against this agreement.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to update the framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the European Union and the Philippines.  While the rapporteur gives a fairly realistic description of the situation in the Philippines, the comments on tensions in the South China Sea and maritime clashes in Asia appear to us to be unwelcome.  I therefore voted against this text because, let us remember, foreign policy is the exclusive act of States and the European Union does not have to claim an international role, however small.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report was a technical acknowledgement of Croatia’s accession to the EU. I abstained on this voted as I have concerns regarding the agreement between the EU and the Philippines. However, I am in favour of the full accession of Croatia to the EU, so therefore, with these concerns in mind, I abstained on the final vote.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this recommendation. This is an important step for a major partner in the region for the EU. In this text, our group has insisted on social and environmental rights, as well as provisions guaranteeing fair trade.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This text updates the agreements between the EU and the Philippines. Although the descriptive part of the report is relatively accurate with respect to the situation in the Philippines, comments on the situation in the China Sea and ongoing clashes in Asia are irrelevant. On the other hand, it should be remembered that foreign policy must remain the exclusive responsibility of States. That is why I objected to this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I voted against this report. I do not believe it is in the interest of the British people that the European Union is negotiating any framework with the Philippines on regards to the accession of Croatia.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal by which the EP supports the signing of a Protocol To the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, which takes account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is an update of the agreements between the EU and the Philippines; while the descriptive part of the report is honest about the situation in the Philippines, the comments on the situation in the China Sea and the ongoing maritime clashes in Asia are completely irrelevant.  Moreover, it should be remembered about this report and the Commission's similar initiatives that foreign policy is the exclusive act of the Member States and that the EU does not have to give itself an international role, however small. I voted against this abusive claim from Brussels.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which approves the protocol to take into account Croatia's accession to the Union in the framework agreement between the Philippines and the Union.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Brok report approving the protocol to the EU-Philippines agreement allowing Croatia to join it. This is an important act that allows Croatia to become part of the framework agreement with the Asian country whose initial draft dates back to 2010, that is, three years before Croatia's accession to the Union.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this own-initiative report which did not include any amendments that our group tabled, the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region and the joint US-Philippine maneuvers, the repression of civil society activists and members of left-wing parties, the proper implementation of the Human Rights Conventions in the country and the existence of extra-judicial killings by state security forces and paramilitary forces. While some of these elements are underpinned in the final text, it is at the end of an instrument that seeks to move towards the signing of an EU-Philippine Free Trade Agreement, which, like the other types of instruments in the process of negotiating with other countries since the Doha paralysis, has a double-sided : on the one hand the promise of new trade opportunities, accompany and secure its reform processes and on the other hand, the risks that trade liberalization between economies with very different levels of development pose to the weakest part.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I support this recommendation as consistent with existing Community law in order to adapt this Agreement to Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This Recommendation relates to an EU-Philippines Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU and is a simple update of EU-Philippine agreements. While the descriptive part of the substantive report is honest about the situation in the Philippines, the comments on the situation in the China Sea and the ongoing maritime clashes in Asia seem ridiculous to us. However, the EU does not have to claim an international role as it is trying to do, since foreign policy is still entirely a matter for states alone. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the measure is purely technical and is necessary as an adjustment after Croatia's accession to the EU, I believe that there are unclear and not fully acceptable passages in it and I have therefore abstained.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the report. I do so simply because it is a logical consequence of Croatia's accession to the European Union; the country shall also be acceded to this framework agreement. This vote is not about the framework agreement itself, but about the consequence of Croatia's accession to the EU. That is why I voted in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of incorporating Croatia, as a newly integrated Member State into the EU, into the Framework Agreement on Collaboration and Cooperation maintained by the Republic of the Philippines and the EU since 2010, now updated.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, which takes account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. It is a legal technical document aimed at incorporating croatia recently acceded to existing EU international agreements.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. If the descriptive part of the substantive report is honest about the situation in the Philippines, the comments on the situation in the China Sea and the ongoing maritime clashes in Asia seem ridiculous to me.  I would like to point out that foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and that the EU does not have to claim an international role, however small.   Also, I voted against that recommendation.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report was a technical acknowledgment of Croatia’s accession to the EU. I abstained on this voted as I have concerns regarding the agreement between the EU and the Philippines. However, I am in favour of the full accession of Croatia to the EU, so therefore, with these concerns in mind, I abstained on the final vote.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is right that the Republic of Croatia, now that it is fully part of the EU, should also participate in the global partnership and/or cooperation agreements that the EU signs with foreign states. We consider this to be a due act.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to update the framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the European Union and the Philippines. While the rapporteur gives a fairly realistic description of the situation in the Philippines, the comments on tensions in the South China Sea and maritime clashes in Asia appear to us to be unwelcome. As a sovereign state, the Republic of the Philippines does not have to meet the Union's requirements for compliance with international conventions. It should also be remembered that foreign policy is an exclusive competence of the Member States and that the European Union cannot claim an international role. As usual, the Union wishes to grant itself prerogatives that are not its own. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU-Philippines Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation (Croatia's accession). because I believe that cooperation for the EU Member States is very beneficial from an economic, political and cultural point of view, but also for the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU. Thus, taking into account the draft Council decision and the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, a common denominator was reached. Thus, it remains only the task of the President to transmit their position to Parliament, the Council and the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Republic of the Philippines.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the favourable vote on this recommendation, Croatia was also included in the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines. This is because Croatia joined the Union in 2014 and the draft framework agreement dates back to 2010. The Philippines has made considerable progress in the field of human rights in recent years, but it is necessary to continue to encourage the country to continue along this path. On the basis of the agreement reached, the EU will continue to provide financial support and assistance to the Philippines for poverty reduction, social inclusion and the promotion of peace. The recommendation calls on the Republic of the Philippines to continue to improve investment conditions by increasing transparency and good governance, implementing the UN guiding principles on business and human rights and further developing infrastructure, where appropriate, through public-private partnerships.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report was a technical acknowledgement of Croatia’s accession to the EU. I abstained on this voted as I have concerns regarding the agreement between the EU and the Philippines. However, I am in favour of the full accession of Croatia to the EU, so therefore, with these concerns in mind, I abstained on the final vote.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to conclusion of this protocol because Croatia should participate in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between EU and the Philippines as soon as possible. Croatia, just as all other Member States, will benefit a lot from this coordinated relationship with the Philippines.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the Philippines needs EU support to address the many challenges and emergencies they face, I voted in favour of the possibility of the EU constraining a partnership agreement with that country.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the Protocol, which includes the Republic of Croatia as a Contracting Party to the EU-Philippine Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, since in accordance with its Act of Accession Croatia undertakes to accede to international agreements signed or concluded by the European Union and its Member States by concluding a Protocol to these agreements.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Recommendation on the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, is part of the wider effort to develop Europe's relations with that State. I believe that we should support the development of these relations, since it could have positive effects on security, the economy and policy. In this respect, however, we see pressure being exerted on issues of surveillance and a strong military presence in the wider Philippines region, which I am opposed to. That is why I have decided to abstain from all aspects of the vote on this recommendation.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal as it only represents the extension to Croatia of the agreement between the European Union and its Member States with the Philippines. I believe that Croatia, which has joined the European Union, should take part, like the other Member States, in this agreement.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Under this proposal, the Council is called upon to adopt a decision aiming to approve the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Philippines, of the other part, to take account of the accession of Croatia to the European Union on behalf of the European Union and its Member States. The proposed Protocol incorporates Croatia as contracting party to the Agreement and commits the EU to providing the authentic version of the Agreement in the Croatian language.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of approving the protocol to the Convention allowing Croatia access as an integral part of the agreement, as a natural consequence of Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States and the Republic of the Philippines will take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. I agree with the scope and the proposal to forward its position to the Council, the Commission and the governments and parliaments of the Member States and of the Republic of the Philippines for approval.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the adoption of this framework agreement between the EU and the Philippines, because the EU's cooperation and cooperation agreements with third countries are the antechamber of a free trade agreement, which we oppose because of its negative effects on the working class of the countries concerned. Moreover, such trade agreements pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. The amendments tabled by our GUE/NGL group on the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region, the crackdown on left-wing activists and politicians, extrajudicial killings and our concerns about how this economic agreement will harm the local population were all rejected, so I have no doubt voting against this agreement.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since obtaining the SPG+ status in December 2014, the Republic of the Philippines has been able to export more than 65% of its products to Europe without tariff barriers, with Member States and the European Union being the main trading partners and investors in the Philippines. I believe that this status, together with the funds allocated by the Union to development cooperation, contributes positively to strengthening democracy in the Republic of the Philippines and its neighbourhood. I would therefore like to encourage the Republic of the Philippines to continue its efforts to effectively implement its human and workers' rights, environmental and good governance obligations and commitments in order to continue to benefit from this status. I voted in favour of this report for the conclusion of an Additional Protocol allowing the Republic of Croatia to become part of the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other, signed in Phnom Phen before Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In view of the request for consent submitted by the Council under Article 207 and 209 and Article 218(6)(6)(a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, as well as the draft Council Decision and the recommendations of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, I fully agree with the protocol submitted to the Agreement, which is intended to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote deals with the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement between the EU and the Republic of the Philippines, specifically in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. This is a procedural vote and hence I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the conclusion of the Protocol of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines. This protocol includes Croatia as a contracting party in the framework agreement since the framework agreement was signed in 2012, when Croatia had not yet joined the European Union.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The text submitted to the vote consists of an update of the agreements between the EU and the Philippines. While the descriptive part of the substantive report is realistic about the situation in the Philippines, comments on the context in the China Sea and on ongoing maritime clashes in Asia are not serious. To the extent that foreign policy is a competence of the States and the European Union does not have to claim to play an international role in this area, I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which is only technical and takes into account Croatia's accession to the EU. Furthermore, I believe that this framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the EU and the Philippines is an important step and strengthens long-standing relations. The agreement must further be ratified by all EU Member States in order to enter into force and produce the desired result.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU in its classic way and method and through various trick attempts to create problems in Member States with various agreements with third countries.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: it should be remembered that foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and that the EU does not have to claim an international role, however small.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation refers to the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU, of the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and the Philippines, to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU in the agreement. A mere formality, therefore. The reasons for the vote are therefore identical to those put forward for the vote on the agreement itself. The reasons for this agreement are put forward in the legislative resolution which is appropriate démins. A resolution which addresses several aspects which show, as a whole, that this agreement is inseparable from an imprint of geopolitical interests, part of a global policy of siege of China. As for economic aspects, the EU is one of the main foreign investors in the country, as well as one of the main trading partners. The EU, for its part, is the fourth largest market for the Philippines, accounting for 12% of exports. The Framework Partnership Agreement is a first step towards the Free Trade Agreement, deepening a path already started. Some of the effects of trade deregulation and liberalisation are already felt, particularly on the European canning industry. This liberalisation has primarily benefited US companies that have settled in the Philippines and export to Europe, exploiting cheap labour without local rights. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are many reasons why Europe must continue to provide support and assistance to the Philippines for the development of its potential. The EU has a major role to play in promoting peace, security, judicial reform and assisting the Philippines in frequent natural disasters. At the same time, the Philippines is very active in the functioning of an international coalition against terrorism.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained. No opinion.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the EU-Philippine Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement (Accession of Croatia). The EU in its classic way and method and through various tycies is trying to create problems in Member States with various agreements with third countries.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU - Philippines Framework Agreement represents, in my opinion, an important step with regard to a major partner in the region for the EU. We must continue insisting on respect for Human Rights, labour, social, environmental rights, as well as on their effective monitoring, and on provisions guaranteeing fair trade. Trade, geo-strategic and security issues are very important considering the delicate regional situation, given China’s increasing assertiveness and territorial claims, maritime security and potential terrorism concerns. I am very concerned about the South China Sea issue and the risk of conflict faced with Chinese assertiveness. Therefore, I support the call on the Vice President/High Representative to identify how the EU should best engage in bilateral and multilateral security cooperation. Finally, I believe we must call for an effective implementation of the UN guiding principles regarding business and human rights.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the intentionality of the Republic of Croatia to accede immediately to all protocols of the European Union quickly. The accession process has been a fundamental principle for European development and this Member welcomes the continued steps of the Republic of Croatia in this regard.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. International agreements concluded by the EU on behalf of its Member States must apply equally to all. I therefore support Croatia's accession to this agreement and the corresponding update.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Croatia will be included as a party to the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States and the Republic of the Philippines.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this own-initiative report which did not include any amendments that our group tabled, the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region and the joint US-Philippine maneuvers, the repression of civil society activists and members of left-wing parties, the proper implementation of the Human Rights Conventions in the country and the existence of extra-judicial killings by state security forces and paramilitary forces. While some of these elements are underpinned in the final text, it is at the end of an instrument that seeks to move towards the signing of an EU-Philippine Free Trade Agreement, which, like the other types of instruments in the process of negotiating with other countries since the Doha paralysis, has a double-sided : on the one hand the promise of new trade opportunities, accompany and secure its reform processes and on the other hand, the risks that trade liberalization between economies with very different levels of development pose to the weakest part.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which is the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation with the Philippines. It express concerns about the potential spread of ISIS in South East Asia but encourages the Philippine government to continue fostering further progress in the elimination of corruption and the promotion of human rights.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The agreement on partnership and cooperation strengthens bilateral relations between two parties. Philippines is an important economic partner for the EU. Also, the EU will help Philippines to improve the path towards greater democracy and respect of fundamental human rights.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report analyses EU-Philippine relations. While its purpose is to approve a cooperation agreement, the report also refers to a possible free trade agreement with all the countries of south-east Asia, and this is problematic for us. He refers to tensions in the South China Sea by calling on China to stop its aggression, but any criticism of the joint Philippine-US exercises is absent. In view of the above, we have abstained in all 3 reports on the EU-Philippine cooperation agreement, regardless of whether this particular one is technical and simply refers to Croatia's accession to the agreement.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Recommendation on the EU-Philippines Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation in order to take account of the accession of Croatia into the European Union. I already supported the Parliament’s non-legislative resolution which we voted on earlier today as well as the legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and the Philippines where we have also voted earlier today.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion as it aids the incorporation of Croatia within the EU as a full member of the community.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Agreement—framework for partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Decision of the Council on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, as this gives consent for the conclusion of the agreement.  It is a process of a technical nature, i.e. that the necessary legal steps are taken to enable Croatia to participate in the Agreement, which naturally stems from its accession to the EU. The European Union is one of the main investors and the Philippines' fourth largest trading partners, and accordingly, development cooperation funds with the country have also increased. Taking into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the Union is certainly necessary, and therefore I support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. It should be remembered that foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and that the EU does not have to claim an international role, however small. I naturally voted against these three texts.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union on the framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the Union and the Republic of the Philippines.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report concerns the framework agreement between the European Union and the Philippines on partnership and cooperation on the occasion of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. This is an adjustment of the framework agreement, which is why I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it is simply a technical file to adapt the Additional Protocol to the Agreement taking into account the accession of Croatia to the EU.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. With this agreement, Parliament believes that the European Union should continue to provide financial support to the Philippines to combat poverty, promote respect for human rights, peace and security, and assist them in preventing and preparing for disasters and climate change. The agreement also aims to encourage the Government of the Philippines to continue to promote progress in eliminating corruption, to develop systems for collecting data on trafficking in human beings and to strengthen legal instruments for migration for work purposes, ensuring that they are treated with dignity in third countries. In order to facilitate cultural and trade exchanges between the islands of the archipelago, the Government of the Philippines is encouraged to invest in new technological tools. For the above reasons, I support the implementation of this recommendation, as I believe that it can play a fundamental role in the European order.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it approves Croatia's accession to the EU-Philippines agreement. However, I do not believe that the EU has to have an international role.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted AGAINST this report. It is an update of the cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Philippines. Although the substance of the text is lucid about the situation in the Philippines, it is lost in comments on the conflicts in the China Sea that divert it from its primary objective. The correction in this report aims to integrate Croatia, since it joined the EU after the signing of the text. I believe that the EU does not have to take the place of the Member States in terms of international policy.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the adoption of this framework agreement between the EU and the Philippines, because the EU's cooperation and cooperation agreements with third countries are the antechamber of a free trade agreement, which we oppose because of its negative effects on the working class of the countries concerned. Moreover, such trade agreements pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. The amendments tabled by our GUE/NGL group on the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region, the crackdown on left-wing activists and politicians, extrajudicial killings and our concerns about how this economic agreement will harm the local population were all rejected, so I have no doubt voting against this agreement.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. I do not want to prevent Croatia from joining the agreement that was drawn up before and therefore without its accession to the EU, even though I do not agree with the agreement as such and voted against the text of the agreement itself.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. In accordance with its Accession Act, Croatia undertakes to accede to international agreements signed or concluded by the European Union and its Member States through protocols to those agreements. The Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other hand, was signed in Phnom Penh on 11 July 2012. The agreement is currently under ratification and has not yet entered into force. Negotiations with the Republic of the Philippines were successfully concluded and the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other hand, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, therefore I supported this recommendation.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ in accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU and the Rules of Procedure, the European Parliament has given its consent to the conclusion of a Protocol to the Agreement formally taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, the Protocol to the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 8/6/2016, and because this recommendation is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against these 3 reports.  We strongly disagree with the way the situation in the China Sea, as well as more generally the way maritime clashes in Asia are described. Foreign policy is the exclusive work of states. We are opposed to the EU trying to play an international role, even if it is a minor one.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU is one of the Most Important Foreign Investors and Trading Partners of the Philippines and reflects 11.56% of their total exports. At the same time, the EU has more than doubled the funds for development cooperation with the Philippines in 2014-2019 and is providing remarkable humanitarian assistance to the victims of tropical storms that regularly hit the country. Seeing significant progress on the part of the Philippines on both human rights and anti-corruption and counter-terrorism initiatives by participating in international coalitions, I welcome the conclusion of a partnership and cooperation agreement with the Philippines with the wider aim of helping the Union to reduce poverty, further promote respect for human rights and the rule of law , ensuring peace and security and assisting in emergencies. Finally, this resolution concerns the Union's partnership with the Philippines but in relation to Croatia's accession to the EU, so that this State as a Member State of the Union can be taken into account and included in the agreement with the Philippines.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Through this Framework Agreement, Parliament gives its assent to the conclusion of the Protocol and instructs its President to forward Parliament's position to the Council, the Commission and the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Republic of the Philippines. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the addition of the agreement between the EU and the Philippines, given that Croatia joined the EU.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Negotiations for a regional free trade agreement between the EU and ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) have stalled. The EU is therefore seeking to push bilateral agreements with countries in the region against North Americans who are moving at a good pace for their similar regional agreement, the Trans-Pacific Partnership. Also, this agreement with the Philippines is above all the way to enter this race. It does, of course, contain interesting elements, on the implementation of ILO conventions or on the fight against terrorism and support for the peace process south of Mindanao. But it is above all the means of opening negotiations for a future free trade agreement, already favoured by the preferential regime granted to the country for its exports of certain key products such as textiles. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is an update of the agreement between the EU and the Philippines. While the descriptive part of the report is honest about the situation in the Philippines, comments on the situation in the China Sea and on the ongoing maritime clashes in Asia appear to us to be inappropriate. It should also be remembered that foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and that the EU does not have to claim an international role, however small. Therefore, I objected to that report.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution because of the benefits in trade and development that come from comprehensive cooperation with the Philippines. It is important that Croatia, as a new Member State, is included in existing conventions and agreements.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on EU-Philippines Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation with regard to the accession of Croatia, because I am in agreement with the text of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part , to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. The proposed Protocol incorporates Croatia as contracting party to the Agreement and commits the EU to providing the authentic version of the Agreement in the Croatian language.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council submitted a draft decision concerning the conclusion on behalf of the European Union and its Member States of the Protocol to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, annexed to the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part. In order to adopt the decision, it must obtain parliament's consent. In its recommendation, the Committee on Foreign Affairs recommends that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Negotiations for a free trade agreement with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) were launched in 2007 and were halted in 2009 and took the form of bilateral negotiations. These bilateral free trade agreements have been designed as the basis for a future agreement with the countries of this region, and the EU has so far finalised bilateral agreements with Singapore and Vietnam.  The European Union is the philippines' fourth largest trading partner and its fourth largest export market, accounting for 11.56% of the country's exports. The Union is also the main foreign investor in the Philippines, with a volume of foreign direct investment in the country exceeding EUR 6.2 billion. EU-Philippine relations are currently governed by the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement signed in July 2012. Since 2014, the Philippines has benefited from the Generalised System of Preferences, which gives them the possibility to export their products into the Union area free of tariffs. In this regard, I am voting in favour, because I believe it is important for the European Union to strengthen cooperation with the countries of South-East Asia in order to move towards a trade agreement with ASEAN.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and the EU does not have to claim an international role, no matter how small. I am voting against this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to give Parliament's approval to Croatia's accession to the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines. Croatia, having joined the European Union only from 1 July 2013, was not present in the draft framework agreement, whereas as a Member State it has a full place in it. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since 1980 the EEC-ASEAN Cooperation Agreement has governed the relationship between the Philippines and the European Union. The European Union and the Philippines’ initial Partnership and Cooperation Agreement was initialled on 25 June 2010. I have voted for this recommendation that will take into account, for this agreement, the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report was a technical acknowledgment of Croatia’s accession to the EU. I abstained on this vote as I have concerns regarding the agreement between the EU and the Philippines. However, I am in favour of the full accession of Croatia to the EU, so therefore, with these concerns in mind, I abstained on the final vote.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I have spoken in favour of this report and Am in favour of the framework agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The conclusion of the agreement is the result of Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The path to becoming an EU member by the Republic of Croatia is full of international agreements necessary to be part of the international organisation. Considering it necessary for Croatia to join the EU-Philippines Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Philippines was signed in 2012 in Phnom Penn before the Accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. Due to the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU, this fact is taken into account that the application of the agreement on this Asian market would also apply to the Republic of Croatia. Croatian manufacturers and companies should not have any obstacles to doing business in the Philippine market. Croatia also has to offer a significant number of its products to the Philippine market and for these reasons it is necessary to solve all bureaucratic difficulties that prevent Croatian businessmen from making a profit in this large and growing market. As a Croatian MEMBER of the European Parliament, I understand the importance of cooperation with external markets and the countless opportunities it offers to Croatian producers, so I support this recommendation and point out that taking into account Croatia's accession to the European Union, conditions for the protection of Croatian interests on the Philippine market are achieved and conditions are ensured that Croatian citizens also feel the positive effects of this partnership after the final ratification of the agreement.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and the EU does not have to claim an international role, no matter how small. I am voting against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Taking into account the draft Council decision (13085/2014), and taking into account the draft Protocol to the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other hand, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union (13082/2014), I give consent to the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Philippines in order to ensure the accession of the last new Member State, the Republic of Croatia.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Under the EU Accession Treaty, Croatia has committed to acceding to all international agreements signed by the European Union and its members. The Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its members, on the one hand, and with the Philippines on the other, was signed on 11 July 2012. I supported Rapporteur Brok's report on the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Philippines in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of approving the conclusion of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other, to take account of the republic of Croatia's accession to the EU. The Act of Accession of the Republic of Croatia provides that the Republic of Croatia shall accede to international agreements signed or concluded by the European Union and its Member States by means of a protocol annexed to those agreements.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Croatia's participation in the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines, which is a natural consequence of Croatia's accession to the Union in 2013.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This document adopts the Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament of 8 June 2016 on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, in order to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union , so I voted for it.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted this afternoon in favour of Croatia's accession to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (CPA) between the European Union and the Philippines signed on 11 July 2012. This broad agreement deals with enhanced cooperation in many political, economic and sectoral areas. In particular, it extends bilateral cooperation in the areas of trade, energy, transport, the environment, migration and the fight against corruption. The agreement also provides for increased cooperation in science and technology, governance, education, health, human rights and culture. On the economic front, the EU is already the Philippines' 4th largest trading partner and there is every indication that the implementation of this agreement will have a positive impact on trade. These amounted to 12.5 billion euros in 2014. In terms of development aid and humanitarian aid, the Commission plans to allocate 325 million euros for the period 2014-2020 with two priority themes: inclusive growth and the rule of law. Croatia's participation in this agreement is a natural consequence of its accession to the European Union, which has been in force since 1 July 2013.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Simple adaptation of the protocol taking into account Croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of incorporating Croatia, as a newly integrated Member State into the EU, into the Framework Agreement on Collaboration and Cooperation maintained by the Republic of the Philippines and the EU since 2010, now updated.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which allows Croatia to be taken into account as a contracting party to the framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the European Union and the Philippines. Parliament accompanied this approval with a non-legislative resolution detailing its recommendations. As a reminder, the partnership between the Union and the Philippines needs to be strengthened, particularly in the areas of the fight against poverty, terrorism, human rights and trade relations. Indeed, since December 2015, negotiations for a free trade treaty between the two parties, including Croatia, have been launched.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The Comprehensive Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Philippines, was signed in Phnom Penh on 11 July 2012. In accordance with its accession act, Croatia has committed to accede to international agreements signed or concluded by the European Union and its Member States through a protocol to these agreements.  In order for Croatia to be included in this framework agreement as a contracting party, the European Parliament had to give its approval to the protocol in question. It is now done.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This issue does not require much discussion. Croatia's EU membership has slightly changed our trade agreements with the Philippines. Today, we are simply legitimising the newly created situation. As far as I know, our trading partners are also satisfied with the proposal put forward, so I am unequivocally voting in favour.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 1 July 2013, the Republic of Croatia joined the EU, becoming the 28th Member State. Consequently, it was thus subject to automatic access to the agreements concluded or signed prior to their joining by the other Member States and the Union with one or more third countries. The Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other, is one such case. The Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement was signed in Phnom Penh on 11 July 2012. With this recommendation as a view to formalising the Republic of Croatia as a Party to the Common Aviation Area Agreement between the European Union, its Member States and the Philippines and no changes to the content of the Agreement are foreseen, I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this own-initiative report which did not include any amendments that our group tabled, the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region and the joint US-Philippine maneuvers, the repression of civil society activists and members of left-wing parties, the proper implementation of the Human Rights Conventions in the country and the existence of extra-judicial killings by state security forces and paramilitary forces. While some of these elements are underpinned in the final text, it is at the end of an instrument that seeks to move towards the signing of an EU-Philippine Free Trade Agreement, which, like the other types of instruments in the process of negotiating with other countries since the Doha paralysis, has a double-sided : on the one hand the promise of new trade opportunities, accompany and secure its reform processes and on the other hand, the risks that trade liberalization between economies with very different levels of development pose to the weakest part.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. The agreement ensures closer cooperation between the EU and the Philippines. Closer cooperation will benefit both sides both economically and strategically. However, it is important that we do not compromise on the requirement that the Philippines must respect human rights, labour rights, social rights and environmental protection.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other hand, on the occasion of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union'. The agreement regulates not only Europe's support for the Philippines, but also our exchanges and cooperation at the economic, cultural and security-informative levels. Croatia, as the eu's youngest Member State, must also be part of this partnership.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against Croatia's accession to this framework agreement between the EU and the Philippines, because the EU's cooperation and cooperation agreements with third countries are the antechamber of a free trade agreement, which we oppose because of its negative effects on the working class of the countries concerned. Moreover, such trade agreements pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. The amendments tabled by our GUE/NGL group on the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region, the crackdown on left-wing activists and politicians, extrajudicial killings and our concerns about how this economic agreement will harm the local population were all rejected, so I have no doubt voting against this agreement.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation as it considers the Republic of Croatia, the newest Member State to join the EU, in this Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation with the Philippines. We will continue to insist on respect for human rights, better labour and social standards and efforts to implement better environmental rights in this country.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of Croatia's accession to the EU, it is necessary to conclude a Protocol to the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part. I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
