text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the conclusion of the Protocol to the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union, its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other. The Protocol is negotiated with a view to the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU. The EU-Philippines agreement itself was concluded as early as July 2012, but has not yet entered into force due to the ongoing ratification process. However, for legislative reasons, croatia already needs to be included among the Contracting Parties and a text in an official translation into Croatian must be drawn up. This Protocol will also make it possible to use Croatia's access to international agreements negotiated at European level. I believe that its application will be beneficial for both parties.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the strongest instruments of European foreign policy is the conclusion of trade partnerships. By acceding to these agreements by the new Member States, we are expanding the areas where entrepreneurs and companies from the European Union can place their products and services.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. In accordance with its Accession Act, Croatia undertakes to accede to the agreements signed by the European Union and its Member States through protocols to those agreements. The Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines is in the process of ratification and has not yet entered into force, and the proposed protocol includes Croatia as a contracting party to the agreement.  I support this recommendation on the draft Decision of the Council on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other hand, in order to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the European Parliament's legislative resolution of 8 June 2016 on the draft Council decision on the conclusion – on behalf of the European Union and its Member States – of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other hand, on the occasion of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other hand, includes, inter alia, issues of current interest such as the issue of peace, migration, taxes, environment, energy, nature and technology, maritime and air transport, tourism, culture, money laundering and terrorist financing, and illicit trade. The accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union as a direct consequence imposes the incorporation of Croatia into the Framework Agreement as one of the Contracting Parties.b I support the adoption of the Protocol, because I believe that Croatia's participation in the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation naturally stems from its accession to the European Union.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union on behalf of the European Union and its Member States. The Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, was signed in Pnom Penh on 11 July 2012, with Croatia joining the agreement concluded. This will, of course, be adopted and taken into account in the same way as the other Member States of the European Union.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report analyses EU-Philippine relations. While the aim is to approve a cooperation agreement, the report also refers to a possible free trade agreement with all the countries of south-east Asia, and this is problematic for us. He refers to tensions in the South China Sea by calling on China to stop its aggression, but any criticism of the joint Philippine-US exercises is absent. In view of the above, we have abstained in all 3 reports on the EU-Philippine cooperation agreement.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU in its classic way and method and through various trick attempts to create problems in Member States with various agreements with third countries.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation as it accepts that the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and its Member States and the Republic of the Philippines should be amended to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU. By adopting this Council Decision, we will facilitate the process of bringing the Republic of Croatia, which joined the EU on 1 July 2013, to the agreements concluded or signed with third countries by the Member States and the EU before 1 July 2013.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I have put a 'one' on the Council's draft decision on the signing, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the protocol to the framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other hand, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Philippines Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, and the Philippines, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU. This will allow Croatia to become a party to the agreement, which strengthens bilateral relations between both countries in the areas of general principles and political dialogue, foreign policy, economic, trade and sectorial cooperation.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒I voted to conclude the Protocol to the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other hand, to take into account the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union.  Since the Republic of Croatia joined the Union on 1 July 2013, in accordance with the Accession Act of the Republic of Croatia, Croatia will accede to agreements concluded or signed by the Member States of the European Union and the Union with one or more third countries prior to its accession to the Union. The proposed Protocol includes the Republic of Croatia as the Contracting Party to the Agreement, and the European Union undertakes to ensure a credible version of the agreement in Croatian.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union on behalf of the European Union and its Member States. Croatia is the last associated country and it is important to be included in the EU-Philippines Partnership and Cooperation Agreement.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this own-initiative report which did not include any amendments that our group tabled, the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region and the joint US-Philippine maneuvers, the repression of civil society activists and members of left-wing parties, the proper implementation of the Human Rights Conventions in the country and the existence of extra-judicial killings by state security forces and paramilitary forces. While some of these elements are underpinned in the final text, it is at the end of an instrument that seeks to move towards the signing of an EU-Philippine Free Trade Agreement, which, like the other types of instruments in the process of negotiating with other countries since the Doha paralysis, has a double-sided : on the one hand the promise of new trade opportunities, accompany and secure its reform processes and on the other hand, the risks that trade liberalization between economies with very different levels of development pose to the weakest part.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. These texts are updates of the agreements between the EU and the Philippines. While the descriptive part of the substantive report is honest about the situation in the Philippines, the comments on the situation in the China Sea and the ongoing maritime clashes in Asia seem ridiculous to us.  It should be remembered that foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and that the EU does not have to claim an international role, however small.   I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Croatia's accession to the FRAMEWORK Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and the Republic of the Philippines has been a natural consequence of its membership of the European Union since 1 July 2013.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU should continue to provide financial assistance and capacity-building support to the Philippines in the areas of poverty reduction, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, the promotion of peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform, disaster preparedness, aid and recovery and the implementation of effective policies to address climate change. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this own-initiative report which did not include any amendments that our group tabled, the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region and the joint US-Philippine maneuvers, the repression of civil society activists and members of left-wing parties, the proper implementation of the Human Rights Conventions in the country and the existence of extra-judicial killings by state security forces and paramilitary forces. While some of these elements are underpinned in the final text, it is at the end of an instrument that seeks to move towards the signing of an EU-Philippine Free Trade Agreement, which, like the other types of instruments in the process of negotiating with other countries since the Doha paralysis, has a double-sided : on the one hand the promise of new trade opportunities, accompany and secure its reform processes and on the other hand, the risks that trade liberalization between economies with very different levels of development pose to the weakest part.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. I believe that the participation of Croatia in this agreement is a natural consequence of its EU accession.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This decision incorporates Croatia into that framework agreement. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in your favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We are in the presence of two recommendations, one on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Philippines and the other recommendation to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU in the agreement. The first recommends the approval of the agreement, the second the approval of the protocol for the addition of Croatia. The Philippines is considered an example to be followed by other countries in the region on human rights. Unfortunately, this report is at least partial and does not take into account reality, with particular emphasis on the statements by the President of the Philippines on respect for human rights.  References to security and military cooperation lead us to conclude that we are talking about another action of imperial interference aimed at increasing the military influence of the EU and Nato in that region. We voted against it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Parliament hereby gives its assent to the conclusion of the Protocol and instructs its President to forward Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Republic of the Philippines, on the occasion of the accession of the Republic of Croatia. I was able to vote in favour of this report without hesitation.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I supported the recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union on behalf of the European Union and its Member States. This will allow Croatia to join, as a new member of the European Union, to the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr It must be said that relations between the European Union and the Philippines have been developing sufficiently proactively for some ten years, for another decade. They have experienced a particular boom in recent years, first of all in trade and linguistics, and a certain culturally religious intimacy is one of the primary factors contributing to our rapprocling. Moreover, around a million Filipinos are currently ubiscoed within the territory of the European Union, in different countries, and provide another impetus for the further development of relations. Given the current potential of the EU-Philippines partnership, I naturally unequivocally support this document and believe that relations between the European Union and the Philippines are looking forward to a very good future.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Republic of the Philippines is one of 10 members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), as well as the fifth largest economy in the region and the second largest market within ASEAN. Since 2014, the EU has granted the Philippines GSP+ status, making it the first country in the area to benefit from duty-free travel for different types of products, such as coconut oil, footwear, fish and textiles. Partnership agreements, generally aimed at establishing political cooperation, are based on the sharing of fundamental values, such as democracy and human rights. In this connection, the ACP has made respect for these values an essential condition for the maintenance of political dialogue and trade relations. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the adoption of this framework agreement between the EU and the Philippines because the EU's cooperation and cooperation agreements with third countries are the antechamber of a free trade agreement, which we oppose because of its negative effects on the working class of the countries concerned. Moreover, such trade agreements pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. The amendments tabled by our GUE/NGL group on the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region, the crackdown on left-wing activists and politicians, extrajudicial killings and our concerns about how this economic agreement will harm the local population were all rejected, so I have no doubt voting against this agreement.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to update the framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the European Union and the Philippines.  While the rapporteur gives a fairly realistic description of the situation in the Philippines, the comments on tensions in the South China Sea and maritime clashes in Asia appear to us to be unwelcome.  I therefore voted against this text because, let us remember, foreign policy is the exclusive act of States and the European Union does not have to claim an international role, however small.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a consent vote on the Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement which provides an overarching strategic political framework for strengthening Philippines -EU bilateral cooperation and a legal framework for further engagement between the EU and the Philippines across a broad range of areas, including political dialogue, trade, energy, transport, investment, human rights, education, science and technology, justice, asylum and migration. It also includes areas of current interest such as the Mindanao peace process and disaster risk management. Negotiations with the Philippines began in 2009 and were concluded in 2010 and the agreement was signed in July 2012. One of the aims of the Framework Agreement is also to constitute the political framework for further negotiations on the EU free trade agreement with the Philippines. I have a number of concerns regarding Free Trade Agreements, however, this is not a FTA and so therefore, I abstained on the final vote, as this Framework Agreement has positive aspects in the area of human rights, education, culture and health issues, such as sanitary and phytosanitary issues also related to animal welfare.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this recommendation. This is an important step for a major partner in the region for the EU. In this text, our group has stressed social and environmental rights, as well as provisions guaranteeing fair trade.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report approves the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between EU Member States on the one hand and the Republic of the Philippines on the other. I voted in favour of this report on the side of the Socialists and Democrats of the European Parliament, as this is an important step in partnership with an important EU partner in the wider region. It is very important, however, for our group to give special basis to respect for labour, social and environmental rights, as well as to effective control and monitoring of the provisions of fair trade.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This text updates the agreements between the EU and the Philippines. Although the descriptive part of the report is relatively accurate with respect to the situation in the Philippines, comments on the situation in the China Sea and ongoing clashes in Asia are irrelevant. On the other hand, it should be remembered that foreign policy must remain the exclusive responsibility of States. That is why I objected to this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I voted against this report. I do not believe it is in the interest of the British people that the European Union-Philippines framework should be given consent.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, as the Commission recommended on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal by which the EP supports the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is an update of the agreements between the EU and the Philippines; while the descriptive part of the report is honest about the situation in the Philippines, the comments on the situation in the China Sea and on the ongoing maritime clashes in Asia are completely irrelevant.  Moreover, it should be remembered about this report and the Commission's similar initiatives that foreign policy is the exclusive act of the Member States and that the EU does not have to give itself an international role, however small. I voted against this abusive claim from Brussels.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses the conclusion of a framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the Union and the Republic of the Philippines.  This partnership represents an additional step in the EU's engagement in South-East Asia, both economically and politically. It is therefore necessary to continue to provide financial and development support, including to fight poverty and build the country's capacity while helping it to fight climate change.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The establishment of a framework agreement with the Republic of the Philippines is an important step forward in strengthening the Union's role in the region, promoting the development and consolidation of democratic processes. At a time when china's presence in the waters of the South China Sea is particularly strong, with a relative increase in tensions in the area, it seems increasingly necessary to establish partnership and cooperation relations that feed a collaborative approach. My vote in favour of the Brok report, which approves the EU-Philippines agreement, is based on the conviction that it is essential to strengthen relations with the archipelago state, paying particular attention to the environmental and climate change dimension. The European Union cannot but take into account the serious difficulties that the country is facing as a result of the threats and risks associated with the emergence of extreme weather events in the area, which are linked to climate change. In addition to providing humanitarian aid and technical support to deal with natural disasters, the Union must support the country's authorities in the fight against Islamic terrorism. A real threat that feeds on a widespread consensus in some social strata, particularly vulnerable to jihadist calls and ISIS propaganda.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this own-initiative report which did not include any amendments that our group tabled, the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region and the joint US-Philippine maneuvers, the repression of civil society activists and members of left-wing parties, the proper implementation of the Human Rights Conventions in the country and the existence of extra-judicial killings by state security forces and paramilitary forces. While some of these elements are underpinned in the final text, it is at the end of an instrument that seeks to move towards the signing of an EU-Philippine Free Trade Agreement, which, like the other types of instruments in the process of negotiating with other countries since the Doha paralysis, has a double-sided : on the one hand the promise of new trade opportunities, accompany and secure its reform processes and on the other hand, the risks that trade liberalization between economies with very different levels of development pose to the weakest part.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This Recommendation relates to an EU-Philippines Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement for Approval and is a simple update of EU-Philippine agreements. While the descriptive part of the substantive report is honest about the situation in the Philippines, the comments on the situation in the China Sea and the ongoing maritime clashes in Asia seem ridiculous to us. However, the EU does not have to claim an international role as it is trying to do, since foreign policy is still entirely a matter for states alone.  So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 While addressing issues that we can support, this resolution opens up passages that could prove critical and hinder EU businesses that want to operate in that country. I therefore did not feel able to fully support this text and voted to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Republic of the Philippines and the EU have maintained a Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement since 2010 and, in December 2014, was granted the SPG+ status, the first ASEAN country to enjoy such trade preferences.  Moreover, the EU doubled its financial endowment for development cooperation with the Philippines in 2014-2020, and has also provided considerable humanitarian and emergency assistance to tropical storm victims. Parliament calls on the Philippines to ratify and implement all fundamental international conventions on human and labour rights, environmental protection and good governance listed in Annex VIII to Regulation (EU) No 978/2012. In 2014, the Commission barned the possibility of banning imports of fishing products from the Philippines if it did not improve the control of illegal, undeclared or regulated fishing before, and the Commission therefore initiated a dialogue to address deficiencies in its fisheries management and control systems. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this Framework Agreement.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because It endorses the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. If the descriptive part of the substantive report is honest about the situation in the Philippines, the comments on the situation in the China Sea and the ongoing maritime clashes in Asia seem ridiculous to me.  I would like to point out that foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and that the EU does not have to claim an international role, however small.   Also, I voted against that recommendation.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This was a consent vote on the Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement which provides an overarching strategic political framework for strengthening Philippines -EU bilateral cooperation and a legal framework for further engagement between the EU and the Philippines across a broad range of areas, including political dialogue, trade, energy, transport, investment, human rights, education, science and technology, justice, asylum and migration. It also includes areas of current interest such as the Mindanao peace process and disaster risk management. Negotiations with the Philippines began in 2009 and were concluded in 2010 and the agreement was signed in July 2012. One of the aims of the Framework Agreement is also to constitute the political framework for further negotiations on the EU free trade agreement with the Philippines. I have a number of concerns regarding Free Trade Agreements, however, this is not a FTA and so therefore, I abstained on the final vote, as this Framework Agreement has positive aspects in the area of human rights, education, culture and health issues, such as sanitary and phytosanitary issues also related to animal welfare.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Economic aid in exchange for democratic reforms and civil progress is one of the most widely used instruments by the EU in its neighbourhood and partnership relations with third countries. A way of relating that has often produced positive results for citizens on both sides and has increased the range of influence of EU soft power. The Philippines is now one of the few countries in East Asia where the transition to the new globalised market condition of the third millennium has reached a modern democratic form, looking to the West and the development of the rule of law despite its still serious structural shortcomings, its own internal social problems, its difficult relationship with minorities and the pockets of guerrilla warfare still active in some marginal areas. Overall, Europe can see the Republic of the Philippines as a friendly democracy, which we must support by enabling it to develop under appropriate conditions, gradually, and gradually to join the area of free trade and joint cooperation.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to update the framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the European Union and the Philippines. While the rapporteur gives a fairly realistic description of the situation in the Philippines, the comments on tensions in the South China Sea and maritime clashes in Asia appear to us to be unwelcome. As a sovereign state, the Republic of the Philippines does not have to meet the Union's requirements for compliance with international conventions. It should also be remembered that foreign policy is an exclusive competence of the Member States and that the European Union cannot claim an international role. As usual, the Union wishes to grant itself prerogatives that are not its own. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the EU-Philippines Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation (approval procedure), because I believe that it is very beneficial to have the best economic, political and cultural cooperation for both the EU Member States and the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU. Both the request for the draft protocol of the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and the Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, and the non-legislative resolution of 2016 on the proposal for a decision for the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, were submitted for approval and submitted to the Council in accordance with Article 207 Article 209 and Article 218 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. Thus, taking into account the draft Council decision and the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, a common denominator was reached. Thus, it remains only the task of the President to transmit their position to Parliament, the Council and the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Republic of the Philippines.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I am in favour of concluding the EU-Philippines Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. The EU is a foreign investor and a leading trading partner of the Philippines. The Philippines is increasingly being hit by extreme weather events that are becoming an obstacle to the country's development. The World Bank recently declared that the Philippines is the third most vulnerable developing country to climate change, and that this will have harmful effects on the country's agriculture and marine resources. It is therefore necessary for the European response to include considerable humanitarian and emergency aid for the victims of tropical storms in the Philippines. I would remind you that the EU can also support climate action in the Philippines through the European Commission's Asia Investment Fund. There are growing concerns that ISIS is taking over affiliated groups in Southeast Asia, as it is spreading propaganda in local languages and there are reports that some extremists in the region have already pledged to cooperate. I therefore call on the EU and its Member States to enter into a dialogue with the Philippines with a view to facilitating an exchange of information between intelligence in order to cooperate and support the strengthening of the government's capabilities in the international fight against terrorism.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a consent vote on the Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement which provides an overarching strategic political framework for strengthening Philippines -EU bilateral cooperation and a legal framework for further engagement between the EU and the Philippines across a broad range of areas, including political dialogue, trade, energy, transport, investment, human rights, education, science and technology, justice, asylum and migration. It also includes areas of current interest such as the Mindanao peace process and disaster risk management. Negotiations with the Philippines began in 2009 and were concluded in 2010 and the agreement was signed in July 2012. One of the aims of the Framework Agreement is also to constitute the political framework for further negotiations on the EU free trade agreement with the Philippines. I have a number of concerns regarding Free Trade Agreements, however, this is not a FTA and so therefore, I abstained on the final vote, as this Framework Agreement has positive aspects in the area of human rights, education, culture and health issues, such as sanitary and phytosanitary issues also related to animal welfare.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report and to give consent for the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership between the EU and the Republic of the Philippines. It will allow us for greater cooperation in many fields such as countering terrorism, migration, taxation or human rights and it is bound to be of great benefit to both parties.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the Philippines needs EU support to address the many challenges and emergencies they face, I voted in favour of the POSSIBILITY of the EU constraining a partnership agreement with that country.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and believe that strengthening bilateral relations is in the common interest.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, is part of the wider effort to develop Europe's relations with that State. I believe that we should support the development of these relations, since it could have positive effects on security, the economy and policy. In this respect, however, we see pressure being exerted on issues of surveillance and a strong military presence in the wider Philippines region, which I am opposed to. That is why I have decided to abstain from all aspects of the vote on this recommendation.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the solution of concluding the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines proposed by the European Commission. I think it is important for the Eu ropean Union to continue to provide financial and assistance support to the country in order to reduce poverty, promote peace and human rights but, above all, support them in the fight against terrorism. I therefore have a vision similar to that of the Commission in the context of the agreement with the Philippines, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Under this proposal, the Council is called upon to adopt a decision aiming to approve the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Philippines, of the other part, to take account of the accession of Croatia to the European Union on behalf of the European Union and its Member States. The proposed Protocol incorporates Croatia as contracting party to the Agreement and commits the EU to providing the authentic version of the Agreement in the Croatian language.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the conclusion of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines, as it aims to promote respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms and the fight against terrorism. The agreement is fully topical because it includes areas such as disaster risk management and the peace process.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the scope of the report and its proposal to forward our position to the Council, the Commission and the governments and parliaments of the Member States and of the Republic of the Philippines, for a conclusion of the agreement.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the adoption of this framework agreement between the EU and the Philippines because the EU's cooperation and cooperation agreements with third countries are the antechamber of a free trade agreement, which we oppose because of its negative effects on the working class of the countries concerned. Moreover, such trade agreements pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. The amendments tabled by our GUE/NGL group on the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region, the crackdown on left-wing activists and politicians, extrajudicial killings and our concerns about how this economic agreement will harm the local population were all rejected, so I have no doubt voting against this agreement.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Republic of the Philippines, as a founding member of ASEAN and thanks to long-standing cooperation relations, is a reliable partner of the European Union in Southeast Asia for both trade and the fight against terrorism. The Republic of the Philippines has also become a human rights model for the neighbouring states following the ratification of eight of the nine main conventions in this area. I voted in favour of the conclusion of the Partnership Framework Agreement, wishing to affirm the major importance of continuing financial support and European assistance with a view to strengthening democracy, respect for human rights and the rule of law, implementing policies for the protection of the environment and the fight against climate change.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union and the Republic of the Philippines have a long-standing relationship that has been significantly expanded and deepened in recent years. The EU is one of the Philippines' main trading and investment partners. These relations have been further strengthened by the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement initialled in 2010 and signed on 11 July 2012. The agreement will first have to be ratified by EU Member States and then submitted to the European Parliament before it formally enters into force. The EU-Philippines Partnership and Cooperation Agreement calls on m.in. to establish a constructive human rights dialogue in the form of a human rights working group. Mindanao, the southernmost large island in the Philippines, has long struggled with communist and Islamic revolutions and terrorism. Since 2007, the European Union has been promoting and supporting a politically negotiated settlement of the conflict in the south of the island. In its recommendation, Elmar Brok (EPP) proposes to agree to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, which I personally support. I also share concerns about the human rights situation and the atmosphere of impunity reportedly prevailing in a country that is very high in terms of impunity rates worldwide. In view of the problems identified, I voted in favour of the agreement.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and the Republic of the Philippines. This is seen as a tool through which the EU encourages the Philippine Government to continue fostering further progress in the elimination of corruption and the promotion of human rights.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the report on the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines, which includes provisions on human rights and the fight against terrorism. In addition, it strengthens cooperation in areas of action such as migration, the fight against the financing of terrorism, the fight against organised crime and corruption.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The text put to the vote consists of an update of the agreements between the EU and the Philippines. While the descriptive part of the substantive report is realistic about the situation in the Philippines, comments on the context in the China Sea and on ongoing maritime clashes in Asia are not serious. To the extent that foreign policy is a competence of the States and the European Union does not have to claim to play an international role in this area, I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Relations between the EU and the Philippines are long-standing and have been increasingly deep in recent years. I welcome this Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and believe that it will strengthen relations and, among other things, it also concerns the establishment of a human rights dialogue in the form of a Working Party on Human Rights. I share the concerns about the state of human rights there, although the situation has improved to some extent in recent years, as well as with the climate of impunity in the country, which ranks very high on the scale of the overall index of impunity.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Negative, for the same reason as above, with regard to the conclusion of agreements with the Philippines.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: it should be remembered that foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and that the EU does not have to claim an international role, however small.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation refers to the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU, of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the EU and the Philippines. The reasons for this agreement are put forward in the legislative resolution which is appropriate démins. A resolution which addresses several aspects which show, as a whole, that this agreement is inseparable from an imprint of geopolitical interests, part of a global policy of siege of China. As for economic aspects, the EU is one of the main foreign investors in the country, as well as one of the main trading partners. The EU, for its part, is the fourth largest market for the Philippines, accounting for 12% of exports. The Framework Partnership Agreement is a first step towards the Free Trade Agreement, deepening a path already started. Some of the effects of trade deregulation and liberalisation are already felt, particularly on the European canning industry. This liberalisation has primarily benefited US companies that have settled in the Philippines and export to Europe, exploiting cheap labour without local rights. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are many reasons why Europe must continue to provide support and assistance to the Philippines for the development of its potential. The EU has long-standing relations with the Philippines, which have deepened significantly in recent years. The EU has a major role to play in promoting peace, security, judicial reform and assisting the Philippines in frequent natural disasters. At the same time, the Philippines is very active in the functioning of an international coalition against terrorism.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained. No opinion.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstain from the resolution because, despite many positive points, it does not take into account some important elements such as the current unfavourable conditions for those who want to do business in the Philippines.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the EU-Philippine Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement (approval). The EU in its classic way and method and through various tycies is trying to create problems in Member States with various agreements with third countries.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU - Philippines Framework Agreement represents, in my opinion, an important step with regard to a major partner in the region for the EU. We must continue insisting on respect for Human Rights, labour, social, environmental rights, as well as on their effective monitoring, and on provisions guaranteeing fair trade. Trade, geo-strategic and security issues are very important considering the delicate regional situation, given China’s increasing assertiveness and territorial claims, maritime security and potential terrorism concerns. I am very concerned about the South China Sea issue and the risk of conflict faced with Chinese assertiveness. Therefore, I support the call on the Vice-President/High Representative to identify how the EU should best engage in bilateral and multilateral security cooperation. Finally, I believe we must call for an effective implementation of the UN guiding principles regarding business and human rights.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the will to ensure that the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines continue to work actively together, the EU must continue to provide the Philippines with economic support and capacity-building assistance for the fight against poverty, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, the promotion of peace , reconciliation, security and judicial reform, and assisting the country in disaster prevention, relief and recovery and implementation of effective policies to address climate change.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. International agreements concluded by the EU on behalf of its Member States must apply equally to all. I therefore support Croatia's accession to this agreement and the corresponding update.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The agreement extends the scope of mutual engagement in the economic and trade sectors. The conclusion of the agreement is in line with the EU's objective of creating a comprehensive and coherent economic and political framework for EU-ASEAN relations.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it would be appropriate to conclude the framework agreement for partnership and cooperation between the Philippines and the EU. I also agree with the position of my fellow rapporteurs on the substance that the EU must continue to provide financial support and assistance to the Philippines for capacity building for poverty reduction, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, the promotion of peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform, and assist the country in preparing for disasters , in relief operations and in the resumption and implementation of effective policies to combat climate change. I believe that this position is, however, consistent with what the Union has already done in recent years, granting the country GSP+ status and thus making it a stable trading partner with favourable conditions. I also call on the Eu ropean Union to trust the country not only in terms of goods but mainly in terms of people's mobility rights, with the emphasis on the opportunities for cultural and scientific exchange that this would entail.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this own-initiative report which did not include any amendments that our group tabled, the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region and the joint US-Philippine maneuvers, the repression of civil society activists and members of left-wing parties, the proper implementation of the Human Rights Conventions in the country and the existence of extra-judicial killings by state security forces and paramilitary forces. While some of these elements are underpinned in the final text, it is at the end of an instrument that seeks to move towards the signing of an EU-Philippine Free Trade Agreement, which, like the other types of instruments in the process of negotiating with other countries since the Doha paralysis, has a double-sided : on the one hand the promise of new trade opportunities, accompany and secure its reform processes and on the other hand, the risks that trade liberalization between economies with very different levels of development pose to the weakest part.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of a framework partnership and cooperation agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other. The European Union and the Philippines have a long-standing relationship. These relations have been significantly strengthened by the EU-Philippines Partnership and Cooperation Agreement signed on 11 July 2011.  Therefore, while I share the concerns about the human rights situation, I support agreeing to the conclusion of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which is the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation with the Philippines. It express concerns about the potential spread of ISIS in South East Asia but encourages the Philippine government to continue fostering further progress in the elimination of corruption and the promotion of human rights.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The Philippines is seen by the EU as a strong economic and political partner in Asia.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report analyses EU-Philippine relations. While its purpose is to approve a cooperation agreement, the report also refers to a possible free trade agreement with all Southeast Asian countries, and this is problematic for us. He refers to tensions in the South China Sea, calling on China to stop its aggression, but any criticism of the joint Philippine-US exercises is absent. In view of the above, we have abstained in all 3 reports on the EU-Philippines cooperation agreement.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States in light of the recommendations expressed in the previous motion for a non-legislative resolution. In the previous resolution, it outlined areas where the Philippine government achieved progress such as in corruption and labour rights. Likewise, the previous resolution outlined areas of concern where the Philippine government needs to make progress, e.g. severe human rights violations by the Philippine military in the conduct of counter-insurgency measures.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement as it strengthens cooperation between the EU and the Philippines.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Agreement—framework for partnership and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other, as this gives consent for the conclusion of the agreement.  The agreement brings mutual benefits for the financial assistance provided by the Union to the Philippines and for the strategic position of this country for the EU. Thus, the European Union supports the Philippines in the fight against human trafficking, and encourages investment in technologies and the Internet to foster cultural and trade exchanges between the islands of the Philippine Islands.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. It should be remembered that foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and that the EU does not have to claim an international role, however small. I naturally voted against these three texts.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation with the Republic of the Philippines. The agreement contains provisions such as human rights, the fight against terrorism and cooperation with the International Criminal Court.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report concerns the agreement on the framework agreement between the European Union and the Philippines on partnership and enhanced cooperation. This is an adjustment of the framework agreement, which is why I am voting in favour of the report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I vote in favour of the proposal as the PCA with the Philippines marks an important step towards strengthening bilateral relations and the EU’s role in South-East Asia, based on shared universal values such as democracy and human rights.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. With regard to the EU-Philippines Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, the European Parliament gives its approval to the conclusion of this Agreement. It aims to manage risks, promote respect for human rights, peace and security, and strengthen cooperation in areas such as migration, taxation, the environment, and the fight against criminal activities. This is an important instrument for a country that is achieving important results in terms of progress.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it approves an agreement between the EU and the Philippines. However, I do not believe that the EU has to have an international role.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the EU-Philippines Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement because I believe that the European Union simply does not have to have an international role. It is up to the nations to conclude international agreements and to pursue a foreign policy, not to the European Union.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is an update of the cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Philippines. Although the substance of the text is lucid about the situation in the Philippines, it is lost in clumsy comments about the conflicts in the China Sea that distract it from its primary purpose. Moreover, I believe that the EU does not have to replace Member States in terms of international policy. I fundamentally oppose this text by voting AGAINST.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the adoption of this framework agreement between the EU and the Philippines because the EU's cooperation and cooperation agreements with third countries are the antechamber of a free trade agreement, which we oppose because of its negative effects on the working class of the countries concerned. Moreover, such trade agreements pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. The amendments tabled by our GUE/NGL group on the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region, the crackdown on left-wing activists and politicians, extrajudicial killings and our concerns about how this economic agreement will harm the local population were all rejected, so I have no doubt voting against this agreement.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree to this agreement. There is a civil war going on in the Philippines, with Islamic State, Al-Qaeda, the Islamic Front for the Liberation of Moro and other Islamist organizations operating there. The agreement, which promises European subsidies to the Philippine government and gives them a European concept of human rights, will not improve the situation in the Philippines. I consider an agreement like this to be a kind of European imperialism, an effort to influence countries around the world in their own image. This kind of interference can lead to further disruption of the country.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The conclusion of a framework partnership and cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Philippines strengthens bilateral relations and increases the role of the European Union in the fight for democracy and human rights in Southeast Asia.  This Partnership and Cooperation Agreement strengthens cooperation in the fields of migration, taxation, environment, energy, science and technology, maritime and air transport, tourism and culture. It also helps fight money laundering and terrorist financing, drug trafficking, organised crime and the fight against corruption. I supported this report because I believe that the stronger role of the European Union in the Philippines has a positive impact on their economic development, strengthening human rights, fighting terrorism, growing the economy and developing trade.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the EU is the Philippines' main foreign investor and trading partner. The EU has allocated more than double the funds for development cooperation with the Philippines for the period 2014-2020. The country has a strategic location in the South China Sea. I support the conclusion of the Framework Agreement with the Republic of the Philippines because it has mutually beneficial trade, economic and geopolitical benefits.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 8/6/2016, and because this recommendation is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against these 3 reports.  We strongly disagree with the way the situation in the China Sea, as well as more generally the way maritime clashes in Asia are described. Foreign policy is the exclusive work of states. We are opposed to the EU trying to play an international role, even if it is a minor one.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU is one of the Most Important Foreign Investors and Trading Partners of the Philippines and reflects 11.56% of their total exports. At the same time, the EU has more than doubled the funds for development cooperation with the Philippines in 2014-2019 and is providing remarkable humanitarian assistance to the victims of tropical storms that regularly hit the country. Seeing significant progress on the part of the Philippines on both human rights and anti-corruption and counter-terrorism initiatives with this participation in international coalitions, I welcome the conclusion of a partnership and cooperation agreement with the Philippines with the wider aim of helping the Union to reduce poverty, further promote respect for human rights and the rule of law , ensuring peace and security and assisting in emergencies.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Through this framework agreement, Parliament gives its assent to the conclusion of the Protocol. Parliament also instructs the President to communicate Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Republic of the Philippines. This framework agreement is sensible and therefore worthy of support.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EU-Philippines Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation. I believe that this agreement will contribute to the economic development of these countries, promote trade, tourism, scientific progress, strengthen the dissemination of democratic values, respect for human rights, and facilitate cooperation between institutions in the fight against terrorism, money laundering, illegal migration.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This Parliament's resolution takes a stand on the EU-Philippines Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. It has the merit of highlighting human rights violations by military and paramilitary units of the regime. It underlines the need to respect the Conventions on Human Rights, in particular on human trafficking. It says it has unwavering support for the peace process south of Mindanao. Above all, it duly points out the condition of many Filipino seafarers serving European ports and calls on Member States to enforce the standards set by the International Labour Organization. But these demands are wishful thinking when, at the same time, Parliament calls for a free trade agreement that will only exacerbate this social dumping and the deterioration of the living conditions that are the breeding ground for local terrorism in Mindanao. In addition, the text is part of the U.S.-backed arms race in the face of the conflict in the China Sea. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is an update of the agreement between the EU and the Philippines. While the descriptive part of the report is honest about the situation in the Philippines, comments on the situation in the China Sea and on the ongoing maritime clashes in Asia appear to us to be inappropriate. It should also be remembered that foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and that the EU does not have to claim an international role, however small. Therefore, I objected to this report.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution due to the economic benefits relating to a cohesive partnership with the Republic of the Philippines.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The EU-Philippines Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement (CPA) will help strengthen bilateral relations between the European Union and the Philippines. The Philippines is a promising economic partner: this market of 100 million consumers represents a huge potential for EU businesses. The EU is the Philippines' fourth largest trading partner and the largest foreign investor in the country, where its direct investments are worth more than 6.2 billion euros. A free trade agreement between the Philippines and the EU would benefit both the EU and the Philippines. The objectives of sectoral cooperation to strengthen political and economic cooperation in areas such as energy, the environment, taxation, migration, but also on money laundering, terrorist financing, illicit drugs, organised crime and corruption, are essential in a globalised world. A geopolitical reading of the world quickly makes us understand our interdependence.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on EU-Philippines Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation because I am in agreement to conclude the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Philippines, of the other part.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council submitted a draft decision on the signing on behalf of the Union of the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part. In order to adopt the decision, it must obtain parliament's consent. In its recommendation, the Committee on Foreign Affairs recommends that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The negotiations for a free trade agreement with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) were launched in 2007 and were halted in 2009 and became a bilateral negotiating character. These bilateral free trade agreements have been designed as the basis for a future agreement with the countries of this region, and the EU has so far finalised bilateral agreements with Singapore and Vietnam.  The European Union is the philippines' fourth largest trading partner and its fourth largest export market, accounting for 11.56% of the country's exports. The European Union is also the leading foreign investor in the Philippines, with a volume of foreign direct investment in the country exceeding €6.2 billion. EU-Philippine relations are currently governed by the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement signed in July 2012.  Since 2014, the Philippines has benefited from the Generalised System of Preferences, which gives them the possibility to export their products into the Union area free of tariffs. To this end, I am voting in favour, because I believe it is important for the European Union to conclude the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the EU, its Member States and the Republic of the Philippines.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and the EU does not have to claim an international role, no matter how small. I am voting against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, this resolution welcomes the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation with the Philippines. It express concerns about the potential spread of ISIS in South East Asia but encourages the Philippine government to continue fostering further progress in the elimination of corruption and the promotion of human rights.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines. This framework agreement is based on a draft dating back to 2010 and Parliament voted on the reasons for this agreement during this June 2016 plenary session as part of a non-legislative resolution to which I voted in favour.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since 1980 the EEC-ASEAN Cooperation Agreement has governed the relationship between the Philippines and the European Union. The European Union and the Philippines’ initial Partnership and Cooperation Agreement was initialled on the 25 June 2010. I have voted for this recommendation on EU-Philippines Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation consent.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This was a consent vote on the Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement which provides an overarching strategic political framework for strengthening Philippines -EU bilateral cooperation and a legal framework for further engagement between the EU and the Philippines across a broad range of areas, including political dialogue, trade, energy, transport, investment, human rights, education, science and technology, justice, asylum and migration. It also includes areas of current interest such as the Mindanao peace process and disaster risk management. Negotiations with the Philippines began in 2009 and were concluded in 2010 and the agreement was signed in July 2012. One of the aims of the Framework Agreement is also to constitute the political framework for further negotiations on the EU free trade agreement with the Philippines. I have a number of concerns regarding Free Trade Agreements, however, this is not a FTA and so therefore, i abstained on the final vote, as this Framework Agreement has positive aspects in the area of human rights, education, culture and health issues, such as sanitary and phytosanitary issues also related to animal welfare.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I also voted in favour of this report. Parliament hereby gives its assent to the conclusion of the Protocol and instructs its President to forward Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Republic of the Philippines.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is important to support the agreement in order to promote cooperation between the EU and the Philippines.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU-Philippines Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement broadly extends the opportunities for the parties to commit to economic and trade. The agreement also marks a significant development in that, apart from purely commercial clauses, there are references to human rights, the fight against terrorism and the International Criminal Court. I therefore believe that I support the agreement and vote in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, which includes provisions on human rights, non-proliferation, counter-terrorism and the International Criminal Court, the peace process and disaster risk management. The PCA strengthens cooperation across a wide range of policy fields, including migration, taxation, environment, energy, science and technology, maritime and air transport, tourism, culture, money laundering and terrorist financing, illicit drugs, organised crime and corruption and broadens the scope for mutual engagement in the economic and trade domain.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Given that the Republic of the Philippines is one of the 10 members of the Association of Southeast Asia (ASEAN), as well as the fact that the Philippine economy is the fifth largest economy in the region and the second largest market in ASEAN, it is important to establish good political relations that would be further improved by this Framework Partnership Agreement. Bilateral trade in goods and services between the European Union and ASEAN reached EUR 235 billion in 2013 alone, so the Philippines and other countries in this association must be understood as serious trading partners and provide ways to achieve partnerships that will benefit both sides. The Philippines is the European Union's sixth trading partner. In 2014 alone, the European Union exported €6.8 billion worth of goods, while EU imports from the Philippines amounted to EUR 5.7 billion, and the European Union is also the largest foreign investor in the Philippines. Due to the invaluable importance and opportunities offered by cooperation with the Philippines, I supported this Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and the EU does not have to claim an international role, no matter how small. I am voting against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I agree with the rapporteur, Mr Elmar Brok, that the EU-Philippine Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement is an important step forward in strengthening THE EU's influence in South East Asia, where the Philippines represents one of the EU's most important partners. Trade, geostrategy, terrorism and security are key motives for the conclusion of this EU-Philippine Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, in particular taking into account China's growing assertiveness and territorial claims. On the other hand, it is important to emphasize the need for effective implementation and supervision of respect for human rights, labour and social, as well as effective measures to combat global warming.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Negotiations on EU partnership and cooperation with the Philippines began in 2009 and the Agreement was signed a year later and is the first bilateral Agreement with the Philippines and replaces the current legal framework of the Partnership Agreement between the European Economic Community and the ASEAN Member States. The agreement is a step towards strengthening bilateral relations and the EU's role in Southeast Asia on the basis of common principles, such as democracy and human rights. As it provides the basis for developing cooperation and creates an opportunity to create a political and economic framework between the EU and the Philippines, I supported Mep Brock's recommendation on the framework agreement.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The PCA (Framework for Partnership and Cooperation) with the Philippines replaces the current legal framework constituted by the 1980 Cooperation Agreement between the European Economic Community and the member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). Politically, the PCA with the Philippines represents significant progress towards consolidating bilateral relations and the EU's role in South-East Asia, based on shared universal values such as democracy and human rights. The agreement paves the way for greater political, regional and global cooperation. I voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union and the Republic of the Philippines have a long-standing relationship that has been significantly expanded and deepened in recent years. The EU is one of the Philippines' main trading and investment partners. These relations have been further strengthened by the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement initialled in 2010 and signed m.in on 11 July 2012. Mindanao, the southernmost large island in the Philippines, has long struggled with communist and Islamic revolutions and terrorism. Since 2007, the European Union has been promoting and supporting a politically negotiated settlement of the conflict in the south of the island. I hereby support the report.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Philippines is a geographically distant country, but it is an important regional power with which we must logically cooperate. The Philippines may also be close to us because it is a democratic country, where elections decide the fate of the government. Nor can we forget the economic opportunities this country offers. It is not only for these reasons that I support the framework agreement.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (CPA) signed between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines, which strengthens the relationship between the 28 Member States and this Asian State in many areas of action: transport, energy, environment, tourism, but also the fight against terrorism and organised crime. The conclusion of this agreement is therefore perfectly in line with a coherent overall political and economic framework for relations between the Union and the countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This document adopts the Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament of 8 June 2016 on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Agreement—Framework for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines.  I voted positively.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. In approving this lunchtime the report of the Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, the European Parliament gave its approval to the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation (APC) between the European Union and the Philippines signed on 11 July 2012. This broad agreement deals with enhanced cooperation in many political, economic and sectoral areas. It expands bilateral cooperation in the areas of trade and investment, energy, transport, the environment, migration, the fight against proliferation, terrorism and corruption. The agreement also provides for increased cooperation in science and technology, governance, education, health, human rights and culture. On the economic front, the EU is already the Philippines' 4th largest trading partner and the implementation of this agreement will have an additional positive impact on trade. These amounted to 12.5 billion euros in 2014. In terms of development aid and humanitarian aid, the Commission plans to allocate 325 million euros for the period 2014-2020 with two priority themes: inclusive growth and the rule of law.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The agreement with the Philippines is an important step in strengthening bilateral relations between the EU and Southeast Asia based on universal values such as democracy and human rights. It paves the way for better political, regional and global cooperation.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Republic of the Philippines and the EU have maintained a Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement since 2010 and, in December 2014, was granted SPG+ status, the first ASEAN country to enjoy such trade preferences.  Moreover, the EU doubled its financial endowment for development cooperation with the Philippines in 2014-2020 and has also provided considerable humanitarian and emergency assistance to tropical storm victims. Parliament calls on the Philippines to ratify and implement all fundamental international conventions on human and labour rights, environmental protection and good governance listed in Annex VIII to Regulation (EU) No 978/2012.
