In 2014, the Commission welcomed the possibility of banning imports of fishing products from the Philippines if it did not improve the control of illegal, undeclared or regulated fishing before, and the Commission therefore initiated a dialogue to address deficiencies in its fisheries management and control systems. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this framework agreement.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In 2004, the Council authorized the Commission to negotiate a Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (APC) with the Philippines. Negotiations with the Philippines were opened in February 2009 and concluded in June 2010. Both parties signed the CPA on June 25, 2010 and the CPA was signed on July 11, 2012 in Phnom Penh, at the ASEAN Regional Forum Ministerial Meeting. The CPA with the Philippines is the first-ever bilateral agreement with the Philippines. It replaces the current legal framework of the 1980 Cooperation Agreement between the European Economic Community and the member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). In foreign policy, the CPA contains commitments that are at the heart of the European Union's foreign policy, including provisions on human rights, the fight against terrorism and the International Criminal Court.  In light of these elements, I have decided, along with a majority of my colleagues, to give my approval to the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This issue does not require much discussion. Croatia's EU membership has slightly changed our trade agreements with the Philippines. Today, we are simply legitimising the newly created situation. As far as I know, our trading partners are also satisfied with the proposal put forward, so I am unequivocally voting in favour.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Framework Agreement on the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other, includes provisions on human rights, non-proliferation, combating terrorism and the International Criminal Court. In addition, it also includes areas of current interest, such as the peace process and disaster risk management.  The PCA thus strengthens EU-Philippines cooperation through various policy areas such as migration, taxation, the environment, energy, science and technology, maritime and air transport, tourism, culture, money laundering and terrorist financing, illicit drugs, organised crime and corruption. In addition, the involvement of both sides in the economic and commercial fields is also strengthened.  As it is in line with the objectives of creating a comprehensive and coherent economic and political framework for relations between EU countries and ASEAN countries (Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam) and also have an important development component, including strict provisions on the protection of the EU's financial interests , I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which gives Parliament the approval of a framework agreement for partnership and cooperation between the European Union and the Philippines. Parliament accompanied this approval with a non-legislative resolution detailing its recommendations. As a reminder, the partnership between the Union and the Philippines needs to be strengthened, particularly in the areas of the fight against poverty and terrorism, human rights and trade relations. Indeed, since December 2015, negotiations for a free trade treaty between the two parties have been launched.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the PPE Group and the parliamentary majority, I voted in favour of the report on the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) between the European Union and the Philippines. This agreement contains provisions on human rights, non-proliferation, the fight against terrorism and the International Criminal Court. The PCA strengthens cooperation in a variety of areas, such as migration, taxation, the environment, energy, science and technology, transport, tourism, culture, but also the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing, illicit drugs, organised crime and corruption. The conclusion of this agreement is positive for relations between the contracting parties and for the possible influence of the EU in that state.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this own-initiative report which did not include any amendments that our group tabled, the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region and the joint US-Philippine maneuvers, the repression of civil society activists and members of left-wing parties, the proper implementation of the Human Rights Conventions in the country and the existence of extra-judicial killings by state security forces and paramilitary forces. While some of these elements are underpinned in the final text, it is at the end of an instrument that seeks to move towards the signing of an EU-Philippine Free Trade Agreement, which, like the other types of instruments in the process of negotiating with other countries since the Doha paralysis, has a double-sided : on the one hand the promise of new trade opportunities, accompany and secure its reform processes and on the other hand, the risks that trade liberalization between economies with very different levels of development pose to the weakest part.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. The agreement ensures closer cooperation between the EU and the Philippines. Closer cooperation will benefit both sides both economically and strategically. However, it is important that we do not compromise on the requirement that the Philippines must respect human rights, labour rights, social rights and environmental protection.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines. With the agreement, we not only support the development of the Philippines towards the rule of law, but also promote cooperation in important areas such as the fight against terrorism or illegal drug trafficking. But we will also work more closely together on research and culture, another component from which both partners of the agreement can benefit.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. –I voted against the adoption of this framework agreement between the EU and the Philippines because the EU's cooperation and collaboration agreements with third countries are the antechamber of a free trade agreement, which we oppose because of its negative effects on the working class of the countries concerned. Moreover, such trade agreements pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. The amendments tabled by our GUE/NGL group on the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region, the crackdown on left-wing activists and politicians, extrajudicial killings and our concerns about how this economic agreement will harm the local population were all rejected, so I have no doubt voting against this agreement.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has had relations with the Republic of the Philippines for a long time, which in recent years have expanded and deepened significantly, especially with regard to trade and investment. One of the main points of the EU's Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Philippines calls for a meaningful human rights dialogue to be established in the form of a working group, given the communist and Islamic unrest and insurgency that has been going on since 2007. As I consider this agreement to be very important for future relations between the EU and the Philippines, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of granting consent to this Framework Agreement on the Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and the Philippines. We will continue to insist on respect for human rights, better labour and social standards and efforts to implement better environmental rights in this country.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Already in 2004, the Council authorised the European Commission to negotiate an individual Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other. This agreement also includes cooperation in different sectors of the economy, namely migration, taxation, the environment, energy, science and technology, maritime and air transport, tourism, culture, money laundering and terrorist financing, drug trafficking, organised crime and corruption. I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I have agreed to conclude a partnership and cooperation agreement between the EU and the Philippines, as there is further potential for developing these relations. The agreement contains a number of areas where mutual cooperation should be deepened. From a foreign policy point of view, these are issues of human rights enforcement, disarmament, the fight against terrorism and criminal cooperation. In the economic sphere, it is mainly about creating appropriate trade and political conditions and deepening cooperation at ASEAN Community level. Other areas include migration, tax issues, the environment, energy, science and technology, as well as tourism and culture. The EU and the Member States should also cooperate more intensively on intelligence sharing, but also in building government capacity to combat extremism. The current problems are particularly concerned about the 2002 tensions in the South China Sea, where, contrary to the 2002 statements, several sides claim land in disputed waters. I therefore hope that, in cooperation with the EU, the Philippines will thrive to improve its political and legal environment. In the medium term, it will be necessary to increase transparency, improve governance and further develop infrastructure to make the Philippines an attractive country for foreign investment.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the strongest instruments of European foreign policy is the conclusion of trade partnerships. By acceding to these agreements by the new Member States, we are expanding the areas where entrepreneurs and companies from the European Union can place their products and services.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The first bilateral agreement with the Philippines between the European Economic Community and the Member States of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations is the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Philippines, and represents an important step towards strengthening bilateral relations and the EU's role in Southeast Asia. The same agreement is essential to create a path for strengthening political, regional and global cooperation, and is based on common values such as democracy and human rights. Also, human rights provisions, non-spreading of weapons, counterterrorism and the International Criminal Court are significant foreign policy obligations, all of which are enshrined in the agreement. I believe that this agreement strengthens cooperation at sectoral level in a number of policy areas, and also covers areas of current interest, such as the peace process and disaster risk management. It also strengthens co-operation on environmental, tourism, culture, energy, technology, maritime and air transport issues. Furthermore, strengthening cooperation through agreements and tackling money laundering and terrorist financing, organised crime, corruption and illicit drugs is very important. Consequently, I support this recommendation, as I consider that this Agreement extends, in addition, the scope of action in both the economic and trade areas.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the European Parliament's legislative resolution of 8 June 2016 on the draft Council decision on the conclusion– on behalf of the Union – the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other. The signing and ratification of bilateral agreements should be left to each Member State.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other hand, includes, inter alia, issues of current interest, such as the issue of peace, migration, taxes, the environment, energy, nature and technology, maritime and air transport, tourism, culture, money laundering and terrorist financing, and illicit trade. The agreement expands the scope for mutual co-operation in the economic and trade domain. The Conclusion of the Agreement is in line with the objective of developing a comprehensive and coherent economic and political framework for relations between the Member States of the Union and the Countries of the Union of Southeast Asian Nations. I support the conclusion of the Agreement, as I believe that the Agreement itself contains an important development component and strict provisions on the protection of the financial interests of the European Union.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, on behalf of the Union. I support the approval of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Philippines, as I agree that the European Union continues to support the Philippines financially with the aim of reducing poverty, promoting social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, promoting peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report analyses EU-Philippine relations. While the aim is to approve a cooperation agreement, the report also refers to a possible free trade agreement with all Southeast Asian countries, and this is problematic for us. He refers to tensions in the South China Sea, calling on China to stop its aggression, but any criticism of the joint Philippine-US exercises is absent. In view of the above, we have abstained in all 3 reports on the EU-Philippines cooperation agreement.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU in its classic way and method and through various trick attempts to create problems in Member States with various agreements with third countries.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on a Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines, which expresses its support for the conclusion of the agreement. It is important for the EU to maintain dialogue with the countries of the region and to strengthen relations with foreign, economic and trade policy. By continuing to assist the Philippines and support capacity building, the EU will help reduce poverty, respect for human rights and the rule of law, promote peace, security and judicial reform. To achieve this, the EP encourages the Government of the Philippines to continue to promote steps to eradicate corruption and promote human rights. As the Philippines is one of the developing countries most exposed to climate change, EU capacity-building support in this area is of particular importance.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I followed the rapporteur on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of giving consent to the conclusion of the EU-Philippines Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation, an agreement that strengthens bilateral relations between both countries in the areas of general principles and political dialogue, foreign policy, economic, trade and sectorial cooperation. This consent will allow the Agreement to be ratified and implemented.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ As the Philippines is one of the fastest growing economies in the region in recent years and the European Union is the Philippines' main trading and investment partner, I supported the Council's decision to conclude a Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other.  The Philippines is one of the 10 members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (AESAN) and the region's fifth largest economy and asean's second largest market. I believe that both sides aim to conclude an agreement covering a wide range of issues, including the elimination of tariffs and other barriers to trade, services and investment, access to public procurement markets and additional rules on competition and intellectual property rights protection. A future agreement would also include a comprehensive chapter to ensure that economic relations between the EU and the Philippines are accompanied by environmental protection and social development.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, on behalf of the Union, I supported it. The Philippines must continue to provide financial support and help reduce poverty, respect for human rights and the rule of law. They should be encouraged to continue towards an end to corruption and respect for human rights. Member States would assist in building capacity in the international fight against terrorism and extremism on fundamental rights and the rule of law through cooperation with the Philippine Government on intelligence sharing. The government should also be encouraged to invest in new technologies and the Internet in order to facilitate cultural exchange and trade between the Philippine islands. The partnership with the Philippines is also important from a strategic point of view, as they are located near the most important international waterways and air routes in the South China Sea.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this own-initiative report which did not include any amendments that our group tabled, the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region and the joint US-Philippine maneuvers, the repression of civil society activists and members of left-wing parties, the proper implementation of the Human Rights Conventions in the country and the existence of extra-judicial killings by state security forces and paramilitary forces. While some of these elements are underpinned in the final text, it is at the end of an instrument that seeks to move towards the signing of an EU-Philippine Free Trade Agreement, which, like the other types of instruments in the process of negotiating with other countries since the Doha paralysis, has a double-sided : on the one hand the promise of new trade opportunities, accompany and secure its reform processes and on the other hand, the risks that trade liberalization between economies with very different levels of development pose to the weakest part.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. These texts are updates of the agreements between the EU and the Philippines. While the descriptive part of the substantive report is honest about the situation in the Philippines, the comments on the situation in the China Sea and the ongoing maritime clashes in Asia seem ridiculous to us. It should be remembered that foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and that the EU does not have to claim an international role, however small. I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Cooperation between the EU and the Republic of the Philippines has two main objectives: intensive economic cooperation and the exchange of political experience. The content of the agreement in question supports both of these objectives and makes it possible to assume that the Republic of the Philippines will continue its political and economic reforms, which is why I voted in favour of it as proposed.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU should continue to provide financial assistance and capacity-building support to the Philippines in the areas of poverty reduction, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, the promotion of peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform, disaster preparedness, aid and recovery and the implementation of effective policies to address climate change. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this own-initiative report which did not include any amendments that our group tabled, the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region and the joint US-Philippine maneuvers, the repression of civil society activists and members of left-wing parties, the proper implementation of the Human Rights Conventions in the country and the existence of extra-judicial killings by state security forces and paramilitary forces. While some of these elements are underpinned in the final text, it is at the end of an instrument that seeks to move towards the signing of an EU-Philippine Free Trade Agreement, which, like the other types of instruments in the process of negotiating with other countries since the Doha paralysis, has a double-sided : on the one hand the promise of new trade opportunities, accompany and secure its reform processes and on the other hand, the risks that trade liberalization between economies with very different levels of development pose to the weakest part.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part. I believe that this agreement marks an important step towards strengthening bilateral relations and the EU’s role in South-East Asia, based on shared universal values such as democracy and human rights. In addition, it paves the way for enhanced political, regional and global cooperation.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU-Philippine Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement includes provisions on human rights, non-proliferation or the fight against terrorism. It also strengthens cooperation on a wide range of political issues such as migration, taxation, the environment, energy, science and technology, maritime and air transport, tourism or culture. We are therefore talking about an agreement which will provide a coherent and comprehensive political and economic framework for EU-Philippine relations, so I think it is necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We are in the presence of two recommendations, one on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Philippines and the other recommendation to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU in the agreement. The first recommends the approval of the agreement, the second the approval of the protocol for the addition of Croatia. The Philippines is considered an example to be followed by other countries in the region on human rights. Unfortunately, this report is at least partial and does not take into account reality, with particular emphasis on the statements by the President of the Philippines on respect for human rights.  References to security and military cooperation lead us to conclude that we are talking about another action of imperial interference aimed at increasing the military influence of the EU and Nato in that region. We voted against it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Parliament hereby gives its assent to the conclusion of the Protocol and instructs its President to communicate Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission, as well as to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and the Republic of the Philippines. I was able to vote in favour of this report without hesitation.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part. I support the approval of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Philippines, which will provide financial support to the Philippines in poverty reduction and strengthen cooperation in the fight against terrorism and extremism.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Forty years, the European Union has provided the Philippines with assistance of around EUR 1 billion to combat poverty and raise living standards. This is particularly true for the poorest sections of society. In particular, eur 325 million was allocated to the EU budget in 2014-2020 and that, compared to a further EUR 130 million in 2007-2013, sufficient assistance is already being provided. And the two primary areas in which the European Union and its Member States provide their support are the rule of law and also inclusive growth through sustainable energy policy and job creation. It must be said that all these issues are also relevant to the European Union. Sometimes the European Union is successfully combating poverty well enough on its own territory, so we can also pass on our experience to filipino friends.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Philippines has enabled them to strengthen their political and economic dialogue with the EU. As the third most vulnerable developing country to climate change, the EU is committed to providing support and assistance to the Philippine Government, with the aim, among other things, of combating poverty, reforming the judicial system and, finally, promoting respect for human rights. It is precisely on this point that, while appreciating the country's participation since 2001 in the international coalition against terrorism, there are still cases of human rights violations, mainly perpetrated by the security forces. For these reasons, considering it essential to look into this matter further, I have chosen to abstain, hoping for a future European commitment to the clear and prompt protection of human rights.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the adoption of this Framework Agreement between the EU and the Philippines, because the EU's cooperation and cooperation agreements with third countries are the antechamber of a free trade agreement, which we oppose because of its negative effects on the working class of the countries concerned. Moreover, such trade agreements pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. The amendments tabled by our GUE/NGL group on the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region, the crackdown on left-wing activists and politicians, extrajudicial killings and our concerns about how this economic agreement will harm the local population were all rejected, so I have no doubt voting against this agreement.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to update the framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the European Union and the Philippines.  While the rapporteur gives a fairly realistic description of the situation in the Philippines, the comments on tensions in the South China Sea and maritime clashes in Asia appear to us to be unwelcome.  I therefore voted against this text because, let us remember, foreign policy is the exclusive act of States and the European Union does not have to claim an international role, however small.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this report. This is an important step for a major partner in the region for the EU. In this text, our group, S and D, has insisted on social and environmental rights, as well as on provisions guaranteeing fair trade.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 In view of the progress made in the country and the positive consequences of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and the Philippines, I voted in favour of this resolution and we now expect it to be forwarded by the President to the Council, the Commission, the European External Action Service, the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and to the Government and Parliament of the Republic of the Philippines.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This text updates the agreements between the EU and the Philippines. Although the descriptive part of the report is relatively accurate with respect to the situation in the Philippines, comments on the situation in the China Sea and ongoing clashes in Asia are irrelevant. On the other hand, it should be remembered that foreign policy must remain the exclusive responsibility of States. That is why I objected to this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I voted against this report. I do not believe it is in the interest of the British people that the European Union is negotiating any framework with the Philippines.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, as the committee recommended on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal by which the EP supports the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part. From the point of view of international and national human rights legislation, the Philippines is a role model for other countries in the region. I agree that the EU should continue to provide financial support and capacity-building assistance to the Philippines in order to reduce poverty, increase social inclusion, strengthen respect for human rights and the rule of law, promote peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform, and help the country in disaster preparedness, aid and reconstruction, as well as contribute to the implementation of effective climate change policies.

name: Amjad Bashir (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Despite support for enhanced cooperation, concerns remain over human rights issues in the Philippines. However, I believe the underlying significance of cooperation between the EU and the Philippines is that increased trade and investment will be critical in helping to solve many of these very problems. Opening up markets will empower the Filipino people, creating wealth and prosperity and a new socio-economic class that will have the clout and stability needed in order to achieve real change. They will be the leaders of tomorrow who will be best suited to tackling pressing domestic concerns, including the human rights issues brought up by my colleagues. Nonetheless, the Philippines should be commended in other areas, such as the Mindanao peace settlement with the Moro Islamic Liberation Front – it is a significant political achievement – as is the Republic Act criminalising enforced disappearances. Let us also hope that the Philippines adopts an even-handed approach in the ever more unstable South China Sea and that the security risk that is Abu Sayyaf, a terrorist group linked with Al Qaeda and Daesh, is swiftly dealt with.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is an update of the agreements between the EU and the Philippines; while the descriptive part of the report is honest about the situation in the Philippines, the comments on the situation in the China Sea and the ongoing maritime clashes in Asia are completely irrelevant.  Moreover, it should be remembered about this report and the Commission's similar initiatives that foreign policy is the exclusive act of the Member States and that the EU does not have to give itself an international role, however small. I voted against this abusive claim from Brussels.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses the conclusion of a framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the Union and the Republic of the Philippines.  This partnership represents an additional step in the EU's engagement in South-East Asia, both economically and politically. It is therefore necessary to continue to provide financial and development support, including to fight poverty and build the country's capacity while helping it to fight climate change.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The establishment of a framework agreement with the Republic of the Philippines is an important step forward in strengthening the Role of the European Union in the region, promoting the development and consolidation of democratic processes. At a time when china's presence in the waters of the South China Sea is particularly strong, with a relative increase in tensions in the area, it seems increasingly necessary to establish partnership and cooperation relations that feed a collaborative approach. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the EU-Philippines agreement, because I believe it is essential to indicate the priorities to be followed in relations with the archipelago state. The EU's primary objective must be to strengthen existing economic ties, pushing for greater commitment by the Asian Republic to the consolidation of democracy and human rights. The Philippines must continue to improve investment conditions, increasing transparency and good governance and further developing the infrastructure system. Investment in new technologies and the Internet must be seen as a key factor in facilitating not only trade but above all cultural exchanges between the many islands of the archipelago.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this own-initiative report which did not include any amendments that our group tabled, the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region and the joint US-Philippine maneuvers, the repression of civil society activists and members of left-wing parties, the proper implementation of the Human Rights Conventions in the country and the existence of extra-judicial killings by state security forces and paramilitary forces. While some of these elements are underpinned in the final text, it is at the end of an instrument that seeks to move towards the signing of an EU-Philippine Free Trade Agreement, which, like the other types of instruments in the process of negotiating with other countries since the Doha paralysis, has a double-sided : on the one hand the promise of new trade opportunities, accompany and secure its reform processes and on the other hand, the risks that trade liberalization between economies with very different levels of development pose to the weakest part.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns an EU-Philippines Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement, which is a simple update of the agreements between the EU and the Philippines. While the descriptive part of the substantive report is honest about the situation in the Philippines, the comments on the situation in the China Sea and the ongoing maritime clashes in Asia seem ridiculous to us. However, the EU does not have to claim an international role as it is trying to do, since foreign policy is still entirely a matter for states alone. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines presents some critical issues that convinced me to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In March 2014, the Resolution notes that, in March 2014, the Philippine Government signed the Peace Agreement in Mindanao with the Moro Islamic Liberation Front, which includes the creation of the Bangsamoro autonomous region. The Philippines has been part of the coalition against international terrorism since 2001. In its fight against other militias that maintain ties with Southeast Asian international and regional terrorist groups, such as Al Qaeda and Dáesh, it is receiving training from the U.S. military in the fight against terrorism and the insurgency and intelligence.  The Resolution states that the EU should continue to provide the Philippines with support and assistance in capacity building for peace promotion, reconciliation, security and judicial reform, and assist the country in disaster prevention, relief and recovery.  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it sets out in a non-legislative resolution the arguments for supporting the EU-Philippines Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation. From the point of view of international and national human rights legislation, the Philippines is a role model for other countries in the region. The Philippines is made up of thousands of islands and the country's structure poses difficulties in terms of internal relations, infrastructure and trade. In 2014, the EU granted the Philippines GSP+ preferential status, making the Philippines the first ASEAN country to benefit from such trade preferences, which allows the Philippines to export 66% of its total products to the EU, including processed fruit, coconut oil, footwear, fish and textiles, without paying export duty. Today, the EU is one of the Philippines' largest foreign investors and trading partners.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Relations with the Philippines are of great importance to the European Union. On the trade side, the EU is the fourth largest export market for the Philippines and the country is a major trading partner, but not only one. The country is, in fact, a positive model in the region when it comes to human rights legislation, and its strategic position cannot be ignored. For these reasons, I welcome the resolution adopted today, establishing a framework for partnership and cooperation between the EU and the Republic of the Philippines. It is important that within the framework of the partnership, the EU continues to offer support to the Philippines, in particular to support the fight against poverty, the realisation of full social inclusion and the creation of capacities for adapting to climate change and responding to natural disasters, to which the country is strongly exposed. It is also crucial that cooperation between the EU and the Philippines in the fight against violent forms of religious extremism is actively pursued, as well as the commitment to implement effective measures to combat this phenomenon.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. If the descriptive part of the substantive report is honest about the situation in the Philippines, the comments on the situation in the China Sea and the ongoing maritime clashes in Asia seem ridiculous to me.  I would like to point out that foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and that the EU does not have to claim an international role, however small.   I also voted against this report.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the European Union's efforts to promote peace, freedom and democracy in the world, and following the efforts of the Council and the relevant committees to reach a satisfactory agreement allowing adequate support to the Philippines within the framework of the overall cooperation that the EU intends to establish with the partner countries of the various continents, it is appropriate to support this act, which may represent a deepening of relations with the Asian island state. , to whom we can only express gratitude and human closeness for its adherence to the fight against global terrorism which – including in the territories of the Philippine Republic – has shown its action of violence, fanaticism and intolerance. Action to which the entire international community must respond adequately.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to update the framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the European Union and the Philippines. While the rapporteur gives a fairly realistic description of the situation in the Philippines, the comments on tensions in the South China Sea and maritime clashes in Asia appear to us to be unwelcome. As a sovereign state, the Republic of the Philippines does not have to meet the Union's requirements for compliance with international conventions. It should also be remembered that foreign policy is an exclusive competence of the Member States and that the European Union cannot claim an international role. As usual, the Union wishes to grant itself prerogatives that are not its own. That is why I voted against it.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the EU-Philippines Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (resolution). I believe that the EU should continue to provide financial support and assistance to the Philippines for capacity building for poverty reduction, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, promotion of peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform. The EU should also assist the Philippines in preparing for disasters, in relief operations and in the recovery and implementation of effective policies to combat climate change. However, I am concerned about the continuing serious reports of human rights violations by philippine military forces in the conduct of riot operations, in particular by paramilitary units. I therefore encourage the Government of the Philippines to continue to promote further progress in promoting human rights.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution because I welcome the EU-Philippines Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation which stresses the importance of the Philippines as a partner of the European Union. Among others, the EU should continue assisting the Philippines in tackling social problems and enhancing national capacity. I am also looking forward to more information exchange and research sharing for the benefit of both parties.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I welcome the partnership and cooperation agreement between the EU and the Philippines, I believe that the accompanying resolution could have been more thorough and could better address some of the country's problems. That is why I preferred to abstain on the final vote.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and believe that strengthening bilateral relations is in the common interest.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report containing a proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, is part of the wider effort to develop Europe's relations with that State. I believe that we should support the development of these relations, since it could have positive effects on security, the economy and policy. In this respect, however, we see pressure being exerted on issues of surveillance and a strong military presence in the wider Philippines region, which I am opposed to. That is why I have decided to abstain from all aspects of the vote on this recommendation.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Philippines has been part of the international coalition against terrorism since 2001. However, there are many concerns about the isis situation as it is spreading propaganda in local languages. That is why I think it is important for the European Union to continue to provide financial and assistance support to the country in order to reduce poverty, promote peace and human rights but, above all, support them in the fight against terrorism. Terrorist acts in the Philippines can significantly affect the European market as the country is located close to the main international air and sea traffic routes. I therefore voted in favour because, as an MEP, I believe it is necessary to continue to support the Philippines.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Under this proposal, the Council is called upon to adopt a decision aiming to approve the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Philippines, of the other part, to take account of the accession of Croatia to the European Union on behalf of the European Union and its Member States. The proposed protocol incorporates Croatia as contracting party to the Agreement and commits the EU to providing the authentic version of the Agreement in the Croatian language.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the partnership agreement with the Republic of the Philippines, which would bring great benefits to the Philippine State in terms of economic development, financial support, poverty reduction, social inclusion, respect for human rights, promotion of national peace and security. In addition, cooperation with the European Union would include assistance measures to the Republic of the Philippines in the effective preparation of natural disasters and to facilitate the implementation of policies to tackle climate change.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with providing financial support and capacity-building assistance to the Philippines for poverty alleviation, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law. Other aspects of mutual interest are the promotion of peace, reconciliation, security and the implementation of effective policies to tackle climate change. The baseline principle of the agreement should remain that of encourages the Philippine government to continue fostering further progress in the elimination of corruption and the promotion of human rights. I agree we need to establish safe trade routes, and encourages confidence-building measures to engage in bilateral and multilateral cooperation in order to effectively contribute to security not just in the Philippines but also in the region. I support the call for investment in new technologies and the internet in order to promote cultural exchange and trade among the islands and the consideration that the EU should further develop people-to-people exchanges of students, academics and scientific researchers, as well as cultural exchanges.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the adoption of this Framework Agreement between the EU and the Philippines, because the EU's cooperation and cooperation agreements with third countries are the antechamber of a free trade agreement, which we oppose because of its negative effects on the working class of the countries concerned. Moreover, such trade agreements pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. The amendments tabled by our GUE/NGL group on the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region, the crackdown on left-wing activists and politicians, extrajudicial killings and our concerns about how this economic agreement will harm the local population were all rejected, so I have no doubt voting against this agreement.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the mid-1960s, the Republic of the Philippines has been an important trading partner of European states in Southeast Asia. Union funds and humanitarian assistance have proven to be key factors in the democratisation of Philippine society, strengthening the rule of law and creating a framework that has enabled considerable developments in respect for human rights. I welcome the considerable efforts made by the Philippine Government to strengthen capacities to combat terrorism and extremism, but I would like to express my concern about the spread of Islamist propaganda and the increase in the number of extremists in the region. In order to combat these emerging trends, the Republic of the Philippines must develop its institutional capacity by ensuring respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law, reducing poverty, increasing social inclusion and promoting social peace. I voted in favour of this report, wanting to call on the Philippine Government and the governments of the Member States to continue to work together both in the fight against terrorism, trafficking in human beings and poverty, and in the establishment of measures to protect human rights and human rights in the field of labour, the environment and governance.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In its resolution, Parliament welcomes the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and takes the view that the EU should continue to provide support and capacity-building assistance to the Philippines in order to promote peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform and to help the Philippines achieve disaster preparedness. Furthermore, it commends the Philippines for its participation in the international counter-terrorism coalition since 2001 and expresses concern about the possible impact of ISIS on related groups in Southeast Asia. It also stresses the importance of the Peace Process in Mindanao. Calls on the government to implement all fundamental international conventions related to human and labour rights, the environment and good governance. It also encourages the Philippines to continue its efforts to improve the investment climate and welcomes the 2015 agreement to open negotiations on an EU-Philippines free trade agreement. I personally support this agreement and understand its importance. I voted yes.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report includes a motion for a resolution on the conclusion, of the EU-Philippines Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation. As a global force for the upholding of human rights and as a leader in supporting developing states, it has always been part of EU’s ethos to support such countries and their population. Hence I supported this report with my vote.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation with the Republic of the Philippines. I support the participation of the Republic of the Philippines in the international coalition against terrorism since 2001 and the strengthening of its government's capacity in the international fight against terrorism and extremism.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The text put to the vote consists of an update of the agreements between the EU and the Philippines. While the descriptive part of the substantive report is realistic about the situation in the Philippines, comments on the context in the China Sea and on ongoing maritime clashes in Asia are not serious. To the extent that foreign policy is a competence of the States and the European Union does not have to claim to play an international role in this area, I voted against it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the accompanying resolution to the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part. The EU should continue to provide support and capacity building to help the Philippines promote peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform and assist the country in terms of disaster preparedness and subsequent recovery. The resolution congratulates the Philippines for being part of the 2001 international counterterrorism coalition, and expresses concern about the possible impact of ISIS on affiliated groups in Southeast Asia. It is important that we support any country that wants to fight its terrorist organizations because, as we see nowadays, they extend globally and fighting them only within our borders is not enough. The resolution also encourages the Philippines to continue improving the investment climate and welcomes the 2015 agreement to open negotiations on a free trade agreement between the EU and the Philippines.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Negative, because with the justification of human rights and democracy in countries such as the Philippines investments are being made resulting in huge problems in EU member countries in need of investment. Multinationals, in their own way because of the great profit, after exploiting the local population of third countries, are also destroying trade in Europe.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In terms of international and national human rights legislation, the Philippines is a model to follow for other countries in the region, having ratified eight of the nine main human rights conventions. The economy is still suffering from the negative effects of Typhoon Haiyan, worsening food insecurity and putting another million people in poverty, according to United Nations estimates. I agree that the EU should continue to provide financial support and capacity-building assistance to the Philippines with a view to poverty reduction, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, promote peace, reconciliation, security and reform of the judicial system, and to assist the country in the context of preparation , disaster relief and recovery and the implementation of effective policies to combat climate change.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: it should be remembered that foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and that the EU does not have to claim an international role, however small.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution addresses the importance of the EU-Philippine Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. This Framework Agreement is inseparable from the blocking situation in the EU-ASEAN agreement. In this context, the EU's orientation is to make partnership agreements with countries in the region.  The Philippines is identified as an example to be followed by other countries in the region on human rights. Elucidative, right away in the face of the recent statements of the new President of the Philippines on the death penalty in the country. Reference is made to the Defence Cooperation Strengthening Agreement with the US. It is nodded by what is considered to be the deterioration of relations between China and the Philippines, with the Philippines' resources being referred to international arbitration, including the International Arbitral Tribunal of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. It is also referred to, what looks like a provocative act, the creation by the Philippines in this maritime region of maritime and air infrastructure that will be accessible to Japanese, American and Vietnamese boats and aircraft. Aspects that show that this agreement is inseparable from an imbrillable theia of geopolitical interests, part of a global policy of siege of China.  Added to this are the economic aspects - trade liberalisation. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are many reasons why Europe must continue to provide support and assistance to the Philippines for the development of its potential. The EU has a major role to play in promoting peace, security, judicial reform and assisting the Philippines in frequent natural disasters. At the same time, the Philippines is very active in the functioning of an international coalition against terrorism.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained. No opinion.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I am of the opinion that the European Union, as a world leader in the protection of human rights and the fight against poverty, should continue to provide financial assistance to the Philippines to support the country in implementing the necessary reforms. However, we must not turn a blind eye to the fact that there are frequent reports of serious human rights violations by Filipino soldiers in the implementation of anti-insupply measures, especially by paramilitary forces. The European Union and its individual Member States must therefore continue to cooperate with the Philippines in intelligence exchanges in order to cooperate and provide support in building government capacity in the international fight against terrorism and extremism in the context of fundamental rights and the rule of law.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstain from the report because better work could be done to help the Philippines.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the EU-Philippine Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement (resolution), because on the grounds of human rights and democracy in countries such as the Philippines, investments are being made, creating huge problems for EU member countries in need of investment. Multinationals, in their own way because of the great profit, after exploiting the local population of third countries, are also destroying trade in Europe.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the adoption of this report as it highlights several important aspects for the future of the agricultural sector. I support the overall view of the report that improving innovation and competitiveness is essential for the agricultural sector moving into the future and that future legislation should take this into account. I also agree with the report on the need to promote a more prudent use of natural resources, to ensure the biodiversity of our farms, to tackle food waste and to tackle soil degradation. I also echo the report in calling for the Commission to provide a more ambitious strategy to align and focus research and innovation on these issues so as the European agricultural sector can retail and even improve its competitiveness in the future.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU - Philippines Framework Agreement represents, in my opinion, an important step with regard to a major partner in the region for the EU. We must continue insisting on respect for human rights, labour, social, environmental rights, as well as on their effective monitoring, and on provisions guaranteeing fair trade. Trade, geo-strategic and security issues are very important considering the delicate regional situation, given China’s increasing assertiveness and territorial claims, maritime security and potential terrorism concerns. I am very concerned about the South China Sea issue and the risk of conflict faced with Chinese assertiveness. Therefore, I support the call on the Vice-President/High Representative to identify how the EU should best engage in bilateral and multilateral security cooperation. Finally, I believe we must call for an effective implementation of the UN guiding principles regarding business and human rights.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part. Indeed, I support the need to continue to provide financial support to the Philippines so that it can devote itself to implementing policies of poverty eradication, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law. In this sense, the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement can strengthen the architecture of the Philippine institutions in a more democratic sense. I strongly supported the call for the Government of the Philippines to develop capacity to combat trafficking in human beings and called on the EU and its Member States to support the government, and in particular the Inter-Nation Council against Trafficking in Human Beings (IACAT), in its efforts to improve assistance and support for victims. Finally, I hope that the newly elected President of the Republic, Mr Duterte, will act as guarantor of demands for peace and democratic stability and a moderate promoter of the unity of the country and social cohesion, continuing along the path of combating corruption and drug trafficking within a framework of law and legality.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. International agreements concluded by the EU on behalf of its Member States must apply equally to all. I therefore support Croatia's accession to this agreement and the corresponding update.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The EU should continue to provide financial support to the Philippines and provide assistance in capacity-building to fight poverty, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, promote peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform. In addition, the country should be supported in disaster preparedness, emergency and reconstruction assistance and the implementation of effective policies to combat climate change.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this own-initiative report which did not include any amendments that our group tabled, the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region and the joint US-Philippine maneuvers, the repression of civil society activists and members of left-wing parties, the proper implementation of the Human Rights Conventions in the country and the existence of extra-judicial killings by state security forces and paramilitary forces. While some of these elements are underpinned in the final text, it is at the end of an instrument that seeks to move towards the signing of an EU-Philippine Free Trade Agreement, which, like the other types of instruments in the process of negotiating with other countries since the Doha paralysis, has a double-sided : on the one hand the promise of new trade opportunities, accompany and secure its reform processes and on the other hand, the risks that trade liberalization between economies with very different levels of development pose to the weakest part.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which is the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation with the Philippines. It express concerns about the potential spread of ISIS in South-East Asia but encourages the Philippine government to continue fostering further progress in the elimination of corruption and the promotion of human rights.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the EU - Philippines framework agreement on partnership and cooperation in order to support the significance of such bilateral relations.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report analyses EU-Philippine relations. While its purpose is to approve a cooperation agreement, the report also refers to a possible free trade agreement with all Southeast Asian countries, and this is problematic for us. He refers to tensions in the South China Sea, calling on China to stop its aggression, but any criticism of the joint Philippine-US exercises is absent. In view of the above, we have abstained in all 3 reports on the EU-Philippines cooperation agreement.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution which called on the EU to continue providing financial support and capacity-building assistance to the Philippines for poverty alleviation and the implementation of policies to tackle climate change. At the same time, I was happy that it called on the Philippines to foster further progress in the elimination of corruption and the promotion of human rights. Considering the Philippines as one of the countries having been granted GSP+ status by the EU, it is essential that the Philippines ensure effective implementation of all the core international conventions relating to human and labour rights, the environment and good governance. Likewise, I supported the call on the Philippines that under the GSP+ beneficiaries they will have to prove that they are implementing their obligations concerning human rights, labour, environmental and governance standards. Finally, the resolution did express concern over the continued reports of severe human rights violations by the Philippine military in the conduct of counter-insurgency measures. It also stressed that there are growing concerns that ISIS will win over affiliated groups in South-East Asia. It is important that we recognise the problems that face the current Philippine Government, especially terrorism.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it highlights the importance of working closely with the Philippines in order to support the country while also benefiting from the exchange of intelligence, research, students and culture.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in order to encourage progress in promoting human rights, including the publication of the National Action Plan on Human Rights, as well as on the elimination of corruption and the development of the economy as a whole.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other because the Philippines represents a strategic partner on the route of transport of goods in the South China Sea.  The financial assistance provided by the Union to the Philippines can certainly contribute to initiation of reforms aimed at establishing long-lasting peace, reducing poverty and social exclusion, promoting the rule of law, and security. It is certainly necessary to solve the Philippines' fundamental problems, such as the Mindanao peace process, and to establish intelligence sharing in the form of strengthening the fight against international terrorism and extremism. In accordance with the above, I support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. It should be remembered that foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and that the EU does not have to claim an international role, however small.  I naturally voted against these three texts.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Framework Partnership Agreement between EU Member States and the Philippines. While the importance of this country is sometimes underestimated, partnership with it is undoubtedly very important for the EU. This year we are celebrating the 25th anniversary of mutual partnership and deepening not only economic relations is the goal of both partners. Given that the Philippines, for example, exports labor, it is important to make sure that human rights are not violated. Ratification of the Framework Agreement with the Philippines will provide a platform for enhanced cooperation and institutionalise long-term relations, particularly in areas such as development, trade, labour rights and human rights dialogue.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, in which Parliament welcomes the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation with the Philippines, and believes that the European Union should continue to provide financial and development assistance to the Philippines.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This motion for a resolution is an inventory of the Council's draft framework agreement on partnership and cooperation between the European Union and the Philippines. It clearly represents progress, but also calls for improvements in certain areas, such as legal protection for Filipino seafarers and the fight against terrorism. Because of the balanced reporting, I am voting in favour of this resolution.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution as it welcomes the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation with the Philippines. It express concerns about the potential spread of ISIS in South-East Asia but encourages the Philippine government to continue fostering further progress in the elimination of corruption and the promotion of human rights.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution has its positives, in particular the promotion of the fight against corruption and the promotion of the protection of human rights. On the other hand, the EU's path towards an EU-ASEAN FREE TRADE Agreement, the Philippines' maritime conflict with China and the related arming of the Philippines, the Philippines-US alliance in the fight against terrorism, and the promotion of public-private partnerships for infrastructure development are problematic. The Philippines has been and is strongly supported by the US, especially in the context of the maritime conflict with China. The Philippine government still supports the country's arms, given China's activities. While the resolution is more objective than anticipated, it still refers to "China's growing assertiveness," while some parts about the US have not been adopted at all. The US, not the EU, plays a key role in the Philippines' fight against terrorism. Moreover, the US is not only engaged in the region because of the fight against terrorism, but also in the context of the maritime conflict with China. At the same time, the resolution highlights cooperation between the US and the Philippines. Although the resolution has its positive aspects, I could not support it in view of the above-mentioned contentious issues.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. In its report, Parliament welcomes the conclusion of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Philippines. It also believes that the EU should act to provide assistance, support and development to the Philippines for poverty reduction, respect for human rights and the promotion of peace. The EU and its Member States are called upon to engage with the Philippines to cooperate and provide support for strengthening the government's capabilities in the international fight against terrorism and extremism. Parliament called for regular exchanges with the European External Action Service, and to allow for a monitoring system on the implementation of the framework agreement and the achievement of its objectives.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – There is little argument for an agreement with the Philippines far from the EU sphere of interest, so it can be reached with broad agreement. It seems completely self-evident, but it somewhat nuances the picture that the European Union is strengthening its relations with an area in the US-China confrontation zone. We are even aware of the problems listed in the report because we can appreciate the positive shift and the high level of commitment of your government to further dynamic progress. It weighs heavily on a country if it is in the right direction in its process, especially if it is strategically located.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it approves an agreement between the EU and the Philippines. However, I do not believe that the EU has to have an international role.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the EU-Philippines Partnership and Cooperation Framework Agreement. Firstly, I believe that the European Union simply does not have to have an international role. It is up to the nations to conclude international agreements and to pursue a foreign policy, not to the European Union. In addition, the text shows a willingness to interfere, under ecological cover, in the affairs of a sovereign state.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I have spoken out AGAINST this report. It is an update of the cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Philippines. Although the substance of the text is lucid about the situation in the Philippines, it is lost in clumsy comments about the conflicts in the China Sea that distract it from its primary purpose. I believe that the EU does not have to take the place of the Member States in terms of international policy.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the adoption of this Framework Agreement between the EU and the Philippines, because the EU's cooperation and cooperation agreements with third countries are the antechamber of a free trade agreement, which we oppose because of its negative effects on the working class of the countries concerned. Moreover, such trade agreements pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. The amendments tabled by our GUE/NGL group on the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region, the crackdown on left-wing activists and politicians, extrajudicial killings and our concerns about how this economic agreement will harm the local population were all rejected, so I have no doubt voting against this agreement.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with calling on the Philippine Government to invest in new technologies and the Internet. That's what private companies, not the government, are supposed to do. I also disagree with this agreement. The agreement, which promises European subsidies to the Philippine government and gives them a European concept of human rights, will not improve the situation in the Philippines. I consider an agreement like this to be a kind of European imperialism, an effort to influence countries around the world in their own image. This kind of interference can lead to further disruption of the country.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EU should continue to provide financial support and assistance to the Philippines to reduce poverty, social exclusion, respect for human rights and promote peace. It should also assist the Philippines in preparing for natural disasters and implementing effective policies to address climate change. This report praises the Philippines' membership in the international counterterrorism coalition, but also highlights growing concerns about the growth of ISIS influence in Southeast Asia. It also highlights strong concerns about tensions in the South China Sea and supports all steps leading to peace and cooperation. The Philippines must continue to improve the investment climate for foreign direct investment and increase business transparency.  I supported this report because I believe that close cooperation between the Philippines and the European Union is of utmost importance for the further economic and political growth of the Philippines.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report containing a proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 8/6/2016, and because this recommendation is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against these 3 reports.  We strongly disagree with the way the situation in the China Sea, as well as more generally the way maritime clashes in Asia are described. Foreign policy is the exclusive work of states. We are opposed to the EU trying to play an international role, even if it is a minor one.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU is one of the Most Important Foreign Investors and Trading Partners of the Philippines and reflects 11.56% of their total exports. At the same time, the EU has more than doubled the funds for development cooperation with the Philippines in 2014-2019 and is providing remarkable humanitarian assistance to the victims of tropical storms that regularly hit the country. Seeing significant progress on the part of the Philippines on both human rights and anti-corruption and counter-terrorism initiatives with this participation in international coalitions, I welcome the conclusion of a partnership and cooperation agreement with the Philippines with the wider aim of helping the Union to reduce poverty, further promote respect for human rights and the rule of law , ensuring peace and security and assisting in emergencies.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This framework agreement concerns the strengthening of cooperation with the Philippines. They have also signed eight out of nine human rights agreements and are an important trading partner in the region. I can therefore only agree with this framework agreement.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EU-Philippines Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation.
