I believe that this agreement will contribute to the economic development of these countries, promote trade, tourism, scientific progress, strengthen the dissemination of democratic values, respect for human rights, and facilitate cooperation between institutions in the fight against terrorism, money laundering, illegal migration.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The aim here is to add Croatia as a stakeholder in the EU-Philippines Partnership and Cooperation Agreement signed before its accession to the EU. I am opposed to this agreement which aims to promote an EU-ASEAN free trade agreement. What I do not want for us, I do not wish for one of the last entrants to the EU, even if I was opposed to this integration without popular consultation. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is an update of the agreement between the EU and the Philippines. While the descriptive part of the report is honest about the situation in the Philippines, comments on the situation in the China Sea and on the ongoing maritime clashes in Asia appear to us to be inappropriate. It should also be remembered that foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and that the EU does not have to claim an international role, however small. Therefore, I objected to this report.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. With this Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation, the EU is committed to providing financial support and capacity development assistance to the Philippines to fight poverty. It will also promote social integration, ensure respect for human rights and the rule of law, promote peace, security and judicial reform, provide support for disaster preparedness, relief and recovery, and implement effective policies to combat climate change. There is currently a real risk that the Philippine military will commit human rights violations and join the "Islamic State" group based in Southeast Asia. In this specific case, the framework agreement will play a key role in providing for the exchange of information, close cooperation with the Philippines and support for the development of its capabilities, particularly in the area of fundamental rights and respect for the rule of law in the international fight against terrorism. This framework agreement is a crucial step for the Philippine government on the road to eliminating corruption, human rights action and the fight against terrorism.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I choose to support this resolution in order to further expand the relationship between the EU and the Philippines and continue the Union’s connection with the Philippines as a major trade partner and investor. This framework benefits citizens of the EU through increased opportunities for trade between the Philippines and Member States.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution on EU-Philippines Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation, which encourages the Philippine government to continue fostering further progress in the elimination of corruption and the promotion of human rights. The resolution calls on the Philippine government to build capacity in the field of systematic data collection on human trafficking, and calls for the EU and its Member States to support the government, and notably the Inter-Agency Council against Trafficking (IACAT), in the efforts being made to enhance assistance and support for victims, to put into place efficient law enforcement measures , improve the legal avenues of work labour migration, and ensure decent treatment of Filipino migrants in third countries. It also calls for the EU and its Member States to engage with the Philippines in order to exchange intelligence, cooperate and provide support for the government’s capacity building in the international fight against terrorism and extremism in relation to fundamental rights and the rule of law.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In addition to the recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs to approve the adoption by the Council of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and the Philippines and the Protocol to the Framework Agreement to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, a motion for a resolution was tabled. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Negotiations for a free trade agreement with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) were launched in 2007 and were halted in 2009 and took the form of bilateral negotiations. These bilateral free trade agreements have been designed as the basis for a future agreement with the countries of this region, and the EU has so far finalised bilateral agreements with Singapore and Vietnam.  The European Union is the philippines' fourth largest trading partner and its fourth largest export market, accounting for 11.56% of the country's exports. The Union is also the main foreign investor in the Philippines, with a volume of foreign direct investment in the country exceeding EUR 6.2 billion. EU-Philippine relations are currently governed by the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement signed in July 2012. Since 2014, the Philippines has benefited from the Generalised System of Preferences, which gives them the possibility to export their products into the Union area free of tariffs. In this regard, I am voting in favour, because I believe it is important for the European Union to strengthen cooperation with the countries of South-East Asia in order to move towards a trade agreement with ASEAN.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and the EU does not have to claim an international role, no matter how small. I am voting against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, this resolution welcomes the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation with the Philippines. It express concerns about the potential spread of ISIS in South-East Asia but encourages the Philippine government to continue fostering further progress in the elimination of corruption and the promotion of human rights.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution sets out to Parliament why the European Union is preparing to conclude a partnership and cooperation agreement with the Republic of the Philippines. The state, which has ratified eight of the nine main human rights conventions, is subject to the presence of terrorists on its territory. The European Union must continue to help the country, which has been part of the international coalition against terrorism since 2001. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In Strasbourg today we approved the draft partnership between the EU and its Member States and the Republic of the Philippines. The draft touches on a number of issues. It mentions that the European Union should continue to support the Philippines in areas such as poverty reduction, respect for human rights and the rule of law, disaster preparedness and climate change management policies. It encourages the Philippine government to end corruption and take steps to promote human rights. Today, modern technologies and the Internet are very important in all areas, so the draft proposes that the government invest in these areas, thereby making cultural and commercial relations between the archipelago's islands more simple.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since 1980 the EEC-ASEAN Cooperation Agreement has governed the relationship between the Philippines and the European Union. The European Union and the Philippines initial Partnership and Cooperation Agreement was initialled on 25 June 2010. I have voted for this recommendation on EU-Philippines Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation resolution.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation with the Philippines, upon the recognition that the EU-Philippines relationship is to be cherished now more than ever. Such recognition is sustained, among other reasons, on the relevance of current trade and investment relations, the strategic role to be played by the Philippines in the South China Sea and in countering the potential expansion of international terrorism in South-East Asia. Further challenges are faced by the country at present, as appears clear in current internal conflict and the desirability of continued progress in the elimination of corruption and the promotion of human rights. The agreement will continue to facilitate EU provision support to the Philippines towards overcoming such issues, particularly financial support and capacity-building assistance.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because this resolution provides the framework for enhanced cooperation with the Philippines. Furthermore, the Philippines is a model for the other countries in the region in terms of international and national human rights legislation.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Philippines is a model for the countries of their region, having ratified eight of the nine main conventions on human rights, as well as the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court. It is important for the EU to continue to support the country in combating poverty, tackling climate change and respecting human rights and the rule of law.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Philippines has had the ability to overcome many obstacles; In fact, there has been a strengthening of human rights in the region. Similarly, efforts to apply environmentally friendly disciplines have been stepped up and the development of foreign direct investment necessary for the country's progress has been supported. Looking at the fact that the European Union accounts for the target market of around 11.56 % of all Philippine exports, it can be seen that the partnership agreement can be seen as part of the good relations between the two players. As a result, I am voting in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of concluding this agreement for the EU to continue providing financial support and capacity-building assistance to the Philippines for poverty alleviation, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, the promotion of peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform, and assisting the country in disaster preparedness, relief and recovery and the implementation of effective policies to tackle climate change. Engaging with the Philippines to exchange intelligence, cooperate and provide support for the government’s capacity-building in the international fight against terrorism and extremism should be beneficial to all actors.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support strengthening mutual cooperation and partnership with the Philippines. The Philippines is a good economic partner, but when opening up economic cooperation we must take care of respecting our values and we must not overlook weaknesses in respect for human rights in the Philippines.  I support all the praise given to the Philippine economy and its progress, but I think much more needs to be done to make the Philippine legislation more effective in protecting human rights. Some improvements are evident, but the European Union must continue to encourage further progress. Our partnership should not only be based on mutual exchange of goods and financial profits, but also on mutual cooperation with which we would exchange ideas that will create a positive living climate for both the philippines and the European Union. The adoption of this resolution should affect all spheres of life. The European Union, together with the Philippines, must make further efforts to eradicate poverty, prevent human trafficking, prosecute corruption.  I also hope that Member States will take advantage of the opportunities brought by this Agreement and that the European Union will ensure that the benefits of this Agreement are available to all its members.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and the EU does not have to claim an international role, no matter how small. I am voting against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I believe that the EU should continue to provide financial support and capacity-building assistance for the Philippines to reduce poverty and for social inclusion, respect for human rights, and I urge Member States not to allow vessels on which working conditions violate labour rights and principles set out in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights to dock in European ports. I agree with the rapporteur, Mr. Elmar Brok, and express my strong concern about tensions in the South China Sea. I find it regretful that, contrary to the 2002 Declaration of Conduct, several parties claim territory in the waters at issue. Bearing in mind that there are a large number of Philippine-crewed vessels in European ports that do not fly the EU flag, and bearing in mind the difficult and inhuman working conditions in which many of these seafarers live, I call on the Member States not to allow vessels on which working conditions violate labour rights and principles laid down in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union to dock in European ports.  I also require that vessels not flying the flag of one of the EU countries guarantee their crews working conditions that comply with international laws and international labour organisation and international maritime organisation standards.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported MEP Brok's report on the EU-Philippine Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. The EU is the fourth largest trading partner with the Philippines and the fourth largest market for their exports, accounting for 11.56 per cent of their total exports. The Union is currently providing financial assistance to the Philippines and we welcome continued cooperation to assist the Philippines in its efforts to reduce the degree of poverty, keep peace and security and ensure respect for human rights. It also calls on the Philippine government to continue the fight against corruption.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) with the Philippines contains commitments of fundamental importance to the EU's foreign policy. It strengthens sectoral cooperation in a wide range of strategic areas, such as migration, taxation, the environment, energy, science and technology, maritime and air transport, tourism, culture, money laundering and terrorist financing, illicit drugs, organised crime and corruption. In addition, the PCA greatly expands the opportunities for mutual economic and trade engagement as the important section on trade cooperation contained in it should facilitate negotiations on the Free Trade Agreement (SAS). I voted in favour of this report because I believe that this agreement can create a comprehensive and coherent economic and political framework for relations between the EU and the ASEAN countries (Association of South-East Asian Nations).

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which stresses the importance of the European Union's support for the Republic of the Philippines, as part of the framework partnership agreement that binds the two sets. Many areas of cooperation are already a success and deserve to be strengthened, from the promotion of human rights and the rule of law to strengthening the capacity of the Philippine government in the fight against terrorism, to the increase in academic exchanges promoting cultural sharing between our continent and this Southeast Asian country.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the conclusion of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Philippines. I voted in favour of this report because it believes that the EU should continue to provide financial support to the Philippines, promote peace, poverty reduction, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, security and reform of the judicial system, disaster relief and effective policies to combat climate change. This report encourages the Government of the Philippines to continue to foster progress in eliminating corruption and promoting human rights, recalling that the country has been the target of barbaric terrorist attacks. The document calls on the EU and member states to work with the Philippines to promote the exchange of information and provide support in the fight against terrorism and extremism.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU should continue to provide financial support and capacity-building assistance to the Philippines with a view to poverty reduction, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, promoting peace, security and reform of the judicial system, as well as assisting the country in preparing, aiding and recovering in disaster situations and implementing effective policies to combat climate change Climate. This agreement is an incentive for the Government of the Philippines to continue on the path of eliminating corruption and promoting human rights.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In March 2014, the resolution highlights that, in March 2014, the Philippine Government signed the Peace Agreement in Mindanao with the Moro Islamic Liberation Front which includes the creation of the Bangsamoro autonomous region. The Philippines has been part of the coalition against international terrorism since 2001. In his fight against other militias that maintain ties with Southeast Asian international and regional terrorist groups such as Al Qaeda and Daesh, he is receiving training from the U.S. military in the fight against terrorism and the insurgency and intelligence.  The resolution states that the EU should continue to provide the Philippines with support and assistance in capacity building for peace promotion, reconciliation, security and judicial reform, and assist the country in disaster prevention, relief and recovery.  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I welcome the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation with the Philippines. Beyond this agreement, I call on the Union to continue to provide financial and development support to the Philippines to fight poverty and build capacity in the Philippines while helping it to fight climate change.  Through this resolution, to which I have supported, I also appeal to the Philippines to work in the fight against corruption and to promote the defence of human rights.  This resolution also contains a series of recommendations made to the Member States of the Union and the Philippines which I share. That is why I have supported this text.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This issue does not require much discussion. Croatia's EU membership has slightly changed our trade agreements with the Philippines. Today, we are simply legitimising the newly created situation. As far as I know, our trading partners are also satisfied with the proposal put forward, so I am unequivocally voting in favour.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In this report, the European Parliament welcomes the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation with the Philippines, advising the EU to continue the support, assistance and financial capacity provided so far to the Philippines. The EU should continue to support this country in poverty reduction, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, in promoting peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform, assisting the country in preparing for possible natural disasters, as well as in the recovery and implementation of effective policies to combat climate change.  It should be recalled that the Philippines has been part of the international coalition against terrorism since 2001 and, as such, the EU and its Member States should strengthen exchanges of information with the Philippines, providing the necessary support for strengthening the Philippine government's capabilities in the international fight against terrorism and extremism.  I have voted in favour of this report to continue the strengthening of bilateral relations with the Philippines, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which welcomes the conclusion of a framework partnership agreement between the EU and the Philippines. The text calls on the EU to continue to provide financial and development support to the Philippines in particular. EU-Philippine cooperation needs to be strengthened in areas such as the fight against terrorism, human trafficking and the regional context of tensions in the South China Sea. The EU and the Philippines have a special relationship, particularly from a commercial point of view. Indeed, the EU is the Philippines' 4th largest trading partner and its 4th largest export market. As such, the report calls on the Philippines, as a recipient of GSP status, to ensure the effective implementation of all major international conventions on fundamental rights, labour law, the environment and good governance. Finally, I supported this resolution because it reminds us that this partnership agreement is part of a moment of strengthening trade relations. Indeed, since December 2015, negotiations for a free trade treaty between the two parties have been launched.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the PPE Group and the parliamentary majority, I voted in favour of the report on the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) between the European Union and the Philippines. This agreement contains provisions on human rights, non-proliferation, the fight against terrorism and the International Criminal Court. The PCA strengthens cooperation in a variety of areas, such as migration, taxation, the environment, energy, science and technology, transport, tourism, culture, but also the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing, illicit drugs, organised crime and corruption. The conclusion of this agreement is positive for relations between the contracting parties and for the possible influence of the EU in that state.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this own-initiative report which did not include any amendments that our group tabled, the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region and the joint US-Philippine maneuvers, the repression of civil society activists and members of left-wing parties, the proper implementation of the Human Rights Conventions in the country and the existence of extra-judicial killings by state security forces and paramilitary forces. While some of these elements are underpinned in the final text, it is at the end of an instrument that seeks to move towards the signing of an EU-Philippine Free Trade Agreement, which, like the other types of instruments in the process of negotiating with other countries since the Doha paralysis, has a double-sided : on the one hand the promise of new trade opportunities, accompany and secure its reform processes and on the other hand, the risks that trade liberalization between economies with very different levels of development pose to the weakest part.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. The agreement ensures closer cooperation between the EU and the Philippines. Closer cooperation will benefit both sides both economically and strategically. However, it is important that we do not compromise on the requirement that the Philippines must respect human rights, labour rights, social rights and environmental protection.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Report with a non-legislative motion for a resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion– on behalf of the Union – of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other', as it is necessary to support the Philippines on its path to more stable governance and better living conditions. The EU has successfully contributed to the fight against poverty, the defence of human rights or the development of the rule of law.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against the adoption of this Framework Agreement between the EU and the Philippines, because the EU's cooperation and cooperation agreements with third countries are the antechamber of a free trade agreement, which we oppose because of its negative effects on the working class of the countries concerned. Moreover, such trade agreements pave the way for putting European business interests before those of the peoples of different countries. The amendments tabled by our GUE/NGL group on the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region, the crackdown on left-wing activists and politicians, extrajudicial killings and our concerns about how this economic agreement will harm the local population were all rejected, so I have no doubt voting against this agreement.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Philippines. The importance of continuing to provide the necessary support for the development and promotion of peace is underlined. The European Union should also assist the country in preparing for possible disasters and then try to manage rescue operations and subsequent recovery. The resolution refers to the important decision taken in 2001 to join the international coalition against terrorism, but at the same time concerns are raised about the possible influence of ISIS in the country's South East Asia. Also important is the call for the Philippine Government to implement all those international conventions on human rights and environmental protection.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the Framework Agreement on the Partnership and Cooperation between the EU and the Philippines. We will continue to insist on respect for Human Rights, better labour and social standards and efforts to implement better environmental rights in this country.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am of the opinion that the EU should continue to provide financial and capacity-building assistance to the Philippines for poverty alleviation, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, support for peace, reconciliation, security and justice reform, while helping the country in terms of disaster preparedness, emergency and reconstruction assistance. I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the conclusion of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, as the EU is the main foreign investor and trading partner in the Philippines, and there is further potential for developing this cooperation. In addition, the Philippines is the third most vulnerable developing country to climate change, which may adversely affect its agriculture and marine resources. As EU countries have a lot of experience in this area, European businesses could bring many beneficial technological innovations to the Philippines. The fight against terrorism is also an important aspect of cooperation. The Philippines has been part of an international counterterrorism coalition since 2001 and was also the target of a terrorist attack in 2004. Moreover, there are fears that IS could acquire affiliated groups in southeast China on its part. The EU and the Member States should therefore cooperate more intensively on intelligence sharing, but also in building government capacity to combat extremism. Tensions in the South China Sea, where several sides claim land in disputed waters, are also of concern, contradicting the 2002 behavioural statements. I therefore hope that, in cooperation with the EU, the Philippines will thrive to improve its political and legal environment. In the medium term, it will be necessary to increase transparency, improve governance and further develop infrastructure to make the Philippines an attractive country for foreign investment.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The report welcomes the conclusion of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Philippines and stresses the view that the European Union should continue to provide financial support and capacity-building assistance to the Philippines with a view to reducing poverty, promoting social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, promoting peace, reconciliation and security and judicial reforms. At the same time, the report also calls on the European Union to help the country prepare for disasters, provide aid and renew, and implement effective policies to tackle climate change. The report encourages the Government of the Philippines to continue to support further progress in tackling corruption and promoting respect for human rights. At the same time, the report also expresses concern at the continued reporting that the Philippine military, and in particular paramilitary units, continues to seriously violate human rights in carrying out measures against the insurgents. The report also calls on the Philippine Government to build capabilities in the area of systematic data collection on trafficking in human beings, working with the European Union to combat trafficking in human beings more effectively. Although I believe that the report could have been more critical of the resolution on respect for human rights, the rule of law and good governance, I believe that it is appropriate, which is why I supported it.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the strongest instruments of European foreign policy is the conclusion of trade partnerships. By acceding to these agreements by the new Member States, we are expanding the areas where entrepreneurs and companies from the European Union can place their products and services.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this report because I believe that the EU should continue to provide capacity-building assistance and financial support for the Philippines, primarily to reduce poverty and then to promote peace, social inclusion, security and judicial reform and respect for human rights as well as the rule of law. I believe that aid should continue to be provided to the Philippines in cases of disasters, namely in activities implementing effective policies to address climate change.  Also very worrying is that, due to the influence of ISIS and the spread of propaganda in local languages, some extremists in the region have already appeared who have pledged allegiance to ISIS.  Furthermore, the EU is the Philippines' fourth largest trading partner and fourth largest export market, making it one of the Philippines' main foreign investors and trading partners. Indeed, the EU accounts for 11.56% of total Philippine exports as one of the largest export markets. I believe that the EU should also provide assistance to the Philippines because they are the third developing country in climate change threat. The Philippines is still feeling the effects of the 2013 typhoon, which, according to UN estimates, has significantly exacerbated food insecurity, leading to an additional 1 million people in poverty.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted against this resolution. It has no discernible added value.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other hand, includes, inter alia, issues of current interest such as the issue of peace, migration, taxes, environment, energy, nature and technology, maritime and air transport, tourism, culture, money laundering and terrorist financing, and illicit trade. The European Union should continue to provide financial support and capacity-building assistance for the Philippines to reduce poverty and to reduce poverty and to ensure social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, promoting peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform. I support the adoption of this resolution, as I believe this encourages the Philippine Government to continue to push for further progress in rooting out corruption and promoting human rights.  The Union and the Member States must make contact with the Philippines to share intelligence, cooperate and support government capacity building in the international fight against terrorism and extremism on fundamental rights and the rule of law.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report with the proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, on behalf of the Union. The Philippines is an example for other countries in the region in the area of international and national human rights law. I support the call for the Philippine Government to build capacity in the area of systematic data collection on trafficking in human beings, while at the same time that the EU and the Member States support the Government and, in particular, the Inter-Agency Council against Trafficking in Human Beings (IACAT) in an effort to improve assistance and support for victims, take effective law enforcement action, improve legal ways of working migration and ensure the decent treatment of Filipino migrants in third countries.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report analyses EU-Philippine relations. While the aim is to approve a cooperation agreement, the report also refers to a possible free trade agreement with all Southeast Asian countries, and this is problematic for us. He refers to tensions in the South China Sea, calling on China to stop its aggression, but any criticism of the joint Philippine-US exercises is absent. In view of the above, we have abstained in all 3 reports on the EU-Philippines cooperation agreement.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 On the grounds of human rights and democracy in countries such as the Philippines, investments are being made, creating huge problems in EU member countries in need of investment. Multinationals, in their own way because of the great profit, after exploiting the local population of third countries, are also destroying trade in Europe.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines, which, in addition to welcoming the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation with the Philippines and acknowledging the country's efforts to date, also draws the Philippine Government's attention to the importance of promoting human rights and labour law and the threat posed by ISIS. The resolution rightly points to the tensions in the South China Sea and the importance of treating them in no way unilaterally and provocatively, but peacefully, in accordance with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. Like the resolution, I urge the Philippines to work towards further improving the investment environment by increasing transparency and good governance by implementing the UN Directives on business human rights liability and by improving infrastructures. In addition, I agree on the need for regular contacts between the European External Action Service and Parliament in order to monitor parliament's implementation of the Framework Agreement and the achievement of its objectives.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union actively pursues the development of relations with Southeast Asian countries. One of these countries is the Philippines, with a population of 100 million and a booming economy. Unfortunately, the country still faces a number of problems in terms of human rights, social rights and environmental standards. There are also a number of sovereignty issues with neighbouring countries with regard to maritime borders, as well as an important dimension of Islamic terrorism in some regions of the country. However, the current proposal for the conclusion of a framework partnership and cooperation agreement is an important step in the development of the EU's relations with the country, in particular in the area of trade and business, but also with a view to strengthening international security, managing climate change and monitoring respect for human and labour rights. I believe that this is an important step in the bilateral relationship and I support this initiative.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution. I believe that the European Union should continue to provide financial and capacity support to the Philippines to fight poverty, promote social integration, ensure respect for human rights and the rule of law, promote peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform, and provide the country with support in terms of preparedness. , disaster relief and recovery, and implement effective policies to combat climate change. In addition, I encourage the Philippine government to continue to push for further progress in eliminating corruption and action for human rights!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Philippines Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation, which marks an important step towards strengthening bilateral relations and the EU’s role in South-East Asia, based on shared universal values such as democracy and human rights. The relation between the Philippines and the EU is based on strong historical ties, and today the Philippines is a key partner for the EU in terms of trade and political cooperation, as well as in the global fight against terrorism. I hope that this agreement will open new horizons for trade, investment, foreign policy cooperation and cultural exchange and will allow this relationship to grow even further over the coming decades. Despite this new achievement however, the EU should continue providing financial support and capacity-building assistance to the Philippines for poverty alleviation and tackling climate change.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on the conclusion of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of the Philippines, on the other. The European Union should continue to assist the Philippines in capacity building to reduce poverty and the Philippine Government should be encouraged to continue to push for further progress in rooting out corruption and promoting human rights.  I also believe that the European Union and its Member States need to make contact with the Philippines as soon as possible to share intelligence, cooperate and support government capacity building in the international fight against terrorism and extremism on fundamental rights and the rule of law.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part, on behalf of the Union.  The Philippines must continue to provide financial support and help reduce poverty, respect for human rights and the rule of law. They should be encouraged to continue towards an end to corruption and respect for human rights. Member States would assist in building capacity in the international fight against terrorism and extremism on fundamental rights and the rule of law through cooperation with the Philippine Government on intelligence sharing. The government should also be encouraged to invest in new technologies and the Internet in order to facilitate cultural exchange and trade between the Philippine islands. The partnership with the Philippines is also important from a strategic point of view, as they are located near the most important international waterways and air routes in the South China Sea.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this own-initiative report which did not include any amendments that our group tabled, the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region and the joint US-Philippine maneuvers, the repression of civil society activists and members of left-wing parties, the proper implementation of the Human Rights Conventions in the country and the existence of extra-judicial killings by state security forces and paramilitary forces. While some of these elements are underpinned in the final text, it is at the end of an instrument that seeks to move towards the signing of an EU-Philippine Free Trade Agreement, which, like the other types of instruments in the process of negotiating with other countries since the Doha paralysis, has a double-sided : on the one hand the promise of new trade opportunities, accompany and secure its reform processes and on the other hand, the risks that trade liberalization between economies with very different levels of development pose to the weakest part.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. These texts are updates of the agreements between the EU and the Philippines. While the descriptive part of the substantive report is honest about the situation in the Philippines, the comments on the situation in the China Sea and the ongoing maritime clashes in Asia seem ridiculous to us. It should be remembered that foreign policy is the exclusive act of states and that the EU does not have to claim an international role, however small. I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Cooperation between the EU and the Republic of the Philippines has two main objectives: intensive economic cooperation and the exchange of political experience. The content of the agreement in question supports both of these objectives and makes it possible to assume that the Republic of the Philippines will continue its political and economic reforms, which is why I voted in favour of it as proposed.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU should continue to provide financial assistance and capacity-building support to the Philippines in the areas of poverty reduction, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, the promotion of peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform, disaster preparedness, aid and recovery and the implementation of effective policies to address climate change. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from voting on this own-initiative report which did not include any amendments that our group tabled, the increasing militarization of the Asia-Pacific region and the joint US-Philippine maneuvers, the repression of civil society activists and members of left-wing parties, the proper implementation of the Human Rights Conventions in the country and the existence of extra-judicial killings by state security forces and paramilitary forces. While some of these elements are underpinned in the final text, it is at the end of an instrument that seeks to move towards the signing of an EU-Philippine Free Trade Agreement, which, like the other types of instruments in the process of negotiating with other countries since the Doha paralysis, has a double-sided : on the one hand the promise of new trade opportunities, accompany and secure its reform processes and on the other hand, the risks that trade liberalization between economies with very different levels of development pose to the weakest part.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of the Philippines, of the other part. The report considers that the EU should continue providing financial support and capacity-building assistance to the Philippines for poverty alleviation, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, the promotion of peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform. The report encourages the Philippine government to continue fostering further progress in the elimination of corruption and the promotion of human rights.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. By this resolution, the European Parliament welcomes the Framework Agreement and stresses that the European Union must continue to provide the Philippines with financial support and assistance in order to combat poverty and to promote social inclusion, respect for human rights, the rule of law, the promotion of peace, security and justice reforms and to help the country develop mechanisms to protect it from potential climate change disasters. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We are in the presence of two recommendations, one on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Philippines and the other recommendation to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU in the agreement. The first recommends the approval of the agreement, the second the approval of the protocol for the addition of Croatia. The Philippines is considered an example to be followed by other countries in the region on human rights. Unfortunately, this report is at least partial and does not take into account reality, with particular emphasis on the statements by the President of the Philippines on respect for human rights.  References to security and military cooperation lead us to conclude that we are talking about another action of imperial interference aimed at increasing the military influence of the EU and Nato in that region. We voted against it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This resolution sets out the framework for enhanced cooperation with the Philippines. The Philippines is a model for the other countries in the region in terms of international and national human rights legislation. The Philippines is also an important trading partner in the region. For this reason, and the fact that the report is openly critical, I can agree with it.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the EU-Philippines Framework Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (resolution) welcoming the conclusion of this agreement. I agree with the rapporteur's view that the EU should continue to provide financial support and capacity-building assistance to the Republic of the Philippines for poverty reduction, social inclusion, respect for human rights and the rule of law, the promotion of peace, reconciliation, security and judicial reform, helping the country prepare for disaster response, humanitarian aid and assistance and implement effective policies to combat climate change. The EP also encourages the Republic of the Philippines to continue to improve the investment climate, including the FDI climate, by increasing transparency and good governance, implementing ungoverning UN guiding principles on trade and human rights, and further developing infrastructure through public-private partnerships, as appropriate.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the report with the proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Framework Agreement for Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of the Philippines. The EU is the philippines' most important foreign and trading partner, having a strategic location near the most important international waterways and routes in the South China Sea, so it is necessary to maintain in-depth cooperation between the two countries.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – Tunisia is not only the homeland of the "Arab Spring", but is also the only Arab state in which democracy is successfully consolidated. Today, Tunisia is a democratic state whose constitution guarantees the rule of law and protects the fundamental rights and freedoms of citizens. A major sign of the country's successful democracy is the existence of a well-developed and stable civil society.  Europe has as its main merit the establishment of democracy and stability in Tunisia. Through the European Neighbourhood Policy, the country deepens its political links with the European Union and receives financial assistance. Thanks to the remarkable efforts of the Tunisian people, the path to establishing the privileged partnership with the European Union has been opened.  Unfortunately, instability in the region and the danger of terrorist attacks negatively affect tourism and the fragile Tunisian economy. At this difficult time for the country, I believe that the European Union must be in solidarity. That is why I supported the proposed macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. The granting of additional aid of EUR 500 million will improve the country's budget balance and create a better business climate, ingesting the country to follow the path of growth.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr A few years ago, the revolutions that took place in Tunisia led to the initiation of a number of reforms. And the aim of these reforms was to modernise the country's legislative system, economy, social sphere and other areas. Since, in the context of the still instability that still exists, it is not really possible to realise all this due to other factors, once again the decision was taken to give Tunisia support from the European Union. This time it is about five hundred million euros in the form of medium-term financial market loans on sufficiently favourable terms. A few months ago, other aid was also adopted in the form of olive oil trade facilities, and it must be said that, given Tunisia's rather important location in the Mediterranean and the North African region and the specificities of its relations with the European Union, it was very logical to vote positively today too.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am happy to support this motion for a resolution because I believe that it is in the geopolitical interest of the European Union that Tunisia should continue to remain a relatively democratic prosperous country. Yesterday we had a debate here on migration, on the need to work with the countries of North Africa, the Middle East, to create stabilisation belts, to eliminate the potential problems of migration. And this philosophy certainly fits with the support of Tunisia as one of the few countries in North Africa that is relatively successful and thriving. But most importantly, it is moving towards democracy and the rule of law. Because of terrorist attacks and tourist outflows, this country has some economic problems, which is why it is geopolitically and strategically right to help this country and provide it with money to overcome this, say, short-term economic disbalance.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this resolution has a significance that goes far beyond the economic aspect. This substantial aid is extraordinarily important for Tunisia, which is experiencing very difficult times, but which is a timely and precise message from the European Union to the whole Arab world. This substantial aid is tending to guarantee, where the democratic conditions are, as is the case in Tunisia, which is the only Islamic country that has this kind of condition, real and concrete aid, precisely in order to be able to give the message that the European Union is looking very carefully at the Mediterranean and is doing so at a time when the Arab world is torn apart by the struggles between Shiites and Sunnis and there is no real solidarity in fact , this is also in order to be able to contrast strongly and appropriately with the danger of terrorism and the devastating messages that ISIS sends to the Arab world. I therefore believe that today's vote is extraordinarily important for the thousand reasons behind this timely and substantial economic aid that the European Union has made available.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, I voted against the resolution on macro-financial assistance in Tunisia, where the new government had typically failed to improve the country's economy, which is now moving towards a lebanese policy. At the same time the Islamists entered the political life of the country. Moreover, Tunisia is a base for the operation of slave trade networks, for the illegal trafficking of refugees and illegal immigrants both in the past and in recent weeks, as ships full of desperate people arrive again in Lampedusa and Crete.  There is therefore no justification for any macro-economic support for this country without clear clauses on the hit of illegal immigration. Nor is there any justification for any support for the olive-producing sector in that country, when the European Union itself methodically impoverished Greek and Italian farmers. That is why we have already voted against the duty-free import of Tunisian oil for 2016 and 2017, the import of oil which has led to a dramatic fall in prices in Greece and a consequent loss of income to the poor from the Memorandum of Greek olive growers.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The growing need for external funding, justified by Tunisia's difficult political situation, has prompted the European Commission to propose the granting of a second assistance to tunisia, amounting to EUR 500 million. The intervention, carried out in the form of medium-term loans, aims to raise the country's budgets and public finances, thus complementing the economic adjustment programme agreed with the World Bank and complying with the reforms agreed with the Union. The first assistance decision provided for support of €250 million, followed by the approval of large trade preferences in 2016. In view of the importance of providing forms of aid and assistance to help consolidate the political transition in the country, I voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report proposes to approve macro-financial assistance to Tunisia for the second time for a maximum value of 500 million. I do not object to helping economically a country like Tunisia whose population has been in a difficult situation since 2001, now aggravated by the threat of the Islamic State and its allies in the region. But by no means should this aid be through the macro-financial assistance instrument, as this financial aid will complete IMF credits conditional on structural reforms, which only impoverish the population and worsen their living conditions: liberalizations and privatizations. That's why I voted against it.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report.  Tunisia is currently in serious financial difficulty following numerous terrorist attacks and growing domestic unrest due to Libyan instability. In this context, Tunisia is again seeking help from the European Union, after receiving a loan of 300 million euros in 2013. This report aims to unlock 500 million euros in return for the implementation of the IMF programme and structural reforms on the labour market and social security.  While we consider it important to provide financial assistance to Tunisia in order to stabilise this region, the implementation of the draconian structural reforms that the Union is demanding in return for the granting of the loan constitute a real interference in Tunisian policy, which could further destabilize the country.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the release of emergency macro-financial aid (AMF) of 500 million euros to Tunisia. Tunisia's economy is in serious trouble: unemployment, especially among young people, is at record highs and regional inequalities are growing dangerously. Terrorist attacks, targeting the tourism and transport sectors, have greatly exacerbated the economic challenges facing Tunisia. But the AMF is only a loan, which Tunisia will have to repay. The European Union needs to look further. In conjunction with the international community, it must work to reduce Tunisia's debt and unblock the process of repatriating assets misappropriated by Mr Ben Ali's regime - in this case partly held in European banks. Otherwise, this new AMF will not fulfill its purpose.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The EU has supported Tunisia in its transition to democracy despite the setback seen in the wake of the 2015 terrorist attacks. The Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats of the European Parliament and I personally voted in favour of this report, as we consider additional tunisian macro-financial assistance necessary as a measure to consolidate democracy in the country, to create a friendly environment for investment and to tackle high unemployment rates.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: Written. 'I voted against it because, after other forms of support measures, preferential trading measures and a first tranche of macro-financial assistance, a second tranche of EUR 500 million is now being granted 'to support a third country in crisis.' Youth unemployment rates (28.6% in Tunisia according to the report) are higher in some EU Member States.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. In April 2013, the IMF released a $1.75 billion loan for Tunisia for an initial 24-month period, which has since been extended. In the same year, the EU granted a loan of 300 million euros disbursed in tranches until 2016. However, Tunisia continues to face significant economic and financial difficulties, particularly as a result of the attacks on its soil and the war in Libya. The government is therefore seeking a new loan of 500 million euros from the European Union over 15 years and a new agreement with the IMF for a period of four years. The loan will be released according to the implementation of the programme with the IMF and structural reforms requested by the European Commission (fiscal, social, trade reforms, etc.). It should be noted that these loans are conditional on respect for democracy. I voted against the Commission's proposal, which is an interference in Tunisia's policy. I abstained on the European Parliament's motion for a resolution, which has the merit of having a more flexible approach to structural reforms.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of democracy and transparency, I wish to confirm that I voted against this report. I do not believe it is in the interest of the British people that the European Union is sending British taxpayers’ money to Tunisia. Tunisia is experiencing balance-of-payment difficulties; it is a very corrupt country.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, the result of a long work by my colleague Marielle de Sarnez. The report aims to help Tunisia's democratic transition through the implementation of macro-financial assistance in the form of loans that Tunisia will have to repay, even if its debt continues to rise. The European Commission is invited to start thinking in the footsteps of France and Germany, which have decided to convert part of Tunisia's debt into investment in Tunisia.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As I have said on previous occasions, Tunisia is a special country in that region and it was there that the Arab Spring began, being so far the only successful example of that same Arab Spring. Tunisia has been making calls for enhanced cooperation and we must be up to our responsibilities. This aid package, with which I fully agree, will help Tunisia to continue to establish a sound democratic transition, implement the reforms needed to modernise its economy and develop relations with its partners, especially the European Union, with whom it is currently negotiating a trade agreement.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. Tunisia is currently facing major challenges. The country has been the target of terrorist attacks and attacks on several occasions, which have had a major impact on key sectors of the economy to which the tourism sector has been targeted, for example. Despite these problems, Tunisia continues to make very good progress towards consolidating the country's democratic transition, implementing the reforms needed to modernise economic structures and strengthening relations with its partners. In this context, macro-financial assistance is a European financial instrument that can be mobilised to support a third country in crisis. In August 2015, in response to a request from the Tunisian Government, the European Commission envisaged a macro-financial assistance programme for Tunisia amounting to a total of EUR 500 million. This will be spent on medium-term loans on favourable terms on financial markets. This support programme will help to support the reforms undertaken by Tunisia in order to improve the budgetary situation, balance the balance of payments and create an investment-friendly environment.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is about additional macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. Tunisia has succeeded in consolidating the democratic transition. It is governed by a grand coalition government formed as a result of free and transparent elections, and the country can rely on proactive and modern civil society, which has been rightly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, awarded to the Quartet of Tunisian National Dialogue. Tunisia, however, is currently experiencing great difficulties. It has been hit by a series of attacks and terrorist attacks that have hit key economic sectors in the country, such as tourism. It is of the utmost importance for the Union that Tunisia succeeds and pushes through the calculations of those who want to destabilise the country. Europe must therefore support Tunisia's development in a concrete way that directly assists the population. On this basis, I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. In the wake of deadly terrorist attacks, Tunisia is suffering more than ever from instability in Libya, growing domestic unrest, a 15% unemployment rate and a consequent lack of tourism (the sector accounts for 7% of GDP). By mid-April 2013, both the IMF and the EU had already released funds. Tunisia is seeking a new loan of 500 million euros from the EU. The loans are conditional on compliance with the structural reforms advocated by the IMF and the EU. While it is indeed important for the region as a whole, which is already very distressed, that Tunisia is not destabilized, the various reforms and interferences could precisely destabilize this fragile country a little more. That is why I was unable to vote in favour of this report and abstained. I voted against the Commission's proposal: let us not further weaken the precarious balance that Tunisia has achieved and are finally working on good cooperation rather than guardianship.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this report, which aims to provide macro-financial assistance to Tunisia, a country currently facing great security and economic difficulties, in order to help it on the path of democratic transition and economic reforms.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tunisia is the only example of democracy leaving the Arab Spring. The process of consolidating the democratic system, threatened by numerous terrorist attacks, has succeeded in establishing itself and defining a constitutional charter that protects citizens' rights and constitutes a stable institutional system. However, the economic crisis affecting the Maghreb country is a serious risk factor, coupled with the persistence of areas of instability in neighbouring areas, particularly in neighbouring Libya, where ISIS-linked military formations are active. I voted in favour of the de Sarnez report because I consider the mobilisation of macro-financial assistance to Tunisia to be fundamental. Thanks to this instrument, the European Union will be able to provide concrete support to an important country that is successfully embarking on the path of democracy, respect for human rights and the rule of law. Thanks to the EUR 500 million allocated, the programme will be able to support the reforms undertaken by Tunisia to improve its fiscal situation, balance its balance of payments and create an investment-friendly climate.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution by calling for greater foreign investment through appropriations to strengthen Tunisia's economy. I believe that the aid Tunisia needs should be granted, if possible, in the form of non-reimbursable aid and not through appropriations with strict macroeconomic conditionality criteria that not only undermine the sovereignty of the country but increase the risk of debt stress.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. Europe meddles in everything and wants to intervene everywhere in the name of its sacrosanct 'common values' or 'shared values'. The report provides an additional 500 million euros in aid to Tunisia's development and economy. Since 2011, the EU has expressed its unequivocal commitment to supporting the country in its process of political and economic reforms. It has increased its financial assistance and increased EIB aid or IMF loans, totalling more than 2 billion euros in five years. But that is not enough yet and Tunisians have understood it well: the generosity of Europeans is limitless. I wonder. Are we going so well in Europe that we have to worry about a country that has been in the midst of a renewal of its institutions and governing bodies since the ouster of President Ben Ali in January 2011?  Eurostat estimates that in March 2016, 21.419 billion men and women were unemployed in the 28 EU countries, of which 16.437 billion were in the euro area. What about 'common EU values'? The defence of democratic values has a price, we are told here...

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the granting of this second financial aid package to Tunisia and hope that the 500 million it is endowed with will support Tunisian society's exemplary effort to modernize. On the other hand, I believe that it is essential to send an unequivocal message of support to a State like Tunisian, which precisely because of its reformist impulse suffers cruel terrorist attacks, which is also focused on destabilizing its political system and coercing its possibilities for economic development.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. In response to the terrorist attacks and economic problems in Tunisia, the IMF released a loan of $1.75 billion in 2013 and the EU a loan of 300 million euros from 2013 to 2016. Here, Tunisia is seeking a new loan of 500 million euros at 15 years and another agreement with the IMF.  The loan will be released based on the implementation of the programme with the IMF and the structural reforms requested by the European Commission. In addition, it should be noted that Tunisia is currently negotiating a free trade agreement with the EU. The structural reforms imposed by the EU on Tunisia risk further destabilising Tunisia, but it is important that this country in serious financial and political difficulty is not left behind. So I decided to abstain.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with this report and the allocation of EUR 500 million to Tunisia. I am sceptical about the real usefulness of this type of macro-financial assistance and even more sceptical about how to control their correct and transparent use. I am increasingly wondering how it is possible for the EU to always be at the forefront of helping third countries and never our citizens and businesses. For these reasons, I did not intend to support this measure with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against the legislative proposal on macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. Tunisia's economy is badly hit, and the EU would have to support Tunisia financially. But this proposal links EU aid with IMF loans, and is already deepening neoliberal economic policies that hit the poorest hardest. The IMF loans, with the deregulation and privatisation that they have entailed, have contributed to Tunisia's debt and have over the years not brought improvement to the living conditions of the population, but, on the contrary, have been one of the causes of the widening gaps and unemployment in the country. That is why I have voted against this proposal.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported Parliament's eu decision granting additional macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. Tunisia has succeeded in consolidating the process of democratic transition. This country now has a constitution that protects citizens' rights and freedoms, a consolidated justice system and an independent media. The country is governed by a broad union government that came to power after free and transparent elections. It is based on a business and modern civil society, which has deservedly been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for the Tunisian Quartet of National Dialogue. However, Tunisia is currently facing major challenges. The country has been the target of terrorist attacks and attacks on several occasions, which have had a major impact on key sectors of the economy to which the tourism sector has been targeted, for example. Moreover, the political and security situation in the region is very volatile, especially with regard to the common border with Libya. Despite these problems, Tunisia continues to make very good progress towards consolidating the country's democratic transition, implementing the reforms needed to modernise economic structures and strengthening relations with its partners, in particular with the European Union, with which it is currently negotiating a free trade agreement. It is very important that Tunisia succeeds in this and that it is against all those who want to destabilise it. That is why Europe must show solidarity and be determined in supporting and supporting tunisia's development through very concrete actions that directly support the people of the country.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is currently experiencing great difficulties. It has been hit by a series of attacks and terrorist attacks that have hit key economic sectors in the country, such as tourism. Moreover, the regional security situation is extremely precarious as the country borders Libya.  Despite these challenges, Tunisia continues to make important progress towards a democratic transition and the modernisation of the structure of the economy. It is currently negotiating a free trade agreement with the European Union.  Thanks to the reforms, Tunisia fully complies with the political conditions for assessing macro-financial assistance. In order to restore stability in the region, it is of the utmost importance that Tunisia be able to take further steps for a democratic system of government and economic development.  This aid package is the second in a row envisaged by the Commission in August 2015, at the request of the Tunisian Government, in the form of a eur 500 million macro-financial assistance programme, which will be disbursed in the form of medium-term loans on favourable terms on the financial markets. This aid programme will be used for reforms aimed at improving Tunisia's budgetary situation, balancing its balance of payments and creating favourable conditions for investment.  In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Following the terrorist attacks, Tunisia's growth has been reduced (3% in 2015). It suffers from instability in Libya, growing domestic unrest, an unemployment rate of 15%, a lack of tourism (the sector weighs 7% of GDP), strikes... Therefore, I am in favour of granting aid in the form of a loan, but the draconian conditions imposed by the Commission on this facility are likely to destabilise this still very fragile country. Therefore, I voted against the Commission's proposal and abstained on the motion for a resolution because it is much less harsh than the Commission's.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Economic aid in exchange for democratic reforms and civil progress is one of the most widely used instruments by the EU in its neighbourhood and partnership relations with third countries. This has often produced positive results for citizens on both sides and increased the range of influence of soft power in the European Union. Tunisia is today one of the few (or perhaps the only) Arab country in which the so-called 'Arab Spring' has landed in a modern democracy, which looks to the West and the development of the rule of law. A friendly democracy, which we must support by enabling it to develop under appropriate conditions, gradually, and gradually to become part of the common free trade area.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Tunisia is currently in serious financial difficulties, largely due to the drop in tourism activity since the 2015 attacks. The Tunisian government is also facing growing internal unrest, particularly due to Libyan instability. In this context, Tunisia is once again seeking help from the European Union, after receiving a loan of 300 million euros in 2013. This report aims, this time, to unlock 500 million euros in return for the implementation of the IMF programme and structural reforms on the labour market and social security.  We consider it important to provide financial assistance to Tunisia in order to stabilize this region, which is facing an Islamist threat. Nevertheless, the implementation of the structural reforms that the Union is calling for in return for the granting of the loan could have the opposite effect. Not only do these draconian conditions constitute interference in Tunisian domestic politics, but they are mainly likely to increase poverty and social inequalities as in Greece or Portugal. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tunisia is currently going through a very difficult period. The terrorist attacks of recent times have profoundly affected the country's key economic sectors. Despite these challenges, Tunisia continues to make very important progress, stabilising the national democratic transition process. In this context, macro-financial assistance is a European financial mechanism that can be mobilised to support a third country in crisis. Thanks to the reforms that have been introduced at national level, Tunisia is now fully meeting the political conditions necessary for the provision of macro-financial assistance, in particular as regards respect for democracy, human rights and the rule of law. In August 2015, in response to the Tunisian Government's request, the European Commission established a second macro-financial assistance programme for Tunisia. This programme is intended to support reforms undertaken by Tunisia to improve its budgetary situation, balance its balance of payments and create a more investment-friendly environment. I therefore subscribe to the proposal of the European Commission and hope that this programme, which provides for additional assistance to Tunisia, will be able to enter into force as soon as possible to support Tunisia at this crucial time.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Tunisia has undertaken a remarkable democratic transition in recent years. Nevertheless, many challenges remain. The country is experiencing major economic difficulties. Terrorist attacks and attacks on the territory and the regional geopolitical situation have a disastrous effect on the country's main economic activity, tourism.  The European Union must help Tunisia continue its democratic transition. This decision by the Council and the European Parliament for additional macro-financial assistance to Tunisia will enable the EU to grant a loan of 500 million euros to Tunisia. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the granting of additional macro-financial assistance to Tunisia because Tunisia is currently a hope in the Arab Mediterranean context. Many problems still remain, the country has repeatedly been the target of terrorist attacks and attacks that have mainly compromised the tourism sector, which has always been a central element for the Tunisian economy. Europe must therefore be able to take all the necessary steps to support this delicate phase of transition for the country. In this way, by means of concrete actions, we will be able to show solidarity and determination by encouraging the country from which the Arab spring began and which is certainly a model for all those who want to try to promote peace and democracy in the Middle East, North Africa and the rest of the world.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ While I agree with the aim to help the Tunisian democracy and economy, macro-financial assistance is being linked to IMF loans and programmes. More liberalisation and privatisation did not bring improvement but caused growing inequalities and unemployment. Therefore I voted against the resolution.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report to show my support to the democratic transition in Tunisia and agree to provide more macro-financial assistance as quickly as possible.
