We have witnessed Tunisia’s notable achievement in democracy reform from many aspects including politics, economy, and foreign affairs. It is a pity to see Tunisia to be the victim of terrorist attacks. I believe our financial support can help the government overcome current challenges and effectively preserve the recent achievements, especially for the people of Tunisia.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the strong security impact of the security situation on the Tunisian economy and the external financing needs during the consolidation of the political transition, the European Commission submits to the European Parliament and the Council a proposal for the granting of a second macro-financial assistance to the Republic of Tunisia for a maximum amount of EUR 500 million in the form of medium-term loans. The new proposal would help Tunisia cover some of the remaining external financing needs, estimated at around US$2.9 billion for the period 2016-17, under the imf's new programme and reduce the economy's short-term vulnerabilities with regard to the balance of payments and public finances, complementing the economic adjustment and reform programme agreed with the IMF and the World Bank , as well as the reforms agreed as part of the EU's budget support operations. Being convinced that the Tunisian people must be supported and that the EU must give real aid to Tunisia, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as we believe that Europe must demonstrate its solidarity and determination to frame and assist Tunisia with very concrete measures from which the entire population of the country can benefit.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on the granting of further macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. It is a fact that the two sides have developed relations and contacts, and helping to ensure the living conditions of citizens is important. However, at a time when strict and inhuman austerity policies are being imposed on the citizens of the Union, I do not think there is the possibility of strengthening the existing aid that Europe is providing to third states. Therefore I decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that in recent years Tunisia has demonstrated its potential by taking a great step forward when drafting a constitution that safeguards citizens' rights and freedoms. It has also made substantial progress by establishing a democratic regime and modernising its economy by achieving stable political conditions. However, the many terrorist attacks in the country have seriously damaged the economic sector. For these reasons, I believe that the European Union's contribution to supporting Tunisia by providing liquidity through soft loans is appropriate, so that the country can strengthen the security of its citizens and improve the local economic sector.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Tunisia has succeeded in consolidating its democratic transition. It now has a constitution that safeguards rights and freedoms, with a consolidated judicial system and empowered media. It is led by a broad unity government that emerged from free and transparent elections, with an enterprising and modern civil society, and has rightly been rewarded with the Nobel Peace Prize for the Tunisian National Dialogue Quartet. At present, however, Tunisia is going through very great difficulties. On a number of occasions it has been the target of terrorist murders and attacks which have hit key sectors of the country’s economy, such as tourism. Growth, projected at 3% for 2015, has been revised down to 0.5% for 2016; the unemployment rate is 15% on average, 20% for women and 28.6% for young university graduates. The regional security and political context is extremely volatile, moreover, chiefly because of the border it shares with Libya.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the aid programme for Tunisia. The country has made great political and economic progress in recent years: the introduction of a constitution, the consolidation of the judicial system, and the freedom of the media strengthened. Unfortunately, the recent attacks have hit the country's most important industry, tourism, hard. With our aid programme, we can support Tunisia at this difficult time and help to implement further reforms, improve the budgetary situation and create an investment-friendly investment climate. In so doing, we are showing solidarity for the countries that are fighting terror together with us.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report proposes to approve macro-financial assistance to Tunisia for the second time for a maximum value of 500 million. I do not object to helping economically a country like Tunisia whose population has been in a difficult situation since 2001, now aggravated by the threat of the Islamic State and its allies in the region. But by no means should this aid be through the macro-financial assistance instrument, as this financial aid will complete IMF credits conditional on structural reforms, which only impoverish the population and worsen their living conditions: liberalizations and privatizations. That's why I voted against it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following changes in the political landscape since 2011, the EU has pledged to support Tunisia in the process of economic and political reforms and, to this end, has increased its financial support. In particular, €524 million in grants for the period 2011-2015 was made available in the Ordinary Convention Programme, and €155 million under the "Support for Partnership, Reform and Inclusive Growth" programme in the period 2011-2013. By voting in favour, I intend to support macro-financial assistance to Tunisia, so that tunisia can make progress in its economic and social development, close its external financial deficit in the balance of payments, and implement structural reforms. I believe that Tunisia is a positive example in the post-2011 regional landscape of political instability and that, therefore, it is the EU's duty to give concrete support to its efforts at democratisation, especially given the fact that, at this stage, it is easy prey to terrorist attacks. Furthermore, I believe that the macro-financial assistance programme can play a proactive role in supporting the Tunisian democratisation process, making the granting of assistance subject to certain preconditions, such as respect for the rule of law and human rights.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The good road that Tunisia had begun has been hampered by terrorist attacks and attacks, which have profoundly affected the country's key economic sectors, such as tourism. The economic growth rate, which should have been 3% in 2015, was revised downwards, being valued at 0.5% for 2016, while the unemployment rate is on average 15%, for women, it is at 20%, and for young people who have completed higher education at 28.6%. Despite these challenges, Tunisia continues to make very important progress, stabilising the national democratic transition process. Europe must show solidarity and act decisively to assist and support Tunisia in its development process through concrete actions. I voted for this programme, which provides for additional assistance to Tunisia, to enter into force as soon as possible to support this country at this crucial time.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia has succeeded in consolidating the democratic transition. It now has a constitution protecting rights and freedoms, an orderly judiciary and independent and free media. It is governed by a grand coalition government formed as a result of free and transparent elections, and the country can rely on proactive and modern civil society, which has been rightly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, awarded to the Quartet of Tunisian National Dialogue.  However, Tunisia is currently experiencing great difficulties due to the many attacks and terrorist attacks. This situation has a negative impact mainly on tourism and unemployment, and the regional security situation is also precarious. It is of the utmost importance that Tunisia receives support as a democratic and developing country. Europe must show solidarity and determination, stand by Tunisia and support its development through concrete actions directly helping the population.  Macro-financial assistance is a European financial instrument that can be used to support a country in crisis. Tunisia meets the conditions for granting macro-level support (democracy, human rights and the rule of law). In 2014, €300 million in financial assistance was approved for Tunisia for reforms to improve the country's public finances. In 2015, the Commission earmarked an additional EUR 500 million for Tunisia to improve the country's budget and create conditions condoning investment. Today, the European Parliament has given its support to the European Commission's proposal, which I voted in favour of.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EU proposal under consideration to grant a medium-term loan of up to EUR 500 million is intended to contribute to meeting tunisia's financing needs for the period 2016-2017, as identified by the Commission on the basis of IMF estimates. Disbursements are subject to the positive results of the REVIEWS of the IMF programme. In addition, the Protocol is likely to address issues relating to trade, tax reform, banking reform, the civil service, labour market instruments and the tourism sector. The urgent need for funding means that the European Parliament must take a decision before the summer break in order for the funds to be disbursed on time. In order to speed up the procedure, the rapporteur does not suggest any amendments to the Regulation. Given the urgency of the document and the need for further assistance to Tunisia, which means that it can make a further transition towards democracy, I voted in favour of the regulation.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of financially supporting Tunisia as part of its transition to democracy and towards being a stable country. The EU wants to see Tunisia’s economic and social development continue and therefore supports this latest tranche of macro-financial assistance (MFA), which is a form of financial aid extended by the EU to partner countries experiencing a balance-of-payments crisis.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament today approved the report on the proposal for a decision on the granting of a EUR 500 million loan to Tunisia, which it will be able to access for a period of two and a half years. This measure is a further piece of a more general policy of support, which the European Union is putting in place with regard to that country. It was only a few months ago that Parliament voted in favour of the introduction of emergency trade measures in favour of Tunisia. The main objective is to strengthen relations with this strategic partner, the only country in the North African region that is facing the difficult transition to full democracy, and to support its economic recovery in a structural way. Access to the loan is conditional on the signing of a memorandum of understanding with the European Commission, which Tunisia will have to respect by ensuring effective reforms. The allocation of this loan is even more important following the severe blow inflicted by the terrorist attacks of March 2015, which severely debilitated a key sector such as tourism, increasing unemployment and instability in the country. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of providing Tunisia with a financial assistance of EUR 500 million from the Union. Indeed, it seems to me absolutely essential that the European Union should support Tunisia in its process of consolidating democratic mechanisms and stabilizing its economy, while Tunisia has also been affected by the scourge of terrorism.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Sarnez's report on macro-financial assistance to Tunisia, with the aim of providing Tunisia with up to EUR 500 million in aid in the form of medium-term loans, allocated on favourable financial terms.  This assistance is a complement to the other subsidies already granted to Tunisia by the European Union since 2011, which amount to more than 1 billion euros. This new assistance will be paid three times over the life of the program. One of the objectives of this macro-financial assistance is to facilitate the reforms necessary for the country's economic integration and regulatory convergence with the European Union.  I supported this report because the partnership with Tunisia is one of the priorities of the European Union. We must fully engage with Tunisia to support the country's democratic transition and economic development. In the wake of the many challenges faced by Tunisians, including the terrorist attacks perpetrated on their territory three times, it is imperative to provide them with our support through this macro-financial assistance.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is currently experiencing great difficulties. It has been hit by a series of attacks and terrorist attacks that have hit key economic sectors in the country, such as tourism. Moreover, the regional security situation is extremely precarious as the country borders Libya.  Despite these challenges, Tunisia continues to make important progress towards a democratic transition and to modernise its economic structure, and is currently negotiating a free trade agreement with the European Union.  Thanks to the reforms, Tunisia fully complies with the political conditions for assessing macro-financial assistance. In order to restore stability in the region, it is of the utmost importance that Tunisia be able to take further steps for a democratic system of government and economic development.  On 15 May 2014, a eur 300 million aid programme was approved for Tunisia. The first two instalments of the programme have already been paid in 2015 and the third will take place in 2016.  This aid package is the second in a row envisaged by the Commission in August 2015, at the request of the Tunisian Government, in the form of a eur 500 million macro-financial assistance programme, which will be disbursed in the form of medium-term loans on favourable terms on the financial markets. This aid programme will be used for reforms aimed at improving Tunisia's budgetary situation, balancing its balance of payments and creating favourable conditions for investment.  In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. This aid to Tunisia, in the form of medium-term loans, is welcome and gives the Tunisian people air, but this decision, which I supported, must also be followed by a discussion on the reduction of The Tunisian debt and the recovery of assets stolen by former President Ben Ali.  The Commission should be a driving force in this area, as well as the greatest flexibility in encouraging the implementation of economic reforms. Tunisia's progress on the path to democracy is a process to be encouraged. It must not be hampered by an additional obligations disconnected from the principles of reality.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Tunisia is currently experiencing great difficulties. It has been hit by a series of attacks and terrorist attacks that have hit key economic sectors in the country, such as tourism. Moreover, the regional security situation is extremely precarious as the country borders Libya.  Despite these challenges, Tunisia continues to make important progress towards a democratic transition and to modernise its economic structure, and is currently negotiating a free trade agreement with the European Union.  Thanks to the reforms, Tunisia fully complies with the political conditions for assessing macro-financial assistance. This aid package is the second in a row envisaged by the Commission in August 2015, at the request of the Tunisian Government, in the form of a eur 500 million macro-financial assistance programme, which will be disbursed in the form of medium-term loans on favourable terms on the financial markets. This aid programme will be used for reforms aimed at improving Tunisia's budgetary situation, balancing its balance of payments and creating favourable conditions for investment.  In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Since the terrorist attacks, Tunisia has experienced moderate growth, balance-of-payments difficulties, growing domestic unrest, a 15% unemployment rate and a lack of tourism, while the sector accounts for 7% of GDP. The country is seeking a new 15-year loan of 500 million euros to the EU and a new 4-year agreement with the IMF.  The programme with the latter and the structural reforms imposed by the EU risk further destabilising the country. These include fiscal reforms, adjustment measures, social security reforms, the labour market, the trade and investment regulatory framework.  Refusing the interference and the risk of destabilization of an already fragile region, I abstained.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the granting of macro-financial assistance to Tunisia in the form of a medium-term loan of up to EUR 500 million for the period 2016-2017, which will cover the country's external financing needs. The purpose of the loan is to lead to economic and political stabilisation of Tunisia and to support the development of the state and the implementation of reforms aimed at improving the budgetary situation, ensuring balance of payments stability and creating a more favourable environment for investment. In my opinion, financial assistance to the country has a direct link to migrant policy and improving Tunisia's economic situation can lead to a reduction in the flow of people arriving in the EU.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Repeating the same wrongs as the EU-Turkey agreement, where money is given for supposed development and democratisation, in order to stop migration flows, rather than being given to combat poverty and austerity in European countries, is a major political and moral error. Any plans to "buy" African countries in order to stop migration flows are unsustainable. A typical example is the increase in VAT on MFI in Greece to 24% with a budgetary gain of only EUR 5 million. Euro!!! At the same time, Tunisia received EUR 300 million from the European Investment Bank (EIB). In 2014, the second MAS programme will receive an other EUR 500 million. In addition to the funds received from regional programmes, the financing through the contribution mechanism, EUR 71.8 million was allocated to the European Investment Bank (EIB). On the basis of the principle of proportional principles, EUR 115 million was granted for the financing of the project. The European Neighbourhood Mechanism is the same as the European Neighbourhood Facility.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is currently experiencing great difficulties. It has been hit by a series of attacks and terrorist attacks that have hit key economic sectors in the country, such as tourism. This aid programme will be used for reforms aimed at improving Tunisia's budgetary situation, balancing its balance of payments and creating favourable conditions for investment.  In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Tunisia is currently experiencing great difficulties. It has repeatedly been the target of attacks and terrorist attacks that have deeply affected the country's key economic sectors, such as tourism. Growth, which was expected to be 3 % in 2015, was revised down to 0.5% in 2016 and the average unemployment rate is 15%, 20 % for women and 28.6 % for young graduates of higher education. It is very important that Tunisia succeeds and that it contradicts all those who want to destabilise it. Europe must therefore be sympathetic and determined to monitor and support Tunisia in its development, through very concrete actions that directly benefit the population of the country, of which macro-financial assistance is a good example and the EUR 500 million is an important aid.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote "Abstention" on the legislative resolution, which is softer on reforms. It is important that this country in serious financial and political difficulty is not left behind, but various reforms and interference could further destabilize this country.  Vote against the European Commission's proposal, identical for the 500 million euro loan, but calling for draconian conditions that constitute interference in Tunisian politics.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Tunisia is currently experiencing great difficulties. It has repeatedly been the target of attacks and terrorist attacks that have affected the country's key economic sectors, such as tourism. Growth, which was expected to be 3 % in 2015, was revised down to 0.5% in 2016 and the average unemployment rate is 15%, 20 % for women and 28.6 % for young graduates. Moreover, the regional security context is volatile, in particular because of the border that the country shares with Libya. In August 2015, the European Commission provided for a second macro-financial assistance programme for Tunisia of a total of EUR 500 million to be granted in the form of medium-term loans on the financial markets. The report states that the 'assistance programme will support tunisia's reforms to improve its budgetary position, balance the balance of payments and create a more investment-appropriate climate'. The principle of cooperation and genuine development aid is not at issue, which must be deepened, while respecting the will and sovereign choices of each State. However, this type of assistance typically has associated the demands of 'structural and macroeconomic reforms', which we reject. For the above, our vote against.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because I believe it is necessary to continue to accompany Tunisia in this transition to a genuine democratic state.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as a neoliberal push is on.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Tunisia is currently one of the countries with several major problems. The security and political situation in the region and terrorist attacks have a significant negative impact on several economic sectors. It is our duty to help Tunisia succeed in combating attempts to destabilise the country. In this context, it is therefore important that we provide Tunisia with macro-financial assistance, which will mainly constitute assistance for the reforms that Tunisia is undertaking in order to improve its budgetary situation, balance of payments and thus create a more favourable environment for investment.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because the real benefits are not clear.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Repeating the same wrongs as the EU-Turkey agreement, where money is given for supposed development and democratisation, in order to stop migration flows, rather than being given to combat poverty and austerity in European countries, is a major political and moral error. Any plans to "buy" African countries in order to stop migration flows are unsustainable. A typical example is the increase in VAT on MFI in Greece to 24% with a budgetary gain of only EUR 5 million. Euro!!! At the same time, Tunisia received EUR 300 million from the European Investment Bank (EIB). In 2014, the second MAS programme will receive an other EUR 500 million. In addition to the funds received from regional programmes, the financing through the contribution mechanism, EUR 71.8 million was allocated to the European Investment Bank (EIB). On the basis of the principle of proportional principles, EUR 115 million was granted for the financing of the project. The European Neighbourhood Mechanism is the same as the European Neighbourhood Facility.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Tunisia remains the Arab Awakening’s last best hope. The country’s political transition is as remarkable as it is fragile, threatened by both security challenges and significant socioeconomic obstacles. I believe we all want to see Tunisia’s economic and social development continue and therefore we should support this latest tranche of Macro Financial Assistance (MFA) to the sum of EUR 500 million. This is a way to help Tunisia further consolidate its democracy, bring about an environment more conducive to investment and urgently address unemployment. I strongly hope that this financial aid will improve public-finance management, operation of the fiscal system, strengthen the social safety net, overhaul the financial sector and improve the regulatory framework for trade and investment. Moreover, I welcome the fact that this proposal will also introduce some changes to the standard Micro Financial Assistance (MFA) text, which will draw on experience and best practice of previous MFA agreements in order to more effectively distribute money.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is currently experiencing great difficulties. It has been hit by a series of attacks and terrorist attacks that have hit key economic sectors in the country, such as tourism. Moreover, the regional security situation is extremely precarious as the country borders Libya.  Despite these challenges, Tunisia continues to make important progress towards a democratic transition and to modernise its economic structure, and is currently negotiating a free trade agreement with the European Union.  Thanks to the reforms, Tunisia fully complies with the political conditions for assessing macro-financial assistance. In order to restore stability in the region, it is of the utmost importance that Tunisia be able to take further steps for a democratic system of government and economic development.  On 15 May 2014, a eur 300 million aid programme was approved for Tunisia. The first two instalments of the programme have already been paid in 2015 and the third will take place in 2016.  This aid package is the second in a row envisaged by the Commission in August 2015, at the request of the Tunisian Government, in the form of a eur 500 million macro-financial assistance programme, which will be disbursed in the form of medium-term loans on favourable terms on the financial markets. This aid programme will be used for reforms aimed at improving Tunisia's budgetary situation, balancing its balance of payments and creating favourable conditions for investment.  In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is currently experiencing great difficulties. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the firm conviction that all necessary assistance to Tunisia needs to be provided. While Tunisia has managed to consolidate its democratic transition and the country is led by a broad coalition government, Tunisia is now in very difficult times, on several occasions it has been the target of terrorist attacks and attacks, which have profoundly affected key economic sectors of the country, such as tourism. Growth, which should have been 3% in 2015, was 0.5%, and the unemployment rate averaged 15%. Moreover, the political context is very unstable, considering that it has a border with Libya.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a Council decision activating a macro-financial assistance programme (MFA) for Tunisia, because I believe that the MFA is an important European financial instrument through which, in this case, the EU can give tunisia a concrete help to stabilise the important democratisation process under way. The assistance programme will be essential to accompany Tunisia on this complex path and to ensure the modernisation of economic structures and the strengthening of relations, particularly with the EU, which have been deepened through the free trade agreement under negotiation. It will also be essential to promote the development of the North African country while at the same time allowing the Tunisian people to benefit effectively. It is Tunisia's second request for MFA, the first being in 2014. It amounts to a total of EUR 500 million, in addition to the first EUR 300 million, which will be allocated through medium-term loans on international markets at advantageous rates. The European commitment, as strongly desired by the European Parliament, should be to participate in sharing the cost of indebtedness together with Tunisia itself. It is not, therefore, a question of subsidies, a hypothesis that has never been taken into account even by the European Parliament.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to adopt this report based on the need for Tunisia to receive additional financial support in order to retain stability and to start to solve the huge financial and social issues the country is currently facing. Tunisia has suffered severely from the Libyan civil war and the regional instability that it has created, combined with a tourist-flight after last year’s terrorist attacks and high unemployment this had put the internal stability of the country in jeopardy. Tunisia, as the only state that emerged from the Arab spring as a democracy, is in urgent need of our support both economically and politically, and it is in our interest that the country become a role model for democracy in North Africa.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. The sustainable, peaceful and democratic development of North Africa is an important concern for the EU as a whole. Only prospects for the people there help to avoid refugee flows before they arise. That is why I voted in favour of the 'Report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council on further macro-financial assistance to Tunisia'.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Macro-financial assistance of €500 million for Tunisia is necessary to help Tunisia meet its external financing needs. However, the grants are subject to political conditions and will be disbursed in three tranches of loans, provided that the conditions are met.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative report – it is in our common interest to have a secure neighbourhood. This is a good way to help Tunisia further consolidate its democracy. I believe that this will provide an environment which attracts greater investment, and which will urgently tackle the problem of unemployment.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly support the actions that the European Commission is developing to support Tunisia. This country was the only country in which the Season of the Arab Spring was followed by real improvements in the social and economic conditions of the population, within a path that can be fully defined as a democratic transition. The country finally has a constitution that protects rights and freedoms, a consolidated system of justice and the media capable of observing and exercising the right of criticism. As an Italian, I can only care about the situation in a country so close to the Sicilian coast, where, unfortunately, the regional political and security context is still extremely unstable, particularly because of the border it shares with Libya. That is why Europe must contribute to a stabilisation process in the country of which macro-financial assistance is a key instrument because it contributes directly to improving the quality of life of the population.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution by calling for greater foreign investment through appropriations to strengthen Tunisia's economy. I believe that the aid Tunisia needs should be granted, if possible, in the form of non-reimbursable aid and not through appropriations with strict macroeconomic conditionality criteria that not only undermine the sovereignty of the country but increase the risk of debt stress.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, in order to support Tunisia following its recent political upheaval. This legislative report represents the EU’s commitment to the country and desire to see the country bring about an environment which is more conducive to investment and will address the urgent problem of unemployment in this area.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The EU’s macro-financial assistance to Tunisia is part of a wider effort by the EU and other international donors to help Tunisia overcome the severe economic difficulties it has faced since its economic and political transition process began following the 2011 revolution. Terrorist attacks in 2015 worsened the situation further by affecting key economic sectors such as tourism and transport.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is currently experiencing great difficulties. It has been hit by a series of attacks and terrorist attacks that have hit key economic sectors in the country, such as tourism. The regional security situation is also extremely precarious as the country borders Libya. This aid programme will be used for reforms aimed at improving Tunisia's budgetary situation, balancing its balance of payments and creating favourable conditions for investment.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is in serious trouble. Our aim should be to help to achieve democracy and to try to lift the country's economy. However, the macro-financial assistance proposed is an instrument linked to loans and IMF programmes, and imposes on the country a neoliberal agenda in the name of so-called structural reforms. With this logic as a group we disagree and for these reasons we voted against the report. We do not in any way vote against the need to help Tunisia deal with the problems it faces.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report. Tunisia has been successful in consolidating its democratic transition. The country has created a new constitution safeguarding rights and freedoms and has developed a consolidated judicial system and free media. Tunisia has come out of the Arab spring most successfully and has taken major steps to build a stable democracy in the region. Currently, however, Tunisia is going through increasingly greater difficulties. This is mostly due to the series of targeted terrorist attacks hitting one of the country’s key sectors: tourism. Due to these attacks, the growth projection for 2016 has been revised from 3% in 2015 to 0.5% in 2016. On 15 May 2014, an initial EURO 300 million programme was approved for Tunisia to improve public-finance management and operation of the fiscal system, strengthening the social safety net and improve the regulatory framework for trade and investment. In August 2015, the Commission has made provisions for a second MFA programme totalling EURO 500 million to improve its budgetary position and balance of payments and bring a climate more conducive to investments. I believe it is absolutely necessary to support economic and political stability on the borders of the European Union and this can be done by providing macro-financial assistance.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal. I had no objections to its final draft.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report shows that Tunisia has succeeded in consolidating its democratic structures. Tunisia, however, is also facing major difficulties at the moment. It has been the target of attacks and terrorist attacks several times. Moreover, from a security and political point of view, it is extremely unstable, mainly because of the common border with Libya. It is important that Tunisia succeeds with its policies and resolutely responds to those actors who want to destabilise the country. Europe must therefore show solidarity and determination and support the country in its development through concrete measures that directly benefit the population. In August 2015, the Commission set aside a second macro-financial assistance programme for Tunisia totalling €500 million, to be granted on favourable terms in the form of medium-term loans taken out on the capital market. This aid programme is intended to support the reforms that Tunisia is implementing in order to improve its budgetary situation. The rapporteur supports the Commission's proposal and wants to see this aid programme enter into force as soon as possible in order to support Tunisia at a critical stage. I agree with this and voted in favour of the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is currently experiencing great difficulties. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tunisia is currently experiencing a difficult economic and social situation, which is reflected in the situation of high unemployment, lack of absorption of young labour and security instability. In this context, Tunisia fulfils the policy conditions indispensable for the provision of EUR 500 million in macro-financial assistance in the form of favourable medium-term loans, a European financial mechanism that can be mobilised to support a third country in crisis. I voted in favour of this report which supports the reforms undertaken by Tunisia to improve its budgetary situation, balance its balance of payments and create a balance and social and financial stability.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council on providing additional macro-financial assistance to Tunisia, as it is a country that, despite political problems after the "Arab Spring" and several terrorist incidents, which have primarily damaged the local tourism economy, has nevertheless remained stable and shows vitality in consolidating the democratic political system.  It is a country that meets the requirements for granting macro-financial assistance in terms of respect for democracy, human rights, and the rule of law. At issue is the second aid programme envisaged by the European Commission to amount to €500 million to be allocated to financial markets in the form of medium-term loans on favourable terms. This supports reforms aimed at balancing the balance of payments and creating the necessary better climate for investment.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The structural reforms imposed by the EU on Tunisia risk further destabilising the country. I abstained on this text.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the provision of additional macro-financial assistance to Tunisia of up to EUR 500 million. It is indeed important to support the democratic construction of this country.   This assistance, which will take the form of loans, will be in exchange for the implementation of structural reforms by the Tunisian authorities.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining on this report. It clearly fails to identify ways of managing future financial assistance to Tunisia to deal with the migration crisis, and does not tie the financial assistance to conditions such as willingness to cooperate.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal. In 2015 Tunisia’s economy has been significantly affected by several terrorist attacks that have targeted key economic industries like tourism and transport as well as aiming to disrupt the consolidation of its political transition. The assistance will target structural reforms aimed at improving the overall macroeconomic management and the conditions for sustainable growth (e.g. targeting the transparency and efficiency of public finance management; fiscal reforms; reforms to strengthen the social safety net; labour market reforms; and reforms to improve the regulatory framework for trade and investment).

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is a special country. A man who knows the history of Europe will find here the ruins of Carthage and traces of the ancient rulers of the Berbers, who today call themselves the Kabyls. In addition to monuments from ancient Rome, the visitor finds oriental culture, one of islam's holy sites – Kairuan – and a number of beautiful holiday resorts. Secondary and higher education is essentially Francophone and the country is relatively stable. The problems facing the current government are "southern European." Low economic growth, significant unemployment among university graduates and women. The situation in neighbouring Libya is extremely unstable. Several assassinations and terrorist attacks have negatively affected tourism developments. In 2014, Tunisia received EUR 300 million, with the last part of this amount to be paid during 2016. In support of further reforms, the European Commission proposes a medium-term loan of EUR 500 million. Given that most Mediterranean countries have a partnership agreement with the EU, but Tunisia is currently one of the few countries in the region considered stable, I believe that it is appropriate to support the programme while asking the European Commission to draw up a report showing how to use the funds to date and to inform the EP of the measures taken by the Tunisian Government to stabilise the economic situation and develop democratic structures.

I agree with this and voted in favour of the report.

This aid programme will be used for reforms aimed at improving Tunisia's budgetary situation, balancing its balance of payments and creating favourable conditions for investment. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the on-going democratic transition of Tunisia, the country still faces huge challenges relative to security, unemployment and vulnerable political context. It is important for Europe to show solidarity in order to bring back the country in its reform process. However, I decided to abstain. I believe that the generalisation of neoliberal agendas as well as the assistance, in the form of medium-term loans, to countries with an already high external debt, could create unintended consequences as they could further increase country’s foreign debt. Hence, compensatory mechanisms should be created.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Some third countries, with which the EU has concluded agreements, are experiencing difficult times, including Tunisia. In fact, Tunisia's economic situation deteriorated further after the 2015 terrorist attacks. For these reasons, the EU wants to make a real contribution to its economic development and to the promotion of the democratic process. The aid consists of a temporary loan divided into instalments of EUR 500 million. However, it is important to remember that financial agreements will only be granted if the country successfully completes the programmes that can be successfully completed during the agreements. In order to improve living conditions in the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, and with a view to a long-term strategy against irregular migration, as proposed in the migration compact, I believe it is useful to act in this direction.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Serious attempts have been made to destabilise Tunisia, which has so far been averted. In order to ensure that this remains the case and that the number of crisis areas where migrants are discharged does not increase, the EU should also invest. In order to maintain stability, the aid scheme and the supplementary loan programme are not a great price. The formation of a grand coalition government is viable and has adequate guarantees. It is essential that the objective to be achieved is not to meet the criteria developed by the IMF, but to promote the well-being of the population.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the Commission's proposal, which is uncompromising on structural reforms to be carried out and interferes in Tunisian politics in exchange for a loan of 500 million euros. On the other hand, I abstained on the legislative resolution, which is much less harsh than that of the Commission. It is important that this country in serious financial and political difficulty is not left behind. However, the structural reforms imposed by the EU on Tunisia risk further destabilising the country.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the Commission's proposal on macro-financial assistance to Tunisia, which is uncompromising on structural reforms and interferes in Tunisian politics in exchange for a loan of 500 million euros.  Following the terrorist attacks, Tunisia is facing serious problems (instability in Libya, growing domestic unrest, 15% unemployment rate, tourist disaffection, etc.). In mid-April 2013, the IMF released a 24-month loan of $1.75 billion (extended since then). The EU made a loan of 300 million euros in 2013, disbursed in tranches until 2016. Tunisia is seeking a new 15-year loan of 500 million euros to the EU and a new 4-year agreement with the IMF.  I abstained on the legislative resolution, which is much less harsh than the Commission's proposal. It is important that this country in serious financial and political difficulty is not left behind. However, the structural reforms imposed by the EU on Tunisia risk further destabilising the country.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Financial assistance to Tunisia will not only support the economy of this crisis-hit country, but will, above all, contribute to the development of democracy in the region. With this money, cooperation between the European Union and Tunisia will be able to develop even better and the values of modern democracy, such as respect for human rights, will be strengthened.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. Tunisia is an unstable country. Notably by the terrorist attacks it has suffered, the proximity of Libya, an unemployment rate of 15%, a disaffection of tourism, strikes. As a result, to prevent a political shift in the country that would encourage the arrival of Islamist terrorists, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) released a loan of $1.17 billion in mid-April 2013 over 24 months, and the EU a loan of 300 million euros in the same year, paid in tranches until 2016. In return, the IMF has set out a programme to be respected and the EU to implement structural reforms. However, they risk destabilizing the country.  Today, Tunisia is seeking a new loan of 500 million euros to the EU over 15 years, which can only be done if structural reforms are carried out. This European requirement is not the right solution, so I got ASBTENU.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report proposes to approve macro-financial assistance to Tunisia for the second time for a maximum value of 500 million. I do not object to helping economically a country like Tunisia whose population has been in a difficult situation since 2001, now aggravated by the threat of the Islamic State and its allies in the region. But by no means should this aid be through the macro-financial assistance instrument, as this financial aid will complete IMF credits conditional on structural reforms, which only impoverish the population and worsen their living conditions: liberalizations and privatizations. That's why I voted against it.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report shows that Tunisia has succeeded in consolidating its democratic structures. Tunisia, however, is also facing major difficulties at the moment. It has been the target of attacks and terrorist attacks several times. Moreover, from a security and political point of view, it is extremely unstable, mainly because of the common border with Libya. It is important that Tunisia succeeds with its policies and resolutely responds to those actors who want to destabilise the country. Europe must therefore show solidarity and support the country in its development through concrete measures that directly benefit the population. In August 2015, the Commission set aside a second macro-financial assistance programme for Tunisia totalling €500 million, to be granted on favourable terms in the form of medium-term loans taken out on the capital market. This aid programme is intended to support the reforms that Tunisia is implementing in order to improve its budgetary situation. Tunisia is not over-indebted, so that the public debt can be considered sustainable and the repayment of the financial assistance seems to be guaranteed. The rapporteur supports the Commission's proposal and wants to see this aid programme enter into force as soon as possible in order to support Tunisia at a critical stage. I agree with this and voted in favour of the report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a medium-term loan of EUR 500 million to Tunisia to help it cover its residual external needs.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the sending of EUR 800 million out of the pockets of European taxpayers as economic assistance to Tunisia. Helping poor countries is supposed to be free trade. On the contrary, I support the easing of trade with Tunisia, which will strengthen its stability better than subsidies and loans.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Tunisia's economic structure has been hit by the negative consequences of internal unrest that occurred after the 2011 revolution. Along with the negative consequences of the revolution, Tunisia's instability was further caused by the weak international environment and the war in Libya.  Tunisia went through a period of stagnation in 2011, and since 2012 has continued to make smaller economic progress thanks to tourism as its main activity and foreign direct investment (FDI). Tunisia has managed to go through a period of consolidation, but the macroeconomic situation remains very fragile. For example, the 3% growth projected for 2015 decreased to a slight 0.5%. With the Macro-Financial Assistance Facility (MFA), the European Union aims to provide funds to Tunisia to better overcome economic and regional instability. The established criteria confirm that Tunisia meets the possibility of receiving macro-financial assistance by valuing and respecting democracy and promoting the rule of law. I supported the report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to provide additional macro-financial assistance to Tunisia.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the plenary meeting held on 8 June 2016, we adopted by a large majority the EP's position on providing additional macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. Tunisia's economy suffered a downturn in 2015 after several terrorist attacks that severely affected tourism and transport in the country and led to a decline in foreign investment. The country needs international financial assistance to stabilise. The new amount to be allocated to Tunisia amounts to EUR 500 million. divided into three instalments over the next two years. This financial assistance will be subject to a number of economic policy conditions that correspond to the newly prepared IMF financial programme for the country. The Commission and the Tunisian authorities will also agree on specific structural governance reforms. Tunisia's respect for fundamental democratic principles, the rule of law and human rights are a prerequisite for the provision of macro-financial assistance by the Union. I voted in favour as I believe that through external assistance Tunisia can tackle these problems and be a responsible partner of the EU.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. At the request of the Tunisian government, the EU has made available macro-financial assistance (AMF) totalling up to EUR 500 million in medium-term loans. It is expected that the aid will be paid in three tranches, one of which could be disbursed in the first half of 2016. Under the practice established since 2009 by a joint declaration of Parliament and the Council, the AMF is subject to a double-conditionality: democratic and macroeconomic. I am voting in favour of this report, because there is an urgent need to support Tunisia. The Commission will need to be most flexible in encouraging macroeconomic reforms. Indeed, this AMF should not be a way for the EU to impose austerity reforms on Tunisia, which could also serve as a political argument in the event of early elections in a country that is beset by multiple crises.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the legislative resolution and voted against the European Commission's proposal. Following many internal and external factors (terrorist attacks, instability in Libya, internal unrest, strikes, etc.), Tunisia finds itself in a difficult situation.  In April 2013, the IMF released a loan of $1.75 billion for 24 months and the EU made a loan of 300 million euros. Today, Tunisia is seeking a new loan of 500 million euros to the EU. We argue that it is essential that Tunisia, in serious financial and political difficulty, be helped on the macroeconomic front, but various reforms and interference, including structural reforms imposed by the EU, could have even more negative repercussions.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Tunisia is going through a period of great economic difficulties, mainly caused by the various terrorist attacks and attacks suffered, with a number of consequences, such as negative effects in various economic sectors, first and first of all tourism, the growth of unemployment mainly of women, instability of the regional political and security context. Despite all these issues, Tunisia is trying to react, but it needs help to create real improvements in the management of public finances, the tax system, social security, reform in the financial sector and in order to improve the regulatory framework for trade and investment. There is a need to strengthen its relations with the main partners, first and first and for all the European Union. As macro-financial assistance is an instrument for a third country that, through a crisis situation and tunisia having all the necessary requirements for the granting of macro-financial assistance, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a proposal to provide further macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. I am fully aware that this country is in a very difficult situation, it has been the target of several assassinations. The political and regional situation is highly unstable, especially because of neighbouring Libya. I agree that further destabilisation of the area must be avoided. However, I am not sure that the EUR 500 million that is being discussed today will actually end up in the hands of those in need. What control mechanisms are set up? And where is the guarantee that the funds sent will actually be used for the purpose for which they are intended? I abstained in the final vote.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The democratic transition in Tunisia is not being easy. This country is living through difficult economic times and must also face the terrible suffering associated with the terrorist attacks that have occurred, especially in tourist areas. From the EU we must help the stabilisation of this country, and that is why I am in favour of the proposal to grant additional macro-financial assistance to which we have already approved in a first programme. This aid programme will support Tunisia's reforms to improve its budgetary situation, balance its balance of payments and establish a more investment-friendly climate.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. With a population of 10 million and a very small size compared to its neighbours, Tunisia faces considerable challenges (unemployment, territorial inequalities, terrorism, the reception of 1.8 million Libyan refugees) with exemplary courage.  In this context, it would have been unthinkable for Europe to refuse to help Tunisia: I therefore supported without amendment sarnez's report, which provided for the urgent release of 500 million euros in macro-financial assistance (AMF) to the Tunisian Republic in the form of loans. However, as rapporteur of the Socialist and Democratic Group for relations between the European Union and the Maghreb, I took advantage of this debate to make a number of reminders in the presence of the European Commission. The latter too often tends to condition its loans on the implementation of structural reforms with questionable effectiveness: the AMF only makes sense if it encourages productive investment, to combat unemployment. Finally, the AMF should not be an excuse to delay the resolution of long-term problems; the EU must make progress on reducing the debt inherited from the Ben Ali regime and recovering the embezzled assets.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we can safely say that Tunisia has made significant and remarkable progress in its democratisation and the protection of the fundamental rights of its citizens. It is no coincidence that he has been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in relation to the country's National Dialogue Quartet. At the same time, however, the country is also facing very serious challenges due to the increased terrorist attacks, which have significantly reduced the country's expected growth and progress, for example in the tourism sector. I believe that Tunisia's efforts to modernise its state infrastructure and economic development should be recognised by the EU and should be an incentive to strengthen the Union's macro-financial assistance to that country. This is because Tunisia also fulfils all the political criteria required to provide this funding. I am therefore voting in favour of the report so that this plan can be implemented as soon as possible.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is about microfinance support for North African countries. In principle, I see these microfinance measures as positive, as they could solve the migration problem on the ground. However, since Tunisia refuses to sign a readmission agreement, I have taken a neutral position.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the decision granting additional macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. The country has been the target of terrorist attacks and attacks on several occasions, which have had a major impact on key sectors of the economy to which the tourism sector has been targeted, for example. The political and security situation in the region is very volatile, especially with regard to the common border with Libya. It is very important that Tunisia succeeds in withstanding the external forces that want to destabilise it. I believe that the EU macro-financial assistance programme will help to support the reforms undertaken by Tunisia in order to improve the budgetary situation, balance the balance of payments and create an investment-friendly environment.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. If we really want to help Tunisian democracy, as the report states, it is not with "macro-financial assistance", i.e. a loan conditional on the implementation of structural reforms demanded by the IMF. This alleged aid of 500 million euros will strangle the Tunisian state budget. Moreover, since the first EU-IMF loan in 2014, the debt now accounts for more than 56% of the country's GDP and is expected to soon reach 72%. As my friends in the Popular Front point out, debt repayment is a waste of money for the state for strengthening democracy, developing health care, fighting unemployment, especially among young people, etc.  The height? We must vote for this assistance without having access to the details of the measures required, i.e. sign a blank cheque. But the reforms demanded in 2014 suggest the content: lower taxes on corporations, destruction of social security, breaking labour law. We must give up some of this debt, at least half of which is illegitimately contracted by the former dictator. States have already understood this and, failing to erase it, are converting their loans into development projects. I'm voting against the report.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. After making a loan of 300 million euros in 2013, the EU is again being asked by Tunisia to the tune of 500 million euros this time. However, this loan is conditional on democratic principles and structural reforms. It is also important to stress that Tunisia is negotiating a free trade agreement with the EU.  I abstained on this issue, because if Tunisia does face serious financial difficulties, the interference and proposed reforms could further destabilize the country.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution due to Tunisia’s development as a democratic nation. The stabilisation of Tunisia through the use of macro-financial assistance is necessary to ensure that terrorism in the area is tackled and people are protected.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – Tunisia has elected a broad coalition government in free and transparent elections. The adopted Constitution guarantees rights and freedoms and an independent judiciary. However, terrorist attacks have affected key economic sectors and have also had a negative impact on tourism. However, given the border with Libya, the security situation in the regions is rather unstable. It is therefore essential that Tunisia thwarts any attempts to destabilise it. The Union's role is thus to support the country in development through concrete measures that will directly benefit the country's people, as well as to promote relations with the Union, in particular in the area of free trade. Thanks to the reforms carried out in the country, Tunisia fully fulfils the political conditions necessary for the granting of macro-financial assistance, in particular as regards respect for democracy, human rights and the rule of law. The Union has allocated EUR 300 million to support the country's reform efforts to improve public finance management and the functioning of the tax system, strengthen the social security network, reform the financial sector and improve the regulatory framework for trade and investment. I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which supports this measure as a way to help Tunisia further consolidate its democracy, bring about an environment more conducive to investment and urgently address unemployment. Tunisia has succeeded in consolidating its democratic transition. It now has a constitution that safeguards rights and freedoms, with a consolidated judicial system and empowered media. It is led by a broad unity government that emerged from free and transparent elections, with an enterprising and modern civil society, and has rightly been rewarded with the Nobel Peace Prize for the Tunisian National Dialogue Quartet. Despite all challenges, Tunisia continues to make very significant progress, firmly establishing democratic transition in the country, carrying out the reforms needed to modernise its economy and bolstering its relations with its partners, in particular the European Union, with which it is currently negotiating a free-trade agreement. It is most important that Tunisia should succeed – that it should thwart all those who seek to destabilise it. For that reason, the EU must show solidarity and resolve to help and back Tunisia in its development process through very tangible actions directly benefiting the population of the country.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. Tunisia has consolidated its democratic transition. It has a constitution protecting rights and freedoms, an orderly judiciary and independent and free media. It is governed by a grand coalition government resulting from free and transparent elections, and the country can rely on proactive and modern civil society. Despite all the serious difficulties it is currently facing, the country continues to make important progress, consolidating the democratic transition and implementing the reforms necessary to modernise its economic structure and strengthening its relations with its partners, including the European Union. It is of the utmost importance that Tunisia succeeds and pulls through the calculations of those who want to destabilise the country.  On 15 May 2014, the EU approved a €300 million aid programme for Tunisia to support the country's reform efforts. In August 2015, at the request of the Tunisian Government, the Commission envisaged a second macro-financial assistance programme of EUR 500 million for Tunisia, which will be disbursed in the form of medium-term loans on favourable terms on the financial markets. The Commission has now proposed to Parliament and the Council a vote on this second financial assistance programme. In its report, the Committee on International Trade recommends that Parliament adopt its position at first reading in the same way as the Commission's proposal.  I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Following the unrest generated by terrorist activities on its territory, Tunisia suffers from an economic slowdown, serious imbalances and internal instability. For example, in 2013, the IMF provided a loan of $1.75 billion and the EU eur 300 million. Despite this, Tunisia is once again seeking a loan of 500 million euros and a further extension of the repayment of old debts. However, these loans are conditional on the implementation of structural reforms (fiscal reforms, social security, labour market, etc.) and respect for democracy. Although it is important that this country in serious financial and political difficulty is not left behind, we are voting against the Commission's proposal, which is an example of European interference and which could further destabilise Tunisia.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Since the Arab Spring, Tunisia has been the target of terrorist attacks, which aim to destabilise the country and the main economic sector, Tourism. Economic growth is below forecast and the average unemployment rate is 15 %.  Because of the effort tunisia is making, I am in favour of the financial support provided by the Union and other initiatives aimed at supporting the population.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. It is important that Tunisia, a country in serious financial and political difficulty, is not left behind. But various reforms and interference could further destabilize this country.  As this report has less restrictive conditions for Tunisia than the EU has requested, I will oppose it only by abstention.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report to support the Commission proposal to provide assistance to Tunisia which will target structural reforms aimed at improving the overall macroeconomic management and the conditions for sustainable growth.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This report relates to macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. The country, which continued its reforms following the Arab Spring, was experiencing difficulties, notably because of the terrorist attacks it had suffered, which affected many economic sectors, including tourism.  I support the 500 million euro aid to Tunisia, which will be essential to restore a climate conducive to investment. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. Tunisia, by setting up a process aimed at democratising the country, is now led by a coalition government, elected in full transparency, its media enjoy independence and its legal system is independent. Because of this success, supported by an active and Nobel Prize-winning civil society, the country is now threatened by attempts at destabilisation, supported by the enemies of freedom and pluralistic values. Terrorist attacks on Westerners in seaside resorts have, in fact, undermined tunisia's tourism industry, the first item in Tunisia's GDP that saw foreign presences fall by eighty percent last season. The high levels of unemployment, which are particularly serious for young people and in rural areas, the threats linked to the proliferation of weapons in the event of new NATO operations in the region and the proximity to Libya, of which the country is home to 1.8 million citizens, could, finally, increase the risk of radicalisation of the population with obvious repercussions throughout the Mediterranean area. In view of all these aspects, therefore, we can only express our sincere support for financial assistance measures which, in the form of long-term loans, can contribute to the stabilisation of the country and the future of tunisians.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia has taken serious steps to form a solid democracy that has paid off. Today, they can boast of a constitution based on rights and freedoms, justice and independent media, free elections.   However, tunisia's economic situation is not so balanced, the country is facing significant financial problems. The main source of these is the numerous terrorist attacks and attacks on Tunisia, which have weakened the key economic sector, tourism, the most, leading, among other things, to a rapid increase in unemployment.  Tunisia clearly needs financial assistance and macro-financial assistance may be able to help combat the crisis.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Tunisia has now a constitution that safeguards rights and freedoms, empowered media and a consolidated judicial system. I have voted for this report that will grant macro-financial assistance to Tunisia in the form of medium-term financial-market loans.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because I am in favour of supporting the North African countries in order to better combat the migration problem on the ground. For this very reason, however, it is incomprehensible that the granting of financial aid is not linked to the strengthening of Tunisia's efforts to stem the current wave of migration.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Tunisia has made progress in promoting democratic principles, but the country has suffered a number of terrorist attacks. The country's economic growth has slowed significantly in recent years, largely due to the unrest in the region. However, the EU's macro-financial assistance instrument can be used to support a third country in a crisis situation. The objectives of the aid programme financed by it are to improve the budgetary situation of the state of the country, to balance the balance of payments and to encourage investment.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Looking at tunisia's considerable steps on the transition to democracy, I believe that macro-financial assistance can both support the country and, at the same time, counter those who wish to destabilise the situation. Given that the reforms implemented by Tunisia fully meet the requirements for the granting of macro-financial assistance by the European Union, I would like to vote in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Tunisia has been suffering severe economic difficulties from the beginning of 2011 when its political and economic revolution began. In order to overcome its problems further assistance is necessary. The terrorist attacks in 2015 worsened the situation affecting tourism and transport which are an essential part of every country’s economy. I take the chance to vote on favour of the MFA to the Tunisian Republic so that the necessary reforms are made, in order for them to achieve a sustainable balance and hopefully the ultimate goal of economic growth.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal to provide an additional macro-financial assistance to Tunisia for a total maximum amount of EUR 500 million, provided in the form of a medium-term loan. The assistance will contribute to cover Tunisia’s residual external financial needs in 2016-17, as identified by the Commission based on the estimate of the IMF.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Tunisia is currently going through a lot of difficulties and I think we need to accept this proposal that seeks to provide it with further macro-financial assistance. The European Union and Tunisia have good relations and are continuously strengthening them. Despite the many challenges tunisia faces, it is managing to implement the democratic transition and reforms needed to modernise the economy and strengthen trade ties. We need to support him in this and that is why I support the proposal for this second macro-financial assistance programme for Tunisia of a total of €500 million. This programme will further support Tunisia's reforms to improve its fiscal situation, balance of payments and create a more favourable investment climate.  I agree with the proposal that the Commission manages macro-financial assistance, as well as that monitoring should be carried out and account should be taken to prevent fraud and other irregularities. Taking into account the geopolitical environment and the social and political situation tunisia is in, I think it is important for the Union to have a reliable partner in North Africa and therefore I supported this proposal for a decision.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. It is important that Tunisia, a country in serious financial and political difficulty, is not left behind. But various reforms and interferences could further destabilize it. The report sets less restrictive conditions for Tunisia than the EU requested. But I have no confidence in the EU's advice and recommendations to third countries, seeing the disastrous results of its policies for the Member States. That is why I prefer to abstain on this text.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tunisia has made tremendous progress on its path to democratic transition. It has a constitution that protects rights and freedoms, with an independent judicial system and media. Civil society, dynamic and modern, has actively contributed to this transformation. The country, however, is experiencing great difficulties, due to terrorist attacks that have targeted its main economic sectors, such as tourism, in order to destabilise it. Economic growth has suffered a setback and the unemployment rate, especially for women and young people, remains very high. Despite all these issues, Tunisia is boldly pursuing its reform programme for the modernisation of its economic structures and is strengthening relations with its partners, including the EU. It is therefore important for Europe to show solidarity and do everything possible to support its development, with concrete actions for the direct benefit of the population. Macro-financial assistance (MFA) is the most appropriate instrument, in this context, to accompany the modernisation programme. Tunisia fulfils all the conditions for granting the MFA and I therefore support the Commission's proposal, supported by Parliament's report, to grant aid.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒in 2012 Tunisia has managed to consolidate its democratic transition. It has a Constitution that protects rights and freedoms and regulated justice and independent media. It is governed by a government of a broad coalition formed after free and transparent elections, and is based on an enterprising and modern civic society, for which the Tunisian National Dialogue Quartet was rightly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. But Tunisia is currently going through very big difficulties.  On several occasions, it has been the target of terrorist attacks that have significantly affected economic sectors crucial to the country, such as the tourism sector. In addition, the security and political regional context is extremely unstable, in particular because of the country's border with Libya. It is very important that Tunisia succeeds in this and prevents all those who want to destabilize it. This is why Europe needs to show solidarity and determination to support and support Tunisia in its development through concrete action that directly benefits the country's population.  At the same time, we must not forget the problem that arose with the unscarin import of olive oil. I accept the Commission's proposal and hope that this additional assistance programme will enter into force as soon as possible to help Tunisia at a crucial time.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. Since 2011, the EU has been providing financial and operational assistance to Tunisia in the process of implementing economic and political reforms. In 2015, Tunisia was hit by terrorist attacks, which left repercussions on primary industries, such as tourism and transport, but also disrupted the stabilisation of the political environment and the country's security. On this occasion, Tunisia requested additional €500 million in macro-financial assistance from the EU, which would be provided in the form of a medium-term loan. Macro-financial assistance is planned to be paid in three instalments, controlled by the Commission and intended for structural reforms to improve macroeconomic governance and conditions for growth.  Accordingly, I supported MeP de Sarnez's report on the provision of macro-financial assistance to Tunisia.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisian economy is largely based on tourism. It was hit very hard by terrorist attacks in 2015. We are currently seeing the remnants of this act in the form of persistent unemployment and subsequent protests. I have therefore supported the medium- and long-term loans that can be granted to this country. Tunisia fulfils the conditions laid down by the European Union. The third wave of assistance should focus on improving the management of public finances, the tax system and the regulatory framework for trade and investment. If Tunisia, with European help, achieves an improvement in its economic and social situation, democracy will also be strengthened and security in the southern neighbouring region will be increased. However, I also voted in favour of the provision which requires the European Commission to ensure the effective protection of the Union's financial interests and therefore to carry out checks and accounting audits.
