The European Union has the means to help states that need it urgently and whose development will be good for the Member States themselves. On the other hand, this certainly does not mean that we can afford to waste the financial resources provided by European citizens, which are limited.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tunisia's economy has been in serious trouble since the start of the so-called "Arab Spring" revolution in 2011. In 2015, the country was hit by terrorist attacks that disrupted tourist flows and aggravated its already weak fiscal balance and credit position. The EU granted Tunisia €300,000,000 in financial aid in 2014. In August 2015, the Tunisian government asked the EU to contribute €500 million to a second International Monetary Fund (IMF) supplementary assistance and lending programme. In order to have access to credit, Tunisia will have to sign a memorandum of intent with the European Commission, committing itself to structural reforms and to pursuing sound management of public finances. It must also ensure respect for democratic mechanisms, the rule of law and human rights, under EU supervision. Once these conditions have been fulfilled, Tunisia will be able to benefit from the loan for a period of two and a half years. I voted in favour of this report and I believe that these are the types of aid that should be pursued by the EU institutions and not agreements, unholy, such as those relating to olive oil.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Since the so-called "Arab Spring" revolution of 2011, Tunisia's economy has been in deep trouble. In addition, deadly terrorist attacks in 2015 did not promote stability in the country.  It was in this context that I voted in favour of a EUR 500 million loan to Tunisia, mainly aimed at reducing its external debt and promoting its budgetary balance. Tunisia is therefore now invited to sign a Memorandum of Understanding with the European Commission committing it to structural reforms and sound management of its public finances.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. Relations between the EU and the Tunisian Republic have been developing within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy. Under the regular cooperation programme, the Union has made EUR 524 million available in the form of grants; the Tunisian authorities and the IMF concluded an agreement totaling USD 1 500 million; EUR 277 million was also allocated to Tunisia under two separate programmes and the European Investment Bank has granted loans of EUR 1 338 million. However, and in parallel with this process of political transition, the country's economy has been affected by ongoing internal disruption and a fragile international environment, such as the various terrorist attacks that in 2015 aimed to disrupt the consolidation of the political transition.  In view of the above-mentioned context, this report states that the Union's macro-financial assistance to Tunisia should be subject to economic policy conditions to be established in a Memorandum of Understanding. In order to ensure uniform conditions of implementation, and for reasons of efficiency, the Commission should be empowered to negotiate those conditions with the Tunisian authorities, under the supervision of the Committee of Representatives of the Member States.  I voted positively.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament is ready to continue to help Tunisia overcome its economic difficulties and return to the path of more sustainable growth through the vote this afternoon in favour of additional financial assistance of 500 million euros.  Tunisia is struggling to overcome the serious economic difficulties that have plagued it since the beginning of the political and economic transition process. This situation was aggravated by the terrorist attacks of 2015 that hit two key sectors of the economy, tourism and transport. MEPs strongly condemn these attacks on this friendly nation whose peace efforts during the democratic transition process are an example for the whole region. The aim is to help certain sectors, such as olive oil production, to facilitate reforms aimed at restoring the balance of payments and fiscal position and to improve the investment climate.  In short, Parliament wants to help Tunisia create the conditions for sustainable economic growth, benefiting all and creating jobs.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. 'u2012 Tunisia has managed to consolidate its democratic transition. It has a Constitution that protects rights and freedoms, a consolidated judicial system and independent media.  However, Tunisia is currently experiencing great difficulties. It has been the target of attacks and terrorist attacks that have deeply affected the country's key economic sectors, such as tourism. Growth, which was expected to be 3 % in 2015, was revised down to 0.5% in 2016, and the average unemployment rate is 15%, 20 % for women and 28.6 % for young graduates of higher education. It is very important that Tunisia succeeds and that it contradicts all those who want to destabilise it. Europe must be united and determined to accompany and support Tunisia in its development. Macro-financial assistance is a European financial instrument that can be mobilised to support a third state that is in a crisis situation. Thanks to the reforms carried out in the country, Tunisia fully fulfils the necessary political conditions. The European Commission therefore provides a second macro-financial assistance programme for Tunisia for a total of EUR 500 million in the form of a loan.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Since its democratic transition began in 2011, the Tunisian economy has been affected by continued internal turmoil, instability in the region, and a weak international environment. Tunisia requested a first macro-financial assistance operation to the EU in 2014, in addition to the IMF's assistance programme. The aid, granted by the EU in the form of appropriations and subsidies, has been disbursed in several tranches throughout 2015 and part one in 2016. However, following the terrorist attacks in 2015, Tunisia's economy has suffered a severe blow, particularly on tourism, transport and investment, with a devastating impact on employment and significant social turmoil. Economic instability is very negatively affecting the balance of payments and its public finances, leaving Tunisia in urgent need of funding. That is why the Tunisian authorities have requested new assistance from the IMF and, in addition, a second macro-financial assistance operation to the EU amounting to EUR 500 million. I have decided to support this new financial assistance to Tunisia, in support of its political, social and economic transition efforts.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of a second macro-financial aid plan of 500 million euros to promote Tunisia's development. It is in the European Union's best interest to have a stable, prosperous and peaceful neighbourhood. It is desirable to forge a political and economic partnership with Tunisia. However, the country is facing a severe economic slowdown since the Arab Spring revolution, which is adding to its substantial debt. Tunisia and its population are experiencing a particularly delicate situation: high unemployment, a tourism sector that has been squeezed by terrorist attacks (while it represents half a million jobs), regional disparities, migration and security challenges linked to neighbouring Libya... This European loan, conditional on a series of reforms, is a strong signal sent to the Tunisian people as a sign of solidarity. Europe supports Tunisia's democratic transition, and stands with its citizens.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Tunisia is an important partner for the EU. What is more important is that it is a close neighbour and stability in it can have a direct impact on our stability and security. I therefore support and call on everyone to support this EU assistance initiative for tunisia's macroeconomic stability.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. Although Tunisia has managed to consolidate democracy as the political regime in force in the country, tunisia continues to face serious difficulties related to its internal security, including terrorist attacks and attacks, which end up affecting nerve sectors of its economy, such as tourism, trade and restoration.  With extremely low product growth rates and high unemployment, especially among the skilled young population, and looking at the scenario of political and security instability, I think it makes perfect sense for the EU's additional support for its enormous effort at democratic development and consolidation.  It is in this context that this proposal for macro-financial assistance supports Tunisia in its efforts to reform the tax system and public finances, the financial sector and the regulatory framework for trade and investment.  This additional macro-financial assistance provides for a total of EUR 500 million in the form of medium-term loans on financial markets with advantageous conditions. As the main objective of this proposal is to support Tunisia's reforms to improve its budgetary position, balance the balance of payments and create a climate that is more conducive to employment and investment, I supported this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution by calling for greater foreign investment through appropriations to strengthen Tunisia's economy. I believe that the aid Tunisia needs should be granted, if possible, in the form of non-reimbursable aid and not through appropriations with strict macroeconomic conditionality criteria that not only undermine the sovereignty of the country but increase the risk of debt stress.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides Tunisia with an additional financial assistance of 500 million euros. This assistance will take the form of medium-term loans on favourable financial terms.  This assistance will cover part of Tunisia's external financing needs in 2016 and 2017, while facilitating reforms aimed at more sustainably restoring the balance of payments and fiscal position, improving the investment climate and promoting economic integration and regulatory convergence with the EU. Through this aid, the Union reaffirms its solidarity and support for Tunisia; the goal remains to create conditions for sustainable economic growth, benefiting all and creating jobs.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mrs de Sarnez's proposal for a decision on the granting of macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. The text voted provides for the granting of a EUR 500 million loan to Tunisia provided by the Commission on behalf of the EU, which will serve to cover at least part of the needs of the country's residual external financing. The loan will be disbursed in three tranches, the first of EUR 200 million, the next of EUR 150 million each. As usual in the case of financial assistance, aid is not an end in itself, and disbursements are in fact dependent on the success of the implementation of the programme provided for by the International Monetary Fund. In addition, the Commission and the Tunisian authorities would agree on specific structural reforms, within the framework of a memorandum of understanding.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. Since the 2015 terrorist attack, The Tuneis's economy has been hit hard by falling tourist revenues. Such an economic downturn could be dangerous for Tunisia's democratic development. With a financial loan to Tunisia, the EU can help reverse economic development and thus also strengthen democratic consolidation. That is why I support the proposal.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of macro-financial assistance in Tunisia as it can only be beneficial for the EU to help neighbouring countries such as Tunisia stabilise the economy and government. With this decision, we are providing Tunisia with a medium-term loan of up to EUR 500 million. Of course, this loan is conditional: for example, there will be constant reviews by the IMF, but there will also be an agreement between the Commission and the Tunisian authorities on state reforms.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: Written. I chose to vote to grant macro-financial assistance to Tunisia because it is well on its way to respecting human rights, establishing the rule of law and succeeding in its democratic transition. It is our moral duty to assist Tunisia along this path to successfully complete the transition, especially at a time when their key economic sectors are vulnerable.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report proposes to approve macro-financial assistance to Tunisia for the second time for a maximum value of 500 million. I do not object to helping economically a country like Tunisia whose population has been in a difficult situation since 2001, now aggravated by the threat of the Islamic State and its allies in the region. But by no means should this aid be through the macro-financial assistance instrument, as this financial aid will complete IMF credits conditional on structural reforms, which only impoverish the population and worsen their living conditions: liberalizations and privatizations. That's why I voted against it.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this measure as a way to help Tunisia further consolidate its democracy since the recent political upheaval. This legislative report represents the EU’s commitment to the country and desire to see the country bring about an environment which is more conducive to investment and will address the urgent problem of unemployment in this area.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Thanks to the reforms carried out in the country, Tunisia fully fulfils the political conditions necessary for the granting of macro-financial assistance, in particular as regards respect for democracy, human rights and the rule of law. The European Union should support and assist Tunisia in its development with concrete measures that will directly benefit the people of the country. In this case, through a loan of EUR 500 million on preferential terms. I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Tunisia is currently in significant trouble. It has been the target of assassinations and terrorist attacks several times, which have hit key economic sectors, particularly tourism, hard. Nevertheless, Tunisia has firmly anchored democratic changes in the country, implementing reforms that require the modernisation of its economic structures and strengthening relations with its partners, namely the EU, with which it is also negotiating a free trade agreement. It is now very important for Tunisia to succeed and to thwart all attempts at destabilisation. That is why the EU must also support and assist Tunisia in its development through concrete measures that will benefit the people of the country. At the request of the Tunisian Government, in August 2015 the Commission drew up a second macro-financial assistance programme for Tunisia totalling EUR 500 million, which will be granted in the form of a medium-term loan on the financial markets on favourable terms. The motion for a resolution of the EP, for which I voted, agrees with this aid.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report shows that Tunisia has succeeded in consolidating its democratic structures. Tunisia, however, is also facing major difficulties at the moment. It has been the target of attacks and terrorist attacks several times. Moreover, from a security and political point of view, it is extremely unstable, mainly because of the common border with Libya. It is important that Tunisia succeeds with its policies and resolutely responds to those actors who want to destabilise the country. Europe must therefore show solidarity and determination and support the country in its development through concrete measures that directly benefit the population. In August 2015, the Commission set aside a second macro-financial assistance programme for Tunisia totalling €500 million, to be granted on favourable terms in the form of medium-term loans taken out on the capital market. This aid programme is intended to support the reforms that Tunisia is implementing in order to improve its budgetary situation. The rapporteur supports the Commission's proposal and wants to see this aid programme enter into force as soon as possible in order to support Tunisia at a critical stage. I agree with this and voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is an example of the Muslim country's successful transition towards pluralism and democracy. It is in our interest to support Tunisia along this path in order to help stabilise the situation throughout the Maghreb region. Among other things, it is one of the tools for tackling the migration crisis. However, medium-term loans totalling EUR 500 million must be used to aid the development of Tunisian society.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Despite all the challenges facing Tunisia, it continues to make progress, consolidating its democratic transition, implementing the reforms needed to modernise economic structures and strengthening relations with its partners, in particular the European Union with which it is currently negotiating a free trade agreement. The EU needs to show its solidarity and determination and support and support Tunisia in its development through concrete action that directly benefits the country's population.  In August 2015, the European Commission envisaged a second macro-financial assistance programme for Tunisia out of a total of €500 million to be granted on financial markets in the form of medium-term loans on favourable terms. This will support Tunisia's reforms to improve its fiscal situation, balance its balance of payments and create a more favourable investment climate.  I support this report because I believe that the EU should support the stabilisation of Tunisia as its partner.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council on further macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. I am fundamentally opposed to macro-financial assistance. Under a different name, I think development aid to Tunisia is possible, provided that it addresses the issues of migration more clearly and, above all, regulates the return of rejected asylum seekers. This applies in particular to Germany, so that aid would also have to be done bilaterally rather than through the EU. The EU is therefore also the wrong actor.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Tunisia has made significant progress by strengthening its democratic transition, implementing the reforms needed to modernise economic structures and strengthening relations with its partners, in particular the European Union. But Tunisia is also currently going through very big difficulties. On several occasions, it has been the target of terrorist attacks that have significantly affected economic sectors crucial to the country, such as the tourism sector. Macro-financial assistance is a European financial instrument that can be mobilised to support a third country in a crisis situation. Thanks to the reforms carried out, Tunisia fully fulfils the political conditions necessary for the granting of macro-financial assistance, in particular as regards respect for democracy, human rights and the rule of law. The European Commission has envisaged a macro-financial assistance programme for Tunisia of a total of €500 million to be allocated on financial markets in the form of medium-term loans on favourable terms. This programme will support Tunisia's reforms to improve its fiscal situation, balance of payments and create a more favourable investment climate. I support the proposal for a resolution, as I believe that Europe needs to show solidarity and determination to support and support Tunisia in its development through concrete action that directly benefits the country's population.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the provision of further macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. I support the granting of financial assistance to Tunisia, which is recording great progress in the area of democracy, the protection of human rights, reforms with which it fully fulfils the political conditions that are mandatory for granting aid. Tunisia, however, has faced a sharp decline in tourism in the past, leading to reduced growth and an increase in unemployment for women and young graduates. However, I also join the opinion in the Budget Committee letter that macro-financial assistance in the form of loans should only be one of the tools available to support Tunisia and that consideration should be given to the possibility of providing macro-financial assistance in the form of grants.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Repeating the same wrongs as the EU-Turkey agreement, where money is given for supposed development and democratisation, in order to stop migration flows, rather than being given to combat poverty and austerity in European countries, is a major political and moral error. Any plans to "buy" African countries in order to stop migration flows are unsustainable. A typical example is the increase in VAT on MFI in Greece to 24% with a budgetary gain of only EUR 5 million. Euro!!! At the same time, Tunisia received EUR 300 million from the European Investment Bank (EIB). In 2014, the second MAS programme will receive an other EUR 500 million. In addition to the funds received from regional programmes, the financing through the contribution mechanism, EUR 71.8 million was allocated to the European Investment Bank (EIB). On the basis of the principle of proportional principles, EUR 115 million was granted for the financing of the project. The European Neighbourhood Mechanism is the same as the European Neighbourhood Facility.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is currently experiencing great difficulties. It has been hit by a series of attacks and terrorist attacks that have hit key economic sectors in the country, such as tourism. Moreover, the regional security situation is extremely precarious as the country borders Libya. Despite these challenges, Tunisia continues to make important progress towards a democratic transition and to modernise its economic structure, and is currently negotiating a free trade agreement with the European Union. Thanks to the reforms, Tunisia fully complies with the political conditions for assessing macro-financial assistance. In order to restore stability in the region, it is of the utmost importance that Tunisia be able to take further steps for a democratic system of government and economic development. On 15 May 2014, a eur 300 million aid programme was approved for Tunisia. The first two instalments of the programme have already been paid in 2015 and the third will take place in 2016. This aid package is the second in a row envisaged by the Commission in August 2015, at the request of the Tunisian Government, in the form of a eur 500 million macro-financial assistance programme, which will be disbursed in the form of medium-term loans on favourable terms on the financial markets. This aid programme will be used for reforms aimed at improving Tunisia's budgetary situation, balancing its balance of payments and creating favourable conditions for investment. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because promoting international economic balance must be one of the EU's main objectives. Without a balanced global economy, the EU economy will not be boosted either. Furthermore, support for democratic development by stabilising Tunisia's public finances is very important. The loan-based aid provides temporary support to Tunisia, but partly puts pressure on the continued work already done to stabilise the economy in the form of a repayment requirement.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Tunisia has been successful in its transition towards democracy, respect for human rights and the rule of law and the country stands by itself as an example to be followed, in a region of the world overwhelmed by conflict. However, Tunisia`s economy has been very affected by the terrorist attacks of 2015 and in recent months there has been a rise in unemployment, which has triggered a large number of protests against the government. In 2014, an initial EUR 300 million programme was approved for Tunisia in order to strengthen the social safety net, improve the financial sector and the regulatory framework for trade and investment. Nevertheless, in light of the terrorist attacks of 2015, I support an additional programme of EUR 500 million, in the form of Micro Finance Assistance (MFA), in order to consolidate Tunisia`s democracy, address the issue of unemployment and create an attractive environment for investors.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text for several reasons. Tunisia has succeeded in consolidating its democratic transition. It is now endowed with a constitution that protects rights and freedoms, with consolidated justice and emancipated media. It is governed by a broad-based government, resulting from free and transparent elections.  But Tunisia is currently going through very great difficulties. It has repeatedly been the target of terrorist attacks and attacks that have deeply affected key economic sectors of the country, such as tourism. Growth, which was expected to be 3% in 2015, has been revised down to 0.5% for 2016, the unemployment rate is 15% on average, 20% for women and 28.6% for young graduates of higher education. Moreover, the regional security and political environment is extremely volatile, in particular because of the border it shares with Libya.  Despite all these challenges, Tunisia continues to make very significant progress, anchoring the democratic transition in the country.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the many challenges it is facing, Tunisia continues making very significant progress, proving that it is indeed capable of establishing a real democratic transition and carrying out the reforms needed for economic modernisation. This is why I support the proposal for a second Macro-Financial Assistance (MFA) programme for Tunisia, totalling EUR 500 million, which will be granted in the form of medium-term financial-market loans on advantageous conditions. Accompanying the successor IMF programme, this assistance programme will support the efforts made by Tunisia to improve its budgetary position and balance of payments and bring about a climate more conducive to investment. I also hope that this will positively contribute to the current negotiation of a free-trade agreement with the EU.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. In a difficult economic context for Tunisia, the Tunisian government has requested emergency macro-financial assistance (AMF) from the European Union totalling 500 million euros. Unemployment and inequality are at record highs in the country, whose economy relies heavily on the tourism sector, which has been weakened by the terrorist attacks of recent months. Moreover, assets embezzled by the Ben Ali regime, sometimes hidden in European banks, are still blocked.   The release of the AMF was absolutely necessary, because Tunisia needs this help. It is a country that has recently embarked on a healthy democratic transition that the European Union supports. The success of this transition will be reinforced by the good economic health of the country. It is therefore necessary to move quickly, without forcing Tunisians to make counterproductive economic reforms. Without this, the AMF would have only a limited effect.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council on providing additional macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. I believe that while Tunisia is going through great difficulties as a course of terrorist attacks, the reforms carried out fully fulfil the political conditions necessary for the granting of macro-financial assistance, in particular as regards respect for democracy, human rights and the rule of law. I believe that Europe needs to show solidarity and determination to support Tunisia in its development through concrete action that will benefit the country's population directly. I therefore supported a second macro-financial assistance programme for Tunisia out of a total of €500 million to be granted in financial markets in the form of medium-term loans on favourable terms.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council to provide further macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. The country is facing difficulties as the tourism sector has suffered a sharp decline following several terrorist attacks, economic growth is low and the unemployment rate is moving close to 20%. However, the country is consolidating the democratic transition, implementing reforms for an up-to-date economy and strengthening relations with partners. It is important for the EU to support Tunisia on its path of development and taking measures that will benefit the people. In this respect, macro-financial assistance is one of the instruments to help third countries in crisis. The latter belongs to Tunisia, as the reforms implemented make it eligible for its allocation. The first part of macro-financial assistance was launched in 2014, amounting to EUR 300 million. The next macro-financial assistance programme is projected to amount to EUR 500 million and will further contribute to the implementation of the reforms.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution by calling for greater foreign investment through appropriations to strengthen Tunisia's economy. I believe that the aid Tunisia needs should be granted, if possible, in the form of non-reimbursable aid and not through appropriations with strict macroeconomic conditionality criteria that not only undermine the sovereignty of the country but increase the risk of debt stress.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because Tunisia is a relatively stable country in such an important region of North Africa for us and as such it also needs financial assistance.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Tunisia has succeeded in consolidating its democratic transition. It now has a constitution that safeguards rights and freedoms, with a consolidated judicial system and empowered media. It is led by a broad unity government that emerged from free and transparent elections, with an enterprising and modern civil society, and has rightly been rewarded with the Nobel Peace Prize for the Tunisian National Dialogue Quartet.  Tunisia is going through very great difficulties. On a number of occasions it has been the target of terrorist murders and attacks which have hit key sectors of the country’s economy, such as tourism. Growth, projected at 3% for 2015, has been revised down to 0.5% for 2016; the unemployment rate is 15% on average, 20% for women and 28.6% for young university graduates. The regional security and political context is extremely volatile, moreover, chiefly because of the border it shares with Libya.  Despite all these challenges, Tunisia continues to make significant progress, firmly establishing democratic transition in the country, carrying out the reforms needed to modernise its economy and bolstering its relations with its partners, in particular the European Union, with which it is currently negotiating a free-trade agreement.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Following the recent terrorist attacks in Tunisia, which have affected key sectors of the economy, including tourism, the international community should show solidarity with our important partner. Despite huge problems such as falling GDP and rising unemployment, Tunisia continues its path of difficult reforms and efforts to build a state based on democratic values. EU support is crucial here and needed by both partners. It is in the interest of European countries to have a stable and predictable partner in the north African region, which is why I supported macro-financial assistance.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia has succeeded in consolidating the democratic transition. It now has a constitution protecting rights and freedoms, an orderly judiciary and independent and free media. It is governed by a grand coalition government formed as a result of free and transparent elections, and the country can rely on proactive and modern civil society, which has been rightly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, awarded to the Quartet of Tunisian National Dialogue. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution by calling for greater foreign investment through appropriations to strengthen Tunisia's economy. We believe that the aid Tunisia needs should be granted, if possible, in the form of non-reimbursable aid and not through credits with strict macroeconomic conditionality criteria that not only undermine the country's sovereignty but increase the risk of debt stress.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as we Greens are generally in favour of granting MFA to the countries which participate in the eastern European Neighbourhood Programme. We regard these countries as in the area of economic influence of the EU which hence deserve support in case of balance of payments problems.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council providing further macro-financial assistance to Tunisia. In response to the Tunisian Government’s request in August 2015, the Commission has made provision for a second MFA programme for Tunisia, totalling EUR 500 million, which will be granted in the form of medium-term financial-market loans on advantageous conditions. This assistance programme will back up the efforts made by Tunisia to improve its budgetary position and balance of payments and bring about a climate more conducive to investment. I voted in favour because I believe that the EU must show solidarity and resolve to help and back Tunisia in its development process through very tangible actions directly benefiting the population of the country.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a proposal that will provide Tunisia with macro-financial assistance of EUR 500 million in the medium term. This assistance is intended to help our neighbouring country carry out a series of necessary reforms that will need to be included in a memorandum of understanding. We are therefore talking about aid needed to help to provide greater stability to a neighbouring Mediterranean country, so I believe it is necessary to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution aims to validate new macro-financial assistance (AMF) from the European Union to Tunisia.  These are once again loans that will therefore aggravate the Tunisian debt and will be used mainly to cover the needs of the Tunisian balance of payments, conditioning Tunisia to carry out these famous structural reforms whose disastrous effects are known in Europe. Tunisia indisputably needs financial assistance, but not under any conditions. The GUE/NGL has tabled several amendments to ensure that this "aid" is granted in the form of grants. We also called for the AMF not to be conditional on the implementation of structural reforms that mean more austerity and liberalisation at the expense of the Tunisian economy and agriculture. We have requested an audit of the Tunisian debt and the suspension of its payments pending the results of this audit, which should highlight the odious debt enjoyed by Ben Ali. Unfortunately, our amendments were rejected, so I decided to abstain.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are in favour of the principle of international cooperation and the aid of countries experiencing economic difficulties for various reasons. However, this cooperation must be genuine and based on respect for the sovereignty of states and their right to be able to dispose of their resources and choose their development model. Supporting Tunisia to improve its public finances, reforming its financial system, improving its trade and investment regulatory framework, or correcting its budgetary position clearly comes out of this genuine cooperation that we advocate. It is more similar to the imposition of reforms aimed at imposing a model based on the complete liberalisation of the economy. These are reforms that the EU imposes on its Member States and the results of which are in sight. We therefore reject this aid because it is not exempt from conditionality. It imposes on the Tunisian people a model which, as here in Europe, will generate more inequality and poverty in the medium term.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, I am in favour of supporting the North African countries so that the migration problem can be better tackled on the ground. For this very reason, however, it is incomprehensible that the granting of financial aid is not linked to the strengthening of Tunisia's efforts to stem the current wave of migration. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the provision of macro-financial assistance to Tonisia. Tunisia has managed to strengthen its progress towards a democratic transition, but is currently going through a very difficult period. Tunisia has repeatedly been the target of terrorist attacks and attacks that have profoundly affected key economic sectors of the country, such as tourism. Despite these challenges, Tunisia continues to make very important progress, stabilising the national democratic transition process. It is very important that Tunisia's efforts are successful and that this country keeps all forces in control that seek to destabilise it. I believe that Europe must show solidarity and act decisively to assist and support Tunisia in its development process, through concrete actions that directly benefit the people of this country.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is gradually becoming a democratic state, despite its difficulties. An important signal that the country is on track was the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize, which stressed the importance of national dialogue as a way of resolving political conflicts. But the assassinations of radical militants have weakened Tunisia's economy, which relies heavily on tourism. The border with Libya poses a significant security risk. The fears of foreign tourists have translated into economic stagnation and high unemployment. Nevertheless, Tunisia continues to make important reforms and is one of the EU's strategic partners in North Africa. I therefore supported the proposal to provide Tunisia with a second macro-financial assistance programme worth EUR 500 million.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I fully support the Commission's proposal. The European Union must support Tunisia through this new financial aid package to help stabilize the country and achieve growth. In a very unstable geographical context, Tunisia faces numerous economic, political and security challenges. Yet we must recognize the progress it is making and the consolidation of its democratic transition and the modernization of its economic structures. The European Union must stand in solidarity by supporting the Tunisian transition process through this EUR 500 million macro-financial aid package.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Building a stable neighbourhood for the European Union requires a concrete financial effort. Tunisia is one of the key elements of Europe's immediate international environment. Recent years have been a period of political and military unrest that is not conducive to the construction of a stable democratic State of Tunisia after many years of military dictatorship. The terrorist threat has effectively hampered the development of the most important sector of the Tunisian economy, tourism. The rise in unemployment and the growing threat of a permanent political crisis could undermine the efforts of supporters of democracy and the civil rule of law in Tunisia for many years to come. I therefore support the provision of macroeconomic support to Tunisia, and I believe that it will help this country to maintain its pro-Western course. We need allies and credible partners in the Arab world. Without such cooperation, it is impossible to stem the tide of illegal immigration to Europe and to fight Islamic terrorism. Tunisia must have the means and tools to participate actively and in the long term in this process. Of course, I agree that such aid cannot be unconditional and that the control of the loan guarantees granted to Tunisia must be reliable and meticulous. I also hope that the Commission will be able to report regularly on the effects of this support, and that further decisions in this regard will be taken on the basis of the real effects of this aid. I also believe that similar tools will be used in the future to support our partners in Eastern Europe.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council to provide further macro-financial assistance to Tunisia, as I support the establishment of assistance of a maximum of EUR 500 million to support Tunisia's economic stabilisation and structural reform programme.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, a report by Oxfam Intermón reflects that the largest Spanish companies are leading caps on tax evasion. The Ibex 35 tripled its presence in tax havens during the crisis. Banco de Santander is the main beneficiary of this tax avoidance. Former President José María Aznar was sanctioned with more than 70,000 euros for using an instrumental company to pay half of what he owed the Treasury. Castellana's papers are revealing decades of tax evasion in the Spanish state. In the meantime, people lose our social and labour rights and public services as a result, among others, of bailout to banking and budget adjustment. The European Union must put an end to this by acting forcefully, adopting strong rules against tax avoidance and evasion, and eliminating any legal hard work that allows it. This report is not strong enough in this, which is why I abstained.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr It must be said that tax avoidance constitutes one of the primary damages, I would say, in the development of an efficient economy and other spheres. For example, aggressive tax planning by international companies generates annual losses of between 100 and 240 billion in public budgets, but they are in US dollars. And that amounts to between four and ten percent of the amount of income tax collected worldwide. It is clear that, as with the same VAT, value added tax, where there is a uniform minimum, the other tax rates at national level will remain... (The President interrupted the speaker.) I said that there is a minimum in the case of VAT, there are no minimums with other taxes, and therefore it remains the competence of the Member States. Since this is not at Union level, a more coordinated policy and set of efforts is absolutely necessary to develop a common strategy for other taxes, so that tax evasion cannot be avoided. Consequently, I support this directive.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tax avoidance is a sensitive and complex issue. Parliament is called upon to state its opinion on the rules for regulating circumvention which directly affects the internal market. In the ECON Commission, our Members have pushed for precise and binding provisions, better patent legislation and a strengthening of Parliament's role. The final document shows the level of deductions too high and the rate too low. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote on this report because, despite being an important step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance by large multinationals, it does not adequately address the mechanisms of large multinationals such as patent boxes. This report represents an undeniable step forward in the development of legislation to combat tax evasion and avoidance, from clarifications and effective definitions, to specific measures, the report improves the existing legal framework. However, certain well-known mechanisms are left out and very high limits are set which will prevent these measures from having the actual effect it pursues. We need a more aggressive fiscal policy to combat the practices of multinationals and put an end to the growth of inequality in Europe. It is to be considered that the report will not achieve its objectives and that I have not been able to vote in favour of it.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported much of the content of this resolution which aims to tackle tax avoidance by corporations operating in the European single market. However, I voted against this overall proposal despite many positive aspects as Sinn Féin is determined to ensure that tax sovereignty remains in the hands of Member States. Changes to tax law aimed at ending loopholes for tax avoidance should be made by national parliaments working as part of an effective international framework -– which is currently being led by the OECD. Many aspects of the report aimed to implement the OECD Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) plan, which I supported. I supported amendments criticising the role of so-called knowledge boxes as tax avoidance mechanisms. Certain aspects of the Commission proposal and Parliament resolution go beyond the OECD BEPS recommendations, including on exit taxation and switchover clauses, which I could not support. While these may be effective mechanisms for combating tax avoidance, our approach is that we want to implement the OECD BEPS recommendations in Member States and EU law where appropriate now – but that we want to continue seeing countries engaging in an international framework as the primary vehicle for combating global tax avoidance.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. Tax must be paid where profits are made! This is what the report by my Socialist colleague Hugues Bayet, which also proposes new rules to combat tax evasion, is advocating. The report also gives the green light to the establishment of a commission of inquiry into the Panama Papers. There is a legitimate exasperation among our fellow citizens, who realize that one of the great principles of our democracies - equality before tax - is being flouted and undermined by a number of practices such as tax optimization, which allow many multinationals to pay ridiculously low taxes and, moreover, in countries where they have no real economic activity. We must put an end to it once and for all!

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on rules against certain tax avoidance practices which refers to the fight against fraud and tax evasion which are top political priorities, in the context of social justice and transparency.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. According to an OECD study, the aggressive tax optimization of multinationals reduces the household revenues of countries worldwide by between USD 100 and 240 billion annually, about 4-10% of global revenues from tax-paying companies. Addressing this is a need for a fair and effective corporate tax rate in the EU. Parliament's proposal provides for the principle that companies pay their taxes where they make their profits. Above all, however, it also seeks a uniform approach, which I also support. A common corporate tax base could also be envisaged, which would allow companies to cooperate with a one-stop shop in the preparation of the tax return and the consolidation of the profit and loss account for all sites in the Union.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission is proposing a series of measures within a directive to combat tax evasion by corporate groups. After those on the automatic exchange of rescripts, this directive is central because it tackles the most common and costly mechanisms for public finances, at the heart of avoidance schemes. The text proposes six regulatory points: a cap on interest deductibility, taxation on the exit of latent capital gains, the introduction of switch over clauses, a general anti-abuse clause, rules for moving profits from parent companies to foreign companies under control and less tax, hybrid schemes generating non-taxation. It should also be noted that the text formulates a legal definition of tax havens, stable establishment, patent boxes and other key concepts in the fight against aggressive optimization. The Bayet report amends some of the sensitive points of the Commission's proposal: for example, it doubles the thresholds for deducting excess interest and introduces exemptions for financial companies or public investors. As one of the eu's least tax-friendly countries in the EU, we have more to gain from restrictive legislation than the other way around. So I voted for it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this legislative resolution as the proposals forget that minimising tax liabilities is not just a right but a duty for company directors. General rules against minimising tax are open to subjective interpretation and consequently add to business uncertainty. This would reduce foreign investment into UK companies.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to combat tax evasion in Europe. However, I would like to make it clear that tax evasion can be hidden in tax optimisation practices which are the result of shameful practices by Member States that are fighting with tax loopholes and tax rulings.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive aims to transpose into EU law measures restricting base erosion and profit shifting. Its main principle is that taxes must be paid in the country where the profits are made. The directive also proposes to define clearly terms such as 'permanent establishment', 'tax havens' and 'minimum economic activity', as they have so far been interpreted in quite different ways, which hinders the effective fight against tax avoidance. One of the EP's recommendations is to curb internal lending within a group of companies, which is one of the most commonly used ways to show low profits and thus avoid tax. The aim is also to limit the amount of interest payable that would be deductible, as this would help to increase the share of the tax payable.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is about limiting aggressive tax optimization. According to the December 2014 European Council resolution, 'efforts to combat tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning at both global and EU level need to be urgently promoted'. As of December 2014, the Commission has already taken the first steps towards an EU approach and in the meantime the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has completed its work on defining global rules and standards for this purpose, which is being used in this proposal. According to an OECD study, aggressive tax optimisation by multinationals causes annual budget short losses of between $100 billion and $240 billion globally, which is why it is necessary to act in a coordinated way. My vote in favour also contributed to the fact that these rules do not yet overly limit the sovereignty of the Member States over their own tax systems.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. In January 2016, the Commission presented a series of measures to combat tax evasion. This directive tackles the most common mechanisms - and costly for public finances - by proposing several regulatory points, such as an anti-abuse clause and formulating a legal definition of the various key concepts in the fight against tax optimisation.  This report has changed some sensitive points in relation to the Commission's draft, for example by introducing various exemptions for financial companies.  However, the European Parliament is not here co-legislator: as with all tax matters, the Council will retain the final say.  I voted in favour of this report in order to support these advances which are in the interest of European public finances in general and French in particular, france being one of the least fiscally welcoming countries in the EU.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has approved my report on new rules to combat tax evasion practices. This vote takes five steps: - the payment of taxes must take place where companies make their profits, through the precise and mandatory definition of the conditions that attest that a multinational is well established in a country; The cap on interest deductions at 20% and up to EUR 2 million, an ambitious and more balanced position than the European Commission's proposal, which prevents multinationals from artificially inflating their debt; The "switch-over" clause; which allows the regulation of controlled foreign companies; Parliament's vote requires that profits entering Europe be taxed at the legal rate of the country of arrival, if, outside the EU, they have not previously been taxed at a minimum of 15%; An ambitious 'exit tax' on profits to reduce double-taxation; Limiting the use of patent filings, through clarification of the definition of investments in research and development. These advances, which are part of the momentum for restoring equality before tax, are to be welcomed.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in support of the Bayet report on the proposal for a directive against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market. Harmful tax competition, which often makes use of the lack of harmonisation in regulation, is, along with aggressive tax planning by multinationals, one of the most important causes of the loss of state resources, estimated at between $100 billion and $240 billion a year worldwide. The need to create a genuine European single market cannot but pass through an agreement on the issue of taxation, which is based on fair and efficient taxation of companies. Multinationals must be prevented from transferring profits to tax havens without paying taxes where they are made. The text adopted improves the Commission's proposal, strengthening the patent proposal and generally enhancing the role of the European Parliament identified as the body responsible for monitoring and evaluating the application of the directive in question in the 28 Member States.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report. While the rapporteur tried to form a progressive majority in Parliament with tough measures to combat tax avoidance, the division of the ALDE group forced him to seek agreements with the EPP, which has substantively reduced the content of the text. For my part, I have tabled amendments aimed at increasing the ability of States to control transactions with countries that are not sufficiently transparent, however these amendments were rejected.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 The aggressive planning practices of large multinationals — as some large companies euphemistically call the work of some large companies to practice tax avoidance — deserve, require and require a European response. States cannot compete with each other with their tax systems to save themselves individually at the cost of undermining all collection and the values and principles of fair taxation. This problem needed and deserved a European response and we are giving it. And that response should involve all tax systems, including those in regions that are considered autonomous tax systems.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This directive is crucial and proposes in particular six regulatory points: the cap on interest deductibility, the exit tax, the introduction of switch over clauses (imposition with a tax credit for foreign flows already taxed but at a significantly lower rate), an anti-abuse clause, rules for moving profits from parent companies to foreign companies under control and less taxed , and the case of non-tax-generating hybrid devices. This Bayet report changed some sensitive points in relation to the Commission's draft on the thresholds for deducting excess interest or the length of time for the carry-over of excess EBITDA (too favourable to multinationals). I would like to remind you that France is one of the least fiscally welcoming countries in the EU and that this legislation is in line with our national public finances but also in the sense that we have more to gain from the legislation presented than with a status quo. So I voted in favour.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I share some of the support, there are passages in this text that I consider contradictory and unclear and for this reason I preferred to abstain.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has given Parliament its position on the Council directive laying down rules against tax avoidance practices directly affecting the functioning of the internal market. According to one OECD study, the aggressive tax optimisation by multinationals deprives all countries of the world of budgets of between EUR 100 billion and EUR 240 billion a year. Dollars. This amount represents between 4% and 10% of the world's corporate tax revenue. Such loss of income is particularly damaging to states by reducing their ability to invest in promoting employment, combating poverty and developing effective global healthcare systems. The economic and monetary union requires a harmonising eu tax system. A fair and effective corporate taxation system must be the cornerstone of the single market. In order to create a sound single market, Member States must agree on taxation. A sustainable approach to the implementation of tax systems is essential to ensure the proper functioning of the Single Market and to successfully establish a Capital Markets Union. Parliament welcomes the Commission's proposal and sees it as a step forward in order to limit tax avoidance by multinationals. However, he believes that the adoption of the proposed amendments would make the proposal clearer and more effective. The main purpose of these proposals is to pay taxes on companies where they make a profit.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Aggressive tax planning and related practices have a high cost on state budgets, resulting in significant income losses that could otherwise have been used to promote employment, more resilient social systems and targeted investment. Greater tax harmonisation at European level and, in particular, in dealing with phenomena and problems of this kind, is therefore desirable, and that is why I supported the text voted on today in plenary. The implementation of a truly functioning single market and the creation of a genuine economic and monetary union requires fair and efficient taxation, and the report adopted today aims to establish common anti-tax avoidance rules in certain specific areas, as well as more general anti-abuse rules. It was important to emphasise that taxes should be paid where they generate profits, and it is good that we have introduced precise and binding definitions, such as 'permanent establishment' or 'tax haven', which make it possible to check more clearly where a multinational is actually established, so as to oblige companies to pay their taxes fairly.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I am in favour of the regulatory points presented by the Commission in January 2016 against tax evasion: - the cap on interest deductibility, - the exit tax), - the introduction of switch-over clauses (taxation with a tax credit for foreign flows already taxed but at a significantly lower rate), - the general anti-abuse clause , - rules for moving profits from parent companies to foreign companies under control and less taxed, - hybrid schemes generating non-taxation. While the Bayet report has changed some sensitive points in relation to the Commission's project, I remain in favour of the appropriateness of this regulation. So I voted for this report.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I supported much of the content of this resolution which aims to tackle tax avoidance by corporations operating in the European single market. However, I voted against this overall proposal despite many positive aspects as Sinn Féin is determined to ensure that tax sovereignty remains in the hands of Member States. Changes to tax law aimed at ending loopholes for tax avoidance should be made by national parliaments working as part of an effective international framework -– which is currently being led by the OECD. Many aspects of the report aimed to implement the OECD Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) plan, which I supported. I supported amendments criticising the role of so-called knowledge boxes as tax avoidance mechanisms. Certain aspects of the Commission proposal and Parliament resolution go beyond the OECD BEPS recommendations, including on exit taxation and switchover clauses, which I could not support. While these may be effective mechanisms for combating tax avoidance, our approach is that we want to implement the OECD BEPS recommendations in Member States and EU law where appropriate now – but that we want to continue seeing countries engaging in an international framework as the primary vehicle for combating global tax avoidance.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tax evasion by multinational companies is a serious act which, in addition to being immoral, is a real problem for European citizens who see an estimated tax gap in the state coffers of between 100 and 240 billion dollars every year worldwide. This represents between 4 and 10% of the world's corporate tax revenues and, above all, a huge loss of income for states, which proportionately reduces their ability to invest to promote employment, combat poverty and develop effective universal health systems. This gap is often made up of public debt, service cuts or increased taxes on resident citizens.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. To combat tax evasion practices that cause states around the world to lose more than 240 billion euros each year, this report proposes to find a common solution so that companies pay their taxes where they actually make a profit. In this context, it is proposed to create a consolidated common corporate tax base in order to curb tax dumping within the Union. In addition, the rapporteur points to a cap on the deductibility of interest on income so that companies can no longer undervalue their profits in order to pay less tax. To the extent that bilateral agreements are insufficient to curb tax evasion in Europe, I believe that it is essential to find a common solution while preserving our national sovereignty. That is why I voted for this text. Nevertheless, tax evasion should not be used as a pretext for the Commission to develop budgetary federalism behind the backs of our peoples.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Combating cross-border tax avoidance practices must be a priority for European authorities, taking into account situations where taxpayers act without respecting the real purpose of the legislation, taking advantage of differences between national tax systems to reduce their tax contributions. This distorts business decisions within the internal market and, if not dealt with effectively, could create an environment of unfair tax competition. What happened to the scandal in Panama confirms, once again, the need for legally binding rules to enable Member States to effectively combat business avoidance of obligations so as to maintain their collective competitiveness and respect the single market, the freedoms provided for in the Treaty, the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and EU law in general. I have expressed myself in favour of this report, because this initiative brings added value compared to what could be achieved by a multitude of national methods.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this consultation report on the proposal for a Council Directive and which is part of the Commission's anti-avoidance package. Fundamentally, it is a question of transferring the shares recommended by the OECD, to avoid the artificial transfer of profits to jurisdictions other than where profits have been generated, characterized by low corporate taxation. The two major developments in this proposal are the establishment of an exit tax on profits in certain cases, and the imposition of limits on the deductibility of interest on financial expenses. The rapporteur Hugues Bayet, a colleague of the Socialist Group, succeeded in improving the initial proposal, in general with regard to the limitation on the deductibility of interests, and the definition of permanent establishment. Several amendments tabled by the Spanish Socialist Delegation during the commission were also included. It is to be expected that the Council will take into account the position of the European Parliament in the context of this consultation procedure.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The Rules directive to combat tax evasion is part of the European Commission's tax transparency package. Parliament is only consulted on this directive. It is time for multinational companies to pay their taxes where they operate. There is no question that SMEs are suffering from the misbehaviour of certain multinationals. This directive proposes to harmonize at European level the criteria for determining cases of tax evasion. Harmonising definitions is a first step towards a convergence of the tax policies of the Member States that I have always supported. It is now up to the Member States to decide unanimously on this issue. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful examination of the documentation and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive because I believe that harmful tax competition, which exploits the delay in information and the lack of harmonisation in regulation, together with the aggressive tax planning of multinationals, cause huge losses of income for states, reducing their ability to invest and driving away the implementation of employment reforms , poverty and universal health. I therefore agree with the report which deals with the sensitive issues of introducing definitions of 'permanent organisation', 'double deduction' and 'minimum economic substance', because courageously and once and for all, the elements enabling a company to be defined on the basis of factual criteria, considering human and material resources, management autonomy, legal reality and the nature of the assets, must be established in a harmonised and coherent manner. On the other hand, the sensitive issue of the digital economy is also addressed, including entirely dematerialised companies that escape a factual definition but which also have a permanent establishment in a Member State.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported much of the content of this resolution which aims to tackle tax avoidance by corporations operating in the European single market. However, I voted against this overall proposal despite many positive aspects as Sinn Féin is determined to ensure that tax sovereignty remains in the hands of Member States. Changes to tax law aimed at ending loopholes for tax avoidance should be made by national parliaments working as part of an effective international framework -– which is currently being led by the OECD. Many aspects of the report aimed to implement the OECD Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) plan, which I supported. I supported amendments criticising the role of so-called knowledge boxes as tax avoidance mechanisms. Certain aspects of the Commission proposal and Parliament resolution go beyond the OECD BEPS recommendations, including on exit taxation and switchover clauses, which I could not support. While these may be effective mechanisms for combating tax avoidance, our approach is that we want to implement the OECD BEPS recommendations in Member States and EU law where appropriate now – but that we want to continue seeing countries engaging in an international framework as the primary vehicle for combating global tax avoidance.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I oppose uniform tax regimes across the EU. I would like to call for attention to various economy features in different Member States when drawing up tax resolutions at EU level. A common set of rules cannot fit for all markets and smaller economies are more vulnerable in this situation which I consider to be unfair. In line with the fight against aggressive tax planning, I suggest tailored tax rulings that empower the Member States to set up national amendments flexibly. I do, however, support sharing information about national tax rulings to ensure tax transparency among the Member States.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This procedure concerns consultation of the European Parliament following the publication of the directive proposed by the European Commission against tax avoidance practices and which sees multinationals as the main target group. I voted against the report presented by the ECON Committee because I do not agree with the way in which the issue of deductions and tax rates is dealt with: the former too high and the latter too low.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Several studies by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) have shown that aggressive tax plans, implemented by some multinational groups, cost Member States hundreds of billions of euros each year in terms of lost tax revenue. It is a phenomenon that reduces the resources available to Member States to promote employment or improve health systems; This situation, which is no longer acceptable, creates unfair tax competition with regard to small and medium-sized enterprises operating mainly in a single Member State. The directive is part of the package of anti-tax evasion rules announced in January by European Commissioner Moscovici and contains the principle that tax must be paid where profits and value are generated, providing for timely anti-circumvention rules in six specific areas: interest deductibility, outbound taxation, switch-over clause, general anti-abuse rule , rules on foreign subsidiaries (CFCs) and a framework for combating hybrid misalignments, are now an integral part of the legislative text and it is the factors that led me to vote in favour of the document. Today we have marked an important step in the fight against evasion by multinationals and in the protection of citizens.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I come from a small country, Cyprus, which is a financial centre. Its comparative advantage is that it has low corporate tax rates; we are at 12%. This is something that healthy competition requires. As in the various consumption taxes there are different taxes, different VAT, I believe it is fair and healthy competition to make a difference in terms of tax rates. Another is the different tax rate and another is tax avoidance and tax evasion, on which we are clearly in favour of their fight. It is one thing for the countries of the European Union and another for tax havens, which we must fight. We must be careful not to hit the European Union itself, bearing in mind what is happening in tax havens and has nothing to do with what is happening in the European Union. I am therefore voting against the report.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the establishment of rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market concerns one of the most crucial issues of our time. The need to impose rules against tax avoidance is obvious, but also capable of making significant economic and social gains. However, this report does not ensure uniform rules for all stakeholders. That is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am convinced that there is a need for a coordinated and decisive approach to the implementation of tax systems. I agree with this proposal, which aims to ensure that companies pay taxes where they make the profits. In order to do this, it will certainly be necessary to introduce precise and binding definitions of the conditions that will judge whether a multinational is actually established in a given country. In my opinion, this is necessary to ensure that multinationals do not transfer their profits to tax havens without paying the necessary taxes. This phenomenon represents a huge loss of money for those States that will have less resources to provide adequate services to all citizens, including evaders. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This was supposed to be a report advocating sound rules to curb tax avoidance practices. Instead, it went above and beyond this goal and was used as a way of delving into Member States tax sovereignty by the back door. It is clear in the EU Treaties that corporate tax rates are decided by Member States alone and that should not be changed.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because we must follow a strict course in the fight against tax avoidance practices. We need a Union-wide definition of tax havens and a 'blacklist', and we need to establish sanctions for non-cooperating territories and financial institutions operating in tax havens. The rule of taxation at the place of profit-making and value creation applies equally to all, and we must abolish common methods that companies like to use to avoid tax.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to build a real economic and monetary union, it is essential to harmonise European taxation, with the imposition of fair and efficient taxation. We therefore need a coordinated and harmonised approach to the implementation of tax systems. However, I believe that the proposal contained in the report can harm many companies with serious investment intentions, as it provides for only a minimum deductibility of interest, which represents the costs of investment projects.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote on this report because, despite being an important step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance by large multinationals, it does not adequately address the mechanisms of large multinationals such as patent boxes. This report represents an undeniable step forward in the development of legislation to combat tax evasion and avoidance, from clarifications and effective definitions, to specific measures, the report improves the existing legal framework. However, certain well-known mechanisms are left out and very high limits are set which will prevent these measures from having the actual effect it pursues. We need a more aggressive fiscal policy to combat the practices of multinationals and put an end to the growth of inequality in Europe. It is to be considered that the report will not achieve its objectives and that I have not been able to vote in favour of it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 European states suffer a loss in unpaid taxes of billions of euros each year due to aggressive tax planning. The fight against tax fraud, evasion and avoidance is therefore a top political priority, as harmful practices such as aggressive tax planning are unacceptable from the point of view of the integrity of the internal market and social justice. The European Parliament resolution, which I voted for, puts at the heart of the principle that taxes must be paid where profits are generated. It is time for all the large multinationals to contribute, as european citizens do, to the well-being of society and to collective services.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Aggressive tax optimization of multinationals brings a loss of between $100 billion and $240 billion each year to state budgets around the world. This represents between 4 and 10% of the world's income from corporation tax. This significant loss reduces the ability of states to develop employment projects, combat poverty and develop high-performance health systems for all. The main objective of this report is to ensure that companies pay their taxes where they make their profits. I voted for a coordinated and harmonised approach to the implementation of tax systems.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The rapporteur makes it clear that harmonisation of European tax systems is the only way to achieve a well-functioning single market. In this spirit, it recommends that the Commission present a proposal for a common corporate tax base as soon as possible and that the Council adopt it without delay. In addition, the report proposed a number of stricter rules on work to combat base erosion, which in practice could affect the European Union's global competitiveness and prove detrimental to companies that invest and pay taxes fairly. This is the case, for example, in the case of a provision which lowers the threshold for deducting interest at a time when tax avoidance in multinational companies is most often of an intra-group nature.
