The report also comes up with the idea that it is the European Parliament that appropriately monitors the implementation of this Directive on tax avoidance rules and that the Member States are accountable to it, which sovereign governments cannot accept under any circumstances because of the treaty allocation of powers.  I believe that the proposals contained in the report very strongly interfere not only with the competences of the Member States, but also with the common rules drawn up by the OECD. In view of the above, I voted against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ When dealing with taxation I am always in favour of having proper tax transparency rules and boosting our fight against tax abuse and tax avoidance. However this should not automatically mean that there should be tax harmonisation or tax convergence, including also the mandatory introduction of a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB). Not all EU Member States have the same economic realities, and small economies face different economic realities, different market sizes and resources which differ greatly from the larger economies. That is why I continue to believe that small economies require flexibility to help them counteract the disadvantages which they would otherwise face. Reducing the tax flexibility of such economies would further increase their disparities, which is unfair, dysfunctional and unacceptable. Tax matters should remain an issue of national competence which can help reflect these different realities. If this does not happen, small economies like Malta will end up carrying the greatest burden. For these reasons I could not support this report.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. In order to ensure the proper functioning of the single market and the success of the Capital Markets Union, harmonised and harmonised implementation of tax systems is key. I voted in favour of this report. I believe that the proposals it includes make clear and standard the laws on patents. To date, multinationals are exploiting the tax incentives associated with filing patents to artificially reduce the amount of their profits. In my opinion, this has a detrimental effect on truly innovative countries. I am pleased that the rapporteur has also strengthened Parliament's role. I, too, believe that the European Parliament should be entrusted with monitoring the effective implementation of the directive in the 28 Member States.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – A harmonised and harmonised implementation of tax systems is key to ensuring the proper functioning of the single market and the success of the Capital Markets Union. I voted in favour of this report. I believe that the proposals it includes make clear and standard the laws on patents. To date, multinationals are exploiting the tax incentives associated with filing patents to artificially reduce the amount of their profits. In my opinion, this has a detrimental effect on truly innovative countries. I am pleased that the rapporteur has also strengthened Parliament's role. I, too, believe that the European Parliament should be entrusted with monitoring the effective implementation of the directive in the 28 Member States.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. In January 2016, the Commission presented a directive to combat corporate tax avoidance. After those on automatic rescript exchange or country reporting, this directive (called ATAD) tackles the most common and costly mechanisms for public finances, at the heart of avoidance schemes. It proposes a cap on interest deductibility, the exit tax, the introduction of switch over clauses (imposition with a tax credit for foreign flows already taxed but at a significantly lower rate), a general anti-abuse clause, rules for moving profits from parent companies to foreign companies under control and less imposed , and hybrid non-tax-generating devices. These advances are in the interest of national public finances, so I voted for this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the proposal for a Council directive laying down rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market, as following the changes made by Parliament, a proposal would be detrimental to business and trade.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The existence of common rules in all Member States of the Union to deal with corporate tax evasion, with the exception of financial institutions and insurance undertakings, does not do justice. It is biased in favour of states with a strong economy and promotes the enhanced implementation of the single market by imposing policies that, instead of helping economically weak countries, lead them to full control over their respective strong ones.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market. The EU needs to do all it can to fight tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning. My constituents in Wales want to see a better system in which everyone pays their fair share, and multinational corporations and multimillionaires contribute like everybody else.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. "Tax avoidance is of course totally unacceptable. In order to reduce advanced tax planning and combat tax avoidance, we need to have globally coherent rules that close the loopholes created by too fragmented systems. The issue of legislation and regulations is bigger than a single country, a single region, or a single continent. Common international guidelines are a prerequisite for addressing the problems. The common framework developed by the OECD through the BEPS is a key to the work on tax rules that combat tax base erosion and tax evasion. In the process, it is important to ensure that harmonised rules allow for circumstances specific to national taxation systems. It is crucial that individual countries or the EU do not diverge through directives from the common guidelines that are already drawn up. Then we run the risk of once again standing with a patchwork of regulations which in turn open up new forms of tax planning. It is important to ensure equal treatment of companies regardless of size. If we are to succeed in this work, we must succeed globally. Then we cannot add even more rules at European level, as this report does.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal put forward lays down rules against corporate tax avoidance in six specific areas, including the deductibility of interest and a clause on the taxation of income generated abroad. This legislation targets situations where groups of companies take advantage of disparities between national tax systems to reduce their tax obligations. The goal is for companies to pay their taxes where they make their profits. These rules aim to identify all taxpayers subject to corporation tax in a Member State, combat cross-border tax avoidance practices and provide a common framework for the coordinated implementation of OECD measures against base erosion and profit transfer in eu Member States' national legislation.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: it seems sensible to continue our line and support these advances that will be in the interest of national public finances.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a key directive in the European Commission's action plan announced a year ago. It is intended that there should be some degree of harmonisation in the interpretation of the BEPS plan guidelines adopted by the OECD. The principle is commendable and we follow the general spirit of the measures, some of which correspond to our proposals made in the Assembly of the Republic. However, there are aspects that misstate the proposals and prevent our vote in favour. The proposal exempts financial companies from limiting interest deductions. In addition, there is a derogation that we do not follow. The OECD advocates a limit on the deduction of interest between 10 and 30%. The European Commission, in its proposal, not surprisingly opts for the upper limit. Why? For whose benefit? The criterion for taxation in the country of origin is that the third country tax rate is less than 40% of the country of origin. It will therefore not apply to most European cases, such as Ireland, the Netherlands or even, in some sectors, Switzerland or Luxembourg. This legislation will conflict with other legislation that is being made on consolidated tax able matters. In other words, we are talking about one-off, isolated, fragmented, and unarticulated initiatives. Finally, nothing is said about tax havens.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained as all our amendments did not pass.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ aggressive tax planning by multinationals causes losses of up to $240 billion a year to state budgets. The main objective of the proposed measure to introduce rules against tax avoidance practices is for businesses to pay taxes where they generate profits. Harmonisation of taxation in Europe is one of the ways in which tax collection could be made more effective in this context. Such corporate taxation will later form the basis of the single market and its proper functioning, and will also prevent tax evasion by multinationals.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstain, the text had to be much stronger.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report, as the existence of common rules in all the Member States of the Union to tackle corporate tax evasion, with the exception of financial institutions and insurance undertakings, does not do justice. It is biased in favour of states with a strong economy and promotes the enhanced implementation of the single market by imposing policies that, instead of helping economically weak countries, lead them to full control over their respective strong ones.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The fight against tax evasion by multinationals is fundamental in regaining the confidence of European citizens. Moreover, I agree with the more comprehensive position on profits that should be taxed where they are created. Firstly, I support a stricter interest limitation rule. I am in favour of the new common definition on permanent establishment that should be applied by Member States, both in relevant legislation and bilateral tax treaties, in order to ensure consistency and to make sure profits are taxed where the economic activity takes place. I also believe that we should develop a common method of calculation of the effective tax rate in each Member State, to make it possible to draw up a comparative table of the effective tax rates across the Member States. Until now, multinationals have used patent incentives to artificially reduce their profits. This has an adverse impact on genuinely innovative countries. These multinationals should be subject to an exit tax where they repatriate proceeds from patents to countries with lower tax rates. Consequently, I agree that the Commission should bring forward a proposal on a withholding tax to make sure profits are taxed before leaving the Union.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. In order to ensure the proper functioning of the single market and the success of the Capital Markets Union, harmonised and harmonised implementation of tax systems is key. I voted in favour of this report. I believe that the proposals it includes make clear and standard the laws on patents. To date, multinationals are exploiting the tax incentives associated with filing patents to artificially reduce the amount of their profits. In my opinion, this has a detrimental effect on truly innovative countries. I am pleased that the rapporteur has also strengthened Parliament's role. I, too, believe that the European Parliament should be entrusted with monitoring the effective implementation of the directive in the 28 Member States.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Bayet report on rules to counter aggressive tax planning practices. I welcome the establishment of an appropriate set of rules providing for the prevention of similar tax planning practices. It is astonishing that, according to a recent OECD study, aggressive tax optimisation by multinationals causes an annual budget deficit of between $100 million and $240 million globally. This amounts to between 4% and 10% of the taxes paid by companies worldwide.  In particular, this represents a sensitive loss of revenue for states where, as a result, resources for investment aimed at stimulating job creation, eradicating poverty and developing effective health care systems are consensible. We must stop the practice of multinationals exploiting the tax incentives associated with filing patents to artificially reduce the amount of their profits.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the conviction that tax evasion practices should be avoided, as these directly affect society as a whole. Aggressive tax planning for multinationals is estimated to cost public coffers between $100 million and $240 billion a year worldwide. This amount represents between 4 and 10% of the world's corporate tax collection. That is why the European Union must evolve from an economic and monetary union to a harmonisation of European taxation. A fair taxation that becomes the cornerstone of the single market.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the Council directive on rules against certain tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market because I believe that the adoption of the directive is urgent as it will contribute effectively to combating tax evasion. Parliament has made this battle a key objective, well aware that taxation falls within the sovereignty of the Member States, but convinced that the current situation, in which there are companies that can avoid paying their fair share of tax, is no longer sustainable, and the recent Panama Papers scandal means that we must move forward and in depth. I shared the European Parliament's clear message to put an end to double taxation, to the mechanism that allows multinationals not to pay taxes where they make their profits, or not to pay them at all, and to control intra-group multinational loans. According to studies by the OECD and the Commission, average taxation in Europe is 19%, which is in line with those of other industrialised countries. I hope that the EU will be ambitious and that it will be able to make progress in this area. The European Parliament will be a staunch ally, because fair taxation can help sustain sustainable growth.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. Tax transparency, fair rules and tax justice for families and small and medium-sized enterprises are a central concern for me. Large corporations must also make their tax contribution – without tricks and double ground! I therefore support the report's approach to the proposal for a Council directive setting out rules to combat tax avoidance practices with a direct impact on the functioning of the internal market.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Parliament supported the new rules proposed by the European Commission to tackle certain tax avoidance practices. OECD research shows that aggressive tax planning for multinational companies is an annual loss to national budgets of between $100 billion and $240 billion, or 4 to 10% of global corporate tax revenues. This loss of income reduces countries' ability to invest and, consequently, is not conducive to employment and poverty eradication. The overarching objective of this report is to ensure that companies pay taxes where they generate profits. In addition, Parliament proposes to tax multinational companies on unrealised capital gains when they transfer their profits to low-tax countries. Strict limits on tax credits and greater transparency of trust funds and foundations will also be introduced.  In conclusion, the rules introduced are a good step towards reducing base erosion. A coordinated approach to taxation is of paramount importance to ensure the proper functioning of the single market and eu capital markets.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The fight against tax avoidance practices is necessary to ensure the functioning of the internal market.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive. Sadly, the scandal of aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion is costing the EU billions every year, meaning schools and hospitals going unbuilt and the tax burden falling on those who can least afford it. The Commission’s original proposals for the Directive were a step in the right direction, but Parliament’s report today pushes them to be even more ambitious. The hope is that national finance ministers will listen to the views of Parliament and agree the most ambitious Directive possible at their meeting on 19 June. Furthermore, it shows that we are far more effective at dealing with the scourge of aggressive tax avoidance as part of the EU and not in isolation.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that the EU's objective of building an economic and monetary union must be a priority, achievable through the harmonisation of European taxation. Corporate taxation, particularly multinational companies, must be fair and effective and must become the cornerstone of the single market. If we want to have a reliable single market, the Member States must necessarily reach an agreement on taxation. A coordinated and harmonised approach to the implementation of tax systems is vital to ensure the smooth functioning of the single market and the success of the capital markets union. The main objective of this report is to ensure that multinational companies pay taxes where they make profits. An OECD study has estimated that tax optimization by multinationals causes losses to public budgets around the world of between $100 billion and $240 billion annually. This represents a significant loss of revenue for states, thus reducing their ability to invest in actions that can promote employment, combat poverty and the development of effective health systems for all.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. Many scandals have revealed the extent of tax evasion or aggressive tax planning practices by multinationals. For them, there is only one watchword: not to participate financially - or as little as possible - in the construction or maintenance of public goods that they benefit from in our countries, be it transport infrastructure, political stability, the education system, etc. So I can only agree with rules that allow taxes to be properly paid where profits are actually generated, and that address the most common circumvention practices. I don't like that these rules are established at European level. But we have to be pragmatic, and citizens, especially in France where the middle classes and SMEs are tax-sized, expect their elected representatives to do something, even if this something is only a non-binding opinion. However, the majority of this text is not overwhelming. In the Council, it will be even more difficult. Even if they have accepted the principle of such a regulation, the Member States that benefit from the current situation, such as the Netherlands, Ireland, Luxembourg, Malta, the United Kingdom, etc. have a strong interest in weakening it. We'll see what happens, and who's going to take care of it.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report. While the rapporteur tried to form a progressive majority in Parliament with tough measures to combat tax avoidance, the division of the ALDE group forced him to seek agreements with the EPP, which has substantively reduced the content of the text. For my part, I have tabled amendments aimed at increasing the ability of States to control transactions with countries that are not sufficiently transparent, however these amendments were rejected.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I believe in strengthening an economic and monetary union through a harmonisation of European taxation. At the same time, I believe that the issue of taxation must be addressed in an efficient and harmonised manner between Member States in order to ensure the smooth functioning of the single market and the success of capital markets. This report is an encouraging step to force multinationals to pay their taxes fairly, in relation to profits, but also to limit tax evasion and eliminate tax havens that put pressure on SMEs and encourage unfair competition. This would avoid the damage created by instruments that artificially reduce the volume of multinational profits. Clear and harmonised legislation would promote the transparency of the European economic environment and foster employment, combat poverty and develop high-performance health systems for all.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive because the scandal of aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion is costing the EU billions every year, which puts a huge strain on our economies. The Commission’s original proposals for the Directive were a step in the right direction, but Parliament’s report today pushes them to be even bolder still.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. Tax must be paid where profits are made: it is by being true to this principle that I voted for this report which aims to fill the gaps used by fraudulent companies and includes legally binding measures to block the methods most commonly used by companies to avoid paying taxes.  This text provides for a precise and mandatory definition of the conditions that certify that a multinational is well established in a country. It includes the establishment of a strict and common blacklist of the 28 Member States of tax havens and countries that distort competition through favourable tax conditions, including those located in the EU. It proposes a cap on interest deductions at 20% and up to EUR 2 million, an ambitious and more balanced position than the Commission's proposal, which prevents multinationals from artificially inflating the number of loans they take out. Finally, a limitation on the use of patent filing (which artificially reduces the amount of profits) is provided, through a clarification of the definition of investments in research and development.  This is a real step forward that deserves to be supported.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. Fair and effective corporate taxation must become the cornerstone of the single market. The goal is to fight against fraud from a competitive and productive approach and to protect medium and small businesses from being damaged by these practices. This is the only possible approach if we want to deliver competitiveness and a fairer tax system.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this consultation report on the proposal for a Council Directive and which is part of the Commission's anti-avoidance package. Fundamentally, it is a question of transferring oecd-recommended shares to prevent the artificial transfer of profits to jurisdictions other than where profits have been generated, characterized by low corporate taxation. The two major developments in this proposal are the establishment of an exit tax on profits in certain cases, and the imposition of limits on the deductibility of interest on financial expenses. The rapporteur Hugues Bayet, a colleague of the Socialist Group, succeeded in improving the initial proposal, in general with regard to the limitation on the deductibility of interests, and the definition of permanent establishment. Several amendments tabled by the Spanish Socialist Delegation during the commission were also included. It is to be expected that the Council will take into account the position of the European Parliament in the context of this consultation procedure.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. In order to ensure the proper functioning of the single market and the success of the Capital Markets Union, harmonised and harmonised implementation of tax systems is key. I supported the report because the proposals it contained make clear and standardify patent legislation. To date, multinationals are exploiting the tax incentives associated with filing patents to artificially reduce the amount of their profits. In my opinion, this has a detrimental effect on truly innovative countries. The rapporteur has also strengthened Parliament's role, as the European Parliament should be entrusted with monitoring the effective implementation of the Directive in the 28 Member States.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tax policy must be a sovereign right of each Member State. That's our proclaimed position. Any concentration of these powers in Brussels would give the Cypriot economy a final blow after the disastrous bailout. Under no circumstances are we against rules on tax avoidance or tax evasion. We are against the creation of rules imposed on them by Brussels and the economically strong Member States and which they will apply to their measures. We voted against the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against many of the proposals in the report because I believe we are gold plating OECD proposals at EU level. Ireland is complying with OECD proposals and that should be our focus at European level. Because this report is consultative i.e. we have no legislative role in this some of the proposals have gone way too far. Some of those strong statements that I could not support included what they call a switch-over clause where profits can be taxed in a third country or another EU Member State under certain conditions. This is a dangerous precedent and is in my view is an attempt to change the Treaty through a directive. I abstained on the final vote because there are some positive points here about profit shifting, rules against tax evasion etc. However the rapporteur went too far on a number of proposals and so I could not support the final report. Some of the important roll call votes were 65 on the switch-over clause and 72, and you will note I voted against these.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this directive as it had surpassed its original goals. The areas it infringed on should be left up to the Member States to decide on.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. In order to effectively tackle tax avoidance and fraud, it is necessary to promote cross-border transparency and improve the coordination of national tax measures. The OECD has made important proposals on this subject under the slogan BEPS (reduction of profits and profit shifting). It is right that the Commission is actively pushing ahead with the implementation of these measures. The report voted on today also contains the right starting points. However, I reject the demands to limit the deductibility of interest. The Commission's proposal had already set the value too low. However, the further tightening demanded by Parliament is made out of the anti-BEPS measures. This hinders much-needed private investment in Europe. A motion tabled by my group not to make private investment more difficult did not receive a majority in today's vote. I subsequently abstained from the final vote. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Commission proposal but against the parliamentary resolution. I fully support the EU’s efforts to tackle tax avoidance but am opposed to a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base. Parliament’s efforts to conflate these two issues is deeply misguided. Parliament’s amendments have little chance of getting through Council and it is a shame that this House has proceeded in this manner.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is important to mention that Commissioner Moscovici presented the Anti-Tax Avoidance Package this year, a package which has 4 proposals in order to fight against tax evasion and tax avoidance and ensure greater tax transparency. One of these proposals is the Council Directive laying down the rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market – the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive. The fight against tax evasion by multinationals is fundamental in regaining the confidence of European citizens. Some rules should be applied not only in the EU but also outside it. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council directive setting rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market because I support OECD rules and commission intentions. Stronger cooperation and better coordination between Member States and their tax services on the implementation of tax systems is necessary, and it is essential to ensure that tax is paid where profits are made. Fair and effective taxation, and a uniform European taxation system are the cornerstone of the Economic and Monetary Union and the Single Market, and I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. It should be remembered that France is one of the least tax-friendly countries in the EU and that we have more to gain from stricter legislation in the area of tax optimisation than in a status quo. That is one of the reasons why I voted in favour of the text.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to combat the most common practices of tax evasion. The text is based on the principle that taxes should be paid where the company's profits are made. After the Luxleaks and Panama papers scandals, it is vital that the European Union is at the forefront of the fight against tax evasion, which represents an annual loss of EUR 160 to EUR 190 billion.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposals in this report on the prevention of unfair tax practices are aimed in places at harmonising tax law in the European Union. While tax avoidance is an evil that must be combated through a harmonised approach, measures that so severely restrict tax sovereignty are excessive on such a sensitive issue. It is also important to consider in the international context that measures that go beyond the OECD-BEPS initiative are not appropriate and do more harm than good to Europe as a location for investment. For these reasons, I am abstaining on this report.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Single Market of the European Union is one of the greatest benefits for the European Union and the Schengen area. Each EU member state benefits from the functioning of the single market, but it is important that it is based on fair and uniform principles, including fair competition on the market. In this respect, EU taxation policy and the practices applied by Member States with regard to it are very important. There are 28 different national tax policies in the EUROPEAN Union, with the differences they have, and it is important that EU Member States continue to retain the existing exclusive national competences in matters of tax law and application. However, it is necessary to seek ways and to develop more coordinated EU legislation in order to reduce the possibility for Member States to exploit uncertainties and to ensure that these differences in national legislation do not distort competition and the functioning of the single market, which is why I voted in favour of this proposal in plenary.

name: Jan Keller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the introduction of tax avoidance rules by my vote, as it introduces options for greater control of tax evasion by large corporations, while promoting measures that give these companies sufficient scope to manoeuvre in cases where they do not commit tax evasion. The proposed directive differentiates its measures according to the size of the companies and the amount of their turnover, so as not to ruin the companies of medium and smaller ones. I consider the adopted directive to be a good step towards reducing tax evasion, which deprives the Member States and the European Union as a whole of a considerable amount of funding each year.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive because the scandal of aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion is costing the EU billions every year, meaning schools and hospitals going unbuilt and the tax burden falling on those who can least afford it. The Commission’s original proposals for the Directive were a step in the right direction, but Parliament’s report today pushes them to be even bolder still. National finance ministers should listen to the views of Parliament and agree the most ambitious Directive possible at their meeting on 19 June.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. In order to effectively tackle tax avoidance and fraud, it is necessary to promote cross-border transparency and improve the coordination of national tax measures. The OECD has made important proposals on this subject under the slogan BEPS (reduction of profits and profit shifting). It is right that the Commission is actively pushing ahead with the implementation of these measures. The report voted on today also contains the right starting points. However, I reject the demands to limit the deductibility of interest. The Commission's proposal had already set the value too low. However, the further tightening demanded by Parliament is made out of the anti-BEPS measures. This hinders much-needed private investment in Europe. A motion tabled by my group not to make private investment more difficult did not receive a majority in today's vote. I subsequently abstained from the final vote.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 In today's vote on a report setting out concrete measures against aggressive tax planning, I expressed my support for the proposal. On April 3, 2016, documents from the international law firm Mossack Fonseca, also known as the Panama Papers, were published. By publishing the affair, it was only brought to the attention of the already known problem of so-called tax havens. According to an OECD study, countries lose USD 100 billion to USD 240 billion each year due to aggressive tax planning by multinationals. So this multibillion-dollar tax evasion is just one of the causes of a dingy public budget. I strongly support the view that taxes must be paid where profits are made. It is essential that the EU adopts the necessary instruments to ensure this requirement. The EU must send a clear signal that its aim is to ensure tax fairness and prevent tax dumping in the EU by means of concrete and functional measures. This is also the position expressed in the report approved today by the European Parliament, which I was very happy to support.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. In order to ensure the proper functioning of the single market and the success of the Capital Markets Union, harmonised and harmonised implementation of tax systems is key. I voted in favour of this report. I believe that the proposals it includes make clear and standard the laws on patents. To date, multinationals are exploiting the tax incentives associated with filing patents to artificially reduce the amount of their profits. In my opinion, this has a detrimental effect on truly innovative countries. I am pleased that the rapporteur has also strengthened Parliament's role. I, too, believe that the European Parliament should be entrusted with monitoring the effective implementation of the directive in the 28 Member States.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on rules against tax avoidance practices is a report that has been much debated in the parliamentary committee. The report was based on the Commission's Fair and Effective Corporate Taxation Action Plan. However, I have abstained, because some amendments find me to be opposed.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – As we can see in many examples, the power of the supposedly democratically elected leaders of the countries can only extend as long as the interests of the international financial 'elite' are not threatened. A gentler manifestation of this is the aggressive tax optimisation of multinationals, which is still causing enormous damage to budgets. In fact, you don't even know how much. Estimates show multiple variances, but the order of magnitude is 100 billion euros. The text of the report is very complicated, but it should nevertheless be supported because it represents a step towards clear regulation and does not overly limit the sovereignty of the Member States over their own tax systems by means of the legislation they want.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I expressed support in the European Parliament's position on the proposed anti-tax evasion package, as I believe that fair and efficient corporate taxation is an essential prerequisite for a credible single market.  Aggressive tax planning of multinational enterprises can lead to a significant loss of revenue for countries, reducing their ability to invest in measures to boost employment, combat poverty, develop effective health and education systems. On the other hand, it must be possible for national governments to effectively exercise their fiscal sovereignty. A coordinated and harmonised approach is needed with regard to the implementation of tax systems, the main objective of which is to ensure the payment of taxes on fair terms, as well as the establishment of mechanisms to ensure that businesses pay their taxes where value added is created and where they make their profits, as multinationals too often organise the transfer of their profits to tax havens without paying any tax.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Following the Panama Papers scandal and in relation to previous work by Parliament, a report is presented on the implementation of rules that go against tax elument practices. If we want to achieve a single, reliable market and promote the success of the Capital Markets Union, the Member States must come to an agreement, creating fair and efficient corporate taxation. The main objective of the report is, in fact, to create a strong and harmonised system throughout the Union that is capable of combating the phenomenon of tax avoidance, with the essential participation of Member States, companies and international partners. The report envisages implementing a system that guarantees the payment of taxes by companies in the country where profits are made, and sets out the parameters for a company to be established in a given country. In response to the practices of multinationals in transferring their profits to so-called tax havens, I am voting in favour of the report.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is no secret that within the EU almost EUR 1 trillion are being lost due to tax avoidance and tax evasion. The problem knows no borders and affects every European citizen therefore we should join efforts in laying down rules against tax avoidance/evasion practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market. In light of this, we should work on a harmonisation of European taxation in order ensure proper functioning of the single market and the success of the capital market union. I supported the resolution because to achieve this, however, we should convince Member States to come to an agreement on tax matters. Last but not least, we should find a way that enterprises pay their taxes in the Member State where they make their profit.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it helps to put in place the six sets of measures against aggressive tax planning, of which France is one of the first victims in Europe.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. On 29 June, the Luxembourg court will rule on the so-called "LuxLeaks" case, which revealed the tax avoidance practices and aggressive optimization schemes enjoyed by multinational firms in Europe. Faced with this problem, the Bayet report on the rules to combat tax evasion practices proposes the introduction of new measures to act against these companies that manipulate the law and take unfair advantage of the disparities between the different taxation systems in our internal market. As a result, I voted for this report which will improve Member States' tax treaties to make them more watertight to abusive practices. Through this vote, I respond to the demands of our fellow citizens who wish to put an end to the tax evasion that companies engage in.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the rules to combat tax evasion practices. In January 2016, the Commission presented a series of measures as part of a directive to combat corporate tax evasion. After those on automatic exchange of rescripts or country reporting, this directive (called ATAD) is central because it tackles the most common and costly mechanisms for public finances, at the heart of avoidance schemes. It proposes a cap on interest deductibility, the exit tax, the introduction of switch over clauses (imposition with a tax credit for foreign flows already taxed but at a significantly lower rate), an anti-abuse clause, rules for moving profits from parent companies to foreign companies under control and less taxed , and the case of non-tax-generating hybrid devices. Of course, I would have preferred a French government to impose it on its partners, but the chances of bilateral success with economically liberal political majorities are low, as evidenced by the current situation. I think it makes sense to support these advances, which will be in the interest of national public finances.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report. It is part of the fight against corporate tax evasion. Specifically, a directive formed by the Commission follows this guideline and tackles avoidance schemes (the most common and expensive mechanisms), under the name of the ATAD directive. It is developing its approach on six new regulatory measures to be applied, from the cap on interest deductibility to the introduction of a switch over clause (tax with a tax credit for foreign flows already taxed but at a lower rate). The whole of this regulation benefits France since it will act in favour of national public finances, thanks to stricter legislation in the tax field.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The fight against tax evasion and aggressive tax planning is a political priority for the ECR. We therefore support the objectives of this Council Directive, i.e. the implementation of the measures from the OECD’s Anti-BEPS framework directly affecting the single market. Such measures should focus on artificial fiscal constructions that lack any commercial justification. The ECR abstained on this report. It goes beyond the OECD framework without any impact assessment. It calls for (double) taxation of foreign income that has been taxed under a rate of 15%, via the switch-over-clause and the cfc-rule. The ECR believes the goal should be to tax profits where economic activity takes place, not to introduce Minimum Effective Taxation (MET). Secondly, the report calls to limit corporate deductions for interest payments to 20% or EUR 2 million, and limits the period during which deductions can be made to five years. This risks hurting companies that apply for a loan for legitimate commercial use in order to make investments. Lastly, the report calls for the Commission to publish an ambitious CCCTB proposal and for the Council to conclude negotiations as soon as possible, and asks for the creation of a harmonised, common European Taxpayer Identification number.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote on this report because, despite being an important step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance by large multinationals, it does not adequately address the mechanisms of large multinationals such as patent boxes. This report represents an undeniable step forward in the development of legislation to combat tax evasion and avoidance, from clarifications and effective definitions, to specific measures, the report improves the existing legal framework. However, certain well-known mechanisms are left out and very high limits are set which will prevent these measures from having the actual effect it pursues. We need a more aggressive fiscal policy to combat the practices of multinationals and put an end to the growth of inequality in Europe. It is to be considered that the report will not achieve its objectives and that I have not been able to vote in favour of it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 The construction of an economic and monetary union must be a harmonisation of European taxation. Fair and effective business taxation must become the cornerstone of the single market. I believe that a coordinated and harmonised approach to the functioning of tax systems is essential to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market and the success of the Capital Markets Union. The main objective of this report is to get companies to tax where they make their profits. To this end, this report has chosen to introduce precise and mandatory definitions of the conditions showing that a multinational is well implemented in a country. It's the only way to force these companies to pay taxes fairly.  Today, multinational companies are too often organized to transfer their profits to tax havens without paying any tax. In order to avoid this and the loss of income and therefore investment capacity to promote employment, combat poverty and develop effective and universal health systems for States involved in this aggressive fiscal planning, I vote in favour of its approval.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. In order to effectively tackle tax avoidance and fraud, it is necessary to promote cross-border transparency and improve the coordination of national tax measures. The OECD has made important proposals on this subject under the slogan BEPS (reduction of profits and profit shifting). It is right that the Commission is actively pushing ahead with the implementation of these measures. The report voted on today also contains the right starting points. However, I reject the demands to limit the deductibility of interest. The Commission's proposal had already set the value too low. However, the further tightening demanded by Parliament is made out of the anti-BEPS measures. This hinders much-needed private investment in Europe. A motion tabled by my group not to make private investment more difficult did not receive a majority in today's vote. I subsequently abstained from the final vote.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I strongly disagree that "the Commission should publish as soon as possible an ambitious proposal for a common consolidated corporate tax base and the legislative component should conclude negotiations on this key proposal as quickly as possible". I have long opposed all attempts to unify the tax base of companies in the EU, which I consider to be an effort by high-tax countries to cut for themselves part of the tax paid by international companies in the Czech Republic.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support efforts to tackle tax avoidance, but I abstained on the final vote, as the report crosses into the area of national tax sovereignty.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ According to an OECD study of aggressive tax planning by multinationals in countries' budgets around the world, losses of $100 billion to $240 billion are recorded each year, representing between 4 and 10% of the world's corporate taxation revenues. This means a large loss of income for states and less opportunity for state investment that encourages job creation, the fight against poverty and the development of effective health systems for all. The European taxation system must be leveled for the Economic and Monetary Union to be functional and for the single market to be a fair taxation of businesses.  This report welcomes the Commission's proposal to prevent tax avoidance by multinationals, but considers that the proposed amendments need to better explain these issues. The main objective of the report is for companies to pay their taxes where they make their profits. It also adopts a definition of the condition confirming that a multinational company actually has an establishment in a country. I supported the Report on the proposal for a Council directive setting rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market. In my view, this would only create a solid basis to prevent the practice of further application of tax avoidance.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the current legal environment allows multinationals to shift their profits to tax havens. This damages the economy and economy of the Union and its Member States and reduces their opportunities to invest public finances in the areas of social affairs, employment, health or the fight against poverty. State budgets around the world thus lose between $100 billion and $240 billion a year. The rules we are proposing go against tax avoidance practices. This will have a direct positive impact on the functioning of the internal market. I support the way for businesses to pay taxes where they make a profit. It is therefore right that we are introducing provisions that more precisely regulate the seat of a multinational company, but also the introduction of an exit tax when transferring profits from patents to low-tax countries, because it is through this way that multinationals artificially reduce their profits. At the same time, we are strengthening the EP's position in carrying out a review of the effectiveness of this directive. These objectives cannot be sufficiently achieved by the actions of individual Member States acting alone.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. This text is Parliament's negotiating position on the proposed directive establishing rules to combat tax evasion practices that have a direct impact on the functioning of the internal market. This report contains many advances in combating these practices, including: - the payment of taxes where companies make their profits, through the precise and mandatory definition of the conditions that attest that a multinational is well established in a country; - the establishment of a strict and common blacklist of the 28 Member States of tax havens, including those located in the EU; - a cap on interest deductions at 20% and up to 2 million euros, which prevents multinationals from artificially inflating the number of loans they take out; - the launch of an indispensable debate on a European-wide corporate tax rate, to eliminate the risk of tax competition. I support the implementation of these measures and therefore vote in favour of this text.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Referring to the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 7/6/2016, I abstained in the vote on the report on the proposal for a Council directive on the adoption of rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market, because it is not sufficiently documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text.  This ATAD directive is central because it tackles the most frequent and expensive mechanisms for public finances, at the heart of avoidance schemes. It proposes six regulatory points: "the cap on interest deductibility, the exit tax on latent capital gains, the introduction of switch over clauses (tax with a tax credit for foreign flows already taxed but at a significantly lower rate), a general anti-abuse clause, rules for moving profits from parent companies to foreign companies under control and less taxed , and the case of non-tax-generating hybrid devices." The text also proposes a legal definition of tax havens, stable establishment, patent boxes and other key concepts in the fight against aggressive optimization. We agree with this text because France is one of the least tax-friendly countries in the EU and we have more to gain from stricter legislation in the area of tax optimisation than in a status quo.  On the tax side, the Council will retain the final say. So far, the ministers of the 28 Member States have not reached an agreement, due in part to opposition from the Netherlands or Ireland.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report on combating the phenomenon of tax avoidance. According to an OECD study, states' budgets lose USD 100 billion to USD 240 billion annually due to unfair tax practices. I understand that this is a significant loss that needs to be combated. I agree with many of the instruments and ideas in the report. At the same time, however, the rapporteur states that uniform tax policy rules across the EU need to be introduced. Since I still believe that fiscal policy should remain the responsibility of the Member States, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the report on the proposal for a Directive, which lays down rules against tax avoidance practices which directly affect the functioning of the internal market. We must stop the bleeding of the system of some multinationals for public accounts, which have devised a whole mechanism to evade the payment of billions of euros, which means less money for public services, for employment promotion, for the fight against poverty and to continue to grow equally. I am firmly convinced that the construction of an economic and monetary union must go through a fair and effective harmonisation of European taxation, and for that we must get companies to pay tribute where they make their profits.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Union is allowing EUR 1 trillion in tax evasion and optimisation to evaporate. This situation is fuelling a public revenue crisis and blames tax inequality between taxpayers - particularly between SMEs and households on the one hand, and large groups on the other.  The Bayet report, which amends the Commission's proposal for an anti-tax evasion directive, contains the first serious measures that have long been proposed to restore tax fairness and prevent white-collar crime.  In particular for the incomes of companies returning to Europe, the so-called 'switch-over' clause ensures that flows into the EU have been taxed at a rate that is not unfair. This clause has been cleverly supplemented by our rapporteur Bayet to apply a common criterion to the whole of the European Union. For outflows from Europe, the tax measure on the exit of profits that leave the Eu completes the scheme. It has long been forgotten, by focusing on double taxation, that there is also a massive double-non-taxation. These measures, and many others, therefore have my full support, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is a resolution on a Commission initiative to combat tax avoidance. This report is a one-way move, but there are a few points with which I cannot go. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Currently, multinationals are too often taking steps to transfer their profits to tax havens that have not paid any corporation tax. I therefore support the amendments to the directive aimed at limiting the ability of multinationals to avoid tax.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Commission now wants minimal tax harmonisation in the wake of the Luxleaks revelations. Every year, multinationals' tax evasion and evasion strategies lose $1 billion in revenue to European states. To combat abuses of research and development tax credits, Parliament proposes to subject multinationals to an exit tax when they repatriate patent proceeds to low-tax countries. Parliament also wants to tax profit transfers to subsidiaries located in countries where corporation tax is less than 15%. If this text does not call into question the global system of financial arrangements and tax havens allowing evasion, it proposes to limit the most visible abuses. I abstain to encourage these measures.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The Bayet report changed a few sensitive points in relation to the Commission's original draft (excess interest deductibility thresholds, forward carry-over period of excess EBITDA, exemptions for financial companies or public investments). The European Parliament is not here co-legislator, the Council will retain the last word. This regulation is an opportunity for France, which is one of the least tax-friendly countries in the EU. I think it makes sense to support progress that will benefit our national public finances. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have voted in favour of the report on tax avoidance practices that directly affect the internal market.  Aggressive tax planning represents a significant loss of revenue for states, which lose their investment and job creation capacity.  This report represents an important step towards a European Union response in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance that cannot be fought by Member States in isolation.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report sends an important political message that we will learn lessons from the Panama Papers and take action. This comprehensive report combats aggressive and abusive behaviour, which our citizens expect us to clamp down upon. It is essential that we manage to do this without impinging on the tax sovereignty of Member States. I therefore supported the report, but voted against any amendments that go in the way of impinging on tax sovereignty or tax harmonisation. Tax harmonisation would have a disproportionate effect on smaller economies like Malta and I will maintain my stand against such measures.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by a very large majority of the report on the crackdown on corporate tax evasion. Panama papers, Luxleaks, all reflect only part of the iceberg. Measures to combat evasion must therefore be strengthened. The European Union, the leading economic and commercial power, has a basic role to play. Following OECD recommendations, the EU must pave the way for global reform of tax practices that are harmful to the economy as a whole. To do this we need to have a common approach. As such, I am pleased that this report supports the Commission's proposal while taking the liberty of proposing common definitions such as 'stable establishment', 'tax havens', 'minimum economic substance', 'transfer price', 'royalty costs', 'patent-friendly measures', 'mailbox companies'. The aim of this text is to call on the Council to show ambition when adopting its position on this essential legislation.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: writing – Aggressive tax planning by multinationals represents a huge loss of revenue for states, which reduces their ability to invest to promote employment, combat poverty, create effective health systems for all. The creation of economic and monetary union requires harmonisation of taxation in Europe. Fair and efficient corporate taxation must become a cornerstone of the single market. In order for the single market to be reliable, Member States must agree on the issue of taxation. In particular, I consider a coordinated and harmonised approach to the application of tax systems to be key to success. The means of paying taxes in a fair way is to prove that a multinational company is properly established in the country. Until now, multinationals have used patent filing incentives to artificially reduce their profits. This is proving to be detrimental to truly innovative countries. It is therefore necessary to subject these multinationals to exit tax when they transfer profits from patents to low-tax countries. I am therefore voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. 'The SP is, of course, in favour of a firm approach to tax avoidance, but does not think the proposed compromise is firm enough. The proposal does not address the root of the problem: transparency is far from complete and the rules are far from strict enough.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As far as taxation at EU level is concerned, I have always been in favour of transparency, coordination and exchange of information including on an automatic basis. I welcome measures proposed by the Commission targeting abuse, enhancing transparency and addressing instances of harmful tax competition in the area of corporate taxation as promulgated by international standards. However, I am not in favour of a move towards an EU-wide basis to introduce tax convergence and harmonisation in direct tax matters and the creation of a set of common rules for all countries in the same manner without allowing an element of flexibility. And this particular proposal, despite its primary objective of laying down rules against tax avoidance practices, is going beyond what is permitted by the EU Treaties. It is important to keep in mind that small economies do not face the same economic realities, market conditions, geographical proximity or resources as big economies, therefore they need flexibility in tax policy, as a one-size-fits-all approach can put them at a disadvantage. The element of flexibility is even present in a series of actions recommended by the OECD which in my opinion is missing in this proposal, therefore I voted against the report.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has submitted a proposal to the Council for the adoption of a directive laying down rules against tax avoidance practices directly affecting the functioning of the internal market. In adopting this Directive, the Council should consult Parliament. The Maltese Parliament and the Swedish Parliament have tabled a reasoned opinion that the draft legislative act is incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity. In its report, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs recommends that Parliament approve the Commission's proposal with 91 amendments in the light of the Maltese and Swedish opinions and ask the Commission to amend its proposal accordingly. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. In January 2016, the Commission presented a series of measures as part of a directive to combat corporate tax evasion. After those on automatic exchange of rescripts or country reporting, this directive (called ATAD) is central because it tackles the most common and costly mechanisms for public finances, at the heart of avoidance schemes. On the appropriateness of this regulation, it must be remembered that France is one of the least fiscally welcoming countries in the EU and that we have more to gain from stricter legislation in the area of tax optimisation than in a status quo. Of course, our philosophy would lead us to prefer that it be imposed on a French government to its partners, but the chances of success bilaterally with the economically liberal political majorities that we know are low, as evidenced by the current situation. It seems sensible to continue our line and support these advances that will be in the interest of national public finances. Vote in favour.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Tax avoidance practices can adversely affect the full functioning of the internal market and social justice. In this context, it is essential that Member States take appropriate measures to discourage tax avoidance practices and to ensure fair and effective taxation, which is carried out in a coherent and coordinated manner.  To this end, this proposal for a Directive provides for the adoption of measures to combat tax avoidance. It provides, inter alia, for measures to prevent the erosion of tax bases, promoting the transparency of profits made by companies and their transfer to tax havens, the introduction of a mechanism for resolving cross-border tax disputes and the implementation of a European tax figure as a more efficient and reliable vehicle for the automatic exchange of information. In order to ensure its full effectiveness, the implementation of this Directive should be accompanied by an impact assessment to ensure that tax administrations have the appropriate means. I vote in favour of this proposal for a Directive, as it is essential for the Union to set common rules to combat tax avoidance practices.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This text allows for progress that will be in the interest of national public finances, especially in France. So I'm voting for this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive because the scandal of aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion is costing the EU billions every year, meaning schools and hospitals not being built and the tax burden falling on those who can least afford it. The Commission’s original proposals for the Directive were a step in the right direction, but Parliament’s report today pushes them to be even bolder still. National finance ministers should listen to the views of Parliament and agree the most ambitious Directive possible at their meeting on 19 June.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to neutralize tax avoidance techniques through six measures. This directive is part of the "anti-tax avoidance" package, which also includes a recommendation on tax treaties, a revision of the Directive on Administrative Cooperation, a communication on an external strategy for effective taxation. According to the Commission's estimates, tax evasion and tax avoidance cause up to EUR 1 trillion to be lost each year. That is why we must do everything in our way to combat this phenomenon.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As reported by Caritas' "Third Report on the Impact of the Economic Crisis in Europe", the number of poor people in Europe is increasing day by day: almost 25 million unemployed, 5 million of them under 25 years of age. At the same time, the OECD points out that aggressive tax planning weighs between $100 billion and $240 billion annually, worldwide, on state budgets, whose ability to invest to promote employment and fight poverty is reduced. For these reasons, I support the proposal for EU tax harmonisation and fair and efficient corporate taxation. It is necessary, in particular, to fight against all forms of tax evasion and avoidance, which, as Pope Francis reminds us, is the prelude to sprawling corruption. I therefore support the idea of introducing precise definitions to ensure that a multinational is actually established in a given country, as this is the only way to force it to pay taxes in the place where it makes the profits. Finally, for greater democratic transparency, I believe that the European Parliament must have a clear role in monitoring the application of this directive.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the opinion to be sent to the European Council. Tax avoidance has for too long been tolerated as a normal practice that, especially large companies and multinationals, use. This ruse costs the European Union, especially its citizens and taxpayers, too much. That is why it is necessary, as the current European Commission has undertaken to implement, to take strong and, above all, effective initiatives. Parliament has been at the forefront for over a year to arrive at a system in which companies pay taxes where profit is generated; It is also crucial that an agreement is reached which prevents multinational groups from carrying out actions which go against the principle of transparency and contributing to the functioning of the country's services and which generate a comparative advantage over competing companies. The European internal market can only become unique when illegal practices are also recognised, sanctioned and prevented in all Member States.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Harmonised and harmonised tax systems must be established in order for the single market and the Capital Markets Union to function properly. According to an OECD study, tax optimisation for multinationals causes a budget deficit of more than 100 billion a year. This tax loss is the biggest problem in states where revenues are intended to create jobs, eradicate poverty and improve health care. The aim of the report is to make companies pay taxes where they operate, where their income is. It is therefore necessary to determine the circumstances under which a multinational company may be considered established in that country. This is how we can make multinationals pay their fair tax, so I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A study made by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) estimated that aggressive tax optimisation made by multinationals causes losses to state budgets of somewhere between 100 and 240 billion each year, worldwide. I have voted for this report that will ensure that enterprises pay their taxes where they make their profits.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it encourages tax practices beneficial to the internal business environment of the European Union. It is commendable that the European Parliament has approved rules for the application of fair and efficient taxation of businesses within the EU, the rules drawn up being in line with the European Commission's Action Plan. One of the new provisions adopted by this report is aimed at eliminating double deductions of taxes, a practice used to avoid tax obligations by companies in the Member States. In this respect, the report provides for the introduction of the switch-over clause, which, by applying it to corporate lending agreements, will help to avoid the risk of transferring profits from high-tax jurisdictions to low-tax territories. I also welcome the adoption of the general anti-abuse rule aimed at supplementing the laws of the Member States in order to prevent abusive tax practices within undertakings.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I supported much of the content of this resolution which aims to tackle tax avoidance by corporations operating in the European single market. However, I voted against this overall proposal despite many positive aspects as Sinn Féin is determined to ensure that tax sovereignty remains in the hands of Member States. Changes to tax law aimed at ending loopholes for tax avoidance should be made by national parliaments working as part of an effective international framework -– which is currently being led by the OECD. Many aspects of the report aimed to implement the OECD Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) plan, which I supported. I supported amendments criticising the role of so-called knowledge boxes as tax avoidance mechanisms. Certain aspects of the Commission proposal and Parliament resolution go beyond the OECD BEPS recommendations, including on exit taxation and switchover clauses, which I could not support. While these may be effective mechanisms for combating tax avoidance, our approach is that we want to implement the OECD BEPS recommendations in Member States and EU law where appropriate now – but that we want to continue seeing countries engaging in an international framework as the primary vehicle for combating global tax avoidance.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The Commission's proposal and the European Parliament's report reflect the sharpening of the contrasts between imperialist centres, but also parts of the capital, the EU's need for measures to protect its internal market and its monopolistic groups. It is not aimed at, nor is it enough, for a tax relief for the grassroots. In conditions of liberalisation of the movement of capital, multiple laws on the legal avoidance of businesses and special tax regimes, tax burdens fall on the backs of workers. It is no coincidence that in the EU-28 corporation tax represents only 2.5% of GDP from 40% of total taxation. The JRC was placed in white because the proposed arrangements do not change this correlation, they serve the same class orientation of EU tax policy. It is no coincidence that measures that could lead to a shift in tax burdens towards large capital are excluded, such as full nominalisation of shares, effective removal of trade and other secrets, taxation of all distributed and non-profitable enterprises, taxation of the current value of shares and changes in that value. The aim of EU policy and this directive is to regulate competition between opposing economic interests of portions of the capital.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because, although the report has some good approaches to avoiding unfair tax practices, the report also shows a very inflexible and excessive harmonisation of tax law at European level.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Businesses should pay income tax where they make a profit. I therefore supported the report's proposal to define the conditions under which the countries where multinationals operate can be verified. In addition, the report also regulates patent provisions and supports innovative entrepreneurship.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation and strengthening of an economic and monetary union cannot be separated from the existence of a uniform fiscal framework. In view of the fact that the aggressive tax planning of multinationals entails considerable losses which affect the distribution of wealth, I welcome the Commission's proposal and the subsequent amendments which provide, among other provisions, for the tax rules of the place where profits are produced to apply. I therefore feel that I am voting in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Combating fraud, tax evasion and tax avoidance are overriding political priorities, as aggressive tax planning practices are unacceptable from the point of view of the integrity of the internal market and social justice. As the report highlights, a political priority of international taxation highlights the need for ensuring that taxes are payable in the countries where the actual economic activity or value creation has taken place. I support the report and the fight against tax avoidance.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒As soon as possible, finally establishing rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market is a necessity. This proposals for a Council directive and the accompanying report of the committee responsible shall attempt to complete this task.  Establishing a common definition of a permanent establishment and a definition of a transfer price, developing a common method of calculating the effective tax rate, presenting a legislative proposal for a harmonised and common European tax identification number and a legislative proposal on a common consolidated corporate tax base are good proposals and I support them. As significant problems cited are the shifting of profits to secret or low-tax jurisdictions, which poses a particular risk to the collection of tax revenues in the Member States and inadequate automatic exchange of tax data. Furthermore, it calls for a ban on the use of shell companies, the introduction of a system of penalties and the establishment of a review and monitoring mechanism which I fully support.  The minority opinion and the close vote on the adoption of the report at the committee responsible point to shortcomings in the proposal for a directive which should be removed before its adoption. Nevertheless, I consider that the proposal for a directive is heading in the right direction and therefore supported this report.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This text allows for progress that will be in the interest of national public finances, especially in France. So I'm voting for this report.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Aggressive tax planning by multinationals costs state budgets hundreds of billions of euros each year. The series of measures that we are approving today is a clear signal to the Member States that ambitious progress needs to be made in the fight against tax evasion, on the principle that taxes must be paid where profits are generated. To this end, it is expected: the introduction of precise and binding definitions regarding the establishment of multinationals in a given country, in order to make it impossible to transfer profits to tax havens with the aim of not paying taxes; the creation of a blacklist of tax havens and countries, including European ones, which distort competition through tax regimes favourable to multinationals; clarification of patent rules and more effective controls on loans between entities belonging to the same multinational in order to avoid abuse. The current system, in which the vast majority of citizens honestly pay taxes while some economic giants manage to evade tax obligations, is intolerable. It is time for everyone to contribute fairly to the funding of health care, safety, schools, universities and youth employment policies. For this reason, I wholeheartedly support the Bayet report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ According to an OECD study of aggressive tax planning by multinationals in countries' budgets around the world, losses of up to $240 billion are recorded each year, representing up to 10% of the world's corporate taxation revenues. This primarily means a huge loss of income for states and less opportunity for state investment that encourages job creation, the fight against poverty and the development of effective health systems for all. I believe that the Economic and Monetary Union must be built by equalizing European taxation systems. I also agree with Rapporteur Hugues Bayet that fair and effective corporate taxation must become the cornerstone of the single market. Member States must agree on taxation issues if they are to achieve a reliable single market. In order to ensure the well-functioning of the Single Market and the success of the Capital Markets Union, a coordinated and coherent approach on the implementation of tax systems is necessary.
