I welcome the Commission's proposal as a positive step towards preventing tax avoidance in multinational companies. Precise and mandatory definitions of the conditions confirming that a multinational company actually has an establishment in a country should be introduced. It's the only way to make them want to pay taxes evenly. Today, multinationals are too often organised to transfer their profits to tax havens without paying taxes.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Aggressive tax planning by multinationals records losses representing up to 10 percent of global corporate taxation revenues each year in countries' budgets. This represents a huge loss of income for states and less opportunity for state investment that should boost job creation, combat poverty and develop effective systems. In order to ensure the well-functioning of the Single Market and the success of the Capital Markets Union, a coordinated and coherent approach to the implementation of tax systems is necessary. I supported a report by Mep Bayet supporting a concrete Commission proposal that would allow the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base to allow companies to use a one-way system when filling in tax returns and consolidating the gains and losses they report to the Union. The main objective of this report is to ensure that companies pay their taxes where they make their profits.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report calls for the possibility of deducting interest to be limited to 20% or EUR 2 000 000 (EC proposal: 30%), and limits the period during which deductions can be made to five years (no limit in the EC proposal). This item is not proportionate and carries the risk of hitting companies that apply for a loan for legitimate commercial use in order to make an investment. Moreover, the wide variation in interest rates between EU Member States is completely ignored. It also suggests that the so-called 'switch-over clause' (which does not exist under the OECD proposal) is also applied within the EU. The EC proposes to refuse this exemption if foreign income is taxed at a rate of less than 40 % of the national rate, which raises problems with the interpretation of bilateral double taxation agreements. I was hereby unsued to support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the proposed directive establishing rules to combat tax evasion practices that have a direct impact on the functioning of the European internal market. This text, which has its origin in the action plan for fair and effective corporate taxation presented by the European Commission in June 2015, aims to adopt a firm and coherent approach at European level to combat abusive tax practices. This will include the implementation in all Member States of the Directive on Combating Tax Evasion, by administrative cooperation between countries on the taxation of multinationals, or by an external strategy for effective taxation, aimed at promoting good tax governance on a global scale.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. According to an OECD study, the aggressive tax optimisation of multinationals loses between US$100 billion to US$140 billion each year to the budgets of states around the world, representing between 4 % and 10 % of global corporate tax revenues. It is clear that this represents a significant loss of income for States and reduces their investment capacity to promote employment, fight poverty and develop effective health systems. This report, which I voted in favour of, states that fair and effective corporate taxation should become the cornerstone of the single market and wants companies to pay their taxes where they make their profits. To this end, the report decided to establish exact and mandatory definitions of the conditions proving that a multinational is well established in a country, taking into account that multinational companies are often organised in such a way as to transfer their profits to tax havens without having paid any tax.  In this way, the document states that the EP should be the body responsible for monitoring the effective implementation of this directive in the 28 Member States. You should also be able to carry out an independent assessment to measure its effectiveness.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Union's proactive policy to combat tax evasion and evasion responds to both a social justice imperative and an economic need for public authorities.  This ambitious text is part of this policy. It is based on the principle that taxes must be paid where profits are made and includes legally binding measures to block the methods most often used by companies, or even Member States, to minimise taxes owed. It also proposes common definitions of terms that until now have remained open to interpretation, such as "stable establishment," "tax havens" or "mailbox companies." While we can welcome the progress proposed, we regret, however, that this text falls under the consultation procedure, thus limiting the role that European parliamentarians can play in this regard. However, Parliament has strengthened the original proposal, particularly with regard to the 'switch-over' clause (revenue taxed in a country outside the EU and then transferred to an EU Member State, often exempt from taxes to avoid double taxation).    In line with the political lines presented, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The main objective of the report is to ensure that companies pay their taxes where they make their profits. The rapporteur has decided to insert a precise and binding definition into the criteria that must be met for a multinational to prove that it is based in a given country. This is the only way to force them to pay their taxes fairly. The report also strengthens the role of the European Parliament and should be the body responsible for verifying that this directive is being implemented effectively in the 28 Member States. It should also be made possible to carry out an independent assessment of its effectiveness.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. If the European Commission is moving in the right direction with its proposal for an anti-tax avoidance directive for multinational companies, I believe that the European Union can and must be ambitious. That is why I have decided to support this report on rules to combat tax evasion practices, which proposes improvements to the Commission's original proposal. As the European Parliament's powers on tax matters are limited, we are only consulted on these issues. It was therefore essential to arrive at a report that was both ambitious but also supported by a large majority of MEPs in order to send a strong signal to the Council. I am therefore pleased that this report was adopted by a large majority (486/88/103) at this plenary session. Among the advances proposed by the European Parliament is a cap of 20% and up to TWO million euros in interest deductions from loans paid by companies. Let us now hope that the Council is as responsible as the European Parliament and adopts an ambitious directive to combat tax avoidance.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Globalisation not only ensures the free movement of labour, capital, services and goods, but also allows the movement of enterprises. Unfortunately, as experience has shown in recent years, companies are very successful in exploiting the differences in tax regulation in order to simply hide their profits and not pay taxes where they produce or provide services. After all, these taxes cover all public services, from public security to enabling these businesses to operate, to training and education that provides skilled workers to companies, or health care that ensures that workers are not only qualified but also healthy. The issue we are discussing today is therefore very important for the whole existence of the present society. Will we be able to ensure that companies, especially the big ones, comply with fair rules of the game? Will we continue to monitor how some companies parasitize at the expense of states, and some countries, including some EU Member States, are helping them not without benefit.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to establish new rules to combat tax evasion. After the SwissLeaks, LuxLeaks and Panama Papers scandals, which revealed the extent of tax evasion practices on a European and global scale, we must act to ensure that tax is paid where profit is made. It is the philosophy of this report that makes five important advances: a precise and mandatory definition of the conditions that certify that a multinational is well established in a country in order to ensure that it pays its taxes there; capping interest deductions at 20% up to 2 million euros, the "switch-over" clause that allows the regulation of controlled foreign companies; an ambitious "out-of-tax" of profits to reduce double-non-taxation; limiting the use of patent filing (which artificially reduces the amount of profits) through a clarification of the definition of research and development investments. These advances must restore equality before taxes, a principle that underpins our democracies.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. Recent oecd studies show that states lose between US$100 million and US$240 million in corporate tax revenue stemming from aggressive tax optimisation by multinational companies. This undermines the capacity of public investment to promote growth solutions for Member States. In order to aim for an effective single market and a robust and reliable economic and financial union, Member States need to agree on a fair and effective harmonisation of European taxation for citizens and businesses. I therefore see this Commission proposal as positive, which aims to establish rules to strengthen the average level of protection against aggressive tax planning in the internal market.  I would like to point out: on the one hand, the obligation of companies to pay their taxes at the place where they obtain their profits, by establishing conditions proving their implementation in a given country; on the other hand, the clarification and standardisation of patent legislation, which no longer allows companies to artificially reduce the profits obtained. Both measures are extremely positive and are an essential contribution in combating tax fraud and avoidance.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a Council directive, for which I voted in favour, aims to adopt rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market. Faced with the impasse of the Member States in the field of tax evasion and avoidance, the European Parliament is engaged in a real fight against unfair tax practices, which mainly harm small and medium-sized enterprises as well as consumers. This report proposes to introduce precise and binding definitions so that multinationals pay taxes in the country in which they are actually established, thus preventing the transfer of profits to tax havens.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the fight against tax evasion. It is a major damage to our economy and cannot be tolerated.   As the report points out, the tax secrecy maintained by some countries poses a particular risk to Member States' tax revenues as well as to the equal and fair treatment of businesses. In order to combat tax havens, it advocates, in particular, withholding tax in the case of payments from member states to entities practising tax secrecy or opacity.  The report also calls for better tax cooperation between Member States, an essential step in European integration.  I supported this text because it calls for tackling the root causes of tax evasion, by proposing reforms at EU level but also at member level. In addition, it is accompanied by a monitoring mechanism to ensure the proper implementation of the directive and the homogeneous interpretation of its measures by member states.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report. While the rapporteur tried to form a progressive majority in Parliament with tough measures to combat tax avoidance, the division of the ALDE group forced him to seek agreements with the EPP, which has substantively reduced the content of the text. For my part, I have tabled amendments aimed at increasing the ability of States to control transactions with countries that are not sufficiently transparent, however these amendments were rejected.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote against this report follows on similar votes on the same subject in past months.  I fully understand the need to control the wide range of practices by which taxes are being evaded by individuals and companies, large and small, as revealed by LuxLeaks and the Panama Papers scandal. I support all measures meant to increase transparency in taxation affairs. But such measures should not end up infringing the existing right of EU Member States to retain sovereignty over their tax systems.  It seems to me that the proposals made in this report open the door fully to further follow-ups that can only lead to tax harmonisation within the EU. With this I cannot agree, for it would serve to increase the growing structural divergences between the central EU economy and the small peripheral economies of the European Union.  For these economies, taxation policy (which they still control) is the only real tool left by which to retain flexibility for competitive purposes. All others they have given up (customs protection, budgetary flexibility in public budgeting, the setting of VAT and excise, state-aid policy, exchange rate). Moves towards harmonisation of income and profit taxes will only further undermine their competitiveness.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the Bayet report, because profit-making companies also have to pay taxes. The Directive includes six measures to combat tax planning and proposes common definitions such as 'permanent establishment', 'tax havens' and 'economic substance', but these definitions have given rise to interpretations. This legislative framework is the Union's response to the final draft on the erosion of the taxable base and the transfer of profits of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD).

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. It is necessary to tighten efforts to combat tax evasion by multinational companies. Tax evasion costs European Treasuries billions in lost tax revenue every year. That is why, with this agreement, we are calling for an ambitious agreement to prevent tax fraud.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Report on combating tax avoidance practices with a direct impact on the functioning of the internal market', as it is important to have clear rules across Europe if we are to prevent tax avoidance. It pursues the principle that taxes must be paid where the actual economic activity takes place. At the same time, however, the report also makes proposals such as the introduction of Europe-wide tax numbers for each company and advocates the introduction of penalties for active tax avoidance. The switch-over clause, which regulates the tax jurisdiction of states for companies with locations in several countries within and outside the EU and is largely already applied in Germany, is now also to be introduced throughout Europe.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – On the one hand, stabling public budgets, on the other hand, multibillion-dollar tax evasion. According to an OECD study, countries lose USD 100 billion to USD 240 billion each year due to aggressive tax planning by multinationals. The fight against tax havens and tax evasion is one of the long-term priorities of the S&D Group. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Hugues has been incredibly ambitious in this report and has managed to get a fantastic message in the final text. Hence, I voted in favour of this report. The scandal of aggressive tax avoidance and evasion costs Member States billions every year; this means that schools and hospitals go under-funded or unbuilt. It pushes the burden of public funds on those who are least able to afford it. The Commission’s original proposal for a Directive were a step in the right direction, but Parliament’s report today pushes them to be even bolder still. National finance ministers should listen to the views of Parliament and agree the most ambitious Directive possible at their meeting on 19 June.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The inhabitants of Slovakia and Europe are victims of shameless thefts from companies, domestic politicians and oligarchs who bypass the payment of taxes. This approach is immoral and contrary to Christian ethics. That is why I am in favour of reducing tax evasion, but at the same time I am in favour of increasing tax harmonisation, which is why I abstained in voting on this resolution.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ tax avoidance practices are taking on an increasingly sophisticated form, and paradoxically they are mostly large multinational corporations that apply tax avoidance practices. Today, multinationals are organised so that they can shift their profits to tax havens without paying any tax. According to an OESD study, aggressive tax planning by multinationals causes losses of $100 billion to $240 billion a year to state budgets around the world. This represents between 4 and 10% of global corporate tax revenues. Fair and efficient corporate taxation must become a cornerstone of the single market. In order for the single market to be reliable, Member States must agree on the issue of taxation. The main objective of the draft report is to ensure that businesses pay taxes where they make a profit. The Commission should present as soon as possible a legislative proposal on uniform rules for the filing of tax returns and the consolidation of all profits and losses of legal entities across the Union.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report by which the EP, as part of the consultation procedure, expresses its support for the EU Directive against tax avoidance practices. The shadow rapporteur for the PPE on this text was my colleague Luděk Niedermayer, whom I thank for the quality of work done on this important subject. In line with the G20 and OECD recommendations on combating tax fraud, the Directive introduces rules to ensure fairer taxation of large firms by targeting precisely the most widely used tax avoidance methods. Today, large multinational supranational firms are able to take advantage of differences between the tax rules of different countries, thus artificially reducing the amount of taxes paid. These practices fundamentally schmoul competition – SMEs do not have the capacity to find holes in tax laws and to set up fictitious subsidiaries in tax havens. The directive will therefore also help small entrepreneurs. Avoiding the most common tax avoidance practices should also increase european countries' tax revenues, which may pave the way for a reduction in tax rates. The European Parliament is only consulted on tax rules and is decided unanimously by the Finance Ministers. However, I believe that the Council will take into account some of our additional proposals, such as the rules against so-called shell companies.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. According to a study by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), losses in the budgets of countries around the world, due to aggressive tax planning by multi-national companies, amount to between $100 billion and $240 billion each year, representing 4% of 10% of global corporate tax revenue. Countries thus lose a huge amount of income, reducing their ability to invest to promote employment, eradicate poverty and establish effective health care systems for all.  The report represents a positive step in limiting tax avoidance by multi-national companies. Its main objective is to ensure that companies pay taxes where they make profits. Thus, the company will have to prove that it is indeed established in a country, as this will only make it obligated to pay taxes in a fair way.  The report strengthens the role of the European Parliament, which should be responsible for overseeing the effective implementation of this Directive in all 28 Member States. It should also be able to carry out an independent assessment of its effectiveness.  Although the report has slightly more weak content than I would have liked, I believe that it represents a step in the right direction, which is why I knocked it down in the vote.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. In order to effectively tackle tax avoidance and fraud, it is necessary to promote cross-border transparency and improve the coordination of national tax measures. The OECD has made important proposals on this subject under the slogan BEPS (reduction of profits and profit shifting). It is right that the Commission is actively pushing ahead with the implementation of these measures. The report voted on today also contains the right starting points. However, I reject the demands to limit the deductibility of interest. The Commission's proposal had already set the value too low. However, the further tightening demanded by Parliament is made out of the anti-BEPS measures. This hinders much-needed private investment in Europe. A motion tabled by my group not to make private investment more difficult did not receive a majority in today's vote. I subsequently abstained from the final vote.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The joint fight against aggressive tax planning, the abuse of so-called tax havens and tax havens must be a priority for the European Commission. It has full support from the European Parliament on this.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Losses of $100 billion to $240 billion are recorded each year due to aggressive tax planning by multinationals in the budgets of countries around the world, which ultimately leads to heavy income losses for states and lower opportunities for government investments that encourage job creation, combat poverty and develop effective health systems for all. Unfortunately, more multinationals are organizing to transfer their profits to tax havens while circumventing tax payments.  I support the report on rules against certain tax avoidance practices, as I think it is important that a reliable single market is created, which requires Member States to agree on taxation issues. Fair and effective corporate taxation must become the basis of the single market and the Economic and Monetary Union must be based on uniform European taxation systems. Furthermore, I believe this report would move closer to the goal of all companies paying their taxes where they make their profits.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive because the scandal of aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion is costing the EU billions every year, meaning schools and hospitals going unbuilt and the tax burden falling on those who can least afford it. The Commission’s original proposals for the Directive were a step in the right direction, but Parliament’s report today pushes them to be even bolder still. National finance ministers should listen to the views of Parliament and agree the most ambitious Directive possible at their meeting on 19 June.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's report on the proposal for a Council directive on anti-tax avoidance practices with a direct impact on the functioning of the internal market. The report is intended to implement the OECD proposals on BEPS. However, the report goes far beyond that. It also introduces country reporting. Furthermore, I see no reason to transfer corporate tax powers to the EU. I want member states to be taxed instead of a Community tax system.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This Council proposal would establish rules to prevent tax avoidance, which is essential for the functioning of the internal market. The main political priority of international taxation is to ensure that taxes are paid in those countries where concrete economic activity takes place. Taxable taxpayers often act contrary to the laws, exploiting differences between national tax systems to reduce or avoid the obligation to pay taxes. Such conduct leads to losses in state budgets, making it harder for states to invest in projects that will promote employment, combat poverty and build effective health systems for all. Building an Economic and Monetary Union must be achieved through the harmonisation of European tax. Effective taxation must become the cornerstone of the single market, and if we are to achieve the single market, Member States must agree on tax issues. I support the proposal for a Directive because I believe it will limit the possibility of tax evasion by multinationals and ensure that companies pay taxes where they make a profit.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council directive laying down rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market.  According to the OECD, Member States lose at least €100 billion a year for tax avoidance, which is a serious problem and calls for effective action.  I support the clear view that companies pay taxes where they make profits. Certainly a harmonised European tax regime is one solution, but it is not the only one. The European Union must be more determined in the fight against tax evaders and the unrepensed payment of taxes.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tax policy must be a sovereign right of each Member State. That's our proclaimed position. Any concentration of these powers in Brussels would give the Cypriot economy a final blow after the disastrous bailout. Under no circumstances are we against rules on tax avoidance or tax evasion. We are against the creation of rules imposed on them by Brussels and the economically strong Member States and which they will apply to their measures. We voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The existence of common rules in all Member States of the Union to deal with corporate tax evasion, with the exception of financial institutions and insurance undertakings, does not do justice. It is biased in favour of states with a strong economy and promotes the enhanced implementation of the single market by imposing policies that, instead of helping economically weak countries, lead them to full control over their respective strong ones.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on rules against tax avoidance practices directly affecting the functioning of the internal market, because I agree with the main aim of ensuring that multinationals finally actually pay tax where they make their profits. Aggressive tax optimisation by multinationals has taken significant resources away from important areas such as health, education and public services. This is an unsustainable situation, so I agree with the rapporteur that, in order to create a reliable single market, Member States need to bring their tax systems into line. European tax harmonisation is also a prerequisite for the establishment of economic and monetary union. The report's comments were intended to clarify and make the Commission's proposal to limit tax avoidance by multinationals clearer and more effective, in an end to the practice of multinationals colliding to evade tax into tax havens. In addition, I welcome the fact that the report has also clarified and standardised patent legislation and strengthened Parliament's role.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this ambitious report, which aims at influencing the Council to agree on a comprehensive text to ensure that profits are taxed where they are created. In light of the Panama Papers scandal, European citizens need reassurance that the European Union will take serious action in order to combat tax evasion. I believe that the fight against tax evasion by multinationals plays a fundamental part in regaining our citizens` trust.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. On Wednesday 8 June, the European Parliament voted in plenary on the new measures proposed by MEP Hugues Bayet to combat tax evasion by multinationals.  This vote is widely supported by the political groups, which once again demonstrates that the European Parliament is a major player in a major reform of the taxation of multinationals in Europe.  Hugues Bayet, who was an excellent rapporteur, points out that with these new measures, it will finally be possible to tax the profits of multinationals where they are generated and thus prevent them from being transferred to a tax haven. This is a major challenge, as EU Member States record between EUR 100 and 240 billion euros in tax losses each year as a result of the aggressive tax optimisation of multinationals.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which amongst other things, limits at 20% and up to EUR 2 million deductions of loan interest paid by companies, the provision which states that profits entering Europe will be taxed at the legal rate of the country of entry if they have not previously been taxed at a level of at least 15% outside the EU , and limits the use of the mechanism of depositing patents, by clarifying the definition of investments in research and development.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The report by my colleague and fellow Socialist Hugues Bayet on tax evasion affirms the European Parliament's ambition to restore justice and equality in the face of tax. The recent revelations (SwissLeaks, Panama papers, LuxLeaks...) have had the merit of putting the fight against tax evasion back on the political agenda. The Socialists and Democrats have established a principle: taxes must be paid where profits are realized. To do this, the report proposed important progress: capping interest deductions, establishing a strict and common blacklist of tax havens in the 28 Member States, and limiting the use of patent filing, a tool too often misused to artificially reduce profits. These advances are beneficial, the tax should not be circumvented because it is the cement of a just society. There is no justification for those who pay their taxes to bear the tax evasion of others. This report is encouraging, and we need to go further by introducing country-by-country public reporting of multinationals. This is the best way to track profits effectively.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I supported the proposal for a Council directive laying down rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market. The provision limiting interest on tax credits to 20 % is inappropriate and harmful, while also hindering investment. Interest payments are the costs of investment projects, which should make them able to claim as such, otherwise the taxable profit will be overestimable. In this context, the 30% cap recommended by the OECD in the BASE EROSION strategy and profit shifting is also problematic. Many companies with serious investment projects would be harmed. It is not right to adopt provisions in the fight against inappropriate tax practices that will also harm companies that pay their taxes fairly. In addition, in particular, intra-group loans are used for tax avoidance in order to redirect profits to low-tax jurisdictions. It would therefore be more appropriate to limit interest payment tax credits only in the case of intra-group loans. However, interest relief should not be limited to third parties. The envisaged option of transferring non-deductible interest payments for up to five years will not be of great benefit, in particular for undertakings which finance real investments. In large-scale investment projects, companies have faced high interest payment charges for several years, which means that there is no possibility of passing on interest.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed directive deals with cross-border tax avoidance practices. This is not justified that in the EU some tax jurisdictions can be regarded as tax heavens and they are used by taxpayers to reduce considerably their tax bill. No corporate income shall remain without taxation and all Member States need to introduce comprehensive rules against tax avoidance.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report. While the rapporteur tried to form a progressive majority in Parliament with tough measures to combat tax avoidance, the division of the ALDE group forced him to seek agreements with the EPP, which has substantively reduced the content of the text. For my part, I have tabled amendments aimed at increasing the ability of States to control transactions with countries that are not sufficiently transparent, however these amendments were rejected.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I finally voted against this report because some points look like the first step towards tax harmonisation and interfere too much with the tax rules of the Member States.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Tax avoidance has become one of the worst problems of our society. With our middle class struggling to adapt to globalisation and our welfare state at risk due to the vulnerability of our public finances, it is fundamental that all elements from society contribute their due taxes and do not avoid their responsibility. Without a level playing field that makes everyone pay taxes the same way, cohesion policy will suffer.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. In January 2016, the Commission presented a series of measures as part of a directive to combat corporate tax evasion. This directive is central because it tackles the most common and costly mechanisms for public finances, at the heart of avoidance schemes. Six points: the cap on interest deductibility, the taxation on the exit of latent capital gains, the introduction of switch over clauses, a general anti-abuse clause, rules for moving profits from parent companies to foreign companies under control and less tax, and the case of hybrid non-taxation schemes. The Bayet report has changed some sensitive points in relation to the Commission's project. The European Parliament is not here co-legislator, and as with all tax matters, the Council will retain the final say. For the record, at its meeting at the end of May, the ministers of the 28 did not reach an agreement, mainly due to the opposition of the Netherlands or Ireland. It seems sensible to continue our line and support these advances that will be in the interest of national public finances. I'm voting FOR.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support all measures aimed at fair and effective corporate taxation. According to an OECD study, aggressive tax planning of multinational companies causes between $100 billion and $240 billion in losses to national budgets around the world each year. Companies should pay taxes where they generate profits. However, I cannot agree with the harmonisation of the tax systems of the Member States of the European Union. This area should be reserved only for the prerogatives of national governments. They should take such action in tax policy as they deem appropriate. Centralising tax powers can create economic problems and hinder competition that benefits the average EU citizen. I therefore voted against.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to an OECD study, aggressive tax optimisation of multinationals causes annual budget deficits of between $100 million and $240 million globally. This amounts to between 4% and 10% of the taxes paid by companies worldwide. In particular, this represents a sensitive loss of revenue for states where, as a result, resources for investment aimed at stimulating job creation, eradicating poverty and developing effective health care systems are consensible. I voted in favour of the S&D group.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report. While the rapporteur tried to form a progressive majority in Parliament with tough measures to combat tax avoidance, the division of the ALDE group forced him to seek agreements with the EPP, which has substantively reduced the content of the text. For my part, I have tabled amendments aimed at increasing the ability of States to control transactions with countries that are not sufficiently transparent, however these amendments were rejected.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive. I had liked that this directive would have gone much further than the OECD agreement. But this directive is absolutely needed in the context of an integrated EU market where tax competition plays an harmful role. My Group has successfully managed to include in the report some additional provisions to tackle artificial establishments and transactions that companies uses only for tax purposes and fight against patent boxes.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council directive laying down rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market. I strongly believe that combating fraud, tax evasion and tax avoidance are overriding political priorities, as aggressive tax planning practices are unacceptable from the point of view of the integrity of the internal market and social justice. Furthermore, I am of the view that fair and effective corporate taxation must become the cornerstone of the single market.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to an OECD study, aggressive tax planning of multinationals costs between $100 billion and $240 billion a year, which is equal to 4-10% of the world's corporate tax revenue, a huge loss of income that could be invested to boost employment and reduce poverty. The European Commission has proposed a directive to establish rules against the tax avoidance practices of multinationals which have a direct impact on the functioning of the internal market. The European Commission's initial proposal against tax avoidance practices was very weak. The text has been strengthened in Parliament. Progress has been made on many fronts, but the crux of the negotiations has been the deductions and tax rates for the large multinationals. We were initially in agreement with the Socialists' proposals, but during the negotiations with the other political groups the text was increasingly watered down. The result was a down-to-the-bottom compromise and as uneambitious as we would have liked. The thresholds proposed in the end still appeared ineffective to us in combating tax avoidance practices in multinationals. In plenary we have resubmitted our requests once again, but since these were rejected, we preferred to vote against the text.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive because the scandal of aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion is costing the EU billions every year, meaning schools and hospitals going unbuilt and the tax burden falling on those who can least afford it. The Commission’s original proposals for the Directive were a step in the right direction, but Parliament’s report today pushes them to be even bolder still. National finance ministers should listen to the views of Parliament and agree the most ambitious Directive possible at their meeting on 19 June.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In the wake of the LuxLeaks, we are told that the European Commission is concerned with making proposals to curb these practices. The proposal for a directive submitted to the European Parliament aims to 'set rules to combat tax evasion'. It is a question of ensuring that companies pay their taxes where they make their profits and thus defining precisely the conditions for the establishment of multinationals. To this end, it also proposes to set up a European tax identification number to facilitate the automatic exchange of tax data, data which, it should be remembered, many companies refuse to disclose. The report proposes to define a new blacklist of tax havens at European level and to include good tax governance clauses in trade agreements and economic partnership agreements with third countries. Given the Panama Papers scandal, this would indeed be an indispensable minimum. Unfortunately, if Parliament has achieved improvements on the Commission's original text, this is still a missed appointment. Definitions and obligations remain too vague, especially with regard to multinationals.  In order to restore the confidence of European citizens, we must do better, so I abstained.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The objectives of this directive are commendable. However, and this is evident with each passing day, the great plan announced by the Commission in 2015, at the height of the tax scandals and at the height of public outrage, is confronted with reality. In the name of pragmatism, namely the hypocrisy of the governments of the countries that have created the conditions to exempt large multinationals from paying taxes, today we have a proposal from the minimalist committee that does not correspond at all to the legitimate expectations of citizens. We follow the report which required that the maximum standards be adopted in the framework of the OECD proposals and not the other way around. We do not understand the exemption from the financial system. The Commission's criteria for applying the switch-over are ineffective. On the other hand, we do not understand the coherence of this proposal with others that are promised, such as the common consolidation of the tax base or the list of tax havens. In other words, this directive seems to us to be more of an instrument of propaganda, designed to give citizens the meaning that something is being done to look all the same.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report contains some good proposals aimed at avoiding unfair tax practices. However, as The tendency towards inflexible and excessive harmonisation of tax law at EU level seems to me to be too strong, I am abstaining.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive because aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion are central causes of global inequality and social injustice. In the EU alone, such practices cost the tax-payers millions, and mean that schools and hospitals are underfunded. Politicians who have imposed austerity and public sector cuts, condemning the weakest in society to poverty and exclusion, often tell us that their measures are inevitable and technical. And yet we see that austerity, as with the decision of who tax and who not to tax, are political decisions. I am glad to see that the EU is now taking this very important step towards global social justice. The Commission’s original proposals for the Directive were a step in the right direction, in line with OECD position, but Parliament’s report today pushes them to be bolder still. National finance ministers must take the Parliament’s position on board Parliament and agree the most ambitious Directive possible at their meeting on 19 June. The EU must be a world leader in the fight to tackle tax injustice, as it is the only actor that is able to act on this on the international stage.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of a motion for a Council Directive that is based on the Bayet report. Based on results by the OECD, we know that multinationals are able to avoid taxes, which annually amounts to a cost between USD 100 billion and USD 240 billion worldwide. The report introduces measures which will ensure a fairer taxation of multinationals so that these do not increase our citizen’s tax burden or disadvantage other companies including SME’s. However measures must not go beyond the OECD guidelines, as this would reduce Europe’s competitive position compared to 3rd countries. I also welcome the call for a stronger role for the European Parliament in ensuring that other institutions follow up on their obligations.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the Commission's proposal for a directive to combat legal tax evasion by firms in the EU. Companies should pay taxes in the country where they make profits. The proposal contains six key measures and includes common definitions of terms such as 'permanent operation', 'tax haven' and 'minimum economic substance', which have hitherto been open to different interpretations. I trust that the Member States in the Council of Ministers (council of the EU) will finally approve the proposal, as in this case Parliament has only an advisory vote.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the fight against tax havens and tax evasion, because taxes should be paid where profits are generated. However, the proposed report is unacceptable given the reference to the introduction of a common consolidated corporate tax base, which is a risky step towards a single EU tax policy, thus undermining tax competition within the EU.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Bayer, from the Group of the Party of European Socialists and Democrats, on new rules to combat tax avoidance schemes used by multinationals. Every year, aggressive tax planning by multinationals costs the world's state budgets between 100 and 240 billion. Large sums, which are taken from public budgets and the possibility of redistributing wealth by investing in policies for employment, education and the fight against poverty. This phenomenon must necessarily be combated at European and global level, so that there is no unfair competition between States from the point of view of taxation. In this respect, the Commission's proposal is a step forward and the amendments tabled by the rapporteur help to further improve its substance. In particular, they emphasise a principle that I share: multinationals have to pay taxes where they generate their profits. Only in this way will it be possible to combat the use of tax havens effectively.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The Commission's proposal and the European Parliament's report reflect the sharpening of the contrasts between imperialist centres, but also parts of the capital, the EU's need for measures to protect its internal market and its monopolistic groups. It is not aimed at, nor is it enough, for a tax relief for the grassroots. In conditions of liberalisation of the movement of capital, multiple laws on the legal avoidance of businesses and special tax regimes, tax burdens fall on the backs of workers. It is no coincidence that in the EU-28 corporation tax represents only 2.5% of GDP from 40% of total taxation. The JRC was placed in white because the proposed arrangements do not change this correlation, they serve the same class orientation of EU tax policy. It is no coincidence that measures that could lead to a shift in tax burdens towards large capital are excluded, such as full nominalisation of shares, effective removal of trade and other secrets, taxation of all distributed and non-profitable enterprises, taxation of the current value of shares and changes in that value. The aim of EU policy and this directive is to regulate competition between opposing economic interests of portions of the capital.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I decided to support the report presented because I believe that it is important to harmonise European tax systems in order to create an economic and monetary union. I think that the Member States should find agreement on taxation, because fair and efficient taxation of businesses is the cornerstone of a single and credible market. I believe that businesses have to pay taxes where they make a profit, because national budgets around the world lose USD 100 billion to USD 240 billion each year due to aggressive tax planning by multinationals. This is a significant loss of state revenue, which reduces states' ability to invest to promote job creation, combat poverty, and develop effective health care systems for all.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe the fight against tax evasion and aggressive tax planning have to be high on the political agenda. I agree that better standards need to be established and certain loopholes need to be closed so as to make sure that corporate taxpayers operating businesses in several countries do not take advantage of disparities and shortcomings in order to reduce their tax bills. Nevertheless, I could not support the Parliament report ‘Rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market’ and, going along with the ECR Group’s position, abstained in the vote. This is because the report seeks to establish a number of rules and practices that may go against its very aim, as well as risk distorting the smooth functioning of the Single Market. There is also the question of proportionality and the respect of the Member States’ sovereignty. To summarise, I believe that the report in its current form, albeit containing some useful measures, is not up to the task of effectively tackling the problem of tax avoidance.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I agree with the idea of combating tax avoidance, but I voted against because the ideas contained in the Bayet report are not only too far interfering with member states' competences and common rules drawn up by the OECD, but also disproportionate to companies that pay their taxes fairly in the EU. The report makes it clear that harmonisation of European tax systems is the only way to achieve a well-functioning single market. In this spirit, your rapporteur recommends that the Commission present a proposal for a common corporate tax base as soon as possible and that the Council adopt it without delay.  In addition, the report proposed a number of stricter rules on work on tackling base erosion, which in practice could hit the European Union's competitiveness on a global scale and prove detrimental to companies that invest and pay taxes fairly, such as a provision that lowers the threshold for deducting interest when most tax avoidance in multinational companies takes place intra-group. The report also introduces the idea that it is the European Parliament that adequately monitors the implementation of this Directive on tax avoidance rules and that Member States are accountable to it, which, due to the division of treaty competences, is absolutely unacceptable by sovereign governments. The report was adopted in committee by a very small majority, indicating that there is no clear compromise in this House.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Bayet report because I agree with the principle that Parliament should use all means at its disposal to influence the Council in combating cross-border tax avoidance practices which cannot be effectively carried out by Member States alone. This report goes beyond the Commission's proposal to achieve an essential minimum degree of coordination within the Union and calls for greater coordination of the Union in the legal and tax framework. I would point out that this type of measure is central, not only to combat tax evasion, particularly by multinationals, but also and above all to restore the confidence of European citizens in their institutions.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a Council directive laying down rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market. The proposal for a directive provides, inter alia, for a stricter limit on the amount of interest amounts recognised as expenditure, as well as greater transparency in the functioning of the Funds and a pan-European list of tax havens. I agree that the fight against tax fraud and evasion and tax avoidance is a top political priority, as the abuses of aggressive tax planning are unacceptable in terms of the integrity of the internal market and social justice.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr It must be said that it is clear that the fight against terrorism cannot be defeated and terrorists cannot be combated only by methods of democracy, and it is clear that sometimes very active, even aggressive, special services must act to punish terrorists, as they say. But, on the other hand, it is a great disgrace that there are prisons in the territory of the European Union where people are tortured, and I join in urging Lithuania, Romania, Poland to provide a transparent, detailed, effective criminal investigation into the secret prisons of the Central Investigation Board. The same applies to other cases of collusion and cooperation, and of course I voted in favour. It is a very necessary and timely document, and in principle such things in general distort transatlantic cooperation between the United States and the European Union, and I repeat that I voted in favour.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on a resolution on the US Senate report on the CIA's use of torture. The resolution produced by the LIBE Committee was opposed to a resolution by my group, the EPP. I chose to support the resolution of my own group. When it did not receive the support of the majority, In the final vote on the LIBE report, I chose to abstain. I believe that the resolution is unnuanced and categorical with regard to the Member States that cooperate with the CIA in the fight against international terrorism. In other parts too, there is reason to be critical, for example, a proposal to give political asylum to detainees in Guantanamo. This also applies to the fact that the report is unsympathetic because, in some cases, national considerations need to be taken into account in the field of counter-terrorism.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The methods of interrogation and brutal torture used by the CIA following the 9/11 attacks are a stain on U.S. consciousness. The fact that European governments were complicit in their actions is not only immoral but a violation of our commitments to human rights and the values on which the EU is based.  Not only does the U.S. Senate report set out the scale of these crimes, but also clearly demonstrate that torture is not effective in preventing and prosecuting terrorist attacks. There can never be any justification for torture from the prism of international law, and we have an obligation to show that we take this matter very seriously, making sure that those responsible are accountable.  That is why I voted in favour of the resolution so that Member States should once and for all assume their responsibilities in these unfortunate events and formally and with facts that such serious human rights violations can never happen again with the collusion of European governments.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. After learning about the participation of different European Union states in the CIA's Extraordinary Surrender programme, through which torture and other human rights violations were perpetrated outside U.S. territory, an investigation into European involvement in the LIBE Commission was approved. After a year, the groups on the right of this house do not want this investigation to be maintained on facts that reveal the subalternity of the European Union to American interests, to the point of allowing serious human rights violations on their territory. I therefore voted in favour of renewing the mandate of the LIBE Commission, to investigate the facts and to prove the political responsibilities of the EU governments which enabled these shameful facts.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution, which calls for the fight against terrorism to be done within the framework of democratic rules and in accordance with member states' human rights obligations.  While this principle is honourable, we dispute the attacks in this text on certain Member States in the text (Italy, Poland and Romania).  In particular, the text accuses them of not conducting a full investigation. The resolution also calls on the Commission to present a white paper on the circumstances under which national security and trade secrets can be invoked, in order to increase transparency. On the contrary, I consider that only the national authorities of the Member States are in a way to determine whether the security of their country is at risk.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as it is rightly highly critical of the CIA and of EU Member States that facilitated or supported their torturous actions. The resolution calls for further and transparent investigations into allegations and for proper judicial punishments for those complicit in illegal torture. It also calls for those Member States and the US to be more cooperative with investigations.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. This resolution follows a previous resolution on the U.S. Senate report on the CIA's use of torture, in which we already condemned the CIA's illegal practices. We also called on the United States, the EU Member States and the Commission to launch investigations into the CIA's secret prisons and the cases of unlawful rendition, detention and torture that might have taken place on European territory between 2001 and 2006. However, it is clear that these recommendations have not yet been followed.  With the adoption of this resolution, Parliament is requesting answers from the Commission and the Council, and a report on investigations and prosecutions carried out before the end of June 2016. I voted in favour of this new resolution because such practices and possible complicity with these CIA programmes must not go unresolved or unpunished. To be complicit in such activities is a clear violation of Human Rights and European values, and those responsible must be prosecuted. The fight against terrorism must respect the rule of law, human dignity and fundamental freedoms.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the follow-up to Parliament's resolution of 11 February 2015 on the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA, because it reiterates the conviction that normal trials in civil courts are the best way to settle the status of Guantánamo detainees. It also insists that those in US custody should be charged soon, and should be tried in accordance with international standards of the rule of law or released. Next, it stresses in this context that the same standards of fair trial must apply to all without exception.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. It is the task of any constitutional state to guarantee the principle of the presumption of innocence and protection against torture. The European Union and every form of liberal democracy is based on these principles. Therefore, violations of these principles, regardless of the context in which they occur, must be pursued consistently. That is why I support the majority decision before us.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution requires that the fight against terrorism be done in accordance with democratic rules and in accordance with Member States' human rights obligations. The text attacks several Member States, in particular Romania, Italy and Poland, accused of failing to carry out serious investigations into cia activities on their own territory. The resolution therefore asks the Commission to present a white paper defining the circumstances in which national security and state secrets cannot be invoked in a democratic society, in order to essentially define what is not a concept of 'national security', which would be too frequently invoked.  The text congratulates Barack Obama, who has promised to close Guantanamo, while this extraterritorial prison is still open. The resolution also calls on Member States to offer asylum to detainees who have been officially declared free. While it is not a question of supporting the CIA's clandestine practices, it is inconceivable that the Commission could decide on what is state secrecy and national security. Therefore, I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As a whole I abstained on this report. I believe that transparency is the cornerstone of any democratic society and a government´s actions should be accountable to its people. National security should not be invoked by a government with the primary aim of blocking public scrutiny. However I voted against the resolution naming the United Kingdom as ‘complicit’ in the CIA’s detention and interrogation programme. I do not agree and voted as such against the resolution calling for more ‘fact-finding missions’ to be organised by the European Parliament to the UK and other Member States named in this document.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which reminds the United States that respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law is essential to the success of counter-terrorism policies.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution contains a number of eligible elements. It underlines that the emphasis on the war on terrorism has made the balance between the various state powers dangerously shifted towards the expansion of the powers of governments at the expense of parliaments and the judiciary. References to state secrets occur with unprecedented frequency, hampering the public investigation into alleged human rights violations. The document fundamentally correctly condemns the operation of the CIA's secret prisons and us anti-terror methods incompatible with human rights. At the same time, I do not agree with the repeated emphasis on the importance of transatlantic relations. Nevertheless, as it demands a full investigation and impeachment on this matter, which has been on the agenda for almost 10 years, I have therefore cast a vote in support.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This text congratulates Barack Obama in particular for promising in 2008 to close Guantanamo... while this great Nobel Peace Prize winner, under whose presidency the United States has never ceased to be at war, has not kept its promise.  It is precisely because I do not accept the clandestine activities of the CIA, which this report purports to condemn, that I have not been able to endorse a text of such complacency.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this resolution which reiterates the strong condemnation of the use of advanced interrogation techniques, which are prohibited by international law and constitute an offence, in particular, of the right not to be subjected to torture and the right to humane treatment.  The resolution also stresses that transatlantic cooperation based on common values such as the promotion of freedom and security, democracy and human rights is, and must be, a top priority in the European Union's external relations.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against international terrorism has been high on the political agenda for the last decade. The succession of attacks in various parts of the world, the increase in damage and casualties has been an important element in the history of the first two decades of the twenty-first century, a factor that has required wider state intervention to stem and defeat the terrorist phenomenon. On a number of occasions, however, this intervention has manifested itself in a dangerous way, through the use of instruments that constitute a clear violation of human rights. In a resolution of February 2015, the European Parliament strongly spoke out against the use of torture, illegal detention and inhuman and degrading treatment by the CIA, which had already been denounced in a US Senate report. The failure to comply with the demands made there is at the root of this new motion for a resolution which I have decided to support. The text strongly reiterates the need to continue investigating, prosecuting the perpetrators of human rights violations arising from the CIA's extraordinary rendition and secret detention programmes, and calls on the Council and the Commission to report on these facts by June 2016.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I believe that this is a very positive motion for a resolution as a whole, which delves into different aspects which we believe should be clarified, both on human rights and torture violations and on the existence of detention centres in Member States of the European Union.  I believe that on these facts, there must be complete transparency and all the actions that Parliament can take to investigate and sanction a number of human rights violations over the past decade. I welcome this report and therefore consider it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. Two weights and two measures! In today's voting session, we once again saw the extent to which many of our colleagues have a variable geometry design when it comes to defending human rights around the world. For Marxist Venezuela, the left immediately finds extorting circumstances, even though this regime does not respect even the most basic of democratic rules. But for the United States, the great Satan, who is nevertheless a democratic ally of the European Union, we pour into tearful hysteria to whom better. Let's not be fooled. All the secret services of all the countries of the world, even democratic states, use methods that are contrary to the constitutional principles of these countries. Is it necessary to forget to mention the emergency context in which the United States found itself after 9/11? Yes, we must denounce torture, all over the world, but not unilaterally.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 I support this Resolution because the best way to strengthen the values on which the European Union is based is to practice them and because we cannot afford, at a time when international terrorism violates the most basic rights, to close our eyes to intolerable violations of fundamental rights by the authorities of partner countries as important as the United States. I also believe that it is essential to completely eradicate these practices from European soil, so I agree to activate investigations in all Member States where, in collusion with American agents, torture of detainees could take place.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution relates to the follow-up to Parliament's resolution of 11 February 2015 on the US Senate report on the CIA's use of torture and makes it clear that a number of EU Member States, their administrations and leaders, as well as their security and intelligence officers, were complicit in the CIA programme. The resolution proposes, among other things, the fight against terrorism in accordance with democratic rules, but the text unfortunately attacks several states (Romania, Italy and Poland) on this point for not having carried out a full investigation.  In addition, the resolution commends Obama for promising in 2008 to close Guantanamo, while it is still not closed, and calls on member states to offer asylum to detainees who have been officially declared free. In light of the above, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I found this text partisan and not acceptable and therefore I did not support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The methods of interrogation and brutal torture used by the CIA following the 9/11 attacks are a stain on U.S. consciousness. The fact that European governments were complicit in their actions is not only immoral, but a violation of our commitments to human rights and the values on which the EU is based.  Not only does the U.S. Senate report set out the scale of these crimes, but also clearly demonstrate that torture is not effective in preventing and prosecuting terrorist attacks. There can never be any justification for torture from the prism of international law and we have an obligation to show that we take this matter very seriously by making sure that those responsible are accountable.  That is why I voted in favour of the resolution so that Member States can once and for all assume their responsibilities in these unfortunate events and formally and with facts that such serious human rights violations can never happen again with the collusion of European governments.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As has already been said by this Parliament, the European Union and its Member States consider any inhuman or degrading treatment, whether aimed at its own citizens or any third-country national, to be reprehensible and unusable. The just need to combat terrorism, to prevent it, to study it and to understand its dynamics must not diminish the guarantees, protections and sensitivities that our culture has erected as a bulwark of human life, its dignity and the right to a just trial by any human being. It must also be reiterated that, on the part of all eu and NATO intelligence authorities, there must be full cooperation and information sharing in all legal counter-terrorism operations. It is reprehensible that the CIA has carried out numerous operations on European soil not only without having been authorised by the country on which it was based, but without even informing its local counterparts. The European Parliament must strongly reaffirm its authority and the rights of European citizens in the face of actions that have often proved to be in violation of individual rights.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution requires that the fight against terrorism be done within the framework of democratic rules and in accordance with member states' human rights obligations. While this point does not require any comment, we dispute the attacks on certain Member States, in the text, notably Italy, Poland and Romania, for not carrying out a further investigation.  The resolution also calls on the Commission to present a white paper on the circumstances under which national security and trade secrets can be invoked, in order to increase transparency. On the contrary, we consider that only the national authorities of the Member States are in a way to determine whether the security of their country is threatened, but brussels technocrats do not like it.  In those circumstances, I voted against this resolution.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The methods of interrogation and brutal torture used by the CIA following the 9/11 attacks are a stain on U.S. consciousness. The fact that European governments were complicit in their actions is not only immoral but a violation of our commitments to human rights and the values on which the EU is based.  Not only does the U.S. Senate report set out the scale of these crimes, but also clearly demonstrate that torture is not effective in preventing and prosecuting terrorist attacks. There can never be any justification for torture from the prism of international law and we have an obligation to show that we take this matter very seriously by making sure that those responsible are accountable.  That is why I voted in favour of the resolution so that Member States should once and for all assume their responsibilities in these unfortunate events and formally and with facts that such serious human rights violations can never happen again with the collusion of European governments.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report which strongly condemns the use by the CIA of enhanced interrogation techniques, which are prohibited by international law and which violate the right to freedom, security, humane treatment, the prohibition of torture, the presumption of innocence, due process, legal assistance and equal protection by the law. The position taken in the 2009 US-EU Declaration is clear: joint efforts to combat terrorism must comply with international law obligations, in particular international humanitarian and human rights law. The United States of America plays a crucial role in the fight against terrorism, including in Europe. Transatlantic cooperation in the fight against terrorism must be preserved for the common good of citizens on both sides of the Atlantic and with full respect for fundamental human rights and privacy as guaranteed by EU legislation. We therefore need to continue the political dialogue between our transatlantic partners on the issues of security and the fight against terrorism, including with regard to the protection of civil rights and human rights, in order to combat terrorism effectively.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was critical of the interrogation techniques used by the CIA, on European soil. The resolution was also supported by NGOs such as World Organisation Against Torture, Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch, and further criticises EU Member States that facilitated or supported these actions on their soil. It calls for further transparent investigations and proper judicial punishments.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the resolution because the already conducted investigation by the European Parliament’s Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs into the alleged transportation and illegal detention of prisoners by the Central Intelligence Agency of the United States in some of the Member States of the European Union has not resulted in any new conclusions that would change the already existing state of affairs. I do not agree that any further investigations could change anything and I believe that this case should be closed.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I obviously voted in favour of the resolution. I would like to remind you that transparency is the cornerstone of every democratic society, the condition of the government's responsibility towards its citizens. I am therefore deeply concerned about the growing tendency of governments to invoke national security with the aim of blocking public scrutiny by citizens. It is extremely dangerous to disable any mechanism of democratic accountability, effectively reasting the government of its responsibilities.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against the report as it contains several points of friction.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted today on the follow-up to Parliament's resolution of 11 February 2015 on the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA. I think it is obvious that this issue has implications for the protection of European citizens and Europe's attitude towards the use of torture. As I believe that we must take a clear line against such practices, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this resolution because I disagree on some points of the resolution. I am very aware of the strategic importance of transatlantic relations at this time and I am convinced that these relations must be consolidated on the basis of respect for the national rule of law. I would also like to add that the United States of America is playing a key role in the fight against terrorism, including at European level. I would therefore have preferred a resolution more geared towards greater cooperation between the Member States and the United States so that we could have a more intensive exchange of information between their secret services so that they would be given full democratic control of these services and their activities.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is highly important that we see increased cooperation and exchange of information between countries’ secret intelligence and security agencies, so we can ensure full democratic scrutiny of those agencies and their activities through appropriate internal, executive, judicial and independent parliamentary oversight.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The alleged use of European countries by the CIA for the transport and illegal detention of prisoners is a matter that was first investigated by the European Parliament.  More facts have been known very slowly, including through a daunting report by the US Senate itself. Unfortunately, much is still to be clarified, too many responsibilities are yet to be established.  Even within the European Union and in strict compliance with the principle of subsidiarity, there are several Member States that have not wanted to cooperate with this Parliament. Or not even with each other. Unfortunately, too, many of the recommendations that have been made have not been followed up.  The concerns of almost ten years remain current. It is not only a question of discovering the truth, but also of preventing such ostentatious violations of fundamental rights from happening again. All the more important ly, today, we seek a balance between security and individual freedoms. I believe that this resolution is, at a time, excessive in its language and even instrumentalized for ideological propaganda. However, its content remains true and the European Parliament cannot be scoffed at its responsibilities.  I therefore support this resolution.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. After learning about the participation of different European Union states in the CIA's Extraordinary Surrender programme, through which torture and other human rights violations were perpetrated outside U.S. territory, an investigation into European involvement in the LIBE Commission was approved.
