After a year, the groups on the right of this house do not want this investigation to be maintained on facts that reveal the subalternity of the European Union to American interests, to the point of allowing serious human rights violations on their territory. I therefore voted in favour of renewing the mandate of the LIBE Commission, to investigate the facts and to prove the political responsibilities of the EU governments which enabled these shameful facts.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The US Senate intelligence report highlighted the CIA's use of torture between 2001 and 2006 as part of its detention and interrogation programs. The case of the Guantánamo Bay detention centre, where the treatment of detainees has violated respect for human rights and international law, is exemplary. The previous European Parliament had already called, in 2013, on the current Parliament to continue to fulfil and execute the mandate given to it by the Temporary Committee on the alleged complicity of European countries with the CIA in the transport and illegal detention of prisoners. I support this resolution condemning the use of enhanced interrogation techniques prohibited by international law and deploring the apathy shown by Member States and EU institutions with regard to the recognition of the multiple violations of fundamental rights and cases of torture that took place in the EU between 2001 and 2006, the conduct of investigations into this matter and the handing over of those responsible to justice. I believe that transatlantic cooperation, while essential for the USA and the EU, especially in the current context of the joint fight against terrorism, must not be separated from respect for fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This resolution follows the European Parliament's investigation into the CIA's alleged use of torture. I personally condemn the use of torture and believe that all aspects of international law and the Charter of Fundamental Rights should be fully respected in this regard. I therefore fully support independent national investigations on this issue. At the same time, I would like to point out that the European Parliament, in accordance with the EU Treaties, does not have competence in the field of national security, which in this case should remain unchanged. The aim of the resolution is to ask whether the Council has fully dispelled the concerns expressed in the latest resolution and whether it has proposed safeguards to ensure respect for human rights in the exchange of intelligence. The resolution also contains a number of critical statements concerning the United States and is highly critical of a number of EU Member States allegedly involved in CIA assistance. However, as a result of the lack of adequate powers of the European Union and the lack of access to specific data, the European Parliament could not gather enough information, statistics and witnesses to approximate the scale of the problem. As a result, much remains in the realm of conjec. That is why I decided to vote for them.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the resolution on the follow-up to Parliament's resolution of 11 February 2015 on the US Senate report on the CIA's use of torture. I disapprove of several provisions of this text carried by the left-wing groups in the European Parliament which put forward a misconception of national security.  I reject the idea that the fight against terrorism is being used as a pretext by governments to extend their powers to the detriment of European citizens. However, we must condemn in the strongest possible terms any use of torture. I also stress the importance of shedding light on the activities and use of torture carried out by the CIA, as well as on the famous "black sites" and secret prisons in Europe. That's why I abstained.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I believe that real democracies should never breach citizens’ fundamental rights or international law and should never resort to enhanced interrogation techniques or torture for whatever reasons.  The events of 9/11 and the war on terrorism have given rise to an atmosphere which has allowed for the violation of Europe’s human rights principles in the name of security. While the safety of our citizens should be at the forefront of our priorities, it is essential that we recognise that the European Union is based on a clear set of values, and we should not allow these to be undermined in any way.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it presents many very problematic points, accusing, among other things, on several occasions the Member States of the European Union and the European Commission of "apathy" regarding cases of human rights violations and torture on European territory. These charges are inadmissible.  The EPP group to which I belong had proposed an alternative, more moderate resolution. While condemning the use of torture, this resolution recalled the primacy of national parliaments and judicial institutions, and emphasized the importance of cooperation between the United States and the European Union, particularly in the area of counter-terrorism. I am of course in favour of this cooperation, which is absolutely necessary, just as I am deeply committed to respect for fundamental rights.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The resolution aims to ensure that the fight against terrorism is done within the framework of democratic rules and in accordance with member states' human rights obligations. However, the text attacks several Member States such as Romania, Poland, or Italy, which are considered apathetic on the subject.  He congratulated Obama on his 2008 commitment to close Guantanamo, which was never followed up.  The text denounces the tendency of governments to invoke "national security" excessively and calls on Member States to offer asylum to detainees who have been officially declared free.  For these reasons, I voted against this resolution.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support the resolution on the follow-up to the resolution on the US Senate report on the cia's use of torture. I and my political group strongly oppose the use of torture and strongly support respect for the principles of international law and the Charter of Human Rights. I support independent investigations into the subject, but I believe that in the EU treaties such powers are not given to the European Parliament.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The US Central Intelligence Agency has proven to have secret detention centres within European territory, bribe governments, organisations and bodies, promote corruption and in most cases violate human rights and the presumption of innocence. Under the pretext of combating terrorism, the balance between governments, parliaments and the judiciary is dangerously shifting. The European institutions, the European Court of Human Rights, all the so-called guardians of the protection of fundamental rights in the political persecution of nationalist movements are 'deaf' and are cut only in cases where they are 'politically'.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. More than a year after the publication of the US Senate report on the cia's use of torture, I regret the lack or slow pace of investigations, reduced accountability and excessive reliance on state secrecy. None of the Member States has carried out comprehensive and effective investigations to bring perpetrators of crimes provided for by international and national law to justice. Joint counter-terrorism efforts must comply with obligations under international law and the US must continue investigations and cooperate with all requests from European countries regarding the CIA programme.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution focuses on the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA.  It reiterates the strong condemnation of torture practices (enhanced interrogation techniques), prohibited by international law.  It is deeply concerned about the 'apathy' shown by the Member States and the EU institutions regarding the recognition of the multiple violations of fundamental rights and torture that took place on European soil between 2001 and 2006. But a lot remains unsaid. Much is omitted by the resolution. The US is an imperialist power that considers itself above any legal obligation, which disrespects international law and which, ironically, has continuously occupyseveral sovereign countries in the name of defending human rights.  The current Us President Barack Obama, despite all his promises, has not yet closed the Guantanamo prison. There is no guarantee that, in the current framework of murderous wars in which the US is the main aggressor, similar events or even more perverse and attentive contours of human dignity cannot be taking place.  For the foregoing, the abstention vote.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution on the use of torture by the CIA. We must condemn violent practices that do not respect human rights and it is essential that we work to prevent and combat them. However, the European Union has no competence in the field of national security, which is why it has no legitimacy to launch investigations within Member States potentially involved in supporting such practices. I believe that the seriousness of this issue deserves an apolitical approach, capable of launching objective investigations in order to limit as much as possible the inhumane practices of recourse to torture.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Union has long been a leader in the protection of fundamental rights and freedoms. Just as we draw attention to their violations within the Member States of the European Union, we are also uncompromisingly pointing out violations of fundamental rights in other countries. With respect to transatlantic cooperation between the EU and the US, we call on the US to make every effort to ensure that eu citizens use torture to the same extent as US citizens.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the resolution because it appears to be excessively unrealistic.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The US Central Intelligence Agency has proven to have secret detention centres within European territory, bribe governments, organisations and bodies, promote corruption and in most cases violate human rights and the presumption of innocence. That is why I am voting against the follow-up to Parliament's resolution of 11 February 2015 on the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The climate of impunity regarding the CIA programs still represents a menace towards the values of justice, equity and dignity on which our societies are built on. We cannot forget that the concepts of democracy human rights and rule of law are the core priority of our society, and that the issue of security should not put our values aside. These are some of the reasons why I strongly support the question to the Council. A follow-up on the Council’s declaration acknowledging Member States’ involvement in the CIA programme and the difficulties encountered by Member States in the context of inquiries is needed. Council should have been holding hearings with relevant EU security agencies to clarify their knowledge of Member States’ involvement in the CIA programme and the EU’s response. Moreover, it should have proposed safeguards so as to guarantee respect for human rights in intelligence-sharing.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution with the determination that human rights are inalienable and must be respected wherever it may be, the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) and therefore the U.S. government has not respected the rights of its prisoners, sometimes subjecting many of them to torture. The European Union is at the side of the US in all the way to the fight against terrorism, but there is international legislation that we must respect.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The brutal methods of interrogation and torture used by the CIA following the September 11, 2001 attacks are a stain on US consciousness. The fact that European governments were complicit in their actions is not only immoral but a violation of our commitments to human rights and EU values.  Not only does the US Senate report set out the scale of these crimes, but also clearly demonstrate that torture is not effective in preventing and prosecuting terrorist attacks. Any justification for torture from the prism of international law is unacceptable. In this sense, we have an obligation to show that we take this matter very seriously by demanding that those responsible be held accountable.  I have therefore voted in favour of the resolution so that Member States should once and for all assume their responsibilities in these unfortunate events and formally and with fact that such serious human rights violations can never occur again with the collusion of European governments.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The methods of interrogation and brutal torture used by the CIA following the 9/11 attacks are a stain on U.S. consciousness. name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the resolution on 'follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 11 February 2015 on the report of the United States Senate on torture by the CIA', as this text has nothing to do with the original title. It is a purely ideological, disproportionate and completely inappropriate attack on transatlantic cooperation in the current presidential elections.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I do not support the motion for a resolution. It does not reflect the interests of EU citizens, but merely serves Russia's agenda. Some Member States are being made serious accusations without any solid evidence.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 International intelligence relations are now of paramount importance to ensure an adequate level of security in Western countries increasingly subject to terrorist attacks. However, in the name of a more effective security system, we cannot derogate from the fundamental rights of individuals or, above all, diminish the role of this Parliament, the committees in which it is set up and the work of Members. That is why I join my colleagues in asking the Council to clarify the alleged cases of illegal transport and detention of prisoners in European countries by the CIA, in the light of the recommendations already issued by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, in association with the Committee on Foreign Affairs and, in particular, the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Consumer Protection. , the Subcommittee on Human Rights.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I believe that this is a very positive motion for a resolution as a whole, which delves into different aspects which we believe should be clarified, both on human rights and torture violations and on the existence of detention centres in Member States of the European Union.  I believe that on these facts, there must be complete transparency and all the actions that Parliament can take to investigate and sanction a number of human rights violations over the past decade. I welcome this report and therefore consider it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The methods of interrogation and brutal torture used by the CIA following the 9/11 attacks are a stain on U.S. consciousness. name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. This resolution follows a previous resolution on the US Senate report on the CIA's use of torture, in which we already condemned the CIA's illegal practices. We also called on the United States, the EU Member States and the Commission to launch investigations into the CIA's secret prisons and the cases of unlawful rendition, detention and torture that might have taken place on European territory between 2001 and 2006. However, these recommendations have not yet been followed.  I voted in favour of this new resolution because such practices and possible complicity with these CIA programmes must not go unresolved or unpunished. To be complicit in such activities is a clear violation of Human Rights and European values, and those responsible must be prosecuted. The fight against terrorism must respect the rule of law, human dignity and fundamental freedoms. With the adoption of this resolution, which I welcome, Parliament is asking for answers from the Commission and the Council, and a report on investigations and prosecutions carried out before the end of June 2016.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. Concerns were expressed regarding the obstacles encountered by national parliamentary and judicial investigations into some Member States’ involvement in the CIA programme, the abuse of state secrecy, and the undue classification of documents resulting in the termination of criminal proceedings and leading to de facto impunity of perpetrators of human rights violations.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although we voted in favour of the resolution as the main message is condemnation of the CIA's use of torture, this does not mean that we are still not troubled by references in the resolution which indirectly disincrimin the American authorities by highlighting the war on terror as an alibi.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution which strongly condemned the US-led Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) rendition and secret detention programme involving multiple human rights violations, including unlawful and arbitrary detention, abduction, torture and other inhumane or degrading treatment and violation of the non-refoulement principle. In addition, Parliament has repeatedly called for full investigations into the involvement of EU Member States in the CIA’s secret detention and extraordinary rendition programme. A recent study of the CIA’s Detention and Interrogation Programme and its use of various forms of torture on detainees between 2001 and 2006 revealed new facts which reinforced allegations that a number of EU Member States, their authorities and officials and agents of their security and intelligence services had been complicit in the CIA’s secret detention and extraordinary rendition programme. In addition, I was happy that the Parliament reiterated its strong condemnation of the use of enhanced interrogation techniques, which are prohibited under international law. Finally, I was glad that the Resolution did repeat its call on the USA to continue to investigate and prosecute the multiple human rights violations resulting from the CIA rendition and secret detention programmes led by the previous US administration and to publish a study on the issue.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. THE ALFA abhors all forms of torture and is firmly committed to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. However, we believe that, in the event of suspected infringements, independent investigations should be carried out at national level, supported by the EU, in order to obtain complete and accurate information. If it is also the task of the European Parliament to draw attention to these matters, it has no power or competence in the area of national security. In the case of the resolution on the US Senate report on the cia's use of torture, it had no access to the necessary documents or to appropriate means of intervention. Parliament should therefore remain aware of what is happening, but should have the matter dealt with by competent authorities. That is why I did not vote in favour of the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. A year ago, Parliament passed a resolution denouncing the "climate of impunity" in Member States, some of which have reportedly allowed secret CIA prisons on their territories. The EPP and I voted against this text for the same reasons that led us to reject this new resolution. Indeed, Parliament denounces, accuses and orders criminal investigations, even targeting the Council of Europe, which had the audacity to close its investigation.  Unfortunately, these are only assumptions and not the result of a thorough investigation based on hard evidence.  To assert that governments act "for the sole or sole purpose of preventing control by citizens or the judiciary" and that the balance of power is dangerously altered for the benefit of governments are value judgments that have nothing to do with the purpose of this investigation.  Firstly, I find it irresponsible that an institution composed of democratically elected parliamentarians suggests that the institutional and constitutional order of the Member States is not democratic and that we are witnessing authoritarian excesses. Secondly, if investigations are to be carried out, it is up to the judicial authorities to decide and certainly not to the European Parliament.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a motion for a resolution on further measures regarding the European Parliament Resolution of 11 February 2015 on the US Senate report on torture by the CIA, as I believe that respect for human dignity, human rights and fundamental freedoms should always be placed at the highest level of any policy, every principle, report, law or rule.  I certainly agree with the European Parliament's decision that strongly condemned the US Central Intelligence Agency's (CIA) extradition and covert detention programme, which entails multiple human rights violations, deprivation of liberty, kidnapping, torture and other forms of inhuman or degrading treatment.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The resolution calls on the Commission to present a white paper on the circumstances in which national security and state secrets cannot be invoked in a democratic society, in order to essentially define what is not a "national security" concept. He wants transparency in the fight against terrorism and attacks the growing tendency of governments to over-invoke "national security". He congratulated Obama for promising in 2008 to close Guantanamo, which is still not closed, and called on member states to offer asylum to detainees who have been officially declared free. It is not a question of supporting the clandestine or other activities of the CIA, but it has enough elements to not support it, hence my vote against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Respect for fundamental human rights and the rule of law is not only a cornerstone of the EU, but also an essential element in the effective fight against terrorism. In any case, inhumane practices of investigation and abuse are reprehensible. In this case, however, I believe that the decision to investigate cia misconduct reported by the US Senate should be left to the responsibility of individual Member States. That is why I abstained this time. The EU as such should, of course, focus on constructive dialogue with the US, a capable ally in the fight against the global phenomenon of terrorism. In my opinion, effective exchange of information, as well as administrative assistance or sharing of best practices, is key.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution, which makes a real case against the Member States and the European institutions accused of "apathy" when it comes to admitting human rights violations and torture on European territory. The political group to which I belong, the EPP, had proposed a more moderate alternative resolution which, while strongly condemning the CIA's secret programme, stressed the importance of cooperation between Europe and the United States in the fight against terrorism.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – Although this resolution repeatedly emphasises the transatlantic partnership, the report is very critical of CIA practices in Europe and condemns the torture prisons maintained by the CIA. The rapporteur also calls for a faster approach to reconnaissance missions. I therefore agree with this resolution.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as it voices serious concerns at the apathy shown by Member States and EU institutions about recognising the multiple fundamental rights violations and torture that took place in US CIA rendition operations on European soil between 2001 and 2006, and it urges them to investigate these violations and to bring those responsible for or complicit in them to justice.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)

Parliament should therefore continue to monitor the events closely, but should have the matter dealt with by the authorities responsible for this. That is why I did not vote in favour of the report.

name: 0Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since I have long opposed the TTIP, I understand that the Commission, as the negotiator of this Treaty, is in a very difficult situation in the context of Parliament's resolution of 11 February 2015 on the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA. The Commission is due to report to plenary by the end of June 2016 on the follow-up to the recommendations and requests made by the European Parliament in its investigation into the alleged transport and illegal detention of CIA detainees in European countries and in its subsequent resolutions, and on the conclusions of the various investigations and prosecutions conducted in the Member States. It means he's going to have to choose between good relations with the U.S. and the rule of law. However, EU citizens who respect human rights and the right to justice expect the European institutions to defend these values against all states, regardless of their global importance. I hope that we will also one day appeal to the US to sign all amendments to the Geneva Convention, to recognise the International Criminal Court, to eliminate surviving segregation in American society, to provide adequate protection for workers and to stop destabilising countries that are close to our borders. Then we will be a true sovereign and defender of European values and interests. I therefore voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it denounces the United States' invocation of state secrecy. In my view, every state has the right to protect its sovereignty by invoking state secrecy.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the follow-up to the U.S. Senate report on the CIA's use of torture. Of course, I support the principle that the fight against terrorism must be done with respect for the rule of law, human dignity, human rights and fundamental freedoms. However, there are several points in this resolution that are contrary to the notion of Member States' sovereignty.  Paragraph 22, for example, in which Parliament states that it is "deeply concerned by the growing tendency of governments to over-invoke national security"." The concept of state security, in quotation marks in the text, is also attacked in paragraph 16 and in recital B. Another problem is the request for Member States to offer asylum to Guantanamo detainees who have been officially declared free. As if in France and other Member States, we do not yet have enough problems.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. In the context of an end to the use of torture against detainees by CIA agents between 2001 and 2006, with the release last year of the US Senate report, the text seems to highlight principles. Indeed, it insists on absolute respect for human rights, the importance of democratic rules in a climate of the fight against terrorism. The rapporteur also calls on the Commission to present a white paper redefining the concept of national security, while warning Member States against their growing tendency to use the term as a pretext.  Despite these wise remarks, some of the remarks are hypocritical, notably when the rapporteur congratulates Barack Obama on having promised in 2008 to close Guantanamo, which is still not the case. It also calls on Member States to offer asylum to officially released detainees. I cannot support these statements, and therefore abstained.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I do not agree that the EU should be involved in the CIA's investigation of torture. This is possibly the case for those EU Member States where such torture is alleged to have took place.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This resolution primarily recalls how extremely important it is, in the current situation of global uncertainty and the threat of terrorism, to preserve the strategic nature of relations with the US and to further strengthen respect for multilateralism, the rule of law and the settlement of mutual disputes through negotiations. It is imperative that Member States investigate allegations of alleged secret prisons on their territory, where the CIA holds prisoners under illegal programs and prosecutes those involved in these illegal operations.  So far, only one fact-finding cross-party mission has been carried out in Romania and the European Parliament should send more fact-finding missions to Member States that the US Senate study says have participated in the deprivation of liberty and interrogation programme. As no report has yet been made on the investigations and prosecution of prisoners in some EU Member States, I have not endorsed this resolution.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Any criminal investigation must be conducted in accordance with laws and international agreements, the rule of law, respect for human rights and freedoms and respect for human dignity. The facts demonstrating the participation of some EU Member States in the CIA's programme for secret detention and extrandition are based on corrupt practices. They are reprehensible and must therefore be investigated and punished. Otherwise, the risk of the same behaviour increases in the future and confidence in EU democracy remains called into question.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Motion for a Resolution on the follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 11 February 2015 on the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA, because the Motion for a Resolution is substantiated.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the Member States referred to in the 'Investigation of alleged cases of illegal transport and detention of prisoners by the CIA in European countries', have carried out the necessary investigations under international and national law or to ensure clarification of the situation. I voted against Parliament's resolution because, unfortunately, the allegations are escalating and are not based on concrete evidence. As for the mention of Romania, accusations have been issued without any basis in the past. However, Romania has responded to all requests from the European institutions and has received on several occasions over the years the CIA Commission and the parliamentary documentary mission of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs in Bucharest. All information has been made available. Romania carried out the necessary investigations and made the results available to those concerned. I believe that it is time for this dossier to be closed, concrete steps to be taken towards combating terrorism and efforts to protect contemporary society, which is currently facing a number of challenges.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text.  The principle of this resolution seems good in itself: the text requires that the fight against terrorism be carried out within the framework of democratic rules and in accordance with the obligations of Member States in the field of human rights.  But the text attacks several Member States (notably Romania, Poland, Italy) for not conducting a full investigation and contains several points that we do not agree with. In particular, the resolution calls on Member States to offer asylum to detainees who have been officially declared free from Guantanamo or to present a white paper on the circumstances in which national security and state secrets cannot be invoked in a democratic society.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The involvement of several EU Member States, their authorities, officials and agents of their security and intelligence services in the torture of prisoners is the central theme of this report. The torture of prisoners must be strongly condemned and full information at European level is desirable.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The resolution "absolutely" condemns torture. And underlines the futility of national security: "the conclusions drawn by the U.S. Senate that the violent and illegal methods used by the CIA failed to provide intelligence that would have prevented further terrorist attacks."  But in the face of the CIA's actions on European soil, this timid text merely "regrets that no author has yet to be held accountable and that the US government does not cooperate with the Member States of the Union". Or politely asks the US authorities "not to practice the death penalty on detainees at Guantanamo." For my part, I believe that politeness is not the order of the day with torturers. And I note that not for a moment does the resolution consider questioning our relations with the United States or suspending the ongoing negotiations on the large transatlantic market. Finally, while NATO has acted as a full partner of the CIA and participated in efforts to conceal the existence of these secret prisons, not a word of the resolution proposes the removal of NATO bases in the countries concerned.  I abstain on this hypocritical text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The resolution requires that the fight against terrorism be done within the framework of democratic rules and in accordance with Member States' human rights obligations. I support this approach, of course.  However, I regret the trial of several Member States over the way in which they conducted their investigation. Other points are also criticised (asylum for free prisoners, conditional national security).  As a result, I opposed this resolution.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of this resolution on the CIA's use of torture. Following its resolution last year on the US Senate report, the European Parliament reiterates its strong opposition to the use of torture and calls on the United States to investigate and prosecute the perpetrators.  Parliament also reiterates its call on the United States to cooperate fully with the Member States of the Union. The use of torture is an intolerable violation of the most basic human rights and, at a time when the fight against terrorism is more than ever prompting the Union and the United States to intensify their cooperation, it must be based on respect for international law, human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing , the European Union is founded on respect for democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms, respect for human dignity and respect for international law, not only within the framework of its internal policies, but also its external dimension. Human dignity and fundamental freedoms should also be respected in the fight against terrorism. It is therefore essential to condemn the CIA's us-led rendition and secret detention programme, which has resulted in numerous human rights violations, including illegal and arbitrary detention, torture and other ill-treatment. The prohibition of torture is a human right which must under no circumstances be derogable and forms the so-called hard core of international and European human rights treaties. It is also unacceptable to use widespread interrogation techniques, which are prohibited under international law and which, inter alia, violate the right to freedom, security, humane treatment, protection against torture, the presumption of innocence, the right to a fair trial, legal aid and equal legal protection. Effective counter-terrorism measures and respect for human rights do not contradict each other, but complement each other and support each other. I welcome the actions of US President Barack Obama in his ongoing efforts to close the detention facility at the US military base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, and to release detainees who have not been charged.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution, which repeats its call on the USA to continue to investigate and prosecute the multiple human rights violations resulting from the CIA rendition and secret detention programmes led by the previous US administration, and to cooperate with all requests from EU Member States for information, extradition or effective remedies for victims in connection with the CIA programme. The resolution encourages the US SSCI to publish its study of the CIA’s Detention and Interrogation Programme in full and underlines the fundamental conclusion reached by the US Senate that the violent and illegal methods applied by the CIA failed to generate intelligence that prevented further terrorist attacks. The resolution also recalls its absolute condemnation of torture and enforced disappearance.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 A motion for a resolution was tabled by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the PPE Group in Parliament on the follow-up to the Resolution of the United States Senate on the cia's use of torture on 11 February 2015. Parliament voted in favour of the former. As the draft resolution, in my view, lacked the expected balance, I abstained from voting.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament through multiple resolutions and the establishment of the Temporary Committee strongly condemned the alleged use by the CIA of European countries for the transport and illegal detention of prisoners. In view of the pillars on which the European project is based, in particular the rule of law, I also believe that no reason justifies the violation of human rights.  However, I cannot be in favour of a report which makes it unclear the separation of powers, the cornerstone of a rule of law, and which repeatedly makes references and suggests clear intrusions of the political system into the judicial system of the Member States.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This text contains too many elements (he congratulates Obama for promising in 2008 to close Guantanamo, when it is still not closed, asks member states to offer asylum to detainees who have been officially declared free...) so that I can support him.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I could not support a text that denounces the strengthening of security in the Member States of the European Union, in particular through mechanisms that allow governments to react more quickly, because of terrorism. The resolution also called on Member States to offer asylum to detainees declared free by Guantanamo.  I therefore voted against the resolution put forward by the LIBE committee.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the motion for a resolution. The European Parliament has already called for respect for the rule of law, human dignity, human rights and fundamental freedoms in the fight against terrorism. Parliament strongly condemned the Extradition and Secret Detention Programme carried out by the Association States, with the intervention of the CIA, in which a number of human rights violations were committed, including unlawful and arbitrary detention, torture and other forms of abuse, and called on the US authorities not to impose the death penalty on Guantánamo detainees.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this motion for a resolution about the US Senate report regarding the use of torture by the CIA because the report creates an unjustified difference between Romania and the other suspected countries.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report, because by coordinating the Romanian Parliament's investigation into this issue, having access to official documents and following the subject in the light of the statements of officials, but also of journalistic revelations over the years, I can say that, if there was the so-called "Bright Light" (a building that is said to have been used as a detention centre), the judicial authorities should have been aware of its existence and not the Foreign Ministry , as claimed in this report. In addition, the existence of this detention centre was revealed by a journalistic investigation which I respect, but my legal group leads me, in the absence of a criminal investigation, to have reservations about the allegations made in the context of these disclosures.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report on the grounds that it disproportionately interferes with military and intelligence relations between the US and European countries that are members of NATO. This is not for the European Parliament, not to mention that this can also be seen as calling into question the fight against terrorism. The interference with the powers of the States is a call on the Commission to define the concept of 'national security' and the requirements relating to the course of criminal proceedings in the EU Member States. It is also completely inappropriate to call on Member States to offer asylum to prisoners who have been officially acquitted and released from Guantánamo. I see no reason why released Guantánamo prisoners should have greater rights in the EU than other asylum seekers.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because it clearly shows the involvement of several EU Member States and their authorities and officials, as well as agents of their security and intelligence services, in the CIA's secret detention and extraordinary transfer programme.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Countries must respect human rights and fundamental freedoms, this also concerns prisoners.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The issue of secret flights is a stain on the recent history of Europe and its member states. Not only have the various executives been complicit in a situation that undermines all the fundamental rights that are the basis of the European Union, but many months later most of these governments have denied active collaboration to the various investigations that have been carried out. It gives me enormous sadness that, by political pressure, we would tended to ally ourselves with examples that the end justifies the means, to defend human rights without any means. I hope that this resolution will serve to show that we do not give up from the European Parliament, and that from the Committee on Fundamental Freedoms of which I am a member we will continue to take responsibility.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I reiterate the importance of human rights and their protection in the european Union's legal order and believe that transatlantic cooperation in the fight against terrorism must respect fundamental rights. I therefore believe that cooperation between the European Union and the United States, which plays a key role in European external action, must promote freedom and fundamental values. In view of what has been said, I support the point of view of my political group.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I consider it important to stand up for the human rights of every man and to ensure compliance with all the basic principles deriving from these rights. I am convinced that we need to make further efforts to act towards de-escalating open crises in the world and prevent them early enough so that there are no violations of anyone's rights.  Each image in these crises has its own face and reverse, and in order to achieve the desired de-escalation of crises, it is necessary to cooperate together and dialogue based on understanding the real situation, not on insinuations that can lead us in the opposite direction to the one we all strive for together. We must be aware of the fact that this is a very sensitive area and that decisions cannot be made provoked by pretentious issues. If we want to reach an understanding and agreement on issues that inevitably concern human rights, then we must focus our concentration on accepting only those measures that will take into account the overall picture of the application of testing techniques prohibited under international law, and not concentrate only on individual segments taken out of context.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This text contains too many questionable elements (he congratulates Obama for promising in 2008 to close Guantanamo, when it is still not closed, asks member states to offer asylum to detainees who have been officially declared free...) so that I can support him. So I'm voting against it.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution denounces several obstacles that have been placed on investigations and the lack of objective clarification of the facts and consequent convictions. It reiterates its strong condemnation of the use of forced interrogation techniques, which are prohibited by international law and which violate, inter alia, the rights to freedom, security, human e-treatment, not to be tortured, to the presumption of innocence, to an impartial trial, legal advice and fair protection under the law. It refers to the 'apathy' of the Member States and the European institutions in the recognition of the multiple violations of fundamental rights and torture that have taken place on European soil. More than 50 countries, including Portugal, have covered the secret extrajudicial transfer program of prisoners suspected of terrorism on CIA flights, a demonstration of the Us as an imperialist power that acts in disrespect for international law and that persists as one of the countries that most promotes the violation of human rights. The Guantanamo military base and its concentration camp where the most barbaric practices have been forced on detainees, most of them innocent people who have not even been charged, are an example of this.  It is essential to condemn the action of the United States and this is not read a word.  For the foregoing, the abstention vote.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒There is no doubt that the fight against terrorism must include robust mechanisms for the protection of fundamental human rights and freedoms. Despite the growing terrorist danger, as well as the fact that the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency have contributed to the punishment and prevention of a large number of terrorist activities around the world, I believe that the fight against terrorism must not deviate from the fundamental obligations of international law.  The United States has approached the CIA's detention and interrogation program constructively and critically. I cannot therefore fully agree to the proposal for further action on the European Parliament Resolution on the US Senate report, as it could serve to undermine cooperation in the common fight against terrorism. The global threat of terrorism is being imposed as a common duty of the EU and all international actors to take decisive action to protect the security of citizens in the first place. Therefore, the priority objective should be to establish closer cooperation in the exchange of information from EU Member States' intelligence agencies with the US and other partners, as the only global action by all actors will achieve positive results in detecting terrorists and prevent radicalisation of individuals.  In this regard, I agree with Parliament's position that the EU, as a global leader in the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms, insists on exposing and condemning all conduct that leads to violations of human dignity.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it deals with an issue relating to the competences and responsibilities of the Member States of the European Union and not of the European Parliament.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament has requested extensive investigations into the participation of EU Member States in the CIA's secret detention and extraordinary surrender programme. , sometimes corruptly, on the basis of the payment of significant sums by the CIA in exchange for its cooperation.  This report expresses its strong condemnation of the use of enhanced interrogation techniques that violate the rights to freedom, security, humane treatment, the presumption of innocence, impartial trials, legal advice and fair production under the law.  The report also reiterates that, in the specific situation of Guantanamo Bay, criminal proceedings under civil jurisdiction are the best way to resolve the situation of detainees, calling on us authorities not to give them the death penalty. I abstained because I believe that there are still aspects that can be improved and investigated at this level.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. It was with a narrow majority (30 votes apart) that the European Parliament passed a resolution on the CIA's use of torture and the involvement of our Member States in these acts. As a reminder, the uncovering of secret CIA prisons caused a great stir in European public opinion when they were revealed at the end of 2005 by the American daily "the Washington post". The climate of impunity that has surrounded the CIA until then has ceased and the European Parliament continues to express its grievances about the CIA's methods of torture. The Obama administration has done its best to condemn the mistakes made by its authorities and has clarified full compliance with the Geneva Convention.  But who are we to claim to hold the truth? This resolution is a matter of the Coué method rather than the ability to assume an inevitably secure policy when the rule of law is in danger in the face of the domestic threat. The resolution also sins out of naivety. This is evidenced by the request made in paragraph 26 to grant asylum in the EU to all ex-prisoners at Guantanamo. This reasoned my abstention, as did that of 48 other MEPs, on the final vote.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this text, which follows the resolution of 11 February 2015 on the US Senate report. We note with regret that, more than a year after the publication of the U.S. Senate study and Parliament's resolution on this matter, no author has yet been held accountable. As a reminder, the study reinforced allegations that some EU Member States were complicit in the CIA's secret detention and extraordinary rendition programme, which was accused of numerous human rights violations and torture from 2001 to 2005.  We reiterate our call on Member States to investigate their territory, ensuring transparency, with a view to bringing to justice those who participated in these operations. We also call on the United States to re-examine the military commission system with a view to ensuring fair trials, and to prohibit in all circumstances the use of torture, ill-treatment and indefinite detention without trial.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. This was a difficult vote, but we were able to pass on the idea that, one year after the publication of the US Senate study, we remain concerned about the apathy shown by the Member States and the European institutions with regard to the recognition of the multiple violations of fundamental rights and torture that took place on European soil between 2001 and 2006, the investigation of these violations and the adoption of measures to bring accomplices and those responsible to court.  Transatlantic cooperation based on common values such as freedom and security, democracy and fundamental human rights must remain a key priority in the EU's external relations. Transatlantic cooperation in the fight against terrorism must respect fundamental rights, fundamental freedoms and the protection of privacy, as guaranteed by EU law.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I signed the majority resolution which expressed the European Parliament's concern about the apathy of the Member States and the European institutions towards the numerous human rights violations and the use of torture that took place during the CIA's "restitution" operations on European soil between 2001 and 2006. The adopted text urges them to investigate these violations and bring to justice their perpetrators or accomplices.  The document also calls for further fact-study missions to be organised by Parliament in Member States identified as accomplices to the CIA's detention and interrogation programme, such as Lithuania, Poland, Italy and the United Kingdom.  Finally, the resolution regrets the fact that more than a year after the publication of the U.S. Senate study on the restitution program, no official has yet been held to account.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The so-called CIA prison case is a serious indictment of both the US and some Member States of the European Union. Unfortunately, there is also my country among them. I am in favour of a comprehensive fight against terrorists and anyone who threatens our security, but I am convinced that, in doing so, we must not descend to the same level of terrorism. I am therefore unequivocally in favour of these accusations being investigated, and it is true that, however unpleasant it does not appear, it is recognised, first and foremost, on the US side.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Resolution was adopted by 329 votes in favour, 299 against and 49 abstentions, including my vote. I have decided to abstain, because I wanted to make it well-wished that I strongly condemn the use of enhanced interrogation techniques, whereas the European Union is based on the principles of Democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms, respect for human dignity and international law, not only on its internal policies but also on its external dimension, and that this commitment, reinforced by the entry into force of the CHARTER of Fundamental Rights of the EU and the process of adhering to the European Convention on Human Rights, must be present in all its fields of action, as can be read in the text of the adopted Resolution. Furthermore, I note that the Council of Europe has decided to close its inquiry and that the inquiry by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on this matter has not concluded anything new or relevant, so It seems more appropriate to me that it is the National Parliaments, the national/European judiciary (in particular the European Court of Human Rights) to promote possible investigations/prosecutions and/or to provide remedies for victims.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I believe that this is a very positive motion for a resolution as a whole, which delves into different aspects which we believe should be clarified, both on human rights and torture violations and on the existence of detention centres in Member States of the European Union.  I believe that on these facts, there must be complete transparency and all the actions that Parliament can take to investigate and sanction a number of human rights violations over the past decade. I welcome this report and therefore consider it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The US Senate report describes how torture is an ineffective means of preventing and prosecuting terrorist attacks. Torture should never be the solution we choose in the fight against terrorism or in any other respect. That is why it is important that we denounce these acts, but at the same time remember that prosecution is a national competence.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. After learning about the participation of different European Union states in the CIA's Extraordinary Surrender programme, through which torture and other human rights violations were perpetrated outside U.S. territory, an investigation into European involvement in the LIBE Commission was approved. After a year, the groups on the right of this house do not want this investigation to be maintained on facts that reveal the subalternity of the European Union to American interests, to the point of allowing serious human rights violations on their territory. I therefore voted in favour of renewing the mandate of the LIBE Commission, to investigate the facts and to prove the political responsibilities of the EU governments which enabled these shameful facts.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I would condemn all use of torture by any government; and if these allegations are true, I am appalled by an important partner like the USA stooping this low. A strong message should be sent that Europeans will not stand by in silence if partners abuse human rights in this way. However I could not support this oral question because the EU has no competence in this area, and must rely on international law to conclude this matter, not the European Parliament.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Transatlantic cooperation on the basis of common values must remain a key priority of EU foreign relations. It is therefore in the common interest of citizens on both sides of the Atlantic to continue the political dialogue on security and counter-terrorism issues, including civil and human rights. I therefore accept with great misunderstanding the report on the conclusion of the investigation by the Secretary-General of the Council of Europe, even though investigations in several Member States remain unresolved. It is essential that Lithuania, Romania, Poland investigate transparently, thoroughly and effectively the existence of secret CIA detention facilities on their territory, taking into account all factual evidence that has been made public, allowing investigators to thoroughly examine all the context of the detention of prisoners on their territories and bring the perpetrators of human rights violations to justice.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. THE ALFA abhors all forms of torture and is firmly committed to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. However, we believe that, in the event of suspected infringements, independent investigations should be carried out at national level, supported by the EU, in order to obtain complete and accurate information. If it is also the task of the European Parliament to draw attention to these matters, it has no power or competence in the area of national security. In the case of the resolution on the US Senate report on the cia's use of torture, it had no access to the necessary documents or to appropriate means of intervention. Parliament should therefore remain aware of what is happening, but should have the matter dealt with by competent authorities. That is why I did not vote in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Torture is a serious violation of both European and international law. All such suspicions must be thoroughly investigated, regardless of who they relate to.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 N-VA strongly supported the alternative EPP resolution B8-0584/2016, which strongly condemns torture on EU territory by foreign powers , while respecting the principle of subsidiarity. By contrast, the N-VA delegation in the European Parliament voted against LIBE resolution B8-0580/2016. In the past, N-VA has also voted against the similar LIBE resolution B8-0098/2015. Parliament has no competence on matters of national security. In addition, it only obtains second-hand information and condemns (foreign and European) governments on the basis of sometimes questionable sources. Finally, since the Council of Europe has already concluded its research on the matter, N-VA considers that it is of little use for Parliament to vote annually on a follow-up resolution on the same subject.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I abstained from the vote on the European Parliament's motion for a resolution, following questions on oral answers B8-0367/2016 and B8-0368/2016 in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. I criticise any state action that interferes with physical integrity, but in this case I do not see any EU competence.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is founded on a commitment to democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity and international law, not only in domestic policies but also in external action. Parliament strongly condemned the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency's (CIA) program for extradition and covert detention that violates human rights multiple times.  The US plays a key role in the fight against terrorism, including in Europe, and transatlantic counter-terrorism cooperation needs to be preserved for the common good of citizens on both sides of the Atlantic. Transatlantic cooperation, based on common values such as the promotion of freedom and security, democracy and fundamental human rights, is and must remain a top priority in the External Relations of the European Union. Effective counterterrorism measures and respect for human rights are not contradictory but complementary objectives that complement each other.  I support the adoption of this Resolution because I believe that at a time of increasing instability in the world, the relationship with the United States is of particular importance. Such a relationship, based on shared interests and values, needs to be further strengthened by respecting multilateralism and the international rule of law. The fight against terrorism must be aligned with obligations under international law, in particular international human rights law and humanitarian law, and such treatment will make our countries stronger and safer.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted against the resolution by Claude Moraes, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the response to the European Parliament resolution of 11 February 2015 on the CIA Report on Torture by the US Senate on Torture.  There are quite a few references in the resolution that I cannot support. One of these is, among other things, that the war on terrorism is spreading the powers of governments to the detriment of parliaments and the judiciary, which is supposed to prevent public investigations into alleged human rights abuses.  I also believe that there have been no new findings in the cia's ongoing investigation into alleged transport and illegal detention of prisoners in EU countries by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, so there is no reason for the committee to continue its investigation.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The US Central Intelligence Agency has proven to have secret detention centres within European territory, bribe governments, organisations and bodies, promote corruption and in most cases violate human rights and the presumption of innocence. Under the pretext of combating terrorism, the balance between governments, parliaments and the judiciary is dangerously shifting. The European institutions, the European Court of Human Rights, all the so-called guardians of the protection of fundamental rights in the political persecution of nationalist movements are 'deaf' and are cut only in cases where they are 'politically'.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the criticism expressed in the proposal for a decision, because I consider it unacceptable that, on the territory of the European Union, with the assistance of the authorities of certain Member States, prisoners could be unlawfully detained and tortured by the CIA. Nor can we ignore the fact that the proposals for action and procedure made in Parliament on this matter have not been implemented, or only very partially, by the Council, the Commission and the Member States concerned. In my opinion, the fight against terrorism will not be more effective with such methods, while at the same time exerting a strain on Euro-Atlantic political relations, while at the same time being a serious and systematic violation of human rights.  I therefore expect the EU institutions and Member States concerned to investigate the circumstances and to provide meaningful answers and measures to the European public and the European Parliament, as set out in this resolution.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 As a whole, I voted in favour of the resolution, but abstained from paragraph 24 of the original text on asylum for prisoners released from Guantánamo. The EU does not have the power to put pressure on member states to grant asylum to released prisoners;

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I agree with the European Parliament's strong condemnation of the use of advanced interrogation techniques, which are prohibited by international law and constitute offences, including the right to freedom, the right to security, the right to humane treatment, the right not to be subjected to torture, the right to the presumption of innocence. , the right to a fair trial, the right to counsel and the right to equal protection before the law.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Respect for fundamental human rights and the rule of law is not only the cornerstone of the EU, but also an indispensable element in the effective fight against terrorism. Inhuman practices in investigation and abuse are in any case reprehensible. However I abstained on this resolution as I believe that this is up to each Member States to investigate such matter. I also believe that the EU should focus on constructive dialogue with the US in the fight against terrorism.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. Resolutions The response to the European Parliament resolution of 11 February 2015 on the US Senate report on torture by the CIA was not supported. The European Union is founded on a commitment to democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms, respect for human dignity and international law, not only in its internal but also external policies. In the fight against terrorism, human dignity, human rights and fundamental freedoms must be respected on the basis of the EU Treaties, the European Convention on Human Rights, national constitutions and legislation on fundamental rights. EU-US relations are based on a strong partnership and cooperation in a number of areas and on the common values of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The US plays an extremely important role in the fight against terrorism, including on European soil. In return for substantial sums, certain Member States cooperate with the CIA on extradition and secret detentions. An investigation into mass human rights violations in connection with the CIA's extradition and secret detentions should be carried out in the US. Taking responsibility for these actions is crucial for the protection and promotion of human rights in the EU's internal and external policies.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I endorse recommendations included in the text of this resolution. Without doubt Lithuania, Romania and Poland shall conduct proper investigations into the CIA secret prisons on their territory which have hardly operated in line with European human rights standards. US President Barack Obama must remember his pre-election commitment and find a way to close the notorious Guantánamo Bay detention facility.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I believe that this is a very positive motion for a resolution as a whole, which delves into different aspects which we believe should be clarified, both on human rights and torture violations and on the existence of detention centres in Member States of the European Union.  I believe that on these facts, there must be complete transparency and all the actions that Parliament can take to investigate and sanction a number of human rights violations over the past decade. I welcome this report and therefore consider it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting because the text is too negatively opposed to the functioning of the CIA. It unnecessarily creates a negative and hostile atmosphere.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The resolution requires that the fight against terrorism be done within the framework of democratic rules and in accordance with member states' human rights obligations. In theory, this principle is indeed difficult to attack. However, the text attacks several Member States (notably Romania, Poland, Italy) for failing to conduct a full investigation. The resolution calls on the Commission to present a white paper on the circumstances in which national security and state secrets cannot be invoked in a democratic society, in order to essentially define what is not a matter of "national security". It wants transparency in the fight against terrorism and attacks the growing tendency of governments to over-invoke "national security" (quotes are in the text). He congratulated Obama for promising in 2008 to close Guantanamo, which is still not closed, and called on member states to offer asylum to detainees who have been officially declared free. Without wishing to support the practices of the CIA, I am obliged to vote AGAINST this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is based on a commitment to democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms, human dignity and respect for international law, both at home and abroad. I supported the position and proposal of the S&D group on this matter.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I believe that this is a very positive motion for a resolution as a whole, which delves into different aspects which we believe should be clarified, both on human rights and torture violations and on the existence of detention centres in Member States of the European Union.  I believe that on these facts, there must be complete transparency and all the actions that Parliament can take to investigate and sanction a number of human rights violations over the past decade. I welcome this report and therefore consider it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Our key amendment re-inserting to LIBE to keep this inquiry failed just by one vote, small positive our split vote para 18 to delete a few words and improve transparency was successful. Weak resolution and does not specify what the EP should proceed on this.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of motion for a resolution on follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 11 February 20015 on the US Senate report on the use of torture by the CIA. The resolution urges EU Member States to investigate, insuring full transparency, the allegations that there were secret prisons on their territory in which people were held under the CIA programme. The resolution calls for more fact-finding missions to be organised by the European Parliament in those Member States which have been identified as complicit in the CIA’s detention and interrogation programme, such as Lithuania, Poland, Italy and the UK.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this new resolution of the European Parliament, which for 10 years has called for full investigations to establish the whole truth about the CIA's detentions, torture, prisons and illegal activities in the European Union. This resolution, unfortunately non-binding, urges Member States and the European institutions to investigate these violations with full transparency and to bring their officials and accomplices to justice.  The adopted text also deplores the unfulfilled commitment of the President of the United States to close Guantanamo and once again calls on the United States authorities to keep this promise and to ban torture and indefinite detention without trial. In view of the fundamental role that Parliament plays in clarifying this matter, we have tabled an amendment for the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs with the Subcommittee on Human Rights to monitor this work.  Unfortunately, some political groups, under pressure from the governments concerned, are trying to prevent our work from continuing. Our amendment was rejected by 1 vote. Nevertheless, I voted for it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The resolution states that several obstacles have been placed on investigations into the use of torture by the CIA, and too much time has passed since the beginning of the same, without the objective clarification of the facts and the consequent convictions. More than 50 countries, including Portugal, have covered the secret extrajudicial transfer program of suspected terrorist prisoners on CIA flights launched by the Bush Administration after the September 11, 2001 attacks. The covert operations consisted of the abduction, transport and torture of suspected terrorists in clandestine detention centres, with the collaboration of several European governments – such as the United Kingdom, Germany, Sweden – and American allies in Africa and the Middle East. The US is an imperialist power that considers itself above any legal obligation, which disrespects international law and which, ironically, has continuously occupyseveral sovereign countries in the name of defending human rights.  Justice is required and justice is required and, at national and international level, at UN level, those responsible, in particular the US administration, which unfortunately remains unpunished in this report, are condemned.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report clearly shows the involvement of several EU Member States and their authorities and officials, as well as agents of their security and intelligence services, in the CIA's secret detention and extraordinary transfer programme. The fact that torture has not been able to obtain information of which, through conventional, non-violent interrogation methods, would have been unaware is also openly addressed. I can therefore only agree with the follow-up to the call for full clarification at European level.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Voting in favour of this resolution, is voting for respect for human rights, transparency and democracy, which is the reason I did. As does the resolution, I would first of all like to state that EU-US relations are very important to me. However, good relations also mean that you respect agreements with one another. Moreover, they are no excuses for violating human rights. As the resolution underlines, the transatlantic relationship is based on mutual respect for democracy and fundamental human rights. I also welcome the condemnation of (to give an example) torture as an interrogation technique. EU Member States that are under suspicion of cooperating in such practices need to allow investigations to be conducted. In addition, I support the call upon the US to provide transparency of information and assistance during those investigations in the concerned EU Member States.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 This resolution is just another example of the anti-American hysteria that is teeming with the European Parliament. The European Parliament has no national security competence, no reason to vote on the US Senate report, which is why I did not support this ideologically motivated resolution.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr With the rapid technological development of the early 21st century, it is no longer possible to ignore space in terms of security and defence. And it must be said that, at present, space is mainly used for the development of telecommunications and space programmes in the European Union and in the case of its Member States. By no means inviting space armaments or anything like that, I nevertheless share the idea that there is an acute need to assess and further develop other opportunities that can potentially be provided by areas beyond our home planet. It must be said that the fight against terrorism, the gradual cleaning of orbital debris, the further development of the Galileo and Copernicus programmes, innovation, science, technology – all of this also contributes to our development here in the European Union, and of course I could not support this report by my colleague Zdraevsky.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the militarisation of space has become a great risk due to the development of anti-satellite technologies, including orbital weapons, which can be used by terrorists and other non-state actors. The report identifies cyber threats for European space programmes. For example, jamming or altering the source from which data packets are sent can endanger military missions and have implications for life on earth. We must respond with one voice and through coordinated and rapid action, in constant collaboration between the European Union, the United States and NATO.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, this is a very surprising report, since you are proposing both the greatest autonomy in space and you say a few lines later that you are saying this incredible thing: that the European Union is about strengthening its cooperation and coordination with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which we call NATO in my country, and with the United States. , both of which remain the guarantors of security and stability in Europe, after voting a few moments ago that the United States was organizing secret prisons where people are tortured in Europe. I think it is all aberrant.
