The European Union must be concerned with demilitarising space, because it is the next frontier, the current border of humanity, and it is not good that it is the place of a proliferation of military devices and methods of control, especially when you end up saying that you intend to control boats that take refugees. All of this is absurd.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I understand that Mr. Mélenchon fears the establishment of CIA prisons on the moon, not without a goat. On the other hand, I voted against the whole resolution, as well as against paragraph 24 in particular, because, firstly, we believe that this is a prelude to the construction of some Kind of European army that would take away the remnants of autonomy for the individual countries that make up the European Union. And secondly, because the experience so far with multi-state space exploration is very daunting, and I am afraid that, just as the probe could not hit the comet and die somewhere, it could have hit the United States by mistake instead of Russia, or vice versa, and then there would be serious international complications. More besides, I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report concerns space technologies as part of the Union's defence and security strategies. Although I agree with the premises, I have my doubts about the possible privatisation of space services and, above all, more could be done to ensure the use of these technologies only in the event of defence and security and to avoid their use in a possible attack. In addition, there is the absence of a genuine European space authority. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report calls for strengthening the EU's security and defence policy rather than prioritising civilian capacities in conflict resolution. In addition, it considers space capacity as an appropriate instrument for border management, internal security and energy and improving the development of the military-industrial complex. It advocates greater militarisation of space as well as the EU. I am opposed to the report, as it also calls for greater EU cooperation with the US and NATO in future space capabilities and services for the CSDP; advocates the use of dual-use space technologies in the space sector, which aims to contribute to the development of European military industry; and calls for mobilizing EU resources to increase its space capabilities in security and defence, deepening its militarisation. I understand that military research should not be financed from the EU budget, and that conflict resolution must take place from a peaceful, civil and diplomatic approach; for this reason, I am not only against greater collaboration between the EU and NATO, but I am calling for the dissolution of the latter.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on space capabilities for security and defence in Europe. This report uses the current terrorist threats as a pretext to define a European space policy. It should be remembered, however, that Space Europe is not even an intergovernmental programme, as France provides more than 60% of the resources needed to finance these projects. In addition, the report stresses the need for European space programmes to be part of NATO and the transatlantic partnership.  While financial and technological cooperation between Member States seems essential to bring these projects to a complete future in space, we challenge the European Union's willingness to submit our space policy to the United States. I objected to this text, because it is essential that France retain its strategic and technological independence.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on Space Capabilities, as it is essentially calling for the militarisation of space.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for the development of critical space technologies and Independent European space capabilities. Space technologies and services, such as satellite communication or Earth observation, are vitally important not only in border management, energy security, disaster management or transport, civilian activities, but also for security and defence.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on space capabilities for European security and defence, because the security environment is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, both inside and outside the Union, which was facing terrorist attacks, hybrid warfare and mass killings affecting all Member States. On these issues, Member States must respond by adopting a common strategy, while providing a coordinated response at all levels and making use, inter alia, of the development of space capabilities.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Under the pretexts of counter-terrorism and migration crisis, this report aims to Europeanise space policy. It is worth recalling here that the European Intergovernmental Programme (European Space Agency) is very largely funded by France. While space policy is a key element of state sovereignty, the report envisages a EU space policy within the framework of NATO and under the aegis of a transatlantic strategic partnership.  This report therefore buries the French conception of space policy, but has the merit of revealing the true nature of European projects for these programmes and technologies. So I logically voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I do not believe that in the long term the EU must have its own instruments to establish a ‘Defence Union.’

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. The Union must consolidate its capacity to ensure security at home and abroad, so as to ensure stability in its neighbourhood and in the world. The Union must contribute to the fight against security threats, particularly those arising from terrorism, both at home and abroad, in particular by assisting third countries in the fight against terrorism and its root causes. Member States and the EU must cooperate to put in place an effective and coherent system of border management and thus secure external borders.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on space capabilities for European security and defence. Space-based capabilities and services play an important role in European security and defence and in other areas. I agree with the need to increase the effectiveness, visibility and impact of the CSDP. I agree that space should be included in future Union policies (e.g. internal security, transport, space, energy, research) and that space interaction should be further strengthened and exploited. It is also essential to use space capabilities to fight terrorism and terrorist organisations, as they provide an opportunity to identify and monitor the location of terrorist training camps. I agree that national governments and the Union should improve access to space-based satellite communication, space situational awareness, precision navigation and Earth observation capabilities, and ensure European independence in relation to key space technologies and access to space.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aim of the report is to draw attention to the EU's underdevelopment in the space technologies and space industry and to propose development goals and possible directions. It is important to note that the parts of the EU and NATO that call for the coordination and deepening of civilian and military developments in this area are not the solution. It is precisely because of the possibility of military use of space technology that the EU must be independent and strive for its own technological developments and use, irrespective of the US and NATO. Space technology provides an opportunity to address the issue of common external and internal security, external EU border protection and curbing illegal migration at the starting point in an appropriate and acceptable manner for all Member States. Currently, 60% of EU space technology, including communications satellites for civilian and military use, uses US-derived components and software, which raises the question of how to ensure adequate data protection for EU citizens. The coordination and introduction into a single umbrella organisation of existing EU and Member State space agencies and research institutes will enable developments to be projected and competitive with the space technology developments and programmes of competing states, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this report which underlines the importance of the role of space capabilities and services in the implementation of the EU's security and defence policy and other policies such as internal security, transport, the environment, climate, humanitarian aid, disaster management...

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Space technologies and research and development activities are a crucial sector for the foreseeable future, in particular through high investment returns and the creation of high-quality software and hardware by-products, which find numerous commercial applications. My vote in favour of the Zdrojewski report is based on the conviction that investment in space technologies must be a priority in the field of foreign and security policy. Through the use of satellite capabilities it is already possible to identify irregular migrant flows, their routes and above all the boarding areas on ships in order to intervene more quickly and save more lives. Terrorist group training camps can be located and monitored, as well as interventions in fields ranging from maritime security to transport, through agriculture and humanitarian crisis management, can be enhanced. The achievement of these objectives depends on a general improvement in access to space capabilities and real European independence in critical space technologies. The text adopted calls on the Commission to develop a White Paper which will help to identify a coherent European space policy.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote against this report. I agree with the rapporteur that the European Union's space capabilities should be incentivised and worked for improvement in innovation, as well as strategic independence in satellite navigation systems. But I do not agree on the military use of these space programs. Galileo and Copernicus should be used only for civilian purposes, and the European Union should not contribute to the militarization of Space.  On the other hand, the increase in funds on these issues should always be reviewed by the European Parliament, and not give so much prominence to the Space Agencies, that while they have to coordinate and manage, they should not do so without democratic oversight, nor for military purposes. The use of satellites for border control, as well as for the military resolution of the refugee crisis, is not the right way to end this problem. We must therefore always seek solutions based on civil society and the solidarity and values of the founding treaties of the European Union.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. There is no doubt that the development of space must be the subject of a comprehensive approach at EU level. It is impossible for a European state to have sufficient resources to develop the many existing and future space technologies on its own. This is especially true in the current climate of insecurity, the rise of terrorism and the migratory surge. Indeed, the Union must allow, within the framework of intergovernmental cooperation, the use of its space capabilities to monitor, in particular, by means of its satellites, terrorist training camps or to foresee migratory outbursts on our shores and stop them before these makeshift boats run aground. Each of us obviously has an interest in the development of joint civil programmes such as Galileo, Copernicus or Airbus, a real success of European technological and commercial cooperation. The European Space Agency must be able to play an important role in defining and implementing a European space policy and it must fully integrate the European Union's security and defence policy.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 I support this report for three reasons. The first, because global threats must be offered global responses and space technology is basic in this area and Europe needs independence and self-sufficiency in it. Secondly, because it is a very appropriate way of turning into fact the many arguments we are making, in order to overcome at once the concept of 'national security' and replace it with a European one where coordination and efficiency take place. The third is linked to development, which this strategy will lead to in European companies engaged in space technology.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on space capabilities for security and defence in Europe is part of the current anti-terrorist atmosphere and takes advantage of this and the migration crisis to want to Europeanise space policy.  It should be remembered that Europe of space is a French programme (France alone covering on average 60% of the project budget, plus all overruns) to which European countries have added to vampirize it (Germany in particular). I would also like to remind you that the independence of space technology is a central point of our sovereignty arrangements.  But the report poses the problem via NATO as well. Nevertheless, it should be remembered that the independence of France was also acquired against America since De Gaulle. Moreover, Russia is also mentioned as an enemy (point 12) and, for all these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on space capabilities for European security and defence has unclear passages and is therefore not fully acceptable. I therefore preferred to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. As the report points out, the security environment is becoming increasingly complex, both inside and outside the Union, with terrorist attacks and mass killings affecting all Member States.  These challenges call for strengthening EU security through the development and support of the Common Security and Defence Policy to make it a more effective political instrument and a real guarantee of the security of EU citizens and the promotion and protection of the rules, interests and values enshrined in the EMU. Space capabilities are key in many situations, from daily use in peacetime to managing the most pressing security crises and challenges. The potential of satellites could be used to better assess and identify the flow of illegal immigrants and their routes and, in the case of those from North Africa, to identify boarding areas, intercept them earlier and save more lives. It is therefore urgent to intensify defence cooperation with a view to building essential capacities, also using a coherent and efficient use of the Union's available funds and capacities.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has given Parliament its position on space capabilities for European security and defence. Space policy is an essential element of the strategic autonomy that the EU must safeguard in order to preserve high technological and industrial capabilities and autonomous assessment capacity. Space capabilities for European security and defence are important, and in most cases even vitally necessary in all sorts of situations, from daily use in peacetime, to crisis management and more sensitive security problems, including real war. The development of such capacity is long-term and therefore the development of capacity in the future needs to be programmed in the formulation of existing capacity. The spread of space technologies and the increasing dependence of society on satellites are increasing competition for space assets (runways, frequencies), satellites are becoming critical infrastructures, and the development of anti-satellite technologies by many actors, including orbital weapons capabilities, shows that space is being attempted to turn into a weapon. Parliament therefore calls on national governments and the Union to improve access to space-based satellite communication, space situational awareness, precision navigation and Earth observation capabilities, and to ensure European independence in relation to key space technologies and access to space. Parliament believes that the situation in space will play a very important role in military and civilian matters, but stresses the commitment not to militarize space.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The security environment inside and outside the EU is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, as terrorist attacks and mass killings are occurring in all Member States, to which Member States must respond by adopting a common strategy and a coordinated response. The report therefore emphasises the importance of space-based instruments and the further development of these capabilities. The Union must work together to implement an effective and consistent border management system, to address the challenges facing our security, riots and armed conflicts in our neighbourhood, and migration, for which the development of these capabilities is absolutely necessary. I believe that the Union should improve access to space-based satellite communications, space observation, precision navigation and Earth observation capabilities and ensure Europe's independence in terms of critical space technologies and access to space. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, which is part of the current anti-terrorist atmosphere, takes advantage of this problem as well as the migration crisis to want to Europeanise space policy. In addition, this report poses the spatial problem within the framework of NATO and a transatlantic strategic partnership. However, I would like to remind you that the independence of space technology is a central point of our sovereignty apparatus (vectors, surveillance, interception, militarization of space, communication) to which I am very attached. This report clearly jeopardizes this sovereignty.  Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this resolution which calls for more market access in space, increased marketing promotion and for more funding EU regarding space developments. The resolution completely fails to critical assess this unnecessary spending, and moreover there are even parts in which they basically say that public spending is necessary to stimulate private sector investments. Also, there is nowhere in the resolution a clear distinction between military functionality of the EU space assets, and civilian and peaceful use. Because of that, I recommend to vote against.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Investing in space means pushing companies and research centres to push the limit of their current technical and scientific skills and knowledge: it means encouraging them to face new problems and invent new solutions. This has positive repercussions in any technological field for civilian life, from new materials to telecommunications, from satellite positioning systems to energy efficiency. Many great inventions that we use in everyday life are the daughters of investments in space research and security and defense: internet, smartphones, microwave, many thermo-resistant polymers, GPS navigators and much more. Investing in this sector therefore means investing in the future. It also means investing in protecting the security of our citizens because, even today and even more so in the coming decades, European states must be prepared to face threats of a mixed and long-range nature, and any progress in the capacity for prevention, satellite monitoring and missile interception is essential to prevent misfortune and save many human lives.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report uses current terrorist threats as a pretext to define a European space policy. In these circumstances, it should be remembered that the Europe of space is not even an intergovernmental programme, as France provides more than 60% of the resources needed to finance these projects. In addition, the report stresses the need for European space programmes to be part of NATO and the transatlantic partnership. While financial and technological cooperation between Member States seems essential to bring these projects to a complete future in space, we challenge the European Union's willingness to submit our space policy to the United States. It is about our strategic independence. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Terrorist attacks as well as mass killings are real threats. The security environment is becoming more dangerous and more difficult to protect, so joint action is needed to be able to counter the threats we face. Common strategies and a strengthened response are needed, thus requiring the strengthening of the European Union's security policy through the continued development and support of the EU's common security and defence policy, in order to make it a real guarantee for the safety of European citizens. Space capabilities for European security and defence are important, from their use in peacetime to managing crises and more acute security challenges, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report on the importance of space capabilities for strengthening security and defence in Europe. The EU is contributing to this as part of the Commission's 2016 work programme, which plans to develop a space strategy. This strategy should include Building on Horizon 2020, Copernicus and Galileo and providing political and financial support to the space industry. I share the objective of coordinating the various axes of EU space activities through a roadmap that will promote targeted sectoral activities and the development of European space programmes. However, a comprehensive approach to space issues should be maintained and they should be included in a strategic security and defence agenda.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe it is essential for the European Union to strengthen its role as guarantor of security within and outside its borders, thereby ensuring the necessary stability in its neighbourhood and in the international arena. In this particular historical climate, terrorist attacks make the eu's security issue, both internal and external, more challenging. All the necessary confidence must be put in the capacity of the space sector to stem terrorism and terrorist organisations. This is possible, for example, through training camp localization and monitoring skills. The EU's objective of ensuring autonomy in space structures is of vital importance for both the civil and security and defence industries. It is estimated that between 6% and 7% of GDP in western countries depend directly on satellite positioning and navigation technologies. Particular praise goes to the Copernicus programme and its excellent contribution to safety. Its useful application can be seen in crisis prevention, humanitarian cooperation and maritime surveillance.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which was on the need to arm space with observational satellites. Such satellites would be used to aid weaponry and militaristic practices. The report aims to use the Galileo (EU GPS satellites) and Copernicus (Earth observation satellites) programmes for military use and to establish a European Framework Cooperation for Security and Defence Research on space. It calls for close cooperation between the EU and NATO in the area of security and defence, and for the establishment for a European Defence Union - all of this to be funded through a strategy agreed by the High Representative and the Commission. As Sinn Féin is committed to protecting Irish neutrality, I voted against this extension to the CSDP policy by militarising space.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because I fully support the development of a common space policy for the European Union which should aim to improve our research and new technologies in this area but also contribute significantly to our security and economy. I welcome the development of our own autonomous space programmes, Galileo and Copernicus and I hope for great progress in our space policies in the future and I support the plans to develop our own European launchers.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I followed the preparation of the report on the use of space technologies as part of the European Union's security and defence strategy as a member of the European Parliament's SEDE Committee. I agree with some of the aspects set out in the draft report, such as the reference to the need for the Eu ropean Union to encourage all actors involved in the provision of technologies and knowledge to pay attention to space capabilities and services, as well as attention to the involvement of small and medium-sized enterprises. However, I voted against the report both in the Commission and in plenary because I found many critical issues that were not overcome even when the compromises were being worked out. Firstly, there is no clear position on the possible risks associated with the privatisation of the space sector. Furthermore, there is no reference to the fact that space instruments should only be strengthened from a defence and prevention perspective and that they must in no way be understood as instruments that can be used by Member States in possible armed attacks.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on space capacity for European security and defence, because I believe that it is essential to strengthen the common security and defence policy at a time when the security environment, inside and outside the European Union, is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging. The new challenges of terrorism and wars on Europe's borders require us to make the Union's defence and security policy a more effective political instrument and a real guarantee for the security of citizens and for the promotion and protection of European standards and values. I would also like to point out that satellite capabilities can also be used to better assess and identify the flow of irregular migrants and their routes, as well as to identify the areas of embarkation on ships, in order to be able to intervene quickly and save lives. The Copernicus programme, which is earth observation from space, can help prevent conflicts by promoting humanitarian support and cooperation, as well as representing significant scientific progress.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the current international context, deeply destabilised by terrorism and various armed conflicts, space programmes can become an important element of Member States' defence and security policies. In particular, I believe that European expertise in the aerospace sector should also be used to monitor the earth's surface and provide information on the positioning of strategic objectives such as, for example, training camps for terrorist groups.  Over the years, the EU has developed an important satellite policy and therefore systems such as Copernicus and Galileo could play a role in the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) and, thanks to their versatility, could also be used to identify routes used by irregular migrants to identify embarkation areas on ships and thus prevent further carnage in the Mediterranean.  However, activities in extra-atmospheric space must respond to an international code of conduct to strengthen protection and sustainability in space. I agree with the multilateral initiative taken by the European Union to this end, not only to protect space infrastructure but also to prevent the militarisation of space, a risk that we must avoid. For the above reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and believe that satellite capabilities could be used to better assess and detect the flow of illegal migrants and migration routes and, in the case of migrants coming from North Africa, to identify boarding points on ships, with a view to faster contact with them and saving more lives.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on space capabilities for European security and defence brings to the fore important issues, especially considering that even today part of the territory of a Member State (Cyprus) is militarily occupied by a foreign power (Turkey). It is a fact that Europe must be active in this area so that it does not depend on actions or programmes of third States or organisations. However, as for the time being the objectives set are of dubious honesty, I have decided to vote against the report.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation and development of the European space sector, in my opinion, will bring multiple benefits in the field of security and defence. It makes it possible, for example, to control borders, illegal immigration and transport by sea and air. These are very sensitive issues that are difficult to control without the appropriate means, but I am convinced that the creation of such a sector independently, developed and tailored to needs, can really increase the security of European citizens. Furthermore, this space programme does not only include the European level, but also provides for cooperation between the European Union and its Member States in order to develop this sector in the best possible way. These are the reasons why I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Space policy is an essential component of the strategic autonomy which the EU must develop in order to safeguard sensitive technological and industrial capabilities and independent capabilities to carry out assessments. Space-based capabilities and services play an important role in the context of European security and defence and EU policies in areas such as external action, border management, maritime security, agriculture, the environment, climate action, energy security, disaster management, humanitarian aid and transport.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. European space security and defence capabilities are important and in some cases vital for a variety of situations, from day-to-day peaceful use to crisis management and more serious security challenges. Satellites can be used to more effectively assess and identify illegal immigrant flows, their routes and identify boarding areas to start procedures faster and save more lives. The development and maintenance of Europe's space security and defence capabilities require effective cooperation and synergies between Member States, European and international institutions. National governments and the Union should improve access to space capabilities in terms of satellite communications and ensure non-European dependence on critical space technologies and access to space. It is essential to strengthen the coordination of space systems used in a fragmented way by the different Member States in order to be able to anticipate as soon as possible a disruption of the different applications. The EU must continue to seek to ensure the highest degree of space and military autonomy. I have for the foregoing supported this report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Independence, competitiveness, work. Investing energy in space policy means giving impetus and launch to one of the most important industrial sectors for our continent, including in relations with all our international partners. This is the conviction of the European Parliament, which has called on the Commission, with a view to approving the new European space strategy scheduled for the end of the year, to implement resources for space research programmes. Not only that: supporting the growth of this sector means, on the one hand, giving more work to our young people and, on the other hand, guaranteeing Europe, as a whole, that independence in terms of security, albeit within the framework of alliances with neighbouring countries around the world. Even so, we will achieve europe's great growth and development target by 2020.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I reckon that security environment is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, both within and outside the Union, characterised by terrorist attacks and mass murder which affects all Member States and to which Member States must respond by adopting a joint strategy and a coordinated response. I support the call for an EU Common Security and Defence Policy to make it a more effective policy instrument and a real guarantee of the safety of EU citizens and the promotion and protection of European norms, interests and values. This will enhance its cooperation and coordination with the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation and with the United States, which both remain warrantors of Europe’s security and stability, with the United Nations, the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, the African Union, and other neighbours and regional partners. I also consider that Space Surveillance and Tracking (SST) should become an EU programme with its own budget while ensuring that the funds for ongoing projects are not thereby reduced because I believe the EU should develop a more holistic space situational awareness (SSA) capacity with more predictive capabilities.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report calls for strengthening the EU's security and defence policy rather than prioritising civilian capacities in conflict resolution. In addition, it considers space capacity as an appropriate instrument for border management, internal security and energy and improving the development of the military-industrial complex. It advocates greater militarisation of space as well as the EU. I am opposed to the report, as it also calls for greater EU cooperation with the US and NATO in future space capabilities and services for the CSDP; advocates the use of dual-use space technologies in the space sector, which aims to contribute to the development of European military industry; and calls for mobilizing EU resources to increase its space capabilities in security and defence, deepening its militarisation. I understand that military research should not be financed from the EU budget, and that conflict resolution must take place from a peaceful, civil and diplomatic approach; for this reason, I am not only against greater collaboration between the EU and NATO, but I am calling for the dissolution of the latter.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are still all touched by the events that in recent months have called into question security in the heart of Europe and beyond. Ensuring the security of citizens is becoming increasingly dangerous and demanding: terrorist attacks, hybrid wars, put our defence systems to the test every day. That is why I believe that Europe must respond by adopting a common strategy and a coordinated response. These security challenges require the strengthening of a common defence policy in order to make it a more effective political instrument to guarantee citizens, interests and values, as enshrined in the Treaty on European Union. The space sector is an essential strategic component, which the European Union must continue to develop, in close connection with the common security and defence policy, in accordance with the provisions of the Treaty. For example, satellites, which could become a tool for better assessing and identifying the origins of illegal immigrant flows and boarding areas, to ensure a faster way to secure more human lives. I believe that this effort must be supported, in the sole interest of the citizens.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Due to the fact that the security environment is becoming increasingly dangerous and difficult both inside and outside the Union, characterised by terrorist attacks, affecting all Member States and to which they must respond by adopting a common and strengthened strategy, the EU must take on the role of security provider inside and outside the Union stability in its neighbourhood and globally. EU space policy promotes scientific and technical progress, industrial competitiveness and the implementation of all EU policies. These programmes bring security and defence benefits that are technologically linked to benefits. I voted for better space cooperation, which aims to ensure an adequate level of security.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Rapporteur Zdrojewski (EPP, PL) analyses the role that space can play in the context of the EU's overall security and defence objectives. In its report, it argues that future developments in this sector will provide Member States and the EU with "improved operational capacity" for the implementation of CSDP and other policy areas. The rapporteur also encourages Member States to use space initiatives to implement joint security and defence programmes. The report also calls for closer cooperation between the EU and NATO. Many of Mr Van Orden's amendments point to the role of governments and cooperation with the United States. These are contained in the report. Mr Krasnodębski's amendments stating that NATO remains a guarantor of security and stability in Europe, and suggesting problems with the launch of the EU satellite related to Russian Soyuz launchers, also have a major impact on the reception of the report as a whole. Despite the complexity of the problem, I voted YES.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on space capabilities for security and defence in Europe. I would like to remind you that the European Union's space programmes, namely Galileo and Copernicus, are essential for crisis prevention and resolution. In addition, the use of space capabilities in the fight against terrorist organizations is crucial to identifying and monitoring terrorist training camps.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a unified EU effort using the EU’s space capabilities to confront terrorist attacks, hybrid war and mass murder and also to assist in humanitarian missions. In Europe’s case space capabilities can be used for example, to better assess and identify the flow of illegal immigrants and their routes, and, in the case of those coming from Northern Africa, to identify the ship-boarding areas in order to engage with them faster and save more lives. I believe that space policy is an essential component of the strategic autonomy which the EU must develop in order to safeguard sensitive technological and industrial capabilities and hence I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The security environment inside and outside the EU is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, as terrorist attacks and mass killings are occurring in all Member States, to which Member States must respond by adopting a common strategy and a coordinated response. The report therefore emphasises the importance of space-based instruments and the further development of these capabilities. The Union must work together to implement an effective and consistent border management system, to address the challenges facing our security, riots and armed conflicts in our neighbourhood, and migration, for which the development of these capabilities is absolutely necessary. The report stresses the need for the EU to improve access to space-based satellite communications, space observation, precision navigation and Earth observation capabilities and to ensure Europe's independence in terms of critical space technologies and access to space.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Invoking the fight against terrorism and the migration crisis, this text aims to Europeanise space policy. However, Space Europe is not an intergovernmental programme, but a French programme, with France alone covering an average of 60% of the project budget plus all overruns. In addition, European countries such as Germany have been added. This report addresses the space issue within the framework of NATO and a transatlantic strategic partnership, even though it is a clear issue of independence and sovereignty. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – I have decided to abstain on this dossier. I think it's too early to draw any conclusions. The space has enormous capabilities and capabilities in terms of European security and defence. However, there are still many challenges in terms of economic, scientific and regional analysis and evaluation. One of the main priorities is to involve all actors involved in this process, especially regions, in order to develop the most effective and analytical future policies.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Positive in its totality. The EU must invest in its space programme and become autonomous and not dependent on the US. The possibilities exist and should be exploited by the EU for the progress of all its services and in all areas for the better quality of life and safety of Europeans.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on space capabilities for European security and defence. The priority of space programmes should not be military. It also uses migration in order to justify far reaching public investment in these projects. It is vital to my constituents in Wales that funding is spent beneficially.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. "Space policy is important for Europe's security and defence, both in day-to-day use in peacetime as well as in crisis management and more pressing security challenges. On the other hand, this resolution contains elements calling for the creation of a Defence Union, which I voted against. There is already in-depth functioning defence cooperation within the framework of NATO. We will use the cooperation that exists instead of building a parallel EU system.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU must strengthen its role as a guarantor of security at home and abroad, ensuring stability in neighbouring countries and on a global scale and contributing to the fight against security challenges, including those arising from terrorism on and off the territory, including by supporting third countries in the fight against terrorism and its root causes.  Space capabilities and services play an important role, among other areas in the context of European security and defence in areas such as external action, border management, maritime security, agriculture, the environment, climate change, energy security, disaster management, humanitarian aid and transport.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: this report buries without a word the French conception of space policy.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report addresses the development of European space capabilities for European security and defence. In short, the aim is to use space capabilities to put them at the service of the European Union's militaristic and bellicose policy. Space capabilities and services are considered to play an important role in a number of areas, such as external action, border management, maritime security or energy security. It is contradicted that space should not be militarised, but then it is considered that space capabilities should not be restricted to civilian activities, and should include security and defense, that is, militarization. The security dimension of the Copernicus programme is underlined. The space sector is included in a new overall EU strategy on foreign and security policy. The dangers of cyberwarfare and hybrid wars are identified - to justify the arms race it is necessary to mitigate the dangers, to create enemies, to which the EU will have to respond. Calls for enhanced US and EU cooperation on "space security"; strengthening close cooperation between the EU and NATO, also in space matters. These are more than enough reasons for our vote against, which we also justified with our speech in plenary.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: In writing ‒ space capabilities and services play an important role in European security and defence. They provide Member States and the EU with better operational capacity to implement the CSDP, but also other policies, such as maritime safety, agriculture, the environment, disaster management, humanitarian aid and transport. It is therefore important that we continue to develop the CSDP and include space in the EU's future policies already mentioned, but also to use space capabilities in the war against terrorism and terrorist organisations by locating and monitoring their training camps.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining because the effectiveness of this report is not predictable.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on space capabilities for European security and defence. The EU must invest in its space programme and become autonomous and not dependent on the US. The possibilities exist and should be exploited by the EU for the progress of all its services and in all areas for the better quality of life and safety of Europeans.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The security environment is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, both within and outside the Union, characterised by terrorist attacks, hybrid war and mass murder which affects all Member States and to which Member States must respond by adopting a joint strategy and a coordinated response. These security challenges call for the strengthening of the EU’s security through the continued development and support of the EU Common Security and Defence policy to make it a more effective policy instrument and a real guarantee of the safety of EU citizens and the promotion and protection of European norms, interests and values as enshrined in Article 21 TEU. The European Council of June 2015, which focused on defence, called for the fostering of greater and more systematic European defence cooperation with a view to delivering key capabilities, including through the coherent and efficient use of EU funds and existing EU capabilities. Space policy is an essential component of the strategic autonomy which the EU must develop in order to safeguard sensitive technological and industrial capabilities and independent capabilities to carry out assessments. I therefore supported the adoption of the report in the Plenary.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The security environment inside and outside the EU is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, as terrorist attacks and mass killings are occurring in all Member States, to which Member States must respond by adopting a common strategy and a coordinated response. The report therefore emphasises the importance of space-based instruments and the further development of these capabilities. The Union must work together to implement an effective and consistent border management system, to address the challenges facing our security, riots and armed conflicts in our neighbourhood, and migration, for which the development of these capabilities is absolutely necessary. The report stresses the need for the EU to improve access to space-based satellite communications, space observation, precision navigation and Earth observation capabilities and to ensure Europe's independence in terms of critical space technologies and access to space.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the establishment of a parliamentary committee of inquiry to comprehensively investigate alleged infringements and maladministration in the application of EU law in relation to money laundering, tax avoidance and tax fraud.  Cooperation between member states' tax authorities is more important than ever in order to reduce tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning. The global economic and financial crisis of recent years has highlighted the importance and enforcement of joint burden-sharing.  It is estimated that member states will be lost billions of euros in revenue as a reason for corporate tax avoidance. Businesses are taking advantage of the complexity of tax rules and the lack of cooperation from Member States to redeploy their profits and minimise their tax obligations. It is therefore essential to promote transparency and cooperation in the fight against aggressive tax planning and abusive tax practices. The importance of this has only been highlighted by the Panama Papers scandal, which makes the establishment of a commission of inquiry inevitable.  We need to investigate any allegations that the Commission has not enforced and the Member States have not actually implemented and actually implemented Directive 2005/60/EC, taking into account the obligation to implement Directive 2015/849 in a timely and effective manner.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the firm determination that a major step forward for the European Union is to move forward on security and defence, the current situation is becoming increasingly dangerous and difficult on security within and outside the Union, and Member States must respond by adopting a common strategy and a coordinated response , we must also continue to make progress in the Common Security and Defence Policy to make it a more effective policy instrument that ensures the security of EU citizens.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on space capabilities for European security and defence because I share the importance of space services with regard to both civil services and the EU's common security and defence policy. Space technologies can indeed be important instruments in the face of a number of challenges related to the security of citizens, while maintaining the principle of non-militarisation of space as requested by the Group of the Party of European Security and Energy. I believe that the contribution of this sector to job creation, technological innovation, research and control of natural disasters is fundamental, and I therefore agree with the need to work to overcome the current technological gap with the United States and to develop an aerospace industry that can become world excellence. The good results of the Galileo and Copernicus programmes confirm the potential of the sector, and the research funding provided for in Horizon 2020 can play an important role in relation to the problem of high costs.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from the vote on the 'Report on Space Capabilities for European Security and Defence'. It is true that I share the report's position that Europe needs more commitment from all Member States in space policy in the future, solely on security and defence issues. At the same time, I do not believe that we have come to the point where it could be a European task.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The new technologies promote both innovative space applications for daily life and security applications. This makes the economic development of space capabilities so important.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Satellite technologies are a vital part of the modern world, for instance if you are setting up a small business or buying goods on your smartphone. The UK works together with the rest of the EU to deliver high quality satellite networks which keep our economy running. Without the EU, Britain would not be able to build and operate a satellite network fit for our economic needs, and that is one of the myriad reasons why we must remain a member of the EU. However, this non-legislative report offers ideas which could interfere in what should be Member State or industry driven activity, and this lead me to abstain on the final vote.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that the security environment, both inside and outside the Union, is becoming increasingly dangerous and demanding, characterised by terrorist attacks and mass murders affecting all Member States and in relation to which states must adopt a common strategy and a coordinated response. These security challenges make it necessary to strengthen the security of the Union by constantly developing and supporting the EU's common security and defence policy, in order to make it a more effective political instrument and a real guarantee for the security of EU citizens and for the promotion and protection of European standards, interests and values. In my opinion, the EU needs to strengthen its role as a security guarantor within its borders and abroad, ensuring stability in its neighbourhood and globally.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote against this report. I agree with the rapporteur that the European Union's space capabilities should be incentivised and worked for improvement in innovation, as well as strategic independence in satellite navigation systems. But I do not agree on the military use of these space programs. Galileo and Copernicus should be used only for civilian purposes, and the European Union should not contribute to the militarization of Space.  On the other hand, the increase in funds on these issues should always be reviewed by the European Parliament, and not give so much prominence to the Space Agencies, that while they have to coordinate and manage, they should not do so without democratic oversight, nor for military purposes. The use of satellites for border control, as well as for the military resolution of the refugee crisis, is not the right way to end this problem. We must therefore always seek solutions based on civil society and the solidarity and values of the founding treaties of the European Union.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote, due to the fact that this non legislative report encroaches in areas that should be led by Member States. Nevertheless, satellite technologies are essential a huge variety of activities, such as setting up a small business or buying goods on your smartphone. Without the EU, Britain would not be able to build and operate a satellite network fit for our economic needs, so it is vital we stay in the EU.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. I believe that a holistic, integrated, long-term approach to the space sector at EU level is necessary. The space sector should be mentioned in the new EU Global Strategy on Foreign and Security Policy, bearing in mind the current development of EU dual-use space programmes and the need to further develop EU civil space programmes that can be used for both civil security and defence purposes.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The security environment inside and outside the EU is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, as terrorist attacks and mass killings are occurring in all Member States, to which Member States must respond by adopting a common strategy and a coordinated response. The report therefore emphasises the importance of space-based instruments and the further development of these technologies. The Union must work together to implement an effective and consistent border management system, to address security challenges, to riots and armed conflicts around the world, and to migration, for which the development of these technologies is absolutely necessary. The report stresses the need for the EU to improve access to space-based satellite communications, space observation, precision navigation and Earth observation capabilities and to ensure Europe's independence in terms of critical space technologies and access to space.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this as it has significant economic importance for the EU as well as expanding the cooperation amongst national space agencies within the EU.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the report, since we are against strengthening cooperation between the EU-US and THE EU-NATO over time. The report contributes to the development of the European military industry, while also requiring that public funds be used to provide funding for start-ups for innovative enterprises, to ensure that the high costs of space research are reduced .

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. I take a positive view of the strengthening of technical capacities in the civil and border security sectors, the strengthening of safety standards and the promotion of research. It is precisely the aspect of border security that is of great importance at the moment, and strengthening the European information systems in this area would be helpful. It also makes sense to open these systems to military purposes, but the European Parliament also wants increased cooperation between the EU's military and civilian programmes in the field of European security and defence policy. There is a risk of creating duplication of structures or increasing interdependence in areas currently covered by NATO. We do not want to replace NATO with a European army. Despite good approaches, the latter considerations led me not to support the report, but to abstain. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The security environment inside and outside the EU is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, as terrorist attacks and mass killings are occurring in all Member States, to which Member States must respond by adopting a common strategy and a coordinated response. The report therefore emphasises the importance of space-based instruments and the further development of these capabilities. The Union must work together to implement an effective and consistent border management system, to address the challenges facing our security, riots and armed conflicts in our neighbourhood, and migration, for which the development of these capabilities is absolutely necessary. The report stresses the need for the EU to improve access to space-based satellite communications, space observation, precision navigation and Earth observation capabilities and to ensure Europe's independence in terms of critical space technologies and access to space. On this basis, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report which encourages the European Union to develop multi-function technologies serving defence and security purposes, to create and promote models and systems that provide security and defence services, and to build a legal framework that allows investment at EU level on space capabilities for European security and defence - would result in broader and more systematic defence cooperation at this level.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Space Capabilities Report for European Security and Defence, as today the Union needs to work on solving its internal and external problems; from climate change, through poverty, migration to threats to security.  Space capabilities could be used to better assess and identify the influx of irregular immigrants and the routes they are moving and to identify boarding areas so that they can reach them more quickly and save more lives. In addition to this particular example, these capacities would also be useful in areas such as external action, border management, maritime security, agriculture, environmental protection, climate action, energy security, disaster management, humanitarian aid and transport.  Member States must adopt a common strategy and a coordinated response around continuous development and support for EU security and defence policy.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report buries the French conception of space policy. It has the merit of revealing the true nature of European projects for these programmes and technologies. A full renationalization of these policies must be designed in the face of this type of document, which jeopardizes our strategic and technological independence. That is why it makes sense to have voted against this text.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which stresses the need for a thorough analysis of the safety of satellite programmes and underlines the economic importance of space capacity development. The European Union is currently developing its own autonomous space programmes, such as Galileo, which allows for a very precise positioning, and Copernicus, which meets complex earth observation needs. It also plans to acquire new communication capabilities through the GOVSATCOM programme, which is currently in its preparatory phase.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report contains sensible approaches to strengthening the autonomy of European space policy. In the European Economic Area, there is a need to further promote the competitiveness of space policy, as many industries are directly and indirectly linked to it. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. I take a positive view of the strengthening of technical capacities in the civil and border security sectors, the strengthening of safety standards and the promotion of research. It is precisely the aspect of border security that is of great importance at the moment, and strengthening the European information systems in this area would be helpful. It also makes sense to open these systems up for military purposes, but the European Parliament also wants increased cooperation between the EU's military and civilian programmes in the field of European security and defence policy. There is a risk of creating duplication of structures or increasing interdependence in areas currently covered by NATO. We do not want to replace NATO with a European army. Despite good approaches, the latter considerations led me not to support the report, but to abstain.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report by the Space Sector for European Security and Defence. Today, more than yesterday, also as a result of the migration crisis and terrorist attacks that have compromised the security of our countries and the EU, it is necessary for the Member States to work together to achieve a harmonised system of national and European border controls. In this context, space policies are essential for maintaining security, and the report highlights the economic importance of developing these skills. I believe it is essential to promote capacity in these areas and we are working together in the EU to achieve these objectives.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The security environment inside and outside the EU is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, as terrorist attacks and mass killings are occurring in all Member States, to which Member States must respond by adopting a common strategy and a coordinated response. The report therefore emphasises the importance of space-based instruments and the further development of these capabilities. The Union must work together to implement an effective and consistent border management system, to address the challenges facing our security, riots and armed conflicts in our neighbourhood, and migration, for which the development of these capabilities is absolutely necessary. The report stresses the need for the EU to improve access to space-based satellite communications, space observation, precision navigation and Earth observation capabilities and to ensure Europe's independence in terms of critical space technologies and access to space.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The report pleads for the use of space-based capabilities and services for European security and defence purposes. However, the militarisation of the EU-space programs, initially conceived for EU Member States and for the private sector, generates some serious concerns, such as the expenditure provisions that will charge EU’s budget and consequently the need to prioritise space military assets within the context of an economic crisis. It also creates some serious doubts whether civilian systems may be used for other purposes and whether NATO’s role will be significant in the matter. Hence, I voted against.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is no doubt that security environment is ever changing. However, in recent years the security environment, both within and outside the Union, has become more dangerous and challenging due to the rise of international terrorism, aggression by foreign states and development of technologies. In this context, the weaponisation of space in terms of the development of anti-satellite (ASAT) technologies and orbital weapons capabilities by a number of actors stress the need of development of space capabilities for European security and defence. I voted in favour because in order to be competitive in space and protect its vital satellite infrastructure, the EU should enhance cooperation among its institutions such as European Defence Agency, European Space Agency and EU Satellite Centre. Deepen cooperation among institutions will ensure more competitive, transparent and consolidated European space industry as well as improved cyber-security and safety of EU citizens. Space capabilities are extremely vital in time of cyber warfare and digitalisation that is why the Union cannot allow itself to not develop and expand them.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it calls for the Europeanisation of space policies and their submission to NATO. This is particularly damaging to France, which is the EU's main space power.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on space capabilities for security and defence in Europe. This report is part of the current anti-terrorist atmosphere and takes advantage of this problem as well as the migration crisis to want to Europeanise space policy (point 2, point 14, point 50 on funding). It should be remembered that Europe of space is not even an intergovernmental programme, but a French programme (France alone covering on average 60% of the project budget plus all overruns) to which European countries have added to vampirize it. It should also be remembered that the independence of space technology is a central point of our sovereignty devices (vectors, surveillance, interception, militarization of space, communication). However, this report poses the spatial problem within the framework of NATO (considering C, point 23) and a transatlantic strategic partnership (considering M, point 21). It should be remembered that the strategic and technological independence that Gaullian France acquired, it also acquired against America. This report buries without a word the French conception of space policy.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted AGAINST this report. France defends a particular vision of space policy, which must above all be independent and an untouchable sovereign competence. The programme called Europe of Space is primarily a French design, covering almost 60% of the project budget and exceeding them. However, the text submitted to the vote, which is based on a context of counter-terrorism and migration crisis, wants to Europeanize space policy and give it a "UN" orientation, fighting against (theoretical) concepts such as hybrid wars or cyberwarfare. It is clear that there is an agreement between European and American leaders, who claim to be fighting the Russian enemy. Our French design, as well as our strategic and technological independence, are jeopardized by this report.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report calls for strengthening the EU's security and defence policy rather than prioritising civilian capacities in conflict resolution. In addition, it considers space capacity as an appropriate instrument for border management, internal security and energy and improving the development of the military-industrial complex. It advocates greater militarisation of space as well as the EU. I am opposed to the report, as it also calls for greater EU cooperation with the US and NATO in future space capabilities and services for the CSDP; advocates the use of dual-use space technologies in the space sector, which aims to contribute to the development of European military industry; and calls for mobilizing EU resources to increase its space capabilities in security and defence, deepening its militarisation. I understand that military research should not be financed from the EU budget, and that conflict resolution must take place from a peaceful, civil and diplomatic approach; for this reason, I am not only against greater collaboration between the EU and NATO, but I am calling for the dissolution of the latter.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. I take a positive view of the strengthening of technical capacities in the civil and border security sectors, the strengthening of safety standards and the promotion of research. It is precisely the aspect of border security that is of great importance at the moment, and strengthening the European information systems in this area would be helpful. It also makes sense to open these systems to military purposes. I thought it was important that the report emphasised that all efforts should be made in cooperation with NATO. We do not want to create double structures, and we do not want to replace NATO with a European army. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. "We Swedish Social Democrats share the view that the space sector plays an increasingly important role in security policy. Space research and increased space capabilities can be very useful from a broad security policy perspective, e.g. by facilitating humanitarian response and disaster management, or for monitoring global warming and natural disasters such as droughts, earthquakes or floods. We want to see cooperation safeguardaccess to space and the use of space services for peaceful purposes so that they promote human development and security. However, we would like to underline how important we think it is that space activities are conducted with due diligence and that the EU stands by the commitment not to militarise space. Nor do we want a common defence union to be established in the future and therefore voted against these wordings in the report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is not even able to guard its own land borders, so it is absurd for it to embark on Star Wars. The report calls for the 'institutionalisation of space', encourages Member States to implement joint programmes of the transnational space observation system for guarding. According to the report, "the EU must continue to strive to ensure the highest possible degree of autonomy in space research and military terms". I warn against the creation of a European army and European surveillance equipment at the expense of NATO.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Space capabilities are important for European security and defence in situations from daily peacetime use to armed conflicts. The European Union must strengthen its role as a security provider to contribute to the fight against terrorism on its territory and abroad. For this reason, innovation and space research for security and defence and raising public awareness among Europeans about the application of EU space programmes is encouraged. More appropriate management of financial resources is required due to increased costs of programmes within the budget. It also seeks to expand cooperation with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the US, NATO and with the United Nations and other neighbours and regional partners.  I supported this report, as I believe that the European Union needs to invest as much as possible in further growing the European space industry and expanding cooperation with partners to ensure regional security and contribute to the fight against terrorism.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the initiative for a single European strategy to coordinate the different strands of the European Union's space activities. It is essential for Europe to strengthen its industry and ensure independent access to space. We should not forget that satellite technologies can be very useful in the security sector, for example, with border control, monitoring of refugee waves, as well as for the control of air and sea traffic. High-resolution Earth observation data and positioning systems are a means of disaster and crisis management, including in the context of energy security and global food security. While the beginning of the era of space competition was laid out by the governments of the strongest countries, today we are seeing the use of space capacity for commercial purposes becoming more important to all. The sector contributes 320,000 employees and €52 billion in profits to member states' economies. These are one of the main prerequisites for the creation of a renewed governance framework at European level. I therefore supported today's motion for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the development of space capacity for European security and defence.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on space capabilities for European security and defence, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 7/6/2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This text aims to Europeanise space policy as part of an anti-terrorist programme as well as in the context of a migration crisis. It envisages this policy through NATO. However, the independence of space technology is a central point of our sovereignty devices ("vectors, surveillance, interception, militarization of space, communication"). This document jeopardizes our strategic and technological independence.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report dealing with space capabilities in the field of European security and defence. I am aware that the security situation in Europe is getting more complicated and worse and that there needs to be a debate on how to ensure the security of our citizens. I also agree with the need to find a comprehensive approach to crisis management, armed conflicts in the neighbourhood, deterioration of living conditions, as well as climate change and poverty. However, I cannot identify with some of the ideas in this report, which is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 The report on European space capabilities for security and defence shows that this aspect is key to the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy and other Union policies in areas such as external action, border management, maritime security, agriculture, the environment, climate action , energy security, disaster management, humanitarian aid or transport. We all know that the Union's space policy promotes scientific and technical progress, industrial competitiveness and the implementation of Union policies, including the above-mentioned security and defence policy. For this reason, it is important that the regulation of this area and the EU strategy on its promotion be clear and this report, which I have supported, makes clear the need for the Commission to bet on a safe and beneficial system for all, which will also enable us to deal with the threats that this development entails.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Public security and peace within the EU itself is being put at risk every day by the increase in terrorist attacks in the Member States of the Union. In this context, it is imperative to strengthen the Union's security by adopting a common strategy and coordination on the issues of the Common Security and Defence Policy in order to protect European citizens more effectively. The EU must find and address the root causes of the challenges it faces today, which are not confined within the EU itself but are cross-border. With this data, the EU's satellite capabilities can be used to better assess the capabilities of the security and defence strategy. I therefore believe that this resolution can contribute to improving access to satellite communications, space surveillance and precise navigation and earth observation capabilities, key strategic technologies, with the ultimate aim of scientific and technical progress and industrial competitiveness in security and defence matters. For the above reasons, I would like to give my vote in favour of the above resolution.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The draft refers to a dual research strategy in military and civilian terms. However, the focus is clearly on military research. In principle, an independent space programme is desirable, but military research in cooperation with NATO is questionable. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the resolution because I believe that the EU's space activities are essential for scientific and technical progress, innovation, economic growth, industrial competitiveness, skilled jobs and business creation.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is part of the context of the fight against terrorism and takes advantage of this problem to Europeanise space policy. It should be remembered, however, that France alone covers 60% of the budget for 'Space Europe' projects. It should also be remembered that the independence of space technology is a central point of our sovereignty mechanisms. Finally, the report raises the spatial problem within the framework of NATO and a transatlantic strategic partnership, going backwards from history. I obviously voted against this report.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am for this report due to Europe’s unique opportunity to further develop our domestic and international security through the development of space technologies.
