This report has the dual benefits of increasing the security of the EU and further economic and scientific development.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Security hazards, particularly terrorist threats, are increasingly present and pose a security risk both inside and outside the Union. In view of this situation, it is imperative, in my view, to continue the implementation of the CSDP while improving its effectiveness, visibility and results. Indeed, I believe that the use of space capabilities is essential in the fight against terrorism because it allows for effective surveillance of terrorist training camps. I would also like to stress the importance of a comprehensive long-term approach by the European Union to space policy. It is indeed necessary for the Union to integrate this strategy into the programme of the PSDC. I stress the need for close cooperation between the European Union and NATO in the area of security and defence, while leaving the Union with a great deal of autonomy at the space and military level so that it can eventually have its own instruments for establishing a defence union. To achieve this, I believe that the creation of a legal framework will promote more intense and systematic European cooperation on defence.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – Space policy is essential for the strategic autonomy that the European Union needs to develop in order to maintain sensitive technological and industrial capabilities, as well as independent assessment capabilities. Space capabilities for European security and defence are important and, in some cases, even essential for a wide range of situations, from day-to-day peaceful use to crisis management and more pressing security challenges, including direct warfare. The development of such capabilities requires long-term efforts. Research and development of space technologies is a sector with a high return on investment, which also creates high-quality software and hardware by-products with different commercial applications. I believe that Member States should improve access to capabilities in the field of satellite space communication, the acquisition of information on the situation in space, accurate navigation and observation of the Earth, and ensure Europe's independence with regard to key space technologies and access to space. Cooperation between Member States and the US, whose experience could be instrumental in space innovation, should also be encouraged. I fully support the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because the security environment is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, both within and outside the Union, characterised by terrorist attacks, hybrid war and mass murder which affects all Member States and to which Member States must respond by adopting a joint strategy and a coordinated response at all levels, including by developing the space capabilities. These security challenges call for the strengthening of the EU’s security through the continued development and support of the EU Common Security and Defence policy to make it a more effective policy instrument and a real guarantee of the safety of EU citizens and the promotion and protection of European norms, interests and values as enshrined in Article 21 TEU. Space capabilities, in Europe case, the satellites could be used, for example, to better assess and identify the flow of illegal immigrants and their routes, and, in the case of those coming from Northern Africa, to identify the ship-boarding areas in order to engage with them faster and save more lives. Space policy is an essential component of the strategic autonomy which the EU must develop in order to safeguard sensitive technological and industrial capabilities and independent capabilities to carry out assessments.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. Following the terrorist attack in Paris on 13 November 2015, France, referring to Article 42(7) of the Treaty on European Union, requested the assistance and support of the European Union. On this subject, the Report of the Committee on Foreign Affairs reviews the opportunities offered by space-based capabilities and services in terms of a common security and defence policy, the defence against terrorist attacks and mass killings affecting all Member States, ensuring stability, combating security challenges, in particular the security challenges arising from terrorism, better assessing and identifying the floods and routes of illegal immigrants and establishing the location of boarding for arrivals from North Africa. It calls for improving access to space-based satellite communications, space observation, precision navigation and Earth observation capabilities and for ensuring Europe's independence in terms of critical space technologies and access to space.  I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to Europeanise space policy, which at the moment is not an intergovernmental programme but a French programme. Moreover, France covers 60% of the budget as well as all overruns. Strategic and technological independence in space was achieved against the will of domination of the United States during the time of General de Gaulle and is decisive for our sovereignty. However, this report is a game of integration of the space sector within the framework of NATO and a transatlantic partnership. We therefore vote against it because we defend our French conception of space policy and its strategic independence.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The growing proliferation of space technology, with their use both for military purposes and increasingly for civilian purposes, such as GPS, weather forecasting, fire testing, among others, make the space sector a strategic area of utmost importance for the European Union.  In view of the potential of exploiting space capabilities, the European Union should seek to make use of it efficiently and sustainably, both in the context of security and defence policy and in other EU policies in areas such as external action, border management, agriculture, the environment, energy security, disaster management, sea security , among others. In this context, it would also be important to consider the development of security and defence-related space capabilities for the next generations of the Galileo and Copernicus systems. In this sense, I am voting in favour because I believe that the exploitation of space capacity is a sector of utmost importance within the framework of the Common Security and Defence Policy.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report buries the French conception of space policy without saying a word. It has the merit of revealing the true nature of European projects for these programmes and technologies. A full renationalization of these policies must be designed in the face of this type of document, which jeopardizes our strategic and technological independence. Vote obviously negative.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Whether you are setting up a small business or buying goods on your smartphone, it would not happen without satellite technologies. Britain works together with the rest of the EU to deliver high quality satellite networks which keep our economy running. Without the EU, Britain wouldn’t be able to build and operate a satellite network fit for our economic needs, so it is vital we stay in the EU. However, this non legislative report offers ideas which could interfere in what should be Member State or industry driven activity. We therefore abstained on the final vote.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on space capabilities for Europe's security and defence. In particular, I support the presence in this text of a provision which stresses that satellite capabilities could be used to better assess and identify the flows of illegal immigrants and the routes they take.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union’s security environment is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging. I have voted for this report that aims to strengthen EU security and increase its role as a security provider at home and abroad ensuring stability in its neighbourhood and globally.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that the EU's civilian programmes in the space sector provide a range of capacities and services that have potential uses in many sectors, including the next stages of the development of Copernicus and Galileo. At the same time, it should be noted that transparency and public awareness of the use of these programmes, which have a direct impact on users such as Galileo and Copernicus, among European citizens, are very important for the success of eu space programmes. It is also worth noting the existence of a public regulated service (PRS) of the Galileo programme, which is limited to government-approved users and is suitable for sensitive applications, where high durability and complete reliability must be ensured. It is therefore important to further develop the prs capacity in future generations in order to respond to changing threats.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because the draft calls for a dual research strategy, both militarily and civilly. Unfortunately, this is due to sensible approaches to strengthening the autonomy of the European Union.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The report on 'space capabilities for security and defence' and the resolution on the 'space market' concern two complementary aspects of EU policy, military and economic. They call on the EU and its Member States to make faster and more intensive use of space for military purposes to support eu imperialist interventions and operations as well as NATO, as well as its repression mechanisms, such as FRONTEX, revealing the main objectives of the EU's costly programmes, such as Galileo, Copernicus, EGNOS, CESAR, etc. At the same time, the political staff of monopolies see in space another area that can enhance capitalist profitability in various economic sectors (new technologies, defence industry, digital market, telecommunications), on the ground of the EU's fierce confrontations with its competing imperialist, capitalist associations and in space. Even the repression of refugees and migrants is part of the EU's space policy objectives, with satellite earth observation instruments, etc. It turns out that there is no side of EU action that is not being used to boost capitalist profitability that goes hand in hand with imperialist bloodshed and repression, to shield the power of capital to ensure the cruel exploitation of peoples.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the implementation of the common security and defence policy must always be pursued with greater commitment. In this context, I imagine that the development of space policy is a necessary objective in order to achieve two further objectives: planetary security and security in extra-atmospheric space. In the hope that there will be greater coordination of European space capabilities and increasingly important support for research and development activities in this area, I would like to vote in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Space capabilities play an important role to the European security and defence. The innovations in today’s security are a key point for our effective fight against terrorism. The development of the Galileo and Copernicus Programme, which will provide accurate positioning, is an important contribution to the necessary observations of borders, aerial transport, migration flow and so. This knowledge is crucial to EU security as a whole. An even broader cooperation is necessary between the Members States so that we enhance our space capabilities for even better security. I support the cooperation of the EU with other partners and the US as well in order to share and build on our capabilities.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support the Space Capabilities Report for European Security and Defence, as I believe that space capabilities and services play a significant role in the context of European security and defence. Current and future space capabilities and services will provide Member States and the EU as a whole with an increased dual intended and operating capacity to implement a common security and defence policy and other EU policies in areas such as external action, border management, maritime security, agriculture, environmental protection, climate action, energy security, disaster management, humanitarian aid and transport. A holistic and integrated approach to the space sector at EU level is necessary. The space sector should be included in the framework of the European Union's new global strategy for foreign and security policy, taking into account the current development of EU dual-use space programmes and the need to further develop EU civil space programmes that can be used for civilian security and defence purposes.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The EU's common security and defence policy must also include strategic space cooperation. The report stresses that space policy must also be taken into account in other policy areas, and stresses in particular that it contributes to the fight against terrorism and promotes the exchange of information through space-based satellite communication systems.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report buries without saying the French conception of space policy. It has the merit of revealing the true nature of European projects for these programmes and technologies. This is all the more damaging because the Ariane project has demonstrated that well-conducted intergovernmental cooperation is producing excellent results in space. Moreover, it is inconceivable that a democracy should delegate to opaque technocratic bodies areas essential for its defence and security. I am, of course, voting against this text.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The security environment, both inside and outside the European Union, is becoming increasingly dangerous and difficult to manage, characterised by horrific and asymmetrical wars, terrorist attacks and mass murders. All Member States have to deal with these threats and the best way to deal with them is certainly to adopt a common strategy. It is therefore essential that we continue to work on the development and strengthening of the Common European Security and Defence Policy, developing more effective instruments to ensure the security of European citizens and the promotion and protection of European standards, interests and values. As far as space technologies are concerned, satellites could make an important contribution in certain areas such as, for example, the location and identification of the routes of human traffickers who, in situations such as the Mediterranean, would save many more lives by starting rescues faster. The EU, as also requested by the June 2015 European Council, must achieve more systematic cooperation in the field of defence, including through a more efficient use of European funds. Space policy would also give an important boost to technological innovation in the civil field. For all these reasons, I am voting in favour of the report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The security situation in and outside the Union is increasingly dangerous and complex and is characterised by terrorist attacks and mass killings affecting all Member States in respect of which Member States must adopt a common strategy and a coordinated response. The Union must strengthen its resilience through cooperation and coordination with the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation and the United States, which guarantee the security and stability of Europe, and with the United Nations, the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, the African Union and other neighbours and regional partners. Therefore, I believe that space capabilities and services play an important role, inter alia, in the context of European security and defence. I am confident that current and future space capabilities and services will provide Member States and the Union with an increased dual-use operating capacity to implement a common security and defence policy and other EU policies in areas such as external action, border management, maritime security, agriculture, environmental protection, climate action, energy security, disaster management, humanitarian aid and transport. This is why I welcome the European Parliament's decision and believe that the EU could play a role in creating a more reliable, resusable and receptive European space capacity.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report pursues the European Union's militaristic and bellicose policy, this time through space capabilities as an important instrument for external action, border management, internal security, maritime and energy and to improve the development of the European military industrial complex.  Calls for enhanced EU cooperation (and submission) with the US and NATO on future space capabilities/services for csdp. It supports continued investment in space, security and defence agencies and the use of dual-use space technologies to contribute to the development of the European military industry. The whole report is imbued with the sense of having security and defence policies at the heart of the European Union's policies, in particular external action policy, deepening the aggressor nature of this process of European capitalist integration and the concept of "Fortress Europe". We voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported A Zdrojewski MP's report stressing that space programmes carry with them security and defence benefits and are technically linked to civil defence. The report highlights the strategic importance of an independent approach to space and the need for specifically targeted EU action. It also underlines the strategic importance of fostering innovation and space exploration for security and defence, and to this end, the process of dissemination of information from satellite to user needs to be improved, including the construction of the necessary technological infrastructure. The report directs Member States to fully engage in the decision-making process in order to avoid excessive administrative costs and to ensure that the programme is compatibled with strategic needs.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report deals with the role played by capabilities based on space programmes in the context of EU security and defence policy. Future developments in this sector will provide Member States and the EU as a whole with what we call 'enhanced operational capabilities' for the implementation of the common security and defence policy and on other issues. The report encourages Member States to use space programmes to implement joint security and defence initiatives. However, it also calls for enhanced EU-US cooperation in future space programmes and EU-NATO cooperation. The report adopts a number of amendments reinforcing the importance of national governments and cooperation with the US, as well as amendments stating that NATO remains a guarantor of European security and stability, as well as suggesting problems related to the launch of EU satellites by Russian Soyuz missiles. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The space technologies and services developed by the European Union are of major importance not only for civilian activities but also for our security and defence. It is with the need to strengthen our access to space and the development of ambitious and effective programmes in mind that I voted for this report on space capabilities for security and defence in Europe. Specifically, the EU's autonomous space programmes such as Galileo or Copernicus will need to require sustained protection and investment. Also, a programme such as GOVSATCOM, increasing our satellite communication capabilities in Europe, will be part of the arsenal of essential and high-tech tools to carry out the common European security and defence policy. Finally, special attention must be paid to European launchers and I also stress the need to preserve the formidable tool that is the Guyanese space centre in Kourou, spearheading a French space industry serving Europe.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. The security environment is becoming increasingly dangerous and demanding, both inside and outside the Union, characterised by terrorist attacks and mass murders affecting all Member States. This report argues that a joint strategy of all Member States should be adopted and a coordinated response should be given. The document also considers that space capabilities and services play an important role in this European defence context, helping in areas such as external action, border management, maritime security, agriculture, the environment, climate change, energy security, disaster management, humanitarian aid and transport.  This report states that national governments and the Union should improve access to space capabilities in terms of satellite communication, knowledge of the situation in space, precision navigation and Earth observation, and ensure European non-dependence on critical space technologies and access to space. I voted for it.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. With this text, we parliamentarians recall the vital importance to the European Union of space technologies and services, whether for civilian activities or for security and defence.  While supporting the principle of non-militarisation of space, we affirm through this report the need for Europe to acquire its own independent space capabilities (satellite communication, situation analysis, precision navigation or Earth observation), as they play a crucial role in border management, energy security, disaster management or transport. , but also in European security. In this regard, space policy is an essential component of the Union's strategic autonomy, in order to preserve its independent technological, industrial and evaluation capabilities.  Given the success of European space programmes (such as Copernicus, and soon Galileo), we call on the Commission and Member States to invest more in space infrastructure and to ensure that EU resources are used to the best of their ability.  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to improve Europe's space capabilities for security and defence. Unfortunately, the security situation is becoming more complex and dangerous, both within and outside our borders. The Union must be able to respond and its space policy can add value if it is used wisely and strengthened strategically. The space sector must be included in the EU's new comprehensive strategy on foreign and security policy issues. In addition, the need for the Union to be independent and autonomous in relation to its space capabilities and infrastructure should be emphasized, just as the commitment to non-militarisation of space should be emphasized. European cooperation must be strengthened, as must synergies between Member States and with European and international institutions. Space programs have advantages in terms of security and defence, but also in scientific, technological and industrial matters. European space policy must therefore be encouraged, especially as it is a source of success, as evidenced by the flagship civil programmes Galileo and Copernicus.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Space capabilities and services play an important role, among other areas, in the context of European security and defence. Current and future space services and capabilities will provide Member States and the Union with improved operational capacity for the implementation of the common security and defence policy and other EU policies in areas such as external action, border management, maritime security, agriculture, the environment, climate change, energy security, disaster management , humanitarian aid and transport.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. As the report points out, the security environment is becoming increasingly complex, both inside and outside the Union, with terrorist attacks and mass killings affecting all Member States.  These challenges call for strengthening EU security through the development and support of the Common Security and Defence Policy to make it a more effective political instrument and a real guarantee of the security of EU citizens and the promotion and protection of the rules, interests and values enshrined in the EMU. Space capabilities are key in many situations, from daily use in peacetime to managing the most pressing security crises and challenges. The potential of satellites could be used to better assess and identify the flow of illegal immigrants and their routes and, in the case of those from North Africa, to identify boarding areas, intercept them earlier and save more lives. It is therefore urgent to intensify defence cooperation with a view to building essential capacities, also using a coherent and efficient use of the Union's available funds and capacities.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European space programmes Galileo and Copernicus are above all civil programmes. But in these difficult times facing the European Union, these programmes must also support the Union's common security and defence policy. In voting in favour of the report on space capabilities for security and defence in Europe, I call on the Council, the Vice-President and high representative and the Commission to ensure that European space programmes put in place civilian space capabilities and services useful for European security and defence, in particular by devoting sufficient funds to research. In the interests of efficiency, I share the view that it is necessary to make dual use, both civilian and military, of space capabilities. I would add that it is, in my view, important that space policies dedicated to security and defence be led by a specific operational service coordination centre.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has an excellent platform for scientific and business cooperation, the space programme. By allocating several billion euros of EU taxpayers' money each year, we should have more control over the concrete benefits they bring. The benefits, I stress, can be measured both by a product that is specifically created and valued in cash, as at the point of new technologies or by the results of fundamental research. The report under consideration highlights these challenges of THE EU's space policy in a rather detailed manner. It is true that it must be emphasised that both parliament and the Commission's documents miss the other side– business – attitude and evaluation. What does business want from space policy, how much of its desires are based, and how unrealistic, and why many space-related business services, even those created by Europeans, rely on American GPS rather than European galileo and Copernicus services? This is a question that I have missed in this document.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The development of European space capabilities is of utmost importance for the Union and its Member States, as technological progress is increasing the number of innovative applications with daily and safety applicability. The EU has developed programmes such as Galileo and Copernicus, which have enabled not only precise positioning, covering the needs of observations made from Earth, but also having other plans to acquire new communication capabilities. Existing programmes require sustained and high investment, and are also of utmost use for missions under the Common Security and Defence Policy. The security purposes they serve are diverse, including the observation of borders, migration flows or even sea and air transport. Promotion and internal cooperation in the EU, as well as the exchange of experiences and information with external partners, will improve aspects of detail by maximising the benefits of this. Recognising the importance that these programmes can play in the safety of citizens, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The space sector, which was the subject of the report discussed and voted on in the AFET Committee, is a strategic field not only for defence and security, it can bring important benefits to other sectors. The benefits of innovations in this sector have repercussions in other economic areas, such as transport, agriculture, climate and energy. Taking an interest in space therefore means taking an interest in the citizens of Europe. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the report presented to plenary, which precisely underlines the economic importance of developing space capabilities and the necessary cooperation that the European Union must establish with the Member States in this area.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote against this report. I agree with the rapporteur that the European Union's space capabilities should be incentivised and worked for improvement in innovation, as well as strategic independence in satellite navigation systems. But I do not agree on the military use of these space programs. Galileo and Copernicus should be used only for civilian purposes, and the European Union should not contribute to the militarization of Space.  On the other hand, the increase in funds on these issues should always be reviewed by the European Parliament, and not give so much prominence to the Space Agencies, that while they have to coordinate and manage, they should not do so without democratic oversight, nor for military purposes. The use of satellites for border control, as well as for the military resolution of the refugee crisis, is not the right way to end this problem. We must therefore always seek solutions based on civil society and the solidarity and values of the founding treaties of the European Union.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. Europe faces a number of security challenges both inside and outside the EU. We have seen terrorist attacks, large migration flows and hybrid war. That is why we should coordinate our security efforts and develop a common strategy. Here, a well-developed space capacity can be advantageous. For example, satellites can be used to monitor coasts and seas, thus identifying and rescuing refugees from drowning in the Mediterranean. However, due to the Danish defence opt-out, I abstain from voting in favour of the part of the proposal which deals with the extension of the EU's military space capabilities. At the same time, it must also be stressed that Denmark has a reservation about pan-European asylum and immigration policy.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Report on Space Capabilities for European Security and Defence', as a separate space programme is very important for Europe, technical progress and also our security. The Copernicus and Galileo programmes already in place open up many possibilities. For example, this will allow us to better monitor our borders and migration, but also maritime and aviation. Especially in times of growing terrorism, this offers us a new form of surveillance and combating.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report calls for strengthening the EU's security and defence policy rather than prioritising civilian capacities in conflict resolution. In addition, it considers space capacity as an appropriate instrument for border management, internal security and energy and improving the development of the military-industrial complex. It advocates greater militarisation of space as well as the EU. I am opposed to the report, as it also calls for greater EU cooperation with the US and NATO in future space capabilities and services for the CSDP; advocates the use of dual-use space technologies in the space sector, which aims to contribute to the development of European military industry; and calls for mobilizing EU resources to increase its space capabilities in security and defence, deepening its militarisation. I understand that military research should not be financed from the EU budget, and that conflict resolution must take place from a peaceful, civil and diplomatic approach; for this reason, I am not only against greater collaboration between the EU and NATO, but I am calling for the dissolution of the latter.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which underlines the importance of the space sector within the framework of the Common European Security Policy. Space policy is an essential dimension and contributes to the EU's strategic autonomy. Having space capabilities is essential to European security and defence. The importance and added value of space policy under the CSDP must be emphasized. In this sense, space should be part of the Union's future policies, particularly in the fight against terrorism. In this context, space policy should pursue two key objectives: security on the planet through orbiting space systems and security in outer space. Given the current growth of the European Union's space programmes, it is necessary to integrate the space dimension into the EU's new overall strategy.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Whether you are setting up a small business or buying goods on your smartphone, it wouldn’t be possible without satellite technologies. The UK works together with the rest of the EU to deliver high-quality satellite networks which keep our economy running. Without the EU, Britain wouldn’t be able to build and operate a satellite network fit for our economic demands; this is also why it is vital that we stay in the EU. However, this non-legislative report offers ideas which could interfere in what should be the sole activity of a Member State or industry-driven activity. For this reason I abstained on this vote.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Space technologies today can no doubt be considered strategic from a defensive and security point of view. Europe must not fall asleep in this regard. Especially in today's volatile security time, when we are facing a number of security risks and challenges. We should therefore strengthen coordination between individual Member States and formulate a common space strategy in this spirit and be competitive in terms of global. We should also support strategic cooperation with NATO and with the United States of America, which continue to guarantee European security and stability. I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The security situation inside and outside the European Union is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging. They are characterized by terrorist attacks and mass killings, which call for the strengthening of the security of the European Union by further developing and supporting the Common Security and Defence Policy so that it becomes a more effective political instrument and a genuine guarantee for the security of the citizens of the European Union.  Nevertheless, it is not entirely clear whether the report on space capabilities for European security and defence seeks to influence the mid-term review of the financial perspective or perhaps to establish a link between terrorism and the need to develop space programmes for national audiences, or perhaps something third, which is regrettable.  While calling for the European Union to finance the space programme in the same amount as the US, this is rather unrealistic due to the limited budgets. Furthermore, terrorism and migration are used to legitimise the ineffective use of large amounts of public funds, which I do not support.  The report is also contradictory because, on the one hand, it requires the EU's strategic autonomy and, on the other hand, close EU cooperation with NATO and the US. It also wants the report to increase the security and military dimension of space programmes while opposing the militarisation of space.  On the basis of the above, I have decided that the report is not appropriate, which is why I did not support it in the vote.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. I take a positive view of the strengthening of technical capacities in the civil and border security sectors, the strengthening of safety standards and the promotion of research. It is precisely the aspect of border security that is of great importance at the moment, and strengthening the European information systems in this area would be helpful. It also makes sense to open these systems to military purposes, but the European Parliament also wants increased cooperation between the EU's military and civilian programmes in the field of European security and defence policy. There is a risk of creating duplication of structures or increasing interdependence in areas currently covered by NATO. We do not want to replace NATO with a European army. Despite good approaches, the latter considerations led me not to support the report, but to abstain.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 At a time when we are facing an information war being led against us by one of the space powers, it is important that we have mapped the state and capabilities of our defense against attacks also on our communication satellites and other devices in space.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this report because I believe that current and future space capabilities will provide an increased dual-designed operating capacity to implement common security for the Union and the Member States. Unfortunately, terrorist attacks and mass killings are the reasons for the increasingly dangerous and complex situation in the Union and affect all Member States. In my view, Member States need to be coordinated and have a common strategy to respond to the issue of terrorism. In order to ensure stability, the EU must also strengthen its role as a security provider on its territory and must contribute to combating the challenges arising from terrorism. The development and maintenance of space capabilities for security and defence in Europe requires effective cooperation and synergies between Member States and european and international institutions. Furthermore, I believe that space policy is a fundamental dimension of strategic autonomy that the EU must have in order to preserve sensitive industrial and technological opportunities.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Whether you are setting up a small business or buying goods on your smartphone, it wouldn’t happen without satellite technologies. Britain works together with the rest of the EU to deliver high quality satellite networks which keep our economy running. Without the EU, Britain wouldn’t be able to build and operate a satellite network fit for our economic needs, so it is vital we stay in the EU. However, this non-legislative report offers ideas which could interfere in what should be Member State or industry driven activity. We therefore abstained on the final vote.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's report on space capabilities for European security and defence. It refers to the EU's common security and defence policy, which I reject. The EU is already unable to develop a coherent strategy on the ground. A space programme is, above all, a work of financial capacity, without creating any added value in terms of security policy. On the contrary, the EU would become an actor that does not protect the Member States, but exposes them to a greater security risk.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The security situation in and outside the Union is increasingly complex and dangerous. Terrorist attacks affect all countries, so they must adopt a common strategy and find a coordinated agreement. The Union must strengthen its role as a recipient of security on its territory and abroad to ensure stability in its neighbourhood and globally.  Space policy is a fundamental dimension of strategic autonomy that the EU must have in order to preserve sensitive technological and industrial opportunities. Space capabilities and services play an important role, inter alia, in the context of European security and defence. Current and future space capabilities and services will provide Member States and the Union with dual operating capacity to implement common security and defence policies and other EU policies.  I support the proposal for a resolution, as I believe that national governments and the Union need to improve access to space satellite communication, awareness of the state of space, precise navigation and Earth observation, and ensure Europe's independence from space technologies.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on space capabilities for European security and defence. Given the increasingly difficult situation in the world and in our neighbourhood, I am thinking, above all, of terrorist attacks, we need swift action at all levels. We need a common strategy and a coordinated response, particularly as regards the EU's common security and defence policy, because the security of our citizens must come first. I support the report, which attaches an important role to space capabilities and services in the area of European security and defence. I therefore join the call for further implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy and to increase efficiency, visibility and impact.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 As stated in the report, the aim is to exploit the new space capabilities to strengthen the European defence and security policy aimed at further promoting militarisation, strengthening the synergy of civilian and military forces, limiting the sovereign role of Member States in foreign policy issues, and in particular strengthening the EU-NATO relationship.   The use of space to serve these purposes finds us opposed. We also have a particularly negative impact on the proposal to develop and promote the GALILEO programme for military law enforcement purposes through surveillance. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU must invest in its space programme and become autonomous and not dependent on the US. The possibilities exist and should be exploited by the EU for the progress of all its services and in all areas for the better quality of life and safety of Europeans.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The security environment inside and outside the EU is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, as terrorist attacks and mass killings are occurring in all Member States, to which Member States must respond by adopting a common strategy and a coordinated response.  The report therefore emphasises the importance of space-based instruments and the further development of these capabilities. The Union must work together to implement an effective and consistent border management system, to address the challenges facing our security, riots and armed conflicts in our neighbourhood, and migration, for which the development of these capabilities is absolutely necessary. The report stresses the need for the EU to improve access to space-based satellite communications, space observation, precision navigation and Earth observation capabilities and to ensure Europe's independence in terms of critical space technologies and access to space.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the development of the EU's capabilities in space exploration, asset development and dual-use space. In developing my opinion, I have taken into account the changes in the international security environment of Europe and of the European Union and its Member States, the new types of challenges to which an effective response can only be given through a joint EU effort, with the same objectives. I support the holistic approach expressed in the report from the point of view of the CSFP and the CSDP, as well as the push for the dual use of European space capability, programmes and instruments, as is already the case with the Galileo and Copernicus programmes.  I also agree that the material underscores separately the interaction between the development of defence and civil space capability and the underpinning of the technical and scientific development of the Member States. In general, I am convinced that without the development of its own space research and capabilities, the EU's meaningful global engagement will not be conceivable in the future, and we must provide adequate political support from the European Parliament.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The space sector is an extremely important element not only for the European economy, but also for the security of EU citizens. The Earth observation and precision navigation capabilities that the Union is building will provide us with opportunities for better border management, early disaster warning, as well as maritime and air traffic control. Eu space programmes are therefore a guarantee of our security. These systems are also an opportunity to develop not only for the large space technology industry, but also for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are increasingly participating in major space exploration projects. The increasing influence of the private sector on space technology development has been observed for some time. We should support these projects and wisely direct development funds so that smaller countries that are just entering the European space technology market also benefit from it. The report presented also rightly highlights the previously neglected promotional aspect of European satellite programmes. We create a new GPS, alternative and more accurate than the American system. Copernicus gives you high-resolution satellite images. It is therefore important that Europeans are aware of the european Union's actions.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Lately, the security of the European Union has begun to be threatened by phenomena with a high degree of danger, such as terrorist attacks, hybrid warfare and mass killings, which can affect all Member States. The response should be a new common and coordinated strategy within the framework of the European security and defence policy, aimed at the safety of European citizens and the protection of European rules, interests and values. One of the components of this policy is the Union's spatial capabilities, manifested in the presence of European satellites or Member States in outer space. They could be used to detect possible threats to EU security early, for example to identify flows and routes of illegal immigrants or embarkation areas, in order to save lives. At the June 2015 European Council dedicated to the issue of defence, the need for systematic cooperation at European level was supported, including through the efficient use of existing European funds and capabilities, including the Union's space policy. In this way, important EU defence capabilities could be developed which, beyond their military application, would constitute important tools for the security of European citizens. I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the report. Indeed, space capabilities and services play an important role, among other things, in the context of European security and defence. I am convinced that current and future space capabilities and services will provide Member States and the Eu with improved dual-use operational capacity for the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy and other EU policies in areas such as external action, border management, maritime security, agriculture , the environment, climate action, energy security, disaster management, humanitarian aid and transport.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution underlining that the European space programmes, Galileo (navigation) and Copernicus (observation of the Earth), are crucial to Member States’ security. With this text we urge the Council, the Vice President/High Representative and the Commission to ensure that European space programmes develop civilian space-based capabilities and services with relevance for European security and defence capabilities, particularly through the allocation of adequate funds for research, for example through the Horizon 2020 framework programme. We need today a holistic, integrated and long-term approach to the space sector at EU level. The space sector should, consequently, be mentioned in the new EU Global Strategy on Foreign and Security Policy.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Space policy is a fundamental dimension of strategic autonomy that the European Union must have in order to preserve sensitive technological industrial opportunities, as well as independent evaluation opportunities. The security environment is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, both inside and outside the Union, terrorist attacks and mass killings affect all members and therefore member states must react by adopting common strategies and coordinated treaties. I believe that the European Union must strive to achieve the highest possible autonomy at space and military level and strive to have its own instruments for the establishment of a defence union.  However, this report calls for strengthening the Union's security and defence policy rather than making concrete proposals to address conflicts. Since I do not support the militarisation of the Union, I voted abstention.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on space capabilities for European security and defence, as space policy represents an essential element of strategic independence that the EU needs to develop. Space capability is important for European security and defence, both from an everyday point of view during the peace period and in cases of major challenges in the wartime period. In the case of a more developed space capability, the EU could also take action in the field of defence through the European Defence Agency (EDA) and the EU Satellite Centre. In recent decades, European space assets have been developed thanks to coordinated efforts by the European Space Agency. Successful cooperation and interaction between Member States is necessary for the development and maintenance of space security and defence capabilities in Europe. Space capabilities play an important role in the context of European security and defence.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote against this report. I agree with the rapporteur that the European Union's space capabilities should be incentivised and worked for improvement in innovation, as well as strategic independence in satellite navigation systems. But I do not agree on the military use of these space programs. Galileo and Copernicus should be used only for civilian purposes, and the European Union should not contribute to the militarization of Space.  On the other hand, the increase in funds on these issues should always be reviewed by the European Parliament, and not give so much prominence to the Space Agencies, that while they have to coordinate and manage, they should not do so without democratic oversight, nor for military purposes. The use of satellites for border control, as well as for the military resolution of the refugee crisis, is not the right way to end this problem. We must therefore always seek solutions based on civil society and the solidarity and values of the founding treaties of the European Union.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from this report, the text does not very happily mix security and military procedures in the European space projects Galileo and Copernicus. However, we should focus above all on EU cooperation in terms of autonomy of access to space and the associated industrial potential. The Galileo and Copernicus programmes should remain primarily civilian. In the area of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP), we must be careful not to create a parallel structure to NATO.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is part of the current anti-terrorist atmosphere and takes advantage of this problem as well as the migration crisis to want to Europeanise space policy. It must be remembered that The Europe of Space is not even an intergovernmental programme, but a French programme to which European countries have added themselves to vampirize it. It should also be remembered that the independence of space technology is a central point of our sovereignty mechanisms. However, this report poses the spatial problem within the framework of NATO and a transatlantic strategic partnership. It should be remembered that the strategic and technological independence that France has acquired, it has also acquired against America. It should also be noted that the report once again tightens the NATO diatribe against hybrid wars (a vague concept in terms of military history) and cyberwarfare. These words are codes in the literature of the Alliance to designate the Russian enemy. This report buries without a word the French conception of space policy. It has the merit of revealing the true nature of European projects for these programmes and technologies. So I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 A European security and defence policy on space policy is important for the European Union in both peacetime and potential war. At a time of increasing competition for space resources (m.in, satellites, etc.) The EU should endeavage to strengthen cooperation and coordination with NATO and US efforts. Satellite capabilities can be used m.in. to better assess and identify the flow of illegal immigrants or in the fight against terrorism. I therefore supported the motion for a resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The security environment inside and outside the EU is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, as terrorist attacks and mass killings are occurring in all Member States, to which Member States must respond by adopting a common strategy and a coordinated response. Space policy is an essential arrelia of strategic autonomy that the EU needs to develop in order to preserve sensitive technological and industrial capabilities and independent assessment capabilities. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote against this report. I agree with the rapporteur that the European Union's space capabilities should be incentivised and worked for improvement in innovation, as well as strategic independence in satellite navigation systems. But I do not agree on the military use of these space programs. Galileo and Copernicus should be used only for civilian purposes, and the European Union should not contribute to the militarization of Space.  On the other hand, the increase in funds on these issues should always be reviewed by the European Parliament, and not give so much prominence to the Space Agencies, that while they have to coordinate and manage, they should not do so without democratic oversight, nor for military purposes. The use of satellites for border control, as well as for the military resolution of the refugee crisis, is not the right way to end this problem. We must therefore always seek solutions based on civil society and the solidarity and values of the founding treaties of the European Union.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Voted against as very badly structured, contradictory document, also terrible links between space policy and migration and terrorism. Only positive outcome is that our language on the need to prevent an arms race outer space was carried (parag.27).

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on space capabilities for European security and defence. The report emphasizes the important role that space-based capabilities and services play in, among other areas, the context of European security and defence. The report urges national governments and the Union to improve access to space-based satellite communication, space situational awareness, precision navigation and Earth observation capabilities, and ensure European non-dependence as regards critical space technologies and access to space. I voted in favour because I strongly believe that research and development in the field of space technology and services should be strengthened within a consistent EU policy framework.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This report highlights the economic importance of space capacity building and the need to develop more mechanisms for cooperation between European space programmes and those of their Member States. It is important to continue to be committed to the development of spatial capabilities through existing Galileo and Copernicus programmes, as well as through new programmes. We are talking about key technologies to be able to continue to innovate and be able to apply them in the future to productive sectors, with the consequent creation of jobs. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Zdrojewski report focuses on space capabilities for security and defence in Europe. Under the guise of offering "a real guarantee of (...) security (to) European citizens" and to fight terrorism, this report is part of the strengthening of the EU's Common Security and Defence Policy (PSDC), which focuses on both militarisation and rapprochement with NATO. This report is also a concern on the migration issue. In particular, it proposes to consider that satellite capabilities could be used to "better assess and identify the flows of illegal immigrants and the routes they follow" and thus be used for migration control purposes. The saving of lives is being put forward, but we know what is happening and I will continue to denounce the security excesses of migration policies which are instead responsible for an increasing number of deaths in the Mediterranean. Refusing a strengthening of the PSDC, a civil and military approach to space capabilities and ever-increasing cooperation with NATO, I voted against this initiative report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The fundamental message of this report is that space capabilities are also put to the defence and security service.  Space capabilities and services are considered to play an important role including in security and defence issues, including in security and defence issues, including in areas where these space capabilities can play an important role: external action, border management, maritime security, energy security, just to mention a few. The argument of preventing humanitarian disasters is used to, in a way, hide the real purpose of strengthening the security and defense capacity of space satellites. Hence our vehement opposition.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The draft calls for a dual research strategy, both military and civilian. The fundamentally very good idea of an independent space strategy is becoming a joint armament plan with NATO. Unfortunately, this is due to sensible approaches to strengthening the EU's autonomy, so that a fundamental focus on the US and NATO also prevails in space policy.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I strongly endorse this parliamentary resolution. Today, space is closer to us than ever before. As a consequence, human activity in space is rapidly increasing. Technological and scientific developments within this field have brought us many important innovations and will continue to do so. But, this also comes with security implications. As we become more dependent on, for example; satellites, we also become more vulnerable. For example, without the proper security, self-driving cars would become vulnerable to hackers. This resolution calls for increased investment in space technology, security of this technology, legal solutions to conflicts that might come up in the future, and an international code of conduct to prevent these. I agree that the EU’s diplomatic services and the EEAS can play an important role herein. Finally, I welcome the resolution’s call for EU-US cooperation as we surely will be able to accomplish more if we cooperate.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the own-initiative report to increase European space capacity in its security applications. A common space policy, with the implementation of a European satellite system, will in fact guarantee greater security for European citizens, particularly in the fight against terrorism. I particularly appreciated the attention paid to humanitarian crises: thanks to information from space, it will be easier to help areas affected by natural disasters or people in emergency situations. This potential can be useful especially in response to the recent migrant crisis, as the text shows. Finally, I am convinced that this sector represents an important opportunity for the European economy. Investing in space means investing in our research and in our large industries and SMEs.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The report on 'space capabilities for security and defence' and the resolution on the 'space market' concern two complementary aspects of EU policy, military and economic. They call on the EU and its Member States to make faster and more intensive use of space for military purposes to support eu imperialist interventions and operations as well as NATO, as well as its repression mechanisms, such as FRONTEX, revealing the main objectives of the EU's costly programmes, such as Galileo, Copernicus, EGNOS, CESAR, etc. At the same time, the political staff of monopolies see in space another area that can enhance capitalist profitability in various economic sectors (new technologies, defence industry, digital market, telecommunications), on the ground of the EU's fierce confrontations with its competing imperialist, capitalist associations and in space. Even the repression of refugees and migrants is part of the EU's space policy objectives, with satellite earth observation instruments, etc. It turns out that there is no side of EU action that is not being used to boost capitalist profitability that goes hand in hand with imperialist bloodshed and repression, to shield the power of capital to ensure the cruel exploitation of peoples.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I welcome the report on the European Union's ability to act in space. Acquiring such capacity is crucial in many situations, both in terms of security and in day-to-day crisis management. It also has an important economic and scientific dimension, as it is estimated that 7% of EU GDP depends on satellite positioning and satellite navigation technology. In this context, it is important to support the European Galileo and Copernicus programmes. Data from earth satellite observation help to manage natural disasters, humanitarian missions, refugee aid, energy security and food security more efficiently. This indicates the need to increase European resources for the development of its own satellite systems. Galileo and Copernicus are two of the EU's leading programmes, the successful implementation of which would confirm Europe's position in the world.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on space capabilities for European security and defence. In the light of the security situation in the Union, I support the proposal to improve access to space communication capabilities with satellites, space monitoring, precise navigation and Earth observation. Satellite capabilities would be used to better assess and detect the flow of illegal immigrants, their routes and – for those coming from North Africa – to detect boarding areas in order to capture them more quickly and save more lives.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr The European Union's scientific base in general is one of the most developed in the world and, of course, also applies to the space sphere. Perhaps only countries such as the US, Russia, China, India and Japan currently have greater or equivalent capacity in the space sphere as the European Union. But i therefore unequivocally support the encouragement of the Commission to come up with a comprehensive, ambitious, forward-looking strategy as soon as possible, which, unfortunately, does not currently have, and which could help the European Union to maintain a leading position in the relevant global markets in the short and long term in the space technology sector. And apart from the need to increase investment, it must be said that, in general, every European citizen will benefit from it, because space and the space market are closely linked, in principle, to all areas in the European Union.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the main elements of the strategy should be the market deployment of space data, services and applications in order to maximise the socio-economic benefits of European space programmes. It also promotes the internationalisation of space companies including SMEs, through better access to finance and adequate support for the competitiveness of the European space industry. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution, because space should not be a commodity left to the market, but is part of the environment, a public good that must be protected by decisions of democratic institutions and not by the interests of multinationals. Faced with manifest problems such as the presence of space junk, this resolution encourages market-controlled development of the industry, more importantly, encourages the putting resources and public research in the hands of private actors. The report further refers to the potential military uses that such a 'market' may entail. In my opposition to the possible military uses that may be given to space, the use of public resources for the benefit of private companies, as well as my opposition to the privatization of the environment, including space, is why I have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution on the opening up of the space market and space technologies.  Like the Space Capabilities Report, it buries any desire for serious strategic independence and applies an irrelevant economic logic about space. Indeed, space is above all an extension of the field of defence.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution which calls for more market access in space, increased marketing promotion and for more funding EU regarding space developments. The resolution completely fails to critical assess this unnecessary spending, and moreover there are even parts in which they basically say that public spending is necessary to stimulate private sector investments. Also, there is nowhere in the resolution a clear distinction between military functionality of the EU space assets, and civilian and peaceful use. Because of that, I recommend to vote against.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the opening of a space market and the EU's efforts to boost investment and access to technology and data. It is essential for the EU to invest in the infrastructure of the European GNSS and Copernicus programmes by 2020. The Commission must also carry out 'space control' of all existing and new strategic initiatives to ensure that EU resources are used wisely in this area.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on space strategy and market penetration, which welcomes the progress made in relation to the two space flagship programmes, Galileo and Copernicus. It also believes that complementary programmes should be considered, and further synergies encouraged, and calls on the Commission to respect the timetable and ensure the rapid and full exploitation of the space and ground infrastructure and services provided by the two flagship programmes.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is a unique resolution on the opening up of the space market and space technologies taken during the space debate marked by the plenary vote on the Foreign Affairs Committee's report on space capabilities. This resolution opposes any serious desire for strategic independence and applies an irrelevant economic logic about space, which remains above all an extension of the field of defence. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I voted against this report.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the placing on the market of products in the space sector. EU space activities are essential for scientific and technical progress, innovation, economic growth, industrial competitiveness, social cohesion, skilled job creation and enterprise creation and new opportunities in both downstream and downstream markets. Satellite navigation, Earth observation and satellite communications services can make a significant contribution to the implementation of a wide range of Union policies. I support the calls for the Commission to present a comprehensive, ambitious and forward-looking strategy that ensures Europe's leadership in global markets for space technologies and services in the short, medium and long term, ensures independent access to space and ensures a level playing field for the European space industry. One of the key elements of the strategy should be the development of the space data, services and applications market, with a view to maximizing the socio-economic benefits of the EU's space programmes.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which calls on the Commission to present a comprehensive, ambitious and forward-looking strategy to ensure that Europe has a leading position in the fields of space technologies and services in short-, medium- and long-term global markets, independent access to space and a level playing field for the European space industry.  It is important to adopt a strategy that takes into account the needs of users of public, private and scientific services. In addition, there is a need for a clear, precise and appropriate legislative framework for scientific and technical progress.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Space technologies and research and development activities are a crucial sector for the foreseeable future, in particular through high investment returns and the creation of high-quality software and hardware by-products, which find numerous commercial applications. My vote in favour of the Zdrojewski report is based on the conviction that investment in space technologies must be a priority in the field of foreign and security policy. Through the use of satellite capabilities it is already possible to identify irregular migrant flows, their routes and above all the boarding areas on ships in order to intervene more quickly and save more lives. Terrorist group training camps can be located and monitored, as well as interventions in fields ranging from maritime security to transport, through agriculture and humanitarian crisis management, can be enhanced. The achievement of these objectives depends on a general improvement in access to space capabilities and real European independence in critical space technologies. The text adopted calls on the Commission to develop a White Paper which will help to identify a coherent European space policy.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against this Motion for a Resolution, which proposes a market system in the space sector, promoting investment and support to private companies of different space services. With the excuse of promoting research and development, what is achieved is to leave in private hands services that should always be oriented to the common benefit and not to enrich private interests. I believe that advances in this sector must always be led by academic scientific research, common interests, and never have a component of militarization as they do today. In turn, we regret the previous "kitchen" that exists in these reports by the Grand Coalition, which leave no room for objections from a sector critical of the bellicolist use of space capabilities and services. Using security and fear discourse to increase the militarization of Space.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. The impetus for a space strategy is essential to end the fragmentation of the digital market, to demonstrate the added value that the Union brings to the economy of this region of the world, to ensure Europe's independence in the sector, to foster a new source of specialization and trade and to enable entrepreneurs to have basic infrastructures for new businesses based on knowledge and exploitation of Big Data. Decidedly, the space strategy must take a preferred place in the European strategy of re-industrialization and relaunch of our economy. In this scenario, the cuts in public investment linked to these programmes are a real counter-feeling with the 2020 development model.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal for a resolution on the opening of a European space market is part of the Europeanisation of space policy, which means the end of the intergovernmental procedure that has made these programmes successful (including French programmes). Unfortunately, this text gives the Commission all the power and authority. I refuse this state and so I have decided to vote against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The potential of Italian entrepreneurship in the space technologies sector is extremely relevant. I believe it is essential for Europe to structure a strategy that will enable it to be in a dominant position in this field and in this market. The return to our businesses and territories will certainly be important. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In space activities, the European Union has a key source of scientific and technological development, but also of highly skilled economic activity, competitiveness and employment. According to studies prepared by Parliament, between 6% and 7% of Western countries' GDP depends on activities linked to satellite positioning and navigation. In addition, the global European satellite navigation system is expected to generate economic and social benefits in the coming two decades, amounting to between EUR 60 billion and EUR 90 billion. And most of that value will be generated by small and medium-sized enterprises. As this resolution, which I have supported, claims, Europe must make a strong bet on developing its space programme so as not to lose its global leadership in this field. Therefore, the space strategy that the Communication must launch in the second half of the year must be to make the development and commercialization of products, services and applications at its centre of gravity to maximize the socio-economic benefits of community space programmes.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it has given Parliament its position on the development of the space market. EU space activities are essential for scientific and technical progress, innovation, economic growth, industrial competitiveness, social cohesion, skilled job creation and enterprise creation and new opportunities in both downstream and downstream markets. Satellite navigation, Earth observation and satellite communications services can make a significant contribution to the implementation of a wide range of Union policies, while satellite navigation and Earth observation services could be of great benefit to EU citizens. The EP therefore called on the Commission to present a comprehensive, ambitious and forward-looking strategy that ensures Europe's leadership in global markets for space technologies and services in the short, medium and long term, ensures independent access to space and ensures a level playing field for the European space industry. Parliament also indicated that one of the key elements of the strategy should be the development of the space data, services and applications market, with the highest possible socio-economic benefits of the EU's space programmes. Parliament called on the Commission to present a proposal for a clear European space industrial policy to be included in the future strategy.

name: David Borrelli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European space strategy being defined should ensure support, coherence and continuity for the Galileo and Copernicus programmes, but above all accelerate the process of transferring satellite data to services and applications. We need to make sure that the use of this data is actually useful to society, research and entrepreneurs, and I am thinking in particular of innovative start-ups and small and medium-sized enterprises. The commercialisation of satellite data-based services covers a great many sectors and represents an opportunity that Europe cannot miss. It will be essential to have an increasing number of European companies able to make the most of the great potential of this data and make the best use of these technologies in order to provide new value-added services, without, however, obliging the companies themselves to move outside the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution is in the same vein as the Space Capabilities Report (Zdrojewski report). It buries any serious desire for strategic independence and applies an irrelevant economic logic about space. Indeed, space is above all an extension of the field of defence. So I voted against it.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
