text: In writing. This report calls on the European Commission to present a comprehensive space strategy, including the opening up of the data, services and space applications market. This European space policy, which the rapporteur calls for, in his view, should be based on increased participation by regional authorities. While increased financial and technological cooperation between Member States seems desirable, we challenge the European Union's desire to create a common space policy within the framework of NATO. It is our strategic interest in defence. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The development of a space market can make a significant contribution in terms of economic growth, industrial competitiveness, social cohesion and job creation. Given that the EU currently does not have an integrated and coherent spatial policy, I believe that the implementation of flagship space programmes is needed to demonstrate the added value and potential of the European Union in this sector. Space data and services can play an important role, giving Europe the chance to be at the forefront of major technological trends, such as the Internet of Things, smart cities and more. I voted in favour of this resolution because I support the development of a coherent EU strategy in this area, which, among other things, should be intended to support space entrepreneurship.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Space is an area of excellence in which Europe plays a leading role. As such, it is necessary to continue our efforts to implement the Galileo and Copernicus programmes, in which we have invested heavily. On the other hand, the European Union must affirm its political and financial support for the space sector because it contributes to innovation and growth in a cross-cutting way. The consequences of the proliferation of global players in the space sector, particularly in emerging countries, as well as competition from NewSpace, should also be taken into account. I therefore voted in favour of this Parliament's resolution, which proposes ways for European space policy in the 21st century.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution today because I believe it is necessary to implement an ambitious global strategy that will ensure that Europe, in the short and long term, has a dominant position in the field of space technologies and services. In order to strengthen European autonomy, it is essential that the Galileo and Copernicus programmes use an innovative approach to the implementation of technology. We need to develop the duality of these programmes and, in this way, focus on both civil security and defence. Space is an investment-intensive industry with very long development cycles. Although the space industry is a niche sector, it generates world-class annual turnover. Over the next twenty years, the EU's global navigation satellite system is expected to create economic and social benefits worth between around EUR 60 billion and EUR 90 billion. I am also convinced that there is considerable potential for the commercialisation of space technologies in terms of approach to the recent challenges posed by migration, border management and sustainable development. Finally, a future strategy will have to pay particular attention to simplifying access to finance for European start-ups and small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution which calls for more market access in space, increased marketing promotion and for more funding EU regarding space developments. The resolution completely fails to critically assess this unnecessary spending, and moreover there are even parts in which they basically say that public spending is necessary to stimulate private sector investments. Also, there is nowhere in the resolution a clear distinction between military functionality of the EU space assets, and civilian and peaceful use. Because of that, I voted against.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Having not encountered any particular critical issues, I voted in favour of the commercialization of space technologies.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and urge the Commission to present a comprehensive, ambitious and forward-looking strategy, ensuring In the short, medium and long term Europe's leading position in space technologies and services in global markets, in order to ensure Europe's independent access to space and a level playing field for the European space industry.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In my opinion, the possibility of having autonomous access to space will bring many benefits to the European Union and its citizens. Activities in the space sector are of considerable importance in terms of scientific progress, innovation and economic growth. Furthermore, the use of navigation and satellite communication services is, in my view, of significant importance in the implementation of various Union policies. I therefore believe it is important for the Commission to present a comprehensive strategy with the aim of guaranteeing Europe a position of power in the field of space technologies and services so that space can have independent access to space. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ We need to see a comprehensive, ambitious and forward-looking strategy, ensuring in the short, medium and long term Europe’s leading position in space technologies and services on global markets, ensuring independent access to space for Europe and ensuring a level playing field for the European space industry.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. THE EU's space activities are of utmost importance for scientific and technical progress, as well as for innovation, economic growth, job creation, business and new opportunities. To this end, the European Commission should present a comprehensive and forward-looking strategy that will ensure europe's leading position in space technologies and services on world markets in the short, medium and long term, independent access to space and a level playing field for the European space industry. It should also promote the internationalisation of European space enterprises, in particular SMEs, through better access to adequate support funding for the competitiveness of the European space industry, as well as specific actions at EU level enabling Europe to access space autonomously. The EU and the Member States should, in cooperation with the private sector, step up their efforts to stimulate skills and entrepreneurship and attract students from technical universities, young scientists and entrepreneurs to the space sector, which will help maintain the leadership capacity in space science and prevent brain drain to other parts of the world.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution, because space should not be a commodity left to the market, but is part of the environment, a public good that must be protected by decisions of democratic institutions and not by the interests of multinationals. Faced with manifest problems such as the presence of space junk, this resolution encourages market-controlled development of the industry, more importantly, encourages the putting resources and public research in the hands of private actors. The report further refers to the potential military uses that such a 'market' may entail. In my opposition to the possible military uses that may be given to space, the use of public resources for the benefit of private companies, as well as my opposition to the privatization of the environment, including space, is why I have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ EU space activities are important for the overall development of scientific progress while also stimulating innovation, new and diverse employment opportunities and industrial competitiveness. It is an untapped market that has the potential for growth and development to benefit not only research and development but global communities through the use of specific tools such as satellite navigation, earth observation and communication services established through satellite implementation. All of these new technologies could not only benefit European Union policies, but also the daily lives of European citizens if the EU works towards maximising the socio-economic benefits of EU space programmes. For this reason, I voted in favour of this resolution which calls for more development in this sector.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the opening of a space market. The resolution recommends that the infrastructure of European space programmes and their services be used in related policies and programmes, in particular, to address challenges such as migration, border management and sustainable development. I believe that there is a need to strengthen the links between the Union's resources and space activities in these areas.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The security environment inside and outside the EU is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, with terrorist attacks and mass killings affecting all Member States, to which Member States must respond by adopting a common strategy and a coordinated response. The report therefore emphasises the importance of space-based instruments and the further development of these capabilities. The Union must work together to implement an effective and consistent border management system, to address the challenges facing our security, riots and armed conflicts in our neighbourhood, and migration, for which the development of these capabilities is absolutely necessary. The report stresses the need for the EU to improve access to space-based satellite communications, space observation, precision navigation and Earth observation capabilities and to ensure Europe's independence in terms of critical space technologies and access to space.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution on the opening up of the space and space technology market rules out any possibility of serious strategic independence. It applies an economic logic that does not take into account the fact that space is above all an extension of the field of defence. Therefore, for these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – The space market has huge commercial potential. I voted in favour of this dossier because I am convinced that this sector holds an important future position for the European Union. I support the initiative to remove certain market and technical barriers that hinder innovation. However, I urge us not to be careful when it comes to the technical aspects of access to data, especially given developments in the digital single market. Moreover, when it comes to issues of sensitive technology of interest to many individuals, we cannot and should not risk lowering standards.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is a fact that the European Union's activities in the field of space are directly interwoven with scientific and technical progress, economic and industrial competitiveness, social cohesion and job creation. Programs such as GNSS and Copernicus contribute to the availability of location information, timing and high-precision earth observation data. We therefore vote in favour of the motion for a resolution on space market penetration in order to achieve a clear European space industrial policy, encouraging both public and private demand, always aiming to make European industry more competitive on the world market.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The security environment inside and outside the EU is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, as terrorist attacks and mass killings are occurring in all Member States, to which Member States must respond by adopting a common strategy and a coordinated response. The report therefore emphasises the importance of space-based instruments and the further development of these capabilities. The Union must work together to implement an effective and consistent border management system, to address the challenges facing our security, riots and armed conflicts in our neighbourhood, and migration, for which the development of these capabilities is absolutely necessary. The report stresses the need for the EU to improve access to space-based satellite communications, space observation, precision navigation and Earth observation capabilities and to ensure Europe's independence in terms of critical space technologies and access to space. In line with the direction of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Over the next two decades, the economic and social benefits of the 'Global Satellite Navigation System Applications Action Plan' are expected to amount to around €60-90 billion, with the potential annual turnover of the 2030 Earth observation downstream services market expected to amount to approximately €2.8 billion , of which more than 90 % arising from the Copernicus programme. I agree that autonomous access is of strategic importance for the EU by having highly reliable and accurate information in terms of positioning and timing, as well as earth observation data.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: this resolution is in the same vein as the Space Capabilities Report (Zdrojewski report). It buries any serious desire for strategic independence and applies an irrelevant economic logic about space. Indeed, space is above all an extension of the field of defence.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We advocate a space policy based on deepening cooperation between European countries and more. But we have always said that this space policy should focus exclusively on peaceful purposes and permanently exclude any use of space for military purposes. Criticism of the militarisation of space and the renunciation of any arms race in space was a position that the majority of this Parliament has never taken. This is again the case with this resolution, which explicitly assumes and advocates militarisation, alongside the development of the space market. It is revealing of the way the European Union looks into space. And it's also dangerous. As we said in the plenary debate, humanity's endless adventure in the discovery of this great book which Galileo spoke to us cannot serve to prolong on earth the wicked, aggressive and oppressive order that some have been imposing. On the contrary, it should help us solve problems, not create problems. An adventure to unleash, not to oppress. By the foregoing, vote against.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: In writing ‒ Following the use of space and its inclusion in future EU policies, I consider it important for the EC to develop a progressive strategy and ensure Europe's leadership in space technologies and services on world markets. One of the main elements of this strategy should be, in particular, the development of a market for space data and services to maximise the socio-economic benefits of EU space programmes. The future development of space programmes should determine the needs of users from the public, private and academic spheres.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution to call on the Commission to guarantee Europe a dominant position in the field of space technologies and services.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is a fact that the European Union's activities in the field of space are directly interwoven with scientific and technical progress, economic and industrial competitiveness, social cohesion and job creation. Programs such as GNSS and Copernicus contribute to the availability of location information, timing and high-precision earth observation data. I am therefore voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on space market penetration in order to achieve a clear European space industrial policy, encouraging both public and private demand, always aiming to make European industry more competitive on the world market.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution aims to input into the Commission’s upcoming strategy on space policy, foreseen for the fall 2016. It aims to ensure that EP’s priorities (to ensure Europe’s leading position in space technologies and services on the global markets, with an independent access to space for Europe and a level playing field for the industry) are pursued in the forthcoming Commission’s document. It highlights, amongst others, the need to focus the new strategy on market uptake of space data and services to maximise socio-economic benefits from the EU’s space programmes, the need for the regional dimension to be taken into account, with support for an increased role of regional and local authorities; and the need to increase efforts of awareness-raising to promote the potential of European space programmes to the public and private sector and end users. Space policy is a fundamental contributor to the implementation of Union’s policies (transport, energy, environment, agriculture, etc.) and thus needs to be given a high level of recognition in boosting EU economic activity and creating jobs. European space industry needs an appropriate normative framework that allows for a level playing field and to ensure it contributes to its fullest in providing its services to the benefit of all EU citizens. I therefore supported the resolution.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The security environment inside and outside the EU is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, as terrorist attacks and mass killings are occurring in all Member States, to which Member States must respond by adopting a common strategy and a coordinated response. The report therefore emphasises the importance of space-based instruments and the further development of these capabilities. The Union must work together to implement an effective and consistent border management system, to address the challenges facing our security, riots and armed conflicts in our neighbourhood, and migration, for which the development of these capabilities is absolutely necessary. The report stresses the need for the EU to improve access to space-based satellite communications, space observation, precision navigation and Earth observation capabilities and to ensure Europe's independence in terms of critical space technologies and access to space.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted positively on this motion for a resolution with the conviction that satellite navigation, Earth Observation (OT) services are essential in our daily lives today, and the EU will finance such projects with EUR 11 billion through 2020 in its GNSS and Copernicus programmes. The connections of current infrastructures in the areas of data storage are necessary to develop the processing and storage capacity of large volumes of satellite data, so it is important to promote a strong and competitive European sector in the field of OT.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the recovery of the space market. In my opinion, the principle of the Buy American Act must apply to Europe, similar to aviation: Buy European!

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against this Motion for a Resolution, which proposes a market system in the space sector, promoting investment and support to private companies of different space services. With the excuse of promoting research and development, what is achieved is to leave in private hands services that should always be oriented to the common benefit and not to enrich private interests. I believe that advances in this sector must always be led by academic scientific research, common interests, and never have a component of militarization as they do today. In turn, we regret the previous "kitchen" that exists in these reports by the Grand Coalition, which leave no room for objections from a sector critical of the bellicolist use of space capabilities and services. Using security and fear discourse to increase the militarization of Space.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. Investing in the space sector means investing in a strategic area for the future of Europe and all our citizens! The space sector, too little known to our fellow citizens, has consequences on all our public policies such as defence, digital, agriculture, the environment or border management! There is an urgent need to make better use of all space data for their benefit and to better share this data to generate new space services and applications, which must require strong political support for our European programmes, Galileo, EGNOS and Copernicus. It would be a huge mistake to miss all these resources. Europe has the means to remain a great space power!

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. There is a need to present a comprehensive, ambitious and forward-looking strategy, ensuring in the short, medium and long term Europe’s leading position in space technologies and services on global markets, ensuring independent access to space for Europe and ensuring a level playing field for the European space industry.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU space-related activities are extremely important for innovation, economic growth and industrial competitiveness. Satellite navigation, Earth observation and satellite telecommunications services can make a vital contribution to the implementation of a wide range of different EU policies and bring significant benefits to all European citizens. Galileo and the Copernicus programme take a unique and innovative approach, and timekeeping information and Earth observation data ensuring reliable and accurate positioning are of strategic importance. It is not for nothing that the EU plans to spend more than EUR 11 billion on programme infrastructure in the period up to 2020. The report believes that in the future it is mainly business that should provide space services, which will stimulate the UNION's entrepreneurial sphere, and supports the braver use of space data by both the public sector and the business community. Space data and space services can play an essential role in europe's leading role in key technological directions, such as the Internet of Things, Smart Cities, Big Data and connected and self-driving vehicles.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the resolution, since we are against the use of technologies for monitoring and for military purposes. We also disagree with the need in the report for the full commercialisation of Space.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Resolution which encouraged the Commission to present a comprehensive, ambitious and forward-looking strategy, ensuring in the short, medium and long term Europe’s leading position in space technologies and services on global markets, ensuring independent access to space for Europe and ensuring a level playing field for the European space industry. One of the main elements of the strategy should be market uptake of space data, services and applications to maximise the socio-economic benefits of EU space programmes. However, the Commission needs to present a proposal for a clear European space industrial policy as part of the upcoming strategy. This will require a broad range of stakeholders involved in implementing EU space policy, particularly the Commission, the European GNSS Agency (GSA), the European Space Agency (ESA), Copernicus service providers and encouraged them to further foster their cooperation. However, there are market barriers to growth in this sector. Therefore, future space services should be mainly provided by, and procured from, commercial enterprises unless there is a good reason not to do so. Thankfully, the resolution called for a mid-term evaluation of the Copernicus and Galileo regulations and this should be used to ensure a greater involvement of the private sector in the procurement of services.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the proposal for a resolution on the development of the space market, as the EU does not yet have an integrated and coherent space policy, and I believe that space activities are extremely important for scientific and technical progress, innovation, economic growth, industrial competitiveness, social cohesion, job creation and businesses.  The EU's space strategy should put Europe at the fore leadership in space technologies and services in global markets.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution is similar to the Space Capabilities Report (Zdrojewski Report). It buries any serious desire for strategic independence and applies an irrelevant economic logic about space. Indeed, space is above all an extension of the field of defence. I naturally voted against it.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution for the opening of a space market, with a view to adopting the space strategy to be proposed by the European Commission in autumn 2016.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This resolution calls for greater importance to be attached to the space industry in Commission programmes. The European space industry is one of the most competitive in the world, and this top position must be developed and defended. As more and more actors, especially local ones, become active in this sector, it is necessary to make data transfer more coherent and to better align internal market policy with almost exclusively cross-border space projects. I therefore agree with this resolution.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution. Space policy is a fundamental contributor to the implementation of Union’s policies and thus needs to be given a high level of recognition in boosting EU economic activity and creating jobs.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The security environment inside and outside the EU is becoming increasingly dangerous and challenging, as terrorist attacks and mass killings are occurring in all Member States, to which Member States must respond by adopting a common strategy and a coordinated response. The report therefore emphasises the importance of space-based instruments and the further development of these capabilities. The Union must work together to implement an effective and consistent border management system, to address the challenges facing our security, riots and armed conflicts in our neighbourhood, and migration, for which the development of these capabilities is absolutely necessary. The report stresses the need for the EU to improve access to space-based satellite communications, space observation, precision navigation and Earth observation capabilities and to ensure Europe's independence in terms of critical space technologies and access to space.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it is part of the Europeanisation of space policy. The fact that the text gives the Commission full authority is unacceptable.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the opening of a space market. This resolution is in the same vein as Mr Zdrojewski's space capabilities report. It buries any serious desire for strategic independence and applies an irrelevant economic logic about space. Indeed, space is above all an extension of the field of defence. The resolution is within the framework of the Europeanisation of space policy, the end of the intergovernmental procedure that made the success of these (mainly French) programmes. The fact that the text gives the Commission full authority is unacceptable.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution, because space should not be a commodity left to the market, but is part of the environment, a public good that must be protected by decisions of democratic institutions and not by the interests of multinationals. Faced with manifest problems such as the presence of space junk, this resolution encourages market-controlled development of the industry, more importantly, encourages the putting resources and public research in the hands of private actors. The report further refers to the potential military uses that such a 'market' may entail. In my opposition to the possible military uses that may be given to space, the use of public resources for the benefit of private companies, as well as my opposition to the privatization of the environment, including space, is why I have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The key justification for EU intervention in the space sector includes the need to develop an independent European space with satellite infrastructure, to pool all resources and experts from the ESA and the Member States, and to give everyone the opportunity to benefit from satellite technology and products that can help us achieve europe's 2020 targets. The launch of European space policy in 2007 gave new momentum to the implementation of the two largest space programmes, Copernicus (Earth Observation) and Galileo (GNSS - Global Navigation Satellite System). Data obtained by space technology can find various commercial and institutional applications in many market segments, which is an example of the market for navigation systems. In general, demand for this data and information is high by the public sector, which wants to develop better services for the benefit of citizens, public administration and businesses. Sectors where the potential for the development of commercial services is the largest agricultural sector (precision agriculture), insurance services and oil and gas exploration and exploitation activities. A common and long-term EU space industrial policy is needed, containing clear objectives and measures, so I supported the proposal for a resolution.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the Motion for a Resolution on space market penetration for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 7/6/2016, and because this Motion for a Resolution is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. It is a resolution on the opening up of the space market and space technologies. Here again, it applies a logic of economic liberalization, while space, closely linked to defence policy, must fall solely under the prerogatives of sovereign states.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU must have a comprehensive, ambitious and future-oriented strategy that guarantees us, in the short, medium and long term, a leading position in space technologies and services in global markets, a level playing field for our space industry and independent access to space. My support for the motion for a resolution tabled in this Parliament, in which we call on the Commission to submit a proposal for a clear European space industry policy.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the resolution because I believe that the EU's space activities are essential for scientific and technical progress, innovation, economic growth, industrial competitiveness, skilled jobs and business creation.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The resolution welcomes European advances in space. Indeed, it is estimated that, in the next 20 years, the European GNSS is expected to generate economic and social benefits worth between 60 and 90 billion euros. The text aims to fully exploit the potential of the space data market, which would necessarily require a stimulating of "both private and public" demand. The resolution also argues that "future space services should be primarily provided by and obtained from commercial enterprises" while still adding that "unless there is a good reason not to do so". I propose several: the main objective of the Galileo project is to no longer depend on the US system and to allow the sovereignty of European states over sensitive data. What about this sovereignty if these services are now in the hands of the private sector? Moreover, this will lead to a privatization of profits even though the main investments have been public, and in particular on the part of the French state. In short, I oppose this commodification of space and I vote against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution is in the same vein as the Space Capabilities Report. It buries any serious desire for strategic independence and applies an irrelevant economic logic about space. Indeed, space is above all an extension of the field of defence. I voted against this resolution.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this motion because of the benefits that come from the recommendations suggests concerning the development of Europe’s space market. Through the removal of technical and market barriers, increased availability of financial resources and expertise, and a new, forward-thinking development strategy, this motion is a catalyst for European economic and technological development.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: writing – One of the main elements of the space technology market development strategy should be the development of a space data market, services and applications to maximise the socio-economic benefits of EU space programmes. The future development of Union space programmes should target users and be determined by the needs of users from the public, private and academic spheres. It is also necessary to simplify the institutional architecture for the Union's space activities in order to facilitate use by both public and private users. Greater efforts should be made to raise awareness of potential European space programmes between the public and private sectors and end-users and to promote the use of space-derived data in the public sector and business. I believe that a problem-solving approach, taking into account the needs of users, where policy needs are coordinated with the relevant operational satellite services, can be effective, and I am therefore voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The PPE, S&D, ECR, ALDE, Verts/ALE and EFDD Groups tabled a joint motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on the introduction of space products to the market. I supported the joint draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. We oppose this unique resolution on the opening of a space market, which follows the Space Capabilities Report (Zdrojewski report) and which buries any serious desire for strategic independence.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Space capabilities play an important role, in particular in the response framework in crisis situations, such as natural disasters, the efficient management of natural resources, the provision of services, such as energy and transport, and security and defence. The activity of the European space industry is characterised by being heavily dependent on institutional initiative, and in comparative terms compared to countries such as the US, China or Russia, it has much lower budgetary availability. The space industry market at EU level is overly fragmented, facing barriers to both the policies implemented and put forward by the various national governments, as well as technical barriers and the still lack of skilled labour for the sector. In this regard, I am voting in favour, because I believe it is important that the European Union makes efforts to adopt a common strategy for space, in particular for the development of the space market.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report buries the French conception of space policy without saying a word. It has the merit of revealing the true nature of European projects for these programmes and technologies. A full renationalization of these policies must be designed in the face of this type of document, which jeopardizes our strategic and technological independence. Vote obviously negative.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution for the opening of a space market. This resolution calls, in particular, in the adoption of the space strategy to be proposed in autumn 2016, to continue the development of Galileo and Copernicus, but also to make the EU a leader in space technology on the world stage.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the strategic interest of space programmes, autonomous access to space in particular, and the economic importance of the aerospace industry, we vote in favour of the resolution. Research, investment and related discoveries in this field not only represent an important source of employment and technological development, but also generate a multiplier effect on other industrial sectors. In detail, noting the remarkable performance and growth forecasts of earth observation services, we agree with the call for the European Commission to develop a comprehensive strategy to ensure the long-term development of the sector. We therefore hope that a holistic industrial policy will be drawn up which will ensure the competitiveness of European operators. We would therefore support measures in favour of greater integration of data exchange systems and bureaucratic and institutional simplification that would create a more favourable environment for the actors involved.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we adopted the report on the capacity of the space market. On the basis of this report, a strategy should be developed to ensure Europe's leading role in space technology and space services. There is a need for a clear European space policy, which also shows how the EU's space programmes are adapted to users. The proposal also mentions the need for the European Union to increase entrepreneurship together with the private sector. The space industry should be presented and made known to the population of the Member States by attracting students from technical universities, young scientists and entrepreneurs to the sector. A well-trained, diverse workforce will help to maintain the leadership of the space industry.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that recommends the Commission to set up a comprehensive, ambitious and forward-looking strategy, ensuring in the short, medium and long-term Europe’s leading position in space technologies and services on global markets.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 EU space activities are particularly important for technical and scientific progress, economic growth, industrial competitiveness, social cohesion, skilled job creation and businesses. We urge the Commission to respect the timetable and ensure the rapid and full functioning of the space and land infrastructure and services provided by the Galileo and Copernicus programmes, especially given that the Union will invest more than EUR 11 billion in the infrastructure of these programmes by 2020. Avoiding further delays is essential to maintaining private sector confidence. I stress the opportunities on the European GNSS global market related to the extension of EGNOS coverage in South-Eastern Europe and Eastern Europe. The improvement of the current coverage of EGNOS is extended, as of June 2016, to the eastern parts of Romania (in addition to the Mediterranean and Finland). I encourage the Commission to present a proposal for a European space industrial policy and a comprehensive and ambitious strategy that will ensure, in the short, medium and long term, Europe's leading position in space technologies and services in global markets. And one of the main elements of the strategy should be to take space data, services and applications into the market in order to maximise the socio-economic benefits of EU space programmes.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this resolution which calls for more market access in space, increased marketing promotion and for more funding EU regarding space developments. The resolution completely fails to critical assess this unnecessary spending, and moreover there are even parts in which they basically say that public spending is necessary to stimulate private sector investments. Also, there is nowhere in the resolution a clear distinction between military functionality of the EU space assets, and civilian and peaceful use. Because of that, I recommend to vote against.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. If I had had the opportunity to take part in this vote, I would probably have voted in favour of this report. In the interests of our high-tech companies, especially in Austria, European space should continue to be seen as a market with considerable growth potential.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. EU space activities are essential for the implementation of satellite navigation, earth observation and satellite communications services. In addition, space policy also plays a major role in science and technical development, innovation, growth, industrial competitiveness and social cohesion.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the importance of the space sector both in terms of technical progress and in terms of economic growth, I stress that free access to space activities would have significant positive repercussions on the European Union economy. In this regard, the Commission has included in its work programme for 2016 the will to act within the framework of a 'Space Strategy for Europe' and this resolution will enable the European Parliament to provide its vision. I therefore feel that I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this resolution, as it calls for the establishment of conditions that need to simplify the institutional environment for EU space activities with a view to enabling greater participation of public and private users. One of the main components of the strategy is the development of a market for space services, applications and data exchange in order to maximise the socio-economic benefits of EU space programmes. When supporting greater participation of regional and local authorities in successful EU space policy, initiatives at local and national level should be coordinated in order to avoid double funding for almost the same projects by the Commission and different Member States, by focusing the efforts of different stakeholders in the sector towards a common goal through better cooperation and information sharing. For example, european GNSS data for increased security and efficient use of intelligent traffic management systems is essential at all levels. This is why it is important to ensure that the GPSS is compatible with Galileo/EGNOS, in particular in the area of civil aviation and related critical infrastructures. Proactive EU industrial policy in the space technology sector is needed in response to major institutional markets around the world that are having increasing strategic and technological impact. The competitiveness of European industry must be improved and the development of the space market can only help this.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Like the previous report, this report is very clear about the true nature of European projects for space programmes and technologies. This Europeanist view is all the more damaging because, in space, the Ariane project has demonstrated that well-conducted intergovernmental cooperation is producing excellent results. On the other hand, it is inconceivable that a democracy should delegate essential strategic areas to opaque technocratic bodies. I am, of course, voting against this text.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported an oral question that highlights the strategic importance of fostering innovation as the main challenge that the European Union's space policy needs to address, in order for funds already invested in space under financial programmes to bring economic benefits to the EU. Europe needs a commercial space industry in all sectors of the value chain to maintain independent access to space technology and Earth observation data and develop a strong and independent space industry. The expected development of the space market leads to an indirect increase in the number of jobs, as the creation of one new job in the space industry results in the creation of up to five new jobs in other sectors.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution for the opening of a space market as part of the forthcoming adoption of the European Space Strategy to be proposed by the European Commission in autumn 2016. As such, I have spoken in the Chamber to remind us that the promotion of a coherent and strong European space policy is necessary for this sector of the future which will be a driver of growth for Europe. I stressed the need for independence of access to space, the further development of European satellite devices such as Galileo or Copernicus, or the need to make a direct application of space resources in our economy and for citizens. Also, our customers today, like India for example, will be our competitors of tomorrow in this very competitive space world. So, to stand out, we need to innovate and strengthen our technological advantage so that France and Europe are always at the forefront of research and the use of data from space.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, which I voted in favour of, calls on the Commission to present a comprehensive, ambitious and future-oriented strategy that guarantees Europe a leading position in the field of space technologies and services, as they guarantee European autonomy, innovation, social cohesion, the creation of skilled jobs, businesses, and new opportunities, both in upstream markets , as the downstream. The document also draws attention to the fact that the future development of EU space programmes must be user-oriented and driven by the needs of the public, private and scientific sectors.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament spoke this afternoon in favour of the motion for a resolution on the opening of a space market, a text aimed at creating a common European-wide space industry with defined objectives. Facilitating access to data provided by the Copernicus and Galileo programmes could add value. With this resolution, Parliament recognises the benefit of pooling the resources and expertise of the European Space Agency (ESA) with those of the Member States. The development of services and products based on satellite technologies is also encouraged. Among Parliament's main proposals is the repeated request for an increase in the share of GDP devoted to research from 2% to 3% by 2020. MEPs also encourage the removal of barriers to the establishment of a market based on the use of space data by public and private actors and awareness of the Galileo and Copernicus programmes.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. This resolution is to be compared with the adoption on the same day of Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski's report on space capabilities for security and defence in Europe.  This resolution, while not of legislative value, remains a step forward in laying the groundwork for the 'space strategy for Europe' which the Commission intends to launch in 2016.   We stressed the need to preserve the openness of the space data, services and applications market in order to maximise the socio-economic benefits of European space programmes, while strengthening, through these programmes, the autonomy and independence of the European Union in space. Indeed, Europe must have its own space capabilities (satellite communication, situation analysis, precision navigation or Earth observation), as they play a crucial role in border management, energy security, disaster management or transport, but also in European security.  Above all, we must work towards the emergence of a space services market and the development of applications that exploit the data generated by the infrastructure developed. In line with this political line, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In space activities, the European Union has a key source of scientific and technological development, but also of highly skilled economic activity, competitiveness and employment. According to studies prepared by Parliament, between 6% and 7% of Western countries' GDP depends on activities linked to satellite positioning and navigation. In addition, the global European satellite navigation system is expected to generate economic and social benefits in the coming two decades, amounting to between EUR 60 billion and EUR 90 billion. And most of that value will be generated by small and medium-sized enterprises. As this resolution, which I have supported, claims, Europe must make a strong bet on developing its space programme so as not to lose its global leadership in this field. Therefore, the space strategy that the Communication must launch in the second half of the year must be to make the development and commercialization of products, services and applications at its centre of gravity to maximize the socio-economic benefits of community space programmes.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is essential that the European Union adopts a genuine space strategy for the European Union. Galileo is an ambitious project of the European Union, but its full success will depend in particular on whether or not existing obstacles to the development of its data exploitation, particularly in the private sector, have been removed. I am therefore pleased that this resolution addresses this issue.  It is also important for the European Commission to carry out spatial monitoring of each EU sectoral policy to determine whether changes are needed to stimulate the use of satellite data and services.  This resolution is in line with an ambitious European space policy. The ball is now in the Commission's court.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has an excellent platform for scientific and business cooperation, the space programme. By allocating several billion euros of EU taxpayers' money each year, we should have more control over the concrete benefits they bring. The benefits, I stress, can be measured both by a product that is specifically created and valued in cash, as at the point of new technologies or by the results of fundamental research. The report under consideration highlights these challenges of THE EU's space policy in a rather detailed manner. It is true that it must be emphasised that both parliament and the Commission's documents miss the other side– business – attitude and evaluation. What does business want from space policy, how much of its desires are based, and how unrealistic, and why many space-related business services, even those created by Europeans, rely on American GPS rather than European galileo and Copernicus services? This is a question that I have missed the answer to in this document.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. In December 2015, during the World Trade Organisation (WTO) Ministerial Conference in Nairobi, 53 members agreed to the expansion of the Information Technology Agreement, which includes a timetable for eliminating tariffs on 201 IT products. Annual trade in these products accounts for approximately 10% of total world trade.  Under this agreement, about 65% of tariff lines will be completely eliminated by 1 July this year. In 2019, almost all imports of the products concerned will be tax-free. Whereas EU space activities are of great importance for scientific and technical progress, as well as for innovation, economic growth, industrial competitiveness, social cohesion, the creation of skilled jobs, businesses and new opportunities, and whereas access to this market by the EU is of particular strategic importance, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution calling for investment in the space sector, particularly in the framework of the European space strategy to be published next autumn. Programmes such as EGNOS, Galileo and Copernicus must also be placed at the heart of the European industrial and space strategy. They have significant potential for research, growth and employment. The European Union's space policy must be coherent and strong. It affects many other policies such as defence, digital or border management; we must therefore ensure that these policies are consistent with each other.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the PPE Group and the parliamentary majority, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the commercialisation of space technologies. The space sector is an important driver for the growth of the European economy. It is not only the preserve of the large multinationals, on the contrary, many SMEs participate in it, helping to make this sector one of the most technologically advanced and cutting-edge. That is why non-tariff barriers must be removed, markets must be expanded and research and development programmes strengthened.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against this Motion for a Resolution, which proposes a market system in the space sector, promoting investment and support to private companies of different space services. With the excuse of promoting research and development, what is achieved is to leave in private hands services that should always be oriented to the common benefit and not to enrich private interests. I believe that advances in this sector must always be led by academic scientific research, common interests, and never have a component of militarization as they do today. In turn, we regret the previous "kitchen" that exists in these reports by the Grand Coalition, which leave no room for objections from a sector critical of the bellicolist use of space capabilities and services. Using security and fear discourse to increase the militarization of Space.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ European space programmes promote the development of space technologies and can support public and private sector jobs by supplying both global and European markets. Market uptake of space data and services could also lead to important socio-economic benefits.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. The European Space Programme is important for the research and development of new technologies. European countries are too small to have their own space research programmes, but the Pan-European Space Research Programme offers the opportunity for an ambitious programme that provides new knowledge, new technologies, growth and jobs. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this resolution, because space should not be a commodity left to the market, but is part of the environment, a public good that must be protected by decisions of democratic institutions and not by the interests of multinationals. Faced with manifest problems such as the presence of space junk, this resolution encourages market-controlled development of the industry, more importantly, encourages the putting resources and public research in the hands of private actors. The report further refers to the potential military uses that such a 'market' may entail. In my opposition to the possible military uses that may be given to space, the use of public resources for the benefit of private companies, as well as my opposition to the privatization of the environment, including space, is why I have decided to vote against this resolution.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The universe is undoubtedly a great stimulator for technological and industrial progress and innovation in terms of its discovery and recharging. We use applications from this activity in everyday life. Today, the European Union can build on its key space projects – Copernicus and Galileo. We should popularize these projects and open them up as widely as possible to users – companies, universities, innovors – and support the development of business and practical applications for users. I voted in favour.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported Parliament's resolution on the development of the space technology market because I believe that space-related activities are of great importance for scientific and technological progress, innovation, economic growth, but also social cohesion and job creation. I also share the view set out in the opinion that satellite navigation, Earth observation and satellite communications services could make a significant contribution to the implementation of a wide range of Union policies. Moreover, autonomous access to space is of strategic importance to the EU. The EU has already invested more than EUR 11 billion in the development of GNSS infrastructure and Copernicus, as the development of these programmes is essential for strengthening European independence. The European GNSS is expected to bring economic and social benefits of around EUR 60-90 billion over the next two decades. In terms of space strategy, one of its main elements should be the development of a market for space data, services and applications to maximise socio-economic benefits. Innovation and the promotion of synergies should be stimulated by space industry groupings or incubators. Such initiatives may also appear at regional level. However, it is essential that the Commission make greater efforts to develop a coherent EU strategy to promote space entrepreneurship.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Between 2014 and 2020, more than EUR 12 billion was earmarked for the implementation of three initiatives: satellite navigation, Earth observation and space research. In 2014, the European Commission also declared that one of its priorities was the adoption of the Space Strategy for Europe. Accordingly, the resolution aims to communicate the European Parliament's opinion on the establishment of a space strategy based on the achievements of the space programmes to date and the opportunities created and improved by various measures. In the area of the space market, the resolution emphasises the implementation of the Copernicus and Galileo programmes, which must be seen as complementary. The resolution also encourages synergy in the future. The resolution also calls on the European Commission to strengthen the links between existing policies on space activities. In the area of access to finance and expertise, the resolution calls for an assessment of the results and possible changes should these prove appropriate. The Commission should also ensure that the geographical imbalance in space activities is corrected, as the countries of central and eastern Europe are currently lagging behind the rest of Europe. The resolution also calls for enhanced cooperation, exchange of information and best practices. As I support the content of the resolution described above, I voted in favour of adopting the resolution.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The development of technological possibilities has opened up space for us to look at the universe through the prism of economic exploitation. Already, European companies and "start-ups", including Slovak ones, are heavily involved in research and applications in this field.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this proposal for a resolution, as I believe that the future development of EU space programmes should be user-oriented and guided by the needs of public, private and scientific users. I believe that EU space activities are extremely important for scientific and technical progress, industrial competitiveness, economic growth, social cohesion, etc. I believe that autonomous access to space is strategically important for the EU and that technologies developed through space exploration are important for mutual breeding and the emergence of other benefits for other policy areas. Finally, I believe that European citizens could benefit significantly from satellite navigation and Earth observation services, but also that satellite navigation and communications would make a major contribution to the implementation of a wide range of Union policies.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union's space activities are extremely important for scientific and technical progress, innovation, economic growth, industrial competitiveness, as well as the creation of new jobs and businesses. Satellite navigation and satellite communications services can contribute to the implementation of a number of Union policies, but Union citizens can also benefit significantly from these services. Autonomous access to space is strategically important for the European Union, as highly reliable and accurate position and timing information is important for strengthening European autonomy. Parliament urges the Commission to adopt a comprehensive strategy that will guarantee Europe's leadership in space technologies and services, independent access to space and a level playing field for the European space industry. It is necessary to work with the Member States of the European Space Agency to create a properly integrated infrastructure system with adequate levels of data security. I support this proposal for a resolution on the development of the space market, as I believe that space data and services can play a key role in enabling Europe to lead in major technological trends such as smart cities, the online marketplace, networked/autonomous vehicles, etc.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the resolution at the conclusion of the debate on the Commission statement on the development of the space market. I support the commission's encouragement to present a comprehensive, ambitious and forward-looking strategy to give Europe a leading position in the short, medium and long term in the field of space technology and services on the global market, to give it independent access to space and to ensure a level playing field for the European space industry. The European Union's space activities are extremely important for scientific and technical progress, innovation and economic growth. We therefore need a coherent and integrated space policy at European Union level.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is a fact that the European Union's activities in the field of space are directly interwoven with scientific and technical progress, economic and industrial competitiveness, social cohesion and job creation. Programs such as GNSS and Copernicus contribute to the availability of location information, timing and high-precision earth observation data. A clear European space industrial policy must be achieved, encouraging both public and private demand, always aiming to make European industry more competitive on the world market.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report because it points to and proposes a number of aspects that could help to maintain Europe's leadership in space technology and its civil and commercial exploitation. I agree with the commission's call for a comprehensive strategy to ensure their future high technical-scientific standards and continued commercial marketability, thereby dynamising the European economy, with a focus on job creation, both for Copernicus, Galileo and future programmes.  I consider it important to establish in the report the need to improve better consistency between EU involvement in the space market and other EU policies, in particular domestic, competition and energy policies. Similarly, I agree with the need in the substance that, in the future, developments should become more consumer-oriented, taking into account the interests of service providers.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is one of the world`s leading actors in the space industry and the EU`s space activities are very important for our union`s economic growth, scientific progress, social cohesion, industrial competitiveness and creation of jobs and enterprises. This report asks the Commission to present the EU`s short, medium and long term strategy on space policy and highlights the need to focus on market uptake of space data and services to maximise socio-economic benefits from the EU’s space programmes. Europe`s space policy is a fundamental contributor to the implementation of the Union`s policies on transport, environment, energy and others. Furthermore, the report asks for more support and involvement from regional and local authorities and the need to raise awareness of the advantages of Europe`s space programmes for the public and private sector. I fully support this report as I can see the need for a framework that fully benefits EU citizens.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on space market uptake calling for greater attention needed to be paid to the space dimension in the European Union’s various sector-specific policies. With this in mind, the European Commission is invited to carry out a ‘space check’ check’ on all existing and new policy initiatives ‘to assess whether any changes are necessary to stimulate the use of satellite data and services’ in regional and town-and-country planning policy.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒Since the European Union does not yet have an integrated and coherent space policy, I voted for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the development of the space market.  I welcome the progress made under the two flagship space programmes, Galileo and Copernicus, and consider it necessary to foster further synergies. It is important to ensure the necessary technical standards enabling the use of space data and services and to support greater participation of regional and local authorities in the successful space policy of the European Union.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the development of the space market, as EU space activities are extremely important for scientific and technical progress, innovation, economic growth, industrial competitiveness, social cohesion, job creation, business opening and new opportunities for upstream and sales markets. Technologies developed in space research also promote and strengthen the areas of other policies. A comprehensive, ambitious and forward-looking strategy needs to be developed that would give Europe a leading position in the space technology sector in the short, medium and long term. A simplified institutional structure is needed for EU space activities to facilitate the involvement of public and private users. In future, the Commission and the Member States should ensure that the infrastructure of European space programmes and their services are also used in related policies and programmes. The EU has a wide range of options for access to finance to support the space capability sales sector and these instruments should be used in a coordinated and focused manner.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against this Motion for a Resolution, which proposes a market system in the space sector, promoting investment and support to private companies of different space services. With the excuse of promoting research and development, what is achieved is to leave in private hands services that should always be oriented to the common benefit and not to enrich private interests. I believe that advances in this sector must always be led by academic scientific research, common interests, and never have a component of militarization as they do today. In turn, we regret the previous "kitchen" that exists in these reports by the Grand Coalition, which leave no room for objections from a sector critical of the bellicolist use of space capabilities and services. Using security and fear discourse to increase the militarization of Space.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution is in the same vein as the Space Capabilities Report (Zdrojewski report). It buries any serious desire for strategic independence and applies an irrelevant economic logic about space. Indeed, space is above all an extension of the field of defence. I vote AGAINST this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU space-related activities are extremely important for scientific and technical development, innovation, economic growth, industrial competitiveness, social cohesion, the creation of skilled jobs and new businesses, as well as the creation of business opportunities in procurement and sales markets. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 I vote against this Motion for a Resolution, which proposes a market system in the space sector, promoting investment and support to private companies of different space services. With the excuse of promoting research and development, what is achieved is to leave in private hands services that should always be oriented to the common benefit and not to enrich private interests. I believe that advances in this sector must always be led by academic scientific research, common interests, and never have a component of militarization as they do today. In turn, we regret the previous "kitchen" that exists in these reports by the Grand Coalition, which leave no room for objections from a sector critical of the bellicolist use of space capabilities and services. Using security and fear discourse to increase the militarization of Space.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Due to terrorism and armed conflicts, the world's security environment is becoming more dangerous and challenging and this requires an adequate response by strengthening the EU's common security and protection policy. For example, using satellite capabilities for better border protection through early identification of immigrant flows is a visible and expected solution. In recent decades, the EU has developed its space policy, but efforts in this direction need to be multiplied. Today, satellite technology is spreading in an explosive way and there is an increasing dependence of society on them, both for military and civilian use. We must not consider the dual use of galileo and Copernicus capabilities, and the development of the next generation of technologies must provide opportunities for precise Earth observation and better management and action in natural disasters, earthquakes, fires and floods, global warming, humanitarian actions and military applications. At the same time, competition and military objectives in space technologies require very high application cybersecurity, for which the necessary research and development tools must be promoted. Ultimately, the competitiveness of the European economy is becoming increasingly dependent on satellite communication systems, so space technologies should develop at a pre-emptive pace.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution to wind up the debate on the statement by the Commission pursuant to the Rules of Procedure on space market uptake. The resolution encourages the Commission to present a comprehensive, ambitious and forward-looking strategy, ensuring in the short, medium and long term Europe’s leading position in space technologies and services on global markets, ensuring independent access to space for Europe and ensuring a level playing field for the European space industry. The resolution highlights the fact that the future development of EU space programmes should be user-oriented and driven by public, private and scientific users’ needs. I voted in favour because I am of the view that pace data and services can play an essential role in allowing Europe to take a lead in major technological trends.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. It is important to continue to bet on the development of spatial capacities, since they are key technologies to be able to continue innovating and be able to apply them in the future to productive sectors, with the consequent creation of jobs. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in favour of this document.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This document is as another milestone in affirming the path of privatization of the sector and strengthening monopolistic control of large multinationals, to the detriment of investment and the public interest. You're talking about deindustrialization... It is necessary to remind the dememorials and warn the unwary that the need for reindustrialisation, which is now being talked about, is the result of years of the fulfillment of an agenda of dismantling the industry that was in the public sphere, with the obsessive objective of reducing jobs and workers' rights. Moreover, the document does not deal with anything, but omits and rejects, precisely because its stubborn objective is to monopolize the sector in the sphere of large European capital, which has in its agenda the increase of profits and the reduction of labor costs, at whom to whom it costs.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The draft calls for a dual research strategy, both military and civilian. The fundamentally very good idea of an independent space strategy is becoming a joint armament plan with NATO. Unfortunately, this is due to sensible approaches to strengthening the EU's autonomy, so that a fundamental focus on the US and NATO also prevails in space policy.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that it is important for the future of our Union. As we all know space is rapidly gaining in importance. It involves many different parties and stakeholders. This resolution correctly calls upon the Commission to develop a coherent, common strategy for the EU. In addition, it draws attention to some technical barriers that currently exist. Even so, I strongly applaud the Galileo and Copernicus programs, and support their further development. I believe that the success of these programmes will be even greater if we move towards a more integrated space infrastructure. With regard to market barriers, it is of the essence that these are removed as quickly as possible. After all, these developments require significant investment. In that regard more public funds should flow in this direction. Horizon 2020 should play a more important role here. In addition, I agree that more should be done to include private investment. With regard to private industry, I strongly applaud this resolution’s recognition of the important role that SME’s should play in the development of our space industry. To this end we need to stimulate space industry clusters and incubators.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the development of the space market. The EU still does not have a coherent and coherent space policy, and I therefore support the Call on the Commission to present a comprehensive, ambitious and forward-looking strategy in the field of space technology, which will enable it to have independent access to space and ensure a level playing field for the European space industry. Space technology can help us meet current global challenges, such as climate change and natural disasters.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE).
text: Madam President, our resolution is what it is, I voted for it because it is essential today to express our support for a suffering people, but it is lukewarm, as it says so little, as it is watered down by the sticky law of our compromises: imprisonment, murder, crime, corruption, twilight of freedoms. And then all these shortages, water, electricity, medicines, everything is missing there, cancers are exploding, people are hungry; Venezuela is rich in oil and the people are hungry. This is a disgrace to President Maduro's regime. Our text talks about dialogue, but the issue of sanctions remains on the table, we need to adjust our attitude to allow for a democratic transition. That said, the observational position is not an option, it is not tenable. I would like to say a word, a final word for the political prisoners, including Antonio Ledezma, the democratically elected mayor of Caracas who was thrown behind bars last February: we think of him, we think of them and we ask Mrs Mogherini to put all the weight of the Commission in securing their release.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the situation in Venezuela is of enormous complexity and any measure must be focused on improving the living conditions of Venezuelans. We believe that all parties should be involved in the promotion and respect of human rights. A call to dialogue and détente is therefore essential. As High Representative Federica Mogherini pointed out this morning, we applaud Unasur's efforts. And, like Mrs Mogherini, we believe that, in the country's current political, social and economic situation, dialogue is indispensable as a key means for a peaceful solution that respects the democratic and constitutional order of the country.  Unfortunately, we consider that this resolution, formulated and negotiated in these terms, has become an instrument for the electoral benefit of some third parties, diverting the focus from what should be essential: people. Therefore, as the roller of the grand coalition demonstrates, any contribution from other groups such as the Greens or the GUE-NGL has been prevented, and the spirit of the text is far from intended to encourage and contribute to dialogue. From Podemos, we insist, we call for dialogue, the assumption of responsibilities, and the understanding of all parties.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the resolution we have adopted strikes an important balance between a call for dialogue and a complaint which the left also has to make. The political left also has to be able to denounce abuses of power in democracy, because the left is democratic. And it is up to us to do so, and in this resolution it is done and our group has supported it for that. Because there is a major complaint about what venezuela's government's abuses of power are against the National Assembly of Venezuela. And it has to be said. You have to be brave to say it, because that corresponds to what is an insufferable democratic situation in that country. And this Resolution does so and, at the same time, calls for dialogue.
