Because, yes, we agree that government and opposition have to negotiate to get that country out of the jam in which it is located. And this resolution strikes a balance, in my opinion, between this complaint and that call for dialogue that some former presidents, including Spanish, are taking place together with the European Union. This is the balanced position of this Resolution.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the Resolution on Venezuela has a hidden purpose. Instead of seeking solutions, he tries to interfere in the internal affairs of the democratic government of a sovereign country. It is a resolution full of falsehoods: there is no separation of powers," he says, or the Supreme Court is illegitimate. But the reality is stubborn. He voted to report that revocation signatures were not validated. Today 1 300 000 have been validated. He voted to demand an investigation into Tumeremo mining, bypassing the investigation by the Attorney General's Office. Or it was noted that the Supreme Court blocked the inauguration of three opposition deputies, concealing that the fourth was from the PSUV.  Meanwhile, at the request of the Venezuelan Government, Unasur leads a facilitating mission for dialogue with the non-violent opposition, supported by the Summit of Caribbean countries, by the OAS, including the United States, and by Mrs Mogherini. This is the path within the framework of international law and the Charter of the United Nations, but this is a resolution within the framework of the Spanish agenda to distort the beginning of general elections falsely.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr As one of the co-authors of the resolution in my political group, I must say that, following the death of Ugo Chavez in 2013 and the coming to power of Nicholas Maduro after the presidential elections, the situation in Venezuela at all cannot be described as stable. In particular, the executive effort to fully control all other organs recently, I mentioned the public administration, the persecution of the opposition, along with the above-mentioned low oil prices affecting the Venezuelan economy, all of this severely destabilises the situation in the country. Of course, I voted in favour of this resolution, but I could not support a number of amendments from the GUE Group, despite the singuvolation in this text. In my view, they were full of populism. But, of course, with my political group, I voted in favour.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Madam President, Venezuela is one of the countries with the largest oil reserves in the world and, at the moment, is in financial collapse. It is true, the price of oil has fallen and suddenly Venezuela has entered a deep financial crisis from which I do not know when it will come out and how it will come out. Inflation is 400%, the population has nothing to eat, prices double every day. People go out on the street and shout "We want food!". What do the state authorities do instead? Protesters are "bombarded" with tear gas grenades and beaten and run so they don't go out into the street. That's not the answer to hunger. The answer is a policy that leads to a decent life and food, which is basic to living. This situation is the result of the policies that have failed for many years, over the last seventeen years, of socialist governments. No European Union aid should go to Venezuela, because we don't know how it will be used: if it's used for people, well, if it's used by politicians, no.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I supported this resolution. I believe that the role of the European Parliament and of the European Union in the international field is also about trying to promote democratisation tendencies in the individual states that are partners of the European Union, and in the case of Venezuela, which is the resolution, it is clear that this country is now on the brink of civil war, that there are huge economic problems that my fore-speakers have also talked about. It is therefore right for the European Parliament to adopt a resolution on this and, inter alia, to offer a debate to the various parties in Venezuela and to participate, where appropriate, in such a debate. On the other hand, it is right that the resolution clearly describes that President Maduro and his people are now the culprits of the problem, that he is abusing the judiciary for his power games, and that on the other side stands a democratically elected parliament, which should be our partner.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, this is a resolution that serves absolutely no purpose. I wonder in which country in the world the government is called a dictatorship when it loses the elections and recognizes it, when it loses the referendums and it recognises it. In which country in the world do we agree to support an opponent who stores weapons of war and bombs at home? If you do that, then be prepared to call any terrorist we have arrested as a political prisoner. Perhaps Mr Maduro should have given 1,000 lashes to this opponent. Because then he would benefit from the complicit silence of this House, as you do for Saudi Arabia, whose way you nevertheless find a way to quote one of the nationals, who is chairman of the Committee on Human Rights - yes, a Saudi, chairman of the UN Human Rights Committee - to point the finger at Venezuela!  The truth is that you only deal with those who defend the poor to lambast and discriminate against them. The truth is that all of this is part of a destabilizing enterprise organized by the United States of America, which is doing institutional coups as they did in Guatemala, as they did in Brazil, as they did in Honduras and that this is all just a moment of international propaganda from NATO and the United States of America.  It is worth absolutely nothing and I say the anger of those who love governments that defend the poor.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the rapid fall in the price of oil is a major shock to Venezuelan society and the economy, as I said in my speech on 10 May 2016 to the plenary of the European Parliament, when I pointed out that the European Union must show restraint, neutrality and objective judgment on the political and social situation in Venezuela and not get involved in the internal affairs of that country. Unfortunately, the European Union has all this time shown a unilateral and invasive attitude towards Venezuela and its people.  This is also the direction of the European Parliament's resolution on Venezuela, because it is unilateral and discriminatory, because it intervenes openly in Venezuela's internal affairs, because it does not help to solve the problems that exist in Venezuela but it throws oil on the fire, because it undermines the conquests of the Venezuelan people that solved the housing problems of millions of people and gave the land to the coasts. That is why I voted against the European Parliament resolution on Venezuela.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I voted in favour of the resolution because I think it is necessary to draw attention to the dramatic situation in Venezuela, where a wacky communist is in power, there are almost equally crazy people among the opposition and no one listens to reasonable people. On the other hand, I voted against one of the points because there was a country that was in and out of a similar situation: chile, ruled by the same madman, the sacred memory of Salvador Allende. And as a result of the assassination of The Holy Memory of General AugustUs Pinochet, the country within two years became the richest country in Latin America, even though it had no oil. So that I voted against this point, which says that a military coup should be ruled out. In such a situation, this is the only sensible solution.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Venezuela has been facing a deep humanitarian crisis for years, where the shortage of food and medicines is accompanied by a stellar increase in the poverty rate which, from 2013 to 2016, has practically doubled. The high crime rates and the complete impunity that reigns in the country have only aggravated the social, economic and political crisis. These factors have contributed to the further deterioration of respect for values, such as democracy and human rights, which have been severely undermined on Venezuelan territory. Unfortunately, the resolution tabled in plenary does not prepare an effective action plan to combat these phenomena.  For these reasons, I voted against, in the hope that in future the Member States will make decisive efforts to ensure respect for fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is a balanced text. The left must denounce the abuses of power and violations of democracy and the rule of law that are being committed in Venezuela. And at the same time, the left has to make a firm commitment to the dialogue between Government and opposition, Executive and Legislative, as the only possible, peaceful and legitimate solution to the problems in Venezuela. The request for dialogue is in line with the request of most of the international community (UNASUR, CELAC, European Commission, G7, USA and the Vatican among other actors), and with the work of mediation between Government and opposition being carried out by the three former Presidents José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, Leonel Fernández and Marín Torrijos, with the support of UNASUR.  But the resolution also wants to help remedy the serious situation of food and medicine desupply in the country. To this end, it has requested the EU to develop a humanitarian assistance plan to send and distribute supplies in Venezuela, and has called on the Venezuelan Government to accept this aid.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against Venezuela's resolution, because it is an interference player and responds to an action of interventionist destabilization, it was driven by the Spanish parties – the grand coalition – to influence the election campaign in Spain. It is a resolution that, instead of seeking solutions, seeks to interfere in internal affairs of the democratic government of a sovereign country. It is a resolution full of falsehoods, distortions and inaccuracies such as arguing that in Venezuela there is no separation of powers or that the Supreme Court is illegitimate. It was voted on to report that the revocation signatures introduced by the opposition were not validated, and just 8 June, the day of the vote, the CNE announced the validation of 1 300 000 signatures. He voted to demand an investigation into the facts in the mining region of Tumeremo, bypassing the fact that the Attorney General's Office is already investigating and taking action.  The Venezuelan government asked UNASUR to lead a facilitator mission of dialogue with the non-violent opposition, which has been supported by CELAC, OAS and Moguerini. However, this unacceptable resolution ignores these advances and efforts on the path framed in international law and the Charter of the United Nations, to serve the Spanish political agenda.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. Venezuela is currently experiencing a period of great internal unrest. Political instability contributes to these tensions. Although President Maduro acknowledged his defeat in the last elections, the country is unable to find a modus vivendi between the two major parties. Added to this is the fact that oil prices remain very low but also that external powers are involved in the conflict and that endemic crime is wreaking havoc.  While international organisations have a role to play in negotiations with the various stakeholders, we consider that the other States (the United States) and the European Union must respect the principle of non-interference in internal affairs. So I voted against it.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution, which was a blatant attempt to join in foreign interference in Venezuela, worsening the situation there and increasing tensions. Despite talking about human rights, aid, and helping resolve the political tensions in Venezuela, the resolution was clearly biased in favour of the Venezuelan opposition, reflecting their demands and claims, while failing to give a balanced view of the situation in Venezuela. Failing to acknowledge the impact of a fall in oil prices, evidence of economic sabotage, and the effect of a severe drought on Venezuela’s hydroelectric sector, the resolution blames the government for the situation in Venezuela. The resolution also echoes the opposition call for hundreds of prisoners to be released, included many who were involved in organising violent protests that led to several deaths. Because this was a blatant attempt to interfere in the internal politics of Venezuela, I voted against this resolution.

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. We are very concerned about the plight of venezuelan citizens at the moment, both in terms of basic daily needs and the political situation. We are also concerned about the lack of respect for the rules of democracy and for people's fundamental rights and freedoms. It is now important that the Constitution is respected by all parties and that they engage in dialogue in order to reach a democratic and peaceful solution. That is also what our green motion for a resolution was about. The Green resolution is free from ideological overtones and puts more focus on democratic deficits, peaceful dialogue and the rule of law than the resolution voted through in this House. MPs chose to stand by our Green proposal instead of signing or voting for the joint. We also abstained from the vote because: 1. The resolution was created mainly to be used as a bat in the Spanish election campaign, in which we do not intend to participate.  2. Parliament recently adopted a similar resolution on Venezuela which, like our resolution, strongly addressed these problems. This was also added weeks before the last Spanish elections in December 2015.  3. The Greens were not welcome in the negotiation process in order to reach a joint resolution.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution. We call on both parties in Venezuela to refrain from any use of violence and to initiate a process of national dialogue on the basis of institutional cooperation and mutual trust for the benefit of Venezuelan citizens. We call on the European Commission to allow the use of the current financial instruments of external action to be able to accompany this dialogue process.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. At the moment, Venezuela is experiencing a period of great unrest. Although President Maduro's government acknowledged defeat in the last elections, the country is failing to restore a peaceful situation. Moreover, oil prices remain very low even though they account for almost all of the country's foreign exchange inflows, with outside powers edgying in the conflict to overthrow the Maduro government, including the United States, Colombia and several European states. Finally, endemic crime in this country is wreaking havoc that the opposition uses politically.  The unfavourable opinion that one may have on the Bolivarian model should not lead to a violation of the principle of non-interference in the internal affairs of a state. In addition, Unasur and the United Nations are currently conducting negotiations between the various parties. The Union is therefore all the more illegitimate to meddle in this matter. I therefore voted against the joint motion for a resolution before us.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I abstained on this resolution.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Venezuelan government to respect the rule of law and the principle of separation of powers. The government of President Nicols Maduro is urged to implement urgent economic reforms to find a constructive solution to the economic, humanitarian and energy crisis. A plan of assistance to the country is also urgently needed and the Venezuelan authorities are invited to grant access to the territory to humanitarian aid and international organizations to meet the most urgent and basic needs of the population.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I share my deep concern about the sharp deterioration in democracy, human rights and the socio-economic situation in Venezuela and the increasing atmosphere of political and social instability. I support the calls on the Venezuelan Government to respect the principles of the rule of law and the division of powers and a constructive approach to overcome Venezuela's current critical situation through dialogue-based constitutional, peaceful and democratic decisions. I support the calls of the EU and The Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to urge the release of political prisoners and arbitrary detainees.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The institutional, economic and social crisis in Venezuela is deeply worrisome, particularly with regard to democracy and human rights, which are constantly deteriorating. There is an urgent need to find a solution quickly so that social tensions can subside and to find a constructive dialogue between the different parties, taking into account the will of the Venezuelan people. I approved this joint resolution which calls on the Venezuelan Government to adopt a constructive attitude in order to overcome the critical situation facing the country through a constitutional, peaceful and democratic solution based on dialogue.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela, led by its President Maduro, is now in a serious economic, political and institutional crisis. The motion for a resolution that I have supported today expresses deep concern at the deterioration of the situation in the South American country. The break-up of the rule of law, human rights violations and non-compliance with the law are alarming factors linked to an escalation of the humanitarian health and food crisis. The European Union must support the action of High Representative Federica Mogherini to promote the restoration of democracy and the restoration of dialogue between the democratic opposition and the government. We need a constitutional exit from the crisis, which must be based on a peaceful process based on the release of political prisoners who are unjustly imprisoned in the country's prisons. The government and the National Assembly must act together to implement the reforms necessary to lift the country out of the disastrous economic situation and put an end once and for all to the shortage of food and medicines.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from the final vote on this Joint Resolution, as I consider the situation in Venezuela to be of enormous complexity, and any measure must be focused on improving the living conditions of the Venezuelan people. I believe that this resolution, formulated and negotiated in these terms, has become an instrument for the electoral benefit of third parties, diverting the focus from what is truly important. I believe that in the current political, social and economic situation of the country, dialogue is indispensable as a key route for a peaceful solution in respect of the democratic and constitutional order of the country. Therefore, since not all the proposals submitted from alternative groups have been made, we consider that the spirit of the text is far from intended to encourage and contribute to dialogue between the parties. Consequently, I abstained.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the content of the Joint Resolution on Venezuela because I believe that its text is the one that can contribute the most from the Union to encourage the deactivation of the powder powder powder in which the Bolivarian Republic is becoming. It contains the doses of criticism required by the undemocratic action of Maduro's government but also proposes possible solution pathways far from maximalisms easier to sustain in an approved role in Strasbourg than to apply on the streets of Caracas and in the Venezuelan political system. Pragmatic, realistic and connected to reality.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. For several months, Venezuela has been in crisis and despite the fact that the government of President Maduro (Chavez) acknowledged its defeat in the 2015 parliamentary elections, the country still cannot agree. On 15 January 2016, he decided to declare a state of emergency, and in April 2016, the main opposition party MUD filed a petition with 2 million signatures in favour of a referendum to remove him from his position.  Moreover, foreign powers are infiltrating the conflict (United States and South American or European allies), poverty is no longer decreasing, crime is endemic and the absence of a policy other than that based on the expected cash inflows from oil (whose prices are very low at present) weakens the country.  However, I think that, even if we can have an opinion on the Bolivarian development model or Chavez's policy, we do not have to interfere in the internal affairs of a state, in particular the Union, which is illegitimate here. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution being voted on is balanced and acceptable. The situation in Venezuela is untenable. There must be a u-turn as soon as possible and the democratic structure of the country, which now seems to be completely lost, must be re-established, and at the same time human rights violations must stop immediately. For all these reasons, I wanted to support this text with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've dropped my voice. Developments in Venezuela have been complex. It is a fact that millions of Venezolaner were lifted out of poverty in the years after the turn of the millennium and that the country's indigenous peoples were included for the first time since colonization in the development of society. But social progress has both been achieved and destroyed. Today, unemployment and poverty are rising rapidly, at the same time as health care has collapsed. Instead of facing growing popular dissatisfaction with dialogue and reform, the government has responded with limited press freedom, violence against demonstrators and the imprisonment of opposition figures on political grounds. Instead of diversifying its economy and implementing long-term reforms, dependence on oil has increased and the economy has collapsed. There are, of course, major economic and political interests in other countries that want to influence the country's development, but the main responsibility for the situation in Venezuela lies with the political leadership of the country. There are important wordings in the resolution that point this out and criticise the government. On the other hand, there are wordings that I cannot support in which the EP takes a stand that President Maduro should face impeachment and demands for EU intervention. All in all, this led me to abstain in the final vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is a balanced text. The left must denounce the abuses of power and violations of democracy and the rule of law that are being committed in Venezuela. And at the same time, the left has to make a firm commitment to the dialogue between Government and opposition, Executive and Legislative, as the only possible, peaceful and legitimate solution to the problems in Venezuela. The request for dialogue is in line with the request of most of the international community (UNASUR, CELAC, European Commission, G7, USA and the Vatican among other actors), and with the work of mediation between Government and opposition being carried out by the three former Presidents José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, Leonel Fernández and Marín Torrijos, with the support of UNASUR.  But the resolution also wants to help remedy the serious situation of food and medicine desupply in the country. To this end, it has requested the EU to develop a humanitarian assistance plan to send and distribute supplies in Venezuela, and has called on the Venezuelan Government to accept this aid.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it is a statement by Parliament on the situation in Venezuela.  During the five months of the legislative action of the Venezuelan National Assembly, the majority of which is the democratic opposition, the Supreme Court has issued 13 politically motivated decisions in favour of the executive, all of which run the risk of disrupting the balance of power necessary in the rule of law. In Venezuela, at the same time, some 2 000 people, including important political leaders, are imprisoned, placed under house arrest or sentenced to probation for political reasons, and these facts show that the government is influencing and controlling the judiciary and the National Electoral Council, which has a negative impact on the legislator and opposition authorities that form the basis of any democratic system, and that it clearly violates the principle of independence and separation of powers , which is typical of democratic states under the rule of law. Parliament therefore expresses its deep concern at the dramatic deterioration in democracy, human rights and the socio-economic situation in Venezuela and the increasing atmosphere of political and social instability. Calls also on the Venezuelan Government to take a constructive approach to overcome Venezuela's current critical situation through dialogue-based constitutional, peaceful and democratic solutions.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this resolution, which was a blatant attempt to join in foreign interference in Venezuela, worsening the situation there and increasing tensions. Despite talking about human rights, aid, and helping resolve the political tensions in Venezuela, the resolution was clearly biased in favour of the Venezuelan opposition, reflecting their demands and claims, while failing to give a balanced view of the situation in Venezuela. Failing to acknowledge the impact of a fall in oil prices, evidence of economic sabotage, and the effect of a severe drought on Venezuela’s hydroelectric sector, the resolution blames the government for the situation in Venezuela. The resolution also echoes the opposition call for hundreds of prisoners to be released, included many who were involved in organising violent protests that led to several deaths. Because this was a blatant attempt to interfere in the internal politics of Venezuela, I voted against this resolution.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Torn apart by a situation of increasing stagflation as well as a context characterized by the worrying development of poverty, crime, violence and increasingly bitter clashes between the majority opposition of the MUD and the executive led by President Maduro, Venezuela is today on the verge of a dramatic crisis that could degenerate into serious social disturbances, leading to a humanitarian emergency with unpredictable consequences. The European Union, as a global defender of values such as pluralism, the rule of law, cooperation and moderation, must make a strong contribution to trying to promote dialogue and confrontation between the parties involved, working for a stable, secure and respectful Venezuela of fundamental human rights. With this in mind, I welcome the resolution tabled by the Group of the Party of European Socialists and Spencer calling on the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to draw up a cooperation plan with that country, in order to meet the most pressing needs of an ageing population, and calling on the European Council to actively promote mediation between the venezuelan political forces in conflict.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Venezuela is currently experiencing a period of internal unrest. Political instability and endemic crime are contributing to tensions in this South American country. In addition, oil prices, the state's largest source of income, remain at historically low levels. While international organizations have a role to play in negotiations with the various stakeholders, we believe that other states must respect the principle of non-interference in internal affairs. This also applies to the United States and the European Union, which is all the more illegitimate to deal with this issue. Indeed, foreign policy remains an exclusive competence of the Member States. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Venezuelan Executive fully controls the country's judiciary and the National Electoral Council, clearly violating the principle of independence and separation of powers, which characterizes democratic states governed by the rules of the rule of law. The Venezuelan government has a clear responsibility to respect the rule of law as a non-permanent member of the UN Security Council since 16 October 2014. I believe that this resolution clearly underlines the problems in Venezuela, in particular the serious deterioration in democracy and human rights, and calls on the Venezuelan Government to respect the rule of law and the principle of separation of powers, which are characteristic of democracy. I am in favour of the resolution because I call on the Venezuelan authorities to guarantee the security and free exercise of the rights of all citizens. I consider this resolution beneficial because it urges the Venezuelan Government to regularise the working and school programmes, in order to bring the country into a situation of normality and respect for social and labour rights, as well as the universal right to education.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is a balanced text. The left must denounce the abuses of power and violations of democracy and the rule of law that are being committed in Venezuela. And at the same time, the left has to make a firm commitment to the dialogue between Government and opposition, Executive and Legislative, as the only possible, peaceful and legitimate solution to the problems in Venezuela. The request for dialogue is in line with the request of most of the international community (UNASUR, CELAC, European Commission, G7, USA and the Vatican among other actors), and with the work of mediation between Government and opposition being carried out by the three former Presidents José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, Leonel Fernández and Marín Torrijos, with the support of UNASUR.  But the resolution also wants to help remedy the serious situation of food and medicine desupply in the country. To this end, it has requested the EU to develop a humanitarian assistance plan to send and distribute supplies in Venezuela, and has called on the Venezuelan Government to accept this aid.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The political, social and economic situation in Venezuela has deteriorated considerably in recent times. The country is suffering from a severe recession and a very high inflation rate. Some basic products are no longer accessible to everyone. Moreover, the Venezuelan government is undermining the principles of democracy, the rule of law and the separation of powers. The resolution calls on the European government to accept humanitarian aid to help those in need. The text mentions the importance of cooperation between the European Union and Venezuela while calling on the government to respect democratic principles. The resolution also calls for the release of all political prisoners. I voted in favour of this resolution, which is a strong message from the European Parliament for the Venezuelan people.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Venezuela because the conditions in the country are truly disturbing. GDP is expected to contract by 10% in 2016. On 15 January, the Central Bank of Venezuela – after more than a year of lack of official communication – informed that inflation in 2015 was 141.5% and GDP fell by 7.1%. The Venezuelan crisis is therefore in danger of being devastating and it is necessary to avert a possible economic collapse with the consequences of a humanitarian crisis. The European Union must urge the Venezuelan Government to establish an effective dialogue with the other political parties. I believe that a confrontation that allows all the political actors to discuss the serious problems facing the country is the only way for Venezuela, at this stage, to find decisive and lasting solutions to improve the current conditions in the country.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution, which was a blatant attempt to join in foreign interference in Venezuela, worsening the situation there and increasing tensions. Despite talking about human rights, aid, and helping resolve the political tensions in Venezuela, the resolution was clearly biased in favour of the Venezuelan opposition, reflecting their demands and claims, while failing to give a balanced view of the situation in Venezuela. Failing to acknowledge the impact of a fall in oil prices, evidence of economic sabotage, and the effect of a severe drought on Venezuela’s hydroelectric sector, the resolution blames the government for the situation in Venezuela. The resolution also echoes the opposition call for hundreds of prisoners to be released, included many who were involved in organising violent protests that led to several deaths. Because this was a blatant attempt to interfere in the internal politics of Venezuela, I voted against this resolution.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report that stresses serious political and social crisis in Venezuela and outlines measures to tackle the current problems. I agree that the Government of Venezuela should rethink its actions which undermine democracy, the rule of law and most importantly human rights. The economic situation of Venezuela is very serious, but I still believe that the unfolding social and political crises can still be reversed.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I did not agree with the majority groups which, in my opinion, produced a party resolution whose clear intention was to encourage a change of government in Venezuela. I would have preferred a more balanced text which, while acknowledging the responsibilities of the Venezuelan Government, did not hold it solely responsible for what is happening. Questions arise spontaneously about the interest that certain parties might have in a change of government in Venezuela, with particular reference to the country's wealth of natural resources.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Venezuela is facing an unprecedented humanitarian crisis and the Venezuelan people desperately need our help. I voted in favour of this resolution because the government cannot keep violating human rights and leading its country to collapse without consequences. Maduro must immediately accept the much needed humanitarian aid, and start taking the necessary steps towards real dialogue, namely by releasing political prisoners and allowing a recall referendum this year. I do feel, however, that this resolution could have put more pressure on Maduro’s government to fully respect the Venezuelan constitution and the rights of its citizens, for instance by including the possibility of targeted sanctions against those who continue to violate human rights in Venezuela, should the government show no signs of entering real dialogue.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We call on the Venezuelan Government to adopt a constructive stance to overcome the country's current critical situation through a constitutional, peaceful and democratic solution based on dialogue.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Venezuela has been suffering from serious internal imbalances lately, both politically and economically. There have been several political conflicts within the country which have even led to the arrest, for political reasons, of two thousand people, including prominent politicians. I am deeply concerned about the situation in the country, which is not only experiencing such political conflicts but is also facing a serious crisis due to a lack of food and medicines. I am convinced that the European Union must help the country by urging the government and public authorities to restore normal social relations, respecting the constitution and releasing political prisoners. Since that is what the resolution argues, I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I think it is highly important for a European Parliament delegation to be sent to Venezuela and to hold a dialogue with all sectors involved in the conflict as soon as possible.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Venezuela today faces a political situation and respect for deplorable democratic values, which is manifested by the interference of the judiciary in the political power through decisions that limit the powers legitimized by the vote of the opposition majority in the National Assembly, the existence of about 2 000 people in prison, house arrest or on parole for political reasons. In addition, this is a serious humanitarian crisis caused by food and medicine shortages, and 75% of medicines considered essential by who are not available. The poverty rate has doubled and the lack of a foresight view of basic infrastructure and governance ineffectiveness have led to a serious economic and social crisis. I support this Resolution condemning the serious deterioration of the situation in Venezuela in terms of democracy, human rights and socio-economic conditions, as well as the growing climate of political and social instability, and I call for a stable situation in Venezuela, urgent economic reforms in cooperation with the National Assembly in order to find a solution to the economic and energy crisis and food shortages.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because it illustrates the serious state of Venezuela, its democratic deficit and terrible economic conditions. I also consider it a top priority to reduce the current high levels of impunity, which aggravates and fuels increasing violence and insecurity in the country, and to ensure compliance with the existing legal system.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Venezuela is facing a situation of serious violation of the rule of law and a consequent humanitarian crisis due to the boycott of the national government. More than 2,000 people are in prison, under house arrest or on probation for political reasons. In addition, the level of crime unpunished is very high: the city of Caracas has the highest rate of violent crime in the world, with over 119.87 murders per 100,000 inhabitants. I believe that the use of state powers by the executive to control the Supreme Court and the National Electoral Council, to hinder the application of laws and initiatives and adopted by the National Assembly, is a particularly dangerous fact in the current social and political context already marked by strong instability. I voted in favour of this resolution, so that the European Parliament can help to put pressure on the Venezuelan Government to respect the separation of powers, the release of political prisoners, the authorisation of access to humanitarian aid and respect for the laws to prevent and punish increasingly widespread acts of crime.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The resolution expresses concern about the deterioration of the situation in the country, in particular the growing economic, social and political crisis and the general dismantling of the democratic rule of law. President Maduro, who now controls parliament, has been called upon to engage in a dialogue with the democratic opposition in order to find a peaceful and constitutional solution to the current crisis in Venezuela. The resolution also calls for the immediate release of all political prisoners. I voted IN FAVOUR.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution in order to express my concern over the deteriorating situation in Venezuela, due to the increasing climate of political and social instability. The allegations of the use of state power to undermine the rule of law are worrying, and while recognising the development that Venezuela has made in the recent years, it is essential that mediation efforts between the various stakeholders are enabled in order to ensure democratic stability.

name: Jakop Dalunde (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. \u2012 The Green Party takes the situation in Venezuela very seriously, the major democratic shortcomings and human rights violations in the country. It is now important that the Constitution is respected and that the parties come to dialogue for a democratic and peaceful solution. However, the Green Party mem bers have chosen to abstain in favour of the Green proposal then – the resolution has been used as a bat in the Spanish election campaign; The Greens have not been welcome in the negotiation process; – the text is substandardly written. The Green resolution is free from ideological overtones and puts greater focus on democratic deficits, peaceful dialogue and the rule of law.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Venezuela's economic, political and institutional crisis is severely affecting the lives of the country's citizens. According to an ENCOVI survey, the poverty rate has doubled from 30% in 2013 to 60% in 2016, and there is a lack of basic goods such as food and medicines as well as a very high crime rate. The IMF estimates that in 2016 there will be an 8% contraction in the Venezuelan economy and an exponential increase in inflation that already makes it difficult to buy basic necessities. My vote in favour of this resolution is a vote to support the mediation of former Presidents Zapatero, Torrijos and Fernadez under the aegis of UNSAR – Union of South American Nations – in seeking solutions to the Venezuelan crisis, including through the involvement of the Commission and the High Representative for EU Foreign Policy. The failure to respect the principles of separation of powers, the freedoms of political opponents and the impasse created between the President and Parliament increasingly prevent a constructive dialogue between institutional powers, which is now more necessary than ever for the good of the citizens and of the whole country.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Venezuela is in the thrly political and economic crisis.  Part of a student protest movement, the grumbling turned into a clash between supporters and opponents of President Maduro. Nearly 2,000 people are now incarcerated for political reasons, including the former mayor of Caracas, Antonio Ledezma. In order to move towards a calming of the conflict, it is urgent that the authorities guarantee the security and the free exercise of rights for all citizens. Social tensions are also due to an untenable economic and social situation. Currency reserves are constantly falling and inflation is the worst in the world; more than 180% last year, it is expected to reach 700% in 2016. The country is on the brink of bankruptcy and is facing severe shortages of food and medicine, raising fears of a humanitarian crisis. The Venezuelan authorities must authorize the delivery of humanitarian aid and allow international organizations to enter the country to assist the most affected sectors of society. The Union must continue to cooperate with Latin American countries and regional and international organisations to ensure that mechanisms for dialogue, national reconciliation and mediation are put in place.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Venezuela is currently experiencing a period of great turmoil. Although President Maduro's government acknowledged defeat in the last elections, the country is unable to find a modus vivendi between the two major parties. On the other hand, oil prices remain very low. However, they make up almost all of the country's income. The United States and its Colombian and European vassals are attempting to interfere in the conflict in order to overthrow the government. At the same time, endemic crime continues to wreak havoc. To the extent that Unasur and the United Nations are currently negotiating between the various parties, the Union is totally illegitimate on this issue. So I voted against it.

name: Linnéa Engström (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. \u2012 The Green Party takes the situation in Venezuela very seriously, the major democratic shortcomings and human rights violations in the country. It is now important that the Constitution is respected and that the parties come to dialogue for a democratic and peaceful solution. However, MPs have chosen to abstain in favour of the Green proposal as we feel that 1. the resolution was created to be used as a bat in the Spanish election campaign; 2. The Greens have not been welcome in the negotiation process; 3. the text is substandardly written. The Green resolution is free from ideological overtones and puts greater focus on democratic deficits, peaceful dialogue and the rule of law. At the same time, we would like to recall parliament's resolution on Venezuela of last year, which, like our resolution, sharply highlighted these problems.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We strongly condemn, condemn the brutal interference in the internal affairs of a third independent state and especially in this case, where the role of the international actor and specific states is from suspect to dangerous to international security and stability.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The Government of Venezuela must immediately release all political prisoners and respect the Constitution, including the legal procedures provided for in venezuela's fundamental law on the removal of the President. In Venezuela, about 2,000 people are in prison, house arrest or on parole for political reasons. The country is going through a serious humanitarian crisis caused by food and medicine shortages and the government is preventing humanitarian aid from entering the country and boycotting various international civil society aid initiatives, as in the case of Caritas and other NGOs. I therefore agree that it is an absolute priority to reduce the current high levels of impunity, which reinforce and promote the escalation of violence and insecurity in the country.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this joint resolution. Most resolutions strictly take up American propaganda. The view that can be given to the Bolivarian model of development is irrelevant in the face of the universality of the rule of non-interference in internal affairs. Unasur and the United Nations are currently negotiating between the various parties. It is totally illegitimate for the Union to get involved in this matter.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This shameful and unacceptable resolution is adopted at a time when the Venezuelan opposition is involved in a process of dialogue with the Government, promoted by UNASUR, and in which the Permanent Council of the Organization of American States, with the support of the right of several countries in the region, adopted a declaration in which it supports that initiative and values the effort of dialogue between the parties , within the framework of respect for Venezuela's sovereignty. The European right and social democracy, however, insist on confrontation, destabilisation and interference. This resolution is absolutely contrary to the effort of dialogue that these and other regional structures (ALBA, AEC) are promoting and valuing and which Federica Moguerini has endorsed and supported today. A resolution that embarrasses and compromises the institutional relations between the European institutions and those Regional Structures of Latin America, as well as with the Republic of Venezuela. A resolution that goes so far as to pave the way for external intervention in Venezuela. Obviously, we voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Venezuela. The deterioration of the rule of law, democracy and the socio-economic situation in Venezuela must be a cause for concern and action on the part of the EU, first and for all the immediate release of all political prisoners. We must engage in dialogue with the venezuelan democratic opposition which controls Parliament, leading the crisis to a more peaceful solution.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ recently Venezuela has become one of the most dangerous countries in the world, especially in terms of huge crime rates and, on the other hand, absolute impunity. People are detained in the country for political and ideological reasons. In March, 28 miners were killed in the massacre and a journalist who dealt with the case was subsequently shot dead. Politically motivated judgments threatening the balance of power, which is an essential element of the rule of law, are accepted by the Supreme Court. The intolerable level of corruption and mismanagement of public funds has led to a terrible economic and social crisis. There is a shortage of resources of raw materials and basic foodstuffs in the country, as well as essential medicines. We therefore call on the Venezuelan Government to ensure the security and free exercise of rights for all citizens, to respect the Constitution and to overcome the current critical situation through a peaceful and democratic solution.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution to demand respect for opposition and respect for human rights, especially against opposition politicians.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the reports on the situation in Venezuela, as I strongly condemn the brutal interference in the internal affairs of a third independent state and especially in this case, where the role of the international actor and specific states is from suspect to dangerous to international security and stability.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Six months after the parliamentary elections were won by the opposition coalition MUD (Mesa de Unidad Democrática), the political, social and economic situation in the country is worsening vastly. Both, legislative and executive are legitimate elected powers in Venezuela. I support the call on both parties to restrain from violence and to launch a national dialogue process based on institutional cooperation and mutual trust for the benefit of the Venezuelan citizens. I support the call on the EEAS and on the EC to allow the use of the current external action financial instruments to be able to accompany this process of dialogue if required by national authorities.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The political crisis in Venezuela is getting deeper and deeper, so I have adopted Parliament's draft resolution. We must pay close attention to the socio-economic situation in Venezuela, which is the root cause of increasing political uncertainty. We must show our support for the suffering people and condemn the political elite that imprisons its own opposition and those who criticise the system. The motion for a resolution provides a good basis for this. We must call on both sides to continue the dialogue, to the importance of compromise agreements and to remedy the country's socio-economic problems as soon as possible. The government must ensure the right to free expression and the full freedom of political prisoners arbitrarily arrested. The EU must take strong action for the release of political prisoners and arbitrarily detained prisoners, along with a number of UN bodies and international organisations, as well as the Amnesty and National Reconciliation Act.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution in the hope that the essential principles of democracy in Venezuela will be respected. In the past elections to the National Assembly, the Venezuelan opposition (MUD) won 112 of the 167 seats of the Assembly and since then, the Venezuelan Supreme Court has handed down thirteen political judgments in favor of the executive, held by the PSUV. It is the wish of this Member that the Venezuelan Government should adopt a constructive attitude to overcome the critical situation currently in Venezuela through a constitutional, peaceful and democratic solution based on dialogue.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is a balanced text. The left must denounce the abuses of power and violations of democracy and the rule of law that are being committed in Venezuela. And at the same time, the left has to make a firm commitment to the dialogue between Government and opposition, Executive and Legislative, as the only possible, peaceful and legitimate solution to the problems in Venezuela. The request for dialogue is in line with the request of most of the international community (UNASUR, CELAC, European Commission, G7, USA and the Vatican among other actors), and with the work of mediation between Government and opposition being carried out by the three former Presidents José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, Leonel Fernández and Marín Torrijos, with the support of UNASUR.  But the resolution also wants to help remedy the serious situation of food and medicine desupply in the country. To this end, it has requested the EU to develop a humanitarian assistance plan to send and distribute supplies in Venezuela, and has called on the Venezuelan Government to accept this aid.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is a balanced text. The left must denounce the abuses of power and violations of democracy and the rule of law that are being committed in Venezuela. And at the same time, the left has to make a firm commitment to the dialogue between Government and opposition, Executive and Legislative, as the only possible, peaceful and legitimate solution to the problems in Venezuela. The request for dialogue is in line with the request of most of the international community (UNASUR, CELAC, European Commission, G7, USA and the Vatican among other actors), and with the work of mediation between Government and opposition being carried out by the three former Presidents José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, Leonel Fernández and Marín Torrijos, with the support of UNASUR.  But the resolution also wants to help remedy the serious situation of food and medicine desupply in the country. To this end, it has requested the EU to develop a humanitarian assistance plan to send and distribute supplies in Venezuela, and has called on the Venezuelan Government to accept this aid.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the adoption of this resolution on the situation in Venezuela as the situation in the country has deteriorated further and the EU needs to make its voice heard on this matter known and to put political pressure on the government of Venezuela. Venezuela is in great need of restarting an internal political dialogue and to this end I hope that European political pressure can do its part. Venezuela is running the risk of falling into a socio-economic abyss, which would create immense regional instability, as so the EU most use all avenues of political action to try to find a solution to the crisis as well as to keeping up pressure on the Venezuelan government to address the current concerns on human rights and democracy.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. As a member of my ECR Group in the Committee on Human Rights, I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Venezuela. I would like to express my serious concern about the serious deterioration of the rule of law, democracy and the socio-economic situation in Venezuela. I strongly condemn the use of state power, in particular that of the judiciary and the National Electoral Council, to distort and disregard legislation lawfully adopted by the Venezuelan Parliament, the National Assembly, thereby undermining the will of the Venezuelan people, which was expressed in the elections of 6 December 2015.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. It is urgent to address the serious economic and social deficits in Venezuela that have caused alarming food shortages. That is why the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats is calling for the release of all political prisoners and for the government to accept the help of human rights organisations.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that the situation in Venezuela must be taken seriously, in its entirety, and with the intention of building the conditions for a real mechanism for dialogue and national reconciliation. The Venezuelan authorities have a duty to re-establish the rule of law, to guarantee security and the free exercise of rights for all citizens, in particular for human rights defenders. I hope that the presence of the delegation has laid the foundations for a real analysis of the situation in the country but, above all, has made the government aware of a concrete and timely change in the European Parliament.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is a balanced text. The left must denounce the abuses of power and violations of democracy and the rule of law that are being committed in Venezuela. And at the same time, the left has to make a firm commitment to the dialogue between Government and opposition, Executive and Legislative, as the only possible, peaceful and legitimate solution to the problems in Venezuela. The request for dialogue is in line with the request of most of the international community (UNASUR, CELAC, European Commission, G7, USA and the Vatican among other actors), and with the work of mediation between Government and opposition being carried out by the three former Presidents José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, Leonel Fernández and Marín Torrijos, with the support of UNASUR.  But the resolution also wants to help remedy the serious situation of food and medicine desupply in the country. To this end, it has requested the EU to develop a humanitarian assistance plan to send and distribute supplies in Venezuela, and has called on the Venezuelan Government to accept this aid.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. There was expressed a serious concern at the increasingly deteriorating social tension caused by the shortage of basic goods such as food and medicines. Therefore, the European Parliament calls on President Nicolas Maduro and his government to implement urgent economic reforms in cooperation with the National Assembly in order to find a constructive solution to the economic and energy crises, in particular the shortage of food and medicines.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is a balanced text. The left must denounce the abuses of power and violations of democracy and the rule of law that are being committed in Venezuela. And at the same time, the left has to make a firm commitment to the dialogue between Government and opposition, Executive and Legislative, as the only possible, peaceful and legitimate solution to the problems in Venezuela. The request for dialogue is in line with the request of most of the international community (UNASUR, CELAC, European Commission, G7, USA and the Vatican among other actors), and with the work of mediation between Government and opposition being carried out by the three former Presidents José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, Leonel Fernández and Marín Torrijos, with the support of UNASUR.  But the resolution also wants to help remedy the serious situation of food and medicine desupply in the country. To this end, it has requested the EU to develop a humanitarian assistance plan to send and distribute supplies in Venezuela, and has called on the Venezuelan Government to accept this aid.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the resolution, since we consider it discriminatory and intrusive against a third country.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I authored and supported the joint resolution and I was happy that it did acknowledge the seriously deteriorating situation as regards democracy, human rights and the socio-economic situation in Venezuela, where the political and social climate is becoming more unstable. I also supported the call on the Venezuelan Government to respect the rule of law and the principle of the separation of powers. Currently, there are around 2 000 people in prison, under house arrest or on probation for political reasons and that the rule of law and the principle of the separation of powers are not duly respected in Venezuela. Therefore, the Venezuelan Government needs to adopt a constructive attitude in order to overcome Venezuela’s current critical situation. In this regard, the Venezuelan authorities need to: - release immediately the political prisoners; - guarantee security and the free exercise of rights for all citizens, in particular human rights defenders, journalists and political activists. In addition, the Venezuelan government needs to implement urgent economic reforms in order to find a solution to the economic and energy crises, in particular the shortage of food and medicines. Finally, I was happy to support the call on the Venezuelan authorities to investigate the Tumeremo massacre, in which 28 miners were murdered.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion as it creates a clear path for the EU to follow in relation to the situation.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the initiatives of the Venezuelan government and local authorities, which are working to remedy the current socio-economic conflict situation by initiating a dialogue towards democracy, respect for social and labour rights, as well as the universal right to education and the constitutional right to peaceful demonstrations and finding concrete solutions against violence.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Joint Proposal for a Resolution on the Situation in Venezuela, as the country is currently in major political, economic, social and humanitarian problems and political and social instability is increasing every day.  Following the crisis with elections, the rule of law and the principle of the sharing of power are not fully respected in Venezuela. In addition, the humanitarian crisis is steadily increasing and causing increasing social tension caused by a lack of essentials such as food and medicine.  This proposal calls on the VP/HIGH REPRESENTATIVE of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to put forward a road plan to help the country and to help the most vulnerable layers of society as soon as possible.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Most resolutions strictly take up American propaganda. The view that can be given to the Bolivarian model of development is irrelevant in the face of the universality of the rule of non-interference in internal affairs. Unasur and the United Nations are currently negotiating between the various parties. The Union is totally illegitimate to meddle in this matter. It is only natural that my vote was against these resolutions.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In this resolution, the European Parliament called on Caracas to release all political prisoners, to authorise the activities of humanitarian organisations and to respect constitutional mechanisms. Europe must contribute to finding a solution to the serious economic, humanitarian and institutional crisis in Venezuela. I agree that the human rights abuses and undemocratic interference taking place in Venezuela are completely unacceptable and the EU should consider targeted sanctions against the Maduro regime. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which expresses concern about the situation in Venezuela, at a time when the country, which has been mired in crisis since the fall in oil prices, is on the verge of a social explosion with the incarceration of political prisoners.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution. It clearly presents the government's human rights violations, identifies socialist mismanagement and nepotism as reasons for the economic crisis that is raging in the country, and condemns the opposition's gait and the erosion of the rule of law.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. European Parliament stands in solidarity with the people of Venezuela. The rapidly deteriorating situation of human rights, democracy and rule of law gives reason to grave concern. The opposition had one month to gather 200 000 signatures to support a referendum to force President Maduro out of office, within a week they collected more than 1.8 million. This is a clear sign that Venezuelan people want a change and a way out of an authoritarian rule. Venezuelan economy is expected to shrink this year by further 8%, there is a shortage of everything from electricity to basic nutrition. It has become a situation of permanent crisis that both the current president Maduro and his predecessor Chavez are to be held responsible for. Venezuela holds one of the biggest oil reserves of the planet, and yet people are told not to blow-dry their hair in order to save electricity. We call on the Venezuelan government: - to respect the peacefully elected new National - to release political prisoners - to respect the legal mechanisms relating to the call for a referendum on the continuity of the  President of the country before the end of 2016.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution, as it supports the ongoing UNASUR mediation efforts and offers pragmatic solutions for unlocking the situation. I believe that the only possible solution to the current Venezuelan crisis is a political one, through mediation and national dialogue.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support the European Parliament resolution of 8 June 2016 on the situation in Venezuela. I did not consider the joint proposal of the people, socialists, conservatives and liberals to be balanced. For example, the resolution ignored the initiative promoted by President Maduro with the support of UNASUR in order to engage in dialogue between representatives of the Government of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela and the opposition, and supports UNASUR in its role, which he advocates, as a priority for this dialogue, the welfare of citizens, peace, justice, truth, good relations between institutions, strengthening the economy, protecting the rule of law, democracy and respect for national sovereignty, the first meeting being held in the Dominican Republic in the presence of former Prime Ministers and President José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero (Spain) , Leonel Fernández (Dominican Republic) and Martín Torrijos (Panama). I was also against the European Parliament sending a delegation to have a dialogue with all the groups affected by the conflict. I believe that the fate of Latin America should only be in the hands of its people, and it is up to the organisations of these countries to find ways of bringing peace to their continent. Moreover, we know from history that Latin America is very squeamish about outside interventions, so prudence is appropriate.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. – The situation in Venezuela is alarming, the fall in oil prices has led to a serious crisis in the country. The government has not made the necessary reforms in time and for years the opposition has focused on inciting chaos. Venezuela must not be used as an instrument of the internal policy of European countries, nor should it be encouraged towards civil war. We must focus on doing everything for it in order to resolve the humanitarian crisis, strengthen the rule of law, reform the economic system and get all parties involved in building the future by democratic means.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The current political, economic and social situation in Venezuela is very complicated and the country is facing a serious humanitarian crisis, caused by shortages of food and medicine. The principles of rule of law and separation of powers are not fully respected in Venezuela. President Maduro rules the country in authoritarian and repressive way by issuing emergency decrees, removing the National Assembly’s powers to scrutinise policy, refusing to recognise its power by the constitution. In the five months during which the new National Assembly has been legislatively active, with the democratic opposition in the majority, the Supreme Court has handed down 13 politically motivated judgments in favour of the executive, all of which imperil the balance of power required in a state governed by the rule of law. In addition to this, Maduro’s government is particularly tough on freedom of speech, freedom of assembly, civil society and etc. Nowadays in Venezuela there are 2000 prisoners of conscience. Therefore, I voted for the resolution because Venezuelan authorities should immediately release all political prisoners, to respect and guarantee the constitutional rights and freedoms of Venezuelan people. The President’s government should adopt a constructive attitude in order to overcome Venezuela’s current critical situation through a constitutional, peaceful and democratic dialogue.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it interferes in the internal affairs of a sovereign state while relaying American propaganda on its situation.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The vote is on motions for a resolution on the situation in Venezuela. The country is going through a period of political and economic instability based on internal and external factors. Internally, the government is struggling to find a balance between the two main parties and endemic crime is corroding the country. The external vectors are the fall in oil prices, which is the main source of wealth in the country, but also the interference of foreign powers (United States, Colombia...) who are trying to overthrow President Maduro. I believe that the principle of non-interference is universal and that no one can judge the development model of a third country, let alone interfere in its internal affairs. The Union is illegitimate on this issue. That is why I voted AGAINST the joint motion for a resolution and those of the EPP, ALDE, S and D and ECR groups. I abstained on the texts of the GUE and the EFDD. Finally, the Greens' proposal being more balanced, I voted FOR.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is a balanced text. The left must denounce the abuses of power and violations of democracy and the rule of law that are being committed in Venezuela. And at the same time, the left has to make a firm commitment to the dialogue between Government and opposition, Executive and Legislative, as the only possible, peaceful and legitimate solution to the problems in Venezuela. The request for dialogue is in line with the request of most of the international community (UNASUR, CELAC, European Commission, G7, USA and the Vatican among other actors), and with the work of mediation between Government and opposition being carried out by the three former Presidents José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, Leonel Fernández and Marín Torrijos, with the support of UNASUR.  But the resolution also wants to help remedy the serious situation of food and medicine desupply in the country. To this end, it has requested the EU to develop a humanitarian assistance plan to send and distribute supplies in Venezuela, and has called on the Venezuelan Government to accept this aid.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against Venezuela's resolution, because it is an interference player and responds to an action of interventionist destabilization, it was driven by the Spanish parties – the grand coalition – to influence the election campaign in Spain. It is a resolution that, instead of seeking solutions, seeks to interfere in internal affairs of the democratic government of a sovereign country. It is a resolution full of falsehoods, distortions and inaccuracies such as arguing that in Venezuela there is no separation of powers or that the Supreme Court is illegitimate. It was voted on to report that the revocation signatures introduced by the opposition were not validated, and just 8 June, the day of the vote, the CNE announced the validation of 1 300 000 signatures. He voted to demand an investigation into the facts in the mining region of Tumeremo, bypassing the fact that the Attorney General's Office is already investigating and taking action.  The Venezuelan government asked UNASUR to lead a facilitator mission of dialogue with the non-violent opposition, which has been supported by CELAC, OAS and Moguerini. However, this unacceptable resolution ignores these advances and efforts on the path framed in international law and the Charter of the United Nations, to serve the Spanish political agenda.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The introduction of socialism in Venezuela by former President Chavez and current President Maduro has led to poverty, hyperinflation, pervasive queues and shortages of goods, power out. I feel sorry for the Venezuelans, and I wish them would get rid of the socialist government soon. However, the European Parliament resolution will do nothing to help this country. Therefore, as usual, I am staying with resolutions that comment on the various sufferings in the world.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The motion for a resolution expresses concern about the deteriorating situation in Venezuela in the areas of democracy and human rights. It strongly condemns the Council's abuse of state power and non-compliance with the legal decisions of the newly elected National Assembly. It calls on the Venezuelan government to act within the limits of democracy. It also requires the creation of an independent international commission of inquiry to determine the circumstances of the Tumerem massacre, where 28 miners were killed. Venezuelan authorities are being asked to guarantee the safety of all citizens, especially political activists and journalists. The Commission also expresses great concern at the increase in social tensions caused by the lack of goods, food and medicines, and calls for a peaceful resolution of the dialogue-based situation between all parties. I supported the proposal for this resolution, as it provides humanitarian assistance to the Venezuelan people and seeks to improve the political and social situation in Venezuela.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ The failure to respect the rule of law and the separation of powers in Venezuela results in violations of fundamental human rights and freedoms, political instability. This affects the economic and social situation in Venezuela. This has created a serious humanitarian crisis linked to food and medicine shortages, the breakdown of basic infrastructure and an increase in crime. Venezuela's poverty rate has doubled since 2013. This instability poses a potential danger to the whole region. I therefore support the call for increased mediation efforts by the Union and international organisations and institutions, which will lead to constructive cooperation between the legislative, executive and judicial powers in Venezuela. It will help to establish democratic processes in the country.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. Since the death of President Hugo Chavez in March 2013, Venezuela has been going through its worst political and socio-economic crisis. Indeed, the Venezuelan economic situation has deteriorated considerably: inflation at 180%, a decline in GDP of 6 points and a price per barrel of oil just above 50 dollars in 2015. In 2014, according to Amnesty International, 43 people were killed and 870 injured in demonstrations. At the political level, the situation is increasingly confused, with President Maduro declaring a state of economic emergency and then a state of emergency. I support this resolution which expresses the EU's solidarity with the Venezuelan people, calls for a referendum by Parliament to be facilitated and condemns the control of the ruling power over the Constitutional Court.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the joint resolution.  This resolution comes against a backdrop of high instability in Venezuela: falling oil prices and endemic crime are the main causes.  We cannot condone interference in the domestic politics of a sovereign state, especially since American interventionism is largely responsible for the chaotic situation in that country.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. My full and convinced support for the resolution we have tabled in the European Parliament, in which we call on the Government of Nicolás Maduro to release all political prisoners, measures in the face of the humanitarian crisis and not to block the possible call for a revocation referendum in Venezuela. I am more than pleased that the EU is finally demonstrating a clear and forceful attitude towards what is happening in Venezuela, conveying the message that Venezuelans are not alone and that the EU is on the side of democracy and human rights in venezuela, as we had claimed since the PP.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. It deals with human rights violations and the unstable economic situation in Venezuela. It also denounces the harassment of the opposition and the lack of the rule of law. The report calls for a solution to these key points. I therefore support this motion for a resolution.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
