text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP resolution, which expresses concern about the sharp deterioration of democracy, human rights and the socio-economic situation in Venezuela and the ever-increasing atmosphere of political and social instability.  I support calls for the EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to step up its cooperation with Latin American countries and regional and international organisations in order to ensure that mechanisms for dialogue, national reconciliation and mediation are put in place in Venezuela and that this supports a peaceful, democratic and constitutional solution to the current crisis.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The country's current instability, due to the price of oil, the rivalry of the two main political parties and endemic crime, must not suffer from further interference. Moreover, the universality of the rule of non-interference in internal affairs, the fact that the Union has no legitimacy in the field and our duty not to blindly relay American propaganda lead me to vote against the resolution.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation currently in Venezuela must concern the entire European community, but also serve as an example for what are wrong public policies. Venezuela is now experiencing a climate of serious deterioration in terms of democracy, human rights and socio-economic conditions, with increasing political and social instability. I follow the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament in calling on the Government of Venezuela to adopt a constructive attitude in compliance with the constitution and democratic principles.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this motion due to the importance of determining a resolution for Venezuela’s violations of both human rights and rule of law. The government of Venezuela must respect the universal human rights of its citizens, as requested by this motion.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – The international community is deeply concerned about the dire situation in Venezuela. The country is in a deep economic and humanitarian crisis. Nearly 60% of the population lives in severe poverty. The vast majority of food and medicines are no longer available and humanitarian aid from abroad is being thwarted. The political crisis does not seem to be coming to an end either. The united democratic opposition won a two-thirds majority in parliament at the end of last year. But despite the fact that President Maduro has conceded defeat, he is doing everything he can to reduce the legitimate power of parliament. Because of their political preferences, more than 2,000 people were deprived of their freedom. That is why we urge the Venezuelan Government to reverse these abuses, respect the rule of law, respect the legitimacy of parliament, restore democracy and tackle impunity. We also ask the HR to contribute constructively to national reconciliation in the country. At the same time, we urge the government and parliament to implement reforms to lift the country out of the mire economically and socially.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – Venezuela accounts for 20% of the world's oil reserves, representing 3% of world production, as oil accounts for 96% of the country's exports. During the economic boom, the country did not make savings in order to mitigate the trade reversal or to cushion the effects of the necessary macroeconomic adjustments. The International Monetary Fund estimates that by the end of 2016 the average inflation rate will reach 700% and in 2017 it will be 2,200%. Ineffective management has led to a serious economic and social crisis, manifested by a long-term shortage of resources, raw materials, inputs, basic foodstuffs and essential medicines, as well as zero production. The country is on the verge of serious social unrest that could cause a humanitarian crisis with unpredictable consequences. The government over-influences and controls the judiciary and the National Electoral Council, which has a negative impact on legislative and opposition powers, which are the cornerstone of any democratic system. I am seriously concerned about the serious deterioration of the situation of democracy and human rights in Venezuela, and therefore the Union should be instrumental in stabilising the country. I support the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution, which calls on the Venezuelan Government to respect the rule of law and the principle of the separation of powers and recalls that separation and non-interference between equally legitimate powers is an essential principle of democratic states guided by the rule of law. The resolution urges the Venezuelan Government to release all political prisoners immediately and recalls that the freeing of political prisoners is a precondition set by the opposition for starting the negotiation talks, and calls on both sides to agree on a compromise solution aimed at supporting the mediation efforts currently in place. It also calls for the EU and the VP/HR to urge the release of the political prisoners and those arbitrarily detained, in line with the demands made by several UN bodies and international organisations and with the Amnesty and National Reconciliation Law.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 A motion for a resolution on the situation in Venezuela was tabled by the PPE, Verts/ALE, ECR, EFDD, GUE/NGL, ALDE and S&D political groups. Among them, the PPE, ECR, ALDE and S&D groups reached an agreement and drafted a joint compromise motion. I voted in favour of the compromise proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. It is necessary for the European Commission to follow intensely the dramatic situation experienced in venezuela in recent times where, let us not forget, we have thousands of Madeiran emigrants. The Venezuelan population, resident emigrants, citizens are facing serious economic and social difficulties, notably in the face of food shortages in supermarkets, systematic power cuts and stagnation in economic activity. We cannot remain indifferent, so I have appealed to the Commission. It is impossible to remain indifferent, especially when many of us have great affinity with this country through the family and friends who live there. I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution because, in addition to the lack of human conditions, Venezuela has been calling into question free trade and not respecting foreign direct investment, thus calling into question the possible trade agreement being negotiated between the European Union and Mercosur.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Most resolutions strictly take up American propaganda. The view that can be given to the Bolivarian model of development is irrelevant in the face of the universality of the rule of non-interference in internal affairs. Unasur and the United Nations are currently negotiating between the various parties. The Union is totally illegitimate to meddle in this matter. I'm voting against this report.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the situation in Venezuela. This text is concerned about the current situation of human rights, the state of democracy, respect for the constitution of that country. In particular, the report denounces the presence of people detained for political reasons in Venezuelan prisons. The resolution calls on the Venezuelan authorities to do everything possible to resolve this situation and calls for a delegation from the European Parliament to visit the site.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that expresses strong concerns about the deteriorating situation regarding democracy and human rights. The motion for a resolution also calls on the Venezuelan Government to respect the rule of law and the principle of separation of powers.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The grave state of democracy, human rights and socio-economic conditions in Venezuela has caused a political and humanitarian emergency to unfold. To solve the crisis, this joint motion for a resolution calls on the Venezuelan government to respect the constitution, rule of law, and engage in dialogue with the opposition and civil society. This also includes allowing the entry of humanitarian aid into the country and securing the right to freedom of expression, of which releasing political prisoners is an important first step. I endorse this resolution because it is important that the EU demands that the Venezuelan Government take on political responsibility and fulfil its obligations towards the people of Venezuela and international treaties.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this resolution, which was a blatant attempt to join in foreign interference in Venezuela, worsening the situation there and increasing tensions. Despite talking about human rights, aid, and helping resolve the political tensions in Venezuela, the resolution was clearly biased in favour of the Venezuelan opposition, reflecting their demands and claims, while failing to give a balanced view of the situation in Venezuela. Failing to acknowledge the impact of a fall in oil prices, evidence of economic sabotage, and the effect of a severe drought on Venezuela’s hydroelectric sector, the resolution blames the government for the situation in Venezuela. The resolution also echoes the opposition call for hundreds of prisoners to be released, included many who were involved in organising violent protests that led to several deaths. Because this was a blatant attempt to interfere in the internal politics of Venezuela, I voted against this resolution.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the joint resolution of the People's Party, Social Democrats, Liberals and Conservative Reformists, because it intervenes openly and openly in the internal political situation of Venezuela, while at the same time hiding that the cause of its people's problems is the capitalist way of production, the domination of monopolies. It is a bottomless audacity for parties in all EU Member States to pretend to be the honoree of popular rights, which in all EU Member States are crushing wages and pensions, demolishing labour and social rights, condemning unemployment, poverty and impoverishment to their peoples, as their relatives in Venezuela have done for decades. This unacceptable resolution paves the way for imperialist intervention by the EU and its allies, the US and NATO, in the country and in the wider region. The Communist Party expresses its solidarity with the working class and the popular strata of Venezuela, which are faced with the consequences of the capitalist crisis. It supports the inalienable right of the Venezuelan people to choose and define the path of development and the social organisation that meets their interests, fighting against their monopolies and power, for radical changes in power and the economy.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Venezuela faces a critical situation both from an institutional point of view, given the high crime rate and political instability in the country, and from an economic point of view. I believe it is necessary, in order to arrive at a shared solution, to establish a dialogue between the government, the democratic opposition and society. I support the request in the resolution to send an EU delegation to define this issue and I am voting in favour.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the report refers to the violations of human rights in Venezuela and the totally unstable economic situation caused by socialist mismanagement. It also calls for a solution to the crisis, which will be found through dialogue with all levels of government, democratic opposition and society.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The motion for a resolution calls on Venezuela to fight more firmly for democratic governance. Venezuela is experiencing an extremely poor human rights and socio-economic situation that requires immediate and decisive action.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The political crisis in Venezuela is increasingly affecting its citizens every day, confirming information about the increasing availability of basic foods for life. It is the duty of the European Union to react in line with our values and capabilities and to clearly stand up for respect for rights and laws in this important State of South America with which Europe has long-standing friendly political and economic relations. Recent developments have severely damaged venezuela's citizens' basic human rights, and Venezuela's economy has been in a severe recession. This resolution is an expression of our concern and should encourage de-escalation. Any further radicalisation of the existing political conflict, but also the increasing social tension caused by shortages of basic goods such as food and medicine, can trigger violence and social unrest.  That is why I am joining calls for all members of Venezuelan society to moderate their actions to overcome the current crisis situation in the country. I would like to say to the political elites in Venezuela that they are responsible for the future of their people, and I support the people of Venezuela so that they feel that they are not alone and that each of us is doing everything necessary to normalize the overall life and political situation in their country as soon as possible.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The situation that Venezuela is experiencing is dramatic. The government's refusal to release political prisoners, the blurring of the separation of powers, and above all the homelessness that much of the population is experiencing, with difficulties in accessing basic necessities and increasingly difficult living conditions, makes this resolution particularly important. I hope that this resolution will be a breath of fresh air for those who advocate that Venezuela regain lost democratic values, and that it will be a benchmark for the future of this country. In this regard, I regret the vote of some of my colleagues who refuse to see the reality and need to safeguard the basic rights of the population, and I regret that ideology blinds them. Hopefully, from the European Parliament we have found great consensus to bring this resolution forward.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Most resolutions strictly take up American propaganda. The view that can be given to the Bolivarian model of development is irrelevant in the face of the universality of the rule of non-interference in internal affairs. Unasur and the United Nations are currently negotiating between the various parties. The Union is totally illegitimate to meddle in this matter. I'm voting against the report.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 At a time when the Venezuelan opposition is involved in a process of dialogue with the Government, promoted by UNASUR, and when the Permanent Council of the OAS, with the support of the right of several countries, adopted a declaration in which it supports that initiative and values the effort of dialogue between the parties, in the framework of respect for the sovereignty of Venezuela, the right-wing majority and social democracy in the European Parliament insist on voting a resolution that absolutely contradicts the dialogue effort that these and other regional structures (ALBA, AEC) are promoting and valuing and which Federica Mogherini has endorsed and supported today. A resolution that embarrasses and compromises the institutional relations themselves between the European institutions and those Regional Structures of Latin America, as well as with the Republic of Venezuela, as it moves forward with a set of "proposals" that are nothing more than a covert support and direct involvement in an external intervention in that country desired by the most reactionary and radical sectors. We reaffirm that it is solely and exclusively for Venezuelans to resolve their internal affairs within the constitutional and legal framework of a sovereign country that for almost two decades has been an example of the democratic functioning of its institutions and participatory democracy.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The political and economic crisis in Venezuela can also add to the humanitarian crisis and the lack of basic necessities of life. The figures show that a worker needs 18 times the minimum wage to be able to buy basic necessities in a week. Basic foods such as flour, powdered milk, bread and diapers are difficult to find in self-support, and hospitals lack medicine and staff. Venezuela is stepping towards ruin and it is worrying that every year 25,000 people die as victims of violence. I supported the Proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament, which encourages regional partners to initiate dialogue and understanding between the parties to the country, in order to ensure peace and stability and respect for basic human rights as soon as possible.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 There are currently significant violations of democratic principles and political persecution of the opposition in Venezuela. The suppression of civil protests has even claimed several lives. As a Social Democrat, I therefore, of course, support the European Parliament's appeal not only to the Institutions of the Union and the Member States, but also to the international community, to take appropriate steps to open up dialogue and ensure public protection and security. I am pleased to be able, at least in this way, to express my solidarity with the Venezuelan people at this difficult time. The European Commission and the Council should then take all necessary measures to protect European interests and legal certainty for European companies active in Venezuela.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Venezuela is currently experiencing an extremely fragile political situation, marked by an ongoing conflict between the opposition-controlled parliament and the pro-Maduro government, all in a climate of economic collapse linked in particular to the fall in oil prices. It was in this context that I voted in favour of this resolution, which urges the Government of the country to release all political prisoners, thereby respecting its constitution.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 By the Resolutions of 2014 and 2015, the European Union has reiterated its concern about the situation in Venezuela. Added to these is the question of the breach of the principle of separation of powers, which is clear in the exercise of the National Assembly. In December 2015, popular suffrage was able to alter the balance of power in favour of the democratic opposition, which has since gathered the support of the parliamentary majority. During this period, the Supreme Court delivered 13 judgments markedly biased and voted to enforce the desiderates of the incumbent executive. This totalitarian and undemocratic modus operandi poses an increased danger to Venezuela in the current precarious context. On the revenue side, the fall in oil prices and the slowdown in crude oil production have led to the paralysis of an economy whose economic model, based on oil exports, is doomed at the outset. Nevertheless, Maduro's government refuses to implement economic reforms and cooperate with the legislature in order to find a solution to the economic and energy crisis. In this context, my vote reflects the rapporteur's position, which invites the Commission to negotiate the conditions for external aid on the basis of its commitments on the rule of law and human rights.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report expresses concern about the climate of political and social instability in Venezuela and its consequent and serious deterioration of the democratic situation, human rights and socio-economic conditions, also expressing concern at the current institutional impasse and the use by the executive of state powers to control the Supreme Court and the National Electoral Council in order to prevent the implementation of the legislative provisions and initiatives adopted by the National Assembly. In this way, we call on the Venezuelan Government to adopt a constructive attitude, through a constitutional, peaceful and democratic solution based on dialogue, to respect the rule of law, as well as the principle of separation of powers, and to immediately release the 2,000 political prisoners. I voted for it.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. We are very concerned about the serious deterioration of the situation in the area of democracy and human rights in Venezuela, as well as the growing deterioration of social tension caused by the scarcity of essential goods such as food and medicines. There will be no viable, peaceful and stable solution for Venezuela without a national and constructive dialogue between all parties involved. The only way out is a negotiated democratic solution. The Government of Venezuela must respect the rule of law and the principle of separation of powers in order to regain democratic and social normality.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the joint resolution on Venezuela. The situation there is indeed very worrying. The country is facing a serious economic and political crisis that calls for urgent reforms. It is essential that the Venezuelan authorities respect the principles of separation of powers and the rule of law, on which any democracy is based. In this sense, I call for the immediate release of thousands of political prisoners and the re-establishment of their civil and political rights. Moreover, while respecting national sovereignty, it is essential that the country accept humanitarian aid in areas plagued by food and medicine shortages and actively combat the exploitation of illegal mines. Venezuela must return to dialogue both at the international level and with its people, adopting a constructive and peaceful attitude.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The situation in Venezuela has been worrying for a long time. Basically, we see a failing country. A country where almost all food grows and has sufficient natural resources and human capacity to live well, safely and richly. The cause of the crisis is easily identified: an undemocratic political regime, a poorly functioning state administration and a long-term dependence solely on oil exports. It is good that the Commission and Parliament are looking for an answer to the question – and what can we help? It is clear that humanitarian aid will not be sufficient to address the current crisis. Although this does not mean that the EU does not have to provide a small budget for this support. After all, the territory of an EU Member State, French Guiana, is also nearby, and we certainly do not want the threat of neighbouring unrest to affect this area as well. It is clear that the humanitarian intervention proposed by some South American countries and the overthrow of political power will also not change the situation significantly. It is clear that Venezuelan society must take responsibility for its own future and take the initiative to change the situation. The EU needs to do everything in every way.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This joint Resolution of the European Parliament on the political situation in Venezuela was adopted with the votes of 501 MEPs, but it was rejected by the majority of MEPs belonging to the most left and right-wing parliamentary groups on the political spectrum in the European Parliament (94 votes against; 73 abstentions). In the debate that took place at the last plenary session in Strasbourg, I had the opportunity to express my strong concern about the dramatic situation that the country is experiencing and i said then that I believe that Venezuela lives "in a real powder keg, which a slightly stronger fuse will explode". I also recalled that a Councillor of the Portuguese Communities from Venezuela said at the end of April in Lisbon "that the situation is unsustainable and our greatest fear at the moment is that we are moving towards a civil war. The situation is serious." That is why I believe that the time has come for the European Union to act to ensure the protection of the large expatriate community of European citizens living and working in Venezuela, which includes close to 200,000 registered Portuguese. To that end, I also asked the Commission on 2 May and, of course, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution tabled by representatives of the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats on the situation in Venezuela. Through this text, the European Parliament wishes to express its deep solidarity with Venezuela, a country that is suffering from a serious economic and social crisis. The recession in Venezuela has been described as the most severe in the world, which seems unheard of for a country with the largest oil reserves. Parliament also expressed its concern at the institutional impasse in the country, where the rule of law and human rights are not recognised by the current government. Through the vote on this text, I join with the rest of the Parliamentary Assembly in calling on the Venezuelan Government to restore respect for democratic principles and the fundamental freedoms of its citizens.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from the final vote on this Joint Resolution, as I consider the situation in Venezuela to be of enormous complexity, and any measure must be focused on improving the living conditions of the Venezuelan people. I believe that this resolution, formulated and negotiated in these terms, has become an instrument for the electoral benefit of third parties, diverting the focus from what is truly important. I believe that in the current political, social and economic situation of the country, dialogue is indispensable as a key route for a peaceful solution in respect of the democratic and constitutional order of the country. Therefore, since not all the proposals submitted from alternative groups have been made, we consider that the spirit of the text is far from intended to encourage and contribute to dialogue between the parties. Consequently, I abstained.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The political and humanitarian situation in Venezuela requires action, and with this agreement we support the STRATEGY of the European Union and the Federal Of South America for emergency aid to the Venezuelan people. However, humanitarian action should be combined with political action so that we can also put an unsettling in the country.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against Venezuela's resolution, because it is an interference player and responds to an action of interventionist destabilization, it was driven by the Spanish parties – the grand coalition – to influence the election campaign in Spain. It is a resolution that, instead of seeking solutions, seeks to interfere in internal affairs of the democratic government of a sovereign country. It is a resolution full of falsehoods, distortions and inaccuracies such as arguing that in Venezuela there is no separation of powers or that the Supreme Court is illegitimate. It was voted on to report that the revocation signatures introduced by the opposition were not validated, and just 8 June, the day of the vote, the CNE announced the validation of 1 300 000 signatures. He voted to demand an investigation into the facts in the mining region of Tumeremo, bypassing the fact that the Attorney General's Office is already investigating and taking action.  The Venezuelan government asked UNASUR to lead a facilitator mission of dialogue with the non-violent opposition, which has been supported by CELAC, OAS and Moguerini. However, this unacceptable resolution ignores these advances and efforts on the path framed in international law and the Charter of the United Nations, to serve the Spanish political agenda.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. The political, economic and social situation of Venezuela is worrying and complex. This crisis has led to a deterioration of respect for human rights, the rule of law, democracy, the socio-economic situation and a deep social upheatory. This resolution on the situation in Venezuela expresses great concern for a country where there are 2,000 political prisoners, including key opposition leaders, where a humanitarian crisis is experiencing a humanitarian crisis due to lack of food and medicine. In Venezuela there is a high rate of crime and impunity. In addition, the Venezuelan Government delays international assistance that could be promptly provided by NGOs.  I voted to approve this resolution because the derailment of the situation in Venezuela is unsustainable and could turn into a crisis with even more serious consequences. The solution is the dialogue between the government, the opposition and society at large. For its part, the European Union must, together with the Countries of Latin America, play a mediation role in order to pressure the Venezuelan authorities to seek a peaceful and democratic solution.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am deeply concerned about the serious deterioration of the situation with regard to democracy, human rights and the socio-economic situation in Venezuela, in an environment of increasing political and social instability. Urgent economic reforms must be carried out in order to find a constructive solution to the economic and energy crisis, in particular food and medicine shortages. I therefore supported this resolution.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I have decided to abstain from this report, and this reasoning for voting comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ The political situation in Venezuela has deteriorated so much in recent years that the country is now facing a serious humanitarian crisis manifested by food and medicine shortages. The Venezuelan National Assembly has even declared a humanitarian health and food crisis and has asked the World Health Organisation for humanitarian aid and a technical visit to confirm the situation. In addition, the poverty rate doubled from 30 percent in 2013 to 60 percent in 2016, according to anecdotal data. In such circumstances, it is unacceptable for the government to prevent aid access to the country and to boycott various international initiatives calling for a halt to the repression of civil society. I supported the motion for a resolution because it calls for calming political and social instability in the country. The Venezuelan Government must return to respect for the rule of law and respect the separation of the various branches of power, as the available information indicates that the government is abusing judicial power to suppress the opposition. In doing so, the opposition coalition won an absolute majority of seats in the national assembly. There must therefore be a process of national dialogue between the executive and the opposition. The escalation of this civil conflict does no one any good, on the contrary, it is particularly damaging to the poorest, who thus do not have access to basic food and medicines. I therefore expect President Maduro, together with the National Assembly, to carry out the necessary economic reforms and to advocate a constructive solution to the current crisis in Venezuela.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The situation in Venezuela is quite tense due to various factors, such as high inflation, the liberalisation of the exchange rate, which has had negative consequences for income and access to goods, and the unprecedented drought resulting from the El Niño phenomenon. What exacerbated tensions in the country was the opposition's victory in parliamentary elections in December 2015. It has requested an unprecedented division of positions on the executive, judicial and legislative branches of government. In 2015, there were riots that had not yet been prosecuted. For this reason, meps of the European Parliament have decided to adopt a resolution to address the situation in Venezuela and to call for an improvement. Unfortunately, the Greens' request for a resolution calling on the Member States of the European Union not to use the situation in Venezuela for political purposes in their home countries has been rejected. What's more, rather than criticism of both sides in the conflict over the use of violence, the resolution unilaterally shifts the blame to the Venezuelan government and calls into question the power-sharing in Venezuela. Although I believe that a resolution on the situation in Venezuela would be welcome, I am not satisfied with the content of the current resolution, which is why I abstained.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Venezuela is an example of where irresponsible and populist politics can get a prosperous country. In our thoughts and actions, we are with the Venezuelan people to overcome this difficult time and put the country back on the path of democracy and sensible economic policy. He has and will have our full support on this.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution, which I have unequivocally supported, draws attention to the literally deplorable situation that is going on in this country. The European Parliament is appealing for solutions to both the economic crisis and the political stalemate. Nearly two decades of socialist rule by President Chávez and his successor Maduro have brought Venezuela, a mineral-rich country, into a state of chaos and dom. Over the past three years, the poverty rate has doubled from thirty to sixty percent. Seventy-five percent of the most important medicines are not available in Venezuela. By the end of this year, the average inflation rate will rise to 700 percent, according to the IMF. High crime and almost total impunity, human rights violations. An executive that uses state power to control both the Supreme Court and the National Electoral Council and blocks the application of laws passed by the National Assembly. Other characteristics of today's Venezuela. Last but not least, in the resolution, we call on the Venezuelan Government to release all political prisoners. These are approximately 2,000 people who are under house arrest, house arrest or probation for political reasons. Among them is Leopoldo López, a prominent opposition politician whose wife, Lilian Tintori, I personally met two years ago. Even then, her husband was in prison. After our meeting, I initiated an urgent resolution on behalf of our political faction, the PPE, in support of Lopez and other unjustly imprisoned Venezuelan citizens.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this motion for a resolution, as I find the current deterioration of the social, political and economic situation worrying. I believe that the Government of Venezuela should take a constructive stance that would overcome the current difficult situation and, with the help of peaceful and democratic policies, resolve the situation. I also think that the Venezuelan authorities should guarantee and respect the constitutional right to peaceful protest and that opposition leaders should exercise their powers responsibly. Unfortunately, the principle of the sharing of power and the rule of law are not fully respected in Venezuela, and the current situation suggests that serious consequences arise for the legislature and the opposition, in violation of the principles of independence and the sharing of powers that are the principles and foundations of democratic states. Finally, I believe that this increasingly serious economic and political crisis as well as the tension that is growing due to a lack of essentials such as food and medicine requires urgent resolution and stabilisation of the current situation, primarily by allowing humanitarian aid to enter the country to at least help the most vulnerable layers of society.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I abstained in the vote on the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the situation in Venezuela. As far as the motion for a resolution calls for the rule of law, this is right, but it is not a matter for the EU.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament is seriously concerned about the deteriorating situation in terms of democracy and human rights in Venezuela. It condemns the abuse of state powers, in particular the State Election Commission and the judiciary, for misinterpretation and disregard for decisions taken in accordance with the law by the legislature of the National Assembly. Parliament calls on the Venezuelan government to respect the rule of law and the principle of the division of power, to act within the limits of democracy and to unconditionally release political prisoners arbitrarily arrested. The growing social tension caused by shortages of basic goods such as food and medicine fuels violence and social unrest, and all members of Venezuelan society must have moderation in action in order to overcome the current crisis situation in the country thanks to constitutional, peaceful and democratic solutions based on dialogue. I support the motion for a Resolution, as I consider it a fundamental priority to reduce the high impunity rate of crimes, as this promotes and encourages the growth of violence and insecurity in the country and ensures compliance with the current legal system. The Venezuelan government and public authorities must respect the constitution and thereby facilitate, not prevent, the functioning of recognised legal mechanisms and procedures.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Venezuela. We need a response to the deteriorating situation in the area of democracy and human rights and the socio-economic situation in Venezuela, where a climate of political and social instability is increasingly prevalent. The Venezuelan Government must take responsibility and move beyond the current critical situation in the country through a constructive approach in a way that seeks a constitutional, peaceful and democratic solution based on dialogue. Only dialogue can take a country out of this difficult situation. Above all, dialogue between the government and the opposition, which must be present and conducted smoothly at all times. I support the call for the Venezuelan Government to release all political prisoners immediately.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We strongly condemn the brutal interference in the internal affairs of a third independent state and especially in this case, where the role of the international actor and specific states is from suspect to dangerous to international security and stability.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a resolution, as it reflects a compromise between party fractions on the issue of political contradictions in the complex socio-political crisis in Venezuela. In my opinion, the European Union and Parliament cannot remain speechless in a situation where human rights are being violated en masse in the political stalemate that has ens emerged in the wake of the Venezuelan elections, political prisoners have been imprisoned and the country's economic and social crisis has reached rock bottom. I therefore support the active involvement of the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and the inclusion of the subject on the agenda of the forthcoming European Council, following the G7 resolution, in order to facilitate the proposed measures contained in the Parliamentary resolution and political consolidation.  In the short term, I expect the European Parliament to contribute to the dialogue between the Venezuelan Government and its political opposition in the meantime, encouraging the implementation of the most urgent measures in terms of restoring democratic relations, eliminating violations, freeing political prisoners and improving the care of the population.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In its resolution, the European Parliament calls on the Venezuelan Government to return to democracy as soon as possible, to respect the rule of law and to release political prisoners. I am deeply concerned about the current economic, social and humanitarian situation in the country. Every day, Venezuelans face shortages of food, medicine and raw materials, while limiting the government's ability to deliver humanitarian aid from outside. We are now witnessing a bizarre situation where a country with the world's largest oil reserves is going through its deepest recession in history, has the highest level of inflation, and poverty has doubled in just three years. I believe that the European Union should be involved in the process of dialogue with the Venezuelan authorities, while providing humanitarian support to the citizens of the country. The European Parliament resolution rightly calls for the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to present an aid plan for Venezuela.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Like the majority of parliament, I am deeply concerned about the serious deterioration of the situation with regard to democracy, human rights and the socio-economic context in Venezuela, where the political and social climate is increasingly unstable. I am also concerned about the current impasse in the institutions and the use of the executive to take control of the Supreme Court and the National Electoral Council to prevent the implementation of laws and initiatives adopted by the National Assembly. The Venezuelan government must respect the rule of law and the principle of the separation of powers. I recall that the separation of powers and the absence of interference between equally legitimate powers is a fundamental principle applied by democratic states based on the rule of law. I only regret that potential sanctions are not mentioned.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution calling on High Representative of the EU for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy Federica Mogherini to set up an aid plan aimed at responding to the shortage of basic food. It also calls on the June European Council to make a political statement on the situation in Venezuela and to support the recent efforts at mediation. This resolution also urges the Venezuelan government of Nicolas Maduro to respect the Venezuelan constitution, including the legal procedures and mechanisms enabling the process to be activated of dismissing the president before the end of 2016. As the ALDE Group we were also supporting targeted sanctions for those responsible of the situation in the country. Today, Venezuela is suffering the biggest recession and the strongest inflation in the world.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the European Parliament resolution on the situation in Venezuela, as both the Venezuelan government and the Supreme Court are drawn up illegally. There is no separation of powers and the principle of independence in the country, which is typical of democratic states. The country is one of the most dangerous countries in the world because of its high crime rates and impunity. The economic and social crisis is the result of a high level of corruption, mismanagement of public funds and inefficient management. There is also a worrying state of concern in the country with regard to democracy and human rights. Opponents of the government cannot peacefully express their disagreement with what is happening in the country, as in most cases they are suppressed by excessive use of force and arbitrary detention by security authorities.  The government should respect the principles of the rule of law, act within the boundaries of democracy and make it a priority to reduce the high level of impunity that promotes growing violence and insecurity in the country.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from the final vote on this Joint Resolution, as I consider the situation in Venezuela to be of enormous complexity, and any measure must be focused on improving the living conditions of the Venezuelan people. I believe that this resolution, formulated and negotiated in these terms, has become an instrument for the electoral benefit of third parties, diverting the focus from what is truly important. I believe that in the current political, social and economic situation of the country, dialogue is indispensable as a key route for a peaceful solution in respect of the democratic and constitutional order of the country. Therefore, since not all the proposals submitted from alternative groups have been made, we consider that the spirit of the text is far from intended to encourage and contribute to dialogue between the parties. Consequently, I abstained.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ With this vote I express my  grave concern for the political, economic, social and humanitarian crisis in Venezuela and the climate of increasing political and social instability. I call on the Venezuelan Government to adopt a constructive attitude and to find a solution to this serious crisis by opening a close and inclusive dialogue with all sectors of society, including the democratically elected opposition. I call on President Maduro and his government to implement urgent economic reforms in cooperation with the democratically elected National Assembly in order to find a constructive solution to the economic and energy crises, in particular the shortage of food and medicines for the population. Finally, I call on the EU, its Member States and VP/HR Federica Mogherini to urge the Venezuelan authorities to allow humanitarian aid into the country and to grant access to international organisations wishing to assist the most affected sectors of society.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Venezuela has been experiencing a period of turmoil for several months now. Although President Maduro's government acknowledged defeat in the last elections, the country is unable to find a modus vivendi between the two major parties. In addition, external factors are added: - oil prices remain very low, while they account for almost all of the country's foreign exchange inflows; - external powers are involved in the conflict in order to overthrow the Maduro government. These are the United States and their Colombian and European vassals; Endemic crime wreaks political havoc by the opposition. Most resolutions strictly take up American propaganda. The view that can be given to the Bolivarian model of development is irrelevant in the face of the universality of the rule of non-interference in internal affairs. Unasur and the United Nations are currently negotiating between the various parties. The Union is totally illegitimate to meddle in this matter. I'm voting against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The current situation in Venezuela may be worrying. The state in which the country is located bodes ill for citizens. There is also concern about the disagreement between the government and the elected parliament. The EU has the right to pay attention to political prisoners and the need for a peaceful agreement between all parties to the conflict, which is why I supported the venezuela project.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The rule of law and the principle of separation of powers are not properly respected in Venezuela. About 2,000 people are in prison, under house arrest or on probation for political reasons, including important political leaders. I voted in favour of the S&D group's position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstain from the final vote on this Joint Resolution, as I consider the situation in Venezuela to be of enormous complexity, and any measure must be focused on improving the living conditions of the Venezuelan people. I believe that this resolution, formulated and negotiated in these terms, has become an instrument for the electoral benefit of third parties, diverting the focus from what is truly important. I believe that in the current political, social and economic situation of the country, dialogue is indispensable as a key route for a peaceful solution in respect of the democratic and constitutional order of the country. Therefore, since not all the proposals submitted from alternative groups have been made, we consider that the spirit of the text is far from intended to encourage and contribute to dialogue between the parties. Consequently, I abstained.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Venezuela is going through a serious economic crisis and political tension is increasing. In May, the opposition controlling the legislature handed over 1.85 million signatures to the Electoral Council calling for a revocation referendum by the president, Nicolás Maduro. This resolution only reflects the current situation in Venezuela, a country with the largest crude reserves in the world, but nevertheless has inflation soaring and suffering from commodity shortages and power outages. The Venezuelan people do not deserve this situation. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. \u2012 The Green Party is very concerned about the plight of Venezuelan citizens at present, both in terms of basic daily needs and the political situation. We are also concerned about the lack of respect for the rules of democracy and for people's fundamental rights and freedoms. It is now important that the Constitution is respected by all parties and that they engage in dialogue in order to reach a democratic and peaceful solution. That is also what our green motion for a resolution was about. The Green resolution is free from ideological overtones and puts more focus on democratic deficits, peaceful dialogue and the rule of law than the resolution voted through in this House. MPs chose to stand by our Green proposal instead of signing or voting for the joint. We also abstained from the vote because: 1. The resolution was created mainly to be used as a bat in the Spanish election campaign, in which we do not intend to participate.  2. Parliament recently adopted a similar resolution on Venezuela which, like our resolution, strongly addressed these problems. This was also added weeks before the last Spanish elections in December 2015.  3. The Greens were not welcome in the negotiation process in order to reach a joint resolution.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this joint-motion resolution because it welcomes the mediation efforts initiated at the invitation of UNASUR to launch a national dialogue process between the executive and the opposition represented by the majority components of the MUD. The motion also calls on President Nicolas Maduro and his government to implement urgent economic reforms in cooperation with the National Assembly in order to find a constructive solution to the economic and energy crises, in particular the shortage of food and medicines.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is a scandal that, at a time when the Venezuelan opposition is involved in a process of dialogue with the Government, promoted by UNASUR, and in which the Permanent Council of the Organization of American States, with the support of the right of several countries, approved a declaration in which it supports that initiative and values the effort of dialogue between the parties, in the framework of respect for the sovereignty of Venezuela , this abject resolution is put to the vote. We are voting against a resolution that is absolutely contrary to the dialogue effort that these and other regional structures (ALBA, AEC) are promoting and valuing and which Federica Moguerini has endorsed and supported today. A resolution that embarrasses and compromises the institutional relations between the European institutions and those regional structures of Latin America, as well as with the Republic of Venezuela.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report rightly denounces the human rights violations in Venezuela and the completely unstable economic situation caused by socialist mismanagement. Another important point is the gait of the opposition and the erosion of the rule of law. It calls for a solution to the crisis through dialogue with all levels of government, democratic opposition and society. I can only agree with this very accurate analysis.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this joint-motion resolution because it welcomes the mediation efforts initiated at the invitation of UNASUR to launch a national dialogue process between the executive and the opposition, and maintaining the rule of law in the country. The motion also calls on President Nicolas Maduro and his government to implement urgent economic reforms in cooperation with the National Assembly in order to find a constructive solution to the economic and energy crises, in particular the shortage of food and medicines. While the situation in Venezuela remains complex, and many on the left remain weary Venezuela’s opposition, the government must take responsibility for the situation of the country after so many years in power.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the joint resolution of the People's Party, Social Democrats, Liberals and Conservative Reformists, because it intervenes openly and openly in the internal political situation of Venezuela, while at the same time hiding that the cause of its people's problems is the capitalist way of production, the domination of monopolies. It is a bottomless audacity for parties in all EU Member States to pretend to be the honoree of popular rights, which in all EU Member States are crushing wages and pensions, demolishing labour and social rights, condemning unemployment, poverty and impoverishment to their peoples, as their relatives in Venezuela have done for decades. This unacceptable resolution paves the way for imperialist intervention by the EU and its allies, the US and NATO, in the country and in the wider region. The Communist Party expresses its solidarity with the working class and the popular strata of Venezuela, which are faced with the consequences of the capitalist crisis. It supports the inalienable right of the Venezuelan people to choose and define the path of development and the social organisation that meets their interests, fighting against their monopolies and power, for radical changes in power and the economy.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Venezuela because it is a balanced call for a constructive dialogue that allows political rights and democratic principles to be respected there, putting an end to an intense conflict that has been suffering, lacking and severe deprivation for the Venezuelan people. The resolution offers active cooperation from the European Union and calls on Venezuelan political leaders to make an effort of mutual respect and respect for the institutions, focusing on incentives and not on possible sanctions that would only contribute to aggravating the unsustainable situation in the country.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Venezuela. We need an immediate response to the deteriorating situation in the area of democracy and human rights and the socio-economic situation in Venezuela, where a climate of political and social instability is increasingly prevalent. I support the call for the Venezuelan Government to go beyond the current critical economic and political situation in the country through a constructive approach by seeking a constitutional, peaceful and democratic solution based on dialogue and respect for human rights.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for more than two and a half years now, the deadline for the Commission to adopt delegated acts for the definition of scientific criteria on endocrine disruptors has expired. This was a clear, precise and unconditional obligation. As early as March 2013, however, an ad hoc scientific committee set up by the Commission itself had made a comprehensive proposal on scientific criteria based on three years of expert work. However, the Commission has never taken this into account because the Commission, in clear violation of European law and the Treaties, felt the need to make an impact assessment, an impact assessment only socio-economic, an absolutely inadequate instrument for deciding on a matter of a scientific nature and affecting health and the environment. We cannot stand this arrogance on the part of the Commission for a long time to come. That is why it fully supported the motion for a resolution adopted today. Parliament is a democratic expression of the will of the citizens of Europe and has a duty to condemn the Commission for failing to fulfil its obligations and we call for it to be established as soon as possible what is an endocrine disruptor or not, and only on the basis of stable scientific criteria. We must protect our citizens, and we, their representatives, in particular must do so.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, by not adopting delegated acts before 13 December 2013 to specify the criteria for substances which are endocrine disruptors, the Commission has breached its legal obligations. I believe that this seriously undermines public health and that the Commission is only trying to buy time for the manufacture of doubts, in what we know, the large companies in the sector are experts – we can set the example of glyphosate – thus allowing nothing, not even our health – public health – to get in the way of the business of these large companies. The Commission knows that with this attitude it is enabling the poisoning of the planet and causing pain, suffering and death. I voted in favour of this report because it condemns the Commission's decision and I hope that the Commissioner will assume his responsibilities and act accordingly, and already.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, 'let's put trade above people, let's not investigate the effect of endocrine disruptors on health'. It is the message that the European Commission is sending us. Some chemicals can have tragic effects on the body's endocrine systems: infertility, cancer, problems in the gestation period, neurological disorders are just some of the consequences they can cause. Does the European Commission expect TTIP to end health protection and no longer have to investigate anything? The action of lobbies in the chemical industry is being decisive in these delays, as has recently been proven in leaked documents. We insist that the European Commission has a moral and legal obligation to conduct rigorous and independent scientific research on endocrine disruptors. However, this mandate is being eternally and premeditatedly delayed.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, what credibility can a Commission that violates its own laws, which refuses to publish the list of endocrine disruptors — substances linked to hormonal disorders, cancers, infertility, neural disorders and diabetes, among other diseases — be used to avoid regular public and occupational health? We do not miss that there are many political pressures in this case and, in particular, of American industry, which wants to remove from European law the precautionary principle and prepare to disembark its insecure products with TTIP. But it is an illegal pulse, because delaying a decision violates a legal norm that is very clear. The identification of these substances, pending since 2014, must have scientific criteria and protect the general interest. The complicity of the right in this House with the Commission and the great capital, obviating that the Court of Justice itself of the European Union has ruled against it, does not surprise me. That is why we have opposed your amendments and supported the text contained in our own motion.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Undoubtedly, we must all carry out scientific evaluations of substances potentially causing endocrine disrupting systems. But given the principled effects of the glands in the body on any human health, even life, this type of assessment is important. I mean, no body is arguing in this hall. However, in the present case, the Commission not only did not have the power to initiate scientific evaluations, but also did not comply with the time limit for the adoption of the relevant scientific criteria laid down in Regulation No 1107/2009, which would then establish whether or not active substances and biocidal products were present. Consequently, there is nothing to talk about here, since there is a judgment of the Court of Justice of 16 December 2015 relating to the current conduct of the Commission. I join my colleagues in calling on the Commission to reassess the current situation.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The European Commission is not complying with its obligations to determine the existence of endocrine-altering properties of active substances and biocides, with a view to prohibiting harmful substances. Endocrine disruptors are largely the cause of neurocomportmental disorders, breast cancer, endometrial cancer, ovarian cancer, prostate cancer, testicle cancer, thyroid cancer, etc. and are found in food, water, packaging, toys, textiles, cosmetics, pesticides, hygiene products, building materials, clinical materials and in numerous other consumer items, etc. I voted in favour of this resolution because I think it is urgent that the Commission assume its responsibilities and take action in this area.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. Endocrine disruptors are chemicals that interfere with the action of hormones, which can cause mental retardation, obesity, diabetes, reproductive problems or cardiovascular disease. They are found in food because of pesticide residues as well as in everyday consumer goods.  However, under pressure from the World Trade Organization and the United States, there is still no legal definition of these substances at European level, as the financial stakes are enormous.  This resolution aims to publish the criteria for defining an endocrine disruptor while the Commission continues to postpone its deadline. I voted against this resolution, which has no binding scope and serves as an alibi for the Europeanist parties supporting the Commission. I would like to point out that we have tabled our own resolution to ensure that Member States themselves can ban products or substances they deem dangerous.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This Joint Motion for Resolution condemns the Commission for its failure to comply with its obligations in the biocides regulation. It calls on the commission to come forward with the criteria which the commission has already stated that it will do this month. By way of background information, Endocrine disrupting chemicals are mostly man-made substances which are found in various products such as pesticides, plastics and other consumer products. They are strongly linked to hormone-related diseases/conditions and cancers such as breast cancer or testicular cancer. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this Joint Motion for Resolution.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. In voting for this resolution, I wished to send a final warning to the European Commission by demanding the adoption of criteria for classifying endocrine disruptors before the summer. We need European legislation against this invisible and permanent threat, which is already affecting the health of human beings. These disorders have increased markedly in recent decades and strongly correlated with endocrine disruptors. The European Commission has not done its job. It did not set out classification criteria for identifying endocrine disruptors in 2013. There is now an urgent need for the EU to strengthen EU regulations: we must drastically reduce public exposure to endocrine disruptors, particularly children and pregnant women. In the same way, we will remain attentive to mergers and acquisitions in the agrochemical sector. On these eminently political issues, beyond the responsibility of the competition authorities, we must reject these monopolies which will eventually put global agriculture in the hands of companies that have become more powerful than states in defining policies that are turned to their own benefit.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this statement by the European Commission, as I believe it is necessary to implement immediately and without further delay decisions to implement clear rules on the prohibition of chemicals that are proven to cause serious diseases due to endocrine disorders. As the Group of the Socialists and Democrats of the European Parliament, we call on the Commission to follow the Judgment of the Court of Justice of 16 December on the observance of strict criteria for limiting endocrine disruptor based on scientific results and not on socio-economic considerations.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Until 13 December 2013, the Commission was obliged to lay down specific criteria to determine endocrine-disrupting properties. Because it did not fulfil this obligation, it was rightly condemned by the General Court of the European Union. Given the indications that these substances are harmful to humans and the environment and also have serious social consequences, a strong appeal to the Commission to comply with its legal obligations is right and important. That is why I fully support the text.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Endocrine disruptors are chemicals that interfere with the action of hormones and are commonly found in food, plastic products, furniture, toys, building materials and cosmetics. The effects are multiple: mental retardation, obesity, diabetes, reproductive problems, cardiovascular disease... The cost of endocrine disruptor-related diseases is estimated at between 150 and 260 billion euros per year in the EU. Huge trade issues justify threats from the WTO and the United States should regulations on endocrine disruptors be curbed by European imports. Despite its obligation under the Biocides Regulation, the Commission is still deferring the publication of criteria for defining what an endocrine disruptor is. Hence the motion of censure tabled in May, supported by our political group. The pro-EU parties, which did not support censorship, wanted to propose a wise resolution calling for the publication of the criteria and recalling the risk of legal action that Parliament can bring before the Court of Justice. This joint resolution has no binding scope and serves only as an alibi for those who did not support the motion of censure. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I abstained. I abstained on the grounds that any other vote accepts EU competence on these matters.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which condemns the Commission for the delay in the publication of the scientific criteria necessary to reduce exposure to endocrine disruptors, which UNEP and WHO consider a global threat.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒  Active substances which are deemed to have endocrine disruptors can pose a significant threat to the welfare of people that are exposed to them. The General Court of the European Union declared on 16 December 2015 that the Commission breached EU law by failing to act to adopt delegated acts to specify scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine disrupting properties. The failure of the Commission to not comply with its obligation and a violation of its institutional obligations must be noted. I voted in favour of this resolution as the Commission must propose scientific criteria for determining endocrine-disrupting properties before the summer. The Commission must comply with its obligations and this resolution and its forwarding to the President of the Council and Commission will help reach that goal.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission is delaying the publication of criteria to determine whether a particular substance is disrupting the human endocrine system. The Commission was committed to this by the end of 2013.  Back in 2013, the European Parliament called on the Commission to take measures to reduce the exposure of substances that disrupt the human endocrine system. These substances are likely to lead to early puberty, cancer and metabolic disorders. In December last year, the European Court of Justice recognised that the European Commission had not set scientific criteria for the identification of endocrine disruptors in a timely manner. They were prepared as early as 2013, but not published because it was decided to carry out an impact assessment, although not required by EU law. The Commission should fulfil its commitment without delay and publish these criteria by the end of June this year.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Under Regulation (EU) No 528/2012, by 13 December 2013 at the latest, the Commission should have adopted delegated acts setting out the scientific criteria for the endocrine disrupting properties of active substances and biocidal products. For this purpose, the Commission set up the Joint Research Centre, whose expert group adopted on 28 March 2013 a report on the identification and characterisation of hormone disrupting substances. According to the decision of the European Court of Justice, Regulation (EU) No 528/2012 does not contain any provision providing for an impact assessment by the Commission of scientific, risk-based criteria, and even if the Commission considered such an impact assessment necessary, this did not exempt it from respecting the deadline laid down in the Regulation. The Court therefore ruled in its judgment that the Commission had a clear, precise and unconditional obligation to adopt delegated acts laying down the abovementioned scientific criteria, at the latest by 13 December 2013 as set out in the Regulation. Since the Commission has not complied with its obligations under the Treaties, despite its orderly action against the Member States as guardians of the Treaties, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution calling on the Commission to remedy its deliberate failure to act immediately.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The World Health Organization has defined endocrine disruptors as a global threat, referring in particular to the upward trend of numerous endocrine system diseases in humans and animals. The danger of these chemicals would require rapid regulatory action setting out scientific criteria for determining the properties of endocrine interference. However, the Commission, which was called upon to perform this function by the end of 2013, did not do what was planned, and so, last December, the Court of Justice of the European Union ruled that it had committed a violation of EU law by refraining from adopting the appropriate delegated acts. The motion for a resolution that I have voted on today condemns the Commission for its non-compliance and calls on the Commission to submit scientific criteria for determining the properties of endocrine interference by the summer, putting an end to this dangerous situation of lack of legislation.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. In this case, the Commission is clearly failing to comply with a judgment of the General Court and the Commission is therefore clearly infringing Article 266 TFEU. I believe that this attitude, since issues related to human health are also at stake, is particularly serious. I hope that the Commission will fulfil its commitment and by summer the scientific criteria for determining the endocrine-altering capacities of disruptors on people will be detailed.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution and debate are intended to put pressure on the Commission to finally propose the criteria for defining what an endocrine disruptor is.  They can be found in food, furniture, toys, etc. The effects of these disruptors are multiple: mental retardation, obesity, diabetes, reproductive problems, cardiovascular disease... In fact, the cost of endocrine disruptor-related diseases is estimated at between EUR 150 and 260 billion per year in the EU! The problem is to demonstrate the indisputable causal link justifying prohibitions. However, the Commission is still deferring the publication of criteria for defining what an endocrine disruptor is (see motion censure in May).  The resolution proposed here has no binding scope and serves only as an alibi for those who did not support the motion of censure; So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Under the Biocidal Products Regulation, the Commission was required to adopt, by 13 December 2013, delegated acts on the definition of scientific criteria for determining endocrine interference properties of active ingredients and biocides. To date, however, it has not adopted such acts, despite even a conviction by the Court of Justice. This is scandalous and I certainly do not intend to support this resolution by my vote, which sounds like little more than a slight pro forma rebuke from this Parliament to the Commission.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Endocrine disruptors are chemicals capable of interfering with hormones in animal species, including humans, thus causing many serious diseases — for example, hormone-dependent cancers, infertility, obesity, diabetes, neurological behavior disorders, etc. . I supported this decision to require the Commission to comply with the Court's judgment and to present as soon as possible strict criteria for endocrine disruptors on the basis of science and not based on socio-economic considerations. Under the Biocidal Products Regulation, the Commission is required to find a way to distinguish endocrine disruptors from other chemicals by establishing scientific criteria for identifying them. The list of these scientific criteria should have been drawn up by the European Commission in 2013. On 16 December 2015, the Court held that the European Commission had failed to fulfil its legal obligation by failing to adopt delegated acts specifying scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine-altering properties. According to the judgment, the scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine alteration properties should be based only on science related to the endocrine system, irrespective of any other consideration, in particular economic considerations.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it speaks out against endocrine disruptors and the situation following the judgment of the General Court of the European Union of 16 December 2015. Under EU law, active substances are not approved according to scientific criteria and have endocrine disrupting properties which may cause adverse effects on humans. The Commission has not yet adopted delegated acts setting out scientific criteria and are currently delayed by more than two and a half years. In its judgment of 16 December 2015 in Case T-521/14, the General Court of the European Union stated that the Commission had infringed EU law by not having adopted delegated acts laying down scientific criteria to define the characteristics of endocrine disrupting. In its resolution, Parliament condemns the Commission not only for not fulfilling its obligation to adopt delegated acts, but also for failing to fulfil its institutional obligations under the Treaties themselves, and recalls the Commission's political commitment to submit a proposal for scientific criteria to define the characteristics of endocrine disrupting by the summer.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is essential for the Commission to carry out the legislative task concerned as soon as possible in order to take effective action against substances that disrupt hormones and to protect human health and the environment. In its judgment concerned, the European Court of Justice clearly stated that the European Commission had not complied with its legislative obligation in relation to the Biocidal Regulation and that it was therefore appropriate for the European Parliament to call for its obligations under EU law to be respected in a decision. The definition of risk-based scientific criteria should be carried out only objectively, on the basis of scientific data, irrespective of any other considerations, and in particular economic considerations. The drafting of the draft joint motion for a resolution is concise and factual and, in view of the above circumstances, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union as the Commission has failed to honour its commitments on an issue of unassay for the public health and well-being of our citizens. With endocrine disruptors we have 2 big problems. One is that they have a very negative effect on our health, affecting the hormonal system of man, and the other that we are surrounded by them in everyday life, in clothes, in food and beverage packaging, in the plastic that we use in everyday life. Various theories are knitting around endocrine disruptors and inaction by the European Commission, some of which are completely unrealistic. However, if the Commission ignores this Judgment of the Court, its credibility will take a strong hit. That is why I call on the European Commission to respect its own rules, the decision of the Court of Justice of the European Union and finally adopt the criteria for dealing with endocrine disruptors. They must be scientifically based, enforceable and, most importantly, serve public health.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
