text: In writing. Endocrine disruptors are chemicals that interfere with the action of hormones and are commonly found in food (e.g. pesticide residues), food contact products, plastic products, furniture, toys, building materials and cosmetics. We are all exposed to it at any age with disastrous public health effects. It is therefore essential that the Commission finally proposes criteria for defining precisely and legally what endocrine disruptors are. To do so, it will have to withstand the threats of the WTO and the United States, which fear a brake on their exports to the Union. This joint resolution, the subject of debate, has no binding scope and serves only as an alibi for those who did not support the motion of censure tabled by the ENF group.  I voted against this resolution.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This Joint Motion for Resolution condemns the Commission for its failure to comply with its obligations in the biocides regulation. It calls on the commission to come forward with the criteria which the commission has already stated that it will do this month. By way of background information, Endocrine disrupting chemicals are mostly man-made substances which are found in various products such as pesticides, plastics and other consumer products. They are strongly linked to hormone-related diseases/conditions and cancers such as breast cancer or testicular cancer. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this Joint Motion for Resolution.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Endocrine disruptors are chemicals that interfere with the action of hormones, which can cause mental retardation, obesity, diabetes, reproductive problems or cardiovascular disease. They are found in food because of pesticide residues, as well as in everyday consumer goods. The cost of these endocrine disruptor-related diseases is estimated at between 150 and 260 billion euros per year in the EU. However, under pressure from the World Trade Organization and the United States, there is still no legal definition of these substances at European level, as the financial stakes are enormous.  This resolution aims to publish the criteria for defining an endocrine disruptor, while the Commission is constantly extending its deadline. I voted against this resolution, which has no binding scope and serves as an alibi for the Europeanist parties supporting the Commission. I would like to point out that we have tabled our own resolution to ensure that Member States themselves can ban products or substances they deem dangerous.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Endocrine disruptors present major hazards to human and animal health. Recent findings confirm that chemicals have particularly serious effects on thyroid and brain functions, metabolism, and homeostasis. Under the legislation in force, the Commission is required to adopt delegated acts setting out the scientific criteria for determining the properties of substances affecting the endocrine system. Unfortunately, the Commission did not issue those delegated acts within the time limit set, although it had a clear, precise and unconditional obligation to carry out its task, in accordance with the judgment of the General Court in December 2015. I have expressed myself in favour of this resolution, because I consider it inadmissible that an institution which acts as guardian of the Treaties, paradoxically, does not fulfil its obligations under the current regulations, and I call on the Commission to adopt immediately scientific criteria based on risks for determining the properties of substances affecting the endocrine system.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Endocrine disruptors are chemicals that are foreign to the body and can have harmful consequences on the endocrine system (the hormonal system). They are mainly present in water and food, but can also be found in the air and in some industrial products. Regulation 528/2012 on biocides stipulates that it is up to the Commission to define the criteria for regulating endocrine disruptors. However, the Commission has not yet presented this list of criteria, which has been expected since 2013. She was convicted by the European Court of Justice for failing to do so. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this resolution to condemn the Commission's delay in publishing the scientific criteria necessary to identify and reduce exposure to chemicals that interfere with hormonal activities, considered a global threat by the World Health Organisation and the UN Environment Programme (UNEP). The Commission's continued delays in the publication of these criteria, which should have been made public by the end of 2013, is a breach of Community law and its institutional obligations under the Treaties. I would point out that, according to the judgment of the Court of Justice of the EU on 16 December 2015, the determination of these scientific criteria by the Commission can only be carried out objectively on the basis of scientific data relating to the endocrine system, regardless of any other consideration, particularly of an economic nature. Endocrine disruptors pose a danger to the health and well-being of citizens. The Commission must start protecting European citizens, not the chemical industry.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This Joint Motion for Resolution condemns the Commission for its failure to comply with its obligations in the biocides regulation. It calls on the commission to come forward with the criteria which the commission has already stated that it will do this month. By way of background information, Endocrine disrupting chemicals are mostly man-made substances which are found in various products such as pesticides, plastics and other consumer products. They are strongly linked to hormone-related diseases/conditions and cancers such as breast cancer or testicular cancer. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this Joint Motion for Resolution.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because action is urgently needed by the Commission to specify scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine-disrupting properties of active substances which were to be adopted over two years ago. Such lack of action is all the more serious given the scientifically proven, negative effects on human health of those substances with such endocrine-disrupting properties.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to send an important political message to the European Commission. The Commission has not yet fulfilled its obligation to adopt specific criteria for determining the properties of interference with the endocrine system of active ingredients and biocidal products. The Court of Justice has also ruled on this non-compliance. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which expresses Parliament's dissatisfaction with the Commission's failures and calls on it to ensure that EU law is a thing of the last.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Endocrine disruptors are found almost everywhere in our daily lives. They can be found in plastic bottles, aluminium packaging, grooming products and fruits and vegetables that have been subjected to pesticide use.   Exposure to specific disruptors found in chemicals and/or mixtures thereof results in the destabilization of the endocrine system and can be held responsible for various cancers, infertility symptoms, nervous disorders, thyroid problems, obesity and diabetes.   The Commission's deafening reluctance to comply with its legal obligations and with the relevant judgment of the European Court of Justice on the immediate establishment of scientific criteria for the recognition of chemicals containing endocrine disruptors is a major scandal and raises reasonable questions about the interests served to the detriment of public health and information to citizens.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the joint resolution and stress the Commission's commitment to propose two measures by the end of June: an implementing regulation including the criteria to be applied to chemicals covered by the Plant Protection Regulation and a delegated act containing the criteria to be applied in accordance with the Biocidal Products Regulation. It is Parliament's primary objective to adopt as soon as possible sound scientific criteria that are appropriate for regulatory purposes.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted today on the changes brought about by the court's decision of 16 December 2015 on endocrine disrupting.  As this issue is directly concerned with the health of European citizens, I believe that any action or process aimed at protecting them is a positive step. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it is necessary for the European institutions to be on the side of the citizens trying to pay the utmost attention to their health. In fact, there are some active ingredients considered to have endocrine interference properties capable of producing harmful effects on man which are not, for obvious reasons, approved. However, more than 2 years after the deadline, the Commission has not yet adopted such acts concerning the definition of scientific criteria. Therefore, since there is no doubt that the Commission has not yet complied with the judgment of the Court of Justice, I agree with this resolution in the hope that it will fulfil its obligations as soon as possible.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is very disappointing to see that the Commission is not complying with its obligation to adopt delegated acts pursuant to Regulation (EU) No 528/2012.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The European Commission is not complying with its obligations to determine the existence of endocrine-altering properties of active substances and biocides, with a view to prohibiting harmful substances. Endocrine disruptors are largely the cause of neurocomportmental disorders, breast cancer, endometrial cancer, ovarian cancer, prostate cancer, testicle cancer, thyroid cancer, etc. and are found in food, water, packaging, toys, textiles, cosmetics, pesticides, hygiene products, building materials, clinical materials and in numerous other consumer items, etc. I voted in favour of this resolution because I think it is urgent that the Commission assume its responsibilities and take action in this area.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Chemicals with endocrine disrupting properties affect the endocrine system of animals and humans and provide a new way of assessing the toxicity of chemicals. There is now a scientific consensus in many areas, although there are different views on specific issues in the scientific and regulatory community around the world. Regulation (EU) No 528/2012 (Biocidal Products Regulation) provides that active substances "which have endocrine disrupting properties which may cause undesirable effects in humans are not authorised unless the exception laid down in the Regulation applies". I fully share the objectives of protecting human health and the environment and ensuring a high level of protection, but I do not support this resolution and question the legitimacy of an arbitrary deadline for defining these criteria. In my opinion, this resolution has some added value, as the Commission has already accepted the judgment and has publicly committed itself to speeding up the adoption of the criteria. In fact, Parliament's Legal Service has acknowledged that further legal action will be pointless, as their subject matter will be unjustified once the criteria are published in June. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the Commission needs to act urgently and fulfil its legal obligations. The Commission had to identify and ban endocrine disrupting substances back in December 2013. More than two and a half years have passed but the Commission failed to act. This was confirmed also by a judgement of the European Court of Justice in December 2015. Even though the Commission politically committed itself to propose scientific criteria to determine which properties are endocrine disruptive, before this summer it has not lived up to its commitment. Our citizens’ health should be a priority for the Commission and hence I share the call made in this Joint Motion for Resolution.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution follows a serious failure by the European Commission, which should have adopted delegated acts on the specification of the scientific criteria for the identification of endocrine disruptors on 13 December 2013. However, no documents have been sent to the European Parliament to date! The European Commission was also condemned by the European Court of Justice, which had been referred by Sweden, with the support of France in particular. I have therefore supported this report to send a strong signal to the European Commission and condemn its inaction in the face of such a public health emergency. I look forward to the next presentation of the criteria for defining and identifying endocrine disruptors, which is due to take place in mid-June. I will be extremely vigilant about the definition of these criteria: economic considerations should not take precedence over scientific expertise! It is imperative that substances identified as endocrine disruptors be immediately banned. Finally, I would like to remind you that special attention must be paid to the "cocktail effects": the toxicity of certain molecules can be increased tenfold when taken simultaneously. We must therefore remain vigilant!

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is essential for the Commission to carry out the legislative task concerned as soon as possible in order to take effective action against substances that disrupt hormones and to protect human health and the environment. In its judgment concerned, the European Court of Justice clearly stated that the European Commission had not complied with its legislative obligation in relation to the Biocidal Regulation and that it was therefore appropriate for the European Parliament to call for its obligations under EU law to be respected in a decision. The definition of risk-based scientific criteria should be carried out only objectively, on the basis of scientific data on the endocrine system, irrespective of any other considerations, and in particular economic considerations. The drafting of the draft joint motion for a resolution is concise and factual and in view of the above circumstances, so I supported it with my vote in line with the Group of the European People's Party.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA supported the resolution on endocrine disruptors. In so doing, the European Parliament is sending an unscapable signal to the European Commission: it is five past 12, the scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors must be put in place. The December 2013 deadline is 2.5 years behind us. The European Court of Justice defaulted to the Commission in December 2015. The N-VA shares concerns about endocrine disruptors and the potential risk to public health. Many studies link the increase in cancer cases, diabetes, obesity and infertility to exposure to endocrine disruptors, among others. Commissioner Andriukaitis has promised to come forward with proposals on 15 June. The Commission must keep its word. She owes it to her citizens. After all, it is about public health. But it is also about credibility and trust. The uncertainty has lasted long enough, both for consumers and producers.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which urges the Commission to break its silence and address a serious public health issue. Decline in male fertility, early puberty, birth defects, breast cancer, etc. These disorders have increased markedly in recent decades and strongly correlated with endocrine disruptors. That is why we need to drastically reduce public exposure to endocrine disruptors, especially children and pregnant women. The Commission must be very good on this issue. There is an urgent need to legislate and implement the precautionary principle.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Effective action against hormone disruptive substances and the protection of human health and the environment are essential for the Commission to carry out the legislative task concerned as soon as possible. In its judgment concerned, the European Court of Justice clearly stated that the European Commission had not complied with its legislative obligation in relation to the Biocidal Regulation and that it was therefore appropriate for the European Parliament to call for its obligations under EU law to be respected in a decision. The definition of risk-based scientific criteria should be carried out only objectively, on the basis of scientific data on the endocrine system, irrespective of any other considerations, and in particular economic considerations. The drafting of the draft joint motion for a resolution is concise and factual and in view of the above circumstances, so I supported it with my vote in line with the Group of the European People's Party.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution, which is only an alibi for those who did not have the courage to support the motion of censure which pointed to the Commission's delay in publishing the criteria for defining endocrine disruptors. These are chemicals that interfere with the action of hormones and are commonly found in food (e.g. pesticide residues), food contact products, plastic products, furniture, toys, building materials and cosmetics. The effects are multiple: mental retardation, obesity, diabetes, reproductive problems and cardiovascular disease. The annual cost of these diseases in Europe is estimated at several hundred billion euros.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to stick to the position of my political group and voted against the resolution on endocrine disruptors. The EQF fully advocates the protection of human health and the environment, as well as ensuring a high level of protection for both. However, the EQF does not support this resolution, as the Commission has already adopted the General Court's decision that the Commission has breached its obligations by not adopting a delegated act before the deadline set and has publicly committed itself to speeding up the adoption of the criteria for determining endocrine disruptors expected to be published in June. Although the Commission has not complied with the deadline for adopting these criteria, according to the EU Legal Service, there will be no justification for further legal action against the Commission after their publication in June. For this reason, I believe that the resolution is invalidate.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the motion for a resolution, as it calls on the Commission to comply with its obligations under Article 266 OF THE EU and to adopt scientific criteria for determining endocrine disruptor properties, which will be scientifically sound and appropriate for regulatory purposes and will be based on a detailed risk assessment to be carried out on the basis of the most advanced science, as requested by Parliament in its report on the protection of public health.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is essential for the Commission to carry out the legislative task concerned as soon as possible in order to take effective action against substances that disrupt hormones and to protect human health and the environment. In its judgment concerned, the European Court of Justice clearly stated that the European Commission had not complied with its legislative obligation in relation to the Biocidal Regulation and that it was therefore appropriate for the European Parliament to call for its obligations under EU law to be respected in a decision. The definition of risk-based scientific criteria should be carried out only objectively, on the basis of scientific data on the endocrine system, irrespective of any other considerations, and in particular economic considerations. The drafting of the draft joint motion for a resolution is concise and factual and in view of the above circumstances, so I supported it with my vote in line with the Group of the European People's Party.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. The Commission’s failure to adequately address the problem of substances that interfere with the endocrine system is potentially very harmful to my constituents. The people of Wales always put public health and well-being before the profits of big business.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) and the World Health Organization (WHO) have identified endocrine disruptors as a global threat. However, the Commission has not complied with its legal obligation to publish scientific criteria on endocrine disruptors, chemicals that will give rise to various diseases, such as cancers, or even increased infertility. Having said that, I agree that the Commission must fulfil without delay the obligations resulting from the Treaty and immediately adopt risk-based scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine disrupting properties.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it, because this resolution is only an alibi for those who did not have the courage to support the motion of censure.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Endocrine disruptors can cause various types of diseases, such as neurobehavioral disorders, various types of cancer, can have negative consequences for pregnancy, genital malformations, obesity or type 2 diabetes. Under Regulation (EU) No 528/2012, the European Commission should have adopted delegated acts on scientific criteria for the determination of the endocrine disrupting properties of active substances and biocidal products by December 2013 with a view to banning harmful substances. In March 2013, the Advisory Group of Experts on Endocrine Disruptors, set up by the Commission and coordinated by the Joint Research Centre (JRC), adopted a report on the main scientific issues relevant to the identification and characterisation of endocrine disrupting substances. It turns out that the Commission has not adopted the delegated acts referred to above.  From then on, the Commission has been urged to act on a number of occasions and forms. But even after the Judgment of the Court of Justice of December 2015, it did nothing. This resolution therefore seems relevant to us. It is worth recalling the complaints of pressure from US officials responsible for trade in the context of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), which will justify the Commission's attitude. All clear as water, so.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ in order to preserve health and environmental protection, the EC was obliged to adopt delegated acts on the definition of scientific criteria for determining the properties of active substances and biocidal products causing endocrine disruption in order to prohibit hazardous substances. However, the EC did not adopt such delegated acts by the deadline and therefore the SD EU decided that the EC had an unconditional obligation to adopt such acts, without accepting the request. The EU SD rejected the EC's legal argument and said that the adoption of the act did not require an impact assessment of the scientific criteria. However, the EC continues to fail to fulfil its obligations and has not adopted delegated acts as required by the Regulation, with endocrine disruptors largely responsible for severe diseases, be it neurobehavioural disorders, adverse pregnancy outcomes or various cancers.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution, as it calls on the Commission to comply with its obligations under Article 266 OF THE EU and to adopt scientific criteria for determining endocrine disruptor properties, which will be scientifically sound and appropriate for regulatory purposes and will be based on a detailed risk assessment to be carried out on the basis of the most advanced science, as requested by Parliament in its report on the protection of public health.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ So-called endocrine disruptors are chemicals capable of interfering with the hormones of animal species, including humans, and are believed to be the cause of many serious diseases (for instance hormone-dependent cancers, infertility, obesity, diabetes, neurobehavioral disorders, etc.). They are found in a multitude of consumer items, cosmetics, pesticides and plastics (such as bisphenol A - BPA). The Biocides Regulation and the Plant Protection Products Regulation provide for special treatment of pesticides and biocidal products. Under those Regulations substances recognised as endocrine disruptors would not be allowed on the EU market. As a result of this provision the Commission was obliged to find a way to distinguish endocrine disruptors from other chemicals by laying down scientific criteria to identify them. I strongly condemn continuous and incomprehensible delays in defining clear rules on chemicals which are believed to cause many serious diseases. I support the call on the Commission to comply with the General Court ruling by submitting strict criteria for endocrine disruptors based on science and not on socio-economic considerations.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is essential for the Commission to carry out the legislative task concerned as soon as possible in order to take effective action against substances that disrupt hormones and to protect human health and the environment. In its judgment concerned, the European Court of Justice clearly stated that the European Commission had not complied with its legislative obligation in relation to the Biocidal Regulation and that it was therefore appropriate for the European Parliament to call for its obligations under EU law to be respected in a decision. The definition of risk-based scientific criteria should be carried out only objectively, on the basis of scientific data on the endocrine system, irrespective of any other considerations, and in particular economic considerations. The drafting of the draft joint motion for a resolution is concise and factual and in view of the above circumstances, so I supported it with my vote in line with the Group of the European People's Party.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution with the conviction that endocrine disruptors can be a health hazard according to PNUM and WHO reports. They may have an impact on the endocrine system in humans and also in animals, as there have been signs of effects such as infertility, cancers, malformations... due to exposure to endocrine disruptors, there is also growing evidence of the effects of these chemicals on thyroid and brain function, obesity and metabolism, and on insulin and glucose homeostasis.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the joint resolution on endocrine disrupting chemicals: the current state of play following the court ruling of 16 December 2015, as I support the alternative text jointly tabled by the ECR and the EPP. It calls, inter alia, on the Commission to fulfil its obligation under Article 266 by establishing robust scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine-disrupting properties, which are appropriate for legislative purposes.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Last week, the Greens and S&D Euro MPs tried to prepare a possible legal case against the EU Commission. These were missed deadlines, for which the Commission has already been criticised by the European Court of Justice. Next week, however, the Commission will finally fulfil its obligations. To aim for another expensive procedure just a few metres from the finish line seems to me to be unnecessary and excessive. Fortunately, we were able to reach a last-minute agreement with the other groups on an appropriate compromise. There will be no further procedure.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. Endocrine disruptors, found in everyday products, interfere with hormones. They cause multiple diseases, ranging from obesity to infertility. However, although experts agree on the negative effects of these substances, no European-wide definition has been established to accurately regulate endocrine disruptors and their circulation.  In this context, our group co-signed a motion of censure against the European Commission in May, in order to stop the postponement of the publication of the criteria defining the characteristics of an endocrine disruptor. In the face of the Commission's inaction, I have therefore proposed, on behalf of the ENF Group, a resolution in line with our objectives, so that Member States can ban the products they deem dangerous themselves. The Europeanist parties, out of partisan spirit, refused to sanction the Commission and defend the health of its citizens. The motion for a resolution put to a vote, put forward by the latter, serves only to mark the hypocrisy of the latter. Since the proposal of our opponents is only a vulgar alibi, I have decided to vote against this measure.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. The Commission has long postponed the publication of criteria for defining endocrine disruptors in violation of its obligations. A few days ago, I joined a motion of censure which proposed to put the Commission before its responsibilities, condemning its ineffectiveness in the face of this considerable public health issue. Some signatories to this motion, however, saw fit to withdraw their signatures in order to prevent its discussion. I dare to consider that their motivations were the smug support they have for Europe in Brussels, their blindness to its inefficiencies and irresponsibility, their desire not to hurt Mr Juncker... The other possibility would be much worse. Endocrine disruptors, which are chemicals, are everywhere: in food, food packaging, plastics, toys, cosmetics... A European regulation to ban products containing such substances would have undoubtedly considerable commercial consequences. The WTO and the United States, which the prospect of such a deregulated trade barrier, have made no mistake. In short, the political groups have always agreed on a somewhat soft procedure and a half-goat- half-chou text. So I voted against it.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution, since Regulation (EU) No 528/2012 does not approve of active substances which, on the basis of criteria to be established or provisional criteria, have endocrine-altering properties that may cause adverse effects on individuals. It is also available that the Commission should adopt, by 13 December 2013, delegated acts specifying scientific criteria for determining the existence of endocrine-altering properties in active and biocidal substances. The Commission has not yet adopted such delegated acts. The WHO report called endocrine disruptors a global threat, referring, inter among other things, to the high incidence and upward trend of many endocrine system disorders in humans and noting that effects on endocrine function have also been observed in wild animal populations; there have been evidence of adverse reproductive effects — infertility, cancers, malformations — of exposure to endocrine disruptors, and there is also increasing evidence of the effects of these chemicals on thyroid and brain function, obesity and metabolism, and on insulin and glucose homeostasis.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, aimed at increasing the pressure on the Commission to finally publish the scientific criteria for the identification of endocrine disruptors. These chemicals in every everyday object disrupt the hormonal system and pose a real danger to public health. Yet the Commission has long dragged its feet, yielding to the pesticide and chemical lobby. Faced with pressure from Parliament and the European Court of Justice, it has finally committed to publishing its definition of endocrine disruptors by mid-June, so that the most dangerous substances can be banned. I will ensure that this definition is based on real scientific expertise and that, beyond substance-by-substance analysis, it also takes into account the "cocktail effect" (the consequences of repeated exposure to several endocrine disruptors of different types).

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. Decrease in male fertility, early puberty, obesity, diabetes, birth defects, breast cancer: most of these diseases are due to endocrine disruptors that are present all around us, in pesticides, cosmetics, packaging, children's toys and even in some medical devices. Today, there is still no European legislation specific to endocrine disruptors, despite the insistent demands of the European Parliament and certain Member States such as France. Expected in December 2013, this legislation has turned into an assessment by the European Commission of the economic impact of the ban on endocrine disruptors on European businesses, giving the impression of putting the economic interests of the chemical industry ahead of the general interest of European citizens. It is to recall this priority that I voted for this resolution, which proposes in particular that the European Parliament reserves the right to lodge an appeal before the European Court of Justice against the European Commission if it does not define its position in the next two months.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The General Court ruled that the specification of scientific criteria can only be carried out in an objective manner on the basis of scientific data related to the endocrine system, independently of any other consideration, in particular economic ones, and that the Commission is not entitled to change the regulatory balance laid down in a basic act via the application of powers delegated to it pursuant to Article 290 TFEU.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Effective action against hormone disruptive substances and the protection of human health and the environment are essential for the Commission to complete the legislative task concerned as soon as possible. In its judgment concerned, the European Court of Justice clearly stated that the European Commission had not complied with its legislative obligation in relation to the Biocidal Regulation and that it was therefore appropriate for the European Parliament to call for its obligations under EU law to be respected in a decision. The definition of risk-based scientific criteria should be carried out only objectively, on the basis of scientific data on the endocrine system, irrespective of any other considerations, and in particular economic considerations. The drafting of the draft joint motion for a resolution is concise and factual and has the view of the above circumstances.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the resolution, since our political position was clear from the beginning.  From the outset we insisted that chemicals or a cocktail of chemicals that have the potential to interfere with the endocrine system and are responsible for adverse pregnancy outcomes, neuro-behavioural disorders, a high rate of infertility in men, genital dysplasia, breast cancer, thyroid problems, obesity, and type 2 diabetes, should be determined as soon as possible on the basis of science and unconditionally by any socio-economic effects.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support the resolution on endocrine disruptors. According to Regulation (EU) No 528/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning the making available on the market and use of biocidal products, the Commission, no later than 13 December 2013, shall adopt delegated acts specifying scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine-disrupting properties of active substances and biocidal products. In a report published by the UNEP/WHO, endocrine disrupters (EDCs) are considered as a global threat. I along with my colleagues condemned the Commission for its failure to comply with its obligation to adopt delegated acts, which are now more than two and a half years overdue. By doing this, the Commission has also failed to comply with its institutional obligations as laid down in the Treaties themselves, notably in Article 266 TFEU. Likewise, the ECJ declared that the Commission breached EU law by failing to act to adopt delegated acts to specify scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine-disrupting properties. This is worrying considering that the proposed scientific criteria were ready in 2013, but remained unpublished as the Commission decided to launch an impact assessment instead. I was happy that the Resolution called on the Commission to comply immediately with its obligations.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The so-called "endocrine disruptors" are substances that have a negative effect on a person's own internal signalling system. The Commission has previously undertaken to propose scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine-disrupting properties before this summer. However, this will be delayed because the Commission is trying to design the criteria according to the standards of science. The delay has led to cases brought by Sweden against the Commission, which are supported by ALFA. The Commission should generally comply with Parliament's decisions. However, it remains unclear what a parliamentary resolution should contribute to the earlier complaint. I did not want to take part in this political game and voted against the resolution. Moreover, it is true that even scientists remain deeply divided on the fundamental question of the actual harmfulness of the substances. The hormonal systems of non-adults are very different from each other and have not been sufficiently researched to date. What applies to an adult, for example, is far from being the case for a child in the hormone sector. Analyses regarding the multiple possibilities of action of an "inner disrupter" on a hormone are hardly available. It is therefore necessary that the Commission does not rush to define it, as this could lead to errors with major negative consequences.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is essential for the Commission to carry out the legislative task concerned as soon as possible in order to take effective action against substances that disrupt hormones and to protect human health and the environment. In its judgment concerned, the European Court of Justice clearly stated that the European Commission had not complied with its legislative obligation in relation to the Biocidal Regulation and that it was therefore appropriate for the European Parliament to call for its obligations under EU law to be respected in a decision. The definition of risk-based scientific criteria should be carried out only objectively, on the basis of scientific data on the endocrine system, irrespective of any other considerations, and in particular economic considerations. The drafting of the draft joint motion for a resolution is concise and factual and in view of the above circumstances, so I supported it with my vote in line with the Group of the European People's Party.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which ensures a high level of protection of human, animal and environmental health by imposing rigorous control and banning substances whose properties affect the endocrine system. The Commission must fulfil its obligations and determine, on the basis of scientific criteria, the properties affecting the endocrine system.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the resolution that has been adopted and i consider the great agreement in Parliament to be very positive. The scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors should be published as soon as possible in order to better investigate and assess the risk to human and animal health and to reduce the risk.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a joint proposal for a European Parliament resolution on endocrine disruptors: the situation following the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union of 16 December 2015 on the ground that I support the judgment addressed to the Commission for not adopting the necessary delegated acts and for non-compliance with the obligations laid down in the treaties. In this context, I support the European Commission's political commitment to propose risk-based scientific criteria for determining the properties of endocrine disruption by the summer.  Endocrine disruptors, even in low concentration, seriously affect the hormonal system and are the reason for certain health problems such as reproductive disorders and decreased fertility. I therefore believe that when it comes to endocrine disruptors, we should be particularly careful and have precise scientific data, and therefore I support this proposal for a resolution.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Despite its obligation under the Biocides Regulation, the Commission is still deferring the publication of criteria for defining what an endocrine disruptor is. Hence the motion of censure tabled in May. The pro-EU parties, which did not support censorship, wanted to propose a wise resolution calling for the publication of the criteria and recalling the risk of legal action that Parliament can bring before the Court of Justice. Of course, this joint resolution has no binding scope and serves only as an alibi for those who did not support the motion of censure. The ENF Group has therefore tabled its own resolution which underlines the Commission's inefficiency and calls for Member States to be able to ban products they deem dangerous themselves. I voted against this resolution because it is only an alibi for those who did not have the courage to support the motion of censure.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to keep up the pressure on the European Commission, which is due to publish in mid-June the criteria for the definition and identification of endocrine disruptors, which we have been waiting for since the end of 2013. The Commission was recently condemned by the European Court of Justice, which was seized by Sweden, for breaching its obligations in this matter. It is urgent that it act, and this text sends a strong message to it in this regard.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – This resolution condemns the Commission and shows that basic acts and the eCJ's ruling have not been complied with, both of which clearly provided for the establishment of scientific risk criteria for endocrine disruptors. So far, only social and economic parameters are considered, as in the impact assessment now to be carried out, without prior scientific criteria for disruptors being established. That is why I am voting in favour of this resolution, because risk assessments need a scientific basis and must not be produced for economic reasons.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We strongly condemn continuous and incomprehensible delays in defining clear rules on chemicals which are believed to cause many serious diseases. We call on the Commission to comply with the General Court ruling by submitting strict criteria for endocrine disruptors based on science and not on socio-economic considerations.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The so-called "endocrine disruptors" are substances that have a negative effect on a person's own internal signalling system. The Commission has previously undertaken to propose scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine-disrupting properties before this summer. However, this will be delayed because the Commission is trying to design the criteria according to the standards of science. The delay has led to cases brought by Sweden against the Commission, which are supported by ALFA. The Commission should generally comply with Parliament's decisions. However, it remains unclear what a parliamentary resolution should contribute to the earlier complaint. That is why I voted against the resolution.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 8 June 2016, we voted in plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on a motion for a resolution on endocrine disruptors: the state of play following the judgment of the Court of Justice (TDU) of 16 December 2015. At the last additional plenary session of the European Parliament in Brussels, I criticised the Commission's outrageous disregard for the COMMISSION's decision on the Commission against Sweden. The European Parliament, together with the Council, has without any doubt committed the Commission, in Directive 528/2012, to adopt criteria for evaluating what endocrine disruptors are by 13 December 2013. The Commission has not yet done so, and it has not done so even after the TDU has unequivocally told it that it should have done so. Due to the non-existent criteria for the evaluation of endocrine disruptors, the prohibition provided for in Directive No 528/2012 cannot be active and therefore continue to significantly harm the health of European citizens. I am therefore very happy to be able to support a joint resolution criticising the Commission's progress throughout the case and, at the same time, calling on it once again to take action.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is essential for the Commission to carry out the legislative task concerned as soon as possible in order to take effective action against substances that disrupt hormones and to protect human health and the environment. In its judgment concerned, the European Court of Justice clearly stated that the European Commission had not complied with its legislative obligation in relation to the Biocidal Regulation and that it was therefore appropriate for the European Parliament to call for its obligations under EU law to be respected in a decision. The definition of risk-based scientific criteria should be carried out only objectively, on the basis of scientific data on the endocrine system, irrespective of any other considerations, and in particular economic considerations. The drafting of the draft joint motion for a resolution is concise and factual and in view of the above circumstances, so I supported it with my vote in line with the Group of the European People's Party.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the resolution on endocrine disruptors. I believe that it is essential and necessary for the European Commission to publish scientific criteria necessary to identify and reduce exposure to substances leading to hormonal disorders, as they lead to serious adverse results. Even in the REPORT of the United Nations Environment Programme/WHO, endocrine disruptors are classed as a global threat. It is also quite disturbing that endocrine-related disorders are increasingly and increasingly prevalent among people. There is new evidence that hormonally disturbing substances can have a serious negative impact on reproductive health (cancers, infertility), as well as on thyroid functions, brain functions, obesity and metabolism, as well as insulin and glucose homeostasis. I welcome the European Commission's decision to publish the criteria by the end of June 2016.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it claims to protest against the Commission's refusal to implement the court order to define endocrine disruptors. But in reality, it serves only as an alibi for political groups that did not want to support the motion of censure proposed by the ENL. Only the ENL group remained consistent by not participating in this charade.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution to increase pressure on the European Commission to publish the scientific criteria for identifying endocrine disruptors. Indeed, these chemicals present in all everyday objects disrupt the hormonal system and represent a real danger to public health. Faced with pressure from Parliament and the European Court of Justice, the Commission has finally committed to publishing its definition of endocrine disruptors by mid-June, so that the most dangerous substances can be banned. Our concern to defend the health of our citizens and our vigilance will be at its maximum!

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on endocrine disruptors. Endocrine disruptors are chemicals that interfere with the action of hormones and are commonly found in food (e.g. pesticide residues), food contact products, plastic products, furniture, toys, building materials and cosmetics. We are all exposed to it at any age. The potential effects are multiple: mental retardation, obesity, diabetes, reproductive problems, cardiovascular disease... There is no legal definition at European level to clearly regulate these products and their circulation. The difficulty is indeed to demonstrate the indisputable causal link justifying prohibitions. Despite its obligation under the Biocides Regulation, the Commission is still deferring the publication of criteria for defining what an endocrine disruptor is. Hence the motion of censure tabled in May. The parties that did not support this motion, for their part, wished to propose a resolution calling for the publication of the criteria and recalling the risk of legal action that Parliament may bring before the Court of Justice. Of course, this joint resolution has no binding scope and serves only as an alibi.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. Endocrine disruptors are chemicals that disrupt the action of hormones and are components of many products such as plastic furniture, toys, cosmetics, food container products... Every individual is in contact with endocrine disruptors, including in utero. They are at the origin of many diseases such as obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular disease... Each year, the treatment of these diseases costs between 150 and 260 billion euros in the European Union. Public health issues are therefore important. However, the Commission is reluctant to clearly define the term endocrine disruptor, which would allow legislation to be put in place to prohibit them. This is partly due to pressure on the EU from the WTO (World Trade Organization) and the United States, which import products with endocrine disruptors on a massive scale each year. The text put to the vote is only a slight reminder to the Commission, which is not binding. So I voted AGAINST.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The so-called "endocrine disruptors" are substances that have a negative effect on a person's own internal signalling system. The Commission has previously undertaken to propose scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine-disrupting properties before this summer. However, this will be delayed because the Commission is trying to design the criteria according to the standards of science. The delay has led to cases brought by Sweden against the Commission, which are supported by ALFA. The Commission should generally comply with Parliament's decisions. However, it remains unclear what a parliamentary resolution should contribute to the earlier complaint. I did not want to take part in this political game and voted against the resolution.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution condemns the Commission for not setting scientific criteria for determining the assessment of endocrine disrupting substances. Chemical preparations which have a potential negative impact on human health must be properly assessed and the authorisation to place them on the market must be based on a benefit and risk assessment.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒in 2012, the Court of Justice of the European Union ruled in its judgment of 16 December 2015 in T-521/14 that the Commission had a clear, precise and unconditional obligation to adopt delegated acts by 13 December 2013 in order to establish scientific criteria on the health impact of endocrine disruptors. The Commission did not comply with its obligations under Regulation (EU) No 100/2013. 528/2012 and disregarded the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union of 16 December 2015 in case T-521/14. In this way, it failed to protect public health, animal health and the environment. Until harmonised criteria are established, Member States can adopt national criteria and independently ban harmful substances, and at the moment the protection of human and animal health and the environment could only be achieved through political measures by the European Parliament and the Member States, as required by Regulation (EU) No 100/2013. 528/2012 Member States may adopt their own criteria independently and take the necessary measures to protect human, animal and environmental health, as the Commission refuses to fulfil its task. This resolution calls on the Commission not to interfere with measures to protect public health, animal health and the environment taken at national levels and not to launch investigations or procedures to identify infringements. I therefore supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Regulation (EU) No 528/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the making available on the market and use of biocidal products in Article 5 laid down an obligation on the Commission to adopt delegated acts by 13 December 2013 at the latest defining scientific criteria for determining the properties of active substances and biocidal products disrupting the endocrine system. Although the Commission has been dealing with endocrine disruptors since 1996, it has not fulfilled its obligation and so far no such acts have been adopted. In doing so, scientists and scientific institutions point out that endocrine disruptors can disrupt the endocrine system of the human body and cause adverse developmental, reproductive, nervous and immune effects on humans, animals and nature. This breach of the Commission's obligations was also found by the Court of Justice in its judgment of 16 December 2015, which stated that the provisional criteria laid down in Regulation (EU) No 528/2012 cannot be understood as ensuring sufficiently large protection. The Commission has failed to fulfil this obligation and has breached the institutional obligations arising from the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. I therefore supported the EP's call on the Commission to fulfil its obligations without delay.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Joint Motion for a Resolution on endocrine disruptors: how the situation develops after the judgment of the General Court of the European Union of 16 December 2015, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution. This resolution is an alibi for the pro-EU parties, which did not have the courage to support the motion of censure against the European Commission. In this case, the European Commission is slow to publish the criteria for defining endocrine disruptors, which it is legally obliged to do. These definition criteria would allow clear regulation of these chemicals, which are commonplace in everyday products and whose harmful consequences on human health have now been proven (cardiovascular diseases, fertility, etc.). This timid reaction by the European Parliament is explained by the trade issues arising from possible binding regulations on endocrine disruptors: the WTO and the United States have already warned the European Union of the trade implications of such legislation. The Europe of Nations and Freedoms group has tabled its own resolution, demanding that Member States be able to legislate sovereignly on endocrine disruptors. In any event, we cannot support this resolution, which is a further abdication of the European Parliament.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 MEPs have shown our unease at the Commission's delay in publishing the scientific criteria needed to identify and address exposure to chemicals that cause hormonal alterations.  For this reason, my vote in favour of the resolution in which MEPs call for information to be published in view of the approach of possible restrictions on the use of these chemicals, associated with deteriorating sperm quality, early onset of puberty, some cancers and other disorders.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. Despite the pressing demands that my colleagues and I have been making for years, the European Commission has still not developed European legislation on endocrine disruptors, these molecules found in certain pesticides, cosmetics or children's toys, whose health effects (breast cancer, decrease in male fertility, diabetes, etc.) are increasingly evident. While it had announced a legislative proposal for December 2013, the Commission had finally only proceeded to... an assessment of the economic impact of the ban on endocrine disruptors on European businesses! After an action brought by Sweden, the European Court of Justice even condemned the European Commission for its inaction.  It was in this context that MEPs decided to table a resolution, voted by an overwhelming majority. It calls on the Commission to no longer push back the deadline and to urgently adopt criteria for the definition of endocrine disruptors, with the ultimate aim of reducing citizens' exposure to these substances. In the face of welcome political pressure from Parliament, the European Commission has committed itself to action before mid-June, but our constant vigilance will continue to be imposed.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This motion for a resolution deals with endocrine disruptors. These are hormone-active substances that can damage the hormonal system. The report condemns the Commission's failures. I therefore support this motion for a resolution.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. WHO defines endocrine disruptors as "an exogenous substance or mixture that alters the functions of the endocrine system and therefore induces adverse effects on the health of an intact organism, its descendants or (sub)populations"." These disruptors are considered by WHO to be a global threat due, among other things, to a high and growing number of endocrine disorders.  However, the Commission has still not adopted delegated acts aimed at defining scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors and thus allowing them to be banned.  While these should be defined for more than two and a half years! The resolution condemns the Commission's shortcomings and acknowledges its commitment to provide scientific criteria for definition before the summer. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Today, there is no legal definition of endocrine disruptors that would regulate these products and their circulation. Trade issues are enormous and pressure from the United States and the WTO is pushing the Commission to constantly delay the publication of definition criteria. In May, for example, a motion of no confidence was tabled. The European parties, for their part, opted for a resolution, having no binding scope and serving only as an alibi for those who did not support the motion of censure. As a result, I voted against this resolution.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission was obliged to adopt, by 13 December 2013, delegated acts specifying the scientific criteria for determining the endocrine disrupting properties of active substances and biocidal products. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution calling on the European Commission to publish these criteria as soon as possible in compliance with the obligations resulting from Article 266 of the Treaty.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion, as it is critical that the Commission complies with the court on establishing the scientific criteria for studying endocrine disruptors, as the matter is one of the public health and well-being of the citizens of the EU. There can be no compromise when it comes to the protection of health of our citizens.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – An increasing number of hormone-related diseases have been diagnosed in humans over the past 20 years. There is an increasing number of conditions related to reduced fertility, dysfunctions of the genitalorgans or premature puberty. These abnormalities and diseases are associated with chemical substances contained in all kinds of products for daily use or which have entered the environment as residual products of human activity. These substances are believed to have endocrine disrupting properties and thus have a possible effect on the endocrine system, metabolism and normal functioning of the human body. The environment, public health and the economic sectors concerned all benefit from avoiding the use of such substances. With this resolution, the European Parliament is keenly lashing out at the European Commission for continuing to delay the promised publication of scientific criteria on the basis of which exposure to endocrine disruptors is recorded. This data should have been available by the end of 2013. At the end of 2015, the European Court of Justice ruled that the Commission had violated the law by failing to publish the criteria. It is now up to the Commission to publish the scientific criteria as soon as possible.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing – the European Commission has infringed Union law by failing to act and adopt delegated acts specifying scientific criteria for determining endocrine disrupting properties. The World Health Organization has identified endocrine disruptors as a global threat, citing, among other things, the growing trend of many endocrine disorders in humans and wildlife populations. There is also increasing evidence of adverse effects of exposure to endocrine disruptors such as infertility, cancer, various deformities and effects of these chemicals on thyroid and brain function, obesity and metabolism, and on insulin and glucose homeostasis. These substances are able to pass through the placenta to the foetus, where their presence has been clearly demonstrated by current studies. I fully share the view that the Commission must adopt risk-based scientific criteria without delay to determine endocrine disrupting properties, and I therefore agree with the proposal that has been tabled.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted all in favour of the report, which calls on the Commission to comply with the General Court ruling by submitting strict criteria for endocrine disruptors based on science and not on socio-economic considerations. It is unacceptable that the institution that should be a guardian of the Treaties is evidently and bluntly in breach of EU law. The resolution strongly condemns continuous and incomprehensible delays in defining clear rules on chemicals which are believed to cause many serious diseases. Last but not least, it takes note of the Commission’s political commitment to propose scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine-disrupting properties before the summer.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The General Court of the European Union ruled on 16 December 2015 in case T-521/14, Sweden v Commission. In its judgment, the General Court ruled that the Commission had a clear, precise and unconditional obligation, under Regulation (EU) No 528/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 May 2012 on the marketing and use of biocidal products, to adopt delegated acts laying down the scientific criteria for the endocrine disrupting properties of active substances and biocidal products by 13 December 2013 at the latest. Failing to do so, the Commission, in accordance with the judgment of the General Court, breached EU law.  For this reason, the EFN, GUE/NGL, EFDD, ALDE political groups are autonomous and the S&D and Verts/ALE, as well as the PPE and ECR political groups, have submitted joint draft resolutions. Among them, S&D, GUE/NGL, EFDD and ALDE reached an agreement and drafted a joint compromise motion condemning the Commission and calling for the failure to be replaced without delay, which was joined by the PPE and Verts/ALE Groups. By my vote, I supported the compromise motion.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Endocrine disruptors are chemicals that interfere with the action of hormones and are commonly found in food (e.g. pesticide residues), food contact products, plastic products, furniture, toys, building materials and cosmetics. The effects are multiple: mental retardation, obesity, diabetes, reproductive problems, cardiovascular disease... And the cost of diseases linked to these disruptors is estimated at between 150 and 260 billion euros per year in the Union! The problem is very serious and the economic stakes are enormous. However, there is no legal definition at European level to regulate products containing endocrine disruptors, and the WTO and the US have threatened Europe if it restricts its imports. In this context, the Commission is constantly postponing the definition and a motion of censure was therefore tabled in May. However, the pro-EU parties that did not support the motion preferred to present a non-binding motion for a resolution, despite the urgency of the situation. So we voted against this resolution.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Decision of the European Court of Justice in its judgment of 16 December 2015 clearly states that the European Commission infringed EU law, since it refrained from adopting specific delegated acts with scientific criteria for determining the deregulatory properties of the endocrine system. I am therefore in favour of the Commission commnaring its obligations as an urgent and priority.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution is only an alibi for those who did not have the courage to support the motion of censure tabled by the ENF group. I'm voting against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to keep up the pressure on the Commission, which has been condemned on this subject for breaching its obligations, which has still not published the criteria for defining and identifying endocrine disruptors when it was due to do so in 2013.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the motion for a resolution, as the WHO in an earlier report called hormone-disrupting substances a global threat and, among other things, refers to the high number of occurrences of human hormone balance disorders and their increasing trend today. We now have new evidence to show that substances that interfere with hormone balance can cause reproductive disorders such as infertility, cancer and birth defects. I am in support of the Commission meeting its obligations as soon as possible and developing scientifically sound criteria for substances that disrupt hormone production.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that calls on the Commission to immediately adopt hazard-based criteria for the determination of endocrine-disrupting properties.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This Joint Motion for Resolution condemns the Commission for its failure to comply with its obligations in the biocides regulation. It calls on the commission to come forward with the criteria which the commission has already stated that it will do this month. By way of background information, endocrine disrupting chemicals are mostly man-made substances which are found in various products such as pesticides, plastics and other consumer products. They are strongly linked to hormone-related diseases/conditions and cancers such as breast cancer or testicular cancer. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this Joint Motion for Resolution.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report as I am in favour of establishing certain criteria for endocrine disruptors (hormone-active substances) which can cause lasting damage to health by changing the hormonal system.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Endocrine disruptors are not healthy for humans and can cause infertility and cancer, so the European Commission must immediately regulate the use of endocrine disruptors.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the judgment of the Court of Justice recogniseing, which recognises that the Commission had a clear and precise obligation to adopt delegated acts on the definition of scientific criteria for detecting endocrine disruptors in the context of the implementation of the regulation on plant protection products and biocides, it is recognised that the above criteria do not yet exist. I therefore support the call for the Commission to fulfil its commitment and I am voting in favour of it.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Regulation (EU) No 528/2012, the Commission was required to adopt, by 13 December 2013, delegated acts on the definition of scientific criteria for determining endocrine interference properties of active ingredients and biocidal products. Sweden, with the support, among others, of the European Parliament, has sued the Commission for not adopting these delegated acts. The Court of Justice of the European Union has ruled that the Commission has violated EU law in this area, has not yet complied with the judgment of the Court of Justice and persists in infringing EU law. The judgment of the Court of Justice stresses that the determination of scientific criteria should only be carried out objectively on the basis of scientific data relating to the endocrine system. I and other Members from different groups had proposed distrusting the Juncker Commission. The resolution voted on today is less strong but has the merit of coalescing large and small groups and giving a political signal to the Commission that Parliament still considers that it has not fulfilled its obligations as 'guardian of the Treaties'.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution because it is not acceptable for the Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, to violate the latter. With the resolution, we call on the Commission to fulfil its obligations and to adopt risk-based scientific criteria for detecting the properties of endocrine disruptors. The Court of Justice of the European Union has already held that scientific criteria can be objectively established only on the basis of scientific data on the hormonal system and that the powers conferred on the Commission does not have the power to change the regulatory balance laid down in the basic act.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Endocrine disruptors, according to the UNEP and WHO report, have been declared a global threat. This report mentions, inter alia, the high incidence and increase in the incidence of a number of endocrine-related disorders in humans and notes endocrine-related effects in wildlife. Evidence of negative effects for the reproductive system (infertility, cancer, damage) due to exposure to endocrine disruptors is also emerging, and more and more evidence is available every day on the effects of these chemicals on thyroid and brain function, on obesity and metabolism, and on insulin and glucose homeostasis. In its Judgment of 16 October 2013, the General Court of the European Union On 1 December 2015, the Commission found that the Commission had breached EU law by not adopting delegated acts to establish scientific criteria for determining the properties of endocrine disruption, and the Court of Justice of the European Union found in its judgment that the Commission had a clear, precise and unconditional obligation to adopt delegated acts in order to establish these scientific criteria no later than 13 December 2013. Given that today is 2016 and we do not yet have established scientific criteria for determining the properties of endocrine disruption, I supported the resolution because I believe that the European Union is failure to ensure the safety of its citizens when approving substances used in general consumption and specialised activities.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution is merely an alibi for those who did not have the courage to support the motion of censure on the subject that several Members, including myself, had wanted to table. So I'm voting against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Chemicals can leave irreversible and adverse consequences on humans. It has been found that endocrine disruptors can cause cancerous tumors, anomalies in childbirth and leave consequences for development and reproduction that can occur only in the later stages of life.  Substances that have been scientifically proven to have such an effect on humans are not approved, nor should they be authorised. In order for such substances to always be avoided, strict scientific criteria must be introduced to regulate exposure to such substances.  I supported Mp Gieseke's report with a view to setting and applying the criteria as quickly and efficiently as possible.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution in which we recalled the European Commission's inaction on the issue of endocrine disruptors. At the end of 2013, it was due to publish scientific criteria for identifying chemicals that are potentially dangerous to our hormonal system, and no text has reached the European Parliament, as the rule normally stipulates. It was therefore the European Court of Justice that condemned the European Commission, which has now committed to publishing the definition and criteria for identifying these endocrine disruptors as early as the week of 13 June 2016. While this issue is of important economic interest, the defence of the health of European citizens is a priority.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I consider it regrettable that the Commission has not complied with its obligation to adopt delegated acts as required by Regulation (EU) No 528/2012. The Commission had an obligation to specify the scientific criteria for determining the disrupting properties of the endocrine system. The role of the impact assessment, in accordance with the Better Regulation Guidelines, is to gather elements to assess the need for future Union action. Even after the conviction handed down by the Court of Justice of the European Union in December 2015, the Commission did not adopt delegated acts on scientific criteria for determining endocrine disrupting properties in active substances and biocidal products. There is therefore a further breach of the Treaties, as the Commission has not taken all the necessary measures to comply with the Court's judgment, and it is regrettable that the President of the European Parliament has announced in plenary the motion of censure submitted pursuant to Rule 119 of the Rules of Procedure and then considered it to be lapsed.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. Present in many everyday products, endocrine disruptors are considered a global threat by UNEP and WHO. Exposure to endocrine disruptors has been linked to reproductive conditions such as infertility, cancer and malformations. These substances also have effects on thyroid function, brain function, obesity and metabolism, and insulin and glucose homeostasis. For more than two and a half years, we have been waiting for the Commission to fulfil its obligations in this regard, namely to present scientific and objective criteria in order to better define and apprehend them, to no avail. The European Court of Justice also convicted her of breach.  I strongly believe that we need to reduce exposure to these harmful substances as soon as possible. The European Union has a role to play and the Commission would do well to remember that.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Endocrine disruptors are chemicals capable of interfering with hormones in animal species, including humans, thus causing many serious diseases — for example, hormone-dependent cancers, infertility, obesity, diabetes, neurological behavior disorders, etc. . I supported this decision to require the Commission to comply with the Court's judgment and to present as soon as possible strict criteria for endocrine disruptors on the basis of science and not based on socio-economic considerations. Under the Biocidal Products Regulation, the Commission is required to find a way to distinguish endocrine disruptors from other chemicals by establishing scientific criteria for identifying them. The list of these scientific criteria should have been drawn up by the European Commission in 2013. On 16 December 2015, the Court held that the European Commission had failed to fulfil its legal obligation by failing to adopt delegated acts specifying scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine-altering properties. According to the judgment, the scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine alteration properties should be based only on science related to the endocrine system, irrespective of any other consideration, in particular economic considerations.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this European Parliament resolution, which again raised the tone on Wednesday with regard to the European Commission on the issue of endocrine disruptors, asking it to adopt scientific criteria to define these substances. The vote, which came by a large majority, came at a time when the European Commission has been accused for several years of inertia on the issue of endocrine disruptors and was convicted in December 2015 for failing to provide their definition, although it was due to do so before the end of 2013.   The adopted text therefore condemns "the Commission's non-compliance (by the Commission) with its institutional obligations" while taking note of its "political commitment to propose scientific criteria before the summer for the determination of properties that disrupt the endocrine system". It should be noted that some sources suggest that the Commission should finally present its definition criteria on 15 June, which I welcome.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU is in a precarious situation as regards the control of dangerous substances.
