The EU Court acknowledged last year that the Commission had breached EU law by not publishing scientific criteria for determining the characteristics of endocrine disrupting, where the current temporary criteria do not provide a sufficient level of protection. Unfortunately, the Commission did not take action and in 2013 decided to carry out an assessment of the socio-economic impact of possible scientific criteria. Strangely, it appears that this investigation has lasted for three years, despite the fact that the Commission had a clear and unconditional obligation to adopt the relevant criteria by 13 December 2013. What makes even more bizarre is that this decision seems to be that no one has required the Commission to carry out such an investigation, i.e. we can find that the Commission decided on its own initiative to violate EU law and suspended the drafting of legislation of interest to the health of all Europeans. We find that the Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, itself infringed the EU Treaties. It seems strange when Commissioner Andriukaitis told Parliament that the Commission would still continue its impact assessment and not legislate. We must condemn this behaviour by the Commission, call for the immediate enforcement of EU law by adopting delegated acts in accordance with Regulation 528/2012 and to fulfil our institutional obligations under Article 266 TEU and to remind ourselves that the explanations given by President Juncker. Juncker or Commissioner Andrew seems pathetic and doubts about their ability to hold office.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. Diseases and disorders such as breast cancer, birth defects, declines in male fertility and early puberty have been on the rise for several years. This can be attributed in part to endocrine disruptors, present in many everyday products: cosmetics, packaging, children's toys. However, there is still no legislation at European level despite the insistence of the European Parliament. Expected since 2013, the Commission has turned this legislation into a study of the economic impact of banning endocrine disruptors, contrary to its commitments. This attitude of the Commission earned him a conviction by the European Court of Justice at the end of 2015. With this resolution, Parliament sends a final warning to the European Commission by requiring the adoption of criteria for classifying endocrine disruptors before the summer. We need European legislation against this invisible and permanent threat that affects our health and weighs on the budgets of our social security systems.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to urge the Commission to publish the scientific criteria for identifying endocrine disruptors. This text supports the condemnation of the Commission by the European Court of Justice. Indeed, since 2013, the European Commission has had to publish these criteria. Having breached its obligations, it is urgent that it publish these criteria to define "endocrine disruptors" as soon as possible.  I supported this text because these chemicals are present in many everyday objects. These disrupt the hormonal system and therefore pose a real danger to public health.  It should still be remembered that the Commission has committed to publishing these criteria in mid-June so that substances with serious consequences for the endocrine system are banned. In the meantime, however, it was crucial that Parliament reiterated its commitment to protecting the health of European citizens.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution, since Regulation (EU) No 528/2012 does not approve of active substances which, on the basis of criteria to be established or provisional criteria, have endocrine-altering properties that may cause adverse effects on individuals. It is also available that the Commission should adopt, by 13 December 2013, delegated acts specifying scientific criteria for determining the existence of endocrine-altering properties in active and biocidal substances. The Commission has not yet adopted such delegated acts. The WHO report called endocrine disruptors a global threat, referring, inter among other things, to the high incidence and upward trend of many endocrine system disorders in humans and noting that effects on endocrine function have also been observed in wild animal populations; there have been evidence of adverse reproductive effects — infertility, cancers, malformations — of exposure to endocrine disruptors, and there is also increasing evidence of the effects of these chemicals on thyroid and brain function, obesity and metabolism, and on insulin and glucose homeostasis.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission’s failure to fulfil its legal obligations on this serious matter of public health is very regrettable. The delay in adopting scientific criteria for endocrine disrupters increases the risk to public health and prevents proper regulation of potentially harmful chemicals. Time is running out for the Commission to fulfil its own commitment to this Parliament and the public to publish the criteria before the summer.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. The Commission should have already presented the scientific criteria for endocrine disruptors by the end of 2012. However, the criteria have not been met, but the criteria are necessary if public health is to be safeguarded. That is why it is also essential that we put pressure on the Commission, and with this resolution we are criticising the Commission for an excessively slow process.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I was pleased to support this non-legislative resolution, which sends out a clear criticism of the European Commission for delaying the publication of scientific criteria for determining the properties of endocrine disruptors. Both the UN Environment Programme and the World Health Organisation see them as a global threat to public health. By not limiting the criteria to be published at the end of 2013, the Commission committed a breach of EU legislative rules and in this way delayed the possibility of introducing measures to limit these disruptors.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 According to the judgment of the General Court of the European Union of December 2015, the Commission infringed EU law by failing to act and adopt delegated acts concerning the specificisation of scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine disrupting properties. As it is unacceptable for the Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, not to act on matters arising from its institutional obligations, I supported Parliament's resolution on endocrine disruptors. The Commission is obliged to carry out impact assessments for legislative and non-legislative initiatives which are expected to have a significant economic, environmental or social impact. Under EU provisions, it is not possible to authorise the use of substances that may have endocrine disrupting properties. So-called endocrine disruptors can only be banned on the basis of specific scientific criteria. These criteria were to be defined by the Commission by delegated acts, but this has not happened for more than two and a half years. The World Health Organization considers endocrine disruptors a global threat, as its latest report revealed the frequent occurrence and growing trend of many endocrine disorders in humans. In addition, there is increasing evidence of adverse consequences of endocrine disruptors on the reproductive system, resulting in infertility, cancer or deformation. I therefore hope that the Commission will finally fulfil its political commitment and propose the necessary scientific criteria for determining endocrine disrupting properties by the summer of this year.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I finally supported the joint motion for a resolution on endocrine disrupting substances submitted by the EPP, S&D, ALDE, GUE/NGL, Greens/NFA and EFDD factions. The Commission's inaction on the adoption of an implementing regulation setting out scientific criteria for determining endocrine disrupting properties has been going on for far too long – since 13 December 2013. The recent judgment of the General Court of December 2015 in Sweden v Commission also confirmed the inaction. The Commission is now obliged under primary law to adopt measures resulting from a judgment of the General Court, i.e. an obligation to adopt an implementing regulation setting out the criteria for a harmful substance within a reasonable time. This is a sensitive matter in the field of public health and Union citizens have the right to know the factors for determining the health of harmful substances. I consider it my duty to the Citizens to appeal to the Commission to issue a list of such criteria as soon as possible. In previous communication with Parliament, the Commission promised to adopt the criteria before the beginning of summer 2016. Parliament's call on the Commission to immediately fulfil its obligations is therefore on the agenda. I very much hope that the Commission will be able to adopt these criteria without delay.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Endocrine disruptors are substances that interfere with the normal functioning of the hormonal system to the extent that they have harmful effects on the body. Back in 2012, the World Health Organization named them as a global threat. Endocrine disruptors are associated with a number of health problems, such as cancer, fertility problems, genital deformities, obesity and neurological behavioural disorders. Legally speaking, endocrine disruptors are dealt with in European laws on chemicals, pesticides, water and cosmetics. A major drawback, however, is that endocrine disruptors are not precisely defined in that legislation. In 2015, in its judgment in Sweden v European Commission, the General Court ruled that the European Commission had infringed EU law by not ing a delegated act specifying the criteria for determining the characteristics of endocrine disruptors. Nevertheless, the European Commission has decided to continue the work as planned before the judgment. The resolution thus expresses strong criticism of the European Commission and condemns its failure to function. At the same time, it calls on the European Commission to adopt immediately scientific risk criteria to determine the properties of endocrine disruptors. It also gives the European Commission two months to act in accordance with Article 265 of the Treaty on European Union. As I agree with the above, I also voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The so-called "endocrine disruptors" are substances that have a negative effect on a person's own internal signalling system. The Commission has previously undertaken to propose scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine-disrupting properties before this summer. However, this will be delayed because the Commission is trying to design the criteria according to the standards of science. The delay has led to cases brought by Sweden against the Commission, which are supported by ALFA. The Commission should generally comply with Parliament's decisions. However, it remains unclear what a parliamentary resolution should contribute to the earlier complaint. I did not want to take part in this political game and voted against the resolution. Moreover, it is true that even scientists remain deeply divided on the fundamental question of the actual harmfulness of the substances. The hormonal systems of non-adults are very different from each other and have not been sufficiently researched to date. What applies to an adult, for example, is far from being the case for a child in the hormone sector. Analyses regarding the multiple possibilities of action of an "inner disrupter" on a hormone are hardly available. It is therefore necessary that the Commission does not rush to define it, as this could lead to errors with major negative consequences.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We must protect the health of European citizens and curb the use of substances that can be dangerous to humans and nature.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒By 13 December 2013 at the latest, the Commission was to adopt delegated acts setting out scientific criteria for determining the properties of endocrine disruption of active substances and biocide products. It has not yet adopted delegated acts, the determination of which is now more than two and a half years behind schedule.  Endocrine disruptors have been declared a global threat and it has been noted that their effects are associated with a number of disorders associated with the endocrine system in humans. Also, due to exposure to the same disruptors, negative effects have been observed for the reproductive system in various forms of cancer, damage, infertility.  In my view, the Commission needs to question the regulatory balance struck by the legislator between improving the internal market and protecting human and animal health. I support this joint motion for a resolution, as I believe that the Commission should respect its institutional obligations as well as its political obligation to propose and adopt scientific criteria for determining the properties of endocrine disruption by the summer.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's joint motion for a resolution on endocrine disrupting chemicals and on the current state of affairs following the judgment of the General Court of 16 December 2015 (2016/2747(RSP)). The Commission should adopt delegated acts establishing scientific criteria for determining the endocrine disrupting properties of active substances and biocidal products by 13 December 2013 at the latest and has not done so. The criticism of the Commission is correct.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Commission has not yet adopted delegated acts setting out scientific criteria, the determination of which is now more than two and a half years behind schedule. Article 5 Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013 528/2012 no active substances which are considered to have endocrine disruption properties with an adverse effect on humans are considered to have on the basis of scientific criteria, to be established or on the basis of provisional criteria.  A report by the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) and the World Health Organisation (WHO) declared endocrine disruptors a global threat. The same report mentions an increase in the incidence of a number of endocrine-related disorders in humans, and evidence of negative effects for the reproductive system due to exposure to endocrine disruptors is emerging. The General Court of the European Union found in its judgment of 16 December 2015 in case T-521/14 that the Commission had breached EU law by not adopting delegated acts to establish scientific criteria for determining the properties of endocrine disruption. I support this joint proposal for a resolution and call on the European Commission to account and respect its institutional obligations set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union itself.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on endocrine disruptors: the situation following the judgment of the General Court of the European Union of 16 December 2015. After two and a half years, we are still waiting for the Commission to adopt delegated acts laying down scientific criteria for the detection of endocrine disruptor properties in active substances and biocidal products. The Commission has thus also failed to fulfil its institutional obligations. I very much hope that the Commission will fulfil its commitment by the summer. The General Court of the European Union has also held that scientific criteria can be objectively established only on the basis of scientific data on the endocrine system, independently of all other factors, in particular economic factors.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Commission is invited to comply with its obligations under Article 266 OF THE EUSC and to adopt scientific criteria for determining endocrine disruptor properties, which will be scientifically sound and appropriate for regulatory purposes and based on a detailed risk assessment to be carried out on the basis of the most advanced science, as requested by Parliament in its report on the protection of public health.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Scientific criteria are needed for the detection and treatment of substances that disrupt hormone balance. The European Commission should have made these criteria public as early as the end of 2013, so I voted in favour of the joint resolution, which calls for this set of criteria to be presented as soon as possible and points out that no substantive action has been taken so far at the ep's repeated requests. Given the importance of human health, it is important to point out that substances that disrupt hormone balance are clearly associated with irreversible health risks even without criteria.  However, there should also be no witch hunt, so a scientific system of judgement is necessary to determine the marketability of a drug. The issue has not only been addressed by the European Parliament, the World Health Organisation calls hormone disruptive drugs a worldwide threat, causing irreversible diseases such as sterility in some affected people and animals. I agree with the strong statement in the resolution that the European Commission must come forward with delegated acts in this area in a short period of time.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Court of Justice of the European Union ruled in its judgment of 16 December 2015 that the Commission had infringed EU law by not taking action to adopt delegated acts concerning the establishment of scientific criteria for determining endocrine disruptive properties. The Commission now has a clear, concrete and unconditional obligation to adopt delegated acts. In this context, it should be borne in mind that it should be important in the Commission's work to maintain the right proportions and to soundly assess the risks to citizens' health. Only in this way will it be possible to maintain the highest safety standards, while supporting the competitiveness of the European agricultural market and other industries at risk of adversely affected by the selection of inappropriate criteria for determining endocrine disruptive properties. EU standards must take into account cases where chemicals pose a real and not just a theoretical threat.  I have therefore been strongly in favour of Parliament's report on this issue.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 So-called endocrine disruptors are chemicals capable of interfering with the hormones of animal species and are considered to be the cause of several serious diseases. They are found in a multitude of consumer items, cosmetics, pesticides and plastics. In this context, the Commission was obliged to find a way to distinguish endocrine disruptors from other chemicals by establishing scientific criteria for their identification. The European Parliament has repeatedly called on the Commission to fulfil its obligations under previous decisions. It is unacceptable that an institution such as the Commission, which should be a guardian of the Treaties, is not doing sufficient work in this area. With this vote, I condemn the continued delays in defining clear rules on chemicals and I call on the Commission to present as soon as possible strict criteria for endocrine disruptors.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I strongly condemn the Commission, not only for its failure to comply with its obligation to adopt acts delegated under Regulation (EU) 528/2012, but also for non-compliance with its institutional treaty obligations, including those covered by Article 266 of the FUE Treaty. We call on the Commission to immediately fulfil its obligations under Article 266 of the FUE Treaty and to immediately adopt scientific criteria based on danger in determining properties that disrupt the endocrine system. It is time to take effective account of the health of European citizens

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this joint resolution urging the Commission to publish scientific criteria for identifying endocrine disruptors. Indeed endocrine disruptors are chemicals which interfere with the hormonal system, potentially causing damage to health and the environment. Under the regulations in force on the marketing of biocidal products (Regulation 528/2012) and of plant health products (Regulation 1107/2009), the Commission ought to have specified scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine-disrupting properties of active substances and biocidal products no later than 13 December 2013. The Commission has, however, postponed that deadline arguing the need for a socio-economic study to be conducted. At the end of 2015, the General Court of the EU found that the Commission had breached EU law. Finally, this resolution condemns the Commission not only for failing to deliver upon its obligation to adopt delegated acts under the terms of Regulation 528/2012 but also for not complying with the Court ruling (Article 266 TFEU).

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. Parliament has demanded that the European Commission adopt criteria for classifying endocrine disruptors before the summer. These disruptors are responsible for a number of diseases (decreased fertility, obesity, diabetes, cancers, etc.). They therefore represent, in addition to a serious public health problem, an annual cost of EUR 157 billion (1.23% of GDP) to the Union. There is no specific European legislation on endocrine disruptors yet. Today, the European Commission has simply assessed the economic impact of banning these disruptors, suggesting that economic interests take precedence over the public interest. The European Commission was first condemned in December 2015 by the Court of Justice for its inaction.  In the event that the Commission does not transform the test by making a legislative proposal, the European Parliament will not hesitate to lodge an appeal with the Court of Justice. The general interest, and here in particular the health of European citizens, must and should take precedence over the pursuit of economic gain.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 In accordance with Article 5. Regulations on the making available on the market and the use of biocide products do not authorize active substances considered to have endocrine disruption properties with an adverse effect on humans on the basis of scientific criteria. Indeed, endocrine disruptors were declared a global threat in the UNEP-WHO report and the report provided evidence of their negative effects on the reproductive system and thyroid and brain functioning, on obesity and metabolism, and insulin and glucose homeostasis.  I therefore believe that the Commission should adopt risk-based scientific criteria for determining the properties of endocrine disruption in order to protect human health.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 Motion for a resolution on endocrine disruptors: I supported the situation following the Court's judgment of 16 December 2015. The latest study on the health costs associated with endocrine disruptors, which assessed five health conditions that could be caused by endocrine disruptors, found that, based on the available expert literature, the social and economic burden of the health consequences of endocrine disruptors is expected to be significant, at an estimated cost of BETWEEN EUR 46 and 288 billion per year. The provisional criteria set out in the Regulation do not provide a sufficient level of protection. Protecting citizens from health threats is one of the three strategic objectives of the European Union's health policy, and we must put hormonal disruptors in the prevention centre. In the area of health, where we can bring a relationship closer to our citizens, only consistent action by the Commission is necessary and permissible. Action needs to be taken as there are more and more cancers for cancer and diabetes. Preventive action is necessary and at the same time economically justified.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution, since Regulation (EU) No 528/2012 does not approve of active substances which, on the basis of criteria to be established or provisional criteria, have endocrine-altering properties that may cause adverse effects on individuals. It is also available that the Commission should adopt, by 13 December 2013, delegated acts specifying scientific criteria for determining the existence of endocrine-altering properties in active and biocidal substances. The Commission has not yet adopted such delegated acts. The WHO report called endocrine disruptors a global threat, referring, inter among other things, to the high incidence and upward trend of many endocrine system disorders in humans and noting that effects on endocrine function have also been observed in wild animal populations; there have been evidence of adverse reproductive effects — infertility, cancers, malformations — of exposure to endocrine disruptors, and there is also increasing evidence of the effects of these chemicals on thyroid and brain function, obesity and metabolism, and on insulin and glucose homeostasis.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting because there have been changes in the report which are manifestly contrary to the views of the professional public.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Endocrine disruptors are chemicals that interfere with the action of hormones and are commonly found in food (e.g. pesticide residues), food contact products, plastic products, furniture, toys, building materials and cosmetics. We are all exposed to it at all ages, including in utero. The effects are multiple: mental retardation, obesity, diabetes, reproductive problems, cardiovascular disease... The cost of endocrine disruptor diseases is estimated at between 150 and 260 billion euros per year in the EU! Trade issues are enormous, "justifying" threats from the WTO and the United States should regulations on endocrine disruptors be curbed by European imports.  The pro-EU parties, which did not support the censorship tabled in May, wanted to propose a resolution calling for the publication of the criteria and recalling the risk of legal action that Parliament can bring before the Court of Justice. Of course, this joint resolution has no binding scope and serves only as an alibi for those who did not support the motion of censure. I therefore vote AGAINST this resolution far too timid.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Commission has failed to fulfil its institutional obligations to implement the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union of 16.09.2015 (in accordance with Article 266 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union). It should determine as soon as possible the scientific criteria of properties that can interfere with the functioning of growth hormone. It is very dangerous for an EU institution to default on its obligations under the Treaties. The European Parliament calls on the Commission to carry out its duties.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The UNEP/WHO report called hormone disruptive substances a global threat and referred, inter alia, to the large number and increasing trend of human hormone balance disorders. There is new evidence that exposure to hormone disruptive substances leads to reproductive disorders (infertility, cancer, birth defects) and the effects of these chemicals on thyroid function, brain function, obesity and metabolism, as well as insulin and glucose homeostasis. With my vote, I followed the position of the S&D group.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution, since Regulation (EU) No 528/2012 does not approve of active substances which, on the basis of criteria to be established or provisional criteria, have endocrine-altering properties that may cause adverse effects on individuals. It is also available that the Commission should adopt, by 13 December 2013, delegated acts specifying scientific criteria for determining the existence of endocrine-altering properties in active and biocidal substances. The Commission has not yet adopted such delegated acts. The WHO report called endocrine disruptors a global threat, referring, inter among other things, to the high incidence and upward trend of many endocrine system disorders in humans and noting that effects on endocrine function have also been observed in wild animal populations; there have been evidence of adverse reproductive effects — infertility, cancers, malformations — of exposure to endocrine disruptors, and there is also increasing evidence of the effects of these chemicals on thyroid and brain function, obesity and metabolism, and on insulin and glucose homeostasis.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Condemns the Commission’s failure to act not only re scientific criteria for endocrine disrupters, but also for failure to comply with Art. 266 TFEU by not complying with the Court judgment (Para 1; ECR AM 10 rejected RCV 72/400/192). Has strong wording on the inappropriateness of impact assessments for a scientific matter and of looking at regulatory changes in the context of the IA, as this is beyond the powers of the Commission in the context of a delegated act Calls on the Commission to immediately adopt HAZARD-based criteria for endocrine disrupters.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on endocrine disruptors: state of play following the judgement of the General Court of the European Union of 16 December 2015. The resolution condemns the Commission not only for its failure to comply with its obligation to adopt delegated acts pursuant to Regulation (EU) No 528/2012, but moreover for failing to comply with its institutional obligations. The resolution stresses that the General Court ruled that the specification of scientific criteria could only be carried out in an objective manner based on scientific data related to the endocrine system, independently of any other consideration. Furthermore, the resolution urges the Commission to comply immediately with its obligations under Article 266 TFEU and to adopt immediately hazard-based scientific criteria for the determination of endocrine-disrupting properties.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. According to the United Nations Environment Programme and the World Health Organization, endocrine disruptors are a global threat.  Present in common products such as pesticides or cosmetics, they can be a source of infertility, cancer, obesity, etc. This is why the Biocides Regulation, which concerns the marketing and use of biocides, prohibits the approval of active substances containing endocrine disruptors, with exceptions. The Commission was to adopt delegated acts establishing the scientific criteria for identifying these substances by 13 December 2013. The deadline is far exceeded, so this joint resolution aims to condemn, once again, the Commission's inaction on this major public health issue. This immobility was ruled illegal by the European Court of Justice in December 2015. Unsurprisingly, the EPP and the ECR took a "comprehensive" stance on the Commission, saying, for example, that identifying scientific criteria was a difficult task.  For my part, I believe that the Commission must urgently adopt the delegated acts it has now promised for June 2016.  So I voted for this resolution.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. On 28 March 2013, the Advisory Group of Experts on Endocrine Disruptors, established by the Commission and coordinated by the Joint Research Centre (JRC), adopted a report on the main scientific issues relevant to the identification and characterization of endocrine disrupting substances. It turns out that the Commission did not adopt the delegated acts referred to above, either before or after 13 December 2013.  It is unacceptable that, even following the Judgment of the Court of Justice of December 2015, the Commission did not adopt the delegated acts relating to the scientific criteria for determining the endocrine disrupting properties of active substances and biocidal products, and justified the need for an impact study that would be completed and that it would calculate that the economic costs of such a list would be significant. It is unacceptable that any economic criterion should overtake the defence of public health and the environment.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Endocrine disruptors are hormone-active substances that can cause lasting damage to health by changing the hormonal system. The report strongly condemns the Commission for failing to fulfil its obligations and for an impact assessment to be carried out without any scientific criteria for disruptors ever being established, but only in the course of this assessment.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I have voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the EU Commission has not fulfilled its obligations here. These obligations are clearly laid out in Article 266 TFEU. Taking this into account I applaud the resolution’s call upon the EU commission to fulfil these obligations. When it comes to defining scientific criteria, the EU Commission should only take objective scientific criteria into account and not economic or other ones, which it did. I herein follow the resolution and acknowledge the General Courts’ judgement.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on endocrine disruptors because I agree with the condemnation of the European Commission for not respecting its obligation to adopt the delegated acts provided for in the Regulation on the making available on the market and the use of biocidal products. I find it unacceptable that the institution which assumes itself as the guardian of the Treaties does not fulfil its institutional obligations in this matter, especially when public health consequences are at stake. I therefore consent to the continued and incomprehensible delays on the part of the European Commission in setting clear rules on chemical elements that may lead to various serious diseases. I therefore share the message of this resolution which calls on the Commission to present strict criteria, based on scientific conclusions, and in a timely manner, in the field of endocrine disruptors.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. This resolution, which I voted in favour of, condemns the European Commission's delay in publishing the scientific criteria necessary to identify and reduce exposure to chemicals that interfere with human and animal hormonal activities. The report by the United Nations Environment and the World Health Organisation calls endocrine disruptors a 'global threat', referring to the upward trend in numerous endocrine-related diseases in humans and wild animals. It is considered that there is sufficient evidence to demonstrate the adverse effects on reproduction (infertility, tumours, malformations) caused by exposure to these substances, which could also affect the normal functioning of the thyroid gland and brain, and intervene on obesity, metabolism, insulin and glucose homeostasis. The European Court of Justice ruled in December 2015 that the EU executive had violated EU law by failing to publish these criteria, which should have been made public by the end of 2013 under EU law. The Commission is therefore guilty not only of failing to comply with the obligation to adopt scientific criteria, but also of non-compliance with its institutional obligations, as laid down in the EU Treaties.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on endocrine disruptors: the situation following the judgment of the General Court of the European Union of 16 December 2015. In its judgment of 16 December 2015 in Case T-521/14, the General Court of the European Union wrote that the Commission had infringed EU law by not adopting delegated acts with scientific criteria for the detection of endocrine disrupting properties. As the Commission has not yet taken steps to take account of the Court's judgment but insists on a breach of EU law, I join the calls for the Commission to fulfil its institutional obligations.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Juncker promised to democratise the process of marketing GMOs. The authorisation concerns a transgenic maize resistant to two pesticides with active ingredients based on glufosinate and glyphosate. Glyphosate, in particular, is a potentially dangerous product for human health and the scientific community has not yet given a unanimous opinion. That is why I voted in favour of the objection.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection, because I am totally against genetically modified organisms, and therefore new authorisations thereof. The more the decision-making process for GMO authorisations for food and feed is not being democratic. The special committee almost never reaches a qualified majority, however, the European Commission is almost always issuing authorisations, without the support of Member States or most EU citizens. This should be the exception, but with GMOs, now it's the rule.  In addition, this maize is tolerant of glyphosate, which makes its authorisation very premature when a qualified majority of the Member States cannot even agree on the reauthorisation of this herbicide — possible carcinogen and endocrine disruptor.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection to oppose the decision to apply the authorization to grow this GMO.  While the use of glyphosate may be fully tolerated as there are not enough commercial alternatives for farmers and the sector needs a transition period before its final ban, the development of a glyphosate-resistant GMO is unsavory in light of health risks.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted against this proposal to allow the importation and marketing in the EU of products containing genetically modified maize Bt11 × MIR162 × MIR604 × GA21, or genetically modified maize combining two or three of the Bt11, MIR162, MIR604 and GA21 events, as well as products consisting of these maize or products from them.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection under Article 106 to the authorisation of genetically modified maize Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21, because GMOs resistant should not be authorised, as this could lead to an increase in the use of such substances.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. With this resolution, the European Parliament rejects a Commission decision to allow glyphosate-tolerant GMO maize throughout the EU, among other things. In view of the fact that I am particularly critical of the plant protection product glyphosate and that I generally reject GMO foods because of the unknown long-term consequences, I fully support this resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The marketing authorization for products and foodstuffs containing this GMO had already been granted while excluding the crop. In 2013, the applicant company requested the extension of this authorization to all sub-combinations of genetic modification. EFSA gave a favourable opinion in 2015 assuring the safety of this genetically modified maize. An objection was raised against the application decision as some combinations of genetically modified maize are tolerant to glufosinate (including ammonium salt) and glyphosate-based herbicides. However, some commercial formulations of glyphosate with adjuvants are "probably carcinogenic" according to the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC).  While the use of glyphosate may be fully tolerated as there are not enough commercial alternatives for farmers and the sector needs a transition period before its final ban, the development of a glyphosate-resistant GMO is unsavory in light of health risks.  So I voted in favour of that objection.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I abstained. I abstained on the grounds that any other vote accepts EU competence on these matters.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection to prohibiting the importation and marketing of herbicide-resistant maize. Its use could have adverse effects on users and consumers.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 9 February 2009 Syngenta France SAS submitted an application to the competent Authority of Germany for the placing on the market of foodstuffs, food ingredients and feed containing genetically modified maize. As stated in the request, maize contains a protein that gives resistance to glyphosate herbicides. On 20 March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, a specialised Cancer Agency of the World Health Organisation, classified glyphosate as a potentially carcinogenic substance in humans. For this reason, the EP considers that the draft Commission implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers envisaged, and I therefore support the request to the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Syngenta submitted an application to the competent authority of Germany on 9 February 2009 for the placing on the market of foodstuffs, food ingredients and feedingstuffs containing, consisting of or produced from × MAIZE bt11 × MIR162 × MIR604 ×. The application shall also cover the genetically modified version, with the exception of cultivation. They contain proteins that can cause cancer in the human body. Our fundamental objection is that the licensing mechanism for GM food and feed is not democratic. The European Commission regularly issues licences in such a way that it is not supported by the majority of Member States or by the majority of EU citizens. President Juncker himself promised in 2014 that this undemocratic decision-making mechanism would be abolished. On this basis, I supported the objection to the Commission's implementing regulation.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution which calls on the Commission to withdraw a draft enforcement decision concerning the marketing of certain products containing genetically modified maize because it exceeded its competence.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the objection to a Commission delegated act authorising the placing on the market of food, food ingredients and feed containing, consisting of or obtained from maize Bt11 × MIR162 × MIR604 × GA21. One of these masts contains the PAT protein, which gives tolerance to herbicides and turns out to be based on glyphosate, a substance considered potentially carcinogenic by the International Agency for Research on Cancer. Given the potential danger to health, I have therefore decided to vote in favour of the objection, reaffirming the need for the Commission to draw up as soon as possible a comprehensive proposal on GMOs and feed from GMOs in order to carefully assess the environmental and health impact of these technologies.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Since 22 April 2015, in the explana motion for its legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, the Commission regretted that since the entry into force of that regulation, authorisation decisions for the use of certain substances have been taken by the Commission, in accordance with the applicable legislation, without the support of the opinions of the committees of the Member States, and that the return of the dossier to the Commission for the adoption of the final decision, which was truly an exception in the context of the procedure as a whole, has become the norm when taking decisions on authorisations for genetically modified food and feed. We consider that the Commission's draft Implementing Decision exceeds its powers. As described in the application, the genetically modified maize MON-A21-9 expresses the cry1Ab protein, which gives it protection against certain lepidoptera pests, and the mEPSPS protein, which gives tolerance to herbicides composed of glyphosate. The International Cancer Research Centre (WHO) classified glyphosate as a likely carcinogenic agent for humans.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report issued in this case by the ENVI Parliamentary Committee, which considers that this draft decision implementing the committee exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1892/2003, so I am in favour of the committee withdrawing it.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution concerns an objection under Article 106 for the authorisation of GMO maize Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21. Authorization for the marketing of products and foodstuffs containing this GMO had already been granted. This authorization, however, excluded the cultivation of this GMO.   This objection to the decision is based on the idea that the decision exceeds the Commission's powers under Regulation 1829/2003. Overall, while the use of glyphosate can be fully tolerated as there are not enough commercial alternatives for farmers and the sector needs a transition period before its final ban, the development of a glyphosate-resistant GMO is unsavory in light of health risks. So I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote the objection to the marketing authorisation of genetically modified maize Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to this implementing act by which the European Commission authorises Syngenta to market products containing, are composed or produced from GM maize Bt11 × MIR162 × MIR604 × GA21, and genetically modified maíces that combine two or three of the Bt11, MIR162, MIR604 and GA21 events. This authorisation from the Commission exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on genetically modified food and feed. In particular, some of the gm maíces in question confer tolerance to ammonium glufosinate and glyphosate-based herbicides, which could lead to increased use of these herbicides. For these reasons, I have supported the objection.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it is in favour of Parliament's implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified maize. In 2009, Syngenta France SAS submitted an application to the competent German authority for the placing on the market of foodstuffs, food ingredients and feed containing maize. The application also concerns the placing on the market of products containing or consisting of genetically modified maize for uses other than food or feed. In 2013, Syngenta extended the scope of the application to cover all combinations of individual genetic modifications that make up maize. The aforementioned corn contains a protein that provides protection against certain pests of the butterfly group, and a protein that provides resistance to glyphosate herbicides. The International Agency for Research on Cancer, a specialised World Health Organisation Cancer Agency, classified glyphosate as a potentially carcinogenic substance in humans in 2015. For these reasons, Parliament considers that the draft Commission implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers envisaged and asks the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. On the issue of GMOs, the profession also does not have a single opinion, so it is expected that Members and the rest of the public will also be divided on these issues. I myself am a supporter of the precautionary principle in GMOs, so I find it completely unnecessary for the process to be brought through the process as quickly as the registration of GMO maize. We are at a sensitive moment when institutions should have greater respect among themselves, and above all we must respect the will of the people who are majority against the use of GMOs in Europe. I also personally wonder very much whether we really need this kind of GN-seed of maize. I understand that, for various reasons, we are not able to produce enough soy bee in the EU and we are obliged to import soy from countries where gms are mostly used. But I can't understand why we need GSO corns. I firmly believe that we can grow enough maize without this GMO seed. I therefore supported the proposed objection of a peaceful conscience.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I voted for this complaint because I believe that the current GMO food authorisation system in the EU needs to be changed. At issue is a political message to the Commission, which gave sales and import authorisation under the GMO food directive, which Parliament considers undemocratic.  Member States were unable to agree for five years on the granting or refusal of a GMO maize licence. In such a situation, the Commission has the right under the existing rules to act as it deems necessary. While the decision is legal, it is not democratic. The problem the European Union has with GMO will not be solved on its own nor is the status quo sustainable. It should be accepted that most Member States are against GMO, but some countries want it.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The objection to the decision to apply the authorization is based on the argument that the decision exceeds the Commission's powers under Regulation 1829/2003.  In any event, I am not in favour of the marketing of products and foodstuffs containing GMOs whose lack of public health effects has yet to be demonstrated. I voted for that objection.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The widespread use of GMO products is, due to the risk of significant adverse effects on natural ecosystems and human health resulting from their use, a practical source of great concern which I believe needs to be limited in greater order. The gradual and increasing use of GMO crops is in fact the cause of an increase in the use of herbicides (such as glyphosate or glufosinate) which seriously undermine the delicate natural biological balance, while at the same time threatening the human health of consumers. Several authoritative studies have highlighted the high risk of carcinogenicity as a result of the use of many herbicides (including glyphosate), a risk that increases significantly in the event of the cultivation of GMO products. I therefore believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified maize and carnation must be vigorously opposed. A project which, as mr Bart States' objection points out, also risks exceeding the implementing powers reserved by the Commission provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2013 and of not meeting the objective of protecting health and the environment laid down in Directive 2001/18/EC.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This objection is intended to oppose the decision to apply the authorization to grow this GMO. As a reminder, until 2013, only the marketing of products or foodstuffs containing this GMO was allowed. Since then, the applicant company has applied to extend this authorisation to all sub-combinations of genetic modification, to which the European Food Safety Authority has responded favourably. However, these sub combinations are found to be tolerant to glufosinate and glyphosate-based herbicides, some of which are likely to be carcinogenic, according to the International Cancer Research Centre. While the use of glyphosate is to be temporarily tolerated in order to allow industry professionals a transition period before its final ban, the cultivation of a glyphosate-resistant GMO is not recommended. That is why I voted in favour of this objection.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The placing on the market of genetically modified agricultural products has always sparked a lot of controversy due to the possible risks to human and animal health. I would like to point out, however, that all agricultural products have undergone long-term improvement processes in order to increase their strength and productivity. Applications for authorisation for the placing on the market of food products and ingredients containing genetically modified maize are intended for uses other than human and animal consumption, excluding cultivation. In this respect, I believe that we should not oppose the Commission's implementing document, because authorisation decisions have been taken in accordance with current legislation. I have spoken out against this resolution because I am convinced that any rejection of authorisation procedures without risk assessments by EFSA creates major obstacles to the progress of research and innovation in agriculture.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, I voted in favour of this objection calling on the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing act authorising the placing on the market of products containing a particular type of genetically modified maize. I am of the opinion that as long as there are concerns about the harmful health effects of the consumption of food containing genetically modified organisms, the Commission should not authorise its sale. In these cases, the precautionary principle must always prevail because the primary objective of the European Union is the protection of the health of all citizens. The objection relates that the malys in question has undergone treatments that give it tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides. A few months ago, the European Parliament voted in favour of another objection opposing the renewal of the approval of this active substance on the basis of the opinion expressed by the International Agency for Research on Cancer, which classified it as probably carcinogenic to humans. In the light of all these factors, I thought it appropriate to oppose the placing on the market of this maly.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I objected to the authorisation of this GMO, because it contains glyphosate-tolerant proteins and this is carcinogenic.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report that proposes the Commission to withdraw the approval of the sales of goods produced from genetically modified maize. Researches have shown the potential of causing cancers by such products. I therefore suggest revoking authorisation of genetically modified maize to protect public health.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The authorisation concerns a transgenic maize resistant to two pesticides with active ingredients based on glufosinate and glyphosate. The danger of glyphosate hangs over a dispute between the International Agency for Cancer (IARC) in Lyon, which classifies it as a probable carcinogen, and EFSA, according to which it is not. Degradation products would also be able to interfere with the proper functioning of the endocrine system. I am therefore opposed to this authorisation. The aim is to put pressure on the Commission to come forward with a new proposal to democratise the process of marketing GMOs, as Promised by Junker since the beginning of his term of office.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against as we consider that the Commission's draft implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 1829/2003

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted today following an objection under Article 106 to the authorisation of genetically modified maize Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21. It is obvious that this issue is of direct concern to the health sector and it is only after careful action that we can make significant changes. That is why I voted in favour of the objection in order to carry out investigations into the suitability of the product concerned.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree with the interruption of trade in this product. Or, at the very least, I believe that the EU should act more consistently when it comes to GMOs: it makes no sense, for our domestic production, to allow trade and not to authorise cultivation. Until this inconsistency is resolved, I think it is appropriate that trade should not be allowed either.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I disagreed with this resolution which called on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection, because I am totally against genetically modified organisms, and therefore new authorisations thereof. The more the decision-making process for GMO authorisations for food and feed is not being democratic. The special committee almost never reaches a qualified majority, however, the European Commission is almost always issuing authorisations, without the support of Member States or most EU citizens. This should be the exception, but with GMOs, now it's the rule. In addition, this maize is tolerant of glyphosate, which makes its authorisation very premature when a qualified majority of the Member States cannot even agree on the reauthorisation of this herbicide — possible carcinogen and endocrine disruptor.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In their resolution, the opposing party considers that the implementing decision constitutes an overrun of the powers set out in Regulation (EU) No 1829/2003 on genetically modified food and feed, claiming, first of all, that genetically modified maize results in tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides. The authors insist that, under the current legal framework, which they consider defective, they should not grant new authorisations for genetically modified food and feed. Given the weight of the problem, I voted YES.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I object to the Commission’s decision to authorise on the market products consisting of genetically modified maize particularly since we are dealing with maize that is tolerant to certain including glyphosate. This authorisation is really untimely since there was not even a qualified majority of Member State in favour of reauthorising this herbicide which is possibly carcinogenic and possibly an endocrine disruptor.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU GMO authorisation system is based on the precautionary principle. Accordingly, the safety of gm products should be ascertained before authorisation.  Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21 maize, formed by a combination of single lines, is resistant to herbicides containing glufosizinate ammonium and glyphosate and a number of pest insects of the order Lepidoptera and Coleoptera. During the cultivation of the GMO maize in question, increased use of plant protection products with this active substance may occur, which may later increase the level of residues in the crop. The herbicide glyphosate was classified as a "likely human carcinogen" by the WHO in 2015. Its high use also increases the appearance of a resistant weed population.  According to domestic experts, studies on the health safety of the product are unsatisfactory. Longer-term feeding trials should also have been carried out in order to determine whether these products do not pose a risk to human or animal health.  In line with hungary's GMO-free strategy, the Basic Law and the precautionary principle, we do not support the authorisation of GM products, so I voted in favour of parliament's objection to the placing on the EU market of BT11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21 GM maize.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA did not support the objection to the placing on the market of a genetically modified carnation and maize. The approval procedure for GMOs is strict. The EFSA risk assessment plays a crucial role in this. The N-VA strongly believes in scientifically based and "evidence-based" policies.  Moreover, the European Commission has not exceeded its mandate in this executive action: if the Member States do not achieve a qualified majority, the European Commission is authorised to approve GMOs on the basis of a positive opinion from EFSA. With regard to glyphosate, it is noted that there is no scientific consensus. I recognise the concerns about glyphosate and call for the discussion on this controversial substance to be further and further deseeded.  It remains important to distinguish between GMO technology and application. It is also clear that the (possible) use of GMOs should always be part of an agricultural policy that integrates the protection of public health, the environment and biodiversity, with integrated pest management (integrated pest management) essential for the sustainable use of pesticides and non-chemical alternatives.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Currently, genetically modified organisms (GMOs) can be grown on the territory of the European Union after the seed companies holding the GMO have obtained a marketing authorization in accordance with European regulations.  The European Parliament has chosen to use its power of objection to ask the European Commission to withdraw its authorisations on the use of genetically modified soybeans tolerant of glyphosate, a herbicide classified as a "probable carcinogen" by the World Health Organization (WHO). In the future, the GMO authorisation process should not be reviewed without the support of a qualified majority of Member States and with the opinion of Parliament.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The EU GMO authorisation system is based on the precautionary principle. Accordingly, the safety of gm products should be ascertained before authorisation.  Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21 maize, formed by a combination of single lines, is resistant to herbicides containing glufosizinate ammonium and glyphosate and a number of pest insects of the order Lepidoptera and Coleoptera. During the cultivation of the GMO maize in question, increased use of plant protection products with this active substance may occur, which may later increase the level of residues in the crop. The herbicide glyphosate was classified as a "likely human carcinogen" by the WHO in 2015. Its high use also increases the appearance of a resistant weed population.  According to domestic experts, studies on the health safety of the product are unsatisfactory. Longer-term feeding trials should also have been carried out in order to determine whether these products do not pose a risk to human or animal health.  In accordance with hungary's GMO-free strategy, the Basic Law and the precautionary principle, we do not support the authorisation of GM products, so I voted in favour of parliament's objection to the placing on the EU market of GM maize Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The development of a glyphosate-resistant GMO is unsavory in light of public health risks. For this reason, on Wednesday 8 June, I voted in favour of this objection that the authorisation decision exceeds the Commission's powers under Regulation 1829/2003.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Article 106 objection on the authorisation of genetically modified maize, as I am firmly behind the ban on the use of GMOs in any form. Citizens' health must be put first, so we must not allow the sale of GMO foods on the European market. I have always been a supporter of the overall ban on GMOs on the European market. I am convinced that this is the only policy we can have on this issue.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the motion for a resolution as it asks the Commission to withdraw its implementing decision.  The commission's draft implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EU) No 1782/2003. 1829/2003.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the entry into force of the respective Regulation, authorisation decisions have been adopted by the Commission in accordance with applicable legislation without the support of opinions of committees of the Member States. The return of the procedure to the Commission for final decision, which should truly be an exception in the whole procedure, has become the norm for decision-making on authorisations for genetically modified food and feed. I therefore consider that the Commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers laid down in the Regulation.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for it. While the use of glyphosate may be fully tolerated as there are not enough commercial alternatives for farmers and the sector needs a transition period before its final ban, the development of a glyphosate-resistant GMO is unsavory in light of health risks.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Syngenta France S.A.S submitted to the competent authority of Germany an application to place on the market food, food ingredients and feed containing, consisting of, or produced from, bt11xMIR604xMIR162xGA21 transgenic maize. This transgenic maize has resistance to some lepidopteran pests, ammonia glyphosinate and glyphosate. This application also covers products containing or consisting of this type of maize, intended for other common uses of maize other than as food or feed, with the exception of cultivation, such as the production of biofuels. This request has been extended to cover all subcombinations of unique processing events constituting this type of maize. The draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on genetically modified food and feed and shall be withdrawn by the Commission. Since the entry into force of this Regulation, authorisation decisions have been adopted by the European Commission, as member states' committees have not given their opinion for lack of consensus; the decision was always due to the exception in the legislation resending the final decision in these cases to the Commission. The exception became the rule. We voted for it.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution challenging the placing on the market of a GMO.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution as it asks the Commission to withdraw its implementing decision.  The commission's draft implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EU) No 1782/2003. 1829/2003.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ On 9 February 2009, and updated in 2013, Syngenta France requested authorisation for placing certain types of genetically modified maize on the market. EFSA issued a favourable opinion on 7 December 2015, stating that the genetically modified maize in question was as safe and as nutritious as its conventional counterpart and that no safety concerns were identified for any of the sub-combinations. The Commission then prepared a draft implementing decision authorising the products containing, consisting of, or produced from the above-mentioned genetically modified maizes. However, the International Agency for Research for Cancer – the specialised cancer agency of the WHO – classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans on 20 March 2015. Moreover, the objectors consider that the current GMO legal framework is unsatisfactory. Herbicide resistant GMOs should not be authorised, because they could encourage the increase use of herbicides, and the wider health and environmental implications of this has not been taken into account. I therefore support the objection.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted against the objection, considering that we should have all the necessary information when making decisions on authorisations for genetically modified food and feed. Our only interest in this case should be to ensure the safety and health of the food we eat in the EU.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the "objection under Article 106: Authorisation of genetically modified maize of the variety Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21", as I fundamentally condemn the cultivation of genetically modified plants in the EU in accordance with the position of my family party in Germany.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. Permission to market products and foodstuffs containing this GMO had already been granted. However, it excluded its culture. EFSA gave a favourable opinion in 2015 on extending the authorisation to all sub-combinations of the genetic modification requested in 2013. This objection relates to the fact that the authorization exceeds the commission's powers.  This GMO is resistant to glyphosate, which is a tolerated pesticide as there are not enough alternatives and the sector needs a transition period before its final ban. In order to protect European citizens again and again, I have decided to vote for this report, for this objection.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Since 22 April 2015, in the explana motion for its legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, the Commission regretted that since the entry into force of that regulation, authorisation decisions for the use of certain substances have been taken by the Commission, in accordance with the applicable legislation, without the support of the opinions of the committees of the Member States, and that the return of the dossier to the Commission for the adoption of the final decision, which was truly an exception in the context of the procedure as a whole, has become the norm when taking decisions on authorisations for genetically modified food and feed. We consider that the Commission's draft Implementing Decision exceeds its powers. As described in the application, the genetically modified maize MON-A21-9 expresses the cry1Ab protein, which gives it protection against certain lepidoptera pests, and the mEPSPS protein, which gives tolerance to herbicides composed of glyphosate. The International Cancer Research Centre (WHO) classified glyphosate as a likely carcinogenic agent for humans.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this objection, which was to ban the marketing of GMO maize in Europe. Established following a scientific opinion from the European Food Safety Agency, the authorisation of this GMO posed no risk to public health. Member States also have the final say on allowing GMOs to grow on their territory, and it is up to them to decide whether or not they want GMOs to be used in their agriculture. I regret that the Greens are systematically using the European Parliament's power of objection to dogma the precautionary principle, whose abusive invocation is a hindrance to progress and innovation.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the implementation of the Commission’s decision to authorize the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified maize. Such a maize contains a protein which confers protection against certain platoon moth pests and the proteins which confer tolerance to glyphosate herbicides which was classified as toxic to humans.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the objection to the approval of genetically modified maize Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21 because of our consistent and timeless position against GMOs.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection, as did the majority of my colleagues. Like other recent objections to the placing on the market of GMO products, the problem continues to be that the Commission is trying to exceed its implementing powers provided for in the GM Regulation 1829/2003 after the Member States deliver a non-opinion. Earlier this year, the Commission attempted to mitigate the rigour of this authorisation system through a proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, which would enable Member States to opt out from an EU-approved GMO by restricting or prohibiting its use based on a set of legal reasons. In October 2015, the Parliament rejected the proposal due to a variety of concerns including the potentially disruptive effects that it might have on the functioning of the internal market. As well as that, I have always been a supporter of environmentally safe farming methods and because of this; I advocate the precautionary principle when it comes to GMO products.
