name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion prohibiting the authorisation of genetically modified maize as a result of empirical studies carried out on the impact on human health and biodiversity.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the Commission's draft implementing decision authorising the marketing of products containing GM maize, consisting of or manufactured from it and genetically modified maize which are a combination of two or three changes since the changes to Bt11, MIR162, MIR604 and GA21 and the repeal of Decision No 11/21. 2010/426/EU, 2011/893/EU, 2011/892/EU and 2011/894/EU as it calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.  In my view, above all, consideration should be given to the potential consequences that GMO can have on human health and the environmental impact of such products. I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision should be in line with the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013. 1829/2003 and therefore I vote for this motion for a resolution.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Permission to market products and foodstuffs containing this GMO had already been granted. This authorization, however, excluded the cultivation of this GMO.   The objection to the decision to apply the authorization is based on the argument that the decision exceeds the Commission's powers under Regulation 1829/2003.  In particular, it is argued that some combinations of genetically modified maize are tolerant to glufosinate (including ammonium salt) and glyphosate-based herbicides. However, some commercial formulations of glyphosate with adjuvants are "probably carcinogenic" according to the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC).  While the use of glyphosate may be fully tolerated as there are not enough commercial alternatives for farmers and the sector needs a transition period before its final ban, the development of a glyphosate-resistant GMO is unsavory in light of health risks.  Logically, I supported the text.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Even though as this vote is an objection to an implementing act, and this objection might be more of a political move made by different groups in the chamber, EH Bildu has maintained a coherent position on matters related to GMOs and always vote against those, or as in cases as such, vote in favour of objections to allowing the authorisation of GMOs. On 9 February 2009, Syngenta submitted to the competent authority of Germany an application for the placing on the market of foods, food ingredients, and feed containing, consisting of, or produced from Bt11×MIR162×MIR604×GA21 maize; and later on 5 July 2013, extended the scope of the application to all sub-combinations of the single genetic modification events, including Bt11×GA21 maize, MIR604×GA21 maize, Bt11×MIR604 maize, and Bt11×MIR604×GA21 which are already authorised by different Commission Decisions. However, this draft Commission implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation(EC) No1829/2003 on genetically modified food and feed. Indeed, some of the genetically-modified maizes in question confer tolerance to glufosinate-ammonium and glyphosate-based herbicides, while the International Agency for Research for Cancer (WHO) classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans. Therefore, EH Bildu has voted in favour of this objection, and will keep voting in the same way to any future objection concerning authorisation of GMOs.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution. The rapporteur rightly points out that the Commission is always releasing new combinations of genetically modified maize varieties, thereby exceeding its competences. In addition, the decisions already taken to authorise various combinations of genetically modified genetically modified maize varieties are to be repealed.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's resolution in Strasbourg calling for the commission's decision to authorise the cultivation of genetically modified maize in the EU. The European Commission should come up with a better proposal on authorisation procedures and, through studies, take more effective and balanced steps with regard to genetically modified products and permits to place such products on the market. The current proposal does not address the often expressed concerns about the potential health and environmental risks of GMOs. The consequences that products containing GMOs can have on humans and the environment are not yet sufficiently identified and there is too much uncertainty regarding genetically modified products.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 8 June 2016, in plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of my factional colleague Lynn Boylan's objection to the authorisation of genetically modified maize. As you know, I have long objected to any authorisation of the cultivation of GM crops on European soil. Personally, I believe that this is a dangerous gamble with our biodiversity and with our health, as all risks to both human health and the environment as a whole are still unpredictable. We already find a number of scientific studies that explicitly point out, for example, that the fruits of animals fed with GM crops show numerous mutations, malformations and other damage to the immune system. There is a real risk that these animal health problems will subsequently be passed on to humans, thanks to the consumption of milk or meat. The current GMO authorisation process is dysfunctional and does not provide proper safeguards. I take the view that, until it is fundamentally reformed, all authorisation processes for such crops should be suspended. Instead of authorising more and more GMOs, the Commission and the Member States should take up their obligations regarding the health of the European population and re-design the system.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the resolution calling on the European Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified maize and products produced using it. Being aware of the potential risks of using GMOs in food production, I would point out that GMO products and food have long been present on the market and that agricultural production using genetic engineering techniques is the most reliable potential means of meeting the food needs of the world's population. Therefore, decisions of the European Parliament and the Commission relating to GMOs should focus on appropriately precise cultivation and marketing regimes, as well as on the control and enforcement of legal restrictions in this area, rather than on prohibitions that can enlarge the grey area and exclude the production of GMOs from the necessary control.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the authorisation of this GMO maize, because I am wary of GMOs as it stands in scientific research.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for the objection in accordance with Article 106: authorization of GMO maize Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21. Approval for the marketing of food products containing this GMO had already been granted. This authorization, however, excluded the cultivation of this GMO. In 2013, the applicant company requested the extension of this authorization to all sub-combinations of genetic modification. EFSA gave a favourable opinion in 2015 assuring the safety of this genetically modified maize. The objection is based on the argument that the decision exceeds the Commission's powers under Regulation 1829/2003. In particular, it is argued that some combinations of genetically modified maize are tolerant to glufosinate and glyphosate-based herbicides. However, some commercial formulations of glyphosate with adjuvants are "probably carcinogenic" according to the International Cancer Research Centre. While the use of glyphosate can be tolerated to the extent that there are not enough commercial alternatives for farmers and the sector needs a transition period before its final ban, the development of a glyphosate-resistant GMO is unsavory in light of health risks.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The text in question opposes the Commission's decision to extend the authorisation to grow GMO Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21. Developing this type of GMO that can resist glyphosate poses a health risk. Combined with commercial glyphosate formulas, it poses a carcinogenic risk according to the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC). The marketing of products and foodstuffs containing this maize is permitted, but it is not desirable to allow cultivation. I therefore voted FOR the rejection of the text, which wants to extend the authorisation to culture.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection, because I consider the procedure followed for authorisation to be inappropriate, which should fully respect the precautionary principle in an area as sensitive as authorisations to Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs). Good evidence of the lack of democracy in decision-making concerning GMO authorisations for food and feed is that a qualified majority is almost never reached in the special committee, however, the European Commission is almost always issuing authorisations, without the support of Member States or most EU citizens. This should be the exception, but with GMOs, now it's the rule. The greater the commercial appeal of this variety is its compatibility with glyphosate, over which there is also no qualified majority of the Member States not for the extension of their authorisation as a herbicide — possible carcinogen and endocrine disruptor.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's decision. The Commission should not authorise and ban the cultivation of genetically modified maize, this Decision should be left to the Member States.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission has authorised the placement on the market of genetically modified maize. This type of corn has been genetically modified to be resistant to glyphosate. A scientific study site claims that glyphosate, the chemical existing in a wide range of products based on genetically modified maize of Monsanto, could be carcinogenic. International Agency for Research on Cancer has classified glyphosate as the possible human carcinogen substance. Despite this, the European Food Safety claims that glyphosate is not carcinogenic and has no toxic effects on fertility, allowing other products based on glyphosate to enter the market. In order to protect the health of European citizens, it is extremely important to analyze the impact of GMO products on the environment and to the people.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 In 2015, the production of GM maize Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x TC1507 x 5307 x GA21 for food and feed purposes, import and processing was approved. This Commission decision was adopted in accordance with the applicable legislation, but without the support of member states' opinions, I therefore supported this objection.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At today's plenary session, I did not follow the ERA line and voted in favour of the proposed objections to the authorisation to place genetically modified maize and cloves on the market. I'm guided by our national interest in the development of organic farming. Bulgaria has a consistent conservative and restrictive national policy on genetically modified organisms. There are numerous arguments for and against GMOs, and I will not repeat them here. However, I can not ignore the concerns of a large number of experts about glyphosate as possibly carcinogenic to humans.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This complaint concerns the Commission's wish to authorise the placing on the market of genetically modified maize Bt11 × MIR162 × MIR604 × GA21 produced by Syngenta France SAS in foodstuffs, food ingredients and feed. One of the reasons why the European Parliament voted against was that mon-øøø21-9 maize described in this application produces the protein mEPSPS, which confers resistance to glyphosate herbicides, while on 20 March 2015 the International Agency for Research on Cancer classified glyphosate as a possible carcinogen in humans. In view of the above, and in view of the fact that the Commission's proposal is not in line with Union law, in particular Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the Parliament and of the Council, the amendments of which proposed on the commission's proposal were refused by Parliament in October 2015, it was also not possible to vote in favour of the Commission proposal this time, so I voted in favour of the EP's rejection decision.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In March 2012, the International Agency for Research on Cancer included glyphosate among substances with a probable cancer-forming effect on humans. This substance also occurs in genetically modified maize. I therefore support the proposal for the Commission to withdraw its proposal for an implementing regulation authorising the placing on the market of this maize. By doing so, the Commission exceeds its implementing powers as set out in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Motion for a Resolution on the draft implementing decision of the Committee of XXXX approving the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified maize Bt11 × MIR162 × MIR604 × GA21, and genetically modified maize with a combination of two or three rows from Bt11, MIR162, MIR604 and GA21, and repealing Decisions 2010/426/EU, 2011/893/EU, 2011/892/EU and 2011/894/EU because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution.  This authorization is only an extension of a marketing authorization already granted. The extension request received a favourable opinion from EFSA in 2015. However, it would appear that some combinations of this genetically modified maize would be tolerant to glyphosate and glufosinate.  The lack of an alternative solution requires at least a transition period before a possible ban on glyphosate. However, its health risks have now been proven and the introduction of a GMO resistant to this substance does not appear desirable for this reason.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This motion for a resolution deals with the combinations of maize varieties which have already been genetically modified. It is right to explain that the Commission has exceeded its powers. It also calls for the repeal of the decisions already taken to authorise various combinations of genetically modified genetically modified maize varieties which have already been approved. I can only agree with this very accurate analysis.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The aim here is to oppose the Commission's decision to authornity for the marketing of genetically modified maize in the EU. The GMO maize examined here has been modified to tolerate glufosinate ammonium-based herbicides. This has the effect of allowing greater use of these herbicides at all stages of the plant, thus increasing the risk of residues in human food. These maizes have been approved by EFSA, a monitoring body that has already demonstrated its incompetence and submission to lobbyists. I am voting for this text which opposes this authorization.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. While the use of glyphosate may be fully tolerated as there are not enough commercial alternatives for farmers and the sector needs a transition period before a final ban, the development of a glyphosate-resistant GMO is unsavory given the health risks. That is why I voted in favour of this objection.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution asking the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I choose to support this objection as it is essential that the Council does not overstep its powers by introducing legislation without the opinions or feedback of Member States.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Sygenta France SAS has submitted an application to the competent authorities of Germany for the placing on the market of food, food supplements and feed containing or consisting of or produced from Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21 maize (and their sub-combinations). The request also included the placing on the market of GM maize in products for purposes other than food and feed, with the exception of cultivation. Following a favourable opinion from EFSA, the Commission has drawn up a draft decision allowing products consisting of or produced from or containing those genetically modified maize. The Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health has not delivered an opinion on the Commission proposal in question. Attention should be drawn to the fact that some of the genetically modified maizes tolerate ammonium glufosinate and glyphosate-based herbicides, while the International Agency for Research on Cancer has listed glyphosate as a substance possibly carcinogenic to humans. Furthermore, the use of any new GM food or feed should not be allowed, taking into account the current lack of legal framework. I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers that are laid down and that the Commission should withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that herbicide resistant GMOs should not be authorised since they could encourage the increase use of herbicides, and the wider health and environmental implications of this has not been taken into account. That is why I have objected to the Commission’s decision to authorise on the market products consisting of genetically-modified maize, especially when we are dealing with maize that is tolerant to certain including glyphosate.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 16 December 2015, the General Court of the European Union delivered a judgment in Case T-521/14. Sweden v Commission. In its judgment, the General Court ruled that the Commission had a clear, precise and unconditional obligation, under Regulation (EU) No 528/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 May 2012 on the marketing and use of biocidal products, to adopt delegated acts laying down the scientific criteria for the endocrine disrupting properties of active substances and biocidal products by 13 December 2013 at the latest. Failing to do so, the Commission, in accordance with the judgment of the General Court, breached EU law.  For this reason, the EFN, GUE/NGL, EFDD, ALDE political groups are autonomous and the S&D and Verts/ALE, as well as the PPE and ECR political groups, have submitted joint draft resolutions. Among them, S&D, GUE/NGL, EFDD and ALDE reached an agreement and drafted a joint compromise motion condemning the Commission and calling for the failure to be replaced without delay, which was joined by the PPE and Verts/ALE Groups. By my vote, I supported the compromise motion.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This objection follows the decision to allow the cultivation of GMO maize Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21. Although we tolerate the use of glyphosate as part of a transition to substitution, we consider the health risks associated with the development of GMOs resistant to this herbicide, suspected to be carcinogenic by the International Agency for Research on Cancer, to be too great. We therefore support this objection.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on genetically modified food and feed regulates in accordance with Article 5 thereof the procedure for the application for authorisation necessary for the placing on the market of a genetically modified organism intended for human food or a food. Pursuant to that provision, the application for authorisation may be accompanied by an opinion of the committees of the respective Member States; however, according to the European Commission, the decisions adopted by it since the entry into force of that Regulation have been made without the support of opinions, and the return of the procedure to the Commission has become a standard rather than an exception. I therefore vote in favour, because I believe that this implementing decision of the European Commission goes beyond the powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, so that the Commission should withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The development of a glyphosate-resistant GMO is unsavory in light of health risks. I'm voting for that objection.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion to object to the Commission’s draft authorisation decisions because GM maize Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21 was engineered to confer resistance to the European corn borer and the western rootworm, however it is also resistant to glyphosate and other herbicides. All these four different genes come in one variety and as such are non-separable.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to the authorisation of GMO maize, which is the responsibility of the Member States or not, because it is based on the false argument that the Commission has exceeded its powers by authorising this maize. Indeed, the Commission has fully complied with the procedure by asking the European Food Safety Authority for a study on the safety of the plant for human and animal health and for the environment. It then proposed this GMO authorization to the Council, which did not refuse it.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the proposal voted on, we asked the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision. One of the reasons why I have decided to withdraw is that the herbicide glyphosate was classified by the International Agency for Research on Cancer a year ago as a 'possibly carcinogenic' to humans. Glyphosate can be harmful to health and should therefore be restricted in its use. I believe that, in addition to the security of long-term food supply and the EU's strategic objectives, we must also take into account the views of the public and domestic producers on GM food.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that authorizes the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically-modified maize Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21 following a risk evaluation to human health and biodiversity.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because the rapporteur rightly states that the Commission is always releasing new combinations of genetically modified maize varieties, thereby exceeding competences. It also calls for the repeal of the decisions already taken to authorise various combinations of genetically modified genetically modified maize varieties that have already been approved.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. Does not consider it necessary to adjust separately. It would be more effective to reform the whole system of regulating the market for GM Products.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's draft authorisation concerns the introduction into trade of products containing, consisting of or obtained from genetically modified maize, resistant to two pesticides with active ingredients based on glufosinate and glyphosate. It should be remembered that, despite differing views on the subject, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), part of the World Health Organisation (WHO), has classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans.  Opposition to this and other GMO authorisations issued by the Commission without the support of a majority, either from the Member States or from the European Parliament, is intended to be a form of protest against the current authorisation system and an invitation to the Commission to suspend the decision in the event that the Technical Committee does not issue a majority opinion. I am therefore also opposed to this authorisation pending a substantial democratic change in the current system of authorisation of GMOs.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i supported the objection because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision exceeded the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003. The Standing Committee of Representatives of the Member States has not delivered an opinion on the commission's draft implementing decision and the Commission should therefore withdraw the draft implementing decision authorising genetically modified maize. I also do not recognise GMO as part of the solution to the problems facing the agricultural and food sectors.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the objection to the approval of GMO maize Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21, including because the new variety expresses a protein that causes tolerance to glyphosate herbicides, which means that it achieves its advantage on the market only in combination with the application of herbicides based on the active substance glyphosate. On March 20, 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, which acts as a World Health Organization agency specializing in cancer, placed glyphosate in the category of substances likely to be carcinogenic to humans due to the higher risk of farmers being exposed to the pesticide.  In my view, that approval of the Commission's implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013. 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and the Council since 22 September 2003 on genetically modified food and feed and I ask the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The development of a glyphosate-resistant GMO is unsavory in light of health risks. It would be better to do without glyphosate and develop alternatives to these products whose harmfulness is shown every day more. I'm voting for that objection.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒in 2012, the European Union defined in its GM Food Regulation, which rejects all carcinogenic substances used in GMO foods, the rules of general principles relating to GMOs. In 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, which acts as a World Health Organization agency specializing in cancer, placed glyphosate in the carcinogenic substance category. Accordingly, the Commission complains about the decision to authorize the marketing of products containing genetically modified organisms in maize.  I support this objection in accordance with Article 106 for the Commission to withdraw its decision.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I must stress that I am generally sceptical about the issue of GMOs. This also applies to the material under discussion. Nevertheless, in this particular case, I accepted the Commission's argument and supported its position.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, considering that on 22 April 2015 the Commission regretted, in the explanaming memorandum to its legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, whereas, since the entry into force of this Regulation, authorisation decisions have been adopted by the Commission, in accordance with applicable legislation, without the support of opinions of Committees of the Member States, and that the return of the procedure to the Commission for final decision, which should truly constitute an exception in the whole procedure, has become the standard for decision-making on authorisations relating to genetically modified food and feed. It should therefore be considered that the Commission's draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2. The Commission should then be asked to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I have once again objected to the current GMO authorisation process in the EU by supporting the objection to the introduction of new genetically modified maize varieties. The aim is to send a clear message to the Commission to review this undemocratic system, with each authorisation decision adopted by the Commission without the support of a qualified majority of the Member States and ignoring the opinion of this House.  Moreover, the precautionary principle here is justified given the tolerance of the maize in question to herbicides containing glyphosate, a substance which I believe should be banned as soon as possible. More generally, it is time for Europe to promote sustainable use of herbicides. We were told that GMOs would allow us to perform better and use fewer products, but in reality the opposite is true: many GMO seeds are now sold with their herbicide, leading to increasing herbicide spraying and, de facto, increased weed resistance to these substances. It is time to put an end to this vicious cycle and find more environmentally and health-friendly alternatives.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I ask the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to this implementing act by which the European Commission authorises Syngenta to market products containing, are composed or produced from GM maize Bt11 × MIR162 × MIR604 × GA21, and genetically modified maíces that combine two or three of the Bt11, MIR162, MIR604 and GA21 events. This authorisation from the Commission exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on genetically modified food and feed. In particular, some of the gm maíces in question confer tolerance to ammonium glufosinate and glyphosate-based herbicides, which could lead to increased use of these herbicides. For these reasons, I have supported the objection.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this European Parliament resolution which aims to oppose the Commission's draft enforcement decision authorising the marketing of products containing genetically modified maize Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21, or genetically modified maize combining two or three of the Bt11, MIR162, MIR604 and GA21 events, products consisting of these maize or produced from them. The resolution recalls that on 20 March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, a specialized agency of the World Health Organization for cancer research, classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans. Of course, it is important to allow our farmers to find a sustainable economic alternative, just as it is necessary to stop the use of this product. Finally, I will continue to highlight the benefits of local agriculture and promoting short circuits with fresh products that have beneficial effects on our health while respecting the environment.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has forwarded to us syngenta's request to allow the EU to grow four types of maize, which are essentially genetically modified products. At the same time, we do not have any information on the long-term effects of such maize on the human body. I am therefore convinced that we must unequivocally say 'no' to such a request. Europe is not a place for genetically modified food!

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Since 22 April 2015, in the explana motion for its legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, the Commission regretted that since the entry into force of that regulation, authorisation decisions for the use of certain substances have been taken by the Commission, in accordance with the applicable legislation, without the support of the opinions of the committees of the Member States, and that the return of the dossier to the Commission for the adoption of the final decision, which was truly an exception in the context of the procedure as a whole, has become the norm when taking decisions on authorisations for genetically modified food and feed. We consider that the Commission's draft Implementing Decision exceeds its powers. As described in the application, the genetically modified maize MON-A21-9 expresses the cry1Ab protein, which gives it protection against certain lepidoptera pests, and the mEPSPS protein, which gives tolerance to herbicides composed of glyphosate. The International Cancer Research Centre (WHO) classified glyphosate as a likely carcinogenic agent for humans.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection, because I am totally against genetically modified organisms, and therefore new authorisations thereof. The more the decision-making process for GMO authorisations for food and feed is not being democratic. The special committee almost never reaches a qualified majority, however, the European Commission is almost always issuing authorisations, without the support of Member States or most EU citizens. This should be the exception, but with GMOs, now it's the rule. In addition, this maize is tolerant of glyphosate, which makes its authorisation very premature when a qualified majority of the Member States cannot even agree on the reauthorisation of this herbicide — possible carcinogen and endocrine disruptor.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 voted in favour of adopting this resolution. I consider it right that the European Parliament's request that the European Commission withdraw the implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing the GM maize in question should be implemented. Scientific studies submitted to parliament classified this maize as, inter alia, 'probably carcinogenic'.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Back in 2009, Sygenta France SAS submitted an application to the German authorities for the placing on the market of food, food ingredients and feed composed of or produced from specific GENETICALLY MODIFIED MAIZE. This application was extended in 2013 to include all sub-combinations of individual modifications constituting this maize. Certain parts of this maize are expressed by the mEPSPS protein, which gives it tolerance to glyphosate-based herbicides. Later, after this application, in 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer included glyphosate among the substances with a probable cancer-forming effect on humans. Moreover, in its explanatory memorandum of 2015, the Commission regretted that it had taken authorisation decisions without supporting the opinions of Member States' committees and that the return of the dossier for a final decision had become the norm for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed. I therefore share the rapporteur's view that the Commission's proposal goes beyond implementing powers, and I support Parliament's motion for a resolution asking the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this resolution proposal because CORN MON-ØØ21-9 expresses the Cry1Ab protein, which provides protection against certain lepidoptera pests and the mEPSPS protein that causes tolerance to herbicides with glyphosate. The International Agency for Research on Cancer, which acts as a World Health Organization agency specializing in cancer, has placed glyphosate in the category of substances that are likely carcinogenic to humans.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. On 9 February 2009, the competent authority in Germany submitted an application to the competent authority in accordance with Articles 5 and 17. Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013 1829/2003 requesting authorisation for the marketing of food, food and feed containing maize Bt11 × MIR162 × MIR604 × GA21, consist or are manufactured from it. July 5th, 2013. Syngenta has extended the scope of application to all subcombinations of individual genetic modifications involving Bt11 maize × MIR162 × MIR604 × GA21 ("subcombinations"), including Bt11 × GA21 maize, MIR604 corn × GA21, maize Bt11 × MIR604 and maize Bt11 × MIR604 × GA21. Corn MON-ØØØ21-9 expresses the Cry1Ab protein, which provides protection against certain pests from the lepidoptera order and the protein mEPSPS that causes tolerance to herbicides with glyphosate.  The International Agency for Research on Cancer, which acts as a World Health Organization agency specializing in cancer, has placed glyphosate in the category of substances that are likely carcinogenic to humans. In this case, the Commission overstepped its powers as it took the decision to issue an authorisation without support in the form of an opinion of the Committees of the Member States. I support the motion for a Resolution, as I consider that the Commission's decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013. 1829/2003.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted against the resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified maize Bt11 × MIR162 × MIR604 × GA21. I cannot agree that the Commission's draft implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers laid down in the Regulation, so I see no reason for the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision. As regards glyphosate, the International Agency for Research on Cancer has classified as substances likely to be carcinogenic to humans. All research in this area should be considered, for example, as EFSA wrote last year on glyphosate that it is difficult to establish a link between glyphosate and the risk of cancer in humans.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the objection to the authorisation of genetically modified maize, taking into account the need to safeguard the interests of consumers, to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health and to protect the environment.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The commission's draft implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EU) No 1782/2003. 1829/2003.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU GMO authorisation system is based on the precautionary principle. Accordingly, the safety of gm products should be ascertained before authorisation. Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21 maize, formed by a combination of single lines, is resistant to herbicides containing glufosizinate ammonium and glyphosate and a number of pest insects of the order Lepidoptera and Coleoptera. During the cultivation of the GMO maize in question, increased use of plant protection products with this active substance may occur, which may later increase the level of residues in the crop. The herbicide glyphosate was classified as a "likely human carcinogen" by the WHO in 2015. Its high use also increases the appearance of a resistant weed population.  According to domestic experts, studies on the health safety of the product are unsatisfactory. Longer-term feeding trials should also have been carried out in order to determine whether these products do not pose a risk to human or animal health.  In line with hungary's GMO-free strategy, the Basic Law and the precautionary principle, we do not support the authorisation of GM products, so I voted in favour of parliament's objection to the placing on the EU market of BT11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21 GM maize.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution rejecting × the placing on the market of genetically modified products containing, consisting of or produced × GM604 × GA21 and genetically modified maize combining two or three of the genetic events Bt11, MIR162, MIR604 and GA21.  The motion for a resolution was necessary because, on 9 February 2009, Syngenta France S.A.S. submitted to the competent authority of Germany an application for the placing on the market of foodstuffs, food ingredients and feedingstuffs containing, consisting of or produced from the abovementioned maize. As described in the application, maize contains proteins to protect against certain pests in the order Lepidoptera or Coleoptera, which provide resistance to herbicides containing gluphosine-ammonium or glyphosate.  However, these substances have been placed in the suspected carcinogenic group by the International Agency for Research on Cancer , the WHO Agency for Cancer. I believe that the current system of approval for genetically modified food and feed is not working properly and that correcting it is essential.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. YES, the Commission's draft enforcement decision exceeds the enforcement powers set out in Regulation (EC) 1829/2003. YES, we call on the Commission to immediately withdraw its draft enforcement decision!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this motion which objects to the authorisation of genetically-modified maize Bt11 × MIR162 × MIR604 × GA21, and genetically-modified maizes combining two or three of the events Bt11, MIR162, MIR604 and GA21) for which the company Syngenta France SAS had submitted an application for marketing in February 2009. This resolution called for a withdrawal of this decision citing as reason that the COM exceeded its implementing powers provided for in the GM Regulation 1829/2003 when it has to continuously take a decision after the Member States delivered a non-opinion. I do not believe that systematically opposing GM authorisations on mainly procedural grounds is the right way of forcing the Commission to change the EU level authorisation regime.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the objection to the Commission's implementing decision to authorize the marketing of products containing GM maize, consist or are manufactured from it, as I believe this will protect human life and health.  In addition, some Member States explicitly oppose the marketing of GM products and the European Parliament has not given authorisation to place such products on the market. Each Member State should decide for itself whether it wishes to introduce GENETICally modified products on its market, and the same applies to the gm maize subject to this complaint.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the authorisation of genetically modified maize Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21. Syn-BTØ11-1 genetically modified maize contains a protein that protects against certain harmful species of butterflies, as well as several proteins that allow resistance to ammonium glufosinate herbicides and herbicide-based herbicides. It is intolerable for the European Commission to decide on the import of genetically modified maize without the consent of most Member States.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Since 22 April 2015, in the explana motion for its legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, the Commission regretted that since the entry into force of that regulation, authorisation decisions for the use of certain substances have been taken by the Commission, in accordance with the applicable legislation, without the support of the opinions of the committees of the Member States, and that the return of the dossier to the Commission for the adoption of the final decision, which was truly an exception in the context of the procedure as a whole, has become the norm when taking decisions on authorisations for genetically modified food and feed. We consider that the Commission's draft Implementing Decision exceeds its powers. As described in the application, the genetically modified maize MON-A21-9 expresses the cry1Ab protein, which gives it protection against certain lepidoptera pests, and the mEPSPS protein, which gives tolerance to herbicides composed of glyphosate. The International Cancer Research Centre (WHO) classified glyphosate as a likely carcinogenic agent for humans.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I was against the vote. I do not agree with the EU-wide ban on placing on the market for these crops, as there is no scientific evidence of negative effects on human, animal or environmental health. Decisions on this matter must remain with the Member States.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Permission to market products and foodstuffs containing this GMO had already been granted. This authorization, however, excluded the cultivation of this GMO. In 2013, the applicant company requested the extension of this authorization to all sub-combinations of genetic modification. EFSA gave a favourable opinion in 2015 by affirming the safety of this genetically modified maize. In particular, it is argued in this objection that certain combinations of genetically modified maize are tolerant to glufosinate (and its ammonium salt) and glyphosate-based herbicides. However, some commercial formulations of glyphosate that contain adjuvants are "probably carcinogenic" according to the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC). While the use of glyphosate may be fully tolerated as there are not enough commercial alternatives for farmers and the sector needs a transition period before its final ban, the development of a glyphosate-resistant GMO is unsavory in light of health risks. So I vote FOR this objection.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Genetically modified foods should be subject to a thorough review of the impact on human health and the environment. Any legislation adopted in this matter should be duly observed. However, the Commission exceeded its implementing powers contained in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 September 2003 on genetically modified food and feed. I therefore supported the motion for a resolution calling on the Commission to withdraw the draft decision.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 2009. On 9 February 2003, Syngenta France S.A.S. submitted to the competent authority of Germany, in accordance with Articles 5 and 17 of Regulation (EC) × No 1829/2003, an application for the placing on the market of foodstuffs, food ingredients and feedingstuffs containing, × consisting of or produced from × × GA21 maize. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Since 22 April 2015, in the explana motion for its legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, the Commission regretted that since the entry into force of that regulation, authorisation decisions for the use of certain substances have been taken by the Commission, in accordance with the applicable legislation, without the support of the opinions of the committees of the Member States, and that the return of the dossier to the Commission for the adoption of the final decision, which was truly an exception in the context of the procedure as a whole, has become the norm when taking decisions on authorisations for genetically modified food and feed. We consider that the Commission's draft Implementing Decision exceeds its powers. As described in the application, the genetically modified maize MON-A21-9 expresses the cry1Ab protein, which gives it protection against certain lepidoptera pests, and the mEPSPS protein, which gives tolerance to herbicides composed of glyphosate. The International Cancer Research Centre (WHO) classified glyphosate as a likely carcinogenic agent for humans.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Voted in favour of objection as this GMO is glyphosate resistant, like the three GM soybeans the EP objected to earlier this year and for which the authorisation is still being delayed by the EC.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – I have always advocated that Latvia and the European Union as a whole be free from genetically modified organisms (GMOs). We must not allow the health of our citizens to be put at risk in the interests of any economic interest. It is regrettable that this is another time when the European Commission, contrary to the member states' position, has given the green light to the placing on the market of new GMOs, using the powers conferred by its legislation. GMO maize is resistant to glyphosate, classified by the International Agency for Research on Cancer, which specializes in cancer research, as a possible carcinogen for humans. This time, the EC not only failed to take into account national concerns about the harmfulness of GMOs, but also ignored the world health organisation agency's research into glyphosate as a potentially carcinogenic substance. In view of the studies carried out by the World Health Organisation Agency on glyphosate and the negative attitude of The Latvian public towards GMOs, I voted in favour of repealing the Commission decision authorising the placing on the market of this GMO maize. Furthermore, I believe that the existing legislative procedure should be changed in order to give both the European Parliament and the states greater decision-making rights when authorising the placing on the market of new GMOs, thereby ensuring more effective democratic control and public interest.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically-modified maize Bt11 × MIR162 × MIR604 × GA21, and genetically modified maizes combining two or three of the events Bt11, MIR162, MIR604 and GA21, and repealing Decisions 2010/426/EU, 2011/893/EU, 2011/892/EU and 2011/894/EU. I voted in favour because the resolution emphasises that while some of those GM events confer tolerance to certain pests, MON-ØØØ21-9 maize is resistant to glyphosate herbicide, which is classified as ‘probably carcinogenic’ to humans by the WHO’s specialised cancer agency.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Commission has proposed to authorise the importation and marketing of GMO carns and maize on the European market. The European Parliament has proposed two resolutions to oppose these authorisations. With regard to GMO maize, the Commission wants to allow maize resistant to glyphosate, a herbicide classified as a probable carcinogen by the International Agency for Research for Cancer. The importation of these genetically modified maize would then encourage the use of a product that is dangerous to health. GMO carns are resistant to sulfonylureas, herbicides that are toxic to plants and therefore pose a risk to biodiversity when disseminated on a large scale. In addition, some populations consume pilled petals voluntarily and EFSA has not yet assessed the health consequences of the consumption of genetically modified eyebts. Finally, the authorisation of GMOs divides the Member States, which are un able to agree by qualified majority. Parliament therefore considers that the Commission has exceeded its enforcement powers by proposing the authorisation of these GMOs I agree and strongly oppose most GMOs. I therefore voted in favour of these resolutions.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We consider that the draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on genetically modified food and feed and should be withdrawn by the Commission. Since the entry into force of this Regulation, authorisation decisions have been adopted by the Commission, as member states' committees have not given their opinion for lack of consensus; the decision was always due to the exception in the legislation resending to the Commission the final decision in these cases, and the exception became the rule for decision-making on authorisations for genetically modified food and feed.  In addition, all this procedural imbroglio challenges both the impartiality of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and the entire process of authorising herbicides in relation to glyphosate. This is because the maize concerned is resistant to both ammonia glyphosinate and glyphosate, it may mean a greater concentration in the final product intended for feeding.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I can vote in favour of the motion for a resolution. On the one hand, the rapporteur rightly states that the Commission is always releasing new combinations of genetically modified maize varieties, thereby exceeding its competences. In addition, the decisions already taken to authorise various combinations of genetically modified genetically modified maize varieties are to be repealed.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted against this resolution for the following reasons. EFSA has delivered a clear opinion on this new GM crop, stating that it is as safe as its non-GM counterpart. It has concluded that this is the case for the GM’s impact on human health, animal health and the environment. The EFSA is a trustworthy agency that enjoys my strong support. If it has concluded that it is safe, I do not see a reason for not allowing these products on our markets.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Juncker promised in the election campaign to democratise the process of marketing GMOs. Transgenic carnation, specifically, is a potentially dangerous product for human health and the scientific community has not yet given a unanimous opinion. That is why I voted in favour of the objection.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection, because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and therefore new authorisations thereof. The higher, this transgenic carnation presents a high risk of field propagation and should only be approved with that criterion. Moreover, the decision-making process concerning GMO authorisations for food and feed is not being democratic. The special committee almost never reaches a qualified majority, however, the European Commission is almost always issuing authorisations, without the support of Member States or most EU citizens. This should be the exception, but with GMOs, now it's the rule.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the decision to apply the marketing authorization for genetically modified carnions covering the importation, distribution and retailing of this flower.  However, on the basis of two scientific opinions, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) concluded that the use of this sugar posed no danger to human health and the environment. However, it turns out that the development of this plant is conditional on exposure to sulfonylurea-based herbicides, the use of which is harmful to the environment. Furthermore, the risks associated with the spread of pollen from this plant were not taken into account in the EFSA report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I objected to this act of application by the European Commission proposing to allow the importation and sale in the European Union of GMO decorative carnies cut SHD-27531-4, resistant to sulfonylurea herbicides. Sulfonylureas, which are a common second-line option for type 2 diabetes, are also used as a herbicide, and are highly toxic to very low-dose plants. For example, the creation of a market for sulfonylurea-resistant plants will encourage the use of this diabetes drug as a global herbicide, at the risk of a global negative impact on biodiversity and chemical contamination of drinking water.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection under Article 106 to the placing on the market of genetically modified carnations, because GMOs resistant should not be authorised, as this could lead to an increase in the use of such substances.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. With this resolution, the European Parliament rejects a Commission decision to place a GMO carnation variety on the EU-wide market. Since I reject GMO foods because of the unknown long-term consequences, I fully support this resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. In March 2013, the notification of a genetically modified carnity was sent to the Dutch competent authority for the application to market a genetically modified carn carnity in the Netherlands. This request covers the importation, distribution and sale of cut flowers of this carny for decorative use. Some Member States, such as Cyprus, have opposed this marketing. EFSA then produced two scientific opinions concluding that there was no scientific reason to consider that the use of this because is possible to have negative effects on human health or the environment. MEPs objected to the decision, saying that the objectives of protecting the environment and human health were not being met. The risk would be related to the intentional consumption of these GMO products, which has not been assessed by EFSA. The spread of pollen from this plant should be taken into account. Furthermore, according to EFSA, plants of SHD-27531-4 that would grow in the environment could only express their improved characteristics by being exposed to sulfonylurea-based herbicides whose use would have a negative impact on the development of other plants. In order to preserve the health of my fellow citizens, I supported this objection.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the interest of democracy and transparency I wish to confirm I abstained. It shows how the EU wants to legislate for everything including trivial matters such as carnations. I abstained on the grounds that any other vote accepts EU competence on these matters.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection to prohibit the importation and marketing of a herbicide-resistant carny. Its use could have adverse effects on users and consumers.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. March 2013 Suntory Holdings Limited (Osaka, Japan) submitted a notification to the competent dutch authority concerning the placing on the market of genetically modified carnations. As the EP considers that the draft Commission implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers set, I support the request for the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementation decision authorising the marketing of a genetically modified carn is not in place because it does not meet the health and environmental objectives of the 2001/18/EC directive.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this administrative objection, since in nature, the cross-pollination of Dianthus spp., is carried out by pollinating insects, in particular lepidoptera; EFSA's Technical Commission on GMOs considers that the risk of lepidoptera transferring pollen from the genetically modified carnast SHD-27531-4 to Wild Species of Dianthus cannot be eliminated. In turn, in its opinion, EFSA states that the Technical Commission on GMOs is aware that in some populations there is a food habit of intentionally consuming clavel petals as a garnish, and that the Commission has not assessed the consequences of intentional human consumption of genetically modified keyials. The genetically modified clavel contains the SuRB gene (ALS) that encodes a mutant cumtase acetolactate (ALS) protein derived from Nicotiana tabacum, which confers resistance to sulphonylureas. According to PAN UK, 'certain herbicides, such as sulphonylureas, sulfonamides and imidazolinens, have, in very low doses, high plant toxicity'. Experts have warned that widespread use of sulphonylureas "could have devastating effects on non-target crop productivity and the composition of phytocenosis and trófic chains."

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report issued in this case by the ENVI Parliamentary Committee, which considers that this draft decision implementing the committee exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1892/2003 and I am therefore in favour of the committee withdrawing it.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution still concerns an objection under Article 106 to the marketing of a genetically modified carnation (Dianthus caryophyllus L., SHD-27531-4). In March 2013, the notification of a genetically modified carn carny was sent to the Dutch competent authority. This request covers the importation, distribution and retailing of flowers cut from this carnity for decorative use only. Some states objected to this marketing, but after two EFSA studies showing no risk, the Commission decided to authorised it. The objection is still based on the argument that the act exceeds the Commission's powers by failing to meet the environmental and human health protection objectives set out in Directive 2001/18/EC. I have therefore decided to support the objection in view of the doubts and risks that remain.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the objection to the marketing authorisation of a genetically modified carnation (Dianthus caryophyllus L., line SHD-27531-4)

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to this implementing act, by which the European Commission authorises the Japanese company Suntory Holdings Limited to introduce to the market the genetically modified caryophyllus L. caryophyllus car car caryophyllus L., line SHD-27531-4, in the Netherlands.  This key is resistant to sulphonylurea. These herbicides, according to the British Herbicide Action Network (PAN), were highly toxic to plants at very low doses, and their widespread use could have a negative impact on the productivity of other crops and on the composition of natural plant communities and wild food chains. Finally, sulphonylureas are common treatments for the treatment of type 2 diabetes and are associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease compared to other antidiabetic drugs. The creation of a market for sulphonylurea-resistant plants will encourage the worldwide use of this antidiabetic drug as a herbicide, with potential harmful effects on biodiversity and chemical contamination of drinking water, so I have supported the objection.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it is in favour of Parliament's implementing decision on the placing on the market of genetically modified carnations. In 2013, Suntory Holdings Limited (Osaka, Japan) submitted a notification to the competent Dutch authority concerning the placing on the market of genetically modified carnations. The notification shall include the import, distribution and retail sale within the Union of cut line genetically modified carnations intended solely for decorative use. The Regulatory Committee did not deliver an opinion, and seven Member States (representing 7.84% of the population) voted against the draft Commission implementing decision, six Member States (representing 46.26 % of the population) abstained, eleven Member States (representing 36.29% of the population) supported it and four Member States were not represented. The EFSA opinion also states that efsa is aware of the eating habits of certain groups of the population when the petals of carnations used for garnish are deliberately used. For these reasons, Parliament considers that the draft Commission implementing decision does not meet the health and environmental objective of Directive 2001/18/EC and therefore exceeds the implementing powers laid down in this Directive and asks the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I voted for this complaint because I believe that the current GMO approval system in the EU needs to be changed. At issue is a political message to the Commission, which gave sales and import authorisation under the GMO food directive, which Parliament considers undemocratic.  For five years, Member States could not agree on granting or refusing a GMO carnation licence. In such a situation, the Commission has the right under the existing rules to act as it deems necessary. While the decision is legal, it is not democratic. The problem the European Union has with GMO will not be solved on its own nor is the status quo sustainable. It should be accepted that most Member States are against GMO, but some countries want it.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The objection raised by some MEPs against this act is based on the argument that the act exceeds the Commission's powers by failing to fulfil the objectives of environmental protection and human health defined by Directive 2001/18/EC. The risk would be related to the consumption of these GMO products, which has not been assessed by EFSA. The spread of pollen from this plant should be taken into account. Furthermore, according to EFSA, SDS-27531-4 plants that would grow in the environment could only express their improved characteristics by being exposed to sulfonylurea-based herbicides. However, the use of this type of herbicide could have a negative impact on the development of other plants. As I was in favour of the precautionary principle of GMOs, I voted in favour of this objection.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The widespread use of GMO products is, due to the risk of significant adverse effects on natural ecosystems and human health resulting from their use, a practical source of great concern which I believe needs to be limited in greater order. The gradual and increasing use of GMO crops is in fact the cause of an increase in the use of herbicides (such as glyphosate or glufosinate) which seriously undermine the delicate natural biological balance, while at the same time threatening the human health of consumers. Several authoritative studies have highlighted the high risk of carcinogenicity as a result of the use of many herbicides (including glyphosate), a risk that increases significantly in the event of the cultivation of GMO products. I therefore believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified maize and carnation must be vigorously opposed. A project which, as mr Bart States' objection points out, also risks exceeding the implementing powers reserved by the Commission provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2013 and of not meeting the objective of protecting health and the environment laid down in Directive 2001/18/EC.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This objection is intended to oppose the decision to enforce the marketing authorization for genetically modified carns covering the importation, distribution and retail sale of this flower. However, on the basis of two scientific opinions, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) concluded that the use of this sugar posed no danger to human health and the environment. However, it turns out that the development of this plant is conditional on exposure to sulfonylurea-based herbicides, the use of which is harmful to the environment. Furthermore, the risks associated with the spread of pollen from this plant were not taken into account in the EFSA report. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this objection.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, I voted in favour of this objection calling on the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing act authorising the placing on the market of a particular type of genetically modified carnation. I believe, in fact, that the precautionary principle must always prevail when environmental protection is at stake. EFSA's studies state that the potential propagation of pollen by lepidoptane of this particular type of carnation cannot be ruled out and that its stems cut with vegetative shoots can spread into the environment by rooting or micropropagation. In addition, once their ornamental function is over, genetically modified carnations become waste which, in accordance with the principles of the circular economy, can be disposed of by composting and used as fertilizers. In the light of all these factors, I felt it appropriate to oppose the placing on the market of this carnation.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I objected to the placing on the market of a genetically modified carnation, as while there is high risk of propagation as different carnation varieties are found everywhere in Europe, EFSA did not evaluate it. Moreover the specific GM variety needs, in order to be ‘in a good shape’ a specific herbicide, which contains as a main substance, sulfonylurea, which is used in antidiabetes drugs.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report that proposes the Commission to withdraw the approval of the sales of genetically-modified carnation. The reason is that previous authorisation fails to consider the potential negative long-term impact on the environment and public health.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The authorisation in question concerns the marketing of a transgenic carnation intended for sale. Although many of the reasons for opposing the risks posed by GMOs are lacking in this case, since they are cut flowers and are not intended for food, the request not to authorise the product remains a form of protest to the current authorisation system. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We vote against as we consider that the Commission's draft implementing decision does not achieve the objective of protecting health and the environment provided for in Directive 2001/18/EC and therefore goes beyond the implementing powers provided for in that Directive.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's vote on the article 106 objection to the placing on the market of genetically modified carnation concerns issues relating to the protection of the health of European citizens. In this case too, we must be very careful when it comes to approving the movement of substances that may pose a risk to citizens' health. That is why I voted in favour of the objection.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the trade in genetically modified carnations must be stopped. This trade severely penalises the main carnation-producing countries such as Italy and France. I do not think that this trade is right and that it seriously threatens small producers. They would find unfair competition because producers of GMO carnations can benefit from high production at a much lower cost than the small businessman. Carcinogens have also been found in the genetically modified carnation which could cause problems for humans and animals if there is intentional or accidental consumption.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I disagreed with this resolution which called on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection, because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and therefore new authorisations thereof. The higher, this transgenic carnation presents a high risk of field propagation and should only be approved with that criterion. Moreover, the decision-making process concerning GMO authorisations for food and feed is not being democratic. The special committee almost never reaches a qualified majority, however, the European Commission is almost always issuing authorisations, without the support of Member States or most EU citizens. This should be the exception, but with GMOs, now it's the rule.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In their resolution, the opposing parties claim that the implementing decision concerning a genetically modified carnation is incompatible with the health and environmental objectives enshrined in Directive 2001/18/EC and therefore constitutes an exceedance of implementing powers. The explanatory memorandum states that EFSA has not assessed the possible consequences of deliberate human consumption of genetically modified clove (e.g. as a decorative element), and draws attention to concerns about the spread of its pollen and resistance to sulfonylurea herbicides. With this in mind, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I object to the Commission decision since the decision making process concerning the authorisation of GMOS is not a democratic process. The special committee rarely reaches a qualified majority but nonetheless the European Commission moves on with the authorisation and many times without the support of the Member States or the majority of the EU citizens.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU GMO authorisation system is based on the precautionary principle. We cannot support the authorisation of GMOs which can spread across wild, related species in certain areas, even if they do not live in Hungary but in southern Europe. We believe that although there is little chance of viable pollen and seeds being released into the environment for cut flowers, this path cannot be completely ruled out. However, sulfonyl-urea herbicide tolerance can significantly increase the survival and reproduction of GM carnations in the natural environment when released, at a disadvantage to wild close-up species. It is also not possible to completely exclude the possibility of horizontal gene transfer between GM carnations and bacteria found in the environment. On this basis, in line with hungary's GMO-free strategy, the Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I voted in favour of parliament's objection to the placing of GM carnations on the EU market.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA did not support the objection to the placing on the market of a genetically modified carnation and maize. The approval procedure for GMOs is strict. The EFSA risk assessment plays a crucial role in this. The N-VA strongly believes in scientifically based and "evidence-based" policies.  Moreover, the European Commission has not exceeded its mandate in this executive action: if the Member States do not achieve a qualified majority, the European Commission is authorised to approve GMOs on the basis of a positive opinion from EFSA. With regard to glyphosate, it is noted that there is no scientific consensus. I recognise the concerns about glyphosate and call for the discussion on this controversial substance to be further and further deseeded.  It remains important to distinguish between GMO technology and application. It is also clear that the (possible) use of GMOs should always be part of an agricultural policy that integrates the protection of public health, the environment and biodiversity, with integrated pest management (integrated pest management) essential for the sustainable use of pesticides and non-chemical alternatives.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Currently, genetically modified organisms (GMOs) can be grown on the territory of the European Union after the seed companies holding the GMO have obtained a marketing authorization in accordance with European regulations.  The European Parliament has chosen to use its power of objection to ask the European Commission to withdraw its authorisations on the use of a genetically modified eyen house. In the future, the GMO authorisation process, which should not be possible, should be reviewed without the support of a qualified majority of Member States and with the opinion of Parliament.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The EU GMO authorisation system is based on the precautionary principle. We cannot support the authorisation of GMOs which can spread through wild, related species in certain areas, even if they do not live in Hungary but in southern Europe. We believe that although there is little chance of viable pollen and seeds being released into the environment for cut flowers, this path cannot be completely ruled out. However, sulfonyl-urea herbicide tolerance can significantly increase the survival and reproduction of GM carnations in the natural environment when released, at a disadvantage to wild close-up species. It is also not possible to completely exclude the possibility of horizontal gene transfer between GM carnations and bacteria found in the environment. On this basis, in line with hungary's GMO-free strategy, the Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I voted in favour of parliament's objection to the placing of GM carnations on the EU market.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. With the European Commission having authorised the marketing of a genetically modified carnilla, some MEPs objected that the act exceeds the Commission's powers by failing to meet the environmental and human health protection objectives set out in Directive 2001/18/EC. The risk would be related to the intentional consumption of these GMO products which has not been assessed by EFSA. The spread of pollen from this plant should be taken into account. Also, I voted for that objection.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the article 106 objection concerning the placing on the market of genetically modified cloves, as I strongly oppose the use of genetically modified products. I have always been a supporter of the overall ban on GMOs on the European market. I am convinced that this is the only policy we can have on this issue.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the motion for a resolution, as it calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.
