The Commission's draft implementing decision does not achieve the objective of protecting health and the environment provided for in Directive 2001/18/EC and therefore exceeds the implementing powers provided for in that Directive.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU GMO authorisation system is based on the precautionary principle. We cannot support the authorisation of GMOs which can spread through wild, related species in certain areas, even if they do not live in Hungary but in southern Europe. We believe that although there is little chance of viable pollen and seeds being released into the environment for cut flowers, this path cannot be completely ruled out. However, sulfonyl-urea herbicide tolerance can significantly increase the survival and reproduction of GM carnations in the natural environment when released, at a disadvantage to wild close-up species. It is also not possible to completely exclude the possibility of horizontal gene transfer between GM carnations and bacteria found in the environment. On this basis, in line with hungary's GMO-free strategy, the Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I voted in favour of parliament's objection to the placing of GM carnations on the EU market.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The genetically modified Dianthus caryophyllus L., when they no longer have ornamental value, become waste that is likely to be managed through composting. The genetically modified craveiro contains a gene that encodes a mutant protein, which confers tolerance to sulphonylurea. Sulphonylureas have replaced other herbicides that are more toxic to animals and their widespread use can have a devastating impact on the productivity of untargeted crops and on the composition of natural plant communities and wild food chains. The Commission's draft implementing decision does not meet the objective of protecting health and the environment and therefore exceeds the implementing powers laid down in this Directive. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: according to EFSA, plans for SHD-27531-4 that would develop in the environment could only express their improved characteristics by being exposed to sulfonylurea-based herbicides.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Suntory Holdings Limited, Osaca, Japan, has submitted to the competent authority of the Netherlands a notification concerning the placing on the market of a genetically modified craveiro to have a specific colour and be resistant to a type of substance used as a herbicide. Again, there was no consensus between the Member States. The doubt and rejection of this decision is due to the fact that the craveiro, belonging to the species Dianthus caryophyllus, is widely cultivated in Europe, with the danger of cross-pollination by pollinating insects, or intentional, or even rooting by humans, and the fact that the OGM panel of EFSA says it is aware of the feeding habits of certain populations consisting of intentionally consuming craveiro pethers as a garrison. Another aspect to be taken into account is its resistance to sulphonylureas, which may lead to the creation of a market for plants resistant to this substance, which could encourage their more widespread use. We are in favour of this objection to the authorisation of GMOs. We insist that Member States' law and consumer will should be respected if they oppose the introduction of GMOs for food and cultivation on their territory, taking into account the dangers to food sovereignty, the environment, biodiversity and public health.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this resolution which is against the introduction of a GMO.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution, as it calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.  The Commission's draft implementing decision does not achieve the objective of protecting health and the environment provided for in Directive 2001/18/EC and therefore exceeds the implementing powers provided for in that Directive.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In March 2013 a notification concerning the placing on the market of a genetically-modified carnation (Dianthus caryophyllus L., line SHD-27531-4) was submitted by Suntory Holdings Limited, Osaka, Japan, to the competent authority of the Netherlands. Following a positive assessment by the competent authorities of the Netherlands, some Member States raised and one (Cyprus) maintained objections to the placing on the market of the product. EFSA issued two scientific opinions in which it concluded that there was no scientific reason to consider that the intended use would cause any adverse effect on human health or the environment. Based on this assessment, the Commission prepared a draft implementing decision according to which carnation SHD-27531-4 should be authorised. The objectors consider that the draft Commission implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in this Directive. The reasons include the fact that carnation petals can be eaten as garnish, and EFSA has not assessed the possible consequences of the intentional consumption of GM carnations by humans. Additionally, propagation would be possible. The carnation is resistant to sulfonylurea herbicides. Herbicide resistant GMOs should not be authorised, because they could encourage the increase use of herbicides, and the wider health and environmental implications of this has not been taken into account.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU GMO authorisation system is based on the precautionary principle. We cannot support the authorisation of GMOs which can spread through wild, related species in certain areas, even if they do not live in Hungary but in southern Europe. We believe that although there is little chance of viable pollen and seeds being released into the environment for cut flowers, this path cannot be completely ruled out. However, sulfonyl-urea herbicide tolerance can significantly increase the survival and reproduction of GM carnations in the natural environment when released, at a disadvantage to wild close-up species. It is also not possible to completely exclude the possibility of horizontal gene transfer between GM carnations and bacteria found in the environment. On this basis, in line with hungary's GMO-free strategy, the Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I voted in favour of parliament's objection to the placing of GM carnations on the EU market.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted against the motion for a resolution, considering that we must ensure that this key is in line with the EU's objective of protecting human and environmental health, which has so far not been corroborated, so the distribution of this decorative flower could have negative consequences for the health of European citizens and the environment.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the "objection under Article 106: Placing on the market a genetically modified carnation variety (Dianthus caryophyllus L., line SHD-27531-4)" as I fundamentally condemn the cultivation of genetically modified plants in Europe in accordance with the position of my family party in Germany.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. In March 2013, genetically modified carns were requested to be marketed in the Netherlands. EFSA has produced two scientific opinions concluding that these eyenings do not pose a risk to human health and the environment. In particular, the agency indicated that transgenic carns plants did not harm other species. The European Commission had therefore planned to give its authorisation to this marketing. However, some characteristics of these GMO plants are only expressed when they are exposed to the sulfonylurea-based herbicides to which they are resistant. However, the increased use of these herbicides will necessarily have an impact on the development of neighbouring species. As a result, transgenic eyenings, even if they do not appear to pose a direct risk, will result in massive use of environmentally harmful herbicides. So I voted in favour of the objection.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this administrative objection, since in nature, the cross-pollination of Dianthus spp., is carried out by pollinating insects, in particular lepidoptera; EFSA's Technical Commission on GMOs considers that the risk of lepidoptera transferring pollen from the genetically modified carnast SHD-27531-4 to Wild Species of Dianthus cannot be eliminated. In turn, in its opinion, EFSA states that the Technical Commission on GMOs is aware that in some populations there is a food habit of intentionally consuming clavel petals as a garnish, and that the Commission has not assessed the consequences of intentional human consumption of genetically modified keyials. The genetically modified clavel contains the SuRB gene (ALS) that encodes a mutant cumtase acetolactate (ALS) protein derived from Nicotiana tabacum, which confers resistance to sulphonylureas. According to PAN UK, 'certain herbicides, such as sulphonylureas, sulfonamides and imidazolinens, have, in very low doses, high plant toxicity'. Experts have warned that widespread use of sulphonylureas "could have devastating effects on non-target crop productivity and the composition of phytocenosis and trófic chains."

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to prohibit the marketing of flowers from a genetically modified eyebe for decoration purposes. Established following a scientific opinion from the European Food Safety Agency, the marketing authorization of this GMO posed no risk to public health or the environment. I regret that the Greens are systematically using the European Parliament's power of objection to dogma the precautionary principle, whose abusive invocation is a hindrance to progress and innovation.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU GMO authorisation system is based on the precautionary principle. We cannot support the authorisation of GMOs which can spread through wild, related species in certain areas, even if they do not live in Hungary but in southern Europe. We believe that although there is little chance of viable pollen and seeds being released into the environment for cut flowers, this path cannot be completely ruled out. However, sulfonyl-urea herbicide tolerance can significantly increase the survival and reproduction of GM carnations in the natural environment when released, at a disadvantage to wild close-up species. It is also not possible to completely exclude the possibility of horizontal gene transfer between GM carnations and bacteria found in the environment. On this basis, in line with hungary's GMO-free strategy, the Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I supported parliament's objection to the placing of GM carnations on the EU market.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the objection to the approval of genetically modified carnation (Dianthus caryophyllus L., SHD-27531-4) because of our consistent and timeless position against GMOs.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection to the placing on the market of a genetically-modified carnation for a number of reasons. Firstly, the resolution calls for a withdrawal of this decision because it exceeds the Commissions implementing powers and does not sufficiently fulfil the objective of health and environment protection. My main concern is that the possible consequences of intentional or accidental intake of GM carnations by humans and animals have not been taken into consideration. With regards to accidental cultivation, I do not see the precautionary principle taken into account sufficiently. According to the EFSA GMO panel, the GM carnation does not show enhanced fitness characteristics except if exposed to the herbicide Sulfonylureas. This herbicide is toxic to animals and can have detrimental impacts on the environment, something I believe should not be allowed on the EU market. In addition, the Commission attempted to change the procedure for authorisation, which would enable Member States to opt out from an EU-approved GMO. I, along with the majority of the Parliament rejected the proposal due to a variety of concerns but mainly the potentially disruptive effects that it might have on the functioning of the internal market.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU GMO authorisation system is based on the precautionary principle. We cannot support the authorisation of GMOs which can spread through wild, related species in certain areas, even if they do not live in Hungary but in southern Europe. We believe that although there is little chance of viable pollen and seeds being released into the environment for cut flowers, this path cannot be completely ruled out. However, sulfonyl-urea herbicide tolerance can significantly increase the survival and reproduction of GM carnations in the natural environment when released, at a disadvantage to wild close-up species. It is also not possible to completely exclude the possibility of horizontal gene transfer between GM carnations and bacteria found in the environment. On this basis, in line with hungary's GMO-free strategy, the Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I voted in favour of parliament's objection to the placing of GM carnations on the EU market.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion prohibiting the placing on the market of a genetically modified carnation, following empirical studies on the impact on human health and biodiversity.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the Commission's draft implementing decision on the marketing of GM carnations, as this calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision. In my view, above all, consideration should be given to the potential consequences that GMO can have on human health and the environmental impact of such products. In addition, efsa's GMO commission has not yet analysed the consequences of the consumption of GM carnation for humans and therefore I am voting for this motion for a resolution.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. In March 2013, the notification of a genetically modified carnity was sent to the Dutch competent authority for the application to market a genetically modified carn carnity in the Netherlands. This request covers the importation, distribution and retailing of flowers cut from this carnity for decorative use only. The objection raised by some MEPs against this act is based on the argument that the act exceeds the Commission's powers by failing to fulfil the objectives of environmental protection and human health defined by the 2001/18/EC directive. The risk would be related to the intentional consumption of these GMO products, which has not been assessed by EFSA. The spread of pollen from this plant should be taken into account. Furthermore, according to EFSA, plans for SHD-27531-4 that would develop in the environment could only express their improved characteristics by being exposed to sulfonylurea-based herbicides. However, the use of this type of herbicide could have a negative impact on the development of other plants. I voted for the text.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ In March 2013 a notification concerning the placing on the market of a genetically-modified carnation (Dianthus caryophyllus L., line SHD-27531-4) was submitted by Suntory Holdings Limited, to the competent authority of the Netherlands; covering the import, distribution and retailing of cut flowers of the genetically modified carnation for ornamental use. On 25 April 2016, with the lack of opinion of the Regulatory Committee on the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market, Dianthus caryophyllus L., line SHD-27531-4 was authorised. However we considered that the draft Commission implementing decision does not fulfil the objective of health and environment protection set out in Directive2001/18/EC and therefore exceeds the implementing powers provided for in this Directive. The reasons: 1. Certain populations intentionally consume carnation petals as garnish. EFSA had not assessed the possible consequences of the intentional consumption of GM carnations by humans and animals. 2. Propagation by rooting, and spreading of pollen of this GM carnation to wild Dianthus species cannot be excluded. EH Bildu has maintained a coherent position on matters related to GMOs and always vote against those, or as in cases as such, vote in favour of objections to allowing the authorisation of GMOs. Therefore, EH Bildu has voted in favour of this objection.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution. The rapporteur considers that the draft does not meet the objective of health and environmental protection as called for in Directive 2001/18/EC and that, therefore, the implementing powers provided for in this Directive have been exceeded. It is therefore appropriate to withdraw the implementing acts on the distribution of genetically modified carnations.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 At the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, I supported a European Parliament resolution calling for the commission's implementing decision concerning the placing on the market of genetically modified carnations (Dianthus caryophyllus L., line SHD-27531-4). The European Commission should come up with a better proposal on authorisation procedures and, through studies, take more effective and balanced steps with regard to genetically modified products and permits to place such products on the market. The current proposal does not address the often expressed concerns about the potential health and environmental risks of GMOs. The consequences that products containing GMOs can have on humans and the environment are not yet sufficiently identified and there is too much uncertainty regarding genetically modified products.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU GMO authorisation system is based on the precautionary principle. We cannot support the authorisation of GMOs which can spread through wild, related species in certain areas, even if they do not live in Hungary but in southern Europe. We believe that although there is little chance of viable pollen and seeds being released into the environment for cut flowers, this path cannot be completely ruled out. However, sulfonyl-urea herbicide tolerance can significantly increase the survival and reproduction of GM carnations in the natural environment when released, at a disadvantage to wild close-up species. It is also not possible to completely exclude the possibility of horizontal gene transfer between GM carnations and bacteria found in the environment. On this basis, in line with hungary's GMO-free strategy, the Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I voted in favour of parliament's objection to the placing of GM carnations on the EU market.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against a resolution calling on the European Commission to withdraw a draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of a genetically modified carnation. The resolution was motivated by concerns about the effects of using this ornamental plant in gastronomy – which cannot be ruled out, as well as the ecological effects of marketing by composting waste after use of the product.  Being aware of the potential unrecognized or anecdotal risks that the use of GMOs may have in the environment and for consumption, I believe that proper control and definition of procedures for the quality of production and destination of products, as well as clear labelling of products so that consumers have complete and fair product information, are a better option than a ban on placing on the market. Bans are easy to circumvent and, with obvious gains from the use of GMOs, there is a risk of switching from the production and sale of agricultural products produced using genetic engineering to the grey economy, which would exclude this production from the possibility of control and visibility on the market, thereby creating much more real risks to human health and the environment.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection to the authorisation of this GMO carnation because I am wary of GMOs in the current state of scientific research.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for the objection in accordance with Article 106: marketing of a genetically modified carnation (Dianthus caryophyllus L., SHD-27531-4). In March 2013, the notification of a genetically modified carn carny was sent to the Dutch competent authority. This request covers the importation, distribution and retailing of flowers cut from this carnity for decorative use. However, some Member States such as Cyprus are opposed to this marketing. EFSA then produced two scientific opinions concluding that there was no scientific reason to consider that the use of this because is possible to have negative effects on human health or the environment. The European Commission has therefore foreseen a decision enforcing the authorisation. The objection to this act is based on the argument that the act exceeds the Commission's powers by failing to meet the environmental and human health protection objectives set out in The 2001/18/EC Directive. The risk would be related to the intentional consumption of these GMO products which has not been assessed by EFSA. The spread of pollen from this plant should be taken into account.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I have spoken for the objection of some MEPs to the cancellation of the authorisation, granted in March 2013, to put a genetically modified carn carny on the Dutch market. Several arguments seem to show the danger of this GMO to human health and the environment. First, there is a risk that this product will be consumed, because of the spread of pollen from this flower in the environment. Second, the modification of this plant is intended for a single herbicide based on sulfonylureas that can have negative consequences on the development of other plants. Finally, in legislative terms, the European Commission is overstepping its rights by authorising such a product.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection, because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and therefore new authorisations thereof. The higher, this transgenic carnation presents a high risk of field propagation and should only be approved with that criterion. Moreover, the decision-making process concerning GMO authorisations for food and feed is not being democratic. The special committee almost never reaches a qualified majority, however, the European Commission is almost always issuing authorisations, without the support of Member States or most EU citizens. This should be the exception, but with GMOs, now it's the rule.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's decision. The Commission should not authorise and ban the cultivation of genetically modified carnations, this Decision should be left to individual Member States.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission has authorised the placement on the market of a genetically-modified flower – the carnation. The European Food Safety Authority is aware that a part of the population consumes carnation petals as condiment. Yet the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) failed to examine the possible consequences on human health. Carnation has been genetically modified in order to be resistant to sulfonylurea, medicine used to treat diabetes. Creating a market of sulfonylurea-resistant plants will encourage the use of this medicine to treat diabetes. According to the findings of the annual congress of the European Association for the Study of Diabetes (EASD), using sulfonylurea as a medicine to treat diabetes, is closely linked with increased risk of cardiovascular disease.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 When placing on the market genetically modified carnation for import, distribution and retail within the European Union, it is emphasised that it is not possible to estimate what consequences this will have on people. In case of spread in the environment through seeds or pollen, GMO carnation will not be able to be eradicated with the help of common herbicides, but only with the use of more harmful herbicides and even diabetes medications. The use of drugs for these purposes can lead to uncontrolled spread in the ecosystem. This can have adverse effects on biodiversity and cause chemical contamination of drinking water. When it loses its decorative value, the GMO carnation will become waste that will be disposed of in the environment by composting. It is worth noting that the environmental effects of such a procedure are still unknown. Therefore, I supported this objection.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to Directive 2001/18/EC, the release into the environment of genetically modified organisms should not be allowed without a comprehensive analysis of the potential consequences. The problem in this case is that the genetically modified carnation affected in the vote has the SuRB (als) gene, which gives the sulphonylurea tolerability. Sulphonylureas, on the other hand, are a common second choice in the treatment of type 2 diabetes, and their use, by the way, is associated with a higher risk of cardiovascular problems compared to other diabetes medicines. Since the creation of a sulphonylurea market would contribute worldwide to the use of these diabetes medicines as a herbicide, it is simply not permissible to place on the market this type of GMO, which would lead to the use of the medicinal product for other purposes not related to public health, and potentially have a very harmful impact on global ecosystems, in particular drinking water and biodiversity.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The commission's draft implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of a genetically modified carnation is contrary to the protection of health and the environment enshrined in Directive 2001/18/EC. It goes beyond the implementing powers provided for in this Directive. This type of carnation contains substances toxic to nature and animals and dangerous also to humans, which is why I support the proposal to withdraw this implementing regulation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Motion for a Resolution on the Commission's draft implementing decision, the XXX, on the placing on the market of genetically modified carnation (Dianthus caryophyllus L., SHD-27531-4) because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution. This resolution follows the objection of some Member States such as Cyprus against the Netherlands' marketing of a genetically modified carn name. However, EFSA has produced two opinions that do not report any health risks arising from this carnation, in particular due to the spread of pollen. The European Commission has followed EFSA's lead in issuing an authorisation decision. However, the use of a harmful herbicide, necessary for the cultivation of this eyen view, is one of the elements that has not been taken into account. Some MEPs argue that the Commission has exceeded its powers. In addition, environmental protection objectives were not met.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This draft calls on the Commission to withdraw its implementing decision on the placing on the market of a genetically modified carnation variety. I can therefore take a positive view of this motion for a resolution.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The resolution opposes the Commission's enforcement decision authorizing the marketing of a genetically modified carn name. The transgenic eyen end contains the SuRB gene (ALS), which gives it resistance to sulfonylureas. However, sulfonylurea pesticides are considered to have "devastating effects on the productivity of non-target crops and on the composition of plant and food chains in wildlife". Further, EFSA has not assessed the possible consequences of the intentional consumption of GMO carnations by humans and animals, nor the spread by rooting and spreading pollen from this GMO to wildlife. I am voting for this text which opposes GMOs.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Some Member States have opposed the introduction of genetically modified carns. The Commission has set out a decision enforcing the authorization. The objection to this act is based on the argument that the act exceeds the Commission's powers by failing to fulfil the objectives of protecting the environment and human health. That is why I voted in favour of this objection.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's draft implementing decision does not meet the objective of health and environmental protection set out in Directive 2001/18/EC, exceeding the implementing powers laid down in that Directive. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution asking the Commission to withdraw its draft decision.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I choose to support this objection as it is essential that the Council does not overstep its powers by introducing legislation that goals concerning environmental and public health protections laid out by previous Directives.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. In my view, this resolution is unfounded. There is no evidence in the scientific sense that genetically modified eyen herts can have harmful effects on human health or environmental protection. The SNIF technical report, to which the resolution refers, clearly ruled that the cultivation of genetically modified eyen cars did not harm human health.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – In March 2013, a notification was submitted by Suntory Holdings Limited (Osaka, Japan) concerning the placing on the market of genetically modified carnations by the competent authorities of the Netherlands. The notification included the import, distribution and retailing of cut flowers of genetically modified carnation for decorative purposes. Following a positive assessment by the competent Dutch authorities, some Member States objected to the placing on the market of the product. EFSA has thus produced two expert opinions on the basis of which there is no scientific evidence that they have an adverse impact on human health or the environment. On the basis of these opinions, the European Commission has drawn up a draft decision which should justify the placing on the market of a genetically modified carnation. The spread of wild species cannot be excluded and resistance to sulphonylmoucin herbicides could call for the use of these herbicides with potentially harmful effects on biodiversity and cause chemical contamination of drinking water. Personally, I believe that the proposal does not meet the objectives of health and environmental protection and therefore goes beyond the implementing powers enshrined in the directive.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because I consider that the draft Commission implementing decision does not fulfil the objective of health and environment protection set out in Directive 2001/18/EC and therefore exceeds the implementing powers provided for in this Directive. The reasons include the fact that carnation petals can be eaten as garnish, and EFSA has not assessed the possible consequences of the intentional consumption of GM carnations by humans. Additionally, propagation, as well as spread of the pollen of this GM carnation to wild Dianthus species would be possible. The carnation is resistant to sulfonylurea herbicides. These herbicides, according to PAN UK, were highly toxic to plants at very low doses and their wide-spread use could have a negative impact on the productivity of non-target crops and the make-up of natural plant communities and wildlife food chains. Finally, sulfonylurea are common treatments for management of type 2 diabetes and are associated with a higher risk of cardiovascular events compared with other antidiabetic drugs. Creating a market for sulfonylurea resistant plants will encourage the worldwide use of this antidiabetic medicine as a herbicide, with possible detrimental effects on biodiversity and chemical contamination of drinking water.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety has submitted a draft resolution. It proposes that Parliament take a position that the draft Commission implementing decision on the placing on the market of genetically modified carnations (Dianthus caryophyllus L., LINE SHD-27531-4) does not meet the health and environmental objectives set out in Directive 2001/18/EC and therefore exceeds the implementing powers set out in the Directive and therefore invites the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision. I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. We supported this objection against a Commission decision authorizing the release of this genetically modified carny for decorative use. Indeed, following the refusal of some Member States of the European Union to put the carnation on the market, EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) has published two scientific opinions refuting the presence of a risk to health and the environment, which served as the basis for the European Commission to impose its decision. This is an act that exceeds the Commission's powers in terms of protecting the environment and human health, because the risks lie in the consumption of this carnation and in the dissemination of pollen, which has not been assessed.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the importance of the protection of human health and the environment, Directive 2001/18/EC sets out the general guidelines on the control of risks resulting from the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms, in particular as regards the placing of these organisms on the markets. The proliferation of the use of genetically modified craveiro could lead to increased worldwide use of sulphonylureas, a substance associated with the treatment of type 2 diabetes, such as herbicides, which could seriously affect not only public health but also ecosystems and biodiversity and also lead to contamination of water resources.  I therefore vote in favour, because I believe that the draft implementing decision of the European Commission does not meet the objective of protecting health and the environment set out in Directive 2001/18/EC, exceeding the implementing powers provided for in it, and the Commission should therefore withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The use of this type of herbicide could have a negative impact on the development of other plants. I'm voting for that objection.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion to object to the Commission’s draft authorisation decisions for these new GM varieties because the GM carnation was engineered to have its colour changed as well as to be resistant to spraying by herbicides. GM maize Bt11 x MIR162 x MIR604 x GA21 was engineered to confer resistance to the European corn borer and the western rootworm, however it is also resistant to glyphosate and other herbicides. All these four different genes come in one variety and as such are non-separable.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to the authorisation of a genetically modified carnity, which is the responsibility of the Member States or not, which is based on the false argument that the Commission has exceeded its powers by authorising this carnity. Indeed, the Commission has fully complied with the procedure by asking the European Food Safety Authority for a study on the safety of the plant for human and animal health and for the environment. It then proposed this GMO authorization to the Council, which did not refuse it.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that authorises the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified maize carnation (Dianthus caryophyllus L., line SHD-27531-4) following a risk evaluation to human health and biodiversity.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this draft as the Commission is invited to withdraw the implementing decision on the placing on the market of a genetically modified carnation variety.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. Does not consider it necessary to adjust separately. It would be more effective to reform the whole system of regulating the market for GM Products.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's draft implementing decision concerns the placing on the market for ornamental purposes of a genetically modified carnation. From a substantive point of view, there are some problematic aspects. For example, once their ornamental function is over, carnations become waste which, in accordance with the principles of circular economy, can be disposed of by composting. However, EFSA has not yet examined the impact of these emissions on the environment, as well as assessing the possible human consequences of intentional clove consumption. From a formal point of view, the opposition to this and other GMO authorisations issued by the Commission without the support of a majority, either of the Member States or of the European Parliament, is intended to be a form of protest against the current authorisation system and an invitation to the Commission to suspend the decision in the event that the Technical Committee does not issue a majority opinion. For the reasons listed above, I am also opposed to this authorisation and support this objection, calling for a decisive democratic breakthrough in the current system of authorisation of GMOs.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the objection because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing decision does not meet the objective of protecting health and the environment set out in Directive 2001/18/EC and therefore goes beyond the implementing powers laid down in this Directive. Creating a market for sulphonylurea-resistant plants will encourage the use of this diabetes drug as a herbicide. However, the use of this medicine for purposes other than public health can have harmful consequences for biodiversity and contribute to the pollution of drinking water.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the objection to the marketing authorisation of GM carnation (Dianthus caryophyllus L., lines SHD-27531-4) for a number of reasons including the protection of biodiversity due to the uncontrolled spread of pollen.  Specifically, the cross-pollination of plants of the genus Dianthus spp. in nature takes place with the help of pollinator insects, especially insects of the order Lepidoptera (butterflies), which have a long enough cyrillic with which they can reach the nectar at the bottom of the flower. Since efsa's GMO commission considers that the possible spread of pollen of gm carnation SHD-27531-4 via Lepidoptera species to wild species of the genus Dianthus cannot be excluded, I can conclude that in this case the approval of the Commission's implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013. 1829/2003 and for this variety I ask the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The development of plants genetically modified to resist herbicides is the worst way to grow crops. On the contrary, sustainable and environmentally friendly techniques must be preferred. I therefore vote in favour of objecting to the introduction of this GMO carny.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In March 2013, an application was submitted to the competent authorities in the Netherlands for the marketing of genetically modified carnations (Dianthus caryophyllus L., line SHD-27531-4). The scope of the application covers the import, distribution and retail of cut flowers of genetically modified carnations in the Union for ornamental purposes only. The Commission's draft implementing decision on the marketing of GM carnations does not meet the health and environmental objective set out in Directive 2001/18/EC of the European Parliament and the Council on the deliberate introduction into the environment of gm organisms. This exceeds the implementing powers set out in the Directive. I therefore supported a resolution asking the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Personally, I must say that I am generally rather sceptical about the issue of GMOs and their use. Logically, this also applies to the material under discussion. Nevertheless, in this particular case, I accepted the Commission's argument and supported its procedure in the vote.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution on the assumption that the Commission's draft implementing decision does not meet the objective of health and environmental protection set out in Directive 2001/18/EC and therefore exceeds the implementing powers laid down in this Directive. I therefore believe that it should be asked by the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision. The Regulatory Committee did not deliver an opinion, as seven Member States (representing 7.84 % of the population) voted against the Commission's draft implementing decision, six Member States (representing 46.26 % of the population) abstained, eleven Member States (representing 36.29 % of the population) voted in favour and four Member States were not represented. It should be taken into account that the use of medicines for purposes other than public health purposes resulting in uncontrolled dissemination in ecosystems can have negative effects on global biodiversity and cause chemical contamination of drinking water.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the objection to the marketing of the genetically modified carnation Dianthus caryophyllus L., line SHD-27531-4.  Rejecting the new GMO marketing authorisations is a way for our Parliament to send a clear message to the European Commission to review the current GMO authorisation process. This process is neither satisfactory nor democratic, as every authorisation decision has been adopted by the Commission without the support of a qualified majority of the Member States and by ignoring the opinion of this House. I would also like to point out that public opinion remains negative about GMOs. Finally, EFSA has not assessed the possible consequences of intentional consumption of genetically modified eyen cars by humans.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I ask the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to this implementing act, by which the European Commission authorises the Japanese company Suntory Holdings Limited to introduce to the market the genetically modified caryophyllus L. caryophyllus car car caryophyllus L., line SHD-27531-4, in the Netherlands.  This key is resistant to sulphonylurea. These herbicides, according to the British Herbicide Action Network (PAN), were highly toxic to plants at very low doses, and their widespread use could have a negative impact on the productivity of other crops and on the composition of natural plant communities and wild food chains. Finally, sulphonylureas are common treatments for the treatment of type 2 diabetes and are associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease compared to other antidiabetic drugs. The creation of a market for sulphonylurea-resistant plants will encourage the worldwide use of this antidiabetic drug as a herbicide, with potential harmful effects on biodiversity and chemical contamination of drinking water, so I have supported the objection.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of objecting to the marketing of a genetically modified carnity. I support this objection primarily for health and environmental reasons. It should be kept in mind that there is still no risk assessment of carnation petals ingested by humans and animals. The precautionary principle must therefore be imposed in my opinion.  Of course, the European Commission is under no obligation to follow this objection made by the European Parliament. Nevertheless, I would hope that the Commission will take this view into account, contrary to what it has done in the past.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has forwarded to us an application from Suntory Holdings Limited, a Japanese company, to allow genetically modified carnations, which are essentially genetically modified products, to be grown in the EU. At the same time, we do not have any information on the long-term impact of such carnations on the environment and on living organisms. I am therefore convinced that we must unequivocally say 'no' to such a request. Europe is not a place for genetically modified plants!

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this administrative objection since in nature, cross-pollination of Dianthus spp., is carried out by pollinating insects, in particular lepidoptera, the EFSA Technical Commission on GMOs considers that the risk of lepidoptera transferring pollen from the genetically modified key carnation SHD-27531-4 to Dianthus wild species cannot be eliminated. In turn, EFSA states that the Technical Commission on GMOs is aware that in some populations there is a eating habit of intentionally consuming clavel petals as a garnish, and that EFSA has not assessed the consequences of intentional human consumption of genetically modified keytials. The genetically modified clavel contains the SuRB gene (ALS) that encodes a mutant cumtase acetolactate (ALS) protein derived from Nicotiana tabacum, which confers resistance to sulphonylureas. According to PAN UK, 'certain herbicides, such as sulphonylureas, sulfonamides and imidazolinens, have, in very low doses, high plant toxicity'. Experts have warned that widespread use of sulphonylureas "could have devastating effects on non-target crop productivity and the composition of phytocenosis and trófic chains."

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection, because I am totally against genetically modified organisms and therefore new authorisations thereof. The higher, this transgenic carnation presents a high risk of field propagation and should only be approved with that criterion. Moreover, the decision-making process concerning GMO authorisations for food and feed is not being democratic. The special committee almost never reaches a qualified majority, however, the European Commission is almost always issuing authorisations, without the support of Member States or most EU citizens. This should be the exception, but with GMOs, now it's the rule.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Parliament's resolution asking the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision on the placing of a genetically modified carnation on the European market. I agree with the rapporteur's position that the draft decision does not meet the objective of protecting health and the environment, because the possible negative effects of using this type of carnation have not been sufficiently analysed. Although the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) issued its opinion on the decision, this does not include a complete impact study. For example, EFSA did not assess the possible consequences of deliberately consuming genetically modified carnations on humans, did not deal with the deliberate or accidental consumption of carnation flowers by animals, nor did it address composted carnation waste that can be released into the environment. The launch of this genetically modified carnation was announced by Suntory Holdings Limited, a Japanese company, to the Dutch authorities back in 2013. Despite the time lag, there are still doubts about the effects that the specific SuRB gene contained in this type of carnation may have. This gene provides resistance to the highly toxic herbicide sulphonylurea, and it is unclear how its spread would affect the environment. I am therefore of the opinion that the Commission should withdraw its decision and examine in detail the possible public health impacts.

Sulfonylurea-based herbicides replaced other herbicides that are more toxic to animals. Experts warn that widespread use of sulfonylurea could have a devastating impact on the productivity of non-feral crops and on the composition of natural plant communities and on food chains of wildlife. I believe that creating a market for sulfonylurea-resistant plants will encourage the global use of this antidiabetic as a herbicide, and the use of a particular medicine for purposes other than public health leads to an uncontrolled spread of this medicine in an ecosystem that can have a devastating global impact on biodiversity.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Suntory Holdings Limited of Osaka, Japan, submitted an application in March 2013 to the competent authorities in the Netherlands to market genetically modified carnation (reference C/NL/13/01). The application area of application C/NL/13/01 includes distribution and retail of cut flowers of genetically modified carnation SHD-27531-4 in the European Union for decorative purposes only.  A report by the European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) said efsa's GMO commission is aware of the fact that in some nations there is a custom to intentionally consume carnation petals used for decorative purposes without analysing the possible consequences of intentional consumption of genetically modified carnations in humans. text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted against the resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision on the placing on the market of GENETICALLY MODIFIED NAGS. name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the objection to the placing on the market of genetically modified carnations based on the need to safeguard the interests of consumers, to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health and to protect the environment.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's draft implementing decision does not achieve the objective of protecting health and the environment provided for in Directive 2001/18/EC and therefore goes beyond the implementing powers provided for in that Directive.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU GMO authorisation system is based on the precautionary principle. We cannot support the authorisation of GMOs which can spread through wild, related species in certain areas, even if they do not live in Hungary but in southern Europe. We believe that although there is little chance of viable pollen and seeds being released into the environment for cut flowers, this path cannot be completely ruled out. However, sulfonyl-urea herbicide tolerance can significantly increase the survival and reproduction of GM carnations in the natural environment when released, at a disadvantage to wild close-up species. It is also not possible to completely exclude the possibility of horizontal gene transfer between GM carnations and bacteria found in the environment. On this basis, in line with hungary's GMO-free strategy, the Basic Law and the precautionary principle, I voted in favour of parliament's objection to the placing of GM carnations on the EU market.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Motion for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Commission implementing decision on the placing on the market of genetically modified carnations (Dianthus caryophyllus L., LINE SHD-27531-4).  The motion is based on the fact that in March 2013 Suntory Holdings Limited in Osaka, Japan, submitted a notification to the Dutch competent authority of the placing on the market of genetically modified carnations. The authorization shall cover the import, distribution and retail sale of carnations for ornamental use only. However, EFSA states that although the EFSA GMO Body is aware that certain groups of the population consume carnation petals at mealtimes as garnish, it has not assessed the possible consequences of deliberate human or animal consumption of GENETICALLY MODIFIED CARNATIONS.  EFSA considers that cropped stems with vegetative shoots can be propagated by rooting or micro-propagation and may enter the environment (e.g. in gardens), and the same risk applies to pollen, as modified carnations also pass on to wild species. The resolution therefore calls on the Commission to withdraw its implementing regulation.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – It is regrettable that this is the time that the European Commission, contrary to the member states' position, has given the green light to the placing on the market of a new GMO product, in the exercise of its powers under its legislation. Although the Commission's authorisation only covers the import, distribution and retail of the GMO carnation solely for ornamental purposes, there are serious concerns that the release of the GMO carnation to the market will not only endanger the environment and human health, but will also have harmful effects on biodiversity and chemically pollute drinking water. It is recognised that, despite the fact that if a GMO carnation is found to be in the environment with seeds, pollen or rooted plants, it would still retain its resilience to certain herbicides, which, even at very low doses, are highly toxic to plants and animals. The use of such herbicides can have a devastating effect on the productivity of other crops, as well as on the structure of the natural communities of plants and the wild food chain. It is also not possible to exclude the spread of GMO carnations into the environment, such as gardens, rooting or composting them. In view of the potential risks to the environment and human health and the negative attitude of Latvian society towards GMOs, I voted in favour of repealing the Commission decision authorising the placing on the market of this GMO carnation. Furthermore, I believe that the existing legislative procedure should be changed in order to give both the European Parliament and the states greater decision-making rights when authorising new GMOs for the placing on the market, thereby ensuring more effective democratic control and respect for the public interest.
