name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the recommendation for second reading by the Committee on Legal Affairs on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council promoting the free movement of citizens by simplifying the requirements for the submission of certain public documents in the European Union and amending Regulation (EU) No 1024/2012 (14956/2/2015 - C8-0129/2016 - 2013/0119(COD)) (Rapporteur: Mady Delvaux) (A8-0156/2016).

name: Mady Delvaux
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, more than 14 million European citizens live in a Member State different from their home state. In order to marry, to declare the birth of a child, to present a blank criminal record, they are forced to face tedious and sometimes expensive procedures. Indeed, it is not enough to produce an official document of their State of origin, yet it must be accompanied by a stamp issued by an authority - this is called the apostille - to which is added a certified translation and, if necessary, certified copies. Yet free movement is one of the fundamental rights of European citizenship. The need to make European citizenship more concrete was highlighted by the Stockholm programme in 2009. In order to strengthen confidence in the European area of justice, he advocates an action plan which specifically includes the abolition of the apostille. Today, seven years later, we are almost there. The regulation on the simplification of the acceptance of public documents, which we will adopt, is a step - I must say a small step - to alleviate these steps, since it abolishes the apostille for the documents that are covered by this regulation. These are civil registration documents: marriage, partnership, birth, life certificate, death certificate, residence certificate, electoral rights and lack of criminal record. Multilingual forms attached to public documents will be used to assist in translation and allow citizens to save on a certified translation. To mitigate the risk of fraud, the text provides for the use of an IMI platform, which is a system for directly exchanging information between the various authorities. Thus, if an administration has doubts about the authenticity of a document, it can contact the relevant authority directly to verify the veracity of the document. The day the platform works properly, within the allotted time, it will significantly improve fraud detection. The deadline for implementation is two and a half years. It is a long time, but it is necessary for the system to be put in place and for citizens to be informed. Indeed, we have fought in Parliament to impose an obligation on the Member States and the Commission to effectively inform citizens about this new legislation. They must be explicitly informed of the abolition of the apostille as well as the existence of multilingual forms, which are much less expensive than certified translations. Parliament also had to fight to ensure that the cost of these forms did not exceed the cost of production or that of the original document.  I want to emphasize the revision clause in particular. A Commission report will have to report on the application of the regulation, but also consider whether to abolish the apostille for other documents. Although the European Parliament has agreed to this proposal, it is not happy about it. We would have liked to go further and include in the scope a greater number of documents concerning companies, including their legal status, but also common documents such as diplomas, certificates of study, or the status of a person with a disability. Unfortunately, all these ambitions had to be relegated to the background in the revision clause. But I am sure that Parliament will remain vigilant about the application of the regulation.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, freedom of movement gives millions of people in the European Union unprecedented opportunities. Cross-border personal and business relationships are thriving: 14 million citizens – and we already had this figure here from Ms Delvaux – reside in a Member State other than their Member State of origin; 13% of all marriages in the Union are international; and 50% of SMEs are engaged in cross-border activities. I expect these numbers to continue rising.  This proposal will make the life of millions of citizens and businesses easier by removing unnecessary and costly red tape. Here we are: after three years of intense negotiations, with your vote tomorrow the Union is about to take another important step. It might not make it to the front pages of the magazines, but many people will breathe a sigh of relief once this regulation enters into force. Today, when people move to another EU country and they want to register a birth, get married, register a house, or apply for a residence card, the national authorities will ask for certified copies, certified translations and rubber stamps such as the apostille. This is time-consuming, costly, and perfectly unnecessary. This is now over for a whole range of life situations and corresponding documents. Based on the principle of mutual trust, the regulation does away with the requirement to authenticate public documents with an apostille and simplifies obligations with regard to certified copies and translations. It also introduces multilingual standard forms to avoid translation requirements and reinforces the fight against false documents by setting up a system of cooperation between Member States. Parliament has been a strong supporter of this regulation from the start. I would like to pay tribute to Mr Rapkay, who gathered a solid majority in first reading under the previous legislature, and wish to thank Ms Delvaux and the shadow rapporteurs who skilfully negotiated the final compromise with the Council. It was not easy; and we have a balanced compromise.  The regulation covers several areas of immediate relevance to most citizens, in particular their civil status. We would all have preferred a broader scope of the regulation, covering additional areas for citizens as well as documents useful to businesses. It is thanks to Parliament’s determination that the regulation provides for an early review of its scope. This early review will allow the Commission to consider the inclusion in the scope of additional areas such as educational records, disabilities, and the legal status and representation of companies. Parliament has also ensured that the fee that Member States may charge to citizens for obtaining a multilingual standard form will be reasonable, and that Member States will inform citizens of their rights under the regulation through their websites and also in individual contacts.

name: Емил Радев
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Delvo, because today we have a compromise agreement with the Council, thanks to its efforts in the long and difficult negotiations with the Member States. I can assure you that the Member States were not prepared to step back from their position. Today's text of the Regulation is therefore a great success for us as the European Parliament, but it is mostly a great success for our citizens because we will facilitate their free movement by simplifying the adoption of certain public documents in the European Union. This Regulation concerns the abolition of administrative formalities such as legalisation and apostille for documents relating to civil status or those certifying a lack of criminal record issued by another Member State. These simplifications for citizens are offset by the possibility for the administration receiving the document to verify directly and electronically the authenticity of the document. This will also reduce the risk of fraud. The creation of multilingual standard forms for most of the relevant official documents saves citizens efforts, time, means of translation of the document. This also greatly facilitates the movement of citizens in the European Union. I hope that a subsequent revision of the Regulation will extend its scope to more documents, with particular attention to business documents as well as documents relating to the acquisition of qualifications, school and subsequent education. I regret that the Member States were not prepared to accept our position during the negotiations and these documents did not enter into the compromise text. In conclusion, I would add that I sincerely hope that in the future Member States will have more confidence in each other so that we can include more documents within the scope of the Regulation and thus all together improve and facilitate the lives of our citizens.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Several million Citizens of the European Union study or work outside their home country, exercising their right to free movement. Every year, several hundred thousand public documents must be legalised or certifying that they are recognised in countries other than those where they were issued.  In this context, it is extremely important to simplify the formalities to which citizens moving abroad are subject. The introduction of standard multilingual forms for most of the documents covered by the Regulation – including documents relating to residence, citizenship, marital status or criminal record certificates – will avoid costly translations and thus simplify the procedures to be completed by Union citizens moving to other Member States.  I am pleased that the regulation contains review clauses providing for the extension of administrative facilities in the future. This is extremely important, especially given that school diplomas and certificates, disability certificates and many other documents relating to enterprises are not covered by this Regulation. The new rules will greatly facilitate the free movement of Union citizens, who will be able to benefit from the new procedures from 2019. Finally, I would like to warmly congratulate the rapporteur on the good compromise reached.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – I would like to join the thanks and congratulations offered to Colleague Delvo for the long, complex, delicate negotiations held within the political groups and for the satisfactory outcome achieved on this dossier so important for European citizens. It not only simplifies formalities in respect of certain types of documents, in particular those certifying residence, nationality, lack of criminal registration and criminal record, but also removes severe bureaucratic setbacks, disproportionate and in many cases unnecessary formalities. Removing documents as apostille is good news because it facilitates the issuance of these documents and their unification. I also strongly support the introduction of standard European multilingual forms, which will minimise the need for legalised translation, as well as the costs, bureaucratic costs and difficulties for Citizens of the Member States in their free movement and in their day-to-day activities within the European Union. Removing these additional setbacks will facilitate the process and requirements for issuing certain official documents.   Once again, I congratulate the rapporteur on the effectiveness during the negotiations and, in particular, on the result achieved.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Verts/ALE). – Mr President, I too would like to thank Mrs Delvaux for the important work she has now completed. The mutual acceptance of public documents between Member States really does make a tangible contribution to freedom of movement. Unfortunately, as the rapporteur has also said, this now applies only to certain documents. The Commission should therefore take advantage of the review clause contained in the regulation. It would be very important, for example, to have certificates of disability covered by this regulation, because of course all Europeans should have the opportunity to make full use of their right to free movement in practice too, and disabled people have a very specific situation. In this context, I would like to mention that the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities will actually enter into force tomorrow in my own country, Finland, at last. And I would now like to see that the EU also ensures that EU legislation meets the requirements for conventions. I would like to emphasise that one important category of documents that should be included in this regulation as a matter of urgency is the disability documents.

name: Diane James
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the purported aim of this legislation is to promote the free movement of citizens and businesses by simplifying the acceptance of certain public documents in the European Union. So today we have the latest gift to those that threaten us, whose activities will directly benefit from this proposal, and a proposal that will only further undermine national security and create further pressures on our security resources. The civil status documents to be ‘harmonised’ via this proposal are the very ones that preserve distinctiveness and act as barriers, two aspects that should be safeguarded and left in the domain of national governments, precisely to thwart the intent of those who will benefit from a one—size—fits—all approach. We all know about the cheapness of fraudulent EU passports, we know about the extent of stolen EU passports and other identifications, so why add to the plethora of stuff out there that only helps people who actually threaten us?  I am left scratching my head completely at this proposal. Its timing is ill-judged, its purpose is ill-judged, and it benefits people who actually want to hurt and threaten us. So I strongly recommend you to put it back on the shelf – if you can’t abandon it completely – and stop gifting things like this to people who will harm us. This is wrong time, wrong place, wrong proposal.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I find it difficult to find the real value of this text, especially in view of the many conventions applicable in this area. Nor do I see the value of these multilingual forms, which are presented as the centrepiece of this text and which, fortunately, are devoid of any autonomous legal value, much to the rapporteur's regret. Indeed, the Council has greatly reduced Parliament's desire to keep its face, and is clinging to revision clauses which envisage the extension of the scope of future administrative simplifications.  In the meantime, far from facilitating the work of administrations and combating fraud, this text will further increase their burden, while some of them are suffering the full brunt of the austerity imposed by the European Union. At a time when we are seeing, day after day, that Schengen is a dangerous and irresponsible instrument, at a time when European nations are facing an unprecedented migration challenge, the European Union is once again revealing its keen sense of a fairer approach by producing yet another gadget.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Fortunately, we have groups in the European Parliament, such as the EFDD and the French Front National, which care about Europe's identity, its closure, that we are safe in its four corners and that we do not allow anyone into the European Union. Let's be closed – thank you very much for taking care of it. The citizens of the European Union expect something completely different. The citizens of the European Union are very pleased that, finally, Parliament and the Council are also adopting documents that make their daily lives easier. And this document, this regulation, makes life easier for millions of citizens moving around the European Union, and they are not immigrants. These are citizens of the European Union. Finally, take note! This regulation, of course, has a scope from which we cannot entirely be satisfied. It should have a wider scope, but something needs to start with. Citizens will be grateful for every step that makes their daily lives easier, which means they don't have to run to translators, that they don't have to confirm the document any time there, that they don't have to apply in a country where they have arrived with two hundred certificates confirmed by stamps, signatures and not known what else. This first step will allow us to introduce further facilities in the future. Except that the Member States must now make good use of this time. We must not waste it. We need to be well prepared to really serve our citizens.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the work done by Mrs Delvaux and her staff, the shadow rapporteurs who have worked with her, is an excellent piece of work. The regulation is a step in the right direction, albeit a modest one. The foundation of the European Union and its cohesion is free movement. Without this, the European Union would not have the opportunities it objectively still has before it. So it was important to simplify, to give individual citizens the opportunity to move without the obstacles they encounter today. There are two things, however, that need to be done just as quickly. One is the one you have already mentioned: it is very important that the Member States work to get to know about this measure. There is nothing worse than doing the right thing and then not being able to present it and not making it known, because then it loses value, whereas we need this regulation to be implemented quickly. The second issue is what has already been mentioned by some of my colleagues, most recently Mr Zwiefka. There are further elements that need to be added to the regulation, information that is not there today, but which is very sensitive because it gives a strong idea of citizenship, from those that affect companies, and that have an economic value, to information concerning individuals, I am thinking of diplomas, training certificates, certificates of disability, that is, everything that makes everyday life as a life worth living. Regulations and laws are for this.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I am glad when any administrative burden to European citizens is reduced. However, I am concerned that new definitions and ideological changes are being pushed through in seemingly practical proposals. As the documents affected by this regulation primarily concern family and marriage, citizens are concerned that ease of document flow should not impose new terms, definitions and laws on other Member States. For example, the term ‘parenthood’ dilutes the more precise terms ‘father and mother’. A child’s birth certificate is fundamental to their very identity, and the names of ‘father and mother’ are sacrosanct.  These irreplaceable roles must be respected, as all of us were born of a father and a mother, forming a family unit, which has greater importance even than democratic government in the establishment of other societies. Every society knows that to have a child, you need a mother and a father, which is the only natural thing. We forget this natural, God-given principle at our peril.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Commissioner, normally there is no second reading in this House on the proposal for a regulation. In this case, it shall be automatically approved and shall be put to the vote only if someone submits a motion to reject it. In this House, I am usually the one who makes such a motion to reject. But this time I'm not giving any such a proposal, and I'm going to explain why. I have committed myself to my constituents that I will vote against all proposals that restrict the freedom of man or the sovereignty of the Member States, and I do not see this proposal as beneficial in principle. In fact, we will have a uniform form of public documents, such as a birth certificate, marriage certificate or divorce certificate. And if a citizen travels to another Member State, he will not have to provide an official translation, it will save him something and the authorities will be able to verify the authenticity. Therefore, no one here is forcing the Member States to recognise the document, it is only making it easier to read it. But it leads me to reflect on the purpose of the European Union in this context. I think that this proposal is a perfect example for intergovernmental cooperation, governments can agree on it, accept it and we do not need the European Union or parliament like that to do so.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The law we are adopting tomorrow affects many millions of citizens, people who do not live, work or study in their home country, but in another EU Member State. It is a step in the right direction for all those people who exercise their right to free movement. Sooner or later, almost everyone will need a birth or marriage certificate or a police certificate of leadership – whether for applying for an ID card, for professional applications or for marriage. Having these documents recognised across borders in the EU still costs – unfortunately – a great deal of time and money. It is high time that this bureaucratic effort was a thing of the past. It is therefore good that it is over with the apostille to prove the authenticity of these documents in another Member State. It is good that the long waiting times at the authorities are over. Yes, that must be the case, and that is why I can only support all the Members who have said here that we would have liked to have gone further. Not only private individuals, but also companies should be able to benefit from the simplified procedure, as the Commission originally proposed. The list of documents to be recognised is also still expandable. Here I am relying on the review clause in the regulation, because that is where we will have the opportunity to improve. This law is a good one, but it is only the first step in the right direction, namely a uniform handling of public documents throughout Europe. I will stick to it and many colleagues will join in.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, freedom of movement of people is one of the fundamental freedoms of the European Union, and in order for citizens to consume it fully, it is necessary to remove as many administrative barriers as possible that make it difficult for them to stay and work in other Member States. While I disagree with the Commission's efforts to tackle unemployment by promoting mobility, as we would condemn less developed members to decline in the long term, I believe that we need to make it as easy as possible for all those who take the decision to change the environment. Neither politics nor the administration has the right to stand in the way of an individual in such important personal decisions. In this context, we should maximise the potential of the e-administration system and work towards a more efficient exchange of data between Member States, which in itself will significantly facilitate these procedures and ensure full freedom of movement for citizens. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure – Mr President, dear colleague, do I agree that promoting free movement by simplifying certain official documents is a way for European citizens to move in the internal market, but do you not think that, as long as we have five Member States which are not in Schengen, even the citizens of the Member States have a problem with movement in the internal market?

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. Mr. President, thank you very much for asking. That is why I said that administrative problems should be abolished, and that much more should be devoted to the problems of those who want to leave the state, but also much, much more should be devoted to those who want to stay and give them reasons to stay in their Member States.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE).
text: – Sur President, amministrazzjoni moderna tiffaťilita l-aèèess gťas-servizzi u tneťi formalitajiet amministrattivi li, fl-aťťar mill-aťťar, huma mekkaniżmi "outdated" u sproporzjonati meta wieťed qiegťed jitkellem fuq id-"Digital Single Market". Is-semplifikazzjoni ma tfissirx anqas eertezza jew sigurtà f'dokumenti pubblièi. L-gťodda diťitali tippermettilna esmertà u sigurtà, kif ukoll effièjenza.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Do you know how complicated it is that an Austrian citizen – I could, of course, also take someone from any other country – who spends his life in Spain, for example, gets his pension, that is, his pension paid out? He must present a so-called confirmation of life, which means that he must prove that he is still alive. This confirmation of life, which must be translated, and that must be certified. It takes time, and it costs money. And that, please, we want to change in this united Europe. The normal daily life in Europe is simply to be made easier. This includes a common EU document in the medium and long term. Obviously, we are not there yet. The result that is now before us is much more modest than our rapporteur, Mady Delvaux, and also the shadow rapporteurs in the European Parliament originally intended. However, this stage is still important. The report will now benefit the citizens of the European Union to a considerable extent. At last, they no longer have to show an apostille for certain documents, such as the birth and death certificates already mentioned at the beginning. In addition, many young adults are drawn to study abroad. One of our priorities was and is to make this step easier for young adults and to achieve automatic recognition of school certificates and diplomas. We have not achieved that now, but let us take that momentum. This is a first stage. This issue should continue to contribute to the integration of Europe.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, let me first thank the JURI committee rapporteur, Mrs Mada Delvaux, and all the other colleagues who have worked on this proposal for their persistence and efforts. The compromise reached shows the real possibilities at our disposal at the moment.  I am aware that the credibility of documents is a prerequisite for the functioning of every society, every judicial system, and it is certainly appropriate to carefully consider all steps that in some way change the rules in place in this area. However, I believe that, nowadays, citizens expect more from the European Union than there is a very gradual and very limited levelling of the rules, especially in this area. I regret that the Member States have not been willing to go as far as the Commission originally proposed in mutual recognition of the instruments, and I hope that in the future we will still have the opportunity to move from the stage of merely reducing complications to the stage of creating a genuine common space. Only this shift will have a real impact on both entrepreneurs and ordinary citizens, providing real proof of the existence of a united Europe.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European More than 10 million EU citizens take the opportunity to move freely. When staying in another Member State, citizens encounter a new foreign administrative, educational and social security system for them. This creates a number of administrative difficulties. By simplifying administrative formalities, the Regulation aims, in particular, to facilitate the cross-border adoption of public documents and other documents certifying marital status, and I therefore respectfully welcome this initiative. As hundreds of thousands of documents are authenticated each year, we can talk about strengthening trust between Member States, which can save EU citizens time and their wallets. The essential achievement of the Regulation is the establishment of multilingual forms.  Multilingualism is an additional burden in administrative matters, and forms that can be issued in all EU official languages will change this situation. I am particularly pleased that, from the point of view of a community which, for example, has a relationship with another Member State because of the identity of the language, I will also be able to present a form, if necessary, in Hungary, issued to me by the Slovak authorities without any additional translation costs. This regulation is therefore a good starting point, which I respectfully support.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, first of all, I too would like to congratulate the rapporteur and shadow rapporteurs on the material put on the table today. The European Union is defined mainly by the free movement of persons, goods, services and capital. Today we have a more than acceptable free movement of people within the Union, even if not all Member States are in the Schengen area.  Unfortunately, the administrative obstacles found in the cross-border use and acceptance of official documents have a direct impact on the free movement of citizens. It is necessary to further identify practical tools that facilitate the lives of citizens beyond national borders.  'Unity in diversity' must also be found in the bureaucratic sphere, thus overcoming the language barriers created in the absence of standard forms. Simplification of these procedures responds to the needs and wishes of citizens, while at the same time being an important step towards deepening and strengthening European integration. A gradual approach is needed in starting this process, starting from the testing of a narrower area, such as civil status documents, and then it is mandatory to move towards an extension of the scope. We must be extremely careful, however, because, with the mirage of simplification, we must not neglect the principles of security and legal certainty, which have been the basis for the establishment of legalisation formalities. I therefore remain firmly in my conviction that the proposal offers a new impetus for the free movement of people.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, fellow members, Commissioner, in the context of a growing number of Europeans working, studying or residing in Member States other than their home member, the European Commission's proposal to simplify the process of accepting public documents is of major importance, both for citizens and for the functioning of the European Single Market. Whether we are talking about tourists in need of medical insurance, employees who need to prove the payment of fees, or students who interact with university administration, bureaucratic requirements act as a real brake on European freedoms. That is why the Commission proposal is a necessary, but not sufficient, step for current mobility needs. In this respect, Parliament's amendments aim to increase the number of documents accepted by the authorities of european states, as well as the transfer of responsibilities from the citizen to the authorities. Beyond the fact that European citizens will be spared the stress of unnecessary bureaucracy, the costs they are obliged to bear will also be substantially reduced. I also welcome this initiative from the point of view of its contribution to the idea of trust between the authorities of the Member States and towards European citizens, who are increasingly mobile.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, it is particularly oxymoron, at a time when many Member States of the Union have suspended Schengen, to discuss the promotion of freedom of movement by simplifying the acceptance of certain documents. Of course making it easier for citizens is important and this will be done by removing the apostille stamp. This is a positive event that will strengthen the free movement of citizens, their establishment in other countries and the finding of work. However, the circle of public documents, particularly those relating to people with disabilities, should be broadened. At the same time, we must pay attention to the security issues that have been raised. The need to recognise documents and abolish apostille is timely, especially now that we have a large migration of young people from the countries of the South and especially from Greece, as thousands of scientists have now gone to the countries of the North. This is a 'brain drain', a brain drain, which must be stopped, and this is an important fact, which, in addition to facilitation, we should also see with measures to support the European region.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I think this proposal is pro-citizen and very much pro-single market. It makes absolute sense that we should have standardised forms in a multilingual context, and I welcome this regulation as a practical example of making the European Union work for ordinary citizens. As others have said, this is the first phase in terms of birth certificates and marriage certificates, and I think we should encourage the Commission and this Parliament to be bolder at the next phase, particularly in terms of young people, when it comes to its translation to diplomas and degrees.  We know that somewhere between 6% and 8% of European Union citizens travel and work in other Member States. We have an obligation to make sure that their passage in those countries is made as smooth as possible. Certainly for Irish people who travel around the European Union, that can be difficult in terms of the number of documents that are needed, so having these standardised documents in a multilingual form makes absolute sense. But I do think we need to be bold and we need to be ambitious for the future; I see this as the first step, rather than the last step.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Signor Presidente, la ringrazio per la buona pronuncia che naturalmente è complicata, anche per voi italiani. Mr. President, communion within the European Union has created a series of freedoms. Freedom of movement is certainly one of the most important freedoms we have, and that is why I strongly welcome this effort by the Commission to standardise the key documents of every citizen.  Of course, the digitization of the system, the e-citizen system that has started to function in Croatia and works very well in many countries of the European Union, should be the guiding thread. We should really have all the documents that citizens have to see through the e-citizen system. So let's start with these documents which are key documents, but really let's not stop there, let's move on, let's go for additional documents when we talk about education, about employment status and everything that is important for citizens.  Congratulations to the Commission. I urge us not to stop there, but to move forward.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Mr President, the exemption from the obligation to validate and mark specific public documents is an important step towards reducing red tape and reducing the suffering of Union citizens. Public documents which can be quickly searched between Member States and certified in a short period of time should not constitute a obstacle to the professional, academic and personal activities of European citizens. Ways, methods and techniques exist and are constantly improved with the development of new technologies. Member States must escape any anchorages that hold them back and improve the quality of life of their citizens by limiting unnecessary and economically damaging suffering to such procedural matters. The scope of these administrative facilities is still limited but can and should be extended to other documents, but not to the detriment of the reliability and security of documents.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, (closed microphone) must facilitate the free movement of citizens, and an important step is this legislative act, which ensures exemption from the obligation of legalisation and apostille for some frequently requested documents, which concern, for example, residence, nationality and criminal record. Another important aspect is the creation of standard multilingual forms for a large number of documents. But unfortunately, I have to criticize a few things. Firstly, I do not understand why the Regulation does not include diplomas and certificates relating to training, certificates relating to disability or other documents relevant to businesses. It is as if students, professionals, entrepreneurs or people with disabilities are not entitled to mobility. I also do not understand why it takes so long to implement this piece of legislation, why it takes almost three years to implement the verification software or to develop additional costs for the release of multilingual documents. I have lived abroad for several years and have dealt directly with these problems.  So, on behalf of the nearly four million Romanians living in other European countries, I would like to thank the rapporteur for this act and call on the Commission and the Council to quickly introduce the other documents.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the compromise you have reached with the Council will bring tangible benefits to our citizens. They will no longer need to spend time and money to have their public documents rubber-stamped by a second authority in their Member State before they can show them to the authorities of another Member State. I can only confirm that I also understand this as a first step on a long-distance run. You rightly pointed out that there is a lot of further work to be done. Madam Delvaux also mentioned that this long-distance run started with the Stockholm programme. So over seven years ago it was clearly planned and foreseen that we need to do our best to cut red-tape and to decrease our administrative burdens on our citizens who travel and who want to live in another Member State, enjoying the freedom of movement around Europe. So I confirm that this is also my understanding, and we will use the review of this regulation for further work. I understand all of you who call for adding the documents related to education, disabilities and businesses. Here we also want to encourage the companies and entrepreneurs to enjoy this benefit of free movement.  So there is a lot to be to be done and I am looking forward to further cooperation with you and I want to thank you for your support on this current proposal.

name: Mady Delvaux
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would first like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their support and contribution and apologise to Mr Rapkay, because we have failed to save his ambitious report, for which he had found a majority at first reading. The debates inspired me. Three points: First, we must confirm that this regulation is a modest step, certainly, but concrete to simplify the lives of citizens, and I hope that soon will follow others. Secondly, the IMI platform, which creates a network between the administrations of the Member States and thus allows for direct exchange between the authorities, is, contrary to what has been said here, an excellent instrument for combating fraud, far more effective than the application of an apostille, a buffer, without being able to verify its authenticity. Thirdly, I am convinced that this regulation is a great step forward, if it happens and helps to create and strengthen trust between Member States. We will need it if we are to create a European area of justice and promote the mobility of citizens in Europe. And finally, let me say, Commissioner, that I am not giving up hope that soon we will have on the table a proposal that will allow not only the acceptance of public documents, but their recognition in the other Member States.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. – An estimated 12 million EU citizens live in an EU state other than their home country, and many more remain provisionally in another EU State for study, work or simply on holiday. All these persons are ever able to contact the administrative authorities of the country of residence. Within the scope of this Regulation, documents relating to marital status, as well as other documents often requested by citizens, relating, for example, to residence, nationality and criminal records, are included. For these public documents, this Regulation provides for the exemption from legalisation and the apostille, two administrative procedures traditionally provided for for cross-border public documents. Acceptance measures provided for certified copies and affidavit translations are also envisaged. Another key step forward in this Regulation is the creation of multilingual standard forms for most of the public documents in question. The proposal to be adopted is a major step forward for European citizens. It allows to end the excess of bureaucracy and gives relevance to the principle of mutual trust.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Millions of Citizens of the European Union study, work or live in a country of which they are not citizens. However, when exercising their right to free movement, they often face administrative difficulties when they submit various public documents. Indeed, many States still recognise either their own documents or those of another state if they are notarized. Work to abolish the requirement to legalise documents and reduce administrative formalities is therefore important. It would be appropriate to adopt in the Union the principle that documents issued correctly in one country are also valid in other Union countries. In order to prevent falsification of documents and to confirm their reliability, it should be established that the administrative authority receiving the document may request directly by electronic means to confirm the authenticity of the document to the administrative authority issuing the document. The dissemination of this practice would facilitate the movement, study and work of millions of Citizens of the European Union. I therefore consider it important to work on a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on facilitating the free movement of citizens by simplifying administrative requirements, and I expect them not to be prolonged.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Mady Delvaux. on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the draft regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the transfer to the Court of the European Union of jurisdiction to decide, at first instance, on disputes between the Union and its agents (N8-0110/2015 - C8-0367/2015 - 2015/0906(COD)) (A8-0167/2016).

name: Mady Delvaux
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, this is not the first time this Parliament has looked at the European Court of Justice in this Parliament.  As you know, for several years now, the Court of Justice in Luxembourg and, above all, precisely, the Court of First Instance have been in a difficult situation due to the constant increase in litigation. The number of cases brought before the court increased from 398 in 2000 to 912 in 2014. Pending business accumulates year after year. Five appeals based on the breach of the duty to rule within a reasonable time have already been lodged. The total amount claimed amounts to almost 27 million euros, double the cost of implementing the reform. That is why we voted on 28 October 2015 for the Council's proposal to increase the number of judges in the Tribunal to two per Member State, abolish the Public Service Tribunal and include the seven judges of the Public Service Tribunal in the Trial Tribunal.  The regulation we are about to adopt is the second step - in short, the implementation of that decision. Its purpose is to transfer the judges of the Public Service Tribunal and, therefore, all cases pending before that court to the Tribunal. In Parliament, we have ensured consistency in this transfer and ensured the legal certainty of cases pending before the Public Service Tribunal. Thus, the pending cases will be transferred as they are and will remain subject to the same procedure. It remains to be hoped that this reorganization will add efficiency and quality to the work and decisions of judges. We want not only to guarantee our citizens faster justice but also high-quality justice. That is why it is worth remembering that we are advocating for more cases to be dealt with by chambers of five judges instead of three, and we also want the Tribunal to have specialized chambers.  I would like to remind the Member States that the European Parliament has explicitly voted for gender parity among judges, and therefore reminds Member States today to ensure that this parity is respected in the appointments they are proposing. Mr President, I will be frank, the solution chosen is not the best. I regret that the Member States have not been able to agree on a smaller increase in the number of judges and on a rotation system, but in the face of the Inflexibility of the Council, Parliament has taken its responsibilities.  European justice is in trouble, we must protect it and defend it by giving it the means to function. It is about securing an area of justice in the European Union, which is essential in a democracy.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Mr President, following the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, for the first time any modification of the Statute of the General Court has to be adopted in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure. The proposal which we are addressing today meets the immediate efficiency and performance-related needs of the General Court, and going beyond it seeks to strengthen the effectiveness of the European court system as a whole in a sustainable manner. I trust that its adoption will contribute to reducing the length of proceedings before the General Court, and this in turn will reduce the risk that the Union is found in breach of its duty, set out in Article 47 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, to rule on cases within a reasonable time. Furthermore, only one jurisdiction – the Court of Justice will be responsible for ensuring uniform interpretation of the law by hearing all appeals. This will simplify the judicial structure of the Union, enhance its overall efficiency and promote consistency in its case law. It is therefore important that the European Parliament support the current proposal in order to allow the European Court system to work in a more efficient manner.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are about to close the second phase of the reform of the Court of Justice of the European Union. We had a political debate about the necessity of this reform last year. At the moment, this is only a consequence of the actions we have carried out, the necessary consequence of the inclusion of the Civil Service Court in the Court of First Instance. The seven judges who have worked so far in the Civil Service Tribunal are judges who will not be the new judges of the Court; they will count in the number of judges already in place, so this change does not generate any additional costs, but brings huge benefits. I would like to draw your attention to the fact that, until now, the judges of the Civil Service Court have dealt exclusively with labour matters. They could not be entrusted with other matters, even though these judges were quite often left without an allocation of cases to deal with. The change that we are making, the latter part of the reform, will allow, firstly, the transfer of staff cases to the Court of First Instance – so they are not in danger, they will continue to be settled correctly – and, secondly, the allocation of other cases to judges who will not be dealing with staff matters at any given time, which has so far been impossible. This reform is, of course, necessary because, as Danuta Hübner said, it weighs on the quality of the functioning of the European justice system. I therefore ask the Court itself and the other institutions to remember that it is an important institution for all of us, that this reform will be assessed over the coming years, because it has many opponents.  I therefore hope that the revision clause contained in the regulation will force everyone to properly assess the effectiveness of the Court's work in the coming years, so that in a few years we can say whether we have made the right choices or made the right decisions, or whether we may have made a wrong one. I don't think we made a wrong er.

name: Evelyn Regner
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. This reform is undoubtedly quite a technical reform. The report is the fourth reform of the Court and, at the same time, a follow-up to the Marinho e Pinto report, in which, as we know, we have increased the number of judges from 28 to 56, so that each Member State has now been able to nominate two judges. The increase at that time was made on condition that the Civil Service Tribunal was dissolved and those disputes were referred back to the European Court of Justice. The provisions of the amendments are now clearer and the provisions on specialised courts are no longer applicable because there is currently no specialised court. The report also includes an amendment to the procedural organisation of the Court and its internal organisation, which is to be welcomed. Furthermore, and this is a particular concern for me, Mrs Delvaux's report once again makes it clear that there must also be a balanced representation of men and women in the appointment of judges. I would like to remind you that, in the vote on the Marinho e Pinto report, we made this a condition and we appealed to the Council to refer to this balance when the nominations are made. I'll do it again. At national level, this is already working, and the judicial posts are more or less well-balanced. That is what I would like to see at European level.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – I fully agree with the need for reform of the Court of Justice. This is a very important issue and it was high time there was such a report.  For a long time now, we have seen the need to find a comprehensive compromise from all political groups in all Member States on the subject. However, we must not ignore the fact that this compromise will be reached with an increase in the number of judges, an extremely difficult decision that has been the result of very long conversations. I would like to emphasise that this substantial change will lead to an increase in structural costs in the sector by at least 20 million more, which is still clear that they will be paid out of the pocket of European taxpayers. Moreover, there is insufficient convincing evidence to justify and justify this decision unconditionally.  When it comes to this topic, we must take into account both the scope and the costs and the possible consequences of that decision.

name: António Marinho e Pinto
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, as we say in Portugal, what is born left, late or never straightens out, and this dossier has been twisted since its inception. The lack of transparency in the General Court's statistics has hung over the whole process, and there is always doubt as to whether the procedural delays relied on were real.  As I have stressed here and in the Committee on Legal Affairs, there has been a deliberate willingness on the part of the Court to prevent Parliament from being properly informed, and many Members are therefore able to vote in conscience. As I said in my report, specialised courts are more economical and their decisions are of better legal quality. However, the opposite was chosen, that is, the most costly, more inflexible and only reversible solution with a new legislative initiative.  The Court's proposal, which is reverently supmendable by this Parliament, is based on a huge lie. As several Judges of the General Court have warned, the pending cases have virtually ceased to exist, but it has been decided to double the number of its judges, who are technically underemployed and in which there are no cases to be distributed to them, let alone the new judges being appointed.  The number of cases entered so far yesterday is much lower than the number of cases decided and predominantly relates to trade mark issues, which have decreased significantly, and competition, which have almost disappeared due to preventive action by the Commission.  The Civil Service Tribunal, which was unanimously recognised for its excellent legal quality and had a balanced cost, was simply abolished and replaced by an exorbitant spending solution paid by European taxpayers, some of them subject to heavy austerity measures.  This stage, Mr President, Commissioner, is just one of the harmful consequences of the error before. This dossier teaches you how to spend the most to get the minimum, that is, the worst results. Unfortunately, it is a very followed method in the European Union.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the transfer of jurisdiction in civil service disputes is part of an important reform of the Court of Justice. The function and efficiency of the EU court system is of the utmost importance for the whole EU legislation, and therefore we in Parliament have taken decisions which have also drawn a lot of criticism. We did it in spite of that.  So far Parliament has supported the Court reform and has kept its promises to the Court and to the Council, but Member States need to do the same and I refer to what colleagues have already raised. Last October the Council and Parliament made a joint statement saying that at the end of the reform process, in order to achieve equality between women and men, the Member States should, to the greatest possible extent, appoint women judges to ensure an equal presence of women and men in the EU Court. I am absolutely convinced that every EU Member State has talented and brilliant judges, both men and women, and I will make sure, for my part, that this Parliament will remind the Council of its promise, which seems to be broken, also in the future.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are at the umpteenth act of what our rapporteur, Mrs Delvaux, has also not hesitated to describe as a 'controversial reform of the Court of Justice'. Last October, this Parliament inappropriately endorsed the duplication of the number of judges at the Court of First Instance from 28 to 56. Parliament is now about to approve the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal, a decision whose constitutionality profiles have been called into question by distinguished lawyers, including university professors and judges of the Court of First Instance itself. I would like to make this quite clear: in addition to the waste of public resources, in addition to the negative considerations regarding the effects of the reform, it seems to us very questionable that the power of the EU legislator to create new courts should also include the power to abolish them, thereby amending a judicial architecture of a constitutional nature that appears in the founding Treaties. We believe in the rule of law and, consequently, we cannot approve a reform that ignores the Treaties.

name: Georg Mayer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Courts, as we all know, are at the heart of jurisprudence in parliamentary democracies and are therefore always a sensitive matter, especially when it comes to their occupation and when politics has its fingers in play. It is also clear to us that the subjects have a right to fast procedures and to quick decisions. As I know from many personal reports, the workload of this Court has increased considerably over the last ten years. In that respect, therefore, there is nothing to object to the replacement or replacement of these judges.  However, it is the procedure that bothers me here, because it is a typical approach of this European Union. Twelve additional judges were requested by the Court. What are you doing now? 28 are ordered. I wonder what happens to the 16 judges who were not actually needed. Are they going for a walk for the next few years, and who pays for it all? In the end, unfortunately, these things always remain at the back when it comes to such occupations. And what is still particularly important to me is the professional appointment of these judges. They should not be politically occupied, but unfortunately this is largely the case.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, a few months ago I expressed here my opposition to the doubling of judges, for reasons that have been taken up by other colleagues of mine. That measure had no basis, no objective reasons and is in danger of turninging a very delicate and important structure for the European institutions. Mrs Delvaux's work is a valuable and important one, trying to remedy some of the distortions that were already easily foreseeable. It will now be very important to ensure that the Civil Service Tribunal, which will be absorbed by the rest of the Court and which has acquired invaluable powers over the years, does not see these powers removed, because if that were the case, we would also have the mockery. I would add that, even with regard to the subject repeatedly raised about the recognition of the role of women in this activity, namely gender equality in the implementation of the future Court, good intentions are not enough, we need constraints. Otherwise we will continue to talk about the enhancement of women's work, the necessary presence of women, but we will not have concrete results. So, if this issue remains a subject that is raised and does not translate into concrete action, I believe that it will lose value and credibility in the eyes of european citizens. That is why I believe that quotas are binding and necessary to be introduced into a desirable integration of the rule.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The ing ing up of the Civil Service Tribunal by the European Court of Justice, one of its institutions, is, as mentioned in this debate, the implementation of previous assumptions. But I would like to say that even this very short discussion, which has been going on here for several minutes, speaks in favour of reconsideiing how this reform will be implemented. There are very important arguments here that are critical of this project, this reform. From within the Court of Justice – and therefore the judges themselves have serious doubts – the question of costs has been raised. Finally, all this should be placed in the context of the debate on the effectiveness of the European Court of Justice, its accessibility and the transparency and effectiveness of judgments. Frankly, having listened to the voices of colleagues from very different political formations, I would argue that we should think again about this reform before we make a decision in the vote. This is too delicate a matter to do in a hurry, and on this matter consensus, broad consensus is particularly needed.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, here we are at the end of the fourth reform of the Court of Justice, the abolition of the Public Service Tribunal. This, like the increase in the number of judges at the Tribunal, has been disgraceful and irresponsible. No in-depth analysis of Article 257 of the FUE Treaty as a legal basis for removing it, no analysis of the impact, costs or its consequences on other jurisdictions have been carried out. I kept reminding you of that in committee. The European Union is not stingy with costly and unnecessary spending on European taxpayers, while austerity is falling on national courts.  We knew the Union's contempt for the peoples of Europe, and we saw this with its own judges and civil servants, who were not consulted. Continue this way: every day, our compatriots discover more about the true face of the European Union. Remember, the important thing is not the fall but the landing. Yours will be painful. The spring of the European peoples is approaching.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I made it clear last autumn when discussing the reform of the Court of Justice that, in my opinion, there are no grounds for doubling the number of judges, that this is more or less a political decision and that I did not vote for it. While it is true that the Court's agenda is growing, it is not increasing to the point where 28 judges suddenly become 56 judges. This is a reality, and anyone who has dealt with the burden of the courts a little bit, I have dealt with the subject in the Czech Republic, it was quite clear to him that he could easily increase the number of judges by only a few specific judges, not by twice the number. However, having already done so, and as I have already mentioned, I did not agree with this, so I think it makes sense to complete the reform in that area, that the Civil Service Tribunal will be abolished and its agenda will therefore be transferred to the General Court. Rather, it is a follow-up effort to find enough work for the Court of Justice, which will have twice the number of judges in the future, while the agenda is not so extensive. This is, in my opinion, conceptually wrong, however, from the point of view of taxpayers at least here, some money will be saved. I am prepared to support this transfer of a specialised institution to the Civil Service Tribunal, but I am saying that, unfortunately, the whole concept of reform had only a political background and did not correspond to common sense.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, trust in European justice is essential for the proper functioning of the European Union. That's why I reject the cost issue. For a just and effective justice, it is not costs that are a problem, but how it works. The proposed reform ensures greater efficiency and improves the functioning of the European legal system. Sometimes changes generate concerns, but it should be noted that this regulation is the result of institutional dialogue and can increase the efficiency of European justice. It is certainly not only the Rules of Procedure of the General Court that need to be amended, but also its internal organisation. I therefore agree with the proposal by the rapporteur and the Commission to apportion a greater number of cases, where their importance justifies it, so as to ensure consistency and quality of case-law. Thematic synergies can be a solution to this and I believe that it is also necessary to reflect on the possibility of adopting rules and practices for the allocation of cases. Last but not least, the gender parity demanded by the European Parliament must be respected, because, after all, joint decisions also contribute to the proper functioning of European justice.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, we are discussing the transfer to the General Court of the European Union of jurisdiction to hear disputes between the Union and its officials at first instance. It was originally proposed by the Court of Justice and the General Court to increase the number of Judges of the General Court to 56, so that each Member State could appoint two Judges. At the same time, this increase also required the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal. However, this Regulation decides to increase the number of Judges of the General Court from 40 to 47 and to abolish the Civil Service Tribunal, which consisted of seven Judges, which will be transferred to the General Court. Finally, given that between 2000 and 2010 there was a 65% increase in cases submitted to the General Court and 1300 cases were pending at the end of 2010, it is necessary to increase the number of judges to 56, two per Member State in order to cope with the increased workload at the General Court.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, coherence, legal protection of citizens, efficiency in the trial, consistency in the trial, of course all are beautiful values and terms used in this report. However, I also want to show some reservations, because I am not sure that this reform will automatically bear the fruit we want and I am not sure that it will be accepted everywhere with enthusiasm. In fact, we see already in this discussion that we have serious problems and serious objections.  That is why I invite you to go into reform, but to make this reform gradually. This is how we get into a situation where we will certainly get complaints, we will have a situation where this report will also experience many criticisms in public. I am in need of reform, but to gradually enter into reform, and if we already do it and if it is accepted in the end that we have two new judges in each member state, then certainly gender equality, we must not give up on that in any way.

name: n/a
text: We would like to thank Commissioner Avramopoulos for following the whole debate, but the Commission has informed us that it does not wish to take part in this debate, which is based, as has been said several times, on a proposal from the Court of Justice.

name: Mady Delvaux
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I believe that everything has been said in this debate. This is the second time in six months that we have discussed this. The positions of both have not changed.  I would therefore like to conclude by saying that I hold in very high regard the justice, all the courts, but above all the Court of Justice of the European Union. I am confident that it will be able to organise itself as best as possible in the service of the Union's justice system.  And, once again, I would like to remind Member States to pay particular attention to gender parity when appointing.

text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, June 9, 2016. (The sitting was suspended at 4.25 p.m. and resumed at 4.50 p.m.) Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. It proposes the abolition of a so-called 'special' court (the one dedicated to resolving disputes), because its functions would be carried out by the Court of Justice, as the court's staff is expected to increase considerably, until the number of judges is doubled. It is not clear, however, why this need will certainly require a considerable amount of public money. In addition, in this way, a function that was entrusted to highly qualified judges for the matter in question, will instead pass to more "generalist" judges, with a consequent lowering of quality. Efficient and effective justice is the primary right of all European citizens, and this must be the sole objective of any action in this area.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – This Regulation follows the third Regulation reforming the Court of Justice, which concerned an increase in the number of judges in the General Court to 56 so that each Member State could nominate two judges. This change was conditional on the dismantling of the Civil Service Court and the referral of its disputes back to the EU Court, as the report relates.  The reform of the judicial system of the Court of Justice of the EU has been originally set out in three separate stages. In the first stage, 12 judges were nominated. In the second, a further seven judges will be transferred from the abolished Civil Service Court, which will increase the number of members of the EU Court to 47 as of 1 September 2016. The third phase will involve the appointment of a further nine judges in 2019. In conclusion, the procedure for gradually increasing the number of Judges of the General Court will be completed in 2019, when the Court of Justice will be composed of two judges from each Member State, including seven judges from the abolished European Union Civil Service Tribunal, who will join the EU Court on 1 September 2016.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next point is the Council and Commission statements on improving the exchange of data and the use of European information systems and databases in the fight against serious international crime and terrorism (2016/2760(RSP)).

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, we are appalled by the horrific terrorist acts which we recently faced and which we strongly condemn. We stand determined in our common fight against terrorism. This is an attack on our open democratic society. This is what we stated on 24 March, two days after the Brussels attacks, at an extraordinary meeting of the Ministers of Justice and Home Affairs. Here, Ministers underlined the urgent need to increase the systematic feeding and consistent use of our different databases and their interoperability. Improving the information exchange and the interoperability of the European Union’s information systems has been a key topic for our Presidency and was cemented in the joint statement on 24 March. Besides the enormous importance of collecting information, it is of equal importance to connect the dots – that is often forgotten – and to make the best use of the information we have. This is why the Presidency has taken up the initiative of developing a roadmap on information exchange and information management, which will be submitted to the Council this Friday. This roadmap provides a coherent framework for a more integrated European Union information architecture in the justice and home affairs area. It lists a number of key challenges in information exchange, as well as principles and guidelines to be followed. The first of these principles is, of course, full respect for fundamental rights and data protection rules, which are the core values of our citizens. The roadmap contains practical, short and medium-term points with which  action can be undertaken quickly, as well as long-term orientations to enhance information management and information exchange in three domains: first, law enforcement, including judicial cooperation in criminal matters; second, detection of persons involved in terrorism and terrorism-related activity and their travel movements; and, third, border management and migration. The essence of the roadmap is to make sure that the practitioners have access to the information they need. I think this is a very important point.  The politics of all this is in its practical operationality – I mean the police officer in an urban neighbourhood, the border guard at a checkpoint or the immigration officer dealing with a visa application. They have to connect the dots; they have to understand what kind of information they get, how they can get it, where they can get it and how it is in real time. They can do their work best when they have access to high-quality systems with high-quality information that can facilitate their task. We are very well aware of the fact that this is only one part of the process. An equally important part relates to the communication on stronger and smarter IT systems that the Commission presented on 6 April. The High-Level Expert Group which the Commission announced in this communication will play an important role in developing a more long-term view for the future of the information systems and databases of the European Union.  The Presidency attaches the highest importance to working closely with the European Parliament on these issues. Your role as co-legislator will be crucial when addressing some of the challenges lying ahead, particularly, of course, when legislative changes are required to achieve our common objective. I can also inform you that the Council, at its meeting on 10 June will again address the Member States’ feeding and use of the databases, such as the SIS, VIS, Europol and Interpol databases, on the basis of a report by the counter-terrorism coordinator. We have to feed and use the information systems to the maximum extent since this is a condition sine qua non for an efficient sharing of information.  There has been very substantial progress over the past year and we will continue to strive for further improvement as soon as possible. In this way, we will be able to continuously improve our information exchange. The quality of information is as important as the quantity. The information that we store, share and use is information about citizens, so it needs to be protected. Citizens have to be confident that this information is used and shared on the basis of proportionality and only for well-described limited purposes. We need to protect our societies but we need to do so without becoming Big Brother. That is the big challenge. In fighting terrorism, we need to uphold our values. Otherwise, the very society that we aim to protect will suffer as a result.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, ‘strength is in unity’, according to the famous ancient quote. Here is what we needed to look for in the Union, in our Union. The unity of the Union. Unity for our security. This is the crucial challenge facing all of us, because our most important duty is to ensure the security of our citizens. In today’s security environment, strength equals information and knowledge. In fact, the capacity to both share and make smart use of information. Information sharing is our only effective weapon against asymmetric and unpredictable threats, and limiting information in our national boxes does not provide security. It is exactly the opposite. The recent tragic events in Brussels and Paris showed again Europe’s major weakness in fighting terrorism. First among them: our information sharing. I am sure you will agree on that. The architecture of our systems for borders and security needs to improve. Sharing information is the strongest example of trust between us. It is not about reinventing the wheel, either. Plenty of tools to exchange information effectively are already in place. Let me give you an example. The Prüm framework. This is potentially a powerful tool against crime, because it automatically compares DNA, fingerprints and vehicle data. But Prüm is only as useful as the amount of information we put in it. It is only as helpful as the number of Member States connected to it. Implementation in practice remains poor. We are using our powers under the Treaties to get better results, but we all need to understand the importance of implementing what we agree, without going to the courts. That is why we presented our vision on Stronger and Smarter Information Systems for Borders and Security already in April, because we saw these problems and we saw the need to bring change, both practically and structurally. First, it is clear that some systems do not work as well as they should. The Schengen Information System contains only names, not fingerprints. Persons with fraudulent documents can go through it quite easily. A fingerprint functionality will be developed urgently in the coming months. Second, there are information gaps which are not covered by any system. We have third-country nationals who do not need visas. When not traveling by air, there is no information about them before they arrive. An EU travel information and authorisation system will be proposed to close this gap. Third, our information landscape is complex and fragmented. Border guards and police officers cannot consult multiple EU systems at the same time. Not all Member States are connected to all systems. Information is stored separately in various unconnected systems. This fragmentation makes us vulnerable. To be useful, our data systems must be interoperable and interconnected. The Entry/Exit System we proposed in April is interconnected and interoperable with the Visa Information System. What we want for the future is to have a common repository of data for different information systems, which will contain all the basic data. Other, more thematic systems, such as the Visa Information System, would be connected to it, with all necessary safeguards for the protection of personal data. All this is not to say that information sharing should improve at the expense of fundamental rights: freedom and security are two sides of the same coin. You cannot have freedom without security. We are now in the final stages of establishing an expert group to look at different options on interoperability. The group will meet this month for the first time, and we will work to give us policy input for decisions next year. We have already invited the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) to work with the experts in this process. Our expert group will work in coordination with the interoperability roadmap of the Council. Let me close by saying that it will be our clear priority in the next 12 months. We will continue to put emphasis on implementation and where there are structural information gaps, we will address them decisively, and with a clear vision to improve the security of our citizens.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work she has First of all, thank you very much for this debate. I think it is essential that we should put the issue of information exchange more closely on the agenda, because there are various shortcomings. On the one hand, there are shortcomings on the part of the Member States in ensuring that effective data exchange is carried out and that the measures of mutual trust actually bring together the relevant data. I also believe that Europol's capacity must be stepped up in order to be able to act in a united and united manner in bringing together information and analysing it. The quality of information plays a major role in particular. But there is also a task on the part of this House, which is brought to us by Member States, namely that law enforcement authorities must have access to EURODAC and, conversely, that Frontex and border authorities must have access to SIS and the dangerous file, so that we can identify terrorists who use or abuse the migration stream at an appropriate early stage. I would also ask colleagues to bear in mind at ECRIS that fingerprints create the possibility of actually identifying them, and if there is no possibility of identifying the fingerprints, it means that you are severely disabled in exchange and have great difficulties.
