I would also ask that we use the entry/exit system in the exchange of information and introduce it as quickly as possible, so that people's confidence in the security of our external borders increases significantly.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: I would like to inform you that, because of the suspension of the sitting, I am now unable to answer 'blue card' questions, but I would like to give everyone a say in the catch the eye procedure.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. Similarly, we have always faced terrorist threats in Europe. For decades, we have lived with terrorism in Spain, Ireland, elsewhere. Recently, threats have come from the outside. But the first phenomenon is not the result of the second and vice versa, which many people like to convince. That is also why I am concerned about this Commission's plan on the future of information systems, which it has presented, in fact, together with the smart borders proposal. The Commission wants to address new threats and challenges by combining databases and building a kind of 'big brother'. The number of passengers will increase sharply in the future. Probably the number of threats, too. Technology will advance, and criminals are likely to be one step ahead of it. The dangers must, of course, be combated, and we must be able to identify and prevent potential threats. But we're not going to do that by setting up new super databases. First of all, it is necessary to thoroughly assess existing systems and to remedy any shortcomings. Above all, their use needs to be improved. The spread of already known information is going down sharply. We have also been taught this by the recent terrorist attacks in Paris, in Brussels. We in Parliament have repeatedly called for the exchange of information to be essential. I am by no means opposed to new effective solutions in the field of information technology. But only when you protect your personal information. We must treat the suspect of a criminal act and a normal tourist very differently, as well as their personal data. Our intention is not to prevent the work of judicial and security authorities, but we cannot in any way agree to completely unrestricted and systematic access to everyone's personal data. Our common future also depends on today's debate, and we will all be responsible for how far we go in the privacy of Europeans.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – The sharing of information is vital for the surveillance of our external borders, for the integrity of the Schengen area and thus also for ensuring our security. We must prevent attacks from continuing to plague Europe. We must prevent governments from having no choice but to close their borders, as the only way to keep criminals out of Europe. We must prevent the public from losing all confidence.  This matter must therefore be taken decisively. A change in mentality at Member State level is required. Yes, security is their competence, but information must be exchanged. Not in bulk, because then it will be for the police forces even to look for a needle in a haystack. But concrete hits must be effectively shared between like-minded intelligence agencies. We need to make the most of existing databases such as the SIS system, which can be used to identify people and goods as detectable. Europol, the EU agency in which a specialised counter-terrorism unit has recently been active, must also be at the heart of this. Belgium is one of the best pupils in the class in this respect, but other Member States are less industrious.  I also welcome the various new initiatives. The ECRIS initiative, for example, which is currently working on a database of convicted foreigners. I can also refer to the reform of Europol, which integrated the Internet cell into regular operation. Together with private ICT partners, the cell is trying to detect and remove jihadist content online. In the context of the creation of the European Border and Coast Guard, too, we are now paying particular attention to access to databases. Without quick access to up-to-date and accurate information, we will always limp on the back. And the terrorists are only too happy to use that. Europe can indeed provide a targeted added value in this area and must not pass up that opportunity.

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, when I saw the title of today’s debate I was really optimistic. I thought this is wonderful; finally we are going to talk about something that we have been calling for a long time: data sharing. This is long overdue because there have been so many examples of terrorist attacks where we found out after the attacks that the information was available, but it had not been shared.  But if I look more closely at what is on the table today, I am actually very disappointed because I get the impression that this is not about more information sharing, this is about collecting more personal data. There is a big difference between mandatory information sharing of vital information and leaving it to the Member States’ discretion whether or not they will share information.  We can have a communication about interoperability, but that is the technical side of things. If the political will is still not there to share vital information, not between two friendly EU Member States, but throughout the European Union, then we are not making any progress here, and then this is all just technical. I get the feeling that the political will is still not there.  Then, I also wonder what are we actually talking about?  I am very curious what will be in this roadmap and it would have been very practical for this debate if we had had the text of the roadmap beforehand. Now maybe I have overlooked it, but it would have been very good to have the text beforehand, because now we do not know what we are actually talking about it. Is this about connecting databases? Is this about collecting more data? Is it only about travel data as some people seem to assume? Why not? Other police information that is probably more useful actually for fighting terrorism? Who is going to provide oversight, not only on the data protection issues, but also in terms of effectiveness? So actually I have lost my optimism on seeing the title. I am a bit more sceptical after this debate, but maybe when I see the road map, which apparently will be adopted on Friday, I will be optimistic again.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, yesterday it was made public that eight relatives of King Juan Carlos used screen societies and accounts in tax havens to divide the million-dollar heritage of María Cristina de Borbón. We already know the cases of Commissioner Cañete's family or the former president of the International Monetary Fund, Mr Rato. These are examples of cross-border crime, tax evasion. Accounts in Switzerland, offshore companies in Panama, or companies in the Virgin Islands. These are the Spanish patriots who take the money to tax havens, who empty the public coffers to keep filling their pockets.  They cannot put forward a proposal for measures against cross-border crimes here thinking of cutting us down on freedoms and shielding borders when many of the offenders are already inside - even in La Zarzuela they have gotten into. Measures against cross-border crime are also to wipe out tax havens or banking secrecy, but I know that some people are not interested and others are directly complicit.

name: Eva Joly
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, improving data exchange is an essential element in the fight against terrorism. The transnational dimension of the most serious crimes requires greater cooperation in this area and more efficient use of European databases, while ensuring respect for fundamental rights, particularly in data protection. In this regard, the principle of limiting purpose is very important: a database that is used for a specific purpose should not be suddenly used for other purposes. For example, the Schengen information system contains data on innocent people, such as missing persons, who should not be interconnected with terrorism-related databases, since there is no link between the two. If we take the lead in the direction of greater interoperability of European databases, it is essential to also provide a harmonised framework for data protection. The two are and must be linked. This is necessary to avoid fragmentation, as the new Police Data Protection Directive does not cover the databases discussed here, such as the Schengen Information System. The establishment of a common set of data protection rules must therefore be an integral part of this path towards greater interoperability. The coherence and effectiveness of our system is at stake, and above all, the protection of our fundamental rights is at stake.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. –Thank you very much, Madam President. Of course, in the United Kingdom, a lot of the debate on the European Union at the moment – as you know, we have a referendum coming up on June – is focussing on matters of security. We are being told by the Remain campaign that somehow Britain would not be secure if we were to leave the European Union. Of course we get most of our information on international terrorism in the UK from the Five Eyes Alliance, which doesn’t require political union or the handing—over of sovereignty. We also participate in Interpol, which has 190 members and was established long before Europol, just adding to the fact that NATO has kept the peace in Europe since 1945. They also lead on counter—terrorism and have a centre of excellence, focusing on cyber—crime, in Estonia. But having said all of that, of course, we in the UK want to continue to work together with our neighbours and friends across Europe. This is not a debate about Brexit in the UK or to say that the UK wants to be some kind of ‘little England’ separated from the continent; rather we want to be a United Kingdom that takes its place in the wider world, but continues to be good friends and good neighbours with Europe. So of course a post—Brexit UK would continue to want to be good friends and good neighbours with Europe and to share data, perhaps, in the right way.  However, in terms of this report, as we are seeing today, there will be questions about what data will be collected on citizens. There will be questions to be asked, I am sure, at a later date.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is above all the absence of border controls. If you do not believe it, ask Austria, which is not by chance armored the Brenner border. This common database doesn't work because it can't work, it's a virtually empty database. No state sends data, it is impossible for states to give content to these databases in the absence of effective control, for example, over the communities of Islamists in general, the illegal immigrants who continue to flow, even now to Lampedusa via the Italian coasts, without any effective control, as they have entered in the tens, perhaps hundreds of thousands, in recent years alone. Since 2014, foreign fighters from Iraq and Syria have more than doubled. It is currently estimated that there are around 6 000, two thirds of whom have returned to Europe, but only 60% have been reported to Europol. This is your data, it's not my data. The calculation is made, among other things, on the basis of only five countries. The databases do not work if the external borders, in addition to the internal borders, are a sieve and are a sieve: we pick them up from illegal immigrants, we cannot control them, we do not control them, we do not want to control them. What is the point of our authorities knowing whether Mohammed or Abdul are foreign fighters if they can then freely enter and leave the borders. The bombers of the recent attacks have been identified and reported in part, but not subject to measures, free to move like wild birds, to go back and leave Brussels and to go to Paris to return, they are forest birds, they do what they want.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Madam President, since the European Union and third countries also operate as a single area of free movement of persons, it makes sense for all kinds of illegals and criminals, from terrorists to arms and drug traffickers, to exploit the structural weaknesses of the Schengen Treaty for the benefit of their activities. In addition, problematic cooperation between police authorities in the various countries of Europe creates even more gaps and opportunities for all those who have such purposes. The exchange of information and data under certain conditions could improve the situation somewhat, but unfortunately there are also many questions and negative aspects here. First of all, the exchange of data alone does not solve the problem, since the problems of competence and jurisdiction of the services, the different legal framework of each country and the inability to coordinate and use information at pan-European level remain unresolved.  But even if we were to establish a single European police force, perhaps in the long run we would create more problems than we would solve. One of the main problems is that there is no reliable authority to control how data and information collected are used. Who's going to take on this role? Even if the Commission took on this role, it does not in fact have any democratic legitimacy for this. Recent incidents have shown us that even state authorities are willing to make the information they collect available to third parties or to use this data for political persecution of their ideological opponents. The only logical option at the moment would be to restore border controls by the Member States until at least a convincing answer to these problems is found.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE).
text: – Fl-aħħar xhur, ilkoll kemm aħna għaddejna minn żminijiet diffiħli b'riżultat tal-attakki terroristi大i fl-Ewropa. I'd like to see Ewropej irrispondew quddiem dawn l-attakki b'determinazzjoni biex ikomplu jgħixu l-ħajja b'mod normali. Irridu nibqgħu viġilanti. Il-ħajja tkompli imma t-theddida ta' aktar attakki tibqa' magħna u allura rridu lkoll kemm aħna nagħmlu l-almu tagħna biex inaqqsu l-possibilitajiet ta' attakki simili u ġodda. L-aġenziji responsabbli mill-infurzar tal-liġijiet jeħtieġ li jkollhom il-mezzikollha li għandhom bżonn biex jirrispondu għal kull thedida li jkun hemm. Ma jistax ikun li dawn ikunu pass lura minn min ikollu pjan li jagħmel attakk terrorista. Waħda mit-tagħlimiet li ħadna b'riżultat tal-attakki terroristi大i f'Pariġi u Brussell hi li l-iskambju tal-informazzjoni bejn l-aġenziji mhux effi大jenti u effika大i daqm nistennew u hu meħtie. Nafu li teżisti ħafna informazzjoni, li qed tinġabar ħafna informazzjoni, imma s-sistemi użati jvarjaw minn pajjiż għall-ieħor u allura tonqos l-effiħjenza. Mhux a大大ettabbli li ma jsir xejn u li i jsirux arranġamenti aħjar. Jeħtieġ li l-iskambju tal-informazzjoni mingħajr diffikultajiet ta' kompatibilità minn sistemi bħal SIS, VIS, EURODAC, ECRIS isiru realtà. Fl-istess waqt, irridu li l-awtoritajiet responsabbli mill-infurzar tal-liġijiet u l-aġenziji Ewropej ikollhom a大大ess għal din l-informazzjoni. Naturalment, irid ikun hemm is-salvagwardji kollha meħtieġa biex ikun hemm protezzjoni tad-data, iżda madankollu i nistgħux na大大ettaw l-istatus quo jew it-tkaxkir tas-saqajn. Nikkonkludi: irridu nibqgħu fuq quddiem fil-ġlieda kontra t-terroriżmu u b'inizjattivi maħsuba li jsaħħu l-effiħjenza, l-organizzazzjoni u s-sigurtà ta大-ittadini tagħna.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The terrible terrorist attacks of recent times have also affected us because they have made our helplessness manifest. They surprised us because we were not able to use the available information accordingly. Yes, the information was at least there. It is therefore right that we learn the lessons to prevent this from happening in the future. I welcome the fact that the Council and the Commission are expressing their views on this, but also national parliaments, such as the German Bundestag, which is dealing with this issue at the same time today. The idea is not to create new intelligence services and investigative authorities, but to network existing databases, i.e. to make them interoperable. There is no objection to this, quite the contrary. One could criticise the fact that this is only now happening. But one should not expect a) the solution of all problems, as if it were a miracle machine, and b) one should also see the problems associated with it. I see three major problems. It can lead to completely new problems if the application is not in line with the case law of the ECJ, is not in conformity with fundamental rights and does not comply with the principles of data protection. Just as we have given the data protection officers a key role in Europol, so must the linkage of these databases. Secondly, we should also consider whether there are already instruments that are not being used, for whatever reason, such as the decision of the Minister of justice in 2005 on the mandatory exchange of information in the event of terrorist offences. So, before we do something new, we need an inventory of existing instruments, and we have to ask ourselves why this is not being applied. There must be reasons for this, and this should also be taken into account in our analyses. I also believe that it is not enough to rely on the mere networking of databases to solve the problem. This is blue-eyed. Not only does it need machine intelligence, but it also needs personnel, it also needs human intelligence, and that, it seems to me, is one of the very important things that joint investigation teams, such as those that exist within Europol, should be developed in order to solve the problem proactively.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the right to life comes first. People died in Paris, in Brussels, in Istanbul. What are we waiting for? We must ensure their security and we must ensure their right to life. We currently have information systems and databases that provide or provide relevant data to police and border officers, mostly on people crossing external borders. I am referring to the Schengen information system, Europol, Interpol and other data systems. But the exchange of information between the Member States that we are talking about today and the transmission by Member States of information in these databases are closely linked. If the Member States do not transmit all relevant information in these Schengen databases, Europol, Interpol, others, then the exchange of information is no longer effective, border management cannot be done and people will continue to die. We won't be able to provide security. What's the point of having these tools and not using them?

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I am glad to hear that the Commission decided to stress the importance of data sharing. In fact this should not be an option but a must. However, what is the reality today? A number of databases full of holes. If there is a lesson to be learned from the recent terror attacks then it is the following: data sharing by the police and all other security services must improve. National egos are creating potholes on the information highway and this is not acceptable.  We do not need to go far back in time, since recently a law was passed that did not include systematic mandatory data sharing: that was the PNR file making its way through this House. There is a massive gap between planning and execution, between ambitions and reality. The system can only succeed if individual Member States deliver information. Member States, however, are still not obliged to do so. There is no need for new instruments. It would only challenge our freedom without protecting us. Mandatory data sharing is the only possible way forward.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am pleased that Commissioner Avramopoulus has said the key phrase: there is no freedom without security. After all, the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, the fact that many of the bombers were already registered as terror suspects in Europe, but were able to travel without problems to join islamic state and then return to Europe as migrants, shed light on the shortcomings of information sharing. According to the EU Counter-Terrorism Coordinator, the biggest challenge at the moment is not to fill in and replace data in the available systems, so the most important thing in the field of information transfer is that Member States make better use of existing European systems and develop them.  Setting up a European Counter-Terrorism Centre within Europol is a good initiative. Two days ago, the Hungarian Parliament approved the establishment of the Counter-Terrorism Information and Crime Analysis Centre, which is responsible for putting together a comprehensive picture of the country's terrorist threat or other serious criminal threat. It would be essential to set up similar centres and work closely together across Europe.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – The Attacks in Paris and Brussels show that we need more Europe for our security and prove the interdependence between internal and external security. Combating terrorism and other forms of organised crime is a priority that no Member State can pursue on its own: it imposes capacity-sharing, in particular in intelligence, justice and police, including border and customs.  Only then will we be able to meet the objectives of the Security Agenda. Today we have a European data protection framework that allows safer data sharing between law enforcement and judicial authorities, a framework that, by imposing respect for fundamental rights, including the principles of purpose and proportionality, allows the protection of blockages and flaws in the architecture of data management control and to combat fragmentation, including the need for security and border control. A framework establishing and regulating the conditions for speeding up interoperability between internal security force databases in each Member State and at European level. And that it requires that in each State, and together, deficiencies in the functionalities of existing systems and, therefore, in the scope and effectiveness of interoperability are eliminated.  Moreover, last month this Parliament adopted a new EUROPOL regulation, which requires the strengthening of democratic control of police cooperation, to be exercised by the European Parliament in association with national parliaments. We want to be more effective in the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing. What has been lacking is political will on the part of the Member States to make their agents and services committed to the use of existing European mechanisms. Agents and services that need to have enhanced resources and capabilities and do not continue to be asphyxiated by budgetary constraints.   The terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels demonstrate how expensive ly we pay for fragmentation, mistrust and disunity. In order to have more Europe in the security and defence of citizens, including in the defence of fundamental freedoms, we need to get rid of neoliberal policies that, by fostering unemployment, social exclusion and discrimination, fuel the resentment of so many young Europeans who join the ranks of Daesh, many radicalising themselves online.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I have always said that we must use every tool available in the fight against terror and serious organised crime. It is vital that we make it easier to enable information-sharing and cooperation to take place between national governments. Terrorism, of course, knows no borders: it is extremely important that there is as much transnational cooperation as possible, particularly in terms of data sharing. We have come a long way in cross-border cooperation, so let us not slow down or stop now. I welcome the recent vote in the Parliament on Passenger Name Record (PNR). The recent phenomenon of so-called foreign fighters returning from the Middle East poses many challenges for our intelligence agencies, and collecting PNR data can be instrumental in detecting and tracking suspicious behaviour of radicalised individuals. In terms of transnational cooperation in the fight against terror we should also note that the European Arrest Warrant has played an instrumental role in tackling dissident Republican terrorism and serious organised crime in my own constituency of Northern Ireland and the border with the Republic of Ireland. I notice that the Commissioner in his address spoke of gaps. Today, Commissioner – and to the Council – you cannot afford to have any gaps in border security. You must have better border control. Schengen has proved not to be effective. Commissioner, it is extremely wise not to leave your back door wide open.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE).
text: – The events of the last few months have clearly shown us that the timely sharing of information between member states' services and between them and Europol is a vital necessity. There are numerous European databases – SIS, Europol's database, the passenger data system, the introduction of a database in relation to the Smart Borders package is discussed. However, only the collection of information, however valuable, could not help us in the fight against terrorism and organised crime if it was not shared in a timely and complete manner between all national security systems. I believe that, in the face of a systematic threat, it is essential that Member States start cooperating fully and introducing automated data exchange between their systems and Europol, because only supranational sharedness can counter modern cross-border criminal networks.

name: Axel Voss (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The security situation in the EU has deteriorated enormously in recent years, and many radicalised religious extremists are also coming with the refugees. This permanent threat is unbalanced the EU's internal security. The fight against terrorism must therefore also be a priority. This extreme threat now also forces us to think about competences and forms of cooperation. Data analysis offers solutions here without always immediately invoking the dismantling of fundamental rights by the evil state. But data protection must not and must not be above the protection of citizens' lives. It is therefore a question of linking the existing instruments vertically and horizontally. I believe that, firstly, we need a central interface which will enable several information systems to be searched at the same time. Secondly, the data collected in one system should also be able to be automatically queried by other systems. Thirdly, we also need the establishment of a common service for the comparison of biometric data. Fourthly, we should clarify whether a common database would actually reduce multiple surveys and multiple storages, which would therefore be in line with the principle of data economy. Fifthly, quality must take the highest order of data, and sixthly Europol should be used and developed as a better platform for exchange.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Minister, Commissioner, the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels a few months ago have highlighted even more, if need be, the urgent need for coordinated action at European level, without which it will be difficult to combat terrorism, international terrorism, a phenomenon that goes beyond the borders of the individual Member State. , as is the case with organised crime. This too, and we are finally beginning to be aware of this, is a phenomenon of transnational crime sometimes linked to terrorism or to the most serious crimes, such as trafficking in human beings, and for which only full cross-border cooperation between law enforcement authorities can make the fight against trafficking effective. After the tragic terrorist incidents in Europe, we have sadly learned one lesson: the exchange of information between national authorities has not worked. We learned later that in some cases those responsible for these crimes were already known in some Member States. Of course, we are not here today and this is not the place to understand what has not worked, but we are here to provide adequate answers to the threat of terrorism and the most serious cross-border crimes. This House recently approved the new Europol regulation and the PNR directive, which is also to be used to prevent and combat international terrorism. The revision of the ECRIS system is also to be welcomed in this respect. These and other existing instruments, however, will not be really effective unless the Member States provide adequate database feed with the desire to pool information, a need that is also being evaluated in the updating of the directive on combating terrorism. Finally, the Commission communication of 6 April to improve the interoperability of information systems is important both for better border management and for external security. Here too, however, we need the right balance between the information provided for security purposes and the fundamental need for respect for rights and privacy.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, in Europe data is gathered in silence. So why is it important? Because it creates data duplication and lack of interoperability and it simply deters data exchange. We clearly do not lack databases in Europe. The problem is that these databases do not communicate with each other. The answer is certainly not a super database and, even less, creating a database accessible for all. It is about setting a framework that interconnects them, making sure that outgoing data is encrypted and all incoming data is authenticated and logged to create trust, protect privacy and get maximum impact from this data collection.  Member States are already implementing such solutions to deploy digital services: X-road is the Estonian example. I fail to understand why the Commission still has not tried to solve this problem. The real problem is the lack of data-sharing using existing technology and technological solutions that are already in place.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, we all know here that the European Union has significant shortcomings in the interconnection of information systems between the Member States and the Institutions of the European Union itself.  We were able to see for ourselves after the attacks in Paris or in Brussels in March that the information system between countries and the exchange of information was not sufficient. And although the European Union and the European Commission, together with the Member States, have tried to take a number of steps to improve the situation, in practice this information sharing still does not work. In particular, as regards the monitoring of investigations of foreign fighters or the trafficking of illicit firearms or the financing of terrorism. These are, in my opinion, essential data that we must not only be able to deal with quickly but also safely, but also use effectively in the fight against terrorism.  How can we continue to protect European citizens when we are unable to secure the fundamental cause, and that is the exchange of information within the States of the European Union? Personally, I think that the European Counter-Terrorism Centre plays a crucial role in this issue, and I firmly believe that it will be set up.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Cross-border crime and terrorism can no longer be combated only nationally. Yes, we need Europe-wide cooperation between states, authorities and institutions. Well, but this is not a new knowledge, God knows, it is now a truism. And after the recent tragic terrorist attacks, it has been repeated and explained everywhere and again and again. But what is the reality?  Let me give you an example: the evaluation of Eurojust, the European Judicial Cooperation Unit published in 2015, states on page 30, and I quote: the slow or incomplete implementation of the 2008 Council decision at national level had a significant impact on Eurojust. The overall effectiveness of the measures envisaged in the Council decision was therefore limited, in particular with regard to an extended exchange of information between Eurojust and the national authorities. Yes, Commissioner, Minister, this situation is unacceptable. The Member States must finally take their own decisions seriously and apply Existing European law! This does not require any special summits of the interior ministers or new legislative proposals from the Commission. This simply requires the will to implement what the European legislator has long since decided. If we were to do so, we would clearly be a decisive step forward.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Today, we are once again finding that the exchange of relevant information between the competent security actors is ingly changing the security of all citizens. This correlation is long overdue. Unfortunately, also in practice, for example in the last terrorist attacks in Europe. We are therefore surprised that it is so difficult to reach a political compromise about allowing law enforcement agencies access to certain data. I wonder what kind of security situation we would be in if the European People's Party had not pushed this issue high on the European security policy agenda for years and years. The European People's Party has also recently made 10 recommendations for the fight against terrorism, including a call for improved collection, processing and exchange of information from criminal files between Member States, between law enforcement agencies, between agencies (Europol, Frontex, Eurojust, etc.) and between systems that must become compatible with each other. We therefore call on the Commission to present without delay systemic solutions to this pressing problem, which perpetuates a weak security situation in Europe. In the effective fight against terrorism, we must also improve cooperation with third countries, not only with the US and Canada, but also with Turkey, the countries of North Africa and the Middle East. Better communication will also improve the effectiveness of the fight against illegal weapons trafficking, radicalisation on the Internet and in prisons, and the financing of terrorism. The treatment of so-called foreign fighters and the protection of external borders will also be improved.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I am involved in highlighting what I have said every time there has been a debate in this European Parliament about the need for measures to strengthen the exchange of information in the fight against terrorism, because it is a criticism of the 28 Member States and the absence of a sharing of the intelligence available to combat terrorism , that is, the analysis and interpretation of information relevant to combating terrorism, which would have served, by the way, to prevent the massacres we have witnessed in Paris or Zaventem recently. That is why, as important as the measures put in place by the Commission, is the requirement of political will for the Member States to share that information and to do so through the instruments already available to us: Europol, the European centre against terrorism. And also, why not, the will to make that base on which we now have the embryo of a European FBI that is effective against terrorism. And that it should also be done with respect for fundamental rights, the principles of necessity and proportionality and the European Data Protection Regulation, because that is the European acquis.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: – The current challenges to European security – migration, terrorism, organised crime and trafficking in human beings – are interrelated threats that require a comprehensive approach and a coordinated response at European and national level. The exchange of information within the European Union is an important component of this new approach, and for this purpose, I believe, technical interconnection of European information systems in the field of security and internal order is needed. Here I would like to welcome the European Commission's proposal to explore the possibilities of improving and connecting border management systems and those used by the security services.   I am of the opinion that improving systems has three main aspects. First of all, technical compatibility between systems must be ensured as soon as possible. This will allow, instead of collecting information on the same person several times, to be inserted into separate systems, the collection of data is one-off and accessible according to the needs of the different services in different Member States. I also call on the European Commission to swiftly come forward with legislative proposals that create a legal basis for data exchange and system connectivity. More importantly, I call on all Members of the European Parliament to put aside political differences and support these proposals in the name of the security of European citizens. Last but not least, the need to protect personal data, regardless of the type of information architecture of the systems, should not be overlooked.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, this is obviously a crucial issue for the future of the Union: ensuring the security of our citizens within the European area while respecting fundamental freedoms. It is therefore essential, in my view, that Parliament be involved in this work. We know that the Commission is planning interesting new tools, but intelligence remains a national competence, it is first of all up to the Member States to take their responsibilities to feed and use the many existing European tools. And the Commission must take care of that. I would like to remind you that after each attack, the Council reiterates this top priority, but it must not only be said, it must also be done quickly and effectively. It is common knowledge that the Focal Point Travellers, the key database for reporting foreign fighters, is 90% fuelled by only five Member States. Five Member States on ving-eight! Similarly, Europol must be allowed to play its coordinating role in these exchanges by providing it with the necessary resources and information.  As we speak, I am afraid, for example, that several Member States have still not sent the planned national experts to the new European Counter-Terrorism Centre. However, the interconnectedness of data banks and a single search interface would maximize these efforts.  So you still have a lot of work to do, Commissioner, and perhaps it is time to issue ballots and identify who is endangering our safety.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE).
text: – Madam President, there is no need to suffer an attack in order to be aware of the need to protect citizens. Attacks such as those in Paris or Brussels have awakened all consciences. There are many of us who thought we could have been at that airport. Therefore, and because anyone can be a victim, we must reinforce the counter-terrorism response and do so from unity, the one that is so often lacking. To protect you have to share information. We need trust between states. Greater coordination between police, more intelligence and investigation. We have to be faster than the terrorists.  And today, as for seven years now, I ask the Commission again: when is a Directive on victims of terrorism? When can a Regulation or Protocol be addressed for all the victims of many countries in Europe when an attack occurs? It can happen to anyone in any country in Europe and we need to be prepared. We don't have instruments for it.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, terrorism knows no borders. Only a joint effort by the European Union and the Member States can effectively combat it. The European Union, in particular, must provide the necessary tools to deal with the cross-border nature of the threat. National authorities should be informed of terrorist movements and this data should be shared with Member States and EU agencies through Europol's European Counter-Terrorism Centre. Member States' intelligence must facilitate the exchange of useful information, determining the conditions for making optimum use of all existing platforms, databases and alert systems at European level, such as the Schengen Information System and the Early Passenger Information System. We also need more effective operational cooperation between Member States and third countries through the use of existing instruments, such as joint investigation teams, the financial transaction control programme and PNR. Joint actions and the sharing of databases at all levels, therefore, but providing appropriate guarantees regarding the protection of citizens' data and privacy.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the exchange of data and their processing should be done with respect to the fundamental right of every individual to the protection of his personal data and his or her privacy, as defined by the provisions in force and the case-law of the Court of Justice of the European Union. In addition, there should be respect for the principle of proportionality, a balance between security and freedom, and data collected and exchanged should be limited to the minimum necessary for the purpose they serve. The purpose of data exchange and processing should be strictly the detection, investigation and prosecution of criminal offences and the enforcement of judgments. To achieve this, there should be appropriate cooperation in data exchange mechanisms between the Member States of the Union. However, since the debate that has taken place so far, the questions we have had because of the gaps and vagueness of the initiative have multiplied rather than been answered. We await the next replies from the Commission and from the Council.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: I would like to ask my fellow Members to speak a little slower. There's a lamp on my desk that shows that interpreters can't translate, they talk so fast in their comments. With this in mind, I am giving the floor to Mr Jakovčić and I ask that you speak in a way that can be well interpreted.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam Chairman, after the Paris attacks and that attack on Zaventem, the main issue I encountered with citizens in Croatia and their question, is it possible that the police stopped terrorists, criminals, did not identify them and did not arrest them? Is it possible that we do not have within the European Union a quality exchange of judicial or police data?  And the related question is it possible and is it necessary for Croatia to enter the Schengen area at a time when there are no automatic data exchanges? Of course, as a man who advocates more Europe, and always and everywhere more Europe, because I believe that this is what we need, I tried to explain that what follows now is the creation of databases, the creation of automatic data exchange, including the freedom and privacy of citizens, that is the direction we are going and the way and the reason why Croatia needs and can enter the Schengen area.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Therefore, while the fight against crime is required by decisive and swift action, these must not come at the expense of unjustified interference with the lives of citizens and measures which do not achieve the measures so desired. Security and freedom are, of course, two sides of the same coin, but unfortunately they are sometimes far away. Control and data collection, data sharing must have their limits and we cannot grant bianco bills for the exchange and processing of data, which can also lead to abuse of power. Precisely the fine lines exist between tracking and processing and, of course, the definition of so-called potential suspects and those who actually are. And that is why it is necessary to carefully handle the information we collect, and of course such rules must not be an end in itself. We must therefore stress the particular importance of guardians and agents for the supervision of personal data protection.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, the ever-increasing rate of terrorist attacks and organised crime actions requires cooperation and exchange of information between all countries. At the same time, however, the principle of the protection of fundamental rights, such as the protection of personal data and respect for a person's privacy, also applies. It is true that the boundaries between the intervention of a State authority for reasons of national interest and respect for personal data and human rights are indistinguishable. This intervention must therefore be carried out only when it is necessary and necessary either to prevent a crime or to prevent an act of terrorism. At the same time, it is also necessary to examine on a case-by-case basis whether the suspected terrorist is actually a suspect. This will result from transnational cooperation and following strict controls at each country's borders when someone wants to enter it.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE).
text: Madam President, I see that the British flags are being taken out of our Chamber now, I would like to know whether the Presidency has had a preview of the results of the Brexit referendum, which removes this symbol from our colleagues in the far-right group who are putting their British flags on the ground all the time.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Obviously, it was a rhetorical question, and he doesn't expect an answer. Looks like the room's being organized. Let us continue this debate: now, after the catch the eye procedure, I am giving the floor to The Commissioner, Commissioner Avramopoulos.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as you have reminded us, the use of a common information system and databases is essential to combat crime, but all crime. There is a lot of talk, as you have heard, about terrorism, and that is understandable. However, I would not like this to lead to a provision, to a reduction in the widespread phenomenon of serious crimes affecting the economic dimension. So we need to standardise the data in order to make it comparable, we need to coordinate everything that is made available. All and all information must be measured and must be constructed in a system which makes it possible to verify the different conditions, state by state. Confidentiality is required, but I would like to add that we also need timeliness. Time is a very important variable: timely action is effective for several reasons, including one that has a deterrence effect on criminals. That's why we have to hurry.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, security must be a priority for everyone: for the Council, for the Commission, for us, for the European Parliament, for all specialised institutions. The Commissioner was talking about our unity in the European Union, and it is true. Tragedies over the past two years have shown that there has not been enough unity and have shown the weakness of data collection, but above all, the exploitation of information. From today's statements, however, by the Council and the Commission, We have not understood exactly what the additional security measures are. Have the Council and the Commission found adequate measures to increase safety in the European Union? Obviously there is also a national responsibility, but the Council is the institution that is made up of the specialist ministers of the Member States and the decisions must be taken there, but also transposed. We are asked by citizens at home what is happening in the European Union? What measures are being taken for their safety? We await these answers, Commissioner and Minister.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I have listened very carefully, as I always do, to your interventions and taken note of your concerns. Ms Hohlmeier, Ms Stevens, I agree with you on Europol. We had the chance, as you remember, to discuss this three weeks ago. As many of you stressed, Ms Metsola and others, and as I said in my opening remarks: respect for fundamental rights, and in particular, data protection, will be integral to our future information architecture. Beyond this, I am pleased that we see eye-to-eye in terms of what the problem is. Information sharing is key to fighting terrorists. Our information cannot be locked up in silos. It must be interconnected in order to be useful. We all know more by sharing more. Trust is the basis on which we will build our new approach. We are moving from rhetoric and political statements to concrete actions on improving our information management. Our expert group on interoperability of systems will deliver tangible policy input 12 months from now. Based on this input, we may need to modify our legal instruments, or even propose new ones.  Ms Fajon, Ms in’t Veld, implementation of these existing instruments is our priority. Our expert group, however, will identify possible gaps, and the contribution to it from the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) is very important. Our commitment to this priority is a given. Your support and contribution will be key. I really, very much count on it.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me conclude by first of all stating that we must remain determined in our common fight against terrorism. Therefore information exchange and the feeding of the databases have been a major priority for the Presidency in the Justice and Home Affairs field. As I mentioned in the first round, that is not so easy because you have to do it on the basis of trust, interoperability and also filling the databases in a way that is immediately concrete for the people who work in law enforcement and intelligence agencies, who are in border control, and who are related to crime and therefore often the relationships that we see between crime and terror. Terrorism is not primarily defeated by bombs and bullets. We know that. It is also the effective and legitimate use of bytes and data that allows us to identify terrorist networks, to detect their plans and to uproot them at an early stage. So that information is vital to protect our societies and citizens. We have of course very often called for improving information sharing, feeding and using the databases in the way that I just mentioned. Figures are available, for instance in the EU CTC’s latest report. We know now that unprecedented levels of information have been shared with the taskforce, Fraternité, which was established at Europol in December 2015. Fortunately – and also importantly – we have made significant progress in recent years in terms of feeding and consulting databases, as is for example shown by the latest report from eu-LISA for 2015. However, I agree with you that we need to further increase every day our efforts for a better exchange of information and interoperability of databases. Yes, to a certain extent that is technical work, but technical work that cannot function without political leadership and trust. That is the reality: the better feeding and use of databases is crucial, in particular SIS, the database ‘Focal Point Travellers’ at Europol. This can be improved immediately without any legislative change. I am convinced that trust and recognition of the operational added value of sharing information between Member States and with Europol or Eurojust are fundamental factors for success. That has to become in reality more and more constraining for the Member States. We do this through the different parameters that have been mentioned. I will not go into the techniques of it, but obviously it has to do with very important issues like sharing biometric matching services, a common repository of data for different information systems, and the like. It is also key that we think through what it means if you have such a system and you believe in fundamental rights and privacy. We have to uphold our values also in fighting terrorism. Therefore full compliance with fundamental rights and data protection rules is a precondition for the way we manage and share that information for law enforcement. On 28 April the European Union Data Protection Package was formally adopted by the co-legislators, and now it has to be implemented and will require measures to ensure clarity, guidance and workable solutions for the day-to-day work of what I just mentioned, the practitioners and the interoperability. Sharing expertise, experiences and practices internationally will facilitate a practical and more uniform support for practitioners when implementing and applying data protection requirements. The Commission’s High Level Expert Group – the Commissioner was speaking about that earlier – is also expected to look at the data protection implications of the various options to achieve interoperability and to report on progress to the Council.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – I believe that data sharing will have a positive impact on the fight against transnational crime and terrorism, but I also believe that each country bears its responsibility. It is very important to accept from all of us that the field of security and defence is a priority of national policy. For our fight to be effective, Member States need to invest internally, thereby crossing transnational criminal groups on their own territory. The fight against terrorism is also a fight involving national states. Therefore, I believe that only through strong national states and local solutions will we be able to counter international crime and terrorism.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – Recent terrorist attacks have directly pointed at one of the biggest vulnerabilities of the EU – fragmentation of the Union’s information systems, exposing their inadequate interoperability and interconnectedness. Substantial amount of information is gathered around EU. However, it is not shared enough among the MS, nor is it fed into common information database. The existing databases are not used to their maximum capacity. Lack of trust between Member States and distrust for common databases is deeply rooted. One of the causes of such a deficiency of trust roots in different level of cyber security around Europe. Protection of critical information systems has to be upgraded to the maximum efficiency level in all Member States; only based on such level can one expect maximum sharing of information. I look forward to the framework on interoperability and interconnectedness of the information systems. In order to detect, follow and prevent terrorism and cross-border crime, law enforcement, border guards and other relevant players need a real time access to quality information of all EU databases. Member States should show political leadership, and implement what they declare – share, feed and use relevant information.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – I welcomed the presence of representatives of the Council and the Commission in the debate on improving the exchange of data and the use of European information systems and databases. I fully agree with Commissioner Avramopoulos's assertion that unity lies in strength. Effective operational cooperation within the European Union and the search for external allies are one of the most effective means of combating terrorism. Strengthening the link between secret services and their databases requires mutual trust in order to achieve a common goal.  This is also highlighted in the written declaration I initiated on the joint fight against terrorism, which has just been placed on the Table of Members at a time of greatest need. I trust that the written declaration will receive the necessary support to get this important message to the highest possible level.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Investigations of major terrorist attacks in Europe have highlighted the contradiction between the seemingly free movement of terrorists across Europe and the lack of EU-wide intelligence sharing. Stories of information non-sharing have emerged in the aftermath of all major terrorist attacks in Europe since the Madrid bombings in 2004. Information sharing is our only effective weapon against asymmetric and unpredictable threats. The exchange of this information, and the coordination of law enforcement activities between two sovereign states presents unique challenges. The ability to work through these challenges is paramount in negotiating effective agreements between the Member States in order to maximize the potential of using advance information. However, despite support for such coordination, we should equally recognise that there is significant work to be done. In part, this is because the political, administrative and judicial framework varies from one member state to another, which adds further impediments to effective information sharing and coordination. I am very encouraged and confident in the international support given to advanced information in the continued fight against international terrorist and criminal organisations.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – I welcome the fact that, within the framework of this item, the Commission and the Representative of the Council have finally focused on what governments have long been supposed to do: the key to the success of combating terrorism and other international crimes is to identify potential culprits and neutralise them by preventive measures, regardless of national borders, but this requires improving the exchange of information and data. Instead, most governments have chosen the path of intimidating, civil rights-limiting, mass measures that disrupt people's normal lives, even though this has not proved to be an effective method in practice. Such are the indiscriminate airport and other travel restrictions, the uncontrolled collection and use of personal data, the excesses of the PNR system.  Above all, however, the self-motivated domestic politically motivated actions of some European governments whose sole purpose is to control their own populations, limit their democratic rights and infight anti-foreigners. These are primarily the ringleaders of the policy of blocking joint EU action, The Hungarian Orban, and the polish right-wing government that followed him. This is evidenced by the constitutional amendment adopted in the Hungarian Parliament under the pretext of 'fight against terrorism', which contains restrictive legislation, and by the polish government's plan to introduce a similar package of laws. Better criminal data and information exchange, closer professional cooperation, more effective counter-terrorism and law enforcement cannot be achieved at European level until the EU is able to put its renitary members at the service of this important issue.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the decision of the Grand National Assembly of Turkey to lift the parliamentary immunity of 138 members(2016/2761(RSP)).

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, first I would like to express my sincere condolences to the families and friends of the victims of the recent terrorist attacks in Turkey. I would also like to take the opportunity to thank the European Parliament for its strong support for our comprehensive agenda with Turkey as stated in the resolution of the 2015 report on Turkey which was adopted only in April. The European Union has demonstrated its willingness to re-energise relations with Turkey across the board, based on our firm principles and criteria. We have delivered on our side in terms of political engagement, high-level dialogues on energy, foreign policy, security and counter-terrorism, economy and trade. In terms of financial support – I am talking about the facility for refugees we have made necessary for the agreed support – so far more than EUR 250 million has been committed, more than EUR 100 million already paid: this gives refugees a perspective and alleviates migratory pressures. And we have worked towards visa-free travel on the basis of the well-known benchmarks, benchmarks which are well known since 2013 and have not changed. This re-energised engagement with Turkey is not a one-way street, it is based on joint interests and pursued through an open, constructive dialogue, and it must be viewed in a wider, regional context, including the very serious developments in Syria. Turkey remains a key partner in managing migration. Turkey indeed has done much to help refugees in need of protection, shelter, food and healthcare. But at the same time this is not a blank cheque, there are number of serious developments affecting the rule of law and fundamental freedoms in Turkey as well as the situation in the southeast of Turkey. We have been very clear about these issues in the Commission’s 2015 report on Turkey, as have you, here, in the European Parliament’s resolution. The Commission is seriously concerned about the Turkish Parliament’s recent decision to permit the lifting of parliamentary immunity from prosecution for a large number of members of Parliament. High Representative and Vice-President Mogherini and I jointly made clear in our statement of 20 May that immunity must apply to all, on a non-discriminatory basis. This is the Commission’s clear and consistent position. Any decisions on lifting immunity must be based on the merits of each specific case, according to transparent criteria not subject to political considerations. The Commission has repeatedly stressed that overall the framework for parliamentary immunity should include specific and objective criteria for taking decisions on lifting immunity as is the case in probably all our parliaments within the European Union. We have also systematically highlighted the problematic interpretation of the legal framework, and the constitution in particular, which continue to pose a risk to the freedom of expression of members of parliament in Turkey. Let me also underline that any alleged wrong-doing or alleged crimes committed by MPs must be subject to due process. The right to a fair trial is fundamental to the rule of law and key to ensuring public confidence in the judiciary. It is the responsibility of the relevant political and judicial authorities in Turkey to ensure that this right is respected, not just for the people concerned but for the broader stability of the country. The rule of law is the very basis for Turkey’s political and economic progress. The Commission will therefore continue to follow this particular issue very closely. We will also raise these important matters in our upcoming high-level contacts with Turkey and we renew our call on the Turkish Government to generally re-engage in reforms in line with European standards. In support of these reform efforts the Commission is currently working at an accelerated pace on preparatory documents for Chapters 23 and 24, of course without prejudice to the positions of Member States in accordance with the existing rules. We believe that defining benchmarks in the key areas of the judiciary and fundamental rights and justice, freedom and security is the best lever to convince Turkey to carry on the work and realise its stated goal to move closer to the European Union. Therefore I am grateful for the strong support of this House in this endeavour.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, lifting a Member's immunity is not an exceptional thing for a Parliament. Every legislative chamber does it, we do it here in Strasbourg as well. But lifting the immunity of 138 deputies is something that is out of the ordinary and it is all the more exceptional because, for the most part, these deputies come from a single party, the Kurds, who oppose Ankara. There is doubt, not only because of the collective nature of this decision, but also because of the impact on the representation of Turkish citizens.  We have important issues on the table in our partnership with Turkey - migrants, visas, negotiating chapters - but we believe that only a Turkey that respects the principles of the rule of law can keep its word and be respected on our side.

name: Kati Piri
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, this morning the funerals were held of the police officers killed in yesterday’s terrorist attack in Istanbul. Another attack took place in Midyat today. I strongly condemn these attacks and I would like to express my sincere condolences to the families of the victims. No justification can be given for these horrendous attacks, but investments must be made in finding a just and durable solution to the Kurdish question. This is very much in the interest of both Turkey and its citizens who live in the south-east of the country.  Here in Parliament we are concerned about the decision of the Turkish Parliament to lift the immunity of one quarter of its members, a move clearly targeted against the opposition party HDP. At such a critical moment, taking away the political representation of many people living in the south-east of Turkey is a wrong move, not because we believe politicians should be immune to prosecution, not because we do not understand that Turkey faces a serious threat from terrorism, but because it is against all democratic principles to silence opponents simply for their political views, no matter how much you dislike them or disagree with them. If not even in the democratically elected parliament, can there be any place left where opposing political views are tolerated?  Mistakes have been made on all sides. Many who saw pictures of HDP deputies attending funerals of PKK terrorists were hurt, and many others were hurt when they saw that curfews did not cause any outcry from the west of the country, and these grievances are understandable, but the only way to overcome this divide is by looking forward. A parliament in exile is not the solution to anything, and nor are military operations. Moreover, the current events could also have a negative effect on EU/Turkey relations. Seeing court cases in the coming weeks whereby democratically elected members of parliament are disappearing behind bars, based on a highly controversial Turkish anti-terrorism legislation, will certainly jeopardise visa-free travel to the EU for Turkish citizens. We will not accept that journalists, academics and members of parliament are thrown into jail for using their right of freedom of expression.  The EU should stand ready to contribute positively to the restart of a peace process, but this process must start in Turkey. The House of People’s Representatives would be a logical place for that. Therefore, I would like to urge all Turkish political parties to come together to make a clear stand against terrorism, and to make a serious attempt to put an end to this bloodshed for the sake of all Turkish citizens.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the Turkish regime continues unabaalthough it is continuing its path towards totalitarianism, as it has decided to waive the immunity of 138 democratically elected representatives of the people, because they express the voice of 25 million Kurds living in Turkey. As if that were not enough, the Turkish authorities decided to perform an Islamic operation in Agia Sofia, thus insulting the faith of millions of Christians around the world. Mr Hahn, I have already sent Mrs Mogherini a letter asking for her intervention here and now, in order to put an end to this challenge, this desecration of the church of Orthodoxy, the Holy Wisdom, where every day the Koran is read. Mr Hahn, the European Union must finally stop blinding itself to Turkey's authoritarian descent, in the face of its challenges to Christianity. Mr Hahn, it is time for the European Union to stop bowing to the Sultan.

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has We are all parliamentarians here and, of course, there are situations in which the immunity of a colleague must be waived. But the idea that we, as a Parliament, would waive the immunity of more than 100 Members for alleged offences ranging from petty grotestres to the most serious accusations – this idea is completely absurd. No parliament in the world does such a thing. It is really more than surprising that the Turkish Grand National Assembly has decided to take this step. On this occasion, I have looked again at the Copenhagen criteria. Turkey is, after all, a country that officially still has the right route to become a full member of the European Union. The first Copenhagen criterion under Eur-lex is 'institutional stability for democratic and constitutional order, respect for human rights and respect for and protection of minorities'. If a Parliament makes itself virtually incapable of working, at least it is no longer democratically representative by waiving the immunity of 138 Members, then there is certainly no mention here of institutional stability. There is also no question of protecting minorities here, because, of course, the measures are primarily directed against the Kurdish minority. It is clear to parliamentary democracies that those who are legally elected must also be able to exercise their mandate legally. This means freedom from fear, freedom from intimidation, freedom from arbitrary legal persecution. If we look at the other institutions in Turkey, we will see, for example, in the High Council of Judges and Prosecutors that the International Court of Justice has established that it has now been politicised – there is no longer any mention of independent justice. Let us look at the action against the press – against the Doan Group, against the journalists of Cumhuriyet. Let us look at the action against the trade unions when they want to hold their May rally in Taksim Square – where is the freedom of assembly? But social groups such as the Hizmet movement are also under pressure. The military has been restricted by Ergenekon and Balyoz by the procedures in a way that is not constitutional. Now it is the Kurds, now it is massive action being taken against this Kurdish minority, against its political representation, the HDP, and we must ask a question in the interests of the Turks: is the security situation in the country getting better? I believe that the opposite is true. And that is why the whole thing is so counterproductive – not only from a European point of view, but also from the point of view of the citizens of Turkey.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report It is now exactly one year since the HDP celebrated an electoral success on 7 June last year. And it is precisely on 7 June that Erdogan signed the law that removes the immunity of Members from the Turkish Parliament. I no longer consider this to be just a formal act by the President, but a very deliberate step towards moving towards a presidential system, an autocratic system. The AKP-dominated parliament is practically abusing its own power and disempowering itself, harming Turkish democracy. However, this law also has an impact on how Members can or cannot fulfil their responsibilities. We are stunned that, in the 21st century, it is possible in Europe to create a climate of fear and intimidation in such a way. This is not only directed against HDP MPs. If I already imagine the absurdity of Erdogan now asking for blood tests to be carried out on members of the Bundestag of Turkish origin because of the acceptance of a statement or a resolution in the German Bundestag, or that it has just become known that complaints are being prepared against members of the Bundestag who have agreed to such a declaration, then I can only say that Erdogan is waging a fight against Members who use the right to freedom of expression in Parliament. And if what Erdogan wants to be applied here in the European Parliament, I would say that at least three quarters of the Members here would be deprived of immunity: because this is an attack on the freedom of speech and, above all, the responsibility of Members to represent themselves. I would also like to point out that among the Members – more than 50 complaints have been made against the 59 HDP Members – there are also two, which we are very well aware of here in Parliament: Leyla Zana, who has been awarded the Sakharov Prize by us, precisely because of the misconduct and because she has exercised her right to freedom of expression in Parliament, and Feleknas Uca, a Yazidi woman who has been a Member of Parliament here for ten years, who has learned the democratic craft here and now has seven cases pending alone.  I do not think we can simply accept this. We have to speak here, here we are talking about more! When the Commission points out that there is confidence in the judiciary, I say that, to date, 3 228 judges and prosecutors have been transferred under Erdogan in the last few days and weeks. How can I have confidence that they will now treat the lawsuits fairly? I would like to call on you once again to do something else, and that is not acceptable. This is about our common European freedom to fight for democracy.

name: Bodil Valero
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Not only is it difficult to get elected in Turkey because of the high threshold of 10%– it can also be dangerous. You can be imprisoned for your opinions. Despite the threshold, the HDP, which brings together various minority groups – the Greens and a number of democratic groupings – managed to enter the Turkish Parliament by a large margin in June last year, but also later in the re-election, albeit with fewer seats and after a dirty election campaign. In Parliament's response to the Commission's progress report on Turkey, we write on the elections: 'Parliament condemns ... the threats and harassment of the media and discrimination against opposition parties in pre-election reporting, the atmosphere of violence and intimidation, which was mainly marked by attacks on individual candidates and the offices of opposition parties, in particular the People's Democratic Party (HDP) and the strong political polarisation'. On 20 May this year, the Turkish Parliament approved a proposal allowing members to be prosecuted and punished. In essence, it is directed against the HDP and, in essence, it will probably be a violation of Turkish terror legislation. It is the same law that is the major stumbling block when we discuss visa facilitation for Turkey, the law that is so markedly different from how we in europe view terrorism, freedom of expression, freedom of assembly, freedom of the press and which I ask how many of us who have openly criticised the Turkish President would suffer if we were Turkish citizens, living in Turkey. How many of us wouldn't have signed the academic petition? But even the accused of corruption get their immunity lifted. Why doesn't the same apply to members of the government or to the president himself? After all, the issue of corruption is another of the stumbling blocks that Turkey has in reaching the visa facilitation criteria. In this case too, the European Parliament has expressed concern in its report. This is how we write: 'The European Parliament reiterates its concern about the anti-terror law. In particular, its broad and extremely vague definition of terrorism, organised crime and propaganda, which makes it completely impossible to establish the exact nature of these crimes'. We also write: 'Regrets the distortion of the course of justice in favour of some politicians, which became an everyday occurrence in Turkey following the corruption scandal in 2013'. The president wants to change the Constitution and gain more power. The president wants to tighten the anti-terror law even further. The victims on the way there are parliamentarians, academics, journalists, judges, minorities and all those who believe in democracy and the rule of law and those who believe that dialogue is better than violence to solve problems. President Erdoğan has now approved the law. He should be ashamed of ya.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what is the point of voting in Turkey now? Its citizens will probably ask for this, given that with the entry into force of this liberticidal choice and the opening of trials against the HDP Parliamentarians, the balance of power and numbers within the Turkish Parliament are bound to change. Erdogan's well-stated goal is to overturn the Constitutional Charter in order to further centralise the powers in his hands. Indicting and arresting 138 – I repeat 138 – Kurdish parliamentarians will recreate the vacuum of representation that has brought Turkish Kurdistan to the brink of civil war in the past, and that is now the case here too, if we see the terrible bulletins coming in from Ankara on a daily basis. This is yet another act that Erdogan is carrying out in the face of a weak and silent Europe, which does not have the courage to denounce it as it deserves. How can we still talk about the accession process, not with Turkey, but with turkey, which is trampling underfoot the rule of law? This immunity cannot be waived! The real tragedy, the real danger to democracy, is not so much Erdogan's authoritarianism, but Europe's silence, and we no longer want to remain silent.

name: Edouard Ferrand
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ever more, Mr Erdogan, and until when? After the blackmail on migrants, here is the new coup de force of the Erdogan state. The maneuver is clear: remove his opposition. A century after the Armenian and Syriac genocides, nothing new, unfortunately, on this side of Europe. A century after the Armenian and Syriac genocides, we see once again that Turkey is threatening Europe.  Our Europe of Nations group has put you in front of your responsibilities. What are you waiting for, ladies and gentlemen, to call, as we do, for the end of Turkey's accession negotiations?
