Do you think, ladies and gentlemen, that the Erdogan dictatorship is a model compatible with our European values?

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Mr President, recently the Kurdish Member of the Turkish National Assembly, Enku Ferhat, courageously stated that Turkey is nothing but stolen land of Greek Armenians and Kurds. As he said, "My witness to history!" Continuing to give examples of the heinous acts of the Turks, he said: "We Kurds live in Kurdistan and, when we lived on this land, the Turks were in Mongolia busy with their horses, and this land belongs to us and we live here. Modern Turkey is less than 100 years old, while Kurdistan is over 5000 years old and there are dozens of ancient Greek texts that mention the name of the Kurds and Kurdistan." I read you some of the threats made by Turkish Members of Parliament: 'Put a bullet in his head!', 'Shoot him!', 'You signed your death sentence', 'Your head will roll, you bum Kurd!', 'Put him in jail for ten years!', 'We will destroy your cities'.  I would, of course, like to ask Mr Schulz who would impose the sanctions he recently imposed on me? To the courageous Kurdish MP or the corresponding Turks? In the parliamentary republic where the President institutionally protects what is more reprehensible, the attitude of the Kurd who invoked the historical truth or the Turks who cursed him, threatened his life and committed crimes against civilians? Lately they have not even respected the religious monument of Agia Sophia. I dedicate this to the dear President for his protégés Turks, who as a former bookseller had to know history well, in order to make fair decisions.

name: Renate Sommer (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the President Erdogan tramples on all european fundamental values. The waiver of the immunity of a quarter of the Members of the Turkish Grand National Assembly is another slap in the face to the European Union. Government critics have long been accused of alleged terrorists, sentenced to long prison terms and thus silenced. And now it is precisely this fate that threatens the Kurdish opposition in parliament in particular, which is to be eliminated in exactly the same way and will be eliminated. This then clears the way for new elections, for by-elections in which, of course, the AKP will win the seats that Erdogan needs for a constitutional majority. Turkey is becoming a presidential dictatorship. This is a tragedy for the country, which has long been in a climate of fear. But it is also a major problem for the European Union, because we need a reliable Turkey as a neighbour with whom we can work closely. But the country is no longer reliable. So we have to react. We must now finally and definitively put an end to the accession negotiations. Clearly, the Turkish side also wants only cooperation below the accession threshold.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D). Mr President, first of all I would like to express my condolences to the victims of the recent terrorist attacks in Turkey. Friends and friends, Mr. Erdogan is leading Turkey into a political middle age. The result of his choices, his political choices, is paid for every day by the Turkish people. It lifts the immunity of HDP MPs on charges of supporting terrorism. We cannot remain just spectators in the persecution of Members just because they are Kurds. We cannot be left in the face of massacres of civilians and the destruction of entire cities such as Nusaybin. At the same time, it threatens German Members of Turkish origin who voted to recognise the Armenian genocide. Finally it offends Hagia Sophia, a world heritage site, symbol of Christianity, using it for cheap propaganda. All this is hostile to the European values of democracy, culture and human rights. We must therefore send a strong message today that it is Mr Erdogan who is closing the door on the European perspective for his country, Turkey.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: Mr Commissioner, I have listened carefully to you and you say that you are very concerned. You say you will continue to follow the case closely. Commissioner, I am gradually concerned about the commission's sense of reality, which does not appear to want to acknowledge the facts.  After Ergodan first silenced the critical media, then expelled the prime minister and brutally attacked his own people in Kurdistan with brutal war, the political opposition had to believe in it. Abolishing the immunity of 138 Members of Parliament is a purely political move targeting the Kurdish Peoples' Democratic Party. We must take it clearly and unequivocally for these Members. They must be able to continue to tell their story for a democratic and a free and peaceful Turkey.  Mr Commissioner, again, what did you actually say? We must be very concerned and we will continue to monitor the matter closely. Well, that's not good enough! How long will we continue to blackmail ourselves? When will you and the European Union make it clear to Erdogan that the refugee deal does not give carte blanche? Opposition, freedom of expression, respect for human rights and minorities are integral to democracy. Know that the European Union will lose its credibility if you fail to protect those values.

name: Marietje Schaake (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, we have seen an unacceptable amount of compromise on the part of the Commission and the Member States on the very values the EU is built on. They have been weakened and traded so that Turkey will protect our borders – or so, it seems, is the hope. Visa liberalisation is one element of what the EU should deliver, if and when Turkey meets the 72 criteria it has itself agreed with Europe in 2013. It is in the abuse of anti-terror legislation that the knot gets tied. Yes, terror must be fought and Turkish parliamentarians should distance themselves from the use of violence. But they also have to have a chance to represent their voters democratically. The lifting en masse of the immunity of parliamentarians clearly does not allow for due process, and it also disproportionately impacts HDP members. Commissioner, you spoke of the rule of law as being key. I call on you to ensure that we, the EU, act according to international law and ensure that Turkey does the same. We cannot afford further compromise: not in the context of the deal on migration; not in the context of the need for reforming anti-terror legislation; and not because the EU needs to remain credible if it wants to lead in the world at all.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, I too would like to express our condolences for the dead of yesterday's bombing, because no explanation can be given for such barbaric acts. But Mr Erdogan's actions are also a megaton bomb on the foundations of the Turkish Republic. We are already counting 300,000 displaced Kurds from their homes. And the aim of his actions to waive the immunity of Kurdish Members is to subjugate the Kurdish population. In the face of this, I think that the European Union must show its dignity first and for all towards itself, first of all with us. We must not allow ourselves to give the impression that we are bowing to the fact that Turkey is hosting the 3 million refugees and is exploiting or exploiting this fact so clearly vis-à-vis all European states. The Turkish President must be given a clear signal that we believe that his actions are blowing up his relations with the European Union.

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the lifting of the immunity is very clearly directed toward the HDP Members and the intention is also very clear behind that, it is to silence the HDP Group and even the HDP party. This is entirely undemocratic. It criminalises a whole democratic party representing a sizable part of the population, a sizable part of the voters even. It is also not just Kurds who voted for HDP, it was a lot of people who believed in a different future for Turkey. It was a lot of people who were protesting for better lives, for human rights, for freedom of expression, for all those things that we are saying we are trying to stand for.  So we need to support those people. It is a great disgrace that the Kurdish conflict is now out again in the open and it is also a huge pity, because Erdoğan himself was on the best way to find a sustainable solution, and now we are back to square one. Hundreds of civilians have died, houses are being bombed, and this is no way to fight terrorism – quite the opposite.  It is a great loss, the lost peace process, I really have to say, and the European Union and also the Member States themselves need to be very strong in their reaction. We have to be clear about the values we are trying to represent. We should not be silent when those who are trying to speed up are being silenced. We have made many mistakes in the past as a European Union, and also the Member States. We have actually made Erdoğan grow stronger on our rejection. We should not make those mistakes. We should support the people who are defending the same values as us, then we can work for a better Turkey.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Take them, and judge them! You should pay the price, whatever! With these words, Erdogan accompanied the waiver of the immunity of 138 opposition figures on 20 May. However, Commissioner Hahn, instead of reacting properly, we are also making a refugee deal with this gentleman and ignoring the fact that Turkey is dismantling democracy at the moment. We promise billions in euros, visa facilitation, new negotiating chapters, while Erdogan and Co. are blackmailing us by the nose. And all this is obviously only to save the head of Mrs Merkel, who, with her insane general invitation to refugees from all over the world, will lead not only Germany, but the whole of Europe into disaster. And as a cheeky encore, Mr Erdogan is now threatening the Union with new waves of refugees and Germany with the mobilisation of the Turks living there if one does not behave as the Sultan wants on the Bosphorus, and for example does not silence a genocide of the Armenians. I can only say, Commissioner, and please you too: Europe, wake up!

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Fifty years ago, Bernadetta Devlin was sentenced to life in prison, but she was transported to the House of Commons because she was an MEP and could not be deprived of her parliamentary representation. In 1933, Adolf Hitler, with the support of two opposition parties, denied the Communists the right to participate in the Reichstag. These two parties regretted it bitterly a month later, as Hitler gained an absolute majority. At the moment, after removing members from the three parties that supported the two opposition parties, Mr Erdogan has a constitutional majority and can do whatever he wants. Those two parties that supported this will also bitterly regret it.  The question is, why do we, why does the EU authorities support Mr Erdogan? I see only one explanation for this situation: out of these 6 billion, Mr Erdogan has given some money to those members of the European Union authorities who are negotiating with him. The bundestag's recent decision has clearly shown that Mrs Merkel's influence is much smaller than it seems, and The Bundestag members have done what they wanted and rightly accused Turkey of. And so it is necessary to act, the truth must be told, and people who act like Mr Erdogan are threatening the whole of Europe at the moment, because Turkey can threaten Europe more than these dispersed masses of migrants. Thank you for your attention.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, I must say that today your answer was insufficient for me. I expect the European Commission to unequivocally reject the actions of the Turkish Government and President Erdogan that limit political pluralism and democracy. I say this as one who was favourable to the EU-Turkey agreement. It is a crucial signal to me, firstly, that this is an act against a particular group of Members of the Kurdistan Party, as well as a clear response from the opposition People's Republican Party, which rejects President Erdogan's move. If Turkey requires visa-free travel from the European Union, it must not only fulfil technical conditions, but must also respect the rule of law and protect civil rights. If it does not fulfil these conditions, the European Union cannot continue negotiations on visa-free travel either.  (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support You have indeed sent very strong messages – rightly so. I fully agree with that, and I see that, likewise, others in this Chamber are sending very strong messages, not only to the Commission, but also to Turkey. However, there is a European member state, namely Hungary, whose Prime Minister Viktor Orban calls Mr Erdoğan and Mr Putin a consistent example to follow, and he has confirmed this in several of his declarations. When will that moment come, I ask you, when your group will speak on this matter?

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – In my opinion, Mr Putin is not an example of an appropriate follow-up, and Mr Erdogan is certainly not an example of an appropriate follow-up in restricting political and civil rights and restricting democracy. That's my answer.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Parliamentary immunity is a valuable legal asset that exists in any democracy. A repeal is only available in exceptional situations and only takes place in individual cases and after checking the circumstances. The events of these days are extremely worrying because they are of the nature of a collective punishment. Among those convicted are well-known faces such as Selahattin Demirtas, who was a guest in the S&D Group only a few weeks ago, or Feleknas Uca, a member of this House for ten years. What is happening is absurd. Both colleagues are above all suspicion. Many of us are still in the memory of talks with the two of us, in which they urged a peaceful solution to the Kurdish question.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Mr President, stripping parliamentary immunity from politicians facing criminal investigation is usually something we would welcome in a democracy such as this House. Unfortunately, in this case, the proceedings appear to be politically motivated – a kind of collective punishment primarily aimed at weakening the Kurdish-majority HDP. President Erdoğan sees them as proxies for the PKK fighting in South-East Turkey.  Mr Erdoğan also seems intent on acquiring unchecked presidential powers to match the magnificence of his newly constructed, sultanesque palace. In order to reach the all-crucial number of 367 seats that are required to amend the Constitution without a referendum, he is pulling out all of the stops he can. Having dispensed with his unruly Prime Minister, he is now focusing on support outside of his AK Party. As Bahçeli support within his own nationalist MHP party is waning after 20 years as leader, Erdoğan now appears to have made a deal with his former rival, using the apparatus of the state to support Bahçeli’s leadership in exchange for his support in the Grand Assembly. Democracy and the rule of law are now under threat in Turkey, and this is just the latest move in a bigger game to undermine those values for Erdogan’s AK, neo-Islamist, autocratic agenda.  Turkey clearly has enormous value to the EU as a candidate country. It is a NATO ally and a necessary partner in the deal to stem the flow of refugees from the Syrian conflict, but Erdoğan is turning his country into one far from the secular democracy of 20 years ago, and we should all be very alarmed by that.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: – The processes against Members, which begin with gross verbal attacks, the insuading of subversive intentions and conspiracies, all of which have always heralded the march of authoritarian power and the concentration of power in one centre and in one person. Today, this is happening in Turkey, our important strategic partners. Erdogan's attack on the rule of law, which has reached a backdrop of deprivation of immunity from elected members, must be condemned without a margin. We need Turkey. She found herself under the back of terrorists and the same problems as the Middle East as a whole and we, Europe, with him. The worst of all options is the one chosen by President Erdogan as he combines external problems with internal inter-ethnic tensions. Perhaps, at the moment when we condemn the autocratic power in Ankara, we must ask ourselves whether there is still time for a proactive approach and a redefining of common interests. Commissioner, I support your introductory speech on this. Many of Turkey's problems have also been created by us and our allies, and we should not forget this.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, yesterday, 7 June 2016, one year to the day after the parliamentary elections, Recep Erdogan published the constitutional revision allowing the collective lifting of the parliamentary immunity of 138 of the 150 deputies of the Grand National Assembly of Turkey. Among them, 53 of the 59 HDP deputies. Mr. Erdogan likes symbols. He wants to show that he has taken matters into his own hands, but at what cost?  We no longer count the authoritarian excesses of this regime. Much has already been said, but I find that a new red line has been crossed: the democratic principles that a country applying for entry into the European Union must respect no longer seem to be part of the Turkish President's concerns. In 1995, we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Leyla Zana. Today, she and other HDP MPs face jail again. Their crime: to say what they think, because it is their freedom of expression that is at issue. As parliamentarians, we cannot be silent. I would like to make a solemn appeal here to your solidarity so that we can individually sponsor these parliamentarians. I believe that in this way, beyond words, we will carry out a strong political act, in line with the values we want to defend.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, yesterday it was a year — yesterday exactly — that, for the first time in history, a Kurdish party entered the Turkish Parliament as a political group, with 13% of the total vote. A year later, today, after a continued campaign of discredit against that same party and a new election in November, the situation has taken a 180-degree turn. Yesterday, President Erdogan signed the constitutional reform law that allows parliamentary immunity to be suspended. As a first consequence, at least fifty Kurdish MPs will be subjected to legal action and perhaps jail terms simply for the simple expression of their opinions. In a year we have gone from the hope of democratic openness, the near completion of the peace process and a huge positive involvement of Turkish society to a situation of armed conflict, to very serious attacks in major cities, as yesterday, and to a total anti-democratic involution of political life. In Turkey, today the disjunction is already explicit. Authoritarianism and concentration of power or pluralism and democracy by the line of reconciliation. The last word, the only one actually, corresponds to Turkish society itself. We have the urgency to work actively for a democratic alternative and for a political project capable of bringing the country back on the path of internal peace and legitimate aspirations for dialogue.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Mr President, just a few days ago the Turkish Parliament approved the waiver of the immunity of 138 Members, including 103 from the HDP, the pro-Kurdish party, which is also the country's third political force. The crime committed by these Members was that they called for an end to turkish armed forces operations in Southeast Turkey against the Kurds and for peace talks to resume. Nevertheless, President Erdogan denounced them and prosecuted them under the Anti-Terrorism Act, with the aim of jailing them and reducing their political power. This action by the Turkish dictator is certainly undemocratic and is going to spark new violence in the country's already tense political situation.  But the question is why some of you are surprised and indignant about President Erdogan's behaviour. Aren't you the ones who have so far tolerated him blackmailing you into threatening you? Aren't you begging him even now to work with you to supposedly resolve immigration? Aren't you the ones who put up with the Greek Samaras government doing exactly the same thing that President Erdogan did, namely to put the leader and deputies of the third political party, Golden Dawn, in jail? Aren't you the ones who even now tolerate him playing you and playing Europe at the same time? I wanted to ask you, if Mr Erdogan asked you this question, what would you answer? And finally, to take this seriously, are you determined, do you have the dignity to threaten Turkey that its accession negotiations will be interrupted? Do you have the ability to threaten Turkey that you will remove the PKK from terrorist organisations?

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Europe needs Turkey and Turkey needs Europe. But both sides must respect the rules of the game. That's not happening. The approval of an amendment to the Turkish Constitution, which will allow the immunity of a large majority of opposition lawmakers to be waived, is expedite. This is a very serious step with far-reaching consequences for the future. Among the conditions for granting visa-free travel to Turkish citizens is the alignment of legislation on terrorism. Among other things, so that the democratically elected opposition cannot artificially fight under his pretext. Hardworking and pragmatist Turkish citizens know that Europe is their most important export partner. The escalation of violence that the government's current action is instillation, and which we saw again yesterday in central Istanbul, is discouraging investors and threatening their safety. It threatens Turkey's economic interests.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am sorry that this debate will take place just one day after the terrible attack which again struck Istanbul yesterday. So my first words have to be a memory for the victims and for us to become aware that Turkey has a very serious problem of terrorism.  And the fight against terrorism must go on, but it should never be at the expense of democracy and freedom, and that is the message. All our support in the fight against terrorism, but respect for democracy and freedoms. And very bad news has come from Turkey in the last year: President Erdogan's authoritarian drift is practically proven. The persecution of journalists and jurists - by the way, yesterday, President Erdogan sent a very derogatory message to all Turkish women - and the political use of parliamentary immunity make the deterioration of the rule of law in Turkey a serious concern for us. President Erdogan should stop and return to the path of dialogue, democracy and peace-building. And on that path you must find a friendly European Union. In the meantime, it can't be like this.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Of the nearly 60 Islamic countries, Turkey has so far been one of the few that has set out on the road to democracy, human rights and equality between women and girls. Now only Tunisia is there. Like any dictator, Erdogan needs images of enemies, and that is now the Kurds. However, their party, the HDP, must distance itself much more clearly from the terrorist organisation PKK. The HDP, for example, should never have attended the funeral of a PKK suicide bomber. He had killed dozens of Turks and Kurds. Otherwise, HDP leader Demirta's simply makes it far too easy for Erdogan to cultivate his enemy image and thus to further expand his dictatorship not only at the expense of the Kurds, but at the expense of all Turks.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, Turkey's semi-authoritarian regime is moving away from parliamentaryism and is changing into an overt dictatorship. Mr Erdogan, along with his submissives, systematically cultivates and markets hatred in order to consolidate the rule of law. It organizes hate celebrations on the Byzantine walls of Istanbul to celebrate its fall about six centuries ago and the massacres and looting that followed. It refuses to condemn the hatred of the Ottomans against armenians and other Christian populations and to acknowledge the genocides committed against them a century ago. It is still waging an unrelenting war against the Kurdish minority in the southeastern provinces and is overturning the immunity of members of the Kurdish HDP party, with the aim of silence the opposition in general. The European Union must speak to Mr Erdogan in the only language he understands, the language of political and economic sanctions.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: –Mr President, 7 June is a symbolic date. Just a year ago yesterday HDP won its great electoral victory with 13% entering the Grand National Assembly of Turkey, and while Kurds voted for them, so also did many other progressive liberals, others who want a European Turkey and who want a political solution to the conflict between Ankara and the Kurds. So it is no coincidence that Erdoğan yesterday signed a law that allows criminal charges to be brought against those 138 MPs whose immunity has been lifted in such an undemocratic way. It looks like revenge by Erdoğan to correct the electoral outcome of last year, and strikes a heavy blow against the rule of law and democracy in Turkey.  So I appeal to the Commission to make sure that Turkey will not be allowed a shortcut for visa liberalisation and that this recent blow against the rule of law makes it very clear that you must not rely on Turkey, we cannot rely on Turkey, to solve the problems that we have with refugees and the solidarity crisis we have.

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης (
text: PPE). Mr President, I too would like to express my deepest condolences and deep concern at the latest terrorist attacks in the centre of Istanbul. I would also like to express my deep concern and discomfort because the Turkish Government, for the first time in eighty-two years, since 1934, allows the Koran to be read during Ramadan in Agia Sofia, which is a world heritage site and is protected by UNESCO. We want a democratic Turkey. We want a Turkey stabilising factor in the wider region. We want a Turkey that offers security and prosperity to its people. But Turkey is a country that is moving away from democracy and slipping into an authoritarian regime with Islamic elements. It is a country that is unfortunately moving away from the European Union under the responsibility of its leadership.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday's amendment to the constitutional amendment tabled by the AKP for the selective removal of parliamentary immunity is an extremely worrying act, aggravated by the comment made by President Erdogan, who spoke of an historic moment for the country. It certainly marks an ever clearer break with the rights and values that the European Union protects and promotes, as stated in the letter of appeal that I signed together with many colleagues a few weeks ago, in an attempt to counter this serious measure.  The proposal put forward yesterday by the Minister of Defence to give disproportionate legal cover to the army and secret services deployed for security operations against terrorist groups is undoubtedly yet another step in the wrong direction beyond the just condolences for the terrorist attacks, which have already been mentioned in this House. We very much hope that the Turkish Government will back down, otherwise it will not be possible to continue cooperation with the European Union on the various dossiers under discussion.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Once again, Turkey, and in particular its leader Erdogan, have proved by their actions that they do not respect democratic principles and that their place is not in the European Union. The waiver of the immunity of 138 MPs - a quarter of the MPs in the Turkish mejlis - is a crushing, blatant, brazen, ostentatious blow to democracy. This is the beginning of a large-scale purge among politicians in Turkey in order to discredit and destroy the pro-Kurdish Peoples' Democratic Party. I would not be surprised if these actions were followed by an escalation of the conflict with the Kurdish minority with multiple bombings, loss of lives and a real hot civil war in Turkey. This is how dictator Erdogan will continue to act if we do not stop him.  I call on the Commission and the Council to activate the human rights clause and to freeze all agreements with Turkey. Erdogan's actions are becoming intolerable and the European Union, which claims to be a resister of democratic principles, must not only say words, but also with actions to show that such acts will not be tolerated by a candidate member of the European Union. Turkey is not our partner, Turkey is a racketeer.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, it is not just an attack on 138 Members. As has already been said, it is a direct attack on the very small remaining democratic system in Turkey. Gabriele Zimmer made this very clear: President Erdogan is trampling on democracy. And this House should send a powerful message, not only against President Erdogan's strategy, but also in favour of these Members and the forces desperately trying to open a democratic debate in this country. The latter is fundamental, because Mr Erdogan and the army are suffocating this possibility. Much more after this last administrative coup. The European Commission is very concerned, but we need much more. With the agreement with Turkey, Member States give money and legitimacy to President Erdogan, but they are silent in the face of the deplorable conditions of refugees trapped in Turkey and the massacre of the Kurdish people.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Although I am convinced that the EU-Turkey refugee agreement is in favour of the EU-Turkey refugee agreement, I believe that the development is appalling, unacceptable and the outcry of this House is necessary and right. If the parliamentary immunity of 138 Members, especially democratically elected representatives of the opposition, is lifted in one fell swoop, if members of a political minority are excluded from Parliament and then prevented from exercising their mandate, if the opposition forces are to be silenced for their political statements, then that is incompatible with our democratic values, with our principles of the rule of law. Then we have to say openly that Turkey is on the wrong track in terms of democracy and the rule of law, and there is no pardon for that!

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – The attacks on democracy and the rule of law in Turkey follow, as are terrorist attacks such as yesterday in Istanbul, which we unequivocally condemn. One and the other are disgracely connected. The collective withdrawal of immunity to 138 Deputies is the undisguised offensive against the HDP parliamentary group. The brutal repression of the Kurdish minority and all critics of President Erdogan's personal project now involves this gross violation of the Copenhagen criteria, democracy and the rule of law. In the meantime, despite what Commissioner Hahn said here today, which I welcome, the Council and the Commission continue to deny reality, to let themselves be blackmailed, devaluing the tragic democratic regression in Turkey, absurdly repeating that it is a 'safe country', that "virtually" all the criteria for visa liberalisation are met and defending the dirty deal for refugee outsource. On this hallucinatory trajectory, we will soon be debating how to respond to the crisis of the influx of Turkish refugees!

name: Martina Michels (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which How do MEPs react to the self-empowerment of the Turkish Parliament? The convicted Turkish journalist Can Dündar described his country: You can trade freely in Turkey if you are willing to pay the price. Now, for MPs, in particular from the HDP, a terrorism law is being applied, which will condemn people for being at peace demonstrations, for example. Ladies and gentlemen, the time for speech and appeals is over! Let us break the silence of the European Commission and the Council! Let us act! As a Parliament, we are currently refusing to give our assent to visa liberalisation for Turkey! On the other hand, however, Members in Turkey also need immediate support. In the German Bundestag there is the project parliamentary sane parliamentarians. Let us call for a similar project together and thereby support the hope for democracy in Turkey!

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D). – Commissioner, the rules of law and democracy have long since crashed in Turkey. What we are discussing today is much more and something much worse. We are witnessing a silent genocide that is happening in the Kurdish provinces with hundreds of murders and innocent victims. Now Erdogan is moving forward and lifting the immunity of MPs who disagree with him. The first objective is to decapitate the leadership of the HDP, the party that is the only formed opposition. But in the face of Erdogan's violence and aggression, the opposition, especially the Kurds, are reacting peacefully and politically. For every single Member who is persecuted by some of us here, we are determined to provide personal solidarity and support. And we also support the HDP's decision to refuse to be questioned after Erdogan's decrees.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL). Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, today's debate confirms my earlier points. Over time you beautify and overlook what is tragically happening in Turkey in the name of serving economic interests and micro-political pursuits of internal consumption and proof is the refugee agreement, denounced by the UN. The politics of petting Erdogan and the Turkish political elite have allowed him to create an undemocratic web of persecution of anyone he disagrees with: political opponents, academics, journalists and others.  Criminalising the Kurdish issue by bringing Kurdish MPs to trial is a natural development. This country you call safe and under its leadership you negotiate agreements. Of course we are obliged to oppose the persecution of Kurdish Members. But this is not an isolated one, Commissioner. It is part of Erdogan's overall plan and I fear that we will soon be faced with worse developments, which will also affect the wider region. So revising your policy, with even sanctions, is imperative.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after the waiver of immunity and after the Constitutional Court rejected the appeal of the pro-Kurdish HDP party, the objective is clear: to put 55 of the 59 members of the HDP on trial. This is a blatant attempt to change parliamentary appearances in order to lead to a centralisation of power in the hands of President Erdogan. The European Commission must get out of its contradictions in its relationship with Turkey. We have a duty and a responsibility to use all our negotiating power to prevent this from happening. We cannot, on the altar of stabilisation, give funds for the management of migratory flows to a country with undemocratic ambitions. Instead, we must insist on the application of the principle of conditionality, respect for human rights and the rule of law in the continuation of any kind of relationship and dialogue with Turkey.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (
text: S&D). Mr President, the decision to waive parliamentary immunity is yet another undemocratic move that undoubtedly has the ultimate aim of strengthening Erdogan's powers. With the new provision, HDP members are not only targeted but are effectively on the way to eliminating the party from Parliament. We cannot turn a look away from the violations of freedom of expression in Turkey for fear that the European Union-Turkey refugee agreement will be compromised. I would remind you that HDP MP Leila Zana, who received the Sakharov Prize, had been jailed for ten years after her immunity was lifted in 1994.  The lifting of immunity is a flagrant violation of Members' rights and will worsen the already tense situation with regard to Kurdistan. Unfortunately, the repeated incidents against freedom of expression, the exclusion of democratic dialogue, the gagging of the press, the continued occupation of Cyprus show that Turkey is far from the principles and values of the European Union to which it wants to join.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Parliamentary immunity in general could be debated a lot, in my country, for example, Members often hide behind immunity and try to avoid impeachment in matters that have nothing to do with the free expression of their political opinions. However, in the context of the Turkish decision, this is not only the case, but also that it obviously leads to the inability of a party and, in practice, the dismantling of a democratic political advocacy instrument of a national minority. If the Turkish leadership outholds the political self-organization of the Kurdish minority, it is such a slap in the face to what we mean by the rule of law and respect for human rights that, in my view, the consequences are unpredictable.  With this decision, Turkey itself is going down the path that could lead to the European Union. We must make it clear that Turkey can only be a strategic partner of the EU, together with the Kurdish minor, respecting their rights, and no other solution is possible. Europe cannot pretend that everything is fine with this decision.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the waiver of parliamentary immunity in Turkey, more than 100 opposition Members are in danger of being arrested and leaving Parliament. It is clear that an authoritarian squeeze is continuing in the country. Doubts have been raised on many quarters about the independence, impartiality and efficiency of the judicial system, the separation of powers and respect for the principle of the rule of law. Critical issues are recorded in relation to the press and the media. "Reporters Without Borders" classifies Turkey as one of the countries where journalists are most exposed to threats and physical aggression. The authoritarian stranglement on the institutional system requires the European Union, in constancy of these serious violations of the principles of the rule of law, to give serious thought to future relations with Turkey and to the continuation of negotiations for turkey's accession to the European Union.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the Turkish Parliament has approved the government's proposed amendments to the Constitution, which will mean the lifting of immunity for around a quarter of Members. We all know who this move is primarily aimed at – the opposition pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party. The question is whether we really want visa-free travel with a country that dismantles freedom of expression, the foundations of the rule of law, and its leaders do business with the Islamic State and primarily fight the Kurds, who, on the contrary, are fighting the Islamic State relentlessly. This is really a very dirty game, and if the European Union plays it with Erdogan, we will harm the Kurds and help the Islamic State. Commissioner, you have heard from everyone here today that it is a mistake for the Commission to remain silent on this matter. And I want to hear from you in your final word what you're going to do about it. If you continue to take it the way you take other things, I guarantee you that the Turkish people will be even worse off, thanks to you and the fact that you have not been able to intervene.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the Commissioner says that the Commission is concerned. I don't know how she's going to be worried, but what I do know is that in Ankara they're not too worried about their concern. You who outsource the mass deportation of refugees will not do much in the face of the massive suspension of immunity to THE PARLIAMENTarians of the HDP and the Turkish left. You, so others, do nothing effective against the closure of the media, the imprisonment of journalists, the bombing of Kurdish civilian areas or the prosecution of European politicians by the infamous anti-terrorism law. This action is a coup d'etaker to exclude Kurdish parliamentarians, but you look the other way, reach infamous agreements with the 'sultan' Erdogan and even hinder any peace agreement by keeping the PKK on the list of terrorist organisations.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The debate has clearly shown that we all have a common view here – at least as far as the unacceptable of this decision to collectively deprive 138 Members of immunity is unacceptable. There is no ifs and buts, this is unacceptable under the rule of law, it must be condemned and contrary to all democratic rule of law practices. I myself was a member of a parliamentary immunity committee for many years. I know what I am talking about in this context. Nevertheless, ladies and gentlemen, whether we like it or not – and we must do so – we must take note of the fact that Turkey is geographically where it is. Turkey is, after Russia and, together with Egypt, the country with the most people in our immediate neighbourhood – 90 million – and they are geographically located where they are. That is why, as the European Union, as leaders, we, as officials, must engage with our neighbours and address the issues that need to be addressed. In the context of the refugee and migration crisis, we have had a need to engage more closely with Turkey. There are also other areas which have made it necessary to cooperate more closely with the candidate country, Turkey. That is why the action plan emerged, and the action plan covers several areas. One area is precisely the question of how to deal. How do we support Turkey in dealing with the refugee crisis? I think that for the longest time there has been a common view that a country that hosts so many refugees, as well as other countries in the region, is entitled to receive appropriate support. On the other hand, there has also been a commitment in this action plan to speed up the accession negotiations, to give them new energy, and to push ahead with visa liberalisation. If, personally, nothing has escaped me, then that has always been Turkey's ambition. Turkey wants to become a member of the European Union, not Europe wants to become a member of Turkey. And Turkey wants visa liberalisation for Turks who want to go to Europe. So, if that is the wish, then we will deal with it. But there are conditions here. And if these conditions are not met, then things do not happen. That is the state of play. I see it, as do many of you, that Turkey, although there are always these statements of becoming a member of the European Union, is moving in a completely different direction. I would like to see a clear statement from President Erdogan – and he is probably the most important in this country – whether they are serious about us or not. In the end, it is also a pity for the amount of time we invest here. We are ready, but only on European terms. The rule of law is non-negotiable, there is no Turkish version of democracy, there is only a uniform view and view of democratic rules of the game, as we operate in Europe, for example, also within the Member States of the European Union. Europe – neither you nor I, no one – need not be afraid of President Erdogan or others. We are going our way, we have our convictions, our principles, and we are interested in good neighbourly relations, but we must act accordingly. And these are the Commission's convictions and principles. Rest assured that we are not giving in for a moment on any issue. But also understand that you have to deal with a neighbour, ultimately also in the interests of our citizens.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Eugen Freund (S&D)
text: Writing. The decision of the Turkish National Assembly to waive the immunity of 138 Members gives cause for concern for the Turkish rule of law and must be strongly criticised by our side. This decision is not only directed against the Turkish opposition, as shown by the example of the 50 members of the Kurdish opposition party HDP, which is now awaiting charges of supporting terrorism, but is also linked to a series of measures that are making Turkish democracy and the Erdogan regime appear increasingly in an authoritarian light. The European Parliament must now send out a clear signal in order to stop the corresponding undemocratic tendencies in the approach. I believe that it is in the EU's interest to maintain appropriate diplomatic and partnership relations with Turkey, owing to its geographical location and geopolitical importance, simply because of Turkey's special role in the refugee crisis. However, in order to liberalise visas and to join the EU, it must be possible to remind Turkey that human rights and freedom of the press and the media must be respected and that there must be no abandonment of the principle of the democratic rule of law.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council Declaration on the Reform of Trade Defence Instruments (IAC), (2016/2763(RSP).

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, this House is concerned about the interests of European industry in the light of unfair trade practices. Let me start by saying that the Council shares these concerns. There is clearly a need to take steps to improve our trade defence instruments in order to tackle unfair trade practices and distortions of competition, as well as to ensure a level playing field for European Union companies. Last month, during our debate regarding the market economy status for China, we also addressed the issue of modernisation of the European Union’s trade defence instruments. As we indicated on that occasion, the Council has restarted technical discussions on the Commission’s 2013 proposal and, although these discussions are still at a preliminary stage, it is worth noting that Member States recognise the need for the modernisation of our trade defence instruments also in the context of the current situation of global overcapacity across industrial sectors, in particular steel. At the Council of 13 May, Trade Ministers had a debate on the Commission’s latest ideas on how to strengthen the European Union’s trade defence instruments, taking into account possibilities of accelerating anti-dumping procedures and changing the methodology of calculating profit margins. The debate clearly confirmed that there is an urgent need for progress on this legislative file. All delegations stress the need for the modernisation of the European Union’s Trade Defence Instruments. But let me also be very honest. The Council is divided – as is this House – on certain elements and particularly on the disapplication of the Lesser Duty Rule. This is the main sticking point in the reform of our trade defence. Many Member States are happy with maintaining the Lesser Duty Rule. They feel that we have adequate anti-dumping instruments at our disposal. However, other Member States feel that more forceful measures are needed and that a relaxation of the Lesser Duty Rule is necessary in order to protect European industry against aggressive trade practices. In the current crisis facing the European Union’s steel industry, the European Union has already been robustly applying existing trade defence instruments, such as renewing anti-dumping duties and applying new measures for certain categories of steel products, investigating anti-subsidy action, launching new investigations and taking pre-emptive action such as the new steel prior surveillance scheme. Work will continue at a technical level in the relevant Council working party with a view to taking action at political level as soon as we can. However, it is still too early to say which of the ideas put forward by the Commission, as well as by some Member States, will ultimately be acceptable for the Council. Please rest assured that, as the Presidency, we will spare no effort to facilitate a compromise within the Council. It is clear that the modernisation of the European Union’s trade defence instruments is linked to the granting of market economy status to China, an issue which is of unprecedented political significance for the European Union. The question of market economy status for China was also considered at the G7 summit in Ise-Shima. Although the leaders’ declaration refrained from mentioning China by name, the G7 recognised the negative impact of global access capacity across industrial sectors, especially steel, on our economies, trade and workers. The Council has not yet taken a decision on the issue of whether it is important, or whether to grant market economy status to China, as the right to initiate legislation belongs to the Commission. We are therefore looking forward to the Commission proposal. The current discussion on trade defence also reveals the growing concern in our societies regarding trade liberalisation. We need to take this seriously and address these concerns. For instance, we need to ensure that the benefits of the global economy are widely shared. This includes countering unfair trade practices, while fighting protectionism and making the argument for trade as a means to create economic opportunities for workers, consumers and companies. Trade needs to be both open and fair. While being tough on trade defence, we therefore need to engage China in a discussion on the global economy and its place in it, in particular now that it holds the chair of the G20. This includes interacting with China on a strategic level to deal with the issues of overcapacity and its consequences.

name: Daniel Caspary
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Minister, I was very curious to see what arguments the Council used to justify the delay, inaction and irresponsibility of recent months and years. We have been working on various reforms for over ten years. In April 2014, the European Parliament took a position on this reform, and now, in June 2016, we hear that you have technical discussions. You say we are at an early stage. I can only call you on – we are all aware of the problems in the existing regulation. We know about the need for reform and we know what is likely to fall on our feet in December. Please deliver at last, and stop consoling Parliament and, above all, many millions of people in Europe!

name: Bernd Lange
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, Minister, I am completely stunned, completely stunned by what you have said. They say it's too early to give an answer. That is a mockery!  We have had legislation on the table since April 2014, and the Council is blocking a sensible reform of trade defence instruments. How do you want to reach a speedboat as a policeman with a sailboat? That is not possible at all! And if you had not carried out this blockade, we would now have more speed, the deadlines would be shortened, we would have an ex-official investigation by the Commission, and we would have tariffs that are really incisive and would not only compensate for the minimum damage. I think your behaviour is completely irresponsible in the face of a globalised world and many anti-dumping crises. We need to modernise trade defence instruments as quickly as possible. Finally, give gas so that we can really act on an equal footing!

name: Joachim Starbatty
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The EU's trade defence instruments are directed against dumping and subsidies and serve special protection: the key word saveguard. These protective instruments can tempt politicians to eliminate foreign competition. However, they are necessary when cut-throat competition threatens, and that is on the table here. Then competitive companies will actually be forced out of the market and competition will be restricted. The Commission and the Council seem to have difficulties with anti-subsidy measures. I would like to make the following three requests to the Commission and the Council: it often takes a long, very long time for these anti-subsidy measures to enter into force. This period is too long. The Commission and the Council must become more efficient and faster. However, in order to take credible action against subsidies itself, the EU must stop subsidising itself on a large scale, for example in the area of agriculture. And the EU must not use trade defence instruments as a means of protectionism. That would be counterproductive. They reduce the purchasing power of citizens and weaken Europe's production location.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all, yes, we need modernised trade instruments as soon as possible, and not only because of the market economy status of China but also simply because there has not been any overhaul of the instruments for over 15 years. My call to the Presidency is to deliver not as soon as you can, as you said, but as soon as possible. On substance, our Group would call for a liberal approach favouring trade and promoting its further liberalisation. On the other hand, we need to be able to make use of a variety of suitable instruments which would provide the EU economies and their sensitive industries with relevant and efficient levels of protection against unfair practices. We need to be able to react when it is obvious that goods coming from a third country are not offered under regular market conditions, that prices are either dumped or artificially subsidised. While discussing the revising of our trade defence instruments, we should continue to follow WTO provisions which are per se non-protectionist. We should therefore continue where appropriate with the application of measures such as the lesser duty rule. On the instruments themselves, there are potential areas we can cover without bypassing the WTO framework and where we can truly help EU businesses, especially small and medium-sized ones. We should, for instance, try to shorten deadlines in anti-dumping and anti-subsidy investigations. We should further investigate possibilities of using alternative methods in calculations of trade defence measures while taking into account special conditions of the third country market or while evaluating the level of damage to domestic industry. We also should consider using anti-subsidy measures more in our trade policy and address other related issues such as access to raw materials and export duties. So I call on the Presidency: please deliver.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Minister, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has Strong protective instruments are something that the European Union should have. I very much agree with my colleagues here in plenary. And yes, it is not acceptable that the Council has not delivered to date – also in the interests of the people and workers in the European Union. Employees must be protected from unfair competition through dumping. We must also give the Commission the flexibility to use the resources of diplomacy. I am therefore opposed to automatic imposition of punitive tariffs and to abandoning the diplomatic instrument of reduced punitive duties if they are sufficient to remedy a problem. It is precisely in view of the many disputes with China that negotiations have been successful in recent years. However, I would like to point out something else: the new global value chains require a new international understanding from us: what is to be defined as dumping, what can and should still have a real effect on national and regional defence of interests? It is precisely the large transnational companies, but also their suppliers in the SME sector, that will have to take much greater account of production conditions in the international context in the future. This includes the interests and conditions of employees as well as the impact on the environment. I call on you, the Council, the Commission and the Member States to push for a modern definition in the WTO and, until then, to seek a bilateral settlement with China in particular. The best trade defence instruments are those that do not need to be applied.

name: Yannick Jadot
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, I hope that European employees have not looked at your speech, Minister, because I think we would have a few more Eurosceptics and Eurocritiques in European society. As Mr Caspary has said, the European Parliament has done its job to protect a number of sectors that are essential to the viability of the European economy and to employment in Europe. That same year, in 2013, this Parliament fought to protect the photovoltaic industry from Chinese dumping, and it was not the Commission that was guilty, it was the Member States which, according to their purely national interests, refused to protect the European photovoltaic industry. Same with the steel industry.  Europe is not just a market. Europe must not be dogmatic from the point of view of liberalism and free trade. Europe must also protect its producers and if we are to succeed, once again, in developing an industry, protecting our employees, in a regulated and fair international trade, we must have instruments of trade defence. We do not just need a free trade policy, which we are fighting it, we need a strategy, we need trade diplomacy that allows us to defend ourselves and gives the European Union legitimacy vis-à-vis our fellow citizens.  That is not at all what you did today, Minister.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation).)

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – You said a lot of things that actually I agree with in your speech. Do you agree that one potential consequence of the failure to defend industries, whether it is in the UK or in any other country in Europe, is that that can then mean that those industries are moved to countries with lower standards of regulation and therefore we end up virtually outsourcing pollution?

name: Yannick Jadot (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" answer. When you don't protect the industry, the worst always happens. I am in my view that there should be strong European social standards, in environmental matters, which also encourage innovation and prevent offshoring. But once we allow countries to explicitly subsidize their industry to kill our own industries in Europe, we abandon those sectors, which end up either collapsing or offshoring. So, yes, but we absolutely need Europe to do that, because every country, facing Russia, facing China or against anyone, will never stand the road.

name: David Borrelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for two years this Parliament has been waiting to hear the Council's position on the modernisation of trade defence instruments, the so-called TDIs. Today, following Parliament's resolution on the granting of the ES MES to China, it is urgent to know whether the Council intends to be present on this issue and, specifically, whether it intends to modernise the TDI, in accordance with the position expressed by the European Parliament in 2014, and whether it intends to take this step in accordance with the May resolution on the ESME to China, thus making it clear that strengthening trade defence instruments cannot be a justification or compensation for the ESA. Unfortunately, no instrument would be effective if China were to acquire market economy status. Therefore, if action is needed on certain technical aspects, such as the timing of procedures or the lesser duty rule, it is all the more essential that the Commission should be able to guarantee their impartial application in order to protect a genuine common and European interest. In fact, in the past, in the practical application of the rules, the Commission has often been an inadequate arbiter in the context of the economic crisis, and today some Member States believe that essential aspects, such as the determination of profit margins, can be proceeded without the involvement of this Parliament. Parliament has expressed clear positions pointing in only one direction. It did so two years ago with regard to trade defence instruments and did so a month ago with regard to the ESA to China. We are now waiting to see how the Council and the Commission will respect our work.

name: Matteo Salvini
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, yet another demonstration that the European Union is a cage from which we emerge the better, because it does everything but defend the interests of European citizens. Summary for those who follow us: if tonight a manufacturer of toys, shoes, furniture, textiles and ceramic products notices that one of his products is copied and counterfeited, for example in China, the European Union does nothing, it does not move a finger. Indeed, perhaps after a year and a half, when the Italian company is already closed down and has already failed, perhaps they will intervene. Does it seem normal to you that we have been debating something for three years that a child in kindergarten believes is urgent and necessary, namely to defend our products? Go to the Commissioner, go outside an Italian steel company and explain to the workers that this building does nothing in the face of their dismissal. Photovoltaic panels, steel, textiles, Tunisian oil, Burmese rice. The great news today is that for the first time in history Europe will pay its farmers in October, not in March, not in April, not in May, not in June, but in October, with thousands of farms already in crisis. Someone in here should be ashamed, in here someone has the salary paid by european citizens to do the interests of others, multinationals, bankers, financiers, to make under-the-counter agreements with the United States, to make under-the-counter agreements with China, while hundreds of thousands of jobs are being lost in Italy and Europe. Hundreds of companies close every day, while the Commission reflects, evaluates and opens a table. Shame on you. The sooner we get out of this cage of crazy people, the better it will be for everyone.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I must say as the rapporteur for trade defence instruments, it has been pretty bizarre to have a debate on a file that was presented in April 2013 and that Parliament took a clear position on in February 2014. Two Commissioners have tried to reform this and both, Peter Mandelson and Karel de Gucht, failed because of the inability of Council to agree. But now we do not have time for that anymore. By 11 December the Council has to find a solution, a robust system that is legally compatible with the WTO, in order to not end up in a trade conflict. You have to find a balance between the producer industries’ competitiveness and the user industries’ competitiveness, and the interests of the consumers. But there are many myths when it comes to trade defence instruments. The most predominant one is probably that they do not deliver any protection at all and do not work to protect industries. But let us look at steel. We have 20 measures today in steel. Measures that have delivered rapid, sustained and substantial degrees of import to the European Union, from 85 to 99%. And we know that, as Mr Frédéric Bastiat concluded 200 years ago when he wrote the Candlemaker’s Petition, many industries are willing to go to considerable extremes to get even more protection. Therefore, we, as lawmakers, have to take the responsibility to guarantee that we strike a balance in the broadest public interest, and that is what I expect from you.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Minister that effective trade defences are a precondition to free and fair trade. The closure of the SSI steel plant in Redcar in my constituency, Minister, shows the human cost of your inaction in the Council to ensure fair prices in global markets. Our current trade defence instruments have been insufficient to shield our manufacturing industries, particularly the steel industry, from unfair competition and excess capacity.  A majority of EU Member States support their modernisation, as do MEPs and the Commission, but in an example of how the EU does not force its will on Member States, the UK Government and its allies have been able to block this reform for more than two years. Well, today it is time for the UK to use its real influence in Brussels to support the EU reforms needed by our communities, rather than hindering them further. We do not need to hurt our industries anymore. Save our steel industry.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE).
text: Mr President, there is a surreal side to this debate when we hear the Council. Colleagues have said that and they are absolutely right. First of all, it is not a technical issue, it is an eminently political issue, and I want to remind the Council and the Commission that our mission as European institutions is to defend the interests of Europeans and European producers. That's why we're here, it's not like that, in the air. That's the first point. Secondly, we must stop being naïve: all the great countries of the world are organizing, all the great countries of the world are able to defend the interests of those who live on their territory. We are completely naïve, especially to the Americans. We Europeans, when we apply additional tariffs to protect ourselves from dumping, we go up to about 20% where Americans sometimes go up to 200%. I would remind you that the U.S. Minister of Foreign Trade decided in May to impose an additional 451% tariff to protect the Americans from Chinese steel. That is the right thing to do, and I do not see why we would be the only block in the world that does not. You talked about China, you said it was related to status. I think - we are not going to reopen the debate on China now - that granting China market economy status would be a serious mistake, and I say it to you too: our citizens do not want it. China is not a market economy and I would like to see, from that point of view, at a minimum, a little political will expressed by the Council and, above all, a unity and union of the Council on this issue, that is vital. Two more words, we also need consistency. Yannick Jadot was talking about photovoltaic panels earlier; when we were fighting here to ban them, the EIB was in the process of financing photovoltaic panels in China. Finally, one day we will have to decide to have a real European industrial strategy to preserve our interests.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL).
text: – We are talking about trade defence instruments, and we cannot do that without also talking about the Chinese steel dump. China is in the process of dumping its surpluses on the European market. And that threatens to become even easier if that country is given market economy status. Once China gains that status, accelerated or not, it is necessary to have an effective toolbox. The levy on Chinese steel is currently 17%, while the United States introduced a 522% levy in May. Does the Commission take into account the interests of steel producers and workers? Or does it really just want to keep the steel-using industry and China happy with such a low tax? Finally, I would like to urge Minister Koenders to make an effort in Brussels and the Netherlands for the manufacturing industry. The manufacturing industry makes a major contribution to the economy and a lot of jobs, but moreover, European companies, such as the steel industry, are obliged to adhere to strict environmental standards. We do not want to allow that advantage to be eliminated by highly polluting companies.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Minister, what you have delivered here was a sign of poverty. The EU simply can no longer afford this council's perplexity. I will give you only one figure: in the twelve years 2003 to 2014, the EU only pursued countervailing duties on China for illegal subsidies in nine cases, 46 by the US over the same period. But times change, and the weather gets heavier. If you do not act now, European industry is in danger of being buried by waves of dumping. As far as our attitude towards China is concerned, this Parliament has shown the way. Take our resolution as the basis for the Council's action, stop thinking about whether china should be given market economy status! You can put order to it, but you cannot let the desired economic reality be given you. China is not a market economy, and as long as it is, we must ensure that there are WTO-compatible safeguards that work. Do something! At last!

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, in my constituency, the North-East of England, we have been hit incredibly hard by the crisis in the steel industry. It has cost thousands of jobs in Redcar directly and thousands more in the supply chain. It is a complex issue, but one of the key components is Chinese dumping on the world market.  So in terms of trade defence instruments, I suppose the decision that is facing the UK in 15 days’ time is, do we do these things ourselves in the UK or should they continue to be done at EU level? And indeed, would it even change anything because the EU anti-dumping rules are very much based on the WTO anti-dumping rules. And you know what, I agree to an extent with my north-east colleague, Jude Kirton Darling, who said that we have been far too slow.  But you know what? If the UK had the power to deal with these things ourselves straight away, we could not hide behind the European Council. We could not hide behind anything that is happening here. We would be able to take a decision straightforwardly and immediately for ourselves, rather than have to negotiate a position with 27 other countries, and actually the UK is going in a slightly different direction. America dealt with this very quickly. It slapped a huge tariff on imported steel and it was able to protect its industries. We should have been able to do the same.  If we were an independent, self-governing nation again in the United Kingdom, one of two things would happen – either the Conservative Government would take action, it would protect our industry, it would put on those tariffs for itself and we would save those jobs in the UK. Or the government would sit on its hands, refuse to help its own industry, in which case we could jolly well vote them back out again in a couple of years’ time at the next general election. That is democracy.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – You said that if the UK had the power to decide on its own, it would not be stopped by the other 27. Now, are you aware of the fact that it was not the other 27 that held back the UK, but it was rather the UK that held back the more progressive countries in the EU? And do you understand that in the case of a Brexit, as you so dearly wish, the UK would be mired in a UK mess while Europe would progress to defend its industry?

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – First of all, of course the United Kingdom would be able to do that itself. My understanding is that the UK is not opposing action on this, it just wants to do it in a different way to the rest of the European Union. We would find out whether the British Government is hiding behind that, using it as an excuse back home, or whether it really means it. And no, of course a UK that was free to make trade deals across the globe, a UK that had our democracy back, had our sovereignty back, had control of our borders, a UK that had the freedom to look at the wider world would not be a UK that would mired in nothingness. It would be a UK for the future.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not want to repeat the reasons that have already been given to the need for the Council to take note of the urgency, which is now undeatable, of adopting the Commission's proposal. In fact, we must equip ourselves with trade defence instruments that go in the direction of protecting first and foremost the system of our small and medium-sized European company, which is the one most exposed to the danger of unfair competition. There is, of course, a problem in European industry which is to be brought back to 20% of GDP, and of course it is a fact that the Council cannot avoid a situation which, increasingly, especially with regard to the issue of recognising China's status, Parliament has proposed, valued and strengthened in the direction that has been indicated. Parliament's role cannot be avoided. Parliament has already expressed its position on this issue on several occasions. We therefore call on the Council to act as a matter of urgency with a positive opinion on the Commission's proposal.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, two years ago and today there is a very large majority in this Parliament for a reform of trade defence instruments. The Council takes note of this. We have not said that we want a closed, protectionist, isolated Europe. Trade defence instruments are defence instruments: they intervene when unfair behaviour is established.  We have clearly called for any WTO plus to be consistent with the principle of full reciprocity and always to be decided within the World Trade Organisation. Today, however, we find that the main issues on which Parliament has made a clear statement, for example on the lesser duty rule, the application of which should also be limited in cases of social and environmental dumping, have been reopened in the Council. Let us be clear about this, as other Members have said: the Commission and the Council must work together strongly with the European Parliament. The starting point can only be the position expressed at first reading by Parliament. The Council cannot continue to be hostage to opposing vetoes, as the current steel crisis shows, because it is our workers and our companies who are paying the consequences, the most expensive price.

name: Bernd Lange (S&D).
text: – Mr President, on a point of order, we have a debate and I would ask the Council and the Commission if it is right to have a conversation and not listen to the Members of Parliament. I think that that is mistrust and misuse of the debate. Please be part of the debate and do not have a private conversation with the Commissioner.

name: Marietje Schaake (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the EU needs effective, flexible and meaningful measures to tackle unfair trade practices such as subsidies and dumping, and it is unacceptable to note that right at the moment when we need it most, with the imminent expiry of a key provision of China’s WTO Accession Protocol later this year – and right when overcapacity on the global market is hurting our already struggling industries , for example the steel industry – we are paying the price for paralysis and disagreement in Council. The Council has no time to lose in finding agreement on trade defence instruments – while avoiding protectionism, because that is no way to strengthen open economies and fair trade. Equally, we must be aware that the best way to address breaches of fair-trade rules by others is for us to lead by example. EU measures must be WTO compliant. Let us also be well aware of the other side of the coin. While they may not be so vocal, the EU also has many companies that import, also providing jobs for people. Our economies and other economies are globally interdependent and retaliatory measures can hurt. Of course, other factors such as low oil prices impact many, including the steel industry. It is an illusion for anyone to think that trade defence instruments alone can save one industry or another. So our Group, the Liberal Group, is seeking an overall balanced trade defence instruments package to ensure fair trade globally, not only vis-à-vis China, although it is an important player here. We need the right measures suitable for an interdependent global economy, flexible and effective and WTO compliant.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, what has always been developed in the European institutions, and that is what is in the treaties, is the theory of full free trade against cooperation. It is therefore good that we have, finally, a debate on new border protection mechanisms aimed at defending employment, a high level of social protection, the environment and the territories.  But I am very concerned that our debate will be a charade as long as we multiply the free trade treaties and Mr Juncker wants to have the treaty adopted with Canada without even consulting the national parliaments and continues this negotiation for the great transatlantic market. Therefore, yes to anti-dumping taxes at borders, which should be decided in connection with trade unions and consumer associations, yes to Community protections, but not to the free trade treaty with Canada and the transatlantic treaty.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the EU has been a very naive in its trade policy. We have opened our markets while our firms cannot export due to trade barriers. Our blind free trade policies have created massive unhappiness in our societies. Industries close down, people lose jobs, incomes drop. Populists are on the rise. The ground is shifting under our feet. Something needs to change.  Massive dumped steel imports have just wiped out most of the UK steel industry.
