In response to a similar threat, the US has just adopted or imposed over 500% of duties on Chinese imports. So what do we do? We still debate the lesser duty rule. The lobby of importers and service dominated countries prefer free trade ideology over recognising that we must protect the few industries that use anti-dumping.  I am speaking to the free traders. Please compromise on the lesser duty rule, otherwise in four years’ time we will have only protectionist parties sitting in the European Parliament and the result will be much more severe for everyone involved.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – There is a great deal of uncertainty as to what awaits us in the next six months around China's place in world trade. As you can see here in this Chamber, there is also a great deal of concern. Of course, we assume that China will not be given market economy status, but Article 15A 2 of the Accession Treaty will expire anyway. That is why I would like to urge the Council and the Commission to put forward a proposal which will also ensure that the EU can continue to use the analogue country method in determining dumping from countries and sectors where there are clearly no market economic conditions. We need this method to continue to effectively protect our industry from unfair competition.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The world is not standing still, everything is changing, even one could say that the world is rushing. Together with this world, of course, the economy is also rushing, all sorts of methods of action in the global market. The European Union, on the other hand, has not reformed its market protection, trade protection instruments for 20 years, nay, even for 2 years, it cannot deal with the reform that it itself initiated. It is, moreover, quite characteristic of the Community that everything with us lasts from months to several years. The United States, for example, is much more active and faster in this area. In the past year alone, in the steel sector alone, they have undertaken 64 procedures, when the European Union has five times less – 12.  But I would caution against combining this subject, which we are discussing with limiting the taking of initiatives on free trade agreements with other countries or with other economic areas of the world. These are two different things, and please don't put it under one denominator. Thank you very much.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Minister, the modernisation of trade defence instruments is part of an arsenal of measures in favour of a European industrial policy. What is the point of supporting research and development, what is the point of supporting investment but also deciding on social and environmental standards, which we of course support, if, at the same time, the European Union does not have effective tools to protect this European industry?  It is true that today, in relation to this unfair competition, as you have heard, there is some unanimity here in the European Parliament. There are proposals from the Commission that are being put forward and you in the Council are procrastinating. You will take on this responsibility for European industrial non-defence.  Therefore, Minister, I would like to tell you that I would like us to have the debate here as to which countries are blocking; they will then assume this responsibility in relation to European industry.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE).
text: Mr President, Minister, I am, like a number of my colleagues, puzzled by your statement. Over the past twenty years, our trade defence instruments have not changed while the economic and trade situation of the European Union has continued to change. The unfair practices of some third countries are multiplying and undermining our competitiveness, especially that of our SMEs, as well as employment in Europe. The current debate over China's market economy status demonstrates the urgency and need for the Union to have strong and strong instruments. It is time to modernize our trade defence instruments and this is not protectionism. At a time when Europe is seeking to revive growth, the Union must speak with one voice and the dossier must be unblocked by the Council as soon as possible, or it would be irresponsible.

name: Karoline Graswander-Hainz (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Minister, I would like to ask you the following: how does the Council even imagine that the EU can defend itself against unfair trade practices and respond appropriately to dumping products if we do not have effective protection against unfair competition, if there are no fair rules for all and if European jobs are not effectively protected because our European trade defence instruments are not up-to-date? Not much has happened since 2013, but we now have 2016. It is time to react immediately. It is clear that it is absolutely necessary to amend, modernise, clarify and ensure that more rapid action can be taken in the future in the event of unfair competition. We urgently need effective instruments against the abuse of subsidies. I call on you to finally put an end to the blockade. It is up to you. Take responsibility, that's what we expect from you here.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D).
text: Mr President, in trade matters, all continents, all the major countries protect themselves and we, the European Union, give the impression of being overstretched, procrastinating, even if we look - a bit like you, the representative of the Council - with our arms dangling, european industry collapsing.  But it is not impotence, it is the choice of inaction. It is not a matter of means, it is a matter of political will. Yes or no, do we want Europe to defend itself? We want it and we can, because the reality - as mr Bernd Lange has been reminded - is that there are very concrete proposals: we increase the anti-dumping procedures, we go back to the rule of less law, we shorten the procedure times, we extend the referral to SMEs, to trade unions that can directly refer the matter to the Commission , even if the Commission itself is self-employed on these issues.  In short, we can do it, we have to do it and it's time to do it! Otherwise, as was pointed out at the time, you take responsibility for ensuring, in the eyes of all Europeans, that Europe gives the impression of not defending itself.  It would be really heartbreaking for the European project that we all support.

name: Joachim Schuster (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Council's inability to act on trade defence instruments to date is shameful. This is not about protectionism or free trade, as some ideologues keep claiming, but simply about fair conditions of competition based on WTO rules. Instead of miming the model student when it comes to free trade, the Council should finally see itself as a representative of the interests of European industry. Time is pressing. The decision to grant market economy status to China is pending. China is not a market economy. Many companies there are subsidised by the state, building up gigantic overcapacity in this way and trying to get rid of them on world markets. Without simultaneous reform of trade defence instruments, we do not need to talk any further about the market economy status in China. And one more thing is important: we need close coordination and cooperation with the United States in our future dealings with China. Here we really have common interests with the Americans, more so than with TTIP.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I will not sing the song of protectionism today, but we have to agree today. We have all to agree today in this room that our trade defence rules are obsolete and they have systematically failed to protect the Union industries effectively against overproduction in third countries and unfair practices. Nevertheless, the Council keeps failing to find a compromise and a reform. Moreover, today we are also facing a long delay and a real urgency to address the need of the partial expiry of China in the WTO, and this should be done before 11 December. Therefore I would welcome the new initiative of the European Commission for relaunching the reform of European basic anti-dumping and anti-subsidy regulations that includes the modernisation of trade defence rules. As many colleagues said today, we have to urge the EU Member States and the Dutch Presidency for an immediate resolution or an immediate response. Before blaming China, we have to name the Council and I hope to name but not to shame. It is already too late.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D).
text: – Mr President, representatives of the Commission and the Council, I think you will have realised that everyone in this Parliament is demanding, demanding, modern, particularly urgent and necessary trade defence instruments now, in the face of the debate on the possible granting to China of market economy status. We need faster and more effective procedures, shorter deadlines for the imposition of measures. And the European Commission must be allowed to initiate investigations on its own initiative and take provisional measures as long as there is a reasonable threat of harm. Frankly, I believe — just as those who have preceded me in the word — that the lower duty rule needs to be abolished in order to apply higher anti-dumping duties, just as other trading partners do. Look, I find it regrettable, totally unacceptable for the representative of the Council to say that they still have time. We can't wait any longer in terms of work, in terms of factory destruction, in terms of talent loss, productive capital. How many jobs do it take for the Council to be able to assume its role, its obligation, and to reach an agreement that prevents a single job from being lost? I ask you, please, not to fuel anti-European expectations for your inability to defend Europeans.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the European Union's trade defence instruments (anti-dumping, anti-subsidy and safeguard measures) are supposed to protect producers against imports that may be the subject of unfair trade practices. Trade defence instruments have been established by the World Trade Organisation on the basis of international law as a means of remedying trade distortions. However, what is happening in practice is far from these objectives. Instead of promoting a fair international trading system, the World Trade Organisation is doing nothing to stop inequalities in international trade.  It is therefore necessary for the European Union's trade defence instruments to effectively activate and protect the interests of producers from unfair commercial practices and not to operate in accordance with the interests and speculation of multinational companies, achieved through imbalanced trade relations. Will you finally take action at European Union level towards China, which is constantly using dumping? Will you finally take measures at Council level to protect the European steel industry or will you see industries closing down and workers and employees left unemployed?

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I have not yet encountered such a unique debate in this Parliament of ours from the far right to the far left. That, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, I mean a clear sign for all of you, but also a clear message to the Council and the Commission. Guys, let's get the job done as soon as possible!  We are too late, too many jobs have been lost, too much industry has been lost and not only the steel industry, but all that industry that is tied to the steel industry is getting into significant and big problems. We need modern instruments, we don't need ultimate protectionism, but we need modern instruments to protect our industry and thereby protect our jobs and our citizens.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, the reform of trade defence instruments is not a fad. It's a necessity. The Council is the European institution that often blocks extremely important initiatives for economic development and, lo and behold, also blocks the reform of trade defence instruments. For two years I have asked the Commission, both in writing and by direct interpellation, to find anti-dumping measures. How do we defend Europe, which is also deindustrialised, by entering subsidised third countries into their countries? We are facing TTIP negotiations with the United States, where we also have problems with the Buy American law. We're not told anything. What will we do if this agreement is concluded without a buy Europe law? There are a few months to go until China's agreement with the World Trade Organization expires and it will be a market economy. Have we prepared the trade defense instruments? Work at other speeds, Minister. The Commission and the Council stand with their arms crossed and do not find or seek trade defence instruments. We are waiting for answers, but above all, concrete measures, gentlemen!

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, first of all let me say that I very much sense the degree of unrest, impatience and worry that exists in this House regarding the issue of the unfair trade practices. I think it is a very important signal also for the Council and for the Presidency work and I will come back to that in a second because I do understand very much the sense of urgency, not only for the people, the workers, in Europe, but also because we have a time limit because of some aspects that you mentioned regarding the WTO.  First of all, let me also say that I do not think it is a debate here between free traders or fair traders or protectionists. I think we all share the concerns regarding the issue of the strengthening of our trade defence instruments in order to tackle unfair trade practices and distortions of competition, as well as to ensure a global level playing field for the European Union. So the signal from this Parliament is very clear and I definitely take note of it and we will benefit from it at the Presidency of the European Union. Secondly, let me also say that, at the Council of 13 May, Trade Ministers had a debate on the Commission’s latest ideas on how to strengthen the EU’s trade defence instruments and I see exactly the same differences here in this House on this as I see in the Council. Let us not assume that we always all agree in the same way. I am not a President who believes in institutions blaming each other. I hear massively that it is the Council. Yes, I said honestly that we disagree there. That is not good. We have to speed it up and I am very honest about it. But it is something else to just simply say that the Council does not work. I think one of the Members out of frustration – which I fully support and understand – even said that we should even change the rules and the Parliament should rule and not the Council. Well, congratulations, we will see if we have a unified position quicker then. But the signal is very clear. I think all of you have mentioned issues that are very, very crucial to us. We have a community of law, we have a qualified majority on this issue and therefore, because of the reasons that you mentioned – and I therefore share your frustration on this because the world economy continues and the issue of overcapacity remains, and our people are waiting for us – in the light of the changed context resulting from Chinese dumping practices and the crisis in the European Union steel industry , the Presidency has reopened a discussion in the Council on the draft regulation on the modernisation of the trade defence instruments. This was proposed by the Presidency. We will continue to do that. We have just announced the intention to start an examination again on 14 June of those issues in the trade defence instruments modernisation package which could in principle be accepted by a majority of the Member States. There are quite a few different forms on that regarding anti—dumping and anti-subsidy investigation proceedings and improving the methodology of calculating the injury and profit margins. I think we have to realise that, in a Europe where we work together and the issue of the qualified majority is there, it is not always easy to find a consensus, but since we are one economic bloc and one trading bloc, we will have to succeed quicker on this, and there I share some of your frustrations as well. But let us not assume that this is just a problem only in the Council. This is something I think we have to work on together in an effective manner. Let me put one other issue on the agenda in that respect. We need to ensure that the benefits of the global economy are widely shared, also in Europe. That includes – yes – countering unfair trade practices, but it also includes fighting protectionism and making the argument for trade as a means to create economic opportunities for workers, consumers and companies. Some of you have mentioned that. Especially in those choices – the political, economic choices we have to make right now – it is true that it is frustrating that we do not yet have a consensual position from the Council. I think we have time limits in front of us. As I told you, the Presidency has taken a few initiatives. We will also again bring the signals from this Parliament to these working groups and I think we have to work here in the Parliament, in the Commission and in our respective national contexts on finding a solution to this problem.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. – After twenty years of intense macroeconomic change, aided by increasing globalisation and the affirmation of new economic players, it is essential that trade defence instruments are reformed so that they can respond more effectively to changed conditions and thus re-establish fair conditions in the internal market. We therefore welcome the renewed attention paid to this sensitive issue, but we reiterate here that any negotiations with the Council and the European Commission must begin with the European Parliament's report. Indeed, on 16 April 2014, by a large majority, Parliament, considering that the EU should not make concessions that exceed the provisions of international regulations, rejected, with the aim of protecting the interests of European workers and companies, the reform proposal presented by the Commission. Following the WTO+ approach, the unilateral granting of more favourable conditions would, in fact, guarantee a competitive advantage to trading partners, thus seriously prejudicing European industry which, abroad, does not enjoy these privileges. We therefore take this opportunity to express our deep regret at the impasse in the Council. The seriousness of the situation, as demonstrated by the crisis in the steel sector and the continuing loss of jobs, requires a very urgent take on responsibility.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on: – an oral question addressed to the Council by Renate Sommer, Renata Briano, Julie Girling, Frédérique Ries, Stefan Eck, Linnéa Engström, Marco Affronte, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on Japan's decision to resume whale hunting in the 2015-2016 season (O-000058/2016 - B8-0702/2016) and– the oral question addressed to the Commission by Renate Sommer, Renata Briano, Julie Girling, Frédérique Ries, Stefan Eck, Linnéa Engström, Marco Affronte on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on Japan's decision to resume whale hunting in the 2015-2016 season (O-000059/2016 - B8-0703/2016).

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Katainen, Minister, I am tabling the oral question on behalf of the Committee on the Environment. As you know, in November 2015 the Japanese fisheries agency informed the International Whaling Commission that it had resumed hunting as part of a new programme. The plan, which spans a 12-year period, would lead to the killing of 333 stranded whales during the 2015-2016 season, and a total of about 4,000 whales over the program's 12-year duration. With this decision to resume whaling, Japan clearly ignores the ruling of the International Court of Justice which, in its decision of 31 March 2014, required Japan to stop its annual whale slaughter in the Antarctic Ocean. Whaling is in fact a very ancient tradition in several countries, and in Japan it has been practiced for thousands of years. But in the 1980s it became clear that the indiscriminate killing of cetaceans should be stopped, which was banned in order to prevent the extermination of the species. Since 1986, when the moratorium of the International Whaling Commission came into force, commercial hunting has also been illegal in Japan. But as early as the following year Japan continued, in defiance of the Court's ruling, to kill these animals, improperly exploiting a loophole of the International Whaling Commission, which provided for the possibility of activating scientific research programmes as a justification for the killing of whales. But as you all know, the International Court of Justice has concluded that, in this case, whaling is not carried out for the purposes of scientific research, as the Japanese authorities and government have argued differently. Whaling by the Japanese authorities is therefore a violation of international law and threatens the protection of biodiversity and marine ecosystems. Furthermore, the same exception presented by Japan today would be rejected, given that scientific research itself no longer allows whales to be exterminated. In this context, therefore, we would welcome an answer from the Commission and the Council to the following questions: apart from the démarche that will co-sign the European Union delegation in Tokyo, do you intend to condemn more strictly Japan's decision to resume whaling and to hunt and kill 333 specimens of minke whales during the 2015-2016 season? Are you considering other means of putting pressure on Japan through bilateral or multilateral channels? If the démarche does not produce the desired results, do you intend to take legal action to ensure that Japan fully fully obtained the judgment of the International Court of Justice?

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr La Via for this important question. The European Union and its Member States are strongly committed to the protection of whales. And in a broader sense I think you mention exactly why this is so important: the protection of biodiversity and marine ecosystems. Let me also be very clear about the position of the Council. We do not approve of the current whaling activities of Japan. Up to this day, Japan has failed to present sufficient evidence to justify its whaling activities with regard to its new research programme and a justification of lethal sampling, in particular, is far below standard. We have conveyed our serious concerns in view of the expert panel findings and the conclusions of the Scientific Committee, and our position has not changed since June 2015. These serious concerns will be expressed again in a meeting in October and we acknowledge that an effective conservation and management regime can only be established through joint efforts and by initiatives that promote mutual trust and cooperation between all the members of the International Whaling Commission. As already said, and I think you mentioned this very important point, at the International Whaling Commission meeting in September 2014, we regard the judgment delivered by the International Court of Justice in March 2014 concerning whaling in the Antarctic as a definitive interpretation of the Convention, and we believe that the principles of the ICJ judgment should be fully incorporated into the working practices , including by a revision of the current review system, Annex B. In our view the judgment clarifies the legal framework for scientific whaling, particularly when it comes to assessing the necessity of having recourse to lethal methods of sampling where non-lethal alternatives exist. The judgment can also help to ensure an effective regulatory framework for international conservation and management. This brings all whaling operations under IWC control.  The European Union and its Member States stand by IWC Resolution 2014-5 adopted in 2014, according to which no further whaling permit should be granted without prior international review, including by the IWC Scientific Committee.  We regret that Japan had not consulted with its partners before engaging in such activities, which are not in line with the ICJ ruling. The Presidency will ensure that the European Union and its Member States are well prepared for the upcoming meeting in October. It is also against this background that the European Union and its Member States joined the démarche led by New Zealand to Japan in December 2015 following the resumption of Japan's whaling activities in the Southern Ocean.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the EU is fully committed to the conservation of all cetaceans and is equipped with environmental legislation to pursue this objective. Commercial whaling is not allowed in Member States’ waters or by ships under the jurisdiction of a Member State. All whale species are protected from deliberate disturbance, capture or killing under the Habitats Directive. In addition, the introduction of cetaceans into, and export from, the EU for primarily commercial purposes is banned under our wildlife regulations. The EU has also clearly positioned itself against commercial whaling at the International Whaling Commission and strongly supports the moratorium on commercial whaling as an essential measure to protect whale stocks that have been decimated by decades and decades of unsustainable hunts. For many decades now Japan has been conducting so-called scientific whaling under the special permit provided under the International Convention on the Regulation of Whaling. The EU welcomed the 2014 landmark judgment delivered by the International Court of Justice ordering the interruption of the Japanese research programme in the Arctic, in the light of its scale, methods and limited scientific output. In December 2015, the EU and its Member States joined New Zealand, Australia, the USA, Mexico and South Africa in a diplomatic démarche towards the Japanese authorities against the decision to issue special permits under its new scientific whale research programme in the Antarctic Ocean for the hunting season 2015-2016. The EU and its Member States do not believe that lethal sampling is required to satisfy the needs of a modern scientific research programme. In addition, we are deeply concerned by the fact that the new Japanese programme has been launched without due recourse to the concerns expressed by the IWC Scientific Committee in line with the clear criteria identified by the ICJ defining whaling for the purpose of scientific research.  Regrettably our diplomatic initiative did not result in reconsideration of the decision by the government of Japan. The issue of scientific whaling will be again on the agenda of the IWC at its next meeting, which will take place in Slovenia in October. The EU will continue to take a strong position on this subject and to work with our international partners to press for decisions within the IWC that lead to better conservation of whales worldwide. The Commission is not considering legal action against Japan at this stage. We should try to resolve the issue through political dialogue as well as further discussions in the competent international forum, the IWC. The overall objective of the EU is to ensure an effective international regulatory framework for conservation and management, that currently is a significant improvement in the conservation status of whales in the long term and that brings all whaling operations under IWC control.

name: Marijana Petir
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Mr. President, last year, at the same time, we discussed the same topic – respect for the conclusion of the International Court of Justice, which found that whaling carried out by Japan in the Southern Ocean could not be considered whaler for scientific research purposes, as Japan claims. Japan has clearly not found a way, such as Norway and Iceland, to allow that catch under agreement with its international partners that allowed it to continue its so-called controlled catch, but abuses the goodwill of the rest of the international community. Japan itself has admitted that more than 300 whales have been caught in the past whaling season, including 200 hills of females, which will cause far-reaching consequences for the population. All the more regrettable is the fact that there is no talk of stopping whale hunting, but rather a new 12-year plan that will allow the liquidation of 333 dwarf whales during the 2015/2016 season, with a total of 4,000 over a period of twelve years. Such disregard for international law raises the question of its meaningfulness, but not only that. Other national fleets could refer questions to their national governments in Australia and New Zealand, or Chile and the European Union whether they too are allowed to go there to investigate the way Japan does. That is why I ask the Council and the Commission if they will finally find an adequate solution to this case of non-compliance with international law and ban Japan from hunting whales.

name: Renata Briano
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, just a year ago in this plenary session we were discussing the same subject and condemning whaling in Japan. We have also learned today that this country will resume this practice as part of a new plan that will last 12 years and allow the killing of some 4 000 whales. In the summer season that has just ended with scientific hunting – my colleague also said this – to whales in the Antarctic seas, Japanese whalers have brought back 333 minke whales killed, of which about 200 are pregnant. The International Court of Justice in The Hague considered it necessary to suspend this practice because it lacked scientific purposes, not least because, as we know, so-called scientific evidence often ended up on the shelves of Japanese supermarkets. By resuming whaling, Japan is clearly ignoring this ruling and its international commitments to stop the annual massacre in the Southern Ocean. Japan's intention, in fact, is clearly at odds with the international moratorium on commercial hunting of sea giants, it is a continuous violation of international law and obligations to protect biodiversity and marine ecosystems. Europe must oppose this and cannot allow commercial interests to always take precedence over environmental interests. Even at the last G7, I was sorry to hear that our summits were not ambitious enough in demanding that Japan honour its international obligations to protect wildlife and, indeed, called for the agreements to be speeded up. I hope, in short, that we can still find some ground for discussion on this. We therefore call on the Commission and the Council to work hard to ensure that Japan stops this slaughter. And I remember today is International Ocean Day.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – You know that I am committed to preserving biodiversity with all my heart. It is in this light that I urge you today to make a firmer fist against Japan's plans to resume whaling. Indeed, whaling not only undermines the protection of biodiversity in marine ecosystems, it is contrary to international law, it is unnecessary for scientific research and there is also no public support for it.  The Commission and the Council must not allow for this heinous practice to be stopped and to protect the iconic animal that is the whale. The free trade agreement still being negotiated between the EU and Japan offers an excellent opportunity for this. As early as October 2012, this Parliament called for the abolition of whaling and the trade in whaling products during these negotiations. Commissioner, I would have liked to have known how the Commission would have raised this issue during those negotiations and whether this is a breaking point for the Commission. A clear signal from the Commission can hopefully influence the next IWC meeting.

name: José Inácio Faria
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Katainen, Mr Representative of the Council, Mr Koenders, I come from a country which has hunted whales for centuries, but which in good time has been able to put an end to economic greed and end the slaughter of these sentient beings. The same cannot be said for Japan which, under the false pretext of scientific capture programmes and in clear violation of the moratorium on commercial whaling, which entered into force in 1986 and to which it is a signatory, has illegally resumed its whaling activity.  And if I say illegally, Commissioner and Mr Minister, it is because there is a binding decision of the International Court of Justice of 2014 which forced Japan to suspend its cetacean hunting programme, to which that country cunningly intends to steal as already mentioned here by my colleague Giovanni La Via, author of the parliamentary questions.  The Japanese argument that these catches are for scientific purposes is of enormous shame and even shamelessness, because we all know that the scientific community no longer needs to slaughter whales for research purposes, as the International Court itself said, which, in deciding to suspend Japan's hunting programme, questioned the scientific purposes of the Japanese programme and considered it untransparent.  Ladies and gentlemen, this illegal unilateral decision by Japan, which will involve the slaughter of more than 4000 specimens over a 12-year period, is a clear violation of international law and an attack on the protection of biodiversity and marine ecosystems. Mr. Commissioner. Mr Minister, the European Union will not be able to watch this macabre game designed by Japan for purely economic purposes and must, on the contrary, do everything to prevent the killing of these living beings, as well as the marketing of products from this illegal activity.  Ladies and gentlemen, we all live on a planet that is not ours, which has only been lent to us so that we can cohabit in peace with beings of other species. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, let us fight firmly for this magnificent heritage.

name: Stefan Eck
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has Despite the ruling of the International Court of Justice and despite massive protests from all over the world, the Japanese government has continued to hunt whales for supposedly scientific purposes in the 2015/16 season, and so it is to continue for the next twelve years. This is a audacity that cannot be surpassed, because we all know that this is an infamous lie. Japan has been slaughtering these peaceful marine mammals for far too long to sell to restaurants. Most people in the EU categorically reject whaling; that is why we, as their elected representatives, should now respond appropriately to whale hunting and the total ignorance of the ICJ ruling. A note of protest or political dialogue is no longer enough; other steps are necessary.  The slaughter of whales is a crime and contributes to the extinction of these marine mammals. The Commission should encourage the International Whaling Commission to become a genuine whale protection commission and it should be possible to impose sanctions on Japan.

name: Linnéa Engström
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Whale hunting is extremely cruel. Whales are harpooned and a slow death is met. In modern whaling, harpoons are fired at the whale. The grenade explodes 30 centimetres into the whale's body and puts it in shock until it dies. Since 1986, there has been a ban on commercial whaling. The aim is to save whales from extinction. The only exceptions to the ban are hunting for the needs and scientific purposes of indigenous peoples. When the decision was made, Japan suddenly became very interested in conducting research. They started their whale research program just a year after the moratorium and continued to hunt whales in Antarctica. Since 1987, Japan has killed over 13,000 whales in its so-called scientific programmes, although it has been widely known that their hunting of whale meat had primarily commercial purposes. However, in March 2014, the International Court of Justice in The Hague ruled that Japanese whaling is not carried out for scientific purposes. I am very disappointed in Japan, which, despite this ruling, has resumed the whale hunt. They now plan to catch 4,000 whales over a 12-year period. During this year's season, they have already killed 333 minke whales, more than 200 of whom were pregnant, several with twins.  Japan does not respect international law. We must make it clear to Japan that this is not acceptable. Not only is it contrary to international law, it poses a serious threat to biodiversity and marine ecosystems. In addition, demand for whale meat has fallen sharply as Japanese consumers have been better informed. That makes it even more incomprehensible why Japan persists in continuing.  Europe must react. It is time for the Council to put more pressure on Japan and not hesitate to take legal action if necessary. Europe must use the levers that we have – political and economic – to end this cruel slaughter.

name: Marco Affronte
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as has already been said a year ago, we were here to tell each other the same things, to make the same statements, to discuss this absurd whaling, and it is strange that in 2016 we are still talking about whaling. This time Japan has surprised us even more because it presents us with a plan that goes even further than 12 years and includes the capture of 4 000 whales. The International Court of Justice has already said that this is not scientific research, that japan's excuses make no sense. But there was no need for the International Court of Justice, just ask any scientist working on cetaceans to know how many alternative methods we have, and none of them includes killing so many specimens, in fact not even one specimen. We are talking about a species that has very complex behaviors, we are talking about species that have high, high social affinity and a species that is declared intelligent, a species that has a high sensitivity. Yet we are here again to talk about it and we do not and do not find the means to put a stop to this. We wonder what the European Union can do and we have not really had any answers because the answers are probably not there either. Let's try to go somewhere else. In Japan, the Japanese cetaceans research institute tells us that, in 2014, of the 1 200 tons of whale imported 900 were not sold and remained in refrigerators. Japanese culture is changing, Japanese consumption is changing. In 2015 each Japanese on average ate 30 grams of whale meat. It means that very few people eat it and it is a tradition that is disappearing, but Japan is moving forward with its tradition, it does not want to hear the voice of the international community. We are now asking the European Union to raise its voice. That is the only thing he can do, because we have no other means, and we are trying to strike, if not politics, if not the institutions, japanese consumers. We must also have their support to stop this absurd massacre.

name: Sylvie Goddyn
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, There are legitimate concerns about Japan's decision to resume whaling, despite the decision of the International Court of Justice. Japan plans to catch about 4,000 whales over 12 years, and the recent slaughter of 541 whales near Australia, including 207 pregnant females, appears completely irresponsible. Japan's scientific justification does not hold up, it is similar to the arguments in favour of laboratory animal testing, which are for the most part completely useless. Parliament's proposals - putting pressure on Japan or even initiating legal proceedings - are interesting, but they are vague and do not suggest any concrete means of pressure. However, there are avenues, particularly in terms of fisheries agreements with developing countries. Japan often enters into fisheries agreements with the same countries as the European Union. Couldn't the resumption of whaling be an argument to be made in the negotiations? I'm asking the question. Finally, Japan is not the only threat to the survival of whales: plastic waste poisons them and leads to massive strandings, especially on European shores. And it is not plastic bags that kill them, but pieces of agricultural greenhouses used in the Netherlands or Spain. It is therefore important to sweep in front of our door, also solving this problem that concerns us directly.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, here in Europe we greatly admire the way in which traditions are cherished and are part of the living culture in Japan. Having said that, we are also aware that no culture is born or living in a vacuum; they transform and adapt to changing circumstances. If we look at the evolution of Japanese culture through the millennia, there is no better example in this regard than the period of Meiji Restoration. While it is true that a number of coastal communities in Japan have indeed practised inshore whale hunting for centuries, it is stretching it a bit too far to invoke traditional culture today to defend sending out ships across the globe and to the Antarctic to hunt whales. Fortunately, the times of post-war world food shortages, when whale meat was the biggest source of meat in Japan, have long past, and most people can afford other types of meat. Consumption has been falling for years, and most Japanese do not even eat whale meat at all. Therefore, just as eating habits have changed, so should the practice of whale hunting. Nor can the killing of hundreds of whales each year be credibly justified by scientific research purposes. Considering the threat to some endangered species, the high economic cost of whaling for Japan’s taxpayers, and the damage that global condemnation brings to its international image, I believe that it would be in Japan’s best interest to call its whaling fleet home.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in 30 years of scientific experience and research at sea, with my teams, I have carried out numerous studies on biology, food ecology, ecotoxicology, migration and population dynamics of various species of Atlantic cetaceans. We studied behavior, analyzed waste, performed biopsies, conducted censuses, put transmitters and sensors on individuals that we monitored through hydrophones and satellites, and produced mathematical distribution models. We never needed to kill any individual. In addition, we used information from animals we found bold on the coast. Technological developments are now instruments and methods that, although intrusive in some cases, do little to disturb the animals to study, little disturb cetaceans. The study of stable isotopes, genetic analysis and genomics allow us to know eating habits, migration dynamics and even kinship relationships. Today there is a huge set of non-lethal methods that are excellent approximations to reality and fully accepted by the scientific community. For these reasons, I find it unfair to argue the need to use lethal methods for scientific purposes. Through DNA barcoding and other genetic-based techniques applied to catering products, we know that cetaceans from hunting said for scientific purposes practiced by Japan are marketed without proper framing, having led to unfair and deceptive commercial practices. Although its scientific research methodologies have been condemned by the International Court of Justice and also by the scientific community in general, Japan, which I regard and respect as a great historical, cultural, scientific and technological nation, has not yet corrected the essential aspect of its Antarctic scientific programme, to stop hunting whales. On this World Ocean sday, I want to affirm, as a scientist and now as a politician, the uselessness of whaling for scientific purposes.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL).
text: – Today is World Ocean Day. People around the world are concerned about the survival of whales. Many are angry with Japan, because despite a ban, Japan has again killed more than 300 whales in recent months, including 200 pregnant animals. The largest animals on our planet are being hunted with heavy artillery. After being chased for a long time, the exhausted animals are shot at with exploding harpoons, harpoons that drill deep into the flesh. The badly injured animals are hoisted on board and killed with gunfire. This agony often lasts several hours. Such a massacre is in no way justifiable. Europe is capable of stopping this suffering by exerting pressure on Japan through its trade policy. If we really want to do something about whaling, we will not talk about a trade agreement as long as Japan continues this heinous and irresponsible illegal whaling. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the Japan Fisheries Organisation has notified the International Whaling Commission of a 12-year plan to allow the killing of 333 whales between 2015 and 2016 and a total of 4,000 whales over the course of 12 years. Unlike the 2014 Ruling of the International Court of Justice, which banned japan's annual whaling, that country continues to kill whales. Since 1986 Japan has killed more than 10,000 whales, using so-called scientific studies as a pretext. Since whaling violates the rules of international law, undermines the protection of biodiversity and marine ecosystems and is not even required for scientific research, it is necessary for the European Union to condemn Japan's attitude towards the killing of whales. Japan will have to comply with the rulings of the International Court of Justice and stop the slaughter of whales on the altar of profit.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, it would be best if we marked this World Oceans Day with a long, long silence in Parliament. Because of all that we have done to the oceans in recent decades and because of all that will unfortunately still happen, and especially in this particular case when we cannot talk about any scientific research of oceans and whaling, when we cannot talk about preserving the traditions of the Japanese in their way of harvesting and later, the use of whales. It's all one big scam. All this is one disgusting job that the European Commission, the European Union must try to stop with all political and legal methods, but especially by the political methods at our disposal.  It's a shame to miss this opportunity, so many species have died out, let's at least do it so that whales don't die out in our oceans.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, as I stated before, the Commission will continue to work to ensure that any future solution on whaling within the International Whaling Commission leads to a better overall conservation of whales worldwide and ultimately to a sizable reduction in the number of whales being killed under whatever whaling regime, commercial or scientific. The EU and Japan are close allies and major international partners. The EU and Japan are currently negotiating a strategic partnership and a free trade agreement. In these frameworks, the EU is pushing for the inclusion of a robust trade and sustainable development chapter in the FTA and a robust article on the environment in the SPA, but whaling as such is not part of the ongoing negotiations on these agreements between the EU and Japan. Our differences of approach on particular issues of whaling should not prevent us from strengthening our economic and political cooperation in other areas. Many thanks for your comments and this discussion.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I thank the honourable Members for all their inputs, which are extremely important for the coming months. This is something that we all share, namely that we do not approve of the current whaling activities of Japan. I continue to be very concerned that Japan has also failed to present sufficient evidence to justify their whaling activities. We are looking ahead now to the meetings that are going to be held soon on this issue. The issue of scientific whaling is discussed at the meeting of the Scientific Committee, which just started in Bled. We have constantly recognised and supported the independence of that committee and we will keep to that position. We conveyed our serious concerns in view of the expert panel findings in 2015 and our position has not changed in that respect. The only way we can work on this is an effective conservation and management regime through joint efforts and by initiatives that promote mutual trust and cooperation. We stand really ready to engage with all partners at the IWC66, while reiterating the importance of respecting international obligations and our opposition to the conduct of so-called scientific whaling outside IWC control. As you know, we have made this démarche earlier. We will ensure that we will continue to take an active position in this debate against the policy that we all abhor and therefore we will also ensure that the European Union and its Member States are well prepared for the next meeting of the IWC in October.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The motion for a resolution to be submitted in accordance with Article 128(5) of the CRP will be announced at a later date. The vote will take place in July. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. In November 2015, the Japan Fisheries Agency informed the International Whaling Commission that it would resume whaling as part of a 12-year plan. The plan calls for the culling of 333 minke whales during the 2015-2016 season and approximately 4,000 whales over the life of the plan. The questions call for a stronger condemnation of Japan and enforcement of the ICJ ruling of 31 March 2014 ordering Japan to stop the annual killing of whales in the Antarctic Ocean. This despicable massacre goes against the EU's animal welfare recommendations, including Article 13 of the FUE Treaty. Moreover, there is evidence that this is not related to scientific needs. Whaling is necessarily an attack on biodiversity because some whale species are on the verge of extinction. However, the problem of indigestion of plastic waste by whales that causes massive strandings will also need to be addressed.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. In November 2015, the Japanese authorities announced a new whaling plan. This plan affects a total of approximately 4,000 whales, including 333 minke whales, during the 2015-2016 season. This resumption of whaling is very bad news for the protection of biodiversity and marine ecosystems. Moreover, it is a flagrant violation of international law, including the judgment of the International Court of Justice on 31 March 2014 ordering Japan to stop the killing of whales in the Antarctic Ocean. The Japanese authorities claim that this fishery is practiced for scientific research purposes. This justification is not credible. The judgment of the International Court of Justice is very clear in this regard. The European Union must weigh its weight to put pressure on Japan. Whaling must be fought. It is a practice of another age that is not in line with the principles defended by the Union in its waters and in international waters. On behalf of the European Parliament's Fisheries Committee, I therefore call on the European Commission to use all possible means of pressure, including judicial proceedings.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – On 31st March 2014 the UN’s International Court of Justice – in its legally-binding decision – ruled that Japan’s state-subsidised whale-hunting in the Southern Ocean did not fall within the scope of scientific research and therefore was considered illegal. In spite of the ruling, Japan has recently resumed whaling, exploiting a loophole that allows for a limited amount of hunting for scientific purposes. Even though there has been a moratorium on commercial whaling since 1982, there is still supply of whale meat in Japan due to imports and the sale of the meat that was hunted on scientific missions. However, the hunting of whales could not be justified by the alleged strong cultural attachment to whale meat, either – which was popular in the post-war period since it was a cheap source of protein – as, according to research conducted by Greenpeace, whale meat consumption in Japan amounted to about 30 grams per person on average in 2015 (whereas the stockpile of unsold frozen whale meat totalled up to 5 900 tons in 2011). Following the suggestion of Greenpeace, activism from within Japan should be combined with international pressure. Therefore, I urge the EU and the Member States to take action and step up against this out-dated and illegal practice.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Our planet’s ecosystems are under increasing pressure. Clean air, fresh water supplies and food security all depend on our ability to protect these ecosystems from over-exploitation. Working with our international partners, through wildlife trade policy and by establishing protected areas and certification schemes, we have made some positive changes. And we have witnessed – as the result of international cooperation – the conservation and recovery of some degraded environments and declining species. 3 years ago we closed a legal loophole and banned the practice of shark finning, to allow the shark population to recover and help restore the ecosystem balance. Whales – like sharks – play a role in balancing the marine ecosystem. International cooperation is the only way to conserve a vast, shared resource like the marine environment. It is hugely disappointing that Japan has decided to resume whaling – ostensibly for research purposes. We must persuade our international partners to adhere to the common rules, and to protect our shared resources, so that our planet may continue to provide for us and for future generations.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on rules for open, efficient and independent management of the European Union by Pavel Svoboda and Heidi Hautala on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs (O-000079/2016 - B8-0705/2016) (2016/2610(RSP)).

name: Pavel Svoboda
text: author. – Madam President, Parliament has repeatedly called for the adoption of a regulation on the administrative procedure of the Union, which would enable European citizens to better exercise their right to good administration. For the first time, in 2001, Parliament called on the Commission to submit a proposal for a regulation containing a code of good administrative behaviour. At that time we had no clear legal basis for an EU administrative procedure law but, with the Lisbon Treaty, Article 298 was introduced as an appropriate legal base. In 2010, the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI) set up a working group on EU administrative law. We concluded that EU administrative law was very fragmented and only a very few areas of the Union’s administrative activities were subject to a systematic approach. That is why Parliament, in January 2013, adopted the Berlinguer report, in which it clearly requested the Commission to submit a proposal for an administrative regulation applicable to the administration of the Union’s institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. In the current parliamentary term we have again followed up, with a working group chaired by my esteemed colleague Heidi Hautala, which has done tremendous work that has now come to an end. As the Commission has, unfortunately, still not come up with a concrete proposal for a regulation, or clearly stated that we are to expect such an initiative, the oral question and resolution we are talking about tonight shall serve as a gentle reminder from Parliament to the Commission. In order to help the Commission to make up its mind, the main aim of the JURI Committee working group was to draft a model regulation, with the advice of law professors, containing a basic set of the rules we would like to see. We have annexed this regulation to the oral question and resolution presented tonight. The objective of such a proposal is to provide citizens and the Union’s administration with a comprehensive and cross-cutting administrative procedure. Especially in the current times, with Euroscepticism on the rise, citizens would enormously benefit from uniform procedural guarantees enforceable in the EU courts. Increased openness, transparency and accessibility of the EU administration will improve trust and the relationship between citizens and the Union’s administration, and in that way we will also reinforce the legitimacy of the EU.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: author. – Madam President, over the years the complexity of the EU’s administration has increased. New bodies, offices and agencies have been created and the tasks for which the European Union is responsible have also grown. This has meant, too, that citizens and businesses increasingly have become directly involved with the Union’s administration. This happens, for instance, when they are applying for EU funds, or when they lodge complaints against a decision which is unfavourable to them, etcetera. However, despite the fact that the Union has at its service officials who are both competent and dedicated, its public image is unfortunately often that of an incomprehensible and distant bureaucracy. The scattered nature of the rules governing the EU’s administrative activities, and the gaps and uncertainties that this leads to, are certainly not helping to improve this image. We have already heard from Mr Swoboda that there is a legal basis now for the Commission to come up with a proposal on law and administrative procedure, which would be applied to all EU institutions. And it is important to emphasise that the draft regulation which has been produced by the working group would apply only to the administration of the Union’s institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, and not to Member States’ administration. It would also concern only administrative activities in the strict sense. It excludes legislative procedures and it excludes judicial proceedings, as well as the adoption of delegated acts and implementing acts and other non-legislative acts directly based on the Treaties. What is very important is that the Commission looks at how, with the help of this draft regulation which has been finalised, we can foster the culture of an open, efficient and independent European administration. Finally I would like to say a word of thanks to the European Law Institute, a group of dedicated academic experts, from the political groups, for the immense amount of work that has gone into this exercise over the years, and notably during the past two years.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I am here today to reply to your oral question on the very important topic of European Union administration. You ask, in particular, if the Commission has analysed your suggestion for a regulation for an open, efficient and independent European Union administration, and whether the Commission has any plans to put forward its own proposal. You ask for the reasons that have prevented the Commission, thus far, from acting on its right of initiative in this field. Let me assure you from the start that the Commission is extremely serious about its commitment to guaranteeing that citizens can interact with a European administration that is open, independent and efficient. That is why the Commission has, for instance, set up the transparency portal. This portal provides citizens with direct access to information and will help them to be better informed and better prepared to follow and participate in the EU decision-making process. I also want to mention the Commission Inter-Service Group on Public Administration Quality and Innovation. This group is working to enable, among others, national administrations, and therefore European businesses, fully to tap the potential of the internal market, joint economic governance and the structural funds. Apart from these more recent initiatives, and as you know, the Commission has a well-established set of horizontal rules which govern its administrative behaviour – as, I would expect, does Parliament. This includes the general provisions of the Code of Good Administrative Behaviour, as well as a range of provisions on staff and financial regulations, on data protection and access to documents, to name but a few of the areas covered. All of these horizontal rules are a reflection of the existing legal principles of good administration, such as non-discrimination, impartiality and fairness, and the right to have one’s affairs handled within a reasonable time, etcetera. As the EU administers a range of diverse and mostly highly specialised activities, it also relies on sector-specific rules. Citizens and businesses concerned by such specialised activities are guaranteed specific administrative rights. Examples here are numerous: we have specific rights in competition law, and in relation to novel foods, the authorisation of medicinal products, GMOs, trade defence, etcetera. The Commission has analysed your suggestion for a regulation for an open, efficient and independent European Union administration against these existing horizontal and sectoral rules, principles and practices. As a result of that analysis, the Commission is, at this stage, not convinced that the benefits of using a legislative instrument that would codify administrative law would outweigh the costs. Codification is a complex and delicate exercise that can often have unintended consequences. In having to clarify the relationship and to ensure consistency with these more detailed rules, codification would require the revision of the considerable volume of existing EU legislation. Even where done with care and a sense of proportion, codification may still lead to problems of delimitation between the general and specific rules – not making legislation any clearer or litigation any easier for citizens and businesses affected. Codification would remove the flexibility required to adapt to particular needs. These challenges and difficulties are also confirmed by the draft regulation. The text does not identify what the gaps and inconsistencies in current law are, and therefore what the justification is for coming forward with horizontal legislative solutions as a proportionate answer to deal with them. It also does not assess the concrete impact of the provisions it contains. While the text is said to be without prejudice to existing rules and rights under specific Union legislation, it provides for no legal mechanism to ensure delimitation between the general and the specific rules. It rather seems to suggest that a case-by-case analysis would continue to apply. Lastly, there is the matter of ways to identify administrative activities of the institutions and bodies that would be subject to the new rules. Instead of engaging in a highly complex exercise of codification, with uncertain value-added, the Commission is of the opinion that we should continue to address concrete problems where they arise, analyse the root causes and then take the sort of action that is needed. The Commission analyses each case of alleged maladministration, and will try to rectify any error that has been made. It also engages constructively in the context of all inquiries by the European Ombudsman. That being said, at this stage the Commission is not aware of any pattern of cases of maladministration that could be addressed through a general administrative law. I am, as is the Commission, therefore grateful for the work you have done, and will continue working with you on all options and good arguments as to how we can improve our citizens’ life.

name: Емил Радев
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – I would like to congratulate Mrs Hautala and the Legal Service of the European Parliament, who have made so much effort to produce this important document for the European administration. The European Parliament has repeatedly called for the adoption of a regulation on the Union administrative procedure. So far, the European Commission has remained deaf to our calls. Let's hope that this time he will make the necessary efforts to make this proposal a reality. Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights provide the right to good administration. But in order for citizens to exercise this right, they need clear, effective, predictable and accessible procedures in their relations with the European administration. The benefits of such legislation are undeniable – on the one hand it will fill gaps in the Union legal system and increase legal certainty by giving citizens and legal persons clearer rights and, on the other hand, help to strengthen confidence in the work of the European administration, the strengthening of the legitimacy of the Union. With our proposal, we provide answers to important questions, such as the initiation of the administrative procedure, deadlines and remedies. I believe that an important element of the proposal is the confirmation of fundamental procedural rights aimed at making the European administration an open, effective and independent administration. The protection of fundamental rights, such as the right to be heard, the right of access of any person to documents relating to him or her, the requirement to provide the necessary information to the parties are only part of the remedies that citizens can benefit from.

name: Victor Negrescu
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, the European Union needs a transparent, efficient and independent administration. This is what the European Parliament also asked for in its resolution of 15 January 2013 a few years ago. Today, the European Union has a cumbersome institutional mechanism. European funds are absorbed on the basis of a complicated and difficult system for citizens to access, and entrepreneurs face bushy bureaucratic mechanisms that block their work. That is why the way the European institutions work must be simplified in order to become easier to understand for everyone and, above all, for young people. The situation needs to change. Good administration is not an option, but a legal right, guaranteed by Article 41 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Institutions need to be more aware of the practical advantages of the citizen-centred approach. The principles of transparency, efficiency and independence lead to a stronger and binding European Union for Member States when their actions are subject to EU law. The European Union, however, is due to make its administration more efficient before criticising the functioning of the administrations of the Member States. However, I note with regret that there are still problems with a common European approach. Some states are protected when they commit violations of European law, while others, perceived as weaker, are sometimes criticised without objective arguments. The absence of the European dimension is also found at the level of representativeness in the European institutions. Whether we are talking about national representativeness or gender. That is why I believe that it is the duty of the European institutions to correct such situations and to propose a transparent and effective legal framework. We're talking about good administration. Finally, I strongly call on the European Commission to comply with the Regulation and to come up with a proposal for the document produced by the Committee on Legal Affairs on a transparent, efficient and independent administration of the European Union.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – For us, from the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists, the issue of an open, efficient, independent administration of the European Union is essential, both for European citizens and for the proper functioning of the institutions of the European Union.  Despite repeated initiatives by Parliament, as well as the texts enshrined in the Treaties calling for an open, efficient, independent European administration, the European Commission has not yet put forward a proposal for a regulation on the subject. A common European administrative law relating to institutions, bodies, agencies and offices would apply to the institutions of the European Union and should cover aspects from conflicts of interest to simple and understandably prepared administrative acts. This would serve not only European citizens, but also the institutions themselves and make them more accessible and understandable to citizens of member states.  I am curious to see what proposal the European Commission would present and what place in it parliament's views on the subject would find.

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. –  Madam President, the words of this resolution might easily have been written with the upcoming UK referendum on Brexit in mind. With the development of the competences of the European Union, citizens are increasingly confronted with the Union’s institutions, bodies, offices and agencies without always having their procedural rights adequately protected. There you have the heart of the matter. The EU has become a bureaucratic monster that pervades all areas of life in the Member States, so wide are its competences and so untrammelled its powers.  The vast majority of UK citizens have absolutely nothing to do with the EU, yet their lives are routinely interfered with by the activities of the EU. When we think of EU administration, the words ‘open’, ‘efficient’ and ‘independent’ certainly never cross our minds. As for the proposed regulation contemplated by the resolution, it is surely a joke. What rational, efficient civil service needs a regulation to tell it how to administer? It is a document written for the Kingdom of Ruritania or some foundling post-colonial state. The British electorate will be underwhelmed by the promises and stated objectives of this regulation. Instead, our voters will think that this is a document, a parody, worthy of the famous television comedy, ‘Yes Minister’. The EU has a well—merited reputation for having a deeply entrenched and ingrained habit of opaque, inefficient and less than independent administration. It will take more than a tick-box regulation to change that habit. Old dogs don’t learn new tricks.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the European Union is a sprawling administration populated by countless institutions, agencies, bodies and various bodies that make administrative decisions. However, each element of this Kafkaesque system is governed by its own rules. This lack of coherence leads to a lack of transparency about the guarantees enjoyed by the citizens. It is likely to encourage abuse of power. That is why I support mrs Hautala's motion for a resolution. This proposal aims to codify and standardise the administrative procedure applicable to all EU bodies. It thus clarifies the rights of the citizens, specifying, for example, that each individual has the right to be heard before being the subject of an individual decision. I regret that the Brussels Commission has rejected this interesting proposal; however, I am not surprised, for I have known for a long time that this oligarchic areopage delights in opacity.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab First of all, I would like to thank my fellow Members very warmly, and in particular our colleague Heidi Hautali, who have been working on administrative law issues for many months within the special team. The result of this work is the motion annexed to today's resolution – a very serious, extremely interesting proposal, which I believe the European Commission should approach in full seriousness – concerning an efficient, independent and well-functioning EU administration. This is, of course, an innovative project, and it is therefore not surprising that some EU institutions approach it with great reserve, including the European Commission. But I think sometimes you have to put something very new, very inspiring on the table, so that you can achieve your goal. The aim is to provide both citizens and business people, but also eu administrations with a comprehensive and horizontal way of acting within the framework of administrative procedures. On the one hand, citizens and businesses will therefore be able to exercise their rights and bring them before eu courts, on the other hand, the administration will be able to benefit from a clear and uniform set of rules.  Of course, the proposal presented by Parliament is an incentive, above all, to discuss between the EU administration and citizens in order to find the best solutions for them. Thank you very much.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as my fellow Members have heard – and it is very important that this consideration comes from different and even very distant political families – our intentions are positive intentions. Pending a formal proposal from the Commission, we have tried to work on this regulation not to replace the current legislature, but to supplement it, to fill in the blanks, to give greater certainty to those who then use these instruments. Certainty is very important in order to give credibility to the institutions. There are two things on which we must focus our efforts, and not coincidentally they have been mentioned here several times. Firstly, legal certainty is essential: to have rules that are easy to interpret and effective at the stage of their implementation. On the other side is transparency. All we are doing is, inevitably, but I would like to say quite rightly, that the citizens of Europe have been observed, sometimes even with a great deal of mistrust. Above all, the people who are most difficult look to the institutions in the spirit of those who need the intervention of the institutions and with the doubt of those who believe that some of the difficulties of their lives stem from uncertainty or the inability of the institutions. So this work is a very useful job, which we would like to do together. We can, as things stand, supplement the rules that are available. But you must quickly help us to get to the job we are doing. If we succeed in having, on the one hand, guaranteed legal certainty and, on the other hand, transparency in the behaviour of the institutions, we will defeat all those who think that Europe is an institutional and fundamentally useless place.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the Administration of the European Union is rightly perceived by citizens as an outgside structure which, in addition to national, regional and local administrative authorities, represents only an additional cost.  However, despite the common opinion that additional levels of administration are redundant and costly, the Union must have its own administration in order to function as a political-legal entity in the first place. Indeed, this administration should be, as the name of this regulation says, open, effective and independent, and I would add a minimum. At all levels of management, the need to change bulky and insouch structures is very often placed under the mantle of efficiency gains. This is a trap that should be avoided because it is the bulking of administrative bodies and the accumulation of regulations that are the main cause of inefficiency.  If we are to have a quality administration at EU level, it must be modern and minimal and work in coordination with member states' governing bodies. A strong and cumbersood administrative apparatus that serves as a preparation for taking on new competences from the national level in an attempt to achieve federalist ambitions will never be open or effective.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Vice-President, what you said in response from the Commission was more than disappointing. It was sobering, it wasn't really something new. We didn't expect anything else. I am taking part in this working group on the part of the Committee on Budgetary Control and I would like to thank Mrs Hautala and all those involved for a great job. What you have said this evening is a long way from enthusiasm, and that is extremely regrettable. It was a third-class funeral. Third class, because in this case the corpse carries the candle itself. All I can say is: how can we not understand certain things? How can we not understand why the administration's small one-off is exactly where an administrative procedure law is set, namely the question of remedies, decisions and the standardisation of procedures? The request is more than just, and it is extremely important for the EU and the EU's reputation. That is why, Mr Vice-President, do not take it personally, but I find what you have said today on behalf of the Commission pathetic and beyond what this EU needs at this very moment. The Member States are wiser than the EU. And that is the reason why I must be ashamed of myself here, because I believe that this administrative state of the Middle Ages, in which the EU finds itself here, must be urgently remedied. Here everyone does what they want. I have been watching this for twelve years now. Everyone does what they want and as they can. Here too, the Commission must make more effort and contribute to greater unification. We are still talking.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I would start by saying that I absolutely agree with what Mrs Gräßle said. He said it in very clear, normal and direct words. Today we hear from the Commission that the Regulation on a transparent and effective administration of the Union will not actually come to us, because that is not the case, because there are very rare cases where such infringements are. The Commission is in no hurry, although I asked, as Parliament, three years ago for this! I find it inadmissible and it really is a mockery. The Treaty of Lisbon provides that the European institutions and agencies must be supported by an effective and independent administration.
