What we give people in return is often inconsistency at the administrative level, bureaucracy and lack of clarity. We're losing sight of the public interest. There are procedures, and the excess of procedures, as well as lack thereof, lead to maladministration. Let's not confuse bureaucracy with the rules! We, in turn, as MEPs, are confined and buried by bureaucracy and cannot do our job for the people.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, in a Union of values, where citizens and businesses pay taxes for the functioning of public administration, it is absolutely normal and natural to want an effective administration capable of responding at all times to their needs and concerns. It is therefore important that, at Union level, there is and ensure a clear definition of rules and procedures that are correlated with their rights and obligations. A high degree of transparency, efficiency and rapid resolution of problems on the part of the institutions must be ensured. At the same time, it is necessary to take into account the fact that, although a number of administrative-sectoral procedures have developed over time, they are not able to ensure the coherence of the system, thus making it difficult for citizens to understand their rights arising from European legislation. We therefore note that an excessive set of rules and procedures, or also their absence from certain sectors, can lead to a maladministration. It is therefore necessary, by force of arithmetic record, to require a common set of administrative procedures to fill the gaps in this system, which will certainly lead to greater legal certainty. In addressing this issue, we must necessarily leave the case-law of the Court of Justice of the European Union, so that the principles of the rule of law are preserved and citizens have a guarantee that they are the beneficiaries of an administration that is always close to them and their rights are always respected.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, while the European Union is going through a period of deep existential crisis, while British citizens are soon expected to vote for Brexit, while in eight other countries citizens have expressed their desire for corresponding referendums, while the European construction is about to be dismantled, some are enlisting the supposed flight forward. It is the last resort in their quest to save europe of memoranda and austerity. They do not refer to a more democratic Europe and, although the major problem from the outset is the lack of democracy in the European Union, what they are interested in is the supposed efficiency and, above all, the independence of the Brussels bureaucracy. What they're interested in is bypassing the popular verdict. In Greece, the troika imposed shackles of automatic measures that would be activated in the event of a derogation from fiscal targets, thus bypassing the Greek Parliament. This is what some people dream of doing all over Europe. But it won't pass them, because the people will react.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Frau Präsidentin! Wir haben immer etwas zu sagen. Madam Chairman, I am probably one of the people in Croatia who are recognized as the greatest Euroentusiacs. And I really am, and I want to stay that way. However, my experience for the last fifteen years in working with the European administration, I will not say that it is disappointing, but in any case it is very, very doubtful.  As if sometimes this administration is enough for itself, as if it were inventing regulations and new procedures, perhaps not to make our lives miserable, but to protect itself because of the forest of regulations that exist within the European Union. This is particularly problematic in the use of European funds, cohesion policy, and therefore because of the need to simplify processes, I call for, as we wish, an open, effective and independent administration.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, every five years, the European institutions always ask why European citizens do not go to the polls and why they are indifferent to the European project. It is true that the European Parliament always tries to throw something at them at the last minute, such as abolishing roaming, in order to get them to participate in elections, but without much success. The simple truth is that citizens have been encountering an often closed, inefficient administration for five years, in which corporate lobbies have more say than the interests of citizens, and often the EU itself. If we are all really on the same page, then we must recognise that streamlining European governance is an absolute necessity now and there is nothing to wait for. I appeal to the Commission to act on this matter as soon as possible. Our citizens have waited a long time, but after your speech, Commissioner, I am not convinced that you know what the European Parliament wants. I'd like to tell you that you're not elected, but we can call you off.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, it has become clear that we do not necessarily agree on every single issue, even though we agree on a lot of things. I want to congratulate the European Parliament for raising the important topic of an open, efficient and independent European Union administration with the Commission today. For everybody in this room, this is a key topic as we are all here to serve EU citizens. What we do for the EU in our legislative and policy work can be found in official documents, but for the individual citizens it is especially in the conduct of the EU institution and bodies that we are judged. We therefore must ensure that we provide them with high quality administration that acts through efficient, transparent and coherent procedures. This is essential for gaining their trust and confidence in the EU. The EU's institutions and bodies, which have been created on the basis of common principles and values, have through the years developed rules and practices that grant citizens rights to impose obligations on the administration.  The Commission, and I trust also the other institutions and bodies, regularly reviews its practices to make sure that they continue to be fit for purpose and are adapted to developments. The European Ombudsman also contributes to ensuring quality in the work of the institutions and bodies and can point out where concrete improvements could be made.  While we see that the Parliament wants a ‘once-size-fits-all’ rule for EU administration, the Commission rather thinks that we best serve citizens if we have administrative rules that are tailor-made and can maximise the effect in each field of concern. We will continue to monitor our rules and practices in this spirit and, as always, are open to examine input by citizens and stakeholders that point our attention to specific needs for improvements. Thank you very much for this discussion and your attention.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: At the end of the debate, a motion for a resolution was tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 7 June 2016.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement on EU economic diplomacy (2016/2733(RSP)).

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, again, this is one of the issues on which I am working very closely with my colleagues in the Commission. The Commission and High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini and the European Investment Bank are currently examining how to have more efficient EU economic diplomacy.  Economic diplomacy is about using all levers that are at our disposal to promote our economic interests abroad. This means removing barriers and creating incentives to trade and investment by opening global markets, fostering cooperation on economic governance, regulatory convergence or a level playing field, concretely supporting the internationalisation of EU businesses and improving the coherence and effectiveness of the external action of the EU in the economic field.  Economic diplomacy is therefore at the forefront of the Jobs, Growth and Investment agenda, one of the top priorities of the Juncker Commission. In a world where most of the future economic growth is expected to happen outside the EU, we must make optimal use of all the levers at our disposal to promote EU prosperity in a global context. To this end, we need to develop a more cohesive and coherent approach that targets strong economic and political outcomes using our trade, investment, industry, innovation, foreign and development policies. EU economic diplomacy also has a financial dimension and access to finance for business internationalisation should be boosted, notably through EIB actions.  The Commission services, the EEAS and the European Investment Bank are already active in working towards removing barriers and creating incentives to trade and investment by opening global markets, fostering cooperation on economic governance, regulatory convergence or a level playing field with key economic partners. They are also supporting the internationalisation of EU businesses. We do this inter alia by negotiating and implementing trade and investment and sectoral agreements, by cooperating on sectoral policies across the world through diplomatic démarches by our EU delegations or at political level when we have summits or high-level meetings with partner countries, and by deploying and financing initiatives to support the internationalisation of businesses and SMEs. This can be done, for instance, via market access, partnership, support to EU chambers of commerce abroad, business missions and regulatory cooperation and projects. But we can still do more to further improve the coherence and effectiveness of the EU’s external action in the economic field.  First, we need to have a clear view of the EU’s economic interests and strategic objectives with key partners. And then we need to use the policy tools and instruments at our disposal to pursue these objectives and ensure coherence and synergies. Proper consultation, coordination and unity must be ensured with Parliament, Member States and industry, as a united EU is stronger and has more leverage.  An inter-service group on economic diplomacy has been set up with representatives of the Commission services, the EU External Action Service and the EIB to examine and make proposals on the above-mentioned agenda. This group has already helped strengthen our internal coordination. One of the next steps will be to equip EU delegations with better guidance and instructions on how to support EU economic interests abroad.  We are also reflecting on how to improve coordination with Member States and EU industry to work the together on the same objectives and divide work in an optimal way, including in respect of concrete support for the internationalisation of EU companies, where we need to avoid duplication. For this, we will discuss with Member States and industry representatives both in Brussels and in European capitals, but also in third countries where economic diplomacy is being carried out on the ground. The role of EU delegations is therefore key.  The European Parliament’s role in EU economic diplomacy is also key, as you have relations with parliaments of most countries in the world and can pass important messages when visiting them. We need to pursue the same objectives and work together to defend EU economic interests abroad. So, honourable Members, I will stop here and I am very interested in hearing your views on what more we could do and maybe learn from best practices you have seen during your visits and activities abroad.

name: Antonio Tajani
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, if the Union wants to play a leading role on the international stage, it must promote its competitiveness through strategic sectors such as industry and energy. In order to achieve this objective, the Union must have real economic diplomacy with three main objectives. The first is to support their companies abroad, helping them to position themselves in emerging markets, I am thinking of Latin America, Africa and the Far East, and of consolidating into traditional ones. Secondly, to promote initiatives to internationalise enterprises, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, through missions of economic operators in growing countries, business forums or B to B meetings; Internationalisation is in fact the best instrument to combat the relocation of our companies. The third objective is to attract productive investment and tourist flows to Europe that will promote the growth of our continent. The European Commission has already developed effective instruments to support this dimension. I am thinking of the growth missions, which have already been carried out in some 30 regions or countries and which have proved very useful in expanding the activities of our companies beyond the borders of the Union. But improving and strengthening these initiatives is critical to addressing economic challenges and seizing opportunities globally. In the offices of the External Action Service we need desks specialized in supporting small and medium-sized enterprises that intend to internationalize. Unfortunately, our diplomacy has not renewed sufficiently and has not developed the economic reflex that would make it much more effective and useful for growth. I hope that we can have new missions for growth. Your words give us cause for hope, and I hope that the commitments you have made will also be followed by the other Commissioners.

name: Maria Grapini
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, economic diplomacy is not a new concept and is not being discussed for the first time in the European Parliament. I recall the work of Mr Tajani as Commissioner and Vice-President of the Committee, when he already launched an interesting programme for economic diplomacy in 2013 so that the European Union could become a stronger player in the world.  In its definition, economic diplomacy is, in fact, a foreign policy function that ensures compliance with very clear objectives to promote the economic well-being of European citizens. Economic diplomacy aims to use foreign policy instruments to support the economic interests of entrepreneurs, Member States. In order to achieve its objectives, the European Union should promote global competitiveness and take the lead in strategic sectors such as industrial, innovative and energy.  Many times, at a meeting with several Commissioners, including Mr Juncker, we raised issues related to concrete measures, reindustrialisation of the European Union, internationalisation of business and, in particular, the support of SMEs to expand their work in third countries. You have also made it clear, Commissioner, but you have not said how. Because, without having concrete budgets for the internationalisation of SMEs, we will not be able to do it with words alone. My question is very explicit and I hope to receive an equally clear answer. What diplomatic instruments in the economic and trade sector do you want to develop now, when the European Union is in extremely important negotiations with large markets: the United States, Canada, China, Japan? Commissioner, as Vice-President of the SME Intergroup, I had the opportunity to meet with many SME associations, Myself I was an SME-ist and Minister for SMEs. What economic diplomacy tools are you thinking of developing to support SMEs in expanding businesses and marketing in third markets? What can be done to have innovative, competitive, solid SMEs in the global market? Do you have a plan? A diplomatic strategy would generate revenue and promote European values by creating a level playing field. Economic diplomacy is useful and would revive Europe in the global arena.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab There is no doubt that the Union can do more to promote European businesses and products in the world and attract investors to Europe by means of economic diplomacy. The level of meso, i.e. the level of countries and regions, seems particularly important to me, as Commission Vice-President Jyrki Katainen said at a seminar at the European Centre for Political Strategy in February. However, new tools and new concepts for economic diplomacy are needed.  In doing so, I would like to point out that economic diplomacy at EU level should take into account the interests of all Member States and all regions of Europe and that it should strengthen the actions of the Member States in this regard, not replace them. Unfortunately, we all know that Europe's economic reality looks different than we would like. The gap between the countries of the European centre and the periphery is widening. Economic diplomacy in support of economic relations with non-European countries should be designed and organised to help reduce these differences.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I think this is a very important discussion, a timely moment and one that our group very much supports. The fact that we are discussing this at a time when many in the EU are actually too inward-focused allows us to look outward again and see not only threats from the outside world but, frankly, the many opportunities. One of the strengths of the European Union is of course our soft power. I think economic diplomacy would be one way to also create a better relevance and clear picture for people of why we have trade and other economic policies and what it can mean concretely. Concretely, that is, for small and medium-sized enterprises and concretely in an outreach that should be a two-way street: on the one hand, we should have our diplomats and our representatives looking for opportunities in third countries, but we should also be a welcome desk providing information and bringing knowledge back to the European Union.  I think we should also strive to be less competing with one another globally and to act more as an EU together. Let me give you an example. Recently I was in Boston, Massachusetts, as the Vice-President of the US Delegation of this House, where there are incubators bringing life science companies from the EU to relevant partners in the US. You see a German hub, a Dutch hub and a Swedish hub operating within metres of each other. Why not join forces, show what Europe has to offer, and bring the knowledge and the entrepreneurship, the investment and other relevant actors back in touch with actors in the EU? The same could be said for Silicon Valley.  I think there are many opportunities to avoid duplication – as you said, Commissioner – but also to connect the dots in a changing world, involve technology and IT in a smart way, and involve the private sector also in our foreign policy goals, which includes them playing a role in advancing human rights, corporate social responsibility and basically streamlining our efforts on the global stage.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, I take your statement: the EU's economic diplomacy means the use of its relations and its influence in opening up markets and generating investment. These objectives will in future be targeted at all relevant policy areas and EU institutions, including the EIB. And this is where fundamental questions to be answered come up. After all, it has long been proven that trade-promoting action only works between developed and less developed countries. In this sense, the approach not only outlines target markets, but already points to a central problem that is clearly emerging: in the global south, international trade currently accounts for 50 percent of the problem and is highly dependent on the consideration of its interests and needs. If the EU does not take this into account in a future trade policy aimed at balancing interests, EU economic diplomacy will find its master in southern trade in the short term. It already accounts for more than a third of world trade. It is therefore necessary to think again.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has On the one hand, I am pleased that this question, led by Antonio Tajani and all the chairmen of the SME Intergroup, can be called today. We were already working on this in the SME Intergroup on 13 October 2015, and I am also pleased because Austria is playing a pioneering role here through the foreign trade organisation that we have had for years and which is a significant part of the export offensive and the successful international activity of SMEs in Austria. As you mentioned, we have the situation that 80-90% of economic growth will take place outside Europe over the next ten to fifteen years, a third of which will take place in China. Although 25% of European SMEs export to the EU, only 13% of all European SMEs currently operate in markets outside the Union. Due to globalisation, investment is largely carried out outside Europe. We want to discuss the EFSI in order to develop our neighbours, an EFSI for Africa. SMEs need support, support, support, door openers, because otherwise they cannot afford it. We therefore ask you to unite the Economic-SME-European External Action Service cooperation.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, at a time when economies are increasingly interdependent, economic diplomacy must necessarily be a fundamental vector of all external policies. And it has to have two fundamental objectives in the European framework: on the one hand, to contribute to the internationalisation of our business fabric, on the other hand, to attract external investment to the European area. With regard to the first objective, it is very important to support small and medium-sized enterprises. These are the ones that most need the support of the European Union. They often have the support of their States, the Member States in which they operate, but they need the support of the European Union because they have some difficulty in conquering new markets outside the European area.  And at a time when we are negotiating various trade agreements with different countries and groupings of countries around the world, this challenge is of particular importance and therefore here we need to create very specific instruments, from the financial component to the logistical support component, in order to allow precisely this business fabric, which is the bulk of the European business fabric. , consisting of small and medium-sized enterprises, to be able to aspire to faster internationalisation, unless they themselves cannot compete in the international framework. And the second aspect is also a very important aspect and which has to do with the ability to attract good external investments to the European political and economic area. There is much to be done in this area.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I share, of course, the diagnoses and prescriptions expressed at the beginning of this debate by Commissioner Katainen and by Antonio Tajani. Of course, the collective strength of the EU institution must be used to promote Europe's economic interests in the world. I applied for this night's debate because, as chairman of the European Parliament-Iran delegation, I have a very interesting field of observation, a very interesting case study. Well, we are certainly dealing here with a great opening of a great country with great economic potential. But what has happened since the nuclear agreement was signed? 144 government visits from individual countries that compete with each other in this newly opened territory. From this comes a certain picture of the tasks for the European institutions, namely the protection of investment, the creation of a better investment area in this new country, breaking down barriers for small and medium-sized enterprises and sharing information. These are undoubtedly values added at European level compared to the 144 government visits and countless private visits that involve countries competing for this brand new market. However, there is another problem on our side, which sometimes happens and must be overcome: we will also be admonished for certain values, for the protection of human rights, which does not always go hand in hand with economic interests. Thank you.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Energy and large-scale industry are strategic economic sectors for which an economic diplomatic initiative is worthwhile. There are a few things to say about this. But the European Union's small and medium-sized enterprises are also the growth drivers, and they are hopeful. With many free trade agreements, the EU enables growth in foreign markets and an ever-improving environment. This is also an invitation to the left in Parliament, but to support the TTIP free trade agreement, because this also gives us a better framework, global export contacts. Many Member States also support initiatives through export protection and the very good service of the chambers of commerce abroad. But I think we can do more. The Commission could make greater use of its global networks for economic contacts, and Parliament's delegations, as has just been mentioned, can also take interested companies with them to the delegation trips. We would even have a budget; we have a lot of money in Parliament's budget to organise these things. In other words, Europe remains below its potential, and it should be possible, in cooperation with the Member States and also with the chambers of commerce abroad, to facilitate, strengthen, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises. It would be appropriate for the Commission to go further in the initiative already launched under Commissioner Antonio Tajani – especially since our companies abroad are always a positive ambassador of the European idea.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the dimension of economic diplomacy is an integral part of the nature of our continent. Our continent is made to propose itself and the economic sphere has always been the area through which Europe has told the world a strong, solid, sustainable development model, based on a great creativity of our entrepreneurs and our citizens in general and, on the other, on the great awareness that to build economic development we need respect for the person. Therefore, creativity and the ability to also build a social model that is up to scratch, so in Europe it is nice to undertake and it is nice to work. But to do economic diplomacy you have to get to know each other well, know what we are strong in, get to know each other and defend yourself to propose yourself. We are the best in manufacturing and we do not have a large amount of raw materials. Therefore, a first strategy in building real economic diplomacy is to associate our production capacity with the strength of countries that have raw materials and with them to go hand in hand. For example, the great challenge of the Mediterranean is a challenge in which our economic diplomacy can play an exceptional role. So great relationships and great ability to propose, defend yourself by proposing, and in this game build a ruling class of economic diplomats who help our entrepreneurs who have historically represented us in the world.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Madam Chairman, first of all I want to thank Mr Tajani for keeping this topic on the agenda. This is not a new concept, but something that is known both in the Member States and in the Union itself. I want to thank you again for continually trying to work on this. The fact is that 24% of GDP is in the European Union, that we are strong and the world's largest economy, but nevertheless we need economic diplomacy.  Personally, I think it needs to be a foreign policy function and that foreign policy cannot go without economic diplomacy. I therefore agree that the European Union, Member States and businesses, as well as the Foreign Affairs and Economic Diplomacy Service need to be linked and coordinated. Without this networking, we will not be able to preserve the first place in the world economy. Certainly, this is all for the benefit of European citizens. I believe that economic diplomacy needs to be internationalised, and a big emphasis should also be placed on the small and medium-sized enterprises we are constantly talking about, because the middle tier is clearly the dominant layer in the European Union and we must provide them with all possible mechanisms.  Of course, the question arises as to what these mechanisms are, but there are many mechanisms that already exist in the Member States and should be used to bring SMEs to full expression and to keep the European economy as the No. 1 in the world.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I originally wanted to start somewhat differently, but the Commissioner's statement provoked me to ask what the objectives of our policy are in economic diplomacy, because I think that the Commissioner mentioned this only partially, and I join Mrs Grapini's request that we, if necessary, hear in his next speech those specific instruments that should be used , and, of course, the objectives of economic diplomacy.  In my opinion, given the strength it has in global markets, the European Union should play a more active role internationally. The European Union is a little undersized internationally in the political sense. I think that this issue should come together here, and the three objectives that my colleague, Mr Tajani, has also talked about should be linked to the support of businesses, because the best report card for what the European Union has achieved is a very functioning company that is making its production on foreign markets. I think that is the best goal and our main point for the development of our economic diplomacy. That's where we should see the light at the end of the tunnel.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, with the existing political forces, European economic diplomacy will be developed and applied exclusively to the measures of The Franco-German multinationals. It will set aside citizens, small and medium-sized enterprises, and bind states to decisions that do not correspond to the free will of their citizens. The economic diplomacy as the Commission perceives it is extremely negative for the people. The disastrous decisions to take action against Russia have, by contrast, had a serious impact on many companies, without the European Union having so far compensated those affected satisfactorily and fairly. At the same time, while there are leaks of documents demonstrating the onerous environmental provisions being processed by TTIR, the Commission continues to 'business as usual'. These events demonstrate the turn that the Eurocrats are trying to take in economic diplomacy and which is nothing more than the creation of an economic NATO, an economic folding within the West, a bow to transatlantic geographical interests, which completely ignore the popular verdict and demonstrate ostentatiously that they are ignoring the multipolar composition of the world economy.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, in order for Europe and the European economy to remain competitive and have opportunities to grow, internationalisation of our economy is undoubtedly needed, as of course europe's share is steadily decreasing as the world economy expands. That is why I strongly support this initiative of European diplomacy and call for synergies with member states, with the diplomacy that member states have in many countries, especially on the African, Asian and South American continents, where we can have a lot of inroads.  I would also like to link this initiative to what we are constantly doing in this aula of ours, which is the problem of the migrant crisis. With our strong economic diplomacy, I am sure, together with the member states, we can also solve this problem in a different way than we solve it.  And finally, I would like to mention, yes, energy and industry are a very important topic, but also tourism, which is mentioned. However, in order for tourism to be even stronger, we need to organize ourselves properly here in Europe because we are not well organized now.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, economic diplomacy is essential in promoting European economic interests in the world and in ensuring sales for European products and in distant markets.  Both the Commission and the European Parliament often say that they think of SMEs in particular and not of large corporations. That's what TTIP says. But what is the truth about European foreign trade? Only 13% of SMEs export outside the EU. This is a very poor result of supporting SMEs in the context of the Economic Diplomacy of the European Union. We need to promote European interests and brands more strongly, collect and disseminate information in our market in order to facilitate international trade, encourage European businesses to access external markets, and, above all, think about SMEs and not corporations that are constantly lobbying the Commission. And let me say one thing to my PPE colleague – we do not need TTIP and CETA, we need order within the European Union. Then we can talk about anything else, as long as we have a mess at home, we can't clean up somewhere else and outwardly.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam Chairman, opening new markets to our entrepreneurs and attracting investment in the European Union is absolutely desirable and to this end we must mobilise all our capacities. Member States already have their own models of economic diplomacy and I see nothing wrong with bodies and representatives of the European Union helping them achieve economic interests in foreign markets and attract foreign investment.  However, I believe that coordination between Member States or between Members and European Union bodies with a view to pursuing economic interests should not be institutionalised. There are significant differences between our countries, their economic realities and ambitions. It is fairly certain that EU economic diplomacy would primarily benefit more developed export-oriented members to world markets, although all of us would finance it, which is the way to new injustice and dissatisfaction.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for this very good debate. I am particularly glad to see Mr Tajani here, who is a genuine pioneer of new economic diplomacy. You launched this concept during your time in the Commission and we are trying to continue and even further develop and try to learn from best practices how we could improve the efficiency of our economic diplomatic activities. There was a good question, asking what are the objectives of economic diplomacy. I will try to explain what we are doing. Basically it elaborates or clarifies what our objectives are at the moment. For instance, we have had two very interesting high—level economic dialogues with third countries, and we will keep these on our agenda. Firstly, the dialogue with China: I regularly meet Vice—Premier Ma Kai, together with other Commissioners, and from the Chinese side there are also other Ministers. At those events we sometimes have discussions with the private sector. Every once in a while we invite private companies to our dialogue just to hear what they are saying and what they are expecting from the EU, what they are expecting from China and what the priorities the private sector is asking of us are in order to improve the business environment. At the same meetings, for instance last time, last September in Beijing, Commissioner Oettinger and Commissioner Bulc participated in the dialogue and discussed the cooperation of 5G. Commissioner Bulc also talked about the connectivity platform and we talked about potential Chinese investment in Europe. As a result of this, we have managed to finalise our technical work with the Silk Road Fund which is interested in investing in Europe more and more. So those are just a few examples of the fruits of high—level economic dialogue with China. Just a couple of months ago we had a similar event in Ankara and Istanbul where Turkey’s and the EU’s business delegations met each other and they also gave us ideas about what more the two parties could do in order to improve the business environment on both sides. There again, we had discussions on regulatory cooperation as well as on macroeconomic issues.  Commissioner Moscovici joined us and we talked about R&D cooperation between Turkey and the EU.  So those are just a few examples of our current activities and clearly show some of our objectives. But of course, as I mentioned during the debate here, one of the priority areas is trade agreements with third countries.  I should also mention development policy and investment – a combination of development policy, trade and investment cooperation, because many of the third countries which we are helping to reform themselves and which are an objective of EU aid are willing to become a partner to the EU rather than just an objective of development aid. There of course diplomacy plays a big role. That is one of the reasons why we are planning to establish some sort of fund, similar to the one we have here, EFSI, which could support European investments to third countries. This is just one of the ideas.  My final point is about SME cooperation. I have already mentioned trade deals but I have to add a couple of other issues. The role of networks of European business organisations in third countries is significant. I have met excellent Chambers of Commerce, for instance in China – they are our ears and eyes about what is happening on a daily basis in Chinese trade issues –  also in Singapore, when I visited there, and in the United States and Turkey. I am planning to visit the Gulf region and also Iran, which was also  mentioned here earlier. But if the Parliament has good ideas about how we could improve our help to SMEs, just let us know. We can make trade promotion trips inviting SMEs to participate, but is there anything else apart from what has been mentioned here? Let us be innovative. Let us think what we could do more and differently than we have done so far. I am sure that, as there are so many experienced MEPs who have experience on trade policies, on trade promotion for instance, you can devise something and let us know because I am open—minded on this issue. The more we can do in order to help our businesses to expand to third countries and trade and sell, the better.  Thank you very much for your ideas.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union, as the world's largest economy, should pursue effective economic diplomacy, which has become a leading form in international relations in recent decades. There is ampered evidence that effective economic diplomacy can be more effective than so-called hard power. As the Commissioner rightly stated in his speech, the vast majority of economic growth is currently generated outside the EU, and we must make sure that, through our contacts in the area of trade and investment, the results of this growth are felt more strongly in Europe as well.  That is why it is so important to support our entrepreneurs on the global market or to promote solutions that eliminate barriers on third-country markets. Closer cooperation between the European External Action Service and the European Investment Bank is needed to create easily accessible sources of funding for European entrepreneurs planning to expand abroad. Trade agreements negotiated by the EU with third countries are also part of economic diplomacy, provided that they ensure that they genuinely facilitate access to the markets in question for our companies and do not discriminate against individual economic sectors.
